title: Old and Ghostly but Still a Hoot
description: The paint on the balconies of the Majestic Theater looks chipped and the electronic drum machine sounds like something left over from a music video from the 1980s. But The Phantom of the Opera really shows its age (17 years and running) when the signature special effect is presented. Musicals have opened and closed in the time it takes that chandelier to lumber to the floor. Looking like one of Ed Woods teetering flying saucers, it crashes to the stage with the force of a shopping cart, the biggest, most extravagant anticlimax in town.

title: British Scientists Say Carbon Dioxide Is Turning the Oceans Acidic
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, JEANNE
description: KLEIN--Jeanne, died on June 29, 2005. She is remembered by her sister-in-law, nieces, nephews, brother and friends. A graduate of New York University, she had a long career as a securities analyst.

title: Searching for a Gear to Be Like Armstrong
description: After Tom Danielson burst onto the cycling scene with a breakthrough victory in 2002, just two months after turning pro, people started calling him the next Lance Armstrong.

title: Consumer Spending Unchanged in May
description: Consumer spending stayed level in May and incomes increased less than forecast, according to a government report released yesterday.

title: From the Scrap Heap to Luxury
description: NANTUCKET, MASS. - FOR decades, tourists would come to Nantucket and shop for dainty lightship baskets. Now they can buy an entire 600-ton lightship.

title: A Curvy Klee Museum, Sprouting From the Swiss Hills
description: BERN, Switzerland - Strangely perhaps, in a land dominated by the Alps, the countryside around the Swiss capital is shaped by rolling hills that invite nothing more dramatic than unhurried contemplation. And it was this, both mood and look, that Renzo Piano sought to evoke when he added an $86 million museum, the Paul Klee Center, to the orderly Bern landscape.

title: Service to provide cellphone-PC instant messaging
Giving and taking away
Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with a sports article about Wilt Chamberlain's 100-point game in 1962 referred incorrectly in some copies to a fan at Hershey Sports Arena. The man, to the left of Chamberlain, was unidentified; he was not Steve Wilson.

title: Bloomberg Vows Strong Response in Bias Attack
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and prosecutors pledged yesterday to seek the maximum penalties in Wednesday's beating of a black man in Howard Beach, Queens, as a second white man was charged in the attack and another was taken into custody as a witness.

title: U.S. leadsa global crackdown on piracy
Metro Briefing | New York: Insurer Ordered To Pay $22 Million
description: A Florida jury awarded $22 million yesterday to Florida Health Plan Holdings, which claimed it was misled about the financial condition of HIP of Florida when it bought the company five years ago from HIP Health Plan of New York. The award, by a jury in Broward County, comes as New York state officials plan to raise more than $1 billion by allowing HIP Health Plan of New York to sell stock and become a profit-making company. HIP of Florida is now called Vista Health Plans of Florida. Michael D. Fullwood, general counsel of HIP of New York, said the company would appeal. Michael Cooper (NYT)

description: Here are reviews of 10 DVD sets of popular television series and special collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Protected Birds Are Back, With a Vengeance; Cormorants Take Over, Making Some Enemies
description: FOUR BROTHERS ISLANDS, N.Y. - The double-crested cormorants perch like conquerors at the tops of the spindly white pines, their driftwood-gray branches devoid of needles. The trees were killed off, along with much of the other vegetation on the small rocky islands here in Lake Champlain, by the birds' highly acidic droppings.

title: Republican Lawmakers Fire Back at Judiciary
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - Stepping up their assault on the federal judiciary, Congressional Republicans announced efforts on Thursday directed at overturning two recent Supreme Court decisions, one that allowed government to claim private property for economic development and another that stripped Kentucky courthouses of the Ten Commandments.

title: Shares Finish Slow Quarter, as Oil and Bonds Move Up
description: Crude oil prices breached $60 a barrel. Bonds gained steadily, pushing yields below 4 percent. And seemingly nothing can break the back of the real estate boom.

Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,736 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Where They Are Today
description: In December 1986, a car stalled in Howard Beach. One of the four black men inside remained with the car, while the other three walked to get help. Outside a pizza parlor where the men stopped to use a pay phone, a white gang pounced on the three black men, severely beating one. One escaped, but a third, Michael Griffith, ran onto the Belt Parkway, where he was struck and killed by a car. The bias attack prompted a nationwide furor over race, and a trial of the suspects followed in 1987. ANTHONY RAMIREZ

title: Summertime, when the loving is easy
In Russia, a Free Market, Less Freedom
description: Kremlin Rising Vladimir Putin's Russia and the End of Revolution By Peter Baker and Susan Glasser Illustrated. 453 pages. A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $27.50.

title: Top Editor at Time Inc. Made a Difficult Decision His Own
description: In the months leading up to the decisive court rulings this week on whether Time Inc. had to turn over documents to a grand jury, its editor in chief, Norman Pearlstine, pored over histories of how other editors, publishers and public officials had handled cases where the ultimate law of the land went against them.

title: Thomas Now Looking for a Few Big Men
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., June 30 - Isiah Thomas returned to the podium Thursday, once more beaming like a proud father as he handed Knicks caps to his two newest acquisitions. It was a virtual repeat of the scene 24 hours earlier, and it completed a busy week in which Thomas added four players that he expected to change the face of the franchise.

title: War of Words
description: London - I WAS hoping it wouldn't come to this, but after Tom Cruise's interview with Matt Lauer on the NBC show "Today" last week, I feel compelled to speak not just for myself but also for the hundreds of thousands of women who have suffered from postpartum depression. While Mr. Cruise says that Mr. Lauer and I do not "understand the history of psychiatry," I'm going to take a wild guess and say that Mr. Cruise has never suffered from postpartum depression.

title: Motor racing: Formula One experiments with its minor league
A Setback for Egypt's Case Against Mubarak Foe
description: CAIRO, June 30 - The government forgery case against Ayman Nour, the most determined opposition figure challenging President Hosni Mubarak in the election scheduled for September, suffered a serious blow on Thursday when another defendant reversed his guilty plea.

title: The Mao Myth Thrives, but Don't Mention Its Dark Side
description: YENAN, China - Horribly outnumbered, poorly armed and constantly under attack, 80,000 Communist fighters set out on foot from a base in China's southeastern Jiangxi Province in October 1934 hoping above all to avoid getting wiped out by their Nationalist enemies.

title: Style: The return of the gender gap
Homecoming at Morgan Stanley
description: For John J. Mack, the new chief executive of Morgan Stanley, it was a moment to savor. On his triumphant return yesterday to the investment bank that unceremoniously dropped him four years ago, Mr. Mack was greeted by a standing ovation from a crowd of 200 employees gathered in a conference room at Morgan Stanley's towering Manhattan headquarters on Times Square.

title: U.S. Pursuing Reports That Link Iranian to Embassy Seizure in '79
description: TEHRAN, June 30 - Two Iranian leaders of the seizure of the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979 dismissed allegations on Thursday by former American hostages that Iran's president-elect was one of their captors. The Bush administration, however, said it took the charge seriously and vowed to investigate.

title: Currencies: Dollar holds steady after Fed raises rates
Voice of the Boss and a Voice of Reason
description: George Steinbrenner has a voice of his own, a once clangorous one, but when he wants to convey his thoughts to a needy news media these days, it is invariably through the tranquil voice of Howard J. Rubenstein.

title: Friendship as a Frail Bridge Across the Chasm of Class
description: "We have two lives: the one we dream of and the one we live," muses Miguel (Werner Schnemann), an idealistic upper-middle-class politician whose 50-year friendship with Jorginho (Antnio Pompo) , a criminal from the Rio de Janeiro slums, forms the spine of Lcia Murat's "Almost Brothers." That observation serves as an epigraph for a movie that reflects on the seemingly unbridgeable class differences in contemporary Brazil, a country of devastating economic inequities.

title: Girls Just Want a Bargain Apartment? Court Favors Lauper
description: ALBANY, June 30 - All right, it did not have all the sex and violence necessary for a sensational trial by West Coast standards. But for a regional twist, especially if the region is Manhattan, it was not bad: the case did involve a celebrity -- the 1980's pop sensation Cyndi Lauper -- a rent-stabilized apartment, and one of New York's most desirable addresses.

title: Afghan Warlord Says He's Underfed in U.S. Jail
description: An Afghan tribal leader who was arrested in New York in April on heroin trafficking charges is not getting enough to eat and is hampered from performing Muslim prayers in his prison cell, his lawyer said at a federal court hearing yesterday.

title: Duck, N.C.
description: THE Outer Banks, those long, skinny barrier islands just off North Carolina, have long fired the imagination -- beginning with Sir Walter Raleigh's famed lost colony and fueled by the islands' delicate, ever-shifting relationship with the Atlantic. It's fitting, then, that Duck, perhaps the frailest stretch of the Banks, should become the hub of so much activity after the state opened Route 12 north of town in the 1980's. Until then, Duck had been just another sleepy fishing village -- charming, sure, but more or less the end of the road. Today, Duck retains its small-town appeal, but it also offers visitors some of the best restaurants in the area, boutique shopping, a colorful local history and, as ever, mile after mile of pristine sandy beach.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Central Bank Lowers Forecast
description: Brazil's central bank lowered its growth forecast for this year to 3.4 percent from 4 percent, saying the economy would be crimped somewhat by high interest rates. The revision came in the bank's quarterly inflation report, where the bank also predicted consumer prices would rise 5.8 percent this year, up from a previous forecast of 5.5 percent and well above the government's year-end target of 5.1 percent. Still, the bank lowered its inflation forecast for 2006, to 3.7 percent from 3.8 percent, arguing that a recent string of interest rate increases had put inflation on a downward course. The bank has raised its benchmark lending rate nine times since September, to 19.75 percent. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: In the Garden of Yin, Yang and Yeats
description: IN April, Petronella Collins, 85, made her annual spring move into a cottage by Tyrrel Lake in Innisfree Garden, 150 idyllic acres hidden away in the verdant horse country of Dutchess County, N.Y. Ms. Collins, who will stay until November, maintaining the garden with the help of nine part-time assistants, is matter-of-fact about her enviable, if rustic, lodgings and her position as curator of Innisfree since 1993. "I'm an old lady," she said. "I'm lucky to have a job at all."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Holiday on Monday, Independence Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Opinions by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
description: Excerpts from opinions by Justice Sandra Day O'Connor:

title: Scene Shifts On Cape Cod
description: FROM the outside, the Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater looks more like a meeting place for Cape Cod lobstermen than an institution applauded by theater critics. On summer evenings, sailors dock at the adjacent town pier and line up at Mac's Seafood, which serves fried clams and onion rings so large it's hard to believe they came from an actual vegetable. Inside the tiny theater, which seats fewer than a hundred and smells vaguely like sea air, actors can only enter from stage right because the women's room is so close to stage left that they would essentially have to enter from the bathroom.

title: Israeli Troops Drag Pro-Settler Squatters From Stronghold
description: KISSUFIM CROSSING, Gaza Strip, June 30 - Israeli soldiers and police officers raided a seaside hotel in the southern Gaza Strip on Thursday, evicting about 150 right-wing protesters who were part of an increasingly confrontational campaign against the planned evacuation of Jewish settlers.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the World Business Briefing column on Tuesday about four banks that planned to return part of the money they received in Mexico's bank bailout misstated the date of the collapse of the peso that led to a financial crisis. It was December 1994, not 2004.

title: Ex-Convict Admits Killing Jeweler on Long Island
description: Christopher DiMeo, a 23-year-old former convict charged with his girlfriend in three murders and a string of jewelry store robberies in New York and Connecticut, pleaded guilty on Long Island yesterday to first-degree murder and robbery as part of a plea bargain. He is to be sentenced to life in prison without parole, the authorities said.

title: Bloomberg Claims a Victory in Battling Homelessness
description: A year after announcing his ambitious plan to slash homelessness in New York by two-thirds by 2009, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city was exceeding its goals and had reduced the number of individuals living in shelters by 9 percent, a drop of about 3,400 people. The success has been so great that Mr. Bloomberg said he would begin shutting down the city's largest shelter for homeless families, the Carlton House shelter, a former Best Western motel near Kennedy International Airport that has been a source of irritation to local residents.

title: A Colorful Holiday, Buzzing in the Bronx
description: A Colorful Holiday, Buzzing in the Bronx

title: 16GI'sdied in copter on Afghan mission
Living in style, and security, in So Paulo
16 GIs died in copteron Afghanmission
Next: Spielberg's Biggest Gamble
description: LOS ANGELES, June 30 - On Wednesday, Steven Spielberg's apocalyptic thriller "War of the Worlds" invaded movie theaters worldwide. But the director had already moved on. That night in Malta, Mr. Spielberg quietly began filming the most politically charged project he has yet attempted: the tale of a secret Mossad hit squad ordered to assassinate Palestinian terrorists after the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympics in Munich.

title: Mixed signals from European data
Flowery inspiration in English gardens
Reluctant Coach, Bad Team and, of Course, Redemption
description: "Courage is just well-concealed fear," declares Roy McCormick (Martin Lawrence), a disgraced basketball coach banned from the Ohio college circuit after throwing one too many tantrums on the court. This sensible word definition is offered to soothe a 13-year-old scaredy-cat who plays for the Smelters, the downscale junior high school team that the newly humbled Roy is reduced to coaching.

title: India can be America's best friend
Is Autism Research Flawed, or Sound? (5 Letters)
description: Why does this page look this way?

title: Plush Like Lite Radio, but Serious Nonetheless
description: Mark Knopfler was 27 when he recorded "Sultans of Swing," the worldwide hit for his band Dire Straits. He's 55 now, but that career-defining song still fit easily at the center of his set on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Louis J. Sigel, 81, a Rabbi and a Force for Integration, Is Dead
description: Louis J. Sigel, a Teaneck, N.J., rabbi who was a prominent voice for integration of the township's public schools in the early 1960's, died on Sunday at his home in Hackensack, N.J. He was 81.

title: Hopes and Shares Rise as Boeing Names Chief
description: Boeing's hiring of W. James McNerney Jr. as chief executive yesterday raised investor hopes that the company can wring bigger and more consistent profits from its operations and left 3M scrambling after Mr. McNerney's abrupt departure.

title: Iranian Leader Denies He Was Among Radicals at Embassy
description: TEHRAN, July 1 - A shiny black Peugeot rolled to a stop, and there he was, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the president-elect of Iran, smiling through an open window, ready to greet a few of the people who have been coming to his street as a sort of pilgrimage since his victory at the polls.

description: Here are reviews of 10 DVD sets of popular television series and special collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Reforms at the F.B.I. and Justice
description: President Bush did all Americans a service on Wednesday by ordering reforms that offer the real possibility of plugging the national security holes that allowed the 9/11 hijackers to plan, train for and carry out mass murder without being noticed. They are a rebuff to Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld's attempts to seize control of intelligence gathering. And they give real power to the new director of national intelligence, John Negroponte.

title: Remarks by President Bush
description: The following is the transcript of remarks made by President Bush today regarding the resignation of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, as provided by CQ Transcriptions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVISON, ISABELLE C.
description: LEVISON--Isabelle C. A resident of Florida, died June 25, 2005. A native of Norfolk, Virginia, she also resided in New York City and Detroit, Michigan. She was a founder at Mount Sinai Medical Center and Miami Jewish Home for the Aged, and a patron of the arts. Survived by her children Sally A. Edwards & Edward J. Minskoff, sister Rena Kriegel, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: Flashing Back
description: The DVD sets of the television series and collections reviewed:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PILCH, TODD DAVID
description: PILCH--Todd David 7/1/61--1/15/99. Happy Birthday in Heaven. I will never stop thinking about you and wondering if you are okay--that's what big sisters are for. With all my love, Sue

title: Skipping Class to Wrestle, Teacher Lands in Trouble
description: At Benjamin N. Cardozo High School in Queens, he was known as Matthew Kaye, an earnest social studies teacher shepherding his ninth- and 10th-grade students across the panorama of global history. But out of school -- on the professional wrestling circuit -- he was Matt Striker, a muscleman known for a move called the lung blower.

title: Arts, Briefly; ABC Dances to a Triumph
description: With the elimination of Joey McIntyre, formerly of New Kids on the Block, next week's finale of "Dancing With the Stars" will feature a dance-off between John O'Hurley and Kelly Monaco, and their respective partners. Wednesday's episode of "Dancing" not only drew the show's best ratings yet -- 18.04 million viewers -- but was also the second highest-rated broadcast of the summer season. That show alone would have propelled ABC to victory for Wednesday night in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers and adults 18 to 49. But a repeat of last week's "Dancing" (9.40 million) in the 8 p.m. hour was also No. 1 in its slot, and a rerun of "Lost" at 10 p.m. benefited from its unlikely lead-in, winning the 18-to-49 audience. Opposite "Lost," NBC's "Law & Order" repeat did place first in total viewers, 9.4 million, which contributed to the network's No. 2 finish for the night. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Flooding Leaves Damage
description: Major damage from downpours on Wednesday night was concentrated mostly in Westchester County's southern communities along the Hudson, where officials described buckled roadways, flooded parks and submerged cars. Initial reports indicated that costly repairs would be needed on public roads. The authorities said they had towed more than 70 cars submerged along the Thruway from Tarrytown to Ardsley on Wednesday night, and hundreds of others parked at train stations in Valhalla and northern White Plains. Jenny Medina (NYT)

title: Around the World: Django in New York, Lebanon parties on, Goya unveiled in Madrid

Survived by beloved wife Dorothy, four sons and five daughters. Gray-Parker Funeral Home, Port Jervis, NY Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM. Funeral Saturday 11AM at funeral home. Memorial contributions to Hospice, 800 Stony Brook Ct, Newburgh, New York 12550. www.grayparkerfuneral home.com

title: The Nontaxpaying Affluent Grew by 15% in One Year
description: The number of affluent individuals and married couples who paid no federal income taxes jumped more than 15 percent in 2002, to 5,650, new government data showed yesterday.

title: Anti-malaria program in Africa set by Bush
Cycling: Armstrong pinpoints his major challengers
World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 3 Stabbed At Jerusalem Gay Parade
description: An ultra-Orthodox protester stabbed and lightly wounded three participants in the annual Gay Pride march in Jerusalem that attracted an estimated 2,000 people, the police said. The attacker was among about a dozen ultra-Orthodox demonstrators arrested as the march worked its way through the city, said Shmulik Ben-Ruby, a police spokesman. The march faced opposition from Jewish, Christian and Muslim religious leaders. The city's ultra-Orthodox mayor, Uri Lupolianski, had sought to ban it, but a court overruled him. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Principal Hid Fraud on Tests in Brooklyn, Officials Say
description: A Brooklyn high school principal covered up a widespread effort to inflate grades on the Regents exams in social studies in 2002 and 2003, education officials said yesterday, and he will face termination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESENT, IGNATZ
description: PRESENT -- Ignatz. Fifth Avenue Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of our distinguished trustee and extends heartfelt sympathy to the bereaved family. Yaakov Y. Kermaier, Rabbi Ira Leon Rennert, Chairman J. Ezra Merkin, President

title: 16 Bodies Recovered in Afghan Copter Crash
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - Nearly three days after a Chinook helicopter went down in heavy combat in eastern Afghanistan, American troops were able to reach the crash site and recovered the bodies of all 16 troops who were aboard, military officials said.

title: Spending Bills Done, House Votes Money for Veterans
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - The House gave initial approval on Thursday to the last of its 11 annual spending bills and passed $975 million in emergency money for veterans' health care as Congress headed toward its Fourth of July break.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEONTIEF, ESTELLE MARKS
description: LEONTIEF--Estelle Marks, 97, died Tuesday, 28 June, 2005 from an unexpected and severe infection. Much loved wife of the late Wassily Leontief, mother of Svetlana Alpers, grandmother of Benjamin and Nicholas and also to their wives Karin and Kathryn, great-grandmother of Noah, Mira, Alina and Isaac, loving sister to the late Dorothy Wigderson. Author, reader, devoted to her piano, deeply engaged friend to so many. It is hard to believe that such a vigorous human presence is gone. She will be greatly missed.

title: Hu heads to Russia for talks
West, Southwest, Plains, Midwest and South
description: WEST

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Teenager Charged In Rape Attempt
description: A teenager was charged yesterday with beating and attempting to rape a woman on the Lower East Side on Monday, the police said. The boy, 15, whose identity was withheld, was charged with attempted rape, assault and burglary. The police said he beat the woman and attempted to rape her before he was scared off by a witness. After a telephone tip, the youth was arrested yesterday by the Manhattan Special Victims Squad in front of 444 Second Avenue, the police said.

title: Corrections

(The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 13, 2004, and Nov. 5 and 14, 2004.) He is the director of a social sciences seminar at Columbia University; he is not on the faculty.

title: Defendant reverses plea in forgery case
Nassau Officials Try a Different Approach to House Filled With Immigrants
description: NEW CASSEL, N.Y., June 30 - For the second time in 11 days, authorities on Long Island cracked down Thursday on a single-family house overcrowded with Mexican immigrants. But this time was decidedly different: no raid and no immediate shutdown or eviction.

title: Amid the Pulp, a Meditation on Fathers, Sons and the Ties That Choke
description: As he walks -- no, make that hurdles -- through the electrifying French film "The Beat That My Heart Skipped," the young actor Romain Duris brings to mind another dirty-sexy guy who once vaulted through the movies with barely restrained frenzy. Mr. Duris, who wears a black leather jacket in the film, along with the ankle boots of a tango dancer or a pimp, is playing the character inhabited by Harvey Keitel nearly three decades ago in a cinematic wack job called "Fingers." Summoned as if from a fever dream by the writer and director James Toback, "Fingers" doesn't just get under your skin; it slithers.

title: The Listings: July 1 -- July 7; GLIMMERGLASS OPERA
description: Summer opera festivals spring up in once-unlikely places and, after they take root, seem a natural part of the landscape. Glimmerglass (named after James Fenimore Cooper's designation of the nearby Otsego Lake) has grown from opera in the local high school to one of the leading opera festivals in the country. Its 900-seat theater, above, is lovely, its program is both adventurous and appealing, and over and over again it offers fine singers and interesting productions (many making their way to the New York City Opera during the regular season). A highlight of this summer's season is Britten's "Death in Venice," directed by Tazewell Thompson; but this opening weekend holds plenty of charms of its own, including the company debut of the baritone Sanford Sylvan in Mozart's "Cos Fan Tutte," which should have a few twists in a production by the British director Tim Albery, and Donizetti's "Lucie de Lammermoor," sung, as the latest fashion has it, in French. ("Lucie," tonight at 8, Sunday at 2 p.m.; "Cos," tomorrow at 8 p.m., Alice Busch Opera Theater, Route 80, eight miles north of Cooperstown, N.Y., (607)547-2255. Tickets: $35 to $110.) ANNE MIDGETTE

title: Hitting Rewind in Rerun Season: DVD's Culled From TV's Past
description: Here are reviews of 10 DVD sets of popular television series and special collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Saving Lives in Africa
description: With President Bush's announcement yesterday of $1.2 billion for a five-year campaign against malaria in Africa, this mosquito-borne disease is finally getting the high-level attention it deserves. The wonder is that it took so long. This ancient scourge is so deadly and pervasive, and effective remedies are so cheap, that there is no justification for the world's past indifference.

title: E.P.A. Proposes Regulations for Diesel Engines at Plants
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - The Environmental Protection Agency proposed regulations on Thursday that for the first time would set limits on air pollution from stationary diesel engines, like those that run factories and power plants.

title: Can a Rainmaker Be Morgan Stanley's Peacemaker?
description: WALL STREET loves heroes. Morgan Stanley, the famous investment bank that has bled talent and endured a long and embarrassing public feud among its factions, is hoping that John J. Mack is that hero.

description: When Bruce L. Hammonds, the chief executive of the MBNA Corporation, stepped into the company's Sikorsky S76C at the heliport at 34th Street in Manhattan with five senior executives on Friday afternoon two weeks ago, the mood was jovial.

title: If farm subsidies ended: Consequences not clear
Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Mayoral Candidate Withdraws
description: Samuel William Sigler withdrew from the mayoral race yesterday, less than three weeks after he agreed to face Dannel P. Malloy, a Democrat and the incumbent. In a letter to Republican leaders, Mr. Sigler said he was "offended and angered" by the weak support from leading Republicans after they learned that he had pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors involving drunken brawls between 1965 and 1980. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: Conventional Wisdom Not Always Right
description: WITH the year half over, the world's financial markets appear to be well on the way to demonstrating a great investment truth: When virtually everyone expects something to happen, it won't.

title: Fired Officer Is Suing Wal-Mart
description: A former Wal-Mart executive responsible for inspecting apparel factories in Central America has sued the company, accusing it of firing him for being too aggressive about finding workplace violations, like locked exits and mandatory 24-hour shifts.

title: Fame Strikes Quickly for U.S. Open Champ
description: GLADSTONE, N.J., June 30 - So much has changed for Birdie Kim since she surprised the golf world by winning the United States Women's Open on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MULLEN, FRANK J.
description: MULLEN--Frank J. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank J. Mullen, associated with The Times since October 1971.

title: Sheffield Is Suspended 2 Games for Outburst at Umpire
description: The commissioner's office has become well-acquainted with the Yankees' Gary Sheffield this season. Although Sheffield dodged disciplinary action for an altercation with a fan at Fenway Park in April, yesterday he received a two-game suspension and a fine for his actions on Sunday night, when he was ejected from a Yankees-Mets game.

title: Every Fifth Day, Martnez Makes the Mets Interesting
description: Four out of five days, the Mets are easy to ignore, a quintessential .500 club that is last in its division and stuck in a summer malaise.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Science Times on June 14 with an article about a tomb discovered inside a Maya pyramid in Guatemala misidentified an artifact that depicted a bearded dragon. It was a detail from a vessel's lid; it was not a plate.

title: Change or End Urged for Terror Insurance Law
description: A three-year-old federal law that provided a backstop to insurance companies in the event of a terrorist attack should not be extended in its current form, Bush administration officials said yesterday.

title: Untethered, and Back on Top of Her Game
description: Wimbledon, England - AS Venus Williams left Center Court, her cellphone was already glowing. Wherever Serena Williams was, she was dialing up her big sister to ask their ritual question, "Can I have your autograph?"

title: Share
description: "Fresh, seasonal ingredients" might as well read "15 billion served" for all the meaning it conveys anymore. It's a restaurant clich that touches a tranquilizing nerve, permitting gullibility in otherwise jaded, discerning, self-protective types. But when Share, an intimate, idealistic little spot in the East Village, stakes its claim to using fresh, seasonal ingredients, I'm willing to bet it is speaking sincerely.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about plans by President Bush to announce a program to fight malaria in Africa misstated the country in which the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation is sponsoring an anti-malaria project. It is Zambia, not Gambia. (Go to Article)

title: Is Autism Research Flawed, or Sound?
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Police Estimate Large Gang Presence
description: A survey released yesterday by the state police estimates that there are 17,000 street gang members in 700 gangs in New Jersey, with more than two-thirds in urban areas. The results are based on a 2004 survey of 439 municipal police departments. A more limited survey in 2001 estimated 300 gangs with 7,500 members. Col. Joseph R. Fuentes, the state police superintendent, said that nearly 44 percent of the state's cities and suburbs had reported an increase in gang activity. Ronald Smothers (NYT)

title: Leaders Reach Budget Deal in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 30 - Saying that they had ironed out differences that had threatened to plunge New Jersey into a fiscal and political crisis, Democratic legislators reached broad agreement Thursday night on a $28 billion budget that would give away more than $1 billion in property tax rebates and take in at least $130 million in new taxes.

title: Follow the Leapin' Leprechaun
description: Dublin - There is a huge debate roiling in Europe today over which economic model to follow: the Franco-German shorter-workweek-six-weeks'-vacation-never-fire-anyone-but-high-unemployment social model or the less protected but more innovative, high-employment Anglo-Saxon model preferred by Britain, Ireland and Eastern Europe. It is obvious to me that the Irish-British model is the way of the future, and the only question is when Germany and France will face reality: either they become Ireland or they become museums. That is their real choice over the next few years -- it's either the leprechaun way or the Louvre.

title: Taking the Measure of the New Freedom Tower
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPAR, LISA
description: SPAR--Lisa. 68, June 27, 2005. Beloved wife of Martin Spar, devoted mother of Steven (Kathleen), Jeffrey (Wendy Jeshion), Lori (Brett Carnot). Ecstatic grandmother of Isabella Rose. Happiness cut short, her memory lives on.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: U.S. Companies at Fair
description: Venezuela, the world's fifth-largest oil exporter, is playing host to more than 200 United States companies in a bid to strengthen trade ties amid growing political tensions between the countries' governments. Venezuela expects to drum up $300 million in business during the two-day trade fair that began yesterday at the Caracas Hilton, from companies in the agriculture, electronics, chemical and mineral industries, the trade minister, Edme Betancourt, said. President Hugo Chvez said in a speech last weekend that American businessmen were invited to the fair, despite poor relations with the United States. "The only thing we ask from the U.S. government is respect, don't mess with us," he said. "Now, with U.S. businessmen welcome, let's work together." In a speech in May, however, Mr. Chvez said "being rich is bad" and "Jesus Christ was a socialist," and he has called for Venezuela to move away from capitalism and embrace socialism.

title: Report of Ritalin Risks Prompts a Federal Study
description: ROCKVILLE, Md., June 30 - Federal health officials said Thursday that they were looking into a suggestion by a small Texas study that Ritalin and other stimulant drugs given to children might increase their risk of cancer later in life.

title: People: Bill Cosby, Backstreet Boys, the screenwriters of "Hotel Rwanda"
O'Connor, First Woman on High Court, Resigns After 24 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, the first woman to serve on the United States Supreme Court and a crucial swing vote on abortion and a host of other divisive social issues, announced today that she was resigning, setting up what is sure to be a tumultuous fight over confirming her successor.

title: Metro Briefing
description: Correction Appended

title: Council Speaker Is Accused of Retaliatory Budget Cuts
description: In an unusually open and personal display of anger, a handful of City Council members yesterday accused Speaker Gifford Miller of cutting their budget requests in retaliation for their decision not to support his fight against the mayor's citywide trash plan.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: ABB to Cut 1,300 Jobs
description: ABB, the world's biggest supplier of power networks, has cut its profit forecast and plans to eliminate 1,300 jobs as it shifts production to Asia to reduce expenses as oil and metal costs surge. Profit before interest and tax may amount this year to no more than 6.6 percent of sales, compared with an earlier forecast of 7.7 percent, the company said. Second-quarter earnings fell "significantly." ABB is cutting jobs in mature markets like Canada and Finland and shifting to sites in India and China, where costs are lower and demand higher.

title: Bank of America to Buy MBNA, a Prime Issuer of Credit Cards
description: Seeking to grab a bigger share of consumers' business by becoming a powerhouse in credit cards, the Bank of America Corporation announced plans yesterday to acquire the card giant MBNA for $35 billion in cash and stock.

title: Schrder loses key vote
Art in Review
description: Banks VioletteThe Whitney Museum of American Art945 Madison Avenue, at 75th StreetThrough Oct. 2

title: Schrder forges strategy on confidence vote
O'Connor, First Woman Supreme Court Justice, Resigns After 24 Years
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 AJustice Sandra Day O'Connor, the first woman to serve on the United States Supreme Court, announced today that she is resigning, setting off what is expected to be a tumultuous fight over confirming her successor.

title: Time Inc. to Yield Files on Sources, Relenting to U.S.
description: With one of its reporters facing an imminent jail sentence, Time magazine said yesterday that it would provide documents concerning the reporter's confidential sources to a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the identity of a covert C.I.A. operative, Valerie Plame.

title: Baathists May Be Joining Iraq's Constitution Drafters
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 30 - At least two of the 15 Sunni Arabs proposed as members of the committee that will write Iraq's permanent constitution have been accused of being senior members of Saddam Hussein's Baath Party, and two others have openly declared themselves strong supporters of the party.

title: Study Examines Sales to Soldiers
description: An extensive study by the Government Accountability Office, delivered to members of Congress yesterday, confirmed that Pentagon rules intended to protect service members from high-pressure or deceptive life insurance sales have been repeatedly violated in recent years.

title: Senate Approves Central American Free Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - After a bitter and prolonged battle over the promises and perils of foreign trade, the Senate voted on Thursday to approve the Central American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Fatal Shooting In Seagate
description: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot last night in Seagate, the police said, and his killer was being sought. The man, whose name was not released by the authorities, was shot in the neck at 3194 Bayview Avenue around 10:30 p.m., the police said. He was taken to Coney Island Hospital and pronounced dead. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Houses on Fly-Fishing Streams: A Vacation at Your Doorstep
description: WHO -- Karen Chick, 53, a retired sporting goods saleswoman from Claremont, Calif., and her husband, Jim (not shown), 59, owner of a chain of sports equipment stores WHAT -- 4-bedroom house WHERE -- Swan Valley, Idaho

title: Bush Proposes New Spending to Assist Poor Africans
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - President Bush proposed initiatives on Thursday to help Africa, calling for increased spending to fight malaria, help more children attend school and ensure the rights of women.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DRUCKER, DAVID L.
description: DRUCKER--David L., 73 years of age, a longtime dentist in Queens, died on Monday, June 27th, 2005 in Portland, ME. He was born in Brooklyn and was a graduate of Queens College and Columbia Dental School. He is survived by his wife Barbara Schulhoff Drucker of Portland, ME, two daughters Claire and Julie Drucker, both of California, and one brother Edmond of Great Neck. Also surviving is one step-son and two step-daughters. It was the family's request that there be no formal funeral service.

title: Oliver Jensen, 91, Magazine Founder, Dies
description: Oliver Jensen, a founder and former editor of American Heritage magazine, died early yesterday morning in Chester, Conn. He was 91 and had lived in Old Saybrook, Conn., for many years.

title: Is Autism Research Flawed, or Sound?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hitting Rewind In Rerun Season
description: AS vacationing Americans begin their summer migratory patterns, the recreation can start as soon as families pull out of the driveway or lift off the tarmac. DVD players descend from the ceilings of minivans and rest on the seat-back tables of airliners. Distance need no longer be measured in miles to go, but in episodes of "Family Guy" still to be screened. Children, becalmed by SpongeBob and Dora, might not think to ask, "Are we there yet?"

title: When the castle in the sky is a chteau
Paid Notice: Deaths   WEST, DR. M. MAURICE
description: WEST--Dr. M. Maurice, at age 83. Beloved husband of Vivienne. Devoted father of Andrew (Lisa), Robert (Denise), and Elizabeth (Andrew) Paleologopoulos. Adored grandfather of Samantha, Zachary, Cody, Morgan, Peter, Michael, Matthew, Samuel and David. Cherished brother of Marsha Yagoda. Dear brother-in-law of Dr. Paul (Ellen) Mitchell. Forever in our hearts. Services Friday, July 1, 2005, at 11:30 AM, at "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels," 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be directed to The Rogosin Institute, 505 East 70 St., Room 230, New York, NY 10021.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Kindred Spirits' on View
description: Asher B. Durand's "Kindred Spirits" goes on view at the National Gallery of Art in Washington today, just seven weeks after the Walton Family Foundation of Bentonville, Ark., bought the 1849 painting from the New York Public Library in a sealed-bid auction, beating out a joint offer by the Metropolitan Museum and the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The painting, left, is to hang in the main floor of the American art galleries until February 2007. From Washington it will travel to the Brooklyn Museum, where it will be included in "Kindred Spirits: Asher B. Durand and American Landscape Painting," from April 6 through Aug. 12, 2007. The painting, which depicts the painter Thomas Cole and the poet William Cullen Bryant standing on a rocky ledge in the Catskills, is titled after a phrase in a Keats sonnet. It has long been considered one of the finest examples of Hudson River School painting. CAROL VOGE

title: Consumers, Long the Targets, Become the Shapers of Campaigns
description: WHEN Crest introduced a toothpaste line two years ago, it used focus groups to help pick three flavors: cinnamon, herbal and citrus. This time around, the new Crest flavors will be chosen by customers.

title: After 2 Years on Ground, Shuttle Is Set to Fly
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., June 30 - NASA will return the shuttle Discovery to space in two weeks, after almost two and a half years on the ground since the loss of the shuttle Columbia, officials said Thursday.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 6 P.M. (TCM) LIGHT IN THE PIAZZA (1962). Yvette Mimieux, George Hamilton, Olivia de Havilland and the city of Florence all look great in this lightweight but poignant romantic drama (which was transformed this season into a Broadway musical). Ms. de Havilland (above, with Barry Sullivan as her husband and Ms. Mimieux as their grown child) plays a wealthy American tourist in Italy who doesn't know what to do when a handsome young Italian (that would be Mr. Hamilton) falls for her adorable blond daughter. The question is whether to tell him that the young woman will always have the mental capacity of a 10-year-old.

title: Bush Selects Admiral for No. 2 Post at C.I.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - A three-star Navy admiral who commanded Special Operations forces during the war in Afghanistan has been nominated by President Bush to become the No. 2 official at the Central Intelligence Agency, the Pentagon announced Thursday.

title: Open Outcry and Very British
description: LONDON, June 29 - It is, the chief executive of the London Metal Exchange acknowledged, a "very odd entity."

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Dancers Win Asturias Prize

title: Bank of America expands its credit empire
Aide to Ayatollah Is Killed in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 1 - A senior aide to Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, was gunned down by assassins while on his way to Friday prayers and a suicide car bomb exploded near the office of a major Shiite political party, an Interior Ministry official said today.

title: Spain gives approval to gay unions
Plenty of Role Players Highlight Free Agency
description: The bidding for N.B.A. free agents officially began this morning with few top stars available, but a deep summer crop nonetheless.

title: Long Distance Biking
description: LONG distance bike rides have been a fixture of summer for decades. You're likely to have heard of Ragbrai (Register's Annual Great Bicycle Ride Across Iowa), the weeklong ride that started in 1973. It reached its limit of 8,500 riders months ago, but there are other rides going on across the country soon, and there's still time to take part. And in many cases, you don't have to commit yourself to the whole ride.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a letter on Tuesday about the problem some American students have understanding foreign teachers misidentified a Nobel Prize winner who taught the writer at Indiana University in the 1950's. He was Hermann Joseph Muller (a 1946 laureate), not Paul Herman Mller (a 1948 laureate).

title: Hitting Rewind in Rerun Season: DVD's Culled From TV's Past
description: Here are reviews of 10 DVD sets of popular television series and special collections. (An introduction appears on Page 1 of Weekend.)

title: Fed Stays Its Course a 9th Time
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - The Federal Reserve raised short-term interest rates on Thursday, the ninth consecutive increase and almost certainly not the last.

title: Five Ways to Win Back Iraq
description: Washington - IRAQ is not another Afghanistan. Notwithstanding what President Bush said in his speech on Tuesday, our primary problem in Iraq is not terrorism, and the administration's single-minded focus on terrorism may help explain why we have not yet adopted a true counterinsurgency strategy or properly tackled so many of the country's other problems.

title: Meanwhile: Sibling rivalry comes of age
Other views: LA Times, Chicago Tribune, Irish Independent
Sprint and Motorola Plan a Joint Effort on Wireless Technology
description: Sprint and Motorola said yesterday they would work together to develop technology for next-generation high-speed wireless technology.

title: Germany looks to score big from World Cup
Slapstick Zombies Run Amok in Australia
description: "Undead," the debut feature from the Australian twins Peter and Michael Spierig, is a broad mishmash of zombie horror, old-fashioned sci-fi, spaghetti western, slapstick comedy and high-tech "Matrix"-style action that bites off more than it can chew but does so without any real teeth.

title: Spain Legalizes Gay Marriage; Law Is Among the Most Liberal
description: MADRID, June 30 - The Spanish Parliament voted Thursday to legalize gay marriage, giving final approval to a bill that would make Spain, a predominantly Catholic country, the first nation to eliminate all legal distinctions between same-sex and heterosexual unions, according to supporters of the measure.

title: U.S. Continues Search for Missing Team in Afghan Mountains
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 1 - American forces are still searching for a small reconnaissance team missing in mountainous terrain in eastern Afghanistan where a helicopter was shot down on Tuesday, killing all 16 aboard, United States military officials said today. The helicopter, a Chinook MH-47, with special operations forces and Navy Seal commandos aboard, was flying in to carry out the soldiers on the ground during a battle with suspected Taliban and Al Qaeda insurgents, the United States military spokesman at Bagram Airbase, Lt. Col. Gerry O'Hara, said. The Chinook came under small arms fire and a missile, probably a rocket-propelled grenade, and crashed, killing all on board, the military has said.

title: Letter from Asia: For many, two Koreas may be better than one
Homeless Sex Offender Held in Stabbing Death Near Mall
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 30 - The police arrested a homeless man who is a convicted rapist on Thursday and charged him with second-degree murder in the stabbing death of a White Plains woman on Wednesday in a parking garage next to a popular downtown shopping mall.

title: Techbrief: Telefnica in new bid for Cesky
Art in Review; Momus and Mai Ueda
description: I'll Speak, You Sing Zach Feuer Gallery (LFL) 530 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through July 15

title: Federer advances to Wimbledon final

description: To the Editor:

title: Some held hostage in '79 say Iran's chief was a captor
Armstrong's View on Possible 7th Tour Win: No Big Deal
description: CHALLANS, France, July 1 - The number is not really that important, Lance Armstrong concedes. Seven would be nowhere near as big as six.

title: A Musician Taking Cues From Worlds Near and Far
description: It rained miserably for most of David Byrne's Summerstage concert on Wednesday, and the sound of his current band doesn't withstand that kind of weather very well. Since last year, he has been touring with a band that includes the Tosca Strings, a six-member outfit from Austin, Tex., as well as a bassist, percussionist and drummer. He plays a little electric guitar, the arrangements are streamlined, and his voice is sounding strong. But it's both a well-wrought show and a delicate mutt: chamber music, mellow marimba tones and domesticated Afro-Cuban rhythm.

title: Caged in a Beijing Theme Park, Yearning for Something More
description: "The World" was shown as part of last year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Manohla Dargis's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 11, 2004; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The unrated film, in Mandarin with English subtitles, opens today in Manhattan at Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village.

title: Shopping | Haute Camping
description: IF the thought of freeze-dried noodles and a warm brew deter you from a night in the woods, take notice: the current crop of gadgets and gear cater to foodie campers, making it possible to bring along such luxuries (essentials?) as wine, espresso and the kitchen sink. So on your next weekend camping trip, skip the trail mix and indulge. WENDY KNIGHT

title: Old and Ghostly but Still a Hoot
description: The paint on the balconies of the Majestic Theater looks chipped and the electronic drum machine sounds like something left over from a music video from the 1980's. But "The Phantom of the Opera" really shows its age (17 years and running) when the signature special effect is presented. Musicals have opened and closed in the time it takes that chandelier to lumber to the floor. Looking like one of Ed Wood's teetering flying saucers, it crashes to the stage with the force of a shopping cart, the biggest, most extravagant anticlimax in town.

title: Mad cow site identified as Texas pet food plant
G.O.P., Democrats in Its Sights, Is Grooming Black Candidates
description: CLARION, Pa. - Lynn Swann, the Hall of Fame former wide receiver for the Pittsburgh Steelers, stood before a nearly all-white Republican crowd at the Holiday Inn here recently and blasted Pennsylvania's Democratic governor, Edward G. Rendell, for failing to reduce property taxes. Then, without prompting, Mr. Swann suddenly turned the subject to race -- his own.

title: Art in Review; Lucia Pagliari and Others After Hopper
description: Bonni Benrubi Gallery 41 East 57th Street, Manhattan Through July 9

title: Israel evicts 150 anti-pullout activists from derelict hotel
When a gimmick only goes so far
Deal Reached on Ethics Committee Staffing
description: WASHINGTON, June 30 - Leaders of the House ethics committee Thursday night announced that they had worked out the details of how to resolve a staffing fight preventing the panel from beginning an inquiry into Representative Tom DeLay, the majority leader, and other members.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Police Break Up Protest Over Election Delay
description: The police used tear gas and live rounds to disperse large demonstrations in Kinshasa staged by activists upset that presidential elections have been delayed into next year. News services reported numerous injuries and dozens of arrests. President Joseph Kabila, the transitional leader, will remain in office until the nationwide elections are held. A peace deal that ended years of war in Congo set June 30 as the election day but allowed the government to delay voting for up to a year. Marc Lacey (NYT)

Germany Looks Forward to World Cup and Fans' Money
description: FRANKFURT, June 30 - There was drama both on and off the soccer field here Wednesday night as Brazil trounced Argentina, 4 to 1, in the final game of the Confederations Cup, a warm-up for the World Cup.

title: Hewlett Cites Progress on Quantum Computer
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 30 - Scientists at Hewlett-Packard said Thursday that they had developed a new strategy for designing a quantum computer composed of switches of light beams that could be vastly more powerful than today's digital electronic computers, which are constructed from transistors.

Italy Denies Any Role in Seizure of Terror Suspect
description: ROME, June 30 - The Italian government, facing growing embarrassment and louder questions, broke a week of silence on Thursday and denied that it had played any role in kidnapping a terror suspect in Milan in 2003 and flying him to Egypt, or even that it had prior knowledge of the operation.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARNETT, JOHN J.
description: HARNETT--John J. On June 29, 2005. Retired Lieutenant of FDNY. Beloved husband of Irene (nee Stack). Loving father of Mary and Nancy. Dear brother of Lillian Mooney, Noreen Malanaphy, the late Joanne Steakelum, Mary Mooney, James Harnett and Eileen Phelan. Also survivecd by 34 nieces and nephews. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th St.) Friday, July 1, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial on Saturday, 10 AM at Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14th St., NYC. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to NY Weill-Cornell Burn Center, C/O Development Office, New York Presbyterian Hospital, 525 East 68 Street, Box 123, NYC 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAMANSKY, RENEE
description: ZAMANSKY--Renee. Temple Shaaray Tefila records with profound sorrow the death of our long-time, cherished member. Heartfelt condolences are extended to her children, Martine, Michael, Stephen and their families. May her memory be for blessing. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein Michael H. Laufer, Pres.

title: Age Joins the Pack in Pursuit of Armstrong
description: CHALLANS, France, June 30 - The year was 1993 and the speaker was Lance Armstrong, going on 22 years old, brash and full of zest, peering over the horizon.

title: Aliens arrive, wielding metaphors
Health Dept. Issues Warning on Tap Water
description: An intense downpour Wednesday evening washed dirt from a construction site into one of New York City's reservoirs in Westchester County, possibly contaminating the water and prompting city officials to warn yesterday that anyone with a weak immune system should boil tap water before drinking it.

title: Russian-Uzbek tiesworrying West
Senate Roll-Call Vote on Cafta
description: The 54-45 roll call by which the Senate voted to approve legislation needed to implement the Central American Free Trade Agreement. On this vote, a "yes" vote was a vote to pass the legislation and a "no" vote was a vote to defeat it. Voting "yes" were 10 Democrats, 43 Republicans and one independent. Voting "no" were 33 Democrats and 12 Republicans.

title: Corrections
description: Charts on June 21 with an article about young men who have shifted their interest to sports video games from televised events carried erroneous labels. One, comparing sales in 2000 and 2004, showed only the sales of sports games, not all video games. The other -- comparing viewership of football, basketball and baseball games in 2000 and 2004 by males aged 12 to 34 -- showed the averages for only regular-season games; it did not include playoffs.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 24 about the acquittal of a California woman arrested at the Republican National Convention when she unfurled a banner criticizing President Bush referred imprecisely in some copies to the disposition of about 400 other convention protest cases and to the videotape evidence they involved. Charges were dropped in some cases, not all (the defendants were acquitted in the others), because the videotapes undermined or contradicted the original accusations. In one case, a police videotape was improperly edited by the Manhattan district attorney's office, but the integrity of the tapes was not otherwise at issue.

title: UBS Hedge Fund Choice
description: UBS, the world's biggest asset manager, said yesterday that it had named its investment banking chief, John P. Costas, to run a new hedge fund unit. The company's global head of equities, Huw Jenkins, will succeed Mr. Costas.

title: Britainrenews its attack on farm aid
Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, LOUIS N.
description: FRIEDLAND--Louis N., 92, died peacefully on June 29th with his adoring family around him. Beloved husband of the late Billie, cherished father of Joanne Friedland Roberts and Eric Friedland, devoted grandfather of Lola Beatrice Friedland Roberts, loving father-in-law of Alyson Denny and uncle of George Lerner. Retired Chairman of MCA-TV and former President of the National Hemophilia Association, Lou was an industry pioneer, esteemed mentor and precious friend to many. Funeral services Tuesday, July 5th, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lou's honor to the Hemophilia Association of New York (HANY), 104 East 40th St., Suite 506, NYC 10016.

(The error also appeared in articles on Dec. 13, 2004, and Nov. 5 and 14, 2004.) He is the director of a social sciences seminar at Columbia University; he is not on the faculty.

description: TOMCHIN--David. On June 29, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Etta. Devoted father of Joy and Stanley & fatherin-law of Cheryl. Cherished grandfather of Emily and Evan. Services on Sunday 11:30 AM at "The Riverside" 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: A lake-studded detour near Berlin
Celebrities' Embrace of Africa Has Critics
description: LONDON, June 30 - It is virtually impossible these days to open a newspaper or turn on the television here without confronting the cavalier locks, rumpled visage and hectoring tones of Sir Bob Geldof, the former Boomtown Rats lead singer now cast by friends and foes alike as Africa's savior.

title: Pakistan opens door to foreign investors
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Spitzer Sues Immigration Counselors
description: Eliot Spitzer, the state attorney general, sued three immigration consultants yesterday, saying they defrauded dozens of clients out of $175,000. Pending a hearing in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, a judge ordered the consultants -- Angela Pasquino, Luis Cuero, and Francisco Morales -- to stop seeking clients, Mr. Spitzer said. He said the three, who operated from Queens, promised to obtain green cards for clients, but did not submit paperwork to federal agencies. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEBER, MIRIAM
description: WEBER--Miriam, died at her home on June 29 at the age of 96. She lived a full, rich life and will be remembered with love by her children, Michael and Suzanne Weber, and Judith Weber and Nat Sobel; her grandchildren, Joshua Weber and Lee, Anna, Adam and Joey Sobel; and her great granddaughter, Eddyl Sobel. A memorial benefit performance for the Amato Opera in her honor is planned.

title: Arts, Briefly; Controversial Clinton Book Tops List
description: A new book about Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton that has attracted both praise and brickbats from both ends of the political spectrum appears to have sold well in its first week. "The Truth About Hillary: What She Knew, When She Knew It and How Far She'll Go to Become President," by Edward Klein, will rank No. 2 on the New York Times best-seller list to be published on July 10. (That edition of the list reflects sales in the week ended June 25, the book's first week on sale.) While the book got off to a fast start, sales may have cooled this week. Yesterday afternoon, the book ranked No. 13 on Amazon.com's best-seller list, and No. 40 on Barnes & Noble.com's list; last week, the book was in the top 5 for much of the week. EDWARD WYAT

title: The Listings: July 1 -- July 7; 'VISUAL GLOSSOLALIA'
description: This show lives up to the nearly trance-inducing onomatopoeia of its name with a seductive buzz of transmuting letters, symbols and equations. It tracks the notion of mediumistic writing or writing in tongues through the work of eight 20th- and 21st-century mostly American self-taught artists and one spectacular Burmese yantra (prayer) book from around 1900. It suggests that legibility is only part of the power of language; touch and emotional urgency can push letter-like marks to the brink of meaning and reveal an artist's personal cosmos, especially when fused with a strong sense of imagery and form. Sometimes the language here is simply not the one most viewers speak, as in the yantra book where striped mythic beasts, rotund monsters and splendidly attired guardians are encircled in palindromic prayers. But often it is fabricated and fragmentary. Minnie Evans (American, 1892-1987) enlivened ornate blocks of foliate motifs with similarly intense faces and swarms of tiny inchoate letters. Darcilio Lima (Brazilian, 1944-1991) drew exquisite hybrid creatures worthy of Gustave Moreau that seem guided by delicate numbered diagrams. Numbers prevail in the mathematical constellations of Melvin Way's small, dark yet somehow immense illuminated drawing. Symbols both ancient and scientific rule a large scribbled grid, above, by William Fields (American, born 1940); a photograph of the artist as a well-groomed young man turns into a professorial portrait (although the grid, with its capelike flutter and regal head, has a life of its own). The gyrating symbols that Leroy Person (American, 1907-1985) rendered in choppy crayon have the effect of repeated incantations. So do the chunks of writing competing for space in an overpopulated drawing by Carlo Zinelli (Italian, 1916-1974). Like Zinelli, Harald Stoffers (German, born 1961) is institutionalized; his lines of blocky cursive, all written to his mother, have the tensility of bent wire and accumulate in tight layers, like sediment, or a wayward musical score. The spidery visionary automatism of J.B. Murry (American, 1908-88) brings the show full circle, back to the vicinity of prayers. (Luise Ross Gallery, 568 Broadway at Prince Street, SoHo, (212)343-2161, through July 15; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Long Sentences For Killers Of Liberal Lawmaker
description: A court found two men guilty of the murder of Galina V. Starovoitova, a liberal politician who was shot to death in her apartment stairwell in St. Petersburg on the eve of elections in November 1998, and sentenced them to prison terms of 20 and 23 years. Ms. Starovoitova's killing caused outrage and was seen at the time as a blow to Russia's nascent democracy. The presiding judge qualified the murder as politically motivated. One defendant was convicted of being an organizer of the killing, and the other an assailant. Two other defendants were acquitted, and two were found guilty of lesser charges and released. Who ordered the killing is still not known. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: A Wildwood Makeover
description: PERHAPS you've heard of party-hearty Wildwood, the blue-collar Jersey Shore town of prom-night flophouse motels, dance-till-dawn nightclubs and roving packs of teenagers prowling the boardwalk. You know, Wildwood: seedy cousin of tonier towns like Stone Harbor and Avalon and traditional rite-of-passage spot for millions of East Coast young people in search of beach days and boogie nights.

Ebbers, the founder and former chief executive of WorldCom who was found guilty of fraud in March, agreed to surrender nearly all of his personal fortune -- about $40 million -- to investors who lost billions when the company spiraled into bankruptcy. title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEDLEY, NATHAN
description: SEDLEY--Nathan. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the loss of Nathan Sedley, a renowned businessman and leader of the Jewish community. Nathan's lifetime of support for humanitarian causes served as the foundation for the Sedley family's commitment to philanthropic concerns. This enduring legacy continues through the leadership of Nathan's son, Ronald, whose service to our Board of Directors and Commission on the Jewish People strengthens our ability to serve those in need. Ronald's generosity and enthusiasm overflows with the spirit of klal Yisrael, positively influencing the global Jewish community. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Nathan's beloved wife, Dina; to their children: Ronald, Rita Katz, Brenda Beeley, Madeline, and her husband, Leo Zern; to their grandchildren and great-grandchildren; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Rhode Island Drops DuPont From Suit Over Paint in Deal

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Pirates Seize Tsunami Aid Ship
description: Armed men commandeered a ship carrying United Nations food aid to northeastern Somalia, the World Food Program said. The pirates forced their way on board the Semlow off the Somali coast, took the ship's 10 crew members hostage and took possession of 850 metric tons of rice that had been donated by Japan and Germany for tsunami victims in Somalia. "It is against international humanitarian law to hinder the passage of humanitarian assistance, and there is no justification for hijacking," the food agency said in a statement. Marc Lacey (NYT)

Somebody ought to be around to advise them if they are violating various rules put forth by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. On their own, they may have trouble figuring things out.

title: The Listings: July 1 -- July 7; KHALED AND FRIENDS
description: Khaled, the reigning male singer in the Algerian pop style rai, has international ambitions for music that was once so blunt and bawdy that it was sung only at private parties. Khaled Brahim became one of rai's first recording stars as a teenager in the 1970's, when the music spread via underground cassette tapes and picked up Western elements like cheap keyboards and drum-machine beats. Singing about the problems and pleasures of everyday life in clear, catchy songs, rai singers were considered rebels, and while the music reached Algerian radio in the mid-1980's, its official acceptance was short-lived. Fundamentalist groups in Algeria brutally suppressed it in the 1990's. By then, Khaled had become an expatriate in Paris, where he continued to broaden the music, drawing on funk, reggae, rock and Latin pop, as rai's audience spread worldwide. Khaled's new album, "Ya-Rayi" (Wrasse/Universal), includes a song in English, "Love to the People," that features Carlos Santana on guitar, while other songs reconnect to roots with accordion, flutes and hand drumming. For his concert at Summerstage, Khaled, above, is being joined by some of his international collaborators, including the producer Don Was, the producer and D.J. Cheb i Sabbah, the Latin-pop producer KC Porter, the reggae singer Elan and the percussionists Luis Conte and Walfredo Reyes Jr. Yet at the center of all the hybrids is Khaled's voice, gutsy and immediate, using Arabic inflections to convey direct passions. (Sunday at 3 p.m., Central Park Summerstage, mid-park at 69th Street, Manhattan, (212)360-2777. Admission is free, with donations requested.) JON PARELES

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Growth, Still Strong, Slows
description: India's economy grew 7 percent from January to March over the year-ago period, backed by strong manufacturing and services, bringing growth for the fiscal year to 6.9 percent, the government's statistics agency said. In the previous fiscal year, output grew 8.5 percent. Manufacturing was up 8.6 percent in the January-to-March quarter, compared with 7.6 percent a year earlier. The services sector grew 7.7 percent in the quarter, as consumers bought cars and built homes as incomes rose. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Insurance Subsidy At Risk
description: The Treasury Department said yesterday that a terrorism-insurance subsidy created after Sept. 11, 2001, was too costly for taxpayers and should be allowed to expire unless it is reduced. The Terrorism Risk Insurance Act, which provides as much as $100 billion to help insurers limit any losses from future events, expires on Dec. 31. In a report to Congress, the treasury secretary, John W. Snow, said that private insurers should be shouldering more of the terrorism risks. A coalition of bankers, developers and business groups who are lobbying for the subsidy called the report "flawed" and said that terrorism coverage would become hard to get and prohibitively expensive without federal assistance.

title: The Listings: July 1 -- July 7; LYNN REDGRAVE
description: "Of course truth is an excellent thing, but before one tells it one should be quite sure that one does so for the advantage of the person who hears it rather than for one's own self-satisfaction." That rather elaborately contrived epigram does not have the brevity or the wit of Oscar Wilde, but you might be fooled into thinking it did by the droll delivery of Lynn Redgrave. In the new Broadway revival of W. Somerset Maugham's comedy "The Constant Wife," Ms. Redgrave, above, plays Mrs. Culver, a plumply upholstered British matron who is called upon, by herself primarily, to interfere in the messy marital affairs of her daughter, who has a straying husband and some bold ideas about how best to deal with him. With her high regard for propriety and her tendency to speak in aphorisms, Mrs. Culver is a distant relation of the imperious Lady Bracknell, from Wilde's "Importance of Being Earnest." As it happens, Ms. Redgrave will undertake that role next season in Los Angeles. Her delightful Mrs. Culver can be considered a most promising sneak preview. (American Airlines Theater, 227 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212)719-1300.) CHARLES ISHERWOOD

Next week, "The Cut" moves to Wednesday at 8 p.m. to make room for one of the three episodes of the sixth edition of "Big Brother." The cap appears to be the most restrictive in the nation, but is just one of many measures being taken by states seeking to rein in soaring Medicaid costs.
