description: Lance Armstrong's War By Daniel Coyle 326 pages. HarperCollins $25.95.

title: U.S. searches for team missing in Afghanistan
Arts Guide
Village Voice Reaches Agreement With Union, Averting a Strike
description: After intense negotiations that lasted until early yesterday, the Village Voice's management and the paper's writers, clerical staff and advertising and marketing representatives reached an agreement, averting a strike.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, LOUIS N.
description: FRIEDLAND--Louis N., 92, died peacefully on June 29th with his adoring family around him. Beloved husband of the late Billie, cherished father of Joanne Friedland Roberts and Eric Friedland, devoted grandfather of Lola Beatrice Friedland Roberts, loving father-in-law of Alyson Denny and uncle of George Lerner. Retired Chairman of MCA-TV and former President of the National Hemophilia Association, Lou was an industry pioneer, esteemed mentor and precious friend to many. Funeral services Tuesday, July 5th, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lou's honor to the Hemophilia Association of New York (HANY), 104 East 40th St., Suite 506, NYC 10016.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, JULIUS
description: YOUNG--Julius, 91, on July 1, 2005. Beloved father of Steve and Sandy. Husband of the late Pearl. Grandfather to Michelle and Ashley. Funeral services July 3rd at 10:00 AM, Weinstein Garlick Funeral Home, 1153 Coney Island Ave, Bklyn, NY, 800-556-7799

title: Jury Finds Infringements on Patents on Stents
description: A federal court jury concluded yesterday that Johnson & Johnson's method for coating its Cypher stent with drugs was an infringement on a patent owned by Boston Scientific. The jury also found that the structure of three Johnson & Johnson stents infringed a second patent.

title: Confidentiality and News Gathering
description: To the Editor:

title: The Rise of Gypsy Punkers
description: HOW many Gypsy punk groups does it take to start a movement? Seven years ago, when Eugene Hutz, an immigrant from Ukraine, formed the band Gogol Bordello, the answer might have been one. Its concerts, mingling the passionate rage of punk with the ragtag theatricality of traditional Gypsy music, quickly caught on, and Mr. Hutz, a rangy philosopher-acrobat, established himself as a leading figure of New York's downtown culture, underground and otherwise; in September, he will make his feature film debut, starring with Eijah Wood in Liev Schreiber's adaptation of "Everything Is Illuminated," a novel by Jonathan Safran Foer.

title: Two 1,000-Horsepower Motors, but No Cloud of Dust
description: IN my younger and more volatile years, my father gave me a piece of advice that I've been turning over in my mind at 6,000 revolutions a minute ever since.

title: Back in Howard Beach, the Pot and the Kettle Are Both Black
description: THE sun glowered, the traffic crawled, and the bay air reeked of salt on a wound. Things were hot again in Howard Beach, and there was nothing to do yesterday but wait once more for Sharpton. Wait, wait, wait.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROULET, JEAN
description: ROULET--Jean. Still loved. Still missed. Always. Your Sisters

title: Family Went About Daily Lives As Body Lay in Hall, Police Say
description: The three sisters -- Gabriel, Clara and Marie Durand -- lived together in a one-bedroom apartment in Flushing, Queens. They were born in Haiti between the two world wars.

title: Lego braces for big changes
Jury Awards Family $1.95 Million in Dick Schaap's Death
description: A jury found a cardiologist at Lenox Hill Hospital liable yesterday for the death of the sports journalist Dick Schaap after hip replacement surgery and awarded his family $1.95 million in compensatory damages.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, ETHEL H.
description: COHEN--Ethel H. July 2, 1925--January 15, 2004 Happy 80th Birthday, dearest Mom, Grandma, Ethel. How we wish we could celebrate with you. All is well, but life will never, ever be the same. Make a good wish, and so will we. With love from all of us, Dad and Howard

title: After a Brief Shock, Advocates Quickly Mobilize
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - Around 9:30 Friday morning, C. Boyden Gray, founder of the Committee for Justice, a conservative group that is a leading ally of President Bush, was sipping coffee at his Georgetown residence and confessing mild frustration to a reporter for The New York Times about the waiting game for a Supreme Court retirement. Suddenly he got a text message and expressed that emotion rare for stage-managed Washington: surprise.

title: For Many, Path to Big One Begins With Low Stake
description: Eight Texas road gamblers were all who dared enter the World Series of Poker in 1972. That was the event's third year but the first time the buy-in reached $10,000. Thirty-three years later the buy-in to the main event remains the same, but more than 6,000 are expected to enter next week. What gave all these people the courage?

title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain Takes On European Presidency
description: Tony Blair and Britain took over the rotating presidency of the European Union, and Mr. Blair made it clear that he wants to use his six months at the helm to urge a new economic model in Europe, in effect a call for Germany and France not to rely on social legislation to protect jobs. His first initiative was to propose an informal summit meeting in the fall. "Everyone in Europe would agree this is an interesting moment to take on the presidency of the European Union, for sure," he said. Graham Bowley (IHT)

title: College Closers Find Short Route to Majors
description: In the spring of 2003, Chad Cordero was closing games for Cal-State Fullerton in the College World Series. That August, he became the first Montreal Expos draft choice to play in the major leagues the same year that he was drafted, pitching a scoreless seventh inning in a 4-3 loss to Florida.

title: Corrections
description: An art review in Weekend yesterday about "Robert Mapplethorpe and the Classical Tradition," at the Guggenheim Museum, included a misspelling provided by the museum for the title of a photograph in the exhibition. The title, which is also the name of the subject, is "Alan Lynes," not Lyne.

title: A Turning Point for the Court, and for the Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: A Turning Point for the Court, and for the Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: Smithtown's Hopes for Redevelopment
description: To the Editor:

title: Other views: Houston Chronicle, Korea Times, Saudi Gazette
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Kidnapping Victims To Stay In Custody
description: A federal judge ordered that 39 kidnapping victims be held in custody along with three people suspected of being the kidnappers for 60 days while prosecutors investigate their possible links to organized crime. Federal forces rescued the hostages in raids on Sunday in the lawless border city of Nuevo Laredo. The group was then taken to Mexico City. Investigators say the hostages may be members of a rival drug gang kidnapped in a turf war over smuggling routes into Texas. Five teenagers rescued in the raids were released. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: The wrong message
Viewpoints: Executives, 1; prosecutors, 1
Corrections
description: A film review on Wednesday about "Tropical Malady," which opened that day at the IFC Center in Greenwich Village, misspelled the name of the actor who plays Keng. (The error also appeared in an article on June 26 about the director of the movie, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, and in a review last Oct. 2, when it was shown at the New York Film Festival.) The actor is Banlop Lomnoi, not Lamnoi.

title: Reporters Facing Jail Time Submit Preferences
description: Matthew Cooper of Time magazine and Judith Miller of The New York Times, who have been held in contempt for refusing to testify about their confidential sources, filed court papers yesterday asking to be sentenced to home confinement or to particular federal prisons if they must be jailed.

title: Arts, Briefly; On the Opry
description: Larry King's wife, the actress and singer Shawn Southwick-King, will make her Grand Ole Opry debut on July 16, The Nashville Tennessean reported. Ms. Southwick-King, right, whose stage name is Shawn King, is signed to the independent country label Lofton Creek Records. As an actress, she was a frequent guest star on 1980's television shows, including "Knight Rider" and "Simon & Simon," and played a small part in the Sci Fi Channel original movie "Bombshell," which featured the "E.T." star Henry Thomas. "Bombshell" was released in 1996, the year before she married Mr. King. Ms. Southwick-King will be the second distinguished relative to make her Opry debut in recent weeks. Georgette Jones, the only daughter of George Jones and Tammy Wynette, sang at the Opry for the first time on June 21, joining her father onstage to great applause. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Gaza Strip: Israel Reopens Settlements
description: The Israeli military reopened the Gaza Strip to nonresidents, a day after it closed off the territory during an operation to oust about 150 right-wing Jewish protesters. The move means that for now Israeli citizens may again travel freely to and from the Jewish settlements in Gaza, though the Israeli government plans to begin removing the nearly 9,000 settlers beginning in mid-August. But the military said it would not permit visitors to bring in heavy equipment, building material or other items that suggested they were planning a long stay. The protesters who were evicted on Thursday had come from Israel and Jewish settlements in the West Bank. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: For Potential Juror, 'Honest' Response to Judge Backfires
description: It may have been an inelegant description, but Stephen Caruso said he thought he was just being honest on Thursday afternoon when a judge asked if he could be fair and impartial toward a defendant on trial for kidnapping. No, Mr. Caruso said during the voir dire portion of jury selection. "I have been held up three times at gunpoint," he said according to transcripts, adding, "I am already looking at him; I think he is a scumbag."

title: Briefly: KPN to lose phone monopoly
Families Mourn as Names of Crash Victims Emerge
description: Steve Reich never expressed regret that his promising professional baseball career lasted only two games for a Baltimore Orioles farm team before the Army summoned him back to active duty 10 years ago.

title: Amid Vows of Opposition, Senate Braces for Disarray
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - The Senate braced on Friday for a Supreme Court confirmation fight that threatens to strain a tenuous new agreement on handling court nominations and plunge the chamber back into partisan strife.

title: Slithering Somberly Through a Solitary Sea of Wistful Introspection
description: Near the beginning of the Eels concert at Town Hall on Thursday night, one audience member felt emboldened to share his feelings about the all-female string quartet onstage. "Pretty ladies, E," the fan called out, addressing Mark Oliver Everett, the bandleader, by his nickname.

title: Corrections
description: A film review on Wednesday about "Tropical Malady," which opened that day at the IFC Center in Greenwich Village, misspelled the name of the actor who plays Keng. (The error also appeared in an article on June 26 about the director of the movie, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, and in a review last Oct. 2, when it was shown at the New York Film Festival.) The actor is Banlop Lomnoi, not Lamnoi.

title: The Traveler
Clash of Beach-Nesting Species: Plover and Human
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. - Of the migrating species, the piping plover is one of those listed by federal conservationists as "threatened," while humans with beach houses, to judge from current demographic trends, are thriving beyond measure.

title: Schrder Loses Confidence Vote; Early Election Is Likely
description: BERLIN, July 1 - Chancellor Gerhard Schrder cleared a crucial hurdle in his quest to hold an early election in Germany this fall, deliberately losing a confidence vote in Parliament on Friday.

title: With Interest: To cut oil dependence, look to the skies
For City Children, Free Swimming Lessons
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Get Out, You Damned One'
description: President Bush has the bully pulpit, but Saddam Hussein has the hot novel. Bootleg copies of his latest work are selling briskly in the Middle East, and not just because of the free publicity he got when Jordan banned it this week. Say what you will about Saddam, he knows his audience.

title: Musicians Forced Into Fakery
description: It was supposed to be a breakout moment in the history of the New York Pops and its music director, Skitch Henderson. On Monday night, on seven barges along the East River, Macy's will present what it is calling the largest Fourth of July fireworks display in America. It will be precisely coordinated to a soundtrack performed by the New York Pops, a 30-minute medley of American music. And the whole show will be televised nationwide on NBC.

title: Sarkozy's ambitions on full-throttle
Corrections
description: A credit listing in Weekend on June 24 supplied by the distributor for the film review of "Lila Says" omitted a co-writer. The screenplay, based on a novel, is by Mark F. Lawrence as well as Ziad Doueiri.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 21 about the failure of Senate Republicans to end debate on the nomination of John R. Bolton as ambassador to the United Nations gave an incorrect number in some copies for senators who did not vote. It was eight, not six. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the initial of the Democratic senator from Delaware who refused to strike a deal on Mr. Bolton's nomination. He is Joseph R. Biden Jr., not Joseph I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KELLY, JAMES A. JR.
description: KELLY--James A. Jr. 78, of Huntington, on July 1, 2005. Partner at the law firm of O'Neill, DiManno & Kelly, NY, NY. Beloved husband of Regina M. and the late Joan Lawson. Cherished father of James A. III, John L., Robert J. Muldowney, Elizabeth K. Droney, Kevin C. Muldowney, Regina K. Bilella, Emily J., Peter J., Katherine K. Siffrin, Ruth K. Carstens, Sarah K. Masciave and the late Claire L. Devoted grandfather of 17. Loving brother of Patricia Ryan and the late Dorothea Hayes. Visiting Tuesday, 2-5 and 7-9 pm, at the M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave, Huntington Station. Mass Wednesday, 9:45 am, St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. Interment at St. Patrick's Cemetery, Huntington, NY. In lieu of flowers family would appreciate contributions to Cornelia Connelly Center for Education, 220 E. 4th St, NY, NY 10009; or Trocaire House, 630 New York Ave, Huntington, NY 11743.

title: Aide to Shiite clericgunned down in Iraq
Antidepressant Tied to Attempted Suicides
description: Federal drug regulators said yesterday that an antidepressant drug, Cymbalta, was linked to "a higher than expected rate of suicide attempts" among women taking it to treat a type of incontinence.

title: Jurors Doubted Scrushy's Colleagues
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 1 - In the end, the jury deciding the fate of HealthSouth's former chief executive, Richard M. Scrushy, focused on one issue: credibility. But it was not Mr. Scrushy's credibility they were thinking about -- he did not testify in his own defense. Instead, they wondered, could they believe the five former company executives who testified against him?

title: Women taking charge of retirement purse strings, sort of
New episode in the Palm saga
Forget Fame and Fortune, Trade Talk Is Personal
description: IN a tirade shortly after learning that his name was mentioned in trade talks with the Mets, Gary Sheffield, the Yankees' intense right fielder, vowed that he would go but would make life difficult -- make that miserable -- for any team that traded for him.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PATRYCH, RAFAEL & BOYANOV, RUSIM
description: PATRYCH--Rafael & BOYANOV--Rusim. 10 years. We remember you both with love. Your families

title: Business Briefs
description: U.S. Takes Airbus Case to W.T.O. Despite Commitment to Negotiate The United States government took its dispute over government aid for the European airplane maker Airbus SAS back to the World Trade Organization, just two weeks after officials indicated they were committed to negotiating a solution. The United States Trade Representative's Office in Washington said it made its request on Thursday to begin legal proceedings on its Oct. 6 complaint that European government loans to Airbus amount to an illegal subsidy and should be stopped. The European Union has a countersuit, claiming the Boeing Company receives unfair financial incentives. The two governments had been trying since October to avoid a W.T.O. confrontation. The most recent attempt at talks broke down May 31 because of differences over a timetable to phase out the use of financial incentives and launch aid, according to past statements from the trade ministers. (Bloomberg News)

title: O'Connor Held Balance of Power
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - The O'Connor Court.

title: Man Says Robbery Fears Preceded Attack With Bat
description: Correction Appended

title: Derrick Z. Jackson: We've heard it before...
In List of Potential Justices, Many Kinds of Conservative
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - President Bush is expected to select a nominee to the Supreme Court from a list of candidates that is, with few exceptions, a small roster of sitting federal appeals court judges, Republican and former White House officials have said. And while all of the candidates may be described as conservative, each brings a different political and philosophical profile to the table.

title: A Scotsman With the Gifts of Gab and Jab
description: LONDON - INCORRIGIBLE to the core, George Galloway is used to being threatened, ousted, libeled, filleted in the press and just plain reviled.

title: O'Connor will retire from Supreme Court
World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Indians Forced To Flee
description: The United Nations said 1,200 Indians had fled their homes in southwestern Colombia because of the escalating conflict on their land, with many fleeing to Ecuador and others trapped in the middle of the combat. The fighting between left-wing rebels and government forces in the mountainous region of Nario state and neighboring Putumayo has gone on for weeks. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Everyone was expecting a conservative replacing Rehnquist. Now you have the question of a woman or a minority for the swing vote on the Supreme Court. That's a sensitivity the White House will really have to grapple with."

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A Buried da Vinci Comes to Light

title: A Turning Point for the Court, and for the Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: Fight Grows Over a Stamp U.S. Sees as Racist and Mexico Adores
description: MEXICO CITY, July 1 - The dispute over a series of new postage stamps labeled racist by United States officials threatened to turn into a full-blown culture war on Friday, even as sheets of the stamp, featuring a comic book character, sold out quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FLECKNER, JAY K., DDS
description: FLECKNER--Jay K., DDS, June 30, 2005, age 56, after courageously battling mesothelioma. Survived by loving wife Stephanie, adored children Sari, Jaime, Allison and Ryan. Devoted son of David and Dorothy (deceased); loving brothers and sisters-in-law Richard, Rusty, Phyllis, Bonnie, Rhonda, Brian and Gail. Beloved inlaws Dolores and Marty; cherished nieces and nephews. Jay will be missed by all and he lives in our hearts forever. Donations in his memory to the Mesothelioma Foundation (www.marf.org) or to The Visiting Nurse Service and Hospice of Suffolk, Inc. Services Sunday, 10 AM at "Gutterman's", 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, L.I.

title: Roundup: Ullrich suffers fall on the eve of Tour
Dr. Johnson's Revolution
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. - AS the nation celebrates one anniversary on Monday, the English language is celebrating another. Samuel Johnson's Dictionary of the English Language was published 250 years ago. And it is fair to say that the book and the nation have grown up together, and that the one can help us understand the other even today.

title: Pentagon Is Asked to Justify Parts of Base-Closing Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - The independent commission assessing the Pentagon's proposed list of domestic base closings directed Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld on Friday to justify more than a dozen of the recommendations, the first clear signal that the panel may alter some of the military's choices.

title: Iranian Leader Denies He Took Embassy Hostages
description: TEHRAN, July 1 - A shiny black Peugeot rolled to a stop, and there he was, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, the president-elect of Iran, smiling through an open window, ready to greet a few of the people who have been coming to his street as a sort of pilgrimage since he won.

title: Obie Benson, 69, the Original Bass Voice of the Four Tops, Dies
description: Correction Appended

title: Justice O'Connor
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's retirement is going to trigger an enormous political collision. This is one time when it's not an overstatement to say that the choice of her successor could have an effect on the nation for generations to come. But as critical as the coming fight is, it would be a shame for the combatants to come out swinging before Americans had a chance to reflect on the career and contribution of the woman who is leaving the bench. In fact, the more time we spend thinking about this sensible, pragmatic jurist, the better. Perhaps it will convince President Bush that he can best serve the country, and his own party, by nominating a new justice with the same values.

title: Business Briefs; Telecom Italia May Give Up Pursuit of Brasil Telecom
description: Telecom Italia confirmed yesterday that it was willing to sell its stake in Brasil Telecom Participaes, Brazil's third largest fixed-line phone operator. Eager to gain a footing in the fixed-line business in Brazil, Telecom Italia has been battling for years to gain majority ownership of Brasil Telecom, which is controlled by Citigroup and a group of Brazilian state-run pension funds. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Call to cut aid echoes far beyond France
For Former Tehran Hostages, a Tangle of Anger at Both Captors and the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - For Thomas Schaefer, being held hostage in Iran for 444 days was a transformative experience but largely a solitary one. It was rare for him, a former Air Force attach, to see any of his fellow hostages during captivity, and he saw few afterward.

title: Confidentiality and News Gathering
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 7 P.M. (BBC America) NORTH AND SOUTH -- To American viewers, this title may evoke Civil War images, but it really refers to 19thcentury England's great social and geographical divide. Daniella Denby-Ashe stars as Margaret Hale, a minister's privileged daughter whose family abruptly moves from the idyllic rural south to Milton, an industrial northern town. Margaret is perfectly horrified by the dirt, noise and nouveau riche mill owners, especially John Thornton (Richard Armitage, above, with Ms. Denby-Ashe). Adapted from Elizabeth Gaskell's novel. Part 2 is tomorrow night.

title: Making It Harder to Swap a Great Song (or Even a Mediocre One)
description: UPSETS and underdogs topped the news this week, with the Supreme Court upsetting the Internet ethos that everything is (or should be) free, a chief executive avoiding conviction for a multibillion-dollar fraud at the company he founded, and a small microprocessor maker suing the industry's dominant leader for using what it calls unfair business practices to smother competitors.

title: U.S. Troops Still Missing After Crash in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 1 - Still searching for a small reconnaissance team, hundreds of United States troops swarmed the mountainous terrain of eastern Afghanistan on Friday, near where a helicopter was shot down on Tuesday, killing all 16 aboard, military officials said.

title: The End User: U.S. weaves tangled Web
World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Bombing Suspect Is Killed
description: The police in Ankara shot and killed a man they say was trying to blow himself up inside the Justice Ministry. The man, identified as a member of a militant left-wing group called the Revolutionary People's Liberation Party-Front and sought by the authorities for two years, was stopped at the ministry entrance when his bomb set off metal detectors. As policemen overpowered him, he tried to detonate the bomb, but it failed to go off. The police then shot and killed him as he ran off, the official news agency reported. The bomb was later defused. Sebnem Arsu (NYT)

title: Senate Leader Calls for Limits on Drug Ads
description: The Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, called yesterday on the pharmaceutical industry to limit drug advertising directed at consumers, increasing the pressure on companies to curb such marketing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROTHSCHILD, FRED D.
description: ROTHSCHILD -- Fred D. peacefully on June 30 surrounded by his loving wife of 59 years, Helen, and his adoring children Evelyn Wolovnick, Maureen DiTata, Ron and Ted. He will be missed by his dear sister Aleece of Johannesburg, S.A. and numerous daughters- and sons-inlaw, grandchildren, nephews and nieces who are all blessed to have him in their lives. Services will be at "Gutterman's" 175 N. Long Beach Rd, RVC, Sunday 10:30am.

title: Federer Dominates Hewitt Again to Reach Final
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 - As if Roger Federer did not have enough in his favor on the grass of Wimbledon, he will now have the luxury of being more rested than his still-to-be-determined opponent in Sunday's final. Federer, the men's champion here the last two years, was in full flow once again on Center Court on Friday, showing the depth of his talent and self-belief against his now-favorite foil, Lleyton Hewitt.

title: New Mayor's Request to Los Angeles: 'Dream With Me'
description: Correction Appended

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Turning Point for the Court, and for the Nation (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Thursday, about the accounting for General Motors' pension fund, misstated the business of Ryan ALM Inc., a company founded by Ronald J. Ryan. It is a money management firm specializing in matching assets and liabilities, not a consulting firm.

title: Heating Demand Pushes Oil Up $2.25
description: Crude oil rose more than $2 a barrel in New York yesterday, pulled higher by record heating-oil prices created by concern that refiners will not be able to meet peak demand during the winter.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Bush administration's order for a freeze on assets controlled by two senior Syrian intelligence officials in American financial institutions misidentified the operator of the flight that was the target of an attempted bombing in which Syria was implicated in 1986. It was El Al, not British Airways.

title: Bush's Reaction on O'Connor
description: Following are President Bush's remarks yesterday about the retirement of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Don't Let Data Theft Happen to You
description: ABOUT two weeks ago, I was alarmed by a phone message from my bank alerting me to some "unusual activity" on my debit card. Unusual wasn't the word. Someone had gone on a shopping spree -- $556.46 and $650.81 at one store, $264.99 and $300 in charges that were pending at another -- and none of it was mine.

title: That Drunken Red Squirrel Whomps Again
description: It was in 2001 that I learned the full extent of my deficiencies as a gamer. The game was Conker's Bad Fur Day, a comically obscene action adventure game developed by Rare for Nintendo's N64 system. At one point in the game, you must drive a speedboat along a river of lava, dodging the legs of lumbering dinosaurs while hitting cavemen with a frying pan. It took me 40 minutes and many, many deaths to knock out just one caveman, and it took me more than two hours to successfully complete the entire sequence.

title: 2 Democrats Seek Early Start to Raising Money for Runoff
description: Two Democratic candidates for mayor have asked the city's Campaign Finance Board to rule that a runoff in September's Democratic primary is "reasonably anticipated," a move that would allow all the candidates to immediately begin raising money for their possible participation in such a contest.

title: U.S. drug makers win little-seen victory in trade pact
Paid Notice: Deaths   COBLE, DAVID LELAND
description: COBLE--David Leland, 6, on June 29, 2005. Artist, paleontologist. He loved Spider-man and Venom. Superheroes, reptiles, dinosaurs, cats big and little, and all things fierce. David inspired us to be our best. We love him. He loved flowers, but donations may also be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, the Valerie Fund; New York Restoration Project or The Metropolitan YMCA of the Oranges Scholarship Fund. Survived by his loving mother Alana, father Rick, sister Julia, aunt Julie, uncles, aunts, cousins and grandparents. A funeral service will be held on Wednesday July 6, 2005 at 11:00AM at St. John's Lutheran Church, 587 Springfield Ave, Summit, NJ. The family will be receiving relatives and friends on Tuesday July 5 from 4-7PM at the The William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit, New Jersey. Interment at Fair Mount Cemetery, Chatham, NJ. The Coble, Erickson, and Parks Families

title: Plasma screens on a cathode-ray-tube budget
Sheffield Is Facing Tough Pair of Battles
description: DETROIT, July 1 - Unless Gary Sheffield can convince the commissioner's office that he did not bump the umpire C.B. Bucknor last Sunday, Sheffield's two-game suspension and $2,000 fine will probably stand.

title: Return of the Space Shuttle
description: The space agency made a reasonable call this week when it elected to launch the space shuttle Discovery in mid-July despite three safety issues that have not been fully resolved. The truth is that the revamped shuttle is probably safer than ever in its history. It is our national confidence in the shuttle that is shaky. After two catastrophic accidents in 113 flights, we now recognize that there is significant risk every time we try to launch one of these aging, finicky space vehicles into a low Earth orbit and bring it back down again.

title: New Book on Watergate Fleshes Out Deep Throat
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - From start to finish, W. Mark Felt was a bureau guy, a true believer, an officer sworn to uphold the security of the country against all manner of enemies, whether they were bank robbers, domestic terrorists, foreign spies -- or, as Bob Woodward writes in his latest book, the highest official in the land.

title: In the Dark of Night, Strange Spirits Fill the Air
description: The full-time musicians of the New York Philharmonic have 52-week-a-year contracts. Wanting to get its money's worth, the orchestra's management tries to find things for the players to do in the weeks between the end of the subscription season in June and the beginning of the popular concerts in the parks in mid-July. Sometimes the orchestra goes on tour.

Bomb kills 10 Russian soldiers in Dagestan
VW hiring auditor to examine Skoda unit
Confidentiality and News Gathering

title: Currencies: Strong U.S. data give dollar a big lift
How to Undermine Opponents, Even With Good Intentions
description: Thursday's column described how on Sunday Andrea Buratti took advantage of an illegal finger signal from his partner, Massimo Lanzarotti, both of Italy, at the European Championships. (They left the tournament and further action may be taken.) In the early 1970's Jaime Ortiz-Patio, who was about to become president of the World Bridge Federation, introduced screens to fight cheating in top-level bridge.

title: Corrections

He is Kevin Klose, not Kline.

title: Louis Friedland, 92, Television Executive, Dies
description: Louis N. Friedland, a retired broadcast executive who played a prominent role in the development of syndicated television programming, died on Wednesday in Great Neck, N.Y. He was 92 and lived in Kings Point, N. Y.

title: Veto of M.T.A. Capital Plan Stalls Repairs and Construction
description: Leaders of the State Legislature rejected the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's proposed five-year capital plan yesterday. Their decision blocks the authority from moving forward with billions of dollars worth of construction and repair projects.

title: 'Welcome': Whatever Was ABC Thinking?
description: "Welcome to the Neighborhood," the reality show that ABC dropped under pressure from civil rights groups, is fascinatingly wrongheaded: a ghastly social experiment tricked up as a fluffy summer reality show.

description: WILLIAM H. GROSS, the chief investment officer at the Pacific Investment Management Company, known as Pimco, is probably the biggest single influence on the direction of bond prices after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.

description: William J. Brink, a former managing editor of The Daily News of New York who was responsible for one of the most memorable headlines in American journalism, FORD TO CITY: DROP DEAD, died yesterday morning in Norwalk, Conn. He was 89 and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: City Drinking Water Safe, Officials Say After Tests
description: A day after warning that people with weak immune systems should not drink New York City tap water unless it is boiled, city officials said yesterday that the levels of microbes in the water were normal and that it was safe for everyone to drink.

title: Howard Beach, Then and Now: Conditions and Voices Grow Calmer
description: They came to the Rev. Al Sharpton by telephone and in person -- New York politicians looking for advice and reassurance about the latest racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called the night the news broke, and the men talked about the city's response. Others, like the Democratic candidates angling to replace Mr. Bloomberg, were looking for more direct cues. Fernando Ferrer, for instance, read Mr. Sharpton his prepared statement and welcomed advice.

title: Rallies mark Hong Kong anniversary

description: The Senate voted early yesterday morning to stop construction of the nation's costliest science project, a laser roughly the size of a football stadium that is meant to harness fusion, the process that powers the Sun.

description: Pastor Crespo, 78, a retired union carpenter from the Mott Haven section of the Bronx, could barely contain his excitement this week.

Microsoft to Pay I.B.M. $775 Million in Settlement
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 - Microsoft agreed on Friday to pay I.B.M. $775 million to settle claims growing out of the antitrust lawsuit brought by the Justice Department against Microsoft in 1995. I.B.M. will also receive a $75 million credit toward the use of Microsoft software.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAFF, GERTRUDE TOUB
description: ZAFF--Gertrude Toub. An attorney and NYC resident, passed away June 23, 2005. Born July 27, 1916, in Bayonne NJ, and graduated from NYU law school in 1939, Gertrude sang briefly at NYC's Metropolitan Opera with her twin sister Kasena Karmel. She practiced law at several organizations, including the United Nations, NYC Family Court and NYC Housing Authority. Widow of the late Dr. Fred Zaff of New Haven, CT, Gertrude was a devoted and loving mother and grandmother who will be greatly missed by her three children, John M. Zaff of Scarsdale, NY, David B. Zaff, of Maple Shade, NJ, and Elizabeth A. Wilbanks of Old Greenwich, CT, and six grandchildren, Rebecca, Sarah, Ben, Daniel, Ori, and Netali.

title: Big Media's Power Plays
description: THE legal battles over the future of copyright in the digital age are often cast as innovation versus the status quo, and in many ways, that's true. MGM v. Grokster is a case in point. MGM's lawsuit lives on, thanks to the Supreme Court, which decided this week to toss out summary judgments in favor of the file-sharing companies Grokster and StreamCast Networks, allowing the lawsuit to proceed.

description: WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 1 - A state rescue package for the financially beleaguered Westchester Medical Center fell apart as the legislative session in Albany ended last week, with the Senate, Assembly and governor's office unable to agree on its details.

title: A Turning Point for the Court, and for the Nation

title: With His Glove, Then His Bat, Floyd States His All-Star Case
description: Because Tony La Russa was stuck on a bench in St. Louis last night, managing the Cardinals against the Colorado Rockies, he might have missed the closing argument in Cliff Floyd's ongoing case to make the National League All-Star team.

title: A Theater's Tiffany Past Uncovered Tile by Tile
description: It didn't sound right, and that turned out to be good.

title: Armstrong Victory Formula: Ride Fast but Dodge Disaster
description: Having survived cancer, Lance Armstrong is not the type of person to come undone because of a bee sting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESENT, IGNATZ
description: PRESENT--Ignatz, July 30, 2005, age 93. Beloved husband for 60 years to Rose; devoted father to David (Karen) and Larry (Suzy); cherished grandfather of Alex, Emily, Michael, Adie and Elie. We will always remember his strength of character, love for his family, devotion to Jewish life and learning, and the integrity and sincerity with which he led his life. He will be deeply missed by all of us who admired & loved him.

title: Robed in Mystery
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA. - IN the fall of 1992, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor spoke to my first-year law school class at Stanford University, her alma mater. My class, which was almost 50 percent women -- black, Hispanic, gay and disabled women among them -- received her warmly. She is, after all, a feminist pioneer. The first woman on the United States Supreme Court, Justice O'Connor broke through glass ceilings the way women of my generation broke nails. She, more than any other woman in the legal profession, proved that we could be whatever we wanted.

title: Personal and Political Concerns in a Closely Held Decision
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - When his mother was nominated for the Supreme Court in July 1981, it came as a surprise to Brian O'Connor. He had been off skydiving, and only learned the historic news along with the rest of the nation when he got home.

title: Philip Hobsbaum, 72, British Poet and Critic, Dies
description: Philip Hobsbaum, a British poet and literary critic whose workshops and criticism helped inspire a new generation of writers, including Seamus Heaney, died on Tuesday in Glasgow. He was 72.

title: They Want the Sharks to Bite
description: POINT PLEASANT, N.J. - Fishing for sharks can be a little like being in a war. It's all about waiting, waiting, waiting. And then all hell breaks loose.

description: The sidewalk between the drug industry's headquarters in Washington and the United States trade representative's office has been taking a pounding from the wingtips of industry lobbyists.

description: To the Editor:

title: Taking the Prostitution Pledge
description: Since 2003, the Bush administration has required foreign groups fighting AIDS overseas to pledge their opposition to prostitution and sex trafficking before they get money from Washington. Last month, the administration expanded the requirement to American groups. On its face, this law seems innocuous. Who supports prostitution?

title: Rain and Familiar Names Give Wimbledon a Retro Look
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 - After all the chatter about change in tennis, about terrible teens and powerful Russians with strong lungs and stronger portfolios, it has turned out to be a throwback Wimbledon, and not just because of the rain that regularly interrupted play this week.

title: Kurds, Emboldened by Lebanon, Rise Up in Tense Syria
description: QAMISHLI, Syria - Here on the fringes of Syria's agricultural heartland, the veneer of normalcy is all around.

title: F.D.A. Says Flaws in Heart Devices Pose High Risks
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that potential electrical flaws in some heart devices made by the Guidant Corporation, including one flaw that the company did not tell doctors about for years, posed a risk of serious injury or death to patients.

title: Business Briefs; Brazil Posts a Record Trade Surplus for June
description: Brazil posted a record monthly trade surplus of $4.03 billion in June, challenging forecasts that a stronger currency would make the country's exports less competitive on world markets. The figure was up from a surplus of $3.45 billion in May and $3.8 billion in the year-earlier period. The trade surplus this year totals $19.67 billion, a 31 percent increase over the first half of 2004. Most economists now expect Brazil, South America's largest economy, to post a $35 billion trade surplus this year, its biggest ever, on booming sales of raw materials like soybeans and iron ore and a push by Brazilian companies to enter new export markets. Last year, the trade surplus was a record $33.7 billion. Todd Benson (NYT)

description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Five Injured as Transformer Blast Creates a Terror Scene
description: A fruit and vegetable market near a busy Brooklyn intersection became a scene of terror and pandemonium yesterday when a transformer exploded outside the store, sending flames and hot gases roaring up from the sidewalk.

description: Luther Vandross Is Dead The silky-voiced crooner, known for romantic hits like "Here and Now" and "Any Love," had never recovered from the effects of a debilitating stroke two years ago. The winner of eight Grammy Awards, including four last year, Mr. Vandross was 54. PAGE C16

description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - Around 9:30 Friday morning, C. Boyden Gray, founder of the Committee for Justice, a conservative group that is a leading ally of President Bush, was sipping coffee at his Georgetown residence and confessing mild frustration to a reporter for The New York Times about the waiting game for a Supreme Court retirement. Suddenly he got a text message and expressed that emotion rare for stage-managed Washington: surprise.

title: Rancher's Burden of Dreams: Staging Opera About Blackfeet
description: GREAT FALLS, Mont., July 1 - In all his years running cattle on the high plains of northern Montana and Alberta, Sherm Ewing didn't give much thought to opera. He never saw one performed, and he certainly never thought he would have any hand in bringing one to the stage.

description: TOKYO, July 1 - Japanese corporate leaders were more optimistic about their prospects in June than they were three months earlier despite signs of a slowdown in exports, according to a quarterly business survey by the Bank of Japan.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Fewer March For Democracy
description: The annual pro-democracy march on the anniversary of Britain's transfer of Hong Kong to China in 1997 drew 21,000 people according to organizers and 17,000 according to the police. It drew close to half a million people in both 2003 and 2004, when the economy was stagnant and many were demanding the resignation of Tung Chee-hwa, the chief executive. A more buoyant economy and Beijing's replacement of Mr. Tung in March with his more popular deputy, Donald Tsang, above at the march, have weakened demands for universal suffrage. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: Chinese Company Asks U.S. to Review Its Bid for Unocal
description: The Chinese oil company fighting for control of Unocal said yesterday that it had asked a top government panel in the United States to formally review its $18.5 billion takeover offer, even as political opposition to the bid was growing in Washington.

Bertelsmann unit to buy stake in Russian TV firm

In Summer, Modern Dance Rises to All Occasions (Watch Out, Ballet)
description: DURHAM, N.C., July 1 - In recent decades, ballet has come to dominate the American public's perception of dance. It has the big companies, it plays in the big theaters, it attracts the big audiences.

title: Johnson Fades Fast; Yankees Quickly Follow
description: DETROIT, July 1 - In less than two weeks, this city will play host to the All-Star Game, an exhibition that usually glorifies the Yankees. When the Yankees began the season, they had 18 former All-Stars on their roster. The emphasis, it seems clearer every day, is on former.

title: G.M. Sales Surge on Offer to Sell at Employee Price
description: DETROIT, July 1 - General Motors sold more vehicles in June than it had in any month since September 1986, propelled by its promotional campaign offering the public the same discounts as G.M. employees for all 2005 models.

title: Top Shiite Cleric's Aide Killed, and Shiite Office Attacked
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 1 - A senior aide to Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, Iraq's most influential Shiite cleric, was gunned down on his way to Friday Prayer in Baghdad, and a suicide car bomb exploded near the office of a major Shiite political party, an Interior Ministry official said Friday.

(The error also appeared in an article on June 26 about the director of the movie, Apichatpong Weerasethakul, and in a review last Oct. 2, when it was shown at the New York Film Festival.) The actor is Banlop Lomnoi, not Lamnoi.

description: Charlie Ebersol's need to tell the story of the Ithuteng Trust school in Soweto -- where traumatized and violent teenagers learn to overcome their young lives' horrors -- began with a visit to the South African township two years ago and has produced a new documentary, "Ithuteng (Never Stop Learning)."

title: Overdoing the Good News
description: The power of really, really positive election-year thinking has gripped New York, as evidenced by the $50 billion city budget announced this week. When Mayor Michael Bloomberg and the City Council speaker, Gifford Miller -- two rival mayoral candidates -- shook hands on the deal, they each had something to crow about on the campaign trail. Mr. Bloomberg spent $250 million to give homeowners property tax rebates. Mr. Miller claimed credit for restoring $230 million to the budget for things like libraries and services for the elderly.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, ELIAS A.
description: COHEN--Elias A. Although 53 years have passed since our beloved founder, Elias A. Cohen, passed away on July 2, 1952, he is still remembered with love and reverence by the thousands of deserving boys and girls who were privileged to come to his Tranquillity Farm and Camp for a few fun-filled weeks each summer since July 1, 1919. In the spirit of Noblesse Oblige, his devoted family, his many loyal friends and a grateful Alumni are all helping to perpetuate his Tranquillity Camp as a living monument to this great American humanitarian. We are proud to announce that Tranquillity is now celebrating its 87th year. Tranquillity Camp, Inc., Earlton, N.Y. Richard Lawrence, President

title: World Briefing | Asia: India: Monsoon Floods Kill 94
description: Floods in western Gujarat have killed at least 94 people and caused the evacuation of 200,000 people, state officials said. Passengers stood atop a train stuck in the swelling water, and officials pressed the Indian Army to help with evacuations. The monsoon rains are expected to continue for several days. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Randolph Is Molding Ring Into Setup Man
description: On a handful of occasions this season, when the left-handed relief pitcher Royce Ring has seen a right-handed hitter walking to home plate, he has reflexively looked into the Mets' dugout, expecting to find Manager Willie Randolph starting to stir.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COHEN, ELIAS A.

title: Italian Leader Chastises U.S. in Kidnapping Case in Milan
description: ROME, July 1 - Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi demanded Friday that the United States show "full respect" for Italian sovereignty, after summoning the American ambassador and asking him to explain the reported abduction of a Muslim cleric by people associated with the C.I.A.

title: Senator Clinton to Deliver Pitch for Olympics
description: Britain is sending Prime Minister Tony Blair. France is sending President Jacques Chirac. Now, New York, trying to go head to head, has gone to the bullpen: It will send Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton to Singapore next week to urge international Olympic officials to bring the 2012 Summer Games to the city.

title: Corrections
description: A cabaret entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about performances by Barbara Carroll tomorrow at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel was published in error. Her engagement ended last Sunday; she will not perform there this summer.

title: Make Way for Angels
description: BOULDER, Colo. - Concluding his First Inaugural Address, President Abraham Lincoln expressed his hope for a resurgence of "the better angels of our nature."

title: Agents Said to Dismantle a Korean Sex Ring
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 - Federal agents raided scores of brothels and businesses and arrested more than two dozen people here in the dismantling of an international sex trafficking and human smuggling ring that lured Korean women to the United States and forced them to work as captive prostitutes, the authorities said on Friday.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Court Urged To Bar Re-Election
description: Inspector General Edgardo Maya said in a statement that the Constitutional Court, the country's highest, should reject a law that would permit President lvaro Uribe to run for a second consecutive four-year term next year because of procedural irregularities in its passage through Congress. His recommendation is influential but not binding. The court is expected to rule on the matter this year. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Kissinger regrets 1971 remarks on India
O'Connor will retire from Supreme Court
Barrett Keeps It Close, but Sorenstam Moves On
description: GLADSTONE, N.J., July 1 - During the first two rounds of the United States Women's Open last week, Tina Barrett played in the group directly behind, Annika Sorenstam, the top-ranked player in the world. So many fans were following Sorenstam's every shot that Barrett often had to wait for them to clear out before she could hit. Barrett may not have realized it at the time, but she was gaining valuable experience in handling large crowds.

description: Bono, Paul McCartney, Green Day and Bjork were some of the headliners at the Live 8 concerts held in cities around the world.

title: Confirmation Battle in Senate Could Define Specter's Career
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - In nearly 25 years on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, has sat through nine Supreme Court confirmation hearings, some short and polite, some ugly and drawn out. Now that he is the chairman, he is prepared for the next one to go either way.

title: On the Old 'Polish Broadway,' Boutiques and Spas Arrive
description: Correction Appended

title: An Unspoiled Japan Survives on Noto
description: THE SEA OF JAPAN, an angry body year round, achieves full power in winter, when it drives the inhabitants along its coast indoors, makes them fortify bamboo sea walls around their villages, and blankets the area in gray desolation. But in summer, the sea tempers its anger, even allowing bathers a dip in the few sandy stretches along the coastline.

title: Hotel Urban in Madrid
description: THE BASICS So large is the eclectic art collection of Catalan businessman Jordi Clos, who opened the Hotel Claris in Barcelona in 1992, that he has built a second hotel to house part of it, this one in Madrid. The Hotel Urban, which opened in November, is a sleek, minimalist space saved from coldness by eclectic antique artwork, much of it from the 19th century, dotting public and private spaces. The Urban's lobby resembles an office-building atrium; it features a circle of stiff chairs and does not invite loitering. But the towering sculptures from Papua New Guinea, tucked along one wall, at least make the place interesting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAFF, GERTRUDE TOUB
description: ZAFF--Gertrude Toub. An attorney and NYC resident, passed away June 23, 2005. Born July 27, 1916, in Bayonne NJ, and graduated from NYU law school in 1939, Gertrude sang briefly at NYC's Metropolitan Opera with her twin sister Kasena Karmel. She practiced law at several organizations, including the United Nations, NYC Family Court and NYC Housing Authority. Widow of the late Dr. Fred Zaff of New Haven, CT, Gertrude was a devoted and loving mother and grandmother who will be greatly missed by her three children, John M. Zaff of Scarsdale, NY, David B. Zaff, of Maple Shade, NJ, and Elizabeth A. Wilbanks of Old Greenwich, CT, and six grandchildren, Rebecca, Sarah, Ben, Daniel, Ori, and Netali.

description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 2 - In the middle of a season of dominance for the megateams at Roush Racing and Hendrick Motorsports, outsider Tony Stewart is proving he cannot be discounted in Nascar's Nextel Cup title hunt.

title: Allison Jacoby and Aaron Abrahms
description: Allison Cara Jacoby, a daughter of Deborah J. and Mark A. Jacoby of Larchmont, N.Y., is to be married today to Aaron Abrahms, a son of Janis Abrahms Spring of Westport, Conn., and Marc C. Abrahms of West Hartford, Conn. Rabbi Jeffrey T. Segelman will officiate at Hildene, a historic home in Manchester, Vt.

title: All-American for the Fourth
description: Although Finger Lakes vintners emphasize European grapes, they still make bright white wines from American grapes like the Delaware. This hybrid was propagated in Delaware, Ohio, in 1849, and its wine became popular overnight. Swedish Hill's aromatic, semisweet 2003 Delaware, made from old vines farmed near Canandaigua Lake, is an ideal Fourth of July dessert wine. Vintage New York, 2492 Broadway (93rd Street) and 482 Broome Street (Wooster Street), SoHo, asks $10. It's open today and tomorrow. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: 'A Day, a Night, Another Day, Summer': Lives of Quiet Desperation
description: A DAY, A NIGHT, ANOTHER DAY, SUMMER By Christine Schutt. 155 pp. TriQuarterly Books/ Northwestern University Press. $22.95.

title: My Dog. Our Wardrobe.
description: PET owners spend about $36 billion a year on their animals, so it makes sense that designers of more than cat beds and parakeet cages would want to tap into this gold mine. Barry Kieselstein-Cord, based in New York and known for his diamond-studded jewelry and leather handbags with sterling silver clasps, is a new entrant in the field: he will now design matching clothes and accessories for dogs and their owners.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an automobile review of the Infiniti M35 and M45 last Sunday misidentified the competitor that Car and Driver magazine ranked sixth in a comparison test. It was the six-cylinder BMW 530i, not the eight-cylinder 545i.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "I'm not going to anticipate a bruising battle, but I'm not going to run from one either."

title: Laura Satterfield and Kavin Buck
description: Laura Christina Satterfield and Kavin DeWayne Buck, the owners of an art gallery in Inglewood, Calif., were married yesterday. Mark E. Albarian, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated at a house rented for the occasion in Palm Springs, Calif.

title: Farmingville's Rock and Hard Place
description: IF there were a public-policy superhero on the landscape -- one who could stem illegal immigration, create affordable housing in the suburbs, raise the minimum wage, end global economic displacements, guarantee liberty and justice for all and assure that lawns were mowed and beans were picked at reasonable rates -- there would be no trouble in Farmingville today.

title: What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)
description: Your article suggests that the passage of anti-gay-marriage amendments indicates that most people are not comfortable with the idea of extending the marriage franchise to same-sex partners. It was not so long ago that our nation recognized that we might have to discomfort ourselves in order to afford all our citizens equality under the law. This has been an ongoing process, and fighting for equal protection and justice for all regardless of sexual orientation and gender identity is today's battle. Perhaps we were not all comfortable with the changes that were legally mandated in the middle of the last century, but with time we did get used to them. Mixed-race couples are no longer an oddity any more than are women a rarity in the boardroom.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEPHENS, WILLIAM J.
description: STEPHENS--William J. 76, of New York City; died on June 23, 2005. For more than 25 years he ran the well respected business, Wallpapers East. He is survived by his brother Lawrence, his partner Tony Sacco and many wonderful friends.

title: Who Supplies 'the Freshest Fish In New York City'?
description: EVERY Saturday morning, a line forms at the small Greenmarket in TriBeCa across the street from Public School 234.

title: In 2002, More Wealthy People Paid No Tax
description: The number of affluent individuals and married couples who paid no federal income taxes jumped more than 15 percent in 2002, to 5,650, government data released last week showed.

title: The Costume, the Thing and the Therapist
description: Actors are no strangers to therapy. But when Michael Chiklis found himself on the phone with a psychologist during the filming of "Fantastic Four," it wasn't to talk about a creative block or the effect of location shooting on his marriage. He needed to vent about his costume.

title: 'Radical Evolution'
description: This book can't begin with the tale of the telekinetic monkey.

title: When Your Neighbor Is Monet
description: MY guess is that most people have never heard of Theodore Robinson (1852-96), which is probably why the Baltimore Museum of Art organizers of a national touring exhibition focusing on his work, now at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art in Hartford, called it "In Monet's Light: Theodore Robinson at Giverny." Everyone has heard of Monet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, MEL
description: MILLER--Mel. 73, of Boca Raton, FL, on Sunday, June 26, 2005. Born December 21, 1931 in New York. Beloved husband of Marilyn Miller for 47 years. Beloved father of Steven and Eric Miller. Beloved grandfather of Ashley and Corey Miller.

title: Birthday Boss Celebrates 75th as the Yankees Show Their Age
description: TO know George Steinbrenner is to keep a calendar flexible to the birthday boy's capricious moods.

title: Thanks, Reggie
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Nobody Here but Us Liberals
description: CONSERVATIVES dominate American politics because there is no conservative tradition in American political thought. Liberals are powerless because all Americans are liberals. Americans argue with each other so virulently because there is so little about which they disagree. They elect presidents from distinguished families because they detest aristocracies. Their society is so secure that they feel constantly under attack. The more isolationist their instincts, the more likely they are to view themselves as saviors of the world.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 19 about Wadi Rum, Jordan, where Lawrence of Arabia sought to unite Bedouin tribes into a guerrilla force against Turks, misstated the year in which the film "Lawrence of Arabia" was released. It was 1962, not 1982.

title: East End Observatory Faces Earthly Concerns
description: NO place on Long Island is farther from the bright lights of the big city than Montauk. Its night skies, in fact, are regarded as among the darkest on the East Coast. And the Suffolk County Legislature wants to capitalize on it by building an astronomical observatory.

title: Gabriela Quirs and Andrew Gilbert
description: Gabriela Victoria Quirs, a documentary filmmaker, and Andrew Brian Gilbert, a music journalist, are to be married today at the Brazilian Room in Tilden Regional Park in Berkeley, Calif. The ceremony is to be led by Alexander T. Grishaver, a friend of the couple, who was appointed by Alameda County as a deputy marriage commissioner for the event.

title: Increase in the Number of Documents Classified by the Government
description: Correction Appended

title: A Beach Community in an Awkward Transition
description: THE transformation of Fairfield's central beach neighborhood is understandably disconcerting to residents who find themselves craning their necks to glimpse the tops of the three-story turreted houses rising around them. Yet at the same time, they can't help but marvel at their good fortune. Encroaching wealth has driven up land values such that the aging six-room Capes that once made the beach one of Fairfield's more affordable areas now get $700,000 or more as teardowns.

title: Support the Troops, With Safer Armor
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: This is music's time of the year to peek out from its many roofs and step into the out of doors. Summer opera in particular will bloom next week.

title: A Small Enclave Survives in the Big City
description: THE tiny Queen Anne-style red-brick enclave of Henderson Place, at the eastern end of 86th Street, has long seemed out of place in a high-rise city -- its dollhouse architecture is dwarfed by its surroundings. But now a new sense of light floods the little 19th-century buildings, which were designed as low-cost housing -- the entire blockfront to the north is being cleared in preparation for a new ultraluxury apartment tower.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 19 about Chiang Mai, Thailand, misspelled the name of the Mandarin Oriental hotel in which the author stayed. It is the Dhara Dhevi, not Dhara Devi.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul misstated the distance from Bangkok, where he was born, to Khon Kaen, where he was reared. It is a five-hour drive, not five miles.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: ROLLER COASTER AND A ROOM The Atlanta Six Flags Over Georgia Package for Two is a one-stop offering that bundles an overnight stay at one of six Marriott hotels in the Atlanta area (rates start at $119 plus taxes of 10 to 15 percent), a booklet of park discounts and two adult Six Flags tickets (regular adult tickets cost $43.99). Two-night packages start from $222 plus tax, and include Six Flags White Water. For information call (800) 922-7849 and use promotion code THM, or go to the Web at www.marriottse.com/sixflags.

title: Happy Fifth of July, New York!
description: STANDING before a gathering of the Ladies' Antislavery Society in Rochester, Frederick Douglass, newspaper editor and internationally known voice of abolition, moved his audience with the force of his argument. It was July 5, 1852, the day after the national celebration of American independence. This former slave confronted a hushed crowd and a nation with the stunning question: "What, to the American slave, is your Fourth of July?"

title: Mr. Anka, Meet Eminem
description: ATLANTIC CITY - JOE RUSSO, lurking behind thick, dark, 90's-hip glasses, jerked and shook as he pummeled his huge drum set. A bit across the massive stage, Mark Benevento tortured his keyboard just enough to coax out a wail that could loosely be called creative feedback; but don't worry, Jimi Hendrix, you can rest easy.

title: For the Poor in Iran, Voting Was About Making Ends Meet
description: TEHRAN, July 2 - They had come from very different neighborhoods and backgrounds, but they were all there for the same reason: to buy government-subsidized food.

title: Where Dead Mice Can Dip Their Little Feet in Ink
description: FOR J.C. Casey, the owner of Casey's Rubber Stamps, a Lilliputian workshop and store on 11th Street near First Avenue, life would be much easier if he didn't have a telephone. Every time he puts down a block of wood or a piece of rubber to pick up the receiver, the object in his hands vanishes.

title: Conservative Groups Rally Against Gonzales as Justice
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - Within hours after Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's announced retirement from the Supreme Court, members of conservative groups around the country convened in five national conference calls in which, participants said, they shared one big concern: heading off any effort by President Bush to nominate his attorney general, Alberto R. Gonzales, to replace her.

title: Elizabeth Sheinkman and James Byng
description: Elizabeth Sheinkman, the daughter of Katherine and Shepard Sheinkman of Bethesda, Md., was married on Thursday to James Edmund Byng, a son of Thomas Edmund Byng, the Earl of Strafford, who lives in Winchester, England, and Lady Bland of Andover, England. Kathy Paton, the registrar for the Kensington and Chelsea town hall in London, officiated. Yesterday, the Rev. Richard Holloway, the former Bishop of Edinburgh, performed a religious ceremony at Blissamore Hall, the home of the bridegroom's mother and stepfather, Sir Christopher Bland, in Andover.

title: In an Epic Wimbledon Final, Williams Prevails
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 - Two fine comeback tales converged on the most celebrated court in tennis Saturday, but only one could end happily.

title: Man Attacks Girlfriend, Then Kills Self
description: A Brooklyn woman who said she was attacked yesterday by her jealous boyfriend who then shot himself said that he began his assault by reminding her he had vowed to kill her if he caught her with another man.

title: Movies
description: THE STEPFORD WIVES (2004) Saturday at 8 p.m. on Showtime. In Frank Oz's reinterpretation of the 1975 "Stepford Wives" (based on Ira Levin's novel), the houses are bigger, the sex is louder, and the men's association is run by Christopher Walken. Nicole Kidman (above) plays a television network president who is fired, has a nervous breakdown, undergoes electroshock therapy and agrees to move with her husband (Matthew Broderick) to a manicured Connecticut town that time and feminism forgot. The uniformly subservient wives, who exercise in dresses and high heels, aren't just turned into basic robots in this likeably camp version; they also have ATM's built into their heads. Don't even ask what the town does to gay men.

title: Burglar-Proof
description: MY car has never been one that would impress a woman.

title: In Battle to Confirm a New Justice, Both Sides Get Troops Ready Again
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - The last time Ralph G. Neas and C. Boyden Gray went head to head as commanding generals in a war over a Supreme Court confirmation was in 1991, when Clarence Thomas was the nominee. Now, with the resignation of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, they are adversaries again.

title: Lola Fayanju and Ian MacMullen
description: Oluwadamilola Motunrayo Fayanju, the daughter of Yinka and Funmi Fayanju of Basking Ridge, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Ian Robert MacMullen, a son of Linda and Andrew MacMullen of Durham, England. The Rev. Dr. Dorothy Austin performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Morristown, N.J.

title: Correction
description: A table accompanying an article June 19 about school districts seeking new external auditors misidentified the firm that the Bethpage School District hired recently. It is Coughlin, Foundotos, Cullen & Danowski, not R.S. Abrams & Company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RASKIN, WILLIAM
description: RASKIN--William on June 30, 2005. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving father of Gabriel, Joshua and Jonah and father-in-law of Melissa. Dear brother of Roslyn. His leadership of industry, community, religion and family will be missed. He was loved by all. Service Sunday, 11:45 AM at "The Riverside" 76 St & Amsterdam Ave.

title: War and Weakness
description: Richard A. Clarke mentions the possible need for reinstating the draft (The Security Adviser, June 19). Since the Pentagon insists that a volunteer force is superior to a conscripted one, why not fold the draft into a larger program of compulsory service? Serving in the military could be one of several choices for 18- to 24-year-olds. The age range would allow those who wished to attend college to do so; others could enter the program after high school. This way, supporters and opponents of the draft could have their cake and eat it too.

title: For One Blogger, Fun and Profit
description: Who said you can't make money giving away news and opinions on the Internet? Apparently not Jim Romenesko, who runs a popular site (poynter.org/column.asp?id=45) devoted to comings and goings in the news media. According to tax records filed by his employer, the Poynter Institute, Mr. Romenesko received $169,187 in salary and other compensation in 2003, making him Poynter's highest-paid nonexecutive.

title: I Am a Wristcam
description: NOT to be cynical, but how is it that when industrial designers and marketers develop clever gadgets to entice a jaded public, the process is known as innovation? In fashion, at least, people don't pretend that what they do is noble. They just call it what it is: next season.

title: Correction
description: A caption on the "Pulse" page last Sunday with three photographs of beach cover-ups misstated the order. These are the correct listings, clockwise from top left:

description: To the Editor:

title: Were the Good Old Days That Good?
description: Correction Appended

title: Humbled Williams Still Capable of Highlight
description: DETROIT, July 2 - After stumbling around center field last Saturday, Bernie Williams stood in the Yankees' clubhouse and calmly but firmly disagreed with Manager Joe Torre. No, Williams said, he did not think he needed rest. He was just finding his groove at the plate.

title: Could a Few Hedge Funds Spoil the Party?
description: WHEN the Long Term Capital Management hedge fund was sinking in 1998, leaders of the Federal Reserve were worried. They feared that if the fund failed, a major disruption could be set off in financial markets, with dire consequences for the global economy. Indeed, that worry was the impetus for the hastily arranged bailout of the fund. Since then, the financial system hasn't faced a similar test. At least not so far.

title: Kaliningrad's 750th anniversary
Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: The Car Is for Kids, but Gramps Is Driving
description: THE next time traffic snaps to a halt in a spectacle of brake lights, glance around. There's a good chance you'll see one of those cool hipster-mobiles -- the coupes with erector-set spoilers, the hatchbacks in emphatic colors, the boxy wagons that seem more square than a 1950's sitcom.

title: Marlins Take Advantage of Mets Errors in Sixth
description: The Mets have several people who can play first base, but none stick out the way, say, Lou Gehrig did. Into the breach yesterday stepped Jose Offerman, the 36-year-old utility man playing for his seventh big-league team. He was booed off the field at Shea Stadium in the sixth inning.

title: Brooklyn Group Swears, It Really Is a Social Club
description: "Come on in, we got nothing to hide," said one of the men sitting in the sun in front of a Brooklyn storefront.

title: Anita Karne and Mehul Dalal
description: Dr. Anita Karne and Dr. Mehul A. Dalal are to be married today in Knoxville, Tenn. Pandit Ronur Murali Bhattar, a Hindu priest, is to perform the ceremony at the Knoxville Convention Center.

title: After Centuries of Enmity, Relations Between Poland and Russia Are as Bad as Ever
description: WARSAW - The Poles say, not without a certain pride, that they are the only ones ever to occupy the Kremlin. That was in the early 17th century, almost 200 years before Napoleon and 300 before Hitler failed in their attempts to do so.

title: In Old Mills, an Artists' Colony
description: BEHIND the gates of the Chongming Industrial Art Park in Shanghai, the buzzing of drills and saws could be heard in various buildings. Located northwest of the city, along Suzhou Creek, this former textile factory complex is finding new life as a cutting-edge art center.

title: O.K., Japan Isn't Taking Over the World. But China...
description: NOT even 20 years have passed since the apparently unstoppable Japanese economic juggernaut struck fear in the hearts of Americans, and now China has emerged to be seen as the new economic menace threatening the nation's vital strategic interests.

title: The Artists in the Hazmat Suits
description: IN a certain part of the art world, the story is recounted like a slowly unfolding nightmare: On the afternoon of May 11 last year, Steven Kurtz, a respected artist and professor at the State University of New York at Buffalo, called 911 to report that his wife, Hope, 45, was not breathing.

title: An Afternoon Like America, Cognitive Dissonance and All
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 2 - Just after noon on Saturday, the actor and rapper Will Smith took the stage in front of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, flanked by a copy of the Declaration of Independence and ready to make his own "declaration of interdependence."

title: An Unspoiled Japan Survives on Noto
description: THE SEA OF JAPAN, an angry body year round, achieves full power in winter, when it drives the inhabitants along its coast indoors, makes them fortify bamboo sea walls around their villages, and blankets the area in gray desolation. But in summer, the sea tempers its anger, even allowing bathers a dip in the few sandy stretches along the coastline.

title: Did You Hear the One About Handel and the Cuban?
description: Manuel Barrueco: 'Concierto Barroco' Manuel Barrueco, guitarist; Orquesta Sinfnica de Galicia, conducted by Vctor Pablo Prez. Koch International Classics KIC-7597; CD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KLEIN, ABRAHAM J.
description: KLEIN--Abraham J. 94, died June 19, in Miami. Teacher of Hebrew and French at Thomas Jefferson High School; scholar, sailor, lover of the arts, ardent Jew and Zionist. Beloved father of Tammy Mitchell and Naomi Grob, grandfather of Jonathan, Jeremy and Rachel, greatgrandfather of four.

title: The Battle for Eardrums Begins With Podcasts
description: IN pre-Web times, marketers counted noses. With the advent of the Web, eyeballs. Mark my words: eardrums are next.

title: Paris Sends Out for a Festival
description: SAN FRANCISCO - AMERICAN dancers -- an entire company of them -- are descending on Paris this week, and while they will perform to Gershwin, it is not for a remake of "An American in Paris."

title: Pan-Asian Dreams
description: LAWRENCEVILLE - AT Elements Asia, everything is new, from the rich black of the asphalt on the parking lot to the glossy white plates in geometric shapes.

title: Egyptian Envoy to Iraq Is Kidnapped in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 3 - The top Egyptian diplomat to Iraq was kidnapped late Saturday by gunmen in western Baghdad, Iraqi officials said today. It was the first abduction of the head of a diplomatic mission here, just as the American and Iraqi governments are vigorously pressing Arab countries to send ambassadors to Iraq.

title: DataBank; A Little Spark for Stocks Ahead of the Holiday
description: The stock market eked out small gains last week, despite a decline on Thursday after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the ninth consecutive time.
