description: RADICAL EVOLUTION The Promise and Peril of Enhancing Our Minds, Our Bodies -- and What It Means to Be Human. By Joel Garreau. 384 pp. Doubleday. $26.

title: Emerald Lawns vs. Green People
description: WEST HARRISON - ALL five of her children chew organic bubble gum, drink distilled water and use DEET-free bug repellent, so when a neighbor's lawn service started spraying sheets of pesticide that she said billowed across her property line, it's no wonder that Lauren Nannariello was incensed.

title: A Livable Shade of Green
description: PORTLAND, Ore.

title: 21 School Districts Adopt Austerity Budgets
description: AT the end of the school year, administrators and school boards typically wind down and welcome the relief of summer vacation. But this year, there was neither a wind-down nor relief for many Long Island school districts.

title: Leah Fleischner and Matthew Reimer
description: Leah Rachel Fleischner, the daughter of Deborah and Arthur Fleischner of Troy, N.Y., is to be married today to Matthew Aaron Reimer, a son of Jane and Michael Reimer of West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Jonathan A. Stein is to officiate at the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N.Y.

title: SuperSonics May Endure Another Makeover
description: A man in pigtails quietly became the Seattle SuperSonics' key free-agent acquisition last summer. Except for signing that man, Danny Fortson, the team changed little and, surprisingly, won big.

title: How Much Is That Teacher Worth? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: PRETTY BIRDS. By Scott Simon. (Random House, $24.95.) Simon, the host of "Weekend Edition" on National Public Radio, draws on his background as a war correspondent in this searing first novel, which traces the experiences of a young sniper during the siege of Sarajevo. Before the war, Irena Zaric is a typical cosmopolitan teenager: a star basketball player, obsessed with Sting, Lady Di and Johnny Depp, she sneaks an occasional joint and carries on a furtive, casual affair with her coach. Then the Serbs advance, intent on purging Bosnia of its Muslim population, and Irena flees across the river with her family. Simon is unsparing in his catalog of war's cruelties -- as the siege drags on, the Bosnians are reduced to burning furniture for fuel and eating the worms in their macaroni -- but his real achievement is in realizing that even as she trades a basketball for a rifle, Irena remains 17 years old, the kind of girl who packs purple nail polish and a teddy bear for her descent into hell. The result is a portrait of resilience, punctuated by mortar blasts and Clash songs, and a tragicomic study of the moral ambivalence war forces on its victims. "I'm kind of a pacifist," Irena tells the man who recruits her as a sniper. His reply: "So am I. When the world permits."

title: Duke's Songs of Opulence
description: For years people driving by Doris Duke's Hillsborough estate wondered what was behind the miles of stone walls that surrounded its 2,700 acres. The walls seemed to enclose some sort of mystery, much as the billionaire tobacco heiress was considered an enigma in her lifetime. It was Ms. Duke's wish that her estate eventually be shared with the public. And since her death in 1993, the beauty and bounty of Duke Farms has slowly but certainly been revealed.

title: The Subway New Yorkers Proudly Call Home
description: WHAT is it about New Yorkers and their subway? Last week, officials moved to adopt new rules that would prohibit passengers from drinking from open containers, moving between subway cars or straddling a bicycle on a moving train.

title: Laissez-Faire Results Of a First-Time Coach
description: HAVING observed youth sports too often for comfort over the years, I went into my first coaching experience -- my daughter's first- and second-grade softball team -- determined to hang loose.

title: Shoulder Soreness Will Force Pavano to Miss a Start
description: DETROIT, July 2 - The Yankees' beleaguered pitching staff took another hit Saturday. Carl Pavano, the starter who signed for $39.95 million last winter, will miss his scheduled start Sunday because of shoulder soreness.

title: A Dance Diaspora
description: When Mehdi Bahiri learned that Dance Theater of Harlem was laying off its dancers last year, he said, "I jumped." He snapped up a group of them for the 14-member Fugate/Bahiri Ballet NY, which opens a week's run at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday. It's not just his high regard for their skills as dancers, he said, "It's practical. They're in New York." Other companies have not been quite as expansively welcoming, but most, if not all, of the Harlem troupe's 44 members have landed on their feet (so to speak):

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OGILVY, STEPHEN HUNTER
description: OGILVY -- Stephen Hunter, age 88, of Westport, CT, passed away on June 16, 2005. Mr. Ogilvy was born on November 9, 1916 in New Rochelle, NY. Mr. Ogilvy graduated from Princeton University in 1939. He founded the AA Hearing Aid Center in 1946. An avid tennis player, he was inducted in the New England Tennis Hall of Fame in 1997. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Alicia, nine children, 30 grandchildren and 14 great grandchildren. A memorial service will be he held at the Saugatuck Congregational Church in Westport, CT at 10:30 AM on July 9, 2005.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: I. THE EXPERIMENT For roughly 1,400 years, from the time the Roman Empire became Christian to the American Revolution, the question of church and state in the West always began with a simple assumption: the official religion of the state was the religion of its ruler. Sometimes the king fought the church for control of religious institutions; other times, the church claimed power over the state by asserting religious authority over the sovereign himself. But the central idea, formally enshrined at Westphalia in 1648 by the treaty that ended the wars of religion in Europe, was that each region would have its own religion, namely that of the sovereign. The rulers, meanwhile, manipulated religion to serve their own ends. Writing just before the American Revolution, the British historian Edward Gibbon opined that the people believed, the philosophers doubted and the magistrates exploited. Gibbon's nominal subject was ancient Rome, but his readers understood that he was talking about their world too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THIESENHUSEN, WILLIAM C.
description: THIESENHUSEN--William C., born February 12, 1936, died June 25, 2005. Professor and long-time director of the Land Tenure Center at the University of Wisconsin at Madison. Foremost authority on land reform as a means for improving the lives of rural people in the Third World. Highly sought-after as advisor to World Bank, USAID, and United Nations agencies.

title: Melissa Boardman and Vincent Henderson III
description: Melissa J. Boardman, a daughter of Debra H. Lewis of Albany and the late Robert F. Boardman, was married yesterday to Vincent C. Henderson III, a son of Sherry Henderson and Vincent C. Henderson II of Little Rock, Ark. The Rev. Bernard Lawrence Keitz, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Inside the List
description: AS SEEN ON TV: In the 1990's, Kevin Trudeau went to prison for credit card fraud. Last year, he was fined $2 million and banned from infomercial advertising -- he's appeared in or produced hundreds of these late-night spots -- in a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission. (Among the dubious products he hawked: Coral Calcium Supreme tablets, which he said could cure cancer.) But Trudeau, a man one F.T.C. attorney called "a habitual fraud artist," is back on television, exploiting a loophole in his ban that lets him peddle books in infomercials. The book he's selling is his own -- it's called "Natural Cures 'They' Don't Want You to Know About," and, groan, it's selling pretty well. The book is No. 6 on this week's extended hardcover advice list. (The extended lists are available on the Web.) Trudeau, who has no medical training, has filled his book with grammatically tortured and possibly dangerous inanities like this one: "Did you know that virtually every disease has been reported to be cured by doing simply energetic rebalancing?" Give Trudeau points for cheek, however. On the cover of the latest edition of his book, he tweaks the F.T.C. by tossing off this line: "As Seen on TV: Over 1.5 Million Copies Sold!"

title: Going Green in the Caribbean
description: The Caribbean is home to powdery-white beaches, rum punch and increasingly, environmentally friendly hotels. One recent example is Young Island, a 35-acre island resort just off St. Vincent. In August 2003, the hotel established policies to conserve energy, reduce waste and raise awareness of the environment. Now, it is aiming for certification by the international Green Globe 21 program, which was established in 1999. The program evaluates resorts on nine environmental criteria, including ecosystem conservation and wastewater management.

title: Impartial Broadcasts?
description: To the Editor: "The Armstrong Williams NewsHour," by Frank Rich (column, June 26), by deploying the word "propaganda," does a great disservice to the more than 140 million people worldwide who look to entities operated by the bipartisan Broadcasting Board of Governors -- the federal body that supervises all nonmilitary international United States media outlets, Voice of America included -- for their reliable news and information. It also diminishes the work of our professional journalists.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; THEATER
description: Besides Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, the unlikeliest coupling of the summer may find the Italian chemist and author PRIMO LEVI painting the town with the eerily well-preserved Hollywood babe and ThighMaster goddess SUZANNE SOMERS: both are arriving on Broadway in one-person, limited-engagement shows that begin preview performances on Friday.

title: What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)
description: Whatever their personal beliefs, anti-gay-marriage activists share the theory that gay marriage is bad because it will produce certain undesired effects in society (Russell Shorto, June 19). If they truly believe this, then they should support it with data. Conveniently, we in Massachusetts have supplied a testing ground. Although it's still early, I'd like to reassure them that it doesn't appear that legalizing gay marriage has had any appreciable effect at all on the lives and marriages of straight people and their children. The divorce rate doesn't seem to have risen, straight couples continue to get married and raise families and not one lawsuit has been filed on behalf of a man wishing to marry a 9-year-old boy or a family pet. Of course, time will tell, but so far, I can assure those with apocalyptic visions that I and everyone I know are just fine. In fact, the only bad thing that has happened to this straight woman as a result of legalized gay marriage is the cost of buying a few more wedding gifts.

title: Skating A Finer Line
description: Skateboarding is taking that inevitable leap toward the high-end market with a new line of boys' clothing called O.D.C.Y. The label (tweenage boarder shorthand for Odyssey) gives parents a fancy alternative to mass-market brands like Quiksilver and Abercrombie. Unlike its all-American counterparts, O.D.C.Y. has a cool European feel, with super-spun cotton T-shirts, shorts and board pants with details like striped canvas collar tabs, silk-screened medieval lions, contrast topstitching and raw-edged overlays. The prices reflect the quality: T-shirts are $28 to $48; shorts and pants $45 to $80; and sweatshirts $50 to $70 (in boys' sizes 4 to 20 at Space Kiddets and Lester's in New York).

title: Eileen Marron and Joseph Keating Jr.
description: Eileen Dollard Marron, a college administrator, and Dr. Joseph Francis Keating Jr., a professor, were married yesterday. The Rev. James A. Schwartz performed the ceremony at St. Louis Roman Catholic Church in Pittsford, N.Y., with the Rev. Eric Menees, an Episcopal priest, taking part.

title: Paperback Row
description: SOUL MADE FLESH: The Discovery of the Brain -- and How It Changed the World, by Carl Zimmer. (Free Press, $15.) Zimmer charts a fascinating chapter in our modern understanding of the human mind and body: the discovery that the brain -- previously dismissed as "a bowl of curds" -- is the seat of consciousness. His principal characters, an elite group of Oxford scholars, include Robert Hooke, Christopher Wren and Thomas Willis, whose studies formed the foundation of contemporary neuroscience. The 17th-century story unfolds against the turbulent backdrop of the English Civil War, the plague and the Great Fire of London.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOLAN, REV. CHARLES F.X., S.J.
description: DOLAN--Rev. Charles F.X., S.J. of St. Peters Preparatory School, Jersey City, NJ on Thursday, June 30. Loving son of the late Mary (nee Egan) and Charles Dolan, dear brother of Dr. Jerome A. Dolan of Jersey City, NJ, Sr. Eileen Dolan, S.C. of Convent Station, NJ and Francis X. Dolan of Toms River, NJ, and the late Rev. James F. Dolan S.J., William S.C. Dolan, Alice Rohan, Mary Mullowney, John F. and Joseph Dolan. Also survived by 24 nieces and nephews and many grand and great grand nieces and nephews. Funeral Mass at St. Peter's Church, Grand and Van Vorst Streets, Jersey City, NJ on Tuesday, July 5, at 7:30pm. Interment Our Lady of Martyrs Shrine, Auriesville, NY. Visitation at St. Peter's Community Chapel, 144 Grand St., Jersey City, NJ on Sunday & Monday, 3-5 & 79pm. Also Tuesday 3-5pm. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Dolan Family Scholarship Fund at St. Peter's Prep, would be deeply appreciated.

title: Dudes
description: The straw cowboy hat crowned both spectators and marchers at last Sunday's gay pride parade along Fifth Avenue. Many wearers give the brim a rakish curl. Several of the floats, above and left, resembled a dude ranch for buff men. Jack Frost, far right, the Percheron pride of the Police Department, was the star of the West Village after-parade.

description: HE introduces himself as the Flag Man, and for him the two weeks leading up to the Fourth of July are always the busiest.

Perhaps if Evalena Gray could meet Lisa Polyak under different circumstances -- say, in each other's homes -- they would stand a better chance of learning about possibilities for shifts in perspectives.

description: It will be nearly three weeks before the Knicks can sign a free-agent big man, and it appears they intend to exhaust the supply of days and names by then.

title: Bulletin! Tree-Hugger Embraces Republican.
description: Well, last week it was the Democrats' turn to worry about whether their house was in order.

title: Stacy at the Bat: Ratcheting Up Women's Sports
description: DRESSED like a Yankee in a navy-pinstriped white uniform, Jaclyn Pasquerella, a third baseman for the New York Juggernaut, hit the ball and took off to first base at the softball stadium at Hofstra University. The Juggernaut, the Island's first women's professional softball team, was beating the Stratford Brakettes, a team from Connecticut.

title: The Two Wars of the Worlds
description: ON the morning after George W. Bush spoke to the nation from Fort Bragg, Americans started marching off to Steven Spielberg's "War of the Worlds." Both halves of this double feature invoked 9/11, perfectly timed for this particular holiday. Ever since "Jaws," a movie set on the July Fourth weekend, broke box office records 30 summers ago, Independence Day has come to stand for terror as much as for freedom.

title: Albania Prepares to Vote Amid Accusations of Fraud and Intimidation
description: TIRANA, Albania, June 30 - Albanians are to vote in parliamentary elections on Sunday in a closely fought race that has been marred by accusations of fraud and voter intimidation.

title: After All These Years, A Red-Headed Stranger
description: LITTLE FALLS - SOMETIMES, the show within the show is just as seductive as the show itself.

title: 'Leaves of Grass' at 150: As Exuberant and Encompassing as Ever
description: Imagine Walt Whitman as he imagines himself, stretched atop a load of hay, one leg reclined on the other, seizing the clover and timothy, rolling head over heels, tangling his hair full of wisps. And then imagine the farmers -- puzzled Long Islanders perhaps -- and the oxen at the wagons watching that ecstatic performance. "What is that you express in your eyes?" Whitman asks the oxen, which might ask the same of him. "More than all the print I have read in my life" is his answer.

title: Disorder in the Court
description: NEW HAVEN - I KEENLY remember the excitement at the Supreme Court when President Ronald Reagan announced the nomination of the little-known Sandra Day O'Connor to replace the retiring justice, Potter Stewart, in 1981. At the time I was a law clerk for Justice Thurgood Marshall, and, although none of us knew who she was, all of us sensed that a new epoch had begun. We were right.

title: Playing Lord of the Manor in Surrey
description: IT had been a long day. My 71-year-old mother had flown overnight from the United States to visit her expatriate daughter and her three grandchildren, arriving as the sun was beginning to come up in London. But instead of letting her take a nap, or even grab a cup of coffee, we had stuffed her into the back of a minivan for a 40-minute journey to the cottage I had rented for a week in the English countryside.

title: Samantha Boardman and Aby Rosen
description: Dr. Samantha Vivian Munn Boardman, a daughter of D. Dixon Boardman of New York and Pauline Pitt of Palm Beach, Fla., was married on Tuesday to Aby Jacob Rosen, the son of Anni and Isak Rosen of Tel Aviv. Dr. David M. Posner, the senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El in New York, officiated at the couple's town house in New York.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; DANCE
description: What's the world's most famous ballet? Some might say "The Nutcracker." Others might vote for "SWAN LAKE." In any case, they both have music by Tchaikovsky. "Nutcracker" probably won't be around until winter. But the METROPOLITAN OPERA HOUSE is aflutter with swan wings, for AMERICAN BALLET THEATER's production of this story about love, deception and redemption is roosting there this week.

title: As the City Shrugs, It's Burgers, Steaks and Ribs

title: You Are What Your Record Is (Except When You're Not)
description: Brian Cashman, the Yankees' general manager, has maintained repeatedly this season that he will recommend no blockbuster trades and make no drastic moves to shake his sedentary club like a snow globe. First, there's his belief that the $200 million payroll should be adequate. And second, even if this aging club wanted more veterans, the Yankees have few marquee minor leaguers to trade.

title: MORE ON THE COURT
description: THOMAS REDUX -- Some of the same faces from the battle over Clarence Thomas in 1991 are gearing up for a new fight. PAGE 19

title: Tone Deaf on Africa
description: BONO, Jeffrey Sachs, Tony Blair, rock bands, finance ministers and aid agencies have been vowing to "make poverty history" in Africa as the Group of 8 summit meeting in Scotland begins this week. The proponents of a comprehensive plan to end Africa's poverty say the solutions are easy. For example, Gordon Brown, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, says preventing the deaths of five million children over the next 10 years would cost just $3 more for each new mother in the world's poorest countries. All told, Tony Blair's Commission for Africa calls for $25 billion more in aid to Africa per year.

title: A Stock Market Riddle May Have an Easy Answer
description: IT is hard to argue with the notion that investors often price some stocks too high and others too low. But if new research is correct, this seemingly banal truth may also explain a long-running mystery: why small-capitalization value stocks tend to beat large-cap growth stocks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOLDSWORTH, FREDERICK JR.
description: HOLDSWORTH -- Frederick Jr. of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY and Gloucester, MA, died on June 25, 2005 of Parkinson's-related pneumonia. He was born October 23, 1917 in Arlington, MA, the son of Frederick Holdsworth and Jessie McCreary Holdsworth (Hilton), and spent his boyhood in Brookline, MA. He attended The Rivers School and graduated from Milton Academy in 1936 and from Harvard University in the class of 1940. After college, he worked for JP Morgan & Co until being commissioned Ensign in the US Naval Reserve where he was assigned to the Navy Department in Washington, DC. His military service included: liaison between the Office of Naval Intelligence and the War Department G2; assignment to the State Department for the Dumbarton Oaks Conference; Aide to Vice Admiral Russell Wilson, USN (Ret.) of the Joint Strategic Survey Committee of the Joint Chiefs of Staff; and attendance at the San Francisco Conference which gave rise to the United Nations. His civilian career was spent primarily in banking and investments at Chase National Bank and then at Scudder, Stevens & Clark as investment counsel. He served for 35 years on the Board of Directors of The Children's Village, a residential treatment center in Dobbs Ferry, NY. He was a member of the Delphic Club of Harvard and the Harvard Club of NYC where he was Secretary for many years. Surviving are his wife of 57 years, Harriet Swift Holdsworth and three children; Ariel Holdsworth and her husband, Thomas F. Berner of Yonkers, NY; Samual Swift Holdsworth, his wife, Betsy Malm Holdsworth and their children Tedric, Lydia and Henry of Santa Fe, NM and Gloucester, MA; and Eric Ashley Holdsworth and his wife, Hilarie Crosman Holdsworth, of Gloucester, MA. Music remained a lifelong interest. He studied jazz piano well into his 80s and played for many benefit events. His focus was the music of the 1920s, 1930s, and 1940s. He was also a proud member of the Gloucester-based jazz ensemble Teddy and the Juniors. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Children's Village, Echo Hills, Dobbs Ferry, New York 10522 or The Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research, Grand Central Station, PO Box 4777, N.Y., N.Y. 10163. Memorial services will be announced at a later date.

Joe took both of her hands in his hands and said, 'The truth is often painful."'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESSMAN, ALINA K., M.D.
description: PRESSMAN--Alina K., M.D. Of Bayside, NY died on June 19, 2005 at the age of 84. Alina was an extraordinary mother and a devoted friend to many. Born in Warsaw, Poland, she lost most of her family in the Holocaust. Despite this, she retained a positive outlook on life. She spent some of her best years after the war studying at the Casa dello Studente in Torino, Italy. Arriving in New York in 1951, Alina began the medical career she cherished and only stopped practicing at the age of 75 due to illness. She will be truly missed by her daughters, grandchildren, sister, brother-in-law and numerous friends. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, New York 11225.

title: What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)
description: The laws of the United States and all the states grant certain rights and obligations to married people. I have gay friends who recently celebrated their 50th anniversary together. I find it appalling that they cannot file a joint tax return, automatically be eligible for health coverage as a couple or be legally considered the next of kin for medical purposes. And I cannot think of any reason that a heterosexual couple married for six months and with any possible number of divorces between them should have these benefits that are denied to other stable and committed couples.

title: Fusion Power, Elusive and Alluring
description: A standing joke among scientists is that fusion power -- the holy grail of those seeking a boundless supply of energy to supplant fossil fuels -- is always decades away. That has been the guesstimate for half a century, and it remained the guesstimate last week when an international consortium announced that it had finally resolved an internal struggle over where to site an experimental nuclear fusion reactor. It will be in southern France, with Japan receiving some consolation-prize benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AMES, HAROLD S.
description: AMES--Harold S. Of Kings Point and Westhampton Beach, NY, passed away Friday evening, July 1, 2005 in North Shore University Hospital after a long illness. Dearly beloved husband and life partner of Dorothy; adoring father of Elizabeth and Allison; father-in-law of Charles Opolinsky; devoted grandfather of Harley Ames Opolinsky; brother of Bernard Roy and the late Renee, Arnold and Milton. Mr. Ames was a leader in the market for non-ferrous speciality metals. In 1958, he founded NonFerrous International Corp., a key supplier of prefabricated aluminum, brass and copper tubing to equipment manufacturers in a variety of industries. A metals industry pioneer in a new era of world trade, Non - Ferrous was among the first to bring European and Japanese metal into the US market. Mr. Ames guided Non-Ferrous as its President and CEO through its 1973 acquisition by the metals division of Mitsubishi North America. He continued as President of Non-Ferrous for nearly a decade after the acquisition. For 26 years, Mr. Ames was the owner of CrossTown Tennis at Fifth Avenue. He was a Founding Director of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center. A passionate supporter of Israel with a lifelong interest in world affairs, Mr. Ames was an officer and founding member of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy. He was a long time active member in the Anti-Defamation League, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, and a contributor to the United Jewish Appeal. For 20 years, he was President of the Board of the Gallery Apartment Condominiums at 32 East 76th Street in NYC. Mr. Ames received his bachelors degree in Economics from NYU. He completed a master degree and doctoral studies in Economics at the New School for Social Research. An avid tennis player and voracious reader, surrounded by music, books and an adoring family, Dad succeeded in business and in life. His strength and courage inspired his children and all who knew him. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, July 6, 2005 at 11 AM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, 516487-9600. The family will receive condolence calls that afternoon 4-8:30 PM at the home of Harold Ames. Friends of Allison Ames can pay their respects the following day, Thursday, July 7 between 12-4 PM or 6-9 PM at the Ames Opolinsky residence. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

title: Albany Report Card
description: Last year, if you had asked us to assess New York State's legislative year, we would have found it hard to get beyond a sigh of disappointment. This year, mostly, we applaud. An impressive number of the 700 or so bills approved by the Legislature reflect a conscientious effort to reform the way Albany does business. Here is a closer look at what the legislators did and did not do.

Robert leaves behind his beloved wife Rita (nee Reiss) Gorman of 53 years. title: Sailing Into History
description: EVEN though it is big enough to contain a battleship, Graving Dock No. 1 has long been one of Brooklyn's best-kept secrets. If you drive down Beard Street in Red Hook, all you see is a line of old brick warehouses. But on the other side, hidden away on the waterfront, lies a 710-foot-long concrete and steel basin originally dug out at the end of the Civil War.

title: 'More Than Human'

title: Changing A Flip Tax
description: Q. For many years, our co-op board has collected a flip tax -- a fee on the sale of an apartment -- of $25 per share. At the last meeting, it voted to change the flip tax to 3 percent of the sale price. Since the change affects all shareholders significantly in the amount they will have to pay when they sell, shouldn't the board bring this to a full discussion at a meeting of all shareholders? Was the decision to change the tax on its own legal, or would such a change require a vote of the shareholders? ... Suzanne O'Keefe, Brooklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CABRAL, RAYMOND
description: CABRAL -- Raymond. The president of Syn-Cronamics Inc., an international management consultant company founded by him in 1963 who also had considerable business interests in Stowe, Vermont, Provincetown, Massachusetts, and Tranquility, New Jersey, died on June 22 in Burlington, Vermont. The cause of death was due to cancer. He was 76. His death was announced by his wife Kim (Marie) Cabral. He had many accomplishments--and talents. He was a well-known business executive and entrepreneur, raced his sailboat, the Fandango, in the Caribbean, and was an artist and art patron. He also mentored many people. He was a self-educated man, an avid reader, and a natural leader of a practical and creative intelligence. A dynamic man who had an adventurous life, he was known for his generosity, sense of fairness, gamesmanship, visionary thinking, and stability. He provided leadership with his personal courage and strength of character. He had a wonderful sense of humor and intense enjoyment of all that life offered. His sensibility was an example to many. He was a true one of a kind. He will be greatly missed by his family and many friends. Born in Fall River, Massachusetts in 1928, Mr. Cabral was the son of the late Anthony F. Cabral and the late Diamantina Medeiros. He graduated from Durfee High School. He was the husband of Kim Marie S. Cabral, nee Plesniak, of Canada. Mr. and Mrs. Cabral lived in Stowe, Vermont and Truro, Massachusetts. They were together 26 years. He leaves a brother, William Cabral of Provincetown, Massachusetts, and a sister, Eileen Darby of New York City. His first marriage was to Miriam Jacques of Massachusetts. He is survived by his four children, Steven Cabral of the Philippines, Susan Megargle of Biloxi, Mississippi, Caroline Dezen of Sudbury, Massachusetts, and Laura Diamond of Harleysville, Pennsylvania and seven grandchildren. Funeral services were held on Monday, June 27 at 1 PM. at the Stowe Community Church in Stowe, Vermont. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The American Cancer Society. For information, contact the Stafford Funeral Home in Stowe.

title: LAND TRUST ACQUIRES FOREST
description: The Natural Lands Trust has bought 1,550 acres of primeval forest in Cumberland County for $1.2 million, the group has announced. Part of the acquisition includes the 800-acre Bear Swamp West, where scientists have found trees more than 400 years old, according to the Trust, a Pennsylvania-based nonprofit group. There are other trees in the swamp, including black gum, sweet gum and red maple trees, that could be more than 700 years old. The swamp was bought from U.S. Silica, a West Virginia mining company. Nearby Bear Swamp East is controlled by the state and the newly preserved area is next to the Glades Wildlife Refuge and Porch Preserve, also run by the Natural Lands Trust, making the total preserve area nearly 7,000 acres. John Holl

title: P.C. Tea
description: Honest Tea The obvious question raised by a product called Honest Tea is: What, exactly, is dishonest tea? This sounds smart-alecky, but the name of the bottled tea does imply something more serious than mere thirst-quenching, so it's legitimate to wonder what it is trying to communicate. Is it healthfulness, or a tie-in to a cause, or a solution to an ethical quandary (in the way that Fair-Trade-certified coffee lets you wake up without feeling as if you're exploiting third-world farmers)?

title: Modernist Masterpiece, and Soon a Prime Building Site
description: The Travertine House has passed through some well-known hands, as befits both its 2.4-acre site overlooking Georgica Pond in East Hampton and its status as an important example of midcentury modern architecture. Gordon Bunshaft, the Pritzker Prize-winning architect best known for Lever House on Park Avenue, designed it to be his own home in 1962. The Museum of Modern Art was willed the house in 1994 and sold it a year later to Martha Stewart. But the one-story glass-and-marble building may have met its final owner. Donald Maharam, who recently bought the house from Ms. Stewart's daughter, Alexis, said that he had "all sorts of ugly" on his hands, and he planned to tear the house down.

title: Television That Leaps Off the Screen
description: IN a nondescript optics lab in tucked into an anonymous office park in the San Fernando Valley, the photon hackers of Deep Light are showing me the future of media. The object of their affection is a small screen on which an animated gladiator is clashing scimitars with a horned monster in a Coliseum-like setting. But this isn't a flat cartoon image: it's full 3-D space, the combatants circling each other inches from my eyes so convincingly that my hand twinges to grab them -- and I'm not wearing those clunky red-and-blue cardboard glasses, either. I'm seeing a 3-D image with the naked eye. My host, Deep Light's co-founder Dan Mapes, bounces on his heels, giggling with delight. "It's cool, isn't it?"

Although he just completed his Master of Fine Arts at the University of California, Los Angeles, in June, he is already something of an art-market sensation. The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles has bought one of his large collages, a profusion of cut-up photos, plastic petals and other found objects pinned to corkboard. The Greek tycoon Dakis Joannou has bought another. Dean Valentine, a Los Angeles collector known for supporting artists like John Currin before they hit it big, has bought three.

title: With Specialties and Mergers, Travel Agencies Carve a Niche

The Alliance of Westchester Travel Agencies has about 50 member agencies in Westchester County and the Bronx -- about half as many as 15 years ago. Aside from the huge decline in business caused by Sept. 11, 2001, two major factors have hurt county travel agencies, according to Corrine Mutarelli, the alliance president: More people are using the Web to make their own travel bookings, and many airlines aren't paying as much in commissions.

title: Independence Day Closings
description: NEW YORK GOVERNMENT OFFICES -- Closed. POST OFFICES -- Express Mail only; main post office on Eighth Avenue at 33rd Street is open. BANKS -- Option to close. PARKING -- Alternate-side regulations will be suspended. Stopping, standing and parking are permitted except in the areas where rules are in effect seven days a week, as indicated by signs. SANITATION -- No pickups, street cleaning or recycling. SCHOOLS -- Closed. FINANCIAL MARKETS -- Stock and bond markets closed. TRANSPORTATION -- New York City subways and buses will operate on a Saturday schedule, some bus lines will be rerouted and some subway lines will provide extra service. For details, check online at mta.info. Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North trains will operate on holiday schedules. The Staten Island ferry will not operate from 8 to 10:30 p.m. FIREWORKS -- The F.D.R. title: 'The Worst Ballpark in the World'
description: I FIRST saw Shea Stadium the summer it opened, 1964, when the world was still young. My parents were taking me to the World's Fair, which was just across the elevated line in Flushing Meadows, Queens. This was appropriate because Shea, like the fair, was supposed to be a showcase for the world of tomorrow. You could tell this because it looked breezy, and fun, and half-finished -- all bright, garish colors, flimsy new materials and unadorned concrete and pipes and steel cables laid out in that functional, neglected-housing-development style that modern architects used to assure us was the best future we could hope for.

title: The Mystery of the Tunnels

At the time, he said, its existence was treated as common knowledge -- old people told stories about being scolded as children for playing in hidden tunnels in front of their houses.

title: A Founder's Advice
description: Never suffer a thought to be harbored in your mind which you would not avow openly. When tempted to do anything in secret, ask yourself if you would do it in public. If you would not, be sure it is wrong. Letter from Thomas Jefferson to his grandson Francis Eppes, age 14, Monticello, May 21, 1816 Jefferson's 19th-century advice would undoubtedly forestall much contemporary misconduct. It would also eliminate most showers -- that's one limitation of an ethics of transparency: the desire for privacy need not be an acknowledgment of wrongdoing. Many benign activities are quite sensibly conducted out of public view -- for example, bathing, the pursuit of sexual happiness or the design of the next iMac -- and our language reflects this. To act in secret (Jefferson's word) can connote the illicit, suggesting shame, furtiveness and criminality (although not for the iMac designer); to act in private implies modesty, dignity and self-reliance. Unfortunately, Jefferson didn't give young Francis a way to distinguish between the two.

title: Michael Winterbottom Gets Naked
description: On a bleak British afternoon last fall, Michael Winterbottom and his small crew were preparing for filming on the top floor of Felbrigg Hall, a possibly haunted 17th-century manor in eastern England. Winterbottom, one of England's most prominent independent filmmakers, was directing an adaptation of Laurence Sterne's often cited, rarely read novel "The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman," aptly described by the comedian Steve Coogan, who plays Shandy in Winterbottom's film, as "a postmodern novel written before there was a modern." (The cast includes the critically acclaimed British actors Jeremy Northam, Shirley Henderson and Stephen Fry, all working at scale just so they can be in a Winterbottom film.) Sterne's book has frequently been described as unfilmable, which is precisely what interested Winterbottom. Published in 1760, "Tristram Shandy" is the memoir of an 18th-century country gentleman who wishes to share his "life and opinions" but is so overcome by the urge to tell digressive, often saucy stories about his father, Walter (a harmless but eccentric pedant), his Uncle Toby (who rides a hobbyhorse and obsesses over an old war wound) and his own conception (which was botched when his mother asked his father if he had remembered to rewind the clock at the moment of climax) that he barely manages to get to his own birth before the book's end. It features many of the avant-garde flourishes now associated with writers like Dave Eggers and Jonathan Safran Foer. There are drawings, blank pages and a page of solid black after a beloved character dies. In keeping with the meta vibe, Coogan plays Tristram, Walter and a version of himself interacting with the film's crew and co-stars. The day's scene had Coogan/Walter leaving the birth of Tristram, walking off-camera and meeting his (Coogan, the charactor's) wife, Jenny, played by Kelly Macdonald, who is breast-feeding their baby, being played by a 6-month-old baby named Daisy.

title: How Long a War? What They've Said

title: For the Record

"What about tapes?" she asked. The associate rolled his eyes, informing her that prerecorded cassettes, too, had gone the way of thermal fax paper. Exasperated, she sighed, "Whatever you call those things they put music on these days."

title: STEM CELL COALITION CREATED
description: The New Jersey Stem Cell Research and Education Foundation and several institutions of higher education announced last week that they were forming a coalition to develop new uses for stem cell research called "Bench to Bedside." The program will use both adult and embryonic stem cells, will be based at the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark and will be financed through grants and private donations. "Stem cell therapy is one of these clear alternatives with great near-term promise to provide relief to millions of people worldwide," said Dr. Gary Friedman, a practicing nephrologist and solid-organ transplant physician. "Our shared vision has at its core a committed focus on rapid, responsible progress." Other organizations involved in the collaboration are Coriell Institute for Medical Research in Camden, the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey in Newark and the Center for Applied Genomics of the Public Health Research Institute in Newark. John Holl
