description: THE restaurant 6 Degrees, which opened recently in Jericho in the quarters once occupied by Capriccio, has the potential to become one of the Island's best. Its food is already there.

title: For Roddick, Tough Road to Rematch Vs. Federer
description: WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 - It was late in the final set of the second men's semifinal at Wimbledon, and Andy Roddick's face was covered with sweat and his tennis clothes covered with dirt as he tried to find a way, any way, to get past the big-serving Swede, Thomas Johansson, on Center Court.

title: When the Everyday Was Revolutionary
description: HE finally stopped taking his Game Boy to work at Goldman Sachs to keep from playing Mario Brothers games during finance meetings.

title: Corrections
description: A dance report on the Week Ahead page last Sunday about the Jacob's Pillow festival misidentified the New York site where Chunky Move, a festival participant, recently performed its work "Tense Dave." It was Dance Theater Workshop, not the Joyce Theater.

title: Islamic Group Says It Set Off Dagestan Blast
description: MOSCOW, July 2 - An Islamic group connected to Chechnya's separatists posted an Internet message on Saturday claiming responsibility for a bomb that killed at least 10 Russian special forces troops as they arrived at a public bathhouse in Dagestan on Friday afternoon.

title: 'The Hummingbird's Daughter': A Saint With Grit
description: THE HUMMINGBIRD'S DAUGHTER By Luis Alberto Urrea. 499 pp. Little, Brown & Company. $24.95.

title: Crossing the Threshold Into a New Condo
description: TWO years ago, when Juan Sanz met his bride-to-be, Karoline Hope, he was renting a small one-bedroom apartment in the far West 30's. "To me it was perfect -- literally three minutes from my office," he said.

title: Par for the Course
description: LOS ANGELES - I CONSIDER myself to be a cool nerd," the director Tim Story said as he lugged his golf clubs to a public driving range across the street from his office at 20th Century Fox.

title: Wrong-Way Driver Collides With Limousine, Killing Two
description: A drunken driver in a pickup truck, hurtling the wrong way on a Long Island parkway, collided head-on with a limousine carrying a family returning from a wedding early yesterday, killing the 59-year-old driver of the limousine and a 7-year old girl, the police said.

title: PHOTO-OP
How Much Is That Teacher Worth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Sorenstam Lets It Slip; Kung Is There to Grab It
description: GLADSTONE, N.J., July 2 - When Annika Sorenstam walked off the 14th green during her quarterfinal round at the Women's World Match Play Championship on Saturday, she led by two holes with four to play. Sunshine drenched the course as Sorenstam waved to her fans. Candie Kung's chances of staging an upset seemed to have vanished.

title: Refined Savages Promenade Through Milan
description: MILAN - A CROQUET ball whacked into a forest halts a group of Stone Age people readying a human sacrifice. Tracing the ball's trajectory, the mud-streaked primitives grunt their way to a clearing that is, in fact, the lawn of a country house where a 1930's garden party is under way. The primitives join the party and, over the course of a long weekend, become civilized, or at least they do until the veneer of civilization cracks for socialites and savages alike.

title: A Green Heartbeat
description: LOOKING out over fields of swaying orchard grass from the enclosed cab of the big John Deere 7410, it occurred to me that my friend Allan Sampson and I were participants in an ancient story, a story as old as time: making hay.

title: Questions for Richard Carmona
description: Thank you for the interview with Richard Carmona (Deborah Solomon, June 19). He spoke at the National Student Nurses Convention in Salt Lake City this spring and was a motivating speaker. Not only is Carmona a surgeon; he is also a registered nurse, the first R.N. to hold the post of surgeon general.

title: Tour de France Q&A with Samuel Abt
A Second Career In Song
description: New Rochelle - IT was a gig just blocks from her home and the partisan audience included her husband and two children, so she did not have any "mommy guilt," but Joan Crowe was still paying her dues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OLSON, KARL A.
description: OLSON--Karl A., June 29, 2005, at 87. The son of Swedish immigrants, he worked his way through the University of Washington and Harvard Business School, then rose to become treasurer of IBM World Trade. He is survived by his wife of 63 years, Mary Lou, and a loving family. Services were held in Guilford, CT. Contributions may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 225 Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL 60601.

title: Upon Further Review: Let's Settle That Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Place in Time Trial Puts Armstrong in Good Position
description: NOIRMOUTIER-EN-L'LE, France, July 2 - Lance Armstrong settled any doubts about his form and motivation Saturday by riding a strong time trial and gaining minutes over some of his most serious rivals as the 92nd Tour de France began. The only thing he failed to do was win, finishing second for the second straight year.

title: The Big Bang
description: BOULDER, Colo. - THE future wasn't supposed to be like this. Not for space-age kids like me, growing up enchanted by the Apollo Moon landings and Arthur C. Clarke's "2001: A Space Odyssey." By now we should be living on the Moon and departing in marvelous ships for the outer solar system, while new technologies gradually make life back on Earth more bountiful and harmonious. Instead 2001 and the years since have been marked by terrorism and conflict. Starvation and environmental destruction have not been eradicated or even stemmed. We have, for now, lost the ability to send people to the Moon, let alone Jupiter and beyond, and, for many of us, the future is not as hopeful a place as it once seemed.

title: The Week Ahead: July 3 - July 9
description: THEATER

title: Albany Report Card
description: Last year, if you had asked us to assess New York State's legislative year, we would have found it hard to get beyond a sigh of disappointment. This year, mostly, we applaud. An impressive number of the 700 or so bills approved by the Legislature reflect a conscientious effort to reform the way Albany does business. Here is a closer look at what the legislators did and did not do.

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: Beset by Opposition, Broadwater Bets on Washington and Time
description: TEST the political winds swirling around the huge floating natural-gas terminal that Broadwater Energy wants to build in the Long Island Sound, and it is easy to conclude that the project is doomed.

title: Friendship Born in Iran by Pursuit of Sturgeon
description: For nearly a week I had been gazing at the Caspian Sea from my hotel room in Ramsar, Iran, wondering what an angling session might produce in such exotic waters.

title: Did You Hear the One About Handel and the Cuban?
description: David Oistrakh in Concert David Oistrakh, violinist; Moscow Philharmonic and Moscow Radio Symphony, conducted by Gennady Rozhdestvensky. EMI Classic Archive 5 99686 9; DVD.

title: INSIDE
description: Increase in U.S. Secrecy The number of documents classified as secret last year by the federal government was about double the number in 2001. At the same time, the declassification process has slowed, to just 28 million pages last year, down from 204 million pages in 1997. The increasing secrecy is drawing protests from Republicans in Congress and the top federal official who oversees classification. PAGE 14

title: Visiting Seoul; Finding a Guide in Istanbul
description: On a trip to Asia in October, my husband and I want to visit Seoul, but we know nothing about where to stay or to go. Can you offer suggestions? -- A.S., Pasadena, Calif.

title: Incroyable! The French Remake a U.S. Film
description: "I ALWAYS thought 'Fingers' felt like a French film, anyway," says James Toback, who wrote and directed it and who now, 27 years later, is enjoying the strange experience of seeing "Fingers" become French not just in feeling but in fact.

title: Up Front
description: This week's cover review, an assessment of a pile of new books about Bruce Springsteen, is written by A. O. Scott, a Times film critic, who says he came to Springsteen's music fairly late. "When I was in high school I thought I was way too cool and cutting edge to listen to him," Scott said in a telephone interview. "I was into punk and new wave. Springsteen's music was what jocks listened to, and probably what the kids who beat me up on the way home from school listened to." The album that changed his mind was "Nebraska" (1982), and from there he went and bought all of Springsteen's earlier stuff, too.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the listed at price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: Some Blacks in Howard Beach See Acceptance, With Limits
description: Once a staple of Queens, all-white neighborhoods have largely become a thing of the past. But they still exist, and the area known as New Howard Beach -- where early Wednesday morning a black man was attacked by a white teenager wielding a baseball bat -- is one of them.

title: Union Square: Countdown Cuisine
description: The digital clock at One Union Square South has been counting down the days, hours, minutes and seconds until Wednesday, the day the International Olympic Committee is to announce whether New York will be the host of the 2012 Games. Here are some Union Square restaurants where New Yorkers can celebrate or drown their sorrows.

title: They'll Take Anything but Manhattan
description: Of the 301 square miles that make up New York City, just 22 belong to Manhattan. The rest are spread across a great expanse that is referred to as the outer boroughs with an inflection that often lands as an expression of disdain.

title: Amy Kimball and Graham Dodds
description: Amy Kimball and Graham Gibbons Dodds are to be married today at the Willows, a house in Villanova, Pa., used for parties and other events. The Rev. John C. Kimball, a retired Episcopal priest and the father of the bride, is to officiate.

title: Preserving Black Landmarks in Setauket
description: SETAUKET - ROBERT E. LEWIS says he will never forget the day a demolition crew came to take down the R.W. Hawkins house in Setauket.

title: The Salt, the Sea, the Sushi
description: Plan the perfect day. Pack the bathing suit, sunscreen and flip-flops, then head toward the Garden State Parkway. Take the Belmar exit, No. 98, and drive toward the beach but not for long.

title: Edwards Awaits Addition to the Family
description: SEASIDE, Calif., July 1 - He strides between verdant playing fields made slick by fog. Eight hundred youngsters are making pandemonium, friends and touchdowns on Wednesday, the third day of Herman Edwards's football camp at California State University, Monterey Bay.

title: Unfriends of Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Victims of Queens Attack Retrace Steps for Inquiry
description: Two of the three black men attacked in Howard Beach on Wednesday morning retraced their steps with investigators on Friday night, providing information that possibly corroborates an account given by a key witness, a law enforcement official said.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; FILM
description: On the early Fox television series "21 Jump Street," JOHNNY DEPP played Tom Hanson, a young policeman who went undercover, mostly in high schools, to smoke out drug dealers, gay-bashers and other under-age lowlifes. Hanson's job meant that he was, like an actor, always taking on new identities, and what made Mr. Depp stand out (apart from his extraordinary good looks) was a palpable sense of enigma. You never quite knew, in a given scene, whether he was really pretending to be Hanson or the person Hanson was pretending to be, and his face, a mask of cunning and reserve, never entirely gave the game away.

title: Trying Out a Career Choice Before You Decide
description: CYNTHIA McKAY'S summer internship lasted three days. This was years ago, when Ms. McKay still thought she wanted to be a mortician. Something about dressing in black and shocking her relatives appealed to her 20-something self. She had been accepted to a mortuary training program when her mother suggested that she work in a funeral home for a few weeks before sending the check for her tuition. In other words, test-drive before she bought.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BYER, JOSEPH
description: BYER--Joseph. 96, died June 30, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Queenie Byer. Devoted father of Cynthia (Ralph) Glogower, Richard (Linda) Byer, loving grandfather of Michael (Terri) Glogower, Stephanie (Fred) Solomon, Brian Byer, Peter (Elyssa) Byer, Lauren Byer, great grandfather of six. Devoted uncle to the Byer, Simmons and Shulman families. Graveside service Sunday, July 3 at 11 AM, Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Moonlighting Sure Pays Off at A.I.G.
description: EVEN the most jaded observer of outsized executive pay may have been amazed when the American International Group, the embattled insurance giant, drew back the curtain on what its top managers received from their association with C.V. Starr, a private offshore company that sells insurance policies for A.I.G. And all that, mind you, came on top of what they were paid for their A.I.G. day jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   DISTEL, KERRY JAMES
description: DISTEL--Kerry James. My Darling Kerry (Passed over July 11, 2004) The Fourth of July is a day to celebrate true independence. The great country in which I lived and you live represents that freedom, that glory of pursuing a goal and reaching it. It is the ultimate expression of freedom and in the lesson, in the bloodshed, in the battle, you find the lesson. And today freedom is still being fought for all over the world and basically it's an individual fight, no matter what--a fight for an identity, a purpose, life itself. It's most important to free each individual spirit to live according to a loving energy. Criticism and aggression are fine, as long as there is not threat to human life. Freedom comes from the inner awareness. If we are tied to something that doesn't represent who and what we really are, we must get free. But the intention must be for true understanding, not for a gratification of the ego. America is a great example of what can be, but it must not be jeopardized by pettiness or greed. And the lessons must be learned before there can be true peace. But we have every day, not just on the Fourth of July, to celebrate our spirit of life, of freedom, of independence, of standing for what we believe in, but not stepping on others' beliefs and ideas. As long as there is no threat to human life. This is something that will come to the light in time so that each person can see the truth and then, as all come together, there will be such a force of love that it will elevate the earth to a new vibration. You see, the worlds are not far apart, neither in the physical nor in the spiritual, because there is no true distance and there must not be any prefabricated distance among people. It is mere propaganda and must be stamped out. There must be oneness. Independence, yes, but oneness always. GOD BLESS AMERICA (Channeled message-received 6/27/05) Edited by wife MaryHathSpokane.com

title: For One Blogger, Fun and Profit
description: Who said you can't make money giving away news and opinions on the Internet? Apparently not Jim Romenesko, who runs a popular site (poynter.org/column.asp?id=45) devoted to comings and goings in the news media. According to tax records filed by his employer, the Poynter Institute, Mr. Romenesko received $169,187 in salary and other compensation in 2003, making him Poynter's highest-paid nonexecutive.

title: WORD MAN
description: Is Joe Mansueto, founder of Morningstar, the mutual fund rater, looking to build a media empire? Last week, he agreed to pay about $35 million for Fast Company and Inc., two business magazines that lost some luster after the economy faltered five years ago. The figure would make a small dent in the net worth of Mr. Mansueto, whose 78 percent stake in Morningstar is valued at more than $800 million.

title: Nancy Moore and Donald Hulnick
description: Nancy Beth Moore and Dr. Donald Howard Hulnick were married yesterday at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated. Cheever Tyler, a friend of the couple, took part in the ceremony.

title: Profits, Not Jobs, on the Rebound in Silicon Valley
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., July 1 - Things are looking up at Wyse Technology, a venerable maker of computer terminals. Unless, that is, you happen to want to work for the company here in Silicon Valley.

title: The Fans Speak: Shorter Fences, Softer Seats
description: What do Mets fans wish to see in their new stadium, besides that extraordinary vendor who stops abruptly in the stands every 10 seconds and shouts at the top of her lungs, "Water!"?

title: Amy Zucker and Douglas Kohen
description: Amy Rebecca Zucker, the daughter of Judith P. Zucker of Morristown, N.J., and Richard Zucker of Springfield, N.J., is to be married today to Douglas Howard Kohen, the son of Susan I. Kohen and David M. Kohen of Newton, Mass. Rabbi Barry Hewitt Greene is to officiate at Elm Bank Reservation, a park in Wellesley, Mass.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOTT, HOWARD M.
description: SCHOTT--Howard M. 82, of Boston, on June 23rd, 2005. Howard was raised in New York and attended Yale University (1944) and Yale Law School (1948). He served in the U.S. Army Military Intelligence Service during WWII. After a 20-year career in international law, he returned to the study of keyboard music and instruments at Oxford in 1968, and received his D.Phil. in 1978. He was an active participant in the Early Music communities of England, New York and Boston. He is survived by his sister Rhoda Ober, his nephew Stephen Ober, his niece Elaine Ober, and her husband Peter Skagestad, his grandnephew Erik Skagestad, and scores of devoted friends. A memorial concert will be held in October.

title: A Tiny Gallery, and a Trickle of Pilgrims From Afar
description: ELLEN RAND'S micro-gallery, squeezed into the foyer of her Williamsburg apartment, has never graced the pages of Artforum or exhibited works by artists whose names might be recognized by the general public. When Ms. Rand opened the gallery last September and invited friends to show their art there, she told them she was running it more for fun than for money.

title: How Much Is That Teacher Worth?
description: To the Editor:

title: Novel Ideas for Reducing Traffic (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: O'er the Lapels of the Free, Fewer Star-Spangled Pins
description: WASHINGTON - TOM DeLAY, not known for having an eye for accessories, greeted a roomful of reporters in his Capitol offices with a fashion rebuke a few weeks ago.

title: Views of Mayor Are Changing for the Better
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's rising approval ratings reflect a significant political milestone: half of those New York City voters who now say they like him also say they disliked him for one reason or another after he was elected in 2001 but have changed their minds.

title: Support the Troops, With Safer Armor
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday with the National Perspectives article, about people in Portland, Ore., who are buying homes together to share housing costs, referred incorrectly to a child shown. The child, Cody Folz, is a boy.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; POP/JAZZ
description: Forget about the language barrier, the lack of hits, the nonexistent profile in North America. The Northeastern Brazilian band NAO ZUMBI is one of the world's best rock bands. Starting in Recife in the early 90's, it was the backdrop for the charismatic singer Chico Science, interweaving the traditional rhythms of maracatu and samba with rock and hip-hop. After Science died in a 1997 car accident, Nao Zumbi carried on, lately incorporating more dub-reggae rhythm and electronics. In the past the band has used four drummers -- two on alfaias, the big bass drums of maracatu, strapped around the waist. The band is only here for one early-evening gig at CENTRAL PARK SUMMERSTAGE, but in past visits the band members have found somewhere else to play a late show; keep your ears to the ground. (Saturday at 7 p.m.; after the show, Daniel Filho's film "A DONA DA HISTRIA" ("The Owner of History") will be screened, as part of the Brazilian Film Festival of New York.) Rumsey Playfield, midpark at 70th Street, , (212) 360-2777.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: Just Moaning Those Deep Down Teaneck Blues

title: Lawsuits And Child Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ACHS, ROBERT
description: ACHS--Robert. 54, film maker, passed away June 21 of cancer, in NYC. Survived by his wife Jackie Leopold, daughter Rachel Achs, father Samuel Achs, sister Naomi Foner-Gyllenhaal and family Jake, Maggie and Stephen Gyllenhaal. Donations to: NYU Cancer Institute Research Fund, C/O Drs. Chachoua/Formenti, 160 East 34 Street, NY, NY 10016.

title: Janel D'Agata and Joseph Lynch IV
description: Janel Katrina D'Agata, the daughter of Joanne Ouellette of Windham, N.H., and Alfred D'Agata of Haverhill, Mass., was married yesterday to Joseph Aloysius Lynch IV, a son of Katherine Lynch and Mr. Lynch III of Kansas City, Mo. The Rev. James Hayes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in St. Joseph Memorial Chapel at the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Mass.

title: Sol LeWitt's Nonmemorial
description: It's no Shake Shack, but the new Sol LeWitt installation in Madison Square Park is attracting a lot of attention -- more than any artwork since the Madison Square Park Conservancy began curating art for the park in 2000, said Debbie Landau, the group's president. "Curved Wall With Towers" and "Circle With Towers," on the Madison Avenue and 23rd Street sides of the park, respectively, are composed of large concrete bricks stacked into identical, evenly spaced square towers. Though the pieces have 25 towers between them, many visitors last week found them evocative of a single pair.

title: Gail Leicht and Leonard Ruvolo
description: Gail S. Leicht and Leonard A. Ruvolo are to be married this evening on the grounds of the Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, Mass. Martin S. Dorfman, the uncle of the bride, has received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 19 about Chiang Mai, Thailand, misspelled the name of the Mandarin Oriental hotel in which the author stayed. It is the Dhara Dhevi, not Dhara Devi.

title: A Dancer's Long Road to Tradition
description: IN Myung Soo Kim's dances, just stepping forward requires enormous skill. First, one foot rises slowly, deliberately, off the floor. The opposite knee bends, dipping the trunk downward. While the leading leg pushes forward, as if through lava, the shoulders and head echo the movement, and the body seems frozen and lurching at the same time. The intricate balancing act ends when the foot comes to rest again on the floor, a few inches beyond its starting point.

title: Using a Cursor to Land a Better Airline Seat
description: FOR years, Internet users have been able to find better deals on air fares than the unwired masses. Now they can get better seats, too.

title: Finally, Def Leppard Without the Pretensions
description: As a songwriter and bassist for the New York bands Ivy and Fountains of Wayne, Adam Schlesinger has probed the expressive possibilities of the pop song, crafting miniature dramas with wit and catchy hooks. A prolific songwriter for film and television, he is currently writing songs for a musical adaptation of the John Waters movie, "Cry-Baby." Last week Virgin released Fountains of Wayne's "Out-of-State Plates," a two-CD collection of new and unreleased material. Speaking recently with Joel Topcik, Mr. Schlesinger discussed what he has been listening to and why:

title: Shirley Liao and Daniel Kong
description: Shirley S. Liao and Daniel T. Kong were married last evening at Carlyle on the Green, a caterer in Farmingdale, N.Y. Gino Papa, an acting justice of East Hills, N.Y., officiated.

title: U.S. Searches for Missing Soldiers Amid Taliban Resurgence
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 2 - American forces continued their search for missing soldiers in the eastern Kunar Province on Saturday, and at least six Afghan soldiers were killed elsewhere in fighting with resurgent Taliban forces.

title: What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)
description: The article and photographs were replete with class markers. Describing gay-marriage opponents, your writer comments on wall-to-wall carpeting in the homes he visits, and a photo shows ugly brown carpeting and what looks like fake wood paneling. Shorto has dinner (surely they called it "supper") where the food is served on paper plates, buffet style: "sliced lunch meats, hamburger buns . . . bowls of pretzels and chips, cookies and . . . two-quart plastic bottles of soda." At another house, "Christmas lights were still up" in March. By contrast, the lesbian couple is described as "upscale." Their apartment has "hardwood floors" and Oriental rugs and a bookshelf "crammed" with children's books. Is this a religious war or a class war?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SICKLES, RENEE
description: SICKLES -- Renee. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Roberta, Alan, Barry and Howard, and mother-in-law of Marlene, William and Hal. Cherished grandmother of Harris and Shira. Devoted sister of Debby Buchwald and Rochell Turshen. Dear aunt of Ivy, Ben, Julia and Sam. Services today, 12 noon at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, Inc., 1283 Coney Island Avenue, Brooklyn, NY. SICKLES--Renee. I'll take care of the soup. My complete love, Julia

title: A Livable Shade Of Green
description: PORTLAND, Ore. - When President Bush travels to the Group of 8 summit meeting this week, he'll stiff Tony Blair and other leaders who are appealing for firm action on global warming.

title: Letters
description: Our cover article on anti-gay-marriage crusaders elicited a strong and spirited response in defense of same-sex unions. A problem for those opposed, one reader said, might be that gay couples, who have supposedly more egalitarian attitudes, might pose a threat to ''conventional modes of domesticity.''

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: In Telluride, the Skis Are Stowed, but Good Times Aren't
description: A QUARTER-MILE up the Cornet Creek Trail, a 10-minute hike from downtown Telluride, Richard Yeager pauses to watch a waterfall roll off the edge of a 60-foot cliff and explode into the small pool below like an endless fireworks display.

title: UConn Finds Breach In Computer System
description: The University of Connecticut has notified about 72,000 people in its computer database that their date of birth, Social Security number, address and telephone number may have been illegally accessed during the last year and a half.

title: Blockbuster Drugs Are So Last Century
description: INDIANAPOLIS - DRUG companies do an awful job of finding new medicines. They rely too much on billion-dollar blockbuster drugs that are both overmarketed and overprescribed. And they have been too slow to disclose side effects of popular medicines.

title: Did You Hear the One About Handel and the Cuban?
description: Manuel Barrueco: 'Concierto Barroco'

title: Lindley Tilghman and John Pless III
description: Lindley Read Tilghman, the daughter of Blanche Nusbaum O'Connell of Greenwich, Conn., and Richard Albert Tilghman Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to John Anthony Pless III, the son of Helena Pless and John Pless Jr. of Dorset, Vt. The Rev. Christopher Smith, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Hildene, a historic house in Manchester, Vt. The Rev. William H. Russell, also an Episcopal priest and the bridegroom's godfather, assisted in the ceremony.

title: Happy Fifth of July, New York!
description: STANDING before a gathering of the Ladies' Antislavery Society in Rochester, Frederick Douglass, newspaper editor and internationally known voice of abolition, moved his audience with the force of his argument. It was July 5, 1852, the day after the national celebration of American independence. This former slave confronted a hushed crowd and a nation with the stunning question: "What, to the American slave, is your Fourth of July?"

title: New Jersey Adopts $27.9 Billion Budget
description: TRENTON, July 2 - More than 24 hours after missing a deadline to keep state government running, lawmakers approved a $27.9 billion budget early Saturday that will shrink property tax rebates for most residents while holding the line on overall spending.

title: Wellesian Voodoo
description: Wellesian Voodoo

title: AMBER FORT, April 16, 2005
description: Gloria Perez-Siquier, a 33-year-old jewelry and fashion designer from Madrid. "I was in Jaipur with my sister on business, but that day we went to see the fort and I said: 'Oh, my God, Sonia, there are elephants, maybe we can touch them.' I went to the Indian man who was washing them and I said, 'Can I do it?' He gave me a big stone and I was washing the elephant. It was amazing. I was almost crying. The man asked me if I wanted to ride the elephant outside the river, and I told him I wanted to do it in the river. Then I swam with the elephant. There is a point when you're in an adventure and you don't think about that. You think you've been with elephants all your life and are just so excited that you're not afraid." As told to Seth Kugel

title: A Magical Island, in View of the Hudson
description: Garrison - THE actors who perform regularly at Boscobel Restoration here must be tired of critics raving about the physical setting, but a Hudson River view this spectacular is hard to ignore. And the Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival puts it to beautiful use in its current outdoor production of "The Tempest."

title: A Career Reprise With the Wounded
description: TWICE a week, busloads of the wounded arrive at an already busy military hospital, some on stretchers, others in wheelchairs. Those arrivals give Col. Martin F. Stein Jr. new certainty that he is putting his medical skills to the right use.

title: I Love You, I Mean It, Now Get Out of Here
description: If there were any doubts about the sincerity of the Republican candidates to work together after a hard-fought primary for governor, Bret Schundler put them to rest. Sort of.

title: No Rest for the Weary
description: The citizens of France are once again taking a pasting on the op-ed pages. Their failing this time is not that they are cheese-eating surrender monkeys, as they were thought to be during the invasion of Iraq, but rather that they voted to reject the new European Union constitution. According to the pundits, this was the timid, shortsighted choice of a backward-looking people afraid to face the globalized future. But another way of looking at it is that the French were simply trying to hold on to their perks -- their cradle-to-grave welfare state and, above all, their cherished 35-hour workweek.

title: What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)
description: I could get a marriage license tomorrow that would sanction my relationship with any one of my male friends. No one would ask if we intended to raise children together, grow old together or any of the other things that supposedly "sanctify" marriage. And we would instantly earn the rights of all married couples. But the one person whose relationship with me truly is a marriage -- with whom I'm raising a child, with whom I intend to grow old -- is the one person who would be turned away at the clerk's office if we applied to be "married."

title: Green and More Than Pleasant
description: IT had been a long day. My 71-year-old mother had flown overnight from the United States to visit her expatriate daughter and her three grandchildren, arriving as the sun was beginning to come up in London. But instead of letting her take a nap, or even grab a cup of coffee, we had stuffed her into the back of a minivan for a 40-minute journey to the cottage I had rented for a week in the English countryside.

title: Summer Job Candidates Just Surfed And Clicked
description: BOB AMORUSO, the general manager of the Splish Splash water park in Riverhead, says the park has received a healthy number of applications for summer employment. Of the more than 2,000 applications, about half came in from the company's Web site.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRUPP, LYNN E.
description: KRUPP--Lynn E. I will cherish your love, courage, tenderness and laughter forever. Love, Jerry

title: On a Flat Stage 2, Armstrong Holds His Position
description: LES ESSARTS, France, July 3 - Lance Armstrong showed up for work in the Tour de France today in the jersey of a leader although it wasn't the jersey he wanted and it wasn't really his anyway.

title: Escrow Account Thefts Are Rare
description: To the Editor:

title: Problem Solver, Or Problem Causer?
description: To the Editor:

title: Unfriends of Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the Thai filmmaker Apichatpong Weerasethakul misstated the distance from Bangkok, where he was born, to Khon Kaen, where he was reared. It is a five-hour drive, not five miles.

title: The Basics; America: Not Their First Choice
description: Where's the love?

title: Hillary Lavely and Parker Corbin
description: Hillary Roberts Lavely, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Magee Lavely of New Orleans, was married in Washington yesterday to Parker Stockton Corbin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Stockton Corbin of Millbrook, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Ronald P. Conner, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at Washington National Cathedral.

title: Marc Gurton and James Kiely
description: Marc Charles Gurton and James Earl Kiely are to be married today at Springstep, a performing arts and cultural center in Medford, Mass. Richard E. Brenin, Mr. Gurton's stepbrother, has received permission from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Man Attacks Girlfriend, Then Kills Himself
The Boss Bibliography
description: Books about, inspired by or making reference to Bruce Springsteen are hardly a new, or especially rare, phenomenon. "Born to Run," the first volume of Dave Marsh's quasi-authorized biography, appeared in 1979, and is now available along with its sequel, "Glory Days," in a single volume called "Bruce Springsteen: Two Hearts." Springsteen's lyrics, which frequently, if modestly, display their own literary pedigree, resonate in the prose of writers like Bobbie Ann Mason, Richard Ford, Stephen King (who prefaced his epic novel "The Stand" with a quotation from Springsteen's song "Jungleland") and T. C. Boyle, who took the title for his story collection "Greasy Lake" from imagery in a cut from Springsteen's first album. The basic Boss studies syllabus includes Daniel Cavicchi's "Tramps Like Us," a sociological study of his fan base; Rolling Stone's omnibus "Bruce Springsteen: The Rolling Stone Files"; and "It Ain't No Sin to Be Glad You're Alive," Eric Alterman's knowledgeable and rousing elaboration of "The Promise of Bruce Springsteen."

title: Albany Report Card
description: Last year, if you had asked us to assess New York State's legislative year, we would have found it hard to get beyond a sigh of disappointment. This year, mostly, we applaud. An impressive number of the 700 or so bills approved by the Legislature reflect a conscientious effort to reform the way Albany does business. Here is a closer look at what the legislators did and did not do.

title: Working in a Coal Mine: Lord I Am So Tired, but Good-Looking
description: MOST people tend to think of coal mining as a dangerous, dirty business. But General Electric, as part of its Ecomagination campaign, is trying to change that. And in a hopelessly conflicted new ad, G.E. is using some powerful explosives: glistening bodies, a soothing message and archness so extreme that it ends up backfiring.

title: A Room With No View
description: FOR many apartment dwellers, a home office is an indeterminate breed, a cross between a region of the house and a piece of furniture. Perhaps it begins as a docile desk with computer but grows into an unruly beast, covered in bills and power cords, spreading out from a corner of a room used primarily for something else, like cooking or sleeping.

title: Taking a Look at the Duck's Dinner, and Ours
description: To the Editor:

title: Chasing the Joneses, in a Fish Tank
description: NEXT to bickering over whose dad is tougher, playground intellectuals may love nothing more than debating whether goldfish can feel pain. The naysayers have the weaker case, given that fish are obviously sentient creatures. On the other hand, because a goldfish cannot yelp or scream, how can anyone tell that it's really suffering? As with the classic head scratcher about trees falling soundlessly in the forest, it's tough to counter that sort of specious logic -- especially for a second grader.

title: A Leap of Faith
description: A LOT of people think I was brainwashed. How else to explain why I would allow the Rev. Sun Myung Moon of the Unification Church to choose my spouse?

title: Corrections
description: The highlight entry on Page 2 of the Television section today for the Macy's Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular at 9 p.m. tomorrow on NBC includes an outdated reference to the performers, provided by the network. The host is Al Roker, not Carson Daly. The musical guest is Mariah Carey, not Fantasia or Sheryl Crow.

title: 'Two Trains Running': No. 1 With a Bullet
description: TWO TRAINS RUNNING By Andrew Vachss. 448 pp. Pantheon Books. $25.

title: 'The Genius Factory': Test-Tube Superbabies
description: THE GENIUS FACTORY The Curious History of the Nobel Prize Sperm Bank. By David Plotz. 262 pp. Random House. $24.95.

title: Whether on the Road or on the Patio, Burning Costly Fuel
description: You just can't win. With gas prices soaring like humidity levels in the Northeast, a lot of Americans were no doubt tempted to leave their Explorers and Hummers, maybe even their Priuses, parked firmly in the driveway for this latest round of national roller derby, technically known as a holiday weekend.

title: Manufacturers Seeking to Link Classroom and the Factory Floor
description: This past winter, Juan Colon, 42, a punch-press operator for Afco Systems, a Farmingdale, N.Y., manufacturer of modular data centers, took a class in blueprint reading from company engineers in a conference room above the production floor.

title: Hotel Urban in Madrid
description: THE BASICS -- So large is the eclectic art collection of Catalan businessman Jordi Clos, who opened the Hotel Claris in Barcelona in 1992, that he has built a second hotel to house part of it, this one in Madrid. The Hotel Urban, which opened in November, is a sleek, minimalist space saved from coldness by eclectic antique artwork, much of it from the 19th century, dotting public and private spaces. The Urban's lobby resembles an office-building atrium; it features a circle of stiff chairs and does not invite loitering. But the towering sculptures from Papua New Guinea, tucked along one wall, at least make the place interesting.

title: Lifeguard Staff Quits At Sherwood Island
description: The five lifeguards who work at Sherwood Island State Park in Westport quit last weekend, with two of them citing equipment problems and a pay discrepancy as the reasons.

title: Boy, 15, Dies In a Dispute Over an Ipod
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed on Saturday night in what investigators believe was a dispute over an iPod, the police said.

title: Joanna Thiele and Tony Curry
description: Joanna Pat Thiele, a daughter of Jane and Patrick Thiele of Warwick, Bermuda, was married yesterday afternoon to Anthony Keefe Curry, a son of Dorothy Curry of Narragansett, R.I., and Andrew Curry of New York. The Rev. Jared Costanza, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Church in Paget, Bermuda.

title: Saudi forces clash with suspected militants in Riyadh
Cup Leaders Are Hoping to Shut the Door to the Playoff
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 2 - As Greg Biffle and Jimmie Johnson vie for the points lead in Nascar's Nextel Cup series, they are suddenly bonded by a common purpose.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The 48-passenger Atlantis XI submarine has resumed its daily schedule of undersea voyages off the coast of Grand Cayman. The attraction, operated by ATLANTIS ADVENTURES, was suspended when Hurricane Ivan struck the island last September. Passengers on the 90-minute excursion view marine life through oversized portholes at depths of up to 100 feet. Information available at (866) 546-7820 or on the Web at www.atlantisadventures.com. ... On Oct. 1, the Socit des Bains de Mer is scheduled to open its fifth hotel in Monaco -- the MONTE-CARLO BAY HOTEL AND RESORT. The 334-room hotel will feature a spa, casino and 10 acres of gardens. Reservations and information are available at (800) 595-0898 or on the Web at www.montecarloresort.com. ... CARNIVAL CRUISE LINES is offering wine enthusiasts the chance to enjoy wine tastings, seminars with wine experts, and wine-themed parties while sailing the Caribbean. Carnival Liberty will sail Dec. 4 to 10 round trip from Fort Lauderdale with stops in Freeport, Grand Cayman and Cozumel. Fares start at $504 a person, double occupancy. Reservations and information: (866) 299-5862, or on the Web at www.presidentialwineclub.com or www.carnival.com. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WALTON, JOHN T.
description: WALTON--John T. It is with great sadness that the InnerCity Scholarship Fund family notes the passing of one of the founders of Children's Scholarship Fund. We are so grateful for Mr. Walton's profound commitment to children-in-need throughout the country, and especially to those boys and girls in the Archdiocese of New York. Without the help of Children's Scholarship Fund and his own championing of school vouchers, thousands of children would not be attending the schools of their choice. His generous spirit will never be forgotten. Our hearts go out to his wife, Christy, son Luke, and the entire Walton family in this time of loss.

title: PHOTO-OP
What's Their Real Problem With Gay Marriage? (It's the Gay Part)
description: I wonder if there isn't another force driving opponents of same-sex marriage: the threat that it may pose to traditional family gender roles. Unbound by the usual gender-based notions of who does what within the family, gay and lesbian couples might be more likely to have arrangements in which each partner's paid employment is valued equally and where each contributes equally to household work and childrearing. Same-sex marriage threatens to teach us all about the possibility of greater marital equality.

title: 'Electing Justice': The People's Court
description: ELECTING JUSTICE Fixing the Supreme Court Nomination Process. By Richard Davis. 211 pp. Oxford University Press. $28.

title: House in the Hamptons Is Destroyed in Explosion
description: A house in Westhampton Beach, on Long Island, was destroyed after it exploded and caught fire shortly before 7 p.m. yesterday, the police said.

title: Call to the Wild: Falconry Is Now Legal
description: IN 1998 the General Assembly passed a law legalizing falconry in Connecticut, but the regulations, and thus final approval, have been hung up in negotiations and the regulatory process. Last month, however, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service approved the rules and Connecticut has become the 49th state to legalize falconry.

title: Fireworks May Resume on Friday
description: THE week starts off with fireworks, and it could end the same way. The monthly employment report, to be released Friday morning, often moves markets sharply -- after Wall Street has taken a few seconds to deliberate thoroughly on its contents. Nonfarm payrolls are expected to have grown by 192,000 last month, according to economists polled by Bloomberg News. That would be a leap from the 78,000 jobs added the previous month.

title: DATEBOOK
description: CORTONA, ITALY

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; TELEVISION
description: O.K., it probably won't be as historically revealing as the British import "The 1900 House," but MTV's reality series "THE 70'S HOUSE" (beginning Tuesday night) may turn out to be fun. A dozen young people move in together (this part we've heard before) and live the way Americans did three decades ago. That means no cellphones, e-mail or iPods. But at least they could have cable.

title: Manischewitz Considers Leaving Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY - EXODUS? That word looms over the nation's largest maker of processed kosher Jewish foods -- the B. Manischewitz Company -- an industrial icon that has maintained its plant in this city since 1932, when dozens of factories dotted the Hudson River waterfront and sent billows of smoke, along with a distinctive aroma, into the North Jersey sky.

title: A Bid to Protect Children, One Videotape at a Time
description: OSSINING - ONE day several years ago, Sylvia Escala's son was missing. Fear and anguish overpowered her, she said; it was impossible in her distracted state to describe the child accurately to the authorities. And she had no current identity records.

title: 'Blow, Gabriel, Blow!' The Novelist Who Found His Voice as an Epic Historian
description: Correction Appended

title: The Prince of Albany County
description: When I grow up, I want to live like Richard Prince. At age 56, the artist is enjoying the kind of regard that seemed both inevitable and improbable when I first met him a decade and a half ago. The past few years have brought a steady stream of books, articles, exhibitions and upwardly spiraling sales prices. His cowboy pictures, rephotographed from cropped Marlboro ads, have become among the most iconic works of the last few decades; his paintings -- some simply printed with jokes, some made of images of nurses copied from the covers of soft-core-porn paperbacks -- are pushing seven figures in the auction market. But for the last eight years or so he has ducked the nonsense that usually accompanies that kind of success by retreating from the city to an 88-acre homestead in a small town in the foothills of the Catskills. It's a kind of private, rural theme park -- Prince World Upstate -- where he lives and works quietly in a comfortable compound with his wife, his children and his stuff.

title: On the Matter of the Paintings, the Jury Is Still Out
description: L. Dennis Kozlowski, the former chairman of Tyco International, is off to prison. His Impressionist art collection, though, is still in legal limbo, sitting in a Sotheby's storage facility. The collection, which includes "Flowers and Fruit" by Renoir, below, and "Prs Monte-Carlo (Le Cap Martin: La Pointe )" by Monet, right, is the subject of a string of dueling criminal and civil lawsuits. Indeed, it was Mr. Kozlowski's penchant for collecting art that got him in trouble in the first place. Before he was indicted for looting millions of dollars from Tyco, he was charged with evading more than $1 million in New York State taxes by having art dealers ship empty boxes of artwork to Tyco's offices in Exeter, N.H., while having messengers bring the actual paintings to his Fifth Avenue apartment. The tax case, which was not part of his recent trial, is pending.

title: The One, The Only, Gaucho
description: The signature look of erstwhile South American cowboys has had surprising fashion impact of late. Last summer the ridiculous-sublime must-have was the poncho; this summer, it's the gaucho. Worn with either wedge heels or flip-flops, these wide-bottomed, calf-length split-skirts are moving like hotcakes. Urban Outfitters makes six versions, including one crinkled cotton model that has a sash to tie at the hip ($38). Splendid's gauchos are made of thin, stretch cotton jersey with a raw-edged hem and fold-over waistband (available in black or brown for $85 at Intermix boutiques). Hip-hugging, roll-down waist gauchos in white, black or brown by Ella Moss have a finished hem and bell-shaped silhouette because they taper slightly at the thigh ($88 at Henri Bendel). And Laundry by Shelli Segal offers tailored, white cotton lycra gauchos with a crisp center crease and nautical silver grommets, a design that says, "Ahoy!" as much as it does "Bravo!" ($165 at Nordstrom). ELIZABETH HAYT

title: Sussex Gardens: Green and More Than Pleasant
description: IN his series called "A Picture of Britain," one of the ornaments of this summer's British television schedule, the broadcaster David Dimbleby chose to focus not on picturesque cities like London and Bath and Edinburgh but on the wonderful landscapes that inspired Wordsworth, Emily Bronte, Constable and Gainsborough.

title: How Much Is That Teacher Worth?
description: To the Editor:

title: These Days, It Has to Do a Lot More Than Roll
description: THOUGHTS of baby strollers kept popping into Johanna Ilfeld's head before the birth of her second son late last year.

title: LONG ISLAND FOOTLIGHTS
description: A Room of Their Own

title: Abortion Takes Center Stage at Women's Rights Gathering
description: NASHVILLE, July 2 - The National Organization for Women's annual convention began Friday morning with an agenda that included discussions about the morning-after pill and feminism in popular culture, along with the election of the group's president.

title: A Disservice to Clients
description: To the Editor:

title: There's No Excuse for Rogers's Rage
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ukraine's Top Assets Are the Spoils in a Post-Election Power Struggle That's Far From Over
description: ZAPOROZHYE, Ukraine - With his face turned to the hellish river of molten metal, Vasily A. Fedko, 55, said he left the Soviet Army 30 years ago and joined a new force, the metal workers at Nikopol, a mill in eastern Ukraine that produces steel alloys. He earns about $300 a month - and he does not talk politics.

title: Correction
description: A chart on June 19 listing odd facts about Brooklyn misstated the number of streets in Williamsburg named for signers of the Declaration of Independence. There are not 4 but 20 or 21, depending on how you count. Keap Street was intended to honor Thomas McKean, a signer, but someone apparently misread his signature.

title: Lesley Oakes and Steven O'Keefe
description: Lesley Jean Oakes, the daughter of Dorothy J. Oakes and Dr. James G. Oakes of Sudbury, Mass., is to be married today to Steven Michael O'Keefe, the son of Dr. Kathleen M. O'Keefe and T. Michael O'Keefe of Minneapolis. Thomas J. Fallon, a justice of the peace in Brewster, Mass., is to officiate at the Popponesset Inn in Mashpee, Mass.

title: Japan investigates strange water vapor plume
With Rebels Roaming Nepal, Tourism Plunges
description: BEFORE setting out from Katmandu, Nepal's capital, for a trekking trip in the countryside in February, Amber Manners got a practical tip. If you see guerillas on the road, she was warned, do as they say, even if they ask you to get off your bus. "If they burn your bus," she recalled being told, "they'll ask you to get off first."

title: National Lampoon Grows Up by Dumbing Down
description: Correction Appended

title: Even Lapdogs Get a Hint of the Lap of Luxury
description: Don CeSar Beach ResortAs George Orwell wrote in "Animal Farm" in 1945, "some animals are more equal than others." And though the book was an attack on Stalinism, one wonders what Orwell would say about capitalism's latest achievement: the luxury hotel package for well-heeled pets. While Fido stays home in a leaky doghouse, Fifi gets a blow dry.

title: Attack of the $1 DVD's
description: THE scientist in the 1959 horror film "The Killer Shrews" is not only mad but also cheap. Monstrously cheap. To solve the problem of world hunger, he tries to breed humans down to half their normal size. Rather than increase the food supply, he reasons, he will decrease demand. But his penny-pinching plans go awry, naturally, or unnaturally, creating a pack of giant, munchies-afflicted shrews.

title: Where Summer Glides Down Like a 9 A.M. Beer
description: Way behind the black-and-white roller coaster pictures and smiling beer girl posters, the snapshots of the regulars and the late lamented Ruby, a sign behind the bar said, "Welcome Back to Coney Island Summer 2004." The scrawny dude everybody calls Master was walking around in a too-big tank top looking for a good place to hang a new sign. Same message, different summer.

title: Wineries Are Hailing Interstate Sales
description: IF the optimists are correct, New York's new legislation permitting interstate wine shipments may be a boon for Long Island's wine industry. When the measure takes effect, possibly in late summer, out-of-state visitors to the East End will be able to buy wines at tasting counters -- or by Internet afterward -- and have them sent home.

title: Garbage Plan And Asphalt Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Some People Pick the Stock. Others Choose the Moment.
description: TIMING is everything. Or is it?

title: The Congo Case
description: Correction Appended

title: No Formulas
description: To the Editor:

title: Juliana Chittick and Can Tiryaki
description: Juliana Holmboe Chittick and Can Mustafa Ali Tiryaki are to be married today at the First Parish Meeting House in Cohasset, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Jan Carlsson-Bull, a Unitarian Universalist minister, is to officiate.

title: A Portraitist Gets Her Due
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mall That Would Save America
description: Robert Congel, a commercial real-estate developer who lives in upstate New York, has a plan to "change the world." Convinced that it will "produce more benefit for humanity than any one thing that private enterprise has ever done," he is raising $20 billion to make it happen. That's 12 times the yearly budget of the United Nations and more than 25 times Congel's own net worth.

title: Slaying Renews Calls For Confinement Law
description: WHITE PLAINS - AFTER a woman was stabbed to death by a convicted sex offender in a mall parking lot here on Wednesday, there seemed to be one sentiment echoing through the county: Our worst fears have been realized.

title: All Politics Is Local, and Sadly, Sometimes Personal
description: TWO Supreme Courts have now spoken on New London's plan to demolish a slightly tatty neighborhood to bring in a better class of taxpayers. The Connecticut Supreme Court said last year, and the United States Supreme Court said 10 days ago, that yes, a local government may remove whoever stands in the way of its dreams -- if it just takes care not to abuse the process.

title: Suffolk County History, On a Screen Near You
description: THE Suffolk Cooperative Library System, which comprises the county's 56 local libraries, plans to make a trove of historic documents available online. If the effort succeeds, with a click of a button, anyone with Internet access will be able to read back issues of The Sag Harbor Corrector, a newspaper that went out of business in the early 1900's, or the diaries of Long Islanders from the 1800's.

title: Shea Stadium, Field of Screams
description: OCT. 28, 1961 Construction begins on Municipal Stadium at Flushing Meadow Park, Queens; the ballpark will soon be renamed Shea Stadium in honor of William Shea, the influential lawyer who strong-armed Major League Baseball into establishing a new team in New York. Unable to persuade any National League teams to relocate here, Shea dreamed up the Continental League, an organization to compete with the majors. But baseball officials buckled, New York was awarded an expansion National League franchise, and the Continental League never saw its first bunt.

title: Tracey Finch and Gabriel Grossman
description: Tracey Lynne Finch, a daughter of Madeline and Wesley Finch of Boca Raton, Fla., is to be married this evening to Gabriel Seth Grossman, a son of Rebekah Ralen Grossman of Allston, Mass., and the late Neil Grossman. Rabbi Emily G. Lipof is to officiate at the Ritz-Carlton in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Vast Crowd Attends Rally for the Poor in Scotland
description: EDINBURGH, July 2 - Wearing white as a symbol of hope and justice, more than 225,000 demonstrators encircled the heart of this graceful medieval city on Saturday and demanded an end to abject poverty around the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORRIS, ALLEN E.
description: MORRIS--Allen E. The officers and employees of Riverside Memorial Chapel express their condolences to the Morris family upon the untimely loss of their beloved brother.

title: Confirmation Battle in Senate Could Define Specter's Career
description: WASHINGTON, July 2 - In nearly 25 years on the Senate Judiciary Committee, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, has sat through nine Supreme Court confirmation hearings, some short and polite, some ugly and drawn out. Now that he is the chairman, he is prepared for the next one to go either way.

title: Seafood in an Inviting (and Stable) Setting
description: CONSISTENCY is often the major bugaboo of restaurants: one day a place can be terrific, the next time it may be so-so, or even closed down. A recent visit to the Shell Station surprised me.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Africa at the Summit
description: "There can be no excuse, no defense, no justification for the plight of millions of our fellow human beings in Africa today. And there should be nothing that stands in our way in changing it." That ringing summons was issued by Britain's prime minister, Tony Blair, earlier this year, when he presented the compelling findings and lucid recommendations of his Commission for Africa. Later this week, we will see whether President Bush has the vision and compassion to meet those challenges, and grasp a historic opportunity to radically improve the life prospects of millions of those fellow human beings.

title: Gabrielle Chassagne and Joshua Klein
description: Gabrielle Marie Chassagne, a daughter of Yolene and Ernst L. Chassagne of Queens Village, Queens, is to be married today to Joshua B Klein, a son of Ruth and Douglas Klein of Valley Stream, N.Y. Rabbi Melvyn May is to officiate at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Nima Kudalkar and David Krodel
description: Poornima Kudalkar, the daughter of Dr. Meena Kudalkar and Kishor Kudalkar of Burr Ridge, Ill., is to be married this afternoon to David James Krodel, the son of Anne and James R. Krodel of Salem, Conn. Pandit Satish Bhagwat, a Hindu priest, is to officiate at the Hyatt Regency Woodfield in Schaumburg, Ill.

title: For a Maligned Line, a Minor Victory
description: Residents of Fort Greene, Brooklyn, have long had a problem with the G train. Many problems, in fact, but this is the story of one problem that got solved.

title: Go Directly to Jail
description: So, what is it like to serve time in jail, when the only thing standing between you and freedom is a thing called "principles"?

title: Navy Seal Is Rescued in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 3 - One member of a four-man Navy Seal reconnaissance team has been rescued after his group were reported missing in a mountainous region of eastern Afghanistan last week, a senior Defense Department official said today.

title: Katherine Sorel and Joseph Boucher
description: Katherine Sorel, a daughter of Nancy Caldwell Sorel and Edward Sorel of Manhattan, was married last evening to Joseph George Boucher, the son of Dorothy and George Boucher of Canandaigua, N.Y. David W. Bills, a pastor of the Religious Society of Friends, officiated in the Audubon Center at the Boathouse in Prospect Park, Brooklyn.

title: Theresa Wong and Tal Lev
description: Theresa Wong and Tal Lev are to be married this evening by Rabbi Chava Koster at the Yale Club of New York.

title: When an Order of Protection Does Not Work
description: MERLINE PORT-LOUIS did everything she could to keep her ex-boyfriend at bay, the police say. She obtained a court order of protection, prohibiting him from coming near her; she called the police each time he violated it; she recorded his phone calls to her, sought advice from a victim's advocate and frequently checked in with friends and family to let them know she was safe.

title: Music Chronicle
description: SEARCHING FOR THE SOUND: My Life With the Grateful Dead. By Phil Lesh. (Little, Brown, $25.95.) It's hard to say which of these miracles is more profound: the fact that after three decades with the Grateful Dead, Lesh has any memories of the experience whatsoever, or that he's been able to consolidate them into a single volume of less than 20,000 pages. In his marvelously economical and engrossing memoir, Lesh, the band's bassist, recounts the Dead's creation against the backdrop of the Bay Area's beatnik culture and its historic performance at Woodstock (and nonperformance at Altamont), but he also takes a frank look at the drug abuse that marred the group's later years, as well as his own struggles with alcohol and with liver disease. Through it all, Lesh proves to be as capable and enthusiastic a writer as he is a musician; whether he's describing the "immense, turbulent, Druidic" snoring of Jerry Garcia, the "saber-toothed crotch cricket" hum of the Woodstock sound system or a road-trip travel game called "Radio I-Ching," he consistently exhibits a peculiar and poetic fondness for language, transforming what could have been a routine exercise in nostalgia into a work as graceful and sublime as a box of rain. Dave Itzkoff

title: Cutting the Losses From Outsourcing
description: OUTSOURCING will inevitably eliminate many more American jobs, says Ron Hira, assistant professor of public policy at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

title: Happy Fifth of July, New York!
description: STANDING before a gathering of the Ladies' Antislavery Society in Rochester, Frederick Douglass, newspaper editor and internationally known voice of abolition, moved his audience with the force of his argument. It was July 5, 1852, the day after the national celebration of American independence. This former slave confronted a hushed crowd and a nation with the stunning question: "What, to the American slave, is your Fourth of July?"

title: Hamas and Other Factions Invited to Join Palestinian Government
description: JERUSALEM, July 3 - The Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, said today that Hamas and other factions had been invited to join the Palestinian government as it prepared to take control of areas evacuated by Israel in the Gaza Strip.

title: Musical Cry to Help Africa's Poor Is Heard Around Globe
description: LONDON, July 2 - Hundreds of thousands of people gathered here and in nine other spots around the world on Saturday for a series of free concerts meant to persuade world leaders to give more money to fight poverty in Africa.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 3 -- July 9; ART
description: Nothing is permanent, in life or art. A case in point, the METROPOLITAN MUSEUM's permanent galleries for European paintings have three guests on view through the summer. Catch them before they're gone. Time flies.

title: Battlefield: Supreme Court
description: Correction Appended

title: 3 Bombings Shake Capital of Kosovo
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 2 - Three bombs exploded late Saturday in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo Province, one of them outside the headquarters of the United Nations mission, a spokeswoman for the mission said.

title: The Long Way Home
description: Growing up, I thought that destiny had marked me for a life of impermanence. I wasn't even 2 years old on Nov. 4, 1979, the day my father hoped to get his visa from the American Embassy in Tehran. Having long harbored academic ambitions, my parents had finally decided to emigrate. They were luckier than many Iranians; they had modest savings and letters of acceptance from the University of New Mexico. A U.S. visa was the only thing standing in their way.

title: The American Dream, Arriving on Wheels

title: Don't Be Fooled by Top Players; They Do Know Their Openings
description: When a less experienced player meets a highly ranked opponent, he often tries to take the game into less explored channels rather than heavily analyzed opening variations. That seems natural, but it has its drawbacks. The better your adversary, the greater his range of experience. And just because there are modes of play he doesn't use, that's no reason to think he doesn't know them through and through.

title: Solving A Sticky Problem
description: As the use of hair products becomes more commonplace, those who like blow-drying, straightening and hair ironing might find themselves in a sticky wicket as hair tools, sinks and countertops become coated with dried hair spray, gel and the like. Dissolve, a commercial-grade spray cleaner, is formulated to remove tacky product residue from all surfaces, be they brushes or blow-dryers, curling or straightening irons. You will need to spray a soiled surface with the cleaner, wait 30 seconds, and then wipe away the buildup. Dissolve, which has been used by professionals in the hair industry for almost a year, is now available for the first time in consumer-friendly size and packaging ($6.95 for a 16-ounce bottle at Sally Beauty Supply stores).

Both officers were taken to Bellevue Hospital Center and listed in stable condition. The two people in the Hyundai suffered head trauma and were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan. In advertiser-supported cable, Nielsen estimates for the second quarter of the year show that TNT was No. 1 in prime time and Nickelodeon had a lock on the total day. From the beginning of April through the end of June, the most-watched program on cable was TNT's broadcast of the seventh game of the N.B.A.'s Eastern Conference finals (9.15 million), in which the Detroit Pistons beat the Miami Heat. In total viewers for the quarter, TNT was also dominant in its scripted offerings: the premieres of "The Closer" and "Into the West" ranked second and third, respectively. For young viewers, every single show in the quarter's top 20 rankings in the 2-to-11 and 6-to-11 demographics came from Nickelodeon. An audience of 3.06 million 2-to-11-year-olds watched Nickelodeon's "Kids' Choice Awards 2005," broadcast in April: that special topped a list otherwise full of episodes of the channel's "SpongeBob SquarePants" and "The Fairly Oddparents." title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LENNARD, HENRY L.
description: LENNARD--Henry L. June 22, in Venice, Italy. Professor, Columbia University and Berkeley, expert in family studies. Co-author of "The Anatomy of Psychotherapy and Patterns in Human Interaction." He challenged the drug industry in "Mystification and Drug Misuse." With his wife, Suzanne Crowhurst, he created the International Making Cities Liveable Conferences and authored 12 books. Besides his family he had three great loves: Martin Buber, Venice and the movies, especially "Beat the Devil." He will be deeply missed by wife Suzanne, children Erica, Elizabeth and Jonathan, the Meyers family and Elaine Lennard. The service was held on Isola di San Michele. A memorial will be held in New York in the fall.

Paid Notice: Deaths   AMES, HAROLD S.
description: AMES--Harold S. Of Kings Point and Westhampton Beach, NY, passed away Friday evening, July 1, 2005 in North Shore University Hospital after a long illness. Dearly beloved husband and life partner of Dorothy; adoring father of Elizabeth and Allison; father-in-law of Charles Opolinsky; devoted grandfather of Harley Ames Opolinsky; brother of Bernard Roy and the late Renee, Arnold and Milton. Mr. Ames was a leader in the market for non-ferrous speciality metals. In 1958, he founded NonFerrous International Corp., a key supplier of prefabricated aluminum, brass and copper tubing to equipment manufacturers in a variety of industries. A metals industry pioneer in a new era of world trade, Non - Ferrous was among the first to bring European and Japanese metal into the US market. Mr. Ames guided Non-Ferrous as its President and CEO through its 1973 acquisition by the metals division of Mitsubishi North America. He continued as President of Non-Ferrous for nearly a decade after the acquisition. For 26 years, Mr. Ames was the owner of CrossTown Tennis at Fifth Avenue. He was a Founding Director of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center. A passionate supporter of Israel with a lifelong interest in world affairs, Mr. Ames was an officer and founding member of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy. He was a long time active member in the Anti-Defamation League, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, and a contributor to the United Jewish Appeal. For 20 years, he was President of the Board of the Gallery Apartment Condominiums at 32 East 76th Street in NYC. Mr. Ames received his bachelors degree in Economics from NYU. He completed a masters degree and doctoral studies in Economics at the New School for Social Research. An avid tennis player and voracious reader, surrounded by music, books and an adoring family, Dad succeeded in business and in life. His strength and courage inspired his children and all who knew him. A service will be held on Wednesday, July 6, 2005 at 11 AM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, 516-487-9600. The family will receive condolence calls that afternoon 4-8:30 PM at the home of Harold Ames. Friends of Allison Ames can pay their respects the following day, Thursday, July 7 between 12-4 PM or 6-9 PM at the Ames Opolinsky residence. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

Decades of Western aid have done little to ease suffering in Africa -- indeed the situation is worse than ever. Is it time for the West to rethink its aid strategy?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CULLEN, EILEEN GALLAGHER
description: CULLEN--Eileen Gallagher. Died peacefully on July 3, 2005 with her family around her. Beloved wife of Bill, cherished mother of Emmett and Charlie. Beloved daughter of Mary Kay Gallagher and the late John T. Cherished sibling of Katherine, Joanne, J.T., Arthur and Edward. A close confidante to many friends who struggled with cancer. Eileen was very active in her neighborhood association and at her son's school, Poly Prep in Brooklyn. Eileen was an associate broker for Mary Kay Gallagher Real Estate. Eileen's earlier professional career included positions at two prestigious art supply companies as the director of marketing. Calling hours will be Tuesday from 2-5 and 7-9 at the Gallagher residence, 196 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, NY. The Funeral Mass will be on Wednesday, 10 AM, at Holy Innocents RC Church, 279 East 17th Street, Brooklyn. Interment St. Charles Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to (P.M.C. - Jimmy Fund) for Cancer Research, at Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, MA. Donations should be sent to Edward Gallagher at 196 Marlborough Road, Brooklyn, NY 11226.

title: Melding Gravity and Guilt at Live 8
description: LONDON, July 3 - The symmetry was clear between the Group of 8 summit meeting, which begins in Scotland on Wednesday, and Saturday's Live 8 concerts, which were staged to pressure the G-8 leaders on policies affecting Africa. The concerts took place in the eight major industrial countries represented by the group (along with a concert belatedly added in South Africa). And like the G-8 meeting, they hinged on the privileged addressing the problems of the impoverished.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHOLL, TOBY
description: SCHOLL--Toby. Beloved wife of the late Benjamin Scholl. Survived by loving sister Beatrice Schuman. Loving mother of Harvey and wife Paula, Kenneth and wife Toni Scholl and the late Martin Scholl and Matthew Schechter. Cherished grandmother of Michael, Larry and wife Jennifer, Ben and wife Tracey, Frank and wife Shelley, Max and Lauren Scholl. Adored great grandmother of Zachary, Madison and Martin Scholl. The love you shared with your family will be in our hearts forever. Funeral services Monday, 10 AM, Schwartz Brothers - Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, NY, corner of 76th Road.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHATZ, IRVING
description: SHATZ--Irving. 91 years old, died July 2, 2005, in Boca Raton, FL. Graveside service at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Hearing the Declaration Anew
description: What solemnity there is on the Fourth of July usually gathers toward evening as a lead-up to the detonations after dark. It isn't usually a holiday for introspection, not even if the rain is pouring down and the fireworks have fizzled. Most years, the Fourth feels, at its most patriotic, like a day of national boosterism with deep historical roots, a display of the justifiable pride of a proud nation. It's something we enact almost without thinking about it, though no less meaningfully for that.

Paid Notice: Deaths   STERNFELD, EDITH JUDITH
description: STERNFELD--Edith Judith. Of Belle Harbor, NY, and Lake Worth, FL. Although she was 95, she was still full of yearning for life and its experiences. Beloved wife of the late David; deeply cherished mother of Joel and Alan, as well as the late Andrew and Gabriel; loving mother-in-law to Martina and devoted grandmother to Andrew and Gabriella; for the last six years she was a second mother to Kim Seejgat and Kevin Glasgow, and the dearest friend of Theresa Glasgow. Artist, sculptor and for several years Horticultural Chairman of the Shore Garden Club of Neponsit and Belle Harbor, she made drawings until her last day. Her eyes were bright and her spirit far brighter--we still see them. Funeral services Tuesday, July 5, at 1:30 pm, at Riverside Chapel, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREUND, VIVIAN
description: FREUND--Vivian. We extend heartfelt condolences to Robert Freund, Lilly Mansbach, her six children and many grandchildren on the loss of his wife, her daughter, their mother and grandmother. A warm and kind person, her positive attitude and modest demeanor made her a role model to those who had the good fortune of knowing her. A Silver Founder of the Medical Center together with Robert, her outstretched hand of kindness touched many. May the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. title: A Mini-'Magic Flute'? Mozart Would Approve
description: When Julie Taymor's production of Mozart's "Zauberflte" opened at the Metropolitan Opera last fall, officials within the company sensed that, despite complaints from some critics, including this one, they had a crowd pleaser on their hands. Here was a spectacle that crowded the stage with Ms. Taymor's trademark menagerie of enormous puppets, exotic animal figures, flying creatures and magic tricks. All those parents who were making multiple trips with their youngsters to "The Lion King" now had another Taymor show to choose from. And Mozart's score beats Elton John's with a stick.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, T. GORDON
description: YOUNG--T. Gordon. On July 2, 2005 at the age of 88, formerly of Briarcliff Manor and Ossining, NY. Retired Director and Vice President of Hospital for Special Surgery, NYC for 35 years. He served as President of the Greater New York Hospital Association, member and President of the Board of Directors of Mary Manning Walsh, NYC. Member of the Community Board of Phelps Memorial Hospital, Sleepy Hollow, NY. He was a WW II veteran and alumnus of New York University. Survived by daughter Judy L. Young, daughters-inlaw Margaret Chalmers and Rose Mary Young and granddaughter Elizabeth Young. Predeceased by his wife of 61 years Nola I. Young and son Roger Young. Reposing Waterbury and Kelly Funeral Home, Route 9, Ossining on Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Church of the Magdalene, Bedford Road, Pocantico Hills, on Wednesday at 10 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Contributions to Mary Manning Walsh Home, NYC.

title: Corrections

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Shot By Police
description: A man was shot in the arm yesterday morning after he pointed a gun at officers responding to an emergency call about a domestic dispute in Bellerose, the police said. Two officers arrived at a basement apartment on 238th Street about 10 a.m. and found a man holding a gun, the police said. The officers ordered the man to drop the weapon and shot him once in the right arm after he aimed the gun at them, law enforcement authorities said. The man, who was not identified, was taken to Long Island Jewish Medical Center, where he was in stable condition yesterday. Neither officer was hurt. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Mexico Braces for Next Move by Elusive Leader of Zapatista Rebels

The masked rebels who usually oversee Oventic have been called to a meeting in the jungles of southern Mexico.

"I can still hit better than 50 percent of you bums," he called out to members of his former team, the Old Timers, as they took turns smacking spaldeens through the legs of their opponents, the Young Bucks. Mr. Ballard, who is 86, was sitting in a lawn chair on the sidelines of the stickball court on 108th Street in East Harlem, and his rollicking banter served to keep the players on their toes. "What a beautiful game," he added, almost to himself. "There's nothing else like it."

Rail tanker cars filled with deadly chemicals pass over the bridge, at Second Street and E Street SW, on their journeys up and down the East Coast. title: Spacecraft Hits Passing Comet, Just as Planned

title: Arts, Briefly; Bonaduce Off the Air
description: Danny Bonaduce, who played the wisecracking Danny Partridge on the 1970's hit television show "The Partridge Family" and has maintained a television and radio career as an adult, has been released from his contract with KYSR (98.7 FM), an adult contemporary station in Los Angeles, after six years, Radio and Records, a trade publication, reported. Mr. Bonaduce, 45, had been a co-host of a morning show at that station, owned by Clear Channel, and had recently returned after a month in rehab. No reason for his departure was given. His co-host on the morning show, Jamie White, will remain at the station. PHIL SWEETLAND
