title: Metro Briefing | New York: Three Arrested In Fatal Crash
description: Three young men joyriding in a stolen sports utility vehicle slammed into several parked cars in Harlem early Sunday morning, killing a Bronx schoolteacher, Diane Newton, 41, who was sitting in a car waiting for her fianc, the police and her fianc said. The S.U.V., traveling north on Seventh Avenue, struck her car and two unoccupied cars between 125th and 126th Streets, the police said. The driver, John Duncan, of Harlem, was charged with second-degree manslaughter, criminally negligent homicide and unauthorized use of a vehicle. Two men who were with him, Jamal Jones, 19, also of Harlem, and Melvin Prince, 18, of the Bronx, were charged with unauthorized use of a vehicle. The police said that Mr. Jones had taken his stepfather's S.U.V. without permission. In Brooklyn, Ivan Rodriguez, 36, was charged with driving while intoxicated and reckless driving after his motorcycle struck a 72-year-old woman on 47th Street between Fourth and Fifth Avenues about 8:45 on Sunday night, the police said. The woman was in critical condition in Lutheran Medical Center. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Dagestan Police Officials Dismissed
description: Several police chiefs in the southern Russian republic of Dagestan were dismissed from their posts amid concerns about the republic's stability. Ten Russian special forces troops were killed in a bombing on Friday in the republic's capital, Makhachkala. An Islamic group with ties to Chechnya's separatists claimed responsibility and promised more attacks. Dagestan, situated at Chechnya's eastern border, has slid perceptibly in recent months toward a full-scale insurgency, with several reports of violence each week. Interfax quoted the republic's interior minister as saying that attackers had targeted the police and that "police response to the terrorists has been inadequate." C.J. Chivers (NYT)

Paid Notice: Deaths   AMES, HAROLD S.
description: AMES--Harold S. Of Kings Point and Westhampton Beach, NY, passed away Friday evening, July 1, 2005 in North Shore University Hospital after a long illness. Dearly beloved husband and life partner of Dorothy; adoring father of Elizabeth and Allison; father-in-law of Charles Opolinsky; devoted grandfather of Harley Ames Opolinsky; brother of Bernard Roy and the late Renee, Arnold and Milton. Mr. Ames was a leader in the market for non-ferrous speciality metals. In 1958, he founded NonFerrous International Corp., a key supplier of prefabricated aluminum, brass and copper tubing to equipment manufacturers in a variety of industries. A metals industry pioneer in a new era of world trade, Non - Ferrous was among the first to bring European and Japanese metal into the US market. Mr. Ames guided Non-Ferrous as its President and CEO through its 1973 acquisition by the metals division of Mitsubishi North America. He continued as President of Non-Ferrous for nearly a decade after the acquisition. For 26 years, Mr. Ames was the owner of CrossTown Tennis at Fifth Avenue. He was a Founding Director of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center. A passionate supporter of Israel with a lifelong interest in world affairs, Mr. Ames was an officer and founding member of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy. He was a long time active member in the Anti-Defamation League, the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, and a contributor to the United Jewish Appeal. For 20 years, he was President of the Board of the Gallery Apartment Condominiums at 32 East 76th Street in NYC. Mr. Ames received his bachelors degree in Economics from NYU. He completed a masters degree and doctoral studies in Economics at the New School for Social Research. An avid tennis player and voracious reader, surrounded by music, books and an adoring family, Dad succeeded in business and in life. His strength and courage inspired his children and all who knew him. A service will be held on Wednesday, July 6, 2005 at 11 AM at Riverside Nassau-North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY, 516-487-9600. The family will receive condolence calls that afternoon 4-8:30 PM at the home of Harold Ames. Friends of Allison Ames can pay their respects the following day, Thursday, July 7 between 12-4 PM or 6-9 PM at the Ames Opolinsky residence. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or the National Multiple Sclerosis Society.

description: The Israeli police said they had arrested an 18-year-old Israeli, Shimson Sitrin, who was suspected of throwing rocks at a Palestinian teenager who had already been knocked unconscious in an assault caught on video. The clash took place Wednesday in the Gaza Strip after right-wing Israelis entered a Palestinian enclave and occupied two abandoned homes. title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fallout From Prince Harry's Test
description: A labor tribunal rejected charges that Prince Harry, third in line to the throne, cheated in art examinations in 2002 at the prestigious Eton College. But the tribunal found that Sarah Forsyth, 30, left, the teacher who made the allegation, had been wrongfully dismissed because Eton College had not handled her firing "objectively." Ms. Forsyth secretly tape-recorded a conversation with Prince Harry to seek evidence that he cheated. The tribunal said the recording was "an abuse of the position of trust in the pupil-teacher relationship." Eton College said it would not pay compensation to Ms. Forsyth. Prince Harry, 20, is now in officer training at the Sandhurst military academy. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPAR, HARRY
description: SPAR--Harry, 94. Died on July 2, 2005. A kind, intelligent and gentle man who enjoyed life. Much loved by his wife Amelia and his late wife Gertrude. Beloved father of Marianne and Harvey Bernstein, Arlene and Peter Topol and the late Herbert Spar. Devoted stepfather and grandfather of Stewart and Ann Arbeit and children Karen and Rachel. Adored grandfather of Jodi and Robert Rosenthal, Stacey and Philip Malakoff, Bradford and Mira Bernstein, Lance and Sheri Topol and Joshua Spar. Cherished great-grandfather of nine.

title: Corruption Hampers Mexican Police in Border Drug War
description: MATAMOROS, Mexico - A crooked cop is the oldest story in the book in Mexico. But this country has been forced to re-examine its police as it struggles against a devastating crime wave that in the last six months has taken more than 600 lives.

title: Test for Security Efforts: Next Harry Potter Book
description: The security plans are in place, the delivery efforts are under way and lawyers are standing by in case any copies of "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" go astray before 12:01 a.m. on July 16, the official time of release for the latest installment in the J.K. Rowling series.

title: Plotting to Save the Structure of Those Aging Bones
description: Osteoporosis is a serious and costly disease. Nearly 30million women and 14million men in the United States already have it or are heading toward it. The numbers continue to rise as the population ages, especially now that far fewer women are taking estrogen, which protects against postmenopausal bone loss.

title: Private Spy and Public Spouse Live at Center of Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, July 1 - For nearly two years, the investigation into the leak of a covert C.I.A. officer's name has unfolded clamorously in the nation's capital, with partisan brawling on talk shows, prosecutors interviewing President Bush and top White House officials, and the imminent prospect that reporters could go to jail for contempt of court.

title: Powerful Issues Shadow Orioles' Aging Sluggers
description: SAMMY SOSA lost his voice and his neck.

title: Regional alliance calls for date of U.S.-led anti-terrorist force withdrawal
Briefly: Sibneft move feeds rumor of sale
2 Days After L.I. Crash, Mother Tells of 'Brutal' Loss
description: Nothing prepared the silent cluster of television and newspaper reporters for Jennifer Flynn as she rose to the lectern yesterday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, N.Y. It was surprising enough that Ms. Flynn, the mother of 7-year-old Katie Flynn, wanted to speak publicly only two days after Katie was killed in an accident that the police say was caused by a drunken driver.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,738 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: A Park, Not a Skyscraper
description: To the Editor:

title: Roundup: Furyk holds off Woods for victory
French Minister Converts Crisis Into Fuel for a Presidential Race
description: LA COURNEUVE, France - Defending his headline-grabbing style, France's would-be president, Nicolas Sarkozy, on a late June day faced a roomful of impatient, sometimes angry residents of this poor Parisian suburb where he had come championing law and order after an 11-year-old boy was killed by stray gunfire.

title: Seeking First to Reinvent the Sports Arena, and Then Brooklyn
description: Frank Gehry's new design for a 21-acre corridor of high-rise towers anchored by the 19,000-seat Nets arena in Brooklyn may be the most important urban development plan proposed in New York City in decades. If it is approved, it will radically alter the Brooklyn skyline, reaffirming the borough's emergence as a legitimate cultural rival to Manhattan.

title: An Author Indulges His Inner Twain
description: NATCHEZ, Miss., July 1 - The first night out was fitful, scary even. After putting in at Helena, Ark., the homemade raft got caught up in the wash of the massive towboats that surrounded it on the Mississippi. The craft bounced along in the inky black, and then searing beams of light from the towboats began to strafe it, the captains wanting to see what manner of contraption was before them. The ragtag crew slept in terrified shifts, dodging the tugs and avoiding a ledge formed by a dike that threatened to pitch them into the mud, water and mayhem.

title: Mohawk to Buy Belgian Floor Products Firm
description: Mohawk Industries, one of the nation's largest carpet makers, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Unilin Group of Belgium for $2.2 billion euros ($2.6 billion) to expand its share of the market for laminate flooring products.

title: In Seeking Unocal, Chevron Ruffles an Asian Partner
description: The last thing Chevron wanted when it made its $16.8 billion offer for Unocal back in April was to be pitted in a takeover battle against the Chinese government.

title: For the Mets, It's One Game in July
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 - The Mets were as much a prop in this Independence Day celebration as the Air Force Singing Sergeants who performed the national anthem and the military helicopters that flew over Robert F. Kennedy Stadium before the game.

title: O'Connor Leap Moved Women Up the Bench
description: When President Ronald Reagan decided to nominate Sandra Day O'Connor as the first woman ever to the Supreme Court in 1981, he did not have a lot of other women to choose from. The bench, one might say, was not deep.

title: Sleeping With More Than One Eye Open
description: Wiring the Molecules

title: Armstrong: The 2005 Edition
Armstrong Captures the Yellow Jersey
description: BLOIS, France, July 5 - Lance Armstrong captured the yellow jersey of the Tour de France's leader in dramatic fashion today, when the rival who was wearing it crashed minutes before the end of a long team time trial and finished nearly a minute and a half behind his teammates.

title: National Lampoon's devolution?
Hank Stram, 82, a Football Innovator and a Hall of Fame Coach, Dies
description: Hank Stram, the innovative Hall of Fame coach who took the Kansas City Chiefs to the first Super Bowl, in 1967, and coached them to a Super Bowl victory in 1970, died yesterday at a hospital in Covington, La., near New Orleans. He was 82. The cause was complications of diabetes, his son Dale said.

title: Malaysia breaks from its old ways, starting with the banking sector
A crisis for journalism?
Hazards: Give an Error to That Thin Catcher's Mitt
description: Forget about the brushback pitch streaking toward the batter's head. It's the poor catcher people should worry about.

title: On Saturn, a Spacecraft Is Finding New Worlds
description: Of all the planets in the Sun's family, the most spectacular seen from afar is Saturn, a sphere of ethereal pastels encircled by shimmering rings of ice. Even up close and under repeated scrutiny by the Cassini spacecraft for a full year now, Saturn does not disappoint. The new familiarity becomes the ringed planet and its host of outlying moons of all sizes and aspects, and excites the mission's attending scientists.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10:30 P.M. (MTV) THE 70'S HOUSE -- Series premiere. Now here's a reality-competition show about young people living together that may go beyond flirtations and snarkiness. Tonight 12 participants (above) agree to give up the technology and other joys of 2005 to live in a world without cellphones, e-mail, iPods or even movie rentals. They will also be forced to wear bell-bottoms and will learn how many things come in avocado green.

title: In Reading Bush on Court, Words Don't Always Help
description: WASHINGTON, July 3 - In the days just before his first inauguration, in 2001, George Bush gave a brief insight into what he looks for in crucial appointments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPANIER, IRVING L., ESQ.
description: SPANIER--Irving L., Esq. ("Coach," "Pop"), 93, passed July 3, 2005. Wonderful husband of Elaine, loving father, grandfather, great grandfather, brother. Information with Gutterman's 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, ISIDOR
description: GREEN--Isidor. Of New York and Palm Beach, 93, died on July 3 after a brief illness. He was born in Milowka, Poland on September 23, 1911. With his beloved wife of 61 years, Marysia he escaped the atrocities of the Holocaust. He moved to the United States in 1947 and established with his family a successful import and export business. He built a beautiful life, filled with much joy and love. He was a longtime supporter of Akim and Yad Vashem. Along with his wife, he is survived by his children, Dr. Jacqueline Green (Dr. John Grossman), Dr. Bert Green (Alexandra Brookshire) and five adoring grandchldren, Mamie, Sophia and William Green, Aggie and Lucy Grossman. Services are at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, Forest Hills, on July 5 at 11 AM with burial to follow at Beth Israel Cemeter in NJ. Shiva will be at the family home.

title: SingTel profits by casting a wide net
Prosecutor Urges Judge to Jail Reporters Who Refused to Testify
description: Matthew Cooper of Time magazine and Judith Miller of The New York Times should be jailed for refusing to cooperate with a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the identity of a covert C.I.A. operative, the special prosecutor in the case said in court papers filed today.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a British scientific panel's finding that carbon dioxide in the atmosphere was turning the oceans more acidic referred incompletely to the pH scale of acidity and alkalinity. It measures concentration of hydrogen ions, not hydrogen. (The scale runs from 1, the most acidic, with the highest concentration of hydrogen ions, to 14, the most alkaline, with almost no hydrogen ions. Ocean water today is somewhat alkaline, at 8.1; water near the surface is expected to be as low as 7.7 by 2100, the report said.)

title: A Bolt From the Blue (the Bad Kind)
description: AFTER a daylong planning meeting with the heads of our cable channels, I chartered a small boat for a private cruise of New York Harbor. While we sipped our drinks at Chelsea Piers, I noticed that the skies were darkening. "Is everything O.K.?" I asked the captain of the vessel, the Pearl Necklace, just before our group of nine boarded.

title: In Germany, the Jobless Work to Keep Their Benefits
description: MINDEN, Germany - In January, Benjamin Dath's eight-month search for a job in northwest Germany led him back to where he started -- the unemployment office, which ordered him to paint classrooms at a local school for just 1.50 euros ($1.89) an hour.

title: Presidents, Picking Justices, Can Have Backfires
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 - In July 1902, confident that he had found a judge opposed to "big railroad men and other members of large corporations," Theodore Roosevelt named Oliver Wendell Holmes Jr. as his first appointee to the Supreme Court, delighted with a choice that their fellow Republican, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge of Massachusetts, called "our kind right through."

title: New York Makes Buttonholing the Newest Olympic Sport
description: SINGAPORE, Tuesday, July 5 - They have matched Olympic delegates beer for beer, downed Asian pizza, exploited their celebrity power and memorized unfamiliar faces from around the globe. Throughout the final 48 hours, New York's Olympic supporters were unable to slow down their frenetic push to bring the 2012 Games to the United States.

title: Bahrain's top diplomat shot in Baghdad
Paid Notice: Deaths   HARRIS, BERTHA ANNE
description: HARRIS--Bertha Anne, novelist, essayist, teacher, editor and literary feminist, died, May 22, 2005 in New York at the age of 67. Her novels, Catching Saradove (1969) and Confessions of Cherubino (1972) were published by Harcourt, Brace. Her third novel, Lover, was published by Daughters Company, Inc. Lover was re-printed by New York University Press in 1993. At the time of her death she was completing her fourth novel, a comedy, Mi Contra Fa. Born in Fayetteville, NC, December 17, 1936, she was the only child of John Homles Harris and Mary Zeleka (Jones) Harris. After graduating from the Women's College of University of North Carolina in 1959, she came to Manhattan and spent her summers in Westport, MA. She was the companion of the late Camilla Clay Smith for twenty-four years, and is survived by a daughter Jennifer Harris Wyland, Bourne mouth Dorset, England. Mass of Christian Burial will be on Thursday, July 7, at 1:30 pm, Holy Name of Jesus Church, 207 West 96th St, Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Help for Africa: Action, Not Words (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Dire Warning About Bird Flu
description: United Nations health experts warned at a conference that chances to contain the avian flu virus before it possibly becomes a global pandemic were dwindling. "We are at a tipping point," said Dr. Shigeru Omi, a regional director for the World Health Organization. "Either we can reverse this situation or things will get out of hand." Two years after the virus first emerged in Asia, cases among humans are on the rise. Last year, a total of 44 cases were reported in humans, but 64 such cases were reported in just the first six months of this year, Dr. Omi said. So far, the virus has led to the deaths of more than 50 people and 140 million birds, officials said. Evelyn Rusli (IHT)

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Walls Off Its Corner of Baghdad, Annoying Some Neighbors
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 4 - Iraqis call it Assur, the Fence. In English everyone calls it the Wall, and in the past two years it has grown and grown until it has become an almost continuous rampart, at least 10 miles in circumference, around the seat of American power in Baghdad.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDLAND, LOUIS N.
description: FRIEDLAND--Louis N., 92, died peacefully on June 29th with his adoring family around him. Beloved husband of the late Billie, cherished father of Joanne Friedland Roberts and Eric Friedland, devoted grandfather of Lola Beatrice Friedland Roberts, loving father-in-law of Alyson Denny and uncle of George Lerner. Retired Chairman of MCA-TV and former President of the National Hemophilia Association, Lou was an industry pioneer, esteemed mentor and precious friend to many. Funeral services Tuesday, July 5th, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in Lou's honor to the Hemophilia Association of New York (HANY), 104 East 40th St., Suite 506, NYC 10016.

title: An Endangered Act
description: The Endangered Species Act of 1973 is far and away the most controversial of all the landmark environmental statutes enacted during the Nixon years. It is especially so among those libertarians and property owners who think that commercial development is unduly restricted by the mandate to protect not only plants and animals, but also the habitats essential to their survival. The law is up for reauthorization again this year, and the pressures to weaken it are great. There are ways to streamline the law and make it less litigious that would not come at the expense of its core values and purpose.

title: The Case of the Shrinking Lotus
description: Humans are the culprits, it seems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARBUS, SARAH
description: HARBUS--Sarah. On July 2, 2005. Loving wife of Meyer, mother of Richard, Lorna, and Fredric, grandmother and great-grandmother. Sarah was was a wonderful homemaker, and a lover of music, art, theater, dance, books and travel; she joined her husband in the fight for social justice. She was warm and kind always and had many friends. Sarah is now with her dearest Meyer forever. We will miss her and Dad very much. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

description: "It's a little bit in the guinea pig stage," Dr. Burton A. Cohen said. "I've only tried it on four people. Are you interested?"

description: WASHINGTON, July 4 - As President Bush prepared for a trip to Europe, advocacy groups continued mobilizing on Monday for an intense campaign to try to influence his selection of a successor to Justice Sandra Day O'Connor and sway any ensuing confirmation fight.

title: Fireworks Crowd in Washington Provides Test of Evacuation Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 4 - After the last of the fireworks expired over the Mall, thousands of people rushed to their cars on Monday night to beat the traffic heading out of the city. Many of them also happened to take part in Washington's largest evacuation drill since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (11) BEAUTY AND THE GEEK -- Season finale. Out of the 14 original contestants (above), only two mismatched couples (a gorgeous but possibly not brilliant woman and a brilliant but not necessarily gorgeous man) are left, each vying for a $250,000 prize. The women have endured spelling bees, car repairs and rocket science. The men have learned to dance, get a stranger's telephone number and give a back massage. And they've all gone camping. Now, the final challenge.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Officer In Murder-Suicide
description: A parole officer fatally shot her husband, then herself, in their Brooklyn apartment yesterday, the police said. The officer, Burnell Brooks, 47, shot her husband, Reginald Carrington, 53, a teacher, at least four times before shooting herself in the head, investigators said. They said the couple were not known to have a history of domestic violence. Ms. Brooks's son found the bodies when he returned home about 5 a.m., the police said. They said that in addition to her pistol, found next to her body, Ms. Brooks left a handwritten will in the apartment, on Milford Street. Abeer Allam (NYT)

title: Ireland's Economic Model
description: To the Editor:

title: No Movement on Either Side to Resolve Minnesota Shutdown
description: The first partial government shutdown over a budget dispute in Minnesota's 147-year history, entering its sixth day today, has kept 9,000 of the 48,000 state employees home as lawmakers remain divided along party lines over financing for education and health care.

title: Briefly: Preliminary tally shows opposition leading vote
Paid Notice: Deaths   KAY, SHANA
description: KAY--Shana. 19, beloved daughter of Jane and Randy Kay, sister to Jared and granddaughter to Gladys Bernstein. She passed on July 3rd after a sudden and quick illness. Shana had a verve for life that was readily apparent to all who knew her. She loved being a student at University of Wisconsin, a counselor at Camp Kinder Ring and being with our close knit family. You are missed so terribly. Till we meet again. We love you very much. Mom and Dad KAY--Shana. My shining star, in my heart forever. Love and kisses. Nanala

title: What music might look like as modern art
Africa in the Balance
description: Eight men are about to decide the future of hundreds of millions of people in sub-Saharan Africa. The choices President Bush and his fellow leaders make this week in Scotland will help determine whether more than two million children under 5 will keep dying every year of diseases that can be easily and cheaply treated, whether 40 million young people will still be unable to go to school and whether 300 million Africans will continue to lack access to clean water.

title: Paris and London in final of 2012 vote
Attack at Temple in India Leaves 6 Dead; Sectarian Strife Is Feared
description: NEW DELHI, July 5 - A brazen attack on India's best-known tinderbox of Hindu-Muslim strife, the heavily fortified Hindu temple compound in the northern town of Ayodhya, left six gunmen dead on Tuesday and raised the specter of a fresh bout of sectarian tension.

title: Bosnian Police Find 2 Bombs Near Memorial
description: SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 5 - The police found two bombs on Tuesday close to the memorial center for the Srebrenica massacre, three days before ceremonies for the 10th anniversary of the atrocities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ENGLANDER, BETTY
description: ENGLANDER -- Betty, of Manhattan, passed away peacefully on July 5, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Philip Englander and the devoted and loving mother of Robert Englander and Rita Sands. Cherished grandmother of Adam, Alex and Andrew Englander and of Jessica and Hillary Sands. Loving and devoted mother-in-law of Nancy Englander and Jeffrey Sands and loving grandmother-in-law of Gretchen Englander. Devoted to and adored by her family, she lived a full, rich life and enjoyed a lifelong passion for contract bridge, for which she earned the title Life Master.

description: Matthew Cooper of Time magazine and Judith Miller of The New York Times should be jailed for refusing to cooperate with a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the identity of a covert C.I.A. operative, the special prosecutor in the case said in court papers filed yesterday.

title: Schools in Thailand Under Ethnic Siege
description: YALA, Thailand - On the weekends now, the military firing range here is crowded with teachers -- in shifts of 50 -- trying out their pistols, an essential new accessory in a place where teaching school has become one of the most dangerous professions.

description: Even for a Wall Street legend, it pays to be average.

title: Global UN strategy directed at bird flu

description: When Robert Marc first toured the raw space in Manhattan's trendy meatpacking district that he was considering for an office, he certainly didn't need sunglasses. The 6,000 square feet in the artsy Milk Studios building resembled an industrial cave.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Survives Fall To Tracks
description: A 38-year-old man fell onto the subway tracks at the Union Square station and was shocked by the third rail, but survived, the police said. The man, who was not identified, lost his balance and fell from the southbound platform of the 4, 5, and 6 trains shortly before 7 p.m., the authorities said. His head became wedged against the third rail, a police official said. He was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, where he was in stable condition, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: EBay Crackdown on Live 8 Pirates Responding to complaints from the recording industry, eBay said yesterday that it had begun removing illegal DVD copies of Saturday's international Live 8 concerts from its Web site, Reuters reported. Although the 10 globe-spanning pop concerts were free to live audiences that totaled more than a million, reports in England said EMI had paid millions of dollars for the rights to release the official DVD of the event, organized by Sir Bob Geldof, right, to pressure world leaders meeting in Scotland to focus on poverty relief. David Martin, director of antipiracy for the British Phonographic Industry, said: "There are too many people out there who believe music is for stealing, regardless of the wishes of artists and the people who invest in them. Sadly we are not at all surprised by this incident." Some of the pirated DVD's were on sale within 24 hours of the end of the concerts and were attracting bids as high as $31 each.

title: Bush Urges Civility in Debate Over Supreme Court Vacancy
description: COPENHAGEN, July 6 - President Bush urged the Senate today not to listen "to the special interest groups, particularly those on the extremes" that are already engaged in a heated battle over the coming nomination to the Supreme Court, and he pledged that he would not screen out candidates solely on where they stand on divisive social issues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, SING, SI
description: SCHWARTZ--Sing-Si. Born October 20, 1954. Son of Diana Kan Schwartz and the late Paul Schwartz. Died in his sleep July 3, 2005. He was a photographer and a computer consultant for Apple Computers. A memorial services will be held at the National Arts Club, Gramercy Park South, Wednesday, July 6th, 6PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the National Arts Club, Sing-Si Schwartz Memorial Photography Fund.

description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 5 - When the Ohio State basketball team upset top-ranked Illinois on March 6 to foil the Illini's bid for an undefeated season, Buckeyes fans stormed the court and celebrated as if their team had just won the national title.

title: Unofficial Berlin Wall memorial is torn down
Paid Notice: Deaths   FLYNN, REV. JOSEPH P.
description: FLYNN--Rev. Joseph P., 87, on July 3, 2005 in Manhattan. A priest of The Paulist Fathers; born and raised in Manhattan. Beloved brother of the late John Flynn and Sr. Loretta Anne Flynn, SC; survived by his brother Michael Flynn. During sixty-one years as a priest, he served with Paulist ministries in Washington, Boston, Los Angeles, Morgantown, Berkeley, Tucson and New York. Viewing at the Paulist Fathers' Motherhouse, 415 West 59th St., Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9. Funeral Liturgy in the Church of St.Paul the Apostle, Columbus Ave at 60th St, Thursday, 10 o'clock. Burial immediately following at Mount Paul Cemetery, Oak Ridge, NJ.

title: Currencies: Investors take profits on recent dollar rally
Home Sweet Office Tower
description: DALLAS - The condo and apartment conversion craze has hit a wall here -- a sleek corporate wall of smoked glass and cheap steel girding.

title: Johnson Comes Through on Short Rest for Yanks
description: There are bad days at the office, and there are days like the one the Yankees inflicted on the Baltimore Orioles yesterday.

title: Soy? Wasabi? Make Mine Frozen
description: CALIFORNIA DOES NOT HAVE A CALIFORNIA LOUIE'S but Columbus Avenue does. The storefront, at 527 (86th Street), sells only frozen soft-serve confections made with soy milk, which seem to be pleasing the young group above. The vanilla flavor has a slight but acceptable soy taste to it; in the chocolate and peanut butter desserts ($3.25 a single serving), you can hardly tell it's there.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Request for Penalties Against U.S.
description: Brazil asked the World Trade Organization for permission to apply trade sanctions worth $2.9 billion against the United States for its failure to comply with the trade body's recent ruling ordering Washington to do away with cotton subsidies. In its request, Brazil complained that the Bush administration balked at eliminating its cotton marketing program, which compensates exporters and millers for buying high-price American cotton. But shortly after Brazil filed the complaint, Mike Johanns, the United States agriculture secretary, issued a statement saying that the Bush administration would send legislation to Congress proposing to end the export subsidies. If Congress votes against the bill, Brazilian officials said they could retaliate by raising import duties on American goods or by disregarding intellectual property agreements with the United States. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: James Stockdale, Perot's Running Mate in '92, Dies at 81
description: Vice Adm. James B. Stockdale, a highly decorated Navy pilot who inspired fellow prisoners of war in North Vietnam and later ran for vice president as H. Ross Perot's running mate in 1992, died on Tuesday in Coronado, Calif. He was 81.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MANNING, JOSEPH V.
description: MANNING--Joseph V. of Solana Beach, CA, passed away peacefully at home with his family at his side on Sunday, July 3, 2005. The flight engineers of American Airlines are indebted to him for his 30 years of dedicated service as president of the Flight Engineers Union. There will be a private family burial service on July 6. He was a devoted husband to his wife, Grace, and a loving father to his children Jerry, Gail, Mike and David. We will keep his memory in our hearts forever. Donations may be made in his name to San Diego Hospice, 1-866-688-1600.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Joseph Nocera column on Saturday, about the career of the lawyer William S. Lerach, who has made a living suing companies on behalf of shareholders, omitted a phrase. It said that Mr. Lerach declined to comment on a Justice Department investigation into his dealings with some former clients. In addition, the column should have noted that Mr. Lerach and his former firm, Milberg Weiss Bershad & Schulman, through separate representatives, denied wrongdoing.

title: The Secret Life Of Mayo
description: THOSE of us who grew up thinking that the chief role of mayonnaise was to moisten canned tuna -- and this is probably the majority of the population of the United States -- see a world of possibilities when we realize that mayonnaise is a real sauce, one you can serve alongside a variety of foods.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Every contact we have with these folks is 'stay on message, stay on purpose.' The extremism of language, if there is to be any, should be demonstrably on the other side."

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on June 25 about Nahum Sarna, a biblical scholar, misstated his role in the Jewish Publication Society's translation of the Hebrew Bible. He was a principal translator of the third section of the Bible, known as the Writings -- not the principal translator and editor of the Torah, the first section. (The Torah was translated by another committee, headed by Harry Orlinsky, and the second section, the Prophets, by a committee headed by H.L. Ginsberg.)

Cherished grandmother of Steven and Jenny, Deena Sadowski, Jay, Brian and Glenn. Great grandmother of Alexandra and Nicholas. Beloved by all who were considered to be her friends.

The little confusion involved the yellow jersey itself - and Armstrong's decision not to wear it.

description: WASHINGTON, July 5 - The American Psychological Association, responding to reports that some of its members may have advised officials on how to conduct harsh interrogations of detainees, issued a report Tuesday telling its members of the ethical dangers of such activities.

Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, ISIDOR
description: GREEN--Isidor. Of New York and Palm Beach, 93, died on July 3 after a brief illness. He was born in Milowka, Poland on September 23, 1911. With his beloved wife of 61 years, Marysia he escaped the atrocities of the Holocaust. He moved to the United States in 1947 and established with his family a successful import and export business. He built a beautiful life, filled with much joy and love. He was a longtime supporter of Akim and Yad Vashem. Along with his wife, he is survived by his children, Dr. Jacqueline Green (Dr. John Grossman), Dr. Bert Green (Alexandra Brookshire) and five adoring grandchldren, Mamie, Sophia and William Green, Aggie and Lucy Grossman. Shiva will be at the family home.

Paid Notice: Deaths   HARLEY, RUTH STRATTON
description: HARLEY--Ruth Stratton. The Adelphi University Alumni Association expresses its deep sadness at the passing of our friend and distinguished alumna Ruth Stratton Harley '24, '50 (Hon.). Ruth generously gave her time and energy to support the University and her fellow alumni. In celebration of her life and legacy, the Alumni Association annually presents the Ruth Stratton Harley Distinguished Alumni Achievement Award to alumni who live by her example of tireless service to the University community. We will profoundly miss our friend and trusted advisor. Martha C. Stark M.B.A. '86 President, Adelphi University Alumni Association HARLEY -- Ruth Stratton. Adelphi University deeply mourns the passing of Dean Emerita Ruth Stratton Harley '24, '50 (Hon.) at the age of 103. A distinguished and dedicated dean of women for 38 years, she shared her knowledge, vision, and commitment to excellence with the Adelphi community as a student, administrator, and alumna. Her legacy will live on in the hearts and minds of students, faculty, alumni, and administrators. Our thoughts are with her nephew Frank. Robert A. Scott, President Michael J. Campbell '65, Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: Briefly: British retail sales drop slows
OFF THE MENU
description: Guido Venitucci, above, the general manager at Arte Cafe on West 73rd Street, always wanted an Italian grocery store in the neighborhood, where he also lives. So, with the owners of the restaurant he has opened Arte Around the Corner, 274 Columbus Avenue (73rd Street), a food shop and espresso bar stocked with pasta, oil, vinegar, cured meats, cheeses and herbs. Prepared foods, including lovely blueberry muffins, panini and a delectable caramelized pine nut and rosemary tart, are the work of Arte Cafe's chef, Andrea Luz Bergquist, above: (212)875-2195.

Risky Mortgage Business
description: By any measure, the housing boom -- now almost four years old -- is one for the record books. A recent study by The Wall Street Journal found that in 55 places, housing prices had risen by at least 30 percent in three years, after inflation. Together, those 55 markets now account for an unprecedented 40 percent of all housing value in the United States.

description: The hurricane season is again rocking global oil markets at a time of tight supplies. Crude oil prices surged to above $61 a barrel today after a tropical storm curbed oil production in the Gulf of Mexico and forced the evacuation of nearly 100 offshore facilities.

description: SAN FRANCISCO - LIKE many people who think about what goes on their plate, the chef Traci Des Jardins wrestles with the question of meat.

title: Around Ruined Zimbabwe, Neighbors Circle Wagons
description: LILONGWE, Malawi - As leaders of the Group of 8 industrialized nations meet in Scotland, African countries will press them to get involved in the fight against poverty. But when the Western nations asked African leaders to take action against Zimbabwe's forced uprooting of its poorest citizens, they were told to mind their own business.

title: Gunmen Ambush 2 Muslim Envoys in Iraqi Capital
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 5 - Gunmen ambushed the senior Bahraini and Pakistani diplomats in separate attacks as they drove through the capital on Tuesday, spurring Pakistan to announce the withdrawal of its ambassador from Iraq.

description: Medtronic, the manufacturer of heart pacemakers, settled a patent-infringement suit yesterday, after Smiths Medical of London agreed to pay for the use of Medtronic's insulin-pump technology.

title: Two Views of Baltimore Compete for Public Money
description: BALTIMORE, July 5 - Hardly anybody lives on this blighted block in East Baltimore anymore. On a steamy Friday morning, a few people mill about outside the two row houses that still have life left in them. All the rest of the houses on this block of Bethel Street are boarded shells.

title: Meanwhile: Kenneth L. Woodward
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Retail Sales Slip Again
description: Sales at British retailers declined for a third month in June, increasing the need for the Bank of England to trim interest rates to help revive consumer spending, the British Retail Consortium said. Sales in stores open at least a year fell 0.5 percent compared with June 2004, the lobby group said. The drop followed a 2.4 percent slide in May and a 4.7 percent drop in April. The highest interest rates among the Group of 7 nations, a slowing property market and oil prices close to $60 a barrel have made British consumers more reluctant to spend. The Bank of England begins its two-day meeting on rates today and will announce its decision tomorrow.

title: Generic Diabetes Drug Cleared for Sale
description: Barr Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had received final federal approval to sell a generic version of a diabetes drug owned by Ferring and licensed to Sanofi-Aventis, clearing it for sale after a patent dispute stalled the decision for more than two years.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday comparing Detroit with San Jose, which displaced it as the nation's 10th most populous city, referred incorrectly to the San Jose Sharks hockey team. It is one of several professional sports teams in the city, not the only one. (Others include the Earthquakes, soccer; the SaberCats, arena football; the Giants, baseball; and Stealth, lacrosse.)

description: At first, the young man from Sunset Park, Brooklyn, was a nameless statistic in a grim compilation.

description: PARIS, July 6 - Defeated and devastated, France struggled to absorb the news today despite the overwhelming odds in its favor, it had lost the 2012 Summer Olympics to London.

Loving grandfather of Lara (Sundar), Robert, Debra, Amy and Moriya. Adoring great grandfather of Ruby. Loving brother of Felix. Died peacefully on July 5. Park Avenue Synagogue mourn the passing of a devoted congregant. We extend to the entire family our heartfelt sympathy. May his memory remain for a blessing. David H. Lincoln, Senior Rabbi Amy A.B. title: Florida's Zeal Against Castro Is Losing Heat
description: MIAMI, July 5 - Fidel Castro is not dead, but he has haunted Miami for nearly 50 years. This is a city where newscasters still scrutinize Mr. Castro's health and workers conduct emergency drills to prepare for the chaos expected upon his demise. Spy shops still flourish here, and a store on Calle Ocho does brisk business in reprints of the Havana phone book from 1959, the year he seized power.

description: St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, the largest Catholic hospital system in New York State, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday morning, citing years of mounting debts and falling revenues.

description: Schools Chancellor Joel I. Klein said yesterday that he remained "strongly committed" to an expensive, privately-financed training program for principals and suggested that the program would continue even if the city had to pay for it.

description: The Broadcom Corporation, which makes microchips for consumer electronics, has filed an antitrust lawsuit accusing its larger competitor Qualcomm of stifling competition and inflating prices in the market for cellphone chips.

title: Joel Gersmann, Director of Experimental Theater Company, Dies at 62
description: Joel Gersmann, the longtime artistic director of the Broom Street Theater, a provocative experimental company based in Madison, Wis., died at his home there on June 24. He was 62.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKUS, MARIE E. S. A.
description: MARKUS--Marie E. S. A. of New York, NY and Chatham, MA. On Tuesday, July 5 at her home, surrounded by her family, after a brief illness. Widow of Frits, survived by her children Frank and Anna, daughter-in-law Nancy, and grandchildren Austin, Ella and Elisabeth. Mrs. Markus was born in 1914 in the Netherlands and was educated as a lawyer. With her husband and parents she found refuge in America where she served the Dutch government in exile. For many years she served as a volunteer at the Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School. After her husband's death, she became a discerning philanthropist. In recent years she made a commitment to Rockefeller University and its work in the life sciences. To the end, she was active in mind and body, enjoying her grandchildren, her garden, the sciences and long walks. Funeral service at 11:30AM on Thursday, July 7 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. The burial will be private. The family will receive condolence calls from 5-8 PM that evening at her home. Contributions may be made to Rockefeller University, the Fresh Air Fund or the Chatham, MA. Conservation Fund.

title: Children of Darfur Know About Life Amid Carnage
description: A crayon drawing by "Taha," who is 13 or 14 and lives in North Darfur, showed helicopters in the sky and houses engulfed in flames. "Now my nights are hard because I feel frightened," says the label accompanying the drawing. "We became homeless."

title: Live Surgical Webcasts Play to Potential Patients
description: MEDICAL advertising tends to involve glowing testimonials from fit-looking former patients, or commercials describing vague health problems that sign off with "Ask your doctor if our drug is right for you." Hospitals broadcast images of state-of-the-art facilities, eminent doctors and attentive nurses.

title: Murder Suspect Told Police He Hunted a White Woman
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 5 - The homeless man arrested last week on charges of stabbing a White Plains woman to death near a busy mall told the police that he had waited for hours in a stairwell for a white victim, the Westchester County district attorney's office said on Tuesday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a number of past hints that Justice Sandra Day O'Connor might resign from the Supreme Court misstated the number of e-mail messages sent by People for the American Way, a main liberal group working on judicial issues, saying that the vacancy created a "critical moment for the Constitution." It was 400,000, not 4,000.(Go to Article)

title: Think About It: Shakespeare Is All in Your Mind
description: LONDON - In the role of Prospero, the proprietor of the ultimate fantasy island, Mark Rylance has the whole world in his hands. Or is it in his head? In the soulful, stimulating new production of "The Tempest" at Shakespeare's Globe Theater here, where Mr. Rylance is in his 10th and final season as artistic director, there seems to be little question that everything that happens occurs in one man's mind. Or that this Prospero, who conducts conversations with the figures on a chess board, is experiencing something like a nervous breakdown in iambic pentameter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RASKIN, WILLIAM
description: RASKIN--William. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of William Raskin, an esteemed friend of the New York Jewish community whose commitment to our Office Products Division strengthened our ability to serve those in need, enriching millions of lives around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to Bill's beloved wife, Ruth; to his children, Gabriel, Joshua, & Jonah; to his daughter-in-law, Melissa; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Central Asians Call on U.S. to Set a Timetable for Closing Bases
description: MOSCOW, July 5 - Russia, China and four Central Asian states called Tuesday for the United States to set a deadline for withdrawing from military bases in Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

title: New York: No Games? Too Bad. What Else?
description: For those who had hoped for a miracle, hearing that New York was knocked out of the contest for the 2012 Olympics was a bitter blow. But the loss did not faze most New Yorkers. Many rushed off to work this morning without giving the bid a second thought.

description: DES MOINES - When Rae Ann Dankovic bought a sprawling town house in the Des Moines suburb of Ankeny early in June, she paid $624 for Iowa's equivalent of title insurance.

title: The Quiet Man
description: Los Angeles - AMERICA is facing a military manpower meltdown. Overwhelmed by the demands in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Army has all but used up its emergency recruiting measures: higher enlistment bonuses, more expensive marketing campaigns, even home loans for some recruits. Although the Army recruited its quota for June, it will probably miss its target for the year. Retention is going fairly well, thanks in part to incentives that are tax-free when a soldier re-ups in a combat zone.

title: Apple Executive Calls Family of Teenager Killed for IPod
description: As Errol Rose made preparations on Monday to bury his 15-year-old son, Christopher, who was killed last week in Brooklyn during a fight over an iPod, he received a telephone call from a stranger. The man spoke in tones that the grieving father said had momentarily quieted his anguish.

title: Mets Get a Strong Effort From Martnez, and Then Waste It
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 - The Mets can peddle every stitch of merchandise bearing Pedro Martnez's name and sell out Shea Stadium every fifth day from now until October, but that does not mean they are not wasting their most valuable commodity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KEMPNER, NAN
description: KEMPNER--Nan. The Board of Trustees and staff of the Hospital for Joint Diseases Orthopaedic Institute, express our sincere sorrow at the passing of Nan Kempner, the wife of Thomas L. Kempner, a current and loyal member of the Board. Mrs. Kempner was the daughterin-law of the late Alan Kempner, a former chairman of the Hospital's Board. We extend our sympathy to Tom and the entire Kempner family. William A. Perlmuth, Chairman of the Board David A. Dibner, CEO KEMPNER--Nan. Lighthouse International mourns the loss of its dedicated Women's Committee volunteer and staunch supporter for more than 30 years. Our heartfelt sympathy to her family. Tara A. Cortes, President and CEO William B. Follett, Chairman Judy Van Nostrand, Chair, Women's Committee Lighthouse International KEMPNER--Nan. The Board of Directors of Christie's and many friends mourn the death of our International Representative, Nan Kempner. Her energy and enthusiasm were legendary. description: Jennifer Tisser, 22, has been working at Kenneth Cole Productions in New York City for almost a year, a job she owes, in part, to a summer internship she held there while a student at Syracuse University.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Checkpoint Charlie Display Gone
description: Berlin authorities removed more than 1,000 crosses and a fake section of the Berlin Wall from a field at the famous former crossing point called Checkpoint Charlie. The controversial memorial was put up in October by the Checkpoint Charlie Museum to commemorate the people killed while trying to escape from East Germany's Communist government from 1961 to 1989. The museum had refused to remove the display after its lease on the land expired. The property owner wants to sell the property. Victor Homola (NYT)

description: AMES--Harold. The Board, Administration and Staff of the Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center mourn the passing of Harold Ames, a founding member of the Board. He will long be remembered for his advocacy and commitment to our Center. Our sincere condolences to the family. Lawrence Simon, Chairman Arthur Goldstein, President Joseph Gurwin, President Emeritus Herbert Friedman, Exec VP

title: European Parliament Fails to Agree on Computer Patents
description: BRUSSELS, July 5 - European parliamentarians are expected to reject legislation on Wednesday on the patenting of computer-related inventions, ending a testy four-year debate without resolution.

title: Hush falls over crowd at Paris City Hall
Investing in Gaza
description: GAZA CITY - I was having coffee at a Gaza hotel on Saturday with a group of Palestinian and Egyptian businessmen when one of the Palestinians, half-serious, half-joking, gave me a stock tip: "Nablus." The Palestine Securities Exchange, located in the West Bank town of Nablus, has skyrocketed since the Israeli-Palestinian cease-fire went into effect in February. And check out Paltel, the Palestinian phone company. It's almost as hot as Google. You don't have a broker in Nablus? Sounds a little risky? No problem. Check out the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange. It's also soared since the cease-fire and Israel's decision to withdraw from Gaza.

title: Teacher in Regents Inquiry Got Job in School on L.I.
description: A former assistant principal in Brooklyn, who resigned last year while under investigation for allegations that she directed widespread cheating on the Regents exams, was hired as the head of the social studies department at a Long Island high school where she was again in charge of grading Regents exams this year.

title: Aircraft Sales Lead the Way, as Manufacturing Picks Up
description: Factory orders rose 2.9 percent in May to $394.1 billion, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, largely driven by sales of aircraft and other highly expensive items.

title: With Few Legal Views on Record, Gonzales Faces Criticism From Two Sides
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 - Conservative opposition to the possible nomination of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales to the Supreme Court rests on two broad complaints: that as a judge on the Texas Supreme Court he showed insufficient opposition to abortion, and as White House counsel in Mr. Bush's first term he supported affirmative action.

title: The Battle for the Supreme Court

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Bombing Kills Police Officers
description: At least two police officers were killed by a bomb blast at a police station in the southern republic of Dagestan, a spokesman for the republic's Interior Ministry said. The bomb exploded in Makhachkala, the republic's capital, just hours after the police discovered and defused a larger bomb outside a theater. Dagestan, which borders Chechnya, has been afflicted with escalating violence this year, with as many as 70 terrorist acts reported. On Monday evening, a Dagestani legislator, Zubair Tatayev, was assassinated when his Mercedes was riddled with rifle fire, and a bomb late last week killed 10 special forces troops. An Islamic group claimed responsibility for that blast. There were no immediate claims of responsibility for the latest killings. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Police and anti-G8 demonstrators clash on opening day of summit
Sharpening Ethnic Barbs and Hoping for a Hit
description: "Just because my name is Carlos Mencia, don't think my show is going to be about the difference between Mexicans and white people," the veteran comedian Carlos Mencia said one recent morning as he made his way to work in Los Angeles.

description: SINGAPORE, Wednesday, July 6 - With just hours to go before the final vote, New York's Olympic bid organizers unveiled their vision of the 2012 Games in a presentation that stressed the city's international flavor, its organizers' enthusiasm and the economic boost the Games would give the Olympic movement.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: 2 In Corruption Inquiry Step Down
description: After new allegations in the press of corruption and demands by the party's congressional delegation that they be replaced, two top officials of the ruling Workers' Party have stepped down. The party's secretary general, Silvio Pereira, and treasurer, Delbio Soares, asked for leaves of absence until the conclusion of official investigations into their actions in connection with loans to their party and accusations of payoffs to members of allied parties. But the party's president, Jos Genono, remains in place despite the insistence of the congressional group that his role in the growing scandal requires that he also go. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Giambi Locates the Power Switch
description: After doubling in the sixth inning yesterday for his third hit of the game, Jason Giambi was replaced by a pinch-runner. As he trotted off the field, Giambi doffed his helmet to salute a standing ovation from the Yankee Stadium crowd. He was congratulated by teammates in the dugout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEILER, GERALD E.
description: WEILER--Gerald E. July 3, 2005, after a valiant struggle with Parkinson's disease. He is survived by his companion Sally J. Evers. He was a gentle and generous man. Donations in his memory may be made to the National Parkinson's Foundation, 1501 NW 9th Avenue, Miami, Florida 33136-1494. A memorial service will be announced in the future. WEILER--Gerald E. July 3, 2005. Adored friend and family member. We cherish the love and thoughtfulness he has shown us these past 40 years. He will be missed and always remembered. Mary Jane, Barbara, Bill, Helen, Susan

title: Officials Across U.S. Describe Drug Woes
description: Local officials from across the country yesterday declared methamphetamine the nation's leading law enforcement scourge -- a more insidious drug problem than cocaine -- and blamed it for crowding jails and fueling increases in theft and violence, as well as for a host of social welfare problems.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: New Administration Moving Fast
description: Congress agreed to hold early general elections on Dec. 4, with the country's voters electing a new president, all 157 members of Congress and, for the first time, provincial governors. The election, aimed at diffusing political tensions, are the centerpiece in the 25-day-old government of President Eduardo Rodrguez, who replaced Carlos Mesa after furious uprisings had paralyzed the country for three weeks. Congress also agreed to convene an assembly next July to rewrite the Constitution and to schedule a referendum that would give Bolivia's far-flung regions more autonomy. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: An answer to a market riddle
Africa Tackles Graft, With Billions in Aid in Play
description: LAGOS, Nigeria - One of Dora Nkem Akunyili's lowest moments as a corruption fighter came about two years ago when her son told her not to visit his boarding school. Obumneme Akunyili, age 13, did not want anyone to know that she was his mother.

title: National Briefing
description: WEST

title: Paranoid at a Quirky Wedding
description: Some plays trade in generalities. Sam Marks's "Bigger Man," which opened on Saturday at Center Stage, sounds almost too specific to be credible.

title: Senators Ask Drug Giant to Explain Grants to Doctors
description: The Senate Finance Committee yesterday began an inquiry into whether Johnson & Johnson used educational grants to promote the pediatric use of its former heartburn medication, Propulsid, even as internal company concerns mounted during the 1990's about the drug's safety in some children.

title: Arts, Briefly; TV Fireworks Catch the Eye
description: On a low-rated July 4, the results of Nielsen's estimates were typical for a Monday. CBS was No. 1 among total viewers and adults 18 to 49. Its lineup, a mixture of repeats and fireworks, gained viewers throughout the night, with the most-watched program being the "Boston Pops Fireworks Spectacular 2005" (8.08 million). Among 18-to-49-year-olds, however, CBS's "CSI: Miami" was the biggest draw on Monday's schedule. NBC was No. 2 among viewers and a close second in the 18-to-49 demographic. Its fireworks display, the lengthily titled "Macy's Fourth of July Fireworks Spectacular: The Light of Freedom," brought in an audience of 7.45 million. Bravo's "Being Bobby Brown" improved the cable channel's Thursday ratings. The series premiere of the reality show, during which Mr. Brown reunited with his wife, Whitney Houston, after a stay in jail, attracted an average of 1.1 million viewers over two half-hour episodes.

title: For Hernandez, Success Is a Payback for Peterson
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 - With every day of this season, Rick Peterson, the Mets' pitching coach, repays some of the debt he has been carrying around the big leagues for more than a decade.

title: Statement of Judith Miller  July 6, 2005
description: YOUR HONOR, on Independence Day two days ago I thought long and hard about what you said to us in court last week. I knew I would have to stand before you today to explain my motives and state of mind.

title: Films Take a More Sophisticated Look at Teenage Sex
description: In Miranda July's shrewdly observed "Me and You and Everyone We Know," a 14-year-old boy and his 7-year-old brother sit in front of a computer screen engaging in an increasingly common form of sex education: an online chat with an anonymous woman. Although the 14-year-old is savvy enough to guess that they could be talking, say, to a grossly overweight man instead of some hot babe, his little brother suggests, "Ask if she likes baloney," then innocently offers a nonsensical, physically impossible act that reminds us he is not so far from his potty training days. The online response is, "You are crazy, and you are making me very hot."

London: Corners Turn Upward on Stiff Upper Lip
description: LONDON, July 6 - Maybe, some speculated, the balance was tipped by the blinding presence in Singapore of the soccer star David Beckham, wearing a shiny white track suit. Maybe it was the un-Olympian remarks by the French president, Jacques Chirac, in which he bizarrely lumped British and Finnish food together as the worst in Europe.

Corrections
description: An obituary of the historian Shelby Foote last Wednesday misstated the relationship between William Alexander Percy, an author, and Walker Percy, a boyhood friend of Mr. Foote's who became a well-known novelist. William Percy was a cousin of Walker Percy, not an uncle. The article also misstated the setting of one of Mr. Foote's novels, "September, September." Although the story unfolds during the 1957 school integration turmoil in Little Rock, it is set in Memphis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWAB, DR. STUART
description: SCHWAB--Dr. Stuart, Scientist, 47, died on June 30 in Houston Texas after a valiant two year fight against leukemia. A resident of Albuquerque, New Mexico, Dr. Schwab grew up in Oyster Bay, New York. Dr. Schwab attended St. Mark's School and graduated from the Milbrook School. He graduated from Duke University in 1981, and obtained his Ph.D. in Chemistry from the University of Texas at Austin in 1986. Dr. Schwab was President and CEO of the company he founded, Thor Technologies. He was a leading scientist in the development of ceramic materials and fiber reinforced ceramic composites that are lightweight but withstand intense heat and pressure. Dr. Schwab is survived by his wife Vicki McClendon Schwab and their children, Elizabeth, Emily, and Stuart T. Schwab Jr. of Albuquerque, New Mexico; his parents Mr. and Mrs. Hermann C. Schwab, his siblings George Schwab, Tatine Kimmick, Margery Weekes, Lesley Forman and Henry Schwab; and numerous nieces and nephews. Services will be held at the Cathedral Church of St. John, Albuquerque, at 2 PM on Thursday, July 7. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that memorial donations be made to The University of New Mexico Health Sciences Center, Cancer Research and Treatment Center, MSC08 4630, University of New Mexico, Albuquerque, New Mexico 87131-0001.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SCHNEIDMAN, SEYMOUR

title: Keep These Kids From Eating Veggies? Try.
description: WASHINGTON - THE great grassy esplanade called the National Mall plays a multitude of roles in the life of the capital. Crowds gather there to witness inaugurals and celebrate patriotic holidays, and for decades demonstrators have assembled there to promote causes or to air grievances. In the course of a year you are likely to see almost anything or anyone on the Mall: kids flying kites or throwing Frisbees, bigger kids playing rugby, dogs chasing their tails.

"Come see the moon!" With similarly passionate enthusiasm, this digital-video documentary, directed by Jeffrey Fox Jacobs, which begins a weeklong run today at the Two Boots Pioneer Theater in the East Village, invites viewers to pause for a moment and consider their place in the solar system, the galaxy and the universe.

Collision With a Comet
description: NASA scored a remarkable triumph this week when it smashed a small spacecraft into an onrushing comet with almost bull's-eye precision. After flying for almost six months to reach its goal 83 million miles away, the two-stage Deep Impact probe released a "smart impactor" spacecraft, which guided itself into the comet while the main flyby craft scooted out of the way to photograph and observe the proceedings. If only our military contractors could do as well in their largely futile attempts to hit incoming ballistic missiles.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Shots Fired At School
description: Two bullets from a high-powered rifle struck a school in Inwood yesterday while a summer camp was in session, the police said. The bullets were fired from a nearby rooftop around 2:30 p.m. and hit a window of a fifth-floor classroom and another room at Intermediate School 218, at 196th Street and Broadway, a police official said. No one was injured. The police said that a school maintenance worker reported seeing two people outside struggling over a gun. June Barrett, the school's assistant principal, sent a letter to parents saying that the school would take additional security precautions. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Briefly: Qualcomm accused of unfair sales
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Woman Shot In Harlem
description: A woman was shot in the neck and shoulder last evening by a former boyfriend who fled in his boxer shorts, the police said. The victim, Lynnae Jones, 20, was shot around 5:30 p.m. inside the second-floor apartment of the suspect, Rodney Green, 21, at the Drew-Hamilton Houses, at 2680 Frederick Douglass Boulevard. Mr. Green fled, and Ms. Jones, who lives across the street from the suspect, was taken to Harlem Hospital Center, where she was listed in critical but stable condition last night. Her mother, Gwendolyn Jones, said that Mr. Green and Ms. Jones had dated for several years, but had broken up some time ago. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: A Pat on the Back
description: Since I have been hired, temporarily, to write about the news, here's some: seeing Pat Robertson on television cheered me up. Until recently, about the nicest thing I would have said about this televangelist is that he isn't boring. Remember when he wanted to boycott the "Satanic ritual" that is Halloween? Or when he said, "The husband is the head of the wife"? Or when he warned the city of Orlando that the flying of homosexuals' upbeat rainbow flags might incite divine retribution in the form of hurricanes or "possibly a meteor"? Yep, good times.

title: For Lobbyist, a Seat of Power Came With a Plate
description: WASHINGTON, July 5 - The lobbyist Jack Abramoff mixed business with business at Signatures, the upscale restaurant he opened here three years ago. Playing host at his private corner spot, Table 40, he courted Republican lawmakers and talked strategy with subordinates while eating rolls of sushi and firing commands to the staff on his BlackBerry.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 5 - At least some reviewers of Walt Disney Pictures' "Herbie: Fully Loaded" found themselves caught in a modern-day conundrum: Should they review the movie about a fledgling ESPN journalist turned Nascar driver who says she's willing to kill for Tropicana orange juice and seldom leaves home without her Goodyear cap? Or just skip the film and go straight to its ubiquitous promotions?

World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Budget Airline Planned
description: The Brazilian budget airline Gol Linhas Areas Inteligentes announced plans to create a low-cost carrier modeled after itself in Mexico by mid-2006. Gol said the new airline would be created in partnership with the Mexican group Inversiones y Tcnicas Aeroportuarias and its controlling shareholders, the Mexican entrepreneur Fernando Chico Pardo and Copenhagen Airports, the Danish airport operator known as CPH. Gol declined to comment on the ownership structure of the new company. But one Brazilian newspaper reported that Gol would end up with a 40 percent stake in the new airline, which will compete with Click Mexicana, the budget carrier owned by Mexicana de Aviacin. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Notorious Killer Freed
description: A day after Karla Homolka completed a 12-year prison term for the rapes and killings of three teenage girls, a lawyer for the families of two of the victims said they would fight any loosening of the restrictions placed on her freedom. Ms. Homolka had received the relatively light prison term in exchange for testifying against her ex-husband, Paul Bernardo. Together they raped and killed Ms. Homolka's younger sister and kidnapped, raped, sexually tortured and killed two other girls in Ontario in the early 1990's. But the full extent of Ms. Homolka's role was not revealed until after her trial, when videotapes of the rapes were uncovered. Two hours after her release from prison, she told a television interviewer that she was no longer a public threat and hoped to settle down in anonymity in Quebec. Colin Campbell (NYT)

description: House Republican leaders have cleared for floor action rival bills that take alarmingly divergent approaches to amending campaign finance laws. One would gut existing regulations and let officeholders and party bosses solicit millions once more. The other would plug the loophole opened last year by organizations that posed as tax-exempt independent advocacy groups and spent hundreds of millions of dollars on partisan campaigning.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Countries Sued to Open Energy Markets
description: European Union regulators filed lawsuits against five nations accusing them of failing to open their electricity and natural gas markets to competition. The European Commission told the countries -- Spain, Ireland, Greece, Estonia and Luxembourg -- that they were breaching 2003 European legislation that gives energy customers the right to choose suppliers. European Union nations must enact the rules and notify the commission, the 25-nation bloc's executive arm. "This legislation is an essential step toward the completion of a truly competitive E.U. energy market," the European energy commissioner, Andris Piebalgs, above, said. The commission filed the lawsuits at the European Court of Justice in Luxembourg.

title: Ministering Agent: 'Entourage's' Shark Proves Warmblooded
description: Television's most bracing summer pleasure, for two years now, has been Jeremy Piven as Ari Gold on HBO's comedy "Entourage." On a forthcoming episode, Ari, the show's peremptory Hollywood agent, experiments with a new way of answering the phone: "You got Gold." His caller responds with disbelief. Is that Ari's new affectation? The likable jerk smiles to himself. It just might be.

title: On a Summer Night in Paris, Ballet and a Few Raindrops
description: PARIS, July 6 - For all the delights of outdoor entertainment, there is no escaping the perils of an unpleasant surprise. And so it was Tuesday evening when unseasonably chilly weather and sporadic drizzle accompanied the opening night of a new festival confidently called Dance Summers in Paris. All the more credit to the San Francisco Ballet, then, that most of the near 2,000-strong audience stayed the course - and were pleased they did.

title: A Frog Kisses a Museum, Then Tries to Grab the Art
description: Not many buildings can claim the unlikely combination of a fairy-tale frog prince and an art thief as influences. Magne Magler Wiggen, an architect in Oslo, designed an inflatable pavilion called the Frog for Norway's National Gallery as part of the celebrations of the country's centennial as an independent state. The structure houses a contemporary art exhibition. "Sometimes it feels like the shape just came jumping onto the drawing board," Mr. Magler Wiggen said.

Editors' Note
description: The Op-Ed page in some copies yesterday carried an incorrect version of an article about military recruitment. The writer, an Army reserve officer, did not say, "Imagine my surprise the other day when I received orders to report to Fort Campbell, Ky., next Sunday," nor did he characterize his recent call-up to active duty as the precursor to a "surprise tour of Iraq." That language was added by an editor and was to have been removed before the article was published. Because of a production error, it was not. The Times regrets the error.

The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Betty Englander, beloved mother of Robert Englander and Rita Sands; mother-in-law of Nancy Englander and Jeffrey Sands, treasured supporters and friends. The Englander and Sands families' generosity and commitment, demonstrated through Nancy's dedicated leadership in our Women's Campaign and Jeffrey's service to our Accountants Division has enabled us to enrich Jewish life and learning worldwide, profoundly impacting millions of lives. Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Second Fire Victim Dies
description: A second child who was trapped in a fire early Saturday morning in Brownsville has died of her injuries, the police said yesterday. The girl, Triena Dennis, 12, died Tuesday at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, where she was being treated for severe burns. Her half brother, Joshua Alexander Maldonado, 3, died in the fire at the family's third-floor apartment at 200 Newport Street. Another brother, Jamel Dennis, 9, was critically injured and was treated at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center. The authorities said that a candle might have started the fire, and that the children had been trapped behind a locked door.

title: Arts, Briefly; TV Ratings: Everybody's a Winner
description: There was a close race among CBS, NBC and Fox on Tuesday night in Nielsen's estimates. CBS was No. 1 in households and total viewers, but NBC and Fox tied for first among adults 18 to 49. CBS's "48 Hours Mystery" (7.35 million) was the network's most-watched hour, but its finale of "Fire Me Please" did the best in the 18-to-49 demographic. NBC trailed CBS in households by a sliver of a ratings point. Its reality offerings, "Average Joe" (4.92 million) and "I Want to Be a Hilton" (4.85 million), puttered along, but the network's average was lifted by a repeat of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" at 10 p.m. That crime show attracted an audience of 8.39 million, making it the night's biggest draw among total viewers and 18-to-49-year-olds. ABC was in fourth place over all. Its "Empire" continued to flounder in its second week with 5.16 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Fatal Stabbing
description: A man was fatally stabbed by another man during an argument inside a home in College Point last night, the police said. The stabbing occurred about 9 p.m. in a basement apartment at 20-21 129th Street, near 22nd Avenue, when a man who lives at that address stabbed another man in the back and chest, the police said. Neither man was identified last night. The police said they recovered an 8-inch carving knife at the scene as well as two bloodied shirts, and arrested a man they said was the assailant, who had recently moved to the apartment with his girlfriend, according to a neighbor.

title: On a Summer Night in Paris, Ballet and a Few Raindrops
description: PARIS, July 6 - For all the delights of outdoor entertainment, there is no escaping the perils of an unpleasant surprise. And so it was Tuesday evening when unseasonably chilly weather and sporadic drizzle accompanied the opening night of a new festival confidently called Dance Summers in Paris. All the more credit to the San Francisco Ballet, then, that most of the near 2,000-strong audience stayed the course -- and were pleased they did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHATTUCK, JAMES H.
description: SHATTUCK--James H. died peacefully at his home in Guilford, CT late Sunday night, July 3rd 2005. He was born on August 5th, 1915 in Neenah, Wisconsin, the son of Ruth and S.F. Shattuck. His friends called him Jim. He was a member of the Yale class of 1939 as well as a student at Tufts University where he studied electrical engineering. While at Tufts he met his future wife, Martha Merrill of Cambridge, Massachusetts. Their marriage lasted 63 years, beginning in June 1941 and ending with her death last August. In 1952, Yale University hired him as Assistant Personnel Director where he worked until 1966. In 1968 he became Personnel Director for the University of New Haven, a job he held until his retirement in 1980. Of equal importance with his professional life was the continuous flow of extraordinarily generous acts of anonymous charity to everyone he met who was in need and the organizations that had impressed him with their good deeds and value. As a man he had been blessed with athletic ability and a degree of physical courage that could verge on audacity. He played football, ran track and wrestled at the Choate School and Yale University. In 1966 he decided to try hiking by walking from Maine to Georgia on the Appalachian Trail. This was the start of a love of the wilderness, the outdoors, and selfsufficient adventure that would last more than two decades. Jim preferred doing things rather than talking about them. But when asked he might sketch the barest outlines of an event of astonishing risk and resourcefulness, the details of which revealed both his quiet sense of humor and his profoundly pious belief in divine guidance. Jim is survived and will be missed by the three sons that he and Martha raised, Bradlee, Alden and Jonathan; his daughter-in-law, Marianne; his five grandchildren, Johan, Kyle, Trevor, Brendan and Avery, his two granddaughters-in-law Trisha and Emily; his great grandchildren Xavier, Elise and Johan; and his two sisters Ann and Mary. A memorial service will be held at the First Congregational Church at the corner of Church and Broad Streets in Guilford, CT on Thursday, July 14th, at 1:00PM.

title: British Officials Say They Had No Warning
description: LONDON, July 7 - For nearly four decades, this city has been on almost perpetual high alert for terror attacks. Again last month, police officials warned that a large-scale attack in Britain was inevitable. But this morning, the police and the intelligence services, considered by their peers to be among the best in the world, were taken by surprise by the coordinated bombings of the London underground and a crowded city bus.
