title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKUS, MARIE E. S. A.
description: MARKUS--Marie E. S. A. of New York, NY and Chatham, MA. On Tuesday, July 5 at her home, surrounded by her family, after a brief illness. Widow of Frits, survived by her children Frank and Anna, daughter-in-law Nancy, and grandchildren Austin, Ella and Elisabeth. Mrs. Markus was born in 1914 in the Netherlands and was educated as a lawyer. With her husband and parents she found refuge in America where she served the Dutch government in exile. For many years she served as a volunteer at the Hawthorne Cedar Knolls School. After her husband's death, she became a discerning philanthropist. In recent years she made a commitment to Rockefeller University and its work in the life sciences. To the end, she was active in mind and body, enjoying her grandchildren, her garden, the sciences and long walks. Funeral service at 11:30AM on Thursday, July 7 at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. The burial will be private. The family will receive condolence calls from 5-8 PM that evening at her home. Contributions may be made to Rockefeller University, the Fresh Air Fund or the Chatham, MA. Conservation Fund. MARKUS--Marie (Rita). The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend Rita Markus, a cherished member of The Rockefeller University Council and the University family. We are fortunate to have known this remarkable woman, whose eloquence, intel ligence, graciousness, and infinite curiosity captured our hearts and our minds. Her interest and involvement had an enormous impact on the small "scientific village" which is The Rockefeller University. She shared our love of science and our belief in its ability to improve the human condition. From her first visit to campus in 1996, Rita forged close and wonderful bonds with faculty members too numerous to mention, each of whom considered it an honor and great privilege to spend time in conversation with her. Rita's scientific interests touched on some of life's most challenging questions, such as the mechanisms of evolution, the origin of language, and the development of the human brain. Through her generous philanthropy, she strengthened a broad spectrum of University initiatives, including the Frits & Rita Markus Bio-Imaging Resource Center. Her keen mind, warm friendship, and passionate commitment to the advancement of science inspired all of us to be better than we are. Rita's return from the Cape each October was a joyous occasion for us, and it is difficult to imagine the future without her. We will greatly miss her, and we extend our heartfelt condolences to her children, Anna and Frank, her daughter-in-law, Nancy, and her grandchildren, Austin, Elisabeth, and Ella. Paul Nurse, President David Rockefeller Honorary Chairman Russell Carson, Chairman Richard Furlaud, Chairman Emeritus Torsten Wiesel President Emeritus Ali Brivanlou, Titia de Lange, Charles Gilbert, and Thomas Sakmar Professors MARKUS--Marie. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Marie "Rita" Markus, an esteemed benefactor and beloved friend whose exemplary commitment to humanitarian causes and the welfare of children marked a life dedicated to tikkun olam. Rita's boundless generosity and passionate enthusiasm for the Jewish community also included her longtime support of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services. She was a shining example of philanthropic leadership, strengthening millions of lives in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Rita's children, Frank and Anna; to her daughter-in-law, Nancy; to her grandchildren; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. MARKUS--Marie (Rita). The Trustees and staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services mourn the death of Rita Marcus, a treasured friend and benefactor. Rita's keen intelligence and sophisticated grasp of the issues facing our staff made an enormous difference in the lives of children in need. We will miss her grace and will always appreciate with enormous gratitude her generosity and support to our agency. Our condolences to her children and grandchildren. Jean L. Troubh, President Joseph S. Kaplan, Chairman of the Board Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D., Executive VP and CEO

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Art Dealer Sentenced For Fraud
description: Ely Sakhai, the owner of the Exclusive Art gallery in Lower Manhattan, was sentenced yesterday to 41 months in federal prison for fraud, said David N. Kelley, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Prosecutors said Mr. Sakhai had pleaded guilty to selling forgeries of works by painters including Chagall, Modigliani and Gauguin. Mr. Sakhai was also ordered to pay $12.5 million restitution and forfeit 11 paintings believed to be authentic works from which Mr. Sakhai produced forgeries.

title: Kidnappers Threaten to Kill Egyptian Diplomat in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 6 - The group that says it kidnapped Egypt's top diplomat in Iraq declared in a chilling Internet posting on Wednesday that a religious court had condemned him to die. The diplomat, Ihab al-Sharif, has been handed over to fighters to carry out the sentence, said the message, which was posted on a militants' Web site.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Better Conditions For Inmate In U.S.
description: An Afghan tribal leader being held in New York City on heroin trafficking charges will receive a better diet and adequate conditions for Muslim prayer, his defense lawyer, Stephen M. Goldenberg, said. Prison officials agreed to changes after the tribal leader, Hajji Bashir Noorzai, had complained in court that he was getting food portions smaller than consistent with a Muslim diet, and could not pray because he did not know which way to face in his cell toward Mecca. Julia Preston (NYT)

title: Uh-Oh: The Wedgwood Is in Pieces
description: Few china patterns are more recognizable than Willow, the blue and white chinoiserie design originally made in the 18th century, with variations, by English china companies. Wedgwood, which first produced the pattern in 1818, now has a new version, After Blue Willow. It can be seen this summer at the Hampton Designer Showhouse in Southampton, N.Y., in a room by Alessandra Branca. It is a reinterpretation by Robert Dawson, a London ceramic artist. Mr. Dawson has put enlarged segments of Willow on each of six dinner plates, available at www.wedgwood.com or 011-44-800-317-412 ($44 each). CURRENTS: CHINA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, DR. CRAIG NEELANDS
description: SMITH--Dr. Craig Neelands, 86, of Main St, South Windsor, CT on July 5, at Kimberly Hall Hospice in Windsor, CT. Born in Ottawa, Canada in 1918. Son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Smith. He is survived by his wife, Marion Farnum Smith, and two daughters, Caroline Beattie Smith and Elizabeth Smith Howard, his son-in-law John Noxon Howard, Jr, and two grandchildren, John Neelands Howard and Stuart Wilcoxen Howard. Dr. Smith received his bachelor's degree from the University of Virginia in 1946, and graduated from the Cornell University Medical School in 1950. He interned at St. Luke's Hospital in NYC, becoming a Senior Attending Physician there. In World War II, Dr. Smith was a Captain in the Canadian Army overseas in the 1st Battalion Canadian Grenadier Guards and served in the United Kingdom and continental Europe from June, 1941 until November, 1945. He was wounded in action on August 8, 1944 at Falaise Gap in Normandy.

title: ON THE STREET: THEN
description: THE surf style that had long been the reigning influence in beachwear became citified in the mid-1980's in the form of baggies, the boldly colored shorts that were a variation on the jams that surfers wore. Urban surfer chic has clearly ebbed since then, but the laid-back look continues to exert a pull on summertime fashion, notably in the baggy cut of cargo pants. As for those athletic socks -- well, that was then.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Loses Immunity
description: The Court of Appeals lifted the immunity of former President Augusto Pinochet for charges in the 1975 cover-up of the disappearance and killing of leftists. The cover-up, by his secret police force, included planting false news articles in Brazilian and Argentine papers claiming the leftists had died as a result of infighting. Mr. Pinochet's lawyers are expected to appeal the ruling to the Supreme Court. Courts decide immunity of former presidents on a case-by-case basis. Last month, the appeals court stripped Mr. Pinochet of immunity from prosecution for tax evasion and other charges. Pascale Bonnefoy (NYT)

title: Thousands Are Arrested in India in Unrest Over Temple Site
description: NEW DELHI, July 6 - The police on Wednesday fired tear gas at hundreds of demonstrators in the center of this city, the Indian capital, who were protesting an attack on a disputed religious site that has emerged as India's most potent symbol of sectarian strife.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Trichet Seeks U.S. Help on Hedge Funds
description: The president of the European Central Bank, Jean-Claude Trichet, said Europe should cooperate with the United States in finding the appropriate measures to regulate hedge funds. "Given the global nature of the hedge fund industry, a regulatory response can only be given on the basis of a solid international consensus and in particular a trans-Atlantic consensus," Mr. Trichet said in a speech at a financial conference in Paris. The accumulation of risk capital in the $1 trillion hedge fund industry has drawn scrutiny from politicians and central bankers globally. The funds' strategies, like placing bets that the prices of securities will fall or pushing for executive changes at companies, have spurred calls for stronger controls from politicians including Chancellor Gerhard Schrder of Germany.

title: Labels Can Hide the Presence of Phthalates
description: PURISTS who try to avoid phthalates in their cosmetics find it is not always easy because phthalates are seldom included on labels. The chemicals are frequently used as components of fragrances (to make scents last longer). And while the Food and Drug Administration requires most cosmetic ingredients to be listed, the agency offers a loophole for fragrances. Their formulas are considered proprietary secrets, so the manufacturer may simply use the generic term "fragrance."

title: Music to Your Cellphone

Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, BERNICE ABELOVE
description: COHEN--Bernice Abelove, 83, of Passaic, New Jersey. Bunny, the beloved wife of Dr. Mortimer Cohen and the late Bernard Abelove, died July 5 in New York City of complications following surgery. She was born in Schenectady, New York, to Rose and Jacob Koslowf. Greatly loved by her daughters, Paula Gilbert of Hastings - on - Hudson, New York, and Judy Shemtob of Scarsdale, New York; her son, Steven Abelove of Lawndale, California, and her stepson, Dr. Jay Cohen of Brookline, Massachusetts, as well as by her grandchildren, Alan Gilbert, Michael Gilbert, Amanda Abelove, and Marshal Shemtob, and her greatgrandchildren, Sara, Alexa, and Carlee Gilbert. She is also survived by her sister, Ida Koslowf, and many nieces and nephews. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, July 7th, at 11 A.M., at the Jewish Memorial Chapel, 841 Allwood Road, Clifton, New Jersey. Burial will be later the same day in Montrepose Cemetery in Kingston, New York.

title: Should You Worry About the Chemicals in Your Makeup?
description: NOT that you would notice from the color, thickness or shine, but nail polish is not what it used to be. Last year many nail polishes contained a little-known chemical that made the veneer more flexible and resistant to chipping. This year some of the biggest brands, including Revlon, Este Lauder and L'Oral, have taken that chemical out and replaced it with another ingredient meant to do the same thing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FONTANA, VINCENT J., M.D.
description: FONTANA--Vincent J., M.D. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Foundling and the Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection mourn the sudden passing of our esteemed and beloved Medical Director and Pediatrician-in-Chief, Dr. Vincent J. Fontana. During his 43 year career at The Foundling, Dr. Fontana fought tirelessly for the rights and protection of mistreated children. Following his groundbreaking article, "The Maltreatment Syndrome in Children," first published in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Fontana authored over 150 scientific publications and texts, including, "Save the Family, Save the Child" and "Somewhere a Child is Crying," texts which have had a profound influence on the field of child abuse prevention. The Crisis Nursery/Family Center that Dr. Fontana established at The Foundling in 1972 continues as a national model as an "island of safety for at risk families." With the opening of the Fontana Center on Christopher Street in November 2004, we are ensured that his legacy of building public awareness, advancing research, and training professionals in the field of child abuse prevention will endure. We extend our deepest sympathies to his brother and sister and large extended family. Plans for a memorial service will be announced at a later date. William F. Baccaglini, Jr. Executive Director Kenneth R. Horner Chairman Sr. Carol A. Barnes Former Chairperson

description: ZEGLER--Manuel. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on June 21, of Manuel Zegler, former Principal Bassoon of the Philharmonic. A graduate of The Curtis Institute of Music, Mr. Zegler performed with the NBC Symphony under Toscanini before joining the Philharmonic in 1945; he retired in 1981. We extend our condolences to his wife, Esther, his son, Paul, daughter Carol and family. Lorin Maazel, Music Dir. Members of the Orchestra Paul B. Guenther, Chairman Zarin Mehta, Pres/Exec. Dir Members of the Staff

title: In a Basement, and Things Are Looking Up
description: SOUTHAMPTON, N.Y. - "I WAS what you call a poor working-class citizen," said Michelle Johnson, sitting at her kitchen table. Ms. Johnson, 49, a mother of five and a member of the Shinnecock Indian tribe, lives on the Shinnecock reservation on the South Fork of Long Island. "I worked really hard, but it just seemed like my money was going in pockets with holes in it."

description: Because of an editing error, an Op-Ed article yesterday about activist justices on the Supreme Court misstated the date the court started. Its first official business began in 1790, not 1791. (Go to Article)

title: Heilman's Future Is Now, but as What?

He has spent the interim volleying between future star and frequent flop, the starting rotation and the bullpen, the major leagues and Class AAA Norfolk.

title: Corrections

It was 400,000, not 4,000.

In May, he opened a second store in Water Mill, N.Y., which he says is enjoying phenomenal success. "I expected to do $250,000 worth of business by Labor Day" Mr. Olivieri said. "But we've already done that much."

description: FERNANDO ZULUETA has an opinion on the use of cellphones at work: he loves it. Mr. Zulueta, 46, who owns a chain of charter schools in South Florida, scratches out the land-line number on his business cards so people won't use it to call him. If he is in a business meeting and his cellphone rings, he often picks it up, even though he considers such behavior annoying.

The Viatek I-Pet Intelligent Pet Dish addresses those concerns; it can be programmed to open each of its four food compartments at specific times.

title: Iran's Reformists Link Defeat to a Split From the Poor
description: TEHRAN, July 3 - Five years ago, Iran's political reformists controlled the presidency and had just won an overwhelming majority in Parliament by promoting an agenda that promised to curtail the role of clerics in the government and to spread democracy, human rights and the rule of law across the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZEFF, KAL
description: ZEFF--Kal. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) mourn the loss of Kal Zeff of Englewood, CO, a generous and loyal friend. A Technion alumnus, Mr. Zeff served on the ATS National Board of Directors and was a chair of the Denver Chapter. A civil engineer, he used the knowledge he gained at the Technion to found Geotek Consultants, and Carmel Companies, Colorado's largest locally owned real estate development and management company. Demonstrating his gratitude to the Technion, he and his beloved wife, Joyce, Technion Guardians, became major supporters of the recently opened Yitzhak Rabin Civil and Environmental Engineering Building. Their equally generous Kal Zeff Post - Doctoral Fellowship supports the work of many outstanding scientists. We extend our sincere condolences to Joyce, children Dana, Diana, Michael and Ron, and the entire Zeff family. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Stephen A. Laser, President Evelyn Berger, Chairman Board of Directors Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Edie Fischer, Western Region President David Polak, Western Region Chair Diane Siegel, Western Region Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHAPIRO, DR. ROBERT S.
description: SHAPIRO--Dr. Robert S. Passed away Tuesday, July 5, 2005. He is survived by his beloved wife, Melba. Devoted father of Mark (Roberta) and Jonathan (Elaine). Cherished grandfather of Rebecca, Sara, Samuel, Jessica and Lara. Loving brother of Dr. Theodore (Joan) Shapiro. He also leaves many loving nieces and nephews and a wide circle of dear friends. Dr. Shapiro was a psychiatrist/psychoanalyst in New York City for over 50 years. He was a graduate of Washington University where he received his B.A. and M.D. He also graduated from Columbia Psychoanalytic Clinic, where he supervised candidates and residents. A memorial service is scheduled for Friday 11 AM at the George T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 Lecount Place, New Rochelle. Family will receive guests from 10 AM.

Schwarz. Come fall, those who work up an appetite creating their bears will be able to visit a child-friendly cafe inside the store. At 565 Fifth Avenue, (212)871-7080.

title: Eyewitness Accounts: The Roof Blew 5 Metres Off the Bus
description: Raj Mattoo, a 35 year old support manager for a charity was on board the number 91 bus travelling through Tavistock square when he saw a bus coming in the opposite direction. "All of a sudden the roof of the approaching bus was blown off 5 metres into the air before it fell in front of the bus." Mr Mattoo said, judging from the explosion he thought the bomb had been on the top deck. "People on my bus were in complete shock and were panicking but they evacuated the bus in an orderely fashion within 30 seconds." Mr Mattoo said the people on the bus torn apart by the explosion were desperatly trying to get off. The explosion was quite contained but there was smoke everywhere.

The police said the painter, John Jairo Giraldo, of Southampton, wore nothing but a ski mask when he jumped a woman strolling on the beach. He has been charged with similar attacks in East Hampton Village and the Town of Southampton, where he was also charged with attempted burglary and public lewdness for waving a crowbar at a woman through her office window while wearing only a ski mask.

Armstrong, the six-time Tour de France champion, finished an irrelevant 45th in Wednesday's flat 114-mile stage, neither gaining on his major rivals nor losing any time to them.

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Phone Companies Can Lease Lines
description: Mexico will allow companies to lease lines from its telecommunications carriers to provide long-distance calls, seeking to lower prices by increasing competition for the former state monopoly, Telfonos de Mxico. The new regulations, to be published in coming days, are part of a settlement with the United States, said Clara Luz lvarez, a director of Mexico's telecommunications regulator. Mexico agreed to open its market to resellers after the World Trade Organization in 2004 ruled in favor of a United States complaint that Telmex thwarted competition and kept rates for completing calls into Mexico at more than double the actual cost. "Resale will be yet another way to stimulate competition, broaden the range of services available, and make rates more attractive for users," Ms. Luz lvarez said in a telephone interview from Mexico City.

title: Ministering Agent: 'Entourage's' Shark Proves Warmblooded
description: Television's most bracing summer pleasure, for two years now, has been Jeremy Piven as Ari Gold on HBO's comedy "Entourage." On a forthcoming episode, Ari, the show's peremptory Hollywood agent, experiments with a new way of answering the phone: "You got Gold." His caller responds with disbelief. Is that Ari's new affectation? The likable jerk smiles to himself. It just might be.

title: Arts, Briefly; Country and Rap CD's Top Pop Chart
description: After a few weeks of mostly static Billboard album charts, new country and rap CD's have taken the top spots. The country star George Strait's 28th album, "Somewhere Down in Texas" (MCA Nashville), is at No. 1 with 245,000 copies sold. The hip-hop group Ying Yang Twins, right, has its "U.S.A.: United State of Atlanta" (TVT) at No.2 with 201,000, according to Billboard and Nielsen SoundScan. Those albums pushed Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol), the top seller for the last three weeks, to No. 3. Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam) is at No. 4, holding strong three months after its release; it sold 131,000 last week for a total of about 2.3 million. The only other new album in the Top 10 this week is the rapper Cassidy's "I'm a Hustla" (Full Surface/J), which is No. 5. New research into the British pop charts has concluded that Queen has overtaken the Beatles for total time on the charts. Queen has been on the Official UK Album Chart for a total of 1,322 weeks, topping the Beatles by 29 weeks, Elvis Presley by 42 and U2 by 172. The research was conducted by the team behind the book "British Hit Singles and Albums," published by Guinness World Records. BEN SISARIO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOSSTRIN, BESSIE
description: KOSSTRIN--Bessie. Of New York passed away on July 5, 2005, peacefully after a brief illness in her 86th year. Beloved wife of the late Archie, devoted mother of five accomplished children, and loving grandmother of seven lively grandchildren, she was an avid reader and a devoted teacher in the New York City Public School System. She took pleasure in teaching many hundreds of underprivileged children the value and importance of the written word. Donations in her memory to the Hadassah Organization would be greatly appreciated.

The conventional wisdom is that for hip-hop stars, there's a connection between crime and credibility. Every time some rapper poses for a mug shot, there is a chorus of commentators ready to declare that it's all a publicity stunt.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Meadowlands Work Allowed By Judge
description: A federal judge yesterday denied a request for a preliminary injunction to stop work on the $1.3 billion Xanadu development project near Giants Stadium. The New Jersey chapter of the Sierra Club and other environmentalists had sought the injunction, but Judge Joel A. Pisano of the United States District Court denied the request, citing the environmentalists' slim chances of success and the failure to produce proof of damages from the developer's actions.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Bloods Leader Pleads Guilty
description: The leader of a Jersey City chapter of the Bloods street gang pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy to commit murder, according to Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in New Jersey. Mr. Christie said that Tommy Terrell Thompson, 32, was the leader, or "five-star general" of the Sex, Money, Murder crew and admitted to ordering gang members to commit assault and murder, including the killing of a Jersey City man believed to be cooperating with law enforcement. Mr. Thompson faces 18 years in prison when he is sentenced in October, Mr. Christie said.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: 5 Charged In Gang Rape
description: Police officers in the central Punjab town of Chiniot arrested five out of the eight men accused of torturing and gang-raping a woman for three days as revenge for an affair between her cousin and a daughter of one of the men accused in the attack. In 2002, the gang rape of Mukhtar Mai, a woman from southern part of Punjab Province, made international headlines and set off worldwide condemnation of so-called honor crimes. Salman Masood (NYT)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Vehicle Registrations Slow
description: New-vehicle registrations in Brazil rose at the slowest pace in three months in June, as higher interest rates slowed demand for expensive goods bought on credit. Registrations of new cars and trucks, made in Brazil and elsewhere, rose 14 percent, to 148,491 units, from 130,697 units in June 2004, the association said in a report distributed in So Paulo. Registrations rose 3.9 percent compared with May. "The numbers are showing that the economic slowdown is not being exaggerated," said Alexandre Lintz, a senior Brazil economist for BNP Paribas. "This is good news for the central bank because it will ease criticism the bank may have exaggerated the dosage."

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Parliament Rejects Software Patent Law
description: The European Parliament rejected a proposed law on the patenting of computer-related inventions after all political parties agreed that no law was better than a bad law. The decision was a blow to large patent owners like Microsoft and Nokia, which had been lobbying intensively to get a patent-friendly version of the law approved. Open-source software companies welcomed the rejection. The European Commission said it had no plans to try a new proposal at this stage. The law had been intended to harmonize the patchwork of patent regulations around Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREEN, ISIDOR
description: GREEN--Isidor. Of New York and Palm Beach, 93, died on July 3 after a brief illness. He was born in Milowka, Poland on September 23, 1911. With his beloved wife of 61 years, Marysia he escaped the atrocities of the Holocaust. He moved to the United States in 1947 and established with his family a successful import and export business. He built a beautiful life, filled with much joy and love. He was a longtime supporter of Akim and Yad Vashem. Along with his wife, he is survived by his children, Dr. Jacqueline Green (Dr. John Grossman), Dr. Bert Green (Alexandra Brookshire) and five adoring grandchildren, Mamie, Sophia and William Green, Aggie and Lucy Grossman. title: 36 Hours in Block Island, R.I.
description: THE same mile-high glacier that parked off southern New England, heaping up Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard for Massachusetts and the Forks of Long Island for New York, also left behind an appropriately diminutive summer playground for little Rhode Island. Giovanni da Verrazano, when he passed by in 1524, thought the place looked like Rhodes in Greece; hence the state's eventual name. But the island itself ended up with the name of a Dutch explorer, Adriaen Block. It was a place for pirates, as well as for fishermen and farmers who piled up the glacier's rocks into deceptively delicate-looking stone walls that lace the island's 10 square miles. Around the end of the 19th century, a string of grand wooden hotels were built with gloriously long porches overlooking the sea and grassy lawns where multispired wedding tents now bloom virtually every weekend of the summer. Away from the hotels, Block Island has a little of the flavor of the quieter parts of Nantucket or the Vineyard (and little in common with anywhere on Long Island). But although people at those bigger and tonier ends of the summer archipelago will sniff their usual sniffs about how you can't get good cheese on the next rock pile over, bass fishermen and others know that, in the very center of the necklace, Block Island is the crown jewel of the bunch.

The televised mtier preferred by children remains the cartoon, but consider the disorienting images that are the norm in that world. Here it's the adult mind that has to learn the visual language.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Irvington: Court Orders End To Mayoral Race
description: The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that Irvington's Board of Trustees should draw lots to determine who will serve as mayor of the village. Since the March election, the Republican incumbent, Dennis P. Flood, has filed two lawsuits alleging ballot irregularities and seeking another election against his Democratic challenger, Erin Malloy. According to uncertified village results, Ms. Malloy was one vote ahead of Mr. Flood, but a four-judge panel ruled on Tuesday that one of the absentee ballots could not be counted, bringing the vote to a tie. Under state law, villages decide ties by a random method, like flipping a coin or drawing straws. The village administrator, Donald P. Marra, said a method would probably be chosen at a meeting on Wednesday. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: Even Comic-Book Superheroes Can Use a Little More Momentum
description: If you like your special effects- driven summer action blockbusters slick, seamless and state of the art, then "Fantastic Four" may not be for you. While the superpowers and their consequences -- flames, stretchy limbs, force fields and so on -- no doubt required a great deal of money and expertise to bring to the screen, they look cheap and cheesy. Which may be the point. In an era when movies based on comic books have become increasingly solemn and serious, this one is content to be trashy. Compared with the psychological probing and spiritual brooding of "Batman Begins," "Fantastic Four" is proudly dumb, loud and inconsequential. It is not an allegory, an archetypal tale of good and evil, or the cinematic equivalent of a graphic novel. It's a comic book.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Charges Dropped In Corruption Case
description: Despite being caught on videotape accepting wads of cash from a city contractor, a former top political aide to Mexico City's mayor, Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador, walked out of jail a free man after a judge dismissed the charges against him. The ruling was an embarrassment for federal prosecutors, who had accused the aide, Ren Bejarano, of laundering money. In March 2004, television news outlets broadcast secretly recorded videotapes of Mr. Bejarano accepting about $1.2 million in cash from Carlos Ahumada, a businessman seeking city contracts. The tapes damaged the anticorruption credentials of Mayor Lpez Obrador, a leftist who polls say is the front-runner in next year's presidential race. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

A dull and occasionally risible remake of an even duller, more risible Japanese horror flick, "Dark Water" stars Jennifer Connelly as a single mother trying to find her bearings. What makes this redo more tolerable than the usual recycled junk isn't the presence of the Academy Award-winning actress, a first-rate weeper who looks good soaking wet. Or that of the respected director Walter Salles, late of "The Motorcycle Diaries," whose deadly serious style here suggests he thought he was remaking "Medea" or, at the very least, a Roman Polanski chiller. It's that this is a horror movie about being shut out of the Manhattan real estate market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FONTANA, VINCENT J., M.D.
description: FONTANA--Vincent J., M.D. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Foundling and the Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection mourn the sudden passing of our esteemed and beloved Medical Director and Pediatrician-in-Chief, Dr. Vincent J. Fontana. During his 43 year career at The Foundling, Dr. Fontana fought tirelessly for the rights and protection of mistreated children. Following his groundbreaking article, "The Maltreatment Syndrome in Children," first published in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Fontana authored over 150 scientific publications and texts, including, "Save the Family, Save the Child" and "Somewhere a Child is Crying," texts which have had a profound influence on the field of child abuse prevention. The Crisis Nursery/Family Center that Dr. Fontana established at The Foundling in 1972 continues as a national model as an "island of safety for at risk families." With the opening of the Fontana Center on Christopher Street in November 2004, we are ensured that his legacy of building public awareness, advancing research, and training professionals in the field of child abuse prevention will endure. We extend our deepest sympathies to his brother and sister and large extended family. Funeral Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral Monday, July 11 at 10:30AM. Visitation Friday July 8 and Saturday July 9, 2-4PM and 7-9PM at O.B. Davis Inc. Funeral Homes, Port Jefferson Station NY(1-800-464-0360). Dr. Fontana's family has requested that in lieu of flowers, gifts be sent to the Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection C/O the New York Foundling, 590 Avenue of the Americas, NY 10011. William F. Baccaglini, Jr. Executive Director Kenneth R. Horner Chairman Sr. Carol A. Barnes Former Chairperson FONTANA--Dr. Vincent J. The Torah tells us that we must be charitable and share our wealth with the stranger, the orphan, the widow and the poor. Dr. Vincent Fontana, our good friend and wonderful neighbor, taught us not only how to give but to always give thanks to those who do, so as to perpetuate the mitzvah of tzedakah. Dr. Fontana was an inspiration to all of us. His passing is our heartfelt loss. Christmas in Florida will never be the same. All our love. The Phillips Family FONTANA--Vincent J. Staff of the Frances L. Loeb Child Protection & Development Center of Bellevue Hospital mourns the passing of a mentor and advocate for children. Margaret McHugh, MD

Paid Notice: Deaths   BEAN, ROBERT WILLIAM
description: BEAN--Robert William. Aged 87, died on July 2, 2005 in Phoenix, AZ. Born and educated in Council Bluffs, IA, he became a National Scholar, honor graduate and member of Phi Beta Kappa at Harvard University. As an American Scandinavian Foundation Fellow, he studied at the University of Oslo, where he was in the winter of April 1940 when the Germans invaded. After the Second World War, in which he served as an Army captain - chiefly in the Office of Strategic Services, London and Norway - he worked as an economist, first with the International Section of the Federal Reserve Board, then, for the rest of his career, in the Office of International Finance, U.S Treasury Department. From 1948, he was U.S. Treasury Representative and Embassy Economic Counselor in Stockholm, Bern and London, successively. He leaves behind his wife, Margaret, three sons, William, Jeffrey and Mark, seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. He was a talented photographer and a great collector of family memorabilia and history. He was much loved by his family who will miss his wit and good humor. As well, they would like to honor the Coronado Home of the Hospice of the Valley where, in his last few days, he was so appreciated and given watchful and tender care.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Judges Say Dean Can Be Fired
description: The dean of students at an intermediate school on Staten Island can be fired for a criminal conviction for drug possession, an appellate court ruled unanimously yesterday. The ruling, by the Appellate Division, First Department, overturned a lower court ruling and invalidated an arbitrator's determination that the New York City Department of Education could not fire the dean, Michael Campbell, of I.S. 72 in the Heartland Village section. Mr. Campbell, who was arrested in 2002 after detectives found cocaine and marijuana in his car, was a teacher at the school for about a decade and its dean for four years, and had no history of wrongdoing. An arbitrator ordered that he be reinstated after completing a drug treatment program. But the Appellate Division said in its ruling that it found the decision "to defy common sense," as it would place Mr. Campbell in charge of the program that discourages drug use among students. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: En Route to the Beach, Seeking Guidance From Above

Just then, my $2,200 traffic-guidance system, the AVIC-N2 from Pioneer Electronics, spoke up. Though not, unfortunately, with advice about the current predicament. "In 30 miles there is slow-moving traffic," it said in a lilting female voice. "Do you want to re-route?"

According to Nielsen's estimates, the finale attracted 21.84 million viewers, the largest audience of the show's run, making it the most-watched show since the summer season began. The "Dancing" conclusion was flanked by a repeat of the previous week's installment (10.18 million) and a "Lost" rerun (7.85 million). ABC easily won the night in all key ratings measures. On WB, another reality show, "Beauty and the Geek," also ended, bringing in 4.1 million viewers. It won the 8 p.m. hour in adults 18 to 34, the demographic WB targets. title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: PHS Group Is Acquired
description: Charterhouse Capital Partners, a British buyout firm, agreed to pay 600 million, or $1.05 billion, for the PHS Group, Britain's second-largest washroom-services company, gaining a business where profit has doubled in three years. Charterhouse, which owned PHS years ago before taking it public in 2001, will pay 116.36 pence a share in cash, including a 1.36 pence dividend. That is 32.6 percent more than PHS's closing price on May 16, the day before the buyout firm first made an approach, it said in a statement. Charterhouse will also assume 139.1 million of debt. "There was a long list of potential bidders, including buyout firms and trade buyers," Jan Astrand, an independent PHS director, said in an interview, without giving details. "I think it's a good offer." He recommended that shareholders accept. PHS, whose clients include the Asda chain owned by Wal-Mart Stores, has doubled sales since 2001 as businesses outsource contracts to maintain washrooms, office plants and water coolers.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Wrong Man In Custody

It was the latest in a series of high-profile bungles by prosecutors that have shaken the credibility of the attorney general's office. The authorities continued to hold the man while investigating allegations he is linked to the drug trade, even though his relatives say that he is a respected architect named Joaqun Romero Aparicio. Jos Luis Santiago Vasconcelos, the head of the federal police's organized crime unit, said the man in custody was not Mr. Carrillo Fuentes, who is believed to have had plastic surgery, after DNA test results came back negative. title: The Listings: July 8 -- July 14; 'FABULOUS! FASHIONS OF THE 1940'S'
description: This show affords a glimpse of the tip of an enormous historical iceberg. Organized by Ellen Shanley, costume curator at the Museum at the Fashion Institute of Technology, around a selection of dresses from the museum's collection, it is about what happened after Germany invaded Paris in 1940 and the city that had been the Western world's unrivaled leader in high fashion lost that role to New York. In Allied countries, response to war by designers and manufacturers was partly determined by officially mandated conservation measures, but new styles also reflected the military spirit of the moment. In contrast to the elaborately frilly neo-Victorian gowns that were coming out of Paris just before the war, American designers like Adrian (see above) began to produce severe, streamlined, square-shouldered dresses: no-nonsense neo-Classical costumes for female warriors. Women's sportswear took off, too, led by the elegantly functional designs of Claire McCardell. (Athleticism was a good cover under which to smuggle in eroticism in the form of tennis outfits and bathing suits.) The Paris fashion industry continued to produce for wealthy French collaborators and Germans, but it was isolated and its influence stifled. Then, shortly after the war, Paris bounced back with the New Look, the ultra-feminine style created by Christian Dior, which restored the city to its former place as ruler of world fashion. (The Museum at FIT, Seventh Avenue at 27th Street, Chelsea, (212) 217-5800 , through July 30.) KEN JOHNSON

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VEAR, JUDD GRAY
description: VEAR--Judd Gray. August 23, 1923-July 5, 2005. Born in Albion, MI, Judd grew up in Wheaton, IL. He enlisted in the Army Air Corps in 1943 and was a fighter pilot of P51 Mustangs in the European theater during WWII. Judd graduated from the University of Michigan in 1947 and married Rita Sullivan. Judd's forty year career with the William Randolph Hearst Corporation took him from Chicago to New York City where he was Publisher of Good Housekeeping Magazine for several years. In addition to his wife Rita, he is survived by his six children Timothy, Casey, Lynn, Jim, Kate and Matthew; their spouses; ten loving grandchildren; and his brothers Charles, David and John. A memorial mass will be performed at St. Monica's Parish in Moraga, CA on Saturday, July 9 at 11:00 AM.

She considered the Institute a force for good in the world, and her warmth and generosity of spirit will never be forgotten. We send heartfelt condolences to her family. Robert B. Machinist, Chairman, American Committee Dr. Albert Willner, President, American Committee Martin S. Kraar, Exec VP, American Committee Stuart Eizenstat, Chairman, Weizmann Institute Prof. Ilan Chet, President, Weizmann Institute

title: Raoul Walsh at the Museum of the Moving Image
description: If you want to know what's wrong with Hollywood, look no further than Raoul Walsh, one of the classic studio system's immortals. Walsh had a prolific career in silent cinema and the talkies, and he was an impeccable craftsman who directed great movies while working under the ostensible creative yoke, including the deranged "White Heat" (1949), which famously features James Cagney shrieking "Made it, Ma! Top of the world!" just before he's engulfed in flames. Walsh was born in New York in 1887 and, after running off to sea as a youth, landed in the movies, where he stayed active for the next half-century. He worked behind and in front of the camera for D.W. Griffith, playing John Wilkes Booth in "The Birth of a Nation." Thereafter, he concentrated on directing, losing an eye along the way. Among the few of his silent films featured in the retrospective at the Museum of the Moving Image is "Regeneration" (1915, with William Sheer, above), a beautifully atmospheric gangster movie about a thug and a settlement worker that was shot on the Lower East Side. Over the decades, Walsh worked across genres, making Bible stories and war movies, westerns and thrillers, and a pip of an entertainment called "The Revolt of Mamie Stover" (1956), starring the full-figured Jane Russell as a very opportunistic honky-tonk hostess. Walsh gave tough women their due, but it is his men that linger, as much for their pathos as for their grit: men like Cagney's racketeer in "The Roaring Twenties" (1939) and Humphrey Bogart's thief in "High Sierra" (1941) who, while certainly hard-boiled, are also softer inside than a three-minute egg. (Tomorrow through Aug. 21, Museum of the Moving Image, 36-01 35th Avenue, at 36th Street, Astoria, Queens, (718)784-4520.) MANOHLA DARGIS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDELL, IRA LEBECK
description: MENDELL--Ira Lebeck. Beloved husband of Joan Armour and the late Peggy Postley died at the age of 92 at his summer home in Purchase, NY. He was a resident of Sarasota, FL. He was a devoted father to his three children and their spouses: Thomas and Andrea Mendell, Alice and Kenneth Starr, James and Peg Kamens Mendell. Adored grandfather to Randall Starr, Carolyn Starr Doolittle, her husband Cameron, Cynthia Starr, Russell, Jake and Molly Rose Mendell, Lauren Mendell and the late Alexander Mendell and one great grandchild Grace Doolittle. He is also survived by four loving stepchildren and eight step grandchildren. He served as an Army Captain and intelligence officer during World War II. Later, he became President of Regional Development Company of New York. He not only enjoyed golf as a sport, but was active in the Metropolitan Golf Association as a former president and for many years served as a committeeman of the United States Golf Association. Tubby, as he was referred to by most all who knew him, was a warm and loving man. He will surely be missed by everyone who had the privilege to know him. Services will be held at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale New York on Sunday, July 10th at 2 PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations in his memory be made to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, New York 10601-4403. MENDELL--Ira. The Board of Directors and members of Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with sorrow the passing of our esteemed friend and member for more than 67 years, Ira Mendell. An active committee member of the USGA and former president of the Metropolitan Golf Association, in 1992 "Tubby" was a recipient of its highest honor, the Distinguished Service Award. Our deepest and heartfelt condolences to his wife, Joan, his children, Alice, Tom and Jim and the entire family. Steven M. Slaven, President Thomas W. Brock, Secretary MENDELL--Ira. Bright, witty and warm. We've enjoyed our time together travelling the world with Joan and Tubby. We'll miss his company. Sincere condolences to the family. Carol and Howard Phillips

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Oil Companies Swap Assets
description: The Russian gas monopoly Gazprom and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group said they had reached a asset-swap deal involving two of their largest projects. Under the deal, Gazprom will buy a stake of up to 25 percent plus one share in the Sakhalin-2 natural gas project off Russia's far eastern coast, and cede a 50 percent interest in its huge Zapolyarnoye-Neocomian gas field in northern Russia. The difference in value between the assets is to be settled in cash, the companies said in a joint statement. The deal has been years in the making, and represents Shell's long-sought-after entry into upstream gas in mainland Russia. Zapolyarnoye, a multilayered asset with numerous gas- and condensate-bearing formations, is the world's fifth-largest gas field, according to Gazprom's estimates. Shell has a 55 percent stake in the project. A Shell spokesman in Russia said, "It is anticipated that Shell will remain the largest single shareholder, with a stake greater than 30 percent."

title: A Son of Two Nations, Stoically Searching for His Father
description: The title of "The Beautiful Country," an earnestly humane film by the Norwegian director Hans Petter Moland, refers both to Vietnam, where the story begins, and to the United States, where it concludes. Stuart Dryburgh's cinematography testifies to the truth of the description in both cases, beautifully capturing the humid, verdant landscape of the Vietnamese countryside and the dry, craggy plains of west Texas, as well as the bustle of Hanoi and Manhattan. The hero, Binh (Damien Nguyen), belongs to both countries, and therefore to neither. The son of a Vietnamese woman and an American G.I., he lives as a pariah in postwar Vietnam, performing menial labor and enduring the contempt of the relatives who grudgingly allow him to live with them.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Assemblyman's Petition Denied
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court yesterday denied a petition in which Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn Democratic leader, sought to prohibit his prosecution in Brooklyn on the basis that it was the wrong jurisdiction. Mr. Norman has been indicted four times in Brooklyn since 2003, on a series of criminal charges. He argued to dismiss one of the indictments. But the court found that the geographic jurisdiction rested in Brooklyn and that separation of powers did not bar his prosecution. The case will now be put on the calendar for trial, said Monique Ferrell, an assistant district attorney. A lawyer for Mr. Norman, Roger Bennet Adler, said the Court of Appeals would be asked to hear the case. Al Baker (NYT)

title: The Listings: July 8 -- July 14; FUGATE/BAHIRI BALLET NY
description: Dancegoers looking for something new in ballet and music might find much to fascinate them in a program of four world premieres by this lively company, directed by Judith Fugate, formerly of the New York City Ballet, and her husband, Medhi Bahiri, formerly of Maurice Bjart's company. Two works have live music. Davis Robertson's "Romeo and Juliet in Mantua" has a commissioned score by David Homan and offers a new version of the classic love story that includes what Mr. Robertson promises will be some unexpected plot twists. Alan Hineline's plotless but energetic and sensual "Quartet 2" is set to a commissioned score of its own, by Jerome Begin. The evening's other pieces are danced to contemporary music on tape. (The troupe's dancers include Fidel Garcia and Melissa Morrissey, above.) Jodie Gates's "now and again" challenges dancers' minds as well as bodies. The steps are often off balance. And there are moments when fixed sequences of movements give way to improvisation. All this happens to a combination of Bach and original music by Dietrich Krueger. Helen Heineman's "Hook-Up," to music by Arnold Dreyblatt, explores the comings together and driftings apart of a man and a woman. All the choreography seems unpredictable. There's certainly not a swan queen in sight. But that very unpredictability helps whet curiosity. (Tonight at 8, tomorrow at 2 and 7 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212)242-0800 or www.joyce.org, $34.) JACK ANDERSON

The Listings: July 8 -- July 14; 'AS YOU LIKE IT'
description: It's almost impossible to take a stroll outside this summer without tripping over a poorly paid actor trying to wrap his tongue around iambic pentameter. Just in recent weeks, there have been free al fresco productions of "Henry V" in Inwood Hill Park, "As You Like It" in Central Park and "Richard III" in a parking lot on the Lower East Side. On Tuesday, the umpteenth production of "As You Like It" (at least it's not "A Midsummer Night's Dream," which has been read aloud more often than the Pledge of Allegiance) opens at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park. I have nothing against the Bard, but couldn't we mix it up a bit? How about Kushner in the Park? Or Albee in the Park? Parks in the Park has a nice ring to it. Considering the lack of choices during these humid months, I bet that Anyone but Shakespeare in the Park would be a hot ticket. Free outdoor theater is one of the great things about the summer, but when will a young producer realize that it could be so much better if the menu of shows was more diverse? To be fair, the Public Theater often presents plays by other (usually dead) writers at the Delacorte. After the run of "As You Like It," it will shake things up with a revival of "Two Gentleman of Verona," a musical based on a play by, well, need you even ask? (Shakespeare in the Park: (212)260-2400 or www.publictheater.org.) JASON ZINOMAN

title: 36 Hours in Block Island, R.I.
description: THE same mile-high glacier that parked off southern New England, heaping up Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard for Massachusetts and the Forks of Long Island for New York, also left behind an appropriately diminutive summer playground for little Rhode Island. Giovanni da Verrazano, when he passed by in 1524, thought the place looked like Rhodes in Greece; hence the state's eventual name. But the island itself ended up with the name of a Dutch explorer, Adriaen Block. It was a place for pirates, as well as for fishermen and farmers who piled up the glacier's rocks into deceptively delicate-looking stone walls that lace the island's 10 square miles. Around the end of the 19th century, a string of grand wooden hotels were built with gloriously long porches overlooking the sea and grassy lawns where multispired wedding tents now bloom virtually every weekend of the summer. Away from the hotels, Block Island has a little of the flavor of the quieter parts of Nantucket or the Vineyard (and little in common with anywhere on Long Island). But although people at those bigger and tonier ends of the summer archipelago will sniff their usual sniffs about how you can't get good cheese on the next rock pile over, bass fishermen and others know that, in the very center of the necklace, Block Island is the crown jewel of the bunch.

title: In Americans, Lurking Fears Rise to Surface

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: President Reaches Out To Rebels
description: President lvaro Uribe said Colombia would consider paying members of the country's second-largest rebel group, the National Liberation Army, known as E.L.N. here, to disarm. Quoted in Spain's most prominent newspaper, El Pas, Mr. Uribe said, "I want to say this: if they accept a complete end to hostilities, the government has no problem in finding funds to sustain E.L.N. members in a peace process, as long as they do not commit crimes." He added, "It is the first time I say this in public." The Cuban-inspired E.L.N., which has been battered by a military offensive, has held talks with Mr. Uribe's government but has so far rejected enacting a cease-fire. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: If It's a Muslim Problem, It Needs a Muslim Solution
description: Yesterday's bombings in downtown London are profoundly disturbing. In part, that is because a bombing in our mother country and closest ally, England, is almost like a bombing in our own country. In part, it's because one assault may have involved a suicide bomber, bringing this terrible jihadist weapon into the heart of a major Western capital. That would be deeply troubling because open societies depend on trust -- on trusting that the person sitting next to you on the bus or subway is not wearing dynamite.

World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deutsche Bank Sells Unit
description: Aberdeen Asset Management, the Scottish money manager, agreed to buy Deutsche Bank's British fund unit for as much as 265 million ($465 million) to almost triple assets under management. Aberdeen will sell 215 million of shares to existing investors to help finance the acquisition, the company said. The purchase may increase Aberdeen's assets to more than 70 billion from 25.4 billion on March 31. The takeover is the first for Martin J. Gilbert, the chief executive of Aberdeen, since the company agreed in December to reimburse investors as much as 78.3 million for losses from the collapse of funds known as split-capital trusts. Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank, has been seeking a buyer for its British fund unit, which has been losing pension clients, for six months.

The Olympic Games
description: New Yorkers whose hopes of getting the 2012 Olympics were dashed this week will surely rally around London. But it is still going to require a major effort for some of the city's leaders to get past their personal disappointment. Deputy Mayor Daniel Doctoroff -- the bid's chief architect -- and Mayor Michael Bloomberg expended a great deal of time and energy trying to bring the Olympics here. But the city's bid was always a dark horse at best, and in the end New York finished fourth among the five competing cities.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Drug Kingpin Pleads Guilty
description: Jos Mara Henao Meja, who was on a Justice Department list of the world's most wanted drug traffickers, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to heading a drug network based in Medelln, Colombia, and conspiring to launder drug money, said David N. Kelley, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Henao was arrested in Colombia in 2002 and extradited to the United States last year. As part of the investigation, law enforcement agencies seized thousands of kilograms of cocaine and convicted 21 people -- 17 in Manhattan and 4 in Spain. Prosecutors said the organization had distribution cells in Miami, Chicago, New York and towns in New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Of Boca Raton, FL and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. Born NYC in 1912 to a family of modest circumstances. In his early 20's he played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." He appeared as an extra in Hollywood movies of the 1930's and became a member of the Friars Club. Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. He served on the board of the Nassau County Adult Rehabilitation Program. Into his early 90's, Irving was an avid golfer. He played in a number of Pro-Am tournaments and shot two holes-in-one. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud self-made man. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Irving's name to a charity of your choice. Funeral Sunday, July 10, 1 PM at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills NY (718263-7600). Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY. PATRON--Irving. The Board of Directors and membership of Glen Head Country Club annouce with profound sorrow the passing of our esteemed founding member, former Board member and Honorary Member, Irving Patron. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the bereaved family. Alvin Levine, President

Although the 29-year-old Krayzelburg is not competing at the world championships in Montreal later this month, he has been tracking other swimmers' times the way an investor follows stocks.

title: Authorities Step Up Security on American Transit Systems
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 - Concerned about a "copycat attack," federal officials elevated the alert for the nation's rail, subway and bus systems on Thursday, prompting more police patrols, searches by bomb-sniffing dogs and inspections of packages across the country.
