title: Suspect in Police Shooting Remains Alive After 14-Floor Fall
description: A man who jumped from a 14th-floor window on Wednesday after a wild shootout at an East Harlem housing project in which he wounded a police sergeant was in critical condition yesterday, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the way changes in bankruptcy regulations may affect small-business owners misstated the given name of the president of the National Association of Consumer Bankruptcy Attorneys, who commented on the overhaul. He is Henry Sommer, not Harry.

title: A Daredevil Prepares for a Great Big Jump
description: In the early 13th century, Genghis Khan's armies were the first major conquerors to circumvent the Great Wall of China. Danny Way, an American skateboarder, will need only a few seconds tomorrow to launch over the wall.

title: Have You Heard the One About the Cabby?
description: TO enter the Midtown loft of Jim Pietsch, the lead-footed author of all three volumes in The New York City Cab Driver's Joke Book series, is to be warned that snide rumors about the demise of jokes-as-social-barometers and founts of merriment, as was reported in the Styles section of this very newspaper, may be premature. Actually, in Mr. Pietsch's opinion, either the reports are outright bogus or his entire life's literary output is. A good belly laugh doesn't lie, does it?

title: Gusto Ristorante e Bar Americano
description: In a big way Gusto Ristorante e Bar Americano goes entirely with the flow. In smaller ways it swims against the current. It's conformist and contrary, familiar and unexpected, leaning on a cuisine of amply proven popularity but then giving it shadings and a kind of showcase that it doesn't always get.

title: Suspect in 3 Rapes Arrested
description: The police arrested a 49-year-old convicted rapist yesterday in connection with a string of early-morning sexual assaults in which the assailant climbed through open apartment windows in Manhattan last month and attacked women as they slept.

title: Birth rate of Latinos rises in U.S.
Group of 8 Leaders Announce Pacts on Aid to Africa
description: AUCHTERARDER, Scotland, July 8 - Striking tones of optimism and defiance a day after the attacks in London, President Bush and the leaders of seven other big industrial nations concluded a summit meeting here today saying they had made substantial progress in addressing African poverty, global warming and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Meanwhile: Why I run with the bulls year after year after year
Bombings Rewrite Agenda for World Leaders in Scotland
description: AUCHTERARDER, Scotland, July 7 - The bombings in London on Thursday knocked the meeting of major industrial nations off its carefully scripted focus on global warming and African poverty and turned it into a forum for President Bush and other world leaders to pledge unity in confronting terrorism.

title: Art in Review; Matthew Monahan
description: Anton Kern Gallery 532 West 20th Street, Chelsea Through July 30

title: London Exchange Continues With Trading
description: LONDON, July 7 - The London Stock Exchange proved resilient Thursday, remaining open after four terrorist attacks hit London, though the market closed lower after setting a trading volume record.

title: Spare Times
description: Attractions

title: 'Emptying' Sculpture to Make Room for Spiritual Energy
description: Few artists have been more exhaustively theoretical in their approach than the Basque sculptor Jorge Oteiza (1908-2003), whose most important work was accomplished during the 1950's. Feeling that he had reached his goal of paring sculpture down to an emptied (not "empty") space filled with spiritual energy, in 1959 he turned his attention to aesthetic and linguistic research, and the political and social causes of the Basques, with a brief return to art-making from 1972 to 1975.

title: The Jailing of Judith Miller, and the State of the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: The Jailing of Judith Miller, and the State of the Press
description: To the Editor:

title: Novartis takes rare road to cures
Who Cares About Inflation?
description: PARIS - INFLATION is coming. Politicians, while they may not actually want it, prefer it to the alternatives in both Europe and the United States.

title: Wider EU sanctions on Belarus urged
Couple Sentenced in Bribery at Bank
description: A New Jersey metals merchant and his wife have been sentenced to federal prison for bribing an employee of the Midtown branch of the Bank of China in exchange for favorable treatment on business loans, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TABAK, TEDDY LAWRENCE
description: TABAK -- Teddy Lawrence, on July 6, 2005. Beloved husband of Alberta (nee Ratzan). Cherished father of James & Nan Tabak and Nancy & Scott Chandler. Adored grandfather of Michele & Corey Chandler and Jillian & Michael Tabak. Loving brother of Sheldon & Marian Tabak and Hope & Michael Proper. Service Friday 11:45AM at "The Riverside," 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Survivor: Liberty Island
description: Survivor: Liberty Island

title: In Police Class, Blue Comes in Many Colors
description: When 1,600 recruits become police officers next week, they will make up the first graduating class in the history of the New York City Police Department that is majority minority; less than half the men and women are white. The difference -- the class is 45.2 percent non-Hispanic white -- is seen by many as a significant marker in the department's slow racial evolution.

title: Finding Schilling's Proper Role Is New Challenge for the Red Sox
description: THE team won the World Series last year for the first time in 86 years and has its largest division lead in more than three years, but the sky above Fenway Park in Boston is cloudy with turbulence and trepidation.

title: Iraq Asks Muslim Nations Not to Be Deterred by Envoy's Death
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 8 - Iraq's transitional government anxiously reached out to Arab and other Muslim countries today, urging them not to be intimidated by the killing of Egypt's top diplomat in Iraq by an Islamic militant group linked to Al Qaeda.

title: Timers Used in Blasts, Police Say; Parallels to Madrid Are Found
description: LONDON, July 7 - Investigators searching for clues in the attacks here said Thursday that the three bombs used in the subway apparently were detonated by timers, not suicide bombers, and that a fourth device may have been intended for a target other than the city bus that it destroyed.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a Westchester County school district's plan to remove PCB-contaminated soil from an elementary school in Yorktown Heights referred incorrectly to a Harvard study that found high levels of the chemical in caulking materials used in 8 of 24 buildings in the Boston area. The study did not also analyze the air and dust in the buildings; it cited similar studies of caulking in other buildings, where PCB-contaminated air and dust were also found.

title: Wall Street Encouraged by Job Growth in June
description: The American economy added 146,000 jobs in June, the government said today in an employment report that showed smaller growth than economists had expected but still gave them reason to be encouraged.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Industrial Production Falls
description: Malaysia's industrial production unexpectedly declined in May for the first time in three years, as mining output fell and demand for Asian electronics cooled. Production at factories, mines and utilities fell 0.4 percent from a year earlier, compared with revised growth of 4 percent in April, the Statistics Department in Putrajaya said. Malaysia joins other Asian electronics exporters including South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore that have been hit by faltering manufacturing and shipments. Softer sales for technology companies amid rising oil prices may make it harder for Prime Minister Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, above, and his government to meet their 2005 growth target of as much as 6 percent. The central bank has forecast growth of 5 to 6 percent in Malaysia's economy, after 2004's expansion of 7.1 percent.

title: Sand Castle Contests
description: AS if to prove that no one ever really outgrows the childhood obsession with digging in dirt, nine professional sand sculptors will convene on the beach in Revere, Mass., next weekend to play with 200 tons of sand. They will compete for $10,000 in prize money in the new master's invitational division at the Revere Beach Partnership Sandcastle Festival.

title: TV's Languishing Laughometer
description: JEEZ, would it kill us to laugh more? Have we, the audience for television comedy, become an inveterately tough crowd, perpetually annoyed grumps who take one skeptical look at focus-grouped new sitcoms that employ empirically adorable comedians and award-winning writers from "Letterman" and "The Simpsons," and still won't for the world crack one paltry half-smile?

title: Witness Photos on WebCaptured London Drama
description: Cian O'Donovan is not a photojournalist, but when he heard about the subway bombings not far from his home in London, he decided to try to photograph them.

title: Bush offers 'condolences' to Britain
Giuliani Was Near Site of Bombing
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani, whose legacy as mayor of New York City was transformed by his stewardship during and after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, was on a business trip to London yesterday when he found himself half a block from the first blast there.

title: Art in Review; What Sound Does a Color Make?
description: Eyebeam 540 West 21st Street, Chelsea Through July 16

title: EU demands service improvements
Paid Notice: Deaths   GROSS, RUBIN
description: GROSS--Rubin, 97, died peacefully at home in New Jersey. He was a quiet man who brought strength, wisdom, love, and his famous sense of humor to so many people. His family will deeply miss him.

title: Roundup: Bulgarian delegate expelled by IOC
Briefs: Uzbeks to reconsider future of U.S. air base
The Secret Man: The Story of Watergate's Deep Throat
Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on June 27, about on-screen commercials at movie theaters, included an outdated reference to a plan by Loews Cineplex to put up signs saying that because of ads and previews, movies start 10 to 15 minutes after the posted time. The program is under way; it was not deferred.

title: An Old Town With Benefits
description: POPULATION 3,433.

title: Free to Choose Obesity?
description: The obvious model for those hoping to reverse the fattening of America is the campaign against smoking. Before the surgeon general officially condemned smoking in 1964, rising cigarette consumption seemed an unstoppable trend; since then, consumption per capita has fallen more than 50 percent.

title: Billions Needed to Improve Great Lakes, Coalition Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 - A coalition of government agencies, businesses and environmental groups on Thursday offered a blueprint for improving the deteriorating health of the Great Lakes, including spending $13.75 billion over five years to stop untreated sewage from overflowing into the lakes from aging wastewater treatment plants.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Friday about Congressional opposition to the purchase of Unocal by the China National Offshore Oil Corporation referred incorrectly in some copies to the party of Representative Jim Moran, who opposed an effort to block the takeover. He is a Democrat.

title: INSIDE
description: Hurricane Gains Power Hurricane Dennis swirled into a Category 4 storm, with 135 mile-an-hour winds and rain. At least four people were killed in Haiti. PAGE A18

title: 7/7: Terror in Britain, Echoes in America
description: To the Editor:

title: McMillan Leaves Sonics, but He Doesn't Go Far
description: Nate McMillan's nickname, Mr. Sonic, will not fly three hours down the road. How about Mr. Trail Blazer?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Sharpton And Pirro Confer
description: The Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine Pirro, said yesterday that the Rev. Al Sharpton had called her office to urge that a black man who said he murdered a White Plains woman last week because she was white be prosecuted "vigorously." Ms. Pirro said that Mr. Sharpton made the brief telephone call to her office yesterday to offer his condolences to the family of the victim, Concetta Russo-Carriero, 56, and to emphasize that he is against bigotry "irrespective of the side from which it comes." Ms. Russo-Carriero was stabbed to death in a garage in downtown White Plains, and the man arrested and charged with the crime, Phillip Grant, 43, told interrogators that he picked her because she was white. Ms. Pirro said this week that she would present the case as a hate crime. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: When a Thug Meets a Working Girl
description: The feature-film debut of the 26-year-old Flemish filmmaker Felix van Groeningen, "Steve + Sky" is the story of how Steve (Titus De Voogdt), a scruffy small-time hoodlum just released from jail, falls for Sky (Delfine Bafort), a nave young prostitute trying to get out of the life.

title: At 15, Wie Tests Menon P.G.A. Tour
description: SILVIS, Ill., July 7 - While many other teenage girls relaxed Thursday on summer vacation, Michelle Wie was playing on the PGA Tour and giving the men a run for their money.

title: These Gladiators on Wheels Are Not Playing for a Hug
description: Who wins and who loses in the gripping sports documentary "Murderball" may not be a matter of life and death. But the ferocity of competition displayed in the film's full-body immersion in wheelchair rugby trumps any high-powered gamesmanship you'll find on reality television. Invented in Canada in the 1970's, the sport used to be known as murderball, until the name proved an insurmountable barrier to securing corporate sponsorship.

title: Case Isn't Closed as Spitzer's Office Plans to Retry Broker on 4 Counts
description: A former Bank of America broker who was acquitted last month on 29 of 33 criminal charges tied to improper trading of mutual funds, faces a retrial on the four counts on which jurors could not agree, lawyers in the case said yesterday.

title: Prisoners Finding New Hope in the Art of Spiritual Bliss
description: "Doing Time, Doing Vipassana," a humane, lotus-scented documentary with a heavy spiritual agenda, tells the story of how an ancient Buddhist meditation technique that's similar but not identical to Zen has improved life for thousands of prisoners incarcerated in Tihar, India's largest prison.

title: Honing Its Image as a Little Investment Bank That Can
description: When John G. Duffy, the chief executive of Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, received a phone call last month inviting him to work on the biggest deal of his career, it was payback for a relationship forged in the Texas Panhandle a dozen years ago.

title: AMD states case loud and clear
For Martnez, Mets' Season Trumps the All-Star Game
description: WASHINGTON, July 7 - Pedro Martnez, who has had a standout first half of the season with the Mets, said on Thursday that he would forfeit his spot on the National League team for the All-Star Game next week.

title: A Commentary on the Ruthless Pursuit of the News, With Some Cat-and-Mouse Thrown In
description: In the sometimes savvy media melodrama "Crnicas," John Leguizamo plays Manolo Bonilla, the charismatic star reporter for a tabloid investigative news show, "One Hour With the Truth," that originates in Miami and is broadcast across Latin America. A swaggering little fame monger ablaze with ambition and hot to pounce on the next gory sensation, Manolo descends with his producer, Marisa (Leonor Watling), and his cameraman, Ivan (Jos Mara Yazpik), on the dirt-poor Ecuadorian village of Babahoyo.

title: The Avant-Garde, Rarely Love at First Sight
description: Have you ever gone to an avant-garde play that some critic (perhaps even myself) has given a rapturous review only to find yourself utterly bored, baffled or both?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hospital Official Admits Fraud
description: A former assistant vice president in the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation pleaded guilty on Wednesday to mail fraud and theft for accepting payments to allow vendors to submit false invoices to the corporation, said David N. Kelley, the United States attorney in Manhattan. The former official, Ronald Maiorana, 45, of Dobbs Ferry, admitted in court that he accepted $700,000 between September 1999 and June 2004 for allowing printing companies to submit invoices falsely certifying that they had done work for the corporation, prosecutors said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Friday about Congressional opposition to the purchase of Unocal by the China National Offshore Oil Corporation referred incorrectly in some copies to the party of Representative Jim Moran, who opposed an effort to block the takeover. He is a Democrat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUNTER, EVAN
description: HUNTER--Evan. The Writers Guild of America, East mourns the passing of its distinguished member Evan Hunter. A strong proponent of creative and economic rights for writers, Evan Hunter served on WGA East Council for ten years and was awarded the Ian McLellan Hunter Award for "Lifetime Achievement in Writing" in 2001. Throughout his 50-year career he inspired generations of writers with the acclaimed novel "The Blackboard Jungle" followed by decades of best-selling novels, short stories, plays and film scripts. His legendary screenplays also include "Strangers When We Meet" (based on his novel) and "The Birds." He was a friend to many guild members and he will be greatly missed. Warren Leight President, WGAE Mona Mangan Executive Director, WGAE HUNTER--Evan. The Hunter College community mourns the passing of our esteemed alumnus whose name has always been associated with his alma mater. One of our first male graduates, he enjoyed interacting with and inspiring our students. His presence on campus will be sorely missed. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College HUNTER--Evan. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and friend, Evan Hunter, and send condolences to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BIRNBAUM, EDITH B.
description: BIRNBAUM--Edith B., age 82, of Heritage Village, Southbury, CT. Died July 6, 2005 at Danbury Hospital. She was loved by her husband Milton, children and grandchildren. She will be very much missed. Services Friday, July 8, 11 AM, at Temple B'nai Israel, 444 Main Street, North, Southbury, CT. Burial Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY.

title: Pension Fund Managers Come Knocking, in Vain
description: THE money managers overseeing the state pension funds in Washington and Oregon have been making the rounds in Silicon Valley in recent months, hoping to find some venture capitalists willing to take their money. So, too, have their counterparts from Ohio, New Mexico and other states.

title: 7/7: Terror in Britain, Echoes in America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Town Where the Spirit World Rules
description: AS the rays of afternoon light filtered into her comfortable reading room, Sherry Lee Calkins swept a piece of brownish chalk over a large piece of drawing paper, a dreamy look in her eye. "There's a short man in the room, wearing a cap with a tassel on it," she said. "He's a Scotsman. A grandparent or great-grandparent."

title: Manically Happy Campers and Rich but Vicious Cats
description: On television, most hours of live-action mayhem can throw a young mind. To children, the flashing of ambulance lights, the cable news crawl, even the histrionics of soap opera vixens -- these all raise a lot of questions. The televised mtier preferred by children remains the cartoon, but consider the disorienting images that are the norm in that world. Here it's the adult mind that has to learn the visual language.

title: Navy Mission of Officer Was Secret to Parents
description: PATCHOGUE, N.Y., July 7 - The only details the parents of Lt. Michael P. Murphy knew about their son's missions were the funny ones. Like the time a pack of hyenas attacked him as he was jogging, or the e-mail message he sent his father about exercising on a running track where a sign read, "Please refrain from using this path until de-mining occurs."

title: Panic Attacks
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Exploring the Experimental
description: Avant-garde theater, including shows at Lincoln Center Festival 2005, takes many shapes.

title: On the Market
Building Jobs
description: From land surveyors to loan officers, the real estate industrial complex has become one of the few reliable sources of growth in recent years.

title: Hurricane Approaches Gulf Coast
description: Coastal residents from the Florida Keys all the way to Louisiana scrambled or held their breath as Hurricane Dennis plowed through Cuba.

title: Bankrolling Fields of Dreams
description: Is there anything more American than baseball and Broadway?

title: A Colt Born on a Battlefield, When Men Were Gallant
description: You might expect a movie about an adorable newborn animal who melts the hearts of soldiers at war to be syrupy, sentimental and not worth the viewing time of anyone older than 8. But "The Colt," which has its premiere tonight on the Hallmark Channel, is only sentimental. And that sentimentality is tempered by several nicely understated performances and a painfully realistic ending.

title: Look Back in Anger: A Punk History for the Pious
description: Punk rock is one thing. Think what you like about it. Go to small shows at clubs in Louisville, Ottawa, VFW halls. Blast the Buzzocks and Suicide. Watch "Sid and Nancy" over and over.

title: Grrr! No One Can Outwit The Hulk
description: Hulk Hogan, the enormous 51-year-old wrestler with the impressive blond mustache, has been described more than a few times as charismatic. So there's a certain logic in building a reality series around him. Even the idea of VH1's "Hogan Knows Best," which has its premiere tomorrow night, is appealing. Surely there's inherent humor in comparing Mr. Hogan's parental woes and decisions with those of Robert Young's character in the old television series, as the title suggests. ("Father Knows Best" ran, on CBS and NBC at various times, from 1954 to 1960.)

title: Australia grants visa to Chinese diplomat who defected
Briefcase: OECD finds gaps in terror coverage
Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with an interview with Adam Bock, author of the play "Swimming in the Shallows," reversed the identities of two actors in the cast. Logan Marshall-Green was at the left and Michael Arden at the right.

title: Tourism industry suffers little damage, but future is uncertain
National Briefing | Washington: Cheney Has Annual Physical
description: Vice President Dick Cheney, plagued by heart problems for more than 25 years, had his annual physical at the George Washington University Medical Center. Doctors there found that Mr. Cheney's "cardiac status remains stable," his office said. John Files (NYT)

description: To the Editor:

title: I.O.C. Drops Baseball and Softball in 2012
description: The International Olympic Committee voted yesterday in Singapore to drop baseball and softball from the Summer Games starting in 2012 without adding replacements, shrinking the Olympics for the first time since 1936.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARTIN, DANIEL S., MD.
description: MARTIN--Daniel S., MD. Friends and colleagues of Dr. Dan Martin, Visiting Investigator at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, express their profound grief at his tragic accidental death. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family. A prominent surgeon, a former Director of Cancer Research at the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens, NY, and a former U.S. Army Medical Corps Captain, Dan devoted his professional life to developing better medicines for the treatment of cancer, especially breast cancer. His entire career demonstrated creativity, courage of conviction, and boundless vigor. He was an early proponent of combination drug treatment and championed its use as an adjunct to surgery, an approach that has saved tens of thousands of lives. We honor him for his lifetime of dedication and achievement, and remain inspired by his vision. He will be greatly missed. Larry Norton, MD Deputy Physician-in-Chief for Breast Cancer Programs Jason A. Koutcher, MD, Ph.D Chief Imaging and Spectroscopic Physics Service Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center

title: Secret Internet chat room helped calm U.K. markets
Envoys make rounds in North Korea crisis

description: FRIEDMAN -- Mayrose. On July 6. Beloved sister of Robert (Ruth) of Sarasota, FL, and Elliott (Barbara) of Freehold, NJ. Rest in peace. Graveside service is at Mount Hebron Cemetery, Sunday, at 1 PM.

title: Their Lighthouse, Our Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: German's Dream Has Everything but Victory
description: KARLSRUHE, Germany, July 8 - Of the 16 Germans competing in the Tour de France, only Fabian Wegmann was adventurous, optimistic or foolhardy enough to think that the ideal way to enter his home country on Friday was alone at the head of the race, alone by far.

title: No jail time for worm's creator
Srebrenica: Lessons of a terrible blunder
Watching for danger in 'good' markets
N.Y.'s 'other expats' in search of a home
G-8 claims some progress on aid and global warming
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Sven Jaschan, 19, the teenage creator of the Sasser Internet worm, which caused millions of dollars in damage worldwide, was convicted yesterday in Verden, Germany, on charges including computer sabotage. Mr. Jaschan received a 21-month suspended sentence and was ordered to do community service, a court spokeswoman, Katharina Kruetzfeld, said. Mr. Jaschan could have been sentenced to up to five years in prison. But, because he was a minor when arrested, prosecutors sought only a suspended sentence. (AP)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARKUS, MARIE (RITA)
description: MARKUS--Marie (Rita). The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the passing of Rita Markus, a devoted benefactor and friend. With her husband Frits, she endowed a fund for the acquisition of drawings, which they--and after his death, she--continued to support generously each year. Her love for her native country, The Netherlands, and her special dedication to the Metropolitan's Department of Drawings and Prints have enhanced the museum's holdings of Dutch and Flemish drawings enormously. Her grace and generosity will be greatly missed, and we extend condolences to her entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director Emily K. Rafferty, President MARKUS--Rita. The Board and Staff of The Educational Alliance thank Rita Markus for her generosity over the years. We extend our condolences to her entire family.

title: Speaking Out to Condemn the Extremists
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SHEPPS, HOWARD ZVI
description: SHEPPS--Howard Zvi. 13 years have passed and the memories are alive.

title: For a Hungry Audience, a Japanese Tom Clancy
description: TOKYO - GROPING for a career as he neared 30, Harutoshi Fukui decided to become a novelist while still working full time as a security guard. In little time he quit that job, after winning a prestigious Japanese literary prize in 1998 for "Twelve Y.O.," a political-military thriller whose title recalls Gen. Douglas MacArthur's infamous comment that Japan was a nation of 12-year-olds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATERS, FRANK T.
description: WATERS--Frank T., age 94, of Port Washington on July 7, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Irene. Loving father of Jane Gabbett (Todd), William, Laurel, and Alison Batten. Adored grandfather of Brittney, T.J., Kristin, Trevor and Bradley. Also survived by nieces, nephews, extended family and faithful caregiver Irakli. Reposing at Austin F. Knowles, Inc. Funeral Home, 128 Main St., Port Washington on Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. Interment private. In lieu of flowers, donations to Crohn's & Colitis Foundation of America, 585 Stewart Ave. (Suite 414), Garden City, NY 11530 would be greatly appreciated.

title: Disputed Driveways and Title Insurance Headaches
description: LIKE most homebuyers, Debra Kling did not pay much attention to title insurance when she and her husband bought a home in Larchmont, N.Y., last year.

title: Share Prices Defy an Oil Spike and the London Bombings
description: Stock markets in Europe rebounded yesterday, wiping out almost all of the losses incurred after Thursday's bombings in London, while stocks moved sharply higher in the United States -- winding up what has turned out to be a surprising week for equities.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Of Boca Raton, FL and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. Born NYC in 1912 to a family of modest circumstances. In his early 20's he played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." He appeared as an extra in Hollywood movies of the 1930's and became a member of the Friars Club. Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. He served on the board of the Nassau County Adult Rehabilitation Program. Into his early 90's, Irving was an avid golfer. He played in a number of Pro-Am tournaments and shot two holes-in-one. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud self-made man. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Irving's name to a charity of your choice. Funeral Sunday, July 10, 1 PM at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills NY (718263-7600). Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: A day when the little things made all the difference
For G.M., a Struggling Delphi Could Prove to Be a Burden
description: DETROIT, July 8 - As General Motors tries to cut tens of billions in labor costs, it faces the increasing likelihood that it will bear some financial responsibility for its former auto parts subsidiary Delphi, industry experts say.

title: Carnivorous Dragonflies
description: In the bug-eat-bug environment of the Adirondacks, a dragonfly turns out to be one of the best little friends a human being can have. Mainly, dragonflies eat flies and mosquitoes. Anything that keeps flies and mosquitoes from feeding on humans in the north woods qualifies as a force for good, and the adult dragonfly is supposed to eat something like 20 flies or mosquitoes an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PIERCE, NANCY W.
description: PIERCE--Nancy W., on July 8th. Beloved wife of Morton. Loving mother of Matthew and Nicholas. Devoted sister of Larry Washor. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service Sunday, July 10th, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. PIERCE--Nancy. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Nancy Pierce. To her family and loved ones, we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Rabbi David M. Posner, Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Secretary

title: Terror in London: Voices From There, and Here
description: To the Editor:

title: 8 Leaders Hail Steps on Africa and Warming
description: AUCHTERARDER, Scotland, July 8 - Striking tones of optimism and defiance a day after the attacks in London, President Bush and the leaders of seven other big industrial nations concluded a summit meeting here on Friday saying they had made substantial progress in addressing African poverty, global warming and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Beer Sponsor Is Dropped
description: To the Editor:

title: German law on chiefs' pay cleared
Borrowing by Consumers Fell in May
description: Borrowing by consumers unexpectedly fell in May, declining the most since December 1990, as customers switched from costly bank debt to cheaper home-equity loans.

title: Wie Stays Below Par but Misses PGA Cut

title: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Biometric Passports Approved
description: Germany's upper house of Parliament approved a plan to introduce new electronic passports with biometric data. "One aspect of combating terrorism is the security of travel documents," Interior Minister Otto Schily said in a statement. The new so-called e-Pass, which will be introduced in November, will initially contain a digital photograph on a chip. Starting in March 2007, the documents will also feature digitalized fingerprints. Germany will be the first European country to issue the new travel documents, which the United States will require visitors to carry for visa-free visits of up to 90 days. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Indonesian Tsunami Survivors Fearful of New Disasters
description: BANDA ACEH, Indonesia - With trees and buildings swept away by the tsunami six months ago, the people who live here can see the volcano clearly now, and it frightens them.

title: No Headline
description: Creator of Sasser Internet Worm Ordered to Do Community Service Sven Jaschan, 19, the teenage creator of the Sasser Internet worm, which caused millions of dollars in damage worldwide, was convicted yesterday in Verden, Germany, on charges including computer sabotage. Mr. Jaschan received a 21-month suspended sentence and was ordered to do community service, a court spokeswoman, Katharina Kruetzfeld, said. Mr. Jaschan could have been sentenced to up to five years in prison. But, because he was a minor when arrested, prosecutors sought only a suspended sentence. (AP)

title: Education Secretary Backs End to Student-Loan Loophole

title: 7-Eleven Beats a Path to the Big Cities
description: THE Big Gulp is returning to Manhattan. 7-Eleven Inc. is opening a store at 107 East 23rd Street on Monday. The company's last one closed in 1982. The opening is part of a broader expansion in cities, including Chicago, Boston and Los Angeles. The urban stores will be about half the size of their suburban counterparts.

title: Heavy Toll in Afghan Fight for Navy's Proud Elite

title: Jail for Robbery Attempt
description: A Brooklyn teenager pleaded guilty yesterday to an attempted robbery that took place hours before an actress was killed on the Lower East Side in January. The teenager, David Simmon, 18, pleaded guilty to first-degree attempted robbery. He was sentenced to six years in prison, and five years of postrelease supervision, which is similar to probation. Five of those years in prison will be served concurrently with his sentence for another robbery, in Brooklyn.

And that sentimentality is tempered by several nicely understated performances and a painfully realistic ending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHERR, HERMAN
description: SCHERR--Herman. Age 94, died July 7, 2005. Funeral services will be held at Riverside-Nassau North, Great Neck, Sunday at 12 PM. He graduated from CCNY with a Master's in Mechanical Engineering in 1934. Despite the Depression & discrimination in the private sector against Jewish engineers, he persevered to form his own company, Herman Scherr & Assoc., PE. He designed mechanical systems for major projects throughout the city. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Ruth Watnick Scherr, four children Judith, Joanna, David & Eloise, their spouses, seven grandchildren & one great-grandchild. Shiva will be at the home of David and Suanne Scherr, 34 North Drive, Great Neck.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORSE, MILDRED HOCKSTADER ''TINY''
description: MORSE--Mildred Hockstader "Tiny". Of New York, Washington D.C., and Geneva, Switzerland. Died July 8, at her home in Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late David Abner Morse, Mrs. Morse was born in New York City in 1911. The daughter of Aline Straus Hockstader and Leonard Albert Hockstader, she was predeceased by a sister, Carol Eggleston, and a brother, Albert F. Hockstader. Her survivors include a nephew, Alan F. Hockstader of White Plains, three great nieces, one great nephew, and a host of godchildren and friends around the world. A graduate of The Spence School and Rosemary Hall, Mrs. Morse was a supporter of The Council on Foreign Relations where she established a lecture series in the name of her late husband; The Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute; The African American Institute; The New York Society for International Affairs, Inc., and Rutgers University where, in 1979, she and her late husband established the first major art acquistion fund at The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum. During David Morse's twenty year tenure as Director General of the International Labor Organization (ILO) in Geneva, the couple accumulated a substantial collection of late 19th and early 20th century French Graphics and paintings which are now among the Zimmerli's holdings. In 1983, the Morse Print and Drawing Room opened at the Zimmerli. In 1995, an expanded version of that space became the major research facility for the museum. After her husband's death, Mrs. Morse also established a series of scholarships in his name at Rutgers University. Everyone who loved Mildred thanks Maria Martin, Rita Purdessy, Jennifer Simpson, Dierdre Mole and Dr. Veronica LoFaso, for their loving care, as well as all the staff at the Beekman who contributed to her well-being and comfort. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the charity of your choice, The Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 East Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown, New York 11787, or The Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, 1484 First Avenue, New York 10021. A memorial service will be held in the Beth El chapel at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, on Wednesday, October 19 at 11 A.M. MORSE--Mildred H. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses to the family of our devoted member, Mildred H. Morse, our deepest sympathies on the occassion of her passing. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life. May all who loved her be comforted. Dr. David M. Posner, Senior Rabbi Dr. Ronald B. Sobel, Senior Rabbi Emeritus Robert A. Bernhard, Pres. George Asch, Sec'y MORSE--Mildred. We shall miss the "Mildred Blue" in our lives. Nina, "WW", Jane, Melissa

description: Pat Burns, the coach of the Devils since the 2002-3 season, has had a recurrence of cancer and will not coach the team if, or when, the National Hockey League resumes play, General Manager Lou Lamoriello said yesterday.

Even with the London attacks, there is little indication that this philosophical divide is narrowing.

Paid Notice: Deaths   STUTMAN, LEONARD JAY, M.D.
description: STUTMAN -- Leonard Jay, M.D., died at Thursday morning at his home in West Nyack, NY. He was 77. Born in Boston to Hyman and Nellie (Wiener) Stutman, he graduated from the Boston Latin School and earned a B.S. from MIT, an M.A. from Boston University, and his M.D. from University of Rochester. Dr. Stutman's medical career began with an internship and residency at Bellevue Hospital from 1953-1957. He then joined the Air Force as a Captain and was stationed Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Dayton, OH where he was Chief of the Medical Services Branch 1957-1959. While at WrightPatterson he pioneered inflight testing of cardiovascular function in zero-gravity using specially modified C-47 aircraft outfitted with socalled "tilt tables." Much of his work in the Air Force is recognized as being a foundation of later "space medicine." After moving to West Nyack, NY in 1959, Dr. Stutman entered private practice as well as holding appointments and fellowships at NYU, NIH, New York Medical College, Nyack Hospital and St. Vincent's Hospital where he attended and was Head of the Coagulation Research Laboratory. He was wellknown for his work on clotting, hemophilia, sickle cell anemia and other aspects of hematology. He was Medical Director of Presidential Life Insurance Company. He was FACP, FACC, and a member of Sigma Xi. He is survived by his wife of 53 years, Jeanne, by children Steve, David, Marc and Robin, and by two grandchildren. Services will be held at 11AM on Sunday, July 10th at Hellman Memorial Chapels, 15 State St., Spring Valley, New York, 845356-8600.

Paid Notice: Deaths   TITONE, HON. VITO J.
description: TITONE--Hon. Vito J. Wisdom, compassion and understanding are benchmark qualities of a life well-lived! In navigating the shoals of life's journey, they serve to arm the traveler with renewed strength of character. Judge Vito Titone came to the side of a legion of this town's shadow--children adrift in the rising tide of drugs and hopelessness. How tall he stood in his rescue efforts as a leading Governor of Daytop Village, Inc. over these four decades. Heaven blessed us, indeed, in his presence among us. May a good and loving God welcome him home after a memorable journey. May God strengthen and console his beloved Peggy and family. Msgr. William B. O'Brien President, Daytop Village Inc.

title: Gadgets of the week: Making the case for watery music
Arts, Briefly; Another 'Night Train' Rides the Tracks
description: The second installment of the Grammy-winning "Night Train to Nashville: Music City Rhythm & Blues 1945-1970" (CMF/Lost Highway/Universal) will arrive in stores on Sept. 20, as a companion piece to the exhibition of the same name at the Country Music Hall of Fame. The two-CD set includes the original R&B version of Bernard Hardison's "Too Much" (1955), later covered by Elvis Presley, and the Gladiolas' "Little Darlin"' (1957), which became a huge doo-wop hit for the Diamonds. The liner notes feature an essay by the Fisk University historian Reavis L. Mitchell Jr. about the origins and evolution of Nashville's Jefferson Street, in those days a haven for black dance and R&B clubs. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Briefly: Aid workers evacuated after attacks in Sudan

description: The Australian government has granted a permanent visa to a Chinese diplomat, his wife and their 6-year-old daughter. The diplomat, Chen Yonglin, defected last month. His case generated a storm when the Australian government initially rejected his asylum request. He also sought asylum at the American Embassy in Canberra but was turned down. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: To Do: Apply Sunscreen, Get Finance Checkup
description: With the year halfway over, there couldn't be a better time for a personal finance checkup to see whether adjustments are warranted in, say, an investment portfolio or insurance coverage. The trouble is that few people are probably thinking much about financial planning these torpid summer days.

title: Al Qaeda's Smart Bombs
description: CHICAGO - WHILE we don't yet know who organized the terrorist attacks in London on Thursday, it seems likely that they were the latest in a series of bombings, most of them suicide attacks, over the past several years by Al Qaeda and its supporters. Although many Americans had hoped that Al Qaeda has been badly weakened by American counterterrorism efforts since Sept. 11, 2001, the facts indicate otherwise. Since 2002, Al Qaeda has been involved in at least 17 bombings that killed more than 700 people -- more attacks and victims than in all the years before 9/11 combined.

title: On Public Transportation, the Mood Is Wary but Calm
description: A day after the bombings in London, the elevated state of alert was on display both above and below the ground in New York yesterday, as state troopers and National Guard members joined city police officers in patrolling trains, buses and ferries. But the subways and commuter trains were as packed as ever, and most riders said the shock of the London attacks had quickly subsided into the workaday vigilance of the post-Sept. 11 world.

title: On the record
Paid Notice: Deaths   LANE, PETER A.
description: LANE--Peter A. Dad, we can't imagine life without you. You have always been our backbone, always larger than life. There will not be a minute where you leave our thoughts. Mom, Eric, Adam and Sarah LANE--Peter A. The Board of Directors, Administration and Staff of The United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourns the passing of Mr. Peter A. Lane. As the President of The United Hebrew Geriatric Center and Vice-President of The UGC Foundation, Peter has been a devoted friend and ardent supporter for many years. Our heartfelt sympathy and prayers are extended to the bereaved family, his wife Rita and his two sons. Malcolm Lazarus, Chairman Rita C. Mabli, CEO LANE--Peter. The Jewish Community Center of Harrison announces with profound sorrow the loss of its esteemed member. We extend deepest sympathy to his wife Rita, his children Eric and Adam and the entire family. Norton D. Shargel, Rabbi Emeritus Sarah A. Zemel, Hazzan Robert M. Schack, President Karen Goldstick, Chairman LANE--Peter. All of the kind words that were ever written on the pages of this newspaper could not fully describe our cousin Peter. He was the kindest, most sensitive man we ever knew and his legacy will live on in his family and all the people who loved him forever. Our hearts go out to Rita, Eric and Adam. Rest on peace cousin Petey. Diane and Morton Setchen LANE--Peter. The Board of Governors and members of Brae Burn Country Club mourn the passing of our esteemed member and past President, Peter Lane. Our heartfelt sympathy is extended to his wife Rita and his children Eric and Adam, and the entire Lane Family. Michael Barasch, President Dr. Robert Green, Secretary LANE--Peter. Taken from his beloved family far too soon. Our hearts and prayers are with Rita, Eric, Sarah and Adam. Your devotion and love for Peter was immeasurable. We share your loss. The Dillon family LANE--Peter A. Mr. Petie, our time together was too short, but my memories are forever. I love you, Sarah

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MENDELL, IRA LEBECK
description: MENDELL--Ira Lebeck. Beloved husband of Joan Armour and the late Peggy Postley died at the age of 92 at his summer home in Purchase, NY. He was a resident of Sarasota, FL. He was a devoted father to his three children and their spouses: Thomas and Andrea Mendell, Alice and Kenneth Starr, James and Peg Kamens Mendell. Adored grandfather to Randall Starr, Carolyn Starr Doolittle, her husband Cameron, Cynthia Starr, Russell, Jake and Molly Rose Mendell, Lauren Mendell and the late Alexander Mendell and one great grandchild Grace Doolittle. He is also survived by four loving stepchildren and eight step grandchildren. He served as an Army Captain and intelligence officer during World War II. Later, he became President of Regional Development Company of New York. He not only enjoyed golf as a sport, but was active in the Metropolitan Golf Association as a former president and for many years served as a committeeman of the United States Golf Association. Tubby, as he was referred to by most all who knew him, was a warm and loving man. He will surely be missed by everyone who had the privilege to know him. Services will be held at the Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale New York on Sunday, July 10th at 2 PM. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, donations in his memory be made to Hospice of Westchester, 95 South Broadway, White Plains, New York 10601-4403.

Tom Gordon, the setup man, walked around the clubhouse with a large bandage on his sore right shoulder, and Darrell May, today's starter, arrived from Class AAA Columbus with his old San Diego Padres bag in hand.

It was the St. Paul's churchyard.

title: On the Web, Photos Strain to Connect 7/7 and 9/11
description: Flickr, a popular photo-sharing Web site that posts pictures from anyone and everyone, has a special folder for images of the bomb blasts that stunned London on Thursday. The folder, labeled "7/7 Community," is remarkable for two things: its cool look not at the event itself but at the news media coverage of the event, and an effort to pictorially link 7/7 and 9/11.

description: The New York Philharmonic values the British conductor Bramwell Tovey as the host of its Summertime Classics series not only because he is a good musician, but also because he brings such a delightfully avuncular sense of humor to the job of introducing the pieces on the program. But on Thursday night, before conducting a program for children titled "Young at Heart," Mr. Tovey was understandably subdued.

title: London Bombs Seen as Crude; Death Toll Rises to 49
description: LONDON, July 8 - Investigators have concluded that the bombs that ripped through three subway trains and a bus on Thursday were relatively crude devices containing less than 10 pounds of explosives each. That finding supports a theory gaining momentum among the authorities that the plot was carried out by a sleeper cell of homegrown extremists rather than highly trained terrorists exported to Britain.

title: Stocks: Jobs report and oil give Wall Street a lift
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: 'Sasser' Hacker Is Sentenced
description: A German teenager was given a 21-month suspended sentence after being convicted of creating the Sasser Internet worm, which disabled millions of computers using Microsoft Windows worldwide after May 1, 2004. The defendant, Sven Jaschan, 19, was found guilty of computer sabotage and illegally altering data, the court in the northwestern town of Verden said. The verdict fell short of the five years that computer sabotage carries under German law because Mr. Jaschan was 17 when he committed the crime and was tried as a juvenile. He was also sentenced to 30 hours of community service. He now works for a German security software firm that specializes in defenses against computer viruses and worms. Microsoft Corporation said that it welcomed the verdict and that it would pay a total of $250,000 in reward money to two informants who had helped link Mr. Jaschan to the computer attacks. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: In the cell-etiquette wars, the workplace is a front line

description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 - Concerned that state workers might be charged with abetting federal crimes, California health officials announced Friday that they would no longer issue identification cards to medical marijuana patients.

title: Globalist:Terrorism all too easily finds favorable terrain
Residents in Storm Path Face More Tough Choices
description: MIAMI, July 8 - Coastal residents from the Florida Keys all the way to Louisiana scrambled or held their breath on Friday as Hurricane Dennis plowed through Cuba before surging to the Gulf of Mexico barely a month into hurricane season.

title: INSIDE
description: Agreement Ends Battle Over Disney Leadership The Walt Disney Company and Roy E. Disney, the nephew of the company's founder, announced that they had patched things up, ending a longstanding battle over corporate governance. The agreement enables the company's new chief executive, Robert A. Iger, to put behind him one of the biggest potential challenges to his leadership. BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1

title: World Briefing | Asia: United Nations: Envoy Will Intercede In Nepal
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan is sending a top troubleshooter, Lakhdar Brahimi, to Nepal this weekend on a five-day mission to help find a solution to the political crisis there. A Maoist rebellion has been active for months in opposing King Gyanendra, and the king has seized power from Parliament and suspended democracy. Mr. Brahimi, a former Algerian foreign minister, was Mr. Annan's special envoy to Afghanistan after the Taliban was removed from power, and he helped shape the transitional government in Iraq a year ago. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Palestinians Feel Like Underdogs Against King David
description: JERUSALEM - Every so often, events surface in Jerusalem that remind its Arab and Jewish residents how easily their city of gentle hills and golden light slips back and forth across time, from the artifacts of the past to the passions of contemporary politics.

title: Pigeons and Coupes
description: Amjad Ali released six of his champion pigeons and watched proudly as they circled higher and higher into the morning sky and gradually became mere specks. When they had all but disappeared, a beefy man walked up and asked, "Hey, you got a radiator for a '97 Pathfinder?"

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the investigation of the terror attacks in London misstated the ranking of the city's subway ridership. It is No. 7; the busiest system is in Moscow.

title: M.T.A. Slow to Spend Money on Transit Security
description: In December 2002, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced it had completed a lengthy assessment of potential threats to the city's transportation infrastructure, from subway lines to major bridges. The authority, which had begun the study in the weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks, said it was committing nearly $600 million to improve the security of the sprawling transportation network.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Defense Minister Quits
description: Colombia's defense minister, under fire for his handling of the war with Marxist rebels, resigned. Though government statistics show that Colombia has grown safer, the minister, Jorge Alberto Uribe, left, faced sharp criticism in Congress over a grinding war that has killed more than 700 soldiers since his tenure began 20 months ago. Mr. Uribe's stature with some generals also was tarnished after he acknowledged having a long relationship with a woman serving a prison term for cocaine trafficking. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Man Charged in 3 Assaults in Manhattan
description: A 49-year-old convicted rapist was charged last night in the sexual assaults last month of three Manhattan women whose attacker crawled through their open apartment windows.

title: British Police Revise Timing of 3 Explosions
description: LONDON, July 9 - A The British police today revised critical details of ThursdayAs terrorist bombings, saying that three of four bombs exploded "almost simultaneously" on subway trains rather than over a period of almost half an hour as initially announced.

description: Big Bosoms and Square Jaws The Biography of Russ Meyer, King of the Sex Film By Jimmy McDonough Illustrated. 463 pages. Crown Publishers. $26.95.

description: Tony Blair was as eloquent as ever when he faced the press at the G-8 summit meeting yesterday, but what was most impressive was what he didn't say. After uttering three sentences of gratitude to the other leaders for their support after the London attacks, he dropped the subject of terror.

title: Grrr! No One Can Outwit The Hulk
description: Hulk Hogan, the enormous 51-year-old wrestler with the impressive blond mustache, has been described more than a few times as charismatic. So there's a certain logic in building a reality series around him. Even the idea of VH1's "Hogan Knows Best," which has its premiere tomorrow night, is appealing. Surely there's inherent humor in comparing Mr. Hogan's parental woes and decisions with those of Robert Young's character in the old television series, as the title suggests. ("Father Knows Best" ran, on CBS and NBC at various times, from 1954 to 1960.)

title: National Briefing | West: California: Attorney General Sues On Redistricting
description: Bill Lockyer, the California attorney general, said he had sued to remove a measure on redistricting from the ballot in November. The measure, to shift the power of drawing political districts from the Legislature and to a panel of retired judges, is one of three measures backed by Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

description: "That's for me to know and you to find out."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TALBOT, PAUL
description: TALBOT--Paul, 86, a television industry pioneer, died on Wednesday at his family home in Brewster, MA. He was a lifelong resident of Manhattan. Along with his wife of 39 years, Susan Talbot, he is survived by his daughter, Rachel, and his three sons, Keith, John and Thomas. As President and founder of The Fremantle Corporation, he was an innovator in the international distribution of American television. Thanks to him, American shows such as "Romper Room", "Biography", "The Galloping Gourmet", "Baywatch" and "The Price is Right" have been seen by viewers throughout the world. Paul Talbot began his career in show business during radio's "golden age" in the 1930's as a performer in live soap operas including "The Adventures of Henry Aldrich" and "Aunt Jenny's Real Life Stories". He served in Europe as a First Lieutenant during World War II. In the 1950's, Mr. Talbot also worked as a writer on the "Superman" and "Batman" comic books. He was politically active, organizing media for the 1948 National Convention of the Progressive Party and later leading a successful campaign to desegregate Stuyvesant Town, a privately owned housing development in New York City. Memorial donations may be made to The Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation, 432 Park Avenue South, 15th Fl, NY, NY 10016.

title: A Defensive Misstep Shows the Value of One Overtrick
description: You are the declarer in one no-trump. Does it really matter whether you win seven tricks or eight? After all, the value of the overtrick is only 30 points. In Chicago or rubber bridge, that often means nothing, but sometimes the measly extra trick is worth its weight in gold.

title: Wallflower on warming
Reconciling the Power of Space

So while a security check isn't officially part of Tom Pearson's site-specific "Reel," seen at the Smithsonian National Museum of the American Indian on Thursday, it certainly helps to get his audience into the mood.

description: SO PAULO, Brazil, July 8 - Brazil reached an agreement late Friday with the American pharmaceutical company Abbott Laboratories that will lower the price it pays for the AIDS drug Kaletra while refraining from breaking the company's patent to produce a generic version of the medicine.

title: Arts, Briefly; Columbus Circle Forum
description: A "people's hearing" to elicit views on plans to renovate a building at 2 Columbus Circle is scheduled for Thursday. Bill Perkins, a New York City councilman and chairman of the council's Governmental Operations Committee, said he would serve as chairman at the forum, at 1 p.m. at 20 West 44th Street in Manhattan, to call attention to the Landmarks Preservation Commission's refusal to hold a hearing on the building. Arguing that its porthole-laced facade represents a turning point in Modernist design, preservationists have sought for a decade to have the structure, designed by the architect Edward Durell Stone, declared a landmark. Extensive renovations to convert the structure into a new home for the Museum of Arts and Design, formerly the American Craft Museum, are to begin this fall. "The hearing on Thursday is not official from the standpoint of the council," Mr. Perkins said, adding, "It's to bring attention to the fact that 2 Columbus Circle is not getting a hearing." The forum was sought by Landmark West, a neighborhood advocacy group fighting to preserve the building. FELICIA R. LEE

title: Police Make Arrest in 1980 Murder Case
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday and accused of a 1980 killing that the victim's 84-year-old father had begged the police to solve before he died.

It is the Public Interest Declassification Board -- not Classification.

description: BEIJING, July 8 - Exxon Mobil, the world's biggest publicly traded oil company, is ready to go ahead with a $3.5 billion oil refining and chemicals venture with Saudi Aramco and a state-run company in China as demand soars, Exxon's chief executive, Lee R. Raymond, said Friday.

Fontana, a national voice for abused and neglected children and the longtime medical director of the New York Foundling, the service agency for such children and their families, died on Tuesday while vacationing on Block Island, R.I. He was 81 and lived in Stony Brook, N.Y.

title: Arts, Briefly; Swimsuits Buoy 'Big Brother'
description: The sixth season of "Big Brother" had its premiere on CBS Thursday night, and viewers have already seen the 14 young roommates in their bathing suits. The perennial guilty pleasure, which will be broadcast three times a week, drew an audience of 8.61 million. That number represented a vast improvement over the former occupant of the time period, "The Cut," with Tommy Hilfiger, below, now on Wednesdays, and bolstered CBS's win in all key Nielsen estimates for the night. With a stronger lead-in, CBS's repeats of "CSI" (14.43 million) and "Without a Trace" (12.26 million) both won their hours even more easily than usual. On UPN, "WWE Smackdown!" continued its summer streak, bringing in 5.19 million viewers and putting the network in second place over all among 18-to-49 year-olds. NBC was No. 3 in that age group and fourth among total viewers with its lineup of repeats -- "Joey," "Will & Grace" and "ER" -- which have all been renewed for the fall season. KATE AURTHUR

description: It was altogether fitting that as a hearse bearing the coffin of Luther Vandross, the prince of the bedroom crooners and a lord of the light FM dial, began to pass into Harlem yesterday, there was a quiet storm.

title: Corrections

After the section had gone to press, the performance was canceled.

title: In Effort to Secure Borders, Iraqis Are Patrolling a River for Smugglers and Pirates
description: ON THE SHATT AL ARAB, Iraq - Deep in the south of Iraq and relatively untouched by the incessant violence of the guerrilla war, the storied Shatt al Arab exists in a world all its own. On this river, squatters live in half-sunken freighters wrecked during the Iran-Iraq war, boys swim naked to stave off the 120-degree heat and merchants motor upstream in skiffs loaded with apples from Iran. In Basra, a port city, couples languidly stroll along a riverside promenade in the evening.

title: New Imam Calls for Help in Catching Bombers
description: LONDON - The new imam at the Finsbury Park mosque, once a hotbed of radical Islam, had a message for those who gathered for prayer on Friday, a day after four bombs killed at least 49 people: help identify the bombers, he told them. Show your anger at what happened here.

World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Soldiers Shoot Boy At Barrier
description: Israeli security guards fatally shot a 17-year-old Palestinian boy from the West Bank village of Beit Likiya. The guards were assigned to defend the construction work on the separation barrier Israel is building there. Through the day, troops arrested 10 Palestinians on the West Bank, including 6 who were said to be members of the militant Islamic Jihad -- 3 in Jenin and 3 in Hebron. The Israelis are trying to break Islamic Jihad, which has carried out numerous attacks on Israeli civilians and soldiers despite the cease-fire between the Palestinians and Israelis announced in February. Earlier, four Israeli soldiers were slightly wounded in the southern Gaza Strip when a roadside bomb exploded in front of their jeep. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Rumors Fly Over Rehnquist's Plans
description: WASHINGTON, July 8 - In April, a letter was read to 500 doctors and scientists meeting in Baltimore to discuss the latest advances in thyroid cancer research. It was from the world's most famous thyroid cancer patient, and it was a thank-you letter.

description: THE GOLDEN WEST Hollywood Stories. By Daniel Fuchs. Selected by Christopher Carduff. Introduction by John Updike. 256 pp. A Black Sparrow Book/ David R. Godine. $24.95.

title: Few Wealthy Farmers Owe Estate Taxes, Report Says
description: The number of farms on which estate tax is owed when the owners die has fallen by 82 percent since 2000, to just 300 farms, as Congress has more than doubled the threshold at which the tax applies, the Congressional Budget Office said in a report released last week.

title: 'Crossworld'
description: I am hopelessly addicted to the New York Times crossword puzzle. Like many addicts, it's taken me time to admit I have a problem. The hints I was heading for trouble came, at first, only occasionally. The moments of panic when I realized that for whatever reason I might not be able to get my fix on a given day. The toll on relationships. The strained friendships. The lost hours I could have used to do something much more productive.

title: Corrections
description: A picture last Sunday with an automobile review of the 2005 Suzuki Reno was published in error. It showed a Suzuki Aerio.

title: Newark Playgrounds In the Picture
description: Usually Michael Yamashita travels the world taking photographs for National Geographic. But recently he pointed his camera at children in the school playgrounds of Newark, Morristown, Mendham and Bernardsville. The Newark playgrounds were in bad shape. "Some were no more than parking lots," Mr. Yamashita said. "Kids were running around and getting hurt. The asphalt was cracking and there were holes here and there."

title: India and Pakistan's Code of Dishonor
description: IN honor-and-shame cultures like those of India and Pakistan, male honor resides in the sexual probity of women, and the "shaming" of women dishonors all men. So it is that five men of Pakistan's powerful Mastoi tribe were disgracefully acquitted of raping a villager named Mukhtar Mai three years ago. Theirs was an "honor rape," intended to punish a relative of Ms. Mukhtar for having been seen with a Matsoi woman. The acquittals have now been suspended by the Pakistan Supreme Court, and there is finally a chance that this courageous woman may gain some measure of redress for her violation.

title: Crime Stories
description: From "To Kill A Mockingbird" to "Law & Order," Hollywood has conditioned real-life jurors to expect a lot from courtroom proceedings: high drama and lawyers willing and able to deliver it. Neal Howard brings the process full circle. He uses his experience as a Hollywood screenwriter to help prosecutors weave compelling stories for their 12-person audiences. "The jury really is just an audience, and every trial is drama," said Mr. Howard, 46, who has written for shows like "The King of Queens" and "The Love Boat: The Next Wave" and for the last three years has been a litigation consultant for the law firm Zagnoli McEvoy Foley in Chicago. "You have your protagonists, your heroes, your victims. The trick is to help ensure that the things that are going to move the story emotionally don't get lost in the legal shuffle."

Around the turn of the last century, when white ostrich plumes were as precious as gold, the feather barons of Oudtshoorn built great palaces. The feather crash of 1914 ended all that.

description: Travelers sit and stare at the walls at the Hotel Des Arts in San Francisco, and that's the idea. Emerging artists have created small universes in 26 of the hotel's 51 modest rooms. On Aug. 3, the two-year-old hotel will unveil 10 more rooms.

title: Go Jump in the River
description: Cornwall, N.Y. - WHATEVER your political ideology, you have to give Gov. George E. Pataki credit for his efforts to revive the near-extinct pastime of swimming in the Hudson River. In late June, New York's Department of Environmental Conservation and Office of Parks, Recreation and Historical Preservation released a study that identified 13 sites where Hudson River swimming beaches could be established.

description: MUSIC OF THE MILL By Luis J. Rodriguez. 308 pp. Rayo/ HarperCollins Publishers. $24.95.

title: Learning From the Experts, via Bill Clinton
description: LEAH ABRAHAM is quick to admit it: As experienced as she and her husband had been in operating bakeries and cafes in Manhattan and Westchester County, "we weren't on target" in moving into another Manhattan neighborhood.

title: 'Blind Spot'
description: "WHAT IS THE CAPITAL OF ILLINOIS, SIR?" A U.S. army jeep flying a gold-braided pennant with four stars had just driven up to the roadblock, and the young American sentry had the unenviable task of quizzing the man in the passenger seat wearing those stars. It was mid-December 1944, and as part of a major counteroffensive on the Western front, the Nazis had sent saboteurs across the lines dressed in U.S. Army uniforms. To separate friend from foe, the U.S. military in northwestern France had tightened security and started this game of trivial pursuit.

description: INVESTORS just love foreign mutual funds these days, and no wonder.

It is "Muori dannato" ("die accursed"), not "Muori donnato."

title: Amansara in Siem Reap, Cambodia
description: THE BASICS -- For exotica with luxury in Asia, it is hard to beat the Amansara in Siem Reap, an enclave of refinement close to the glorious temples of Angkor. Like all Amanresorts hotels, it is very expensive. But if you are going to see Angkor only once, what the heck. As you would expect for the price, you get attentive service: there are five staff members for every guest and the hotel's guides take guests to the temples on routes not used by tour buses. Amansara was built in the 1960's as Prince Sihanouk's guesthouse. The single-story structure became a hotel and in the 70's, as political conditions worsened, a state guesthouse for the Khmer Rouge. Ultimately, it deteriorated. After a restoration, the villa opened to guests late in 2002, retaining the modernist look of stark white exteriors and plenty of glass. Given that many new hotels in Siem Reap are huge, hastily erected concrete piles, the Amansara is definitely in a discreet class of its own.

title: Turning Point
description: ATLANTIC CITY - OUTSIDE the new Coach outlet store -- where $250 handbags are marked down as much as $100 -- stands a decorative pole ready to display the photographs of Miss Americas 2010 through 2019, a bit of optimism that may seem misplaced these days.

title: Take My Second Home, Please
description: Correction Appended

title: The New Classics: 'Jaws 3-D' and 'G.I. Jane'
description: JAWS 3-D," "Lionheart," "Smokey and the Bandit II," "G.I. Jane": these are a few of the titles the cable channel American Movie Classics has had in frequent rotation recently. This July, if you miss a showing of "Missing in Action," there will be four more chances to see it. Curious about "Staying Alive," the John Travolta "Saturday Night Fever" sequel? It's playing four times. (On the Web site rottentomatoes.com, which rates films according to their reviews, "Staying Alive" is one the few movies that actually gets a zero rating.).

title: Where Will He Sit? Where Does He Stand?
description: Seems you can't please all of the ideologues all of the time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LOCKARD, ELIZABETH EASTMENT
description: LOCKARD--Elizabeth Eastment, 52, at her home in Warwick, NY, July 8, 2005. Survived by her husband Arthur; four brothers: Anthony, Jeffrey, John and Robert Eastment; stepmother, Cleunice Eastment. Graduated Friends Academy, Locust Valley, NY, 1971 and Middlebury College, VT, 1975. Employed by Varig Airlines 1976-1991. Memorial at Warwick Conference Center, Hoyt Road, Thursday, July 21, 6-9 P.M. In lieu of flowers, donations to Hospice of Orange & Sullivan County, 800 Stony Brook Road, Newburgh, NY 12550.

title: Cul-de-Sac Cred
description: Marc Ecko is a fan of pop culture, fashion, entrepreneurs and the American dream. He loves movies and video games, and he has 30,000 songs on five iPods. Two and a half years ago, he was at a company holiday party that featured a brief video titled, "Who Is Marc Ecko?" In it, Gary Coleman, the former child star, walked up and down Melrose Avenue in Los Angeles, asking people if they were familiar with the clothing line Ecko Unlimited, which often features the stark silhouette of a rhinoceros on T-shirts, baggy jeans and other garments. They were shown photographs of four men and asked which one they figured was Ecko. Most picked the cool-looking black man. Hardly anyone chose the boyish white guy, who perhaps appeared a bit too much like a grown-up New Jersey mall rat to be running a multimillion-dollar clothing line that routinely turned up in rap videos. But that, of course, was Ecko. Everybody knew the brand; no one knew the man.

title: Pocket of Demand in the Office Market
description: IN the last year, the office vacancy rate in Westchester has hardly budged, settling at 16 percent on June 30, the same as it was at the midpoint of last year. At first glance, the second-quarter numbers for 2005, which were released last week by the real estate firm Newmark & Company, indicate that the county's business sector, while not in a recession, is failing to grow.

title: Who Are Americans To Think That Freedom Is Theirs To Spread?
description: I wonder if Ignatieff can point to a single case in which Jefferson advocated the imposition of democracy through military conquest by a foreign power. Yes, like the Enlightenment philosopher he was, Jefferson wanted a world freed from priests and tyrants, but he envisioned liberation as coming from below and from within.

title: Facing Jihad, Recalling the Blitz
description: London - WITH their legendary British fortitude, Londoners are already riding the subways and buses that proved so deadly during Thursday's terrorist attacks. Making sense of what happened, however, will take much longer -- for the British and the rest of the world. And as in most crises, there are a lot of early, false assessments that may take hold and become a standard account. If we let this happen, it will not serve us well in the coming months and years of our struggle against terrorism.

title: Romancing the (Female) Tourist
description: SHE is between 35 and 54, lives in the New York metropolitan region, has a household income of at least $80,000 and needs an easily accessible break from her fast-paced life. She may be single or married and travel with friends, or she may be married and travel only with her husband. But she does not travel with children.

title: Greetings From SoFi, N.Y.C.
description: SANDWICHED between Murray Hill and Chelsea, Madison Square Park and Bryant Park, the area straddling the spine of Fifth Avenue from about 26th Street to 38th Street has, until now, had no image, no patina, no label.

title: A Local Artist Finally Makes Good
description: BERN, Switzerland - CAN a town be blamed for, or take credit for, its citizens? The arcaded shopping streets of Bern, the Swiss capital, are papered with photocopied black-and-whites of Albert Einstein making faces: the city is celebrating the centenary of the theory of relativity, which Einstein was pondering when he lived here. A couple of years ago, the Kunstmuseum Bern had a show about the Giacomettis -- the brothers Alberto and Diego and their father Giovanni -- all of whom lived for quite a while in Switzerland but just one of whom became famous. Alberto Giacometti, however, will always be associated with Paris.

title: Detroit Is So Hollywood, and Vice Versa
description: THE capital of the American automotive industry and the capital of American entertainment don't seem to have much in common. Detroit wears Brooks Brothers, Hollywood wears Armani. Detroit eats meat and potatoes, Hollywood (when it's not dieting) dines on sushi and low-carb shakes. Detroit is Rust Belt; Hollywood is Botox Belt.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 10 -- July 16; ART
description: What better way to enjoy the summer than to take in a garden show? Just don't look for mindless botanical bliss at these thought-provoking exhibitions:

title: Beyond the Cookie Sale
description: I WAS a Girl Scout myself for five years, starting in second grade in Dallas in the late 1950's. My mother was the troop leader and also a secretary with the Internal Revenue Service and the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. I saw her in that role, and then she had this fun leadership role with the Girl Scouts. Seeing her come into her own in these positions was a formative experience for me.

title: Surveying What's Better and What's Worse Around the Leagues
description: IN the eighth inning of their game Thursday night, the Atlanta Braves served up a microcosm of their season. With the Cubs ahead, 4-3, Andruw Jones hit a two-run home run. Three batters later, Jeff Francoeur smacked a three-run homer, sealing the Braves' 9-4 victory.

title: Corrections
description: A letter to the editor on June 12 about leasing an automatic-transmission car in France misstated the relationship between Auto France, based in Wood-Ridge, N.J., and the Peugeot company. Auto France is an agent of a short-term leasing program known as Peugeot Open Europe, not a division of Peugeot.

title: Who Are Americans To Think That Freedom Is Theirs To Spread?
description: The issue is not that conservatives support promoting freedom and liberals do not. After all, President Bush is a very recent convert to the cause of global democracy. The issue is how to promote freedom and whether pre-emptive wars carried out in a way that wastes precious lives is the way to do so.

title: Can Woods Steer Clear of the Sand Yet Again?
description: TIGER WOODS was never better. He had won the 2000 United States Open at Pebble Beach by 15 strokes and now, on a sunny Sunday in Scotland, he was sitting behind a microphone in the British Open interview tent after having won not only by eight strokes, but, remarkably, without his golf ball thudding into the sand of any of the 112 mostly hidden bunkers at St. Andrews

title: On the Cover
description: THE last time Ambrose Monk visited Adrian, his obsessive-compulsive brother, he went home with an Emmy Award. This week he returns -- to "Monk," the popular USA series that began its fourth season on July 8. The series's star, Tony Shalhoub, plays Adrian Monk, a brilliant crime-solver with a ridiculous array of personal phobias. And John Turturro, in a guest appearance on Friday, will reprise his role as Ambrose, a character whose fear of leaving the house makes him as psychologically fragile as his fictional sibling. The brothers will be reunited, Mr. Shalhoub said, when their long-absent father surfaces.

You could likewise spend a few days on the southwestern coast of Florida looking for America's best grouper sandwich, or take a week or more to cruise the open highways of central Texas in search of the pre-eminent barbecued brisket.
