title: An Oscar Barrier
description: "The Warrior," Asif Kapadia's historical epic about a renegade Indian warlord, finally makes it into American theaters this week -- three years after its release in Britain, and two years after it won a Bafta award as best British film. Its profile here might have been higher had it gone on to be Britain's nominee for the foreign-language Oscar. And Britain tried: it submitted "The Warrior" as its official entry in October 2002. But the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences rejected it, citing 14-II-2 in that year's Oscar rulebook, which began: "The dialogue track must be predominantly in a language of the country of origin ." Meaning that "The Warrior," which is in Hindi, could not compete for the foreign-language Oscar because it wasn't in English. John Pavlik, a spokesman for the academy, acknowledged the apparent contradiction, but said, "When you have rules you have rules, and either you abide by them or you don't."

description: This summer -- like the one before it and, come to think of it, many of the ones before that -- is a great time to be a fan of Southern hip-hop. MIKE JONES began the Houston invasion back in April, when he released his debut album, "WHO IS MIKE JONES?" (Swisha/Asylum/Warner Bros.), which has since been certified platinum. And last week, the Baton Rouge rapper WEBBIE released "SAVAGE LIFE" (Atlantic), which should enjoy a strong debut on this week's charts; the album has already spawned a hip-hop hit, "Give Me That," a woozy sex rap co-starring the pioneering Houston rapper BUN B.

title: A Better Farmingville

Unfortunately, the ones that affect Latino immigrants invariably seem to involve some collision with law enforcement -- mass arrests of suspected gang members, raids on illegal rooming houses, plans to deputize county police officers to enforce federal immigration laws.

description: A 128-CRAYON box of Crayolas does not guarantee a better drawing than the standard eight-crayon version, but any child will tell you that more is better. And so it goes in the fast-growing world of exchange-traded funds, as marketers busily dream up new shades of index-tracking portfolios for investors who have recently adopted these funds as the new "it" investment.

title: The Emotions That Fly When a Son Returns
description: AT the very beginning of "The Subject Was Roses," John Cleary does something human and significant. His son, Tim, came home from World War II the day before, and his Army jacket is hanging on a wall nearby. John looks around warily, and when he is assured that he is alone, he takes down the jacket and tries it on.

title: Nyree Copeland and Paul Whyte
description: Nyree Dawn Copeland and Paul Andrew Whyte were married on Wednesday at St. Martin's Episcopal Church in Manhattan by the Rev. Johan Johnson, its rector. Mr. Johnson led an earlier ceremony at St. John's Anglican Church in Ocho Rios, Jamaica, on July 2, with the Rev. Kenute Francis, an Anglican, taking part.

title: Jennette Drmacich and Istvan Hajdu

title: On the Boardwalk, Strutting Once More
description: THERE was a time, back in the first half of the 20th century, when being crowned the prettiest girl in Coney Island really meant something. Coney Island in those days was a domain that included Steeplechase Park, the famous parachute jump, and one of New York's most famous beaches. And the title was hard to win, open only to the most elegant of bathing beauties, as judged in places like Childs Restaurant.

title: In Big Stock Funds, a Little Risk Is Still Risk
description: MANY big mutual funds -- those with lots of stocks -- have been criticized as being nothing more than closet index funds. But a new study has found that those funds don't deserve that label.

description: To the Editor: The London Visitor Travelcard recommended in "Deals & Discounts" (June 19) by Pamela Noel, may be more than most tourists need.

title: Financial District: Bon Appetit
description: Despite the prolonged downturn that followed the attacks of Sept. 11, the dining scene in the financial district has become increasingly robust. Among the standouts is Les Halles Downtown, on John Street. It will celebrate Bastille Day on Thursday with an event being called the Liberty Festival, which will start at 11:30 a.m. and will feature music, cancan dancers and of course, French food.

title: On-Time Budget Heads List of Actions Taken in Legislature's 228th Session
description: ALBANY, July 9 - The 228th annual session of the New York State Legislature closed in an unusually orderly fashion here on June 24, just a day later than it was scheduled to, after lawmakers who had been stung by criticism of Albany's ways took steps to try to shore up public confidence in state government.

title: Who Are Americans To Think That Freedom Is Theirs To Spread?
description: One wonders how readily Jefferson and the other founders would have accepted an occupying nation (France or Germany, for example) if it had stage-managed the development and implementation of American democracy following our own Revolutionary War. Ignatieff notes that the French assisted our revolutionary cause. The French did not, however, occupy the newly independent nation and did not impose their own corporate contractors in the task of building Jefferson's homeland.

title: Swamp Thing
description: LIKE some tribal romancer entrusted with the history of his ancestral clan, James Lee Burke keeps telling the same story over and over in his novels about Dave Robicheaux, a Cajun sheriff's deputy who works out of Iberia Parish in the Louisiana bayou country. That story is a powerful one, about the exploitation of a land and its people by a corrupt ruling class that operates above the law. And because it never fails to stir strong feelings in Burke's hero, it bears retelling.

title: Summer Days Down the Shore (Not at the Beach)
description: There is a small black-and-white photograph at the beginning of Bob Krist's photography collection, "Down the Shore" (Old Mill Productions, $24.95) that is iconic of the Jersey Shore of the 1950's. A bare-chested man sits cross-legged on the beach with his wife, who is clad in a modest bathing-suit-cum-skirt, her hand placed gently on his shoulder. Between his legs, squinting and quizzical, is a tousle-haired toddler. They look into the camera, determined to have this small bit of leisure, their week's worth of paradise, recorded forever.

title: Will Any Organ Do?
description: Last summer at one hospital in Dallas, four people died from rabies, an unheard-of level of incidence of this rare disease. As it turned out, each patient was infected by an organ or tissue -- a kidney, a liver, an artery -- that he or she received in a transplant several weeks earlier. Their shared donor, William Beed Jr., a young brain-dead man, had rabies, caught apparently through a bite from a rabid bat, something the surgeons never suspected. They all thought he had suffered a fatal crack-cocaine overdose, which can produce symptoms similar to those of rabies. "We had an explanation for his condition," says Dr. Goran Klintmalm, a surgeon who oversees transplantation at Baylor University Medical Center, where the transplants occurred. "He'd recently smoked crack cocaine. He'd hemorrhaged around the brain. He'd died. That was all we needed to know."

title: Jack's Death, His Choice

title: Fit to Print
description: I work for a small print shop where a customer placed an order for bumper stickers that read, "Defend American Against the Communist/Vote Republican." I think his faulty grammar suits his ridiculous message, and I do not want to correct it. I'd rather save my energy for helping those who mean well. What should I do? Susannah Myers, Asheville, N.C. You should do your job according to the usual professional standards, ensuring that the printing isn't blurry and the ink doesn't run in the rain. You have no obligation to provide extra services -- correcting this customer's solecisms, improving his prose, painting his house. He employs you to perform a skilled mechanical operation, not to be his literary collaborator.

title: Target: Ground Transportation
description: Terrorist attacks on buses, railroads, subways and bridges increased during seven decades studied by the Mineta Transportation Institute at San Jose State University. It compiled lists of attacks starting in the 1920's; the most detailed reports focused on the period from the 1970's through mid-1997, which charted here. This tally includes both successful attacks and those that were set in motion but ultimately thwarted by authorities.

Lovingly remembered by Ellen, Liam, Michael, and Carolanne; Keith Phillips; Andy Scheinman; Florence and Louis (late) C. title: Packed Planes Give Passengers Fewer Choices
description: FIVE managers from Aisin World Corporation of America, an auto parts company, got an unexpected surprise when they arrived at Detroit Metropolitan Airport recently. Bound for Cincinnati on a 7 a.m. flight, they learned that mechanical problems had forced Delta Air Lines to cancel both their flight and the one after that. A third flight did not have enough seats for them. Ultimately, the men decided to forgo the 27-minute flight and drive instead, having encountered a preview of what more passengers may face this summer.

description: A 37-year-old New Yorker who left the city four years ago to see the world and change his life was missing and feared dead in Thursday's rush-hour terrorist attacks in London, a relative in the Bronx and friends in New York and London said yesterday.

description: Aside from Merce Cunningham's "Ocean" [related article, Page 6], the biggest event of the week is the season-ending run of "GISELLE" from AMERICAN BALLET THEATER at the METROPOLITAN OPERA HOUSE, with the usual starry revolving casts. Alessandra Ferri, scheduled for opening night, is out with an injury, but this poetic piece of French Romanticism always casts its spell. Indeed the entire idea of the wispy Romantic ballerina, angelically on pointe yet somehow part of a dark malevolence in nature, stems from this one ballet. Monday through Saturday at 8 p.m., Wednesday and Saturday at 2 p.m., Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center, (212)362-6000 or www.abt.org, $22 to $130.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: SEVEN DAYS IN BARBADOS -- The Best of Barbados package wraps air fare, automobile rental and accommodations into one bundle for visitors. Guests who stay seven nights or longer receive the first night free, reduced air fare and one day of free car rental (minimum three days paid). The price varies depending on when the trip is booked, the departure city, the airline and the availability at the 26 participating hotels. But a seven-night stay at Time Out at the Gap Hotel, with a departure from Boston on American Airlines, booked by July 29 (for travel from Aug. 22 to Dec. 16), could be as low as $499 a person. Add about $60 in taxes and fees. For details, call the Barbados Tourist Authority, (800) 221-9831.

title: Defending America
description: In just a few months, the Pentagon will complete its most important military planning exercise, and Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld has a chance to act boldly in applying the hard lessons of the past four years. He should insist that his planners propose the radical revisions in strategy and force structure that America's security now demands, and should be prepared to face down fierce resistance from service chiefs who do not want their budgets cut and military contractors that do not want their profits reduced. Flinching would mean that even as military spending soars beyond current levels of a half-trillion dollars a year, this country's most essential fighting forces will continue to degrade while its most dangerous enemies grow even more emboldened.

You won't find fast-food joints, tacky souvenir shops or even a single traffic light. And Starbuck is just the name of one of the island's original families, who made their wealth from whaling oil -- the island's staple commodity in the late 18th and early 19th centuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HASKINS, JAMES
description: HASKINS--James, of New York and Gainesville, FL. On July 6, 2005. Beloved husband of Kathleen, father of Michael, Elisa and Margaret; brother of James McKinney, Will, Henry Jr., Eddie Lee, Alfred, Julia H. Foster, Virginia H. Webb, and Johnny Ray; adoptive brother of Nathaniel and Inez M. Spratt; cousin of Susie Hairston, Mary Robinson, and a host of other cousins; uncle to many nieces and nephews. Awardwinning author of more than 145 books, including "Diary of Harlem School Teacher", "The Cotton Club", and, "With Rosa Parks, Rosa Parks: My Story". A professor of English at the University of Florida, he is credited with playing a key role in the development of African-American studies at the University. Service July 17th, 3PM at the Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine. Contributions may be made to the James Haskins Visiting Scholar Fellowship, Department of Afro-American History, or the James Haskins Collections in AfroAmerican Studies, both at the University of Florida, Gainesville, FL. 32611.

title: How to Read a Book
description: Reading requires remarkably little in the way of paraphernalia: a book, a source of light and maybe a pair of glasses. So what, other than our propensity for buying things we don't need, explains the success of the Levenger catalog? The founders of this purveyor of "Tools for Serious Readers" started off hawking halogen lamps out of their den 18 years ago and now sell fancy paper clips, elaborate note-taking systems and dapper leather goods -- all designed "for the productive enjoyment of reading, writing and working with ideas" -- via a 70-plus-page catalog and a "flagship store" in Delray Beach, Fla. There are no leaning towers of newsprint, dusty desktops or eyestrain-inducing fluorescent bulbs here: instead, a fully stocked cherry bookcase squats comfortably in a corner, a suede-bound journal (sold four to a box, each with a different-colored cover "so you can keep your thoughts straight") awaits inspiration, and fountain pens filled with jewel-tone ink beckon from their own "pen easel." If all this seems a bit fussy to those content with ball points and legal pads, Levenger's happily Luddite fantasy of the reading life is irresistible. With that adorable little book light to guide my way, you can't help thinking, I just might be able to get through the complete Proust.

title: An Enclave Wonders if It Is Too Private
description: WEST ORANGE - DR. VICTOR GROISSER remembers the day 35 years ago when he and his wife sneaked into Llewellyn Park. Full of curiosity about the gated neighborhood perched on this town's border with Montclair, where they lived at the time, the couple searched out an entryway to the private enclave, where there was no guard on duty, and proceeded to take an unauthorized look around.

title: Hot Wheels
description: Forget the wheelchairs. They're necessary, of course, but they project an image of vulnerability, and that image just doesn't fit with these guys. Scott Hogsett, Andy Cohn and Mark Zupan have all suffered severe spinal-cord injuries and their movement is permanently limited, but they should not be defined by their impairments. They are rugby players, with all that that entails. They may play the sport in their wheelchairs, but they are tough, fast, hard-drinking, 2-a.m.-strip-clubbing jocks. "People think we sleep in our wheelchairs," said Hogsett, 32, who was paralyzed when an angry man punched him and snapped his neck. "People think we have sex in our wheelchairs. They think we never get out of them. It's good for people to realize otherwise."

title: At Hall of Fame Induction, Noah Remains an Original
description: NEWPORT, R.I., July 9 - At 3 a.m. Saturday, Yannick Noah, one of Europe's leading pop singers, finished a concert in Marbella, Spain, his 90th concert of the year in Western Europe and Africa. His day was only beginning.

This July, if you miss a showing of "Missing in Action," there will be four more chances to see it. Curious about "Staying Alive," the John Travolta "Saturday Night Fever" sequel? title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANG, MRS. VON SUNG
description: YANG--Mrs. Von Sung. Widow of Dr. Ho Ching Yang. Died July 9, 2005. She was born in China, April 7, 1902, and died at her apartment in Manhattan with three of her seven children and two grandchildren at her side. Mrs. Yang witnessed the 20th century almost in its entirety and was personally touched by a number of its most visible events and people. Two of Mrs. Yang's children, Gertrude and Stella, preceded her in death. She is survived by Annie, Alvie, John, George and Lucy. Mrs. Yang was a strong woman, never to be forgotten by her large and active family.

title: Skyscrapers Grow in Brooklyn
description: Reports that there are now competing bids to develop Brooklyn's downtown should be good news for the city and for anyone who uses public transportation. Assuming open and fair competition, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority -- which practically gave away the rights to build a football stadium over its rail yards in Manhattan -- might actually get something approaching market value for the development rights over its rail yards at Atlantic Avenue. It is not a promising sign, though, that the monetary details of the two bids on the MTA property have not been disclosed by either bidder. A little sunlight in such an important transaction should be a minimum requirement.

title: Docudating

The five-part program was produced for ABC's news division by Terence Wrong, whose acclaimed "24/7" series has documented the inner workings of a hospital, a police department and a city government. title: Circus-Fire Memorial Unveiled in Hartford
description: A memorial to the 168 people who died in the July 6, 1944, Hartford Circus Fire was unveiled Wednesday on the site where the main tent's center pole once stood. A series of dogwood trees form what was the tent's outline.

title: The Return of the R-Rated Comedy
description: THERE'S a startling moment near the opening of the new buddy comedy "Wedding Crashers." Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn play divorce mediators who slip into weddings in order to seduce guests who are feeling misty-eyed and romantic. A sequence demonstrating how the heroes ply their trade ends with a montage of bare-breasted beauties tumbling into bed with the guys. The nudity is something of a novelty in this summer's films, and it's just the beginning of the film's assaults on propriety. Four-letter words abound, along with raunchy moments, including one in which the sister of the bride fondles Mr. Vaughn quite brazenly at the dinner table. Before the scene even ends, there's no doubt that "Wedding Crashers" has earned its R rating, which has lately become less desirable for mainstream movies.

title: Suzanne Snavely and Mark Weiss
description: Suzanne Desmond Snavely, the daughter of Mary Jo Snavely and Gordon Snavely of Orchard Lake, Mich., was married last evening to Mark William Weiss, a son of Betsy Weiss and Dr. Stanley Weiss of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. The Rev. William H. Easton, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Orchard Lake Country Club. Rabbi Richard Weiss, a cousin of the bridegroom, took part in the ceremony.

title: Summertime at Wlffer
description: ROMAN ROTH'S summer collection of light whites and a ros from Wlffer Estate, in Sagaponack, illustrates his winemaking philosophy: less is more. They are uniformly understated and can never be confused with plump, juicy, over-the-top wines.

title: B Movies Invade Your TV!
description: ATTACK OF THE SABRETOOTH." "Bloodsuckers." "The Man With the Screaming Brain." And, most indelible of all, "Mansquito."

title: Garbage Land
description: The Dream of Zero Waste

title: The Half-Life of Anxiety
description: FOR all their murderous power, the four terrorist bombs detonated in London on Thursday morning have not created anything close to mass panic. It's possible to imagine a scene straight out of the movie "War of the Worlds," an unraveling of society, with people disoriented, afraid for their lives, holing up in their basements or fleeing the city.

title: An Arena That Will Not Be, and Those Who Never Knew
description: If New York's Olympic bid had not failed, the South Bronx could have been a contender. Specifically, a trash-strewn parking lot and no-man's land just north of 149th Street on the Harlem River could have been transformed by a $76 million velodrome, a grand enclosed arena for cycling races.

title: The Market's Up. Why Do We Feel Blue?
description: THE second quarter proved to be, well, a conundrum for mutual fund investors.

title: Dennis Hits the Florida Panhandle and Alabama Coast
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., July 10 - After strengthening over the Gulf of Mexico and scaring coastal residents into neighboring states, hotels and shelters, Hurricane Dennis weakened to a Category 3 storm just before speeding ashore near Pensacola this afternoon.

title: AMERICAN ON LOAN TO CHARLTON
description: Jonathan Spector, a 19-year-old defender from Chicago who played for Manchester United last season, has been sent on loan to Charlton of the English Premier League. Spector was a member of the United States under-20 national team. Jack Bell

title: EXCHANGING HOMES
description: To the Editor: Regarding Q&A (June 12) by Marjorie Connelly, in which a couple asked about exchanging their large Tucson home for a vacation at a home in another country: Exchanging homes should never be "my home has five bedrooms and a pool -- how about yours?"

title: BICYCLING IN GIRONA
description: To the Editor: In "Finding Nirvana on Two Wheels," (June 12) Girona sounds lovely. But now I don't dare go there, for fear of being run over by a cyclist hurtling down the street, or even down the stairs.

title: Uniting China to Speak Mandarin, the One Official Language: Easier Said Than Done
description: DATIAN, China - As a crowd formed around a rare foreign visitor in this town's open-air market, the conversation turned quickly from the price of dried fish and fresh fruit to how many dialects people here could muster.

title: Donald Gardenier and Thomas McGillis
description: Donald Gardenier and Thomas Arthur McGillis were married on Monday by Lucette Saint-Amour, a deputy clerk of the Superior Court of Quebec, at the Palais de Justice in Montreal. Yesterday, the Rev. Michael F. Delaney, an Episcopal priest, led another ceremony at the couple's weekend house in Claverack, N.Y.

title: A New SoHo 200 Miles Northeast
description: FIRST there was SoHo, then SoBe. The contractions continue with SoWa, as in South of Washington Street.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-11

title: This Inflation Hedge Can Be a Bit Volatile
description: INVESTMENTS known as Treasury Inflation Protected Securities, or TIPS, look like sure-fire successes -- combining safety, inflation protection and rapid appreciation.

title: Elizabeth Irvine and James Bray
description: Elizabeth Anne Irvine, the daughter of Joan and Arthur S. Irvine of Westport, Conn., was married last evening to James Keith Bray, a son of Ashlin and James S. Bray of Chadds Ford, Pa. The Rev. Edward C. Horne, a minister of the United Methodist Church, officiated at the Silvermine Tavern in Norwalk, Conn.

title: If You Have to Ask, Get Lost
description: I TOOK my son to see the Great Falls of the Passaic recently. The Falls should be a 15-minute drive from our home -- but in New Jersey, as we discovered, even a short excursion can quickly turn into an adventure.

title: Third-Track Project Finds Its Nemesis
description: Floral Park - AS a funeral home owner, Timothy J. Dalton prefers a quiet and respectful atmosphere. So he has never much liked the noise and vibrations from the Long Island Rail Road trains hurtling by on elevated tracks only yards from his family business on Atlantic Avenue in Floral Park.

title: As a Gold Mine Prepares to Close, Montana Argues Over the Hole in the Ground
description: WHITEHALL, Mont. - First, there was Bull Mountain. Through all the ages of human striving and much that came before, it sat here in southwest Montana, silently enshrouding a treasure in fine-particle gold buried deep beneath its flanks.

title: We're Not in Watergate Anymore
description: WHEN John Dean published his book "Worse Than Watergate" in the spring of 2004, it seemed rank hyperbole: an election-year screed and yet another attempt by a Nixon alumnus to downgrade Watergate crimes by unearthing worse "gates" thereafter. But it's hard to be dismissive now that my colleague Judy Miller has been taken away in shackles for refusing to name the source for a story she never wrote. No reporter went to jail during Watergate. No news organization buckled like Time. No one instigated a war on phony premises. This is worse than Watergate.

title: INSIDE
description: Srebrenica 10 Years On: Tormenting Memories The massacre of 7,000 Muslims at Srebrenica, Bosnia, and the forced expulsion of 30,000 others 10 years ago will be commemorated on Monday, when as many as 50,000 people are expected to gather there. Three lives reflect how Srebrenica has changed and how the effects of its horror live on. PAGE 3

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHWARTZ, SHIRLEY GLASSBERG
description: SCHWARTZ--Shirley Glassberg. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Relgion family expresses its profound sorrow at the death of Shirley Glassberg Schwartz, beloved mother of Ilene and Stanley P. Gold of Los Angeles. Ilene and family have been steadfast and loyal friends of the College for more than three decades. They have opened their hearts to those associated with the College-Institute. We, in turn, have been blessed by this unique association. May they and their children, Charles and Jennifer, be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: 'Squandered Victory' and 'Losing Iraq': Now What?
description: SQUANDERED VICTORY The American Occupation and the Bungled Effort to Bring Democracy to Iraq. By Larry Diamond. 369 pp. Times Books. $25.

title: Rowland B. Wilson, 74, Creator of Wry Cartoons, Is Dead
description: Rowland B. Wilson, whose watercolor cartoons were instantly recognizable to readers of Playboy, The Saturday Evening Post, Esquire and The New Yorker, died on June 28 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in Encinitas, Calif. He was 74 and lived in La Costa, Calif.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A Disney-themed rail line, complete with mouse-shaped windows, will transport visitors to the newest DISNEYLAND, set to open Sept. 12 on Lantau Island in Hong Kong. Visitors travel by subway from anywhere in the city to the new Sunny Bay Station and transfer to a train decorated with Disney classic characters for the two-and-a-half-minute ride to the Disneyland Resort Station. Information about the park is available on the Web at www.hongkongdisneyland.com. According to a recent ABC NEWS/ WASHINGTON POST POLL, 53 percent of Americans plan to vacation away from home this summer, and a third of them expect to spend more money than usual. The telephone poll was conducted June 2 to 5 with 1,002 adults nationwide. New kiosks at the shuttle bus stop at the AVIS car return location in Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta airport allow Delta passengers with carry-on luggage only to check in for their flight, take the shuttle bus to the terminal and then head directly to security with their boarding pass. Avis is considering a future expansion of this service to other airports and other airlines. CONTINENTAL AIRLINES will start flying once a week from Houston to Bonaire, in the Caribbean, Bonaire beginning Dec. 16. The flight will depart Houston at 11:30 p.m. Friday, and arrive on Bonaire at 6:15 Saturday morning. The return flight will depart Bonaire Saturday at 8 a.m. and arrive in Houston at 10:30 a.m. Reservations and information: (800) 231-0856 or visit www.continental.com. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: Hello Moto: Rossi, a Top Italian Racer, Comes to the U.S. on Two Spinning Wheels
description: MONTEREY, Calif. July 9 - When asked about the popularity of motorcycle racer Valentino Rossi in his native Italy, the broadcaster Guido Meda did not mince words. "In this moment he is the first sportsman in Italy, and over all, I would say he is somewhere in line between the president and the pope," he said.

title: Salve for the Workweek
description: Summer beauty products are usually all froth and light, celebrating sand, surf and endless weekends. This year's crop is particularly delectable: weightless moisturizers, cooling blushers and citrus-spiked fragrances that offer ways to fight the heat, stave off humidity and banish the workweek. Here are some of the season's best picks -- get 'em while it's hot.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIEGEL, LOTTIE
description: SIEGEL--Lottie. Beloved wife of the late Leo Siegel; on July 7, 2005. Precious mother of Cynthia, Helene, Paul and Edward, adored grandmother of Susan, Andrew, Mindy, Howard, Michele, Martha, Kenny and Linda; loving great grandmother of Elyssa, Tracie, Seth, Jennifer, Danny, Michael, Lisa, Haley and Joey. Services Sunday, 12 noon, at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Ave corner 91 Street. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Westside Jewish Center, 347 W. 34 St., NY, NY 10001.

title: Euthanasia for Babies?
description: One sure way to start a lively argument at a dinner party is to raise the question Are we humans getting more decent over time? Optimists about moral progress will point out that the last few centuries have seen, in the West at least, such welcome developments as the abolition of slavery and of legal segregation, the expansion of freedoms (of religion, speech and press), better treatment of women and a gradual reduction of violence, notably murder, in everyday life. Pessimists will respond by citing the epic evils of the 20th century -- the Holocaust, the Gulag. Depending on their religious convictions, some may call attention to the breakdown of the family and a supposed decline in sexual morality. Others will complain of backsliding in areas where moral progress had seemingly been secured, like the killing of civilians in war, the reintroduction of the death penalty or the use of torture. And it is quite possible, if your dinner guests are especially well informed, that someone will bring up infanticide.

title: Their Lighthouse, Our Stars
description: To the Editor:

title: Seeking a Little Respect for a Long-Suffering Monument
description: The Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument at 89th Street in Riverside Park is still majestic from afar, with its 12 soaring Corinthian columns and surrounding terraces. But up close the dilapidation is clearly visible. Pave-stones, many damaged by skateboarding and soccer playing, need replacing. The paint covering the many splotches of graffiti is tacky. And the tomblike interior, which is leaking, has long been closed to the public. Major work last took place in 1962.

title: Helping Law Firms Reduce Paperwork
description: WHITE PLAINS - A JUMP in the number of lawyers here, along with a technical sea change in the legal industry in recent years, have prompted a mom-and-pop enterprise to transform itself into a rapidly expanding electronic document services company.

title: Bond Investors Are Joining the Index Fund Parade
description: BOND index funds have been catching on, and for good reasons. Like stock index funds, they have cheaper fees, more transparent holdings and higher average annual returns, over time, than the vast majority of actively managed funds in their category.

title: 'Losing Iraq'
description: George W. Bush did not imagine that preemption and nation-building would preoccupy his presidency. However, the 9/11 terror attacks gave Bush a defining mission. To defend the American homeland and U.S. global interests, the United States would retaliiate against failed states, such as Afghanistan, that provided sanctuary to al-Qaeda or other shadowy terrorist networks. It would also act preemptively, targeting rogue regimes to prevent them from developing weapons of mass destruction (WMD), which could be used against the United States or given to terror groups.

title: Using Feng Shui in Offices and Stores
description: FENG SHUI seemed destined to go the way of hippie communes, ridiculed as a bourgeois lifestyle fad. Instead, like yoga and organic food, the ancient Chinese practice of positioning objects, buildings and even whole communities to maximize the flow of energy, or chi, has penetrated the culture beyond the New Age world of crystals and chimes.

title: 3 Hurt in Collapse of Scaffold in Bronx
description: Three men were injured, one critically, when the construction scaffold they were working on collapsed yesterday afternoon in the Bronx.

title: And Now, a Word From the Streets
description: The underground street-art scene usually maintains an antagonistic equilibrium: graffiti artists bomb (i.e., paint) highly visible sites; civic groups buff (i.e., paint over) their handiwork. But new graffiti-style advertisements -- done, it must be said, by real-live graffiti artists -- for decidedly above-ground companies like Time Warner, General Motors and Unilever have lately upset that balance. Now it's angry artists who are protesting and even buffing, and marketing experts who are joining in on heated debates about selling out. For the advertisers, of course, (almost) any publicity is welcome. Reports from three new battlegrounds:

title: Ten Afghan soldiers beheaded in Taliban ambush
It's All Happening at the Tulsa Zoo
description: Christian creationists won too much of a victory for their own good in Tulsa, where the local zoo was ordered to balance its evolution science exhibit with a display extolling the Genesis account of God's creating the universe from nothing in six days. A determined creationist somehow talked three of the four zoo directors, including Mayor Bill LaFortune, into the addition by arguing that a statue of the elephant-headed god Ganesh at the elephant house amounted to an anti-Christian bias toward Hinduism.

title: 'Death and the Sun'
description: Pozoblanco, September 26, 1984. They couldn't see more than a few feet ahead of them. Within the obsessive compass of the headlights the black road uncoiled, split by the white line, stretching and bending with the land. The BMW sedan was bone white, built heavy, well suited to drone out the thousands of miles a top matador must travel from town to town, from bullfight to bullfight, from February to October, through the eight-month marathon of the bullfighting season. Sometime early that morning-later documents would differ on the exact time-the car pulled into a small town and stopped before a building with the words Hotel Los Godos spelled out over the doorway. The driver got out, opened one of the rear doors, and prodded the shoulder of the man who lay asleep in the back seat.

In late June, New York's Department of Environmental Conservation and Office of Parks, Recreation and Historical Preservation released a study that identified 13 sites where Hudson River swimming beaches could be established.

title: Summer Days Down the Shore (Not at the Beach)
description: There is a small black-and-white photograph at the beginning of Bob Krist's photography collection, "Down the Shore" (Old Mill Productions, $24.95) that is iconic of the Jersey Shore of the 1950's. A bare-chested man sits cross-legged on the beach with his wife, who is clad in a modest bathing-suit-cum-skirt, her hand placed gently on his shoulder. Between his legs, squinting and quizzical, is a tousle-haired toddler. They look into the camera, determined to have this small bit of leisure, their week's worth of paradise, recorded forever.

title: The Star Maker Of the Semipopular

Here in Los Angeles, we are the ones subjected to the narcissistic bleating of this one-dimensional show during our drive times.

title: Somerville's Story and My Great-Grandfather's Legacy
description: My family's slave-era history has survived in rich detail, thanks to my aggressively talkative great-grandfather John Wesley Staples (1865-1940), who was conceived in the closing days of the Civil War and became the first freeborn black person in the Staples family line. My family has always treasured these stories, but my generation is just beginning to realize the value of the gift John Wesley left us.

That's the question a friend of Brandon and Brody Jenner asks after the two rich slackers are financially cut off by their stepfather, DAVID FOSTER, the bazillionaire record producer and songwriter, on FOX's new comedy series "THE PRINCES OF MALIBU" (Sunday at 8:30). description: WHEN Greg LeMond became the first American to win the Tour de France in 1986, the bicycles he rode were made in Europe. For a contender back then, anything other than a European model was unthinkable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOONS, TILGHMAN B.
description: KOONS--Tilghman B. 79, on July 7, 2005, at his home in East Hampton. Son of Margaret O'Hara and Lucius Koons. Beloved and admired by his friends, "Skip" Koons had a wide-ranging career in the military, government and banking. Born in Plainfield, NJ, he received his B.A. from Princeton, with honors, at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs in 1946. From 1946 to 1949 he was in the U.S. Navy, learning Russian at the Language School in Boulder, CO, serving in Washington with Secretary James Forrestal and in China for two and a half years, working with Russian emigre communities in Shanghai, Peking and Manchuria. After receiving a Fulbright Fellowship, in 1952 he earned a Ph.D., with highest honors, from the University of Paris (Sorbonne). His thesis traced the political ideas and activities of the Russian emigres from the Russian Revolution to the outbreak of World War II. From 1953 to 1957 he served in the Executive Office of the President, as an adviser to General Robert Cutler, President Eisenhower's Special Assistant for National Security. Upon leaving the government, he joined the First National Bank of Boston and, in 1962, the Chase Manhattan Bank where, as Vice President, he was concerned with strategic planning of the bank's overseas expansion in Latin America, the Far East and Canada. In addition to his professional activities, Skip was learned in history and the arts, and assembled a notable collection of marine water colors and prints from the 18th and 19th centuries. His wisdom, warmth and generosity will be sorely missed by his many friends in this country and in Europe. A Memorial Service will be announced.

title: U.S. Says It Will Release American Held in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, July 9 - Military officials have agreed to free Cyrus Kar, an aspiring American filmmaker who has been imprisoned without charge for nearly two months at a United States military detention center in Iraq, lawyers and relatives of Mr. Kar said Saturday.

title: The Basics; Dahling, I Am Not a Socialite
description: When Nan Kempner died last Sunday, she was lauded as one of the last of a breed of well-off women, envied for their wardrobes and admired as swell hostesses, who married rich and powerful men.

title: TRUMP RESORTS C.E.O. IS NAMED
description: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the company that emerged when the casino empire of Donald Trump came out of bankruptcy in May, has named James E. Perry chief executive officer. Mr. Perry, a director of the company, retired in 2003 as chief executive of Argosy Gaming Company, a riverboat casino operator. Mr. Trump had been C.E.O. and chairman of the company before it went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy in November 2004, and then reorganized. He said in May that he would stay on as chairman, but relinquish the duties as C.E.O. to spend more time on real estate and other activities. Trump Entertainment runs three Atlantic City casinos -- Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, Trump Marina Hotel Casino and Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort -- and the Trump Casino Hotel, a riverboat casino in Gary, Ind. Robert Strauss

title: At Funds, Stiff Upper Lips About New Rules
description: A RAFT of new mutual fund regulations issued over the last two years by the Securities and Exchange Commission has given the Nottingham Company a new line of business. The company, a mutual fund accountant and administrator based in Rocky Mount, N.C., has begun renting out helpers for chief compliance officers.

title: Speed Limit Lowered To 25 M.P.H. in Village
description: Summer traffic through the Hamptons is already at a crawl on most weekends, but that isn't stopping the Village of East Hampton from lowering the speed limit.

title: Tours in St. Petersburg, Russia; Bach Festivals in the United States

title: Solo Health Insurance: Possible, Yes, but Not Easy
description: GREG AND LINDA JOHNSON thought that they had allowed plenty of time to find new health insurance last year. They were losing coverage at the end of December, so they started looking after Labor Day. "We thought three to four months would be plenty," Mr. Johnson said.

Dressed as a merman, Mr. Stiller stares intently into the camera and recites with a straight face the ad's tagline: "Moisture is the essence of wetness, and wetness is the essence of beauty."

description: To the Editor:

title: Students Plan Syllabus For Board of Education
description: The two high school students recently chosen by the governor to serve on the state's Board of Education for the 2005-6 school year said Tuesday that they hoped to speak out on issues of choosing a school, bullying, safety in schools and the quality of inner-city schools.

title: Julia Moffett and Toby Constantine
description: Julia Francesca Moffett and Toby Russell Constantine were married yesterday in a civil ceremony in London. Andrew Kenyon, a registrar, officiated at the Kensington and Chelsea register office. Last evening the Rev. Richard Harriott, a Roman Catholic priest, performed a religious ceremony at the Orangery in Holland Park in London.

title: Dana Klein and Mark Feuerstein
description: Dana Klein, a television writer and producer, and Mark Feuerstein, a television, film and theater actor, were married last evening at the Four Seasons-Biltmore Hotel in Santa Barbara, Calif. Rabbi Jonathan Aaron officiated.

title: STATE PASSES UP GRANTS; FIGHTS FOR BASE
description: State officials said last week that they would continue to fight the Pentagon over the proposed closing of Fort Monmouth, and did not file for federal grants that could help retrain civilian workers who would lose their jobs when the base closes. New Jersey was one of 15 states that did not apply for the grants, according to the Department of Labor. Kelley Heck, a spokeswoman for Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, said the state did not want to take the money because "we are committed to keeping the base, we will continue to fight to keep it open and want the federal government to realize they made a mistake." The Pentagon announced in May that it would be closing more than 100 bases, including Fort Monmouth, a communications technology base. If Fort Monmouth closes, the state stands to lose nearly 3,700 civilian jobs. John Holl

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEUERSTADT, OSCAR
description: FEUERSTADT--Oscar. July 8, 2005. Oscar Feuerstadt of 6845 Fountain Circle, Lake Worth, FL, and 200 Fountain St, New Haven. Devoted husband of Rita (Shapiro) Feuerstadt. Beloved father of Ivy Feuerstadt and her husband Barry Becken of West Newton, MA, and the late Bruce Feuerstadt. Dear brother of the late Paul Feuerstadt. Cherished grandfather of Becky, Gabriel, & Samantha Wasserman. Funeral services at Robert E. Shure Funeral Home, 543 George St, New Haven, CT, Monday, at 10 am, with interment to follow in the Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing, NY. Memorial contributions may be sent to Congregation B'nai Jacob, 75 Rimmon Rd, Woodbridge, CT 06525; or to Yale-New Haven Hospital Department of Cardiology, Attn: Dr. Mukheyee, 20 York St, New Haven, CT 06519. A period of mourning will be observed at 200 Fountain St, New Haven.

title: Longtime Haven for Arabs Now Must Ask: Why Us?
description: LONDON, July 9 - A makeshift corrugated-iron fence now blocks the view of the bombed Edgware Road subway station. The blare of sirens has grown more sporadic, and the trappings of normalcy are slowly coming back to this central business district, with shoppers and diners filing back into the cafes and onto the sidewalks.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the "Going To" column on June 12, about Copenhagen, referred incorrectly to the architect who designed an extension to the Ordrupgaard museum in suburban Charlottenlund. The architect, Zara Hadid, is a woman.

title: The Seat-Belt Solution
description: A Car-Seat Crash Test On a recent Monday morning, nearly 20 police officers gathered in Clarkstown, N.Y., for a four-day seminar. They had assembled to fight one of modernity's great scourges: child deaths in motor-vehicle crashes. Each officer was given a 345-page training manual issued by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). At seminar's end, each would be certified as a "child passenger safety technician," which primarily means that they would be experts in the installation and use of child car seats.

title: Under the Microscope Longer Than Most
description: WASHINGTON - THE period during which a court's membership remains unchanged is known to political scientists as a natural court. It is useful as a kind of controlled experiment that permits study of the institution itself without the distraction of judges coming and going. Or so the theory goes.

title: Fishing in Central Park. For Fish. Really.
description: After years of reading about how fishing is not really about catching fish, but about "the experience," I finally asked myself: Why not just save the gas money and avoid the aggravation of fighting traffic en route to the Catskills? Why not fish here at home, across the street in Central Park?

title: Armstrong Gives Up the Overall Lead in the Tour de France
description: MULHOUSE, France, July 10 - In a tactical decision, Lance Armstrong yielded the yellow jersey of the Tour de France's leader today, dropping to third place as he sought to decrease the workload and pressure for his team after its collapse the day before.

title: Corrections
description: The "What I'm Wearing Now" feature on the Pulse page last Sunday, about Olivia Chantecaille, founder of a cosmetics company, misspelled the surname of a clothing designer she listed among her favorites. He is Lars Nilsson, not Nillson.

title: Is Youth Too Green To Notice The Greenery?
description: BY any decent reckoning, the Hudson Valley is the birthplace of the modern environmental movement. Notably, there was Con Edison's attempted assault on Storm King Mountain, perhaps the river's most famed natural locale. The plant it sought to build there in the 1960's and 70's never materialized, because the opposition was ferocious.

title: Why Wait for Labor Day? Candidates for Governor in New Jersey Set Torrid Pace
description: TRENTON, July 8 - The calendar may say that it is early July, but in New Jersey, the race for governor makes it feel as if it were already October.

title: Mutal Funds Report; SECOND QUARTER: APRIL 1-JUNE 30, 2005
description: Stocks vs. Bonds Average returns, by mutual fund category, for the second quarter.

title: Hey, Sports Fans, Guess What We've Named Your Stadium
description: I ask you, would the fans in Mudville have named their stadium Fritos Field? Would there have been a Gipper if the Irish were asked to play in Sara Lee Stadium? Could the Babe have possibly smoked No. 60 into the bleachers of some ballpark named after an onion dip enhancer?

title: An Easy Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: A Last Whiff of Fulton's Fish, Bringing a Tear
description: It smells of truck exhaust and fish guts. Of glistening skipjacks and smoldering cigarettes; fluke, salmon and Joe Tuna's cigar. Of Canada, Florida, and the squid-ink East River. Of funny fish-talk riffs that end with profanities spat onto the mucky pavement, there to mix with coffee spills, beer blessings, and the flowing melt of sea-scented ice.

title: One Mo' Time
description: THERE are more lights now, shining on the liquor bottles behind the bar at Smalls. It is no longer dark enough to pretend the musicians are playing only for you. The bar has replaced the cushioned banquette that used to frame the room, allowing Mitch Borden, the former owner, to cram in many more than the 50 people he was allowed.

title: Tech Lust Grips Some Bargain Hunters
description: AS patrons of the underpriced and the overlooked, value investors have typically shunned pricey, high-profile technology stocks. But David C. Fondrie, manager of the Heartland Select Value fund, concluded late last year that nearly five years of eroding prices had finally turned some tech shares into bargains. "A lot of guys would say: 'What are value hunters doing in the tech sector?' It is in our opinion undervalued," Mr. Fondrie said.

title: Martha Knolle and J. C. Melcher
description: IN a way, the tragic end of the space shuttle Columbia, which broke apart over Texas in 2003, was the catalyst that brought Martha Minnette Knolle and John Charles Melcher IV together. In another twist, changes in the launch plans for the shuttle Discovery, now scheduled to lift off next week, ruined the couple's honeymoon plans and added to their wedding pressures.

title: The Great Mango War Flares Once More
description: Adam Smith probably never tasted a mango. But Smith, the 18th-century Scottish economist, would surely recognize his theories of supply and demand at work on the streets of Jackson Heights, Queens, one heart of the city's fiercely competitive mango market.

title: 'Hot Property'
A Resilient Holdsclaw Displays Her All-Star Form
description: UNCASVILLE, Conn., July 9 - This time last year, Chamique Holdsclaw said, she was profoundly sad and not thinking much about basketball.

title: The Daily Minyan: Finding a Center of Comfort
description: Dix Hills - AFTER her son Adam was killed in a car accident on Mother's Day last year at the age of 27, Anita E. Rayman of Dix Hills was so upset that she did not want to recite Kaddish, the Jewish prayer for the dead.

title: Editors' Choice
Paid Notice: Deaths   KATZ, THELMA
description: KATZ--Thelma. On July 1. Beloved wife of the late Harvey Katz. Wonderful mother of Bennett. Thelma retired as a partner with Harvey in Holiday Wine & Liquor in Grand Central Terminal. She will be missed by all who knew her. Donations in Thelma's memory may be made to Project Ezra, 197 E. Broadway, NY, NY 10002.

title: Will Storm and Attacks Weigh on Consumers?
description: THE University of Michigan's consumer confidence report, scheduled to be released on Friday, could provide a glimpse of the impact of last week's London bombings on consumer sentiment.

title: On Civil Commitment
description: The tragedy of Concetta Russo-Carriero, stabbed to death last month in a parking garage in White Plains, has prompted calls for swift justice for her accused killer, a homeless convicted rapist, and for the swift enactment of laws to make sure that men like him never prey again.

title: In Edgemont, Does It Really Take a Village?
description: Correction Appended

title: The Judge Is an Activist. Maybe.
description: To the Editor:

title: In Troubled Detroit, Mayor's Race Is a Referendum on Style
description: DETROIT, July 9 - The day after Kwame M. Kilpatrick was elected mayor in 2001, he put his diamond stud back in his left ear.

title: Letters
description: Michael Ignatieff cited Thomas Jefferson's ''dream of freedom'' as one reason for the Iraq war, but many readers said the motives were not so lofty. They cited weapons of mass destruction. The ''3-D Word Hunt'' puzzle was a huge hit. Hundreds of ''genius level'' solvers weighed in with words for the grid.

title: Alexandra Lyon and Jonathan Perelman
description: Alexandra Lyon, the daughter of Judith Lyon and Anthony Lyon, both of Bethesda, Md., was married last evening to Jonathan Sondik Perelman, a son of Abby and A. Steven Perelman of Avon, Conn. Rabbi Howard S. Herman officiated at the St. Regis Hotel in Washington, with Rabbi Andrew Koren, a cousin of the bride, assisting in the ceremony.

title: No Surprise, New Terror Attack Quickly Is Grist of Politics
description: WASHINGTON - JUST hours after last week's terrorist bombings in London, David Sirota, a liberal blogger, issued a missive titled "Iraq, London and America's Homeland Insecurity" -- a pointed critique of President Bush's assertion that the United States is fighting terrorists overseas in Iraq and Afghanistan so that it does not have to face them at home.

title: Corrections
description: Correction Appended

description: To the Editor:

title: Did You See 'War of the Worlds'? Did You Get the Message?
description: THANK you for stopping by at TomCruiseAteMyBrain.com and reading my Weblog, which is devoted entirely to my musings on the use of metaphor in the new film "War of the Worlds." Most bloggers, of course, are utterly without qualifications to pontificate on whatever subject they've chosen, but not me.

title: Locked or Unlocked, Your Car's in Trouble
description: To the Editor:

title: Leah Buhl and Christopher LaPlaca
description: Leah Angelica Buhl, a daughter of Sarah J. Buhl and G. Lawrence Buhl of Bryn Mawr, Pa., was married yesterday evening to Christopher Mark LaPlaca, a son of Patricia and Nick LaPlaca of Whitehall, N.Y. The Rev. Dexter Lanctot, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Ritz-Carlton Philadelphia.

title: COUNCIL'S ROLE DIMINISHED
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey restructured the state's Public Health Council, leaving the 58-year-old independent agency virtually powerless. The council, whose eight members are volunteers, has been responsible for creating regulations for vaccines, food safety and public health policies. Under the restructuring, the council will serve in an advisory role to the state Department of Health and Senior Services. Dr. Robert M. Pallay, chairman of the council, said that some of the work the council has done has been contentious, "but that comes with the territory." He said the governor was doing a disservice to residents by stripping the council of all of its power. Kelley Heck, a spokeswoman for the governor said the restructuring was justified. "It's not about one issue," she said. "The council is not really part of the administration, and the governor and the health commissioner should really have control of the state's health policies." BRIEFING: HEALTH

title: Children's Books
description: CONRAD'S FATE A Chrestomanci Book. By Diana Wynne Jones. 375 pp. Greenwillow Books. $16.99.

title: Who Are Americans To Think That Freedom Is Theirs To Spread?
description: While American influences were undoubtedly important in West Germany after World War II, it isn't true to say that these influences brought about German democracy all by themselves. Germany had a strong democratic tradition that was suppressed, but not entirely destroyed, by Kaiser Wilhelm and Adolf Hitler. Without the Frankfurt Parliament of 1848, there could have been no Konrad Adenauer in 1949, and Willy Brandt owed more to Germany's Social Democratic heritage than to American political ideas.

title: 10 Years On, Tormenting Memories of Srebrenica
description: SREBRENICA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 9 - A decade ago here in eastern Bosnia, Camila Omanovic tied a rope around an iron pipe in an abandoned factory. She asked God to forgive her and tried to hang herself.

title: Everybody Comes to Hubba's. O.K., Maybe Not the Health Food Crowd.
description: Port Chester, N.Y. - YES, David Mobarek and Randy DiPietro, 17-year-old rising seniors at Port Chester High School, had been to Pat's or Hubba's or whatever it's called, every day for the last week. Yes, they had already had a proper dinner -- tacos -- at David's house. But there it was, almost midnight Thursday, and the two were digging away once again at their chicken platter, an enormous mound of fried chicken, smothered in a giddy, greasy glop of fries, melted cheese and chili.

title: CLOSE CALL
description: He could not escape a prison sentence for his role in the insider-trading scandals of the 1980's, but Ilan K. Reich did escape an even worse fate while flying a small plane north of New York City on June 30.

title: Change in Brooklyn: For Better, or Worse?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: H.O.V. Lane, Done at Last. Does It Work?
description: DIANE RODRIGUEZ tries hard not to gloat, but it's not always easy.

title: GIANT SUITCASES
description: To the Editor: Regarding "Overweight Bag? Have Your Wallet Ready," (Practical Traveler, June 5): This old fogey, who remembers china plates in coach and stewardesses offering Chiclets in baskets, has been dying to know what is inside the giant suitcases of American travelers dressed like slobs -- more sneakers, T-shirts, and jeans?

title: Among the Believers
description: Urbana, Ill. - IN elementary school, I spent a great deal of energy trying to explain the difference between atheism and devil worship. Until second grade I answered the commonplace query: "Where do you go to church?" with this: "My father says that we don't believe in God." Adults took this information with shocked silence, but children lack restraint. "You're a devil worshiper?," they asked. I didn't think I was but I asked Daddy who assured me that we were not. "Atheists," he explained, "don't believe in the devil either."

title: 5 New Roommates Play 'Getting to Know You'
description: THE previous sublet tenants in this five-bedroom loft in Hell's Kitchen were a French recluse and a cameraman from MTV's "The Real World." It is this last fact that has the current five residents, Daniel Santangelo, 23, Sara Vigneault, 24, Luke Masselink, 27, Keren Davies, 33, and David Allyn, 36, convinced that there are cameras hidden everywhere, and that they are the unwitting subjects of a new quasi-reality series: perhaps "The Real World" meets "The Truman Show."

title: Who Are Americans To Think That Freedom Is Theirs To Spread?
description: Much as I have been opposed to the Iraq war, I agree with Michael Ignatieff (June 26) that if it succeeds, it may actually help in democratizing the Middle East -- in which case George W. Bush will be vindicated. Ignatieff, however, omitted one pivotal point: the rationale Bush originally gave to the nation for invading Iraq was to intercept weapons of mass destruction, not to free the Iraqi people. Original intent makes all the difference.

title: Wie Embraces the Challenge of a PGA Tour Event
description: SILVIS, Ill., July 9 - If Michelle Wie chooses to compete on the PGA Tour again -- and it appears she will have the chance -- then the men may need to watch out. Each time Wie plays against them, she gains more confidence.

title: 'A Strange Death'
Paid Notice: Deaths   TZIRLIN, RONALD M.
description: TZIRLIN--Ronald M. Devoted husband and soulmate of Rita. Loving father of Stacie, Steven, Barbara, and Hal, grandfather of Dylan and brother of Jody. A generous and loving spirit, he will long be remembered. Service Monday, July 11, 12 noon, at "Sinai Chapels," 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows. NY.

title: Jordena Ginsburg and Efrem Nidam
description: Jordena Mae Ginsburg, a television reporter, and Efrem Raphael Nidam, a television cameraman, were married on Monday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden by Rabbi Jacob S. Rubenstein.

title: Inside the List
description: CASES AGAINST HILLARY: Edward Klein's new biography, "The Truth About Hillary," has united (no easy task) literary critics, politicians and talk show hosts -- it is easily this year's most vilified book. That hasn't stopped Klein's book from landing on beach blankets; it makes its debut at No. 2 on this week's hardcover nonfiction list. Writing in the Book Review in 1988, Joyce Carol Oates coined the term "pathography" to describe hatchet jobs like Klein's. Reading Oates's taxonomy of that genre today, it sounds as if she somehow had an advance copy of Klein's book rotting at her elbow: "Its motifs are dysfunction and disaster, illnesses and pratfalls, failed marriages and failed careers, alcoholism and breakdowns and outrageous conduct" Oates wrote about the pathography. "Its scenes are sensational, wallowing in squalor and foolishness; its dominant images are are physical and deflating; its shrill theme is 'failed promise' if not outright 'tradedy.' " More than a few book-length attacks on Hillary Rodham Clinton have made the Times hardcover list in recent years, from Peggy Noonan's "Case Against Hillary" (2002) to Dick Morris's "Rewriting History" (2003) to Christopher Anderson's "American Evita" (2004). None of them sold as well as Senator Clinton's own memoir, "Living History" (2003), which stayed on the hardcover list for 20 weeks, five of them at No. 1. Bill Clinton's memoir, "My Life," remains on the paperback list, by the way, where it is No. 6. It did slightly better than his wife's book on the Times list: It survived for 28 weeks in hardcover, six of them at No. 1.

title: The Star Maker Of the Semipopular
description: After reading Jaime Wolf's excellent profile of Nic Harcourt and "Morning Becomes Eclectic," I boasted to my wife that I was a fan years ago, before he got famous (June 26). As a 32-year-old music lover who is no longer plugged into the scene, it's been a long time since I said that. Thanks.

title: Airy Lofts in a Manufacturing Neighborhood
description: Correction Appended

title: Betty Boop's Playground
description: THE little-known 1933 short film called "Stoopnocracy" opens with two cartoon dogs driving a truck painted with the words "Nut House Wagon." A dispatcher's voice commands them to "go to 1600 Broadway--big nuts just broke loose!"

title: Sarah Miller and Todd Wendel
description: Sarah Townsend Miller and Todd Eckerson Wendel were married yesterday evening at the Commodore Perry Farm, the bride's family farm in Wakefield, R.I. The ceremony was led by Mark D. Hagen, a friend of the bride's family and a hospital chaplain, who was designated by Rhode Island as a marriage officiant.

title: Scent of Honey From Chile
description: The Chilean producer Cousio-Macul farms sauvignon gris vines, a relative of sauvignon blanc, within sight of the Andes in the Alto Maipo region. The forerunners of these vines arrived in the 1860's from Bordeaux, where gris remains an antique grape. Adventurous lovers of rare whites will be captivated by Cousio-Macul's 2004 bone-dry gris. Its scent combines honey and wildflowers. Its power as a piquant aperitif lies in a prolonged grapefruity aftertaste.

title: Poker Is Drawing Growing Interest
description: LAS VEGAS, July 9 - The poker faithful, pros and amateurs alike, part as the man in the white cowboy hat stiff-legs his way into the mammoth ballroom here at the Rio Hotel and Casino. They lean closer when Doyle Brunson offers a kind word in his honeysuckle Texas baritone along with his autograph.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the English National Opera's harshly criticized decision to use supertitles with its English-language productions misspelled a phrase from "Tosca" that figured in a comparable tempest of the past. It is "Muori dannato" ("die accursed"), not "Muori donnato."

title: Outlasting the Brewery Competition
description: BACK in the early 1990's, microbreweries became a trend, and Long Island was not immune to it. While the industry was hot and the beer was cold, Southampton Publick House and the Blue Point Brewing Company in Patchogue entered the microbrewery business, too.

title: Nannies and the Clouds of Doubt
description: THE mother got home from work, removed her gold and ruby earrings, a present from her mother, and carelessly left them on a bookshelf, too tired to put them into the jewelry box. When she went back to look for them a few days later, they were gone. Had the nanny seen them? No, the nanny replied. She looked innocent. And maybe she was. Maybe the earrings had been brushed to the floor and vacuumed up, accidentally.

title: 'A Strange Death': Four Angry Women
description: A STRANGE DEATH By Hillel Halkin. 388 pp. PublicAffairs. $26.

Loving grandmother of Dawn, Heather, Renee, Nicholas, Robert, and grandmother and best friend of Erin. Dear sister of Adele and Virginia. Visitation Saturday and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at Joseph G. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th St., Bklyn. Funeral Mass, Monday, 10:00 AM, at St. Saviour Church. Interment Green-wood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the American Lung Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBOWITZ, JULIA
description: LIEBOWITZ--Julia. On July 7, 2005 at age 83, passed peacefully, surrounded by her loving family and friends. Adored wife, mother, sister and grandmother. We'll miss her always. Services are on Monday, July 11th at 12 noon, at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, Forest Hills, NY.

title: If It Were Raining Men, She Would Forgo the Umbrella
description: MY friend Melanie Rosenthal, a smoldering brunette in a short black dress, looked troubled as we drank tequila shots one Friday night at the club PM in the meatpacking district. "Is it just me, or does everyone wonder why I'm still single?" she asked.

title: Target: Ground Transportation
description: Terrorist attacks on buses, railroads, subways and bridges increased during seven decades studied by the Mineta Transportation Institute at San Jose State University. It compiled lists of attacks starting in the 1920's; the most detailed reports focused on the period from the 1970's through mid-1997, which charted here. This tally includes both successful attacks and those that were set in motion but ultimately thwarted by authorities.

title: EL CAPITAN, JUNE 25, 2005
description: Dr. Ham Tan, a general practitioner from the Netherlands, with his wife and two daughters. "We didn't want to sit down in a hotel lobby. We wanted to sit outside in nature. That's why we decided to go camping, and an RV is a great way to do that. When you drive down a long stretch of road with nobody else on it, you think, 'Wow, this is really a large country.' When we were looking at El Capitan, there was a climber going up the rock face. The awesome forces of nature and, in my opinion, the Lord, who made this exist -- the climber, he tries to match his own forces to those of the rock. Our family tried to do the same by walking around it, but, well, we got driven away by the mosquitoes."

title: The Boys of Summer, 30 Years Later
description: ALOT has already been written -- and, if current trends continue, a lot more will be written -- about the movie box office slump: whether it exists, what it means, how it might be reversed. I will spare you any further speculation on these questions, except to note that if the faulty climate control at the Manhattan theater where I finally caught up with "Batman Begins" a week ago is any indication, then the receipts may be down for the simple reason that summer movies are no longer living up to their one great and consistent promise, two hours of air conditioning.

title: A Glory Hole Of American Glassmaking
description: In 1904 Carl Sandburg proclaimed: "Down in southern New Jersey they make glass. By day and by night, the fires burn on in Millville." On Friday, leading glass artists, collectors, curators and dealers arrive for GlassWeekend, a three-day symposium and exhibition at Wheaton Village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERG, RABBI PAUL M.
description: STEINBERG--Rabbi Paul M. The President, Board of Governors, administration, faculty and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion deeply mourn the death of our beloved colleague, Dr. Paul M. Steinberg. For 50 years, the name of Paul M. Steinberg has been synonymous with the College-Institute. His love, devotion and influence on the College have extended to each of our four campuses, Cincinnati, New York, Los Angeles and Jerusalem. He loved Judaism and the Jewish people. And in turn, people loved him -- the twinkle in his eyes, the laughter in his heart and the pleasure taken in a loyal friendship. Funeral services will take place on Monday, July 11, at Hebrew Union College, 1 West 4th Street, at 11 am. Contributions may be made to the Paul M. Steinberg Memorial Fund of HUC-JIR. May his dear wife, Trudy, and their children, Lonnie, Alan, their grandchildren, Lindsey, Michael, Alex, Haley, Joshua, Arielle and Natalie, be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

Ken Goldstein, the Corcoran Group (718)832-4185; www.corcoran.com TAXES: $1,880 a year PROS: The adjacent side lot, not legally large enough for a separate structure, could be used to expand the existing house significantly.
