title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORSE, MILDRED HOCKSTADER ''TINY''
description: MORSE--Mildred Hockstader "Tiny". Of New York, Washington D.C., and Geneva, Switzerland. Died July 8, at her home in Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late David Abner Morse, Mrs. Morse was born in New York City in 1911. The daughter of Aline Straus Hockstader and Leonard Albert Hockstader, she was predeceased by a sister, Carol Eggleston, and a brother, Albert F. Hockstader. Her survivors include a nephew, Alan F. Hockstader of White Plains, three great nieces, one great nephew, and a host of godchildren and friends around the world. A graduate of The Spence School and Rosemary Hall, Mrs. Morse was a supporter of The Council on Foreign Relations where she established a lecture series in the name of her late husband; The Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute; The African American Institute; The New York Society for International Affairs, Inc., and Rutgers University where, in 1979, she and her late husband established the first major art acquistion fund at The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum. During David Morse's twenty year tenure as Director General of the International Labor Organization (ILO) in Geneva, the couple accumulated a substantial collection of late 19th and early 20th century French Graphics and paintings which are now among the Zimmerli's holdings. In 1983, the Morse Print and Drawing Room opened at the Zimmerli. In 1995, an expanded version of that space became the major research facility for the museum. After her husband's death, Mrs. Morse also established a series of scholarships in his name at Rutgers University. Everyone who loved Mildred thanks Maria Martin, Rita Purdessy, Jennifer Simpson, Dierdre Mole and Dr. Veronica LoFaso, for their loving care, as well as all the staff at the Beekman who contributed to her well-being and comfort. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the charity of your choice, The Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 East Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown, New York 11787, or The Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, 1484 First Avenue, New York 10021. A memorial service will be held in the Beth El chapel at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, on Wednesday, October 19 at 11 A.M.

title: Jack Conquers Oldies On New York Radio
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMITH, RITA
description: SMITH--Rita, 89, died peacefully at the Allerton House Assisted Living Facility, Duxbury, Mass., on Tuesday, July 5. A longtime resident of Forest Hills, NY, she moved there in January to be near her daughter and son-in-law, Barbara and Morgan Lamarche. Also survived by grandson, Gregory La marche, and his wife, Mikaela, of NYC; sister, Alyse Dettmers of Chevy Chase, MD, and sister-in-law, Pat Schoenfeld of Durham, NC. Contributions in her memory may be made to Cranberry Hospice, 36 Cordage Park Circle, Plymouth, MA 02360. A woman of great worldliness, charm and spirit, we will all miss her very much.

title: Chertoff Says U.S. Transit Is Safe, but Not Perfect
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 - American trains, subways and buses are safer now than before the London or Madrid bombing attacks, top homeland security officials said today. But they added that full protection was impossible and that the best security came from finding terrorists early and engaging them, as in Iraq.

title: 'The Rescue Artist': Taking Pictures
description: THE RESCUE ARTIST A True Story of Art, Thieves, and the Hunt for a Missing Masterpiece. By Edward Dolnick. Illustrated. 270 pp. HarperCollins Publishers. $25.95.

title: Galway
description: WHY GO NOW -- Ireland, like New York City, is not a place where people go for the weather. But to experience the sun breaking out over Galway Bay, and the headlands of nearby Connemara, the time to travel to Ireland's West Country is July and August.

title: Roar Britannia, Weep Britannia: July 3-9
description: CRICKET, ANYONE?

title: Keeping the Faith
description: Lindenhurst - MOST grade-school children are ecstatic when they fly out the doors on the last day of school. But that wasn't the case last month for more than 500 children at St. Bernard in Levittown, the School of the Holy Spirit in New Hyde Park and St. Joachim in Cedarhurst. These schools join the 22 Catholic schools in Brooklyn, Manhattan and Queens that are being closed for good.

title: Q&A | Emerging Issues; Facing Terror After London
description: Is there evidence that the war in Iraq has aggravated the threat of terror attacks in Europe and America?

title: Corrections
description: The "What I'm Wearing Now" feature on the Pulse page last Sunday, about Olivia Chantecaille, founder of a cosmetics company, misspelled the surname of a clothing designer she listed among her favorites. He is Lars Nilsson, not Nillson.

title: An Italian Place That's Organic (and Cozy)
description: AT Basta Trattoria recently, a young woman sat cross-legged on the banquette that runs along most of one side of the restaurant. She was eating lunch alone, as was I.

title: 'Lion of Hollywood': Mogul of Make-Believe
description: LION OF HOLLYWOOD The Life and Legend of Louis B. Mayer. By Scott Eyman. Illustrated. 596 pp. Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: Movies
description: FAHRENHEIT 9/11 (2004) Sunday at 8 p.m. and Friday at 8 p.m. on Showtime. Monday at 8 p.m. on Showtime 2. It won the Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival. It made a ton of money. But in the end, Michael Moore's mischievous, powerfully anti-Bush film will have to be remembered as the documentary that didn't bring down a president. Even with Condoleezza Rice, then the national security adviser, testifying about a pre-Sept. 11 report, "I believe the title was 'Bin Laden Determined to Attack Inside the United States."' Maybe the "Bonanza" parody is a little over the top, but when Mr. Moore (above right, with Representative John Tanner, a Tennessee Democrat) urges members of Congress to send their own children to fight in Iraq, he quietly hits his target. He also gives the other side its say, in a way. "I think we should just trust our president in every decision that he makes," announces a gum-chewing Britney Spears.

title: Cheek by Jowl
description: IVAN LOPEZ, an unemployed forklift operator who has lived most of his life in Chelsea, was chatting about his recent lunch with Harrison Ford, a newcomer to the neighborhood. "I met him at La Taza de Oro," Mr. Lopez said, referring to a small rice-and-beans shop on Eighth Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAYCOFF, AARON (BOB), M.D.
description: KAYCOFF -- Aaron (Bob), M.D., 90, of Palm Beach Gardens, FL., retired urologist, passed away July 2. Beloved husband of Leila Kroll, father of Virginia Kaycoff, Kathryn (Mark) Manos, grandfather of Jacob, Lukas and Stephen Manos. Donations may be made to Weizmann Institute of Science, 2300 Glades Rd, Boca Raton, FL 33431 or Hospice of Palm Beach County.

title: Marines and Iraqi Troops Start Push Against Rebels
description: FALLUJA, Iraq, July 9 - American marines began an offensive sweep on Saturday through fertile farmland south of Falluja in an attempt to disrupt suspected insurgent cells in the area. The offensive comes as insurgent attacks appear to be on the rise again in the city, once a stronghold for the guerrillas.

title: 'Crossworld': Le ___ Juste
description: Correction Appended

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 10 -- July 16; THEATER
description: Quick quiz: name a living French playwright besides Yazmina Reza. Unless you remember the name of the guy who wrote "The Controversy of Valladolid" at the Public last season (it's Jean-Claude Carrire, by the way), most of you are probably stumped. Outside of Ms. Reza, who has had success in the commercial theater with dramas like "Art," French playwrights are not produced often in this country. That's part of the reason the French government is sponsoring the ACT FRENCH festival, which begins on Friday and runs through December. Featuring a diverse lineup of French artists and plays (some of which are in French), the festival will be all over the city, everywhere from the BROOKLYN ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- "4.48 Psychose" starring Isabelle Huppert -- to the KITCHEN -- "Big: Episode No.2 (Show Business)".

title: Kasabian: Good Trip, Innit?
description: SAN FRANCISCO - FIVE shaggy British guys who make up the band Kasabian ambled out of the Hotel Triton here a few weeks ago and clambered into a van. In the middle of a grueling months-long world tour for their self-titled debut album, they finally had a bit of downtime and decided -- of all possible things -- to spend it visiting Alcatraz.

title: Q&A | Emerging Issues; Facing Terror After London
description: Have American officials adopted a new style for the danger warnings they issue when attacks like this happen overseas?

title: South Korea Welcomes Return to Disarmament Talks
description: SEOUL, July 10 - South Korea and other countries in the region said today that they welcomed North Korea's agreement to return to disarmament talks, a move that breaks a 13-month deadlock and restarts negotiations that are as difficult to predict as the North's ambiguous strategies.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the United States Supreme Court decision on eminent domain omitted a word, reversing the meaning, in describing the court's role in the fight by Frank Bugryn Jr. against condemnation of his property in Bristol. The sentence should have read: "When he lost, the United States Supreme Court would NOT hear the case."

title: Up Front
description: "I am a New York provincial," James Traub says. "I have rooted for the Yankees since age 5. I have lived in New York, and only New York, my entire adult life." Traub has been writing about the city for a quarter-century now -- covering everything from politics, race and education to sports, food and Donald Trump. His 1994 book, "City on a Hill," recounted the shifting fortunes of the City College of New York in the era of open admissions. "The Devil's Playground," published last year, recorded Traub's ambivalence about the transformation of seedy Times Square into a sanitized tourist attraction. "Above all," Traub says, "I've made a mini-industry of Rudy Giuliani." He has written three cover stories about the mayor for The New York Times magazine, and the heroes of his first book, "Too Good to Be True" (1990), about the $300 million Wedtech scandal, were the lawyers in the office of United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani. "We miss Rudy," Traub writes in this week's cover review, though he admits he may be thinking primarily of journalists like himself, "who found in this abrasive and difficult man a bottomless source of material." Traub is now doing research on the United Nations under Kofi Annan. Thus, even as he broadens his canvas, he is taking on one more New York institution. The Editors

title: Where Will He Sit? Where Does He Stand?
description: Seems you can't please all of the ideologues all of the time.

title: It's July 2005. Do You Know Where Your Pension Is?
description: In all the discussion about Social Security, there is much doomsday talk about the flood of plaid-pants-wearing baby boomers on the verge of inundating the nation's retirement havens.

description: Cannes on the East End

title: Jennifer Andrews and Adam Burke
description: Jennifer Lynn Andrews, a daughter of Dr. Joseph L. Andrews of Concord, Mass., and the late Margareta L. Andrews, was married yesterday to Adam Terry Burke, a son of Daphne E. Burke of Stonington, Me., and the late Dr. Fred G. Burke, who lived in Milford, Pa. Rabbi Albert Sturmer officiated on Idlewild Island, in the Thousand Islands on the St. Lawrence River in New York.

title: 2006 Mercedes-Benz ML350 and ML500: More Class, at Last, for the M-Class
description: PROGRESS is great, except when you are the one it leaves behind, a predicament that stings all the more when you are a company, like Mercedes-Benz, with a reputation for innovation.

title: A Retail Revolution Turns 10
description: THE image in Mark R. Anderson's head was that of an airplane struggling to gain altitude. Mr. Anderson, one of the technology world's more highly regarded pundits, watched a speck of a company called Amazon.com grow from a three-person start-up in a converted garage into a publicly traded corporation that came to symbolize both the best and the worst of the dot-com era.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Has anybody else had to watch their husband die on television over and over? I know that it's public and I know that it's national, but it's so private for me."

title: A Place for Commodities in Mainstream Portfolios
description: THE commodities market has long evoked images of the Wild West -- a world dominated by gamblers and speculators, where few ordinary folks dare to tread.

title: BICYCLING IN GIRONA
description: To the Editor: Girona is of interest not only because of its medieval past or its present-day cyclists.

description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FONTANA, VINCENT J., M.D.
description: FONTANA--Vincent J., M.D. The Board of Trustees and Staff of The New York Foundling and the Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection mourn the sudden passing of our esteemed and beloved Medical Director and Pediatrician-in-Chief, Dr. Vincent J. Fontana. During his 43 year career at The Foundling, Dr. Fontana fought tirelessly for the rights and protection of mistreated children. Following his groundbreaking article, "The Maltreatment Syndrome in Children," first published in The New England Journal of Medicine, Dr. Fontana authored over 150 scientific publications and texts, including, "Save the Family, Save the Child" and "Somewhere a Child is Crying," texts which have had a profound influence on the field of child abuse prevention. The Crisis Nursery/Family Center that Dr. Fontana established at The Foundling in 1972 continues as a national model as an "island of safety for at risk families." With the opening of the Fontana Center on Christopher Street in November 2004, we are ensured that his legacy of building public awareness, advancing research, and training professionals in the field of child abuse prevention will endure. We extend our deepest sympathies to his brother and sister and large extended family. Funeral Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral Monday, July 11 at 10:30am. Visitation Friday July 8 and Saturday July 9, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at O.B. Davis Inc. Funeral Homes, Port Jefferson Station NY(1-800-464-0360). Dr. Fontana's family has requested that in lieu of flowers, gifts be sent to the Vincent J. Fontana Center for Child Protection c/o the New York Foundling, 590 Avenue of the Americas, NY 10011. William F. Baccaglini, Jr. Executive Director Kenneth R. Horner Chairman Sr. Carol A. Barnes Former Chairperson

title: Cunningham's Mystical, Teeming Circle
description: FOR the opening of the Lincoln Center Festival this week, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company revives "Ocean," the epic and intricate 90-minute work that had its New York premiere at the first of the festivals, in 1996. Then, it packed Damrosch Park, playing in an outdoor arena open to the sky. This time around, a special stage floor is being built for the Rose Theater at Frederick P. Rose Hall, which will be reconfigured in the round.

title: If You Can Sort It, She Can Sort It Better
description: PEEKSKILL - THE huge stack of spiral notebooks has to be divvied up. Beverly Parsons instructs her assistant, Ghaneisha Ford, and offers a couple of suggestions.

description: To the Editor:

title: Park Place
description: Once again, a provocative piece of new architecture is spending the summer next to the Serpentine Gallery, a 1934 neo-Classical building in Kensington Gardens in London. For the past six years, the gallery has commissioned a summer pavilion. The latest is from two highly regarded Portuguese architects: lvaro Siza, who won the Pritzker Architecture Prize in 1992, and Eduardo Souto de Moura, who is best known for a soaring stadium completed in 2003 in Braga, Portugal. The two men collaborated with the renowned structural engineer Cecil Balmond of the London-based firm Arup.

title: No Longer Unbuttoned?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fathers and Sons, At War and at Peace
description: TOM MATHEWS, an author in Sag Harbor, doesn't seem like a whiner. A big rumpled man, he looks comfortable in his own skin and in his cozy "book house" in his backyard, as he and his wife, Lucille, call the 18th-century cottage where he does his writing.

title: Elizabeth Fauvre and William Gerard
description: Elizabeth Stockton Fauvre, a daughter of Joan Higgins Fauvre and John C. Fauvre of Pasadena, Calif., was married yesterday to William Alexander Gerard, a son of Elizabeth Gallatin Ehrenkranz and Robert A. Gerard, both of New York. The Rev. Zelda Kennedy officiated at All Saints Episcopal Church in Pasadena.

title: You Can Call It a Fairness Opinion, but That Wouldn't Be Fair
description: FAIRNESS opinions may be fairer than many of their critics think.

title: No Fanfare as Luxembourg Plans to Vote on European Constitution
description: LUXEMBOURG, July 7 - There was little outward sign this week, in the historic old capital of this tiny country, that the fate of Europe might hinge on what people here decide on Sunday.

title: Feeling London's Bombs in Madrid
description: IN Madrid, where I live, I know more than a few young women who, ever since the March 11 bombings, are petrified of boarding a train. I am sorry to say that they will now probably feel the same way about traveling across town on the bus or subway -- the way the victims of the attacks in London traveled through and to King's Cross, Edgware Road, Aldgate, Russell Square.

title: Corey Feldman's Fourth Act
description: ON a humid June day, the latest attempt to revive Corey Feldman's career is in full swing in a damp studio on the West Side of Manhattan, where the tongue-in-cheek satire "Fatal Attraction: A Greek Tragedy" is in rehearsals. The problem, though, is that at this particular moment, Mr. Feldman is nowhere to be found.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 19 about the value derived by a city that plays host to the MTV series "The Real World" misspelled the surname of an owner of the Palms Casino Resort in Las Vegas, where the cast of the show's 12th season lived. He is George Maloof, not Malouf.

title: The Week Ahead: July 10 - July 16
Optic Nerve
description: Amy Sacks Eyewear For years now, gurus who focus on the implications of changing demographics have been making the screamingly obvious point that baby boomers are graying their way toward retirement and that they are likely to redefine the concept of old age when they get there. (For one thing, they are unlikely to accept being referred to as "old.") Despite this, the consumer marketplace remains largely focused on 18- to 34-year-olds, failing to understand the nature of the new un-young. Or so it seemed to Ann Sacks, who is 56, when she realized some years ago that she needed to start wearing reading glasses.

title: Dina Lucas and Daniel Relles
description: Dina Rachelle Lucas, a daughter of Edy Haber Lucas and Rabbi Alan B. Lucas of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., is to be married today to Daniel Max Relles, a son of Mary B. Relles and Dr. Nathan Relles of Maple Glen, Pa. The bride's father is to officiate at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn Heights, where he is the senior rabbi.

title: Questions Remain About Those Killed in London Bombings
description: LONDON, July 10 - On a day that blended prayer and pageant, jitters and defiance, today was a day of bewildering contrasts across the British capital in the aftermath of the terrorist bombings Thursday that killed at least 49 people.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIRO, LAURENCE H., M.D.
description: SPIRO--Laurence H., M.D., 62, and Heather J., 55, of Rock Hill, NY. Suddenly on June 25, 2005. Loving parents of Victoria Mesh and son-in-law Eugene Mesh. Beloved son of Gertrude Eichschlag and the late Jerome Spiro. Beloved daughter of Bernice and David Fashler. Loving brother of Richard Spiro (Alison) and Ellen Freeman. Loving sister of Robert Fashler (Anita). Also survived by nieces and nephews, and many wonderful friends. A memorial service will be held later this month in Rock Hill, NY.

title: Correction
description: A chart last Sunday recalling battles over nominees to the Supreme Court misstated the American Bar Association's stance on the selection of Louis D. Brandeis in 1916. The organization took no position; it did not oppose him, although the president of the association, Elihu Root, did.

title: Go to the Mattresses (No, It's Not a Mob War)
description: BUTLER - AT least once a month, James Callari, 36, grabs some cans of Red Bull, packs up his computer and tells his girlfriend he is going out to play some video games. Don't bother waiting up, he'll say -- he won't be back for two or three days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITTLE, WILLIAM SPENCER
description: LITTLE--William Spencer, 93, on July 6, 2005. Bill was the husband of the late Verbena May Little and the father of Wm. Brian and Christopher, both deceased. He had a 47 year career with Becton Dickinson and Co. After living for 40 years in Ridgewood, NJ and Essex, CT he moved to Santa Barbara, CA and resided at Casa Dorinda. He is survived by his daughter-in-law, Judith Little; two grandchildren, Jackie and Greg; and five great-grandchildren. There will be a private memorial service for family only.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 10, 2005
description: Weeks

title: The Way We Eat: Kings of Convenience
description: In Nina Katchadourian's world, the Jolly Green Giant is married to the Indian maiden on Land O' Lakes butter and Little Debbie is sister to the Charmin baby. Mr. Clean and the Brawny Man are now partners and have adopted the Gerber Baby. Katchadourian recently offered these revelations in "The Genealogy of the Supermarket," her 30-foot-wide wall installation displaying an imaginative family tree of American grocery-store icons at the Sara Meltzer Gallery in Chelsea.

title: Popspeak
description: We have all heard, and at times we all speak in, pop phrases: Hel-lo? I don't think so. Duh. Step up to the plate. Think outside the box. Give back to the community. LOL. You da man! Pop phrases are not just popular phrases or current clichs -- they shine with an extra glamour. They are words that pop out of their surround, that have built-in applause signs and that, if inflected properly, step into the spotlight as verbal celebrities, the stars of our sentences. And like, say, Britney Spears or Wayne Newton, a You go, girl! or a What part of "no" don't you understand? is not necessarily the latest or hippest thing around. A phrase might be so last millennium, but familiarity only expands its fan base.

title: 'The Prince of the City': Cut Out for the Job
description: THE PRINCE OF THE CITY Giuliani, New York and the Genius of American Life. By Fred Siegel with Harry Siegel. 386 pp. Encounter Books. $26.95.

title: A 'Terrestrial' Station, Unafraid of the Satellite
description: THE PEAK, a new station broadcasting around the county out of North White Plains, is not cowed by the might of satellite radio. Or at least its programmers talk a good game: They say they're banking on the belief that "terrestrial" radio still has the power to be unpredictable and exciting.

title: Options Grow for Players After High School
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., July 8 - Virtually everywhere O.J. Mayo went at the ABCD Camp this week, all eyes followed.

title: In One Arizona Community, an Oasis in a Toxic World
description: Snowflake, Ariz. - IN this town 150 miles northeast of Phoenix, "for sale" signs have become as commonplace as sagebrush. "Real estate has gone crazy around here," said Bruce Wachter, an agent with the local Century 21 franchise.

title: HARD TO GET
description: When he signed up as the chief executive of TiVo, Thomas S. Rogers, the former president of NBC Cable, did not agree to go to Silicon Valley cheaply, or even full time.

title: COUNCIL'S ROLE DIMINISHED
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey restructured the state's Public Health Council, leaving the 58-year-old independent agency virtually powerless. The council, whose eight members are volunteers, has been responsible for creating regulations for vaccines, food safety and public health policies. Under the restructuring, the council will serve in an advisory role to the state Department of Health and Senior Services. Dr. Robert M. Pallay, chairman of the council, said that some of the work the council has done has been contentious, "but that comes with the territory." He said the governor was doing a disservice to residents by stripping the council of all of its power. Kelley Heck, a spokeswoman for the governor said the restructuring was justified. "It's not about one issue," she said. "The council is not really part of the administration, and the governor and the health commissioner should really have control of the state's health policies." John Holl

title: The Enigma of Damascus
description: The opera house in Damascus was a long time coming. Hafez al-Assad, the iron-willed military man who ruled Syria for three decades, was in power just a few years when he laid the cornerstone. But lack of materials and equipment, hard economic times and a devastating fire delayed the project year after year. It fell to Assad's son and successor, Bashar, to finish the job. He opened Al Assad opera house with his wife, Asma, last year. Decorated with paintings and sculptures by Syrian artists, offering up classical concerts and works by Arab playwrights, the building expresses something of the elder Assad's vision of Damascus as the Arab capital of cultural, if not political, enlightenment. The name of his controlling party, Baath, means resurrection, and nothing could better reflect an Arab renaissance than achievement in the arts.

title: A Press to Find Teachers As Diverse as Students
description: EFFORTS to promote diversity at the Hackley School in Tarrytown are bearing fruit. This fall, three minorities will join the teaching staff: a Hispanic woman, an alumna, will be teaching fourth grade; an African-American woman will become a first-grade teaching assistant; and an Indian woman will be teaching English to freshmen and sophomores. In recent years, said Walter Johnson, headmaster at Hackley, the proportion of nonwhite students has risen to about 22 percent of the student body, but only 11 percent to 12 percent of the faculty were from minority groups.

title: Sing Along With Roald
description: There are many ways in which Tim Burton's "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (opening Friday) hews more closely than its predecessor, the 1971 "Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory," to the Roald Dahl book on which both are based. In one case, the new film went directly to the source: of its five songs, four feature lyrics Dahl wrote for his 1964 children's classic (also called "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory"). Danny Elfman, who wrote the score, said he "wouldn't have dreamt" of writing his own words: "Dahl already had such great, rhythmic lyrics," he said. "They were just waiting to be put to some form of melody."

title: Who Let the Goats Out? The Barn Is Jumpin'
description: RICKIE SIMPKINS, a fiddler who has played many prestigious halls, looked amused as he sat outside David and Annie Bingham's Salem barn on a Friday afternoon last month. His long dyed-blond hair was as conspicuous as his Chevy Silverado, which was parked in the Binghams' yard.

title: First World Cup Could Feature American Arms Against Dominican Bats
description: Baseball's first world cup will probably be decided by a matchup between one of the most fearsome lineups ever assembled and one of the finest pitching staffs.

title: Places That Tell America's Diverse Story
description: THE family summer car trip is as much of an American institution as any of the places that families get into the car to visit. Let's learn about our country together! The Travel Industry Association of America is predicting that this summer Americans will take 328 million trips by Labor Day, and that more than 80 percent of them will be by car.

title: Paperback Row
description: FOUR SOULS, by Louise Erdrich. (HarperPerennial, $13.95.) Erdrich's novel continues the Ojibwa tale she began in "Tracks" (1988). The narrative unfolds through parallel stories that are alternately comical and haunting. In one, Nanapush, an elderly Ojibwa, seethes over the man who married his sister and, he believes, killed and ate her. The other story follows Nanapush's adopted daughter, Fleur Pillager, as she plots revenge against the timber baron who bought what once was her land. The book "finishes in gorgeous incantation and poetry," Karen Joy Fowler wrote in the Book Review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAFREN, HERBERT CECIL
description: ZAFREN -- Herbert Cecil. 1925--2005. The Zafren family has been devastated by the loss of their very dearly beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend, Herbert C. Zafren, on June 30, 2005 in Cincinnati, Ohio. Born in Baltimore, he graduated from Baltimore Hebrew College and Johns Hopkins University. He was Director of Libraries Emeritus at the Hebrew Union College. He is survived by his wife of 54 years, Miriam, a son, Ken, a daughter, Edie Lowe, and a granddaughter, Rachel Zafren. He donated his body to the University of Cincinnati School of Medicine. A celebration of his life will be scheduled in the near future. If desired, donations may be made to the Hebrew Union College Library or to the American Parkinson Disease Association.

title: Froky Doesn't Play Around Here Anymore
description: I WAS playing with my friend's toddler recently, taunting him with an animal voice: "Grrrr, get over here. I'm a hungry tiger, and you're one tiny mouse!"

title: Turning the Grocery Isle Into Nitches
description: CATHY FINELLI inspected the rows of hand-packed olives available at North Shore Market Place in Port Washington.

title: NATIONAL PARK BOOKING
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the experience of Dr. Ah Yin Eng in "On Some Lodging Sites, It's Booker Beware" (Practical Traveler, June 12). My wife and I have been traveling to national parks for the last 35 years. Thanks to the AAA guide, I have always booked directly with the national park concessionaire. I cannot recall a bad experience. The personnel are always courteous.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 26 about politically conservative filmmakers misidentified the director of the documentary "Celsius 41.11," which was made as a rebuttal to Michael Moore's "Fahrenheit 9/11." He was Kevin Knoblock; Lionel Chetwynd was a writer and producer of the film.

title: Nicole Leiser and Daniel Greninger
description: Nicole Michelle Leiser, a daughter of Jane and H. Wayne Leiser of Englewood, Colo., is to be married today to Daniel Adam Greninger, a son of Francine and Roger Greninger of San Ramon, Calif. Rabbi Edward S. Boraz is to officiate at the Aspen Lodge in Estes Park, Colo.

title: The Vatican Removes 6 Priests in New York Accused or Convicted of Sexual Abuse
description: The Vatican has expelled six New York priests either accused or convicted of sexual abuse, including one man who was convicted of sodomizing a teenager in an upstate church rectory.

title: When Buying on Impulse Pays Off
description: THE decision to buy a pied--terre on the Upper West Side was an impulsive one, said Susan Serra, a kitchen designer and native Long Islander. "I didn't even talk to my husband much about it because it was just so not going to happen," she said.

title: Short Lists of Stocks Can Reap Tall Profits
description: MANY stock mutual funds made money in the second quarter, with general domestic stock funds rising 2.4 percent, on average, according to Morningstar Inc.

title: The 60-Day Course in Perfect Fake Piano Playing
description: Correction Appended

title: Ireland's Garbage Secrets Come Glaringly to Light
description: BRAY, Ireland - The earthen cliffs near this seaside harbor town have been sporting colorful decorations recently: erosion by the gentle waves of the Irish Sea has exposed the scraggly remnants of hundreds of blue, black and yellow trash bags. The shredding plastic flutters in the wind alongside jutting scraps of rusted metal; the twisted wrecks of unidentifiable junked machines already lie on the rocky beach below.

title: How to Choose a Fund (No Experience Necessary)
description: THREE years ago, like a good little squirrel, I gathered up all my nuts and finally opened a retirement account. As a freelance journalist, I didn't have access to a company 401(k), so I opened an I.R.A. -- and immediately began stressing about the fact that I had no idea how to invest it.

title: Tour de France: Armstrong looks for quick improvement on 9th stage
Lenient With Rogers
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Corrections
Adoption Case Haunts Participants
description: Adoption Case Haunts Participants

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 10 -- July 16; FILM
description: "THE EDUKATORS," a German-language film, is a reminder that you don't have to constantly blow things up to provoke the audience's attention. This film is about three radicals -- two young men, one young woman, you do the relationship math -- who break into wealthy homes and rearrange the furniture, leaving a disquieting message behind: "You have too much money." When one break-in goes awry, they kidnap a businessman who turns out to have been a radical himself 30 years before. The young "edukators" are reminded that the debate over capitalist privilege isn't new, while the onetime radical faces the betrayal of his former ideals. A generational debate ensues, and age-old dilemmas result. The film opens in New York on July 22, and in Los Angeles on July 29.

title: Shinnecock Golf Club Drops Its Indian Logo
description: Just weeks after the Shinnecock tribe filed a federal lawsuit laying claim to 3,600 acres in the Town of Southampton, including Shinnecock Hills Golf Club, the club has deleted from its logo the symbol of its longstanding relationship with the tribe.

title: Bicycling in Girona; Europe's Great Parks
description: BICYCLING IN GIRONA

title: STATE PASSES UP GRANTS; FIGHTS FOR BASE
description: State officials said last week that they would continue to fight the Pentagon over the proposed closing of Fort Monmouth, and did not file for federal grants that could help retrain civilian workers who would lose their jobs when the base closes. New Jersey was one of 15 states that did not apply for the grants, according to the Department of Labor. Kelley Heck, a spokeswoman for Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, said the state did not want to take the money because "we are committed to keeping the base, we will continue to fight to keep it open and want the federal government to realize they made a mistake." The Pentagon announced in May that it would be closing more than 100 bases, including Fort Monmouth, a communications technology base. If Fort Monmouth closes, the state stands to lose nearly 3,700 civilian jobs. BRIEFING: JOBS

title: This Crusader Tilts at PCB's
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS - DR. DANIEL LEFKOWITZ seems to have a knack for spotting potential environmental dangers and a willingness to make noise about them. If not for him, PCB contamination might never have been discovered at his 7-year-old son's school, French Hill Elementary.

title: Jessica Rose and Timothy Streeto
description: Jessica Anne Rose, a lawyer, and Timothy Streeto, a film and television editor, were married on Friday evening at Tribeca Rooftop, an event space in Manhattan. The Rev. Deborah Roth, an interfaith minister, officiated.

title: A 1930's County Jail, With Art Deco Detailing
description: THE BRONX HOUSE OF DETENTION FOR MEN has been overshadowed by its much grander cousin, the Bronx County Courthouse, since they both opened in the 1930's. Although the courthouse has been meticulously cleaned and restored in recent years, its lesser relation is closed and empty. But the jail is still a prominent sight from the Major Deegan Expressway.

title: Walking for My Life
description: When you first tell people that you're going to walk across the country, a lot of them are like, "Wow, that takes courage just to say it." Others are like, "You'll never make it." I weigh 400 pounds, and I'm carrying an 85- pound backpack, and so far, I've gone more than 300 miles. If I was going to quit anywhere, it would be out here in the desert -- because this is not fun.

title: 'Lion of Hollywood'
Paid Notice: Deaths   WACHTER, BLAIR TOLMIE, MD.
description: WACHTER -- Blair Tolmie, MD. Formerly of Sea Cliff and Cold Spring Harbor, NY, died in Salt Lake City, UT, Sunday, June 12, 2005. Born in Victoria, BC, Canada, 1935. Earned medical doctorate from University of British Columbia. Began career at Meadowbrook Hospital (Nassau County Medical Center), 30 year practice and President of Medical Staff at Brunswick Hospital in Amityville, NY. Survived by wife of 45 years, Ann-Mari, daughter, Nanette, son, Tolmie, and three grandchildren. A private service was held at the Wachter home in Holladay, UT.

title: Reena Agarwal and Matthew Shaines
description: Dr. Reena Agarwal, a daughter of Dr. Nalini Bade Agarwal and Dr. Jai Bhagwan Agarwal of Somerset, N.J., is to be married there today to Dr. Matthew David Shaines, the son of Maxine and Victor Shaines of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Dennis C. Tobin is to officiate at the Palace at Somerset Park, an event space, with Pandit Chaitanya B. Agnihotri, a Hindu priest, taking part.

title: His Way Meets a Highway Called Court
description: LOS ANGELES - THERE is no question that Dov Charney is an unconventional chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEWARD, ROSE MARY (NEE LEO)
description: STEWARD--Rose Mary (nee Leo). Born November 16, 1921, in Corona, NY, passed June 6, 2005, in Jamaica, NY. The widow of Charles J. She is survived by her children Janet and Michael, her stepson Harris, and her devoted brother John. Singing was her joy and passion.

title: Mercedes Quality: Back on Track?
description: COMPLAINTS about the quality and reliability of Mercedes-Benz products have dulled the company's once-sparkling image, but the automaker seems to be regaining some luster in closely watched surveys.

title: Who Bears the Risks of Terror?
description: WASHINGTON - IF nothing else, the synchronized bombings and bloodshed in London on Thursday will stifle any creeping complacency about the risks of terrorist attacks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Of Boca Raton, FL and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. Born NYC in 1912 to a family of modest circumstances. In his early 20's he played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." He appeared as an extra in Hollywood movies of the 1930's and became a member of the Friars Club. Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. He served on the board of the Nassau County Adult Rehabilitation Program. Into his early 90's, Irving was an avid golfer. He played in a number of Pro-Am tournaments and shot two holes-in-one. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud self-made man. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation in Irving's name to a charity of your choice. Funeral Sunday, July 10, 1 PM at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills NY (718263-7600). Interment at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: DataBank; Stocks Rise Despite Terrorist Attacks in London
description: The stock market shrugged off the terrorist attacks in Britain and posted solid gains for the week on optimism about the state of the economy.

title: An Ex-Champ Is a Restless Contender
description: FIDELITY is struggling to fix the business that made it famous.

title: U.S. Can't Confirm Taliban Claim They Beheaded Commando
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 9 - The Taliban said Saturday that they had beheaded a Navy Seal commando whom it had claimed to be holding for several days. The United States military said it could not confirm the claim and said the search continued for the missing commando.

title: Mets Still Look Tattered Despite New Threads
description: PITTSBURGH, July 9 - Mets outfielder Cliff Floyd will always remember this weekend at PNC Park for saliva and sunflower seeds.

title: Little Boxes
description: LIKE many New Yorkers, I groaned when the Kmart went up in Astor Place in 1996. Although I've been known to celebrate Target's underwear supply, and I bought my fax machine at Best Buy, I find nothing more overwhelming than browsing in a big-box store, with its booming pop music, jaundiced fluorescent lights and mind-numbingly endless aisles of products.

title: Onetime Enemies Join Forces to Lead Sudan on Rocky Road to Peace
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, July 9 - Sudan elevated a former rebel leader on Saturday to the vice presidency of the government he had long tried to overthrow, a merging of onetime combatants into a single leadership that took Sudan another step away from decades of war.

title: Casey Whalen and Robert Sellers
description: Casey Dow Whalen and Robert Foster Sellers were married yesterday by the Rev. Louise B. Higginbotham at the United Church on the Green in New Haven.

title: Scottish Midfielder Eyes Spot on MetroStars
description: Neil Barrett, a 24-year-old midfielder who played last season for Dundee in the Scottish Premier League, told Sky Sports that the MetroStars had offered him a two-year contract.

title: Children's Books: Bookshelf
description: WHILE MAMA HAD A QUICK LITTLE CHAT. By Amy Reichert. Illustrated by Alexandra Boiger. Richard Jackson/Atheneum. $15.95. (Ages 4 to 7) It's Rose's bedtime when Uncle Fred telephones and Mama says she needs to have a quick chat with him. Rose tries to tell her about the four men delivering furniture, the guests arriving for a party, the magician and the band. But by the time Mama is off the phone, Rose has fallen fast asleep.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WEINTRAUB, SAMUEL
description: WEINTRAUB--Samuel. Lovingly remembered each day. With love, Jane, Jerry, Linda, Doug, grandchildren and great-grandchildren

title: A Freedom Tower Restarted From Scratch
description: The redesign of the Freedom Tower at ground zero was announced publicly last month amid fanfare and festivity. But its presentation was the consequence of a devastating, and expensive, private decision made in the 18th-floor conference room of Silverstein Properties at 530 Madison Avenue on an afternoon in mid-April.

title: 'Canaan's Tongue': Manhunt
description: CANAAN'S TONGUE By John Wray. 341 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $25.

title: TRUMP RESORTS C.E.O. IS NAMED
description: Trump Entertainment Resorts, the company that emerged when the casino empire of Donald Trump came out of bankruptcy in May, has named James E. Perry chief executive officer. Mr. Perry, a director of the company, retired in 2003 as chief executive of Argosy Gaming Company, a riverboat casino operator. Mr. Trump had been C.E.O. and chairman of the company before it went into Chapter 11 bankruptcy in November 2004, and then reorganized. He said in May that he would stay on as chairman, but relinquish the duties as C.E.O. to spend more time on real estate and other activities. Trump Entertainment runs three Atlantic City casinos -- Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino, Trump Marina Hotel Casino and Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort -- and the Trump Casino Hotel, a riverboat casino in Gary, Ind. BRIEFING: BUSINESS

title: Easing the Trauma Of Rape Victims
description: HAMILTON - THE state has taken steps in recent months that it hopes will ease the emotional trauma of rape victims, and at the same time give the police a better chance of arresting and convicting rapists.

title: The Prince of the City
description: New York has a tradition of larger-than-life mayors who've become characters to conjure with in the national political imagination. Governing a center of money, media, and social movements gives Gotham's chief executives a disproportionate role in defining the country's assumptions about big cities.

title: Bracing for Hurricane Dennis
description: Across the U.S. Gulf Coast, residents evacuated or hunkered down as the storm approached.

title: Hurricane Dennis
description: The storm hit the Florida Panhandle and the Alabama coast with 120-mile-an-hour winds.

title: Children of Methamphetamine
description: Methamphetamine is sending children to strained agencies.

title: Hurricane Dennis
description: The storm headed for the Gulf Coast on Sunday.

title: First Vioxx Suit: Entryway Into a Legal Labyrinth?
description: In a small town in South Texas, a long legal journey will begin this week for Merck, the giant drug maker, and thousands of people who suffered heart attacks and strokes after taking its painkiller Vioxx.

title: Conquistadors, Swords and Those Skittish Zebras
description: Jared Diamond, the U.C.L.A. professor, blew many minds when he charted the entire history of man in just one book, the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies." His research had once been rather peaceful, the study of birds in New Guinea, until an indigenous tribesman encouraged him to study all things martial.

title: The Not-So-Simple Life of the Very Rich and Very Pretty
description: One problem with true-crime television movies is that they do not settle - rather they aggravate - questions about the crimes on which they're based. Take the murder of Ted Ammon, the multimillionaire who was found bludgeoned to death in East Hampton in October 2001. At the time, it was hard to tell why Mr. Ammon - by all accounts an exceedingly decent, if rich, man - ever became mixed up with his erratic wife, the former Generosa Rand. And as suspicion fell on Mrs. Ammon and her boyfriend, the electrician Danny Pelosi (who was convicted of the murder in 2004), it was hard to tell what she saw in Mr. Pelosi.

title: School Reform Moves to the Suburbs
description: Washington - DESPITE all the talk about improving inner-city schools, the greatest promise of the No Child Left Behind Act was always in America's leafy suburbs. Unfortunately, that promise is in danger of being squandered.

title: Media access a challenge in U.K. attacks
Many Rules Have Exceptions, A Senior Teams Match Shows
description: Correction Appended

title: Marriage and Family, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: She Sings of Her Longings, Especially When Dozing
description: KATONAH, N.Y. - While still asleep, Amina, the title character in Bellini's "Sonnambula," manages to get some exercise walking around town, take a tour of a local hotel, give voice to her deepest fears and longings, and sing some extremely rich music full of demanding ornamentation. Call it an efficient night's rest in our multitasking age.

title: No Corn Cob Bob on Canada Day's Guest List
description: Like most Canadians, Corn Cob Bob put his feet up on Canada Day, the national holiday on July 1. But the day off was unexpected for Bob, a mascot for a renewable fuel organization, and it came from an unexpected source: the Canadian division of the global oil company Royal Dutch/Shell Group.

title: Hurricane Dennis pounds Alabama-Florida coast
Blimpie Introduces a Talking Sandwich
description: Blimpie International, the sandwich restaurant chain, has hooked up with PepsiCo brands Pepsi and Frito-Lay to create a new promotional campaign, featuring the Nascar driver, Jeff Gordon, that debuts this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PSALTOS, DIMITRIOS MEGRIS (''JAMES'')
description: PSALTOS--Dimitrios Megris ("James"). On July 8, 2005. He was 73. A devout Christian; Korean War veteran; Vice President of Equity Sales for Shearson Lehman; graduate of Pace University and George Washington High School; archon; past president and life long member of St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church in Washington Heights, NYC. Beloved husband of A. Dorothea, nee Vlamis. Loving father of John, Nicholas, Christopher and Elizabeth. Loving father-in-law to Theodora, Leigh and Nira. Cherished grandfather of Dimitrios, Katherine, Henry and Gabriella. Loving brother-inlaw, uncle, cousin, nephew, godfather and friend to many. Reposing at St. Spyridon Greek Orthodox Church, 124 Wadsworth Avenue at 179th Street, NYC, Tuesday, 4-9 PM. Funeral Liturgy at the Church, Wednesday, 11 AM. Interment at Tappan Reformed Church Cemetery, Tappan, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations preferred to "St. Spyridon Restoration Fund," 124 Wadsworth Avenue, NY, NY 10033, 212795-5870, in memory of Dimitrios M. Psaltos.

title: A Drug Scourge Creates Its Own Form of Orphan
description: TULSA, Okla., July 8 - The Laura Dester Shelter here is licensed for 38 children, but at times in the past months it has housed 90, forcing siblings to double up in cots. It is supposed to be a 24-hour stopping point between troubled homes and foster care, but with foster homes backed up, children are staying weeks and sometimes months, making it more orphanage than shelter, a cacophony of need.

title: China's currency trade thriving without yuan
Visiting Tsunami Survivors, Rice Faces Annoyed Asian Leaders
description: BAN BANG SAK, Thailand, July 11 - Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice traveled here today to visit a tsunami-ravaged village, saying she wanted to show that the United States "cares about Southeast Asia."

title: Philip Bowring: The Philippines at an impasse
Taliban Kill 10 Afghan Police Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 10 - Ten Afghan border police officers were killed in a clash with Taliban fighters in the country's south, and all are believed to have been beheaded, government officials said Sunday.

title: With No Leads, British Consult Allies on Blasts
description: LONDON, July 10 - British intelligence officials, frustrated by their failure to quickly crack the worst terrorist attack here since World War II, have sought help from counterparts in the United States and two dozen European allies to develop possible leads, European counterterrorism officials said Sunday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Philharmonic Promotion
description: The New York Philharmonic announced the appointment on Friday of Xian Zhang as its associate conductor. Ms. Zhang, below, the orchestra's assistant conductor since last September, will serve a two-year term. Born in Dandong, China, and trained at the Central Conservatory of Music in Beijing, she is scheduled to conduct six of the seven Philharmonic Time Warner Concerts in the Parks, tomorrow through July 18. (Lorin Maazel, the orchestra's music director, who appointed Ms. Zhang, will lead the July 19 all-Dvorak program in Central Park.) The previous associate conductor was Roberto Minczuk, who served for two seasons beginning in fall 2002. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: Johnson and Yankees Will Their Way to Optimistic Finish to First Half
description: About an hour into his All-Star Game break, George Steinbrenner marched into a Yankee Stadium elevator yesterday with his shades on, his chin up and his chest out. At last, his team also seemed stout. Winners of seven out of eight games, the Yankees must look just as he expected.

title: It Takes Two (Tires) for Earnhardt
description: JOLIET, Ill., July 10 - Dale Earnhardt Jr. has not been having a great season, but things finally seem to be turning around for him. Earnhardt gambled late by changing only two tires, and it paid off. He won the USG Sheetrock 400 at Chicagoland Speedway on Sunday by 0.291 of a second over Matt Kenseth.

title: Ricky Williams Steps Carefully Toward Return
description: For a while, Ricky Williams was a character straight out of a Herman Melville short story, a modern-day Bartleby. He withdrew from the workaday world last July, telling his employer, the Miami Dolphins, that he preferred not to carry the football anymore.

title: On the Threshold
description: When it feels like time -- no matter what the clock says -- I walk the horses down to the night pen from the pasture where they've spent the day. Our habits mingle on that walk. I whistle when I open the gate. Their heads turn abruptly to the sound. I rattle the grain in the bucket, and, if they show any reluctance, Remedy the gelding begins to drive the other two horses toward me. Ida makes a feint toward the pigs in their enclosure, and they dart in circles round and round, barking and snuffling as they go. I lead the horses down the drive and into the corral, never looking back to see whether they follow or not. It's part of the contract. They trot the last few steps and settle over their sweet feed.

title: 20 wounded in bombing in Turkey
Talking terror, Too early to praise China
Briefly: Church declines to join calls for Arroyo's ouster
High-Tech Antiterror Tools: A Costly, Long-Range Goal
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 - With the mass transit systems in Britain and the United States on high alert, the best available defense the governments can provide against a terrorist armed with a bomb is decidedly low-tech: vigilance with dogs, video cameras and security officers.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Inches at a Time, Crews Search for Bodies in a London Tunnel
description: LONDON, July 10 - The subway tunnel between King's Cross and Russell Square is one of several "deep tubes" bored through London's bedrock and clay more than a century ago: 70 feet down, 12 feet in diameter and reinforced with iron rings, the single-track tunnel's walls have just inches of clearance for trains.

title: First of Merck's many court days
Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERG, RABBI PAUL M.
description: STEINBERG--Rabbi Paul M. The President, Board of Governors, administration, faculty and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion deeply mourn the death of our beloved colleague, Dr. Paul M. Steinberg. For 50 years, the name of Paul M. Steinberg has been synonymous with the College-Institute. His love, devotion and influence on the College have extended to each of our four campuses, Cincinnati, New York, Los Angeles and Jerusalem. He loved Judaism and the Jewish people. And in turn, people loved him -- the twinkle in his eyes, the laughter in his heart and the pleasure taken in a loyal friendship. Funeral services will take place on Monday, July 11, at Hebrew Union College, 1 West 4th Street, at 11 am. Contributions may be made to the Paul M. Steinberg Memorial Fund of HUC-JIR. May his dear wife, Trudy, and their children, Lonnie, Alan, their grandchildren, Lindsey, Michael, Alex, Haley, Joshua, Arielle and Natalie, be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi David Ellenson, President Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors

title: Marriage and Family, Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wages of Denial
description: Washington - TEN years ago this week, Serbian forces slaughtered more than 7,000 Muslim men in the eastern Bosnian town of Srebrenica. Despite the efforts of a dedicated few in Serbia, and despite the war crimes prosecutions at The Hague, Serbia is no closer today than it was a decade ago to reckoning with its war guilt.

title: Textile exports hauntU.S.-China trade talks
When Seeing Is Not Always Believing
description: Is there anyone out there who wouldn't want to look into the mind of a security guard spending hour after hour in front of surveillance screens trying to spot crimes?

title: Bosnian Muslims RetraceFinal Day of '95 Victims
description: KONJEVIC POLJE, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 10 - About 500 Bosnian Muslim men set out on foot at 7:30 a.m. Sunday from this quiet farming village in eastern Bosnia on the third and final day of their re-enactment of the "march of death" a decade ago this week.

title: It Was an Expeditionary First for a Woman and a Panda
description: The Lady and the Panda The True Adventures of the First American Explorer to Bring Back China's Most Exotic Animal By Vicki Constantine Croke. Illustrated. 372 pages. Random House. $25.95.

title: Unnecessary Powers
description: The Patriot Act already gives government too much power to spy on ordinary Americans, but things could get far worse. Congress is considering adding a broad new investigative power, known as the administrative subpoena, that would allow the Federal Bureau of Investigation to gain access to anyone's financial, medical, employment and even library records without approval from a judge and even without the target knowing about it. Members of Congress should block this disturbing provision from becoming law.

title: Vacation in Nepal? Beware guerrillas
Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, BERNARD (BUNNY)
description: FELDMAN--Bernard (Bunny). On July 9, 2005, of Roslyn, NY, and Boynton Beach, FL. Beloved husband of Florence (Fidge). Devoted father of Stephen and Susan Feldman, Sharen and Shelly Tarakan, Adrienne and the late Marty Chernick. Dear brother of Yetta Friedman and Marlie Oatley. Cherished grandfather and great-grandfather. Services Monday, 1 pm, at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Rd, Roslyn Heights, LI.

title: Back From the Baltics
description: Sorry for the absence, Pogue's Posts fans. For once, people were right to say that I'm out to sea. I was on a cruise ship for ten days, as a speaker on one of the computer conferences organized by GeekCruises.com.

title: Militia Chief Chosen to Lead Iranian Police
description: TEHRAN, July 10 - Iran's supreme religious leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, on Sunday appointed the commander of a conservative militia as the new chief of the national police force, the Iranian Student News Agency reported.

title: Tony Blair'ssummit meeting
Ruling on Property Seizure Rallies Christian Groups
description: Conservative Christian groups seeking to galvanize support for a battle over a Supreme Court nomination are rallying around the unlikely symbol of a mega-church in Los Alamitos, Calif., one of a handful of houses of worship that have tangled with towns over the use of eminent domain to take their properties.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALLIS, ANTHONY ARTHUR
description: ALLIS--Anthony Arthur. Died Tuesday, July 5, 2005, at age 83. He will always be remembered for his positive spirit and the "light" he brought to every gathering. He will be missed dearly by his family and friends. He is survived by his devoted wife of 57 years, Christine G. Allis, and his loving children, Beatrice C. AllisMinion of Boca Raton, Barbara A. Allis, M.D., of Lloyd Harbor, NY, and Anthony J. Allis of Bronx, NY, his three grandchildren, Kathryn, Anthony and John Robert, and his brother, Arthur Allis of Fort Worth, TX. Memorial service will be held in August, in Long Island, NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Fire Department To Investigate Handling Of Pipe Bomb
description: The Fire Department will investigate a breach of protocol that occurred when firefighters brought a pipe bomb to their firehouse instead of calling the police bomb squad, a Fire Department spokesman said yesterday. The firefighters found the pipe bomb after extinguishing a small blaze in a trash bin at 35-16 201st Street in Bayside about 10:30 p.m. Saturday and took the bomb to their firehouse at 36-18 Francis Lewis Boulevard, the police said. The bomb squad was called to the firehouse at 11:19 p.m. and removed the bomb for disposal, the police said. Charlie Markey, the Fire Department spokesman, said department protocol required the firefighters to call the police to handle bombs. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Deadly hurricane closes in on U.S.
California Utility Workers Claim Bias in Pension Changes
description: Employees of the Southern California Gas Company have sued the utility, arguing that changes it made to its pension fund in 1998 violated federal and state laws against age discrimination, as well as a federal provision requiring companies to notify workers in advance of changes that reduce benefit accruals.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (2) ROCK STAR: INXS -- Series premiere. In this music-competition show, the Australian pop-rock group INXS (from left, Tim Farriss, Andrew Farriss, Jon Farriss, Kirk Pengilly and Garry Beers) searches for a new lead singer -- "somebody that you can't take your eyes off of," says Mr. Pengilly, the guitarist, saxophonist and vocalist. It doesn't sound like such a happy project, though, when you remember that the band's original frontman, Michael Hutchence, hanged himself in a suburban Sydney hotel room in 1997. He was 37.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HASKINS, JAMES
description: HASKINS--James, of New York and Gainesville, FL. On July 6, 2005. Beloved husband of Kathleen, father of Michael, Elisa and Margaret; brother of James McKinney, Will, Henry Jr., Eddie Lee, Alfred, Julia H. Foster, Virginia H. Webb, and Johnny Ray; adoptive brother of Nathaniel and Inez M. Spratt; cousin of Susie Hairston, Mary Robinson, and a host of other cousins; uncle to many nieces and nephews. Awardwinning author of more than 145 books, including "Diary of Harlem School Teacher", "The Cotton Club", and, "With Rosa Parks, Rosa Parks: My Story". A professor of English at the University of Florida, he is credited with playing a key role in the development of African-American studies at the University. Service July 17th, 3PM at the Cathedral Church of Saint John the Divine. Contributions may be made to the James Haskins Visiting Scholar Fellowship, Department of Afro-American History, or the James Haskins Collections in AfroAmerican Studies, both at the University of Florida, Gainesville, FL. 32611.

title: Weakened Hurricane Leaves Less Damage Than Expected
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., July 10 - After strengthening over the Gulf of Mexico and scaring more than a million coastal residents into hotels, shelters and neighboring states, Hurricane Dennis weakened as it came ashore near Pensacola on Sunday afternoon, near where the devastating Hurricane Ivan made landfall last year.

title: Martnez Pulls the Mets Back to the .500 Mark
description: PITTSBURGH, July 10 - The Mets scattered to a variety of desirable locales Sunday -- South America, the Caribbean, downtown Detroit -- in hopes that a brief change of scenery can help improve their destination at season's end.

title: BUSINESS DiGEST
description: Goldman Sachs and Allianz of Germany in Talks To Acquire a Stake in a Large Chinese Bank Goldman Sachs and Allianz of Germany are in talks to pay more than $1 billion to acquire a stake in China's largest state-owned bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, according to a person briefed on the discussions. The talks come at a time when some of the world's biggest financial institutions are rushing into China to acquire stakes in some of the country's large but troubled state-owned banks. [Page C1.]

description: Jared Diamond, the U.C.L.A. professor, blew many minds when he charted the entire history of man in just one book, the Pulitzer Prize-winning "Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies." His research had once been rather peaceful, the study of birds in New Guinea, until an indigenous tribesman encouraged him to study all things martial.

title: Kurdish Suspects Reveal International Links, Officials Say
description: ERBIL, Iraq, July 10 - Kurdish security officials said Sunday they had arrested suspects from six different terrorist groups that they believe help form wide insurgent training and support networks inside Iraq and have links with international terrorist organizations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERTZBERG, BOB
description: HERTZBERG--Bob. 92, newspaperman. Husband of the late Claire Hertzberg, father of Michael, Papa of Julie and David. He quit high school to work for the "Daily Mirror" as a copy boy, reporter, and News Editor until the paper's demise in 1963. He then was a Features Editor with the "Daily News." He made reporters look better, and, better still, made everyone he came in contact with laugh. A graveside service will be held at 1 PM, Monday, July 11, 2005 at Beth David Cemetery.

Ullrich Injured in Crash at Tour
description: MULHOUSE, France, July 10 - Jan Ullrich of Germany, who has finished second to Lance Armstrong three times in the Tour de France, crashed on a descent Sunday. He will have X-rays Monday, a day off for the riders, to determine if he broke any ribs.

title: When a Tree Isn't Really
description: The Adirondack Park Agency, a powerful group charged with protecting New York's six million-acre state park, decided last week that a cellphone tower could be constructed near Lake George. The tower, a 104-foot fake pine tree, will be "substantially invisible," the agency's statement promised. If this tower looks like others in the cellphone tree arboretum, one suspects it will be about as substantially invisible as a smiley face tucked into one of the famous Georgia O'Keeffe paintings of the very landscape in question.

title: Red, White and Beer? A Brewer's Strong Talk
description: LONDON - ANHEUSER-BUSCH is taking some chances by circulating marketing materials that may cross the line from patriotism to jingoism.

title: Body of U.S. Commando Is Found in Afghanistan
description: NEW DELHI, July 11 - The body of a missing American sailor, whom the Taliban had claimed to have beheaded, was found in the northeast region of Afghanistan, the United States military announced today.

title: Why Do So Many Consumers Choose Frills When Plain-Old Will Do? Pure Laziness
description: PHILADELPHIA - WHEN you cross over the Walt Whitman Bridge from New Jersey into Philadelphia, you are not likely to notice a big change in local driving habits. They do not become more aggressive on that side of the Delaware River, nor do they have trouble keeping their cars in a single lane. Pennsylvanians seem no more or less accident-prone than their neighbors.

title: Death Toll Rises to 52 in London
description: LONDON, July 11 - The official death toll from last week's bombings in London rose to 52 today, and the authorities began making their first formal identifications of the victims.

title: Show of Resolve as Religious Leaders Try to Cool Tensions

In Poker World Series, a Novice Flirts With Glory
description: LAS VEGAS, July 10 - Last March, Josh Baer sat before a glowing computer screen in his apartment in Bloomfield, N.J., and let tears roll down his cheeks. For a $160 buy-in, and after three hours of carefully calculated mouse clicks, Mr. Baer, then a theater major at Montclair State University, had achieved a dream: He had defeated 80 other online players in no-limit Texas Hold'em, earning a trip here and a seat worth $10,000 in the main event of the 36th World Series of Poker.

title: Trying to Get Serious About Porn, and Failing With Valor
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISS, BYRON
description: PREISS--Byron. Beloved and cherished husband of Sandi Mendelson, devoted and adored father to Karah and Blaire, devoted and loving son of the late Edmund and Pearl Preiss, caring son-inlaw of Norman and the late Belle Mendelson, admiring brother-in-law of Alan Mendelson, and revered uncle of Leslie and Erin Mendelson, died Saturday, July 9, at the age of 52, in an automobile accident. A compassionate, spiritual and charitable man, Byron was considered to be an important figure in the renaissance of illustrated books in America. He was President of Byron Preiss Visual Publications, Inc, and iBooks, Inc, working with numerous celebrities as well as esteemed science fiction authors Isaac Asimov, Ray Bradbury and Arthur C. Clark. A pioneer in multi-media and digital publishing, Byron's productions often pushed the boundaries of combining education, science and entertainment. A graduate of the University of Pennsylvania and of Stanford University's Film School Masters Program, Byron began his career in publishing, working with luminaries such as Harvey Kurtzman, Jim Steranko, Stan Lee and Ian Valentine. A true original, his humor, generosity and intelligence deeply affected every life he touched, in both his professional and personal relationships. Always first with a joke, a hug or a kind word, Byron's blend of wit and warmth was his signature. Byron was an extremely active New Yorker with membership in the Friars Club, a Trustee of the Sutton Place Synagogue, and Co-Chair of the UJA Federation of New York-Publishing Committee. He was a member of the Jewish Center of East Hampton and the South Fork Country Club. Byron's passions were many and varied: an avid collector of art, a longtime collector and devotee of comic and other graphic works, golf, traveling and music, but most of all, a kind, loving, nurturing and devoted son, husband, father and friend. Funeral services will be held at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st St, NYC, on Tuesday, July 12, at 11 am. The family requests that all donations be made to the United Jewish Federation of New York.

title: Mayor Pursues Plans Outside Manhattan, and Even Critics Applaud
description: While public attention was focused on the city's ill-fated plan to build a stadium on the West Side of Manhattan over the past two years, the Bloomberg administration quietly labored over projects and development plans in corners of the city -- from Jamaica, Queens, to Staten Island -- that generated very few headlines.

title: John Stubblefield, 60, Saxophonist Who Worked With Jazz's Best, Dies
description: John Stubblefield, a tenor saxophonist who worked with Mary Lou Williams, Charles Mingus, Tito Puente, Miles Davis, Anthony Braxton and Abdullah Ibrahim, among other jazz musicians, died last Monday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

The Queen Is Back. Now How About Her Kingdom?
description: It may have been the swimsuit competition, in which she performed a catchy little dance for the judges. It may have been her response during the on-stage interview -- intended to reflect poise -- in which she was asked, "Will it be difficult to face your family and friends if you lose?"

title: Vietnamese Writer Won't Be Silenced
description: PARIS, July 9 - Wearing an elegant tweed jacket and sipping fruit juice in a Left Bank cafe here, the writer Duong Thu Huong hardly cuts a threatening figure. But Ms. Huong, 58, evidently does in her native Vietnam, where she has spent time in jail, has seen her books banned and for 11 years was denied a passport to travel abroad.

title: Jerusalem mayor tries balancing act

Our sympathy to her family. Service, Plaza Memorial Chapel, Tuesday, at noon. West End Synagogue A Reconstructionist Congregation Janet Rosenberg, Pres.

title: The Art of the Steal: Podsednik Keeps Pitchers on Edge
description: CHICAGO, July 10 - Last Friday, on a night the gods conspired to make perfect for baseball -- shirt-sleeve summer weather, the flags fluttering only slightly in the breeze, the grass sparkling under the lights -- the 33,623 fans at U.S. Cellular Field watched Scott Podsednik lead off the first inning for the hometown White Sox against the Oakland Athletics. In typical fashion and with the shot-from-a-cannon speed that has made him the premier base thief in all of baseball, with 44, and a newly minted All-Star as well as the American League leader in infield hits, with 25, Podsednik beat out a slow roller to the right of the mound.

title: The Business Week Ahead
description: REMEDY -- Already considered an innovator in cancer treatments, Genentech will report its quarterly earnings but analysts, investors and even patients may be watching to see how the company drug maker will capitalize on recent positive clinical trials for its potential blockbuster drugs Avastin and Herceptin. (Monday.)

title: Britons 'just tend to get on with it'
Deadly storm heads for U.S. Gulf Coast
Another China Bank Is Courted by the West
description: SHANGHAI, July 10 - Goldman Sachs and Allianz of Germany are in talks to acquire a $1 billion stake in China's largest state-owned bank, the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

title: Thousands mark 10th anniversary of Srebrenica massacre
It Just Gets Worse
description: Back in March 2004 President Bush had a great time displaying what he felt was a hilarious set of photos showing him searching the Oval Office for the weapons of mass destruction that hadn't been found in Iraq. It was a spoof he performed at the annual dinner of the Radio and Television Correspondents' Association.

title: First body identified among victims of London bombings
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: City Housing Technician Arrested
description: A technician who administered drug screenings on behalf of the New York City Housing Authority was charged Saturday with accepting a bribe to alter a drug test, a spokeswoman for Rose Gill Hearn, the city's investigation commissioner, said yesterday. The technician, Ada Stephen, 41, of Brooklyn, accepted a $100 bribe from an undercover investigator, Ms. Hearn said in a statement. Ms. Stephen, who was arrested Thursday, worked as a technician for Bay Park Medical, which provides pre-employment screening for Housing Authority workers.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayor Urges Transit Security Spending
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg urged the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday to spend the $600 million it has committed for security improvements in the transit system. After the terrorist attack in London last week, the agency acknowledged that it had spent only a fraction of the money it had secured since the Sept. 11 attacks. "Clearly the M.T.A. has to ratchet up the pace of increasing security on our subway system, whether it is with people or technology," Mr. Bloomberg said at a news conference. "I don't know how far along some of their plans are, but clearly they're not far enough along." The M.T.A. officials have said that by the end of 2005 they will have a plan to spend more than $300 million on eight projects.

title: A Guiding Hand in Evolution?

title: Interim Kyrgyz President Is Expected to Win a Quiet Election
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, July 10 - Three and a half months after rioters overturned the government here by storming the presidential building to protest flawed parliamentary elections, voters in Kyrgyzstan peacefully returned to the polls on Sunday to select a new president.

title: Americana to Comfort Roots Rockers
description: Son Volt is a band that inspires either passionate devotion, or very little response at all. One of the two groups that resulted from the breakup of the alternative-country exemplar Uncle Tupelo (the other was Wilco), Son Volt made its last album in 1998. Since then its leader, Jay Farrar, has been working on his own, making an American mythology with comforting bits and pieces, including Neil Young's electric guitar sound and Woody Guthrie's social consciousness.

title: High-Flying Epigrams Whiz By Like Arrows
description: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., July 7 - When "Lady Windermere's Fan," the melo-comedy of manners that made Oscar Wilde's name as a playwright, opened in London in 1892, at least one eminent critic was not amused. "There is of course absolutely no characterization," Henry James wrote to a friend, "and all the people talk equally strained Oscar."

description: HERE are some upcoming events where GMC and other types of motor homes will be on display.

A Colorful Farewell for the Chief of Chiefs
description: NEW ORLEANS, July 10 - From the streets outside, the sound of hundreds of tambourines bled into St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church, where a priest led funeralgoers through a three-hour Mass on Saturday. As the service concluded, the pallbearers, in dark suits and bright white gloves, picked up their own tambourines and led a chant for Allison Montana, better known as Tootie, the "chief of chiefs" of the Mardi Gras Indians.

You were one of a kind and touched so many. We love you and will miss your warmth, unique humor, intellect and sage advice. Memorial service July 12, 11 am, at Ballard - Durand Funeral Home in White Plains. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the National Kidney Cancer Association.

description: LOS ANGELES, July 10 - A lawsuit filed last week against producers and broadcasters of reality television shows accused those companies -- including ABC, CBS and the WB -- of planning to falsify payroll records of employees to avoid paying wages for overtime.

title: For Time Inc. Reporter, a Frenzied Decision to Testify
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 - Matthew Cooper, a reporter for Time magazine, stood before a federal judge on Wednesday, facing up to four months in jail for refusing to testify about a confidential source. But he told the judge that he had just received a surprising communication from his source that would allow him to testify before a grand jury investigating the disclosure of the identity of a covert C.I.A. operative.

description: In a small town in South Texas, a long legal journey will begin this week for Merck, the giant drug maker, and thousands of people who suffered heart attacks and strokes after taking its painkiller Vioxx.

title: Londoners, Remembering Crises Old and New, Just 'Get On With It'
description: LONDON, July 10 - For several heart-stopping hours, it seemed as if last Thursday would be Britain's 9/11. There were the same panicky television reports -- an explosion here, a power outage there, a bomb somewhere else -- and the same terrible sense that events were unfolding almost too quickly for human understanding, that there might be fresh hell yet to come.

title: Bosnian Muslims Recall Executions
description: SREBRENICA, Bosnia and Herzegovina, July 11 - At a ceremony marking the 10th anniversary of the execution of about 7,000 Muslim men and boys here during the war in Bosnia, American and European leaders again promised that two Bosnian Serb leaders indicted for the killings would be brought to justice. But many of the 30,000 Bosnian Muslims who gathered here today dismissed the promises as empty.

title: Relative lull in violence ends
Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Death Reclassified As A Homicide
description: The city medical examiner has changed the cause of death of a Bronx man to homicide, the police said yesterday. The man, Wellington Contreras, was struck last week in Bedford Park by a street sign that had been knocked down from a pole by a driver who had been shot. The driver, Shawron Hughes, 21, was shot by an unknown assailant and his car swerved out of control, hitting the pole and then knocking down the sign. Mr. Hughes is in stable condition at St. Barnabas Hospital, the police said.
