description: LONDON, July 10 - A confidential British military assessment examines the possibility of drastically cutting troop strength in Iraq by the end of next year, to 3,000 from about 8,500 now, in a memo leaked to the newspaper The Mail on Sunday. The memo also raises the possibility of a sharp drop in the number of troops the United States and other allies have in Iraq by the middle of 2006.

Arts, Briefly; Fox Led Bombing Coverage On Cable Television
description: Of the cable news channels, Fox News drew the largest audience on the day of the terrorist attacks in London. According to Nielsen Media Research, Fox News attracted an estimated average of 1.66 million viewers, compared with CNN's 1.09 million and MSNBC's 427,000. The same pecking order applied to prime time: Fox News drew an estimated 2.43 million, while CNN and MSNBC averaged 1.33 million and 413,000, respectively. Of the three channels' programs on Thursday, Fox's "O'Reilly Factor" was the most watched, with an audience of 3.01 million. For the week ending July 3, "The 2005 BET Awards," with hosts Will Smith and Jada Pinkett Smith, was the No. 1 show on advertiser-supported cable, with 6.58 million viewers. The show featured a surprise reunion of the formerly feuding Fugees, and heaped awards on Kanye West. It was the top-ranked program in all the adult ratings demographics for the week, and helped BET place second among 18-to-49-year-olds.

title: INSIDE
description: Bomber Kills 23 Recruits At Center for Iraqi Army An attacker mingling with a crowd outside an Army recruiting center in Baghdad detonated his explosive vest and killed at least 23 volunteers while wounding at least 40 more. The attack, which ended a brief lull in the suicide bombings, came on a day when the war claimed the lives of at least 43 people, including a mother and eight children. PAGE A6

title: Six-Lane Highways for the Mediterranean Island of Ibiza
description: The Balearic island of Ibiza has long been an idyllic beach getaway free of mass development. But plans for six-lane highways, golf courses and urbanization projects on the island have many questioning whether paradise will soon be lost.

title: Officials Pleaded Guilty, but Town Was Changed Forever
description: MARLBORO TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 6 - The price of corruption in this New Jersey town may best be seen in the many rooflines that snake down Woodcliff Boulevard at a uniform 25-foot setback from the curb. Or perhaps in the postmodern stylings of the luxury five- and six-bedroom homes in the planned community of Lexington Estates.

title: The Not-So-Simple Life of the Very Rich and Very Pretty
description: One problem with true-crime television movies is that they do not settle -- rather they aggravate -- questions about the crimes on which they're based. Take the murder of Ted Ammon, the multimillionaire who was found bludgeoned to death in East Hampton in October 2001. At the time, it was hard to tell why Mr. Ammon -- by all accounts an exceedingly decent, if rich, man -- ever became mixed up with his erratic wife, the former Generosa Rand. And as suspicion fell on Mrs. Ammon and her boyfriend, the electrician Danny Pelosi (who was convicted of the murder in 2004), it was hard to tell what she saw in Mr. Pelosi.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KOONS, TILGHMAN B.
description: KOONS--Tilghman B. 79, on July 7, 2005, at his home in East Hampton. Son of Margaret O'Hara and Lucius Koons. Beloved and admired by his friends, "Skip" Koons had a wide-ranging career in the military, government and banking. Born in Plainfield, NJ, he received his B.A. from Princeton, with honors, at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs in 1946. From 1946 to 1949 he was in the U.S. Navy, learning Russian at the Language School in Boulder, CO, serving in Washington with Secretary James Forrestal and in China for two and a half years, working with Russian emigre communities in Shanghai, Peking and Manchuria. After receiving a Fulbright Fellowship, in 1952 he earned a Ph.D., with highest honors, from the University of Paris (Sorbonne). His thesis traced the political ideas and activities of the Russian emigres from the Russian Revolution to the outbreak of World War II. From 1953 to 1957 he served in the Executive Office of the President, as an adviser to General Robert Cutler, President Eisenhower's Special Assistant for National Security. Upon leaving the government, he joined the First National Bank of Boston and, in 1962, the Chase Manhattan Bank where, as Vice President, he was concerned with strategic planning of the bank's overseas expansion in Latin America, the Far East and Canada. In addition to his professional activities, Skip was learned in history and the arts, and assembled a notable collection of marine water colors and prints from the 18th and 19th centuries. His wisdom, warmth and generosity will be sorely missed by his many friends in this country and in Europe. A Memorial Service will be announced.

title: American Filmmaker Held by the U.S. Military in Iraq for 7 Weeks Is Released
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 - After being held for more than seven weeks in solitary confinement in an American military prison in Iraq, Cyrus Kar, an aspiring filmmaker from Los Angeles, was freed Sunday in Baghdad, exhausted and hungry but relieved that his ordeal was coming to an end.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WELLS, MILDRED BRENNER
description: WELLS -- Mildred Brenner. February 7, 1923-July 8, 2005. Beloved wife of 59 years of Carl F. Wells, who survives her, along with their children, Wendy Ellen and Nicholas Adam, and her grandson Richard Martin Wright, all of Mohegan Lake, NY. We will always carry you in our hearts, and our lives have been the richest because of you. Every minute of your life you took tireless care of everyone: your patients in your career as a clinical social worker, and your family. You never let us down, and you listened and counseled with compassion, acute insight, humor, and endless love. No one can ever imagine the depth of your bounty and your love of life. You fought against this terrible disease of cancer so bravely, because we needed you so. We hope you are at peace, and will miss you forever.

title: Briefly: Democrats want views heard on judicial choice
Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIRO, LAURENCE H., M.D.
description: SPIRO--Laurence H., M.D., 62, and Heather J., 55, of Rock Hill, NY. Suddenly on June 25, 2005. Loving parents of Victoria Mesh and son-in-law Eugene Mesh. Beloved son of Gertrude Eichschlag and the late Jerome Spiro. Beloved daughter of Bernice and David Fashler. Loving brother of Richard Spiro (Alison) and Ellen Freeman. Loving sister of Robert Fashler (Anita). Also survived by nieces and nephews, and many wonderful friends. A memorial service will be held later this month in Rock Hill, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STERN, MILTON
description: STERN--Milton. Beloved husband of Pearl. Loving father of Bradford and Rona, Mindy and David. Dear brother of Seymour, and Rita and Stan Wecker. Services were held.

description: BIRMINGHAM, England, July 10 - After an emergency shutdown of much of this city's center on Saturday night that left nerves on edge and brought Birmingham to a standstill, the city slowly came back to life on Sunday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANG, MRS. VON SUNG
description: YANG--Mrs. Von Sung. Widow of Dr. Ho Ching Yang. Died July 9, 2005. She was born in China, April 7, 1902, and died at her apartment in Manhattan with three of her seven children and two grandchildren at her side. Mrs. Yang witnessed the 20th century almost in its entirety and was personally touched by a number of its most visible events and people. Two of Mrs. Yang's children, Gertrude and Stella, preceded her in death. She is survived by Annie, Alvie, John, George and Lucy. Mrs. Yang was a strong woman, never to be forgotten by her large and active family.

description: MOSCOW, July 10 - Venus Williams won her singles match Sunday, but it was too little, too late for the United States Fed Cup team, which lost its semifinal showdown, 4-1, against Russia at Olympic Stadium.

title: Florida Plans for Recovery by Looking to Last Year
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., July 10 - Hoping to avoid the delays that bedeviled recovery efforts after Florida was hit by four major hurricanes last year, Gov. Jeb Bush ordered 2,600 National Guard troops and 700 law enforcement officers to staging areas just beyond the path of Hurricane Dennis on Sunday, with instructions to move into ravaged areas as soon as the winds eased.

title: Paper withholds leak-based articles
The Writing's on the Board for Woods in Scotland
description: On the eve of the third round of the 2000 British Open, much of St. Andrews, Scotland, was beside itself. While many at the home of golf looked on in wonder as Tiger Woods yanked the teeth out of the Old Course -- a few fans during the week actually shouted, "Easy, Tiger!" -- others tried to prod some fight out of a field trailing Woods by three shots.

title: Building's Extra Fuel Tanks Raise Concerns in TriBeCa
description: Saying that a dangerous amount of diesel fuel is stored in a 25-story building in TriBeCa, elected officials and residents called on Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday to rescind a variance that permits its storage.

title: Byron Preiss, 52, Digital Publishing Pioneer, Dies
description: Byron C. Preiss, an author and a publisher who specialized in illustrated books by celebrities, graphic novels and science fiction, died in a traffic accident on Saturday in East Hampton, N.Y. He was 52 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, LAWRENCE, MD, DDS, PH.D.
description: COHEN -- Lawrence, MD, DDS, Ph.D. 78, born Leeds, England; died July 4, 2005. DDS, Leeds University, School of Dentistry 1949. Instructor, Birmingham University, College of Dentistry 1949-50. Squadron leader, oral surgeon, Royal Air Force Dental Branch, Germany 1950-52. MD, Guy's Hospital Medical School, University of London. Ph.D.-Oral Diagnosis, University of London 1966. Professor and Head of Department of Oral Diagnosis, University of Illinois 1967-1976. Earned MD and DDS licenses in US. Chairman, FDA Panel-Review of Oral Cavity Drug Preparations 1974-79. Consultant, FTC 1980s. President, American Academy of Oral Medicine mid-80s. President, Medical Emergency Associates Illinois 1978-92. Retired in 1994. Lectured extensively throughout world. Authored many books and scientific papers. Predeceased by loving wife Gloria. Survived by three sons, Alan, Martin, David and their families. Services were held in Chicago. Info: Shalom Memorial Funerals, 847255-3520.

title: Un-Spin the Budget
description: Later this week the White House budget director plans to put on an aviator costume, march up to a microphone and declare Mission Accomplished in the war on deficits. O.K., I'm not sure about the costume bit.

title: James Haskins, an Author on Black History, Dies at 63
description: James Haskins, an educator who in seeking to make up for the dearth of children's books on black historical figures ultimately became one of America's most prolific children's book authors with more than 100 works of nonfiction to his credit, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

description: WASHINGTON, July 10 - Senator Arlen Specter, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, suggested on Sunday that President Bush could name Justice Sandra Day O'Connor, who is retiring from the Supreme Court, to the position of chief justice if it opens up.

title: Setting the Table for North Korea's Return
description: PHUKET, Thailand, July 10 - Just hours before North Korea agreed to return to the six-nation talks on its nuclear program, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice reiterated that the United States would not sweeten the offer laid on the table more than a year ago. "We are not talking about enhancement of the current proposal," she said Saturday.

title: Israel Said to Seek $2 Billion From U.S. to Aid Gaza Pullout
description: JERUSALEM, July 11 - Israel, which has traditionally been the largest recipient of United States assistance, is seeking an additional $2 billion or more to help pay for its planned withdrawal of soldiers and Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip, Israeli officials said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORSE, MILDRED HOCKSTADER ''TINY''
description: MORSE--Mildred Hockstader "Tiny". Of New York, Washington D.C., and Geneva, Switzerland. Died July 8, at her home in Manhattan. Beloved wife of the late David Abner Morse, Mrs. Morse was born in New York City in 1911. The daughter of Aline Straus Hockstader and Leonard Albert Hockstader, she was predeceased by a sister, Carol Eggleston, and a brother, Albert F. Hockstader. Her survivors include a nephew, Alan F. Hockstader of White Plains, three great nieces, one great nephew, and a host of godchildren and friends around the world. A graduate of The Spence School and Rosemary Hall, Mrs. Morse was a supporter of The Council on Foreign Relations where she established a lecture series in the name of her late husband; The Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute; The African American Institute; The New York Society for International Affairs, Inc., and Rutgers University where, in 1979, she and her late husband established the first major art acquistion fund at The Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum. During David Morse's twenty year tenure as Director General of the International Labor Organization (ILO) in Geneva, the couple accumulated a substantial collection of late 19th and early 20th century French Graphics and paintings which are now among the Zimmerli's holdings. In 1983, the Morse Print and Drawing Room opened at the Zimmerli. In 1995, an expanded version of that space became the major research facility for the museum. After her husband's death, Mrs. Morse also established a series of scholarships in his name at Rutgers University. Everyone who loved Mildred thanks Maria Martin, Rita Purdessy, Jennifer Simpson, Dierdre Mole and Dr. Veronica LoFaso, for their loving care, as well as all the staff at the Beekman who contributed to her well-being and comfort. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the charity of your choice, The Guide Dog Foundation for the Blind, 371 East Jericho Turnpike, Smithtown, New York 11787, or The Irving Sherwood Wright Center on Aging, 1484 First Avenue, New York 10021. A memorial service will be held in the Beth El chapel at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and 65th Street, on Wednesday, October 19 at 11 A.M.

title: Congress Urged to Extend Help After Attacks
description: WASHINGTON, July 10 - Elected officials, private insurers, builders and real estate companies across the country are mounting a broad campaign to urge Congress to extend a program that requires the federal government to cover insurance losses in a terrorist attack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LISS, ETHEL
description: LISS--Ethel. With profound sadness and love, we mourn the death of Ethel Liss, whose extraordinary caring and thoughtfulness touched the lives of all who had the privilege to know her. Her devotion to her children Mark, Steven, David and Mindy, daughters-in-law Bonnie, Carol and Michelle, and adored grandchildren Aaron, Adam, Emma and Jackson, knew no bounds. Beloved sister and sister-in-law, caring aunt and cousin, and cherished friend, our memories of Ethel will strengthen and inspire us always. Funeral services will be held Monday, July 11 at 1:30 PM, Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road.

title: 6 Afghan police officers are found beheaded
2 Are Killed in Shootings at 3 Parties
description: Three separate outdoor parties, two in Queens and one in Brooklyn, ended in violence early yesterday when gunmen opened fire, leaving two people dead and injuring three others, one critically, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Age 92. Of Boca Raton, FL, and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. In his early 20's, Irving played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud selfmade man. Interred at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

And much depends on how they are understood, for the Martians, as everyone knows, are also metaphors. They may even have some connections with Mr. Spielberg's next film and its views of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

description: SCHWARTZ--Shirley Glassberg. The Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Relgion family expresses its profound sorrow at the death of Shirley Glassberg Schwartz, beloved mother of Ilene and Stanley P. Gold of Los Angeles. Ilene and Stanley have been steadfast and loyal friends of the College for more than three decades. They have opened their hearts to those associated with the College-Institute. We, in turn, have been blessed by this unique association. May they and their children, Charles and Jennifer, be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Soaring Cost of Drugs May Force Industry To Make Difficult Decisions on Health Care The costs of new cancer treatments and other drugs are rising at an alarming rate that could force difficult decisions on doctors and health policy makers. Cancer treatments in particular now cost tens of thousands of dollars for a few months' supply, and doctors warn that the price might someday exceed the limit that society is willing to pay for health care. Now there's We're Not Afraid (werenotafraid.com), a mass pictorial response to the terrorist bombings in London.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: Peace Activist Gunned Down
description: Gunmen killed Abdulkadir Yahya Ali, a prominent peace activist, at his home in Mogadishu in the latest in a string of targeted attacks on civilians who are seeking to promote stability in Somalia. Mr. Yahya founded the Center for Research and Dialogue, a group that has worked to help reconstruct the war-torn country. "This is a great loss to Mogadishu and Somalia at this particular time when people of his courage and tenacity are most needed," said Maxwell Gaylard, the United Nation's humanitarian coordinator for Somalia. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Keeping Ground Zero Free

They helped drive forward the inquiries of the Sept. 11 commission. They helped formulate any number of the projects being developed at ground zero. They have reminded us conscientiously of what was lost on that day.

title: Latin American Singer's Rainbow Coalition of Identities
description: RIO DE JANEIRO - He was born in Uruguay, the son of a German Jew who sought refuge from Hitler in the New World. He also lived for a time in Israel, but when his own career as a musician began to take off a decade ago, he chose to return to the Old World, settling in Spain, marrying and having a child there and writing songs since recorded by Argentine, Brazilian and Cuban artists.

title: Arts, Briefly; Sharing the Ratings Spoils
description: In Sunday's Nielsen estimates, CBS was No. 1 in households but NBC won in both total viewers and the 18-to-49-year-old audience. CBS's "60 Minutes" was the most-watched show of the night, with 9.44 million viewers. That, in combination with a "Cold Case" rerun (7.37 million) and the made-for-television movie "Open House" (7.62 million), added up to the CBS victory in households. But the lineup was not as popular in the 18-to-49 demographic, where CBS placed fourth. NBC edged out Fox in that age group, with a two-hour "Dateline" (8.01 million), along with repeats of "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" (8.7 million) and "Crossing Jordan" (8 million). Fox featured the most popular offering of the night among adults 18 to 49, an original episode of "Family Guy" (6.10 million). The series premiere of "The Princes of Malibu," Fox's reality sitcom in which the music producer David Foster financially cuts off his layabout stepsons, drew 4.97 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

They tell a story exhaustively told in forests of newsprint, books, government reports, made-for-TV movies and a Bruce Springsteen record.

title: Usually Volatile Mayor Wins Praise for Low-Key Presence

description: Fidelity Investments said yesterday that it had reassigned Scott DeSano, its chief of stock trading, to a new position within its new business development group.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISS, BYRON C.
description: PREISS--Byron C. Colleagues of Byron Preiss, President and Publisher of ibooks and Byron Preiss Visual Publications express their profound grief and sense of loss following his tragic accidental death on Saturday, July 9. Under Byron's visionary leadership, all of us over the years have been privileged to participate in a challenging and exciting creative process. Every day, he came into the office the eternal optimist, and inspired us to create fresh and unique publishing and packaging projects--always to innovate, to experiment, to push the envelope. In meetings he was a dynamic presence, overflowing with ideas and lighting up tth room. Byron always looked for the best in everyone, and we responded by reaching further and deeper to live up to his high standards. He brought out the best in all of us. Our lives will be immeasurably diminished without him, but his vision will live on in our hearts and in our work. The Staff of Byron Preiss Visual Publications and ibooks

Then hundreds of Air Force chaplains stood and sang, many with palms upturned, in a service with a distinctively evangelical tone.

title: Transit Officials Now Concede They Did Not See Terrorism in the Initial Confusion
description: LONDON, July 11 - It was 8:51 a.m., the height of the morning rush hour on July 7, when the first emergency call came in. At 8:59 a.m., a train at Edgware station was reported to have hit a tunnel wall. At 9:01 a.m., a manager on the Metropolitan Line said that a person might be under a train at Liverpool Street. At 9:03 a.m., controllers on the Piccadilly Line received accounts of passengers running out of King's Cross station.

title: Blast in Lebanon Wounds Deputy Prime Minister
description: BEIRUT, July 12 - Lebanon's outgoing pro-Syrian defense minister was wounded today by a car bomb that killed at least two and injured 12 in a residential Christian enclave north of Beirut. In a series of bombings in the Lebanon this year, this attack was the first aimed at a pro-Syrian official.

title: AT WHITE HOUSE, A DAY OF SILENCE ON ROLE OF ROVE
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 - Nearly two years after stating that any administration official found to have been involved in leaking the name of an undercover C.I.A. officer would be fired, and assuring that Karl Rove and other senior aides to President Bush had nothing to do with the disclosure, the White House refused on Monday to answer any questions about new evidence of Mr. Rove's role in the matter.

title: Interim Kyrgyz leader wins presidential vote
Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAKARIA, RAFIQ
description: ZAKARIA--Rafiq. Scholar, politician, philanthropist, humanist and lover of life. The American friends and admirers of Rafiq Zakaria mourn the passing of a towering figure and send their condolences to his beloved wife Fatma, his children Tasnim, Mansour, Arshad, and Fareed, and their families. From Mumbai to Aurangabad to Delhi to London to New York and beyond, his example will shine for all who knew him or were touched by his wisdom, humanity, and great works.

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Runaway Trailer Kills Driver
description: A driver was killed by a runaway truck trailer yesterday morning after it broke loose from a truck on Hillside Avenue in Hollis. The police said that about 7:30 the flatbed trailer broke away from a vehicle moving west and crashed into a passenger car going east near 189th Street and Hillside Avenue. The car struck a utility pole, and the driver, who was not identified yesterday, was killed, the police said. The truck driver, Vincent Castellano, 40, of Mastic Beach, was issued a summons for an unsecured load, the police said. An investigation continued yesterday.

title: Fire Captain Is Suspended in Bomb Case

description: To the Editor:

title: In a Bronx Neighborhood, a Long, Losing Battle
description: The apartment buildings lining Decatur Avenue north of 195th Street have official-looking signs bolted to the brick, declaring that hallways are off limits to drug dealers, muggers and anybody else with mayhem in mind. The signs warn any and all here in the Bedford Park neighborhood of the Bronx that the police will arrest trespassers.

title: Satellite Radio Is Music to Fans' Ears
description: In this retro season that has taken baseball back to Washington and big-league sluggers closer to their natural size, a new breed of radio is reclaiming its place on the front porch.

title: Official Sees New Jersey on Verge of a 'Transportation Meltdown'
description: TRENTON, July 11 - In New Jersey, there are few activities in life as vital, maddening or culturally defining as the task of getting from one place to another.

title: By the Sea, by the Sea, by the Beautiful Sea
description: Lincoln Center Festival 2005 opened with a mighty wave of movement and motion on Tuesday night in the Rose Theater in the Frederick P. Rose Hall of Jazz at Lincoln Center. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company revived "Ocean," one of the successes of the first Lincoln Center Festival in 1996, but not seen in New York since then.

Bombs in London Are Now Called Military Quality
description: LONDON, July 11 - British investigators believe that the 10-pound bombs used in the coordinated terrorist attacks here contained "military quality" high-grade explosives, British and European counterterrorism officials said Monday.

title: When Green Frogs Frolic and Naked Marionettes Dance
description: The Lincoln Center Festival has a sure hit on its hands with Ottorino Respighi's 1922 puppet opera "La Bella Dormente nel Bosco" ("Sleeping Beauty in the Woods"), which opened last night at the Gerald W. Lynch Theater of John Jay College. No doubt most of the buzz the presentation is sure to generate will go to the enchanting production by the puppeteer and director Basil Twist, which played recently at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C.

title: Great Promise in Molecular Tinkering, but Better Bathroom Will Have to Wait
description: For four years, inventing a new toilet bowl freshener has been a sideline pursuit for Michael Lefenfeld, a 25-year-old graduate student in molecular electronics at Columbia. Mr. Lefenfeld's doctoral research focuses on the structure of molecules in nanoscale devices like transistors.

title: Briefly: Voters endorse switch to one-house system

description: Cellphone service in car tunnels to Manhattan, which was quietly disabled by transit officials last week after the terrorist attack in London, was partly restored yesterday after the mayor publicly questioned the move and after a dispute over who ordered the shutdown was resolved.

title: Briefs: AB Foods to buy clothes outlets
Frances Langford, Trouper on Bob Hope Tours, Dies at 92
description: Frances Langford, a mellow contralto who ventured into combat zones with Bob Hope's troupe during World War II and the Korean and Vietnam Wars to serenade tens of thousands of servicemen with ballads that reminded them of the girls they left behind, died yesterday at her home in Jensen Beach, Fla. She was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   REGAN, JAMES J.
description: REGAN--James J. On July 7, 2005 of Rockville, Centre, N.Y. Beloved husband of Mary Jane (nee Lockyer). Loving father of John A., Daniel, Michael and Andrew. Cherished grandfather of Brian, Esther, James, Wen, Anna and Luke. Reposing at Macken Mortuary Rockville Centre, Chapel 52, Clinton Avenue. Tuesday 2-4, 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Wednesday 10AM. St Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Private Cremation to follow. In lieu of flowers friends may make contributions to Leukemia-Lymphoma Society.

title: White Tulle and Toe Shoes
description: What is there to say about American Ballet Theater's revival, for an eight-performance run to end its Metropolitan Opera House season, of its 18-year-old production of "Giselle"? Same old same old?

title: News Analysis:In all fairness, opinions on deals aren't so bad
Paid Notice: Deaths   KIMBALL BOYCE, MARY
description: KIMBALL BOYCE--Mary. Died July 10, after a brief illness. A Navy nurse in WWII, Mary is survived by her daughter, Kristine Cate of Londonderry, NH, her son, Roger Kimball of Norwalk, CT, and ten grandchildren. Requiescat in pace.

title: An Inside Look at the Arteries Brings a Pleasant Surprise
description: I have had cholesterol scores of more than 300 for decades, and several doctors have urged me to take statin drugs, but I had a bad experience with Lipitor, the only one I tried.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Age 92. Of Boca Raton, FL, and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. In his early 20's, Irving played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud selfmade man. Interred at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: Help us stop Israel's wall peacefully
A Possible Bid for Westinghouse
description: TOKYO, July 11 - Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is considering buying Westinghouse Electric, the builder of nuclear power plants, from British Nuclear Fuels, as Mitsubishi strives to expand its reactor business outside Japan.

title: A Day of Roots, Dancehall and No-Shows
description: Why do promoters even bother to announce the headliners at reggae shows? On Sunday afternoon, thousands of fans showed up at Randalls Island for the nine-hour installment of the annual Reggae Carifest concert. They came even though they couldn't be sure who would perform.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHRIFTMAN, MOLLIE
description: SHRIFTMAN -- Mollie. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our devoted member. We extend our condolences to her family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Charles Berman, President

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the bombings in London on Thursday misstated the number of commuter trains bombed in Madrid on March 11, 2004. It was 4, not 10.

Democratic Leader Discounts a Filibuster
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 - Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, said Monday that he did not foresee a filibuster against President Bush's choice for the Supreme Court, but warned that Democrats would not hesitate to slow the confirmation if they found the process or the nominee objectionable.

title: Revenge Attacks and Vandalism Unnerve Muslims in Britain
description: BIRKENHEAD, England, July 11 - Muslims all over Britain, in small towns and big cities, are beginning to feel the repercussions of Thursday's terrorist attack on London, confirming widespread concerns that resentment over the bombings would spill over into harassment and violence.

description: Premieres to Avoid: Charlie and the Tripe Factory

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FONTANA, DR. VINCENT J.
description: FONTANA--Dr. Vincent J. In memoriam to our esteemed colleague and friend, Stony Brook University mourns the death of Dr. Vincent J. Fontana, who devoted his life to the care of children. We offer our most heartfelt condolences. A funeral Mass was held Monday, July 11 at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Manhattan.

title: All-Star Memories: Piazza Flips the Pages
description: DEARBORN, Mich., July 11 - Mike Piazza kept saying that he did not want to reflect on what might be his final All-Star Game appearance in a career that will inevitably guide him into the Hall of Fame. Not now, not yet, Piazza said, trying to keep those memories stored for as long as possible.

description: STRUM--Elias. Passed away Sunday, July 10. Beloved husband of Elaine, father of Nina Weinstein and Jeffrey, stepfather of Harold and Jeffrey Verschleiser and Joy Pearl. Grandfather and great grandfather, brother of Anita Gluck and Marilyn Frisch. Services 10AM Tuesday, Temple BethEl, North Ave, New Rochelle

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JORDAN, SHEILA
description: JORDAN--Sheila, July 10. Beloved wife of Frank Jordan; loving mother of Michele Schwartz, Suzanne Fellini and Barry Filene; loving grandmother of Jacqueline Brecher and Anjelica Fellini and great-grandmother of Mikaela and Cary Brecher. She will be deeply missed by her family and all who knew her. Services Tuesday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, donations to American Liver Foundation, 75 Maiden Lane, NYC 10038.

title: Parties Failing in Joint Effort to Review Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 - Efforts in Congress to reach a bipartisan compromise over the future of the USA Patriot Act appear to have splintered, with Republican leaders on the Senate and House Judiciary Committees moving ahead on their own with proposals to extend the government's counterterrorism powers under the hotly debated law.

title: 'Godfather': A book, a film, a video game
Paid Notice: Deaths   CARR, MILDRED S.
description: CARR--Mildred S. On July 9, 2005, at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Frank Edward Carr. Loving mother of Dr. Ronald (Nancy) Carr and Richard (Diana) Carr. Adored grandmother of Peter (Rebecca), Jacqueline (Richard Lonoff), Timothy (Whitney) Carr and great grandmother of Peter, Lucy, Hannah, Emily, Benjamin, Alexandra and Caroline. Interment private. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Thursday, July 14th, 4 P.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Volunteer Referral Center, 161 Madison Ave., Suite 5SW, New York, New York 10016.

title: VNU to Buy a Specialist in Tracking Health Care
description: LONDON, July 11 - VNU, the Dutch market research company, said Monday that it would buy IMS Health, a provider of health care research and data based in Connecticut, for about $6.4 billion, to take advantage of the growth in so-called lifestyle drugs.

title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Outside Shopping Mall in Israel
description: NETANYA, Israel, July 12 - A Palestinian suicide bomber blew himself up this evening at a busy intersection outside a shopping mall in this Israeli coastal town, killing himself and two women, and wounding more than 50 people, Israeli police said.

title: MEMO PAD
description: PAYING MORE TO STAY IN NEW YORK -- The most expensive hotels in New York City -- the ones that generate $300 or more a night for a room -- are increasingly becoming even more expensive. PKF Consulting says that room rates paid in May averaged $386.15 in the top-luxury category in Manhattan, a 15.1 percent increase over May 2004. Occupancy in that category was 88.6 percent -- up 4 percent. It can be difficult to find a hotel room in New York at any price. For Manhattan hotels in all price categories, the average occupancy rate was 89.6 percent in May (up 4.5 percent from May 2004). The average rate paid for a room was $240.23, up 12.6 percent from $213.30 in May 2004.

title: Chinese currency trading thrives without yuan
Arts, Briefly; Sharing the Ratings Spoils
description: In Sunday's Nielsen estimates, CBS was No. 1 in households but NBC won in both total viewers and the 18-to-49-year-old audience. CBS's "60 Minutes" was the most-watched show of the night, with 9.44 million viewers. That, in combination with a "Cold Case" rerun (7.37 million) and the made-for-television movie "Open House" (7.62 million), added up to the CBS victory in households. But the lineup was not as popular in the 18-to-49 demographic, where CBS placed fourth. NBC edged out Fox in that age group, with a two-hour "Dateline" (8.01 million), along with repeats of "Law & Order: Criminal Intent" (8.7 million) and "Crossing Jordan" (8 million). Fox featured the most popular offering of the night among adults 18 to 49, an original episode of "Family Guy" (6.10 million). The series premiere of "The Princes of Malibu," Fox's reality sitcom in which the music producer David Foster financially cuts off his layabout stepsons, drew 4.97 million viewers.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a decision by The Cleveland Plain Dealer to withhold two articles that were based on illegally leaked documents misstated the name of the paper's owner. It is Advance Publications; while the company is owned by the Newhouse family, it is not called Newhouse Newspapers.

title: Longtime Schwab Executive Is Named Chief of Visa USA
description: Visa USA named a chief executive yesterday whose experience with credit and debit cards has consisted largely of swiping them at restaurants and stores. The executive, John Philip Coghlan, the former vice chairman of the Charles Schwab Corporation, succeeds Carl F. Pascarella, Visa's longtime chief executive who said last summer that he was planning to depart for a job in investment banking.

title: Rival bid brewingin Italian bank battle
Field of Blood, Blood of Angels
Unlike Giuliani, London mayor keeps low profile
Kodak says it developed camera chip with IBM
Lost Commando Is Found, Killed in Afghan Firefight
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 11 - The body of a Navy Seal commando missing since last month was found Sunday evening less than a mile from where his reconnaissance team was attacked, American military officials said Monday.

title: One Bad Call
description: Williamstown, Mass. - BASEBALL is all about memories, and the All-Star Game tonight in Detroit will remind us of such shimmering moments as Carl Hubbell striking out Babe Ruth, Lou Gehrig, Jimmie Foxx, Al Simmons and Joe Cronin in succession in the 1934 game; Ted Williams winning the 1941 game, also in Detroit, with a titanic home run; and Bo Jackson leading off the 1989 game with a towering shot over the center field wall. We will watch tonight hoping to add to those memories and to see the best players in the game try their utmost even though there is very little at stake.

title: Vatican silences Philippine bishops
Chinese jar sets record for Asian art
Corrections
description: Because of a telephone transcription error, an article in The Arts on Saturday about the wrongful death suit filed against the city of Los Angeles by the family of the slain rapper Notorious B.I.G. misstated a word in a quotation from Don Vincent, a lawyer for the city. He said that everything the plaintiffs' witnesses are saying is "hearsay," not "heresy."

description: Shakespeare: The Whole Ball of Wax

title: A City's Traffic Plans Are Snarled by China's Car Culture
description: SHANGHAI, July 9 - When officials drew up the blueprints for the redesign of this city in the early 1980's, nary a skyscraper punctuated the low-slung horizon, whose buildings mostly dated from the decades of Western control early in the last century.

title: Cousin of the Jellyfish Spurs Fresh Theories on Seeing Red
description: Hungry predators of the sunless depths have long used the ghostly lights of bioluminescence to attract the unsuspecting. Anglerfish, accomplished hunters with daggerlike teeth, wave lines tipped with glowing lures. Viper fish dangle long rods with luminous tips that can draw prey into their needlelike fangs.

title: Most Floridians Find Branches Down but Properties Blessedly Whole
description: MILTON, Fla., July 11 - The small towns are worn, like the pocket of a catcher's mitt that is the Gulf of Mexico, where bad storms slap to a stop.

title: After 3 Months on the Shelf, Acelas Begin a Return to Service
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 - Amtrak put two of its Acela Express trains back in service on Monday, nearly three months after all 20 were sidelined because of cracked brakes.

title: Making a Profit Not Montreal's Game
description: The Montreal Impact speaks the language of soccer, albeit in French and with a novel business approach in a cutthroat sport.

description: The United Nations flew a 50-man rapid reaction force into the conflicted South Kivu Province in Congo to investigate reports that an estimated 30 people had been killed there by Rwandan rebels. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Hands-Free Cellphone Devices Don't Aid Road Safety, Study Concludes
description: DETROIT, July 11 - A study of Australian drivers found that those using cellphones were four times as likely to be involved in a serious crash regardless of whether they used hands-free devices like earpieces or speaker phones that have been perceived as making talking while driving safer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRACAUER, GERTRUDE

title: Shanghai suffers as car culture takes hold
Closing Arguments Offer Sharply Contrasting Views of a Wife's Killing
description: TRENTON, July 11 - Prosecutors argued that Jonathan W. Nyce, 55, the former chief executive of EpiGenesis Pharmaceuticals, after an disagreement with his wife, Michelle Nyce, 34, knowingly killed her by repeatedly bashing her head into the concrete floor of the garage of their Hopewell Township home. Mrs. Nyce had returned that night after a motel tryst with her boyfriend, Miguel DeJesus, according to trial testimony. The lawyer for Mr. Nyce, Robin Lord, argued that his wife fell from the car in a "sad and unfortunate and tragic accident."

title: Put Your Embarrassment Aside: Get the Colonoscopy
description: Mickey Martinez was a vigorous 64-year-old with a smashing smile and a backhand to match. Fluent in four languages, he devoted his professional life to public service and his personal life to being a good husband, father, grandfather and neighbor.

title: Terminally Ill in Oregon (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: At Least 20 Killed In Mall Fire
description: At least 20 people died in a fire at a shopping center in the northern Russian city of Ukhta. A local official said the fire was set by two teenagers who "hurled a bottle with a burning substance into the building," the Itar-Tass news agency reported, and other reports suggested the motive was a commercial dispute. Initial reports of the fire speculated that the cause was a gas explosion. Earlier, the fire raised fears of a terrorist attack, coming in the wake of the London bombings. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A schedule note in The Arts yesterday with a theater review of "My Year of Porn" misstated the days it plays at the Brick Theater in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. They are this Thursday and Sunday, not Thursday and Friday. (It also plays on Friday nights through Aug. 19 at the Magnet Theater in Manhattan.)

title: Exxon Mobil Becomes Focus of a Boycott
description: WASHINGTON, July 11 - A coalition of environmental and liberal lobbying groups is planning a boycott of Exxon Mobil products to protest the company's challenges to warnings about global warming and its support for oil and gas exploration in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge.

title: Gustaf Sobin, 69, a Writer Who Celebrated Provence, Is Dead
description: Gustaf Sobin, an American-born writer who for more than 40 years wove the history, sensations and language of his adopted Provence into his poetry and prose, died on July 7 at a hospital in Cavaillon, Vaucluse, near his home in Goult in the south of France. He was 69.

title: VNU to buy U.S. health data firm
There's plenty of blame for us all
Rediscovering fiction through films
Paid Notice: Deaths   FINGER, AMBASSADOR SEYMOUR MAXWELL
description: FINGER--Ambassador Seymour Maxwell. The Ralph Bunche Institute for International Studies of The City University of New York, extends its heartfelt condolence to Max's wife Annette and entire family on his passing on July 10. Max's directorship of the institute from 1971 to 1982 and insights into international affairs laid a solid foundation for our current research. His mentoring helped numerous scholars. His warmth and counsel will be sorely missed. Professor Thomas G. Weiss Director Ralph Bunche Institute for International Studies The CUNY Graduate Center

title: First School Day in Russia That for Many Was the Last
description: Larisa Kudzieva was inside School No. 1 in Beslan, Russia, when Chechen terrorists took her and some 1,200 children, teachers and parents hostage there. She remembers the terrorists choosing 20 heavily built men and taking them away to shoot them.

title: Insurance Executive Resigns Over Subpoena
description: RenaissanceRe Holdings, a Bermuda-based reinsurer, said yesterday that Michael W. Cash, a senior vice president, resigned after refusing to accept a regulatory subpoena about the company's earnings restatement.

title: The Dangerous Comfort of Secrecy
description: The Bush administration is classifying the documents to be kept from public scrutiny at the rate of 125 a minute. The move toward greater secrecy has nearly doubled the number of documents annually hidden from public view -- to well more than 15 million last year, nearly twice the number classified in 2001 -- as bureaucrats have invented more amorphous categories like "sensitive security information." At the same time, the declassification of documents required under the Freedom of Information Act has been choked down to a fraction of what it was a decade ago, leaving the government working behind an ever darker, ever denser screen.

title: Police raid residences in northern England
Judge Limits Statute's Ability to Curb Iraq Contractor Fraud
description: A federal judge issued a ruling yesterday that will limit the applicability of a critical antifraud statute against corporate contractors in Iraq.

title: The Claim: Chiggers Attack Humans by Burrowing Under Their Skin
description: THE CLAIM -- Chiggers attack humans by burrowing under their skin.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Old Bridge: Dupont To Preserve Land
description: More than 1,800 acres of land will be preserved in an agreement between the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and the DuPont Company, Bradley M. Campbell, left, the environmental commissioner, announced yesterday. Under the agreement, one of the largest involving the damage of natural resources in the state, the company will preserve 1,875 acres in Cape May, Gloucester, Middlesex, Passaic and Salem Counties, plant 3,000 trees in urban areas, and pay $500,000 for water restoration projects and the construction of a boat ramp on the Salem River. The settlement is intended to compensate the public for damage the company caused to groundwater involving 2,400 acres at eight sites. Tina Kelley (NYT)

title: Discovery's Day-by-Day To-Do List
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 11 - The crammed 13-day flight of Discovery will be busy for both the shuttle and International Space Station crews.

title: Utilities still hold earning power
The Team From Zippo Goes to Washington
description: NOTE to air travelers, including the tens of thousands whose lighters were confiscated from checked bags at airports in April, when the government began enforcing a ban on lighters: Never mind.

title: Torre Event Draws Crowd
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., July 11 - For six of the past eight years, Yankees Manager Joe Torre had been busy at this time of year managing the A.L. All-Star team.

title: This time, America shrugs at high oil prices
Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACKWELL, EDWARD S., JR.
description: BLACKWELL -- Edward S., Jr., of Basking Ridge, NJ, formerly of Dorset, VT, Short Hills, NJ and Point O'Woods, NY, on July 9, 2005 at the age of 94. A graduate of Williams College 1933 and Harvard Law School, he had a distinguished career in commercial insurance brokerage. He is survived by his wife, Elsie Wilson, to whom he was married for 71 years, and his children, Janet Bent, Edward S. Blackwell III, Marion Meserole, their spouses, nine grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Memorial service at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to The Church at Point O'Woods, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

title: Diocese Removes Priest Accused of Sexually Abusing a Child
description: NEWARK, July 11 - A Roman Catholic priest was removed from his church over the weekend in response to an accusation that he sexually abused a child 18 years ago.

title: Paying More to Stay in New York
description: PAYING MORE TO STAY IN NEW YORK -- The most expensive hotels in New York City -- the ones that generate $300 or more a night for a room -- are increasingly becoming even more expensive. PKF Consulting says that room rates paid in May averaged $386.15 in the top-luxury category in Manhattan, a 15.1 percent increase over May 2004. Occupancy in that category was 88.6 percent -- up 4 percent. It can be difficult to find a hotel room in New York at any price. For Manhattan hotels in all price categories, the average occupancy rate was 89.6 percent in May (up 4.5 percent from May 2004). The average rate paid for a room was $240.23, up 12.6 percent from $213.30 in May 2004.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Ex-Premier's Real Estate Deal Investigated
description: Russia's general prosecutor's office has opened a criminal investigation into a real estate deal involving former Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov, who was fired by President Vladimir V. Putin last year and has suggested he might run to succeed him in 2008. Mr. Kasyanov was critical of the case against the oil magnate Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, who was jailed on charges of fraud, forgery and tax evasion. In recent weeks, a pro-Kremlin journalist and lawmaker has accused Mr. Kasyanov of corruption over the purchase of a country retreat at a cut-rate price. Liberal politicians said Mr. Kasyanov was being singled out in a new Kremlin campaign against perceived political threats. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: Bear Stearns Sets Aside $100 Million as Investigations Loom
description: Bear Stearns said yesterday that it was setting aside an additional $100 million in legal reserves in connection with an investigation into improper mutual fund trading.

title: Man Who Fled Bias Attack Is Arrested in Robbery
description: A companion of the black youth severely beaten last month in Howard Beach, Queens, in what the authorities called a hate-crime attack by whites, was arrested on Sunday night and charged with participating in a gunpoint robbery aboard a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said yesterday.

title: On Eve of Sentencing, WorldCom Founder Loses Bid for Retrial
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, who was convicted of fraud in the $11 billion WorldCom accounting scandal, lost his bid for a new trial today and is to be sentenced on Wednesday.

title: Prevention: Forget Fashion. Make a Health Statement at 35,000 Feet.
description: People who take long airplane flights may want to wear graduated compression stockings when they fly; those who don't are considerably more likely to suffer deep vein thrombosis, blood clots in the veins of the legs that can be fatal if they travel to the pulmonary arteries.

title: Rice, in Asia, takes heat for avoiding Asean trip
Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about Republican efforts to damp down conservatives' criticism of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales as a potential Supreme Court nominee misstated the name of an opponent of abortion whose statements describing Mr. Gonzales's views on the subject are being circulated by some conservative groups. He is J. C. Willke, not C. J. Willkie.

title: Cholesterol Drugs Show No Effect on Dementia Risk
description: Those who believe that taking cholesterol-lowering drugs will reduce their risk for Alzheimer's disease may want to reconsider. A large study published yesterday in Archives of Neurology found no proof that the drugs affected the risk of developing dementia from any cause -- Alzheimer's, vascular dementia or the two combined.

description: LANE--Peter. The Board of Directors and staff of the Thyroid Head and Neck Cancer (THANC) Foundation wish to extend deepest sympathies to the Lane family on the death of Peter Lane.

In Lithia Springs, Ga., above, heavy rain inundated a car dealership; in St. Marks, Fla., far to the east of the hurricane's center, the water was every bit as deep. PAGE A13

Bush Vows to Fight Until Terrorists' Defeat
description: QUANTICO, Va., July 11 - President Bush on Monday added the deadly bombings in London to his list of reasons that the United States should aggressively continue pursuing terrorists around the world, and told F.B.I. recruits and marines stationed here that "we will fight until this enemy is defeated."

Arts, Briefly; Chesney Packs Them In
description: The country artist Kenny Chesney, below, sold the most concert tickets of any artist in any genre in the first half of 2005, the trade paper Pollstar reported. His "Somewhere in the Sun" tour has sold roughly 610,000 tickets and has grossed $35 million. U2 is tops in road revenues, at $48.4 million, and second in total tickets sold, with about 500,000. Celine Dion, who plays exclusively at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, has sold 322,000 tickets and grossed $43.9 million. Mr. Chesney's tickets sell for an average of $57.39, far and away the least expensive of the leading concert acts. U2's tickets go for $96.94 on average and Ms. Dion's for $136.70. PHIL SWEETLAND

title: Suspect in Killing of Dutch Filmmaker Maintains His Silence
description: AMSTERDAM, July 11 - Still recovering from a shootout with the Dutch police, a suspected Islamic militant accused of assassinating a Dutch filmmaker limped into a high-security courtroom here on Monday, clinging to both a copy of the Koran and his right to remain silent.

title: For Girls Only: What Mom, Dad and a Good Report Card Can Do for You
description: A new study has found that adolescent girls who have good grades and girls who perceive that their parents strongly disapprove of their having sex are less likely than others to contract sexually transmitted diseases by the time they reach young adulthood. The predictors did not apply to boys.

title: Arts, Briefly; Chesney Packs Them In
description: The country artist Kenny Chesney, below, sold the most concert tickets of any artist in any genre in the first half of 2005, the trade paper Pollstar reported. His "Somewhere in the Sun" tour has sold roughly 610,000 tickets and has grossed $35 million. U2 is tops in road revenues, at $48.4 million, and second in total tickets sold, with about 500,000. Celine Dion, who plays exclusively at Caesars Palace in Las Vegas, has sold 322,000 tickets and grossed $43.9 million. Mr. Chesney's tickets sell for an average of $57.39, far and away the least expensive of the leading concert acts. U2's tickets go for $96.94 on average and Ms. Dion's for $136.70.

title: 16-Year-Old Dominican Prospect Gets $1.4 Million From the Mets
description: When the Mets signed Jos Reyes out of the Dominican Republic in 1999 as a 16-year-old, they paid him $15,000.

Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLL, MARJORIE COWEN
description: STOLL -- Marjorie Cowen. Born May 14, 1920 in New York, died July 10, 2005, in Palm Beach. Preceded in death by her husbands, Jack Weiner, Lawrence Stoll, Lou Holtz, and daughter Lynn Switzer, brother, Richard Cowen, parents William and Jean Cowen. Survived by son, Jonathan Stoll, daughter-inlaw, Lori Stoll, grandchildren, Lauren, Jesse, Lawrence, Jack, and Liana Stoll, of Palm Beach, and John, Max, and David Switzer, of Boca Raton, and nephew, James Cowen, of New York. She was involved in many charities. In lieu of flowers, donations to Alzheimers Association of PB. Funeral and interment today Menorah Gardens, West Palm Beach.

Octavius believes he's safe there from people who want him dead. He is mistaken. Part 3 of 5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LECLAIR, ELLENANNE MARSH
description: LeCLAIR--Ellenanne Marsh. 83, of Chappaqua, NY and Peterborough, NH on July 8. Beloved wife of the late Leopold LeClair, mother of Joelle LeClair Whitmarsh of Wrentham, MA, Isabella LeClair, of Seattle, WA, Amelia LeClair of Newtonville and Truro, MA and son, Amory LeClair of Ottawa, Canada. As assistant Editor for the Office of War Information in NY, Mrs. LeClair began her U.S. Foreign Service partnership with her husband in 1946 serving for almost 30 years in Athens, Bordeaux, Beirut, Sri Lanka, Ottawa, Carlisle, PA and Washington, DC. She was a member of the Overseas Woman's Club, President of the Peterborough Branch of the Monadnock Community Hospital Auxiliary and a member of the Monadnock Chorus. Funeral services will be held at All Saints' Episcopal Church in Peterborough, Wednesday, July 13 at 1 PM with burial to follow at St. Peter's Cemetery, Vine St., Peterborough. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Habitat for Humanity, Inc., 12 Habitat St., Americus, GA. 31709

World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Lawmaker Caught With $2.6 Million In Cash
description: A lawmaker carrying $2.6 million in his luggage was detained by federal police at the Braslia airport as he prepared to board a private plane bound for a city 60 miles from the capital, the police said. The lawmaker, Joo Batista Ramos da Silva of the opposition Liberal Front Party, told investigators the money was collected as tithes from the Universal Church of the Kingdom of God denomination. Mr. Silva was accompanied by six other people and as many as seven suitcases. Carrying large amounts of cash without reporting it is illegal, though Mr. Silva is immune from prosecution because of his Parliament seat.

title: Rogers Takes the Heat, Then Ducks a Question

title: Black Hollywood's broad appeal
Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Body Found In Backyard
description: A man returning home yesterday afternoon discovered a dead woman in his backyard, the police said. The body was discovered shortly before 4 p.m. in the backyard of 1542 East 15th Street, in Midwood. The police said that the woman was dark-skinned, had long black hair and was clad only in a shirt. The body was taken to the medical examiner's office for an autopsy to determine the cause of death, they said. Last night, the police said they had few clues about the woman's identity or how she came to be in the yard. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT

title: Secrecy Is Lifted in Some Tax Court Trials
description: Burton W. Kanter, one of the nation's most prominent tax lawyers, spent a career pushing the limits of the tax laws. He used creative tax planning to finance such movies as "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" and "The Rocky Horror Picture Show." He pioneered the use of foreign trusts to reduce taxes. He lectured for decades on his creative tax structures at the University of Chicago Law School and wrote a regular column in The Journal of Taxation.

title: Leader Wins 88% of Vote in Kyrgyzstan
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, July 11 - Kurmanbek S. Bakiyev, a former opposition leader who had become interim president of Kyrgyzstan, was declared Monday to be the winner of the presidential election by a landslide, capturing nearly 90 percent of the ballots cast.

description: When oil prices spiked in the early 1980's after the Iranian revolution, Jared Nedzel gave up his 1978 Pontiac Trans Am, an emblematic American muscle car, for a smaller, less extravagant Toyota Corolla. He was on his way to Cornell University to study civil engineering and he needed a more economical car.

title: In Hawaii, a Chance to Heal, Long Delayed
description: Less than a month after 9/11, with terrorism fears threatening to put jet travel and thus the Hawaiian economy into a death spiral, tourism officials there announced an emergency marketing campaign to promote the state as a place of rest, solace and healing. Anyone who has ever stepped off a plane in Honolulu, trading the brittle staleness of the aircraft cabin for the liquid Hawaiian breeze, warm and heavy with the scent of flowers, knows exactly what they meant.

Metro Briefing | New York: Franklin Square: Teacher In Inquiry Quits
description: A former Brooklyn assistant principal accused of involvement with grade-tampering on Regents exams in 2002 and 2003 resigned yesterday as chairwoman of the social studies department at the H. Frank Carey High School in Franklin Square, on Long Island, saying she wanted to devote herself to clearing her name. According to a report last month by an investigator for New York City schools, the former assistant principal, Theresa Capra, directed teachers to falsify grades on dozens of social studies Regents exams at the Cobble Hill School for American Studies. She was removed from the school in May 2004 and resigned from the city school system six weeks later to take the job as the head of the social studies department. Ms. Capra said that the allegations were trumped up by a disgruntled teacher and corroborated by others afraid of losing their jobs. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

We are particularly grateful for his caring generosity in helping enrich the cultural lives of the Jewish blind and visually impaired home we serve. May his memory serve as a blessing. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of the Board Barbara B. Friedman, Hon. Chairman of the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO

title: National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Serial Killer's Home Is Sold
description: The Park City home of the convicted serial killer Dennis Rader was sold at auction for $90,000. The buyer would not identify herself except as "a real estate investor," but she was immediately recognized from television advertisements as an owner of a local strip club, Michelle's Beach House. She said she hoped the proceeds, which a Sedgwick County district judge ordered held by the court clerk on Friday, would benefit the family of Mr. Rader, who called himself the B.T.K. killer, for bind, torture and kill. The price paid for the modest, 960-square-foot house was well above what a similar house would usually cost in Park City, a working-class suburb of Wichita. Bud Norman (NYT)

title: A Passage From India
description: ACCORDING to a confidential memorandum, I.B.M. is cutting 13,000 jobs in the United States and in Europe and creating 14,000 jobs in India. From 2000 to 2015, an estimated three million American jobs will have been outsourced; one in 10 technology jobs will leave these shores by the end of this year. Stories like these have aroused a primal fear in the Western public: that they might soon need to line up outside the Indian Embassy for work visas and their children will have to learn Hindi.

title: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Joining Requires Reform
description: Olli Rehn, the European Union's top official responsible for enlargement, issued a blunt warning to Bulgaria and Romania, telling them that their membership in the European Union in 2007 would be postponed if they did not carry out necessary reforms. He cited the need to address corruption and to reform the judiciary in both countries. Mr. Rehn also said that member states should not close the door on including Turkey, despite increasing skepticism among Europeans toward enlargement. Judy Dempsey (IHT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZORENSKY, LOUIS I.
description: ZORENSKY--Louis I. The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourns the passing of its lifetime Board Member, and generous supporter, Louis Zorensky, who, from his home base in Saint Louis, reached out to Jewish communities around the globe. He had a special concern for jews in the former Soviet Union and in Israel, where he helped sustain JDC's Taub Center For Social Policy Studies, as well as many cultural and educational institutions. All this was done in close partnership with his beloved wife, Mary, and we extend our deepest sympathy to her, and to the entire family. Judge Ellen M. Heller, President Eugene J. Ribakoff, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Executive Vice President

title: Quick! Set Your Watch To Cherry Time

description: WITKOFF--Martin. On July 12, 2005 at age 76. Beloved husband of Lois. Devoted father of Steven (Lauren), Robert (Elaine), Amy (and fiance Gary Gelman), and Susan (Dr. Peter) Stein. Adored grandfather of Andrew, Alex, Zach, Elizabeth, Holden and William. Cherished brother of the late Ethel Halperin. Dear brother-in-law of Martin (Myra Weiss) Birnbaum. Services Thursday, July 14, 2005, 1PM at the Riverside - Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza (opposite the LIRR) Great Neck, NY. Interment at the New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY. WITKOFF -- Martin. We've lost our dear friend and "Uncle" Marty. They didn't make them any kinder, brighter, or loving. The Falk Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZAKARIA, RAFIQ
description: ZAKARIA--Rafiq. Scholar, politician, philanthropist, humanist and lover of life. The American friends and admirers of Rafiq Zakaria mourn the passing of a towering figure and send their condolences to his beloved wife Fatma, his children Tasnim, Mansour, Arshad, and Fareed, and their families. From Mumbai to Aurangabad to Delhi to London to New York and beyond, his example will shine for all who knew him or were touched by his wisdom, humanity, and great works.

title: Let a Thousand Licensed Poppies Bloom
description: EVEN as Afghanistan's immense opium harvest feeds lawlessness and instability, finances terrorism and fuels heroin addiction, the developing world is experiencing a severe shortage of opium-derived pain medications, according to the World Health Organization. Developing countries are home to 80 percent of the world's population, but they consume just 6 percent of the medical opioids. In those countries, most people with cancer, AIDS and other painful conditions live and die in agony.

title: Experts to Consider Withdrawal of Asthma Drugs
description: A panel of lung experts is being convened today to advise the government on whether three popular asthma drugs should stay on the market or be withdrawn because of safety concerns.

The National League Can't Get Untracked
description: Detroit - IN retrospect, that 7-7 tie three years ago doesn't look too bad to the National League. It's the only All-Star Game in the past nine that the N.L. hasn't lost.

title: Judges Cite Concerns Over Trial of Banker
description: Three federal appeals judges indicated yesterday that they had reservations about a jury's decision to convict Frank P. Quattrone, the former technology investment banker, on obstruction of justice charges.

description: It was meant to be a balm for upset journalists, or at least a start.

It was a spokesman for the state Administrative Office of the Courts, not a Guilford County judge.

title: China assails Australia on defector
Insurer muscles into battle for Italian bank
For the Spice Rack That Has Everything
description: NIRMALA NARINE has her eye on your spice rack. "Spices are the soul of every cuisine," said Ms. Narine, 35, an entrepreneur in Long Island City, Queens. "And as sophisticated as we may have become, there is still plenty to learn."

title: A Bay Ridge Bistro With Malaysian Roots
description: THE sign says bistro, but Banana Leaf, a Malaysian restaurant on Fourth Avenue in Bay Ridge, sure doesn't look like one. There's a waterfall by the entrance and a gurgling empty fish tank. The delivery menu, with its $4.25 lunch special, is festooned with photographs in unreal colors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREYTAG, RICHARD A.
description: FREYTAG--Richard A. Citicorp Banker, of Wilmington, DE, age 71, died on July 4, 2005. He retired in 1996 as President and CEO of Citicorp Banking Corporation, New Castle, DE after 34 years service with the bank and he retired from the U.S. Air Force with the rank of Major General after 38 years service. Survivors include his beloved wife, Pamela; son, Richard; daughter, Bliss Smith; 2 grandchildren; brother, Donald; sister, Dotti Howe. Friends and associates are invited to attend a military funeral service at 3PM, July 19 at Bolling Air Force Base, Chapel #

title: Nuclear Weapons Expert Backs Reliability of Disputed Warhead
description: Joining a debate over the reliability of the W-76, a top American warhead, a nuclear arms expert at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has concluded that at worst, 70 percent of those in the nuclear arsenal would explode as designed.

title: Experts Fear Suicide Bomb Is Spreading Into the West
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 - A suicide bombing may be the ultimate act of devotion, and so it also represents the ultimate security nightmare: an attack in which the one essential ingredient is not training or technology but commitment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KESTENBAUM, RUTH
description: KESTENBAUM--Ruth. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the mother of our member, Ruby Gottlieb. May her entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Joseph S. Kaplan, President Paulette Papilsky, Sisterhood

title: Man on Trial in Dutch Killing Says He'd Do 'Same Again'
description: AMSTERDAM, July 12 - Breaking a self-imposed silence that had confounded court officials here, a young Muslim man coolly accepted responsibility Tuesday for the brutal slaying of a controversial Dutch filmmaker, adding that he would do it all over again if given the chance.

title: Why Is the White House Silent?
description: To the Editor:

title: On Eminent Domain, Many Shifting Stances
description: HARTFORD, July 12 - It should be familiar ground for Democrats, defending the little guy against big-money interests, but on the question of whether a string of modest waterfront homes in New London, Conn., should be seized by the government for private development, the Democrats dithered while the Republicans charged into battle.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (FX) 30 DAYS "Off the Grid." Tonight two 30-year-olds leave their technology- dependent lives to spend a month without modern conveniences at an eco-village in Missouri. Johari Jenkins and Vito Summa (above) live in a converted grain bin, take solar-heated showers and grow their own food. In real life, she's an events coordinator and D.J. from Jersey City, and he's a bouncer from the Bronx.

title: Illinois to Pay for Cell Research
description: CHICAGO, July 12 - Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich signed an executive order on Tuesday making Illinois the fourth state to devote public money to embryonic stem cell research.

title: Add the Fireflies and It's a Summer Idyll
description: For summertime art as light as a lemonade, drift by Cinders, a Williamburg, Brooklyn, storefront with a street-facing gallery and a shop in the back. The gallery space is minute, about the size of a one-room cabin. But for the current exhibition, "The Porch Show," on through July 24, its interior has been turned into a rural backyard, with a wood-frame porch, an Astroturf lawn, gardening tools and work by 17 artists jostling for space.

title: 10 Sunnis Suffocate in Iraqi Police Custody
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 12 - Iraq's widely feared police commandos were struggling on Tuesday to explain how at least 10 Sunni Arab men and youths, one only 17, suffocated after a commando unit seized them from a hospital emergency ward and locked them in a police van in summer temperatures exceeding 110 degrees.

title: Woods Is Hoping to Sweep Farewell Tour of His Idol
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 12 - Tiger Woods's grasp of golf history has been apparent since the day, as a child, he posted Jack Nicklaus's records on his bedroom wall. He has also played some of his best golf when an event coincided with Nicklaus's making a final appearance at a major. When Nicklaus bowed out at the United States Open at Pebble Beach in 2000, Woods won.

title: One Thing Missing From Patrick's Season: A Victory
description: Danica Patrick's first season in the Indy Racing League has been a blur of accomplishments: a front-row start and fourth-place finish in Japan, then a heady and historic run in the Indianapolis 500, then her first pole position 10 days ago.

title: Another Vote for the Old Recipe
description: To the Editor:

title: Chambers Given 3 Months After Guilty Plea for Heroin
description: Robert E. Chambers Jr., the convicted killer whose crime seemed to expose a dark side in the lives of young people on the Upper East Side in the 1980's, is heading back to jail -- for three months. At a pretrial hearing in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday, Mr. Chambers agreed to plead guilty to heroin possession and driving with a suspended license, avoiding what could have been a one-year sentence if he had been convicted by a jury.

description: JetBlue Airways said yesterday that it planned to begin flights from Newark Liberty International Airport in October, meaning that it will serve all three major airports in the New York City area.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 12 - Prime Minister Ibrahim al-Jaafari said Tuesday that some Iraqi cities were secure enough for American-led forces to begin withdrawing to outside bases, a move he suggested could later lead to a more definitive timetable for the departure of foreign troops.

title: Footwear For Summer Wineglasses

There are two sets, one in blue and purple tones, the other in bright orange, yellow and green. Each set is $15 from Table Settings, 276 Norwood Avenue, Deal, N.J.; (732)531-0800 or (866)934-7437 toll-free from outside New Jersey.

title: J. G. Baker, Designer of High-Altitude Camera Lenses, Dies at 90
description: James G. Baker, an astronomer who designed powerful lenses and cameras for the U-2 spy plane in the 1950's and became a pioneer of satellite reconnaissance in the cold war, died on June 29 at his home in Bedford, N.H. He was 90.

description: YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, July 12 - Canada's leading literary magazine has written about it. The local newspaper devotes a weekly column to it. And it is the hottest issue going in this arctic territorial capital.

description: Pete Rose should not expect an answer any time soon from Commissioner Bud Selig on his application for reinstatement to Major League Baseball. At a question-and-answer session Tuesday with members of the Baseball Writers' Association of America, Selig was asked the status of Rose's appeal.

description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 12 - With threatening skies the last remaining barrier, the administrator of NASA said Tuesday that the revitalized space shuttle Discovery was ready to lift off at 3:51 Wednesday afternoon on the shuttle fleet's first mission in nearly two and a half years.
