Cherished grandmother of Alicia, Holly, Lauren and Jose Feliciano, Melissa and Dr. Michael Levine, great-grandmother of Benjamin Noah and Talia. Remembering you today with great love and affection.

title: Corrections
description: A map on Monday showing the path of Hurricane Dennis gave an incorrect name in some copies for the Air Force base east of Pensacola, Fla. It is Eglin, not Egland.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Retired F.B.I. Agent To Run For Mayor
description: Pressed into service by fellow Republicans whose earlier missteps had left them without a candidate, Christopher D. Munger, a retired F.B.I. agent, said yesterday that he would challenge the longtime Democratic incumbent, Dannel P. Malloy, in this year's mayoral race. Republicans, who failed to field a challenger in 2001, had to regroup this year when they learned that their likely choice, Samuel William Sigler, had a criminal record. Mr. Munger, 67, a Vietnam veteran, coordinates training programs for the Rockland County police academy in New York State and advises Rockland County and New York State on counterterrorism. His family has lived for 29 years in Stamford, where Mr. Munger's son Bryan is a deputy fire marshal. Alison Leigh Cowan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GREGER, LESTER
description: GREGER--Lester. On July 7, 2005, Age 95. Married for 75 years to his beloved wife Frances. Family historian, astute businessman, the Baron Dukey King, exuberant soul. We will miss him. Laurie & Dave

title: An Olympic Shutout
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Plan for New Oil Sands Project
description: Imperial Oil filed an application with regulators in Alberta to build an oil sands mine project valued at 4.5 billion to 6.5 billion Canadian dollars. The Kearl Oil Sands project, a joint venture between Imperial, which is almost 70 percent owned by Exxon Mobil, and Exxon Mobil Canada, would produce 100,000 barrels of raw bitumen, the tar that emerges from processed oil sands ore, within five years if approved. According to the filings, that figure would eventually increase to 300,000 barrels a day. At the moment, Imperial's plans do not include an upgrader to turn the bitumen into oil. The project must be approved by the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board as well as the province's ministry of the environment. The mine would be built near the Northeastern Alberta community of Fort McMurray. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUNDERLAND, J.B.
description: SUNDERLAND -- J.B. Born Aug. 14, 1928, died at home on June 8, 2005. He was President of Aminoil and Transpacific Geothermal Co., a director of the Near East Foundation since 1966, and a founder and director of Americans for Middle East Understanding since 1967. He was also a Member of the Council on Foreign Relations since 1971. He is survived by his wife, four children, and their families. Services will be held at 11A.M. on July 18 at St. Bridget's Church, Cornwall Bridge, CT. Donations may be made to A.M.E.U. 475 Riverside Dr. NY, NY 10115-0245 or the Near East Foundation, 90 Broad St, 15th Fl, NY 10004.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday listing recent court rulings on abortion laws referred incorrectly to the one struck down by a district court in San Francisco in the case known as Planned Parenthood Federation of America v. Ashcroft. It was a federal law, not a state law.

title: North Korea gets incentive to talk
Spreading Skepticism and Joy in the Park
description: Good Monsieur Melancholy, the freelance philosopher Jaques, is the primary source of joy in the Public Theater's production of Shakespeare's "As You Like It" in Central Park. Credit the presence in the role of Brian Bedford, a consummate classical actor with a few decades of stage experience, for this apparent paradox. Whenever Mr. Bedford's Jaques is center stage, spreading skepticism among the spirited lovers in Shakespeare's pastoral comedy, the sun comes out, at least in aesthetic terms. When he retreats to the fringes, clouds of mediocrity gather with alarming speed.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Tax Payments Sour Sibneft Profits
description: Sibneft, Russia's fifth-biggest oil producer, said profit fell 10 percent last year as income taxes more than quadrupled amid government demands for a larger share of oil companies' earnings. Consolidated 2004 net income fell to $2.05 billion, or 43.14 cents a share. Revenue rose 32 percent, to $8.89 billion. Sibneft, controlled by the billionaire Roman A. Abramovich, left, the owner of the Chelsea soccer club in Britain, paid more taxes after President Vladimir V. Putin demanded that businesses stop minimizing payments to the budget and tax collection tightened. The Yukos Oil Company takeover of Sibneft collapsed last year as the government levied $28 billion in tax claims against Yukos. Income-tax payments soared to $874.7 million, from $183.8 million, increasing the tax burden to 30 percent, from 7 percent, last year, the company said. Earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization rose 39 percent, to $3.24 billion.

title: Arts, Briefly; Stanching Harry Potter Leaks
description: J.K. Rowling has gone to court for a second time to try to prevent details of her new novel, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," from leaking. After 14 copies of the book were sold to customers at the Real Canadian Superstore in Coquitlam, British Columbia, the Canadian publisher, Raincoast Books, obtained a court order to have the copies returned. It also received an injunction prohibiting disclosure of any information from the novel before its scheduled release at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday. Jamie Broadhurst, a spokesman for Raincoast, said the company is "in conversations with a number of the customers" who bought the book, but he declined to say whether any had yet agreed to return their copies. Raincoast has offered to return the books to the customers at the time of the scheduled release along with a bookplate signed by the author and a T-shirt. Last month, a British court issued a similar injunction after two men were arrested and charged with trying to sell stolen copies to reporters at two newspapers in Britain.

title: A survivor's tale
Codey Signs Law to Restore Office of Public Advocate
description: TRENTON, July 12 - Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed a law on Tuesday to bring back New Jersey's Department of the Public Advocate, a move he billed as the latest in a series of steps to reform state government before he leaves office at the end of the year.

title: More Remains, Thought to Be Woman's, Emerge
description: More remains believed to be those of a Bronx woman were discovered in Queens yesterday, across the East River from where other parts were found in the Bronx last week, investigators said.

title: Fear of Flying
description: AS NASA prepares for its first space shuttle launching since the Columbia disaster, the question on everyone's lips is this one: Is the shuttle safe? My answer, as the former chairman of the NASA Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel, is that there is no such thing as safety. Spaceflight will always be risky. But that doesn't mean we shouldn't do it.

title: The Wages of Failure on Wall Street
description: Words like golden parachute hardly do justice to the stunning $32 million worth of a not-so-fond adieu engineered at Morgan Stanley, the troubled Wall Street securities giant, for its departing co-president, Stephen Crawford. Stockholders and employees are properly seething at the deal cut for Mr. Crawford -- after a mere three months on the job -- by a board that was oblivious to protecting the bank's reputation as it over-rewarded his fealty to Philip Purcell, the chief executive who was driven out in a messy power struggle last month.

description: ONE of the wonderful things about wine is its seemingly infinite capacity to surprise. Consider, for example, white Riojas.

description: When he was about 10, the actor Ed Harris wrote a poem about Mickey Mantle. On "Mantle," a documentary tonight on HBO, Mr. Harris abashedly recites a quatrain.

title: Blast Kills Up to 27 Iraqis, Including Many Children
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 13 - A suicide car bomb was detonated today near a group of American soldiers who were distributing candy to children in a poor neighborhood here, killing as many as 27 people, about two dozen of them children, and wounding dozens more, government and hospital officials said.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Police End Hunger Strike Rally
description: Police dispersed some 200 protesters who gathered outside Tehran University in downtown Tehran to demand the release of Akbar Ganji, a journalist who was jailed five years ago and has been on a hunger strike for 31 days, according to local news reports. Mr. Ganji has said he will continue his hunger strike until he is unconditionally released. Among the protesters was Hashem Aghajari, the professor who was sentenced to death in 2002 and was released last year. Nazila Fathi (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLOTZER, GEORGE
description: GLOTZER--George. Age 93. Died July 12, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Diana (Sorkin). Loving father of Sandy Wang (Michael) and Alan (Susan Miller); proud grandfather of Andy Wang (Karen), Kathy Seward (Duane), Emily, and Owen; adoring great grandfather of Lydia and Sophie Wang, and Zachary and Macy Seward; cherished uncle, cousin and friend. Loving, articulate and witty throughout his life. A private service was held on Cape Cod.

title: Big Weather
description: On the national weather maps yesterday, the remains of Hurricane Dennis looked like the print of an elephant's foot in red dust -- an isolated low-pressure system lingering in hot weather. The storm was centered squarely over the middle Mississippi River, where it promised to bring drenching rains. And late on Monday, a tropical depression in the Caribbean, Dennis's successor, was upgraded to a tropical storm, which means, among other things, that it gained a name: Emily. This is the fifth named storm this season -- more named storms by this time in the hurricane season than ever before. At last report, Emily was plunging westward toward Barbados at wind speeds still short of hurricane force.

title: Kazakh Ascends in Alps Stage, but Armstrong Not Worried
description: BRIANAON, France, July 13 - Lance Armstrong had priorities today in the Tour de France and Alexandre Vinokourov was not among them when he went on a long breakaway over two major mountains in the Alps nor when he won the daily stage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KREMENTZ, VIRGINIA
description: KREMENTZ--Virginia. Goodbye, darling, I will miss you terribly. Kitty Carlisle Hart KREMENTZ--Virginia Hyde. Died on July 12, 2005, at the age of 87, in New Vernon, New Jersey. The cause was brain cancer. Born on August 12, 1917, she grew up in Sagaponack and in Manhattan. She was a graduate of both Brearley and Miss Porter's School. She attended Juilliard School of Music and was for many years an accomplished concert harpist. She was predeceased by her husband, Walter M. Krementz, whose family founded Krementz Jewelry. The couple owned houses in Morristown, New Jersey, and in Paget, Bermuda. She was a member of The Coral Beach & Tennis Club in Bermuda and The Colony Club in NY. For almost two decades, in the 60's and 70's, Virginia Krementz ran her own very successful fashion business in New York City. Operating out of a showroom in The Wyndham Hotel, she represented a group of wellregarded foreign fashion designers that included Simonetta (Italy), Strelitz (Ireland) and Polly Hornburg (Bermuda). In 1973, she coproduced a film with Doubleday Multimedia, "There is an Addict in the House," which won numerous awards and was, she felt, her proudest achievement. A passionate volunteer and a woman of tireless energy, Mrs. Krementz taught Sunday School for over twenty years. She tutored children in after-school programs for The Kips Bay Boys Club in lower Manhattan, and worked at Memorial Sloan-Kettering in the pediatric ward. Widowed in 1992, she moved to Vero Beach, Florida, and was an active member of the Oak Harbor Club, where she participated in, and won, many bridge tournaments. In Vero, she mentored at the Beachland Elementary School and did volunteer work for The Riverside Theater at the Center for the Arts. She is survived by her three children, Jill Krementz, Christie Graham, and Tony Kent; her two sons-in-law, the novelist Kurt Vonnegut, and Campbell Luke Graham, a VP of Richard Krementz Gemstones; and by her eight beloved grandchildren: Jessica, Jason, Tara, & Justin Kent; Ian, Eric, & Paget Graham; and Lily Vonnegut. A son, Wick Krementz, died in 1969. In lieu of flowers please send donations to The Riverside Theater, 3250 Riverside Park Drive, Vero Beach, Fl. 32963. KREMENTZ--Virginia. Anything good assumes the personalities of those who love it. Riverside Theatre is richer for that part of Ginny that lives on in us. Chuck Still, Exec. Director KREMENTZ--Virginia. She had what the Nuns in school called a smart mouth. The older she got, the smarter and wiser it got. Good-bye Aunt Gini, miss you forever. David Billings

title: Pro-Syria Official Survives Latest Lebanon Car Bombing
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 12 - Lebanon's departing pro-Syria defense minister escaped an assassination attempt with minor injuries on Tuesday in a car bombing that killed at least two people and wounded a dozen in a Christian suburb north of Beirut.

title: In a Logging War in Mexico, Forests' Peasant Defenders Are Besieged
description: ZIHUATANEJO, Mexico, July 12 - Felipe Arreaga, a farmer-turned-environmentalist, has been sitting in a cramped, squalid jail here for eight months, charged with murdering the son of his nemesis, a wealthy landowner who brokered the sale of much of the lumber in the nearby mountains.

Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISHAKER, DOROTHY
description: FLEISHAKER--Dorothy. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dorothy Fleishaker, beloved wife of Donald Fleishaker. The Fleishakers' commitment and devotion to the Jewish community has made an indelible mark on millions of lives in New York, in Israel, and around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to Donald; to their children, Aaron, Abbe, Rhoda, and Sandra; to their grandchildren; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. FLEISHAKER -- Dorothy L. Passed away July 11. Beloved wife of Donald; loving mother of Sandy and Tim Wuliger, Rhoda and Craig Smolow, Abbe Fleishaker, and Sheryl and Aaron Fleishaker. Proud grandmother of 11 wonderful grandchildren. Funeral services at Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, New York, at 10 A.M., July 13, 2005.

title: Italian cyclist arrested after doping products found in wife's car
Lord King, Who Remade British Airways, Dies at 87
description: Lord King, a tough-minded executive who in 1981 took over British Airways when its initials were said to signify "bloody awful," and turned it into a sleek, profitable airline attractive enough to draw throngs of public investors when it was privatized six years later, died yesterday at his estate in Leicestershire. He was 87.

title: N.H.L. and Players Reach Deal to End Lockout
description: More than 300 days after the beginning of a lockout that led to the cancellation of the 2004-05 season, the National Hockey League and the N.H.L. Players Association said today that they had agreed in principle on a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: Southeast Asia's war on corruption
Three Lost Girls Who Just Said Yes Instead of No
description: As the Statue of Liberty shimmers in the distance like a ghostly sentinel in "On the Outs," its image of promise seems to belong to a country apart from the mean streets of Jersey City, where the lives of three desperate teenage girls unravel. The docudrama, which opens today in New York, is certainly not the first film to show how a crushing urban environment can make a sensible-sounding antidrug slogan like "just say no" seem like so much nonsense, but it's one of the strongest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about competing theories on whether the statute of limitations would apply in the case of two retired New York detectives accused as paid assassins for organized crime referred erroneously to a comment by Edward Hayes, a lawyer for one defendant, Stephen Caracappa, about the British diplomat Kim Philby, who spied for the Soviets. Mr. Hayes said that if the allegations against his client were true, Mr. Caracappa's actions would be a betrayal much like Mr. Philby's; he did not say that Mr. Philby had been wrongly accused.

title: Icebox Cake Needs No Updating
description: To the Editor:

title: Sharp Rise in IPod Sales Drives Apple's Profit to $320 Million
description: Apple Computer said today that third-quarter profits more than quintupled, to $320 million, driven largely by roaring sales of its popular iPod music player.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOUGH, MARY E.
description: HOUGH--Mary E., on July 10, 2005, formerly of the Bronx. Born in Boyle, County Roscommon, Ireland. Beloved mother of Patricia Murphy of Vero Beach, FL and Mary Agnes O'Callaghan of Stewart, FL. Dear sister of Patricia Purcell of Ireland. Funeral Mass will be held Friday, 10 am, at Sacred Heart Chapel in Sparkill, NY with burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. Visiting hours Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Moritz Funeral Home, 98 Route 303, Tappan, NY.

title: World Briefing: Americas; Africa; Europe; Asia; Middle East
description: AMERICAS

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Village Raids Kill At Least 19
description: Armed raiders attacked two villages in northern Kenya, resulting in at least 19 deaths and dozens of injuries, authorities said. Children were wounded in what the police described as ethnic clashes between two feuding communities near Kenya's northern border with Ethiopia. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about DreamWorks Animation's reduction in its earnings forecast misidentified an analyst who commented on the company's plan to delay a stock offering and on the slowdown in DVD sales. He was Alan Gould of Natexis Bleichroeder. (Lowell Singer of S.G. Cowen & Company is another analyst who follows DreamWorks.)

title: Korean advance
From Russia, With Retribution
description: In February 2004, President Vladimir Putin fired Mikhail Kasyanov as Russia's prime minister. A year later, Mr. Kasyanov said Russia had taken a "wrong turn" and hinted that he might run for president in 2008. On Monday, the prosecutor-general's office said it was investigating whether Mr. Kasyanov had illegally obtained a government-owned house when he was prime minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACKWELL, EDWARD S., JR.
description: BLACKWELL -- Edward S., Jr., of Basking Ridge, NJ, formerly of Dorset, VT, Short Hills, NJ and Point O'Woods, NY, on July 9, 2005 at the age of 94. A graduate of Williams College 1933 and Harvard Law School, he had a distinguished career in commercial insurance brokerage. He is survived by his wife, Elsie Wilson, to whom he was married for 71 years, and his children, Janet Bent, Edward S. Blackwell III, Marion Meserole, their spouses, nine grandchildren and nine greatgrandchildren. Memorial service at a later date to be announced. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations to The Church at Point O'Woods, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Pitt Checks Into Hospital Brad Pitt, right, was hospitalized yesterday in the Los Angeles area after complaining of flulike symptoms. "I think he has the flu," said Cindy Guagenti, his publicity representative. She said that he checked himself in and that it was not known if he contracted the illness while with Angelina Jolie last week in Africa, where she adopted a baby girl. Mr. Pitt, 41, starred with Ms. Jolie in "Mr. and Mrs. Smith" and has been her companion recently.

title: Why Is the White House Silent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Is the White House Silent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FINKEL, STEVEN L.
description: FINKEL--Steven L. 7/13/95 Your love is within us always. Mom, Dad, Aaron, Richard and Vicki

title: Funds Will Be There When Technology Is, M.T.A. Chief Says
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority acknowledged yesterday that the agency had been slow to spend more than $600 million budgeted for counterterrorism efforts, but he maintained that a lack of reliable technologies had made it difficult to determine how best to defend the transit network against a potential attack.

title: Kentucky Racing Official Says State Ignored Drug Results
description: When Ernie Fletcher became the governor of Kentucky in late 2003, he sought to clean up its image as a state where the use of drugs, illegal and legal, in horse racing was out of control. The Kentucky Horse Racing Authority was established.

title: Kicks, Cheers and Tears at a Dance Gala Finale
description: On Monday night, just before the trumpets heralded the start of the final gala of the New York City Dance Alliance's national championship, the girls of the Dance Club of Orem, Utah, were bending themselves into funny groups, hips high, smiles stretched, as Allison Thornton, their teacher, snapped a dozen cameras in turn. It was a giggly beginning to the end of the nine-day competition, which -- part sleepover party, part "American Idol" -- had drawn 1,500 young dancers eager to test themselves on a New York stage.

title: A Higher View of What's Italian
description: AT L'Impero, the chef Scott Conant set out to elevate this city's ideas about Italian cooking, so often regarded and approached in a more rustic, robust fashion. At Alto, he tries to lift them all the way into the stratosphere.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Car Dealer Sent To Jail
description: Richard Gidron, a Bronx car dealer and former chairman of the Bronx County Democratic Committee, was sent to jail yesterday for violating parole from his 2002 conviction for tax fraud. The Manhattan district attorney's office said that Mr. Gidron, left, failed to pay more than $800,000 in sales tax collected since August 2003 at Gidron Cadillac Oldsmobile, his dealership in Yonkers. The district attorney's office also said that Mr. Gidron failed to repay several bank loans on cars traded in from February to May 2004. A sentencing hearing is scheduled on Tuesday. Alan Feuer (NYT)

title: Doing Deals While Wary of Bubbles
description: It was only last year that the Bank of America Center, long the dominant building in San Francisco's financial district, was sold to a group of New York investors for an impressive $825 million. Now the 52-story reddish-brown granite tower is said to be going on the market again. This time, the sellers are hoping that the price will reach as high as $1.25 billion.

title: She's Got Stacks of Chips, and an Eye on the Finals
description: LAS VEGAS, July 12 - Nani Dollison was stacking a color kaleidoscope of chips, which eventually added up to $448,500. She knew a woman had never won the main event of the World Series of Poker, and only one had ever made the final table in its 35-year history. She nodded to the lines forming at the bathrooms by way of explanation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FURLONG, PADRIC F.X. ''PAT''
description: FURLONG--Padric F.X. "Pat" of Duxbury, MA., formerly of Garden City and Brooklyn, NY on July 10, 2005. Born December 29, 1927 to John L. Furlong and Alice. Loving husband of Mary and father of Brenda, Padraic (Sandra) of Manhasset, Myles (Jan), Edmond (Carolyn) and Matthew (Maria). Brother of Alice, Daniel (Maureen), Maryann (Ed), Christopher (Angela) and the late John L. Furlong, Jr. (Louise). Proud grandfather of 12. US Army, St. John's Univ. Employed by Abraham and Straus from 1947-1976, Helmsley Spear, Bradlees, Almy's and B.J.'s Wholesale. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Thursday 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 12PM, St. Francis of Assisi Church, Bklyn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHINE, JACOB DAVID
description: SHINE--Jacob David. On July 10, 2005. CPA. Beloved husband of Sylvia for 65 years. Loving father of Carol Horemis and her husband Spyros, and Joseph Shine Sr. and his wife Stephanie. Devoted grandfather of Joseph Shine Jr. and his wife Kelly and Vincent Shine. Ecstatic great grandfather of Karissa and Ricky. Devoted brother of Edith Picker and the late Saul Shine, Esther Shine and Lilly Shine. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 14920 Northern Blvd, Flushing.

title: Bachelor prince takes throne of Monaco
Paid Notice: Deaths   SOBEL, MICHELLE
description: SOBEL--Michelle. A Memorial Service will be held for Michelle Sobel, beloved wife, friend, and devoted educator on Wednesday, July 20, 7 PM at Kneses Tifereh Israel, 575 King St, Port Chester, NY.

title: Questions for Pope on Evolution Stance
description: Three scientists, two of them Roman Catholic biologists, have asked Pope Benedict XVI to clarify the church's position on evolution in light of recent statements by Cardinal Christoph Schnborn, an influential theologian, that the modern theory of evolution may be incompatible with Catholic faith.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Charged In Wife's Death Denied Bail
description: An Upper East Side man whom prosecutors have charged with murder in the stabbing death of his wife was ordered held without bail yesterday by a State Supreme Court judge. The man, Ben Odierno, 70, has been held since April 24, when the police found his wife, Christine, 57, dead of multiple knife wounds on the kitchen floor of the couple's East 84th Street town house. Mr. Odierno was at her side, attempting to stab himself. His lawyer, Jack T. Litman, who said that Mr. Odierno killed his wife in self-defense, requested bail of $1.5 million. Justice Gregory Carro, however, rejected the idea of bail, saying the coroner's report "doesn't bode well for a self-defense claim." Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

title: North Korea gets incentive to talk
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judges Hearing Appeal of Quattrone Conviction Raise Concerns About Fairness at Trial A panel of federal appeals court judges indicated that they had reservations about a jury's decision to convict Frank P. Quattrone, the former investment banker, of obstruction of justice. During a hearing in the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan, the three judges expressed concerns about whether the behavior of the prosecutor and the judge's jury instructions may have unfairly affected its outcome. [C1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISS, BYRON
description: PREISS--Byron. A wonderful presence, full of love for family and friends. Sandi, Karah and Blaire, our hearts are with you. Families and Friends, Class of 2007 Trevor Day School

title: Israel Seals Off Palestinian Territories
description: TULKARM, West Bank, July 13 - Israel sealed off the Palestinian territories, reoccupied the West Bank town of Tulkarm and declared the Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip a closed military zone in an energetic response today to a Palestinian suicide bombing on Tuesday that killed four Israeli women.

title: Sharp Rise in Tax Revenue to Pare U.S. Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 - For the first time since President Bush took office, an unexpected leap in tax revenue is about to shrink the federal budget deficit this year, by nearly $100 billion.

title: The Cardinal's View Of Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (FX) 30 DAYS "Off the Grid." Tonight two 30-year-olds leave their technology- dependent lives to spend a month without modern conveniences at an eco-village in Missouri. Johari Jenkins and Vito Summa (above) live in a converted grain bin, take solar-heated showers and grow their own food. In real life, she's an events coordinator and D.J. from Jersey City, and he's a bouncer from the Bronx.

title: The Girl Who Dares to Be One of the Boys
description: MICHELLE WIE is a pure teenager, interested in perfecting her parallel-parking skills, spending her monthly allowance and dismissing her annoying critics with responses that sound like polished versions of the disdainful "whatever."

title: In a Neighborhood in Leeds, Tolerance Tempers the Hard Economic Times
description: LEEDS, England, July 12 - Jodie Reynolds said her neighbor, now a suspect in the London bombings, always loved one song above all: Elvis Presley's version of the Eddy Arnold song "Make the World Go Away." News that the young man, whose identity had not been confirmed by the police on Tuesday evening but whose name was circulating in the British news media, was implicated in the bombings quickly filtered through Beeston, a working-class community on the outskirts of Leeds.

title: Ebbers Sentencing to Proceed as Judge Denies Plea for Retrial
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former WorldCom chief executive convicted of orchestrating the largest corporate fraud in United States history, had his bid for a retrial shot down by a federal judge yesterday, setting the stage for his sentencing today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, JACK
description: EPSTEIN--Jack, on July 11, 2005. Beloved uncle of Susan Tofel and George Hecht. Widower of Ruth Gutman, sculptor. Born in Pikesville, MD. A graduate of the Friends School in Baltimore and of Babson College in 1929. Jack resided in New York City for more than 50 years. He headed the New York Metropolitan Section of Parents Magazine. A veteran of World War II, he was a member of the Navy League, the Board of Trustees of The Elder Craftsmen, The Lambs Club, Artists - Equity and Temple Emanuel. He served as president of the B'nai B'rith Advertising Lodge and as Vice President of the Babson College New York Alumni Association, Long Island Advertising Club, New York Advertising Club, New York Advertising and Communication Club and the Philo Music Society. He directed the advertising and marketing curriculum of the Advertising Club of New York and was a big brother with the Jewish Board of Guardians. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell--The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue on Friday, July 15, at 10:30 AM.

title: Meanwhile:They could have sworn it was Putin's daughter
Keeper of Expired Web Pages Is Sued Because Archive Was Used in Another Suit
description: The Internet Archive was created in 1996 as the institutional memory of the online world, storing snapshots of ever-changing Web sites and collecting other multimedia artifacts. Now the nonprofit archive is on the defensive in a legal case that represents a strange turn in the debate over copyrights in the digital age.

title: A passage from India
Town Uses Trespass Law to Fight Illegal Immigrants
description: JAFFREY, N.H., July 12 - One day in April, Jorge Mora Ramrez stopped his car on the side of a road in the small southern New Hampshire town of New Ipswich and was making a cellphone call when a police officer approached him.

title: Indonesian acquittal has shades of the past
Vantage Point: For soccer's stars, check is reality
Standouts in a crowded market
Among Janitors, Labor Violations Go With the Job
description: LOS ANGELES - From the age of 14, Isaias Garcia cleaned office buildings, waxing floors and scrubbing bathrooms, as long as 16 hours a day.

title: Unocal Bid Opens Up New Issues of Security
description: The fate of the China National Offshore Oil Corporation's bid for Unocal remains uncertain, but one thing is clear. The takeover offer has prompted a gathering groundswell in Congress to make sure oil is defined as a product vital to America's national security.

title: Civil Liberties in Europe: A Look at the Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Editor's Note
description: An article on Sunday about the coming mayoral election in Detroit reported that the campaigning shows the contrasting styles of Mayor Kwame Kilpatrick and his predecessor, Dennis Archer, whose former deputy and chief of staff, Freman Hendrix, is challenging Mr. Kilpatrick. The article included an interview with Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Alphonso R. Jackson, who praised Mr. Kilpatrick and expressed frustration at dealings with the Archer administration, including a man he identified as Mr. Archer's chief of staff. The Times asked if the chief of staff was Mr. Hendrix, and Mr. Jackson said yes.

title: Study Great Ideas, but Teach to the Test
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich. - BECKY KARNES, a high school English teacher, recently completed a graduate-level writing course that she loved at Grand Valley State University.

title: Edna Lewis's Friends and Family
description: To the Editor: Many things distressed me about the article featuring Scott Peacock and mentioning Edna Lewis ("Chicken on the Plate, Family on the Side," July 6), the headline among them. I am a longtime friend of Miss Lewis and her family. The headline does a disservice to her relationship with her loving family, who want her to be allowed to return to them in Virginia. I know firsthand that before her last "decline," she had expressed the desire to return to Virginia and to her family.

title: By the Sea, By the Sea, By the Beautiful Sea
description: Lincoln Center Festival 2005 opened with a mighty wave of movement and motion on Tuesday night in the Rose Theater in the Frederick P. Rose Hall of Jazz at Lincoln Center. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company revived "Ocean," one of the successes of the first Lincoln Center Festival in 1996, but not seen in New York since then.

title: The Church and evolution, After Gaza, Jailing journalists
Paid Notice: Deaths   LAVIALE, ELAINE
description: LaVIALE--Elaine. On July 11 in her hundredth year. Formerly of NYC, late of Sherman, CT. Devoted wife of the late Roger LaViale; adored mother of the late Roger LaViale Jr. Survived by daughters Colette (Mrs. Charles W.) Russell and Yvonne LaViale, both of Manhattan. Loving grandmother of eight; great grandmother of eleven; and great-great grandmother of one. Visitation July 14, 910:30AM, Horn & Thomes Funeral Home, Pawling, NY (845-855-3550). Funeral 11AM, Christ Church, Quaker Hill, Pawling NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Christ Church in memory of Mrs. LaViale.

title: Crackdown in Uzbekistan Reopens Longstanding Debate on U.S. Military Aid
description: Correction Appended

title: HBO Sports Steps Up to the Plate With 'Mantle'
description: Two years ago, George Roy began suggesting to HBO Sports that he make a documentary about Mickey Mantle. The 10th anniversary of Mantle's death in 1995 was coming, and Mantle was an ideal subject for HBO: a brilliant, haunted ballplayer on a great team whose life spiraled out of control, but whose recovery from alcohol abuse and an unsuccessful fight against liver cancer created the perfect story arc of a fallen sports hero.

title: Let's Picnic, And We'll Bring The Pie
description: This double-decker basket makes it easy to pack up a fruit pie or cake to take to a picnic or along on a weekend visit. Put the pie on the wooden rack and tuck plates, forks and napkins or even a plate of hors d'oeuvres under it. The canvas liner is washable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   YANG, VON SUNG
description: YANG--Von Sung. China Institute in America sends its deepest condolences to the family of former Trustee Von Sung Yang who dedicated many generous years of service and leadership to China Institute.

title: $478 Million U.S. Grant for Trade Center Security
description: Offering a rare glimpse of the magnitude of security spending on the new World Trade Center, the Federal Transit Administration announced a grant of nearly half a billion dollars yesterday for an underground vehicle screening center at the site.

title: Recipe: Jerk Spice Rub
description: Time: 5 minutes

title: Bush to Hold Comments on Rove During Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - President Bush parried questions about Karl Rove today, insisting that he will not comment about his trusted adviser until the conclusion of an investigation into the unmasking of a C.I.A. operative.

title: Dictionaries Are Set Aside in Patent Suits
description: Inventors, not dictionaries, get to define the terms in patents involved in lawsuits, a federal appeals court said in a ruling that sets guidelines for judges on how to interpret patents.

title: An Oil Importer Struggles to Keep Growing
description: BANGKOK, July 12 - Backed into a corner by rising oil price rises and falling economic growth, the Thai government announced measures Tuesday aimed at propping up consumer confidence and curbing fuel consumption.

title: Spitzer Urges Support of Transportation Bond Act
description: ALBANY, July 12 - Dipping into a state policy debate, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer urged state leaders on Tuesday to work together to promote a $2.9 billion transportation bond act that will go before voters in November.

title: Who Has Bloomberg's Number? Anybody With a Phone Book
description: Forget 311.

title: Colin Powell Joins Venture Capital Firm
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 - Most everyone you meet in Silicon Valley, or so it sometimes seems, dreams of joining a top venture capital firm, a job that brings prestige and the power to finance promising start-ups -- and, not incidentally, typically pays in the millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JUST, HAL
description: JUST--Hal. Saddened by the death of Hal Just, extraordinary illustrator and great personal friend. He will be missed. Heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife Judi, his daughters Riki, Layne and his son-in-law Luis. Anita Grien & Julius Medwin

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Trade Center Cleanup Review Planned
description: A plan to test for slag wool, a type of insulating material used in the World Trade Center, as evidence that dust from the center is still present in Lower Manhattan and Brooklyn will undergo a scientific peer review in the next several weeks, despite strong opposition from people who live and work in the buildings to be tested. Under the plan, 150 buildings would be checked for traces of slag wool to determine the extent of any future cleanup. E.Timothy Oppelt, interim chairman of the technical panel of experts advising the federal Environmental Protection Agency, defended the proposal and said it would be thoroughly reviewed by other independent experts. At the panel's hearing in Manhattan yesterday, residents and workers called the plan inadequate and scientifically unsound. In 2002, the federal agency oversaw the cleanup of 4,100 apartments, but there are concerns that those residences may have been re-contaminated, and that others that were never cleaned may pose a health hazard. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: 'Americans with you,' Bush assures Britons
Recipe: Hot-and-Sour Slaw With Five-Spice Jerk Chicken
description: Time: 1 hour 15 minutes, plus 1A12 hours to 24 hours for marinating

title: In Firehouse, Fastest Way Down Is on Its Way Out
description: Of all the tools associated with the dangerous but sometimes romantic world of firefighting, few capture the spirit of the job quite like the shiny firehouse pole, that simple brass delivery system that relies on little more than gravity to get a fireman to his truck a few seconds faster.

title: France offers subsidies to keep reseach groups at home
Briton and Austrian workers kidnapped in Gaza Strip
National Briefing
description: ROCKIES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CARR, MILDRED S.
description: CARR--Mildred S. On July 9, 2005, at age 95. Beloved wife of the late Frank Edward Carr. Loving mother of Dr. Ronald (Nancy) Carr and Richard (Diana) Carr. Adored grandmother of Peter (Rebecca), Jacqueline (Richard Lonoff), Timothy (Whitney) Carr and great grandmother of Peter, Lucy, Hannah, Emily, Benjamin, Alexandra and Caroline. Interment private. Memorial Service at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St., Thursday, July 14th, 4 P.M. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Volunteer Referral Center, 161 Madison Ave., Suite 5SW, New York, New York 10016.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Costa Rica: Fire Grips Hospital
description: At least 18 people died when a fire engulfed the top floors of the Caldern Guardia Hospital in San Jos, Costa Rica's capital. The fire broke out at 2:20 p.m. on the fifth floor and consumed three floors above before being controlled three hours later. It was the second fire this year at the 62-year-old institution, whose fire exits and sprinkler system are antiquated. President Abel Pacheco declared three days of national mourning. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Renovation of the Plaza Hotel Clears a Hurdle
description: Renovations at the Plaza Hotel will restore it to its original grandeur, city landmarks officials said yesterday after they cleared the way for vast changes, including converting hotel rooms to condominiums and adding an underground complex of luxury stores.

title: To Your Health, From the Amazon
description: Aa (pronounced ah-sigh-EE), a palm berry from the rainforests of Brazil, comes with an impressive rsum: about three ounces contains plenty of vitamin C, vitamin A, omega-6 and omega-9 fatty acids, and is high in antioxidants. It is harvested by local workers and helps sustain the rainforest. The indigo-purple fruit has the flavor of blueberries with a slightly tannic aftertaste that suggests bitter chocolate. It is sold as a frozen pure with guaran extract (from a tropical seed).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, LINDA
description: MILLER--Linda. On July 12, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Herman Miller. Devoted mother of Robert Miller and Rochelle Miller. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Michael, Melissa, Jason and Danielle. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Wednesday 7:00-9:00 P.M. and Thursday 2:00-5:00 P.M., 7:009:00 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Friday, 12:30 at Frank E. Campbell. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, NY.

title: British Police Search for Mastermind of Blasts
description: LONDON, July 13 - Britain said today that it was hunting the mastermind of the terror attacks here last week, and the British Home Secretary offered the first official indication that officials believe the four attackers were suicide bombers who "blew themselves up" in the blasts.

title: The Revolt of Israel's Center
description: Gush Katif, the Israeli settlement bloc in the heart of the Gaza Strip, is an unusual place -- a bizarre combination of "Fiddler on the Roof" and Club Med, barbed wire and dune buggies, surfers and settlers, all surrounded by over one million Palestinians. In the last year, though, the resurgent Israeli center, the most important political force in the Arab-Israeli conflict today, concluded that this Jewish outpost was a bridge too far, and the Army has been ordered to uproot its settlers as part of a general withdrawal from Gaza.

title: U.S. lifts travel ban for London
Building in Iceland? Better Clear It With the Elves First
description: HAFNARFJORDUR, Iceland - Do elves exist? Like many Icelanders, Hildur Hakonardottir considers the question to be more complicated than it appears.

title: Farm aid in focus at trade talks
Suicide Bomber and 2 Women Die in Attack at Mall in Israeli Town
description: NETANYA, Israel, July 12 - A Palestinian suicide bomber set off his explosives Tuesday evening at a busy intersection outside a shopping mall here, killing himself and two women and wounding more than 50 people, the Israeli police said.

title: Arts, Briefly; Dim Debut for 'Rock Star'
description: Fifteen performers began competing on Monday to be the new lead singer of INXS on the premiere of CBS's "Rock Star: INXS." Dana Robbins, above, whose biography on the CBS Web site lists her current and former jobs as a yoga instructor and adult film actress, was the first contestant to be eliminated. She made the judges uncomfortable during her rendition of Bob Dylan's "Knockin' on Heaven's Door." The series, which is scheduled to be broadcast three times a week, drew only 5.62 million viewers for the first episode, according to Nielsen's estimates, putting it in fourth place for the 9 p.m. hour. Because of CBS's strength in the other time periods -- with repeats of "Everybody Loves Raymond," "Two and a Half Men" and "CSI: Miami" -- the network was No. 1 in Nielsen's estimates of total viewers and households. But Fox easily won the among 18-to-49-year-olds with back-to-back episodes of "Hell's Kitchen." KATE AURTHUR

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the fatal shooting of Richard Charles, a college student, by two gunmen in Queens referred incorrectly in some copies to family members' account. They said Mr. Charles and a cousin had been returning from a visit to their grandmother, but did not say that the men separated at Merrick Boulevard when the gunmen approached. (The police said the cousin was able to outrun the attackers and escape.)

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the disappearance of a Greenwich, Conn., man from a cruise ship in the Mediterranean referred incompletely to the first news reports of it. While Greenwich Time covered the disappearance on Thursday, a local cable station, News 12, reported it on Wednesday night.

title: At NASA, Another High-Stakes Comeback Mission
description: After the first American spacecraft disaster, a launching pad fire in 1967, Thomas J. O'Malley remembers arriving back at Cape Canaveral, Fla., as a contract engineer called on to shake things up. "I walked into the worst mess that I ever saw in my life," he said.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVENE, RICKY
description: LEVENE--Ricky. So dearly loved, so deeply missed, so much too soon. Our constant love, Mom and your family.

title: An Athletic World of Surf and Turf and Tortured Lovers
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STRUM, ELIAS
description: STRUM--Elias. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Elias Strum, beloved husband of Elaine Verschleiser Strum and stepfather of Jeffrey Verschleiser, treasured friends and leaders of the N.Y. Jewish community. The Strum and Verschleiser families' generosity and commitment, demonstrated through Jeffrey's dedicated leadership in our Wall Street Division and Amy Verschleiser's devoted service to our Women's Campaign, has enabled us to enrich Jewish life and learning worldwide, profoundly impacting millions of lives. We extend our deepest sympathies to Elaine; to Jeffrey and his wife, Amy; to Harold Verschleiser and Joy Pearl; to Nina Weinstein and Jeffrey Strum; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O. STRUM--Elias. The AntiDefamation League mourn the passing of Elias Strum, a member of our National Commission. Eli was a longtime ADL supporter and activist. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife Elaine and the entire family. Barbara B. Balser National Chair Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: 3 Trains Collide in Pakistan, Killing 123
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 13 - Three commuter trains rammed into one another this morning in Southern Pakistan, leaving at least 123 dead and 170 injured, railway and police officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINTO, CONNIE (SKLAR)

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Plan for New Oil Sands Project
description: Imperial Oil filed an application with regulators in Alberta to build an oil sands mine project valued at 4.5 billion to 6.5 billion Canadian dollars. The Kearl Oil Sands project, a joint venture between Imperial, which is almost 70 percent owned by Exxon Mobil, and Exxon Mobil Canada, would produce 100,000 barrels of raw bitumen, the tar that emerges from processed oil sands ore, within five years if approved. According to the filings, that figure would eventually increase to 300,000 barrels a day. At the moment, Imperial's plans do not include an upgrader to turn the bitumen into oil. The project must be approved by the Alberta Energy and Utilities Board as well as the province's ministry of the environment. The mine would be built near the Northeastern Alberta community of Fort McMurray.

title: Allure of Hedge Funds Is Waning for Investors
description: THE party may be winding down.

title: Europeans Step Up Investigation Into Intel
description: BRUSSELS, July 12 - The European Commission turned up the heat in its antitrust inquiry into Intel on Tuesday, conducting unannounced visits to company offices around Europe, a commission spokesman said.

title: Lawsuits Charge Fraud in Cleaning Business
description: Joo Padilha had been saving money from his work as a restaurant deliveryman outside Boston when he heard a tantalizing offer to buy a cleaning franchise.

title: An Artist and Dealer and the Women She Promoted
description: The dealer and artist Betty Parsons (1900-82) is in the history books for shaping the careers of some of the biggest of postwar American art's big boys. Jackson Pollock, Barnett Newman and Mark Rothko were on her list. Less celebrated is the attention she paid to artists who happened to be women, at a time when a woman was far more likely to earn a reputation as so-and-so's girlfriend than for having an art career.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULNER, LAWRENCE
description: SCHULNER--Lawrence. The Union for Reform Judaism mourns with deep sorrow the passing of Lawrence Schulner, of Agoura, CA, a member of its Board of Trustees since 2002. In a variety of roles, Mr. Schulner served the Union with great devotion. We extend deepest condolences to his entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem and may his memory be for a blessing. Robert M. Heller, Chairman Rabbi Eric H. Yoffie, Pres

title: The A.L. Has It All, Especially the Victory
description: DETROIT, July 12 - The flashbulbs, the fireworks and the noise that filled Comerica Park for the All-Star Game had mostly dissipated by the fifth inning Tuesday night. Half the game still remained, but the ballpark was quiet, the attitude was subdued and the outcome was barely in doubt.

description: A MONTH after winning a battle with management, the corporate investor Vincent Bollor has consolidated his control of Havas, the French agency company.

description: COURCHEVEL, France, July 12 - Lance Armstrong used the first mountain stage in the Tour de France on Tuesday to regain the yellow jersey of the race's leader and open a lead of nearly three minutes over all his major rivals but one.

She will live on forever in the hearts of her husband, Gordon; her sons Richard and Gary; her daughter-in-law Carol; her grandchildren Nicole and Hannah; her large extended family and her many friends, all of who loved and treasured her. Funeral service July 13, 12:00 noon at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Rd., Rockville Centre, NY.

There is even value in the sanctioned leak, such as when the White House, say, lets out information that it wants known but does not want to announce.

description: TRENTON, July 12 - Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey on Tuesday indefinitely postponed the implementation of a controversial law that speeds permits for developers.

title: Arts, Briefly; 75 Candles On Dagwood's Sandwich?
description: In September, the comic strip "Blondie" will turn 75. To commemorate the anniversary, Dean Young, 66, the strip's writer, has embarked on a three-month plotline. (Mr. Young took over the strip in 1973, after the death of his father, Chic Young, who created it.) The story, which began on Sunday, follows Blondie and Dagwood as they plan their wedding anniversary. The party's special guests are a veritable who's who of comic strip stars, and they will make appearances in "Blondie," up to and including the big celebration. Readers can expect to see Beetle Bailey, Hagar the Horrible, Mother Goose and Grimm, Marvin, Dilbert, Dennis the Menace, Dick Tracy and more. Characters from "For Better or Worse," "B.C." and "The Family Circus" will also be included. Additionally, many of the guest stars' own strips will include references to the anniversary party. "Blondie," first published on Sept. 8, 1930, is syndicated by King Features to more than 2,300 newspapers and is translated into more than 35 languages. The anniversary party, a color Sunday display with appearances by all the guest stars, will run on Sept. 4. GEORGE GENE GUSTINES

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISEN, ALBERT
description: EISEN--Albert. On July 11, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Claire. Loving father of Jane and Vitka. Dear brother of Edward. Cherished grandfather of David, Chloe and Patima. Services Wednesday 11:15 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: In First of Many Vioxx Cases, a Texas Widow Prepares to Take the Stand
description: HOUSTON, July 12 - Carol Ernst's sadness is evident when she speaks of her husband. Ms. Ernst, 60, is the widow of Robert Ernst, who died in his bed on May 6, 2001, in Keene, Tex., a town about 25 miles south of Fort Worth. On Thursday, opening arguments will begin in a lawsuit she and Mr. Ernst's two children have brought against Merck, the giant drug maker, claiming that Merck's painkiller Vioxx caused Mr. Ernst's heart to stop.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Age 92. Of Boca Raton, FL, and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. In his early 20's, Irving played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud selfmade man. Interred at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Mayor Criticizes Police Recruits' Pay Cut
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, speaking at a news conference after a swearing-in of new officers, accused police union officials yesterday of making it harder to attract new officers by favoring a reduction in pay for recruits rather than savings in salary or benefits for veteran members of the force. Departing from the conciliatory tone he adopted after an arbitrator's ruling that lowered starting pay for recruits while granting increases to current officers, Mr. Bloomberg said the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association had rejected proposals that did not target rookies. Al O'Leary, a union spokesman, denied that the pay cut for recruits was the union's idea. "It was something the city came up with," he said. "It was forced on us." Edward Skyler, the mayor's communications director, said the city had tried to avoid the cut, to no avail. Mike McIntire (NYT)

title: To Eat In Laos
description: FROM my seat at an outdoor table at the Caf Ban Vat Sene I had a privileged view of the afternoon's civic unrest. The traffic on the main street of Luang Prabang, Laos's third-largest city (population 16,000 at its core), had come to a halt. Poised nose to nose in the avenue were a large dog and a bellicose lizard. Children gathered to watch. I clutched a glass of Lao beer as the dog growled and lunged and the lizard leapt at the dog's snout. When the dog finally began to get the upper hand, the lizard wisely high-tailed it into a bush. The traffic resumed its customary slow pace and I resumed drinking my beer, which, like most food and drink in this town, tasted mighty fine.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORDON, GEORGE
description: GORDON--George, age 91, on July 9, 2005. Husband of the late Elsie Wexler Gordon. Father of Judith and Henry. Grandfather of Jason and Evan Brown, Lily, Paul and Maya Gordon. Graduate of Columbia Law School, he had a 45-year career with West Publishing Co. as an editor of Corpus Juris Secundum. Longtime resident of Roslyn, NY, he had vacation homes in Mahopac, NY and Delray Beach, FL. He loved reading, walking and tennis.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Two Admit Bias Attack
description: Two Queens men pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that they beat a man because they thought he was a Satanist, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. The men, Paul Rotondi, 18, of Howard Beach, and Frank Scarpinito, 18, of Middle Village, admitted they attacked Daniel Romano, 20, with a metal pipe and an ice scraper on Jan. 9 in Middle Village. Prosecutors said the two shouted "Hey, Satan" before attacking Mr. Romano, who had dyed his hair blue and was wearing an upside-down crucifix. The two men will be sentenced to probation and community service, over the objection of prosecutors who had asked for three years of imprisonment, Mr. Brown said.

title: Toronto-Dominion to Acquire Bank Based in New Jersey
description: Toronto-Dominion Bank, one of Canada's largest financial institutions, said yesterday that its American banking division had agreed to buy Hudson United Bancorp for $1.9 billion as part of a long-term American strategy that includes moving into New York City.

title: Guantnamo Reprimand Was Sought, an Aide Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 - A high-level military investigation into accusations of abuse of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, recommended a reprimand for the former commander of the prison, but his superior declined to admonish him, said a Congressional aide who has read a report on the inquiry.

description: LONDON, July 12 - The British police said Tuesday that a team of four British-born men had carried out Thursday's deadly terrorist attacks in London, including at least one possible suicide bombing, which would be the first in Britain.

description: MELCHET--Asher. Beloved husband of Ruth. Loving uncle and great-uncle. Taken from us suddenly after a long life. Lifelong Zionist dedicated to all Jewish causes. Funeral services today, 1:30, at Schwartz Bros.-Jeffer Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY.

title: Assemblyman Gains Support for Manhattan Borough Post
description: In the crowded race for Manhattan borough president, one candidate is emerging from the pack with prominent union endorsements: Assemblyman Scott Stringer, who plans to announce the backing of the city teachers' union and several other labor organizations today.

description: DETROIT, July 12 - Roger Clemens, ever the entertainer and ever the magnet for attention, was the last National League All-Star to strut into the clubhouse Tuesday.

description: CBS News is turning its eye on itself.

title: Off the Menu
description: Chris Cheung, below, closed Tiger Blossom, a showcase on the Bowery for his inventive Chinese cooking, after 9/11 hurt business. The chef, who had worked at Jean Georges and Ruby Foo's, went on to cook at Rain in Manhattan and Long Tan in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Now, with Steven Ng and Sam Wong, he has opened Little Bistro, 158 Court Street (Pacific Street) in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. The restaurant offers American comfort food like lobster pot pie, and Mr. Cheung brings Chinese accents to other dishes like sweet and sour baby back ribs with macaroni and cheese: (718)797-5655.

title: Floating Through the Park: Wagner, Lalo and Tchaikovsky
description: At least it wasn't sweltering, or actually raining. Still, the New York Philharmonic's newly appointed associate conductor, Xian Zhang, might have hoped for something closer to the ideal for her concert with the Philharmonic on the Great Lawn of Central Park on Wednesday evening.

title: 26% of Births in City Are Caesarean Deliveries, Study Says
description: The number of Caesarean section births performed at hospitals in New York City varies greatly, with the average well above the recommendations of the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, according to a report to be issued today by the city's public advocate.

title: Iconic tech conference sets up shop in Oxford
Iranians Warning Europe of Resumed Atomic Effort
description: TEHRAN, July 12 - Iran will resume uranium enrichment if the European Union does not recognize its right to do so, two Iranian nuclear negotiators said in an interview published Tuesday.

title: Shell Settles Employee Suit About Overstated Reserves
description: AMSTERDAM, July 12 - The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said Tuesday that it had agreed to pay about $90 million to settle a lawsuit brought by its United States employees after company restatements of its oil and gas reserves by a total of 41 percent.

description: CLEVELAND - When Ohio enacted a pilot program of school vouchers here a decade ago, David Brennan, an Ohio businessman, quickly founded two schools for voucher students.

title: Chorus grows to get Europe competitive
World Briefing | Asia: Uzbekistan: U.N. Report Condemns Abuses
description: United Nations investigators said that Uzbek security troops used "indiscriminate and disproportionate" force and committed "grave human rights violations" in the eastern town of Andijon in a crackdown on protesters in May. Citing eyewitness accounts of Uzbeks who fled to neighboring Kyrgyzstan, the report disputed the government estimate of 187 deaths and its characterization of the victims as armed Islamic terrorists, saying the real number was between 200 and 700 and that most of them were civilian protesters and onlookers. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Mam's Shrimp, With Garlic and Just a Touch of Sherry
description: AS the tasting panel discussed one of the richer white Riojas, the 1987 Lpez de Heredia Tondonia reserve, Eric Asimov said, "shrimp in garlic sauce." A fine idea. Then, Mani Dawes, an owner of Ta Pol, and I considered a white gazpacho, made with ground blanched almonds and serious amounts of garlic and garnished with green grapes.

title: Complaint Is Filed by Fired Officer With Blog
description: A police officer who claims that he was fired because a Web site he operates criticizes the Police Department -- often in crude language -- has filed a complaint with the New York State Division of Human Rights, saying he was the victim of retaliation and reverse discrimination.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Parliament Eliminates Term Limits
description: Parliament voted by a wide margin to amend the country's Constitution to lift presidential term limits, allowing President Yoweri Museveni to seek a third term next year. The 220 to 53 vote was expected after a preliminary vote on the issue passed last month. The move to extend his tenure has been criticized by opposition lawmakers and foreign donors. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; Stanching Harry Potter Leaks
description: J.K. Rowling has gone to court for a second time to try to prevent details of her new novel, "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince," from leaking. After 14 copies of the book were sold to customers at the Real Canadian Superstore in Coquitlam, British Columbia, the Canadian publisher, Raincoast Books, obtained a court order to have the copies returned. It also received an injunction prohibiting disclosure of any information from the novel before its scheduled release at 12:01 a.m. on Saturday. Jamie Broadhurst, a spokesman for Raincoast, said the company is "in conversations with a number of the customers" who bought the book, but he declined to say whether any had yet agreed to return their copies. Raincoast has offered to return the books to the customers at the time of the scheduled release along with a bookplate signed by the author and a T-shirt. Last month, a British court issued a similar injunction after two men were arrested and charged with trying to sell stolen copies to reporters at two newspapers in Britain. EDWARD WYATT

title: For Sonny Liston, a Ballad to a Heavyweight
description: Correction Appended

title: Nicklaus Seeks Surprise Finish to Close the Book
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 12 - As seagulls darted and chatted above, Jack Nicklaus walked around a short green fence to the first tee at the Old Course at St. Andrews.

title: Pomp and Fireworks in Monaco as Prince Albert Takes Throne
description: PARIS, July 12 - With all the pomp and splendor befitting a very rich man ruling 6,000 people on a seafront outcropping of rock, Prince Albert II of Monaco on Tuesday assumed the throne left vacant in April by the death of his father, Prince Rainier III.

title: A Southern Spirit in Have-Nots on Junkyard Roads
description: Jim White, the wry, sorrowful singer, songwriter and hero of alt-country music who narrates the documentary "Searching for the Wrong-Eyed Jesus," has the gift of poetic gab. As he conducts a highly selective back-roads tour of the rural Deep South, salty epigrams fall from his lips like drippings from a plug of chewing tobacco.

title: Senators Advise Bush on Picking a Court Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, July 12 - In their first meeting with President Bush over the Supreme Court vacancy, Democrats went so far Tuesday as to offer names for consideration while senators of both parties encouraged the president to look beyond the federal judiciary for candidates.

title: Shuttle's Liftoff Canceled After  Fuel Sensor Fails
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 13 - The shuttle Discovery will not be launched today because of a malfunctioning fuel sensor, NASA said, delaying the return to space for a fleet grounded since the Columbia disaster in February 2003.

title: In Brooklyn, Little Light on Mystery of a Body in a Yard
description: Ever since the police and the medical technicians came and took the woman's body away from the backyard on East 15th Street in Midwood, Brooklyn, on Monday, people have been waiting to hear what really happened.

title: The Speech the President Should Give
description: A couple of weeks ago, on this very page of this here newspaper, Senator John Kerry wrote an Op-Ed article imagining "The Speech the President Should Give," about that night's televised presidential address on the war in Iraq. Of course, Kerry had about as much chance of George W. Bush's following his advice as the producers of "MTV Cribs" have of getting the president's mother to show them around Kennebunkport.

title: Why Is the White House Silent?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Dim Debut for 'Rock Star'
description: Fifteen performers began competing on Monday to be the new lead singer of INXS on the premiere of CBS's "Rock Star: INXS." Dana Robbins, above, whose biography on the CBS Web site lists her current and former jobs as a yoga instructor and adult film actress, was the first contestant to be eliminated. She made the judges uncomfortable during her rendition of Bob Dylan's "Knockin' on Heaven's Door." The series, which is scheduled to be broadcast three times a week, drew only 5.62 million viewers for the first episode, according to Nielsen's estimates, putting it in fourth place for the 9 p.m. hour. Because of CBS's strength in the other time periods -- with repeats of "Everybody Loves Raymond," "Two and a Half Men" and "CSI: Miami" -- the network was No. 1 in Nielsen's estimates of total viewers and households. But Fox easily won the among 18-to-49-year-olds with back-to-back episodes of "Hell's Kitchen."

title: Back in Iraq, a Stranger From the Outside World
description: When the Iraqi-born filmmaker Maysoon Pachachi returned to her homeland in early 2004, it was her first visit in 35 years. Her 80-year-old father, Adnan, had become a member of the United States-appointed Iraqi Governing Council the previous summer, and Ms. Pachachi wanted to document the drafting of a transitional constitution and bill of rights. But in a country brutalized by wars, sanctions, and Saddam Hussein's cruelties, the creation of a unifying law seems as utopian as peace itself.

title: INSIDE
description: Suicide Bomber Kills 2 Women at a Mall in Israel A Palestinian suicide bomber killed himself and two women and wounded more than 50 people in Netanya, the Israeli police said. But the government said the attack would not derail its withdrawal of settlers from Gaza next month. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon's spokesman said Israel would act against those responsible if the Palestinian Authority did not, but officials did not offer any details.

title: Zucchini Solved
description: AROUND this time of year many gardeners try to figure out what to do with zucchini, a vegetable that has become a year-round staple in supermarkets but still comes on like gangbusters in millions of backyards every July. The desperate make fried zucchini sticks or something akin to potato pancakes with it. The really desperate use it for compost, or perhaps even bread.

title: Ten Characters Seeking Out the Proper Dramatic Equation
description: Peter Gil-Sheridan has left practically no clich unturned in "Top Ten," a two-hour-plus exercise in pure self-indulgence. One by one he trots out a series of stereotypes, mixing and matching cardboard characters in predictable permutations: the ambitious but clueless politico, the racist mother, the corrupt evangelist and the fallen soldier.

title: Corrections
description: An Editorial Observer column in The Times on July 4 misidentified the North Carolina official who said that if Muslim witnesses were allowed to swear on the Koran, someone who worshipped brick walls might want to swear on a brick. It was a spokesman for the state Administrative Office of the Courts, not a Guilford County judge.

title: Tribes of New York
description: Whether they chose the romance of period clothing or synthetic hair extensions and bright colors or industrial grunge, New York's goth girls are never boring. Their stories can be heard at nytimes.com/tribes.

title: Globalist: A glimpse of Earth in its precious fragility
Charges Dropped Against Mayor Who Performed Gay Weddings
description: The Ulster County district attorney dropped charges against the mayor of New Paltz, N.Y., yesterday for marrying same-sex couples, saying that a trial would be needless and divisive.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Airport Squatter Becomes Citizen
description: A man who spent 13 months at the Nairobi airport to press British immigration authorities to issue him a passport was sworn in as a British citizen. Sanjai L. Shah, who was born in Kenya while it was still a British colony, had been in an immigration fix in which neither country accepted him. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Large Development Planned In Flushing
description: The city has chosen a team of developers to build a $500 million retail and residential complex on municipal land in Flushing, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The project, called Flushing Commons, is expected to take several years to complete and will include stores, restaurants, a multiscreen cinema, a 50,000-square-foot recreation center and one acre of open space. The development team includes the Rockefeller Development Corporation of Manhattan and TDC Development and Construction Corporation of Queens, Mr. Bloomberg said. Mike McIntire (NYT)

description: The New Jersey Audubon Society uses radio telemetry to keep track of turtles on the threatened species list.

description: Photographs from today's home page of NYTimes.com.

title: Real Women Seek Dates, Must Love Technology
description: The women here - these daters - look familiar. You know the type. Trim, breezy, frank, supremely at ease making confessions to cameras. They're recognizable anywhere now: reality-show Jens and Amys, spirited representatives of that plucky work force that dutifully fills the girls' slots on offerings from "Blind Date" to "The Apprentice" to "Beauty and the Geek."

title: As Police Search for Clues, Britain Pauses to Mourn
description: LONDON, July 14 - As police sealed off streets and scoured homes for clues about the London bombing attacks today, untold thousands of people here and across Europe stood in silence for two long, quiet minutes in memory of those who died the attacks just one week ago.

title: A.M.D.'s Profit Exceeds Predictions of Analysts
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 - Advanced Micro Devices defied Wall Street's predictions and posted a profit of 3 cents a share on Wednesday, its first profitable quarter in nine months, as strong sales of its microprocessors offset pricing pressure in its troubled memory chip division.

title: Southampton Chic: As Seen on TV
description: OF all the fashion designers who are not household names, Steven Stolman has happily, and almost entirely, confined his celebrity to elite resort enclaves. Mr. Stolman's bright nautilus prints and swimsuits made of decorator's fabrics might not be for everyone, but they are catnip for the die-hard preppies who were weaned on the pinks and greens of Lilly Pulitzer and who frequent his stores in Southampton or Palm Beach.

title: Top Officials in Europe Vow to Press Fight on Terrorism
description: BRUSSELS, July 13 - Interior and justice ministers of the 25 European Union countries held a special meeting here on Wednesday and renewed their pledges to take concerted action against terrorism, committing themselves to some specific actions and timetables.

title: America's wage gap widens
Surprising results from a heart scan
Free flow: Air hubs face downward spiral
An Ancient Japanese Art in Modern Guise
description: The Japanese region of Karatsu has been known for its earth-tone pottery since the 15th century. The Nakazatos, one of the area's original potting families, still produce pieces in the Karatsu tradition, although now with modern touches. This week an exhibition, "Connecting Through Clay: Karatsu Pottery," opened at the Felissimo Design House (10 West 56th Street, 800-565-6785, through July 30th) with works by three members of that clan, Taki and Hanako Nakazato and their father, Takashi Nakazato, above, as well as an American potter, Malcolm Wright. The vases shown are by the senior Mr. Nakazato; other pieces by the four are available for $28 to $1,200 at Sara, a Japanese ceramics store (950 Lexington Avenue at 70th Street, 212-772-3243). MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: POTTERY

title: Bush Says He Will Withhold Judgment on Rove Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - President Bush said Wednesday that he would withhold judgment on whether Karl Rove, his senior adviser and political strategist, had identified an undercover C.I.A. operative in a conversation with a reporter for Time magazine.

title: Data Shows Rising Toll of Iraqis From Insurgency
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - Iraqi civilians and police officers died at a rate of more than 800 a month between August and May, according to figures released in June by the Interior Ministry.

title: Relaxing Under the Dome, Awaiting Financial Angels
description: Judging by the giant patchwork quilt of picnic blankets that rolls out over the Great Lawn in Central Park on concert nights, plenty of New Yorkers know about the performances by the New York Philharmonic and the Metropolitan Opera in Central Park. But these concerts are far from the only free classical music to be heard in the city's greenest precinct.

title: Taylor Has a Polished Jab for an Aging Hopkins
description: LAS VEGAS, July 13 - Jermain Taylor was 16, an amateur in Little Rock, Ark., and "right-hand crazy," he said. He wanted to brawl, not box, which his coach, Ozell Nelson, told him was a dumb, reckless strategy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SKLAR, LEO J., M.D.
description: SKLAR--Leo J., M.D. Happy Birthday. Lovingly remembered in our hearts and minds. Love always, Rita and family

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROBBINS, LESTER
description: ROBBINS--Lester. Your family and close friends are thinking of you, remembering your warmth, strength, wit and your deep, abiding interest in and love for each of us. Sheila

title: Picking Non-Judge Justice Would Return to Tradition
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - If President Bush picks a Supreme Court nominee from outside the roster of sitting judges, he will be breaking with recent precedent and returning to tradition.

A Laptop Bag That Powers Everything, Except Laptops
description: You need not be a fashionista to want more than a generic black laptop bag. While Voltaic Systems' new messenger-style laptop case may not have the slickest of designer looks, its innovative use of solar energy makes it worth more than a window-shopper's glance.

title: 57th Annual Primetime Emmy Nominees
description: Drama Series : "Deadwood ," HBO; "Lost ," ABC; "Six Feet Under," HBO; "24," Fox; " The West Wing," NBC.
