Paid Notice: Deaths   BODDICKER, MARY L.
description: BODDICKER--Mary L. Of Garden City and Saltaire, New York on July 12. Beloved wife of Arthur F. and mother of Christine Roach. Grandmother of Alison, Jennifer, Edward and Eliza. Sister of John, Michael and Florence. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her.

title: MP3 Watch From 50 Cent (the Price Is a Bit Higher)
description: The rap star 50 Cent is branching out into the listening end of the music business, lending the name of his G-Unit rap group and record label to a wristwatch with an MP3 player tucked inside.

title: Boss Weighs In on Red Sox and Giambi
description: On the eve of his team's four-game series with Boston, George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, weighed in modestly with a statement released through his spokesman, Howard Rubenstein.

title: Dropping $2.5 Million, and Name, Into Fountain
description: The usually bone-dry concrete heart of Washington Square Park is about to get a formal name after being known simply as "the Fountain" for 130 years.

title: 2 youths, British to core
Scholar Is Given Life Sentence in 'Virginia Jihad' Case
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 13 - An influential Muslim scholar, whom prosecutors called a "purveyor of hate and war," was ordered on Wednesday to spend the rest of his life in prison for inciting his young followers in Northern Virginia to wage war against the United States in the days after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Episcopal Priest Is Removed in Connecticut
description: Correction Appended

title: Cuomo Hopes Funds and Muscle Will Oust Green Before '06 Vote
description: Nearly 16 months before New Yorkers vote for a new attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo hopes to drive his fellow Democrat and rival Mark Green out of the race with a mix of financial and political muscle, advisers to Mr. Cuomo say.

title: Judge Returns to the Bench After Killings in Her Family
description: CHICAGO, July 13 - The long-running cases seemed like old friends. The black robe made her feel more herself. The routine docket lasted just 15 minutes, but for Judge Joan Humphrey Lefkow of Federal District Court, returning to the bench on Tuesday was a tiny triumph in recovering from the Feb. 28 murder of her husband and mother.

title: IPod Sales Give Apple 75% Jump in Revenue
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 - Showing continued strong growth of its popular iPod digital music player and impressive personal computer sales in the United States, Apple Computer reported quarterly earnings on Wednesday that far outpaced the expectations of financial analysts.

title: Real Women Seek Dates, Must Love Technology
description: The women here -- these daters -- look familiar. You know the type. Trim, breezy, frank, supremely at ease making confessions to cameras. They're recognizable anywhere now: reality-show Jens and Amys, spirited representatives of that plucky work force that dutifully fills the girls' slots on offerings from "Blind Date" to "The Apprentice" to "Beauty and the Geek."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, BEATRICE
description: KAUFMAN--Beatrice. Died peacefully on Wednesday, July 13. Beloved wife of the late Barry Kaufman. Cherished mother of Barbara, Sharon and Howard. Loving grandmother of Barry, Amy, Jennifer, Michael, Brian, Alicia, Daniel and Nicole. Adored great-grandmother of Hannah, Maya, Zachary, Jacob, Dylan and Leah. Services on Thursday, July 14, 2:00 P.M. at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, at 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations may be made in her memory to The Hebrew Home of Riverdale, 5901 Palisade Ave, Riverdale, NY 10471.

title: Arts, Briefly; Rap and R&B Return to Top of Chart
description: For the last three months rap and R&B were largely absent from the top of the Billboard album chart as a succession of rock acts, from Nine Inch Nails to Coldplay, took the peak position. This week's chart ends that trend, as R&B and hip-hop albums occupy most of the top slots. R. Kelly's "TP.3 Reloaded" (Jive), right, with guest spots by the rappers Snoop Dogg, the Game and Twista, made a big showing at No. 1, with 491,000 copies sold, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Missy Elliott's latest, "The Cookbook" (Atlantic), sold 176,000 in its first week, reaching No. 2. Other top sellers include Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam), at No. 4; the Ying Yang Twins' "U.S.A. (United State of Atlanta)" (TVT), at No. 5; and the Black Eyed Peas' "Monkey Business" (A&M/Interscope), at No. 6. But at least one rock band is still holding strong: Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol) is at No. 3, with 127,000 sales in its fifth week of release. BEN SISARIO

title: Arts, Briefly; A New Leader Picked For Houston Grand Opera
description: Anthony Freud, below, who as the longtime general director of the Welsh National Opera moved the company into a new $210 million home last year and reduced ticket prices, will take over the Houston Grand Opera, officials said yesterday. As general director, Mr. Freud will replace another opera sachem, David Gockley, who ran the Houston house for three decades before recently being appointed general director of the San Francisco Opera. Mr. Freud said that when the Welsh National Opera moved into the Wales Millennium Center, he cut top ticket prices by 25 percent to attract first-time and intermittent operagoers. "We're in the business of providing a cultural service," he said. Mr. Freud, 47, held several positions at the Welsh opera from 1984 to 1992, and became general director in 1994. A former record company executive, he helped put many Welsh opera productions on television. He takes over in Houston in March. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Stockings: The dress for flights
Knicks Can't Be Wedded to the Idea of Brown
description: HERB WILLIAMS is a soldier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FURLONG, PADRIC F.X. ''PAT''
description: FURLONG--Padric F.X. "Pat" of Duxbury, MA., formerly of Garden City and Brooklyn, NY on July 10, 2005. Born December 29, 1927 to John L. Furlong and Alice. Loving husband of Mary and father of Brenda, Padraic (Sandra) of Manhasset, Myles (Jan), Edmond (Carolyn) and Matthew (Maria). Brother of Alice, Daniel (Maureen), Maryann (Ed), Christopher (Angela) and the late John L. Furlong, Jr. (Louise). Proud grandfather of 12. US Army, St. John's Univ. Employed by Abraham and Straus from 1947-1976, Helmsley Spear, Bradlees, Almy's and B.J.'s Wholesale. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd., Manhasset, Thursday 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Friday 12PM, St. Francis of Assisi Church, Bklyn.

title: Lawmakers Agree to Renew Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - Lawmakers on three separate Congressional committees moved Wednesday to impose restrictions on some of the more controversial elements of the law known as the USA Patriot Act, suggesting continued resistance in Congress to the idea of giving the government unchecked authority to fight terrorism.

title: At P.S. 1, an Illusion of Tents Billowing in the Breeze
description: The blob is back.

title: The Battle of Bunker Hill Looms at St. Andrews
description: St. Andrews, Scotland - WITH a Scottish burr, this is known as the "auld grey toon," where old is really older than dirt.

title: The Real Meaning of Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: Arthur Fletcher, G.O.P. Adviser, Dies at 80
description: Correction Appended

title: A Stalker With Big Hair and Her Prey
description: Does the bunny get boiled? It has to or the audience at this Cliffs Notes stage parody of "Fatal Attraction" would riot. Most of the major scenes in the 1987 movie about the big-haired "working woman" stalker (Glenn Close) and her married prey (Michael Douglas) are accounted for in "Fatal Attraction: A Greek Tragedy," by Alana McNair and Kate Wilkinson: the first encounter at the bar; sex, with the kitchen sink thrown in; sex, in the elevator; the knives; the slit wrists; the blood; the all-white loft; the nave wife; the child; the knives; the bathtub.

title: Srebrenica, an Obligation Unfulfilled
description: Ten years ago, during the war in Bosnia, ethnic Serb forces murdered more than 7,000 men and boys in Srebrenica, almost every Muslim male in the city. That genocide stands as the worst atrocity against civilians in Europe since World War II, and as a tragic symbol of the inability of United Nations peacekeepers to protect civilian populations. A decade later, the two men with ultimate responsibility for the massacre remain free. And despite the parallel tragedy of Rwanda, the major powers that run the U.N. Security Council have yet to make peacekeeping operations more credible and effective.

title: Wrestling With the Gift of Grab
description: IT started in the early 1990's with one roll, taken by two sisters, from the ladies room of the InterContinental Hotel Paris.

title: Public Service and Private Lives: A Home Base in the Military
description: The likelihood of combat may not be the only reason for the Army's low recruitment numbers. Soldiers, like civilians, want nice homes, and "service members were not staying in the Army because of the quality of the housing," said Chris Sherwood, a senior vice president at Actus Lend Lease, a developer in Nashville that has teamed up with the Army under a privatization plan to build 5,400 houses in Oahu for soldiers, like the two officers' houses above. The $1.7 billion program, called Army Hawaii, also involves demolishing 5,300 homes and renovating 2,500 existing ones, and will be completed in 2015.

title: Clinton Urges Inquiry Into Hidden Sex in Grand Theft Auto Game
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is calling on federal regulators to investigate the latest version of Grand Theft Auto, a popular video game series that allows players to go on simulated crime sprees.

title: What? Your Watch Only Tells Time?
description: LIKE the other conductors who worked for the Chesapeake & Ohio in the early part of the last century, my great-grandfather carried a pocket watch whose accuracy had been approved by the railroad. In that pretech era, he set his beloved Hamilton with a lever that popped out of the side of its face. It ran accurately at temperatures from freezing to August and was precise to within 30 seconds a week.

title: Convicted, Executed, Not Guilty
description: If Larry Griffin were being tried today for the murder of Quintin Moss, he would almost certainly be acquitted. The evidence is overwhelming that he did not kill Mr. Moss.

title: Familiarity Breeds Fans: Daryl K Is Back
description: THE bank of the Delaware River is a strange place to be talking about fashion, but this is where Daryl Kerrigan began a recent morning, talking about a dress. Her hands swooped up to convey a wide-open neckline, chopped a voluminous silhouette out of the hazy sky and then traced a delicate zigzag pattern to indicate ruching, a technique of gathering the fabric along a seam.

title: Man Admits to Identity Theft in a Complex Mortgage Scheme
description: A man who went on a four-month odyssey across three continents before his arrest admitted yesterday in Nassau County Court in Mineola, N.Y., that he had masterminded an elaborate identity theft and mortgage scheme that took in about $3.1 million, according to the Nassau district attorney's office.

title: When Art Imitates Pain, It Can Help Heal, a Therapy Group Finds
description: The psychologist handed a painting by Frida Kahlo to a woman in a group therapy session for depression recently at a Brooklyn hospital.

title: In Philadelphia, Back to Being Whee! Again
description: Twelve kids can hurtle side by side down the Giant Wooden Slide at Fairmount Park in Philadelphia. The slide, which opened in 1905, is part of the Smith Memorial Playground and Playhouse and has been shuttered for two years while it underwent a $325,000 upgrade. It reopens today with a fresh foundation, new roof timbers and a boardwalk for wheelchairs. Shellac and Butcher's wax coat the 40-foot-long maple floor. "The goal is to make this thing fast," said Hope Zoss, the playground's executive director. The inaugural slider will be Ida Newman, 92, who grew up nearby and paid for the restoration. Aside from Mrs. Newman, no riders over 10 are allowed. Open Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., no fee: smithplayhouse.org or (215)765-4325. EVE M. KAHN CURRENTS: CHILDREN ONLY

title: 2 North Africans convicted under Italy's terrorism law
Letters: Israel's defense, For the record in Spain, G-8 and Darfur
Harry Potter and the Half-Crazed Summer Camper
description: The boys and girls at the Kennolyn Camps in the redwood forests of the Santa Cruz Mountains in California will get a most unusual wake-up call on Saturday. Roused from their beds at 6:30 a.m., more than an hour earlier than usual, they will be marched to a campfire meeting, served hot chocolate from a bubbling cauldron and read the first chapter of the new Harry Potter novel by counselors dressed as characters from that popular series.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 6:30 P.M. (Sundance) THE HOUSEKEEPER -- (2002). For Bastille Day, the Sundance Channel presents an evening of French films, beginning with this wise romantic comedy about a depressed divorc (Jean-Pierre Bacri) who hires a sexy young cleaning woman (milie Dequenne, above, with Mr. Bacri). The evening's other films include Patrice Chreau's "Those Who Love Me Can Take the Train."

title: Child in L.A. Shootout Was Killed by Police, Officials Say
description: LOS ANGELES, July 13 - Facing growing criticism over a shootout on Sunday that left a gunman and his toddler daughter dead, Chief William J. Bratton of the Los Angeles police acknowledged on Tuesday that a shot from a police officer, not the gunman, had killed the child.

title: Botox Plus: New Mixes For Plumping And Padding
description: BABAK AZIZZADEH, a facial plastic surgeon in Beverly Hills, recently concocted a menu of "Cosmetic Cocktails." Although the frothy title might suggest intoxicating mixed drinks for patients who have just gone under the knife, the doctor's elixirs are not alcoholic. They are toxins and wrinkle fillers that he injects into patients' faces to smooth their age lines and puff up their cheeks.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Mineola: Man Convicted Of Commuter's Murder
description: A Freeport man was convicted yesterday of the 2003 killing of a commuter who was attacked by a gang on Sept. 19, 2003. The man, Nelson Zuniga, 21, was convicted of second-degree murder and robbery for the killing of Anthony Battaglia, 37, of Lynbrook, said Denis Dillon, the Nassau County district attorney. Mr. Battaglia, a mechanical engineer who worked in Manhattan, was stabbed and shot as he was walking home from the Lynbrook train station. Four other men have pleaded guilty to charges including robbery and murder, and two testified against Mr. Zuniga.

title: An Organist in His Loft, and You Are There
description: One thing about organ recitals that has always seemed odd, if understandable, is that the organist is rarely seen. These performances take place mostly in churches, where the organ loft is out of sight. The organist may come out for a bow at the start and at the end, and sometimes between pieces, but when the organ sound floods the room there's nothing for a listener to watch.

title: National Briefing | Education: Money Cut For Merit Scholarships
description: The University of California said it would stop providing money for National Merit Scholarships beginning with the class entering in fall 2006. Many campuses pay for the scholarships to raise the number of prestigious merit scholars they attract, but the university's chancellors objected to the National Merit Scholarship Corporation's practice of using the score from a single test, the College Board's PSAT exam, to choose a pool of possible winners. In the 2004-5 academic year, about 600 students at the university's six campuses received National Merit Scholarships totaling about $735,000, paid for by the university. Elaine Detweiler, a spokeswoman for the scholarship corporation, said there were no plans to change the selection process. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: Amid Rising Demand, Oil Supply Is Tight and Vulnerable to Threats
description: Global oil markets are expected to remain under intense pricing pressure as demand picks up next year, an indication that even at $60 a barrel, oil prices are doing little to slow consumption, the International Energy Agency said yesterday.

title: Believe What You Will, Just Don't Promote It, Tax Foe Is Told
description: A federal appeals court upheld a lower court order yesterday that bars a "professional tax protester" from promoting a popular tax fraud known as the 861 position and requires him to turn over the names of clients to the Justice Department.

title: In a Wide Sweep for Militants, Italy Detains 174
description: ROME, July 13 - In a nationwide sweep aimed at ferreting out potential terrorists, the Italian police on Wednesday searched 201 homes and detained 174 people suspected of being involved in militant Islamic groups. But at the day's end, the police announced no formal arrests and said only that they had confiscated some literature in Arabic from some of the homes.

title: Death Toll Reaches 123 in Pakistan Train Crash
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, July 13 - Pakistani officials said Wednesday that the crash of three commuter trains in southern Pakistan earlier in the day, which they said had killed 123 and injured 170, appeared to have been caused by an error on the part of one of the train drivers.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: WorldCom Chief Is Given 25 Years for Huge Fraud
description: Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chairman of WorldCom, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison for orchestrating a record $11 billion fraud that toppled the telecommunications company he founded.

title: Mets Fumble for the Word for Baseball in Esperanto
description: Late on the afternoon of May 22, the globalization of the Mets became more than a marketing campaign.

title: ASML net rises 72%, but demand slackens
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a dance review yesterday about the Pilobolus company, at the Joyce Theater, referred incorrectly to Michael Tracy, who choreographed "Aquatica." He is one of the company's four artistic directors, not the only one.

title: Big City Union Shifts Support to Bloomberg
description: The union representing more than a third of the city's municipal work force endorsed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg for re-election yesterday, giving the mayor, a Republican, crucial labor backing and signaling labor's disenchantment with the field of Democratic candidates.

title: Senate Democrats Call for Increase in Troops
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York and other Democrats proposed Wednesday to increase the size of the Army by 80,000 troops as a way to alleviate what she called a "crisis" in the military caused by lengthy deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: The Real Meaning of Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: I, Roommate: The Robot Housekeeper Arrives
description: WHEN my home robot arrived last month, its smiling inventors removed it from its box and laid it on its back on my living room floor. They leaned over and spoke to it, as one might to a sleeping child.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NYMARK, JAN A.
description: NYMARK--Jan A. On July 13, 2005, at age 58. Beloved husband of Raya, loving father of Michael (Jenna) and Natalie. Future grandfather of Maryn. Dear brother of Richard. Cherished uncle. Born in Poland, married in Cyprus and built his life in New York City. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Ave. at 20th St., Friday, 2-5 and 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, 10AM, at Epiphany Church, 22nd Street and 2nd Ave., NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to American Cancer Society.

title: Retailers' Deal Advances
description: Shareholders of Federated Department Stores and May Department Stores approved the $11 billion combination of the companies yesterday. More than 99 percent of votes cast by Federated shareholders and more than 97 percent of votes from May investors favored the deal, the companies said.

title: Iraq bomber kills 27, most of them children
Rice Claims U.S. Role in Korean About-Face
description: ANCHORAGE, July 13 - Returning from a six-day trip to Asia, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice and her aides said Wednesday that North Korea's decision to return to nuclear disarmament talks was a vindication of the Bush administration's strategy and not solely the result of a South Korean offer to provide the North with electricity.

title: The Storm Around Karl Rove
description: To the Editor:

title: Mortimer Levitt, Clothier and a Patron of the Arts, Dies at 98
description: Correction Appended

title: Japan is undeterred in U.N. fight
Briefly: Costs at the curb rising for passengers with bags
Higher Consciousness of the Lowly Mat
description: FOR thousands of years, yogis in India did sun salutations on the bare ground. When 20th-century Westerners first took up the discipline, the only cushioning they used on the hard floor was a blanket, a pillow or a piece of carpet, mostly to designate their personal space.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEGRETI, ANTOINETTE ADELINA
description: SEGRETI--Antoinette Adelina, on July 11, 2005. Survived by her children, Mary Whitten, Irene Birdsong, Sylvia Walsh, Rose DeVenuto and John L. Segreti; 13 grandchildren, 19 great-grandchildren, and one great-greatgrandchild. Visitors may call at John Dormi & Son Funeral Home, 1121 Morris Park Ave., Bronx, NY, July 14 and 15. Services will be held at St. Francis Xavier Church, 1703 Lurting Ave., Bronx, NY, Saturday, July 16, at 9:45AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Foundation Fighting Blindness Inc.

description: Out, Black Spot

title: Jury Is Selected for Case Involving the Drug Vioxx
description: ANGLETON, Tex., July 13 - Lawyers selected a jury today in Ernst v. Merck, the first Vioxx case to reach trial, as both sides subtly began to highlight facts that they will present in detail over the next month.

title: Security chief stresses need to be 'nimble'
WTO says tariff talks in trouble
Sports Briefing: Running; Keflezighi in Marathon
description: Meb Keflezighi, who in a 70-day span last summer finished second in the Olympic marathon and second in the New York City Marathon, announced yesterday that he would run in this year's New York race Nov. 6.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAHER, PAUL J., S.J.
description: MAHER--Paul J., S.J. Beloved brother of Dr. Francis Maher, Mary Ann Hession, and sister-in-law Delores Maher. Cherished uncle of seven nieces and nephews. Reposing at The Jesuit Community Chapel at Murray Weigel Hall, 515 East Fordham Rd, Bronx, NY. Visitation Friday 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at The Loyola Hall, Saturday 11:30AM. For further info contact Farenga Brothers Inc. Directors.

title: Accord Reached on Transportation Spending Plan
description: ALBANY, July 13 - State leaders settled their differences over how to pay workers on state transportation projects on Wednesday, clearing the way for a state board to approve a five-year capital plan for billions of dollars worth of projects.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Treaty Close On Kyrgyz Base
description: Russia moved closer to cementing a military presence in Kyrgyzstan, as the upper house of its legislature ratified a treaty allowing it to use an air base there for 15 years. The treaty now requires a signature from President Vladimir V. Putin. The ratification occurs as the Pentagon faces pressure to withdraw from two military bases in the region, including one on Kyrgyz soil. Central Asia has been undergoing a diplomatic shift since May, when Uzbekistan cracked down on escaped prison inmates and demonstrators in Andijon. The United States has called for an investigation, angering the Uzbek government as well as Russia and China, which are pressing for a lessened American presence in the region. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Low-Income Health Insurance Expanded
description: More than 150,000 additional low-income children and parents will receive low-cost, federally subsidized health insurance, known as FamilyCare, under a bill signed yesterday by Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey, left. The law also provides for more streamlined enrollment procedures and better ways to keep children insured through the system. The FamilyCare program covers children in families earning up to 350 percent of the federal poverty level of $19,350 for a family of four, and it reaches parents whose incomes are too high for them to be eligible for Medicaid but too low for them to afford private insurance. In 2002, the state froze enrollments for parents. This year, said Kevin M. Ryan, the state's child advocate, 106,000 children and 97,000 adults are in FamilyCare.

title: Fallon Pulling Out of New York
description: AFTER a decade of riding the roller coaster in the competitive New York market, the Minneapolis agency Fallon Worldwide is looking to walk away, a bit dizzy but at least still ambulatory.

title: The Real Meaning of Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: 3-train crash kills 127 in Pakistan
Baghdad Bomb Kills Up to 27, Most Children
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 13 - A suicide car bomber on Wednesday steered his sport utility vehicle toward a group of children who had crowded around a patrol of American troops and detonated his payload, killing as many as 27 people, nearly all of them children, government and hospital officials said. One American soldier was also killed.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   WAGNER, NORMAN WILLIAM
description: WAGNER--Norman William. Dear Dad, you are always in our hearts and thoughts. Love, Your Family

title: PublicAffairs Founder Plans to Step Down
description: PublicAffairs, a division of the Perseus Books Group, is looking for a new publisher after Peter Osnos, below, the founder and publisher of the company, announced yesterday that he is stepping down and will work as an editor at large for the company. "Anybody who has ever founded anything knows the second-most important thing you do is to decide when to turn it over," Mr. Osnos, 61, said in an interview. He plans to work on a PublicAffairs autobiography of W. Mark Felt, the former F.B.I. official who in May revealed himself as Deep Throat, the source for many of the Watergate stories by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein that were published in The Washington Post. In its eight years, PublicAffairs has published more than 300 books, including works by Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, and George Soros, the investor and philanthropist, and anthologies related to the 9/11 attacks and the Abu Ghraib investigations. EDWARD WYATT

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Less oil demand seen
Ronald W. Haughton, 88, Innovative Labor Mediator, Dies
description: Ronald W. Haughton, an innovative mediator and arbitrator whose work put him in the forefront of major national labor disputes over 40 years, died on July 4 at his home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 88 and also kept a residence on Martha's Vineyard, Mass.

title: The Storm Around Karl Rove
description: To the Editor:

title: Hormone therapy still a hope for the obese
Research Changes Ideas About Children and Work
description: WHEN Americans think about child labor in poor countries, they rarely picture girls fetching water or boys tending livestock. Yet most of the 211 million children, ages 5 to 14, who work worldwide are not in factories. They are working in agriculture -- from 92 percent in Vietnam to 63 percent in Guatemala -- and most are not paid directly.

title: Reports of Bombs in Small Packages Lead to Warnings in Jakarta
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 13 - The attacks in London bear similarities to circumstances described in intelligence reports -- plans for multiple attacks in public places with bombs secreted in relatively small packages -- that have led the United States Embassy and other embassies to issue a series of warnings here in recent weeks.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Stamford: Rematch Planned In Fourth District
description: Westport's first selectwoman, Diane Goss Farrell, announced yesterday that she would run again for Congress next year against the 10-term Republican incumbent Christopher Shays. Mrs. Farrell, a Democrat, ran a close race in Connecticut's fourth district in 2001, attracting 48 percent of the vote.

title: Funds in brief: Top pension provider seeking to raise fees
World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Ryanair Bookings Drop
description: Ryanair Holdings, Europe's biggest low-cost airline, said bookings declined about 10 percent in the four days after the London bombings as travelers held off taking flights. "We expect if there are no other attacks that bookings will be back to normal by this weekend," Michael O'Leary, the chief executive, said at a news conference in London. "I doubt whether London has ever been a safer place to visit." Bombs on the city's subway and a double-decker bus on July 7 killed at least 52 people. The airline took about 24,000 fewer bookings compared with previous weekends, Mr. O'Leary said. The lost sales are worth 960,000 euros ($1.2 million), based on the company's average fare of 40 euros.

title: Iraq's Rush to Failure
description: Stanford, Calif. - IRAQ is rapidly approaching a watershed moment: the unveiling of its new constitution. This event will probably be seen in retrospect as either the moment that the leaders of Iraq reconsecrated their troubled nation, or as the opening act of the country's descent into civil war. It is troubling, then, that events are proceeding with undue haste and a lack of public input, either of which might doom the process and invite a conflagration that would make the insurgency look like a garden party.

title: E.R. for Hard Drives
description: NOVATO, Calif. - He knew it was important, but backing up his hard drive was the last thing on Ryan Risdal's mind. Mr. Risdal, 35, was too busy rearing four children and caring for his ill wife.

title: Wild Things, Domesticated
description: WHATELY, Mass. - WILLIAM CULLINA, the nursery director for the New England Wild Flower Society, stood over a dozen tiny potted trees last month, describing how striking they will be when they bloom in about three years. "Stewartia ovata var. grandiflora," he said, towering over one infant. "It has beautiful big white camellialike flowers, with violet-blue anthers, and you can't find anyone selling it."

title: U.S. Says It Captured Key Member of Al Qaeda in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 14 - A senior commander of the Islamic terrorist group Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, who is suspected of involvement in the recent killing of Egypt's top diplomat to Iraq, has been captured by coalition troops in Ramadi, the American military announced today.

title: Palmeiro Seeks No. 3,000 Against His Favorite Staff
description: SEATTLE, July 13 - Rafael Palmeiro is on the threshold of his 3,000th hit but, like choosing one's relatives, he has not had much control over when and where it will come. His swing and his schedule dictate his fate, and those two things should conspire to help him achieve the milestone in the next few days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOLGIN, ISRAEL M.
description: DOLGIN--Israel M. We cannot believe what life will be like without you. You have given us the memory of your memories to carry with us forever. The stories of growing up with your brother and sister and most of all your beloved twin, Jeannette (Post), all of blessed memory, will mingle in our hearts with equal amounts of laughter and love. You taught us the importance of Tzedukah (charity) to be performed without public display but with compassion for the dignity of all people; you taught us the value of Mishpuchah (family), and the rich texture that adds to all aspects of our life; you taught us the value of Zichor (memory) so that history became a living part of our present and future actions. And you taught us the beauty of our heritage so that we understood that Hebrew is not something you only hear with your ears but feel with your heart. You showed us the importance of permanence by your love and devotion to our mother, Diana, for over 63 years. You never left the house without leaving a funny note or card. We will care for her, tend the gardens you loved and keep you with us within our hearts forever and ever. Services Thursday, 10AM at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels" 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Kal and Peggy; Neil and Cindy; Gail, Ellie; Josh and Rebecca; Brynn & Alan and Emma (Klein); Daniel; Amelia and Ben (Nardenelli); Grant, Carly, Chad, Brett; Rebecca, Ari, Heather

title: Tiger Woods Tops Leaderboard at St. Andrews on Opening Day
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 14 - Through the tinted windows of the Royal and Ancient clubhouse, silhouettes moved toward the glass behind the first tee, closer to the golfer who five years ago rendered these links defenseless.

title: From a Scandal Springs a Chance for an Overhaul at Volkswagen
description: FRANKFURT, July 13 - Volkswagen must be one of the few companies that could record a 9 percent increase in its stock price after accusations that two of its executives solicited bribes, siphoned money into fake companies and arranged visits to prostitutes on the company tab.

title: Younger Students Show Gains in Math and Reading
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 - America's elementary school students made solid gains in both reading and math in the first years of this decade, while middle school students made less progress and older teenagers hardly any, according to test results issued today that are considered the best measure of the nation's long-term education trends.

title: Trade Gap Narrowed in May; Trend Seen as Short-Lived
description: The trade deficit shrank markedly in May, the government reported yesterday, but economists warned that the decline could not be sustained because it was caused by a drop in oil prices that has since reversed.

title: Turkey Seeks Iraq Extradition of 2 Islamists in '03 Bombing
description: ISTANBUL, July 13 - Turkey announced Wednesday that it had requested that Iraq extradite two Turkish Islamists suspected of taking part in a 2003 terrorist attack in Istanbul and being held in Abu Ghraib prison.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "At the end of the day everybody lost."

title: N.H.L. and Players Reach Agreement
description: The National Hockey League and its players union agreed in principle yesterday on a six-year collective bargaining agreement, apparently ending a damaging lockout that stretched 301 days and led Commissioner Gary Bettman to become the first leader of a sports league in North America to cancel an entire season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PERNICIARO, CLAIRE H.
description: PERNICIARO--Claire H., 79, of Yardley, PA, on July 13, 2005. Wife of the late Joseph A., mother of the late Kevin, and sister of the late William and Jacqueline Hunt. Survived by children, Robert, Missy, and Carol, brothers Rev. Kevin Hunt, O.C.S.O. and Kenneth Hunt, 3 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren. Funeral Mass at 10am Saturday at St. Ignatius Church, Yardley. Burial St. Ignatius Cemetery. Calling 6pm-9pm Friday at Fitzgerald-Sommer Funeral Home, Yardley (215-493-2228)

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on Tuesday about two men who were taken into police custody after they were seen taking pictures of the George Washington Bridge from an inflatable raft in the Hudson River referred incorrectly in some copies to the property that the police impounded. It consisted of the raft and an unclaimed car in the parking lot of a marina near the bridge, not two rafts.

title: Lives of Three Men Offer Little to Explain Attacks
description: LEEDS, England, July 13 - In the gritty, working-class suburbs of Leeds, Shahzad Tanweer, 22, was the fun-loving, rich kid of the neighborhood, the son of a savvy, Mercedes-driving shop owner.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   POTTER, HARMON S.
description: POTTER--Harmon S. Of Bellport, NY, at the age of 90 on July 13, 2005. The son of Dr. James H. Potter and Nina Potter, he was born in New York City on October 3, 1914. He was the valedictorian of P.S. 186 and graduated from Columbia University (A.B. 1935) and Columbia University Law School (L.L.B., 1937). In private practice before the war, Mr. Potter served as an officer in the U.S. Army from 1941-46. He was a patent attorney with the U.S. Atomic Energy Commission in Washington, D.C. starting in 1947, and from 1959 until his retirement in 1972 served as Chief of the AEC's Patent Group located at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, NY. Throughout his life he read and traveled extensively, and was an avid numismatist. He was a lifelong reader of this newspaper. His brother, Professor James H. Potter of Stevens Institute of Technology, died in 1978. He leaves his devoted wife of 58 years, the former Anna L. Goddard, loving children, Lawrence (Forest Hills, NY) and Jane (Winchester, MA) and grandchildren Carley Graham (Alexandria, VA) and Laurie Graham (Savannah, GA). His family sorely miss him and cherish his memory. A memorial service will be held at Ruland Funeral Home, 500 North Ocean Avenue, Patchogue, New York, on July 15 at 11 AM, with interment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery at 11 AM the following day.

title: News Analysis:Ebbers's fall transformed world's securities markets
The Real Meaning of Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Home Field Secure, Real Business Begins
description: WITH two out in the National League's ninth inning of Tuesday night's All-Star Game, Terry Francona, the American League manager, stood on the mound and handed Mariano Rivera the ball.

title: Additional Security Measures Are Taken
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 13 - David Hill, an official with the Royal and Ancient Golf Club, said Wednesday that additional security measures had been taken for the 134th British Open at St. Andrews after last week's bombings in London. He did not specify what the measures were. St. Andrews is 456 miles from London.

title: The Storm Around Karl Rove (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: British Seeking 5th Man, Thought to Be Ringleader
description: LONDON, July 13 - British investigators have mounted a worldwide manhunt for the suspected bomb maker in the London attacks, a man seen on a videotape with four suspected bombers last Thursday morning at the Luton train station, an American official said Wednesday.

title: Israel Seals West Bank and Gaza to Suppress Violence
description: TULKARM, West Bank, July 13 - Israel sealed off the West Bank and Gaza on Wednesday, reoccupied Tulkarm and declared the Jewish settlements in the Gaza Strip a closed military zone in an energetic response to a Palestinian suicide bombing a day earlier.

title: Report Discredits F.B.I. Claims of Abuse at Guantnamo Bay
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - A high-level military investigation into complaints by F.B.I. agents about the abuse of detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, concluded in a report released Wednesday that their treatment was sometimes degrading but did not qualify as inhumane or as torture.

title: Library Gets Control of Items From Kennedy's Presidency
description: BOSTON, July 13 - For years, curators at the John F. Kennedy Presidential Library and Museum here have had a quintessentially New England problem: they were missing a winter glove. This was no ordinary glove, but the one that President Kennedy wore on his left hand on the day of his inauguration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DANIELS, THOMAS A.
description: DANIELS--Thomas A., 94 years, formerly of West 57th St. died July 13 in Allentown, PA Owner of Peter's Beauty Home on West 57th St; retiring in 2003. Husband of Anne J. Kvietkauskas Daniels. Also survived by a son, Thomas K. and wife Lynn of Allentown, Pa. and two grandchildren, Katie and Adam. Services 11AM Saturday, Keller Funeral Home, 1018 Church St., Fogelsville. Call 9:30-11AM. Contributions to the Lutheran Home at Topton, C/O funeral home, PO Box 52, Fogelsville PA. 18051.

title: Financially Set, GrandparentsHelp Keep Families Afloat, Too
description: When he got home from a three-day school camping trip last winter, Schuyler Duffy, a 10th grader at Friends Seminary, told his parents he had had a fantastic time and thanked them for sending him to that Manhattan private school.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EPSTEIN, JACK
description: EPSTEIN--Jack, on July 11, 2005. Beloved uncle of Susan Tofel and George Hecht. Widower of Ruth Gutman, sculptor. Born in Pikesville, MD. A graduate of the Friends School in Baltimore and of Babson College in 1929. Jack resided in New York City for more than 50 years. He headed the New York Metropolitan Section of Parents Magazine. A veteran of World War II, he was a member of the Navy League, the Board of Trustees of The Elder Craftsmen, The Lambs Club, Artists - Equity and Temple Emanuel. He served as president of the B'nai B'rith Advertising Lodge and as Vice President of the Babson College New York Alumni Association, Long Island Advertising Club, New York Advertising Club, New York Advertising and Communication Club and the Philo Music Society. He directed the advertising and marketing curriculum of the Advertising Club of New York and was a big brother with the Jewish Board of Guardians. A funeral service will be held at Frank E. Campbell--The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue on Friday, July 15, at 10:30 AM.

title: Ferrer Presents His Proposal to Reduce City Dropout Rate
description: Fernando Ferrer proposed a slate of education reforms yesterday aimed at reducing the number of dropouts from public high schools, presenting the first major initiative in his campaign for mayor since he suggested a controversial tax on stock sales in April.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCKEON, GRACEANN M.
description: McKEON--Graceann M., died July 11, 2005. Resident of Riverside, CT. Loving daughter of Peter T. and Lorraine D. McKeon (predeceased). Beloved sister of Peter, Virginia, Agnes, Francine, Marianne, Paul, and Andrew. Beloved sister-in-law of James, Alice, Mary, and Brian. Wonderful aunt to Kate, Peter, Addie, Elisabeth, Emilia, and Alice Georgie. Loving owner to Spice. Graceann was an attorney at the firm of Sullivan & Cromwell for 30 years. We love you and will miss you dearest Graceann. Receiving hours Leo P. Gallagher, 31 Arch St, Greenwich, CT on Wednesday July 13 and Thursday July 14 from 5-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at St. Catherine of Sienna Church, 4 Riverside Ave, Riverside, CT at 11AM. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made in her name to Greenwich Hospital Home Hospice, 5 Perryridge, Greenwich, CT 06830 or St. Angela Merici School, 917 Morris Ave, Bronx, NY 10451.

title: Security Loses; Pork Wins
description: This was a sad week for the war on terror. The Senate voted, disgracefully, to shift homeland security money from high-risk areas to low-risk ones -- a step that is likely to mean less money to defend New York and California against terrorism and more for states like Wyoming. Before the vote, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff made a powerful appeal to the senators to distribute the money based on risk. But the Senate, led by Susan Collins, a Maine Republican, and other small-state representatives, put political pork ahead of national security. It now falls to the House to fight for a financing formula that will keep the nation safe.

title: Closings Alone Won't Solve Hospitals' Troubles, Panel's Chairman Says
description: A commission created by New York State to reorganize its hospital system took a broad view of its mandate yesterday at its first meeting, with its chairman saying that simply closing down hospitals would not be enough to solve the current financial crisis.

title: In This Neighborhood, Reality TV Falls Short
description: AUSTIN, Tex. - EARLY this summer, when Faye Rencher first saw advertisements for an ABC reality program called "Welcome to the Neighborhood," she barely took note. Seven families would compete to win a suburban house, while three families in the neighborhood judged their suitability. Yawn.

title: Keeping Wyoming Secure
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SOBEL, MICHELLE
description: SOBEL--Michelle. A Memorial Service will be held for Michelle Sobel, beloved wife, friend, and devoted educator on Wednesday, July 20, 7 PM at Kneses Tifereh Israel, 575 King St, Port Chester, NY.

title: Diving Into a Tide of Creative Energy
description: Lincoln Center Festival 2005 opened on Tuesday night with a mighty wave of movement and music. The Merce Cunningham Dance Company revived "Ocean," a success at the first Lincoln Center Festival in 1996, but not seen in New York since.

title: Calendar
description: A Garden Opening The Native Plant Center at Westchester Community College, 75 Grasslands Road (Route 100) near Knollwood Road (Route 100A), Valhalla, N.Y.; (914) 606-7870.

title: Briefs: Lego sells parks to Blackstone
Tiger Woods Surges to British Open Lead
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 14 - Five years after Tiger Woods conquered the Old Course at St. Andrews, he began his chase for a second British Open title today by shooting a six-under-par 66 to take a two-stroke lead early in the first round.

title: Montgomerie Is Wearing His Game Face, With His Heart on His Sleeve
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 13 - The greatest hope in Scottish golf takes up half of page 56 in Wednesday's Scottish Sun. It is a photograph of Colin Montgomerie with his eyes closed. He appears almost peaceful.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Arrest In Officer's Shooting
description: A Cambria Heights man was charged yesterday with shooting a police officer in a Queens park last month, the police said. The man, Lasana Philbert, 21, was picked out of a lineup by the officer, Christopher T. Wiesneski, a police spokesman said. The shooting occurred on June 14 about 8 a.m. in a park near the Cross Island Parkway at 121st Avenue and the Laurelton Parkway. Officer Wiesneski, 32, who was patrolling the park on a scooter, spotted a man with a gun in his waistband, investigators said. When Officer Wiesneski confronted him at a baseball diamond, the man grabbed the officer's gun. During the struggle that followed, the gun went off and a bullet hit Officer Wiesneski in the left knee. Mr. Philbert has been charged with attempted murder, the police said.

title: Other views: Sydney Morning Herald, Irish Times, Globe and Mail
Rehnquist Checks Into Hospital With Fever
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist checked into the hospital with a fever late Tuesday night, heightening uncertainty about whether he plans to retire.

title: INSIDE
description: Shuttle Liftoff Postponed Over Faulty Fuel Sensor Just two hours and 20 minutes before liftoff, NASA postponed the flight of the space shuttle Discovery because of a malfunction in a fuel sensor that engineers thought they had fixed a month ago. "All I can say is 'shucks,"' said N. Wayne Hale, the shuttle program's deputy manager. When the order to stand down was issued shortly after 1:30 p.m., the shuttle's seven astronauts were already strapped into their seats, after a morning in which they had been sent off to the launching pad to thunderous applause from employees of the space agency. PAGE A18

title: Correction
description: An article on June 23 about the designer Vladimir Kagan and his wife, Erica Wilson, misstated the rent she paid five years ago for her needlepoint shop on Madison Avenue. It was $7,300 a month, not $3,000.

title: Valley girl meets Oxford don for brainstorming
Paid Notice: Deaths   STEINBERG, DR. PAUL
description: STEINBERG--Dr. Paul. His wisdom and his caring will be deeply missed. Our heartfelt sympathy to Trudy Steinberg and to the children. Ruth Bar-On, Prof. Dan Amir Selah, The Israel Crisis Management Center

title: Techbrief: Britons go for speed of broadband
World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Trade Surplus Narrows
description: Canada's merchandise trade surplus dropped sharply to 3.99 billion Canadian dollars in May, from 4.9 billion Canadian dollars in April, Statistics Canada, a government agency, said. Many economists had been expecting that the surplus would drop only to 4.7 to 4.8 billion Canadian dollars. Increased heavy machinery imports for construction and oil and gas projects in Western Canada were responsible for much of the decline in the surplus, along with a 19 percent rise in oil imports. All categories of exports from Canada declined, except for automotive products and consumer goods. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Slowly, the Shared Car Is Making Inroads in Europe
description: AMSTERDAM - When Mariane Polfliet discovered she had an emergency meeting in a hard to reach suburb of Amsterdam recently, there was no need for panic: within minutes, she had used her computer-coded key to drive away in one of the hundreds of shared cars that are now scattered around the quaint canals of this city's center.

title: Britons mark one week since London bombings
Man Beaten in Howard Beach Leaves Hospital
description: Glenn Moore, the black man who was beaten with a baseball bat wielded by a white man in Howard Beach, Queens, last month, was released from the hospital yesterday.

title: Entrepreneurial Spirit Meets the Philanthropical
description: Successful entrepreneurs like to contribute to worthy causes, whether the local Kiwanis or a national charity. Their motives can be mixed, of course; they might want to help make a better world, but polishing their public image doesn't hurt their bottom lines, either.

title: Guests Evacuated at Gracie Mansion
description: Gracie Mansion, the official mayoral residence, was evacuated last night after a jogger called the police to report seeing someone throw white powder onto the promenade in Carl Schurz Park, next to the mansion on the Upper East Side.

title: With Liftoff Postponed, Spectators Move Along
description: TITUSVILLE, Fla., July 13 - Mary and David Savoie had returned to their favorite viewing spot along the Indian River, bringing cousins from Pennsylvania to watch the shuttle launching in the distance. Joshua Lacy had settled beside them with a cooler, and nearby, Tony Vivian had fired up his radio and grill.

title: Pressure mounts against Arroyo
Corrections
description: A commentary article in Science Times on July 5 about people's tendency to blame their genes for their medical fate misstated the full expression for DNA. It is deoxyribonucleic acid, not deoxynucleic acid.

title: Dispatches From the Geek Cruise
description: I took two weeks off from my Times column in order to see a part of the world I've never seen before. As a speaker on a computer cruise organized by GeekCruises.com, I gave talks during the days at sea-and saw tiny bits of Denmark, Estonia, Russia, Finland, Sweden and Germany during the days in port.

title: A Kiss Was Still a Kiss; 75 Puppets Tell Old Story
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EMDEN, DENA
description: EMDEN--Dena. In cherished memory of a beloved mother and grandmother. Passed away July 14, 1988. Forever in our hearts. Howard, Jeffrey, James and Robert

title: Tame the Desktop Cable Jungle With a 'Multi' Hub
description: The U.S.B., FireWire and audio ports on the back of a desktop computer are not too handy when the things you want to plug and unplug are in the front. And cluttering your desk with an array of different hubs would leave little room for the iPods, cameras and other things that those connections are for. Nyko Technologies has put connections for just about everything into a compact hexagon, the Desktop Multi Hub. The device, which will be available next month for $59.99 from CompUSA, is about five inches across and just over an inch high.

title: Corrections
description: An editors' note last Thursday about the recent fact-checking of a 2003 Times article from Baghdad, which confirmed some specifics but found a name misspelled, gave an outdated title for a new book by the article's writer, Alan Feuer. The book, in which the writer cast doubt on some of the details he reported in 2003, is "Over There: From the Bronx to Baghdad, A Memoir" (Counterpoint Press). The proof copies that circulated to reviewers bore the title "Over There: From the Bronx to Baghdad, Two Months in the Life of a Reluctant Reporter."

title: Safety Board Complains to F.A.A. Over Fuel Tanks
description: Correction Appended

title: A Royal Odd Couple on a Bizarre Quest
description: Freddy and Fredericka By Mark Helprin 553 pages. The Penguin Press. $27.95.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts last Thursday with an article about the New York City Dance Alliance's national championship misstated the name of a group whose dancers took part. It is Harlequin Extravaganza, not Harlem Extravaganza.

title: Stocks: Day of mixed messages leaves Wall St. flat
Paid Notice: Deaths   EISEN, ALBERT
description: EISEN--Albert. There will always be a place for you at our table, and in our hearts. The Romeos Retired Old Men Eating Out

title: EU warns Romania and Bulgaria on reform
When a Cool Dip Isn't Enough
description: WOULDN'T it be nice if having a pool only meant watching the water temperature? Not a chance. What about guests who need to be entertained and swimmers like me who prefer a comfortable float to doing laps? This season's accessories address all aspects of pool life, including peace of mind for dogs who never learned to swim.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Tracking the Wood Turtle, Somewhere in New Jersey
description: Gylla MacGregor consulted her Global Positioning System device, laying it on a rock near her somewhat elusive prey. In four hours, the animal had moved all of 396 feet as the crow flies. But it does not fly like a crow. It is a wood turtle, and it had probably lumbered up the stream bed, into a miniature forest of skunk cabbage, most likely covering at least 500 feet.

title: UNTIL I FIND YOU
Correction
description: A photograph last Thursday with the Physical Culture feature, about lightweight hiking gear, was published in error. The backpack shown was the GoLite Galaxy Pack, not the GoLite Gust Pack, which was tested.

title: ABC Piles Emmy Nods
description: Two new series that helped pull ABC out of a prime-time ratings slump this past season - the guilty-pleasure suburban comedy "Desperate Housewives" and the eerie post-plane-crash drama "Lost" - are among the shows that led the list of nominees for the 57th annual prime time Emmy Awards, which were announced this morning in Los Angeles.

title: The Storm Around Karl Rove
description: To the Editor:

title: Switch Maker's News Lifts Guidant Shares
description: Shares of the Guidant Corporation, which recently halted sales of several heart devices because of a component problem, rose yesterday after a component supplier said it was providing such a part to a manufacturer it did not name but which the market surmised was Guidant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, MORTIMER
description: LEVITT--Mortimer. On July 12, your great and courageous heart could no longer sustain life in you. During the 98 years you spent on this earth you were known as merchant prince, philanthropist, producer, author, and above all as a confirmed iconoclast. You wanted to live to 104, but you will live much longer because we will carry forward your vision and your dreams. Your wife Mimi, your daughter Elizabeth, and your son Peter, will miss your strong presence and your wonderful sense of humor. You influenced the lives of many people with your intelligence, your creativity, your exquisite taste and your zest for life. We will celebrate your remarkable accomplishments and your extraordinary spirit at a memorial tribute a la Mortimer in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Young Concert Artists, 250 West 57 St., New York, NY, or Friends of the Levitt Pavilion, 85 East Holly St., Pasadena CA. 91103.

title: Yellow Jersey Still in Place, Armstrong and His Team Endure Rival's Attack
description: BRIANON, France, July 13 - Lance Armstrong had priorities Wednesday in the Tour de France, and Alexander Vinokourov was not among them. When Vinokourov went on a long breakaway over two major mountains in the Alps and went on to win the 11th stage, Armstrong didn't blink.

title: Unocal Bid Denounced at Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - A former director of central intelligence testified Wednesday that a Chinese company's bid for Unocal should be seen as part of that government's strategy for energy security in competition with the United States and that the American government should consider preventing such a deal.

title: Couture Steps Lively for a Corpse
description: PARIS - MAYBE the only thing more surprising than Giorgio Armani's comment in Paris Match last week that designers had "killed haute couture" was that he bothered to say it at all. Couture has been dead for a while, a victim not of decadent couturiers but rather of ready-to-wear designers like Mr. Armani, who came along and offered women something more modern. All of which makes his quest to save couture as touching in its futility as a Spanish novel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULTANOV, ALEXEI
description: SULTANOV -- Alexei. The House of Steinway & Sons notes with sadness the passing of the pianist Alexei Sultanov on June 30 in Fort Worth, Texas, at the age of 35. A Russian native, Alexei Sultanov was a valued member of our Steinway Artist family for 16 years. Brought to the spotlight by winning the 1989 Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, Mr. Sultanov was immediately recognized for his extraordinary musical gifts. His promising career was thus launched, only to be felled by a series of catastrophic strokes four years ago. Despite losing the use of his left hand, Mr. Sultanov continued to perform in the Fort Worth area, along with his wife Dace, at nursing homes and before groups of the physically challenged. His courage and determination to persevere, despite his disability, will leave a lasting legacy for many. To Dace and to his family we extend our heartfelt condolences. Bruce A. Stevens, President Peter B. Goodrich, V.P., Worldwide Concert and Artist Activities

title: People: Gwyneth Paltrow, P. Diddy, Ravi Shankar
S.&P. 500 Hits 4-Year High
description: The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closed at a four-year high today, buoyed by several days worth of positive economic and corporate earnings reports.

title: A Nobu for Midtown, Inspired by Asians That Swim and Some That Don't
description: After exporting the upscale downtown vibe of Nobu to London, Milan, Miami and beyond, the Japanese-born chef Nobuyuki Matsuhisa has finally ventured into Midtown Manhattan. The Rockwell Group, which designed the original Nobu restaurant in TriBeCa and the outposts in Las Vegas and Dallas, have turned the first two floors of an office tower at 40 West 57th Street into Nobu 57, scheduled to open next month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHTER, ROBERT C.
description: RICHTER--Robert C., formerly of NYC, July 8, 2005 at Crosslands, Kennett Square, PA. A Graduate of NYU and Hamilton College, he served as an officer in the US Navy. He was survived by cousins and many friends. Memorial Service at 1:30pm, Friday, July 15 at Crosslands, Crossland Dr., Kennett Square. Memorials may be sent to Hamilton College Annual Fund, Clinton, NY 13323.

title: FedEx to move Asia center to China
Currencies: Dollar gains on euro as trade gap narrows
Sans Socks, Sans Cares: Some Maintenance Needed
description: IT seems almost obscene, given the expanses of midriff, thigh and backside that too many people are all too willing to bare today, that the decision to show a little ankle with dress shoes should raise eyebrows. But almost obscene is just how it seems to many.

title: U.S. Transit Agencies Turn to Cameras in Terror Fight, but Systems Vary in Effectiveness
description: In San Francisco and Washington, subway stations and platforms are under constant surveillance by closed-circuit television cameras. New Jersey Transit uses computer software that automatically alerts the police when an unattended package shows up on video monitors. The light-rail system in Houston plans to enable its onboard security cameras to transmit live images, wirelessly, to police cruisers.

title: New York and Florida
description: WHETHER it is soap you need or something to take the sting out of a sunburn, you may find it at one of Manhattan's two new beauty stores.

title: Test-Driving a Retirement Community (Yes, You Can)
description: Ardsley, N.Y. - ROSE WEGNER arrived at the Woodlands assisted living community with only a suitcase.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Bank Leaves Rates Near Zero
description: The Bank of Japan became more optimistic about the economy, the world's second-largest, citing improved business confidence and higher capital spending. "Japan's economy continues to recover," the bank said in its monthly report. Gov. Toshihiko Fukui and the bank's policy-making board voted by majority to keep interest rates almost at zero and maintain the level of cash the bank pumps into the economy to end more than seven years of falling prices. "Corporate profits remain high and the Tankan confirmed that business sentiment is picking up again," Mr. Fukui said at a news conference.

title: Bridge; First Glance: Good All Around. 2nd: Well
description: The regional tournament held annually around July 4 has undergone many metamorphoses. I first played in 1971 when it was called the Fun City Regional and was held in the Hilton Hotel on Sixth Avenue. This year it was the July 4th Regional held in the Crowne Plaza Hotel in White Plains under the auspices of both the Greater New York Bridge Association and District 3 (Eastern New York State, excluding New York City, and Northern New Jersey).

title: For Surfers, a Roving Hot Spot That Shares
description: When the Sunningdale Country Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., opened its gates last week to a location shoot for "The Sopranos," a new fixture was on display in the mobile dressing rooms -- a roving Wi-Fi hot spot.

title: Handsome Floor Coverings
description: Q. I'm renovating and in the market for flooring that looks great yet can withstand heavy traffic. What can you suggest?

title: Briefs: Cleric given life term for seditious speech
A Crime So Large It Changed the Law
description: HIS name is not on the law, but maybe it should be. Perhaps more than either Senator Paul S. Sarbanes or Representative Michael G. Oxley, Bernard J. Ebbers is responsible for the most far-reaching change in American securities laws since the Depression.

title: 2 Black Truckers Sue, Accusing Wal-Mart of Hiring Bias
description: Two black truck drivers have filed federal lawsuits against Wal-Mart Stores in Arkansas, arguing that the company discriminated against them by denying them jobs because of their race. Lawyers who filed the suits are seeking class-action status and they said they expected Wal-Mart to respond to their initial information requests by the end of the week.

title: Japanese joining party after India heats up

The book, in which the writer cast doubt on some of the details he reported in 2003, is "Over There: From the Bronx to Baghdad, A Memoir" (Counterpoint Press). description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Tuesday, about a campaign by Coca-Cola to promote exercise and healthy living, misstated the relationship of the head of the company's lobbying concern in Connecticut to Gov. M. Jodi Rell. The lobbyist served as an informal adviser during Mrs. Rell's campaign for lieutenant governor, not as an aide.

title: Reviving His Works, on Paper and Plaster
description: OXFORD, Miss. - WILLIAM FAULKNER wrote most of his novels while living at Rowan Oak, a two-story Greek Revival home at the end of an alle of antebellum red cedars here. The place was barely fit for chickens when he bought it in 1930, for $6,000, and so for the next three decades, Faulkner repaired, expanded and tweaked the house and grounds to his quirky, stubborn satisfaction.

title: Resolution on Brown Must Wait Another Day
description: Larry Brown came to a meeting in suburban Detroit yesterday requested by the Pistons' owner, Bill Davidson, but after two hours, they articulated their distinct positions without resolving whether Brown would stay as the team's head coach. A decision could come as soon as today and could result in a buyout.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, LINDA
description: MILLER--Linda. On July 12, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Herman Miller. Devoted mother of Robert Miller and Rochelle Miller. Cherished grandmother of Jennifer, Michael, Melissa, Jason and Danielle. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Wednesday 7:00-9:00 P.M. and Thursday 2:00-5:00 P.M., 7:009:00 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Service Friday, 12:30 at Frank E. Campbell. Interment Nassau Knolls Cemetery, Port Washington, NY.

title: Bush and G.O.P. Chief Court Black Support
description: President Bush told an audience of black business and civic leaders in Indianapolis today that his administration had worked to help African-Americans get better educations, buy more homes and own more businesses.

title: Knicks Sign James From Sonics to Be Their Starting Center
description: For 10 days last spring, Jerome James looked, played and preened like one of the premier big men of the N.B.A. The transformation was sudden and short-lived, but it was enough to earn James a starting job and a huge contract from the size-starved Knicks.

title: As French Have Their Day, Armstrong Loses a Teammate
description: DIGNE-LES-BAINS, France, July 14 - Lance Armstrong lost a valuable teammate from the Tour de France today as Manuel Beltran, a strong Spanish climber, hit his head when he crashed and had to be withdrawn from the race after he showed signs of confusion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Founder of WorldCom Is Sentenced To 25 Years in Prison for $11 Billion Fraud Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chairman of WorldCom whose name has become synonymous with corporate greed, was sentenced to 25 years in prison for orchestrating a record $11 billion fraud that toppled the telecommunications company he founded. [A1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CUNNINGHAM, JOHN J. ''JJ''
description: CUNNINGHAM--John J. "JJ", 65, of Jupiter, Florida and formerly of NY, died July 12, 2005. Son of the late Edward P. and Marion I. Cunningham; brother of Edward Cunningham, brother of Carol Ann Moran, uncle of Cathleen Moran Elisha, Patti Moran Scully, Tod Moran, grand uncle of Kate Elisha, cousin of Margaret and Teresa Igoe. Mass of Christian Burial, 11AM, on Friday, July 15th at St. Jude Catholic Church, Tequesta, FL. For information contact Taylor & Modeen Funeral Home, Jupiter, FL 561-744-2030.

title: Who's serving the public?
The Editor's Tale
description: Just after midnight on the night of July 15, the year's most anticipated book -- "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" -- will be released. The first printing in the U.S. alone is 10.8 million.

title: Israel shuts Palestinian territories after attack
City to Settle With Thousands Over Illegal Strip-Searches
description: The Bloomberg administration sent settlement notices yesterday to tens of thousands of people who were illegally strip-searched in at least six different New York detention centers between 1999 and 2002. It is the second time in five years that the city has settled a lawsuit because of strip-searches.

title: Fired Aide Releases E-Mail Notes He Sent to Fields
description: Just as C. Virginia Fields was trying to move past questions about a doctored campaign photo, her former chief political consultant released a string of e-mail correspondence yesterday that he said buttressed his claim that she should have known about the altered photo.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

Devoted mother of Marcia (Martin) Gettinger, Helen (Dr. David) Mazor, Susan (Robert) Hamer, Stephen (Roberta) Server and Elliott (Pamela) Server. Loving grandmother of fourteen grandchildren and doting great-grandmother of eighteen great-granchildren. Services King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ, Friday 10:30AM. Contributions to "Play For Pink" of the American Breast Cancer Foundation, the American Kidney Foundation and the Safe Harbor Children's Shelter. Gutterman-Musicant Funeral Directors 1-800-522-0588.

title: Bringing Hamas into the peace camp
The Real Meaning of Ground Zero
description: To the Editor:

title: A Meandering Thirst for a Cold One
description: In the cool of the tasting room, the Blanche De Brooklyn was an unpretentious bracer. Chilled, more nibbling than biting, this summer beer with an off-white head offered aromas of coriander and orange peel amid the winter wheat at its heart. "Fruity, spicy and satisfying in the finish as well," one studious quaffer said.

title: Vanguard Trading Limits
description: The Vanguard Group is taking a major step to clamp down on investors who frequently move in and out of its mutual funds. As of Sept. 30, investors will not be able to buy shares of a Vanguard fund by phone or online within 60 days of selling shares in the same fund. The firm will allow the repurchase of shares by mailed check.

title: 2004 British Raid Sounded Alert on Pakistani Militants
description: LONDON, July 13 - Scotland Yard called it Operation Crevice. In late March 2004, a force of 700 police officers arrested eight British-born ethnic Pakistanis and a naturalized Briton born in Algeria in two dozen raids in southern Britain. They also seized 1,300 pounds of ammonium nitrate fertilizer, which can be used in making bombs.

title: Bullish Report on I.B.M. Helps Dow to Another Gain
description: The Dow Jones industrial average gained for the fourth day in five after an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company said I.B.M., the Dow's worst performer this year, was undervalued.

title: Mr. Bush, Pick a Genius
description: Mr. President, they must think you're head of programming at CBS. Some people are telling you to name a Hispanic as your first Supreme Court nominee. Others say, Pick a woman. Harry Reid says, Pick someone who's not too controversial. Arlen Specter says, Look outside the judiciary for a fresh face.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Theater Chain Shuns Dirtiest Joke

title: Rice praises Seoul's energy offer as 'useful'
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Boutique Raided by Police
description: Federal police and tax authorities raided Daslu, an ultraexclusive luxury boutique in So Paulo that caters to Brazil's superrich, arresting the store's owner on allegations of tax evasion, fraud and racketeering. Authorities contend that the closely held Daslu, one of the top retailers in Latin America of upscale brands like Chanel and Prada, evaded at least $10 million in taxes in the last 10 months by underreporting sales and falsifying import documents. Four people were detained, including the store's owner, Eliana Tranchesi, above, whose mother founded the boutique in 1958. The raid came just one month after Daslu moved to a sprawling new $50 million location. A spokesman for Daslu said the store was cooperating with the investigation, but declined to comment further. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about American aid to foreign military forces referred incorrectly in some copies to the estimate of aid Afghanistan received in the 2005 fiscal year under the Foreign Military Financing program. It was $397 million, not $204 million.

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Cuban Athlete Seeking To Defect
description: A member of the Cuban national soccer team is seeking to defect to the United States, immigration authorities in Seattle said. The player, Maikel Galindo Castaeda, a 24-year-old forward, is scheduled to appear before an immigration judge soon, possibly in Seattle, officials said. His team competed in Seattle last week for the Gold Cup, the championship for North America, Central America and the Caribbean. The defection attempt was first reported by The Seattle Times on its Web site. Mr. Galindo did not show up for a match in Foxboro, Mass., Tuesday night, and a defection would be the third by a Cuban soccer player competing in the Gold Cup since 2002. David Carrillo Pealoza (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Law Sought To Restrict Property Seizure
description: After a United States Supreme Court ruling upholding the government's right to take property through eminent domain to foster economic development, Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky proposed legislation yesterday to protect residents. Mr. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat who is running for state attorney general, proposed a law that would give residents more time to appeal decisions condemning their land, require local governments and legislatures to sign off on economic development plans for the entire area, and give affected residents more money, among other things. The new headquarters of The New York Times on Eighth Avenue is being built on land acquired through eminent domain. Michael Cooper (NYT)

title: Try Some Play-Doh Behind Your Ears
description: SURE, our sense of smell is important. From an evolutionary standpoint it allows us to recognize danger and experience pleasure. Certain odors identify food, mates and predators. Studies show that people with no sense of smell don't get enough nutrition, suffer from depression more frequently and have sex less often than other people. The very survival of the human race may depend on our noses.

title: The Real Meaning of Ground Zero

description: HORAN--Dan. CPA. A fine accountant, a wonderful gentleman and a true friend in time of need. We mourn his passing and offer our condolences to his family. Carl and Loretta Neuman

title: Briefly: Extradition is sought of 2 held at Abu Ghraib
Paid Notice: Deaths   FLEISHAKER, DOROTHY
description: FLEISHAKER--Dorothy. The Board of Directors and staff of HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, sadly mourn the passing of Dorothy Fleishaker, beloved wife of HIAS Board member Donald J. Fleishaker. The Fleishakers' commitment to living a life enriched by and connected to Jewish tradition and values as well as passing it on to their children and grandchildren set an example for all of us. The Fleishakers have for many years been major contributors to the success of HIAS' worldwide mission of refugee resettlement and relief and particularly the HIAS Scholarship Program for immigrant students in the United States and Israel. We extend our deepest sympathy to Donald Fleishaker and the entire Fleishaker family. May her memory be for a blessing.

title: Aceh peace talks take leap forward
Tube question: Will it happen again?
Pitchers Have a Hard Time Fooling Boston's Ortiz
description: David Ortiz places his left foot near the back line of the batter's box, leans in and positions his right foot so that his stance is slightly open and he has a clear view. He wears slick red batting gloves that would complement a Spider-Man costume and gray and white wristbands, and has a neat beard circling his round face.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIZEL, MILTON ''BREEZE''
description: BRIZEL--Milton "Breeze". Of Fallsburg and formerly of NYC, retired professor died July 11, 2005. Graveside service today at Sullivan County Veteran's Cemetery, Sunset Lake Rd, Liberty, NY, 10 am with full Military Honors. For info www. colonialbryantfuneralhome.com

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PATRON, IRVING
description: PATRON--Irving. Age 92. Of Boca Raton, FL, and Floral Park, NY. Died July 7 at his home in Florida after a long illness. Beloved husband of Maureen. Father of Glenn, Lisa and Eugene. In his early 20's, Irving played minor league baseball for the NY Giants, earning the nickname "Red Patron." Irving helped pioneer the industrial power transmission industry of which his firm Patron Transmissions became a leader. Irving was a founder and past President of the Power Transmission Distributors Association. His family, including surviving sisters Lenore Feller of LA CA and Dorothy Danish of WP Beach FL, his grandchildren and great grandchild, nieces and nephew, will always be inspired by Irving's life as a proud selfmade man. Interred at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont NY.

title: Property Tax Is Hot Subject for Corzine and Forrester
description: TRENTON, July 13 - In a prelude to what is likely to be a particularly combative campaign, the two multimillionaire candidates for New Jersey governor challenged each other Wednesday to a numerical duel over their plans to reduce the state's perennially high property taxes.

title: Swing Senators Face New Test in Supreme Court Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - When seven Democrats and seven Republicans joined in the Senate to avert a showdown on President Bush's judicial nominees, they urged the president to remember the word "advice" in the Constitution's advice and consent clause. Now that Mr. Bush is consulting with leading senators on a Supreme Court vacancy, the so-called Gang of 14 is patting itself on the back.

title: You've Seen the Web Site, Now Read the Catalog
description: Web sites may be on their way to replacing catalogs, but not for weekend shoppers far from their computers. A new furniture and lighting catalog, Europe by Net, offers many of the same European furnishings from companies like B&B Italia, Kartell and Artemide as the Web site of the same name (europebynet.com), at the same discounts of up to 40 percent off American retail prices. The Spiral coffee table, above, by Cattelan Italia, is $1,034 (the retail price is $1,569); for a catalog: (888)660-4870. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?

title: From China, Some Relief on Oil Demand
description: PARIS, July 13 - A sudden and mysterious drop in China's oil consumption helped to push down the International Energy Agency's estimate on Wednesday of global demand for this year.

title: Desperately Seeking Wispy Lovers in White Tulle
description: What is there to say about American Ballet Theater's revival, for an eight-performance run to end its Metropolitan Opera House season, of its 18-year-old production of "Giselle"? Same old, same old?

title: Report on Atlanta Court Killings Is Said to Lead to Firing of Deputies
description: ATLANTA, July 13 - Four months after a prisoner escaped and killed three people at the Fulton County Courthouse, Sheriff Myron Freeman has started termination proceedings against more than 10 deputies and officers whose actions have been criticized in the shootings, the president of the deputies' union said Wednesday.
