description: PUISSEGUR--Daniel. 53, from Manhattan on July 10. Survived by his life partner William Way. Also survived by his brother Frank and sister Alby and his parents Alba and Daniel Puissegur from Lakeland, FL.

title: This Game Device Entertains and Tutors, but Tell the Children It's a Toy
description: New technology toys are further blurring the line between educational software and television. Consider VTech's V.Smile Pocket, a book-size gadget for ages 3 to 8 that plays arcade games laced with educational content. Available for $90 at major electronics and toy stores, it also runs 19 games made for the console-size version released last year.

description: The Food and Drug Administration pulled a controversial painkiller from the market yesterday based on evidence it could cause serious side effects, but an advisory panel to the agency said three widely used asthma medications should remain in use despite safety concerns.

He was a long time resident of New York; loving father of Richard & Judith; proud grandfather of Audrey & Sarah and great-grandfather of Logan; preceded in death by his loving wife Celia. description: IT'S not inside the washing machine. It's not in the dryer. And it's definitely not in your laundry basket. At Laundrobot in the East Village, the best place to look for your missing sock is on the wall. In a frame.

title: Signs of Consumer Inflation Absent Again
description: Consumer prices remained stable in June, the government reported today, indicating inflation stayed firmly in check in a growing national economy.

description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - The White House predicted on Wednesday that the federal budget deficit would drop sharply this year and that it would continue to shrink for the next four years.

description: WASHINGTON, July 13 - Saying that "much remains to do," Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff announced Wednesday that he was reorganizing his sprawling department to better prevent -- or at least react to -- a terrorist attack.

Her dedication, leadership and unique ability to inspire others accomplished a great deal in UNICEF's efforts to improve the lives of the world's most vulnerable children. She will be deeply missed.

title: A Digital Viewfinder to Rival the Wide-Screen TV
description: Despite their high-resolution images, film cameras suffer from a basic problem: a frustratingly small viewfinder that you must align with your eyeball. Digital cameras changed that with liquid-crystal displays. But these neat mini-TV's tend to be thirsty for battery power, compelling many digital shooters to resort to the thumbnail viewfinder.

title: One-Story Building Collapses Into Busy Block of Manhattan
description: A one-story building collapsed into a busy uptown block of Broadway this morning, trapping a handful of people waiting at a bus stop and leaving a heap of debris that spilled across three lanes of traffic.

title: Arts, Briefly; All-Stars Draw Fans to Fox
description: The American League's victory over the National League in baseball's All-Star Game, right, resulted in an easy triumph for Fox in Nielsen's overnight ratings as an estimated 12.3 million viewers watched the game on Tuesday night. Fox, which has had a slow summer in the ratings, was No. 1 among 18-to-49-year-olds in every half-hour. At 9 p.m., before the game's conclusion became foregone, the annual exhibition had its best hour, drawing an audience of just over 14 million. CBS took second place in both total viewers and the 18-to-49 demographic. The second episode of "Big Brother" brought in 8.46 million viewers, which helped lift the following show, "Rock Star: INXS," to better numbers, 6.31 million viewers, than it had for its premiere. Among viewers ages 18 to 49, "Rock Star" came in second to the All-Star Game, beating NBC's repeat of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (8.8 million) and ABC's "Empire" (4.69 million) in that age group. KATE AURTHUR

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DENNIS, CLARENCE, M.D.
description: DENNIS--Clarence, M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Clarence Dennis, M.D., master surgeon, chair of surgery from 1951 to 1972, originator of the heartlung machine, and generous benefactor. A graduate of Harvard College in 1931, and Johns Hopkins Medical School in 1935, he received a Master's and Ph.D. in physiology from The University of Minnesota. He trained in surgery there under Owen Wangensteen, and stayed in Minnesota on the faculty prior to coming to Downstate. An original "translational scientist," Dr. Dennis established himself as a leader in cardiopulmonary bypass physiology. As our chairman, he performed the first successful open-heart surgery in New York State, using an apparatus he built in our laboratories. A gifted educator, he trained scores of surgeons in New York, affecting the lives of countless people around the world. His residents established The Clarence Dennis Society in his honor, which is still active. Upon his retirement, Downstate awarded him its highest honor, an honorary doctorate in science. With his wife, Mary, he made a generous gift to SUNY Downstate, establishing one of the few endowed academic chairs in honor of great surgical educators. Upon leaving Downstate, he established a presence in our sister organization, SUNY Stony Brook, prior to returning to Minnesota for retirement. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to Mary, to their children, Jane, Richard, James Wigertz, and David, to his fifteen grandchildren, five great grandchildren, and to all their colleagues and many friends. Michael E. Zenilman, M.D., Chairman, Department of Surgery John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean, College of Medicine

description: POWELL--Ann B. On your birthday a void impossible to fill. Remembered with love Harry

description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 13 - In a frustrating setback just 2 hours and 20 minutes before liftoff, NASA postponed the flight of the space shuttle Discovery on Wednesday because of a malfunction in a fuel sensor that engineers thought they had fixed a month ago.

title: World Briefing | Asia: The Philippines: Arroyo Faces Protests
description: Tens of thousands of Filipinos gathered in the financial district in Manila to demand the resignation of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo. It was the biggest demonstration to date against the embattled Philippine leader, who faces allegations that she cheated in last year's election. While officials of Mrs. Arroyo's administration and analysts said they believed the protest was not large enough to endanger her presidency, it revitalized the ranks of her opponents, who suffered a setback recently when she gained the support of former President Fidel Ramos and the country's Roman Catholic bishops refused to join in calls for her resignation. Crowd estimates made by the police and rally organizers were between 40,000 and 65,000. Carlos H. Conde (NYT)

title: With Ads Down, Gannett Profit Posts Drop for a Second Quarter
description: The Gannett Company, the nation's largest newspaper publisher, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit fell 4.5 percent as costs rose and advertising revenue dropped at its 21 TV stations and its flagship newspaper, USA Today.

title: How Long Can Workers Tread Water?
description: James Barnes, a $350-a-week guard at an office building on Madison Avenue in Midtown Manhattan, has not had a raise in years. But his income just jumped sharply: Three months ago, he took on a newspaper delivery route from 3 a.m. to 7 a.m., which pulls in an extra $235 a week.

title: New Jersey Rebound Slower This Time, Study Says
description: NEWARK, July 13 - New Jersey has the nation's highest median household income and second-highest per capita income, and its unemployment rate has been well below the national average in the current economic recovery. But the state has nevertheless produced far fewer jobs over the last three years than in past economic recoveries, according to a new Rutgers University study.

title: Words of Wisdom Delivered Twangily
description: This summer, country music fans are getting something that many other kinds of fans wouldn't appreciate: unsolicited advice. Maybe it's pure coincidence, but four of the season's most popular country songs come with instructions included. On radio stations and on the country-music cable networks (CMT and GAC), the genre sounds unexpectedly stern these days, thanks to the singers who are moonlighting as counselors.

description: Since 1935, more than five million people have flocked to the Hill Cumorah Pageant in New York to see the riotously colorful retelling of Mormon history.

title: Running Mom's Comedy Club While Walking a Tightrope
description: This may not be a good time for comedians, but it's a great time for laughingstocks. Jason Alexander and Wanda Sykes can't sustain sitcoms, but reality television viewers can't get enough of the enigmatic stylings of Bobby Brown, Britney Spears, Jose Canseco, Kelly Monaco and Hulk Hogan. And now another punch line - Pauly Shore - has turned his tarnished talents to the scoundrels' pastime, reality television, in "Minding the Store," which starts tonight on TBS.

title: A Pair of New Witches, Still in Search of the Right Spell
description: The Lion King received better reviews. The Producers won more Tony Awards. And Avenue Q and Spamalot probably made more headlines. But measured by the standard of box-office receipts  these are Broadway musicals, after all  the reigning king of the commercial theater is, inarguably, Wicked. Last week it led all Broadway shows with $1.3 million in ticket sales.

title: 36 Hours in Missoula, Mont.
description: TWO hundred years ago, Lewis and Clark made camp beneath cottonwoods near what would become one of Montana's most vibrant communities: Missoula. They called the camp Travelers' Rest, a name that seems odd given that you'll find few Missoulians actually resting once July begins. That's when summer kicks in with the force of a bucking bronco, daylight lasts till 10 p.m., and Missoula's 63,000 people, who know that winter is never far away, pack in as much fun as they can. They'll hit the hills, go fly-fishing or otherwise disport themselves. There are hundreds of miles of trails, four mountain ranges and five major rivers, all within an hour's drive. So there are plenty of reasons to bring boots and a bike - but none to bring a tie. This onetime logging center, unlike some once-depressed, now-chic Western mountain towns, flaunts its unpolished, industrial edge. Whatever Missoula lacks in cosmopolitan style can be overcome with a Trout Slayer ale, brewed in town, and a well-earned night's sleep.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Central Bank Official Defends Rate
description: Otmar Issing, the chief economist of the European Central Bank, said the outlook for inflation in the dozen nations that use the euro has deteriorated in the last month, suggesting the bank sees no scope to lower interest rates. "The outlook for prices has clearly worsened since June," Mr. Issing, above, said in Frankfurt. Rates are still "appropriate" and inflation will probably slow below the central bank's 2 percent ceiling next year, he said. Mr. Issing and at least nine other policy makers have said in the last 10 days that rates are low enough to revive demand.

title: California Chamber Music
description: ROLLING hillsides awash in golden light, sea lions roaring as they play in the surf, perfect weather day after day: Northern California is almost unreal in its beauty and bounty, particularly in late summer. Inject into this setting the drama of Beethoven's unrequited love and premature deafness, Frank Zappa's version of a tango or a Mozart string quartet performed in the barrel room of a winery. And then add wine -- lots of wine. Northern California just gets better.

title: German Chain Is Still Mired, and Its Chief Scales Back
description: FRANKFURT, July 14 - Thomas Middelhoff's highly visible campaign to turn around KarstadtQuelle, Europe's largest department store and mail-order chain, remains very much a work in progress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUTMAN, BENJAMIN HARRIS
description: LAUTMAN--Benjamin Harris. With profound sadness, William and Wendy (King) Lautman mourn the loss of their dearly loved son, Benjamin Harris Lautman, whose little heart failed on July 14, 2005. His four short years filled his family with tremendous joy and an extraordinary appreciation for the simple things in life. His smile brought laughter and love to everyone whose life he touched. He is the adored grandson of Susan and Robert King of Westport, Connecticut, and Dan and JoAnn Lautman of Los Angeles, California, and the beloved great grandson of Margery B. Neuhaus of Baltimore, Maryland. He will be deeply missed by his special treasure of friends...Thomas Percy, James, Gordon, Toby, Emily, Chocolate Percy, Edward, Ben, Bill, Henry, Salty, Diesel Ten, Dirty Percy and a trainload of others. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, all contributions in honor of Ben be sent to the Bless Your Heart Fund at Columbia University, c/o Lautman, 201 W. 70th St., Apt 39E, N.Y., N.Y. 10023. A memorial service will be held at 10AM Sunday, July 17, 2005 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th Street at Amsterdam Ave, New York City, followed by a graveside service in Tucson, Arizona on Monday.

title: N.Y.R.A. Shakes Up Its Staff
description: A major shake-up of upper-level management at the New York Racing Association took place yesterday with the announcement that Mike Lakow, the racing secretary, Celeste Kunz, the chief examining veterinarian, and Ralph Chetcuti, the vice president for human resources and labor relations, had been fired. The N.Y.R.A. also accepted the resignation of Dave Hicks, the 76-year-old steward.

title: G.O.P. Hopes Bill on China Will Assist Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 - For House Republicans, the path to Central America apparently leads through China.

title: The Women of Gitmo
description: There are countless reasons to be outraged about the abuses of detainees at American military prisons. But there is one abuse about which there can surely be no debate, even among the die-hard supporters of President Bush: the exploitation and debasement of women serving in the United States military. This practice must come to an immediate end, and the Pentagon must make it clear that such things will never be tolerated again.

title: Prices Stayed Flat in June, Even With Demand High
description: The cost of living, as measured by the Consumer Price Index, was unchanged in June despite strong economic growth and a hint of rising labor costs, the government reported yesterday.

title: Ways to Fight An Elusive Foe
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly; Martha Stewart's New Book Is Strictly Business
description: Martha Stewart fans hoping for details of her recent prison stint will have to keep waiting. Ms. Stewart has instead signed a $2 million deal with Rodale to publish "Martha's Rules" in October, shortly after finishing her current sentence of house arrest. Steve Murphy, president and chief executive of Rodale, which specializes in lifestyle books and is the company behind "The South Beach Diet" books, said "Martha's Rules" "is not a Jack Welch or a Lou Gerstner type of book," referring to the former leaders of General Electric and I.B.M., who wrote best-selling business memoirs. "This is a straight-ahead business primer for the entrepreneur," particularly fans of Ms. Stewart who have been inspired by her how-to books to start their own small businesses. EDWARD WYATT

title: Inflation Remains Flat Despite Energy Costs
description: Wholesale prices, an early indicator of inflation in the economy, were unchanged in June, the government reported today, indicating that most businesses are not passing on rising energy costs to customers.

title: Lab Owner in Steroid Scandal Pleads Guilty
description: Victor Conte Jr., the central figure in the Balco steroids scandal that linked the use of performance-enhancing drugs to some of the country's top professional baseball, football and track and field athletes, pleaded guilty to reduced federal charges in a plea arrangement today that was strongly criticized by anti-doping experts.

title: Embattled Congressman Will Not Run in '06
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 - Under investigation for a real estate deal and his ties to a military contractor, Representative Randy Cunningham, an eight-term Republican, announced Thursday that he would not seek re-election next year in his district in the San Diego area.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Tuesday about urban fashion in the boxing ring misstated Seth Horowitz's title at Everlast, the sporting goods company. He is president and chief operating officer, not chief executive.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SELLARS, LOUISE ROY
description: SELLARS -- Louise Roy, whose life's work was dedicated to service and volunteerism, died peacefully July 6 in Mount Vernon, NY. In her work with the Red Cross, Girl Scouts, March of Dimes, UNICEF and the League of Women Voters, she inspired partnerships and collaborations among people. At the March of Dimes she pioneered health programs involving young people and civic and social leaders. During her 15 years as a full-time volunteer with UNICEF, she received many awards for her leadership and vision and, as president of the Bronxville League of Women Voters, she continued to empower others. She saw the natural synergies between individuals and groups, creating positive outcomes for the participants and beneficiaries. Among her survivors is her grandson, Peter Sellars, the theater and opera director. All who knew this great lady will deeply miss her. A memorial service will be held in her honor Sunday, August 7, at 2 PM, at the Women's Club, 136 Midland Ave., Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to U.S. Fund for UNICEF, 333 E. 38th St., NYC 10016; March of Dimes, 1275 Mamaroneck Ave, White Plains, NY 10605; the League of Women Voters, PO Box 321, Bronxville, NY 10708.

title: Getting the ship back on course

description: SMERLING--Sylvia. Dearest Sylvia, on this summer day, your birthday, we continue the daily conversation as if you were right here beside us and hear your reply in the bird's song and the flower's bloom. With all our love, Doree, Karen, Pearl, Anita, Paolo and Roz

It was Diego Corrales, not Jose Luis Castillo.

description: FOR legions of admirers, the Bolshoi Ballet has never been simply first-rate. With dancing that exudes power and passion, it has always been a company distinct from any other.

description: AGRY--Warren Cram, Jr. of Greenwich, CT died on July 12. He was 82. His wife Nancy Vogt Agry predeceased him in 2000. He is survived by his son Bradford W. Agry of New York City. A long time resident of Rye, New York, Mr. Agry was a member of the Rye Presbyterian Church and The Apawamis Club. A memorial service will be held Monday, July 18, 10 AM at the Rye Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Rye Presbyterian Church, or Dartmouth College, Att: Nancy Bates.

description: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about the Knicks' interview with Paul Westphal for an assistant coaching position referred incorrectly to his tenure with the team. It was two seasons -- 1981-82 and 1982-83 -- not one.

Jr. and his wife Jessica of Bolton, MA, Bryan T. and his wife Elyse of NYC, Kevin M. of NYC and Ann M. Specht and her husband Robert of Carlisle, MA. Grandfather of Olivia and Daniel Weadock, Allison, Danielle and Noelle Weadock, Daniel and Roan Specht. Brother of Walter of NJ, Michael of FL, Kathleen of NJ & Margaret Cossentino of NJ. Funeral Mass Saturday, July 16 at 10AM in Holy Family Parish, Monument Square, Concord Center. Interment St. Bernard's Cemetery, Concord. Visiting hours at the Joseph Dee & Son Funeral Home, 27 Bedford St, Concord Center on Friday 5 to 9. Contributions in his memory may be made to American Heart Association, 20 Speen St, Framingham, MA. 01701 or to Jimmy Fund, 10 Brookline Place West, 6th Fl, Brookline, MA. 02445. Army Veteran. For obituary directions or to sign family guest book, please visit www.deefuneralhome.com

Rehnquist Denies Rumor of Retirement
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 - Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, ending months of increasingly frenzied speculation about his retirement plans, declared on Thursday night that he would continue to serve "as long as my health permits."

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Hackensack: Youths Charged With Terrorizing Cabdrivers
description: Five Bergen County youths have been charged with juvenile delinquency and robbery in connection with a series of nine taxi robberies over the past two months, said John L. Molinelli, the Bergen County prosecutor. Prosecutors said one boy would call a taxi and, when it arrived, a group of boys ranging in age from 15 to 17 would rob the driver and escape on foot. None of the drivers were hurt, and the prosecutors say about $2,000 was stolen. Three other boys are being sought. John Holl (NYT)

title: Where next?
Yankees Face Reality Check on Mound
description: Boston - TELL the Yankees they are flirting with pitching disaster another time. Remind them they have four starters on the disabled list and they can't possibly win the pennant or even make the playoffs with what they have after the glow of last night fades.

title: The BBC advantage
Shuffle of Top Management Completed at Paramount Pictures
description: LOS ANGELES, July 14 - Rob Moore, a partner at Revolution Studios, was named president of marketing, distribution and operations at Paramount Pictures on Thursday.

title: 1 million expected to voteon leader of Kuomintang
All Rock, No Action
description: Yaound, Cameroon - LIVE 8, that extraordinary media event that some people of good intentions in the West just orchestrated, would have left us Africans indifferent if we hadn't realized that it was an insult both to us and to common sense.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: City Contractors Barred For Wage Violations
description: Eleven corporate and individual contractors will be barred for five years from state and city public building work after an investigation of prevailing-wage violations in city projects, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer announced yesterday. As a result of the investigation, conducted by the attorney general's office and the city's Department of Investigation, 147 workers will receive back pay of $4.2 million, he said. The contractors worked on projects for the city's School Construction Authority and Housing Authority.

description: CLUTCHING the armrest in the back of a BMW 330i, D.T. Miller braces for impact. Valerie Kuehne, a 17-year-old from Brevard, N.C., is driving in circles on a patch of wet concrete and trying to throw the car into a skid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STAMM, ESTHER S.
description: STAMM--Esther S. Beloved wife of Robert C. On June 22. Graduate University of Massachusetts. Retired officer of The Rockefeller Foundation. Memorial service 2 PM, July 23, Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church at 73rd St. Contributions may be sent to the church in lieu of flowers.

title: Dead, Buried or Risen Again, Garbage Is Forever
description: Garbage Land On the Secret Trail of Trash By Elizabeth Royte

title: Time to Pull Out. And Not Just From Iraq.
description: Cambridge, Mass. - AMERICAN foreign policy should be guided by two general principles: the first is advancing our security and political interests; the second is encouraging prosperity and responsive government for all people. It may be that with our encouragement and example, many countries will choose to adopt democracy and a market economy, presumably adapted to their own culture. Of course, others will follow a very different road for some time, perhaps indefinitely, as ethnic differences, poverty and historical and religious traditions affect and constrain choices.

title: When a Professional Pillager Decides to Change His Ways
description: Set during an unspecified ancient time in the seldom-captured picturesque locales of India's northwestern desertland and the western Himalayas, Asif Kapadia's feature debut, "The Warrior," which sat on Miramax's overstocked shelves for close to four years, is a minimalist but strikingly beautiful tale of renounced violence told with uncommon precision and depth.

title: Citigroup backs fund started by ousted chief
China's export palette includes cheap art

title: 13 Years Later, an Indictment in a Staten Island Murder Case
description: The authorities on Staten Island said yesterday that they had solved a 13-year-old murder with a grand jury indictment in the killing of a young hospital worker whose throat was slashed, his body found under a pile of brush in Ingram Park.

title: Addenda; Former Ogilvy Executives Sentenced for Overbilling
description: Two former senior executives of the flagship New York office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, have been sentenced and fined after being found guilty of overbilling a federal antidrug agency for advertising work.

title: Candidates in New Jersey Agree on Eminent Domain
description: TRENTON, July 14 - Weighing in on an issue that has generated a national groundswell of discontent, the two candidates for New Jersey governor promised on Thursday to protect homeowners from being victimized by a recent United States Supreme Court ruling on eminent domain.

title: Pushed by Fuel Costs, Delta Increases Cap on Air Fares
description: What a difference seven months and $61-a-barrel oil makes.

Harry Potter and the Frenzied Fans: The 6th Book Draws a Crowd
description: Diehard fans of Harry Potter, and lukewarm readers enticed by the publicity surrounding the release of the sixth Potter book, have been flocking to bookstores across the country today to attend festivities planned around its midnight release.

title: A Cry of 'My Baby! My Baby!' Then Hands Digging at Debris
description: The flood of bricks and plaster spilled in a thunderous crash onto Broadway. In seconds, 30 pairs of hands were digging at the pile. They clawed through dust and rubble. They cleared away a concrete slab.

title: Even After a Few Too Many Rounds, She's Still a Professional
description: Is there anything more exciting than watching a brilliant young performer making her New York City debut? On Wednesday night, the 19-year-old British rapper Lady Sovereign swaggered onto the Knitting Factory stage. O.K., staggered. "I want to jump around," she said. "But if I do, the front row will be covered in vomit."

title: Demolition-Site Collapse Buries 5; All Are Recovered Alive
description: A supermarket under demolition on the Upper West Side of Manhattan collapsed yesterday morning in a thunder of bricks, concrete and scaffolding timbers that engulfed five people, one of them a 7-month-old baby in a stroller, and plunged a neighborhood into a storm of screams, sirens and frantic rescues.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a chart on Friday describing events that led to a criminal investigation of the leak of Valerie Wilson's work under cover for the C.I.A. misstated her whereabouts at the time her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, traveled to Niger in Feb. 2002. She was at the agency's headquarters in Virginia, not in Niger. (Go to Chart)

title: ECB stands firm on rates
Aimless in Gaza
description: The planned withdrawal of Israeli soldiers and settlers from the densely populated Gaza Strip, scheduled to begin about five weeks from now, represents the best chance in five years of moving relations between Israelis and Palestinians to a more peaceful basis. But there is a growing risk that this chance could be squandered through the failure of Israeli and Palestinian leaders to work out even the simplest arrangements for managing the imminent transfer of physical assets and political authority.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Wisconsin: Alderman Indicted In Fraud Case
description: A federal grand jury indicted a Milwaukee alderman on charges of defrauding the government by voting in favor of a $200,000 grant for a corporation he started five years ago. The alderman, Robert G. Donovan, 49, was charged with making a false statement to the Department of Housing and Urban Development and not disclosing his financial connections to the Milwaukee Alliance Inc., a nonprofit community development corporation. If convicted, Mr. Donovan faces one year in prison and a $100,000 fine. Three other aldermen have been indicted in Milwaukee on federal charges of financial misconduct in the last three years. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, MORTIMER
description: LEVITT--Mortimer. On July 12, your great and courageous heart could no longer sustain life in you. During the 98 years you spent on this earth you were known as merchant prince, philanthropist, producer, author, and above all as a confirmed iconoclast. You wanted to live to 104, but you will live much longer because we will carry forward your vision and your dreams. Your wife Mimi, your daughter Elizabeth, and your son Peter, will miss your strong presence and your wonderful sense of humor. You influenced the lives of many people with your intelligence, your creativity, your exquisite taste and your zest for life. We will celebrate your remarkable accomplishments and your extraordinary spirit at a memorial tribute a la Mortimer in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Young Concert Artists, 250 West 57 St., New York, NY, or Friends of the Levitt Pavilion, 85 East Holly St., Pasadena CA. 91103. To receive information about the memorial service send an email to: MortimerMemorial@aol.com LEVITT--Mortimer. The Writing Center at Marymount Manhattan College notes with sadness the passing of our great benefactor and dear friend, Mortimer Levitt. Mortimer once observed that "Endless troubles are the price we must all pay for the gift of life. There are no exceptions," and he urged us all to adopt his motto and philosophy "Keep smiling," to best deal with the absurdity of the situation. To his wonderful wife, Mimi, his great love and guiding spirit, and the rest of his family, we send our deepest sympathies. Lewis Burke Frumkes, Director LEVITT--Mortimer. The musicians, staff and board of directors of the Bard Music Festival mourn the passing of Mortimer Levitt, husband of Mimi Levitt, who is a friend and member of the board. His fabulous and utterly unique personality will be missed. We extend our condolences to his entire family. Robert C. Edmonds, Chair Leon Botstein, Christopher H. Gibbs, and Robert Martin, Coartistic Directors Irene Zedlacher, Exec Dir LEVITT--Mortimer. Everyone at The New Victory Theater will miss the dapper Mortimer Levitt, his pithy comments and his spirited enthusiasm for life and for our shows. He may have been our oldest audience member, but he was certainly the youngest at heart. We all send love to Mimi and the family. Marian S. Heiskell, Chairman Cora Cahan, President The New 42nd Street LEVITT--Mortimer. The Board and staff of the Landmarks Conservancy are saddened by the death of Mortimer Levitt, husband of our long time board member, Mimi Levitt. He was a man of wit, charm and generosity. Our condolences to Mimi and her family. John J. Kerr Jr., Chair Peg Breen, President LEVITT--Mortimer. The Film Society of Lincoln Center deeply mourns the loss of its dear friend and board member. His wisdom and irrepressible humor will be sorely missed by all who have worked with him these many years. The Board and Staff of the Film Society LEVITT--Mortimer. You may have been a curmudgeon, but to us you were always a cherished friend. We shall truly miss your provocative but supportive critiques, and send our love to Mimi, Elizabeth, and Peter. Ronnie and Sam Heyman LEVITT--Mortimer. Mercy College mourns the loss of scholarship benefactor Mortimer Levitt and extends our condolences to Mimi and his family. Louise H. Feroe, President LEVITT--Mortimer. You are unforgettable. A unique influence on all you touched. We cannot miss you--you'll always be with us. Felice

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Contract Awarded For Deutsche Bank Site
description: Pipe scaffolding 535 feet high will be constructed around the former Deutsche Bank building opposite ground zero, under a $13.1 million contract awarded yesterday by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. The Regional Scaffolding and Hoisting Company of the Bronx will begin erecting the scaffolding next month, said Luis F. Mendes, the development corporation's construction director. It will enclose the 41-story tower, badly damaged on 9/11, as it is being demolished. Regional is cited by Guinness for the world's tallest scaffolding, 650 feet high, which girdled the Municipal Building in Lower Manhattan. John C. Whitehead, the chairman of the development corporation, reiterated its commitment to a cultural center at the trade center site -- a plan criticized by some victims' relatives as inappropriate. Mr. Whitehead said officials would take "one last look" for another location, but added it was unlikely to be found. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Briefly on Top, Nicklaus Shoots 75
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 14 - For a brief moment Thursday, Jack Nicklaus was on the leader board at the 134th British Open.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEWIS, NANCY
description: LEWIS--Nancy. Beautiful, adventurous caring daughter. Miss you terribly. Mom, Dad, sisters

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WHITESIDE, ANDREW GLADDING
description: WHITESIDE--Andrew Gladding, passed away July 10, 2005 at age 83. Ph.D. in history from Harvard, full professor at Queens College and author of two books, he will be remembered for his wit, love of cats and the history lesson that was included in every conversation. He is survived by Alice Harnoncourt, his wife of 46 years, son Andrew and daughter Anne.

title: Speaking, and Sweating, for the Senator
description: THE boss, a perpetual motion machine, indulges in no downtime after the homeward leg of the 39-hour round-trip, ending a valiant but vain stint in Singapore meant to put some razzle-dazzle in New York City's bid to host the 2012 Olympics. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton functions best on an endless agenda. No stopovers for her.

title: Swing Senators Meet on the Court Vacancy, but Their Course Remains Uncharted
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 - Members of the so-called Gang of 14, the bipartisan group of senators whose compromise averted a showdown on the process of confirming judicial nominees, met Thursday morning over coffee and Krispy Kreme doughnuts to talk about the Supreme Court vacancy created by the retirement of Justice Sandra Day O'Connor. But their conversation was stymied by the lack of a central ingredient: a nominee.

title: This Time, Rodriguez Enjoys Last Word
description: BOSTON, July 14 - Alex Rodriguez returned to the Yankees' dugout, a safe haven for him in hostile territory, and he wrapped Gary Sheffield in a quick bear hug. He did not smile as he did it. This was business for Rodriguez, and it was personal, too.

title: Running Mom's Comedy Club While Walking a Tightrope
description: This may not be a good time for comedians, but it's a great time for laughingstocks. Jason Alexander and Wanda Sykes can't sustain sitcoms, but reality television viewers can't get enough of the enigmatic stylings of Bobby Brown, Britney Spears, Jose Canseco, Kelly Monaco and Hulk Hogan. And now another punch line -- Pauly Shore -- has turned his tarnished talents to the scoundrels' pastime, reality television, in "Minding the Store," which starts tonight on TBS.

description: Correction Appended

title: INSIDE
description: London Police Say Video Captured Bomb Suspect A surveillance camera caught a man the police identified as Hasib Mir Hussain on July 7 at the Luton rail station. The police say that soon after this, he detonated a bomb on a double-decker bus. He was one of four British men who carried out the suicide bombings that left 54 people dead, the police say. PAGE A6

Wal-Mart Accuses Second Executive in Fraud
description: Wal-Mart Stores said yesterday that a former vice president who contended that he was fired for helping to uncover wrongdoing by another executive was himself involved in the fraud.

Brother of Jane (Peter) Gruber. Beloved Uncle. Family and Friends are invited to his life celebration on Saturday, July 16, from 7-9pm and again on Sunday, July 17, from 11-12 noon followed by his Funeral Service at 12 noon at SwartzGivnish of Newtown, 215968-3891, 323 E. Washington Ave, Newtown, PA. Interment is private. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to Chandler Hall Hospice, 99 Barclay St. Newtown, PA 18940. 215860-4000

title: News Analysis:Seoul relies on silence to sway North
Corrections
description: A festival review on Monday about Tanglewood's opening weekend misidentified the Beethoven piano concerto played by Emanuel Ax. It was the Third, not the Fourth. The review also misidentified the group that played an all-Wagner program on Saturday afternoon with the conductor James Levine in a rehearsal that the critic did not attend. It was the Tanglewood Music Center Orchestra, not the Boston Symphony.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday about settlements to be paid to doctors by health insurers involved in a class-action suit omitted a label. The figures represented millions of dollars. A corrected chart appears today, on Page C2.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the decision of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis, against the Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act referred incompletely to the circumstances in which such abortions occur. While they are indeed performed in cases involving complications of pregnancy, supporters of the ban say the procedure is also used when the pregnant woman and the fetus are healthy.

title: Nanny's Desperate Screams Help Save 7-Month-Old Girl
description: Brunilda Tirado, 56, has three children of her own, all grown, two of them police officers.

title: Middelhoff's lukewarm report
Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: State To Pay Social Workers' School Loans
description: New Jersey will repay student loans for recent graduates who go to work for nonprofit or government social work programs, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey announced yesterday. State legislators have set aside $3.5 million for the program, which begins in January. State officials said the repayments, intended to support qualified social workers, will be offered to recent graduates with bachelor's or master's degrees in social work. Applicants must sign a contract with the state, which will repay up to $5,000 for each year applicants remain in their new jobs, up to a maximum of four years.

title: Still Feeling Like a Natural Woman, and Even Men Sing Along
description: The moment Carole King struck the rolling gospel piano chords of her greatest song, "(You Make Me Feel Like a) Natural Woman," on Wednesday evening at Radio City Music Hall, the house buzzed with a groundswell of excitement. By the time she reached the chorus, the middle-aged audience in the sold-out Music Hall was singing along. The concert, which coincided with the release of an album by Ms. King being sold at Starbucks, "The Living Room Tour" (Rockingale/Concord/Hear Music), was her first New York concert in 12 years.

title: Young Students Post Solid Gains in Federal Tests
description: WASHINGTON, July 14 - America's elementary school students made solid gains in both reading and mathematics in the first years of this decade, while middle school students made less progress and older teenagers hardly any, according to federal test results released on Thursday.

title: Yanks May Lose Wang for Rest of the Season
description: BOSTON, July 14 - The Yankees took a body blow before the first pitch of the second half of the season on Thursday. Chien-Ming Wang, the rookie who has been the Yankees' most consistent starter since his promotion from the minors in April, may be finished for the season because of a shoulder injury.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRIZEL, MILTON
description: BRIZEL--Milton, died Tuesday July 12, 2005. Husband of Marilyn. Father of Robert. Brother of Rita. Preceded in death by parents Sarah and Sigmund Brizel and brother Irving. Born in the Bronx and resided in South Fallsburg for 80 years. Served as an officer in the US Army in WWII as well as in the Korean War. He was an educator, businessman and above all, a raconteur. He will be deeply missed and always remembered. Shiva in New York City at home of sister Rita Brizel.

Care Providers Need a Union, 3 Groups Say
description: New York City's teachers' union, the state teachers' union and Acorn, a grass-roots advocacy group, announced yesterday that they were undertaking one of the biggest unionization drives in the state's history -- an effort to unionize 52,000 home day care providers across the state.

title: Contrary Tales of Vioxx Role in Texan's Death
description: ANGLETON, Tex., July 14 - Two very different lawyers presented two very different opening arguments -- in both style and substance -- Thursday in Ernst v. Merck, the first Vioxx-related lawsuit to reach a jury.

title: Ethicists Offer Advice for Testing Human Brain Cells in Primates
description: If stem cells ever show promise in treating diseases of the human brain, any potential therapy would need to be tested in animals. But putting human brain stem cells into monkeys or apes could raise awkward ethical dilemmas, like the possibility of generating a humanlike mind in a chimpanzee's body.

title: Keeping Shareholders in the Dark
description: THE government had opened a criminal investigation and the company's stock plunged. What was the company to do?

title: Former Executive Guilty of Lesser Charge in Wife's Death
description: TRENTON, July 14 - A former pharmaceutical executive was found guilty on Thursday of killing his wife after she returned home from a rendezvous with her lover and then attempting to cover it up by staging an accident. He could face up to 11 1/2 years in prison.

title: They Went West: Explorers, Traders, Miners, Thieves

title: Dudes Toasting the Newlyweds (and Their Bodacious Guests)
description: What's old is new again, kind of, in the amiably raunchy sex comedy "Wedding Crashers." A wink-wink, nudge-nudge Trojan horse of a story, the film pivots on two cut-rate Lotharios persuasively inhabited by Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn, who love the ladies, but really and truly, cross their cheating hearts, just want a nice girl to call wife. The latest chapter in the endless movie epic about childish men and the women who mother them, this film basically presents an R-rated riff on the usual Mutt and Jeff, Hope and Crosby pairings, "The Road to Bootytown" for Maxim page-flippers.

title: A Miscellany of Angelenos, Meeting in Love and Anger
description: It's possible that Maggie Gyllenhaal will never become a major star, but there isn't an American actress in movies today who holds the screen with as much deep-seated soul. In Don Roos's slyly subversive "Happy Endings," a drama disguised as a wisp of a comedy, Ms. Gyllenhaal plays Jude, a heartbreaker whose throaty voice was made for torch songs and drama. Adrift in a melancholic haze, with pixie hair and long, loose limbs, her eyes rimmed with liner and worry, Jude looks a lot like a doll, one that knows she is fated to be forgotten.

title: The Listings: July 15 -- July 21; SIREN MUSIC FESTIVAL
description: This annual free festival takes over Coney Island for one day every summer, giving fans a chance to prove their devotion by spending nine hours braving the elements: the sun, the fried food, one another. The festival is sponsored by The Village Voice, but while that weekly paper struggles mightily to avoid devoting itself to indie rock, the Siren lineup is usually devoted to nothing but. (Visit http://www.villagevoice.com/specials/siren/ for the full list of performers.) This year's headliner is the great Austin band Spoon, which has perfected a coolly minimalist variant of old-fashioned rock 'n' roll; the singer and songwriter Britt Daniel swaggers and shivers while his bandmates sketch the outlines of songs, using as few notes as possible. Also on the bill: the spaced-out Swedish folk-rock band Dungen, above, the indie-pop duo Mates of State, the post-punk band Q and Not U (which is to disband after the summer), the singer-songwriter Brendan Benson and the hip-hop-inspired poet Saul Williams. One group that may steal the show is Be Your Own Pet, a teenaged punk band from Nashville led by Jemina Pearl, who can be expected to spit out a thrilling version of the band's petulant kiss-off "Damn Damn Leash." It's unfortunate that this festival doesn't have more in common with the mish-mash city -- and, moreover, the mish-mash neighborhood in the mish-mash borough -- where it takes place; the Siren line-up doesn't even try to gesture at the diversity of Coney Island. But maybe that's the idea. This concert, on two stages, usually feels slightly surreal, anyway (no matter what you're imbibing); it's an odd (and often hot) little bubble of indie rock (loosely speaking), and in any case, by the time Spoon closes the show, some attendees may no longer be entirely sure where they are. (Tomorrow at noon to 9 p.m., 1200 Surf Avenue, Coney Island, Brooklyn.) KELEFA SANNEH

Now, as the issue approaches a climactic moment, Mr. Frist, speaking as the Republican majority leader and someone with presidential ambitions, will lead the debate as a convert to President Bush's unrealistic hobbling of full-fledged research financing. The results will affect the fate of a worthy and overdue commitment to add funds for greater research, something that has already been approved by the House.

title: Unprepared and Ill-Equipped for a Serial Killer at Large
description: "Memories of Murder" is such a taut, effective thriller it's a shame you have to read subtitles to gauge just how good a movie it is. If you don't speak Korean, that is. The problem isn't the film's South Korean provenance or that it centers on two detectives tracking a serial killer, perilously overworked terrain. The problem is that persuading audiences to watch foreign-language films by directors they've never heard of has never been easy even if -- and here's my shameless hard sell -- the movie in question works better than most Hollywood thrillers and even those "Law & Order" procedurals with Vincent D'Onofrio.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROBIE, EDWARD ADAMS
description: ROBIE--Edward Adams. 86, died peacefully in the early morning of July 11, 2005 surrounded by his family and loved ones at his Orono, ME home. Ed served on CARE's Executive Board from 1979-1996, acting as Chair from 1986-1989. He embraced CARE's mission of reducing poverty through empowerment, equity and sustainability. While with CARE, Ed led efforts to professionalize CARE's Human Resources, was instrumental in transforming CARE into an international organization, and increased corporate donorship by effectively communicating CARE's mission directly to executives. He and his wife, Jackie, traveled extensively supporting CARE projects and workers around the world. In 1953, Ed became Assistant to the President of the Equitable Life Assurance Society. As Senior Vice President, he pioneered in development of the human resources organization that became the model for industry. In 1982, he created the Group Move and Consulting Services Division of Merrill Lynch Relocation Management, and was President and Chief Operating Officer until 1985. He served as advisor to the Departments of Defense and Navy and on President Nixon's Committee on the Status of Women. He testified as a witness on behalf of industry at hearings of the Privacy Commission, Civil Rights Commission and the Joint Economic Committee. Ed served on numerous boards and committees, including Princeton University's Personnel Advisory Council, the Board of Education for the New Rochelle Public School System, the National Conference of Christians and Jews, the Board of the Harlem School of the Arts, the National Council of the Aging, the American Child Labor Committee and the New York Medical College and the Personnel Committee of the National YMCA. Ed graduated Phillips Academy Andover, Westminster School in England and Phi Beta Kappa from Princeton University's Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs. He was a Navy pilot from 1943-1945, receiving the Distinguished Flying Cross, Air Medal, Navy Commendation and Philippine Liberation Ribbons for his service in the South Pacific. He leaves his wife of 57 years, Jackie, and four children: Betty of Stamford, CT, Ted of Jupiter, FL, Ned of Newport, NC, and Jill of Old Town, ME. He leaves ten grandchildren: Robie, Adam, Theo, Chelsea, John, Teddy, Lissy, Tara, Paige and Anna. There will be a memorial service at the home of his son Ned, at Newport, NC, on August 13, 2005. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to CARE, Attn: Donor relations 151 Ellis St., Atlanta, GA 30303. For information: Birmingham Funeral Home 438 Main Street, Old Town, ME 04468 (207) 827-6369.

description: The championship event of the World Series of Poker at the Rio in Las Vegas wound up last night, but the most impressive feats so far in the first 39 events have to include record 10th bracelets for both Johnny Chan and Doyle Brunson. And Brunson's son, Todd, won an Omaha high-low event, making them the only father-son bracelet holders. Todd has earned millions playing what is called smash-mouth poker - heads-up Hold'em, for example, which is more like a street fight than a subtle 10-handed affair.

title: 36 Hours in Missoula, Mont.
description: TWO hundred years ago, Lewis and Clark made camp beneath cottonwoods near what would become one of Montana's most vibrant communities: Missoula. They called the camp Travelers' Rest, a name that seems odd given that you'll find few Missoulians actually resting once July begins. That's when summer kicks in with the force of a bucking bronco, daylight lasts till 10 p.m., and Missoula's 63,000 people, who know that winter is never far away, pack in as much fun as they can. They'll hit the hills, go fly-fishing or otherwise disport themselves. There are hundreds of miles of trails, four mountain ranges and five major rivers, all within an hour's drive. So there are plenty of reasons to bring boots and a bike -- but none to bring a tie. This onetime logging center, unlike some once-depressed, now-chic Western mountain towns, flaunts its unpolished, industrial edge. Whatever Missoula lacks in cosmopolitan style can be overcome with a Trout Slayer ale, brewed in town, and a well-earned night's sleep. TIM NEVILLE

title: The Listings: July 15 -- July 21; 'GOLF: THE MUSICAL'
description: When "Golf: The Musical" turned up Off Broadway in late 2003, the show description had "irritating novelty" written all over it. A revue consisting entirely of songs about golf? C'mon. But the show was a delightfully silly surprise, and it proved both durable and portable: it ran for almost seven months at the John Houseman Theater, and touring versions hit Michigan, Florida, Arizona, New Mexico and other locations. There's even a version playing at the moment in St. Andrews, Scotland, site of the British Open. Not bad for a show conceived by a guy who doesn't play. That guy, the producer Eric Krebs, has now brought "Golf" back to New York: it's playing on Wednesdays at Sofia's. The show, Mr. Krebs said, was inspired by his very calculated look at pocket musicals like "Forbidden Broadway" and the comedy troupe the Capitol Steps: "I thought to myself; 'What can I do that will have a built-in audience and is going to be really simple to tour, four people and a piano. And I thought of golf, with the foursome." He recruited Michael Roberts to write the show, whose songs -- with titles like "Let's Bring Golf to the Gulf" and "No Blacks, No Chicks, No Jews" -- are a mixture of sly and shameless. Among the rotating foursome at Sofia's will be Joel Blum, above, a member of the original cast, who does a dandy Bob Hope impersonation, part of an audacious Bob-and-Bing routine. He has had many memorable moments while performing "Golf," but the one that really stands out, he said, is one he wasn't involved in. He had to miss a show, and his first-time replacement tried to copy Mr. Blum's golf-club-twirling moves. "He rapped himself right on the forehead," Mr. Blum said. "The blood was just spurting out during the number. Trouper that he was, he wanted to go on, and the audience was saying, 'No, no, go to the hospital!"' (Wednesdays at 2:30 and 8 p.m., Sofia's, 221 West 46th Street, (212)352-3101, www.golfthemusical.com.) NEIL GENZLINGER

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Sakhalin Costs May Rise
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group said costs in the second phase of the Sakhalin II gas project, which it leads, were significantly underestimated and may double to $20 billion, delaying the project by half a year. Shell did not say how much of the extra costs it would bear. At present Shell's stake stands at 55 percent, but a week ago Shell signed a major asset swap with Gazprom that would give Gazprom up to 25 percent of the project.

title: In Love With Harry, Over and Over Again
description: While the world tends to focus on the next new thing, devoted readers often return to the beloved familiar, again and again. For some, the draw is complexity, the why of the whale in "Moby-Dick." For others, the lure is to rekindle the pleasure of a juicy tale read at a particular moment in time. But perhaps no group today rereads more faithfully (make that compulsively) than the young fans of Harry Potter. And nothing inspires them to look backward more than the prospect of a new volume.

description: BEIJING, Friday, July 15 - China should use nuclear weapons against the United States if the American military intervenes in any conflict over Taiwan, a senior Chinese military official said Thursday.

title: A Poverty of Dignity and a Wealth of Rage
description: A few years ago I was visiting Bahrain and sitting with friends in a fish restaurant when news appeared on an overhead TV about Muslim terrorists, men and women, who had taken hostages in Russia. What struck me, though, was the instinctive reaction of the Bahraini businessman sitting next to me, who muttered under his breath, "Why are we in every story?" The "we" in question was Muslims.

title: The Listings: July 15 -- July 21; BILL CHARLAP
description: When it was announced last year that the pianist Bill Charlap would replace Dick Hyman as the artistic director of the 92nd Street Y's long-running Jazz in July series, you could hear a soft, secure click. Mr. Hyman's concerts were always driven by a keen musicianly brain, connecting the dots of history and style; they focused especially on the first third of jazz's history. Bill Charlap, above, who is only 38, has a system of musical values that goes in slightly different places than Mr. Hyman's did, tending more seriously toward musical-theater songs and postwar jazz piano. But he won't fragment Jazz in July's constituency; he's into history and beauty and subtleties as well, and his first series of shows over the next two weeks look extremely promising. Tuesday's opening concert, "Gershwin's Vision," features new septet arrangements of Gershwin's music by Mr. Charlap, created around his own first-rate trio along with others including the saxophonist Houston Person and the trumpeter Jeremy Pelt. (On the same subject, Mr. Charlap has just released a new Gershwin-themed album on Blue Note, with typically ironclad focus, called "The American Soul.") Wednesday's show, "Continuum," lines up pianists from a few different generations -- Mr. Charlap, Renee Rosnes, Mulgrew Miller, Ray Bryant, and Hank Jones -- showing how the mainstream jazz-piano style has evolved. On Thursday, "A Portrait of Jim Hall" brings the great jazz guitarist to the foreground, mixing him among excellent soloists (Joe Lovano, Peter Bernstein) and a string section. (Tuesday through Thursday, 8 p.m., 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, (212)415-5500 or www.92y.org, $45.) BEN RATLIFF

title: Mexico Says 2 Agents Sought to Blackmail Salinas Brother
description: OAXACA, Mexico, July 14 - Nearly eight months after the brother of former President Carlos Salinas de Gortari was discovered smothered to death, two federal agents were arrested Thursday and charged with trying to extort millions of dollars from him.

title: Arts, Briefly; Tribute to London Victims
description: The BBC Proms concerts, the annual summer extravaganza at the Royal Albert Hall in London, open tonight and will be dedicated to the victims of the terror bombings last week, said Nicholas Kenyon, the festival's director. "The whole mood here is very positive," he said in an e-mail message. "Life goes on, and we want to be as upbeat as possible." The festival offers 74 concerts and runs through Sept. 10. Opening night will be televised on a giant screen in Trafalgar Square and elsewhere in Britain. Two of the works in that program, scheduled before the bombings, turn out be apt, Mr. Kenyon noted: Michael Tippett's oratorio "A Child of Our Time," dealing with man's inhumanity to man, and Elgar's concert overture "Cockaigne," celebrating the indomitable spirit of London. DANIEL J. WAKIN

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Actor Rejects Plea In Harassment Case
description: The actor Christian Slater, left, who was arrested in May and charged with groping a passer-by on the Upper East Side, rejected a plea deal yesterday that would have required him to serve three days of community service in exchange for pleading guilty to second-degree harassment. Mr. Slater did not speak during his appearance in Manhattan Criminal Court, but his lawyer, Eric Franz, turned down the arrangement, saying, "We believe this case warrants dismissal." Prosecutors have charged that Mr. Slater grabbed the buttocks of a woman who was standing outside a deli on Third Avenue and 94th Street. Judge Richard Weinberg told Mr. Slater to return to court on Sept. 19, rejecting his request for a later date that would not interfere with his London stage appearance in "Sweet Bird of Youth." Andrew Jacobs (NYT)

He did not want to subject his children to another year of shuttling between New York and the family's off-season home in Tampa, Fla.

title: Arts, Briefly; Brats Hike to Popularity
description: ABC has traded in dancing for delinquents. Its summer success "Dancing With the Stars" ended last week, so its Wednesday lineup is now anchored by "Brat Camp," in which troubled teenagers, below, are rehabilitated through enforced hiking. The results in Nielsen's estimates were the same as on recent Wednesdays: ABC easily won the night in all key ratings measures, as the two-hour series premiere of "Brat Camp" brought in 10.28 million viewers and won every half-hour among the 18-to-49 demographic. At 10 p.m., however, "Lost" drew less than half of that, with an audience of 5.03 million. The Emmy-nominated series was beaten by reruns of NBC's "Law & Order" (8.86 million) and CBS's "CSI: NY" (7.68 million). Despite the success of "Lost" and ABC's other first-year hit, "Desperate Housewives," during the regular season, repeats of these shows are performing poorly in the summer ratings. KATE AURTHUR

title: Muslim Approval of Terrorism Declines, a Global Poll Finds

On a recent ride were a striking array of passengers: a deeply tanned lesbian couple with hairdos like 80's rocker chicks, a 30-something straight couple with a baby, a gaggle of smartly dressed young men with a tiny yipping dog, a flamboyant gentleman wearing piles of gold chain bracelets and a buxom woman with long fingernails painted the same glowing orange as the Knicks number on her team jersey. Passengers chatted excitedly over a fierce bay wind.

The matte black and solid chrome cruisers, draped with young men in mesh-back caps, clustered outside the local dive on Washington Boulevard. At Windward Avenue an art girl in thrift-store couture pedals past, a Paul Frank monkey mugging from her bike's shiny red frame. These days it seems beach cruisers catch your eye everywhere you go in Venice, even at the beach.

title: Six Characters in Search of a Job
description: This is just speculation, of course, but it would seem that Kevin Doyle ate a large helping of Sartre, Kafka and a few similar dishes, finished things off with a "Twilight Zone" sundae, then went to bed and dreamed "The Position," his 90-minute comic nightmare about six men awaiting a job interview. The play, one of a half-dozen getting a quick look during the Ice Factory 2005 festival at the Ohio Theater, has the obligatory elliptical dialogue and some big laughs, but it also has enough dead spots to make you wonder whether this particular theatrical vein is tapped out.

title: Arts, Briefly; Here Comes the Frog
description: In May, a bouncy electronic pop song credited to a cartoon frog became a No. 1 hit in Britain, outselling the new single by Coldplay by four to one. Now that frog is coming to America. The song, by Crazy Frog, is a remake of the 1980's instrumental hit "Axel F," began as a cellphone ringtone and spent four weeks at the top of the British singles chart. It will be released here in September on the Universal label, Billboard reported. An album, "Crazy Hits," will be released in Britain on July 25, and a new Crazy Frog song, a remake of the 1972 hit "Popcorn," is to be released on Aug. 25. BEN SISARIO

title: The Listings: July 15 -- July 21; 'JESUS CHRIST SUPERSTAR: 140 YEARS OF JESUS CHRIST IN PHOTOGRAPHY'
description: Jesus Christ was a superstar long before a Broadway musical called him one, as centuries of Western painting and sculpture attest. That he has been a constant presence in the relatively modern medium of photography is somehow more surprising. His ubiquity is the subject of "Jesus Christ Superstar: 140 Years of Jesus Christ in Photography" at the Bruce Silverstein Gallery in Chelsea. With images by nearly 50 artists and photographers, including works by Diane Arbus, Man Ray and Walker Evans, the exhibition runs the historical, technical and emotional gamut. One of the earliest works is Secondo Pia's 1898 photograph of the Shroud of Turin; among the recent are three photographs by Frederick T. Zugibe, a doctor, documenting a simulated crucifixion. Some inclusions are expected, like Andres Serrano's plastic crucifix submerged in urine from 1987; F. Holland Day's misty Pictorialist stagings of scenes from Christ's life from 1898; and the color photographs documenting Hermann Nitsch's campy, creepy Actionist performances, laced with animal entrails and Catholic imagery and arranged in crosses. Less familiar are Paul Strand's startling photograph, taken in Connecticut in the late 1930's, of a skeleton crucified on a swastika; Frantisek Drtikol's self-portrait naked on a cross, from 1914;and three images by the painter Jose Maria Sert that depict the descent from the cross using small wood figures, a study for a mural and also an early instance of set-up photography. The Last Supper is the template for images by Vic Muniz (in chocolate), Annie Liebowitz (the cast of "The Sopranos"), Rene Cox (with the artist as Christ) and most affectingly, Raoef Mamedov, in which all roles are played by men with Down's Syndrome. The show also reminds us that many religious narratives grow out of the basic human condition. A wrenching image from W. Eugene Smith's Minimata series, of a mother bathing her handicapped son, forms an inadvertent pita. Bill Eppridge's news photograph "Robert Kennedy Shot" is an instance of contemporary martyrdom. Theresa Frare's "Final Moment," above, from 1990, shows David Kirby, an early AIDS activist who looks eerily like Christ, on his death bed, surrounded by his anguished family. Included in the 2003 book "Life 100 Photos That Changed the World," it captures the reality of grief in a way that is beyond the reach of most art. (Bruce Silverstein Galley, 535 West 24th Street, (212)627-3930. through July 29; free.) ROBERTA SMITH

title: Argentine Ruling Revives Cases of 'Dirty War' Victims
description: BUENOS AIRES, July 12 - Before they killed him and dumped his body in a still-unknown location, the state security agents responsible for the death of Jos Poblete toyed with him like a cat plays with a mouse. Mr. Poblete had lost his legs in an accident, and in torture sessions his captors would dump him out of his wheelchair, mock him as he lay on the floor and call him "Shorty."

description: UNITED NATIONS, July 14 - Four countries that have mounted a joint diplomatic offensive to gain permanent seats on the Security Council -- Brazil, Germany, India and Japan -- are facing unexpectedly strong opposition from the United States, the African Union and regional rivals, just days before a decisive General Assembly vote.

title: In Poker, a Mouth Says a Lot, Even When Closed
description: LAS VEGAS, July 14 - His nickname is "The Mouth," and for six days at the World Series of Poker, Mike Matusow has shown it is well earned. Last Saturday, less than an hour into his opening round, he was banished from the table for 40 minutes for violating the tournament's rule against profanity. It hardly quieted him.

title: Unocal's Board Decides to Continue Talking With Chinese
description: Despite mounting opposition in Washington, the board of Unocal, the American oil company at the center of a takeover battle, instructed its management yesterday to continue negotiations with a government-backed Chinese oil company to seek a higher bid than its $18.5 billion offer, executives close to the company said.

description: GRAY--Ervin, 63, of Secaucus, NJ, on July 12, 2005. Beloved husband of Willett. Loving father of Lt. Col. Andre Gathers (Carmen), stationed in Germany. Brother of Andrena Montgomery of Greensboro, N.C., Martha Lee Coaxum (Frederick) of Brooklyn, NY, Andrew Gray (Elayne) of Clinton, MD, Robert Gray and Vernon C. Gray of Charleston, S.C. Father-in-law, Lawrence Johnson of Columbia, MD; aunt, Louise Cox of Charleston, S.C.; sisters-in-law, Barbara Ward (George) of Mount Pleasant, S.C., and Kathleen Wragg of Columbia, MD. Brothers-inlaw, Lawrence Johnson Jr. (Yolanda) of Columbia, MD, Durand Harrell (Valerie) of Bowie, MD. Grandson, Andrew Gathers Jr., and a host of nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. Viewing from 11 AM-2 PM at Mack Memorial Home, 1245 Paterson Plank Road, Secaucus, NJ. Funeral services to follow at 2 PM. GRAY--Ervin C. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Ervin C. Gray, associated with The Times from July 1966 until retiring in June 2001.

A devoted teacher at Jamaica High School for many years. Service Sunday, 9AM, at "Sinai Chapels," 162 - 05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHULTE, JOHN H.
description: SCHULTE--John H., 85, of State College, formerly of Brooklyn and Massapequa, New York, died Tuesday, July 12, 2005. Born October 7, 1919 in New York City, he was a son of the late William and Rose Casey Schulte. He grew up in Brooklyn during the Depression and helped support his mother, disabled father and younger brothers. On November 27, 1943, he married Edna May Donegan, who died July 20, 2000. He was the Delivery Foreman for the New York Times, retiring in 1983 after 27 years. He was former member of Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church in Massapequa, New York. He was a retired member of the Newspaper & Mail Deliverers Union in NYC. He is survived by his son, David L. Schulte and his wife Patricia of State College, three grandchildren, two great grandchildren, and a brother, Frank Schulte of Rancho Santa Fe, CA. He was preceded in death by two brothers, William and George Schulte. Burial will be in Old Stone Fort Cemetery in Schoharie, NY on Saturday July 16 at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Our Lady of Lourdes Church, 855 Carmans Road, Massapequa Park, New York 11762. SCHULTE--John H. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John H. Schulte, associated with The Times from December 1946 until retiring in June 1983.

title: Wells Appeals Suspension and Defeats the Yankees
description: BOSTON, July 15 - David Wells sat slouched at his locker before Friday night's game, leafing through a magazine and relishing a few quiet moments before his start.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about Truman Capote and two movies about his approach to nonfiction writing misstated the timing of a lawsuit against Janet Malcolm, who has written about the ethics and methods of such writing. It was before The New Yorker's publication of two articles she wrote on the relationship between a writer and a former Green Beret accused of murder, not afterward.

title: Hope of Fed rate rise underpins the dollar
Harry Potter: A Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Challenger to Morgenthau Tops Him in Fund-Raising
description: Leslie Crocker Snyder, a former State Supreme Court judge who has never run for public office, has raised more than $1 million in the last six months in her campaign for Manhattan district attorney, outpacing the incumbent she hopes to defeat, Robert M. Morgenthau.

title: When museums play a commodities game
Plea Agreement in Balco Case Draws Criticism
description: Victor Conte Jr., the central figure in the steroids scandal that linked the use of performance-enhancing drugs to some of the country's top professional baseball, football and track and field athletes, pleaded guilty yesterday in a deal with federal prosecutors that was strongly criticized by anti-doping experts.

title: Court Gutting in Congress
description: Congress is quietly considering whether to destroy one of the pillars of constitutional law: the habeas corpus power of the federal courts to determine whether an indigent defendant has been unjustly sentenced to death in state courts.

title: News Corp. Puts Web Businesses Into New Unit
description: In the latest effort by a big media company to get its arms around the Internet, the News Corporation yesterday announced the creation of a division to house its interactive businesses.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Venezuela: Protest Against Cuban Doctors
description: Hundreds of doctors protested in Caracas, saying their jobs were in danger because of a government program that has brought in 20,000 Cuban doctors and dentists. The Cuban doctors are popular in poor neighborhoods, where health care had been rare, but Venezuelan medical workers say that the Cubans are unqualified and that the program that brought them to Venezuela siphons off money for medical equipment. President Hugo Chvez has close ties with the Cuban government, which receives cut-rate oil shipments in return for sending medical teams to Venezuela. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: German testifies on visas
World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Bird Flu Suspected In 3 Deaths
description: Indonesian health officials said the bird flu virus was the probable cause of the deaths of a 38-year-old man and his two daughters. If confirmed, these would be the first people to have been killed by bird flu in Indonesia. Blood samples have tested positive for the virus, but further tests will be conducted. Officials also said they had no evidence that the victims had any contact with poultry, raising the possibility of human-to-human transmission of the virus. Evelyn Rusli (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A review on July 4 about the Sounds of the Underground metal tour misidentified the band and singer who performed the song with the lines "This isn't at all unpleasant / I'm enchanted by the lavish ballet" and misstated its title. The song is "Off Broadway," not "Bayonetwork"; it was sung by Keith Buckley of Every Time I Die, not by Cory Brandan of Norma Jean, who also performed.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Antiques column in Weekend yesterday referred incorrectly to the piece of furniture shown. It was a dressing table, not a high chest.

title: Profit falls at Samsung, but outlook is brighter
Anger Burns on the Fringe of Britain's Muslims
description: LEEDS, England, July 15 - At Beeston's Cross Flats Park, in the center of this now embattled town, Sanjay Dutt and his friends grappled Friday with why their friend Kakey, better known to the world as Shehzad Tanweer, had decided to become a suicide bomber.

title: U.S. Forces Kill 24 Militants Fleeing to Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI, July 15 - American troops killed 24 men suspected of being Taliban fighters fleeing Afghanistan into Pakistani territory, the Pakistani military said Friday, but left unclear whether American forces had crossed into Pakistani territory.

title: Wanted: Pitchers Who Can Get Outs
description: BOSTON, July 15 - By necessity, the Yankees keep using pitchers who were not supposed to reach a major league clubhouse this season, at least not the Yankees' clubhouse. Where have you gone, Sean Henn, Colter Bean, Jason Anderson, Darrell May and Tim Redding? The better question would be, "Who are you?"

title: Don't count pope among Harry Potter fans
Immigration Sting Puts 2 U.S. Agencies at Odds
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 - The 48 immigrants thought they were attending mandatory safety training by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. But it was not until they showed up to the meeting in Goldsboro, N.C., last week that they discovered they had been summoned for an altogether different reason.

title: Shuttle Launching May Proceed Without Sensor Solution
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 15 - NASA officials confessed Friday that they were still perplexed by the fuel sensor malfunction that caused them to scrub the liftoff of the shuttle Discovery on Wednesday, and they postponed the shuttle's return to orbit until next Friday at the earliest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTZ, WILLIAM N.
description: HARTZ--William N. July 13, 2005 at age 83. Beloved husband of Joan (Fellerman). Devoted father of Randee, David, Cindi, Suzie and the late Kenneth. Cherished grandfather of eight. Loving brother of Toby Hornstein and Allan Kaplan. Alumnus of Baruch College of CCNY. Bill's integrity, intelligence and skill made him a leading producer at Salomon, Smith Barney from 1957 to the present. Service Sunday, July 17th, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cornell-NY Presbyterian Hospital, Division of Cardiology, 525 E. 68 St., NY, NY 10021.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Tied to Threat to Blow Up New Jersey Trains
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested in Newark on Thursday and charged with threatening to blow up commuter trains in New Jersey one day after the subway and bus bombings in London, the authorities said yesterday.

title: GE banks on Third World as key to growth
Hard Time for a White-Collar Criminal, Good Times for Apple
description: A federal judge sent a message to corporate leaders about their fiduciary duty when she handed down a particularly long jail term to a wayward chief executive. Across town, meanwhile, a big investment bank agreed to pay a departing co-president two years' salary for three months' work.
