description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Ruling Lets U.S. Restart Trials at Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 - A federal appeals court ruled unanimously on Friday that the military could resume war crimes trials of terrorism suspects at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, which were suspended last year.

title: Kidnap Attempt in Bronx
description: A 37-year-old Bronx man was arrested and charged with attempted kidnapping, sodomy and endangering the welfare of a child yesterday, the police said.

title: Religion's Debate With Secularism Might Benefit From Review of Social Forces at Play
description: Religious leaders spend a great deal of energy denouncing secularism. Perhaps they should spend more trying to understand secularization.

title: Fans around the world swoop on new 'Harry Potter' volume
Bush adviser's talk with columnist described
G.E. Becomes a General Store for Developing Countries
description: Correction Appended

title: City Nannies Say They, Too, Can Be Mother Lions
description: For 8, 10, sometimes 14 hours a day, they wipe apple juice off sticky chins, chide wobbly toddlers lurching toward a staircase, snuggle dusty 2-year-olds as they make their way from the playground.

title: Envy
Prime Minister Blair's Speech
description: The following is the text of the speech delivered by Prime Minister Tony Blair on Saturday, July 16, 2005.

title: World Briefings
description: ASIA

title: Growth and Low Inflation Keep Rally Going for 3rd Week
description: Bolstered by new signs that the economy is growing nicely while inflation is still in check, the stock market posted its third consecutive weekly gain this week.

title: Norman Raab, 89, a Co-Founder of Villager Clothing Line, Dies
description: Norman Raab, a co-founder of the Villager line of women's clothing that was a mainstay of country club and collegiate style in the 1960's, died Saturday at his home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 89.

title: Yanks Are Reminded How 17-1 Feels
description: BOSTON, July 15 - It was obvious very early on that the Yankees would have no chance to beat the Boston Red Sox on Friday night. Their flagging pitching staff was just not up to it. When reliever Buddy Groom warmed up to Cheap Trick's "Surrender" in the sixth inning, it seemed as if the Fenway Park disc jockey was piling on.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Colombia: Top Cocaine Boss Arrested
description: The authorities said they had captured one of Colombia's top cocaine kingpins, Jose Aldemar Rendn, who is wanted by federal prosecutors in New York for trafficking 500 tons of cocaine since 1999. Mr. Rendn, 54, one of the top leaders in the Norte del Valle cartel, was captured by the police on a farm in northern Antioquia Province. He had a $5 million bounty on his head and is expected to be extradited soon. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: Doctor on Dating Show Faced Licensing Hearing
description: Dr. Lisa Aptaker appears on the ABC Web site for "Hooking Up," the new documentary series about the world of online dating, saying that she has a tough time partly because she does not post her picture and conceals her name and occupation. On Thursday night, the 36-year-old gynecologist could be seen on the first show of the five-part series giving a false name to a surgeon during a date and refusing to disclose her profession.

title: Business Digest
description: McDonald's Expects Second-Quarter Earnings To Surpass Wall Street Expectations

title: Briefs: EU approves Gillette deal
Roundup: Founder of Balco to plead guilty
Paid Notice: Memorials   GLAZER, SIMON
description: GLAZER--Simon. Tim Dear, it's been a long, lonesome twenty years without you. Love, Val

title: Making Clothes for the Forgotten Man
description: Henry Jacobson is not yet a household name. But he wants to be.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accusations Against Ex-Premier
description: A Kremlin rival and potential presidential candidate faced a blistering public attack from a senior prosecutor who accused of him rigging a real estate deal at the expense of the Russian state. The accused, former Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov, began criticizing the Kremlin after being fired by President Vladimir V. Putin last year. He has been under increasing pressure since hinting that he may seek the presidency in the next election, in 2008. Deputy Prosecutor Vladimir Kolesnikov told the Interfax news agency that in 2003, when Mr. Kasyanov was in office, he directed a prime piece of state-owned real estate to himself for a deeply discounted price. Mr. Kasyanov did not immediately respond to the allegation. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Appeals Court Frees Somali Man Held 6 Years in Deportation Case
description: Six months after the Supreme Court approved his deportation despite the violence and chaos plaguing his homeland, a Somali man who has spent nearly six years jailed in immigration limbo will instead be set free, perhaps as soon as today, according to an appellate court order issued yesterday afternoon.

title: Students Say High Schools Let Them Down
description: Correction Appended

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-8

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on July 2 about military recruiting at Nascar events referred incorrectly to a sponsor for the Busch Series driver Kim Crosby. It was BMAR & Associates, a defense contractor, not the Army, although the racecar displayed the logos of the Army, the Navy, the Air Force and the Marines. The article also referred incorrectly to a statement made by Col. Tom Nickerson, who is in charge of the Army's recruiting outreach program. He said that the Army would spend $16 million on Nascar this year -- not that sponsorship of Crosby was part of that total.

title: Stream of Bouquets for a Romantic Farewell
description: "Giselle" is a ballet about any mother's nightmare: a daughter loses everything -- her judgment, her dignity and ultimately her life -- for the sake of a two-timer. For such a tale to work there must be a spark between the lead couple, especially if the audience is to accept the rest of the story, in which ghostly Wilis, the spirits of maidens who die before their wedding nights, come to life in the second act, forcing any male intruder to dance to his death.

title: DoCoMo: Growth stock or utility?
Opposition's security plans bring uproar in Germany
World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Court Blocks Tsunami Aid Deal
description: A court in Sri Lanka issued a temporary injunction on parts of an agreement signed last month to share $3 billion in post-tsunami reconstruction funds between the government and the rebel Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, who hold parts of the country's north and east. The order follows a petition by a hard-line ethnic Sinhala nationalist party that criticized the aid-sharing deal with the rebels as unconstitutional and pulled out from the coalition government. Tensions have been rising between the government and rebels, and clashes in the east of the country have threatened a three-year-long cease-fire. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

description: Arnold Schwarzenegger, the writer, has many voices.

title: Loud, Alternative and Still Definitive
description: Those loud and melancholy songs, those monumental guitar lines and mumbly vocals: Dinosaur Jr. helped create the sound that would define the alt-rock boom of the 1990's. But so what? On Thursday night, the three founding members -- the singer and guitarist J. Mascis, the bassist Lou Barlow, the drummer Murph -- came to Central Park to put on a glorious show, and to remind fans of an older connection.

title: U.S. Rebukes Chinese General for His Threat of Nuclear Arms Use
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 - A Chinese general who said his country would use nuclear weapons against the United States if the American military intervened in any conflict with Taiwan drew a sharp rebuke from the Bush administration on Friday.

title: Seoul and Pyongyang
description: To the Editor:

title: In Cairo Suburb, Man in Bombing Inquiry Is Described as Committed to His Studies
description: CAIRO, July 15 - Mahmoud Mustafa el-Nashar, the elderly father of the Egyptian man being questioned by the police about possible links to the London suicide bombers, sat slumped in one corner of the family's narrow apartment in a battered Cairo suburb late Friday, stunned that his son had gone downstairs for evening prayers a day earlier and never returned.

title: Large pro-Arroyo rally set in Manila
Balance Sheet: No magical solution

description: LEBANON, Ohio, July 15 - Michelle Wie's dream of becoming the first female player to compete in the Masters might come true one day, but it will not happen next year. Wie was beaten by Clay Ogden, 5 and 4, in the quarterfinals of the men's United States Amateur Public Links championships Friday.

title: S.E.C. Queries Brokers on Pricing Option Trades
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether major brokerage firms are fulfilling their obligation to secure the best price for customers who are trading options, according to a letter sent to Wall Street brokers.

description: To the Editor:

title: At 65, a Legend Bids Farewell With a Birdie
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland - TO know where Jack Nicklaus was on the Old Course in the 134th British Open, you just had to listen for the applause that followed him from hole to hole. And as he walked up the 18th fairway here for the last time, the cheers from the thousands of spectators in the grandstands and in front of the adjacent shops, homes and hotels grew louder -- warm, loving applause unlike any other for a golfer unlike any other.

title: Blair Calls Fight on Terror a 'Battle of Ideas'
description: LONDON, July 16 A In a major speech drawing battle lines for the global response to terrorism, Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that "evil ideology" could only be beaten by confronting its "symptoms and causes, head-on, without compromise or delusion."

description: An article on Thursday about a decision by the Episcopal bishop of Connecticut to remove a priest from his duties because he felt the priest had taken an unauthorized sabbatical referred incorrectly to the $77,000 balance on a loan the diocese had made to the priest's church in Bristol. It has not been repaid.

title: Whether Winning Or Losing, Mets Find The Middle Ground
description: The Mets resume their 10-game homestand tonight at Shea Stadium with the odds overwhelmingly in favor of a split.

title: Near a Breakthrough at the Baltimore Symphony
description: The conducting podiums of large American orchestras have historically been an all-male province, but the Baltimore Symphony may finally be changing that. On Wednesday, a 21-member search committee voted to make the American conductor Marin Alsop the orchestra's next music director. If her appointment is ratified by the orchestra's board on Tuesday, she will become the first woman to lead a major American orchestra.

title: Modest gains seen for hedge funds :
Woods Pulls Away, but It's Nicklaus's Day
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 15 - They bumped into each other in a small tent around dinnertime on the eastern edge of the Old Course, Jack Nicklaus with tears in his eyes, Tiger Woods with visions of a major championship in his.

title: Tolerating a Time Bomb
description: AMSTERDAM - FOR centuries the Netherlands has been considered the most tolerant and liberal nation in the world. This attitude is a byproduct of a disciplined civic society, confident enough to provide space for those with different ideas. It produced the country in which Descartes found refuge, a center of freedom of thought and of a free press in Europe.

title: People: Valentino, Cameron Diaz, Christian Slater, Bob Dylan
Paid Notice: Deaths   WILCOX, RONALD M.
description: WILCOX--Ronald M. 79, of NY died on July 12, 2005. Former chief of psychology for the Manhattan VA Hospital. He is survived by his wife Venoris, three children; Ronald, Shonna and Keith, and three grandchildren. Services 12:30 PM Sunday, Marble Collegiate Church, 5th Ave and 29th St., NY, NY.

A $600 Baby Stroller Comes Out of the Rubble and Into the Spotlight
description: It is impossible to say with certainty that the Mountain Buggy Urban Double Stroller -- which costs roughly half the monthly rent of a small Brooklyn apartment -- actually saved Abigail Lurensky, 7 months old, as a Manhattan building collapsed around her on Thursday.

title: After Taking On Car Safety, Moving On in Washington
description: DETROIT, July 15 - Dr. Jeffrey W. Runge was not what one might have expected as the Bush administration's top auto safety regulator.

title: Moses' Top Ten
description: The Ten Commandments have a shot at being named Time magazine's man of the year. This week, a Wall Street Journal/NBC News poll showed that 63 percent of the respondents want President Bush to appoint a Supreme Court nominee who supports "allowing displays of the Ten Commandments on government property." The Conservative Caucus is even petitioning the president to appoint the former, as in fired, Alabama chief justice, Roy Moore, the legal whiz who defied a federal court order to remove a Ten Commandments monument from the lobby of Montgomery's state judicial building.

description: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince By J.K. Rowling Illustrations by Mary GrandPr. 652 pages. Arthur A. Levine/Scholastic. $29.99.

title: The Thrilling True Adventures of Atlanta's Baby-Faced Braves
description: Shortly before the Atlanta Braves played the Mets at Shea Stadium last night, Brian McCann, the 21-year-old rookie catcher, sat in the clubhouse facing his locker. From behind him came Jeff Francoeur, the 21-year-old rookie right fielder.

title: Showgirls in Their Autumn, Minus Frost
description: SHEFFIELD, Mass., July 14 - Dazzling, depressing, brilliant, shallow, cynical, sentimental. Big and contradictory adjectives have been applied routinely to that beautiful and damned musical "Follies" since it was first staged in 1971. No one, to my knowledge, has described it simply as sweet.

title: China calls Japan plan for drilling 'a violation'
One Person's Catastrophe
description: We're sure no one in Washington would argue that the life of an airplane passenger is more precious than that of a subway rider. But remarks made this week by Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff certainly left that impression.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Escapes on May 27 about new restaurants and other changes in the Hamptons and a listing in the Dining Guide published with the Long Island section on June 26 reported that the Tuscan House restaurant of Riverhead, N.Y., was moving to Southampton. In fact the restaurant remains open in Riverhead, at 673 Osborne Avenue, (631)727-2330.

title: Arts Guide
Palmeiro Delivers 3,000th Career Hit
description: SEATTLE, July 15 - Rafael Palmeiro became the 26th player in major league history, and the third Latin player, to join the 3,000-hit club Friday night with a fifth-inning double against the Mariners.

title: Yes, Take Back Memorial
description: To the Editor:

title: Yankees Have Plan to Fill Out Rotation
description: BOSTON, July 15 - The state of the Yankees' rotation improved slightly Friday, if only because the team appeared to have found two bodies to fill the fourth and fifth spots. A day earlier, after announcing that Chien-Ming Wang had a serious shoulder injury, the Yankees could not even say that much.

title: Phone Quarrel Led to Death of Queens Man, His Friends Say
description: A Queens man was stabbed to death early Thursday by a woman he was dating after he told her during a long argument on the telephone that he did not feel like coming to her apartment, his relatives and friends said yesterday.

title: Egyptian Biochemist Is Arrested in Cairo and Questioned in the London Bombings
description: LONDON, July 15 - As Britain stepped up its global investigation into the London bombings, Egypt on Friday announced the arrest of an Egyptian biochemist in Cairo while the British police admitted that another potential suspect had escaped detection because he was not considered a serious security risk.

title: Bush Stays Mum on Rove, Who Stays by His Side
description: DALLAS, N.C., July 15 - For the second day in a row, Karl Rove was at President Bush's side in a highly public appearance on Friday, a signal that Mr. Bush continues to support him as the political pressure mounts over Mr. Rove's role in discussing an undercover C.I.A. officer with reporters.

title: Divergent paths for 2 ex-moguls
National Briefing | West: California: Father And Son To Be Deported
description: A Muslim father and son from Lodi, detained on immigration charges since June 6 in connection with an federal investigation into possible terrorist activity, agreed to be deported to Pakistan. The men, Muhammed Adil Khan, 47, an Islamic cleric, and his son, Mohammad Hassan Adil, 19, will leave the United States in exchange for the government's withdrawal of accusations that they lied to obtain visas. Carolyn Marshall (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Northwest: Washington: Defeated Candidate Opts Out
description: A month after losing his quest to overturn results of a tight race that put Christine Gregoire, a Democrat, in the governor's office, Dino Rossi said that he would not run for a Senate seat next year. Mr. Rossi, 45, left, who had been courted by Republican Party officials to challenge Senator Maria Cantwell, a Democrat, said he wanted to spend more time with his family. Mr. Rossi lost the election for governor by 129 votes. David Carrillo Pealoza (NYT)

title: Sharp Elbows And Karl Rove
description: To the Editor:

title: Emergency declared in Thailand
Health Care at the Swipe of a Card
description: The paper-pushing method of paying medical bills, which has long been fairly resistant to the electronic age, is about to be challenged as new payment options like health savings accounts and prepaid medical cards gain wider acceptance in the workplace.

title: In the Ring, but Still Attached to the Cellblock
description: GRATERFORD, Pa., July 12 - They met in Cellblock D. Each of them initially kept his guard up, an instinctive reaction for men from a neighborhood where respect had to be earned.

title: Schwarzenegger, Under Fire, Cuts Financial Ties to Magazines
description: LOS ANGELES, July 15 - Reacting to a storm of accusations about a conflict of interest, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger said Friday that he would sever a financial relationship with a publisher of fitness magazines that would have paid him at least $5 million over five years.

title: Making new connections
Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, MORTIMER
description: LEVITT--Mortimer. On July 12, your great and courageous heart could no longer sustain life in you. During the 98 years you spent on this earth you were known as merchant prince, philanthropist, producer, author, and above all as a confirmed iconoclast. You wanted to live to 104, but you will live much longer because we will carry forward your vision and your dreams. Your wife Mimi, your daughter Elizabeth, and your son Peter, will miss your strong presence and your wonderful sense of humor. You influenced the lives of many people with your intelligence, your creativity, your exquisite taste and your zest for life. We will celebrate your remarkable accomplishments and your extraordinary spirit at a memorial tribute a la Mortimer in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Young Concert Artists, 250 West 57 St., New York, NY, or Friends of the Levitt Pavilion, 85 East Holly St., Pasadena CA. 91103. To receive information about the memorial service send an email to: MortimerMemorial@aol.com

title: Double-Digit Earnings Growth Posted by All of G.E.'s Units
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its revenue for the second quarter rose 13 percent, to $41.56 billion, and that its earnings jumped 24 percent, to $4.6 billion or 44 cents a share, in line with analysts' expectations.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Bush Nominates Wildlife Chief
description: President Bush nominated Dale Hall as the new head of the Fish and Wildlife Service, the administration's point person on wildlife protection. Interior Secretary Gale A. Norton praised Mr. Hall as forging consensus with other federal agencies and interest groups on issues like the distribution of water in San Joaquin Valley in California and restoration of the Florida Everglades. But Mr. Hall, who heads the New Mexico regional office, has been rebuked by colleagues for telling his staff to ignore new findings in genetics when deciding what measures would help endangered species. Felicity Barringer (NYT)

title: Sharp Elbows And Karl Rove
description: To the Editor:

title: Compromise May Extend Terrorism Insurance Aid
description: A compromise appears to be taking shape to extend a federal program that would pay most of the commercial insurance losses in a major terrorist attack, easing months of uncertainty about the program's future.

title: The End User: Scaling down the real Web
Where's the Newt?
description: We are in the midst of a remarkable Washington scandal, and we still don't have a name for it. Leakgate, Rovegate, Wilsongate -- none of the suggestions have stuck because none capture what's so special about the current frenzy to lock up reporters and public officials.

title: Alberto Lattuada Is Dead at 90; Made Postwar Italian Films
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STILLMAN, LINDA A.
description: STILLMAN--Linda A. At age 72. Devoted wife of Ronald. Loving mother of Michael, Rose and Jonathan. Beloved grandmother of Joshua, Benjamin, Leo, Harry and Ariana. Dear sister of Joan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Lee Iacocca Foundation: Cure for Diabetes, 17 Arlington St, Boston, MA 02116 (www.joinleenow.org). Services Sunday 12:30pm at "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Going Nowhere on North Korea
description: It's mildly encouraging that after a year of cooling its heels, North Korea will be returning to the stalemated six-nation talks on its nuclear weapons programs later this month. But since neither Washington nor Pyongyang seems to have changed its underlying attitudes, there is little reason to expect the next round to produce any more progress than previous sessions. The more months that go by without a deal, the more nuclear weapons material North Korea can produce, sell and make into bombs.

title: Arts, Briefly; Thursday Was a Sweep for CBS
description: In Nielsen's estimates, CBS swept every hour of the Thursday prime-time television schedule, a typically strong performance for that night of the week. The network's lineup began with "Big Brother," on which Ashlea Evans (left) was the first of the housemates to be voted off the show. "Big Brother" also revealed that each contestant is secretly playing the game with another. The episode drew an estimated 7.88 million viewers and led into repeats of "CSI" (12.3 million) and "Without a Trace" (11.68 million). CBS was also No. 1 among 18-to-49-year-olds in every half-hour. ABC, which was second among total viewers and third in the 18-to-49 demographic, featured the debut of "Hooking Up" at 9 p.m. As it played opposite "CSI," the most-watched show of the night, the documentary series that follows a group of Internet daters brought in a weak 5.09 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: Aliens in the Suburbs, Surrounded by Stupidity
description: If one could look behind the facades people create for themselves, one would see amazing things. That fiery right-wing senator could be wearing women's underwear under his pinstriped suit. That macho football player might be hiding an uncontrollable fear of puppies. As for the housewife walking down the street, she might, at any time, transform before your eyes into a small, hideous creature holding a disintegrator gun. Whatever you do, don't scream, "Little green aliens!" They hate that.

title: New York Is Supported in Ruling on Exit Ramp
description: A state appeals court panel has ruled that the city acted appropriately last year in agreeing to permanently close the 72nd Street exit ramp off the West Side Highway to accommodate a $3 billion building project being developed by Donald J. Trump.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about the rival formats emerging for high-definition DVD's -- HD-DVD and Blu-ray -- misspelled the names of two directors of Panasonic's Blu-ray laboratory in Torrance, Calif. They are Keisuke Suetsugi, not Suetsujgi, and Yoshihiro Mori, not Yoshiichiro.

title: Fierce Criticism of Miller Erupts After Mailings
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller faced intense criticism yesterday following reports that his office spent $1.6 million in Council funds on a series of mailings to millions of households around the city, far more than the $37,000 figure previously released.

title: Ill-Secured Soviet Arms Depots Tempting Rebels and Terrorists
description: Correction Appended

title: Counting Corporate Crooks
description: THIS week, Bernard Ebbers, the former chairman and founder of WorldCom, was sentenced to 25 years in prison for his role in an $11 billion fraud that bankrupted his telecommunications company. Meanwhile, Kenneth Lay, the founder of Enron, awaits trial on fraud and conspiracy, and Dennis Kozlowski, the former chief executive of Tyco, is soon to be sentenced after being convicted, along with his chief financial officer, of stealing $150 million from the company and reaping $430 million more by selling company shares while inflating the stock value.

title: Neoliberalism? It doesn't exist
Charter School Plan Wins Approval
description: A plan by the New York City teachers' union to open a charter school in Brooklyn in September was approved yesterday by the State University of New York board of trustees.

title: An Oasis of Indulgence Amid Brazil's Poverty
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, July 15 - One Brazilian magazine hailed it as the "biggest store for high-end consumption in Latin America." Local newspapers call it the "temple of luxury," "Disneyland for the rich" and the "shopping bunker."

title: Toms Plays by the Rules, and Ends Up Disqualified
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 15 - David Toms, the winner of the 2001 P.G.A. Championship, disqualified himself from the British Open on Friday after reporting to the Royal and Ancient Golf Club offices a possible breach of the rules during his first round on Thursday.

title: Brazil's 'temple of luxury' becomes symbol of excess
Tourists Seeking Wild Beauty, in New Jersey? Seriously, They Find It
description: ABOARD EDWARD ABBEY, near Secaucus, N.J. - This area is better known to most as Exit 15W on the New Jersey Turnpike, or the flight path out of Newark Liberty International Airport, or the railroad crossing on New Jersey Transit's main line. But beneath these human landmarks, unnoticed and as foundational as a heartbeat, lie dirt, water, grass and life.

title: Settlement Is Reached With Enron
description: More than four years after rolling blackouts and skyrocketing electricity bills shook California and the rest of the West Coast, the Enron Corporation finally settled claims that it played a major role in the energy crisis of 2000 and 2001.

title: History trumps aesthetics at Old Masters sales
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart on Friday describing events that led to a criminal investigation of the leak of Valerie Wilson's work under cover for the C.I.A. misstated her whereabouts at the time her husband, Joseph C. Wilson IV, traveled to Niger in February 2002. She was at the agency's headquarters in Virginia, not in Niger.

title: Waltrip to Leave D.E.I. at End of This Season
description: Michael Waltrip, whose first big victory came as Dale Earnhardt died in a wreck at the end of the 2001 Daytona 500, said yesterday that he would not return next season to the team that bears Earnhardt's name.

title: Physician ministers to a drug maker
Hopkins Displays Anger a Day Before the Fight
description: LAS VEGAS, July 15 - When George Foreman made his comeback, as a jovial, overweight heavyweight, he made light of his conditioning and his eating habits, and gave voice to a second life on the other side of 40.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GORMAN, ELEANOR (LARKIN)
description: GORMAN--Eleanor (Larkin) Born in New York City to the late Patrick and Rose Ann Larkin. Beloved wife of the late Joseph P. Cherished mother of Joseph, Patrick, Joanne, Michael and Dennis. Dear grandmother to Erica, David, Krista, Kerin, Meagan, Brianne; great grandmother to Cassidy Rose. One of nine "Larkin Girls." Survived by her dear sister Veronica (Bonnie) Loughran, predeceased by her loving sisters, Rosalie Brown, Margaret Moffat, Mary McCartan, Virginia Spiess, Rita Corby, Violet Pariot and Aileen Larkin. Dear aunt of many. Reposing Vanella's Chapels, 29 Madison St, NY, NY. Visitation Sunday 2-5 & 7-9PM. Mass of the Resurrection St. James R.C. Church, Monday 9:30AM.

title: Young Fans of Wizard Still Under His Spell
description: At last, after months of military-level security and a public relations blitz that would put P.T. Barnum to shame, Harry Potter is back.

title: Church, State and a Court Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUTMAN, BENJAMIN HARRIS
description: LAUTMAN--Benjamin Harris. Dearest Wendy and Bill, we grieve for the loss of sweet Baby Ben. While barely four years old, he was indeed an Old Soul, who touched all of our lives. His fight was valiant and inspirational. We will remember and rejoice Ben & his spirit forever. With much love: Miranda; Stephanie, Stephen & Alexander; Margie, Warren, Samantha & Jacqueline; Leslie, Mark, Emma & Sam.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 11 P.M. (BBC America) I'M ALAN PARTRIDGE -- Americans have Jiminy Glick (Martin Short's fabulously unprepared talkshow host). The British had Alan Partridge (Steve Coogan, above), but now we have joint custody. In this show's second-season United States premiere, Alan has given up his slot on local radio, had a nervous breakdown and driven to Scotland in his bare feet. Now he has a great time slot on Radio Norwich.

title: A Potpourri of Movement by a Master of the Eclectic
description: BECKET, Mass., July 15 - Ben Munisteri's choreography was perfectly at home at Jacob's Pillow. That was no surprise.

title: Poker face
An Ultra-Orthodox Mayor in an Unorthodox City
description: JERUSALEM - URI LUPOLIANSKI is the first to admit he runs an unusual city a place considered holy by Muslims, Christians and Jews, who talk about tolerance more than they practice it, at least here.

title: Legislators take leave from their jobs at VW
Church, State and a Court Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Contraceptive Sales Status on Calendar at F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 - The Bush administration said on Friday that it would decide by Sept. 1 whether to allow sales of an emergency contraceptive without a prescription, apparently clearing the way for a Senate vote on President Bush's nominee to head the Food and Drug Administration.

title: State Dept. Memo Gets Scrutiny in Leak Inquiry on C.I.A. Officer
description: WASHINGTON, July 15 - Prosecutors in the C.I.A. leak case have shown intense interest in a 2003 State Department memorandum that explained how a former diplomat came to be dispatched on an intelligence-gathering mission and the role of his wife, a C.I.A. officer, in the trip, people who have been officially briefed on the case said.

title: Three Die After Van Hits a Truck Upstate
description: A young couple from Brooklyn and another man were killed yesterday when their minivan crossed a wide grass divider on Route 17 in Orange County and crashed into a tractor-trailer traveling in the opposite direction, the authorities said.

title: Bush Sells Trade Pact in Hostile Territory
description: DALLAS, N.C., July 15 - President Bush charged into hostile territory on Friday to sell his Central American trade agreement, a pact that is unpopular here among textile workers and many mills that have been battered by foreign competition.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LEVITT, IRVING LESTER
description: LEVITT--Irving Lester on, July 16, 1990. "Death be not proud." Your great strength lives on in your loved ones. Jeanette, Ann and George

title: More Signs That Inflation Is Subdued
description: Most businesses seem to be absorbing higher energy costs in an effort to keep prices down and stay competitive, economists said yesterday after the latest economic report showed few signs of inflation.

title: INSIDE
description: Plea Deal Criticized In Steroids Scandal Victor Conte Jr., the central figure in the steroids scandal that linked the use of performance-enhancing drugs to some of the country's top athletes, pleaded guilty in a deal with federal prosecutors that was strongly criticized by antidoping experts. SPORTSSATURDAY, PAGE D1

title: Blair Calls Fight on Terror a 'Battle of Ideas'
description: LONDON, July 16 A In a major speech drawing battle lines for the global response to terrorism, Prime Minister Tony Blair said today that "evil ideology" could only be beaten by confronting its "symptoms and causes, head-on, without compromise or delusion."

title: When C.E.O.'s Get the Boot
description: CONGRATULATIONS! You have just been named chief executive. Here's a bit of advice: don't unpack your bags.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: More Troops In The Caucasus
description: Officials announced efforts to reinforce military and law enforcement units in the Caucasus, undermining the Kremlin's longstanding and public insistence that the war in Chechnya and the disorder in neighboring Russia republics had passed. A Kremlin spokesman told the Interfax news agency that army mountain brigades might be permanently posted in the region. That disclosure came on the same day the Federal Security Service, a descendant of the Soviet K.G.B., announced it had opened a new office in Makhachkala, the capital of Dagestan. Dagestan, a Russian republic that borders Chechnya, has been struck by a wave of bombings and killings of police officers and prominent citizens. An Islamic group linked to Chechnya's separatists has claimed responsibility for some of the attacks. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: A Producer Takes Over
description: A drama set in the shadow of the early 20th-century Armenian genocide, "Beast on the Moon" is already melodramatic enough. It doesn't need exaggerated facial expressions and theatrical line readings, but if David Grillo is overdoing it a bit as the pained photographer Aram, it may be because he has more at stake than your typical replacement actor. He is also the co-producer.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about new findings on musical hallucinations included an incorrect identification from a researcher for the journal in which the study is to appear. The research, led by Dr. Victor Aziz of St. Cadoc's Hospital in Wales, is to be published in The International Journal of Geriatric Psychiatry, not the journal Psychopathology.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Cell Phone Ban For Teenagers
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich signed legislation that prohibits drivers under the age of 18 from using cellphones while driving except in an emergency. The action came a day after Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota signed similar legislation. A handful of other states, including Colorado, Connecticut, New Jersey and Tennessee, have similar restrictions. Illinois drivers can be fined $75 for violating the ban, which takes effect immediately. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Flamenco Lessons With a Difference
description: Two women, best friends, fall in love with the same man; he seduces them, one after the other, and thinks he has gotten away with it. But when the women find out that they have been duped, they abandon the man and resume their friendship.

title: Corrections
Religion's evolution
What to Do After Your Data Is Stolen
description: IT'S been a month since someone swiped my debit card account data and went on a two-day, $1,772.26 shopping spree. While the bank reimbursed the money, and the nightmare seems to have passed -- thus far no one has bought a small island in my name -- I'm still slogging through an endless maze of questions and misinformation.

title: Church, State and a Court Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Click Fraud and Halli-Bloggers
description: GOOGLE is expected to announce next week that its revenue doubled over the last year, to $841 million or so. A huge chunk of that is a result of someone's tapping a mouse button. Through its AdWords program, Google is paid when people click on the keyword-generated ads that appear next to search results. Not surprisingly, a lot of people try to game the system -- for instance, by repeatedly clicking on a competitor's ad links.

title: All-Day Suicide Bomb Blitz Claims 22 Lives in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 15 - A spate of suicide attacks in Baghdad continued on Friday, as insurgents struck at American and Iraqi security forces around the city using at least eight suicide car bombs, killing at least 22 people and wounding scores more, officials said.

title: Pulp and Circumstance (and Chardonnay
description: Correction Appended

title: M.T.A. and Police Discussing How to Pay for Terror Security
description: Increased police patrols on New York City subways and buses since the July 7 bombings in London have cost about $1.9 million a week, and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the Police Department are discussing how to pay for that expense, officials said yesterday.

title: If Money Is All, Democrats Still Fall Short
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has spent more than $23 million on his re-election campaign as the four major Democrats seeking to unseat him have struggled to raise half of that among them, according to campaign filings released yesterday.

title: Nice Work, if I Can Get It
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Warns of Dangers From Patch Used for Pain
description: The government warned yesterday that painkilling skin patches could cause drug overdoses and said it was investigating reports of serious side effects and 120 deaths that might have resulted.

title: While Pataki Gazes at Iowa, Re-election Donations Drop
description: ALBANY, July 15 - In the latest sign that Gov. George E. Pataki is unlikely to run for a fourth term, campaign finance reports filed on Friday showed that the governor's re-election committee has raised less money over the past year than it has in any year since its campaign filings were first posted on the Internet in 1999.

title: Competitive Twirling (as Not Seen on ESPN)
description: WICHITA, Kan., July 12 - It was a low-budget and glamour-free enterprise. The costumes, sequined or frilly or both, seemed borrowed from marching bands or figure skaters from the 1970's, and the music chosen by many of the participants tended toward varieties of Muzak.

title: Court Says E.P.A. Can Limit Its Regulation of Emissions
description: A federal appeals court rejected on Friday an effort by a dozen states and cities, along with environmental groups, to have the Bush administration regulate greenhouse gases that spill out of the tailpipes of new cars and trucks.

title: Harry Potter: A Dissent
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Rules That Reporter Can Withhold Source's Name
description: A federal appeals court in Atlanta ruled yesterday that a reporter for Sports Illustrated does not have to reveal a confidential source as part of a libel case against the magazine.

title: West, Northwest, Midwest, South, Mid-Atlantic, Washington, and Science and Health
description: WEST

title: Globalist: A tale of Latin leftists who have parted ways
Taking Inference to Its Limit Produces the Margin of Victory
description: The Summer North American Bridge Championships of the American Contract Bridge League will begin Thursday in Atlanta, and next Saturday night the league will have its Hall of Fame dinner.

title: Nanny Search Ends After Finding the Manny Within
description: ON a recent sun-drenched Sunday morning, I saw myself fire up a Montecristo No.2 and slip behind the wheel of a Ferrari 360 Modena, top down and ready for a rocking good time. I howled along the highway at triple-digit speed to a yacht basin where a cigarette boat was waiting to whisk me across Long Island Sound to play golf with a billionaire at one of the most exclusive private clubs in America.

title: Fathers, Sons and Other Big Winners
description: The championship event of the World Series of Poker at the Rio in Las Vegas wound up last night, but the most impressive feats so far in the first 39 events have to include record 10th bracelets for both Johnny Chan and Doyle Brunson. And Brunson's son, Todd, won an Omaha high-low event, making them the only father-son bracelet holders. Todd has earned millions playing what is called smash-mouth poker -- heads-up Hold'em, for example, which is more like a street fight than a subtle 10-handed affair.

title: Legionnaires' at a Westchester Hospital Infects 12
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 15 - Westchester County health officials said on Friday that the number of patients who had contracted Legionnaires' disease at Sound Shore Medical Center had climbed to 12, and they urged anyone with strong flulike symptoms who had been in the vicinity of the hospital to have a medical examination.

title: Harold Stevenson, Education Psychologist, Dies at 80
description: Harold W. Stevenson, a psychologist specializing in child development who produced the first comprehensive study highlighting the difference between the academic achievement of American children and children overseas, particularly in Japan and Taiwan, died on July 8 at a hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 80 and until recently had made his home in Ann Arbor, where he was an emeritus professor of psychology at the University of Michigan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THAL, RUDOLF
description: THAL--Rudolf. Age 83. Of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. and formerly of Bernkastel-Kues, Germany, on July 14, 2005. Loving and devoted husband of Ruth Thal. Dear brother of Hilda Herbst of Boca Raton, FL. Beloved father and father-in-law to Susan Thal and Elliot of Teaneck, N.J. and Gary Thal and Kathy Hoffstedder of Demarest, N.J. Adoring and doting grandfather to Joshua, Gabrielle, Adam, David and Jonathon. Loving uncle to Leonard and Roberta Herbst of Pikesville, MD.and Alwin and Heidi Herbst of Boca Raton, FL., and cherished by a host of relations and friends. Rudy and his family escaped from Nazi Germany to become a successful entrepreneur in the United States, which he was also most proud to serve in the U.S. Army during WWII. Co-founder of E&T Plastic Mfg., Co., Inc., in Long Island City, his many accomplishments in business over the past 50 years are non the less surpassed by the deep and everlasting love of his family and friends and the admiration, esteem and respect of his business associates. We will always remember and dearly miss his passion and boundless enthusiasm for life. Funeral service Sunday, July 17th, 11:30AM at GuttermanMusicant, 402 Park St., Hackensack, N.J. In lieu of flowers, the family request that contributions be made in Rudy's memory to UJA Federation of Northern N.J., P.O. Box 4176, River Edge, N.J. 07661.

title: Spain joins France on terrorism
Demolition Company to Have Role Downtown
description: Safeway Environmental Corporation, the demolition company cited for violations in Thursday's collapse of a half-demolished supermarket on the Upper West Side, will have a role in dismantling the Deutsche Bank building in Lower Manhattan, one of the most complex demolition jobs in the city, officials said yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Sports Briefing: TRACK AND FIELD; Meet Record at Icahn
description: Pat Manson, a 37-year-old Kansas graduate from Boulder, Colo., pole-vaulted the meet record height of 17 feet 1 inch last night at the U.S.A. Track and Field National Club Championships at Icahn Stadium on Randalls Island.

title: A slippery European energy outlook
Paid Notice: Memorials   BAUMWELL, EARL
description: BAUMWELL--Earl. Dad, we love you and miss you. Mom, Lisa, Eric, Peter, Lori, Jed, Gail & Families

title: Brazil Says Deal on Drug Isn't Assured
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, July 15 - Just one week after Brazil announced an agreement with Abbott Laboratories to get a lower price for an important AIDS drug, the country's new health minister said that the deal had not been completed and that the government could still break Abbott's patent and produce a copycat version of the medicine.

title: Procter & Gamble Gets European Approval to Buy Gillette
description: BRUSSELS, July 15 - The European Commission approved the $57 billion acquisition of Gillette by Procter & Gamble after Procter agreed to sell its Crest battery-powered toothbrush business, the commission said late Friday.

title: Arts, Briefly; Tomlinson's Successor?
description: Cheryl Halpern, a major Republican fund-raiser and a member of the board of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, has emerged as a leading contender to become the chairwoman of the corporation, officials at the corporation said. Ms. Halpern, who lives in New Jersey, is a former chairwoman of the Republican Jewish Coalition. She has complained that National Public Radio's coverage of the Middle East is slanted against Israel. Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, the current chairman, will complete his term in September and, under the corporation's charter, cannot be appointed to another term. He is expected to remain on the board. Mr. Tomlinson is under investigation by the corporation's inspector general for a series of decisions he says were necessary to ensure balance in programming. His critics say those decisions have violated a law that is supposed to make the corporation a political buffer. The board of the corporation, which is dominated by Republicans, is appointed by the president and confirmed by the Senate. The board selects its chairman.

title: A Sprint Into a Weekend of Climbing
description: MONTPELLIER, France, July 15 - For the Tour de France, this was the day before the Pyrenees, a fast, rolling stage from Miramas to Montpellier that was won by Robbie McEwen of Australia. Lance Armstrong sat back and finished in 33rd place, protecting his yellow jersey and his 38-second overall lead.

title: Israel hits Hamas, killing 7 militants
Church, State and a Court Nominee
description: To the Editor:

title: Beef Imports From Canada to Resume
description: CHICAGO, July 15 - The United States Agriculture Department said on Friday that it planned to resume imports of Canadian cattle within days, after an appellate court lifted a two-year-old injunction imposed because of mad cow disease.

title: Post-Soviet danger: Vulnerable munitions depots
Using Farmers as Bait
description: In the arguments about taxes on inheritance, no one tugs at the national heartstrings more urgently than the family farmer. Anti-tax forces and big family businesses like to conjure up a field of dreams' turning into condos -- a young family inherits their birthright and then has to sell it to pay the taxes.

title: Crossing the bridge: Nicklaus takes his bows
Dark Water
7 Big Retail Chains Sue Visa, Saying Its Fees Are a Form of Price Fixing
description: A series of court rulings over the last few years were intended to encourage banks and credit card companies to compete more vigorously. But some merchants are complaining that they have not reaped the benefits and that consumers are footing the bill.

title: With Shoves and Curses, Newark Political Rivalry Takes Ugly Turn
description: NEWARK, July 15 - The mayor of Newark, Sharpe James, and Cory Booker are political rivals who mix like a match and gasoline. When they faced off in the 2002 mayoral race, their debates devolved into shouting matches and altercations over campaign signs flared up repeatedly.

title: Israeli Airstrikes Kill 7 Militants in West Bank and Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, July 15 - Israeli helicopter gunships killed seven militants of the radical Hamas movement on Friday in separate airstrikes on two vehicles, one near Nablus in the West Bank and the other in Gaza City, Israeli Army and Palestinian officials said.

title: A Stellar Showing by Glavine Is Wasted
description: For seven innings last night at Shea Stadium, Tom Glavine matched the outstanding performance of an old friend and a respected foe. And in stretching his streak of strong starts to four, he also posted a rare strong outing against the organization that once employed him, but now serves as his nemesis.

title: Casualties of the London Bombings
John J. Ford Jr., 81, Dies; Coin Dealer and Collector
description: John J. Ford Jr., a coin dealer and collector known for catalogs that brought new clarity to numismatics and whose collections, including the earliest American coins and prized Confederate pennies, have dazzled recent auctiongoers, died on July 7 at a nursing home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.

title: Robin Hoods or Legal Hoods?
description: "Without notes he launched into a brief history of the American tort system and how crucial it was in protecting the masses from the greed and corruption of big corporations that make dangerous products. And, while he was at it, he didn't like insurance companies and banks and multinationals and Republicans, either."

title: Belated Charge Ignites Furor Over AIDS Drug Trial
description: It was seen as one of the great successes of AIDS treatment. In the late 1980's and early 1990's, hundreds of children in New York City were dying of AIDS. The only approved drugs were for adults, and many of the patients were foster children. So doctors obtained permission to include foster children in what they regarded as promising drug trials.

title: Wynn Las Vegas
description: The Basics Steve Wynn, the hotelier and casino owner, reportedly spent $2.7 billion to build his dream resort, which opened April 28. That's about a million dollars for each of its 2,716 rooms.

title: Exquisite Dining in Traditional Kyoto
description: I FELL in love with Japan when I was 13. Banished from the living room because my parents were entertaining, I flopped down in my sister's bedroom and watched Akira Kurosawa's "Seven Samurai" on PBS; within minutes I was smitten. I renounced the platform bed in which I'd slept for the previous five years, replacing it with a futon. I started cooking when I came across Shizuo Tsuji's superb "Japanese Cooking: A Simple Art" (Kodansha International) in a bookstore. I found in Mr. Tsuji's elegant presentation a real-world articulation of the aesthetic and ideological purity that I had perceived as the essence of the Kurosawa film; if Kurosawa had ignited my love for the country, Mr. Tsuji deepened and defined it.

title: Aceh rebel's military wing welcomes draft peace deal
A Right at Righteous, a Left at Licentious
description: HELL has no air-conditioning, but I knew that. Still, the message had never been brought home to me in quite the same way as it was when I stopped my motor home along a country road near Prattville, Ala., lured by a roadside display called Cross Garden.

title: Race Behind the Race Can Give a Rider an Edge
description: AX-3 DOMAINES, France, July 16 - On two difficult climbs in the Pyrenees, Lance Armstrong increased his lead on his main rivals in the 14th stage of the Tour de France on Saturday, aided by a different frenetic race that followed the peleton.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the listed at price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: FAST TRACK POSTPONED
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey last Tuesday indefinitely postponed the implementation of a controversial law that speeds permits for developers. Originally scheduled to go into effect last November, the so-called "fast track" law would have expedited the environmental permit process in areas that the state had deemed suitable for development. But while supporters said that the law would revitalize urban areas, critics called it the worst piece of environmental legislation in state history, and blamed former Gov. James E. McGreevey for caving in to developers. In November, Mr. McGreevey, in an act of compromise in his final days in office, delayed the law's effective date until July 15. Late Tuesday afternoon, Mr. Codey extended that delay by executive order, saying that three state agencies needed more time to make sure the law would adhere to federal standards. David W. Chen

title: John J. Ford Jr., 81, Dies; Coin Dealer and Collector
description: John J. Ford Jr., a coin dealer and collector known for catalogs that brought new clarity to numismatics and whose collections, including the earliest American coins and prized Confederate pennies, have dazzled recent auctiongoers, died on July 7 at a nursing home in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 81.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWSON, GEORGE. M.
description: LAWSON--George. M. On July 14, 2005 at age 94. Longtime domestic partner of Elliot Rabner. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Thursday, July 21st 3:30 PM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORNE, WILLIAM G.
description: HORNE -- William G., 81. Passed away at home June 22 as a result of cancer. Survived by Esther R. Horne of New York, their son Adam G. Horne, also of New York, and his sister Judyth H. Whitaker of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and our extended families. Served aboard U.S.S. Murray in World War II. Bill touched the hearts of all who knew him. He was a gentle, loving soul who had multiple talents and interests. We mourn our loss but celebrate the life of this beautiful man. Memorial to be held Saturday, July 23 at Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave and 28th St at 2PM.

title: By Courting Sunnis, G.I.'s See Security Rise in a Sinister Town
description: QABR ABED, Iraq - These days, this town in northern Iraq is relatively safe compared with other Sunni Arab-dominated areas of Iraq. For a village that long held folk status among Iraqis as one of the most sinister places in the country, that is quite a change.

title: In Croatia, a New Riviera Beckons
description: Correction Appended

title: Catherine Polisi and Andrew Jones
description: Catherine Elizabeth Polisi, the daughter of Elizabeth Marlowe Polisi and Joseph W. Polisi of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Andrew Wendell Jones, a son of Susan and Bruce J. Jones of Washington, Va. The Rev. Daniel O'Reilly performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: Crunch Time in Hempstead
description: Who says the members of the Hempstead School Board can't get anything done? Just last Tuesday they fired the superintendent (for the second time) and hired her replacement, a man they had fired, reinstated and later suspended last year. They recited the Pledge of Allegiance without a hitch, then cleared up some confusion over when school would start, and gave last year's senior class president a public scolding about disrespect, for reasons unclear.

title: A Radio Sweetheart of the Rodeo
description: JERSEY CITY - "PARDON me," Laura Cantrell said, swiveling in her disc jockey's chair to face the microphone. "Oh, the indignity," she muttered, pulling on a 70's-era set of earphones and offering on-air apologies for the skipping LP that she deftly plucked from a nearby turntable.

title: Battlefields
description: The carnage in the London Underground follows an even more horrendous attack on Madrid commuters 16 months ago. When President Bush sought recently to reassure Americans about his Iraq policy, he emphasized that we are fighting terrorists in Iraq so that we do not have to fight them here at home. Unfortunately for Britain and Spain, fighting terrorists in Iraq did not immunize them from attacks at home.

title: Rangers Excel From First to Third
description: TWO American League teams, Texas and Baltimore, had three-fourths of their infields at the All-Star Game. One National League team, St. Louis, would have had three-fourths of its infield there had Scott Rolen not withdrawn because of a troublesome shoulder. None of the infielders had reason to say to any of their teammates, "Funny seeing you here."

title: Abbreviated
description: Short pants are a frequently seen alternative to trousers this summer. They are cut close to the leg and their very precise knee length looks perfect with heels. Some women are wearing them with matching jackets or sweaters. At left is a pair of brocade shorts, worn with a twin set for a very current evening look.

title: What Happens When Builders Build Their Own
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR - THE Messer family's dream home has a swinging bookcase that leads to a secret passage, a treehouse made from 1930's-era garage doors, a nautically themed master bathroom recently featured in a national magazine, and glass-fronted kitchen drawers filled with jelly beans, Chiclets, Tootsie Rolls and Jolly Ranchers.

title: Lauren Helfman and Andrew Powell

title: Governors Concerned Over National Guard Deployments in Iraq
description: DES MOINES, July 16 - The nation's governors are expressing growing concern that the extended deployment of National Guard soldiers in Iraq is depleting troop resources at home, threatening to leave states unable to respond to the natural disasters, civil unrest and other domestic emergencies that traditionally lead governors to call out the Guard.

title: A Schoolyard Brawl, but It's the Adults Who Are Fighting
description: Hempstead, N.Y. - IN the Balkanized geography of Long Island, where you can almost feel the differences in temperature between the have and have-not towns, it's not hard to figure out which category Hempstead fits in. With its drab, dilapidated apartment buildings with names like House Beautiful, the rap and salsa pouring out of car windows downtown, Hempstead is a place where even the trees seem to instantly disappear as soon as you cross the border from affluent Garden City.

description: IF Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey keeps it up, he just may get his very own Garden State Parkway rest stop -- or, at least, an off-ramp.

title: 'Kremlin Rising'
description: Tatyana Shalimova's high heels sank into the mud as we rounded the corner to her brother's house. To our left, four chickens feasted in a large, open garbage bin. Ahead, her brother's wife stood alone in the kitchen, a gigantic pot of slops simmering on the stove to feed their pig, Masha. Inside the house, there was no toilet, no hot water, and no telephone. Pulling on her Ray-Bans, Tatyana shook her head as she considered the gap separating her life in Moscow from her brother Misha's in the "workers' settlement" of Mokshan. "I can't stay here for more than a few days at a time," she said. Then came a question, the question: "Why don't the people here change their lives?" Her unspoken rebuke hung in the air: "I did."

title: In a Show of Force, Israeli Forces Gather Outside the Gaza Strip
description: JERUSALEM, July 17 - After months of reduced violence, Israel and the Palestinians faced the possibility today of a major confrontation as Israel massed tanks and other armored vehicles just outside the borders of the Gaza Strip.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAND, HELEN HIRSH
description: FAND--Helen Hirsh. On July 5, 2005 in Morristown, New Jersey. Beloved wife of the late Theodore I. Fand for 55 years; loving and devoted mother of Rita, Marlene, and the late Steven Fand; dear sister of Ruth Press, Sidney Goldstein, and the late David Hirsh. Helen was born in Brooklyn, NY, on December 6, 1916. After her marriage on December 7, 1941, she lived in the Bronx and White Plains, NY, before moving to Morristown in 1959. Learning and teaching were Helen's lifelong passions. She graduated from Franklin K. Lane High School in 1932, earned a B.A. in Latin from Brooklyn College in 1936, and an M.A. in American and English literature from Drew University in 1975. She taught Latin at Walton High School in the Bronx and English as a second language in White Plains. She was also a volunteer tutor for inner-city students at the College of St. Elizabeth in Convent Station, NJ, and a substitute teacher in Madison and Chatham, NJ. Helen was a graduate of Talmud Torah Chaim Berlin and Hebrew high school in Brooklyn, and later studied at the Midrasha of the Jewish Education Association of NJ. She taught Hebrew classes at Morristown High School and in area adult education programs. Helen was a longtime member of Morristown Jewish Center Beit Yisrael, where she chanted the Haftorahs with great feeling. She wrote poetry from the time she was a young girl and passed on her love of languages and books to her children. Helen graced all who knew her with her quiet eloquence. Contributions may be made to the Morristown & Morris Township Library, 1 Miller Road, Morristown, NJ, 07960, or Women's American ORT.

title: What's That You Say? A New Misfits Album?
description: The Misfits, born in Lodi in 1977, were one of the most extreme hard-core bands of the time, melding horror-film references with the fury of punk. In concert, dressed in requisite proto-Goth black with greasy stringy hair smudging their faces, the band damaged the hearing of many an adoring fan.

description: USING frequent-flier miles to book an award ticket can be such a frustrating experience that it has even inspired an ad campaign featuring a sarcastic agent who relishes telling customers, "No can do," when they call to book an award.

title: ON THE ROAD TO SANTIAGO
description: To the Editor: Regarding "On a Holy Road, Punk'd Pilgrims and a Man Who Barked at Dogs" (June 26) by Jack Hitt: In his article, Mr. Hitt asks why people walk the Camino de Santiago/Chemin de St.-Jacques. I have walked from Roncesvalles-Estella and then from Rabinal del Camino to Santiago -- 227 miles last year -- and this year I just returned from walking Le Puy to Moissac, France, 258 miles. I can say that my reasons are many.

description: ONE of the pleasures of restaurant reviewing is discovering little gems off the beaten path. Such was my experience with Little Thai Kitchen in Greenwich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEINSTOCK, IDA
description: WEINSTOCK--Ida. Born July 22, 1914 in Brooklyn, NY. Died July 8, 2005 in Los Angeles, California. She is survived by her son Robert, M.D. and her daughter Diana, Ph.D. Her husband of 66 years, George, predeceased her. She was a devoted, wise, inspirational, loving, treasured wife and mother. She filled the room with warmth, selfless generosity, good humor and empathic insight. She had been a distinguished teacher in the NYC public schools. She enriched the lives of all who knew her.

title: Lured by the 'Badlands'
description: I AM standing on the roof of Freeman Gardens, the brick and concrete carapace of a low-income apartment house that is rising on Freeman Street, in Morrisania, deep in the heart of the South Bronx, where I grew up. Standing beside me are Michael Avramides, the building's architect, and his wife, Bascove, an artist best known for her dreamy paintings of the city's bridges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SUNDERLAND, J.B.
description: SUNDERLAND -- J.B. Born Aug. 14, 1928, died at home on July 8, 2005. He was President of Aminoil and Transpacific Geothermal Co., a director of the Near East Foundation since 1966, and a founder and director of Americans for Middle East Understanding since 1967. He was also a Member of the Council on Foreign Relations since 1971. He is survived by his wife, four children, and their families. Services will be held at 11A.M. on July 18 at St. Bridget's Church, Cornwall Bridge, CT. Donations may be made to A.M.E.U. 475 Riverside Dr. NY, NY 10115-0245 or the Near East Foundation, 90 Broad St, 15th Fl, NY 10004.

title: Three Sisters, With No Chekhov in Sight
description: LONG BRANCH - THE New Jersey Repertory Company may never win the Tony Award for regional theater, but it deserves some kind of prize for sheer unpredictability. Its last show here, "Ten Percent of Molly Snyder," was as whacked-out a comedy as New Jersey is likely to see this year. But its new show, "A Child's Guide to Innocence" by Vincent Sessa, is as delicate and nuanced a drama as you'll find, its three actresses telling a sublime intergenerational tale beautifully.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: On the surface, Feldman's proposal for solving the conflict between church and state has all the hallmarks of a good compromise. It gives both sides something and leaves both somewhat unhappy. However, a deeper look shows problems. Would the broad acceptance of religious speech protect the kind of evangelical proselytizing that has been going on at the United States Air Force Academy? At what point does religious speech cross the line from being simply an expression of one's faith to being intimidation?

title: Corrections
description: The "Living In ..." article last Sunday, about the fashion district in Manhattan, omitted a school in the area. St. Michael Academy, a parochial high school for girls, is at 425 West 33rd Street, at Ninth Avenue.

title: McMurray Rebounds by Not Sweating the Details or Being a Defensive Driver
description: LOUDON, N.H., July 16 - Jamie McMurray could not sleep that night. A broken valve spring -- just 20 laps from the finish -- had wiped out all his hard work and his team's aspirations for a Nascar Nextel Cup championship.

title: Crafts in Provincetown, Mass.
description: At Womencrafts -- a small, unassuming gray cottage in the heart of Provincetown that sells jewelry, books, music and gifts by women -- girls rule, as one T-shirt says. "Everything is handcrafted," said Debbie Estevez, who has owned the shop with her partner Kathryn Livelli since 1999. "But we're not a gallery; it's more crafts as opposed to art." They purchase works from about 50 women around the country, ranging from 50-cent bumper stickers with slogans like "Real Women Drive Trucks" to a $900 opal and diamond ring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STOLER, BARNEY
description: STOLER--Barney. Of Sunrise, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY, passed away gently and peacefully in his sleep on July 14, 2005. Barney enjoyed over 90 glorious years, 62 years of which he shared with his wife, Jean. Barney was a devoted and adored father of his loving daughter Marcia (William) Birnbaum who was with him as he entered into his peaceful new world. He leaves a family legacy including three grandsons, Brett (Melissa) Gottlieb, Jamie (Michelle) Gottlieb, and Scott Gottlieb, and four lovable great-grandchildren, Shawna, Kaleb, Devin and Joshua. Barney was the apple of his mother's eye, and his brothers and sisters looked up to him even though he was the baby of his family. His business accomplishments were highlighted as a respected CPA member of AICPA and NYSSCPA, Treasurer of Big Apple and Waldbaums Supermarkets, and was instrumental in their being listed on the NYSE. He will truly be missed by all those who had the great fortune to know Barney. Services at Star of David, Lauderdale, FL, 1:45pm

title: Blacktop Heaven
description: To the Long Island driver, so accustomed to stop-and-go misery, a ride in the new car pool lane of the Long Island Expressway can bring a thrill so sharp it almost feels illegal. Speeding along beside a motionless ribbon of brake lights gives a new meaning to the term rush hour.

title: Baseball: Yankees get much-needed boost

Judge Patty Shwartz of Federal District Court in New Jersey officiated at the Waldorf-Astoria in New York.

title: On a Wrought-Iron Block, a 21st-Century Interloper
description: The stretch of Senator Street between Third and Fourth Avenues in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, is lined with early-20th-century brownstones, complete with original wrought-iron gates and lion's head ornamentation. Although new construction is widespread in the neighborhood, Senator Street looks much as it did when it was built, except for the coach lights dotting the occasional front yard.

title: Type Casting
description: Bello In a world of images, words sometimes don't seem to have as much value as appearances. But what about the appearance of words? While most of us don't think about typography, beyond choosing among the preinstalled fonts in our home computers, consider an up-and-coming font, like Bello. Bello recently won a best new "display font" award from the Type Directors Club, and is on pace to sell a respectable 160 licenses in its first year. Underware, the European three-man type foundry that created Bello, will be on hand at the font-maker gathering TypeCon in New York City this weekend. Yet it's unlikely that you have heard of Bello. "People are very unaware of this whole business," says Akiem Helmling, one of Underware's principals.

title: So Crisp, So Complex, So Unexpected
description: RINGOES - TEN years ago, New Jersey had 14 wineries. Today it has 27, and within the next year or so the number is expected to reach 40.

title: A Paycheck in Their Pockets, but a Song in Their Hearts
description: The chasm between the job that pays the bills and the lifework that provides personal satisfaction never seems as wide as when one's bliss depends on securing a place at the table set by the music industry.

title: State Police Target Hartford Trouble Spots
description: The state police patrolled Hartford for the second week in the past week, after the number of shootings for the year reached 90 through June 20.

title: Faking Out a Fake Tan
description: Brown discolored palms left over from zealous fake self-tanning are scarcely the ideal summer fashion statement. To nip such blotches in the bud, Jersey Girl Tan has introduced Shimmer Dimmer, a cream sunless tan remover that may be used prophylactically, as a pre-self-tanner application, to prevent build-up in spots like feet, knees and palms (as Lindsay Lohan's hand shows, right). Shimmer Dimmer can also be applied to smooth out existing stains and tone down the color contrast. The self-tanner-tamer runs about $14.50 (www.jerseygirltan.com) and comes in a four-ounce pump bottle.

title: A Soaring Bridge Puts an Ancient Town Back on the Map
description: A DELICATE butterfly of concrete and steel, the Viaduct of Millau soars across the sky as if eager to proclaim that no bridge on earth is taller. Yet its arrogant daring can surely be forgiven. It took a feat of engineering and a leap of the imagination to span the rough, rugged Tarn Valley in the Midi-Pyrnes region of southern France.

title: Letters
description: Noah Feldman's solution to the church-state divide sparked a wide-ranging debate on his proposal. Readers' concerns ran the gamut from the implications of unfettered religious speech to tax exemptions. Other correspondents weighed in on vets and war stories and on sex on the screen.

title: For Now, the Grass Is Still Greener in Foreign Markets
description: AS the stock market makes its second attempt this year to break out of the doldrums, investors who have stuck with American equities may be feeling a little better. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had its highest close in more than four years on Friday, while the Dow Jones industrial average is now just 360 points from a return to 11,000.

title: Super Cheap
description: There is no delicate way to say this: Jesus is going on sale. Rodgers & Hammerstein Theatricals, which licenses about 5,000 productions a year, is discounting "Jesus Christ Superstar" in its annual "spotlight" promotion. "Superstar," the 1971 hit by Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice, is the choice for the coming season because its availability has been limited in recent years: shortly after the company began handling the show's North American stock and amateur rights in 2001, a professional tour put a crimp in the number of amateur productions that could be licensed, said Bert Fink, a company spokesman. That tour ended in February, leading to next season's deal: a royalty-free opening night. (The 2004-5 promotion, now in its last two months, applies to the company's Irving Berlin offerings.) The only fine print is a requirement that there be a total of at least four performances. R&H needs to collect something to pass along to Lord Lloyd Webber and Mr. Rice.

title: A Reminder That the Sky Really Can Fall Now and Then
description: "HONEY," April Chestner told her daughter, Jasmine, who is 4, when she picked her up from preschool on Thursday afternoon, "You know where your candy store is? We can't go there today."

title: On Water's Edge, a Land Where Art Flowered
description: WHEN most people think of Denmark, they imagine the Baltic version: Lilliputian towns rising out of compact fields, flat landscapes and narrow beaches overlooking close horizons where boats never sail out of sight. Baltic Denmark is the orderly, safe land of an orderly, safe people.

title: 'Thomas Jefferson'
description: Born on April 13, 1743 (April 2 until the adoption of the Gregorian calendar in 1758), Thomas Jefferson was the offspring of stable planter stock in the native aristocracy of Virginia. His father, Peter Jefferson, was a surveyor and cartographer whose immigrant parents were said to have come from the Snowdonia district of northern Wales. Peter's marriage to Jane Randolph, whose own family was one of the "names" of traditional Virginia society, can only have improved his standing. Perhaps it was young Jefferson's evident contempt and dislike for his mother - to whom he almost never alluded - or his apparent indifference to aristocracy, but when he came to write his own very brief Autobiography in 1821, he spoke of these matters of bloodline and provenance and "pedigree," especially in his mother's case, with an affected indifference. "Let everyone," he wrote, "ascribe the faith and merit he chooses," to such trifling questions. Since Jefferson always founded American claims of right upon the ancient Saxon autonomy supposedly established by the near-mythical English kings Hengist and Horsa, who had left Saxony and established a form of self-rule in southern England (he even wished to see their imagined likeness on the first Great Seal of the United States), we are confronted at once with his fondness for, if not indeed his need for, the negation of one of his positions by another.

Truitt Jr. of Lutherville, Md. The Rev. Michael G. Wallens, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the Aspen Wye River Conference Centers in Queenstown, Md.

title: DataBank; Healthy Earnings Help the Market Climb Again

title: A Park Ave. Mansion Built With Beer
description: Q. In the 1920's, I often visited relatives in Manhattan in the East 90's, and I remember the big brownstone house at 93rd Street and Park Avenue, with privet hedges and an iron lance fence, owned by Ehret the brewer. When was it built? ... Robert O'Connell, Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: INSIDE
description: After Attacks, Israelis Arrest 30 in West Bank Responding to attacks that killed six civilians last week, Israel arrested 30 members of Hamas and Islamic Jihad on the West Bank and fired rockets at sites suspected of producing weapons in Gaza, while the Palestinian leader called on Palestinians to uphold a truce. PAGE 3

title: Faces of an Older America
description: If there were not so much evidence of it, most of us would be tempted to disbelieve in the existence of a past much before our parents' early lives. It seems so improbable. Could all those people really have walked the earth, as convinced of their own existence as we are? Yet there they are, a few of them, staring out at us from daguerreotypes made more than a century and a half ago by a Boston firm called Southworth & Hawes. These portraits, which carry the full weight of an earlier reality, have been gathered for an exhibition called "Young America" at the International Center of Photography.

title: A Neighborhood Traveled in Dozens of Languages
description: JACKSON HEIGHTS, a middle-class Queens neighborhood only three express subway stops from Manhattan, is so ethnically and culturally diverse that some people call it "a utopia of diversity."

Calarco of Woodbridge, Conn. Cantor Martin Feldman officiated at the Harvest Inn in St. Helena, Calif.

title: The Producer
description: When Stephanie Allain read the script for "Hustle & Flow," the story of a Memphis pimp with rapper dreams, she immediately signed on to produce the movie. "I fell in love after the first few pages," said Ms. Allain, who heads her own production company, Homegrown Pictures, in Los Angeles. She joined John Singleton, whom she met while working at Columbia Pictures (she brought his "Boyz N the Hood" script to the studio) and last January the movie, which opens nationwide on Friday, won the audience and cinematography awards at the Sundance Film Festival. At a screening in New York, Ms. Allain, 45, wore a viscose jacket by Ghost and a fringed cotton muslin skirt made by the Women of the Corn in Resistance, a collective of artisans in Chiapas, Mexico. She bought her espadrilles in NoLIta. "I don't look at labels," Ms. Allain said. "I shop for style, comfort and interesting fabrics and textures." She also likes to keep things casual. "I'd wear this to work in Hollywood," Ms. Allain said. "But on set I'm down and dirty. I wear tank tops, shorts and Nikes to keep cool and keep moving. I also love my Paper Denim & Cloth jeans. I have to force myself not to wear them every day." JENNIFER TUNG

title: The Floating Armoire
description: I HAD never lived with anyone before. My past relationships had all taken place in a kind of extended apartment. If I were to have mapped out these relationships, the result would look like the flight plan for an airline, or maybe trade routes. My apartment in the West Village was the hub, and there were routes to TriBeCa, the East Village, Washington Square and points beyond. Finally, there was a route to Gramercy Park, where Elizabeth lived in a very nice place with large windows.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: As a "values evangelical," I found Feldman's article appealing. His argument makes sense: allow for religious conviction to enter into public discussion, but cut off government financial support for religious programs of any sort. There must be a way to allow for both unity and diversity without silencing any comers willing to engage in public debate, and Feldman's proposal seems to do just that.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: I commend Noah Feldman for his attempt to bridge the widening chasm between values evangelicals and legal secularists. However, what does it mean to say that these camps share a common goal of national unity, when one side thinks "religious values" is a threatening euphemism and the other thinks "secular values" is an oxymoron?

Yes, they were playing the Boston Red Sox at Fenway Park on a Saturday afternoon, the same setting that produced ugly brawls the last two seasons. But this felt different.
