title: Michael Pitt: Indie Nirvana
description: BEING around the actor Michael Pitt is like living inside a seamy teenage flick by Larry Clark or Gus Van Sant, two directors this indie film heartthrob has worked with. At 7 on a recent evening Mr. Pitt, with his prominent lips, angelic blue eyes and thick greasy hair requisite for playing sexually ambiguous, dysfunctional young men, was chain-smoking cigarettes outside Pianos, a club in the Lower East Side. His rock band, Pagoda -- he is the shy, mysterious lead singer -- had just finished a sound check. The group had four hours to kill before the show.

title: Put College First
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Small Feet, Big Dreams
description: In New York, the city of everything, even a consumer's most obscure desires can be satisfied. A litchi-nut martini from a former speakeasy. Gucci loafers for a newborn. A shearling bomber jacket for a potbellied dog. But Heaven help a girl like me who wears a size 5 shoe.

title: Spies in the House
description: It's the summer of 1969, just before my father tells me that he works for the C.I.A., and I am beginning my own secret life. I'm 14 years old, and down in Georgetown, a few blocks west of the White House, a string of new shops burn incense, blast rock music and sell Jefferson Airplane and Grateful Dead posters. My friend's older brother, Joe, is painting Blue Meanies on a wall of his room. I know something's going on, but I'm not quite getting it. I'm convinced that grown-ups hide everything. Then Joe puts down his paintbrush and pulls out a plastic baggie. "You guys ever smoke grass?"

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MALAN, ROY MARK
description: MALAN--Roy Mark, July 11th, 2005. Beloved husbandof Marion. Father of Isabel Soma and Peter Malan. Grandfather of Daniel, Philip and David. Memorial service in Italy at a later date.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, MORTIMER
description: LEVITT--Mortimer. On July 12, your great and courageous heart could no longer sustain life in you. During the 98 years you spent on this earth you were known as merchant prince, philanthropist, producer, author, and above all as a confirmed iconoclast. You wanted to live to 104, but you will live much longer because we will carry forward your vision and your dreams. Your wife Mimi, your daughter Elizabeth, and your son Peter, will miss your strong presence and your wonderful sense of humor. You influenced the lives of many people with your intelligence, your creativity, your exquisite taste and your zest for life. We will celebrate your remarkable accomplishments and your extraordinary spirit at a memorial tribute a la Mortimer in September. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Young Concert Artists, 250 West 57 St., New York, NY, or Friends of the Levitt Pavilion, 85 East Holly St., Pasadena CA. 91103. To receive information about the memorial service send an email to: MortimerMemorial@aol.com

title: Bitter Sweets
description: The picture is taken again and again: the big, grinning G.I. handing out candy and drawing a wan smile from a child. It was taken in France after D-Day, in Tokyo after V-J Day, in Korea, in Vietnam.

title: Up Front
description: David Leavitt, who was born in 1961, got off to an early start as a writer of fiction. At 20, he published his first story in The New Yorker; when he was 23, his first collection, "Family Dancing" (1984), put him at the forefront of a new generation of writers. Like many of Leavitt's subsequent books, "Family Dancing" dealt with homosexuality, and in this week's issue he contributes an essay about the demise of many of this country's gay bookstores. The buying and selling of gay-themed books has come a long way in two decades, he said in a telephone interview. "When I was growing up in Northern California, there was -- and still is -- a great bookstore in Menlo Park called Kepler's, and it had a gay shelf tucked way in the back of the store. I remember sneaking back there, very furtively, and I was always terrified someone would see me. There was a lot of anxiety and fear about these books, particularly for a young person, even in California in the 1970's. It's hard to believe how much things have changed." Leavitt, who lives in Gainesville, Fla., and teaches creative writing at the University of Florida, said that, on some level, gay bookstores have simply become irrelevant. "These stores no longer serve the function they once did. They were community centers, they were sources of information. These days, young readers are more likely to seek out community -- and books -- on the Internet." The Editors

description: Riverhead - CYNICS around here used to say that nearly every house and building in town was for sale, if only someone would make an offer.

title: Seattle
description: WHY GO NOW -- When summer comes to Seattle, blinking residents emerge from bookstores and coffeehouses, shrug off their rubberized rain jackets, chrysalis-like, and change into cycling shorts, then rock-climbing shoes, and finally strappy sandals for a night on the town. (Call it the Seattle triathlon.) From July through September -- the dry months in this notoriously wet city -- Seattle hums with a manic energy as residents try to shoehorn as much outdoor fun as possible into those precious, long-lingering summer days.

title: Corrections

He was Bruce Spenadel, their architect.

description: Boston - THIS is about survival now for the Yankees and their pitching staff of sticks and sand. First, the weekend, then seven more games, in Texas and Anaheim, until the aching shoulders heal or the inevitable roster additions beyond Al Leiter occur.

title: Bomb on Bus Near a Resort in Turkey Leaves 5 Dead
description: ISTANBUL, July 16 - An explosion on a minibus in the Turkish resort town of Kusadasi on Saturday morning killed five people and wounded 13, the government said. Initial reports said a young woman might have set off a suicide bomb, though the police said they were still investigating.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BAKER, WILLIAM GRAHAM, JR.
description: BAKER--William Graham, Jr., 86, of Sanibel, Florida, died on July 9, 2005. He was a retired Vice President of the F.W. Woolworth Co. He is survived by his wife, Janice, daughters, Linda, Kim, Cindy, Leigh, sons William III, Robert, nine grandchildren, two great grandchildren, sisters Margaret Weber and Viann McGarry.

title: Exquisite Dining in Traditional Kyoto
description: I FELL in love with Japan when I was 13. Banished from the living room because my parents were entertaining, I flopped down in my sister's bedroom and watched Akira Kurosawa's "Seven Samurai" on PBS; within minutes I was smitten. I renounced the platform bed in which I'd slept for the previous five years, replacing it with a futon. I started cooking when I came across Shizuo Tsuji's superb "Japanese Cooking: A Simple Art" (Kodansha International) in a bookstore. I found in Mr. Tsuji's elegant presentation a real-world articulation of the aesthetic and ideological purity that I had perceived as the essence of the Kurosawa film; if Kurosawa had ignited my love for the country, Mr. Tsuji deepened and defined it.

title: Night Lines: July 10-16
description: JAY LENO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTZ, WILLIAM N.
description: HARTZ--William N. July 13, 2005 at age 83. Beloved husband of Joan (Fellerman). Devoted father of Randee, David, Cindi, Suzie and the late Kenneth. Cherished grandfather of eight. Loving brother of Toby Hornstein and Allan Kaplan. Alumnus of Baruch College of CCNY. Bill's integrity, intelligence and skill made him a leading producer at Salomon, Smith Barney from 1957 to the present. Service Sunday, July 17th, 1:30 PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81st St. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Cornell-NY Presbyterian Hospital, Division of Cardiology, 525 E. 68 St., NY, NY 10021.

title: A Black Market for Bomb Materials Is Said to Flourish in Europe
description: LONDON, July 16 - With experts now suspecting that the London suicide attackers used crude homemade bombs made from common commercial products, the spotlight has shifted to the wide availability of black-market explosives in Europe.

title: Paperback Row
description: MIDDLETOWN, AMERICA: One Town's Passage From Trauma to Hope, by Gail Sheehy. (Random House, $15.95.) Middletown, N.J., lost nearly 50 residents when the World Trade Center was destroyed on Sept. 11, 2001. Through two years and more than 900 interviews, Sheehy follows Middletown through the spiral of shock, anger, grief and determination, introducing us to widows of Wall Street traders, families of police officers who died in the rescue effort and survivors who escaped. "Their stories compose a powerful parable for our times," Sheehy writes.

title: LAND SET ASIDE
description: More than 1,800 acres of land will be preserved in an agreement between the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection and the DuPont Company, according to Bradley M. Campbell, the environmental commissioner. Under the agreement, one of the largest involving the damage of natural resources in the state, the company will preserve 1,875 acres in Cape May, Gloucester, Middlesex, Passaic and Salem Counties, plant 3,000 trees in urban areas, and pay $500,000 for water restoration projects and the construction of a boat ramp on the Salem River. The settlement is intended to compensate the public for damage the company caused to groundwater involving 2,400 acres. Tina Kelley

description: My husband and I would like to fulfill what was a youthful dream: a cruise of the South Pacific islands. Does such a cruise exist? -- Irene Schwartz, East Meadow, N.Y.

description: Two Long Island men were charged with a hate crime after they yelled ethnic slurs yesterday at a Hispanic man in a Farmingville parking lot and one of them threw a beer bottle at him, the police said.

And, while he was at it, he didn't like insurance companies and banks and multinationals and Republicans, either."

But in anime's strangest new trend, these often hypersexualized moppets are being turned into killing machines. Several recent Japanese television series released on DVD in the United States focus on innocent girls who have undergone deadly transformations.

description: Evidence that deer in upstate New York have been infected with a disorder called chronic wasting disease is stirring great anxiety among hunters, conservationists and politicians. The disease is invariably fatal to deer and elk, but is not known to harm humans.

Symbolic statement can send the message that those who do not belong to the majority are not full members of the community even if no "coercion" is involved.

title: Welcome to the Run. Now Remember, Dogs Are People, Too.

The tone was set early, when Patricia Barry, president of Bedford D.O.G. (Dog Owners Group) was describing the new features in the dog park scheduled to open here soon. Someone in the audience -- a furry type -- began barking.

There is belief again this summer that somehow, some way, the Braves will start winning more than any other team in the National League East, and that when the regular season ends on Oct. 2, they will be in first place.

title: The New Nanny Diaries Are Online
description: OUR former nanny, a 26-year-old former teacher with excellent references, liked to touch her breasts while reading The New Yorker and often woke her lovers in the night by biting them. She took sleeping pills, joked about offbeat erotic fantasies involving Tucker Carlson and determined she'd had more female sexual partners than her boyfriend.

title: Housing Goes Frothy to Flat in Denver Area
description: PARKER, Colo., July 12 - Tom Woods, a 37-year-old defense industry consultant, wanted to build a nest egg for one of his young sons' college tuition. Inspired by rising prices for homes in this Denver suburb, three years ago he invested in a new three-bedroom townhouse for $155,000. His hopes were that renters would cover most of his mortgage and that the property's value would appreciate by at least $10,000 a year.

title: Here's a Social Security Plan That's Really Two Plans
description: IT'S no surprise that President Bush can't seem to gain enough allies in Washington for his Social Security plan. The program pits two very different constituencies against each other, and trying to please both with the same policy changes is a thankless task. It's time for a healing dose of new ideas.

Some passengers eyed him suspiciously, and one reported him to the F.B.I. because of his first name. "Every time I went to go get the cab," he recalled, "I was feeling sad."

title: Taking Back the Hamptons
description: The Shinnecock Indians would like their land back -- 3,600 acres to start, including the Southampton College campus, the Shinnecock Hills Golf Club and Shinnecock Hills, a resort community. They want back rent, too -- it must total billions by now. They know this is a lot to ask, and if it's too much of a hardship, they might just drop their legal actions and settle for something simpler, like a casino.

title: Through the Looking Glass
description: THERE is little to be said about the artwork of James Britton (1878-1936), the subject of a well meaning if bland art-history recovery effort at the Lyman Allyn Art Museum in New London. His paintings are ordinary, and his subject matter desultory. He liked to do self-portraits, painting himself brush in hand in front of his art with the aid of mirrors. The background images are flipped.

title: PHOTO-OP
'Last Call for Blackford Oakes'
Roundup: Price is agreed for Wright-Phillips
'NPR'
description: When I first began to study the history of National Public Radio, I did not expect very much in the way of adventure. Given the civilized tone of the stories on Morning Edition and All Things Considered, I had no reason to think these shows would inspire the same level of passion as a play-off series between the Boston Red Sox and New York Yankees. Over time, though, I came to realize that NPR's news programs often did stimulate passionate discussions later in the day, whether at home, in the supermarket, at the gym, or in the lobby of a local theater.

title: 'The Icarus Girl': The Play Date From Hell
description: THE ICARUS GIRL By Helen Oyeyemi. 338 pp. Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $23.95.

title: Allyson Boyle and Albert Tornatore
description: Allyson Christine Boyle, the daughter of Beverly Boyle and Dr. James C. Boyle of Hartford, was married yesterday to Albert Tornatore, the son of Mary and Albert N. Tornatore of Manhattan. The Rev. James F. Hynes, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick-St. Anthony Church in Hartford.

title: The Cloths That Filled Matisse's Canvases
description: HENRI MATISSE, born into a family of weavers and brought up in the textile town of Bohain-en-Vermandois in northern France, took his love of cloth with him when he left home to become an artist. His enthrallment with color and pattern endured from his early paintings to his late-period world of colorful paper cutouts and large-scale scissor work, and he amassed an extensive textile collection. That lifelong fascination with fabric stands out in "Decorative Figure on an Ornamental Ground," an oil on canvas on view in "Matisse: The Fabric of Dreams -- His Art and His Textiles" at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: Feldman's church-state solution epitomizes two uniquely American strains of problem-solving: a well-intentioned though nave restatement of the "Why can't we all just get along?" approach to pluralism and a classic American belief that money lies at the root of all solutions.

title: Julie Belkin and Michael Rand
description: Julie Ann Belkin and Michael Gerard Rand were married yesterday evening at a farm in South Natick, Mass. Rabbi Edward Schecter officiated.

title: Pyrenees and Heat Can't Slow Armstrong
description: AX-3 DOMAINES, France, July 16 - A surging Lance Armstrong faced his most direct challenge in this year's Tour de France on Saturday, the first of three days in the Pyrenees, only to widen his lead by more than a minute over his closest rival.

title: First Case Against Hussein, Involving Killings in 1982, Is Sent to a Trial Court
description: The Iraqi Special Tribunal set up to try Saddam Hussein said in a statement today that Mr. Hussein and three others will be referred to criminal court on charges related to the killings of about 150 Shiites in the Iraqi town of Dujail in 1982. The tribunal said that investigations into millions of documents and the questioning of thousands of witnesses have been completed, and that the trial related to the Dujail killings was one of several Mr. Hussein and his top aides are expected to face.

title: A Modern K.G.B. Colonel
description: KREMLIN RISING Vladimir Putin's Russia and the End of Revolution. By Peter Baker and Susan Glasser. Illustrated. 453 pp. A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $27.50.

title: Milford Bars Itself From Taking Property
description: In response to the recent ruling by the United States Supreme Court that fostering economic development is an appropriate use of the government's power of eminent domain, Milford's Board of Aldermen passed an ordinance on Tuesday night barring the city from doing so.

title: Double Parking, at a Fraction of the Price
description: Fellan Florists, a venerable, family-run flower shop in Trump Plaza on Third Avenue at 61st Street, received $8,000 in parking violations on its three delivery vans last year. But the owners had neither the time nor the inclination to make much of a fuss.

title: For School Parents, Fund-Raising 101
description: AFTER a few weeks of summer vacation, many parents of school-age children look forward to Labor Day and the start of the new school year. But for several hundred on the Island, the end of the summer looms as a dreaded deadline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRAZIANI, CHARLES P., DDS
description: GRAZIANI--Charles P., DDS. 93, of Santa Barbara, CA., formerly of Brooklyn, N.Y. and Plandome, L.I. Passed away on July 7, 2005. Beloved husband of Anne and the devoted and loving father of Clara Graziani Bronson, Audrey Graziani Brown and Charles Graziani, Jr. He was the cherished grandfather of eight grandchildren and six great grandchildren. He is survived also by his brother Thomas E. Graziani, DDS, and sister Lee Kralicek. His life was dedicated to his wife, his family and his profession. He enjoyed life fully and was a source of inspiration and a model of courage to his family. Services were held at Santa Barbara Cemetery on Tuesday, July 12.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FORD, JOHN J., JR.
description: FORD--John J., Jr. Born March 5, 1924 in Los Angeles, California, died July 7, 2005 in Scottsdale, Arizona. John was a renowned numismatist who began working in the coin business at age 15. He had a lifelong fascination with history. His exhaustive research and vast knowledge on a range of historical subjects made him a noted expert on rare historical artifacts. John served in the army's CounterIntelligence Corps in World War II. In 1947 he married the former Joan MacDonald of Detroit. John spent almost his entire life in Rockville Centre, NY before moving to Phoenix in 1986. In addition to his wife, John is survived by three daughters, Susan Dobbins of Scottsdale, AZ, Leslie Sanderson of Prescott, AZ, and Kimberly Moon of Haddonfield, NJ; his sons-in-law Brian, John and Tom, his grandchildren Stacey and her husband Tom Lammot, Christopher, Kent, Clay, Matthew, Claire, John and Savannah, his great granddaughter Taylor Lammot, and his sister Mary Jane Confort of Garden City, NY. Please send donations in memory of John Ford to the American Numismatic Association, 818 North Cascade Ave., Colorado Springs, CO 80903.

title: A Night in the Tropics
description: Culver City, Calif. - METEOROLOGISTS call it the calm before the storm. For a bartender, it's that hour or so of eerie tranquillity when the scrape of a stool squeaks loudly. "It doesn't get going until later, and then it gets really crazy," Brittany Istre said as she swabbed the bar at Carbon, a gritty club on a dejected stretch of boulevard in a suburb of Los Angeles. Only three people hunched over their drinks on this Tuesday night. It didn't look promising.

title: The Best of Magnolia, Without the Long Lines
description: LEXINGTON, a 5 1/2-year-old husky-Labrador mix, weighs a little more than 50 pounds these days, just about what he should. He has a curly tail and fur that his owner, Elizabeth Petit, describes as vanilla white. It's a description he might appreciate, because Lexington, like many of his Greenwich Village neighbors, has a bit of a sweet tooth.

title: How Costco Became the Anti-Wal-Mart

title: At Sea
description: Anyone daydreaming of solitude on a crowded beach this summer might wish to trade places with the bathers in these images, part of a series begun four years ago by Richard Misrach. All of the pictures were taken from a balcony of a Hawaiian island hotel that he previously discovered while on vacation. To create the feeling of hovering above the swimmers, he deliberately excludes the horizon line from the frame -- he's making art, not documentary photographs -- and he reinforces the feeling of aloneness in some cases by digitally removing other swimmers from the water in the post-production phase of his picture-making. There's another, more disquieting revelation in these photographs, one resulting from seeing these small human figures afloat in such vast seascapes. As in much of his other work -- his images of the desert or of the sky above the Golden Gate Bridge, for example -- Misrach here uses scale to put people in what he sees as their proper perspective. "The huge scale enhances the beauty and the sense of the sublime," he says of his pictures, "but it also begins to expose our vulnerability and fragility as human beings."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RIES, SYLVIA L.
description: RIES--Sylvia L. Of Florida. Formerly of Elizabeth, N.J. July 13, 2005. For information, "Wien & Wien", 1-800-322-0533

The Miracle of Flight, No Airplane Necessary
description: WHEN Jaime Camarena was a teenager in Mexico City, he told his brother his life's ambition was to fly. A practical sort, the brother took him to the airport for a short hop in a vintage biplane. It wasn't what the young man had in mind.

title: A Lovely Scent From the Alps
description: La Cave du Vin Blanc de Morgex et de la Salle, a cooperative in Val d'Aosta in the Italian Alps, specializes in the native pri blanc grape. It is farmed on rocky, steep terraces within sight of Mont Blanc. The virtually weightless 2004 white has a lovely floral scent and is as bracing as snowy air.

title: Unprepared for a Flu Pandemic
description: If a much-feared pandemic of avian influenza starts sweeping through the world's population anytime soon, neither the United States nor international health authorities will be prepared to cope with it. There is not enough vaccine or antiviral medicine available to protect more than a handful of people, and no industrial capacity to produce a lot more of these medicines quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DENNIS, CLARENCE, M.D.
description: DENNIS--Clarence, M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Clarence Dennis, M.D., master surgeon, chair of surgery from 1951 to 1972, originator of the heartlung machine, and generous benefactor. A graduate of Harvard College in 1931, and Johns Hopkins Medical School in 1935, he received a Master's and Ph.D. in physiology from The University of Minnesota. He trained in surgery there under Owen Wangensteen, and stayed in Minnesota on the faculty prior to coming to Downstate. An original "translational scientist," Dr. Dennis established himself as a leader in cardiopulmonary bypass physiology. As our chairman, he performed the first successful open-heart surgery in New York State, using an apparatus he built in our laboratories. A gifted educator, he trained scores of surgeons in New York, affecting the lives of countless people around the world. His residents established The Clarence Dennis Society in his honor, which is still active. Upon his retirement, Downstate awarded him its highest honor, an honorary doctorate in science. With his wife, Mary, he made a generous gift to SUNY Downstate, establishing one of the few endowed academic chairs in honor of great surgical educators. Upon leaving Downstate, he established a presence in our sister organization, SUNY Stony Brook, prior to returning to Minnesota for retirement. Our heartfelt sympathies are extended to Mary, to their children, Jane, Richard, James Wigertz, and David, to his fifteen grandchildren, five great grandchildren, and to all their colleagues and many friends. Michael E. Zenilman, M.D., Chairman, Department of Surgery John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean, College of Medicine

title: Poetry Chronicle
description: WHILE WE'VE STILL GOT FEET: New Poems. By David Budbill. (Copper Canyon, paper, $15.) Budbill belongs to the tradition in American letters inaugurated by Thoreau and continuing today in manifestations both benign (Wendell Berry) and malignant (Ted Kaczynski), wherein the writer abandons the cacophony of human society for a little paradise in the woods, but instead of quietly living out his days in smog-free solitude insists on coming to town (or writing an essay, or mailing a bomb) every few months to remind us of what a benighted existence we're living. Budbill's Walden, in Vermont, sounds like an enchanting place, with a "lovely garden / sleeping quietly now under the snow," "an evening grosbeak / perched on the topmost branch of the / fifty-foot-high white pine tree / here on the edge of the dooryard" and days filled with reverie. Still, it seems presumptuous for Budbill to assume we'd want to crash his hermitage: "So much silence / is frightening. Better not come here if you / don't want to fall in upon yourself. Better yet, / better not come here at all." Such moments are few, though. Budbill's frank self-awareness keeps him from sounding smug for long; he's quick to include himself among the benighted. When Budbill's on his mountain, he longs for the city, and vice versa. Fame, wealth and sex are false gods, he insists, but he hastens to add that he still, at times, craves all three. These are not new ideas -- a list of references in the book shows how strongly he's been influenced by the classical Chinese poets -- but they find fresh expression here, thanks to Budbill's good humor and gusto. Joel Brouwer

Two and a half years after the Columbia shuttle disaster, the return to space will wait at least until the end of the week.

title: London After the Bombings: Life Goes On
description: ANYONE arriving in London on July 7 -- the day terrorists struck the city with four bombings -- might well have expected to find a city under siege, a world capital ground to a halt, a situation similar to what New York felt like in the days after 9/11. But when I arrived at Heathrow airport that evening, having flown in from Italy (where I had watched news reports on the attacks on TV monitors in the Milan airport), I was struck at how oddly normal the city seemed.

title: 'The Icarus Girl'
Robber Barons Have Feelings, Too
description: IT took 100 years, but someone found something nice to say about Jay Gould. According to Edward J. Renehan Jr., the conventional portrait of the robber baron is all wrong. Gould was not a "one-dimensional villain," nor (merely) a Wall Street leech or manipulator. He was "a detail-oriented owner," a "workaholic who painstakingly consolidated dying railroads, transformed them into highly profitable megalines." Indeed, "the case for Gould as an exemplary, successful, long-term C.E.O. is there to be made."

description: So, the intensely awaited Edward Klein book on Hillary Rodham Clinton is out, and has been lambasted by critics.

title: Ron Moore's Deep Space Journey
description: The interior of the Battlestar Galactica is a warren of shadowy, angular hallways and spare functional chambers split over two sound stages situated on the semi-industrial fringe of Vancouver, British Columbia. The Galactica is a spaceship, but it does not feel particularly space-age. The communication panels on the walls were scavenged from a Canadian destroyer; the desk lamps are from Ikea. If you have seen "Battlestar Galactica," which began its second season on the Sci Fi Channel on Friday, you will know that this Galactica only vaguely resembles the ship that previously bore that name, when "Battlestar Galactica" first flew on prime time in 1978, square in the shadow of "Star Wars." And it certainly does not resemble the Enterprise, the "Star Trek" vehicle that has defined the visual and thematic vocabulary of television science fiction for four decades. On the Galactica, there is no captain's chair; there are no windows full of stars. The command center is busy and dark, protected deep within the ship the way it would be on an actual military vessel. As the actors move from room to room, hand-held cameras swoop behind them, closing in on them claustrophobically. The characters do not travel heroically from planet to planet, solving the problems of aliens. There are, in fact, no aliens at all.

All along, Mr. Newhart's ordinary-man persona has been his genius. As LARRY GELBART says in the special, "The big thing about Bob is, you think he's there to check the gas meter."

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: FAITH AND BETRAYAL: A Pioneer Woman's Passage in the American West. By Sally Denton. (Knopf, $23.) In 1850, the 40-year-old Jean Rio, a wealthy London widow and mother of seven, packed up her brood and shipped off for Salt Lake City to join the Mormon community, recently corralled into existence by Brigham Young. It's difficult to understand why Rio did this (something to do with "a more primitive Christianity" and London's cholera epidemic), but Denton, her great-great-granddaughter, wisely doesn't belabor such details. What she has on her hands is a great, often scary American story, much of which is told through excerpts from Rio's diary. Denton sweeps much history into a mere 200 pages, too much perhaps, and the book does serve as a primer on the origins of Mormon life. (Denton is the author of "American Massacre: The Tragedy at Mountain Meadows, September 1857," also about Mormon life.) So from a teeming dock in Liverpool, she takes us on a nauseating trans-Atlantic voyage, through the sticky luxury of New Orleans, up the Mississippi and across the Mormon Trail. Rio "harbored no regrets about her decision to leave England," but that was before she got to Utah, a land of poverty, polygamy and killings. The Mormon missionaries never mentioned that such misfortune awaited the converts in the lonely West, and eventually Rio flees, though some of her children remain Mormons. Their brave mother stays faithful only to God, and, in the end, finds a more comfortable Zion in San Francisco.

description: IT isn't easy being a commercial real estate executive. Modern leaders must mix frontier passion with corporate savvy, while traveling in rarefied philanthropic and social circles.

description: THE whir of a paper shredder may recall numerous scandals of recent vintage, from the Iran-contra affair to the Enron debacle. But in the future, much noisier machines will be needed to dispose of evidence -- or, in the case of most shredder users, to keep trade secrets and personal data from falling into malicious hands. No matter how many paper documents are destroyed, the efforts will be in vain if data-rich CD's and DVD's are left intact.

title: A Most Exotic Art Scene Blooms in Ulan Bator
description: MOST Thursdays, the airy, light-suffused gallery on the square fills with the city's vibrant, burgeoning arts community. They gather to see new work, speaking in animated tones about color, texture and perspective. Typically, the featured artist holds court, drawing a crowd that leans close to hear something of the inspiration for the work. If the season is right, a bowl of fermented mare's milk is sometimes passed around. The mare's milk notwithstanding, you'd be forgiven for thinking you had stumbled into a Parisian salon.

title: Artest Begins Long Way Back to Uncertainty
description: MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 - Silence, a few hands clapping and then the sound of a ball bouncing in the cavernous Target Center on Friday welcomed Ron Artest back for his first game in eight months.

title: Indie Snacking
description: Does a love of independent film go with a taste for fancy snacks? The management of the new IFC Center in Greenwich Village is hoping so. Not only has it installed a restaurant, the Waverly, with a menu overseen by the chef couple Claudia Fleming and Gerry Hayden; it's also gone the gourmet route at the concession stand, where the refreshments include truffle-butter-topped organic popcorn and Niman Ranch hot dogs.

title: Las Vegas's Mayor Pulls Out the Glitz While Attempting to Attract a Pro Team
description: LAS VEGAS, July 16 - Mayor Oscar Goodman is obsessed with showgirls. To secure a long interview, he suggested, "Bring showgirls!"

title: Official Outings
description: I have always believed that an elected official's private life is not a part of the public record. Before and after the Mayor Jim West episode, I have heard colleagues discuss outing legislators who oppose gay rights but are rumored to be gay. What are the ethics in this case? State Senator Ken Jacobsen, Seattle Your colleagues may ethically out an official only if that official's being gay is germane to his policy-making. A person who seeks elected office, voluntarily entering the public arena, does surrender some claims to privacy. (Financial disclosure comes to mind.) Some, but not all. An official's private life should remain private unless he or she makes it relevant to a public position freely taken. A cross-dressing secretary of agriculture who voiced no opinion on the sexual high jinks of soybeans -- do legumes engage in high jinks? -- would not meet this standard; a gay state senator who opposed gay civil rights would. Similarly, the assault weapons stockpiled by a gun-control advocate would be pertinent; his nude trout-fishing would not be.

title: Wynn Las Vegas
description: THE BASICS -- Steve Wynn, the hotelier and casino owner, reportedly spent $2.7 billion to build his dream resort, which opened April 28. That's about a million dollars for each of its 2,716 rooms.

title: Sympathy for Tea
description: Caution: you are now entering a latte-free zone.

title: Eye vs. Eye: Inside the Photo Wars
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. - TWO-FIFTEEN, a balmy Thursday afternoon. A slow day for the paparazzi. On Melrose Avenue, just east of La Cienega Boulevard, Steven Ginsburg's Toyota 4Runner idles in front of Bhava, the kind of hip salon whose patrons are wealthy, famous, or the recipients of televised makeovers. Minutes ago his cellphone beeped with a tip: Alyssa Milano, a star of the WB series "Charmed," is getting her hair done.

title: Mad Hot New York

title: The Right Kind of Justice
description: President Bush has made clear that he intends to nominate a conservative to fill Justice Sandra Day O'Connor's pivotal seat on the Supreme Court. That is hardly a surprise, but the question is what he means by conservative. Some of the president's supporters on the far right really want him to name a radical ideologue who would work to upend well-established legal doctrines and take away basic rights that Americans have come to cherish. The Senate must work hard to ensure that this does not happen.

title: CHANGING CHIANG MAI
description: To the Editor: I read the article about Chiang Mai and was disappointed. I recently returned from a week's travels, many of those days spent in Chiang Mai. My experience is that it is far from ruined by Western influences. Rather, it is Western influences that are bringing new life to the city and its citizens. The prominent picture of a Starbucks next to a McDonald's is the one place in the entire city where you could have seen that.

title: Another resort in Turkey is bombed, leaving 5 dead
'Listener Supported' and 'NPR': All Things Considered
description: Correction Appended

title: A Secular Messiah Gets His Own Opera
description: ON Sept. 26, 1940, in the small Spanish town of Portbou, Walter Benjamin's desperate flight from Nazi-occupied Europe came to a tragic end. After being turned back just beyond the French border, within sight of his freedom, he committed suicide. Historians have long considered the death of this German-Jewish philosopher a grievous intellectual toll exacted by the Third Reich, and now a new opera tries to register the loss through a fractured avant-garde prism. Its opening scene takes place on Benjamin's final night.

title: Jenny Blascovich and Michael Best
description: Jenny Lynn Blascovich and Michael Best are to be married today at Battery Gardens, a restaurant in Manhattan. Rabbi David E. Fass is to officiate.

title: Critics and Fans Alike as Navy Chief Steps Down
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 - Adm. Vern Clark is stepping down next week as the longest-serving chief of naval operations in a half-century, having spent five years revamping the fleet and trimming Navy budgets in an unusual sacrifice to help pay the Army's bills in Iraq.

title: Fighting Words
description: One does not ask a combat veteran, "Did you kill anyone in the war?" (Questions for Chuck Hagel, Deborah Solomon, July 3). A fellow veteran, at a quiet moment, might ask that question, but a civilian who has never been placed in harm's way has no right.

description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba - Canada's native peoples are often depicted in the national media as suffering an array of social afflictions: broken families, glue-sniffing children, violent gangs, alcoholism and homelessness.

description: Kudos to Charles McGrath (July 3) for informatively and wittily cutting through the economic tripe we're being fed by the globalizers. And hail to the French resisters!

description: Some politicians build their careers around compassion. Some build their careers around loyalty to a group or a class. But there are others, like Theodore Roosevelt, Robert Kennedy, John McCain and Rudy Giuliani, who build their careers around courage.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 17 -- July 23; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: The TANGLEWOOD MUSIC CENTER is in full swing. For those who missed concerts from James Levine's first season as music director of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, here is a chance to catch up. On Sunday the orchestra plays works by JOHN HARBISON and CHARLES WUORINEN, two of the most important living American composers and favorites of Mr. Levine. The Boston Symphony commissioned the pieces, Mr. Wuorinen's Fourth Piano Concerto and Mr. Harbison's "Darkbloom: Overture for an Imagined Opera," and gave their premieres last season.

title: Bali High
description: Even by the festal standards of their adopted Bali, where get-togethers are as common as tourists having their hair braided on the beach, John and Cynthia Hardy know how to party. The couple behind the jewelry company John Hardy Designs are known almost as much for their high-octane entertaining as they are for their high-impact ornaments. "You don't need much of an excuse to have a party in Bali," John says. "They go all-out here; so we do, too."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROMAINE, RALPH O.
description: ROMAINE--Ralph O. Age 87. On June 26, 2005 in Hastings, Nebraska. Born April 14, 1918 in Portland, Oregon to Lillian and Orie Romaine, Ralph began his career in aviation with his first solo flight in a Taylor Cub at the age of 18. Never far from the stick and rudder thereafter, he became a flight instructor at the Spartan School of Aviation in 1941 and taught aspiring British fighter pilots who went on to win the Battle of Britain at the Number 3 British Flying Training School in Miami, Oklahoma. He later became a test pilot with Brewster Aeronautical Corporation, Fisher Body Aircraft Division in Clevland, and the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation in Saint Louis in 1945, where he was the test pilot for the first U.S. Navy jet fighter, the FH-1 Phantom, including the aircraft carrier takeoff and landing demonstration flights at Patuxent Naval Air Station, through acceptance of the Phantom by the Navy. In 1946, he joined Edo Corporation in New York as chief test pilot, later advancing to Vice President of Marketing and President of Edo Commerial Corporation. He retired from active managerial responsibilities in 1978, but remained on the Board of Directors until 1994, 48 years of association with the company. He was a member of the Quiet Birdmen and the Experimental Aircraft Association. He is survived by his wife of 64 years, Vera, his two sons, Gary and Randolph, and one grandchild.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: Feldman has made a valuable contribution to the church-state debate, but some further analysis seems necessary. His proposed solution -- taking government money out of the religious sphere -- would be far more complex than he may believe. It ignores the taxation components of the equation. His proposal seems to require elimination of things like property-tax exemptions for religious institutions and the deduction for charitable contributions. At the least, he doesn't address this issue, which will inevitably arise in any debate over his plan.

title: A Quest for Green, Not Asphalt

Close to home in Putnam County, there isn't much to choose from, she said, except for one shopping center and a few small strip malls.

title: Gus Van Sant's Own Private Hollywood
description: FOR a guy with one mainstream smash -- "Good Will Hunting" -- and strong ties to major stars, Gus Van Sant remains uncannily inner-directed. At 52, he still approaches movies like a graduate school conceptual artist dabbling in modes of perception. Every film, even the major-studio ones, is a potentially disastrous experiment. If you've seen his last two, "Gerry" and "Elephant," you might be puzzled or exasperated by shots that go on and on (and on), and by what seems like a perverse refusal to provide psychological explanations. Or you might be turned on by how he lets you drift through time and space, dispensing information in tiny increments and allowing you to arrange the pieces in your head.

title: Comings and Goings
description: This summer, travelers can beat the heat by visiting the Arctic Circle region. On July 10, CRUISE NORTH EXPEDITIONS, owned by Inuits, began a series of eight one-week cruises aboard the Ushuaia, a 66-passenger ice-strengthened ship. The trips through remote areas of northern Canada -- home to polar bears, caribou, walruses, seals and whales -- will be accompanied by naturalists, historians and ornithologists. Participants in the final cruise, Aug. 28 to Sept. 4, will have the opportunity to race in a marathon that starts in Kangiqsujuaq, a traditional Inuit community, and continues across tundra and fjords. The price, starting at $2,490 a person, double occupancy, includes the two-hour flight from Montreal to Kuujjuaq in northern Quebec, where the ship departs. Information: (866) 263-3220 or www.cruisenorthexpeditions.com. AIRTRAN inaugurated service from Richmond, Va., on June 23, with four daily nonstop flights to Atlanta and two daily nonstops to Philadelphia. Daily service between Richmond and Orlando, Fla., will start Nov. 8. Information and reservations: (800) 247-8726 or www.airtran.com. SWISSTEL plans to open its first hotel in Moscow on Monday. The 235-room Krasnye Holmy Moscow is on the eastern tip of Kremlin Island between the Moscow River and the Obvodny Channel, and, at 34 stories, is one of the tallest buildings in the city. Reservations and information: (800) 637-9477 or www.swissotel.com. MARJORIE CONNELLY

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, RALPH M.
description: GOLDMAN--Ralph M. Died Sunday, July 10th in his home at age 85. Specializing in American and transnational political parties, Professor Goldman championed the use of parties as the institutional alternative to civil and international war, and as crucial to overcoming terrorist and anti-democratic movements. Prof. Goldman published more than a dozen books and over 80 articles in scholarly journals and encyclopedias. In 1960 he co-authored the ground-breaking Brookings Institution study of The Politics of National Party Conventions. In From Warfare to Party Politics, 1990, he shows how nations evolve from violence to party competition via a "critical transition" in their political development. Viewing war a last resort, Prof. Goldman co-authored Building Trust: An Introduction to Peacekeeping and Arms Control (1997). His journal articles and citations to most of his books may be found in The Future Catches Up, 2002 and his professional work is described in Who's Who in America. A Professor of Political Science at San Francisco State University (1962-1986), Prof. Goldman served as Dean of Faculty Research and Director of the Institute for Research on International Behavior. From 1956-1962 he taught at Michigan State University and from 1953-1956 he was a Research Fellow at The Brookings Institution in Washington, DC. Post-retirement, he was Sr. Consultant to the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs and directed off-campus graduate programs in Politics at The Catholic University of America in Washington, D.C. Prof. Goldman was born in Brooklyn, NY on May 14, 1920. While at Boys High School, he edited the school newspaper, organized the peace club, and led the honor society. He served for four years in the Adjutant Generals Corps during World War II, rising to the rank of Captain. He then earned his B.A. at New York University and his M.A and Ph.D. in political science at the University of Chicago. Prof. Goldman is survived by his wife, Barbara Alban, two adult children, Peter and Meg, and his brother, Leonard. Meg, her husband Gary Prince, and two grandchildren, Laurel and Austin, reside in Washington. Leonard and his wife Elinor live in New Jersey. Professor Goldman's marriage to Joan Walsh ended in divorce.

title: A Diary Comes to Life Musically and Electronically

But thanks to John Morton, a composer who specializes in pieces using electronically altered sounds of music boxes, this antique instrument -- which chimes arias and popular ditties from the early 20th century -- is having its solo turn here through early September.

title: PHOTO-OP
THE WEEK AHEAD: July 17 -- July 23; THEATER
description: It's getting hard to keep track of all the summer theater festivals in Manhattan. The second annual SUMMER PLAY FESTIVAL at Theater Row continues through the end of the month. The Fringe Festival is just around the corner. And beginning this week, the MIDTOWN INTERNATIONAL THEATER FESTIVAL takes over an otherwise unremarkable block of West 36th Street, presenting more than 50 productions in three weeks. There are not a lot of well-known -- or even vaguely known -- theater names on the roster, but, as is often the case with scrappy grab bags of work by mostly young artists, there are a lot of attention-getting concepts and titles. The festival will feature a musical about Gen X (it's called, wouldn't you know, "APATHY") and another about the doomed marriage of Charles and Diana. (Maybe that one should have been called "Apathy," too.) My pick for Most Unpromising Title: "CERVIX WITH A SMILE," described in press materials as "hilarious and slightly disturbing." Just slightly? Runner-up: "COSMOS/ETHOS: FROM BRIS TO ABYSS." There is also a play by ANNE FIZZARD titled "GOOD OPINIONS," in which a coat-check girl is discovered to have a gift for predicting the responses of a theater critic from The New York Times. I hope she's well tipped. Begins performances on Monday at various stages on West 36th Street, (212)868-4444.

title: The Years of a Clown (45 Years, to Be Exact)

title: PUBLIC ADVOCATE RETURNS
description: Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey signed a law last Tuesday to bring back New Jersey's Department of the Public Advocate, a move he billed as the latest in a series of steps to reform state government before he leaves office at the end of the year. The office, which was eliminated more than a decade ago by Gov. Christie Whitman on the grounds that it was unnecessary and expensive, is supposed to function as a government ombudsman, consumer watchdog and lawyer for the indigent, the elderly and the mentally ill. The office will derive much its influence from its power to bring civil suits against state and local officials. Mr. Codey said that the new public advocate would be a "champion of ordinary people with real needs but without political capital," and he called Mrs. Whitman's decision to cut the position "penny-wise and pound-foolish." At the ceremonial signing of the bill in his office last Tuesday, the governor recited a list of other laws he had signed to make state government more transparent and efficient, including one that places limits on campaign contributions from state contractors and one that creates a state inspector general to monitor governmental waste and abuse and one that mandates ethics courses for state employees. Josh Benson

Although its shares are down 2.8 percent this year, at $40.96, Dell is trading at a ritzy price-to-earnings ratio of 30, well above the average of 18 for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

Lama's house, a two-bedroom brownstone, had running water in both the bathrooms and a kitchen and a stove. "Gosh, we won't have to collect wood to start fires," she thought. Even though Lama had told her he also had other African immigrants staying there (they were actually Jamaican), the brownstone had a lot more room and amenities than Fatou was accustomed to.

title: Scarves With 'Tude Complete the Package
description: The little chiffon neckerchiefs of yesteryear have been replaced this summer by long flowing scarves in lace, crocheted yarns and threads and silk. Worn as frivolous ornament -- much in the vein of last summer's ponchos -- the new skinny scarves are paired with tank tops or T's and are worn loose or tied once around the neck, the ends hanging down to brush belt loops or even knees. Missoni's sweetly hued cotton knit scarf is striped in pink and green with a creamy scalloped pattern ($348 at Henri Bendel) while Moyna's mesh scarf glimmers with large silver paillettes ($68, also at Henri Bendel). Silk charmeuse scarves by Tamsen are brightly watercolored with the numbers of a clock ($375 at Marissa Collections in South Naples, Fla., 239-263-4333). And Erickson Beamon's tropical-weight muffler ($1,480, 212-643-4810, extension 139 to order) goes the distance with jet beaded fringe and 12 solid feet of black lace. Who cares if the mercury's rising? Just tie one on.

title: 'Fantastic'
description: As California Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger stood at the podium of the Republican National Convention in August 2004, scanning the vast assemblage, everything was fantastic. Arnold's favorite word was fantastic. Of course, his wife, Maria Shriver, was "fantastic," but so was working with his predecessor and archrival, former Governor Gray Davis, during the transition. Now that Arnold was in office, every Californian would have a "fantastic job." When a judge ruled that he had violated campaign laws and would have to repay $4.5 million out of his own pocket, that was "fantastic," too.

title: Inside the List
description: OFF THE GRID: No one seems to know very much about the writer who calls himself John Twelve Hawks -- he's publishing's new international man of mystery. According to the terse biographical sketch on the dust jacket of his first novel, "The Traveler," Twelve Hawks is simply a man who "lives off the Grid." No book tour for this literary Unabomber. His agent and editor say they've never met him. Twelve Hawks communicates with them by satellite phone, and employs spy-store technology: a voice scrambler that can make him sound like Darth Vader or, presumably, Umberto Eco after a 10K sprint. Twelve Hawks's publisher, Doubleday, is trying to make this game of hide-and-go-seek work for them in the summer of Deep Throat Redux, and perhaps it is -- The Traveler" enters this week's hardcover fiction list at No. 13. Twelve Hawks's book is a "Matrix"-like thriller set in a society where "the Vast Machine" watches everything people do; it's about "a fierce group of warriors" who try to protect "a select few" known as Travelers. As a sci-fi entertainment machine, "The Traveler" skims along, but it's studded with op-ed pronouncements about the end of privacy that quickly become leaden. The more we learn about Twelve Hawks, the less spooky he seems. According to USA Today, he likes wine and lives in New York, London and Los Angeles. In a Q. & A. posted on Doubleday's Web site, the author sounds more like Chuck Norris than Thomas Pynchon: "I studied martial arts for several years," he intones, Vaderishly, "and have fought both in tournaments and on the street." He isn't laconic about his own gifts: "There are a great many provocative ideas in this novel. Everyone who reads 'The Traveler' is going to be entertained by an exciting story." Who is this guy? Patrick Anderson, writing in The Washington Post Book World, floated a rumor that Twelve Hawks is actually "fat, 40 and named Bernie Broadbeam."

title: Israel Responds to Attacks, Arresting 30 Militants
description: JERUSALEM, July 16 - The Israeli Army arrested 30 members of the militant groups Hamas and Islamic Jihad on the West Bank early Saturday morning and fired rockets from helicopter gunships at three sites suspected of being Hamas weapons factories in Gaza City and Khan Yunis, army spokesmen said.

title: The Brazilian Who Sang Bowie Sings Again
description: Seu Jorge

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 3 about Congo misstated the year that Rwandan troops began killing Hutu opponents who had fled there. It was 1996, not 1966.

title: Small Courtesies
description: To the Editor:

title: IS ALASKA MELTING?
description: To the Editor: How delightful and bittersweet was Timothy Egan's article "The Race to Alaska Before It Melts" (June 26).

title: Breaking the AIDS Chain
description: IN the summer of 2003, a young man went to his doctor complaining of a high fever, headache, painful joints and muscles and a rash. His doctor diagnosed the flu, and told him to rest and drink plenty of fluids. After a week, the man's symptoms went away. Unknown to this young patient and his doctor, however, those symptoms were caused by a very recent infection of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: A Pass on Privacy?
description: Anyone making long drives this summer will notice a new dimension to contemporary inequality: a widening gap between the users of automatic toll-paying devices and those who pay cash. The E-ZPass system, as it is called on the East Coast, seemed like idle gadgetry when it was introduced a decade ago. Drivers who acquired the passes had to nose their way across traffic to reach specially equipped tollbooths -- and slow to a crawl while the machinery worked its magic. But now the sensors are sophisticated enough for you to whiz past them. As more lanes are dedicated to E-ZPass, lines lengthen for the saps paying cash.

title: Rocknroll Hanover Wins Million Again
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 16 - Rocknroll Hanover has proved again that he is the top horse in harness racing by winning the $1 million Meadowlands Pace on Saturday night. It was the third victory in a million-dollar race for Rocknroll Hanover, the son of Western Ideal.

title: Responding To the Law Of 'Nimby'
description: PERHAPS the most surprising thing about the past few stormy weeks in the life of Steve Levy, Suffolk's county executive, is that he seems surprised.

title: Facing the Problem Of North Korea
description: To the Editor:

title: Woods Wins British Open for Tenth Career Major Title
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 17 - In front of a gallery rooting hard for its European sons, Tiger Woods subdued the field at the Old Course at St. Andrews today, winning the 134th British Open by five strokes over Colin Montgomerie.

title: Homeland Security's Intelligence Gap
description: Washington - THE results of Secretary Michael Chertoff's top-to-bottom analysis of the Department of Homeland Security are in, and the reviews are following close behind. The critics fall, predictably, into two camps: those who think that the changes are merely cosmetic, essentially rearranging the deck chairs on the Titanic; and those who think that they represent a first step in the right direction.

title: Boatcraft Tried and True
description: A GROUP of "Queer Eye for the Straight Guy" episodes this summer focused on a man who created a boatbuilding and maritime skills program for Bronx teenagers.

title: Trials and Errors
description: NOT long ago, they were headline news, the details of their private lives -- from credit card statements to love letters -- splashed across the state's newspapers and television reports. The public watched them resign from office, go to prison, testify against others.

title: Nonstrategy on Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: POTENTIAL 'MELTDOWN'
description: State transportation experts are warning that speed limits may have to be lowered, that potholes may remain unfilled and that lanes may be closed for long periods because of delays in maintenance work. There also may be fewer buses and trains available, which would make commuters wait longer and stand once aboard. "Simply put, New Jersey is facing a transportation meltdown," said Thomas G. Dallessio, vice president and New Jersey director of the Regional Plan Association, one of the main authors of a study on the Transportation Trust Fund, the state's primary mechanism to repair roads and bridges. The report, released last Monday by a coalition of planners, transportation groups and academics, urges the state's elected officials to figure out a way to replenish the fund by next summer. David W. Chen

title: Blowing Up in the West
description: WASHINGTON - THE young man was poor and without prospects, but that was not why he carried the bomb. He had not been recruited and was not out for revenge, he said, but simply longed to fulfill "the love of martyrdom." As he lugged his heavy black bag toward an Israeli bus stop, his main worry was not moral but practical. The bomb, evidently derived from fertilizer, smelled terrible, and might give him away. He bought a $3 bottle of perfume and doused it.

title: Corrections
description: A table last Sunday with an article about minimotorcycles included a reference, erroneously, to the top speed of a full-size motorcycle, the Harley-Davidson VRSCA V-Rod. The company does not disclose top speeds for its motorcycles. (Cycle World magazine, however, recently estimated the V-Rod's at 134 miles per hour.)

title: Backbreakers And the Briefcase's Demise
description: STEPHEN SILVER can pinpoint the year the attach case died. It was 1994, and commuters were switching to backpacks and soft-sided briefcases that could be slung over the shoulder.

title: Jasmine's Method
description: Jasmine Long of Jersey City (above) was first jailed when she was 13, and was in and out of juvenile detention centers five or six times a year after that, by her own count. It was at the center in Secaucus, N.J., in 2003 that she met the filmmakers Lori Silverbush and Michael Skolnik and the actress and teacher Paola Mendoza, who had started an acting program there. The workshops they offered fed into a script they were developing about teenage women whose lives intertwine on the streets of Jersey City and in prison; it became the film "On the Outs," which won the grand jury prize at this year's Slamdance Film Festival and is now playing at Film Forum. The movie's protagonist, Oz, was loosely based on Jasmine, and when it came time for filming, Ms. Silverbush asked Jasmine to offer some advice to Judy Marte (at left), the actress playing Oz. Kevin Giordano spoke with Jasmine, who is on parole after serving 11 months in a New Jersey state prison for robbery and will turn 18 in August, about her work as an acting coach.

title: CALIFORNIA KISMET
description: The Art Center School of Design in Pasadena, Calif., is famous for grooming car designers, and Jay Leno is famous for his car collection. Today, the two will mix at the school's fifth annual Car Classic.

description: To the Editor: I read with interest "After Sibelius, a Rich Bounty of Musicians" (June 12) by Richard B. Woodward.

title: Man of the Year
description: So far, the leading candidate to become this year's Jude Law -- in the indie division, at least -- appears to be Chris Mulkey. Though not exactly a household name, Mr. Mulkey appears in as many as eight films that may be released by year's end, surpassing the six pictures that won Mr. Law a reputation for ubiquity in 2004. Mr. Mulkey, 57, has lately been onscreen as the father of a disturbed child in Gregg Araki's "Mysterious Skin." He's also in the forthcoming "Thanks to Gravity," "D-War," "Dreamland," "Dirty," "Farewell Bender," "Unknown" and -- the only major-studio release of the bunch -- a still untitled Warner Brothers project from the director Niki Caro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOROFSKY, HAROLD
description: BOROFSKY--Harold. Age 79, on July 7, 2005, at home in Princeton, NJ. Beloved husband of the late Dr. Leatrice Borofsky, father of David Borofsky, Lewis Borofsky and Rosalyn Ritts. Devoted grandfather of Eliana Ritts, Jacob Ritts and Joshua Borofsky, he was also loved as a father by his son-in-law Dean Ritts and his daughter-in-law Anne Borofsky. A memorial service was held on July 10, 2005, attended by family and friends, to whom he was and will always be an inspiration. He was loved by those who knew him and will remain in their hearts forever.

ANDREWS, Scotland - EVEN with Jack Nicklaus on the way home to North Palm Beach, Fla., the glow of his glorious farewell to the major championships still hung over the 134th British Open yesterday. It was not only there for his record 18 major victories that Tiger Woods is chasing, but also for another remarkable number in the 65-year-old Golden Bear's remarkable career: 19 second-place finishes in majors.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at East 81 St; 212-288-3500.

Each room's amenities include fresh flowers and one iPod preprogrammed with the guest's requests -- but only for use during the hotel stay. For reservations call (312) 345-1000 or (877) 762-5468.

It was the Connecticut Army National Guard, not the Air National Guard.

description: WASHINGTON, July 16 - In the months before the Iraqi elections in January, President Bush approved a plan to provide covert support to certain Iraqi candidates and political parties, but rescinded the proposal because of Congressional opposition, current and former government officials said Saturday.

title: Bowlful of Mystery
description: TO look at the august world of American silver is to wonder whether fine and august are not tantamount to tired. A layman might well leaf through a catalog of stolid, patrician silver produced over the last 100 years and wonder, What if Paul Revere had just let the British come? Surely they couldn't have had a more deplorable lack of imagination.

title: Officials' Pitch for Drug Plan Meets Skeptics
description: SCARBOROUGH, Me., July 15 - Four months before enrollment begins, the Bush administration has started a cross-country campaign to sell its most significant domestic policy initiative, the new Medicare drug benefit. But it is encountering skepticism from some consumers, whose participation is critical to the program's success.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COHEN, ROBERT F.
description: COHEN--Robert F., 79, died July 8 at home, Pt. St. Lucie, FL. Formerly Executive Director, Stephen Wise Free Synagogue and Rodeph Shalom in Manhattan, Temple Emanuel, Westfield, NJ. Survived by his wife Charlotte, daughter Susan, grandchildren, great-grandchildren.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: Feldman's suggestions can move us along a conciliatory path. But an additional point should be made: even with the steps he proposes, a simple majority can impose its faith and mores on the minority, forcing a woman to carry a fetus to term, preventing gay couples from marrying, keeping me from physician-assisted dying if I want it. We still need a judiciary that supports truly strict separation.

title: One Robe, Two Hats
description: FOR now, the announcement by Chief Justice William Rehnquist that he will continue in office as long as his health permits is likely to dampen discussion of his replacement. Instead of speculating about his physical condition and playing the nominee name game, we should focus on the unique role played by the chief justice of the United States.

title: Evolving Through Sculpture
description: MICHAEL STEINER, subject of a substantial exhibition at Yellow Bird Gallery in Newburgh, was once trumpeted by the art critic eminence Clement Greenberg as the everlasting hope of American abstract sculpture. These days, Mr. Steiner lives quietly in Bridgewater, Conn., turning out elegant if somewhat domesticated steel sculptures for house, lobby and garden, several dozen of which are inconspicuously parked here.

title: On the Job, the Pauses That Refresh
description: WHEN my computer developed a series of quirks and ticks a few weeks ago, the endlessly patient guys in tech support assured me the problem was not my abuse of the "refresh" key. That was a relief. I have been riding that key hard lately -- ever since my younger son left for sleepaway camp at the beginning of the month.

title: More Passengers And More Perks
description: NEWARK - TWICE a year, Kelly Powers is able to see his family and friends and eat a New Jersey staple, Taylor ham.

title: With N.A.A.C.P. Feud, Issues Go Begging
description: OSSINING - IN this Hudson riverfront village of 25,000, blacks and Hispanics represent close to half the population, and problems affecting the poor often weigh heavily. Now is an especially crucial time, because many lower-income residents are losing the protection of a 1950's-era program designed to stabilize the housing costs they pay.

title: A Guest at Large
description: Over the recent holiday weekend I was thrilled to have guests in my country house upstate. They had an absolutely wonderful time. And so did I. Maybe it's because we never saw each other. I was with friends in the Hamptons, where I stayed in a guesthouse, complete with well-stocked kitchen and cable television. I hardly saw my hosts. And that was fine, too.

title: A Feminist Classic Gets a Makeover
description: The unthinkable, though perhaps inevitable, has happened. Long known for its ardent denunciations of society's obsession with image, the feminist health guide Our Bodies, Ourselves (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, paper, $24.95) turned 35 this year and received a drastic makeover, like a contestant on "The Swan" concerned with brow furrows.

title: Suicide Bomber Ignites Tanker, Killing Scores of Iraqis
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Sunday, July 17 - A suicide bomber wrapped in explosives detonated himself next to a gasoline tanker south of Baghdad on Saturday night, creating a devastating fireball that killed at least 59 and wounded 86 , an Iraqi police official said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   THAL, RUDOLF
description: THAL--Rudolf. Alpine Country Club, its officers, Board of Governors and members deeply mourn the untimely passing of their fellow member, Mr. Rudolf Thal, and offer their deepest sympathy to his wife, Ruth; his children and the entire Thal family. Alpine Country Club Sam Terner, President

title: A Gondolier and an Adonis: Guides to Britten's Inner Torments
description: IN the fall of 1972, having nearly finished the compositional sketch for "Death in Venice," his last opera, Benjamin Britten was emotionally drained and deeply insecure about the work. He wrote to the choreographer Frederick Ashton that the opera, based on Thomas Mann's 1912 novella, was "either the best or the worst music I've ever written," adding that he had an utter dread of playing it for anyone.

title: A Maritime Icon, Threatened by Ikea
description: To the Editor:

title: Sighs, and the City
description: MONTCLAIR - I AM combing, as I do every Sunday, the Manhattan real estate ads.

title: Closer to Villagehood
description: A special election on whether to incorporate as a village could be held in the hamlet of Sagaponack as soon as next month, now that the Town of Southampton has accepted a petition signed by 538 eligible voters. Patrick Heaney, the town supervisor, approved the petition June 30.

title: The Farrar, Straus & Giroux of Street Lit
description: IN his usual spot on 125th Street, taking call after call on his cellphone on a recent Tuesday, Sidibe Ibrahima looked every inch an editor. Under one arm, he carried proofs of a novel that a friend had asked him to look at. Over the phone, he was reassuring another writer about her book. "Send me two chapters," he told her soothingly.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 3 about changes in standards of living in the United States misidentified the Massachusetts employers of two profiled workers, Tom and Marie DeSisto. Mr. DeSisto is a teacher at Waltham High School, not in Newton, and Mrs. DeSisto is director of nursing for the public schools of Waltham, not Framingham.

title: We Were Soldiers Once, and Broke
description: AS should be clear to anyone who reads these columns, I am fascinated by finance. I have been since I was a lad. Finance distributes risk. The smart, aggressive, tireless men and women in it allocate capital. In many ways, this efficient allocation of capital -- sometimes more efficient than others -- explains why capitalism so thoroughly trounces socialism and communism.

title: Iranian Lessons
description: [I] In south Tehran there is a huge walled cemetery dedicated to the martyrs, the young men who died fighting in the 1979 revolution and the Iran-Iraq war of 1980-1988. This vast city of the dead, complete with its own subway station and shops, does not share Arlington National Cemetery's sublimely stoic aesthetic of identical tombstones, row upon row. In Tehran's war cemetery, each of the fallen is remembered individually with his own martyr's shrine, a sealed glass cabinet on a stand. The cabinets are filled with faded photos of men forever young, some in helmets or red bandannas, some carrying their weapons, others at home stroking the family cat or grinning during a meal with friends. Next to the yellowing photographs might be a Koran, or a faded copy of a Persian poem, or a set of plastic flowers, or one of the painted eggs that Iranian families exchange at their New Year. These little shrines seem to go on forever, each one a family's attempt to confer immortality on some young man who died in the trenches at a place like Khorramshahr, the pinnacle of Iranian resistance to the Iraqi invaders.

title: Poker Is Not a Sport
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the debate in Edgemont over whether to incorporate as a village referred to the community incorrectly and omitted a village that is part of the Town of Greenburgh. Edgemont is a section of Greenburgh; it is not one of the six villages partly within the town. Elmsford, however, is one of them.

title: Which Mortgage? A Complicated Tale
description: FIXED-RATE mortgages, adjustable-rate mortgages, 30-year terms, 40-year terms, low down payments, no down payments, prepayment penalties! How is a home seeker, particularly the befuddled first-timer, supposed to wade through the current mire of mortgage offerings?

title: Bill Giving Native Hawaiians Sovereignty Is Too Much for Some, Too Little for Others
description: HONOLULU, July 15 - Hawaii is once again awash with mainlanders, as summer vacationers delight in its beaches and make themselves feel at home even on distant tropical islands. Breakfast at Starbucks, lunch at Subway, dinner at Red Lobster and a restful night at the Marriott or Hilton.

title: Stiffer A.T.V. Penalties
description: The Nassau County Legislature unanimously approved a law on Monday to increase penalties for using all-terrain vehicles on county property and to impose new ones for encroaching on county land by extending fences, yards and other improvements beyond the boundaries of adjacent private property.

title: So These Two Guys Show Up in Trenton ...
description: It was a Monday afternoon in the state capital, normally a somnolescent time of year. But there were the state's two United States senators at the State House, making pronouncements about the Supreme Court.

title: 'The Last Flight of the Flamingo': You Must Dismember This
description: THE LAST FLIGHT OF THE FLAMINGO By Mia Couto. Translated by David Brookshaw. 179 pp. Serpent's Tail. Paper, $15.

title: Texan With Bench Experience Wades Into Justice Fray
description: WASHINGTON, July 16 - It is like Congressional clockwork. Senate Democrats argue their case on judges; Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas, soon strides onto the floor and in calm and measured tones, seeks to dismantle the Democratic argument.

title: Golden Egg, Darien Style: Backyard Fresh
description: EVERY afternoon, 9-year-old Kathryn Ledwith collects eggs from the family chicken coops. But she is not the daughter of a farmer, and she does not live on a farm. She lives in Darien, in a 108-year-old Victorian house in a neighborhood that is the archetype of picture-perfect suburbia.

title: Courtney O'Donnell and Cassidy Morgan
description: Courtney Diesel O'Donnell, a daughter of Phyllis and Thomas O'Donnell of Town and Country, Mo., was married yesterday to Cassidy Stevens Morgan, a son of Maria Morgan of Spracdes, France, and the late Clay Baleri Morgan. The Rev. Reid Mayo, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Christ the King Church in Rutland, Vt.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: The best hope for closing the church-state rift in our society lies in the schools, but educators avoid religious discussion, fearing lawsuits. Instead of avoiding controversy, schools ought to develop curriculums for teaching about beliefs, without endorsing them, rather than ignoring religious discussion.

title: British Preparing Laws to Crack Down on Terror Suspects
description: LONDON, July 17 - After the shock of the London bombings, British authorities are readying new and tighter laws enabling the police to thwart suspected attacks and to silence clerics regarded as what the police call "preachers of hate."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STILLMAN, LINDA A.
description: STILLMAN--Linda A. At age 72. Devoted wife of Ronald. Loving mother of Michael, Rose and Jonathan. Beloved grandmother of Joshua, Benjamin, Leo, Harry and Ariana. Dear sister of Joan. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Lee Iacocca Foundation: Cure for Diabetes, 17 Arlington St, Boston, MA 02116 (www.joinleenow.org). Services Sunday 12:30pm at "Riverside - Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Shorts, More and Less
description: Every summer has its shorts, which flatter legs without seeming overly scant, silly or mutton-dressed-up-as-lamb. So forget the Daisy Duke hot pants and Bermudas that really only look good on giraffes. This year's winner: Club Monaco's sashed washed-cotton shorts. Available in a multitude of colors (none too bright so as not to draw too much attention to problem lumps and bumps), the shorts give the appearance of being attractively short (but not thigh stranglingly so) and bell slightly at the hem for a forgiving fit. The low-slung sash attractively frames the backside and also serves to camouflage any tummy tumult in the front. All this for $49 (at Club Monaco stores).

title: 'Until I Find You'
description: According to his mother, Jack Burns was an actor before he was an actor, but Jack's most vivid memories of childhood were those moments when he felt compelled to hold his mother's hand. He wasn't acting then.

title: Palmeiro: Born in Cuba, Raised in Miami and Third Hispanic to Hit 3,000
description: SEATTLE, July 16 - Rafael Palmeiro's baseball career reached a crossroads in 1971. He was 6 years old.

Inspectors regularly visit homes to make sure the portraits are well cared for.

title: Kitchen Voyeur: Kitchen Sage
description: There are a baby's handful of people in this city you can point to and say, "That's who folks come to New York to be" -- Mayor Mike from Boston, Bobby Short from Danville, Ill., and Kate Spade from Kansas City, to name a few. Kurt Andersen from Omaha, to name another. Andersen, 50, whose rsum is as diverse as Leonardo's, has been a literary force in town from the moment in 1976 that he stepped off the plane with a Harvard B.A. under his arm and walked into The Daily News to work as a copy boy. He lasted a day before fleeing to NBC to write radio copy for Gene Shalit. Since then, he has been the editor of and is currently a columnist at New York magazine, was a writer at The New Yorker and co-founder and editor of the notoriously punchy and nose-tweaking Spy magazine, has published one novel with a second in the wings ("Wonderstruck," due out next spring) and is currently host of "Studio 360," a weekly public radio show that recently won a Peabody.

Mad Hot Reggaeton
description: LOS ANGELES - JESSICA ESCOTO'S music is hip-hop, and on a recent Thursday she and a large group of girlfriends were celebrating the end of finals at California State University by dancing all night at a club called Ice. The scene looked like a rap music video -- young women booty-shaking, couples tightly swaying, a crowd in their late teens and 20's grinding to the same strong beat -- but this rap was in Spanish, and the beat was called reggaeton.

title: A Church-State Solution
description: As a die-hard secularist, I have long bristled at any attempt to mix religion and government, down to the "under God" in the Pledge of Allegiance. Noah Feldman's article (July 3) changed my mind about where the line should be drawn. He's right to argue that laws and money are the true tools of government, which must refrain from using them for religious ends. Symbols, on the other hand, are the stuff of free expression -- which the Constitution exists to protect, not prohibit.
