title: Shen & Vicinity
description: The Chinese-born, New York-based choreographer Shen Wei says he's dissatisfied with dancing that's just "pose, pose, pose." That dissatisfaction has driven him to develop one of the more distinctive, and difficult, dance techniques around. In his new work, "Map," commissioned by the Lincoln Center Festival (where it will have its world premiere on Tuesday night), Mr. Shen has codified his free-flowing technique, which he calls "natural body development." Using the pelvis as the body's center, it focuses on innate momentum and simple transitions prompted by shifts of weight, changes in direction and the pull of gravity. "Map," for 16 dancers, is divided into seven "maps," or movement techniques, and takes its pulse from the multilayered rhythms of Steve Reich's score, "The Desert Music." Usually one dancer introduces the theme of a map, which builds to a crescendo as the other dancers hook in; the results range from poetic to whimsical. Joseph Carman attended a recent rehearsal of "Map" by Mr. Shen's company, Shen Wei Dance Arts, and compiled this glossary of his technique as illustrated by the work's seven sections:

title: The Framing Wars
description: After last November's defeat, Democrats were like aviation investigators sifting through twisted metal in a cornfield, struggling to posit theories about the disaster all around them. Some put the onus on John Kerry, saying he had never found an easily discernable message. Others, including Kerry himself, wrote off the defeat to the unshakable realities of wartime, when voters were supposedly less inclined to jettison a sitting president. Liberal activists blamed mushy centrists. Mushy centrists blamed Michael Moore. As the weeks passed, however, at Washington dinner parties and in public post-mortems, one explanation took hold not just among Washington insiders but among far-flung contributors, activists and bloggers too: the problem wasn't the substance of the party's agenda or its messenger as much as it was the Democrats' inability to communicate coherently. They had allowed Republicans to control the language of the debate, and that had been their undoing.

ANDREWS, Scotland, July 17 - He spent his last hour on the Old Course at St. Andrews with a gentle breeze at his back, carrying him past yellow wisps of grass that swayed beneath gathering clouds. His pursuers had vanished from the fight, leaving Tiger Woods alone to stride brown footpaths toward the claret jug he had been waiting all week to claim.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Fatal Stabbing In Street Fight
description: One man was killed and two were seriously injured early Saturday after a fight in Willowbrook. The dispute began about 2:30 a.m. at Port Richmond Avenue and Forest Street. For unknown reasons, the police said, Moses Boyd, 18, of 18 Albert Court, stabbed a 17-year-old several times in the neck. The victim, whose name was not released, was taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Staten Island, where he was pronounced dead. Two other men, who were stabbed, were also taken to St. Vincent's, where one was in critical condition and the other was in stable condition, the police said yesterday. Mr. Boyd was charged with murder, assault and weapons possession, the police said. A second man, Javon Ivory, 21, of 175 Trantor Place, was charged with attempted murder and weapons possession, the police said. The investigation continued yesterday. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on July 1 about the crash of a small plane into a Hudson River inlet referred incorrectly to the pilot's escape from the plane, a Cirrus SR-22, which has a built-in parachute. He pulled the cord for the plane's parachute, and he and the plane went down together; he did not parachute out of the plane. (Go to Article)

title: As China Raises Its Arts Profile, Officials Try to Catch Up
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 - Zhou Ping joined the Shanghai Symphony Orchestra five years ago as a librarian, cataloging its scores and recordings. A sharp, plain-spoken former music major, she was promoted last August to performance and promotions manager. With a nine-person staff and no management experience, Ms. Zhou, 30, suddenly found herself with a mandate to raise the 126-year-old orchestra's public profile -- and by extension, its profits.

He is a clear-thinking player, theorist and writer who is also a renowned backgammon expert and author. In bridge he has three world titles: the Rosenblum Cup in 1986 and the Senior Teams in 2000 and 2003. He has won two world championship silver medals and many national titles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GISSEN, BENJAMIN
description: GISSEN--Benjamin. Of Tamarac, FL, and formerly of Mount Vernon, NY, on July 15, 2005, pre-deceased by wife, Bernice. Loving and devoted husband of Hilda. Cherished father of Dr. Rhona Stanley of New York, Malcolm Gissen of San Francisco and Philip Gissen of Milwaukee. Dearest grandfather of Dr. Starfinder Stanley of Oakland and Brittany Barnes of Milwaukee. Beloved fatherin-law to Judith Cohen Gissen of San Francisco and Donna Gissen of Milwaukee. Loving uncle to Bernard (Barbara) Gissen, Matthew (Valera) Gissen, Rochelle (Thomas) Krause, Gary (Joan) Goldberg, Phyllis (Martin) Van Dyne, Sandy Wolstein, and Philip (Melanie) Elphand, and loved by a host of relatives, friends and colleagues. Son of Louis and Sarah Nitzberg Gissen, "Doc" graduated from the NYU Dental School and practiced dentistry and orthodontics in the Bronx for 58 years. He was a founding member of the prestigious NewConn Orthodontic Study Club and on staff at Harlem Hospital and Mount Sinai. He was devoted to his extended family and was cherished by all who knew him for his caring and loving nature and ever-bright and optimistic view of life. Ben was the patriarch of the Nitzberg family and esteemed Editor of the Nitzberg Family Newsletter. He was in regular contact with hundreds of cousins around the world, always keeping the family together. We will always remember and so dearly miss his passion for life, his generosity of spirit, his concern for others and his limitless love for family. If you wish, please give to a charity of your choice in his memory. Funeral service Wednesday, July 20, 10:30 am, at Star of David in Tamarac, FL.

Arts, Briefly; Another Sweet Weekend
description: A master of eccentricity sweetened the box office this weekend and buoyed hopes for a repeat of last weekend's reversal of the steady decline in admissions. "Charlie and the Chocolate Factory" (Warner Brothers), starring Johnny Depp, right, as Willy Wonka, opened strongly at No. 1 with $55.4 million in three-day ticket sales, according to the box-office monitor Exhibitor Relations. It is the biggest opening ever for Mr. Depp ("Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl," in 2003, was the other) and his fourth collaboration with Tim Burton (the fifth, "Corpse Bride," is scheduled for release this fall). It is also the largest July opening in Warner Brothers history, surpassing "Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines," which opened with $44 million in 2003. The R-rated comedy "Wedding Crashers" (New Line), starring Owen Wilson and Vince Vaughn as divorce mediators who prey on bridesmaids, also had a strong opening; it was No. 2 with $32.2 million in estimated receipts. "The Fantastic Four" (Fox), which pulled the box office out of its 19-week slump with a $56.1 million, No. 1 opening last weekend, dropped to No. 3 with $22.8 million in receipts. There was a sharp drop for the holdovers rounding out the top five: "War of the Worlds" (Paramount) was at No. 4 with $15 million, and "Batman Begins" (Warner Brothers) was No. 5 with $5.6 million. CATHERINE BILLEY

title: America's Truth Deficit
description: Washington - DURING the cold war, as the Soviet economic system slowly unraveled, internal reform was impossible because highly placed officials who recognized the systemic disorders could not talk about them honestly. The United States is now in an equivalent predicament. Its weakening position in the global trading system is obvious and ominous, yet leaders in politics, business, finance and the news media are not willing to discuss candidly what is happening and why. Instead, they recycle the usual bromides about the benefits of free trade and assurances that everything will work out for the best.

title: A flurry of suicide bombings shakes Iraq
Pillow-Talk Pressure for a Woman in O'Connor's Robe
description: WASHINGTON - When Laura Bush said in a television interview last week that she hoped her husband would name a woman to succeed Justice Sandra Day O'Connor on the Supreme Court, a lot of people saw it as a top item on the first lady's "honey-do" list. But Republicans close to the White House said that people had it reversed. Mrs. Bush, they said, was not so much nudging her husband as reflecting his thinking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARNETT, BERNARD
description: BARNETT--Bernard. Died of cardio-respiratory failure on July 2nd in Sleepy Hollow, New York, at the age of 84. He graduated magna cum laude from CCNY in 1941 with a degree in accounting. He was with Apfel & Englander from 1941-1969, becoming a senior partner; with Seidman & Seidman from 1970-1986, where he was national director of tax practice; and he served as a senior consultant with BDO Seidman from 1987 to his death. An expert in estate planning, he served as president of the New York State Society of CPAs from 1976-7 and chaired several AICPA task forces on estate taxation, was a frequent speaker and writer on tax law and estate planning, and was a champion of estate tax reforms. He was born October 14, 1920, in New York City, minutes ahead of his twin Stanley. As a youth he sold concessions at Yankee Stadium and the Polo Grounds (on those days when a Mr. Goldstein chose the vendors; on other days the Irish kids got the nod); Bernard was sad to report that many of those Babe Ruth signatures from the Babe's 1938 return to the Polo Grounds as a Brooklyn Dodger coach were actually signed by fellow Dodger coaches Jesse Haines and Andy High. Among his early clients as a CPA were several artists and writers who worked at The New Yorker; without betraying confidences, we can report that A.J. Liebling's remuneration did not keep pace with his gustatory appetites. Bernard twice served in the armed forces. In his first stint, from 1942-1946, he served as a finance officer with the Army, stationed most memorably in England; he rose to the rank of Captain. He served from 1951-1952 as a Major in the Air Force, based in New York City, where he audited military contracts. He was a lifelong traveler; he and his wife visited every continent (including Antarctica); thanks to his accounting nature we know that they took thirty-five cruises on twenty-three different ships (including a dugout canoe) between 1963 and 2000. He beat polio as a teenager and was a three-time cancer survivor, a testament to his determination. He was predeceased by his son, Douglas, in 1960, and his twin, Stanley, in 2004. His survivors--his wife of 53 years, Helen, of Sleepy Hollow; his daughter, Susan, of Roscoe, New York; his brother, Joseph, of Culver City, California, and nieces and nephews all over--will miss his humor and elan. There will be a memorial service in New York City at a later date.

title: Remembering Gilbert, Residents of Yucatn Brace for Emily

description: Life has not always been kind to Suzanne Somers, the ex-sitcom star and perky pitchwoman who has brought her new solo show, "The Blonde in the Thunderbird," to the Brooks Atkinson Theater on Broadway for a limited run.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Cinemax) GARDEN STATE (2004). -- Zach Braff's quirky comedy is about a struggling young actor-waiter who goes home to New Jersey for his mother's funeral and leaves his antidepressants back in Los Angeles. With formerly smoothed-out emotions popping up everywhere, Mr. Braff's character, Andrew Largeman, meets a manic young woman (Natalie Portman, above, with Mr. Braff) and sheds a tear for the first time in ages.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Monk' Returns, 'Hamptons' Kills
description: The fourth-season premiere of USA Network's "Monk" on July 8 brought in the series's largest audience ever with an estimated 6.38 million viewers, according to Nielsen Media Research. The episode, in which Jason Alexander, in a guest role, plays the grubby opposite of the obsessive-compulsive detective Adrian Monk (Tony Shalhoub), was also the most-watched cable show in total viewers for the week that ended July 10. Last Monday, Lifetime's movie "Murder in the Hamptons," a fictional account of the sensational 2001 murder of Ted Ammon rendered as the film equivalent of a beach-read, drew an estimated 4.8 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: White House Letter:An inner-circle tilt for a female nominee
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Body Found In Apartment
description: The city medical examiner will determine the cause of death for a 75-year-old Manhattan man whose body was found in his apartment on Saturday, the police said. Officers found the man, Juan Crespo, after tenants at 173 Henry Street complained of a foul odor coming from his apartment. Investigators said yesterday that the condition of his body made it impossible to immediately determine the cause of death. Thomas J. Lueck (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHERR, WILLIAM CHARLES
description: SHERR--William Charles. 80, beloved husband of Miriam Sherr for 51 years, and loving brother to Jessie Wallerich and Nettie Kitzes, died on July 15, 2005 in Phoenix, AZ. Mr. Sherr graduated from the University of Wisconsin and received his Law Degree from Fordham University in 1949. He also served honorably as an Ensign and later promoted to Lieutenant J.G. during WW II in the Pacific. During the 1950's in the US Navy through the 1980's, Mr. Sherr practiced law in NYC--helping hundreds of clients with his brilliant legal mind, and his great compassion. He also served as President of the Board of his Sutton Place condominium complex. Retiring in 1981, Mr. Sherr moved to Paradise Valley, AZ, where he was an active member of his community and President of the Board of the Marquesa Condominium. Other survivors include his five nieces and one nephew who live in Phoenix, New York, Washington, DC, and Israel, along with numerous grand nieces and grand nephews. Memorial services will be held at Riverside Chapel in Manhattan on Monday, July 18th, at 11:30 am, and burial will follow at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY.

description: GENSER--Ruth and Sid. Happy 57th. Thank you for watching over me always. Miss you more than you'd believe. Love, Barbara

title: Saving Oneidas' Language, One Long Word at a Time
description: ONEIDA, N.Y. - In 1999, Marion Johns was near death.

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Advertisement Parodies
description: From Pogue's Inbox: "David, I saw the iPod flea video by Scott Kelby you posted on nytimes.com, and thought you might enjoy the iPod spoof my sketch comedy troupe produced earlier this year."

title: The Passion of the Marketers
description: LOS ANGELES, July 17 - In the summer blockbuster movie "Mr. and Mrs. Smith," from 20th Century Fox, Brad Pitt and Angelina Jolie play godless suburbanites and professional assassins. But when they steal their neighbor's car for an extended chase scene, a crucifix hangs conspicuously from the rearview mirror, and in the next scene the actors wear borrowed jackets that read "Jesus Rocks," as they go on the lam.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Pulled From Water
description: A 33-year-old man was in stable condition at Coney Island Hospital last night after being pulled from the water off Coney Island by a passer-by who noticed him flailing, the police said. The victim, Reuben Delgada Garcia, was in the water near Stillwell Avenue when the passer-by, Gary Heath, saw him struggling shortly before 6:30 p.m., the police said. Witnesses who saw Mr. Heath pull Mr. Garcia from the water said Mr. Garcia had appeared to be having trouble breathing. "The hero brought him to shore," said Miguel Ramirez, 28, a waiter from Chicago who is on vacation in New York with his girlfriend and nephew. "We thought he was dying, then we saw him breathing." Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Resurgent Couples Falls Just Short
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 17 - After finishing his final round in the tournament he craves, Fred Couples waited for the last groups to walk up the 18th fairway, knowing he had a chance to win his second major championship.

title: Knees, Elbows and Faces Conceal the Beating of Hearts
description: An artichoke is a thorny vegetable with a delectable heart. But there was no such essence in place at the Joyce SoHo, where Artichoke Dance Company, directed by Lynn Neuman, performed Friday night. Instead, the choreography meandered through layers of acrobatic vignettes with little focus.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "It's like a honey pot. It truly is."

title: Armed With Right Cellphone, Anyone Can Be a Journalist
description: Got a cellphone camera? You, too, can be a television journalist. The news staff of WABC-TV, the ABC affiliate in New York, started soliciting cellphone pictures and amateur video last week from people who witness a news event.

title: Filmmaker Who Depicts the Village as It Used to Be
description: When Karen Kramer last talked to The New York Times about her film "The Ballad of Greenwich Village," she said she felt pressed for money and time. Especially time. She had been working on her opus about Village history and lore for six years and was worried that much of what she wanted to record was going to disappear before she could memorialize it on film.

title: Large Volume of F.B.I. Files Alarms U.S. Activist Groups
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 - The Federal Bureau of Investigation has collected at least 3,500 pages of internal documents in the last several years on a handful of civil rights and antiwar protest groups in what the groups charge is an attempt to stifle political opposition to the Bush administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORRIS, NORMAN DAVID
description: MORRIS -- Norman David. July 15, age 94. Devoted husband of the late Sylvia, with whom he shared 65 wonderful years. Beloved father of Barbara (Kuperman) and Fredric and father-in-law of Leonard and Marcia. Cherished by his North American and South American grandchildren. Loving brother-inlaw of Emil and Rima Kustin. Norman's full life was enriched by love shared with Terry in his last years. His affection, loyalty, quick mind and jovial spirit will be missed and always remembered.

title: New York Medicaid Fraud May Reach Into Billions
description: It was created 40 years ago to provide health care for the poorest New Yorkers, offering a lifeline to those who could not afford to have a baby or a heart attack. But in the decades since, New York State's Medicaid program has also become a $44.5 billion target for the unscrupulous and the opportunistic.

title: New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: Magazine Deal Puts Publisher in Spotlight
description: TWO strivers came together in a room in July of 2003. One was a former bodybuilder turned actor who wanted to be king, at least of California, and the other was a former C.P.A. who has refashioned himself into a media mogul who hoped to take his company public. Each had something the other wanted, although it could be argued that David Pecker, the chief executive of American Media, needed Arnold Schwarzenegger more.

title: Storm aims for Mexican tourist site
Paid Notice: Memorials   FEINSTEIN, GARY ''STRANNY.''
description: FEINSTEIN--Gary "Stranny." It's been three long years and you are ever part of our worlds. Not a day passes that we don't remember our lives together. Never forgotten..."with you." Mickey, Shmoozy & The Bear

title: A Time for Blockbusters and for the Guys to Shine
description: Fall is for dances; spring is for dancers. That's one bit of conventional wisdom about American Ballet Theater's fall season at the City Center and its spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Another is that while the company's female principals and soloists may be of variable quality, its males are sterling.

title: Thank You, Grandma and Grandpa
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Students Instead of Banks
description: The higher education lobby has rightly criticized Congress for failing to pay for student aid programs at a level that comes anywhere near meeting the national need. But some of those same lobbyists and the universities they represent have opposed a beneficial bill that could potentially produce billions of dollars in new student aid, basically because the banking industry, which dominates the student loan business, dislikes the measure.

title: After a Week's Vacation, Martnez Has an Easy Day at Work
description: Pedro Martnez was working with a week's rest and had thrown only 61 pitches when he left yesterday's game in the sixth inning while holding a six-run lead over the Atlanta Braves.

title: New CD's
description: Already Platinum Slim Thug

title: Signature Issue: How Many Did You Get?
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner went on the offensive against City Council Speaker Gifford Miller -- one of his three main rivals in New York's Democratic mayoral primary -- at a candidates' forum last week, accusing the speaker of not being tough enough with the Bloomberg administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, LOLA
description: KRAMER--Lola. 94, of Palm Beach, FL, and Harrison, NY. Beloved wife of 73 years to Saul. I loved you greatly for all these years, goodbye darling.

title: Thank You, Grandma and Grandpa
description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis mass tanks on border of Gaza
Team Chosen for Project to Develop Transit Hub
description: The Pataki administration plans to announce today that it has selected a development team to transform the general post office in Midtown Manhattan into a dramatic new $930 million transit hub, a long-awaited project that proponents say will be a catalyst for development and an opportunity for civic redemption.

title: Whose Oil Is It? Property Rights at Issue in China
description: JINGBIAN, China - As a truck driver hauling crude from private wells sprouting up all over this arid countryside, Gao had a bird's-eye view of the oil boom that was sweeping this county in the 1990's. After years of hesitation, he did what tens of thousands of other folks were doing: collected his savings and contributions from every friend and relative he could, and drilled a well.

title: German Court Refuses to Extradite Terror Suspect to Spain
description: BERLIN, July 18 - In a ruling seen as a sharp blow to coordinated counterterrorism efforts in Europe, Germany's highest court today refused to turn over a terrorist suspect to Spain, arguing that a recent European agreement to streamline extradition procedures violated the rights of German citizens.

title: In Class, Still Together After All These Years (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSEN, MICHAEL
description: ROSEN--Michael. July 18, 1980. A special man lovingly remembered always. Your Family

title: The Bitter and Sweet of Fame
description: "Sweet Songs of the Soul" had a limited run in Manhattan in the spring. Following are excerpts from Anita Gates's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 6, 2005; the full text is online at nytimes.com/theater. The show, which runs through July 30, is playing at the Harry de Jur Playhouse at 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side, (212)279-4200.

TRANSACTIONS
description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: A Disputed Verdict, an Undisputed Title
description: LAS VEGAS, July 17 - Jermain Taylor had just won a split decision Saturday night over Bernard Hopkins to become the undisputed middleweight champion, but he sounded almost apologetic for his effort.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in Business Day on Saturday with the Joseph Nocera column was supplied by The Associated Press with an erroneous label and published in error. It showed Sam M. Antar, the father of Eddie Antar, founder of the Crazy Eddie electronics chain -- not Sam E. Antar, the company's former chief financial officer and a cousin of Eddie.

title: Rain Causes Flooding in Parts of New Jersey
description: Rainfall inundated Middlesex County, New Jersey, with as much as 10 inches of rain yesterday, triggering flash flooding, evacuations and road closures in some towns, an emergency official said.

title: Thank You, Grandma and Grandpa
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEARA, CHARLES E.
description: MEARA--Charles E. Deceased on July 15; former CEO of NY Criminal Courts; veteran US Navy WWII. Father of six children; grandfather of eight. Private ceremony Monday. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to St. Mary's Hospital for Children, 2901 216 Street, Bayside, NY 11361.

title: What Motivates Suicide Bombers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Development Could Tame a Land Forever Wild
description: TUXEDO, N.Y., July 17 - "Today's historic announcement will forever preserve Sterling Forest," New York Gov. George E. Pataki said seven years ago when he -- along with Christine Todd Whitman, then the governor of New Jersey -- proudly proclaimed the land deal that transformed a vast region of woodlands, rugged ridges and crystal streams into one of the largest state parks in New York.

A New Magazine for Aficionados of 'Chicken Soup for the Soul'
description: The "Chicken Soup for the Soul" brand, which started with the highly successful series of inspirational books, has generated North American sales of $1.3 billion since 1993, spawning greeting cards, pet food and a syndicated radio program. So why not a magazine?

title: Heavy Israeli Armor Presses Gaza Border
description: Correction Appended

title: An Empty Apology
description: One of President Bush's surrogates went before the N.A.A.C.P. last week and apologized for the Republican Party's reprehensible, decades-long Southern strategy.

title: Serb gets 40 years in ex-leader's death
News analysis:Political maturity remains elusive in Philippines
Gordon Feels It All Slipping Away
description: LOUDON, N.H., July 17 - A light rain sprinkled on Jeff Gordon's crew members as they glumly loaded his broken car onto its hauler Sunday afternoon. Misfortune had walloped Gordon again, and it may be too late for even him to do something about it.

title: When Writing an Irate Letter to the Editor Is Just Not Enough
description: Convention dictates that when newspaper readers question the accuracy of an article, they ask for a correction or write a letter to the editor. But when the conservative pollster and political consultant Frank Luntz had a complaint with The Forward, the venerable New York newspaper of Jewish culture, he took a different approach.

title: Report Names Abusers in Afghan Wars
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 17 - The first report to cover human rights abuses committed over the full two and a half decades of war in Afghanistan was released here on Sunday, identifying militia leaders responsible for some of the worst atrocities since 1978; many are candidates in the national elections scheduled for Sept. 18.

title: What Motivates Suicide Bombers?
description: To the Editor:

title: Thousands of Israelis Stage Rally Against Gaza Withdrawal
description: NETIVOT, Israel, July 18 - Some 30,000 right-wing Israeli protesters, many clad in orange, staged a boisterous rally in southern Israel this evening against the planned withdrawal of Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip. But police and soldiers, who were present in only slightly smaller numbers, blocked their route to the coastal territory.

title: Martha Stewart's Next Big Project: Justifying Her Investors' Expectations
description: By attempting a corporate comeback while still serving out her felony sentence, Martha Stewart is in uncharted territory. And so, it appears, is her company's stock.

title: To Scouts, Wood Bat Tournaments Are True Test for Prospects
description: MARIETTA, Ga., July 16 - As Justin Smoak stood in the on-deck circle, it was easy to see why he could be in a major league uniform in a few years. Smoak, an 18-year-old from Goose Creek, S.C., is a muscular 6 feet 4 inches and 195 pounds, and with a few practice swings, there was evidence of sound mechanics and potential.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about General Electric's international sales efforts misstated the company's 2001 earnings. They were $13.684 billion, not $30 billion.

title: Leiter Proves to Be Just the Pitcher the Yanks Needed
description: BOSTON, July 17 - Al Leiter's buddy Bruce Springsteen sang about an aging pitcher whose glory days passed him by in the wink of a young girl's eye. These days, it seemed, that pitcher was Leiter.

title: For a British Novelist, a Fictional Plot Jarringly Leads to a Real-Life Problem
description: FOR Chris Cleave, a British writer, the date stamp "7/7" will forever mark the bizarre convergence of two events: the deadly terrorist attack in London two weeks ago and the debut of his first novel, "Incendiary" -- a story of despair and recovery in the wake of, yes, a deadly terrorist attack in London.

title: Description of Sheffield Falls Short at Fenway
description: BOSTON, July 17 - Gary Sheffield is fearless. Gary Sheffield is scary. Gary Sheffield is focused. Gary Sheffield is superb. Those are the types of words that spill out of Manager Joe Torre's mouth in describing Sheffield.

title: The Netherlands: Tolerating a time bomb
Official Says Turkish Blast Was Not by Suicide Bomber
description: ISTANBUL, July 17 - The explosion that killed 5 people and wounded 13 on Saturday in the Turkish resort town of Kusadasi was set off by a timer or remote control, not a suicide bomber, a regional government official said Sunday.

title: Blair Angry Over Report Faulting Terror Policies
description: LONDON, July 18 - The government reacted sharply today to a private research report saying that Britain was particularly exposed to terrorist attack because of its role in Iraq as an ally of American policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUTMAN, CRAIG
description: RUTMAN--Craig. The students, faculty, and staff of Monroe College have lost a very special person, a true leader and teacher who everyone admired. As Chair of the Culinary Arts Program, he loved what he did, most of all working with and seeing the success of his students. He will be missed by all of us. Our deepest sympathies to his widow, Cindy, and daughter, Brooke. Stephen J. Jerome, President, Monroe College

title: Other Views: The Australian, Daily Telegraph, Christian Science Monitor
LOOKING AHEAD
description: BANKS AND BLUE -- I.B.M., Bank of America and Citigroup kick off a week of major corporate earnings reports. (Monday.)

title: Indonesia and Separatists Reach Deal to End 30 Years of Fighting
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 17 - The Indonesian government and separatists from the tsunami-devastated province of Aceh, meeting in Helsinki, Finland, agreed Sunday to end a 30-year conflict, one of the longest in Southeast Asia, which has killed some 15,000 people.

title: At Cornell, a Push to End Stalemate Over Parking Lot
description: ITHACA, N.Y., July 17 - The battle over turning Cornell University's Redbud Woods into a parking lot moved closer to a showdown this weekend with protesters tethered to trees and chained to pipes in the ground and the administration declaring them trespassers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAWSON, GEORGE. M.
description: LAWSON--George. M. On July 14, 2005 at age 94. Longtime domestic partner of Elliot Rabner. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. Thursday, July 21st 3:30 PM. Interment private.

title: A Teenage Golfer May Also Be a Marketer's Dream
description: Michelle Wie came in 23rd at the United States Women's Open last month, behind other personable young golfers -- the winner, Birdie Kim, 23, and Brittany Lang, 19, and Morgan Pressel, 17, who tied for second place. Ms. Wie failed to survive elimination in the P.G.A. Tour's John Deere Classic this month and fell short in her attempt to qualify for the Masters tournament next year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KERR, RICHARD J. JR.
description: KERR--Richard J. Jr. Memorial Mass, 6 pm, Wednesday, Epiphany Church, 22nd Street at 2nd Ave, NYC.

title: Two G.O.P. Lawmakers Spar Over Climate Study
description: A public dispute has flared between two Republican House committee chairmen over an inquiry one of them began last month into the integrity of an influential study of global temperature trends.

title: Investigators Are Clear Who Carried Bombs, but Have Far to Go to Explain More
description: LONDON, July 17 - Now that Scotland Yard has publicly identified the four men believed to have carried out the July 7 terrorist attacks here, investigators have embarked on a far more difficult phase of the inquiry, one that officials concede could take months or even years to complete.

title: An Aeschylus Antiwar Play Adapted in Reality TV Style
description: Although "The Persians," by Aeschylus, is the oldest surviving play in the Western canon, in this free adaptation by a young company called Waterwell it feels as though it were still being created. It's as implausibly funny and entertaining as promised by its subtitle, "a comedy about war with five songs," alive enough to surprise even the performers themselves.

title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince
Mining the Drama in a Rock Catalog
description: LONDON - Rock's conquest of the West End here, and of Broadway, has arrived largely in the form of unchallenging oldies: familiar songs that mimic the recorded hits and are attached to revue vignettes or a cobbled-together storyline. Queen, Abba and Billy Joel are among those whose songs have found that kind of afterlife, and a John Lennon musical on Broadway is now in previews.

title: Edward Heath, Former British Leader and Advocate of European Unity, Dies at 89
description: Correction Appended

title: Flaw in 'No Child' Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about a letter from the National Transportation Safety Board complaining about the slow pace of an aviation rule change intended to prevent explosions like the one off Long Island in 1996 misspelled the surname of the safety board's acting chairman. He is Mark Rosenker, not Rosenkur. The article also misstated the date of the letter. It was Tuesday, not Wednesday.

title: Marrying Maps to Data for a New Web Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 - In 1991, David Gelernter, a computer scientist at Yale, proposed using software to create a computer simulation of the physical world, making it possible to map everything from traffic flow and building layouts to sales and currency data on a computer screen.

title: Typhoon Haitang lashes northeastern Taiwan
On the Loose in Badlands: Killer With a Cattle Gun
description: No Country for Old Men By Cormac McCarthy 309 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95

title: The VW Scandal: Perspective Wanted
description: Volkswagen has supplied Germany with an unusually juicy summer scandal, involving prostitutes, foreign junkets, bribery and one of Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's major political allies. The whole affair is small potatoes compared with the other problems VW faces in sales, quality and foreign ventures. Its significance is that it has focused attention on one of the most hallowed institutions of German industry, "co-determination," under which companies with more than 2,000 employees are required to give at least half the seats on their supervisory boards to representatives of the workers.

title: If Harry Potter Vanishes, What's Next for British Publisher?
description: PARIS, July 17 - This is the magical summer season when Hogwarts students loll on vacation and Bloomsbury Publishing's chief executive, Nigel Newton, hunkers down in his 18th-century Soho Square offices in London to monitor sales of the sixth installment of the Harry Potter epic.

title: On Advertising:On the scent of a battle on smoking
Brown and Pistons Appear Close to Buyout Deal
description: The Detroit Pistons moved closer to separating from their head coach Larry Brown today as he intends to accept a buyout of his contract, according to a person in the N.B.A. briefed on the negotiations.

title: Three London Bombing Suspects Visited Pakistan Last Year
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 18 - Pakistan government officials confirmed today that three of the four London bombing suspects visited this country last year. Two of them arrived together and stayed for three months.

title: Iraq Is Set to Have Its Own News Service
description: Iraqi journalists are getting the chance to shop their rsums.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Iranian arrests of people accused as part of a terrorist cell gave an erroneous title in some copies for Ali Younessi, who reported them. He is the intelligence minister, not the information minister.

title: German court blocks extradition of Qaeda suspect
You'll Laugh. You'll Cry. You'll Look Puzzled.
description: You'll be hearing a lot of vile, filthy and disgusting things about a movie called "The Aristocrats" in the coming weeks, because most of it is vile, filthy and disgusting. Though not in a bad way, exactly.

title: Modern Opera Shines in Mozartland
description: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, July 15 - Patrice Chreau is one of a handful of stage directors whose name is automatically attached to the work he is directing. Thus, a landmark Wagner production at the 1976 Bayreuth Festival is remembered as Patrice Chreau's "Ring" cycle. And again, before this month's Aix-en-Provence Festival, the buzz centered on Mr. Chreau's "Cos Fan Tutte," his first venture into opera in 11 years.

title: Strong Ties Bind Players in Battle for Seat on Court
description: WASHINGTON, July 17 - Judge J. Michael Luttig of the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., one of the handful of people seen as uppermost on President Bush's list to fill a Supreme Court vacancy, stood nine years ago as a groomsman at the wedding of another assumed to be on that same short list, Judge John G. Roberts of the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit, who once clerked for Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist.

title: A Remorseless Rudolph Gets Life Sentence for Bombing at Clinic
description: Eric Rudolph, who has confessed to the Atlanta Olympics bombing and three other explosions that killed two and injured 150, received two life sentences today for a fatal abortion clinic blast after angrily denouncing abortion and telling the federal court that "deadly force is needed to stop it."

title: Indonesia settleswith Aceh rebels
A Democratic Group Endorses Bloomberg
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg crossed party lines yesterday to receive his first campaign endorsement from a Democratic organization, and he did it in the backyard of the leading Democrat in the race, Fernando Ferrer.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HABER, BERNARD H.
description: HABER--Bernard H. Beloved companion of Lila Probstein. Dear brother of Ruth Adelson. Graveside service Monday, 11 am, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Contributions to Calvary Hospital, Bronx, NY. For information, "Gutterman-Musiciant," 800522-0588.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MERMELSTEIN, FLORA BOCKIAN
description: MERMELSTEIN -- Flora Bockian. 95, died at home in New York, Friday, July 15. She was preceded in death by her husband Martin Mermelstein. She is survived by daughters Barbara Haskel, Rhoda (Noah) Berley and Sara-Jane (William) Cohen, six grandchildren, and six greatgrandchildren. Funeral Monday, July 18, 10 am, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave at 91st St. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Zornberg-Carmel Group of Hadassah, 25 W. 45th St, NYC 10036.

title: News Corp. to Acquire Owner of MySpace.com
description: The News Corporation, making one of its largest bets on the Internet, announced today that it is paying $580 million in cash to acquire Intermix Media Inc., a Los Angeles-based company whose chief asset is MySpace.com, a Web site that is enjoying surging popularity with young audiences.

title: The Dropout Puzzle
description: Many seemingly authoritative figures, not all of them partisan shills, say that the American economy has fully recovered from the recession that began in 2001. They point to the unemployment rate, which has fallen from a peak of 6.3 percent in 2003 to 5 percent last month. That's not quite as low as the 4.2 percent unemployment rate in February 2001, when the recession began, but it's fairly low by historical standards.

title: Medical Claims From 9/11 Are Assigned to Single Court
description: Thousands of lawsuits alleging respiratory injuries by firefighters, police officers and other workers in cleaning up the contaminated debris of the World Trade Center after the Sept. 11 terrorist attack will all be tried in Federal District Court in Manhattan, a federal appeals court in New York has ruled.

title: Iraqi Boy's Journey to Erase the Scars of War
description: Correction Appended

title: The Bolshoi Returns, With Familiar Characters and Footwork
description: Like some mighty machine, clanking and groaning, the Bolshoi Ballet lumbered into the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday night, its first visit in 18 years to the home it used to the haunt, at the old Met and the new, from 1959 through the 1970's.

title: Signature Issue: How Many Did You Get?
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner went on the offensive against City Council Speaker Gifford Miller - one of his three main rivals in New York's Democratic mayoral primary - at a candidates' forum last week, accusing the speaker of not being tough enough with the Bloomberg administration.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZINGMAN, BARBARA GOLD
description: ZINGMAN--Barbara Gold. On July 15. Beloved wife of Edgar. Mother of Aileen, Margaret and Jonathan. Grandmother of seven. Sister of Bette Rosen and Arthur Gold. Mother-in-law of Fred and Ann. We will always hold her close to our hearts and never forget how her laughter and words carried us through hard times. These words are with us now. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, NYC 10021. Service Monday, July 18, at 11:30 am, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at East 81 St; 212-288-3500.

title: Hurricane Emily lashes Mexico's Yucatan peninsula
Abbas Criticizes Hamas for Breaking Truce
description: GAZA CITY, Gaza, July 18 - The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, sharply criticized the radical Hamas faction today for breaking the truce with Israel that all Palestinian groups had agreed upon and for allowing Israel to take advantage of Palestinian internal strife.

title: Tour's Pedal Pals: Stage to Hincapie; Armstrong Rolls On
description: ST.-LARY-SOULAN, France, July 17 - In a day of triumph for the Discovery Channel team, Lance Armstrong solidified his hold on the lead of the Tour de France and, in a surprise, his teammate George Hincapie won the stage through six daunting climbs in the Pyrenees on Sunday.

title: EU turns its attention and resources to East
What Motivates Suicide Bombers? (3 Letters)

title: Credit Card Ads Place Renewed Focus on Security
description: WHEN Visa USA learned last month that a data breach had put the personal information of millions of its customers at risk for theft, the company's top executives huddled to come up with a plan for responding to the inevitable concerns. A public relations team sought to reassure consumers. Marketing managers looked for a way to address in Visa's advertising its cardholder security fears, which a phone poll showed were at all-time highs.

title: The Bitter and Sweet of Fame
description: "Sweet Songs of the Soul" had a limited run in Manhattan in the spring. Following are excerpts from Anita Gates's review, which appeared in The New York Times on April 6, 2005; the full text is online at nytimes.com/theater. The show, which runs through July 30, is playing at the Harry de Jur Playhouse at 466 Grand Street, Lower East Side, (212)279-4200.

title: British Seek New Laws to Confront Terror
description: LONDON, July 17 - After the shock of the London bombings, British authorities are readying new laws that would give the police stronger powers to try to pre-empt terror attacks and to silence clerics regarded as what the police call "preachers of hate."

title: New Muslim at 15, Terror Suspect at 19
description: LONDON, July 17 - When Germaine Lindsay, the 19-year-old man suspected of blowing up a subway train at Russell Square, took hold of Islam four years ago, he did so zealously, his friends say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TOCCI, DR. LEONARD J.
description: TOCCI--Dr. Leonard J. Age 80, of Newton, MA, July 17, 2005. Devoted spouse of the late A. Lee (Tocci). Proud father of: Paula Tocci of Tuxedo Park, NY, Leonard J. Tocci III and spouse Elaine of Waban, MA, Dr. Jeffrey W. Tocci and spouse Frances of Weston, MA, Philip D. Tocci and spouse Cindy of Hamilton, MA. For information: A.J. Magni & Son F.H., Newton, MA. Services pending.

Paid Notice: Deaths   PLUNKETT, DONALD JAMES
description: PLUNKETT--Donald James. Of Larchmont, NY, on July 15, 2005. Beloved husband of Mary Elizabeth (Liz) Plunkett (nee Wetherby). Loving father of Hilary Plunkett Jones, Chrisotpher Wetherby Plunkett, Elizabeth Ellen Mastoloni and Emily Plunkett Fleischer. Father-in-law of Francis John Mastoloni and Scott Andrew Fleischer. Adoring grandfather of Patrick Christopher Jones, James Francis Mastoloni, Emily Ann Mastoloni and Lauren Ellen Mastoloni. Visiting Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 pm, at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY. Mass Wednesday, 11 am, at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. In lieu of flowers, donations to the charity of your choice is appreciated.

title: Governors Endorse a Standard Formula for Graduation Rates
description: DES MOINES, July 17 - Governors from 45 states agreed Sunday to adopt a common formula to calculate high school graduation rates, an initiative intended to help policy makers more accurately measure student success and identify academic programs that need improving.

title: Yanks' Roster Resembles a Rubik's Cube in Motion
description: BOSTON, July 17 - The Yankees started the season with a roster so inflexible that they were virtually locked into it. They have given up on some players -- Steve Karsay, Mike Stanton, Paul Quantrill -- and others have been lost to injury.

title: Three policemen, government worker gunned down in Baghdad
Iraqis Stunned by the Violence of a Bombing
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 17 - Even in Iraq, where shocking killings have become part of daily life, some acts are so profoundly violent that the country seems to pause, trying to fathom what happened.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Whirlpool Makes Unsolicited Bid For Maytag, Creating 3-Way Race The Whirlpool Corporation made an unsolicited $1.36 billion bid for Maytag, two months after it agreed to be sold for $1.13 billion to Ripplewood Holdings. Also in the running for Maytag is Haier, a major Chinese conglomerate, which recently made a $1.28 billion bid for the company. [C1.]

title: Guidant Issues Warning for 28,000 Pacemakers
description: Troubles for the Guidant Corporation continued today when the pacemaker manufacturer announced that some of its older implantable heart devices could fail, potentially leading to what the company called "serious health complications."

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: In Suspect's Neighborhood, Anger 'Comes and Goes'
description: Correction Appended

title: Like Comparing Apples to Apples
description: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland - BEFORE the 134th British Open began, one of Tiger Woods's advisers mentioned to him that if he were to win here on the old course, his 10 victories in pro majors and his three United States Amateur titles would match Bobby Jones's total of 13 majors won from 1923 to 1930.

title: Court TV's New Image
description: A cable television network is courting potential viewers and advertisers with an unconventional campaign asking them to come in with a verdict of guilty A of changing for the better.

title: INSIDE
description: Edward Heath Is Dead; Led Britain in Early 70's Sir Edward Heath, who as prime minister took Britain into the European Economic Community in 1973 and for decades was the Conservative Party's leading advocate of European unity, died at his home in Salisbury, his spokesman said. He was 89 and had served in Parliament for 51 years. PAGE A17

title: Briefly: Infineon raid brings resignation
A Church That Packs Them In, 16,000 at a Time
description: HOUSTON, July 17 - Where the Beers of the World kiosk once dispensed suds to rowdy N.B.A. fans, volunteers were handing out church literature on Sunday. And where Patricia Davis, 38, once saw ZZ Top in concert, she now plans to worship.

title: More Social Security Follies
description: Of all the participants in the strange Kabuki dance that passes for a Social Security debate, the one who might have had the best chance to do some actual good was Representative Bill Thomas, the Republican chairman of the Ways and Means Committee. Last May, Mr. Thomas held a hearing on ways to boost retirement savings, and some of the ideas put forth -- such as matching funds rather than tax deductions for I.R.A.'s -- could increase retirement security, if they were combined with prudent measures to ensure the solvency of Social Security. But now, under pressure from Republican leaders, Mr. Thomas is being drawn into the White House's single-minded drive for a privatization scheme the public doesn't want and the nation can't afford.

title: Besieged but Not Silenced, a Newspaper Keeps Publishing
description: OAXACA, Mexico, July 15 - Ismael Sanmartn Hernndez, the managing editor of Noticias, one of this town's two major newspapers, has a bad cold and has not eaten a good meal in days, but those are the least of his problems.

title: Firefighters killed in Spain forest blaze
A Cellphone, a Movie Lobby and a Message
description: This summer, moviegoers walking through theater lobbies in three cities might have felt a sudden vibration in their cellphones, the work of a nearby Bluetooth promotional kiosk.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, MORTIMER
description: LEVITT--Mortimer. Your favorite classic work was Schumann's "Warum?" ("Why?"). And, you always asked why, never accepting conventional wisdom, or the bureaucrats who think they know, when they don't know. May your questioning style become pervasive in this too-accepting world. Sarah and Gideon Gartner

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a decision by Republican leaders in Congress to postpone action on Social Security misstated the effect of legislation proposed by Senator Jim DeMint, Republican of South Carolina, on the solvency of the system. Over 75 years, the bill would reduce the Social Security shortfall by 0.15 percent of the taxable national payroll, according to the Social Security Administration's actuary, not "do nothing to improve the system's solvency." The system would still become insolvent in 2041, the same year as under the existing law.

title: Could Cars That Read Minds Save Drivers From Themselves?
description: PARIS - PILOTS log hours in cockpit simulators before they ever take the controls of an airliner, practicing emergency procedures and learning the layout of a plane's instrument panel. Automakers also rely on simulators, though their intent is to study drivers, not train them.

title: A Yankees Reprise Evokes a Stellar Debut
description: BOSTON, July 17 - He was big and boyish, he pumped fastballs on the inside corner, he chatted before, after and even during his pitches, and he was nervous. That is how four players who appeared in Al Leiter's first game with the Yankees on Sept. 15, 1987, remember him.

title: Britain planning tighter laws to fight terrorism
Thank You, Grandma and Grandpa
description: To the Editor:

title: Hindu party battles an internal revolt
Bush Says He'll Fire Any Aide Who 'Committed a Crime'
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 - President Bush said today that he would fire anyone in his administration who has broken the law in the unmasking of a C.I.A. officer two years ago.

title: North Korea may demand more concessions
Treasury Bills Set for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: As Clear Channel Enters the Fray, Online Radio Looks to Be Coming of Age
description: Correction Appended

title: First Case Against Hussein, Involving Killings in 1982, Is Sent to a Trial Court
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 17 - After more than 19 months in American custody, Saddam Hussein was referred for trial on Sunday in the first of more than a dozen cases of crimes against humanity that Iraqi and American investigators have been building against the deposed Iraqi dictator.

title: Armstrong Climbs Closer to 7th Win
description: PAU, France, July 18 - There were many doubters before Lance Armstrong set out to win the Tour de France for the seventh consecutive year - a feat he should accomplish, barring accident or illness, on Sunday in Paris.

title: GE: A general store for developing world
We Were Here First
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Today's Home Page Images
description: Photographs from today's home page of NYTimes.com.

title: Punishing Pain
description: ZEPHYRHILLS, Fla. - When I visited Richard Paey here, it quickly became clear that he posed no menace to society in his new home, a high-security Florida state prison near Tampa, where he was serving a 25-year sentence. The fences, topped with razor wire, were more than enough to keep him from escaping because Mr. Paey relies on a wheelchair to get around.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Council Given Inspection Role
description: City Council members will have the authority to order housing inspections within their districts under a new agreement with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The program will rotate among the 51 council members, with three districts participating every three months, department officials said. Each council member will be able to schedule inspections of up to 400 housing units in 30 buildings. The program is scheduled to begin immediately with the council districts of Bill Perkins in Harlem, Joel Rivera in the Bronx, and Diana Reyna in Bushwick and Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,759 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: U.S. to Broaden India's Access To Nuclear-Power Technology
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 - President Bush, bringing India a step closer to joining the club of nuclear-weapons states, reached an agreement with Prime Minister Manmohan Singh to let India secure international help for its civilian nuclear reactors while retaining its nuclear arms.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8:15 P.M. (Cinemax) WE DON'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE (2004). It's hard to explain exactly who started what and why, but in a quiet college town, Jack is having an affair with his best friend's wife, Edith, while the best friend, Hank, is sleeping with Jack's wife, Terry. And no one is having a good time. The film is gloomy but insightful, based on two novellas by Andre Dubus. (Above, from left: Mark Ruffalo as Jack, Peter Krause as Hank, Naomi Watts as Edith and Laura Dern as Terry.)

title: INSIDE
description: German High Court Blocks Qaeda Suspect's Extradition In a ruling seen as a sharp blow to coordinated counterterrorism efforts in Europe, Germany's highest court refused to turn over a German citizen suspected of aiding Al Qaeda to Spain, arguing that a recent European agreement to streamline extradition procedures violated the rights of its citizens. PAGE A11

title: Never Touching the Ground in a Constant Search for Refuge
description: Correction Appended

title: Steps to Protect Our Homeland
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Three Die In Crash
description: Three people were killed last night when their car slammed into a tree on Cross Bay Boulevard, the police said. The accident happened just before 10 p.m. when the car, traveling north, seemed to go out of control. Two men died at the scene, the police said, and a woman who was gravely injured died a short time later at Jamaica Hospital. A fourth passenger, a man, was listed in critical condition at the hospital.. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Failing to Teach in High School
description: The national math and reading scores that were released last week came at just the right time for Congress, which is about to reauthorize the Higher Education Act and talking yet again about the neglected but crucial issue of how to improve teachers' training. The message of the new scores is that education reform will fail unless the country gets enough qualified teachers to staff the middle and high schools, which have been stubbornly resistant to the reforms that are clearly taking hold in the early grades.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, NORMAN JACOB
description: BLOCK--Norman Jacob. Of Brooklyn, NY on July 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Carole. Loving father of Gail Block Harris and Ira Jay Block. Dear father-in-law of Walter Harris & Madelon Rosenfeld. Adoring grandfather of Katherine Clark Harris and Jennifer Leigh Harris. President of Carole Block, Ltd. Past President of Avenue M Merchants Association. Army veteran of World War II. Services Tuesday, 10AM, Midwood Memorial Chapel, 1625 Coney Island Avenue at Avenue M. Interment Knollwood Park Cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Cancer Research, N.Y. Presbyterian Hospital, 525 E. 68 St., NY NY 10021, Box 123 appreciated.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Phone Company Buys Dutch Rival
description: Tele2, the Swedish phone company, agreed to buy Versatel Telecom International of the Netherlands for 1.34 billion euros ($1.6 billion) to add Dutch and Belgian users. Tele2 offered 2.20 euros in cash for each Versatel share, 14 percent more than the closing price on July 15, the companies said yesterday in a regulatory filing. That values Versatel at 1.14 billion euros. Tele2, which provides fixed-line phone services in more European countries than any other company, said last week that it bought Comunitel Global of Spain from ONI Group for 257 million euros.

title: News Corp.'s youth move
Pacemakers by Guidant Have Flaw
description: The Guidant Corporation, already embroiled in controversy over recalls of heart devices, alerted doctors yesterday that nine of its older pacemaker models were prone to failing. Some patients might need to have the units replaced, the company said.

title: The Claim: You Gain More Weight by Eating at Night
description: THE CLAIM -- You gain more weight by eating at night.

title: Corruption in Asia, Europe's Muslims, The vision thing
InBev to buy a Russian beer maker
Magical Medicine on TV
description: On the Fox television show "House, M.D.," a misanthropic, pill-popping, grizzled ber doctor named Gregory House leads a group of impossibly bright young physicians in the department of diagnostic medicine at a teaching hospital in New Jersey.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A credit was omitted yesterday for a picture of an Israeli medic evacuating a child after an Israeli settlement was hit by mortar fire in the Gaza Strip. The photographer was Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times. (Go to Article)

title: German banks lose state backing
Investors to Add $100 Million in New Financing to Spirit Air
description: Spirit Airlines, the nation's biggest privately held carrier, plans to announce today that it has obtained $100 million in new financing, which it will use to try to offset the soaring price of jet fuel.

title: Leiter Gets Save From Mets, and Another From the Yanks
description: AL LEITER doesn't have to win another game for the Yankees. He has done enough for them, coming to the rescue of a team in extremis. But last winter, Leiter did even more for the Mets. He is an equal-opportunity benefactor.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENJAMIN, JOAN ELLETT
description: BENJAMIN--Joan Ellett, 87, widow of William H. Benjamin, of New York and Garrison, New York, died while swimming in her pool at home in Garrison Saturday, July 16, 2005. She attended the Chapin School, Madeira School, and Bennington College. She was an accomplished sculptor and gardener. She is survived by her children, Beverley Goodwin of New York, John Benjamin of Garrison and Hotchkiss, CO, Nathaniel Benjamin of Vineyard Haven, MA; six grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at St. Philip's Church, Garrison, on Saturday, July 23, 2005, at 11AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Hudson Highlands Land Trust, PO Box 226, Garrison, NY 10524.

title: Deep Purple = Moody Blues
description: "Why is the sky blue?" is a favorite question of children and physics teachers. A more subtle question is, "Why is the sky not purple?"

title: Yankees Are Still Looking to Upgrade in Center Field
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 18 - The Yankees were deficient enough in center field two weeks ago that they called up a 20-year-old prospect, Melky Cabrera, who had never even played in major league spring training.

title: Chief of Universal Studios Renews Contract
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 - Ron Meyer, who has presided over Universal Studios as its president for a decade, has signed a new five-year contract with NBC Universal. He will continue to oversee the studio and the parks and resorts business.

title: Shooter vs. shooter in paparazzi wars
Officers Shot at Church Begin to Recover
description: A day after he was shot in the head at close range during a gunfight with a suspect in Queens, Officer Dominick Romano emerged yesterday from several hours of cranial surgery with his sense of humor intact.

title: Governors Warn of High Costs Arising From New ID Law
description: DES MOINES, July 18 - The nation's governors told Michael Chertoff, the secretary of homeland security, on Monday that the new law expanding the role of state motor vehicle departments to include national security responsibilities was presenting enormous financial and logistical challenges that could take many years to meet.

title: Miller Defends Council's Campaign-Style Mailings as Legal
description: Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker and Democratic mayoral candidate, defended himself yesterday against criticism for campaign-style mailings that cost city taxpayers $1.6 million, saying the mailings did not break any laws.

title: EU slump hurts sales at Philips
With New Data, a Debate on Low-Level Radiation
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 - A report on the health effects of small doses of radiation has renewed a debate on the way exposure is regulated and how the public should regard such doses.

title: In libel case, Polanski denies seduction
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENNETT, VIOLETTE
description: BENNETT--Violette. Passed away at 93 in Exeter, N.H. July 12, 2005. Born and brought up in Algeria, she met her husband George on an Atlantic crossing. Accompanied by her husband, she continued to be an inveterate traveler, and was very involved with the Phillips Exeter Academy, where she worked in the library, bookstore and art gallery and also developed lifelong friendships with PEA students. She is fondly remembered for her hospitality to students and returning alumni friends, and for assisting others of her generation who were not as active as she. She is survived by son Coburn, daughter-inlaw Mimi Curran, a brother, a sister and two grandchildren. Service at Phillips Church, Exeter, N.H. July 27, at 2 P.M. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations to the George Bennett Fellowship, PEA, 20 Main St, Exeter, N.H. 03833. For more information contact Brewitt FH, Exeter, N.H. Phone: 603-772-3554.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OREMLAND, MELVYN JAY, PH.D.
description: OREMLAND--Melvyn Jay, Ph.D. 66, on July 17, 2005, in NYC. Devoted Professor of Physics at Pace University. Loved by his students and all who knew him. Will be greatly missed by his wife of 41 years, Lenore, daughter, Patricia, son, Dr. Gordon, and his wife, Dr. Carrie, grandson, Colin, brother, Alan, and his wife, Marilyn, brother, Dr. Ronald, and his wife, Francine, and in-laws, Dr. Samuel, and Paula Thier, and Dr. Richard, and Roberta London. Services Tuesday, 1:15 P.M., at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Multiple Myeloma Research Foundation, 51 Locust Avenue, Suite 201, New Canaan, CT 06840.

title: June Report Led Britain to Lower Its Terror Alert
description: LONDON, July 18 - Less than a month before the London bombings, Britain's top intelligence and law enforcement officials concluded that "at present there is not a group with both the current intent and the capability to attack the U.K.," according to a confidential terror threat assessment report.

title: From the Grandparents: Love, Not Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Fire in Queens Kills 3, Including Baby Girl
description: A fire swept through a two-story house in Queens this morning, killing three people, including a baby girl, the New York Fire Department said. Five family members and nine firefighters were also injured in the blaze.

title: The Firestorm in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, LOLA
description: KRAMER--Lola. Beloved wife of Saul, mother of Kathie and Robert, grandmother of Charles, Nancie, James, Michael, David and Lesley, beloved great-grandmother of Justice. A life may end but the relationships endure. We loved you then, we love you now, we will love you always and forever.

title: Gunmen Kill 2 Sunnis on Iraqi Constitution Panel
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 - In a setback to Iraq's fledgling democratic process, two Sunni Arab participants in the committee mandated to draft Iraq's constitution were assassinated this afternoon on a busy street in central Baghdad, officials said.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Gotbaum Faults Schools
description: The Department of Education is not adequately addressing domestic violence faced by students, particularly teenage girls, according to a report released yesterday by the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum. Ms. Gotbaum criticized the school system for what she said was its failure to train teachers to recognize and address abusive relationships among students. She also said the department should adopt a policy making it easier to transfer the batterer to another school.

title: In the Hospital: When Medical Tests Fall Through the Cracks
description: Hospital patients are often sent home before the results of all their medical tests are in, and some lab reports that should signal a need for new or different treatments instead fall by the wayside, researchers reported yesterday.

title: Governor Pataki and Women's Rights
description: Gov. George Pataki will soon have a chance to sign a bill that would give New York's women the chance to get emergency contraceptives without a prescription. The governor, who has apparently been eyeing the possibilities of a 2008 run for president, may be thinking about the politics of this bill more than the science. If so, he should think about how this law could help cut down on unintended pregnancies for all women in New York state.

title: Victims Have Say as Birmingham Bomber Is Sentenced
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 18 - It was Emily Lyons's first chance to address Eric R. Rudolph, the bomber whose attack on an abortion clinic here in 1998 left her half-blind and maimed. And she had plenty to say.

title: A Skeleton Moves From the Courts to the Laboratory
description: SEATTLE, July 18 - The bones, more than 350 pieces, were laid out on a bed of sand, a human jigsaw with ancient resonance. Head to toe, one of the oldest and best-preserved sets of remains ever discovered in North America was ready to give up its secrets.

title: Boys Who Died Lived 17 Hours in Car Trunk, Lawyer Says
description: Correction Appended

title: Detainee Trials to Resume Soon, Rumsfeld Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 18 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld said Monday that the war crimes trials of two detainees at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, that were suspended last year would be resumed "as soon as possible."

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CALVERT, GEORGE
description: CALVERT--George. The New York Housing Conference mourn the passing of our longtime board member, colleague, and friend George Calvert, an outstanding community leader in East Harlem and a tireless advocate for human services and affordable housing for all New Yorkers. Our most sincere condolences to his wife, his children, and their families. Clara Fox, John Kelly, Carol Lamberg and David M. Muchnick

title: Truckers Steam and Fruit Roasts as Syria Chokes Lebanese Border
description: MASNAA, Lebanon, July 16 - Syria has suddenly increased the inspections it imposes on commercial traffic coming from Lebanon, leaving hundreds of trucks stranded at border crossings for more than a week, and adding a bitter trade dispute to the already strained relationship between the two countries.

title: Trial of Curator at the Getty Postponed by Italian Court
description: ROME, July 18 - The trial of Marion True, a curator at the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles charged with conspiring to import illegally excavated antiquities, was postponed here Monday after a brief hearing in criminal court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTSEGEN, RITA (GILLETTE)
description: GOTTSEGEN--Rita (Gillette), died suddenly on July 16, 2005, her 78th birthday, in Rye, NY. Survived by her loving husband of 54 years, Dr. Robert Gottsegen. Cherished mother of Dr. David Gottsegen (Shelly), Daniel Gottsegen (Margaret Jackson) and Jonathan Gottsegen (Mindy). Devoted grandmother of Jessica, Liza, Samuel, Benjamin, Kate and Gardner. Dear sister of Dr. Burton Gillette (Marcia). A chemist who taught science at the Brearley School in Manhattan for 20 years. She will always be remembered for her great sensitivity, curiosity about the world and her passion for people. Memorial service Wednesday, 2PM at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, 914-381-1809. Donations in her memory may be sent to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, Montgomery, AL 36104 or The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

description: SPINGARN -- Jerome. 91, Washington, DC, attorney, arms control expert. Predeceased by wife Natalie Davis Spingarn. Survivors: sons Jonathan and Jeremy; grandchildren Hannah and Caroline. Dressler's 770-451-4999.

title: Spaniard Wins Tough Stage  and Moral Victory, Too
description: PAU, France, July 19 - Oscar Pereiro went from moral victor to real victor today in the Tour de France, his face alight with the glow of triumph as he magnanimously declared that all is forgiven. He will no longer badmouth George Hincapie - at least not full time.

description: Except in one spot, the rhythm of life on Third Avenue between 67th and 68th Streets suggests a steady drumroll of affluence: commerce in and out of shops, in and out of apartment buildings with doormen.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Church Equipment Stolen
description: A burglar broke into St. Gabriel's Church in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, yesterday morning and stole computer equipment, the police said. The thief climbed through a skylight in the roof of the church, at 331 Hawthorne Street, about 9:30 a.m. and carried off the equipment, the police said. An investigation continued yesterday.

title: On a Sticky Summer Night, Thousands Gather for Dvorak in Central Park
description: The players of the New York Philharmonic earned their city's thanks on Tuesday night by performing a two-hour-plus outdoor program on one of the stickiest and most uncomfortably humid nights of the summer. This kind of weather wreaks havoc on instruments, skews intonation and generally makes performing a very unglamorous activity, but the musicians persevered and dutifully produced an evening of Dvorak. Officials estimated a crowd of 47,000 on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: On White House Visit, Australian Vows to Stand Firm on Iraq
description: The prime minister of Australia today reasserted his country's commitment to helping the United States-led war in Iraq, saying Australian troops would stay as long as necessary.

title: Kurt Busch Avoids a Disaster and Keeps His Place in the Chase
description: LOUDON, N.H., July 18 - Bobby Labonte's car nudged Kurt Busch's blue Ford by mistake Sunday afternoon, sending Busch's car into a smoky spin. It looked for a moment as if Busch's car would hit the wall or collide with another car. It did neither.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILBERMAN, ROSALIE
description: SILBERMAN--Rosalie. Died July 16, 2005, after a lengthy illness. She was born in New York City. She married Alfred Silberman on April 6, 1941. She is survived by her two children, Karen Scott, News Director of WPIX TV, Alan Silberman, a guidance counselor from Baltimore, MD, along with a daughter-in-law, Ellen, three grandchildren, Paul, Evan, and Charles, and several nieces and nephews. Memorial services will be at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street & Amsterdam Avenue in Manhattan, 1:15 P.M., Wednesday, July 20, 2005. She will be buried next to her husband, Colonel Alfred Silberman in Arlington National Cemetery, August 10 at 1:30 P.M.

Plans call for Powell to be merged with a midsize MDC agency also based in New York, Margeotes Fertitta & Partners.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia Singapore: Raffles Hotel Business Is Sold
description: Colony Capital L.L.C., a private-equity firm, will pay 1.45 billion Singapore dollars ($859.6 million) in cash for the hotel business of Raffles Holdings, including the 118-year-old Raffles Hotel in Singapore. Colony HR Acquisitions L.L.C., an affiliate of the Los Angeles-based Colony Capital, will buy 41 hotels in 35 countries, Raffles said yesterday. Colony Capital's chief executive, Thomas Barrack, has spent more than $5 billion since 1991 buying assets.

description: Genentech said yesterday that its experimental Lucentis drug had restored patients' vision in a study. The finding gives the product an edge over a drug called Macugen from Eyetech Pharmaceuticals, analysts said.

description: On her Web site, Danica McKellar, the actress best known as Winnie Cooper on the television series "The Wonder Years," takes on questions that require more than a moment's thought to answer.

Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Candidate Withdraws From Race
description: Paul Wooten, a former assistant district attorney and now a lawyer in private practice, dropped out of the race for Brooklyn district attorney yesterday. His campaign manager, G.Joyce Hamer, said the decision was because Mr. Wooten would "not come close" to raising the $500,000 his staff felt he needed to win the Democratic primary against the incumbent, Charles J. Hynes, and four other candidates. Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

description: Stepping into the increasingly heated issue of how Long Island houses its growing immigrant population, the Nassau County district attorney announced yesterday that a special grand jury would investigate illegal and overcrowded housing in the county.

description: The 3M Company said yesterday that it had its smallest quarterly profit gain in three years, hurt by a drop in sales of film used to brighten computer and cellphone screens.

title: Blair Meets With Muslim Leaders, Seeking Aid Against Extremism
description: LONDON, July 19 - As Britons struggled to explain the London bombings to themselves, Prime Minister Tony Blair met with moderate Muslim leaders today, seeking to enlist their support against Islamic extremism and to discount the war in Iraq as the prime cause for the attacks.

title: Happy Landings
description: HAPPY LANDINGS -- Two major new airport terminals were scheduled to open this week, but the debut of one has been postponed. At Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport, international flights are scheduled to begin operating Saturday from the $1.7 billion, two-million-square-foot Terminal D. The airport was ranked sixth in the world last year in passenger traffic (after Atlanta Hartsfield, Chicago O'Hare, London Heathrow, Tokyo Haneda and Los Angeles International). But the opening of a $438 million terminal at Southwest Florida International Airport scheduled for tomorrow has been delayed to allow the completion of last-minute work and federal certification of baggage handling systems. A new date has not been set for the opening of the terminal, which will replace a 22-year-old building. The airport serves the booming Fort Myers-Cape Coral region.

title: G.M. Hires an Adviser for Try at Comeback
description: General Motors, the world's largest automaker, has hired the prominent automobile business analyst Stephen Girsky from Morgan Stanley to help guide its efforts to return to profitability.

title: Robert Klein's Comic Tour of the Neighborhood
description: If Robert Klein had been fingering a rubber ball as he strolled through his old Bronx neighborhood the other day, there's no doubt what he would have done when he reached the apartment house that squats across the street from Woodlawn Cemetery on the lot where he played baseball as a boy. A sign on the red brick building, next to the beige one in which he grew up, warns "Positively No Ball Playing Allowed." To Mr. Klein, even at age 63, this would have been an invitation to smash his Spaldeen against the wall.
