title: Arts, Briefly; Trace Begins to Dish
description: Trace TV, a spinoff of the multicultural music and fashion magazine Trace, began on the Dish Network yesterday, bringing global urban music stateside. Established in Paris two years ago, Trace TV, a 24-hour music channel distributed in 62 countries, features everything from reggae to Latin music, as well songs by Indian, Asian and African artists. "We're providing a platform for artists who don't have one," said Richard Wayner, who founded the network with Olivier Laouchez and the Trace magazine creator, Claude Grunitzky. Mr. Wayner said: "There is a ghetto way to do multiculturalism and that is to have an African channel for Africans. The international and aggressive way to do it is to have a multicultural channel for the whole world. African artists want to get on Trace because they know they're going to be seen in Switzerland and the West Indies and France and now in the U.S. We want everyone to be exposed to everything out there."

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on Friday, about marketing food to children, misidentified a group that has appointed a committee to review oversight of video games that food companies incorporate in their Web sites, a practice that has drawn criticism from consumer groups. The appointment was made by the Children's Advertising Review Board, not the Grocery Manufacturers Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPPES, CARL HENRY III
description: KAPPES--Carl Henry III. 68, of Sun Valley, ID, died with dignity July 13, 2005, in Hailey, ID. He graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy in 1955 and Princeton University in 1959. He was a Field Artillery Officer in the US Marine Corps. Survivors are his sisters Karen Kappes of Holden, MA, and Ellen Kappes of Northeast Harbor, ME; his beloved Claudia Casey of Peapack, NJ, his step-daughter Christina Winters of Greenwich, CT, and four nephews, Michael Carl Darrah, Eric Darrah, Alexander Kimball and Benjamin Kimball. He was a sales manager for American Sugar Company and Vice President/Director with Farr Mann & Company in New York. Memorial services are at 5 PM Thursday, July 21, 2005, at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Ketchum, ID. Memorials suggested to Hospice of Wood River Valley, Croy Canyon Ranch Foundation or Heifer Project International, care of Wood River Chapel, 403 North Main, Hailey, ID 83333. A memorial service will be scheduled for the fall at Christ Church in Rye, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILLER, NORMAN
description: MILLER--Norman. Beloved uncle and brother, distinguished football writer and columnist, died Thursday, July 14, in New York City, after a long decline in health. He was 87. Born October 28, 1917, in Springfield, Massachusetts, Mr. Miller graduated from the University of Michigan in 1942. After serving as a Navy Air Corps pilot in World War II, Mr. Miller began his long and extremely successful career as a sportswriter. He joined United Press International in 1946, where he covered all sports. In 1964 he joined the New York Daily News, and quickly became the paper's beat writer for the Giants football team, while continuing to cover primarily professional football during his two-decade career with the Daily News. Mr. Miller moved to Palm Springs, California, in 1980, where he continued writing as a West Coast correspondent for the Daily News and, later, for the New York Post. During this time he was also a pro-football columnist for the on-line news service, Sportsticker, until he retired in 1989. Football was Mr. Miller's lifelong passion, and he was highly regarded by all who knew him for writing with fairness, honesty and integrity. He was one of a handful of sportswriters who covered the first 37 Super Bowls, until illness prevented him from travelling. In 1981 he received the Dick McCann Memorial Award for long and distinguished writing in football, the highest honor awarded to writers in his profession. Mr. Miller counted among his close friends athletes, owners and peers alike, including Giants owner Wellington Mara and the late Giants General Manager George Young. He is survived by his younger brother, David Miller, of New York City; his nieces, Neredith Miller of New York City and Laurie Miller of Barboursville, VA; his nephew, Matthew Miller, and great-nephews, Ethan and Justin Miller, all of Colchester, VT. A memorial service will be held in New York City in the fall.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Pearl River: Police Inspector Electrocuted
description: A New York Police Department inspector was electrocuted during a downpour that flooded his home last night, Sgt. John Purcell of the Orangetown Police Department said. The inspector, Michael Shortell, 45, was working the pump at his house in Pearl River, a hamlet in Orangetown, when a current ran through the flooded area and electrocuted him. Inspector Shortell, who was married and the father of three girls, was taken to Nyack University Hospital, where he died, Sergeant Purcell said. A department roster identified him as commanding officer of the Bronx narcotics bureau. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; '60 Minutes' Makes CBS's Night
description: On Sunday, CBS edged out NBC in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers and households. The most-watched program of the night was CBS's "60 Minutes," with 8.6 million viewers. CBS also broadcast repeats of "Cold Case" (7.87 million) and the 2002 made-for-television movie "Gleason" (6.3 million). But among 18-to-49-year-olds, the network's lineup was No. 4. Fox's comedy schedule ranked first over all, largely thanks to two episodes of "Family Guy." The 9 p.m. original episode of the animated comedy, which was resurrected after cancellation, was Fox's most-watched show in the 18-to-49 demographic, and brought in 5.75 million viewers. A repeat followed it and drew nearly as large an audience, 5.61 million. Earlier, however, the second week of Fox's "Princes of Malibu" didn't do nearly as well. It attracted only 3.96 million viewers and was beaten handily among adults 18 to 49 by the second half of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition."

Paid Notice: Deaths   MASUR, ALLAN A.
description: MASUR--Allan A., 81. Died peacefully on Sunday July 17, surrounded by many of his loving friends and family. He graduated City College Phi Beta Kappa and received a law degree from Columbia University. He served in the Army in WWII. He practiced law all of his life in NYC. He played an instrumental role in founding Congregation Beth Simchat Torah in NYC and received their Chesed Award for Lifetime Achievement in May 1994. In 1973, he founded Congregation B'nai Olam in his beloved Fire Island Pines. Beginning with High Holy Days Services in his home, he has nurtured the Congregation into an important and self-sustaining community organization, which conducts annual services attended by hundreds of congregants from the Pines, Cherry Grove and surrounding communities. It was one of his proudest accomplishments. He is survived by his two sisters Irene Solomon and Gladys Hallerman; nieces Carole, Sheila, Barbara and nephew David; great nieces and nephews and a new great-great-nephew. Allan profoundly touched the lives of countless people. We will never forget this man who throughout his life gave all of his many friends unconditional love, caring and honest advice. He is forever etched in our lives and how we live them. Services today Tuesday, 11:45AM at "The Riverside," 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in Allan's memory to the Congregations he cared so deeply for would be appreciated.

Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODYEAR, JOHN ''JACK,'' JR.
description: GOODYEAR--John "Jack," Jr., July 6, 2005, in Cherry Valley, New York. To everything he did, Jack brought a sharp eye and an even sharper wit, intelligent and wide-ranging curiosity, a gift for writing born of the pleasure he took in sharing his passions with others, the ability to take things in stride, a buoyant and infectious enthusiasm, an unquenchable sense of humor, engaging charm and a flair that was unmistakably his. These qualities never deserted him, even in his last illness, and accounted for his unusually wide and diverse circle of close friends. He had seven godchildren. He is survived by a large family, including his wife, the former Jane McGovern; two brothers, Dick and Sam Goodyear; and a cousin, Bradley Goodyear Smith.

title: Arts, Briefly; Harry Potter's Latest Battle
description: Now Harry Potter is taking on the pirates. Two days after the debut of the latest installment in the popular book series, lawyers for the author, J.K. Rowling, said they had already had to defend "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" against copyright infringement. An offer to sell a scanned P.D.F.-file version of the book that was posted on Half.com soon after its release was removed after a lawyer for Christopher Little Literary Agency, which represents Ms. Rowling, contacted the site, which is owned by eBay. The lawyer, Neil Blair, said the agency has been notified of "a couple of other" potentially pirated copies of both the print and audio versions of the book and is pursuing them. Compared to legitimate sales of the book, which totaled nine million in Britain and the United States in the first day, the number of violations "is quite small so far," Mr. Blair said. "But we do take it seriously."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STILLMAN, LINDA
description: STILLMAN--Linda. We will miss you forever--our dearest and closest friend. Lennie and Peter Benjamin

title: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Traffic Police Sent Packing
description: Taking a page from his peer in Georgia, President Viktor A. Yushchenko of Ukraine announced that he was firing the entire traffic police force, wire services reported. The traffic police, with their institutionalized practice of shaking down motorists for bribes, are almost uniformly loathed in much of the former Soviet Union. Mr. Yushchenko said the Ukrainian force, estimated at 23,000 officers, would be immediately disbanded and replaced by a more professional contingent that would meet European standards. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Sharpton Backs Developer's Plan for Brooklyn Arena and Towers
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton said yesterday that he was backing a plan by Bruce C. Ratner, the developer, to build a canyon of skyscrapers and an arena for the Nets over railyards near Downtown Brooklyn.

title: SABMiller buys brewer to grow in Latin America
Briefly: Powerful hurricane hits Yucatn Peninsula
Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMPSON, MARY MCELDOWNEY
description: SIMPSON--Mary McEldowney. The President and Board of Trustees of Vassar College note with deepest sorrow the passing of Mary McEldowney Simpson, beloved wife of the late Alan Simpson, Vassar President from 1964 to 1977. Mary Simpson's wisdom, wit, and generosity and her devotion to the College will stand in the memory of all who knew her. She touched the College and so many of us in simply extraordinary ways. As an institution and as individuals, we are very grateful for her service and friendship. We extend our condolences to her daughters Barbara and Carol, grandchildren Mary Kathleen Flynn, Vassar Class of 1984, and Kevin Flynn, and the rest of her family and many friends. Richard E. Van Demark Chair, Board of Trustees Frances D. Fergusson President

title: Video Formats
description: Today, let's go to the mail bag to answer 583 reader queries. As it turns out, they all ask the same question, and they arrive daily:

title: Blair says bombings not linked to wars
Travel brief: North Korea to open more sites to outsiders
National Briefing | Washington: Fund-Raising Continues Apace
description: Ethical inquiries and investigations apparently have not hurt Representative Tom DeLay's ability to raise money. Mr. DeLay, the Texas Republican who is majority leader, raised roughly $800,000 in the second quarter for his 2006 re-election campaign, bringing his total to more than $1.4 million, according to the latest reports to the Federal Election Commission. He had $726,000 in the bank on June 30. Former Representative Nick Lampson, a Democrat challenging Mr. DeLay, raised about $500,000 and had about $485,000 in the bank, reports show. Glen Justice (NYT)

title: A Sex Symbol of the 1970's Does Lawrence Welk for Hip Seniors
description: In the most seductive cut on "Moonlight Serenade," Carly Simon's likable new collection of popular standards, the album's brisk foxtrot rhythms are briefly interrupted by a silky pop-samba arrangement of the Howard Dietz-Arthur Schwartz ballad "Alone Together." Crooning against a luminescent backdrop of strings and electric keyboard, Ms. Simon, whose voice has deepened into a weathered contralto, invests this Depression-era vision of lovers clinging to each other in the darkness with the forthright openheartedness that has always been her calling card.

title: Case Raises New Concern Over Withdrawal of Drugs
description: In recent years, many anticonvulsant drugs have been widely prescribed not only for seizure disorders, but for various kinds of chronic pain and for several different psychiatric illnesses, even though few have been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for those purposes.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Rare Turtle Saved From The Soup
description: A critically endangered mangrove turtle, left, bound from a Cambodian river to China's illegal wildlife markets, turned up in Vietnam when a microchip imbedded under its skin set off sensors used by inspectors there. The species, also called the royal turtle in Cambodia because it was once deemed the sole property of the royal family, is just one of many threatened turtle varieties that are being depleted by smugglers serving the gourmet food trade in China. The recovered 33-pounder with the implanted tag will be released soon in the Sre Ambel River, said Doug Hendrie, a biologist with the Wildlife Conservation Society. But he added that thousands of other rare turtles are smuggled unnoticed across borders in the region daily. Andrew C. Revkin (NYT)

title: Visa to Bar Transactions by Processor
description: Visa USA said yesterday that it would stop allowing the payment processor CardSystems Solutions to handle its transactions, months after the processor left the records of millions of cardholders at risk for fraud.

title: Frequently Overcrowded Oases
description: On a trip to Beijing last spring, Christian C. Johnson, a consultant with BearingPoint Emerging Markets and an elite member of United Airlines' frequent-flier program, went to the carrier's Red Carpet Club at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago to get some work done.

title: The Firestorm in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies
description: THE DOOR IN THE FLOOR (2004) Thursday at 8 p.m. on Cinemax. Once in a while, a good novel turns into an even better movie. Based on the first section of John Irving's "Widow for One Year," this wistful romantic drama is about an unhappy couple in the Hamptons. Jeff Bridges gives a brilliant performance as Ted Cole, a self-involved, semi-alcoholic children's book author and illustrator. He and his wife, Marion (Kim Basinger, who seems exhausted from having been beautiful for so long), have never recovered from the deaths of their teenage sons, even though they went on to have a beautiful little girl (Elle Fanning, above, with Mr. Bridges). The marriage is falling apart just as a teenage boy (Jon Foster) arrives to be Ted's assistant for the summer. And, as it turns out, to have an affair with Marion. Tod Williams directed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRENNER, ARTHUR
description: BRENNER--Arthur. Sutton Place Synagogue records with sorrow the loss of our longtime member, friend and worshipper, a gentle man appreciated by all. Sincere condolences to his beloved wife Miriam, children, grandchildren and the entire bereaved family. Allan Schranz, Rabbi Mark Wiener, President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HALL, ELIZABETH BLODGETT
description: HALL -- Elizabeth Blodgett. The overseers, faculty, staff and alumni/ae of Simon's Rock College of Bard and the trustees of Bard College mourn the passing of the esteemed founder of Simon's Rock, Elizabeth Blodgett Hall. A visionary and courageous leader in education, she was a friend, neighbor and benefactor. We are forever indebted to her and committed to her legacy. She was the widow of Livingston Hall. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to her children, Thomas Livingston Hall, Margaret Hall Whitfield Courant, Elizabeth Hall Richardson and John Kendrick Hall, and to her entire family. Leon Botstein, President Simon's Rock College of Bard and Bard College Emily H. Fisher, Chair Mary Marcy, Provost and Vice President Simon's Rock College of Bard Charles P. Stevenson, Chair David E. Schwab II, Chair Emeritus Dimitri B. Papadimitriou, Executive Vice President Bard College

title: Harry Potter and the Magical Weekend
description: To the Editor:

title: Storm Lashes Yucatn, Then Goes Out to Sea
description: CANCN, Mexico, July 18 - The newest hurricane, desigated Emily, battered the Yucatn peninsula in the early hours on Monday, leaving millions of people without power, water or telephone service, but causing few deaths before limping back into the warm waters of the Gulf of Mexico, where it was expected to regain some of its fearsome strength.

title: Tax Refunds Seen as Prop in Ford's 19 Percent Decline
description: DETROIT, July 19-The Ford Motor Company reported a 19 percent decline in second-quarter earnings today as it continues to struggle to keep American customers.

title: Britain to Try 3 Soldiers on War Crimes Charges
description: LONDON, July 19 - Britain's attorney general announced today that three British soldiers would be tried on war crimes charges for the inhumane treatment of Iraqi detainees, one of whom died.

title: Hunting for Life in Specks of Cosmic Dust
description: Correction Appended

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Edward Heath, who as prime minister took Britain into the European Economic Community in 1973, referred incorrectly to his election to the House of Commons in 1950. He won by 133 votes, not 133 seats.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCGINN, TIMOTHY J.
description: McGINN--Timothy J., age 54, on July 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Mary (nee Ehmann). Devoted father of Timothy Jr, Brian and Maura. Cherished son of Alice and the late John. Graduate of Regis H.S. '68, Fordham College '72 and Fordham School of Law '76. Friends may call at The Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue (at 20th Street) NYC, Wednesday and Thursday, 2-5 & 79PM. Mass of Christian Burial 10AM, Friday, at Epiphany R.C. Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to Regis High School, 55 East 84th Street, NYC, NY 10028.

title: Harry Potter and the Magical Weekend
description: To the Editor:

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Insurer Joins Bank Fight
description: Compagnia Assicuratrice Unipol, an Italian insurer, offered 4.9 billion euros ($5.9 billion) for the part of Banca Nazionale del Lavoro it does not own, topping a rival offer from Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain. Unipol, which already controls almost 42 percent of Banca Nazionale with allies, offered 2.7 euros a share in cash for the remaining shares, Unipol said yesterday in a statement. Through the support of other shareholders, including Deutsche Bank, Unipol may control more than half of Banca Nazionale. Unipol's bid intensifies a battle of Italian companies and foreign lenders who are trying to gain control of two of the country's banks. The Dutch bank ABN Amro Holding, which has made an offer for Banca Antonveneta, and Banco Bilbao are facing opposition from local companies and the Bank of Italy.

title: Berlin sells off stake in Deutsche Post
Briefs: Sibir gets injunction on venture
A Jar of Red Herrings
description: It is getting hard to keep track of all the issues stirred up by the leaking of a C.I.A. operative's name to a conservative columnist two years ago. Our colleague Judith Miller has been in jail for nearly two weeks for refusing to identify her confidential sources to a grand jury investigating that leak. Her position -- that reporters cannot do their jobs if they cannot guarantee some sources anonymity -- is very clear, as is her willingness to accept the legal consequences of her principled stand. But the case itself is complicated, and it's been made more so by a raft of distracting issues.

title: A Dose of Potent Advice: Don't Mess With Tetanus
description: If you scare easily, maybe you'd better not read this column. Then again, maybe a good scare is really what you need to get your immunization against tetanus up to date.

title: U.N. Cites Lag in Educating Peacekeepers About AIDS
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 18 - United Nations officials said Monday that despite progress in fulfilling a mandate five years ago to better educate peacekeeping forces about AIDS, they had not fully met their goal.

title: Work Covered by Transportation Bond Act Is Listed
description: The Pataki administration has released the full list of 3,414 road, bridge and highway projects that would be partly financed by a $2.9 billion transportation bond act that will go before New York State voters in November.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Shot In Car
description: A man in a black Jaguar sedan was fatally shot late Sunday in Rego Park, Queens, the police said. Officers responded to a report of shots at Rutledge Avenue and 88th Street about 11 p.m. and found a man slumped inside the parked car. The victim, who was not identified yesterday, had been shot several times. The police said that they found a gun in the car, and that witnesses reported seeing people flee in a tan Ford Explorer.

title: Traveling Coach, with class
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "One time, I got up the next morning and looked in the mirror and there were two of them up in my hair."

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8:15 P.M. (Cinemax) WE DON'T LIVE HERE ANYMORE (2004). It's hard to explain exactly who started what and why, but in a quiet college town, Jack is having an affair with his best friend's wife, Edith, while the best friend, Hank, is sleeping with Jack's wife, Terry. And no one is having a good time. The film is gloomy but insightful, based on two novellas by Andre Dubus. (Above, from left: Mark Ruffalo as Jack, Peter Krause as Hank, Naomi Watts as Edith and Laura Dern as Terry.)

title: Politicus:What a Merkel victory would mean to Europe
For Some, the Tax Cut on Investment Income Is Not as Sweet as Advertised

title: Behavior: The Night Before the Morning After
description: When morning-after pills become more easily available, do women become less diligent about using birth control?

title: Arts, Briefly; Renomination for Chairman Of Humanities Endowment
description: Bruce Cole, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has been nominated by President Bush for a second four-year term. Mr. Cole, 66, was a professor of fine arts and comparative literature at the Hope School of Fine Arts at Indiana University before beginning his first term in December 2001. He served earlier on the National Council on the Humanities. His nomination requires approval by the Senate.

title: Sign, Veto or Some Combination: Pataki and the Emergency Contraception Bill
description: ALBANY, July 18 - As Gov. George E. Pataki prepares to decide the fate of a bill to make emergency contraception available to women and girls, his associates say one of the courses he is considering is a compromise.

title: The Firestorm in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: One Dead and Two Hurt In Shooting
description: One man was killed and a man and a woman were wounded in a shooting yesterday morning in Jackson Heights, Queens, the police said. They said they responded to a call at 4:53 a.m. about shots fired at 83-09 31st Avenue, and found the three victims. A man and woman in the area were arrested, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Family Fare column of Weekend on Friday about the musical "Sleepover," at the Tada! theater in Chelsea, misidentified the director. She is Stephanie Gilman; Janine Nina Trevens is the executive and artistic director of the Tada! company.

title: Mayor Plans New Standards for 7th Graders
description: Boasting that his threat to hold back failing third and fifth graders had spurred record increases in reading and math scores, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he would extend the policy to seventh graders.

title: Clarence Dennis, Builder of Machine Crucial to Heart Surgery, Dies at 96
description: Dr. Clarence Dennis, a pioneering developer of the heart-lung bypass machine and other mechanical heart devices that have extended the lives of millions, died on July 11 in St. Paul. He was 96.

title: The Plot Thickens Between a Coach and His Team
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y. - LARRY BROWN was relaxing yesterday afternoon in the Hamptons -- at least, this is what he called relaxing: standing in the middle of a basketball court with 12 children, ages 10 to 14, at the Neighborhood House in East Hampton. The sky was overcast with a threat of rain and a refreshing breeze that lightened up the heavy humidity.

title: Rangers Are Set to Bring Back Graves
description: Adam Graves, the gritty and beloved left wing on the Rangers team that ended a 54-year drought by winning the 1994 Stanley Cup, will rejoin the club to work with the young players in the organization and to be a community liaison. The Rangers will announce his hiring today.

title: 'Kickbacks' case embroils class-action powerhouse
Court-gutting in Congress
Thai shift of power by decree draws fire
Some Pointed Questioning at the Vioxx Trial in Texas
description: ANGLETON, Tex., July 18 - The plaintiff's lawyer in the first Vioxx lawsuit to reach trial confronted his first witness on Monday, challenging a senior scientist from the drug maker Merck over the company's marketing practices.

title: Abbas Criticizes Hamas Radicals in Harsh Terms
description: GAZA, July 18 - The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, sharply criticized the radical Hamas faction on Monday for breaking the truce with Israel that all Palestinian groups had agreed upon and for allowing Israel to take advantage of internal Palestinian strife.

title: General Westmoreland Dies; Led U.S. in Vietnam
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who commanded the United States forces in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968, overseeing the vast troop buildup and the height of the fighting, died last night in a retirement home in Charleston, S.C., his son, James Ripley Westmoreland, announced. The general was 91.

title: Nannies and the Family
description: To the Editor:

title: O Mom, Where Art Thou? A Tweener Wants to Know
description: The traveling company Theaterworks/USA has decided to set down some New York roots, and the first production by its Theaterworks/NYC arm, "Walk Two Moons," couldn't be more appealing.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Jamesburg: Floods Damage Middlesex Homes
description: New Jersey officials declared a state of emergency in parts of Middlesex County on Sunday after a thunderstorm deposited 10 inches of rain in two hours, causing flash flooding, washing out roads and forcing nearly 700 people from their homes. At least 32 people spent the night at a Red Cross shelter, and 60 homes were still without power yesterday. John Holl (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPARBERG, LESTER
description: SPARBERG -- Lester. Died peacefully at home in Great Neck, New York, on June 25, at age 88. Beloved husband of Esther Braun Sparberg. Loving father of Alice and Nick Alexiou, and Andrew and Donna Sparberg. Grandfather of Alex and Joseph Alexiou, and Mark (Rebecca) and Neil Sparberg. We all miss him terribly.

title: Arts, Briefly; Renomination for Chairman Of Humanities Endowment
description: Bruce Cole, chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities, has been nominated by President Bush for a second four-year term. Mr. Cole, 66, was a professor of fine arts and comparative literature at the Hope School of Fine Arts at Indiana University before beginning his first term in December 2001. He served earlier on the National Council on the Humanities. His nomination requires approval by the Senate. ELIZABETH OLSON

title: A Soggy Night Takes the Summergarden Out of the Garden
description: The Museum of Modern Art's Summergarden series, dormant during the renovations of the last three years, returned on Sunday evening, more or less. The concerts are meant to be held in the Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, but the museum's new configuration allows for moving them indoors when the weather is threatening. The weather Sunday was dismal, so the museum took its option.

title: Do You Hear What I Hear?
description: To the Editor:

title: Arroyo may soon face call for impeachment
Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about an Iraqi boy who will be treated in the United States for injuries caused by a cluster bomb misidentified the city where he walked to a doctor's appointment. It was Washington, not Baltimore.

U.K. denies U.S. ties prompted attacks

Newark Officer Is Slain
description: A school police officer was shot and killed yesterday by one of two assailants who drove up as the police tried to break up a fight between two girls outside a high school in the city's troubled South Ward, the authorities said.

title: Britain Assails Critical Report on Role in Iraq
description: LONDON, July 18 - The government reacted sharply on Monday to a private research report that said Britain was particularly exposed to a terrorist attack because of its role in Iraq as an ally and "pillion passenger" of American policy.

title: Earnings: Net rises but revenue falls amid grim environment
Arts, Briefly; '60 Minutes' Makes CBS's Night
description: On Sunday, CBS edged out NBC in Nielsen's estimates for total viewers and households. The most-watched program of the night was CBS's "60 Minutes," with 8.6 million viewers. CBS also broadcast repeats of "Cold Case" (7.87 million) and the 2002 made-for-television movie "Gleason" (6.3 million). But among 18-to-49-year-olds, the network's lineup was No. 4. Fox's comedy schedule ranked first over all, largely thanks to two episodes of "Family Guy." The 9 p.m. original episode of the animated comedy, which was resurrected after cancellation, was Fox's most-watched show in the 18-to-49 demographic, and brought in 5.75 million viewers. A repeat followed it and drew nearly as large an audience, 5.61 million. Earlier, however, the second week of Fox's "Princes of Malibu" didn't do nearly as well. It attracted only 3.96 million viewers and was beaten handily among adults 18 to 49 by the second half of "Extreme Makeover: Home Edition." KATE AURTHUR

title: Armstrong protects lead after final high mountain stage
Arts, Briefly; Harry Potter's Latest Battle
description: Now Harry Potter is taking on the pirates. Two days after the debut of the latest installment in the popular book series, lawyers for the author, J.K. Rowling, said they had already had to defend "Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince" against copyright infringement. An offer to sell a scanned P.D.F.-file version of the book that was posted on Half.com soon after its release was removed after a lawyer for Christopher Little Literary Agency, which represents Ms. Rowling, contacted the site, which is owned by eBay. The lawyer, Neil Blair, said the agency has been notified of "a couple of other" potentially pirated copies of both the print and audio versions of the book and is pursuing them. Compared to legitimate sales of the book, which totaled nine million in Britain and the United States in the first day, the number of violations "is quite small so far," Mr. Blair said. "But we do take it seriously." EDWARD WYATT

title: Mack Hires Ex-Colleague as Morgan Stanley's Legal Officer
description: John J. Mack, taking his first step to repair Morgan Stanley's legal and regulatory standing, named Gary G. Lynch yesterday to be the firm's chief legal officer.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Christian Warlord Is Pardoned
description: Lebanon's newly elected Parliament approved amnesty for a Christian militia leader, Samir Geagea, left, who had served 11 years of four life sentences for killing political rivals during the country's long civil war. He has insisted that the sentences, handed down under the pro-Syrian leadership, were politically motivated. Leena Saidi (NYT)

title: Typhoon Haitang barrels into mainland China
The Firestorm in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Remember the Pueblo
description: PYONGYANG, North Korea - Moored on a river here in the North Korean capital is the U.S.S. Pueblo, described as an "armed spy ship of the U.S. imperialist aggression forces."

title: BBVA expected to raise BNL bid
Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDBERG, IRWIN M., MD.
description: FREEDBERG--Irwin M., MD. 74, of New York, New York and Holderness, NH, formerly of Newton, Massachusetts. Husband for 51 years of Irene (Lisman) Freedberg. Father of Marjorie F. Bogdanow and her husband Michael of Lexington, Kenneth A. and his wife Joyce Jen of Weston, and Deborah A. and her husband William Diebold of Portland, OR. Grandfather of Matthew, Daniel, and Alyssa Bogdanow, Suzanne and Katherine Freedberg, and Joseph and Abigail Diebold. Chairman of the Department of Dermatology at New York University School of Medicine from 1981-2005. Formerly Chairman of Dermatology at the Beth Israel Hospital in Boston and the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Avid skier, world traveler, and lifelong Boston sports fan. Funeral service will be at Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 E. 51st St, New York, NY on Tuesday, July 19 at 3 PM. Burial at Lindwood Memorial Park in Randolph, MA on Wednesday, July 20th at 12 noon. Donations in his memory may be made to the Irwin M. Freedberg, MD Fellowship Fund, Department of Dermatology, NYU School of Medicine, TCH 100, 550 1st Avenue, New York, New York 10016.

title: 3 linked to attacks had traveled to Pakistan
Intentional Neglect
description: ANDES, N.Y. - NOW that the speculation about who will replace Justice Sandra Day O'Connor on the Supreme Court is in full frenzy, we can look forward to debates in which words and phrases like "originalist," "strict constructionist," "textualist," "judicial activist" and "intentionalist" will figure prominently, because these labels are thought by many to stand for different styles of interpreting the Constitution. Those who think so are wrong.

title: Watch Where You're Pointing That Finger
description: EVEN people too young to remember Harry S. Truman's White House know about the sign on his desk. It carried one of the best-known aphorisms in political history. Surely you recognize it: "The buck stops over yonder."

title: New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Guidant Warns That Some Older Models Of Pacemakers May Need to Be Replaced Guidant, embroiled in controversy over recalls of heart devices, alerted doctors that nine of its older pacemaker models were prone to failing. Some patients might need to have the units replaced, the company said. [Page C1.]

title: The Decline and Fall of Journalists on Film
description: In the efficient little Latin American thriller "Crnicas," John Leguizamo embodies the reporter as seen in current films: he's a sleaze. The character, Manolo, works for a lurid television news magazine, "One Hour With the Truth," but we quickly see through the half-truths he delivers. His cameraman approaches grieving parents draped over their small son's coffin, and moves them slightly for a better shot. Manolo asks a man who may be a serial child killer a question that is a staple of network and local news: What is he feeling? The reporter even inserts himself into a story, Geraldo-style, to stop a lynching. His own producer tells him, "You just want to be a hero."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCH, MICHAEL ''MICKIE''
description: HIRSCH--Michael "Mickie". Devoted husband of Patricia. Cherished father of Nancy Meredith and Kathy Jo. Dearest grandfather of Bradley, Brooke, Ryan and Kelsey. Beloved father-in-law of Dan Geoffrey and brother of Stanley. Loved by all who knew him for his humor, and caring and loving nature. Services Wed., July 20th, Beth Israel Chapel, Boynton Beach, FL.

title: When a Dog Day Afternoon Starts Before Dawn
description: Women trudged by wearing see-through shirts, some men no shirts at all. The basketball courts were left to the ghosts, and the sunlit sidewalks were wet as the sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GLICKSMAN, ALBERT
description: GLICKSMAN--Albert. Beloved husband of Frances A. Devoted son of the late Frances. Truly a Renaissance man with a love for baseball to books and classical music, to the rescue and humane treatment of animals. A student of learning all his life. Services will be held on Wednesday, 1 P.M., at the Dix Hills Chapel of I.J. Morris, Inc., 21 East Deer Park Road.

description: Correction Appended

title: PanAmSat Is Buying Satellite to Serve More Overseas Markets
description: PanAmSat, the world's fourth-largest wholesale satellite operator, is to announce today that it bought a satellite and two orbital slots from Alcatel to expand its coverage further into Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia.

title: European Union's New Members Await the Spoils of Defeat
description: PLZEN, Czech Republic - One recent afternoon, Petr Osvald, a director of European affairs for the city council in Plzen, stood on the bridge above the Mze River and imagined the benefits that money from the European Union would bring to this city, just an hour's drive from the German border.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday with a music review of Wyclef Jean, at the Lincoln Center Festival, misidentified the site. It was Avery Fisher Hall, not Alice Tully Hall.

title: Milosevic Aides Found Guilty of Yugoslav Political Assassination
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, July 18 - The former director of Serbia's secret service, a onetime paramilitary commander and five others were given lengthy jail sentences by a Serbian court on Monday for the killing of a political rival to Slobodan Milosevic, then the Yugoslav leader.

title: Gavin Lambert, 80, Writer Who Chronicled Hollywood Life, Dies
description: LOS ANGELES, July 18 - Gavin Lambert, an incisive observer of life in Hollywood through his screenplays, novels and film histories, died on Sunday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 80.

description: The Mets resume their 10-game homestand tonight at Shea Stadium with the odds overwhelmingly in favor of a split.

title: That Gaze! That Hair! Those Trippy Tricks!
description: You might expect a young magician to emulate an established illusionist like David Copperfield or a legend like Harry Houdini. Criss Angel seems to want to be Jim Morrison.

title: The Case of the Writer Who Left Wall Street
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., July 19 - As a child living in Forest Hills, Queens, Peter Spiegelman invented a superhero whose stories he told in homemade comic books. Packed off to boarding schools as a teenager, he consumed vast helpings of crime fiction to while away the hours and fend off the boredom. Later, as an undergraduate at Vassar, he discovered 20th-century poets like T.S. Eliot and Wallace Stevens and composed somber poems that snared the college's top poetry prize.

Appeals Court Clarifies Rules on Family Limited Partnerships

title: Card firms change tone in approach to security
Colleagues call high court nominee a smart, self-effacing 'Eagle Scout'

New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: A Little Disagreement Among Friends in Queens
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has not yet said whether he will challenge the petitions of the man who intends to run against him in the Republican primary, Thomas V. Ognibene. But some people have beaten the mayor to it, among them one Bart Haggerty, a Queens Republican who happens to be the brother of a campaign aide to Mr. Bloomberg, John Haggerty Jr.

title: An Appreciation; Every Inch a General, Steely and Determined, but of a Steel That Did Not Bend
description: The thing about Gen. William C. Westmoreland was that he looked the part: straight back, bushy eyebrows, patrician nose, steely gaze, jutting jaw.

title: A Stolen Base for Boston Is Roberts's Ticket to San Diego
description: The most celebrated dash in the history of the Boston Red Sox has taken Dave Roberts across the country, up the batting order and back into first place.

title: Cycling: With 'best day' yet, Armstrong rolls smoothly along
Bush names John G. Roberts Jr. to Supreme Court
Bush's Supreme Court Choice Isa Judge Anchored in Modern Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 - Standing at the president's side Tuesday night, Judge John G. Roberts, a veteran of 39 arguments before the Supreme Court, spoke of his "profound appreciation" and "deep regard" for it.

title: Highs and Lows of Lesbian Parenting
description: "Making Grace" is a small, intimate documentary that patiently observes the highs and lows of a 30-something couple who want to become parents. That the couple are lesbians is perhaps the most remarkable feature of an unremarkable film; yet, in its very mundanity, the story of Ann Krsul and Leslie Sullivan is quiet proof that families are indeed created, not mandated.

title: Car bomb in Indian Kashmir kills at least six
Bush Defends Efforts to Secure Mass Transit
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - In his most extensive comments on homeland protection since the bombing attacks in London, President Bush today promised significantly higher spending on transit and port security and vowed that "these terrorists will not shake our will."

title: Europe seeks creation of unified credit-card clearing system
An Ultimate Capital Insider
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 - In nominating Judge John G. Roberts for the Supreme Court, President Bush, who likes to portray himself as an outsider to Washington and its culture, chose an ultimate insider in the capital.

title: How Harlem Could Electa White Council Member
description: For the last few generations, central Harlem has been the home turf of City Council members who were among the powerhouses of black politics in New York, including Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and J. Raymond Jones, the master organizer known as the "Harlem Fox." C. Virginia Fields, who in most polls is running second among Democratic mayoral candidates, held the seat during the 1990's.

title: Ritual and Faith in Epic Theater of Two Visionaries
description: It would be a major stretch to claim either of the large-scale novelties of this summer's Lincoln Center Festival for dance. Yes, both "I La Galigo" and "Le Dernier Caravansrail (Odysses)" contain ample movement, some of it very beautiful. But Robert Wilson and Ariane Mnouchkine are not falsely and deliberately billing dance as theater. They are not Matthew Bourne.

title: Northlich of Cincinnati To Open New York Office
description: Northlich, the biggest agency in Cincinnati, plans to open an office in New York next month.

title: Leaving Gaza, The price of lies, Enemies at home
Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, JOHN BURNETT
description: RUSSELL--John Burnett. Chapel Hill, NC, 82, on July 19, 2005. Former president of Burlington Industries International and chairman of Dan River International. He graduated from Pomfret School and in 1945 from Yale University. He served two years in the Navy during WW II and was awarded Man of the Year from the National Conference of Christians and Jews in 1976. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Cynthia Lee, five children, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the All Saints Church at 11 A.M. in Locust, N.J. on August 4. Donations to UNC Hospice in lieu of flowers.

title: In Shadows of a City of Pleasure, Courtesans Grow Old
description: The Dancing Girls of Lahore Selling Love and Saving Dreams in Pakistan's Ancient Pleasure District By Louise Brown. 311 pages. Fourth Estate. $23.95.

title: S.& P. Continues Its Rise and Nasdaq Resumes Rally
description: Shares rose yesterday, giving the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index its eighth gain in nine days, as profit reports from I.B.M., Merrill Lynch and other companies encouraged investors.

title: 2 Sunnis at Work on Constitution Are Shot Dead in Car in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 - Two Sunni Arabs involved in drafting Iraq's constitution were assassinated Tuesday afternoon on a busy street in central Baghdad, delivering a setback to the country's fledgling democratic process.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $967,500 725 Morris Park Avenue Bronx This mixed-use property has four three-bedroom apartments, office space and a coin-operated laundry. Buyer: Kim Chiep, New Rochelle Seller: Cupelli Construction, Bronx Broker: Mark Scholack, Massey Knakal

title: School Board May Have Stumbled Into Race Issue
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif. - When the regional school board prepared a plan to fill a new high school here, it made sure its boundaries did not cause any of the district's other high schools to end up with a minority population of more than 35 percent.

title: Sunnis Boycott Panel Drafting Charter for Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 20 - After the assassination of two colleagues, Sunni Arabs on the committee writing the new Iraqi constitution said Wednesday that they were temporarily withdrawing, a move that could delay the drafting and undermine the legitimacy of the American-backed political process.

title: Joined at the Hip
description: On the question of whether China's Cnooc oil company should be permitted by the U.S. government to purchase the U.S. oil and gas company Unocal, my view is very simple: let the market rule. Oil is fungible. It is all one global market. And if China wants to overpay for a second-tier U.S. energy company, that's China's business. Anyway, the more starved Americans are for oil, the sooner we will adopt alternatives and get off this drug once and for all.

title: HUD Refuses To Raise Rating For Newark
description: Federal housing officials opened the door yesterday to a takeover of the Newark Housing Authority by rejecting an appeal to reverse the agency's designation as "troubled."

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Metro to Buy A.&P. Unit
description: Metro Inc., Canada's third-biggest grocer, agreed to buy the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company's Canadian unit for 1.7 billion Canadian dollars ($1.39 billion) in cash and stock, almost doubling its stores and increasing its market share in Ontario, Canada's most populous province. The offer includes 1.2 billion Canadian dollars ($986 million) in cash and 500 million Canadian dollars ($411 million) in shares of Metro, the company said. Metro adds 236 A.&P., Dominion and Food Basics stores in Ontario with the purchase. Metro, which is based in Montreal and relies on Quebec for 90 percent of its sales, becomes a bigger rival for Loblaw Companies, controlled by the Toronto billionaire Galen Weston, which has more than 40 percent of the market in Ontario.

description: The Iraqi tribunal preparing Saddam Hussein's trial has been thrown into turmoil by the dismissal of 9 senior staff members and the threatened dismissal of 19 others. Page A9.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Whirlpool's bid to buy Maytag for $1.36 billion misidentified the takeover offer scheduled for a vote by Maytag shareholders on Aug. 19. It is the one from Ripplewood Holdings, another potential buyer, not the one from Haier, a Chinese company.

title: Avenue Queue
description: IF you happen by Manhattan's theater district this afternoon, matinee day, perhaps you'll notice a trend that has me baffled. I first spotted it when I set out to see "The Pillowman" one Friday night. Approaching the Booth Theater on West 45th Street, I was astonished to behold a long line, doubling back on itself a couple of times, snaking down Shubert Alley: hundreds of people inched their way toward the entrance.

title: German banks lose state support as shakeup of system begins
Lucas's New Headquarters Give Bay Area Film a Lift
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 - Daylight streams through the windows of George Lucas's gleaming new $350 million headquarters, situated conveniently -- and to some degree, surprisingly -- in the middle of the Presidio, a former Army post on the edge of this city, where the public can mingle beside the Yoda fountain with company employees.

title: With Otherworldly Grace, Portraying an Everyman
description: Lincoln Center Festival's curatorial decision to present the Javanese choreographer Mugiyono Kasido as a new voice in contemporary dance is a bit misleading. For him, the point of departure is the body -- so far, so traditional -- and while he is a splendid technician, his work, seen Monday at the Clark Studio Theater, is fairly tame conceptually.

title: Bush's Announcement On the Supreme Court
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's announcement that he was nominating Judge John G. Roberts to the Supreme Court and Judge Roberts's comments, as recorded by The New York Times. Video of the announcement is at nytimes.com/supremecourt.

title: Intel Says Earnings Rose 16% in Quarter
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 - Intel, the largest chip maker and a bellwether stock of the technology industry, reported Tuesday that its profit rose 16 percent because of healthy growth in the computer industry and strong demand for notebook computers.

title: Microsoft Sues Over Google's Hiring of a Former Executive
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 - Microsoft filed a lawsuit against Google on Tuesday asserting that Google hired away a Microsoft executive in violation of a clause in the executive's contract that precludes him for working for a competitor.

description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - President Bush urged senators today to give his nominee for the Supreme Court a "fair and timely" confirmation hearing, but some Democrats made it clear that it would be an exhaustive process, and perhaps heated, as well.

title: State Audit Accuses Yonkers of Underfinancing Public Schools
description: The City of Yonkers has chronically underfinanced its public schools and used risky financial practices to balance its books and cover the costs of operating the city, according to a state audit released yesterday.

title: National Briefing | New England: Rhode Island: Quarantine In Pet Virus Case
description: Health officials in Ohio have quarantined a pet distribution center in Zanesville after federal officials determined that a hamster carrying a virus blamed in the deaths of three organ recipients in southern New England in May was shipped to a Warwick, R.I., pet store from the center, Midsouth Distributors of Ohio. The transplant recipients who died all received organs from a Rhode Island resident who owned a hamster that tested positive for the disease, lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, or LCMV. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FELDMAN, ISABELLE
description: FELDMAN--Isabelle. Died peacefully on July 18, 2005 at age 94. Mother of Debbie Honigstock, Bonnie Weingard & Walter Feldman. Grandmother of eight and great grandmother of nine. Loved by all.

title: From the 80's, Time Capsules Uncorked
description: NO matter how much we think we understand about wine, the development of a bottle remains mysterious and unpredictable. Sure, scientists understand how a wine slowly incorporates oxygen over time, how tannins and acids soften as it ages and how flavors mature and mellow. But to predict how a particular bottle will evolve, and how people will perceive it, is as dicey a bet as stowing away a prom dress for your new baby girl. You can hope that in 18 years her taste will coincide with your expectations, but you probably shouldn't count on it.

description: WASHINGTON, July 19 - China is modernizing its military and emphasizing preparations "to fight and win short-duration, high-intensity conflicts" over Taiwan, the Pentagon said Tuesday with the release of its annual report on Chinese military power.

title: Kodak, Posting Another Loss, to Lay Off 10,000 Workers
description: Eastman Kodak said today it would lay off up to 10,000 more people because its film business was declining much faster than the company had anticipated.

title: U.S. Says 46 Pilots Lied to Obtain Their Licenses
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 - Prosecutors in Northern California have charged 46 pilots with lying to federal authorities to obtain airplane licenses, in most cases not disclosing debilitating illnesses that should have kept them grounded.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Murder Charge Rejected
description: A Jackson Heights man arrested Monday after fatally shooting his sister's estranged husband will not face murder charges because he was defending his sister and himself, the district attorney, Richard A. Brown, said yesterday. The man, Juan Carlos Duque, shot Boris Bunch about 5 a.m. after Mr. Bunch began beating his estranged wife, Sulay Duque, at Mr. Duque's house, a law enforcement official said. Mr. Duque fired three shots, hitting Mr. Bunch once in the chest, and striking a male and a female companion of Mr. Bunch in the leg. A spokeswoman for Mr. Brown said Mr. Duque was being held pending arraignment on charges of criminal possession of a weapon in the third and fourth degree. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Intelligence Briefing for Bush Is Overhauled
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 - The highly classified daily briefings prepared for President Bush have been expanded to include significant contributions from sources other than the Central Intelligence Agency, and will soon be modified further to absorb a separate daily terrorist threat assessment, two senior intelligence officials said on Tuesday.

description: An article last Wednesday about the political evolution of Hillary Rodham Clinton misstated a word in a comment from her interview with WABC radio in 2003. She said, "I am, you know, adamantly against illegal immigrants" -- not "illegal immigration."

description: A 2-year-old girl and her mother and grandmother were killed yesterday morning in a fire that swept through a Queens house that was home to 13 members of an extended family, witnesses and the authorities said. Nine firefighters were injured, and a fourth family member was critically injured.

Paid Notice: Deaths   QUIGLEY, GERARD JOSEPH
description: QUIGLEY--Gerard Joseph, on July 17, 2005 at Alexandria, VA. A Bronx native, graduate of Regis High School, Holy Cross and Catholic University. Worked with inner city youth, runaways, mentally challenged adults and terminally ill while with the Jesuit New York Province. Was an Assistant Dean at Fordham University and taught art at Fordham, Holy Cross and the Loyola School. With a heavily classical education, his art frequently explored and gave expression to the mystery of the sacred. He was a frequent illustrator for America Magazine. Survived by his father, Charles, and brother, Robert, a nephew, Michael, and two nieces, Caroline and Jeanne, all of Alexandria, VA. Reposing at Castle Hill Funeral Home, 1528 Castle Hill Ave., Bronx, NY, Thursday 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday 9:30 AM at St. Helena's Church, 1315 Olmstead Avenue, Bronx, New York. Interment, Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Hartford: New Job For Rell's Spokesman
description: Gov. M. Jodi Rell's chief spokesman, Dennis Schain, will become the director of communications for the State Department of Environmental Protection, the governor said yesterday. Mr. Schain, 53, of Manchester, was a reporter and worked in corporate communications before becoming Mrs. Rell's spokesman when she took office last July. Beginning Friday, he will succeed Matthew Fritz, who was named chief of staff for the Department of Environmental Protection. Mrs. Rell did not announce Mr. Schain's replacement. Stacey Stowe (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAGUIRE, ROBERT A.
description: MAGUIRE--Robert A. His many musician friends mourn his loss and will remember forever the delight of playing chamber music with this talented violist, a deeply generous, erudite, optimistic and funny man.

title: A City Too Hot to Bother With a Hero
description: IN the shorthand language of the police, a 10-54 took place Sunday evening on the shores of Coney Island. A 33-year-old male, beginning to drown, was rescued from the water and a 911 call was placed. The police and Emergency Medical Service personnel responded. Said male was taken to Coney Island Hospital, where he was listed in poor condition.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teacher Pact Seen By School's Start
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg predicted last night that he would have a "substantial" new deal with city teachers by the start of the school year. His comments about the contract talks, made to the Queens Jewish Community Council in Fresh Meadows, were among his most positive so far, and officials of the United Federation of Teachers said they took them as a sign that relations were improving and talks could soon bear fruit. The teachers' last contract expired two years ago.

title: Ford Motor's Earnings Decline 19% in the Quarter
description: DETROIT, July 19 - The Ford Motor Company reported a 19 percent decline in second-quarter earnings on Tuesday as it continues to struggle to keep American customers.

title: Georgia's Undemocratic Voter Law
description: Georgia has passed a disturbing new law that bars people from voting without government-issued photo identification and seems primarily focused on putting up obstacles for black and poor voters. The Justice Department is now weighing whether the law violates the Voting Rights Act. Clearly it does, and it should be blocked from taking effect.

title: Fields Camp, Trailing in Cash, Says Workers Have Been Paid
description: For months, the mayoral campaign of C. Virginia Fields has typically paid many of its consultants at the beginning of the month, dutifully registering the payments in its campaign finance filings every two months.

description: Leaders of several dissident unions warned yesterday that they might shun next week's A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention in Chicago unless the labor federation's president, John J. Sweeney, agreed to some of their demands.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Newspapers Still Silenced
description: Zimbabwe's largest independent newspapers, shut down by President Robert G. Mugabe's government nearly two years ago, have again been denied a government license to resume publishing, newspaper officials said. The newspapers, The Daily News and the weekly Daily News on Sunday, were the best-selling publications in Zimbabwe before being closed in September 2003. Both newspapers often criticized Mr. Mugabe's authoritarian rule. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Raw, Cooked and Both
description: REDEFINING both the shrimp cocktail and the summer salad has largely been the provenance of restaurants, but there's no reason a home cook can't quickly put together a highly spiced Mexican-style salad that is akin to ceviche.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: New Rochelle: More Legionnaires' Patients
description: The number of people who contracted Legionnaires' disease from a contaminated cooling tower near Sound Shore Medical Center has climbed to 18, a hospital spokesman said yesterday. Last week, Westchester County health officials announced that since June 21, they had identified at least 12 patients infected with the disease, a potentially lethal bacterial infection that strikes the elderly and people with weakened immune systems. All, including the six who came to light yesterday, used the hospital's outpatient entrance in the last month, and investigators believe they inhaled droplets of mist laden with Legionella bacteria from the tower, 50 feet away. The spokeswoman said the patients had either recovered or were hospitalized in stable condition. At least 10 people with symptoms similar to those of the disease, which resembles pneumonia or the flu, are being evaluated. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Los Angeles Times Names New Top Editor
description: John Carroll, the editor of The Los Angeles Times, said today that he was stepping down "for professional and personal reasons" and that Dean Baquet, the newspaper's managing editor, would take his place as top editor.

Patrolling the Border for Migrants From Mexico, With a Humanitarian Goal
description: SUNLAND PARK, N.M., July 16 - The small airport in this town on the edge of El Paso does more than straddle two countries. As seen by Armando Alarcon, an amateur pilot engrossed in an effort to prevent migrants from dying of thirst on their odyssey across the Chihuahuan Desert, it straddles two worlds.

title: Greenspan Signals Further Rate Increases in Testimony on Hill

title: Arts, Briefly; Mia Farrow Testifies For Roman Polanski
description: Mia Farrow, right, told a British court yesterday that Roman Polanski was in "really bad shape" when the two met at Elaine's restaurant in Manhattan for dinner in August 1969, soon after his wife, Sharon Tate, was murdered. Describing Mr. Polanski's mood at the time, she recalled his "utter sense of loss, of despair and bewilderment and shock and love" as they left the restaurant and "just walked around and around." Ms. Farrow, 60, was testifying on behalf of Mr. Polanski, 71, in his libel suit against Vanity Fair magazine. The magazine reported in 2002 that Lewis H. Lapham, the editor of Harper's Magazine, observed Mr. Polanski stroking the thigh of a "Swedish beauty" at Elaine's while en route to his wife's funeral in Los Angeles, spinning "a long honeyed spiel which ended with the promise 'And I will make another Sharon Tate out of you."' Although acknowledging that he went on a casual sex spree soon after Ms. Tate's murder, Mr. Polanski denied that the incident described by Mr. Lapham ever took place. Ms. Farrow said that when she was with Mr. Polanski at Elaine's, he ignored two women who were trying to flirt with him and that he spoke obsessively about Ms. Tate, who was eight months pregnant when she died, and about the couple's unborn child. Mr. Lapham, who is expected to stand by his account of what he saw, is scheduled to appear today on behalf of Vanity Fair.

title: 3 British Soldiers Face Abuse Trials

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Rock Star' Lacks Luster
description: CBS nearly swept every half-hour of Monday's ratings competition in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49, easily winning the night in Nielsen's estimates. The one chink in the CBS armor was "Rock Star: INXS" at 9:30 p.m., which was its only original offering on a schedule of repeats. Monday's episode of "Rock Star," during which the contestants tried on clothes and picked songs, drew 5.69 million viewers, putting it behind the second halves of both Fox's "Hell's Kitchen" (6.44 million for the 9 p.m. hour) and NBC's rerun of "Las Vegas" (5.85 million). CBS also won the week that ended on July 17 in total viewers for the seventh week in a row. On the strength of the All-Star Game, Fox was No. 1 among 18-to-49-year-olds. Friday's season premiere of "Battlestar Galactica" on the Sci Fi Channel brought in 3.05 million viewers, the show's highest figure to date. On cable, only an original episode of "Monk" on the USA Network did better, with 4.97 million.

title: Dialing for a Doctor, Some Got an Unexpected Earful, Prosecutor Says
description: WHITE PLAINS, July 19 - When Steven Showalter left an answering service in 1997 to start a rival business called Statcomm, he had at least a vague idea that his former boss, Gerald Martin, would be unhappy. But, the authorities said Tuesday, they were stunned at the lengths to which Mr. Martin went to sabotage his new competitor, at one point hacking into Statcomm's computer system so clients who called heard either a busy signal or lewd moans.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Large Type for Pittsburgh Authors

title: Anger Greets News That Death May Have Come Slowly to 3 Boys in Trunk
description: CAMDEN, N.J., July 19 - Anger. Fatigue. Disbelief.

title: Columbus Ave. Distances Itself From Broadway
description: Perhaps Columbus Avenue in the West 70's should be called the anti-Broadway, for its recently rising fortunes seem linked to the healthy, even haughty, retail distance it maintains from its thronged rival a couple of blocks to the west.

title: Briefly: EU agrees to provide traveler data to Canada
World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: A Call From France Tlcom
description: France Tlcom, Europe's second-largest phone company by sales, is considering an offer for Grupo Auna's Spanish mobile business Amena, which analysts say may be worth 9 billion euros ($10.8 billion). Auna, based in Barcelona, is Spain's third-largest mobile phone operator. A spokeswoman for France Tlcom said the company was not interested in Auna's cable assets. France Tlcom, which says it is Spain's second-biggest provider of Internet services, does not have a mobile business in Spain after losing its bid for a license in March 2000.

title: Such a Senseless Choice, It Makes Perfect Sense
description: THE now highly anticipated union of Larry Brown and Isiah Thomas would be doomed from the start, is sure to be as flammable as the War of the Roses, and can't possibly work. So it probably would.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 8 about the failure of officials to capture the two top wartime leaders of the Bosnian Serbs and turn them over for trials at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia misstated the title of Michael Johnson, who criticized NATO. He is a former chief of prosecutions for the tribunal, not the chief prosecutor.

title: Venture Firm and Ally Plan China Fund
description: SHANGHAI, July 19 - Accel Partners, one of Silicon Valley's biggest venture capital firms, said Tuesday that it would team up with the venture capital arm of the International Data Group, the American publisher and media company, to create a $250 million fund to invest in Chinese technology companies.

description: WATERS--Frank. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Frank Waters, associated with The Times from August 1966 until retiring in September 1980.

title: Chief Finance Officer No. 4 In 2 Years for Interpublic
description: The troubled Interpublic Group of Companies yesterday named its fourth chief financial officer in two years, hiring Frank Mergenthaler to succeed Robert Thompson, who announced last month that he would resign after a year on the job.

title: The Urban Migrants
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y. - Eight years ago, Sister Margaret Rose Smyth had to go out of her way to find illegal immigrants who might need her help, listening for Spanish conversations at the Kmart on the North Fork of Long Island.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: New Government Formed
description: Prime Minister Fouad Siniora announced the formation of Lebanon's first government since Syrian forces left in April. After 19 days of wrangling, President mile Lahoud agreed to a cabinet of 24 ministers, including, for the first time, one from Hezbollah, the guerrilla group labeled a terrorist organization by the United States. The government is dominated by anti-Syrian politicians, who were part of the effort to get Syria's military out of Lebanon after the assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri and 19 others in February. Leena Saidi (NYT)

title: Cutting College Aid, and Fostering Crime
description: One of the most irrational initiatives in the war on crime was a decision by Congress in the 1990's to cut off some ex-offenders from federal education aid. It's highly unlikely that anyone has been deterred from lawbreaking as a result. But if people who have paid their debts to society and are seeking new starts are denied education aid, they could well be locked out of the new economy and sent right back through the revolving door into prison.

title: The place Danes go to dream
World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Holocaust Denier Charged
description: Ernst Zndel, the internationally known Holocaust denier who was deported to his native Germany from Canada in March, has been charged with 14 counts of hate crimes, a court in Mannheim said. Prosecutors accuse Mr. Zndel, a 66-year-old white supremacist, of decades of anti-Semitic activities, including repeated denials of the Holocaust, which is a crime in Germany. Victor Homola (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, LOLA
description: KRAMER--Lola. We mourn the loss of a treasured friend. We will miss her intelligence, her sparkling wit, and her extraordinary courage. She will remain an inspiration for her compassion, her philanthropy, and her devotion to friends and family. Our sincere condolences to her beloved husband, Saul, her devoted children, Robert and Kathie, and her adored grandchildren. The world will be a colder and darker place without her. Marjorie and Jack Schleifer

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RANDISI, HON. MARTIN A.
description: RANDISI--Hon. Martin A. Class of 1948, Saint John's University School of Law. A talented, distinguished jurist possessed of impeccable legal scholarship. Totally devoted to his ever loving wife Anne, who has been his life's partner. Marty was a mainstay at Saint John's School of Law and held every leadership position that the University could bestow. His energy, commitment and strength will forever be remembered. Jerome Belson, Class of 1948 Saint John's University School of Law

title: U.S. Allies and Congress 'Positive' About India Nuclear Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 19 - A senior Bush administration official said Tuesday that the administration had gotten a "fairly positive" response among its allies overseas and Congressional leaders for a new agreement to give India help for its civilian nuclear program while allowing it to retain nuclear weapons.

title: That Gaze! That Hair! Those Trippy Tricks!
description: You might expect a young magician to emulate an established illusionist like David Copperfield or a legend like Harry Houdini. Criss Angel seems to want to be Jim Morrison.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 - A working draft of Iraq's new constitution would cede a strong role to Islamic law and could sharply curb women's rights, particularly in personal matters like divorce and family inheritance.

description: Austin,Tex. - WHICH American communities pay the highest price for the war in Iraq? A look at the demographics of soldiers killed reveals that Iraq is not the war of any one race or region. Rather, it is rural America's war.

title: Randolph Plays Down Mets' Latest Lineup Shakeup
description: Manager Willie Randolph did not see what the big deal was. All he did before last night's game against San Diego at Shea Stadium was drop Mike Piazza in the batting order to sixth from fifth and promote David Wright to fifth from sixth. But the swap led to a barrage of questions from reporters.

description: Boston Scientific, which has been steadily acquiring smaller companies to expand its portfolio of medical devices, said yesterday that accounting charges related to three such deals had cut its second-quarter net income by one-third, to $205 million.

title: Corrections
description: Entries in the Television section on Sunday for 13 cable channels at the bottom of each page of late-night program listings all this week were incorrect. The programs shown for the Oxygen Network (OXY) are actually those of Ovation (OVA); Ovation's symbol was omitted through a production error. Oxygen's symbol and those that follow should each move down one line, and WAM should be omitted, since it has no late-night listings. The last line, for WE, is correct. Listings in the daily newspaper have been corrected, and a corrected version of the page from the Sunday section is online at nytimes.com/television.

title: Funny Cide Having Trouble Winning as 5-Year-Old
description: Funny Cide looks fine, acts fine and trains fine in the mornings. It's the afternoons, when the races roll around, that are the problem. That's when he has been routinely thrashed. Funny Cide, the gelding who was the feel-good story of 2003 when he won the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness Stakes and the 3-year-old championship, is among this year's biggest disappointments.

description: DOYLE--Thomas M. Retired Senior Vice President, W.R. Grace & Co., Knight of Malta and Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Beloved husband of Ellen (nee Dennehy). Devoted father of Mary Ellen, Noreen, Thomas, Patrick, Martin, Vincent, Brendan, Denis and the late Arthur. Proud grandfather. Graduate of Xavier High School, 1939 and Fordham University, 1943. Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Teenager Admits Killing Deliveryman
description: One of three Queens men charged with the 2004 killing of a restaurant deliveryman pleaded guilty to murder and robbery yesterday, said the district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Nayquan Miller, 18, of 127th Avenue in Rochdale Village, admitted attacking Huang Chen, 18, after Mr. Chen delivered Chinese food to an apartment in Rochdale Village, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Chen was beaten with a bat, stabbed and dumped in a pond. Mr. Miller faces 20 years to life in prison at his sentencing in September. Charles Bryant, 18, of 147th Street in Rosedale, was convicted in March of murder and robbery for the attack, and William Capehart, 18, of Corona, was charged this week with murder.

title: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Teacher Fired Over Web Posting About Student
description: A former sports columnist for The Boston Herald was fired from a teaching job at Boston University after officials discovered he had posted comments about a female student on an Internet site. The former columnist, Michael Gee, who was hired to teach an introductory journalism class, was fired last Wednesday, the day officials learned of the posting, said Robert Zelnick, chairman of the university's journalism department. On July 5, Mr. Gee wrote on sportsjournalist.com, "of my six students, one (the smartest, wouldn't you know it) is incredibly hot" and, in another posting, wrote of the student's "to-die-for eyes," according to bostonsportsmedia.com. Katie Zezima (NYT)

Roberts, President Bush moved Tuesday to plant the conservative imprint on the Supreme Court that has been a central aim of his presidency, but with a member of the Washington legal establishment designed to frustrate any Democratic effort to block Mr. Bush's replacement for Justice Sandra Day O'Connor.

title: Top City Officials Arrested in Chicago Hiring Fraud
description: CHICAGO, July 19 - Two top city officials face charges in what federal prosecutors described as "pervasive fraud" in City Hall hiring and promotions, prompting Mayor Richard M. Daley on Tuesday to promise "fundamental changes" in his administration's personnel processes.

title: France and Britain renew EU battle
Scrutinizing John Roberts
description: The American people know little about Judge John Roberts, other than that President Bush is nominating him to fill Sandra Day O'Connor's seat on the Supreme Court. But in the coming weeks that should change. The Senate has a duty to scrutinize his background and to question him closely at his confirmation hearings about substantive areas of the law. If he is a mainstream conservative in the tradition of Justice O'Connor, he should be confirmed. But if on closer inspection he turns out to be an extreme ideologue with an agenda of stripping away important rights, he should not be.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Trooper Charged With Fraud
description: A state police sergeant accused of using other people's names to apply for credit cards has been charged with identity theft and fraud, Attorney General Peter C. Harvey said yesterday. Prosecutors said that Sgt. Gary L. Stolinski, of Mount Laurel, applied online for at least five credit cards from a state police computer, using people's identities without their knowledge. Capt. Al Della Fave of the state police said the sergeant had been suspended without pay. If convicted, he could face 15 years in prison. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: West Bank: Two Palestinians Killed
description: Security forces killed two wanted Palestinian militants during a gun battle in the West Bank, the military said. Israel has stepped up its military operations after a recent increase in violence. The militants belonged to Islamic Jihad and Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades, according to the military. Greg Myre (NYT)

title: Seeking Moderate Support, Blair Meets Muslim Leaders
description: LONDON, July 19 - Prime Minister Tony Blair met with moderate Muslim leaders on Tuesday, seeking to enlist their support against Islamic extremism and to discount the war in Iraq as the main cause for the London bombings this month.

POTTISH--Morris. The residents of the Kenilworth Apartments are saddened by the death of one of our longtime neighbors who served on the Board of Directors for many years. To his daughter Susan and his family we extend heartfelt condolences. Timothy Hogue, President Board of Directors Kenilworth Apartments
