description: DURHAM, N.C., July 19 - The American Dance Festival went globe-trotting on Monday night when it presented its annual International Choreographers Commissioning Program at Reynolds Industries Theater at Duke University here.

title: Chicagoans Look Deep Inside Their Pizzas and Find Art
description: Chicago - "EVERYBODY'S juices bubblin' and sizzlin' and spittin' inside: / And a crust that can be thick, when it needs to be thick / When it gets poked and fingered and belittled / And cast off as just another second-city helping, a flatlander's windy cheese."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOWD, MARGARET AGNES
description: DOWD -- Margaret Agnes. The staff of The New York Times was deeply saddened by the death of Peggy Dowd, the beloved mother of our colleague Maureen Dowd, on Sunday, July 17. Mrs. Dowd, who was 97, was born when Teddy Roosevelt was still building the Panama Canal and lived to see her children, grandchildren, and greatgrandchildren enjoy the marvels of the digital age. Her long and rich life was filled with the love of her family and her many friends and admirers, including generations of Times employees. Her boundless good humor, compassion and strength were inspiring to all those whose lives she touched. Faithful readers of the Times Op-Ed page knew her as the wise, wry and immensely humane observer on the profundities and oddities of life who appeared from time to time in Maureen Dowd's column. Margaret Agnes Dowd was the wife of the late Michael J. Dowd and mother of Michael J., Martin M., Margaret A., Kevin B. and Maureen B Dowd. She was grandmother of Dana, Jennifer, Michael, Tara, Brendan, Patrick and Brian; and great-grandmother of Anthony, Anna and Kasey. A Memorial Mass will be held at the Shrine of the Most Blessed Sacrament Church, Washington, D.C., at Western Avenue & Qesada Street, on Wednesday, July 27, at 11 A.M. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Multiple Sclerosis Society, National Chapter, 2021 K Street, NW, suite 715, Washington, DC 20006-1035.

Roberts of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit and offered him a place in history on the Supreme Court.

title: A Career Largely on One Side of the Bench and Involving a Wide Variety of Issues
description: John G. Roberts has been on the federal bench for two years, but he made his reputation on the other side of it, as one of the great Supreme Court advocates of his generation.

City's Success Built on Power to Seize Land
description: Stamford, Conn. - THE signs all over town herald Stamford as "The City That Works," a predictable enough bit of local boosterism with the added advantage of being mostly true -- especially downtown, where Stamford's business district is by far the biggest success story in a state known for wealthy suburbs and distressed cities.

title: A Poor Man's Porcini, in a Silly Hat
description: I FIRST saw the paper-white mushrooms, the shape of small garden gnomes, at the upscale markets. But at $16 to $20 a pound, I passed. However, when I saw a mountain of them at $5.50 a pound at a couple of indoor Chinatown markets, I biked home with a basketful.

title: Horseradish Has a New Teammate
description: Move over, pesto: horseradish is here with its refreshing bite. Horseradish dressings and horseradish crusts on fish are more popular than ever. Nip 'N Tang, a condiment made with horseradish and fruit, will give an entirely new personality to hot dogs, grilled chicken or fish. It can even be a glaze for rotisserie duck or a dip.

title: Rebel Kurds may have new enemy
To Many, Talk of a Crackdown in Pakistan Seems Hollow
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 19 - Three and a half years ago, in a speech that crystallized a post-Sept. 11 turnaround, President Pervez Musharraf vowed to eradicate extremism in his country. "We will take strict action against any Pakistani who is involved in terrorism inside the country or abroad," he said.

title: Chinese End Maytag Offer; 2 Suitors Left
description: A consortium led by Haier, a large Chinese conglomerate, abandoned its $1.28 billion bid for the appliance maker Maytag late yesterday, according to people involved in the negotiations. Haier's decision to drop its bid came just two days after the Whirlpool Corporation made a $1.36 billion offer for Maytag.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STAHL, JOSEPH
description: STAHL--Joseph, of Brookline, MA. Entered into rest July 18, 2005. Beloved husband of Reva (Silver). Devoted father of Bernard Stahl, Jeffrey & Dina Stahl, Lewis & Helene Stahl and Sharon Stahl Wexler & Howard Wexler. Loving brother of the late Jacob Stahl. Cherished grandfather of Allison, David, Jonathan, Evan and Jacob. Services were held at the Stanetsky Memorial Chapel, 1668 Beacon Street, Brookline, MA, on Tuesday, July 19, at 9 AM, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, New York, at 2 PM. Shiva will be at the home of Jeffrey & Dina Stahl. Expressions of sympathy may be donated to the Jewish National Fund.

title: Corrections

They had lived at least 13 hours, not 17. The article also misstated the earliest estimated time of death. It was 6:30 a.m. on June 23, not 10:30 a.m. An article about the community's reaction to the release of the new findings appears today on Page B7.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: Now that Cesare Casella, below, has opened Maremma, an outpost of what he calls the Tuscan wild West, will he trade in the signature bunch of rosemary that sprouts from his chest pocket at Beppe for a tuft of sagebrush? The Maremma region, on Tuscany's rugged coast, is cattle country. The restaurant, at 228 West 10th Street, in a duplex space designed by Larry Bogdanow with slate, wood and leather, serves a playful Italianesque take on Western grub, including sloppy Gios (sloppy Joes); a jackrabbit salad; a dish called the mess kit, with sausages and Texas onions; peppery campfire fish stew; and pork-fried steak. Tuscan chili is one of the side dishes: (212)645-0200.

title: Brown Leaves the Pistons; Knicks Leave a Door Open
description: The Detroit Pistons agreed to part ways with Larry Brown as their coach yesterday after a successful two-year run but following tense negotiations that had been developing over the last two weeks.

title: Modernist Music That Draws Whoops, Instead of Bravos
description: There is an image of the contemporary-music concert as an insider-only affair presented for audiences of two dozen people, three of whom are critics and half of whom are friends of the composers.

title: Draft Iraqi charter backs Islamic law
Arts and Science Remake the Steel City
description: PITTSBURGH, July 19 - Though the steel mills here started to cool off more than 20 years ago, the city seemed slow to shed its rusty old skin. The opportunity to recast its polluted industrial waterfront as a high-tech hub and recreation destination took nearly two decades to emerge.

title: Hewlett-Packard to Lay Off 14,500 in Turnaround Effort
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 - Hewlett-Packard announced Tuesday that it will lay off 14,500 workers, or nearly 10 percent of its staff, over the next 18 months as part of a revamping plan that the company's executives hope will turn around the struggling fortunes of the giant computer and printer maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STANLEY, CHARLES J., AKA CARLO PITTORE
description: STANLEY--Charles J., AKA Carlo Pittore. My dearest brother lived his life as he chose...to be a true and honest artist. He lived his life to its fullest--just not long enough. His wish was for all to appreciate his art. It was what he worked for and lived for. Art was his life. His inspiration came from not only learning from the masters, but from teaching his students. I shall remember my brother for his love of life, his true gratefulness for life, his art, and the wonderful love that he gave to his family and friends. Rest in peace, my dear brother. With love forever, Marion and Elliott

title: Who's Watching the Underwater Tunnels?
description: Correction Appended

title: Globalist:A deadly idea defies any simple doctrines
2 Men Charged in Slaying of Officer at Newark School
description: Two members of the Bloods gang were charged yesterday with first-degree murder in the schoolyard shooting death on Monday of a Newark school police officer who had intervened in a fistfight between two teenage girls, the authorities said.

title: Nets to Acquire Abdur-Rahim, Agent Says
description: It took a year and four days to plug the gaping hole left by Kenyon Martin, but the Nets finally did so yesterday, and perhaps pushed themselves back into the top tier of the Eastern Conference.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,763 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Very Premature Babies Are Still at Risk, Researchers Find
description: Children born prematurely at weights of 2.2 pounds or less during the 1990's have high rates of mental and physical disability, despite advances in treatment that doctors had hoped would improve their conditions, researchers are reporting today.

title: Yanks Get Gift, Then Give It Back
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 19 - It was a risk that Joe Torre and Mel Stottlemyre simply would not take. Mike Mussina had thrown 109 pitches through six innings in the broiling heat at Ameriquest Field, and they would not allow him any more.

title: Indonesia confirms its first human deaths linked to bird flu
Correction
description: An article on July 6 about ice box cakes misstated the dessert that won a French Culinary Institute honor for Deborah Snyder, the pastry chef at Lever House. Her winning recipe for best dessert revival was for a chocolate-mint ice box cake with mint chip ice cream, not a chocolate-peanut butter ice box cake.

title: Palestinians' president assails Hamas militants
Graves Back With Rangers for Off-Ice Job
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., July 19 - Somehow looking cool and comfortable in a royal blue warm-up suit Tuesday, Adam Graves strolled through the corridors of the Rangers' practice facility, which was still being built when he last played for the team.

title: Briefs: Storm gathers strength and takes aim at Texas
James Doohan, Scotty on 'Star Trek,' Dies at 85
description: James Doohan, who faked a Scottish burr to create one of television's most endearing characters, Chief Engineer Montgomery (Scotty) Scott of the U.S.S. Enterprise, died today at the age of 85.

title: Armstrong's Lead Unchanged After the Pyrenees
description: PAU, France, July 19 - Oscar Pereiro went from moral victor to genuine victor in the 16th stage of the Tour de France on Tuesday, and with the glow of triumph lighting his face, he said that all was forgiven. He will no longer speak badly of George Hincapie, at least not all the time.

title: Shell Turns a Stock Page but Has Chapters to Go
description: LONDON, July 19 - Royal Dutch/Shell begins trading as a unified oil company on Wednesday, ending a century of divided Dutch and British rule and beginning what its chief executive, Jeroen van der Veer, promises will be increased accountability, clarity and flexibility.

title: Empanadas, From the Classic to the Elvis
description: Empanada Mama, a new shop and cafe at 763 Ninth Avenue (51st Street), offers modest-sized empanadas with a choice of more than 25 fillings. There are classic pork, beef, chicken and cheese varieties, plus tuna and fried onions; spinach and cheese; Polish kielbasa and sauerkraut; mozzarella and tomato; and even an Elvis (peanut butter and banana), as well as sweet fillings like fig, caramel and cheese. They are $1.75 to $3. The bright little shop, owned by Socrates Nanas, above, and Javier Garca, is the Manhattan branch of a company that has two locations in Queens. In addition to empanadas, Empanada Mama sells tamales and slushy tropical drinks, including guanabana (soursop or custard apple), lulo (green orange), pineapple, mango and passion fruit. Drinks are $4.25 each. It's open daily, 9 a.m. to midnight: (212)698-9008. FOOD STUFF

title: John Seitz, 67, Father Figure on the Off Broadway Stage, Is Dead
description: John Seitz, a mainstay of the Off Broadway stage for 40 years, died on July 4 at an assisted-living residence in Baltimore. He was 67 and had lived most of his life in Manhattan.

title: Civilian Toll in Iraq Is Placed at Nearly 25,000
description: LONDON, July 19 - Almost 25,000 Iraqi civilians were killed in the two years since the United States-led invasion of the country, more than a third by American forces, according to a report released Tuesday that is sure to stir debate.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on July 14 about a decision by the Episcopal bishop of Connecticut to remove a priest from his duties referred incorrectly at one point to the clergymen known as the Connecticut Six, who oppose the ordination of gay bishops. They are priests, not bishops.(Go to Article)

title: Somers, sequinless and silly
William C. Westmoreland Is Dead at 91; General Led U.S. Troops in Vietnam
description: Correction Appended

title: Clarence Dennis, Builder of Machine Crucial to Heart Surgery, Dies at 96
description: Dr. Clarence Dennis, a pioneering developer of the heart-lung bypass machine and other mechanical heart devices that have extended the lives of millions, died on July 11 in St. Paul. He was 96.

title: Hussein Tribunal Shaken by Chalabi's Bid to Replace Staff
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 19 - The Iraqi tribunal preparing the trial of Saddam Hussein has been thrown into turmoil by the dismissal of nine senior staff members and a threat to dismiss 19 others, including the chief investigative judge.

title: Body of Long Island Climber Is Found Near Base in Pakistan
description: Search teams found the body of an expert rock climber from Long Island yesterday buried beneath an avalanche in remote northern Pakistan, not far from the base camp from where she disappeared during an afternoon hike on July 9, family members said.

title: Tribes of New York
description: At Belmont Park, as at racetracks across the country, exercise riders have plenty of guts and none of the glory. Their stories can be heard at nytimes.com/tribes.

title: The workplace: A bright light for the gray, Part 2
Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDBERG, IRWIN M., M.D.
description: FREEDBERG--Irwin M., M.D. The Department of Dermatology at the Weill Medical College of Cornell University and the New York-Presbyterian Hospital notes with great sorrow the passing of Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D., until recently the Chairman of the Department of Dermatology at New York University School of Medicine. Dr. Freedberg made unparalleled contributions to the practice and science of dermatology. He also trained many leaders in dermatology throughout the world. We have lost a valued and beloved colleague. Our condolences go to his family and his colleagues at N.Y.U. Richard D. Granstein, M.D. George W. Hambrick, Jr. Professor and Chairman Department of Dermatology Joan and Sanford I. Weill Medical College of Cornell University FREEDBERG--Irwin M. The New York State Society of Dermatology and Dermatologic Surgery records with great sadness, the passing of our colleague, Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D., and extends the condolences of its members to his family. Peter C. Lombardo, M.D., President FREEDBERG--Dr. Irwin M. The New York Dermatological Society mourns the passing of Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D., a loyal member, a friend, and mentor who made enormous contributions to our specialty. He will be greatly missed. R.D. Granstein, M.D., Pres.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (5) SO YOU THINK YOU CAN DANCE -- Series premiere. That means just about any kind of dance, from ballroom to hip-hop, from salsa to ballet. Fifty contestants fly to Los Angeles to work with choreographers and compete, "American Idol"-style. (The four above flew there just to audition, after missing the casting call in New York.) According to ublicity materials, "Some dancers wow the judges while others leave them speechless."

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 25 about a debate over whether autism is caused by thimerosal, a mercury-containing preservative once routinely used in vaccines, misattributed a statement that was part of an exchange in which a parent of an autistic child asked officials of the Minnesota Department of Health, "How did my daughter get so much mercury in her?" The final statement in the exchange, "Well, do you breathe the air?," was made by Patricia Segal-Freeman of the Health Department, not her colleague Kristen Ehresmann. (When read a transcript before publication, Ms. Ehresmann confirmed that she was the speaker in the exchange; she later acknowledged that the statement was made by Ms. Segal-Freeman.)

title: Friends Killed in Crash Had Just Bought Car
description: It was a used car, about a decade old, but in the eyes of the four friends from Brooklyn, it was new -- a tan Mercury Sable bought just last weekend from a man in New Jersey.

title: German Opposition Leader Stirs Up Politics in France
description: International Herald Tribune

title: An Emmy Surprise for 'Will & Grace'
description: There was one big surprise when the Emmy Award nominations were announced in Los Angeles last Thursday. Some results were fairly predictable: "Desperate Housewives," ABC's hot new Sunday night soap, received 15 nominations. The same network's equally hot new drama, "Lost," got 12. This year's sentimental sitcom favorite, "Everybody Loves Raymond," which ended its nine-year run on CBS in May, received 13.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINOGRAD, MARY ANN
description: WINOGRAD--Mary Ann, on July 17, 2005. Beloved wife of Steven. Loving mother of David. Devoted sister of Kevin, Kathy, Pat and Eileen. Family will receive friends on Wednesday 2-5 and 7-9 P.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street. Mass of Christian Burial Thursday 10 AM, St. Stephen of Hungary, 414 E 82 St. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, please call Frank E. Campbell 212-288-3500.

title: China Has an Ancient Mariner to Tell You About
description: NANJING, China, July 17 - The captivating tale of Zheng He, a Chinese eunuch who explored the Pacific and Indian Oceans with a mighty armada almost a century before Columbus discovered America, has long languished as a tantalizing footnote in China's imperial history.

title: Who's Minding Medicaid?
description: New York's Medicaid program has always had a reputation as the Cadillac of state health care programs. The 4.2 million people in the state's program have access to some of the best and most complete medical coverage in the country. The very fact that it's so generous makes it particularly critical that the public is assured that money is not being wasted. Unfortunately, the opposite seems to be true. As revealed by a year's investigation by Clifford J. Levy and Michael Luo of The Times, New York's $44.5 billion Medicaid program has become a honey pot for unscrupulous practitioners.

title: Today's Home Page Images
description: Photographs from today's home page of NYTimes.com.

title: Allow Me to Demonstrate
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Currents
description: Homage to a roller rink, at play with the Eameses, the campaign desk reborn and more.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Shade is a precious commodity, whether on a beach, near a pool or at a campsite. This season its providers come in many forms.

title: The Right Stuffing
description: Matthew Haly knows that when it comes to upholstered pieces, outward appearances mean little. It's what's deep inside that counts.

title: Bordello Modern
description: Lenny Kravitz designed his Miami and New Orleans homes with personal touches.

title: 'The Parachute Pavilion'
description: A contest to design a year-round pavilion at the base of the 262-foot-high Parachute Jump at Coney Island attracted 864 submissions from 46 countries.

title: Bolivia's Wrestlers
description: It's Bolivia's version of World Wrestling Entertainment: indigenous women wrestlers who wear traditional skirts, hats and shawls.

title: A Look at the Exhibits
A Nominee's School Days
description: Growing up, Supreme Court nominee Judge John G. Roberts was an active scholar and athlete.

title: A French Annus Horribilis: Now, English in Molire

title: Court Nominee's Life Is Rooted in Faith and Respect for Law
description: This article was reported and written by Todd S. Purdum, Jodi Wilgoren and Pam Belluck.

title: India welcomed as new sort of superpower
Paid Notice: Deaths   JOHNSON, SYDNEY P.
description: JOHNSON--Sydney P. 60, of Ridgefield, CT., husband of Cynthia and father of St. John on July 18, 2005 at his home. Graduate of Lehigh University and the University of York, U.K., he was formerly a VP of computers for Louis Harris & Associates and a 4th Degree Knight of Columbus. Service July 22, 11 AM, St. Patrick's Church, Bedford, NY.

title: Bill to Shield Journalists Gets Senate Panel Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - The Senate Judiciary Committee gave a generally positive reception on Wednesday to proposed legislation that would protect journalists from having to divulge confidential sources in most cases. But a harshly worded dissent from the Justice Department, which called the bill "bad public policy" that would hamper its ability to enforce the law and fight terrorism, underscored the difficult road the legislation faces in becoming law.

title: Training musicians, not stars, in China
A Montanan Keeps Trying for the Tour's Top Five
description: MENDE, France, July 21 - For a few minutes today, long after the first 10 riders had finished a testing daily stage, Levi Leipheimer seemed to have done it - to have capitalized on his next-to-last chance of fulfilling his ambition in the Tour de France. But it didn't happen, and now he is down to one final opportunity.

title: Polanski trial hears witness on advances
Another Stage Victory for Discovery Channel
description: Correction Appended

title: J.P. Morgan profit at low for year
National Briefing
description: WEST

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Industry Ratings Board Changes Label On Grand Theft Auto Game to 'Adults Only' The video game industry's ratings board changed the label on the game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas to "Adults Only" from "Mature," effectively removing it from most store shelves in the United States. [A1.]

title: A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad News
description: THE conventional news media are embattled. Attacked by both left and right in book after book, rocked by scandals, challenged by upstart bloggers, they have become a focus of controversy and concern. Their audience is in decline, their credibility with the public in shreds. In a recent poll conducted by the Annenberg Public Policy Center, 65 percent of the respondents thought that most news organizations, if they discover they've made a mistake, try to ignore it or cover it up, and 79 percent opined that a media company would hesitate to carry negative stories about a corporation from which it received substantial advertising revenues.

title: Despite a June Surge in Sales, G.M. Posts Another Losing Quarter
description: DETROIT, July 20 - General Motors reported its third consecutive losing quarter on Wednesday as surging sales in June did not translate into profits.

title: Bush makes Supreme Court choice
Formal Inquiry Begins in a Simmering Boeing-Airbus Dispute
description: BRUSSELS, July 20 - The World Trade Organization began its formal investigation Wednesday into billions of dollars in government support that Boeing and Airbus, the world's largest aircraft manufacturers, receive from the United States and the European Union.

title: A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudan's vows on Darfur doubted
In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Londoners Carry On Despite Chaos and Confusion
description: LONDON, July 21 - The rumors swirled around the city like poison gas. Smoke was billowing from three subway stations. A bus had exploded. There were chemical weapons, nail bombs, gas attacks. The London Underground had been put on "Code Amber," whatever that was.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Burundi: Peacekeepers Sent Home
description: Two United Nations peacekeepers in Burundi have been dismissed and sent home to Ethiopia for military punishment for having sex with prostitutes, one of whom was a minor. Under United Nations policy, peacekeepers are barred from having sex, even if it is consensual. A "zero tolerance" policy was adopted after peacekeepers were found earlier this year to have sexually abused women and girls in Congo. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Foreign Interference Condemned
description: President Vladimir V. Putin lashed out at foreign financing of political activities in Russia, saying "we won't permit it." Many human rights activists contend that the government wants to control the nation's fledgling nongovernmental organizations, partly out of a belief that Western financing has helped regime changes in Georgia, Ukraine and Kyrgyzstan. Sophia Kishkovsky (NYT)

title: House Panel Issues Subpoena Tied to Nuclear Waste Plan
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - The House subcommittee that is investigating falsification of research at the government project to bury nuclear waste at Yucca Mountain in Nevada issued a subpoena to the Energy Department on Wednesday.

title: As a Lawyer, Court Nominee Was Considered a Skillful Advocate for Corporate Clients
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLACKMAN, STANLEY F.
description: BLACKMAN--Stanley F. Age 88 died peacefully at home on July 18, 2005 surrounded by his loving family and devoted caregivers. He spent much of his life in Florida, graduating from the University of Miami in 1940 and serving in the Coast Guard during WWII. An inventor, he held numerous patents relating to pharmaceutical production. He manufactured pharmaceutical chemicals and drugs for major drug companies and for the US government. Consultant to firms in the US and abroad. He retired in 1980 as President of Stanley Blackman Labs, Inc. in South Hackensack, NJ. Devoted husband of June Rothberg and the late Doris Weinstein, he was "amazed" that he could love two women so deeply. Loving father and step-father of Betsy Blackman Wahmann (Chris) and Suzi Blackman Terven (Michael) and of Robert Rothberg (Carol) and Alan Rothberg (Debbie). Adored grandfather of Michael and Mark Rothberg, Kimberly Wahmann, Jennifer Stang (Michael), and Joseph Terven. Great-grandfather of Sydney and Gage Stang. Services were held. Information: "Gutterman's" 800-992-9262.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUKE, PAUL
description: DUKE--Paul. On behalf of the Board of Trustees, staff and volunteers of Educational Broadcasting Corporation, licensee of Thirteen/WNET and WLIW21, we express our profound sadness at the passing of Paul Duke and extend our condolences to his family. A journalist of the utmost integrity and fairness, Paul Duke represented the highest ideals of the profession. Always on target, always asking the right questions, he illuminated the critical issues of the day for countless Americans during his long tenure as moderator of "Washington Week in Review" on PBS. Paul Duke was an inspiration to all who work in public broadcasting, and we will strive to live up to the legacy of brilliance he left us. Steven Rattner, Chairman William F. Baker, President

title: Israel moves ahead on Gaza withdrawal
Tax Panel Wants to End Alternative Minimum Tax
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - President Bush's tax advisory commission will recommend abolishing the alternative minimum tax for individuals, the commission chairman said on Wednesday.

title: From Sailing Ships To Sleeping Porches
description: Outdoor furniture is easy to find, but a fine interpretation of a classic is rare. Penobscot Bay Porch Swings are handmade in Brunswick, Me., by two women, Sarah Bloy and Nan Bogart, who happened upon a traditional sailor's hammock on a sleeping porch a few years ago. They updated the design, making it half swing and half hammock, and created three versions. The swings, made of Sunbrella fabric in a choice of colors or stripes, start at $600, and one for babies, the Infant Swammock, is $150; (877)729-1616 or www.penobscotbayporchswings.com.

title: Irwin Freedberg, 74, Dermatologist and Professor, Is Dead
description: Dr. Irwin M. Freedberg, a dermatologist and an influential educator at New York University who led national medical organizations and advanced the study of the genetic foundation of the skin, hair and nails, died on Sunday at N.Y.U. Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 74.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on Monday about the Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto, Italy, misidentified the composer of a recently unearthed opera that will be performed at next year's festival. It was Vivaldi, not Verdi.

title: A French Annus Horribilis: Now, English in Molire
description: PARIS, July 20 - It seemed to begin as a bruising summer for the French.

title: A Young Ballerina Learns to Walk Through Open Doors
description: When Svetlana Zakharova was 10, her mother took her to an audition at a Kiev ballet school. Ms. Zakharova wanted none of it. She had no taste for ballet, positive or negative; her dread had more to do with the prospect of leaving her family, who lived in Lutsk, a town in western Ukraine.

title: The Quest Continues for Left-Handed Relief
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 20 - After the Yankees lost Ruben Sierra to an injury on Monday night, Manager Joe Torre and General Manager Brian Cashman discussed several options for filling Sierra's spot on the roster. That is the usual procedure; Cashman respects Torre's input and seeks it before making a move.

title: Armstrong Stars, but France Still Steals the Show
description: Albi, France - ON television, there is a different view of the Tour de France. Instead of the man in the yellow jersey (Lance Armstrong, that is to say), the star on the tube is the host country, which gave us this singular event.

title: Better Phone Reception and a Place to Dock, Too
description: For people who want to use their cellphones in apartments and houses as replacements for landline phones, reception can be a problem. Decent reception may be found in only one room or be available only when the user stands near a window.

title: Pfizer's earnings increase 21%
Algerian Diplomats Are Abducted in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 21 - The top Algerian diplomat in Iraq and a fellow envoy were abducted in the capital today by gunmen in what appeared to be the latest strike in the insurgent campaign to drive Muslim diplomats from the country.

title: INSIDE
description: The Saudi Ambassador To the U.S. Is Resigning Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's ambassador to the United States, is resigning for "private reasons," Saudi Arabia announced. In 22 years in the United States, Prince Bandar operated as an insider's insider and wielded enormous influence in Washington over successive administrations. He is to be replaced by another member of the royal family, Prince Turki al-Faisal. PAGE A3

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts on July 12 about efforts by the Lincoln Center Festival to promote its offerings and attract audiences misidentified the organizer of a news conference in Chinatown for the Chinese news media. It was Alan Chow of the Chinese-American Arts Council, not Shen Wei, a Chinese choreographer whose "Map" had its world premiere at the festival.

title: British Seeking Cleric's Top Aide in Connection With July 7 Attack
description: LONDON, July 20 - The police investigating the terrorist bombings here have begun a worldwide hunt for a former aide to one of Britain's most militant Islamic clerics who they believe may have played a key role in the July 7 attacks, according to British, European and American intelligence and law enforcement officials.

title: Bruschi to Sit Out the Patriots' Season of Many Questions
description: If the New England Patriots are to win a third consecutive Super Bowl, they will have to do it without Tedy Bruschi.

title: Shuttle Specialist Expects a Busy Mission
description: Capt. Wendy B. Lawrence of the Navy looks at her first space shuttle flight in 1995 almost as a vacation.

title: Public Transit and Security
description: Until the attacks in London two weeks ago, efforts to secure the trains and buses that carry some seven million riders through the New York City area every day have moved with too-deliberate speed. The state-run Metropolitan Transportation Authority, with some $600 million in state and federal funds to spend on system security, has managed to spend only a small fraction of that amount. The authority now says it is ready to spend more than half of the money by the end of the year, and spend it efficiently. That's welcome but overdue news. That nothing horrible has happened in the city's public transit system is no reason to put off what can be done now to reduce the risk of attack.

title: Mets' Triumvirate Makes Heads Spin
description: The Mets released their script for the second half of the season last night: Mike Piazza starring as the best No. 6 batter in the major leagues, Carlos Beltran as the slugger who hits home runs for pitchers besides Pedro Martinez, and Jose Reyes as the dervish who runs circles even around umpires.

title: Hopkins Appeals Split Decision
description: Bernard Hopkins appealed to the Nevada State Athletic Commission and the World Boxing Association yesterday to review the scoring of the 12th round of his loss to Jermain Taylor in their fight for the undisputed middleweight championship Saturday night in Las Vegas.

title: In Takeover Dance, the Chinese Miss a Step
description: Don't count the Chinese out just yet.

title: On The Street: Then
description: IN the early 1990's, Courtney Love resurrected the baby-doll smock, a look synonymous with the London youthquake of the 60's. The high-waisted, puffy-sleeved thrift-shop frocks she wore were soon identified with grunge. Before long would-be Courtneys followed suit, toughening up the look with track shoes or hiking boots. Today their counterparts take fashion cues from nouveau bohos like Sienna Miller, who accents her toddler-style dresses with calf-hugging boots and floppy hats. This fall Anna Sui and Antonio Marras of Kenzo paraded dressed-up interpretations in velvet or lam.

title: A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts
description: To the Editor:

title: Jim Parker Is Dead at 71; Kept Johnny Unitas Protected
description: Jim Parker, who was the first full-time offensive lineman elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame and is widely regarded as the best offensive lineman ever, died Monday at a nursing home in Columbia, Md. He was 71.

title: London bombings give U.S. stocks pause
Attorney General in New York Pushes to Punish Medicaid Fraud
description: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer called on state lawmakers yesterday to return to Albany to pass two bills that he said were urgently needed to help prosecute fraud in the state's Medicaid system.

title: These Musical Genres Are Made for Mashing
description: When it came time to pick a single to go with the movie adaptation of "The Dukes of Hazzard," the producers evidently faced a difficult choice. Did they want a raucous country song? A Britney Spears-style club track? An old hit that everybody knows? Something by the beloved veteran Willie Nelson, who appears in the film as Uncle Jesse? Something by the teen-pop-star-turned-reality-TV-star Jessica Simpson, who plays Daisy Duke?

title: When the Defense Is Hopeless, Sowing Confusion May Be Best
description: The Blackwood Award is given annually to a Hall of Fame inductee who has made a major contribution to the game outside expertise at the table. This year's winner is Marshall Miles of Redlands, Calif. This is a slightly surprising award because Miles has also been an expert player for several decades, having won four national titles and the 2004 World Senior Teams. But he has written many excellent books and articles and is a leading theorist.

title: Thompson, Comptroller, Starts Drive for 2nd Term
description: He is a candidate for citywide office with an overabundance of money for his campaign, and he has drawn support from prominent Democrats, like Edward I. Koch. But that is where his similarities with Michael R. Bloomberg end. William C. Thompson Jr. is a shoo-in for re-election as city comptroller, facing no competition in the Democratic primary and no Republican opponent in the general election in November.

title: Redecorate the Fridge With a Faster, Better Inkjet
description: "THE inkjet printer. An industry barely alive. Gentlemen, we can rebuild it. We have the technology. We can make it better than it was before. Better, cheaper, faster." (Music swells.)

title: In Training Video, Merck Said Vioxx Did Not Increase Risk of Heart Attack
description: ANGLETON, Tex., July 20 - Merck told its sales representatives that its painkiller Vioxx did not increase the risk of heart attacks, according to a Merck training video played on Wednesday for jurors in the first Vioxx lawsuit to reach trial.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Roche Earnings Rise Unexpectedly
description: Roche Holding, the world's biggest maker of cancer medicines, reported an unexpected earnings increase for the first half as demand grew for its drugs Avastin, Herceptin and Tarceva. Net income rose to 3.24 billion Swiss francs ($2.5 billion), from 3.12 billion francs in the year-earlier period. Sales rose 14 percent, to 16.6 billion francs. Roche, which received European approval for Avastin against colon cancer in January, is the only one of Europe's top five drug makers to obtain clearance for a new product with billion-dollar sales potential this year. Franz Humer, left, the chief executive, said, "We're growing more than three times faster than the market and our operating profit is growing considerably faster than sales."

title: Leaps of Imagination for the Parachute Jump
description: Correction Appended

title: Germany hankers for its heritage
Traditional culture strikes back
Funds in brief: Settlements for CIBC and ex-Amvescap officials
Is Pataki's Veto Latest Jab in Fight With Comptroller?
description: ALBANY, July 20 - Gov. George E. Pataki vetoed a bill this week that would have given State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi more flexibility in how he invests pension funds, causing the comptroller to shoot back on Wednesday that the veto was retribution for his blocking the governor's attempt to "raid the pension fund."

title: NASA Plans to Launch Space Shuttle on Tuesday
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - NASA will try to launch the space shuttle Discovery on Tuesday after having narrowed down the most likely cause of the fuel tank sensor problem that delayed last week's effort to fly for the first time since the Columbia disaster in 2003, space agency officials said Wednesday.

description: Johnson & Johnson's aggressive marketing of its heart-failure treatment Natrecor has become the subject of an inquiry by the Justice Department.

title: Ice in July Sounds Good to 700 N.H.L. Players
description: TORONTO, July 20 - After more than a year of bitter haggling and bluffing with National Hockey League owners, many of the league's more than 700 players said they were relieved about the prospect of returning to the ice this fall and collecting their paychecks again.

description: New York City will begin making random checks of bags and backpacks at subway stations, commuter railways and on buses, officials announced today in the wake of a second wave of bombings on the London transit system. The checks will begin on Friday morning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EISENBERG, ARLYNE (NEE KRAUS)
description: EISENBERG -- Arlyne (nee Kraus). On July 19, 2005 at age 75. Resident of Hewlett, New York and Hypoloxo, FL. Beloved wife of Albert J. Eisenberg for over 52 years. Loving mother of Leslie and Dennis Appleton, John and Jenny (Santiago), and Steven and JoAnn. Cherished grandmother of Melissa, Danielle, Adam, Marc and Amy. Devoted sister of Walter L. Kraus and sister-in-law of Shirley M. Jason. Donations in memory of Arlyne may be made to National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Services Thursday, July 21 at 1:30PM at the "Boulevard-Riverside Chapels," 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FOX, EUGENE J., ESQUIRE
description: FOX--Eugene J., Esquire, on July 20, 2005. Beloved husband of Mary Christina (nee Finn). Cherished father of Christina A. Wondsel (husband Glenn D.) and Eugene J. Devoted grandfather of Matthew, Sarah & Connor. Loving brother of Joseph, Francis, John and the late Donald. Reposing Thursday 7-9PM and Friday 2-4 & 7-9PM at Riverdale-onHudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Ave, Bronx. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday 9:45 AM at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery.

title: Air Safety Officials Reveal a Near Collision at Kennedy Airport This Month
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - A fully fueled wide-body jet carrying an unknown number of passengers apparently blundered onto a runway at Kennedy International Airport and into the path of a cargo plane accelerating for takeoff two weeks ago, federal safety officials said on Wednesday. They said that the crew of the cargo plane narrowly prevented a collision by taking off early.

title: Sides Square Off Verbally in the Howard Beach Case
description: After lashing out yesterday at prosecutors and the news media, relatives and supporters of Glenn Moore, a black man who was beaten by a white man with a baseball bat last month in Howard Beach, met with District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens.

title: Bomb Kills 4, Injures 18 in Indian-Held Kashmir
description: NEW DELHI, July 20 - A car bomb hit a small army convoy on Wednesday in Srinagar, the summer capital of Indian-administered Kashmir, killing at least three soldiers and a civilian.

Nominee Gave Quiet Advice on Recount
description: MIAMI, July 20 - John G. Roberts advised Gov. Jeb Bush during Florida's presidential recount in 2000, even traveling to Tallahassee from Washington to help him navigate those frenzied 36 days.

title: Title Insurers Agree to $23 Million Settlement of Kickback Charges
description: The three largest title insurers in the country agreed yesterday to pay $22.8 million to settle charges that they paid kickbacks for business referrals, as investigations into the title insurance industry continue in more than a dozen states.

description: "It is not a gorgeous plush studio," said the Oz-like voice behind "The Music Museum" before the show went on the air. "You have to promise me you won't tell. Radio is theater of the mind."

title: Free flow: Shippers think huge for growth
Rearranging the Furniture As an Act of Protest
description: Furniture plays a major role in "The Edukators," an award-winning film that tells a story of three radicals who protest the ravages of capitalism in Berlin by breaking into mansions and, in an act of nonviolent but annoying protest, rearrange sofas, chairs and televisions in startling tableaus. A deep-cushioned sofa goes into a swimming pool. Chrome-legged chairs, below, are stacked in pyramids. The three scrawl a warning -- "Your days of plenty are numbered," for example -- nearby. The film opens tomorrow in New York and on July 29 in Los Angeles, with other cities to follow. ELAINE LOUIE CURRENTS: MOVIES

title: Tracking the Dead (Not the Band) of Rock 'n' Roll
description: Killing Yourself to Live 85% of a True Story By Chuck Klosterman 245 pages. Scribner. $23.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on July 9 about an influential cardinal's skepticism on evolutionary theory referred imprecisely to the Roman Catholic Church's position on stem cell research. The church opposes such research with cells from human embryos that are then discarded; it does not oppose stem cell research in general.

title: Weakness in Trading Crimps Profit at J.P. Morgan
description: J.P. Morgan Chase reported a profit for the second quarter yesterday as its consumer businesses posted healthy gains, but poor trading results and a big legal settlement cut into its results.

NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Kodak expands layoffs by 10,000
New Emission Rule for Bay Area Refineries
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 - California air regulators on Wednesday adopted a rule, the first of its kind in the nation, intended to reduce sharply the fiery flares and excess gas emissions vented from oil refineries in the Bay Area.

title: Listening to the bones of an ancestor
Israel Defeats Efforts to Delay Gaza Pullout; Protest Thwarted Again
description: JERUSALEM, July 20 - Israel's Parliament on Wednesday easily voted down three bills aimed at delaying the withdrawal of Jewish settlers from the Gaza Strip, while in southern Israel, for the third straight day, security forces prevented pro-settlement demonstrators from marching on Gaza.

title: Sunni Arabs suspend work on Iraq constitution
O'Brien Hopes Injuries Are a Tweak of the Past
description: The tug in John O'Brien's right hamstring last November might as well have been a pull at his morale.

title: Off Course in Iraq
description: Most of the Bush administration's justifications for invading Iraq have turned out to be wrong. But the one surviving argument for overthrowing Saddam Hussein has been an important one: it was a chance to bring freedom and equality to the citizens suffering under a brutal dictatorship. For those of us holding onto that hope, this week brought disheartening news on multiple fronts.

title: Sunnis Boycott Panel Drafting Charter for Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 20 - After the assassination of two colleagues, Sunni Arabs on the committee writing the new Iraqi constitution said Wednesday that they were temporarily withdrawing, a move that could delay the drafting and undermine the legitimacy of the American-backed political process.

title: N.H.L. on Offense to Win Back Fans
description: When major league baseball returned from the players' strike that eliminated the 1994 World Series, it gradually regained public interest by increasing offense, particularly its home run totals.

title: A Range of Movement From Surreal to Dogged
description: Shen Wei, the Chinese-born, New York-based modern-dance choreographer (and actor and painter and calligrapher, as he likes to point out), first attracted national attention at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., in 1995. He has appeared regularly there, and he formed his Shen Wei Dance Arts company there in 2000.

title: News Analysis: Bush aims to disarm opposition
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "If he understood the concept, I was good. If not, teach it all over again"

title: EBay, With a Global Boost, Beats Wall Street Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 - EBay, the online marketplace, surprised investors on Wednesday when it reported that earnings rose 53 percent in the second quarter, driven by growth in international business.

description: It is considered pure coincidence that Mike Piazza dropped in the batting order on the same day Ramon Hernandez showed up at Shea Stadium.

Metro Briefing | New York: Garden City: Removal Of Files To Be Checked
description: The Nassau County district attorney, Denis Dillon, agreed yesterday to review County Clerk Karen V. Murphy's removal of eight boxes of files from her office last Friday. He acted at the request of the Nassau comptroller, Howard S. Weitzman, who accused Ms. Murphy of thwarting an audit and subpoenaed her records after learning of the removal. She said that she has taken work home for 12 years, and that the boxes held documents to be mailed. "I'm actually stuffing envelopes," she said, because rising workloads and inadequate staffing has created a three-year backlog. Ms. Murphy, a Republican, said she did not thwart auditors and accused Mr. Weitzman, a Democrat, of playing politics because she is running for judge. Mr. Weitzman denied Ms. Murphy's accusations and called her actions "bizarre." Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: Gerry Thomas, Who Thought Up the TV Dinner, Is Dead at 83
description: Correction Appended

title: Calling In Envoy, Beijing Assails Pentagon Report
description: BEIJING, July 20 - China's Foreign Ministry called in a senior American diplomat in Beijing on Wednesday to denounce a Pentagon report on China's military strength. The United States report, released Tuesday, was "groundless" and based on "reckless accusations," the vice foreign minister, Yang Jiechi, told David Sedney, the deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Beijing.

title: An Interview By, Not With, The President
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - When President Bush sat down in the White House residence last Thursday to interview a potential Supreme Court nominee, Judge J. Harvie Wilkinson III of the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, he asked him about the hardest decision he had ever made -- and also how much he exercised.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Petition Intrigue Continues
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he could very well join the challenge against the nominating petitions of Thomas V. Ognibene, the former City Council minority leader who wants to run against the mayor in the Republican primary. "We do have laws that say that if you want to be on the ballot, you do have a certain level of support, you have to be able to demonstrate that," the mayor told reporters. Mr. Bloomberg said his position did not contradict his stand during his losing fight two years ago for nonpartisan elections, when he argued that the system discriminated against challengers. "Even in nonpartisan elections, you would have to go through a virtually identical process of showing minimal support," he said. Mr. Ognibene's campaign charged yesterday that a man who is helping in the challenge against his petitions, John Haggerty Jr., who also happens to be a consultant to Mr. Bloomberg, was apparently working for Mr. Bloomberg's campaign without pay. His name does not appear in Mr. Bloomberg's expense filings. The Bloomberg's campaign, however, said that his services were not being donated, but rather he had not yet submitted a bill. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: World Briefing | United Nations: Oil-For-Food Panel To Get More Money
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said he had accepted a request for increased financing for the panel led by Paul A. Volcker that is investigating mismanagement and possible corruption in the oil-for-food program in Iraq from its initial request of $30.9 million to a new figure of $35.1 million. The panel said it needed the money to pay for a four-month extension in its completion date to the end of October. Iraq has protested the continuing use of Iraqi funds to pay for the investigation, but in a letter to Samir Sumaidaie, Iraq's ambassador, Mr. Annan said the conclusion of the inquiry was "very much in the interests of your government and the Iraqi people." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Don't look now, but Europe is in outer space
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Hybrid Cars To Join Taxi Fleet
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill yesterday that requires the Taxi and Limousine Commission to approve, within 90 days, at least one hybrid vehicle model for use as a taxicab. The City Council members who introduced the measure said they did so because no alternative-fuel vehicles are in use, even though a Council bill in 2003 called for the sale of special medallions to encourage the use of cleaner fuels. Environmentalists applauded the bill signing. One of them, Marcia Bystryn, the executive director of the New York League of Conservation Voters, said that hybrid cars have far greater fuel efficiency because they combine a small gasoline engine with an electric motor that recharges automatically. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Hong Kong allows sale of public space to trust
Officer's Killer Got Out in May, the Police Say
description: NEWARK, July 20 - A man who the police say shot and killed a Newark school police officer this week was released from jail in May after a charge of attempted murder was dismissed when a witness changed her story.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: More Riots Over Constitution
description: Riot police clashed with demonstrators for the second consecutive day, as hundreds in Nairobi pushed for changes in the country's Constitution. President Mwai Kibaki has been criticized for backing away from reforms that would reduce the powers of the presidency and create a new prime minister's post. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Bid to Honor 9/11 Victims Comes to End
description: EASTON, Conn., July 20 - After a couple here lost their son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter on 9/11, residents of this small town urged, and town officials resolved, to establish a memorial at the town's new elementary school.

Greenspan favors steadily rising rates
Filibuster on Supreme Court Nominee Appears Unlikely
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 - The possibility of a filibuster against John G. Roberts, President Bush's nominee to the Supreme Court, appeared to recede today, as several Democrats emerged from a meeting of swing senators to say they did not envision their party trying to block the nomination.

title: Acquittals and Mistrial in Enron Unit Cases
description: HOUSTON, July 20 - After four days of jury deliberations, a federal judge declared a mistrial on Wednesday on all but a handful of 164 counts against five former Enron executives who were accused of overstating the strength of the company's broadband services division.

title: Fed to Keep Rate Policy in Place
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Wednesday that the central bank would keep raising interest rates and gave little hint of when it might stop.

title: Arts, Briefly; Pop Charts: R. Kelly Holds On
description: R. Kelly's new album, "TP.3 Reloaded" (Jive), last week's best seller, held on to the No. 1 spot on the Billboard chart this week, but just barely. Its 139,000 sales beat the Houston rapper Slim Thug's "Already Platinum" (Geffen/Interscope) by about 10,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. Bow Wow, the not-so-young-anymore rapper once known as Lil' Bow Wow, was close by at No.3, with 119,000 copies for his new album, "Wanted" (Columbia). Meanwhile, Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol), at No. 4, and Mariah Carey's "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam), at No.5, held strong as the most durable hits of the summer; each sold just fewer than 100,000 copies during the week that ended on Sunday. Farther down the chart, Carole King scored her highest position in 28 years with "The Living Room Tour," above, (Concord). It opened at No.17 with sales of 44,000; the last time she reached that high on the Billboard chart was in 1977, with her album "Simple Things." BEN SISARIO

title: Cold Paper Trail Leads Some to Scrutinize Nominee's Past Words on Abortion
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - In the late 1980's and early 1990's, lawyers for the first Bush administration repeatedly argued before the Supreme Court for the reversal or rollback of Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision recognizing a constitutional right to abortion. Protests roiled the streets, and blockades shook the abortion clinics.

title: China's steel policy reduces makers
Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Pastor Admits Theft Of Church Funds
description: The former pastor of Morning Star Missionary Baptist Church in Jamaica pleaded guilty yesterday to grand larceny in the theft of $31,800 from the church, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. The Rev. Charles Betts, 69, the pastor from 1971 until his resignation in 2003, is scheduled to be sentenced to five years' probation in September and required to make restitution. His former administrative assistant, Anna Lenore Kilpatrick, and her husband, Barry Kilpatrick, have also been charged with grand larceny in connection with the theft, prosecutors said.

title: First Rule for a Mitchum Man? Don't Read the Subway Rules
description: On hundreds of subway cars, advertisements for Mitchum, a line of deodorants, are carrying playful messages that presumably evoke the can-do virility of the men in their 20's and 30's at whom the product is aimed. "If you've ever hurdled anything while running for the train," one ad proclaims, "you're a Mitchum Man."

title: Liberated by the Slaughterhouse
description: The producers of "The Gut Girls," a play set in late-Victorian London about women who scraped entrails from slaughtered animals, were giving out free bottles of cold water and paper fans earlier this week. It fit the mood of the moment, as fiction and fact met in an industrial-like space at the Chocolate Factory in Long Island City that set one small portable air-conditioner against the high temperatures and humidity.

title: Homage to a Roller Rink: Day-Glo Circles and Synthetic Rabbit
description: The New York architect M. Ali Tayar, above at left, has drawn from 1970's roller rinks and 1980's pop art in creating a look for Pizza Bar, which Roy Liebenthal, at right, and Sasha Tcherevkoff opened this week in the meatpacking district.

title: Court Nominee's Life Is Rooted in Faith and Respect for Law
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - He is the son of a company man, and he has lived a loyalist's life. His teachers remember him as the brightest of boys, but his classmates say he never lorded it over them. He was always conservative, but not doctrinaire. He was raised and remains a practicing Roman Catholic who declines, friends say, to wear his faith on his sleeve.

title: Adding Up the Oil-for-Food Payoffs
description: "IN my old age," Paul A. Volcker, the former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told me, "I've learned that there's a lot of corruption in the world." Mr. Volcker, who heads the independent committee investigating the United Nations oil-for-food program in Iraq, was not talking about the program per se, but about corruption in general.

title: Bold Bathroom Tiles
description: Q. I'd like to replace the tile in my bathroom with something besides the usual plain four inch squares. What styles and patterns can you suggest?

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Cinemax) THE DOOR IN THE FLOOR -- (2004) Ted and Marion Cole (Jeff Bridges and Kim Basinger, above) have a great house in the Hamptons and a beautiful little daughter, but they can't get over the death of their sons. Ted numbs the pain with alcohol, adultery and his celebrity as a children's book author and illustrator. Marion just has an affair with her husband's new teenage assistant.

title: A Mac Option for the Music Producer Who Wants More Control
description: With its library of sound samples and easy-to-use interface, the GarageBand program from Apple has been helping Macintosh mavens create and mix their own musical compositions since it was introduced early last year.

title: Iraqi Insurgents Aided by Hussein's Nephews, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - The Treasury Department today identified four nephews of Saddam Hussein who it said had played significant roles from bases in Syria in providing money, weapons, explosives and other support to the anti-American insurgency in Iraq.

title: Save PC's From the Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: The women of Guantnamo

description: A month ago, Sanford I. Weill basked in the limelight as more than 300 Wall Street power brokers, elite dignitaries and political insiders filled tents outside his Greenwich, Conn., mansion, joining him and his wife, Joan, to celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary.

title: In American Cities, No Mirror Image of Muslims of Leeds
description: After the four suicide bombers in London were identified last week, news accounts focused on life in the old mill town of Leeds, where they grew up: the immigrant enclaves, the high unemployment, the rising anger and alienation of Muslim residents. Some Britons grasping for an explanation pointed at those conditions, however tentative their link to homegrown terrorism.

title: NATO adds troops for Afghan election
Knicks Hope Brown Picks Them as His Next Project
description: Larry Brown's rsum is so lengthy that it could fill a beach towel and so rife with twists and turns that it could be modeled after a Tom Clancy novel. Brown's career has been chaotic and at times controversial, yet the Knicks can hardly wait to write themselves in as the next chapter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, FRED
description: BROWN--Fred. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member Dr. Fred Brown. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred D. Youngwood, Pres

title: Briefly: Saudi envoy is quitting for 'private reasons'
Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about a British intelligence report that led the government to lower its terror alert three weeks before the July 7 bombings in London misstated the age of Mohammad Sidique Khan, one of the suspected bombers who died in the attacks. He was 30, not 22.

title: Weight-Loss Theory Is Losing Some of Its Strength
description: BARBARA WOODWORTH, 35, a social worker in Seattle, wanted to drop 40 pounds. Alisa Rivera, 39, a college adviser at the University of California, Los Angeles, also wanted to lose weight. She also wanted to build long, lean muscle. So the two women routinely began to lift weights. But like many of the other 36 million women nationwide who each year pick up dumbbells hoping to lose pounds or develop a sculptured body, both Ms. Woodworth and Ms. Rivera ended up disappointed because the strategy is not as simple -- or as effective -- as it sounds.

title: British Police Evacuate 3 Subway Stations After Explosions
description: LONDON, July 21 - Just two weeks after a string of attacks on buses and subways in London that killed 56 people, the British police evacuated three subway stations in the city today after small explosions that sent commuters into a panic. But casualty numbers appeared to be low. The police said the Oval subway station in south London, Shepherd's Bush in the west and Warren Street in central London had been evacuated. There was also a small explosion on the No. 26 bus in the Hackney Road section that blew out the bus windows, police said.

title: Police Officer Is Accused of Deception
description: Officer Michael Forman of the Suffolk County Police Department told departmental doctors in April 2003 that he had hurt his wrist while on duty, and for the next two years he continued telling them that the injury was too painful for him to drive a patrol car, county officials said yesterday.

title: Transit Union Hires a Security Trainer, Saying M.T.A. Is Not Doing Enough
description: Transit union officials, charging that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has not done enough to prepare workers for the possibility of a terrorist attack, said yesterday that they had hired a Israeli security expert to train subway and bus workers in recognizing suspicious packages and passengers.

title: Northwest at an Impasse in Talks With Mechanics
description: The clock is officially ticking on a 30-day cooling-off period in the labor dispute between Northwest Airlines and its mechanics' union. After that, the union could strike or the airline could impose the $176 million in cuts that it wants -- but neither is certain.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: A Plan to Create 2 Big Steel Makers From 264
description: China, whose 264 steel makers supply a third of the world's steel, plans to shut smaller producers and force mergers to create two companies big enough to compete on world markets, the National Development and Reform Commission, the country's top planning agency, said. The two companies would each be able to make more than 30 million metric tons a year by 2010, the commission said. The Shanghai Baosteel Group, China's biggest steel maker, last year made 21.4 million tons, compared with about 59 million tons from Mittal Steel, the world's leader. China has been trying to rein in expansion after output doubled in four years, driving up prices of iron and coal and spurring inflation.

title: News Release From China's Central Bank
description: Following is the text of the news release from The People's Bank of China announcing that it will no longer peg the yuan to the dollar.

description: To the Editor:
