Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHAFFER, LAURENCE
description: SCHAFFER--Laurence on July 19, 2005. Beloved husband of Loretta, devoted father of Roni, cherished grandfather of Jamie and Jocelyn. Loving son of Milton and the late Harriet. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Piero Cappuccilli, 75, Rich-Voiced Baritone, Is Dead
description: Piero Cappuccilli, considered one of the finest Italian baritones of his generation, died on July12 in Trieste, Italy. He was 75.

title: Democrats and Allies Lament Lack of Record
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - Democrats and liberal advocacy groups scrambled on Wednesday to see if they could -- or should -- build a case against the Supreme Court nomination of John G. Roberts. They said they would demand memorandums, briefs and other documents he wrote as a deputy in the solicitor general's office to flesh out an understanding of the views of this conservative newcomer to the federal judiciary.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Food and Drug Administration's decision to change the label of the abortion drug Mifeprex after the deaths of two women in California, to include a warning of possible bacterial infection, misstated its generic name. It is mifepristone. (Misoprostol is the drug taken after mifepristone to induce abortion early in pregnancy.)

title: A Competent Conservative
description: Roberts nomination, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways.

title: Chief quits Wal-Mart's Japan unit
Briefs: EU backs extension for Portugal
Stocking Up for Fall in a Time of Bikinis
description: SUMMER sales have been picked clean, and most stores are not yet stocked for fall, but a few Web sites are getting a jump on autumn, offering crisp-weather fashions before they line the racks of your favorite stores.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: War Criminal's Appeal Denied
description: A panel of five judges at the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague denied an appeal and confirmed a 10-year prison sentence for Miroslav Deronjic, left, a former Bosnian Serb politician who confessed to ordering the destruction of a village in 1992 in which more than 60 Muslims were killed. Mr. Deronjic, an important prosecution witness in the trial of Slobodan Milosevic, originally pleaded not guilty, but later reached a plea bargain by assuming responsibility for ordering the village be razed. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: Long Ball Lifts Small in Yankees' Debut
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 20 - The Huskies of South Hills High School in West Covina, Calif., made it all the way to the 1989 state title game at Anaheim Stadium. Their two ace starting pitchers led the way.

title: Consumer Philosophy by Tar-zhay
description: WHEN Siddhartha Gautama, the young man who later became known as Buddha, attained enlightenment, he saw the path to fulfillment: keep earthly belongings to a minimum. Stuff -- material possessions, goodies, thingamajigs -- was spiritual dead weight.

title: China far outpaces India in Web use
Karl Rove: the real story
Metro Briefing | New York: West Nyack: Mall Evacuated In Bomb Scare
description: Tens of thousands of people were evacuated from the Palisades Mall in Rockland County after a suspicious package was spotted yesterday afternoon. Local police exploded the package, which was found by a security guard in a bathroom on the mall's third floor near the food court, said a spokesman for the Clarkstown Police Department, Sgt. Harry Baumann. About 30,000 people were evacuated, tying up evening traffic on the New York State Thruway and local streets and roads, the police said. Sergeant Baumann said the package, a 6-inch box wrapped in tinfoil with wires sticking out of it, contained no explosives. The mall reopened about 7 p.m. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Philadelphia Gallery, At Play With the Eameses
description: "Whimsical Toys: The Playful Designs of Charles and Ray Eames" opens tomorrow at the Arthur Ross Gallery at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. The exhibition highlights the Eameses' lesser-known works, including children's plywood furniture from 1945, which preceded their adult designs, and toys, including a building set called the Toy (below, with Ray Eames). "Toys and games are the preludes to serious ideas," Charles Eames said once, explaining why they liked things for tots. The exhibition, which runs through Sept. 11, includes drawings from the Eames collection at the Library of Congress and 3 films of the 100 by the couple featuring objects from their collections of things like toy trains and tops (above). Children are invited to use a video camera to make films. The Arthur Ross Gallery is at 220 S. 34th Street in Philadelphia, (215)898-3617. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: DESIGN FOR CHILDREN

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Chief Executive Resigns at Wal-Mart Affiliate
description: The chief executive of the supermarket chain Seiyu, the Japanese affiliate of Wal-Mart Stores, resigned as his company said it expected to post its fourth consecutive loss this year. The executive, Masao Kiuchi, said he was stepping down to take responsibility for the poor performance of his company, which is 42 percent owned by Wal-Mart. And Seiyu announced a new 2005 forecast of a loss of 7.5 billion yen, or $68 million, replacing a forecast of break-even. Seiyu has lost money every year since 2002, when Wal-Mart acquired a stake in it. Seiyu blamed missteps in the first three months of the year for much of this year's predicted loss, like stocking spring clothing too soon and then having to put it on sale when temperatures remained cool. Seiyu's chairman, Noriyuki Watanabe, will add the role of chief executive. Martin Fackler (NYT)

title: Lots of wealth, lots of people, lots of flaws
Turkey and Europe, Aid for Africa, Nuclear terror
With Many Modifications, Penn Station Project Is 'Go'
description: OVERLOOKED in the fanfare this week over the announcement that the long-delayed Pennsylvania Station expansion project will be taken over by two powerful developers, the Related Companies and Vornado Realty Trust, is the fact that the design has been significantly altered. Again.

title: Dodgy deal with India
The Clean-Air Wars
description: Jeffrey Holmstead, who served as both an agent and an architect of President Bush's industry-friendly clean-air policies, resigned yesterday to return to private life after four years as the top clean-air official at the Environmental Protection Agency. Though we can always hope for the best, Mr. Holmstead's successor is unlikely to reverse the administration's ragged retreat from environmental protection -- one step forward, then two back. Here are some recent examples of that:

title: Currencies: Greenspan comments give lift to the dollar
World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Mining Company Looking for Coal in Australia
description: Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, the Brazilian mining giant known as C.V.R.D., signed a deal to explore for coal in Australia, marking its first foray onto the home turf of its archrivals, BHP Billiton and the Rio Tinto Group. C.V.R.D., the world's biggest producer and exporter of iron ore, said it had agreed with the Australian mining companies Aquila Resources and AMCI Holdings Australia to lead studies into developing a large coal project in the state of Queensland. The area is estimated to contain 2.7 billion tons of high-quality coking coal, making it a potential major supplier for Asian steel makers. C.V.R.D. agreed to pay $2.5 million each to Aquila and AMCI, and will have 18 months to complete the studies. After that, it will have the option to acquire 51 percent of the venture for $90 million, and eventually 100 percent at fair market value. Todd Benson (NYT)

title: Roundup: Gerrard completes his rout of Welsh
A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Police Seek Rapist
description: The police yesterday released a description of a man they say raped a 19-year-old woman early Sunday. The rapist is described as black, 25 to 30 years old, 5-foot-7, and weighing about 200 pounds, with a pockmarked face. On the night of the attack, the police said, the attacker was wearing a black baseball cap. Investigators said that he approached the woman about 3 a.m. Sunday, as the woman waited to hail a cab in East Flatbush. He then raped her at knifepoint. Kareem Fahim (NYT)

title: Second round of blasts put London on edge
Suspect in 2004 Australian Embassy bombing sentenced
Calendar
description: Family Nature Hikes Inwood Hill Park; entrance at Indian Road and 218th Street, the Bronx; (718)788-8500. Sharon Seitz, author of the new "Big Apple Safari for Families: The Urban Park Rangers' Guide to Nature in New York City" (Countryman Press), a guide to activities like hiking, biking, bird-watching and fishing, will lead a 1.6-mile walk along trails in Inwood Hill Park on Saturday from 3 to 5 p.m.

title: GM reports higher U.S. sales but still posts loss
Piano Teachers Who Are Also Piano Doers
description: The International Keyboard Institute and Festival is both two weeks of master classes at the Mannes College of Music and two weeks of nightly concerts by the institute's faculty. It is hard to say which element drives the other. The teacher-performers vary from the big career in waiting to the big career that never really happened to the career that went only so far. The star attraction, now approaching 90, will be Earl Wild on Saturday, promising more of his geriatric miracles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, JOHN BURNETT
description: RUSSELL--John Burnett. Chapel Hill, NC, 82, on July 19, 2005. Former president of Burlington Industries International and chairman of Dan River International. He graduated from Pomfret School and in 1945 from Yale University. He served two years in the Navy during WW II and was awarded Man of the Year from the National Conference of Christians and Jews in 1976. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Cynthia Lee, five children, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the All Saints Church at 11 A.M. in Locust, N.J. on August 4. Donations to UNC Hospice in lieu of flowers.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Correction Appended

title: Hiding From the Sun in Plain Sight
description: MY friend Tina, who is a very good tennis player, was the first in our circle to take drastic steps to combat the shortcomings of sunscreen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDBERG, IRWIN, M.D.
description: FREEDBERG -- Irwin, M.D. The faculty and residents of the Department of Dermatology, Henry Ford Hospital, Detroit, Michigan, note with sadness the passing of Irwin Freedberg, M.D., Chairman of the Ronald O. Perelman Department of Dermatology at NYU. Dr. Freedberg was one of the greats in dermatology who was an excellent chairman, superb leader, invaluable mentor, trusted advisor, and dear friend. He had served on the leadership position of all major dermatologic organizations, had edited the major textbook of dermatology and the most respected investigative dermatology journal, and had made numerous contributions in advancing the scientific base of dermatology. His enthusiasm for and his service to this specialty is an inspiration to all. He has left a lasting impact on dermatology and he will be dearly missed by all. Our heartfelt condolences go to his wife Irene, his children and his loving family. Henry W. Lim, M.D., Chairman and C.S. Livingood Chair, Department of Dermatology, Henry Ford Hospital, Detroit, Michigan FREEDBERG--Irwin M. M.D. The Department of Medicine at the NYU School of Medicine is deeply saddened by the death of our dear colleague, Irwin M. Freedberg, M.D. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his family and colleagues. Martin J. Blaser, M.D. Chair Department of Medicine NYU School of Medicine

title: Putin flares again at outside political aid
Merkel joins with Sarkozy to back change in Europe
A Better View of the Fairway?
description: THE latest in golf-specific eyewear, soon to include specially tinted contact lenses, offers more than protection from ultraviolet rays and the sun's glare, the manufacturers say. New tints and coatings promise to help players gauge distances more accurately on the fairway and to discern subtle dips and shadings on the greens. To test these claims, Gil Morgan, right, a 23-time winner on the Professional Golfers Association Champions Tour and a nonpracticing optometrist, tried six of the new models this month.

title: NBC and Mazda Jointly Promote New Lineups
description: NBC is beginning what may well be its most elaborate campaign ever to woo viewers to watch its series for the coming fall season. The multimillion-dollar campaign, which involves a big marketer, Mazda, and a big media company, Time Warner, also represents NBC's most extensive effort to use the firepower of branded entertainment in promoting a new-season lineup.

title: As It Retools, Kodak Plans More Layoffs
description: Eastman Kodak said yesterday that it would lay off up to 10,000 people over the next two years as it tried to speed its transition to digital photography from film, a business that the company pioneered and dominated for decades.

title: The Chair Doctor Is In
description: THE once-over glance is an art form at the Chelsea Flea Market, a jumble of tents, tables, dealers and worn miscellany from Hummel to Herman Miller laid out in a parking lot on Sixth Avenue every weekend. Shoppers casually scrutinize teacups for blemishes and scan Pledge-scented chairs for Stickley imprints, looking as uninterested as possible in order to ward off the aggressive dealer's hard sell.

title: Coach Abducted, Adding Focus to Common Mexican Dread
description: MEXICO CITY, July 20 - Armed men kidnapped a famous soccer coach in broad daylight on Tuesday afternoon as he left practice, fanning the anger of supporters of crime victims who say that kidnapping gangs are running amok in Mexico.

title: A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts (10 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An article on July 7 about a modernist house in the Hamptons that was designed on a tight budget misstated its location. It is in Springs, not Amagansett.

title: Howard vows to 'stay the distance' in Iraq
New York and Paris
description: ITALIAN jewelry, European fashions (including French gossamer skirts and bejeweled jeans), Tibetan rugs and antique furniture all vie for attention at Textures (below), an Upper East Side boutique that opened in May. Antique windows hung from the ceiling separate categories of merchandise, and give the place a feel that is part exotic bazaar, part antiques shop. Jewelry is $275 to $9,000; handbags are $350; hand-woven custom rugs are $3,000 and up. At 1200 Lexington Avenue, (212)861-2611.

title: Saudi Arabia's Longtime Ambassador to the U.S. Is Resigning
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - Prince Bandar bin Sultan, who in 22 years as the Saudi Arabian ambassador to the United States operated as an insider's insider and wielded enormous influence in Washington over successive administrations, is resigning for "private reasons," Saudi Arabia announced Wednesday.

title: A New Face for the Court: Meeting Judge Roberts
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on July 10 about London's attraction as a haven for radical Muslim clerics in the years leading up to the July 7 terrorist bombings misspelled the first name of a prominent Muslim in the House of Lords, who was quoted as advocating the expulsion of these clerics from Britain. He is Lord Nazir Ahmed, not Nizar Ahmed.

title: Floridian Charged in Fatal Drag Race
description: A Florida man involved in a drag-racing accident that killed a Queens man on Tuesday night faces charges including criminally negligent homicide, manslaughter and reckless endangerment, a spokeswoman for District Attorney Richard A. Brown of Queens said yesterday.

title: 800 million cellphones this year?
But What I Really Want to Do Is Design
description: Correction Appended

title: Earnings Rise at 2 Airlines Despite Price of Jet Fuel
description: In a tentative sign of momentum in the airline industry, Continental Airlines and the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, posted better-than-expected net income yesterday, a result of higher passenger traffic and better cost controls -- which helped to offset the high price of jet fuel.

title: Pfizer Earnings Rise 21%, Exceeding Estimates
description: Pfizer reported earnings yesterday that exceeded analysts' estimates, on increased demand for medicines to treat the ailments of an aging population.

title: Indonesia Is Latest Asian Country to Report a Case of Bird Flu
description: Indonesia has reported one confirmed case and two suspected cases of human avian influenza, making it the fourth Asian country in less than two years to detect in humans what is popularly known as bird flu, the World Health Organization said yesterday.

title: EU pledges to listen up but doesn't give details
Letter from the Middle East: Gaza's story depends on who spins the tale
Editor at Los Angeles Times Stepping Down After 5 Years
description: Correction Appended

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GELB, LILLIAN BERGER
description: GELB--Lillian Berger. Passed in Chicago, July 16, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Harold. Loving mother of Steven. Mother-in-law of Rita. Proud grandmother of Alexis. Her family and friends will always remember her unique wisdom and insights, and most of all, her wonderful personality and enthusiastic approach to life. Expressions of sympathy may be donated to the Council for Jewish Elderly for Adult Day Services, Attn: Judy Siegel, 3003 West Touhy Avenue, Chicago, IL. 60645. Services on Friday, July 22, 2:15 P.M. at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Roberts Makes His Official Debut on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - Greeting official Washington on his first full day as a Supreme Court nominee, Judge John G. Roberts joined President Bush for morning coffee at the White House and later began his delicate courtship of senators at the Capitol, drawing accolades from Republicans and a polite, if cautious, welcome from Democrats.

title: If It's Fab, Who Cares if It Has a Past?
description: Los Angeles - IT'S funny: people just fall in love with these pieces, and they don't care about a name or a pedigree," said Ron Woodson, an owner of Woodson & Rummerfield's House of Design, a shop in Hollywood that sells high-end refurbished furniture along with new pieces. Pointing to a no-name 1970's Lucite chair upholstered in Kelly green velvet, Jaime Rummerfield, his partner, said: "It's like putting on a piece of fabulous vintage jewelry which attracts attention. No one cares what it is. They just know it looks good."

title: Education's Collateral Damage
description: Stop the presses! Within just a few days we've had a scandal involving a world-class presidential guru bumped off the front pages by a prime-time presidential announcement of a nominee to the Supreme Court.

title: House to Take Up Patriot Act Extension
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - After months of political maneuvering, the House is set to open debate Thursday on the future of the sweeping antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act, as the Bush administration pushes to solidify support for the law and Democrats sought to impose new restrictions.

title: Earnings: Strong Lipitor sales help quarterly net surge 21%
A Portable Hard Drive That Even Looks Secure
description: The actual disk inside the Imation Micro Hard Drive is about the size of a nickel, sealed out of sight in a casing slightly smaller than a commemorative stamp. Despite its size, the drive holds two gigabytes of data, with a four-gigabyte version due by the end of this year. That's enough for an awful lot of photos or other files. The smaller version is available for $159 through computer dealers.

title: French fear eye of 'ogre' is on Danone
Chief of Card Processor Fires Back at Visa
description: The chief executive of CardSystems Solutions, John M. Perry, fired back at Visa last night, sharply criticizing it for stopping his company from processing its cardholders' transactions on the eve of Congressional hearings into the vulnerability of consumer data.

title: Publisher Names 9/11 Charities
description: W.W. Norton & Company, which last year won the right to publish the first authorized edition of the Sept. 11 commission's report, said yesterday that it would donate $600,000 from its profits on the book to three programs focused on emergency preparedness and international relations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JATLOWSKY, ALICE
description: JATLOWSKY--Alice. Died in her home on July 19, 2005 at the age of almost 95. Adored mother of Ethel Jatlowsky and Francine and Alan Rothenberg. Services today at 1 PM at The Riverside Memorial Chapel (Schwartz Bros. Building), Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY. Shiva will be observed and the family welcomes visitors Sun., July 24, 4 PM to 9 PM in Manhattan at the Ritz Carlton Hotel, 50 Central Park South.

title: Hamas attacks homes of its Palestinian rivals
China Says It Will No Longer Peg Its Currency to the U.S. Dollar
description: SHANGHAI, July 21 - After several years of resisting intense political and diplomatic pressure from its biggest trading partners, China said today that it would no longer peg its currency strictly to the dollar, a step that make it possible to rise gradually in value over time.

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,764 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Keeping T-Shirts in the Moment
description: NEVER underestimate the power of a martini when drafting a business plan. This point may not be taught at the Wharton School, but it is probably worth keeping in mind. It was over a boozy discussion of guy trouble three years ago that Kristin Bauer and Liz Vassey had the light-bulb moment that led them to found JustDumped.com, a company that makes T-shirts with slogans that read like semaphores flared from the battleground of contemporary romance.

title: Turning Up the Heat
description: AMONG the endless ribbons of news zippers, glass-walled television studios and countless samples of a Godiva frozen chocolate drink handed out in the daily overkill of marketing that is Times Square, the one-day installation of a Calvin Klein billboard in the shape of a fragrance bottle, one that was inhabited by live models, might not have drawn as much attention as it did on Tuesday had several of those models not been wearing leather pants. It was 88 degrees, after all.

title: Rice outraged by Sudanese security
Baltimore Hires Director Over Objections of Musicians
description: The Baltimore Symphony Orchestra said yesterday that it had closed a deal with Marin Alsop, announcing that she would take over as its music director in 2007 on a three-year contract.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Economic Growth Accelerates in 2nd Quarter
description: China's economy raced ahead 9.5 percent in the second quarter compared with a year ago, spurred by soaring exports, buoyant consumer spending and high investment, the National Bureau of Statistics said. The second-quarter growth result edged past the 9.4 percent of the first quarter, surprising many economists who, after a year of government efforts to slow growth, had thought the economy was finally responding. Average growth for the first half of the year was also 9.5 percent, the statistics bureau's spokesman, Zheng Jingping, said in Beijing. China's exports grew 32.7 percent in the first half of the year, to $342 billion, a decrease of three percentage points from the growth rate a year ago, Mr. Zheng said. But import growth plummeted to 14 percent in the first half of this year, from 42.6 percent in the first half of last year. Chen Xingdong, who follows China's economy for BNP Paribas Peregrine in Beijing, said about 45 percent of China's economic growth derives from exports, leaving the country's economic health increasingly vulnerable to pressure from the United States and Europe for China to stanch its trade surplus by raising the value of the yuan. Mr. Zheng said that China's rapid growth is also sustained by high levels of investment in factories, power plants and other infrastructure, despite government efforts to cool investment in some of those sectors. Chris Buckley (NYT)

title: Thousands Gather in Park for Dvorak
description: The players of the New York Philharmonic earned their city's thanks on Tuesday night by performing a two-hour-plus outdoor program on one of the most uncomfortably humid nights of the summer. This kind of weather wreaks havoc on instruments, skews intonation and generally makes performing a very unglamorous activity, but the musicians persevered and dutifully produced an evening of Dvorak. Officials estimated the crowd at 47,000 on the Great Lawn of Central Park.

title: China's economy grows despite effort to slow it
New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on July 1 about the crash of a small plane into a Hudson River inlet referred incorrectly to the pilot's escape from the plane, a Cirrus SR-22, which has a built-in parachute. He pulled the cord for the plane's parachute, and he and the plane went down together; he did not parachute out of the plane.

title: Israel considers moving up Gaza pullout
3 Aerospace Manufacturers Report Results
description: United Technologies said yesterday that its earnings for the second quarter rose on sales of airplane parts and elevators, while Honeywell said its profit fell because of costs to repatriate $2.7 billion in foreign earnings.

title: James Doohan, Actor Who Played Scotty on 'Star Trek,' Dies at 85
description: James Doohan, who faked a Scottish burr to create one of television's most endearing characters -- Scotty, the chief engineer of the U.S.S. Enterprise on the original "Star Trek" -- died yesterday at his home in Redmond, Wash. He was 85.

title: Two suicide car bombings, attacks kill at least 14 in Iraq
Time for a Federal Shield Law
description: It was immensely encouraging to see Republican and Democratic lawmakers testify together yesterday about the need for the federal government to follow the lead of 49 states and guarantee that journalists are allowed the right to protect the names of confidential sources in most circumstances. Two Republicans, Senator Richard Lugar and Representative Mike Pence of Indiana, and Senator Christopher Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, spoke eloquently about the role of a free press in a democracy. They have also shown that drafting a responsible shield law is not as hard as some critics say. Just this week, they amended bills pending in both houses of Congress to address the government's concern that the rights of reporters should not override the security of the nation when it faces an imminent threat.

title: Con Ed to Pay Millions More in E. Village Electrocution
description: Consolidated Edison agreed yesterday to pay $10.6 million as part of a settlement with a state regulatory commission over the death of a Manhattan woman who was electrocuted last year while walking her dogs on a wet street in the East Village.

title: It Gasps, It Yawns, It Even Listens: Furby Is Back, Kilobytes to Spare
description: Remember Furby? When this furry little electronic toy came out in 1998 it was an instant hit -- more than 40 million were sold worldwide. Now Furby is back in a new version that has 500 kilobytes of memory, which is six times what the original had, and uses voice recognition to respond to its owner.

title: Video Game Known for Violence Lands in Trouble Over Sex
description: Under pressure from Democratic senators, the board that rates video games assigned the latest installment of the Grand Theft Auto series an adults-only label yesterday, effectively removing it from the shelves of most major retail stores.

title: Secrets to Good Hard-Drive Hygiene
description: My cousin Steven Cristol should enter the lottery: he's already beaten seemingly impossible odds by enduring "seven mechanical hard drive failures in five computers," as he describes it.

title: U.S. Will Offer Doctors Free Electronic Records System
description: There is no one in medicine who does not consider it both crucial and long overdue to have electronic records in doctor's offices and hospitals.

title: China severs its currency's link to the U.S. dollar
Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about testimony at the Vioxx trial misstated the scene. It showed Dr. Nancy Santanello, a senior scientist for the drug maker Merck, in the courtroom on Monday before the trial resumed, not on Tuesday during questioning.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STEIN, GERDA (NEE LANDES)
description: STEIN--Gerda (nee Landes). On Tuesday, July 19, in Ewing, New Jersey. Born Stettin, Germany, 1914. Former resident of West Palm Beach, FL, Englishtown, NJ and Manhattan. Married for 58 years to the late Harry M. Stein (1996). Came to the United States September 1938. Was a registered nurse at Jewish Memorial Hospital in Manhattan for more than 25 years. Beloved mother of Carol Tannenwald (Palo Alto, CA), and Linda Meyer (Monroe Township, NJ). Motherin-law of Ludwig Tannenwald and Walter Meyer. Proud Nana of Diane Tannenwald, Eric (Laura) Tannenwald, Rochelle (David) Goldberg, Rebecca (Paul) Steinman and Marc Meyer. Great grandmother of five. Shiva will be observed in Monroe Township, New Jersey.

title: My Voice Has Got to Go
description: WHEN the telecom bubble burst a few years back and David LaBerge, 45, found himself looking for work as an independent marketing consultant, he decided it was time to spiff up his act. New clothes. New haircut.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRAMER, LOLA
description: KRAMER--Lola. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of the Jewish Federation of Palm Beach County mark with great sadness the passing of Lola Kramer, a pillar of Jewish life in the greater Palm Beaches. Her unwavering support of the Jewish people and our community will forever serve as a valued inspiration and example to all who knew and loved her and for generations to come. We extend our deepest sympathies to her family. Judith A. Levy, President Jeffrey L. Klein, CEO KRAMER--Lola. The Partners of Katten Muchin Rosenman mourn the passing of our longtime friend and client Lola Kramer and offer our sincere condolences to her husband Saul, her children, Robert Kramer and Kathie Kramer Rudy and her grandchildren, David, Nancie, James, Charles, Lesley and Michael.

title: Gershwin Is Played, and a Torch Is Passed
description: Bill Charlap faced unusually high expectations as he took the stage on Tuesday night at the 92nd Street Y. It was his first appearance as artistic director of Jazz in July, a concert series that thrived for 20 years under the aegis of his fellow pianist and mentor Dick Hyman.

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: Manhattan

title: In This Corner, in the Flouncy Skirt and Bowler Hat...
description: EL ALTO, Bolivia - In her red multilayered skirt, white pumps and gold-laced shawl, the traditional dress of the Aymara people, Ana Polonia Choque might well be preparing for a night of folk dancing or, perhaps, a religious festival.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAUFMAN, SAMUEL
description: KAUFMAN--Samuel. Beloved husband of Elaine. Adoring father of Kerry and Jan Brandin, Andrea Weiner and Randi and Peter Alpert. Loving Poppy of Elizabeth, Daniel, Nina, Anna, Lauren and Chelsea. Services at "Boulevard-Riverside", 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I. 12:30PM Thursday.

title: Director Puts His Name, and Money, at Stake
description: LOS ANGELES - Dressed in a Puma T-shirt, jeans and white sneakers, John Singleton walked into the lobby of a building on the Paramount Pictures lot here and suddenly stopped in his tracks. Before him were two giant billboards: one for a film he had bankrolled and produced, "Hustle & Flow," which hits theaters on July 22, the other for his latest directorial effort, "Four Brothers," due in August.

title: Trouble Spots Got You Down? Lighten Up
description: IN a country that takes pride in its multiethnicity, a strange-sounding beauty trend is picking up steam. Suddenly, a torrent of new face creams and gels are promising "whiteness" or "lightness."

title: The Campaign Desk Reborn For Tight Space and Quick Hiding
description: No room for a home office? Not to worry. Indochine, a contemporary twist on an 18th-century campaign desk, knocks down for storage. Its leather writing surface flips up, hiding paperwork in a detachable box that is 39 inches tall, 35 inches wide and 15 inches deep. The trestle legs fold, and both pieces can be stowed in the back of a closet. The desk is made of rosewood, with brass fittings and seven camphor-wood drawers; $2,100 at the Conran Shop, 407 East 59th Street or (866)755-9079. MARIANNE ROHRLICH CURRENTS: FURNITURE

title: 4 Small Explosions Jolt London and Disrupt Transit
description: LONDON, July 21 - Assailants with explosives struck at three subway trains and a double-decker bus today, sending passengers fleeing for safety just two weeks after the London terror bombings claimed 56 lives.

title: 3 Biologists Question Evidence in Sighting of Rare Woodpecker
description: Three biologists are questioning the evidence used by a team of bird experts who made the electrifying claim in April that they had sighted an ivory-billed woodpecker, a bird presumed to have vanished from the United States more than 60 years ago, in the swampy forests of southeast Arkansas.

title: Italy extends funding to continue Iraq troop mission
Sprint and Cingular Named in Complaints
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 - A California consumer advocacy group said in complaints filed yesterday that Sprint and Cingular Wireless had duped cellphone customers into overpaying for some services.

title: Even Tech Writers Need Support
description: Every now and then, I share, in this column, a true tale of tech some technical trouble that torments me for days. A few readers always write in response: AIAm so relieved to hear that even you, a technology columnist, also have computer problems!A

title: A Lush Garden of Delights, Eager to Share Its Secrets
description: Raleigh, N.C. - FOR some Southerners, gardening once meant venturing outdoors for two weeks in March or April, when the azaleas bloomed, then dashing back inside an air-conditioned house.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Elizabeth Blodgett Hall, who founded Simon's Rock College, now part of Bard College, referred incorrectly in some copies to the given name of the president of Bard, who commented on her legacy. He is Leon Botstein, not Leo.

title: Iraqis Not Ready to Fight Rebels on Their Own, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 20 - About half of Iraq's new police battalions are still being established and cannot conduct operations, while the other half of the police units and two-thirds of the new army battalions are only "partially capable" of carrying out counterinsurgency missions, and only with American help, according to a newly declassified Pentagon assessment.

title: Safe and Serene Behind a Firewall
description: Safe and Serene Behind a Firewall

title: Hybrid Morphs and Fills Several Household Voids
description: If one consideration has kept the tablet PC from becoming a popular household item, it's that few hardware manufacturers have designed one that's actually handy around the house. A cross between a souped-up P.D.A., tablet PC and hand-held gaming device, the Pepper Pad from Pepper Computer tries to fill that void. It begs to be held in your hands while you loaf on the couch.

title: A Confident Pilot With an Eye for Detail
description: Col. James M. Kelly of the Air Force has logged more than 3,000 hours in F-15 fighters and 35 other types of aircraft. Flying the shuttle, he says, is not all that different.

title: Maximum S.P.F.'s, Some With Zippers
description: EVERYONE waits for the sun to shine, and then runs for cover. Shade is a precious commodity, whether on a beach, near a pool or at a campsite, and this season its providers come in many forms, including umbrellas, tents and cabanas, some equipped to double as outdoor showers.

title: Israel Considers Moving Up Gaza Pullout
description: JERUSALEM, July 21 - Israel could advance its planned mid-August withdrawal of nearly 9,000 settlers from the occupied Gaza Strip to avoid further mass protests and attempts to infiltrate Gaza by settler supporters, Vice Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said today.

title: Sudan Still Paying Militias Harassing Darfur, U.S. Says
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan, July 20 - The Sudanese government, after promising a parade of foreign leaders over the past year to rein in the violence in Darfur, is still paying regular salaries to leaders of militias there that continue to attack and kill civilians, say American officials and aid workers stationed in Sudan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RANDISI, HON. MARTIN A.
description: RANDISI--Hon. Martin A. Class of 1948, Saint John's University School of Law. A talented, distinguished jurist possessed of impeccable legal scholarship. Totally devoted to his ever loving wife Anne, who has been his life's partner. Marty was a mainstay at Saint John's School of Law and held every leadership position that the University could bestow. His energy, commitment and strength will forever be remembered. Jerome Belson, Class of 1948 Saint John's University School of Law

title: Lapham Takes Stand in Polanski Libel Trial
description: LONDON, July 20 - Lewis H. Lapham, the editor of Harper's Magazine, reached far back into the past on Wednesday, telling a British court about an encounter he says he saw in Elaine's restaurant in Manhattan in August 1969, between the filmmaker Roman Polanski and a Scandinavian model named Beatte Telle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOYLE, THOMAS M.
description: DOYLE--Thomas M. Retired Senior Vice President, W.R. Grace & Co., Knight of Malta and Knight of the Holy Sepulchre. Beloved husband of Ellen (nee Dennehy). Devoted father of Mary Ellen, Noreen, Thomas, Patrick, Martin, Vincent, Brendan, Denis and the late Arthur. Proud grandfather. Graduate of Xavier High School, 1939 and Fordham University, 1943. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St Thursday and Friday, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Immaculate Conception Church, 414 E. 14 St., Saturday, 10AM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Xavier High School, Arthur Doyle Memorial Scholarship Fund, 30 West 16 St, N.Y., N.Y. 10011.

title: Once Again, Hound Bites Theater Critics
description: In the 1968 whodunit "The Real Inspector Hound," Tom Stoppard acts out nearly every playwright's occasional fantasy: killing off a few obnoxious theater critics. Indeed, by the time the 80-minute farce ends, the critics within the play-within-a-play have already hoist themselves with their own verbal petards, but Mr. Stoppard -- a former critic himself -- isn't satisfied until he has totally shot them down.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 24 about a new park open to skateboarders, beneath the Manhattan side of the Brooklyn Bridge, referred incorrectly to the work of Ellen Epstein, a landscape architect who has designed a "skate feature," with a goal of creating a space that both skaters and nonskaters can enjoy. Her design was for Highbridge Park in Washington Heights, not for the Brooklyn Bridge park.

His space-age left leg extended from a pair of khaki shorts, and he had the soldiers' attention even before he told them that he too had been in the Army, and that he too had fought in Iraq.

title: Las Vegas Rolls Out a Challenge to Tradition

title: Saunders Set to Join the Pistons
description: The Detroit Pistons have apparently moved on after saying goodbye to Larry Brown on Tuesday. The team is expected to introduce Flip Saunders today as its new coach at a news conference in Auburn Hills, Mich.

description: HERE is what liberals and conservatives can agree on about John Roberts, President Bush's first Supreme Court nominee: He is perhaps the most impressive Supreme Court advocate of his generation, extremely intelligent, thoughtful and able -- a lawyer's lawyer. In a reasonable world, that should be enough to assure his confirmation with bipartisan enthusiasm. Unfortunately, Washington politics is anything but reasonable.

title: U.S. Officials Have Mixed Reaction to China's News
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 - The Bush administration welcomed China's move toward a more flexible currency today, but the move raised almost as many questions as answers.

Arts, Briefly; CBS Isn't Overruled
description: The big four networks interrupted their prime-time programming at 9 p.m., Eastern time, on Tuesday for brief coverage of President Bush's Supreme Court announcement. That pause did not hurt CBS, as its victories in both the 8 p.m. and 9 p.m. slots helped the network carry the night in the most important measures of Nielsen's estimates. CBS began its schedule with an "NCIS" repeat, which was No.1 in both total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. CBS's "Big Brother" was also dominant in that age group and among total viewers. On Tuesday's "Big Brother" episode, one housemate, Michael, was accused of sexually harassing some of the women in the house. He responded by yelling at them. At 10 p.m., NBC's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" rerun trounced both CBS's "Rock Star: INXS" and ABC's limited series "Empire." Over all, NBC was second to CBS among households and the 18-to-49 demographic. KATE AURTHUR

title: Arts, Briefly; From Getty to Minneapolis
description: Only three months have passed since William M. Griswold, acting director of the J. Paul Getty Museum in Los Angeles, told Barry Munitz, the president and chief executive of the J. Paul Getty Trust, that he was withdrawing from the list of candidates being considered for the director's job, and already Mr. Griswold has been snapped up to run another museum. Yesterday the Minneapolis Institute of Arts announced that he had been appointed its director and president. Mr. Griswold succeeds Evan Maurer, who retired in February for health reasons. Before becoming acting director of the Getty in October, Mr. Griswold had been the museum's associate director responsible for curatorial, conservation, exhibition and education departments. As soon as the museum world learned that he had decided not to go for the Getty's top job, his name was bandied about for several other available museum director openings, including the job held by Katharine Lee Reid, who is retiring from the Cleveland Museum of Art at the end of the year. CAROL VOGEL

title: A Legal Argument
description: On Oct. 6, 1992, John G. Roberts, who was deputy solicitor general for the Department of Justice at the time, argued before the Supreme Court as amicus curiae (friend of the court) supporting Operation Rescue and individuals who blocked access to abortion clinics. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Ithaca: Cornell Protesters Arrested
description: Several protesters were arrested by Cornell University police yesterday as workers moved to cut down a stand of trees to make way for a parking lot. At least four protesters were charged with trespassing as student and university negotiators tried to persuade three remaining protesters, none of whom were students, to leave the two-acre spot known as Redbud Woods. Most protesters left the woods on Monday after administrators promised to examine ways of conserving natural resources at the university. Barbara Whitaker (NYT)

description: John H. Ostrom, a paleontologist influential in the revival of scientific research about dinosaurs, notably previously unsuspected clues to their speed and agility and their probable ancestral link to modern birds, died on Saturday in Litchfield, Conn. He was 77.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MAZOUR, JOSEPHINE LURIE

Both her husband, Professor Anatole Mazour, and her daughter, Natasha Mazour Jorgenson, preceded her in death. She leaves a son, Alexander, and four loving grandchildren.

Mr. Iguarn has the challenge of demonstrating his independence from President lvaro Uribe's government, though he has strongly defended a new law critics say gives paramilitary commanders virtual immunity in exchange for disarming. After the company changed hands several times, it was purchased in 2001 by Michael Smith and renamed Custom Shop Clothiers. It did not go out of business.

Now they've introduced their own reality dance competition, "So You Think You Can Dance," which started Wednesday with a boilerplate reality-competition lowlight reel, culled from the open-call audition of occasionally goofball amateurs. Shattering the dreams of starry-eyed young people, this time around, is Nigel Lythgoe, a shaggy, leering know-it-all whose over-styled putdowns lacked even the coherence of Simon Cowell's.

title: Why Do They Hate Us? Not Because of Iraq
description: Paris - WHILE yesterday's explosions on London's subway and bus lines were thankfully far less serious than those of two weeks ago, they will lead many to raise a troubling question: has Britain (and Spain as well) been "punished" by Al Qaeda for participating in the American-led military interventions in Iraq and Afghanistan? While this is a reasonable line of thinking, it presupposes the answer to a broader and more pertinent question: Are the roots of Islamic terrorism in the Middle Eastern conflicts?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, MARGARET ERSKINE
description: LEE -- Margaret Erskine. WWII Red Cross Nurse, died July 15, 2005 in Huntington, NY. She was 89. She was born in New York City, September 26, 1915 to Marion and James Erskine and grew up in Locust Valley, NY. She worked with the British Red Cross in the London Blitz, created the first USO in 1941, joined the 20th General in 1942 and served under General Stilwell on the Ledo-Burma Road. She married Burton J. Lee, Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor in 1946, was stepmother to four children, and had four of her own. She often said, "The Burma jungles were perfect training for the challenges of family life." Margaret is survived by sons, Jared and Timothy; daughters, Marion and Cecilia; stepchildren, Burton, Rosamond, Susannah and Mary Jo; brother, Drummond, and sister, Alison; 15 grandchildren and numerous great-grandchildren. Funeral service at 4 PM, Sunday, July 24, 2005, St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

Grand Theft Adult

The fact that you couldn't actually see into the room was one of the few moments of coyness in an otherwise explicit game, rather like the fireworks over the Riviera in "To Catch a Thief," if Cary Grant and Grace Kelly had shot up most of a doped-up, gang-ridden Southern France to get there.

title: The Listings: July 22 -- July 28; MYRA MELFORD AND THE TENT
description: In September 2000, the pianist and composer Myra Melford traveled to Calcutta on a Fulbright scholarship to study the harmonium, a hand-pumped reed organ widely used in North Indian music. Eight months later she returned, eventually forming the Tent, a group consisting of improvisers familiar with her free-flowing yet disciplined musical ideals. "Where the Two Worlds Touch" (Arabesque) captures the ensemble's uncommon cohesion; Ms. Melford's compositions tumble from ethereal to earthy so naturally that the transition seems all but inevitable. In performance, the music benefits enormously from the textural acuity of Cuong Vu, on trumpet, and Chris Speed, on clarinet and tenor saxophone, and from the rhythmic elasticity of the electric bassist Stomu Takeishi and the drummer Elliot Humberto Kavee. But the driving force is Ms. Melford, above, who was reaching beyond Western conventions well before her subcontinental drift. Raised outside of Chicago, she absorbed that city's unruly mix of blues and avant-garde jazz. Moving to New York in the mid-1980's, she sought out Henry Threadgill and Leroy Jenkins, expatriate pillars of the Association for the Advancement of Creative Musicians, an influential collective that promotes experimentalism in jazz. Although she now lives and teaches in Berkeley, Calif., she continues to be co-leader of a trio with Mr. Jenkins and Joseph Jarman, of the Art Ensemble of Chicago. She credits another Chicagoan, the pianist and composer Andrew Hill, as an inspiration, along with the poet Rumi, the Siddha Yoga master Gurumayi and now the Surrealist artist Joan Mir. For this concert, which reinstates a tradition of jazz at the Museum of Modern Art, Ms. Melford has composed a piece called "Moonbird" in tribute to the Mir sculpture that playfully perches near the museum's outdoor stage. (Sunday at MoMA's Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, 14 West 54th Street, Manhattan, (212)708-9431. Admission is free, but tickets are required, and will be distributed at 5:30 p.m. on a first-come-first-served basis. The garden opens at 7 p.m.; the concert begins at 8 p.m.) NATE CHINEN

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BULLEN, RICHARD H.
description: BULLEN--Richard H., on July 18, 2005, of congestive heart failure, having wondrously and with singular grace survived several years of failing health. Beloved and loving husband of Anne Marie; devoted father of Richard and Thomas; grandfather of Valerie, Georgia, Juliana and Richard. Born May 9, 1919, in Logan, Utah, son of Vivian and Asa Bullen. Dick Bullen graduated from Utah State University 1939, received an MBA from Harvard Business School, and served in the U.S. Army as a Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps in WWII. He enjoyed a long and successful career with IBM, joining the company as a salesman in 1945 and leaving 27 years later as Senior Vice President. He later served for many years on the boards of the Upjohn Company and Alaska Interstate and was a trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital. Dick Bullen was typical of men from an era often referred to as "The Greatest Generation" and exhibited their characteristic qualities of integrity, courage, optimism, and generosity. He was modest about his successes and never embittered by his setbacks. He will be profoundly missed by his many friends and loving family. A memorial service will be held on Monday August 22 1PM at Holy Trinity Church, 316 E. 88th St., (212) 289-4100. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Waterford School, 1480 East 9400 South, Sandy, UT. 84093.

title: Green Light for Bomb Builders
description: The Bush administration is full of tough talk about opposing the spread of nuclear weapons. But it keeps undermining the world's most effective instrument for doing so: the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty. In May, top administration officials stood aside as a crucial review conference meant to strengthen the treaty ended in a stalemate. Now Washington wants to allow India an end run around the treaty's basic bargain -- the one that rewards the countries that are willing to renounce nuclear weapons with the opportunity to import highly sensitive nuclear technology for power reactors.

title: The Listings: July 22 -- July 28; MOSTLY MOZART
description: This annual festival was in desperate need of new energy and ideas when the French conductor Louis Langre took over as music director in 2003, and he has since provided ample quantities of each. Under his direction, the festival has been productively experimenting with fresh formats -- like late-night concerts in a jazz club-like setting -- and this year, Avery Fisher Hall will receive its own extreme makeover: a new 30-foot stage extension will thrust the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra out into the hall and allow for surround-seating on all sides . Mr. Langre has also been renovating the ensemble's sound and raising its performance standards, so one can hope that these Mozarteans will be prepared for the enhanced scrutiny. The new configuration will be inaugurated on Thursday night, when the festival opens its 39th season with the soprano Rene Fleming and the pianist Stephen Hough, above, joining the orchestra in works by J.C. Bach, Rameau, Handel and, of course, Mozart. The program is part of the festival's monthlong focus on the composer's European travels as a child and as an adult, and the various musical exchanges that ensued along the way. (Thursday at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500, $38 to $58. The event will also be broadcast nationally that night on "Live From Lincoln Center" on PBS.) JEREMY EICHLER

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) STARGATE -- SG-1 Vala (Claudia Black), the space pirate, has already caused trouble for Daniel Jackson (Michael Shanks, above, with Ms. Black), handcuffing him (with ancient bracelets) and forcing him to do some decoding. Now Daniel and Vala are transported to a galaxy far far away, where everyone seems to be a devout worshiper of a mystic (and possibly very evil) race. And they don't take kindly to people who don't share their faith.

title: Dollar Falls Against Asian Currencies After China Says It Will End Link
description: The dollar dropped sharply yesterday against the Japanese yen and other Asian currencies and Treasury yields shot higher after China announced that it was revaluing its currency and ending its direct tie to the dollar.

title: China Unpegs Itself
description: Thursday's statement from the People's Bank of China, announcing that the yuan is no longer pegged to the dollar, was terse and uninformative -- you might say inscrutable. There's a good chance that this is simply a piece of theater designed to buy a few months' respite from protectionist pressures in the U.S. Congress.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Man Arraigned In Police Shooting
description: A man the police said was a member of the Bloods gang pleaded not guilty yesterday to first-degree murder in the killing of a Newark police officer on Monday. Hassan Reeds, 32, is charged with the murder of Officer Dwayne Reeves, 35, outside a Newark high school after a fight between two students. Authorities say that when officers went to arrest Mr. Reeds and another man, Omar Tindell, 26, Mr. Tindell fired one shot from a handgun, striking Officer Reeves in the head and another officer in the finger. Mr. Tindell was arraigned on Wednesday in the hospital where he is recovering from a gunshot wound sustained while struggling with the officers. The Newark Police said yesterday that Officer Reeves's funeral would be held on Tuesday morning at New Hope Baptist Church. John Holl (NYT)

title: Bush choice iscalled 'someone who gets it'
Currencies: Yuan revaluation fuels sharp yen gains
National Briefing | New England: Vermont: State Blocks A Land Deal
description: A state land-use commission has rejected a land deal that neighbors said would block public access to a 955-acre conservation area in Manchester. A hotel had sought to sell 16 acres to a wealthy Florida businessman, John Zoltak, who planned to build a large home on the property. The parcel included a trail leading to the conservation area near Mount Equinox. The hotel can appeal the ruling. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Fatally Shot
description: A man was fatally shot during an argument with another man on Wednesday evening, the police said. Kevin Singleton, 38, of Webster Avenue, was shot once about 7:30 p.m. during a dispute outside his house, the police said. He was pronounced dead at St. Barnabas Hospital. An investigation continued yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MALOFF, RUBIN
description: MALOFF--Rubin. In loving memory, Rubin Maloff, July 22, 1998.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LONG, LOIS
description: LONG--Lois, 86, dear, delightful friend. Died Tuesday, July 19. Artist, illustrator, fabric designer, wit, world traveler. Collaborator with John Cage on Mushroom Book and Mud Book. Born 1918, Clarksdale, Mississippi. Survived by son Tucker, daughter Paula and three grandchildren.

title: Bench Battle of 2 Lawrences Taking Shape
description: WHILE Lawrence of Long Island kept on the lookout for paparazzi yesterday out in the Hamptons, Lawrence of Teaneck marched a potential benchwarmer through workout paces and chaperoned a free-agent reserve point guard on a guided tour of northern New Jersey.

title: A Fateful Stop for a Bite to Eat
description: To say that Elisabeth Kbler-Ross meets David Lynch in the twisty paranoid thriller "November" is not to suggest that this surreal cinematic puzzle is at all profound or that it even wants to be. The movie, directed and edited by Greg Harrison from a screenplay by Benjamin Brand, refers to Kbler-Ross's stages of grief in chapter titles like "denial" and "acceptance." And its aggressively spooky surrealism, its evocation of multiple realities (it has three different endings) and its method of obsessively circling back in time recall Mr. Lynch's "Mulholland Drive."

title: Briefly: Airport is briefly closed as officials inspect plane
Grasso says he may be open to deal
Strides for Canada's Native Peoples
description: WINNIPEG, Manitoba - Canada's native peoples are often depicted in the news as suffering an array of social afflictions: broken families, glue-sniffing children, violent gangs, alcoholism and homelessness.

title: Ahead | Outdoor Film Festivals
description: FROM Bryant Park in New York to Grant Park in Chicago, there are hundreds of outdoor film festivals every summer, a chance for an audience to relax on a lawn and watch a favorite movie on the big screen. Indeed, outdoor movies have proved to be so popular that even hotel chains are getting in on the act: this summer Holiday Inn's SunSpree properties have begun a nightly Dive-Inn movie series where children and their parents can view "The SpongeBob SquarePants Movie" and TV cartoons while lounging poolside or floating in the water.

title: China Revalues the Yuan
description: China's currency revaluation was not as big as the blame-Beijing-first crowd in Congress has been demanding. But it is the start of something big, and now it's up to Congress to show equal sense.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHELDON, JUDITH WEST
description: SHELDON--Judith West. Died on July 20, 2005. Born and raised in Manhattan, she lived for many years in Concord, MA and then Shelburne, VT. She leaves many friends and family who will miss her spirit, touch, humor and love.

title: 'What a Swell Party This Is!  A Salute to Bing Crosby'
description: Bing Crosby, aka the Groaner and Der Bingle, may be the most reassuring Hollywood screen presence of the 20th century. This avuncular pipe-smoking crooner and actor, whose career is being celebrated in a 14-film series, "What a Swell Party This Is! -- A Salute to Bing Crosby," at the Walter Reade Theater, was hands down the 1940's top box office star. Unflappably calm, neighborly and churchgoing (he won an Academy Award for the role of Father O'Malley in Leo McCarey's "Going My Way"), with a practical joker's sense of humor (his "Road" movies with Bob Hope), Crosby poured balm over America's anxieties with his theme song, "Where the Blue of the Night Meets the Gold of the Day." Of special historical interest in the series is a rare screening on Sunday evening of "High Tor" (1956), a CBS made-for-television musical, based on a Maxwell Anderson play, with lyrics by Anderson and music by Arthur Schwartz, and featuring the screen debut of Julie Andrews. Kathryn Crosby, the star's widow, will introduce the screening. Other high points include the Irving Berlin movie musical "Blue Skies," which reunited Crosby with Fred Astaire (above) and which Martin Scorsese has cited as a major influence on "New York, New York," and "High Society," Cole Porter's musical adaptation of "The Philadelphia Story" and reputedly Crosby's favorite film. "True Love," his soothing duet with Grace Kelly in that film, proved to be both Crosby's and Porter's last great hit. (Walter Reade Theater, Lincoln Center, (212)875-5600 or www.filmlinc.com.) STEPHEN HOLDEN

title: Miller Campaign Worker Resigns in Aftermath of Message
description: A member of City Council Speaker Gifford Miller mayoral campaign staff resigned last night after an appeal she made to members of his Council staff to work on the mayoral campaign in their free time became public.

title: Sales bring profit rise at telecoms
Paid Notice: Deaths   SEH, EDWARD
description: SEH--Edward. On July 20, at age 78. Beloved husband of Carmen Seh. Loving father of Jody Berman and Ellen Seh. Cherished grandfather of Jeb Berman. Dear brother of Rowie Samson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Saturday 7-9PM with service Sunday, 1:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Bethesda Memorial Hospital Fund of Boynton Beach, Florida.

title: U.S. Calls Revaluation a Good Start for Beijing
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 - The Bush administration welcomed China's move toward a more flexible currency on Thursday, but the cautious shift may not be enough to cool the anti-China sentiments boiling up in Congress.

Briefly: Ethnic fighting leaves 13 villagers dead

Paid Notice: Deaths   GILL, T SMYTH
description: GILL--T Smyth, artist, devoted wife, beloved aunt and friend to many, June 30 at NY-Presbyterian Hospital. She was born in Rio de Janerio, Brazil, daughter of Samuel Smyth, a marine surveyor for Lloyd's of London and of Elizabeth Smyth. Always loving drawing and painting, she graduated from the Moore Institute of Art and Design. Following work with Philadelphia advertising agencies, she was employed in New York as a commercial artist and as a designer of children's games. T's talents in arts and crafts were honored in 2003 by a reception and exhibit at New York University. She was an active member of the Church of the Incarnation participating in many church activities. She and John Lee Gill were married in 1954 at Old St. Paul's Church, Fairlee, MD. He was a naval aviator in WWII and is a retired federal investigator. Both enjoyed travel, underwater photography and various Manhattan offerings. Both lost many FDNY friends at the World Trade Center on 9/11. A memorial service will be held at the Church of the Incarnation, 209 Madison Ave, NY, NY 10016 on August 19 at 3PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory at the Church of the Incarnation or Moore College of Arts and Design, Philadelphia, PA.

title: Art in Review; Gerald Monroe
description: In the Garden Michael Steinberg Fine Art 526 West 26th Street, Chelsea Through July 29

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUDENSING, PATRICK
description: DUDENSING--Patrick. Died at his home in Naples, FL on July 19, 2005. He was born in Ithaca, NY on June 7, 1926. Pat was educated at the Park Lodge School in Pau, France, Deerfield Academy, Harvard College and Dartmouth College. He served in the U.S. Army in the South Pacific during World War II, achieving the rank of 2nd Lieutenant. He married the late Margaret Jane (Peggy) McDonald in 1950. They were married until her death in 1993. Pat ran an art gallery in Woodstock, VT in the early 1950's. He then worked at Amro, and Young & Rubicam in New York City. He moved his family to Duxbury, MA in 1964, and continued to maintain a home there. He worked for Ocean Spray, United Fruit, and United Brands. He became a resident of Naples in 1989. He is survived by DD Allen of New York City, Ellen Strickland of Santa Barbara, CA, Elizabeth Udell of Campbell, CA, and Peter and Nicky Dudensing of Duxbury, along with their children Christopher, Daniel, and Lauren.

title: Bensel Wins N.Y. Title
description: Frank Bensel shot a two-under-par 71 to finish with a 54-hole total of 208 to win his first New York State Open championship yesterday at Bethpage Black Course on Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSSELL, JOHN BURNETT
description: RUSSELL--John Burnett. Chapel Hill, NC, 82, on July 19, 2005. Former president of Burlington Industries International and chairman of Dan River International. He graduated from Pomfret School and in 1945 from Yale University. He served two years in the Navy during WW II and was awarded Man of the Year from the National Conference of Christians and Jews in 1976. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Cynthia Lee, five children, 12 grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at the All Saints Church at 11 A.M. in Locust, N.J. on August 4. Donations to UNC Hospice in lieu of flowers.

title: Guidant Quarterly Profit Falls Because of Expense of Recalls
description: The Guidant Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter net income fell 15 percent from a year ago, reflecting costs associated with recent recalls of tens of thousands of heart devices.

title: Don't point fingers, Musharraf tells Britain
The Legacy of a Fearless Environmentalist
description: Opens today in Manhattan Directed by Kelly Duane Not rated, 77 minutes

title: Arts, Briefly; Ireland's Abbey Theater On Rocky Road
description: With the Abbey, Ireland's national theater, below, recording a deficit from last year of more than $2 million, all members of its board and finance committee will resign, the Abbey's chairwoman, Eithne Healy, said in a statement. According to internal correspondence that was leaked to the press, the theater could face "technical insolvency" by today. The Irish government's Arts Council, which finances cultural bodies, promised to pay employees' wages. The theater made no statement about the status of its next production, a revival of Oscar Wilde's "Importance of Being Earnest," featuring an all-male cast and scheduled to open on Wednesday. The deficit figure was included in an audit by KPMG, which blamed antiquated financial and reporting systems for not discovering the losses earlier. Fiach MacConghail, who took over as director this year after a string of job cuts, now faces a cumulative deficit of $4.1 million. BRIAN LAVERY

title: Following the Fences in Bluegrass Country
description: MILES of low fences line the winding, two-lane roads of the Bluegrass in north central Kentucky and dissect its rolling green horse farms, where magnificent thoroughbreds rest near pristinely painted barns. Now and again, the fences break for a leafy lane leading to an age-old bourbon distillery with doors open for a tour and a tipple. Then they lead away to a quaint 19th-century town, a quintessential country inn or a serene Shaker village.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TILLES, NORMAN
description: TILLES--Norman. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the passing of Norman Tilles, who had a long and distinguished history of service to the American Jewish community, and especially to HIAS the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, for which he served as Board President from 1995 to 1998. Norman's selfless and hard work on behalf of refugees, asylumseekers and other immigrants in need marked him as a true humanitarian of global scope. Our sincere condolences go to his wife, Florence, their children, grandchildren and great - grandchildren. May his memory be for a blessing.

title: Starwood to Buy Luxury Brands
description: Starwood Capital Group, the property investment firm, agreed yesterday to buy a controlling stake in Taittinger and Socit du Louvre, the French luxury companies that own the crystal maker Baccarat and the landmark Htel de Crillon in Paris, for about 1.2 billion euros ($1.5 billion), company executives said.

Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Mayoral Debates Scheduled
description: The city's Campaign Finance Board has scheduled a series of election debates, which are required of candidates seeking public financing, officials said yesterday. In the mayoral contest, the board has set two Republican and two Democratic primary debates, in August and September, with a runoff debate if necessary, and two bipartisan debates, in October and November, for the general election. This year, the board is reserving some debates for leading candidates and is permitting candidates who are not in the campaign finance program to participate. Bill Cunningham, a strategist for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who is financing his own campaign, said the mayor would debate an opponent as he did in 2001, but not whether that would be in the Finance Board debates or under a different arrangement. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FANCY, ANWAR AMIRALI
description: FANCY--Anwar Amirali. The family of Anwar Amirali Fancy is deeply saddened to announce his sudden passing on July 20, 2005 in New York City. Born in Tanzania, Mr. Fancy was educated in Pakistan and U.K. and was a 1966 Yale graduate. He was an entrepreneur, international businessman and philanthropist. A much-loved father and husband, he is survived by his wife, Saeeda, and three children, Mahnaz, Khadijah and her husband Tim, and Hussein and his wife Rebecca. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to DIL (www.4dil.com).

title: 10 Are Charged With Smuggling of Immigrants
description: NEWARK, July 21 - A group of girls and women from Honduras were kept in crowded apartments and forced to dance at bars and drink with male customers to pay back thousands of dollars to the people who smuggled them into the United States, the United States attorney for New Jersey charged on Thursday.

title: Pennington Vows to Be Ready
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 21 - Like an actor studying his lines, Jets quarterback Chad Pennington has gone over and over the scripted plays from Mike Heimerdinger, the new offensive coordinator.

Corrections
description: An article on July 14 about new findings on the virulence of SARS referred incorrectly at one point to the enzyme system that the SARS virus appears to attack. The system, the renin-angiotensin pathway, which regulates the balance of body fluids, has long been associated with the lungs; the association is not new. As the article noted, angiotensin-converting enzyme-2, the critical molecule in the research, was not previously known to exist in the lung or to be linked to lung disease.

title: Strong PC Sales Help Microsoft Beat Earnings Estimates
description: Microsoft reported yesterday that earnings rose nearly 38 percent in the fourth quarter helped by a tax benefit and strong demand for personal computers. Sales largely met Wall Street's goals.

title: A District Attorney and the Plight of Migrant Workers
description: MINEOLA, N.Y. - THERE is no way to tell if he's wearing his heart, assuming deadpan by-the-book district attorneys possess hearts, on his sleeve. Sensing an imminent photo op, Denis Dillon, the perennially incumbent Nassau County district attorney, deftly slides his suit jacket over his white shirtsleeves, the better to display the cri de coeur he wears on his lapel: a tiny red rose with the word LIFE embroidered in script.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BROWN, FRED, PH.D.
description: BROWN--Fred, Ph.D. The Mount Sinai Medical Center and its Board of Trustees mourn the passing of of Fred Brown, Ph.D., Professor Emeritus of Psychiatry, at the age 0f 100. Dr. Brown was selected as the first full time psychologist and Director of Psychology at The Mount Sinai Hospital in 1947, a position that he held for 28 years. In 1975, Dr. Brown was named Professor Emeritus at Mount Sinai School of Medicine. He was much loved and admired by his colleagues, not only for his brilliance as a clinical psychologist, but also for his quick wit, willingness to share his gifts, and dedication to his family. During W.W. II, Dr. Brown served in the U.S. Air Force and was discharged in 1946 with the rank of Major. After his retirement from Mount Sinai, Dr. Brown remained in private practice until the age of 91, making a specialty of forensic psychology and testifying in many high profile cases. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Brown's wife, Minerva (Mickey) Brown, who is the former Administrator for Mount Sinai's Post Graduate School, and their two children, Janet and Daniel. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Kenneth L. Davis, M.D., President, CEO and Dean Dennis S. Charney, Dean of Research

title: Some Retailers May Keep Video Game Off Shelves
description: Some video game retailers said yesterday that they might not restock the popular video game Grand Theft Auto: San Andreas even if sexually suggestive content was removed.

description: An article last Friday about plans for a weekend trip by George E. Pataki to Iowa for a national governors' meeting -- and, according to associates, to explore the possibility of a presidential run in 2008 -- misidentified an event he was to attend. It was a minor-league baseball game, not, as his aides said, a Little League game.

title: Don't Get Fresh With Me!
description: SOME are depressed by the sun deprivation of winter; my anxiety peaks instead at the height of summer. This isn't some sort of seasonal affective disorder-in-reverse. My worsening temper can be calibrated precisely not to the longer days but rather to another unrelenting symbol of the season: the blossoming farmers' market I walk through in Manhattan's Union Square. I confess that half an hour browsing in that utopia of produce -- or the new Whole Foods Market at the square's south end -- often leaves me longing for the antiseptic but nonjudgmental aisles of low-end supermarkets like Key Food or Western Beef.

Perhaps this is only fitting, since the movie's hero, a Memphis pimp named DJay (Terrence Howard) who dreams of becoming a rap star, is both cunning and earnest, a scam artist who claims to want nothing more than to speak his mind and lay bare his soul.

title: Suburban Break-In as Political Statement, With Kidnapping
description: "The Edukators," Hans Weingartner's second feature film, concerns three young Berliners whose frustration at the iniquities of global capitalism leads them, not quite intentionally, to cross the line that separates provocation and protest from serious crime. The film is, to some extent, a sympathetic exploration of the state of political idealism in the contemporary West, where all avenues of resistance seem blocked or co-opted by the system. But it is also a sometimes mocking expos of what the old left used to call political infantilism. The director is clearly fond of his radicals -- and the terrific actors playing them do so with exemplary conviction -- but he also points out the blind spots and contradictions that distort their view of the world and turn their self-styled heroism into self-dramatizing foolishness.

title: Major Abortion Rights Group Gives Approval to Bloomberg
description: A major New York City abortion rights group gave its approval to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday, saying his record of support outweighed his affiliation with a party whose national leadership was overwhelmingly opposed to abortion.

title: Deal on Pollutant Cleanup Pushed to Save Energy Bill
description: The oil industry has agreed to contribute $2 billion to help clean up spills of a gasoline additive that is fouling groundwater in exchange for immunity protection against dozens of lawsuits, people close to the negotiations said.

title: Teacher Sought Sex With Girl, Police Say
description: A Queens middle school teacher who the authorities said sought to have sex with a 13-year-old girl he met on the Internet faced charges last night including attempted sex abuse and attempting to disseminate indecent material to a minor.
