title: Pentagon May Consider Older Recruits
description: The Army told John Conroy on July 8 that it did not want him, despite his master's degree in business and his marathon-proven fitness. Just shy of 41, he is too old.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about fruit that is identified with laser tattoos instead of stickers misstated the method of tracking radio frequency identification tags used by Wal-Mart to track pallets of produce. The tags, with a limited range, are monitored by radio within feet of their use, not by satellite.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the new edition of Ethnologue, a compendium of the world's languages, used an incorrect ranking of linguistic diversity, taken from a table in the book. As noted in a chart that accompanied the article, the nation with the least diversity is North Korea, with one language, not Haiti, with two.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about the nomination of John G. Roberts to the Supreme Court referred incorrectly to a document that restated the opposition of the first Bush administration to Roe v. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision that established the constitutional right to abortion. The statement was included in a brief he helped write as deputy solicitor general, arguing in favor of a government regulation banning abortion-related counseling in federally financed family planning programs. It was not in a separate brief.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Smugglers Arrested
description: The police in Switzerland and the Netherlands have broken up an international drug trafficking ring and detained eight people accused of smuggling cocaine into Switzerland. The Swiss police stumbled on the network after they detained two Dutch nationals at Zurich airport as they sought to smuggle hundreds of grams of cocaine in specially prepared shoes. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: The Bollywood girl: From virgin to vamp
O'Connor Sees Strains Between the Judiciary and Some in Congress
description: SEATTLE, July 21 - In her first public speaking engagement since she announced her retirement from the Supreme Court, Justice Sandra Day O'Connor told a crowd of 700 judges, lawyers and other admirers on Thursday that "in all the years of my life, I don't think I've ever seen relations as strained as they are now between the judiciary and some members of Congress."

title: Lawmakers Examine Credit Card Breaches
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 - Major credit card companies and the payment processor at the center of the country's largest data breach were called to Capitol Hill on Thursday to testify about a security compromise that exposed some 40 million cardholders to fraud.

title: INSIDE
description: The Met's Facial After 103 years, even the face of a goddess shows its age. A limestone nose job by an expert stone carver, Shi-Jia Chen, 100 feet above street level, is part of a four-year, $12.2 million renovation project by 17 workers on the facade of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. WEEKEND/ARTS, PAGE E29

title: Protests may hasten Gaza move
The Kids Are All Right; the Coach Has Problems
description: Is there a movie role Billy Bob Thornton can't pull off? In Richard Linklater's enjoyable remake of Michael Ritchie's equally entertaining, considerably harder-edged 1976 comedy, "The Bad News Bears," Mr. Thornton plays a womanizing drunk named Morris Buttermaker. Ornamented with tattoos and sporting a salt-and-pepper goatee, Buttermaker earns his keep by exterminating rats and other pests, a job that cramps neither his style nor his overweening self-regard. The rat catcher has a fondness for pneumatic women, but as a confirmed loner he walks and boozes alone, often while lead-footing through a Southern California wasteland in his wreck of a convertible.

description: Facing a reaction against consumer drug advertising, the pharmaceutical industry moved toward self-policing yesterday, releasing draft guidelines that endorse a period of informing doctors about new drugs before running ads for them.

title: Manslaughter Charge for Lawyer in Drunken Driving Case
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., July 21 - The lives of Keith J. Kalmus, a former prosecutor with a promising law practice on Long Island, and Claudio Bertuccioli, a molecular biologist and principal in a $2 billion private equity firm in Manhattan, intersected violently on June 5 on the road linking Amagansett to Montauk. There, Mr. Kalmus, with a blood-alcohol level more than twice the legal limit, caused a car crash that injured Dr. Bertuccioli, his wife and an aunt, and killed his mother, prosecutors said.

title: Danone Plays Down Rumor of a Takeover by PepsiCo
description: PARIS, July 21 -Executives of Danone said Thursday that they were not in contact with PepsiCo over a rumored hostile takeover, but the statement did little to defuse a national furor over the possibility.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: U.N. Criticizes Emergency Powers
description: The United Nations said the new emergency powers invoked by Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra to combat insurgents in three predominantly Muslim provinces violated the international treaty protecting basic civil and political rights that Thailand had signed. Christine Chanet, chair of a United Nations human rights committee, said Thailand "crossed the red line" by granting impunity to officers who might have committed abuses and by allowing suspects to be arrested for up to 30 days without charges. Thailand is among 154 nations to have ratified the treaty. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Judges May Tread on Them, but They Still Gotta Dance
description: The blowout success this summer of ABC's "Dancing With the Stars" hasn't escaped the notice of the creators of Fox's warhorse, "American Idol." Now they've introduced their own reality dance competition, "So You Think You Can Dance," which started Wednesday with a boilerplate reality-competition lowlight reel, culled from the open-call audition of occasionally goofball amateurs. Shattering the dreams of starry-eyed young people, this time around, is Nigel Lythgoe, a shaggy, leering know-it-all whose over-styled putdowns lacked even the coherence of Simon Cowell's.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Housing And Food Stamp Bills Vetoed
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed two City Council bills yesterday that would have required food stamp applications to be made available at all city-financed food programs and would have given tenants in subsidized housing the right to join together and seek help to buy their buildings when landlords reached the end of their contracted time and began to charge rents at market rates. The mayor said that he supported efforts to increase New Yorkers' access to food stamps, but that the Council lacked the legal authority to expand the food stamp program, which is controlled by state law. He said the building purchase proposal would have been illegal under federal and state law, and questioned how the measure would benefit low-income tenants without providing funds to maintain the buildings.

title: Up, but Then Down
description: Both Google and Microsoft reported results in the quarter yesterday that exceeded expectations.

title: Making His Rounds, Nominee Is Pressed to Become More Forthcoming This Time
description: WASHINGTON, July 21 - As he makes the rounds of senators who will decide his fate, Judge John G. Roberts has been noncommittal about the kinds of questions he will answer during his confirmation hearings, but has said that if confirmed to the Supreme Court, he will place a high emphasis on "modesty" and "stability."

title: Violinist Dropped by Philharmonic Goes to Court
description: For Anton Polezhayev, a promising violinist with a few midlevel competition victories under his belt, winning a coveted seat at the New York Philharmonic at the tender age of 26 was deeply fulfilling.

Mr. Levitt was a great patron of the arts and we feel fortunate to have benefited from his personal friendship and vision. Susan L. Baker, Chairman Robert Bass, Music Director

description: Alex Shibicky, who was a mainstay of the Rangers team that won the 1940 Stanley Cup and is believed to be the first player to use a slap shot in a National Hockey League game, died July 9 in South Surrey, British Columbia. He was 91 and lived in Surrey.

description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 21 - Bubba Crosby made his third consecutive start for the Yankees on Thursday, in left field against the Angels after making two starts in center. As the Yankees approach the trading deadline, they are giving Crosby a longer look to see if he can handle more playing time in center.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Director Of National Reconnaissance Office Named
description: Donald M. Kerr, the Central Intelligence Agency's deputy director for science and technology, has been named the director of the National Reconnaissance Office, which builds and operates the nation's spy satellites, the Defense Department announced. Dr. Kerr, who has a Ph.D. in plasma physics and microwave electronics, came to the C.I.A. job in 2001 after working as assistant director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, where he oversaw the laboratory division. He was director of Los Alamos National Laboratory from 1979 to 1985. Scott Shane (NYT)

description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, July 18 - It looks like a Starbucks. It smells and tastes like one too. Settle into one of the comfortable Starbucks-like armchairs and it certainly feels like the real thing.

description: EXPERIENCE Martha's Vineyard the way the locals do by skipping the shopping streets, using the bike paths and eating well. Page 2.

description: IF the Mets and their fans let themselves, they could begin to get very excited right about now. They would be making a mistake, but how often can they get excited?

description: Ace, the Bermuda-based insurance company under investigation by New York state and federal authorities, said yesterday that it would restate more than five years of results to correct accounting on a type of insurance that companies can use to smooth earnings improperly.

description: As the New York Police Department begins randomly checking the bags and backpacks of people entering the city's subway system, it is entering largely uncharted legal terrain, where the requirements of protecting the public against terrorism may run into the constitutional right to privacy.

title: Militant London Sheik Had Predicted More Terror Attacks
description: LONDON, July 21 - On the eve of four attempted bombings here on Thursday, Sheik Omar Bakri Mohammad, one of Britain's most outspoken militant clerics, predicted that another terrorist attack would hit London.

title: Another Spinoff Completed in Remaking Liberty Media
description: John C. Malone, the media industry financier, moved a step closer to carving up what remains of his United States holdings yesterday. He completed the spinoff of Liberty Media's 50 percent interest in the cable channel group Discovery Communications to shareholders. On their first trading day, the shares closed at $15.09, up 24 cents.

title: Business Digest
description: China, Responding to Pressure, Says It Will Revalue Its Currency After at least two years of resisting intense political and diplomatic pressure from its trading partners, China said that it would no longer peg its currency strictly to the dollar, a step that could allow the yuan to rise gradually over time. [Page A1.]

title: Martha's Vineyard
description: BY now, Martha's Vineyard is so well known (Bill and Hillary took care of that) and so frequently visited (those Black Dog T-shirts are now ubiquitous) that any sightseeing advice seems almost superfluous. Sure, go to the legendary Black Dog Tavern and buy a T-shirt like all the other tourist lemmings. But be warned: some shirts are printed with the year, and to Vineyarders, the only cool ones are the old ones. And, absolutely, go to the cliffs in Aquinnah (better known as Gay Head) on the western end of the island -- "up-island" in Vineyardese. The view is breathtaking, even with all those buses and ticky-tacky souvenir shops. But take some time to do as the Vineyarders do: ignore the shopping (every establishment aspiring to Black Dog status now sells its own T-shirt) and the zillions of restaurants (many are good; the best are mobbed) and enjoy this island outpost of Massachusetts for its history, idiosyncrasies, nature reserves and beaches. In its 100 square miles, with several very different towns, the choices are infinite. MARY SUH

title: No Soul, Perhaps, but This Clone Has a Skeptic's Heart
description: "The Island" is the kind of movie almost entirely devoted to the explanation of its own premise. This takes some time, because the premise is complicated. But since the explainer is Michael Bay, the exposition is carried out on the run, and you have a lot of flashy images to look at while you're connecting the dots.

title: Bombs Set at 4 London Sites, but Fail to Explode
description: LONDON, July 21 - Assailants with explosives struck at three subway trains and a double-decker bus on Thursday, sending passengers fleeing for safety just two weeks after the London terror bombings that claimed 56 lives. But the bombs did not explode, and no one was hurt.

title: Hevesi Blocks Transportation Borrowing Plan
description: ALBANY, July 21 - State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi Thursday canceled the Pataki administration's plan to refinance $2.9 billion worth of transportation bonds. The move cast doubt on part of a multibillion-dollar plan for transportation projects across the state and signaled the comptroller's resolve to curb the state's expensive borrowing habits.

Stevens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HORNE, WILLIAM G.
description: HORNE -- William G., 81. Passed away at home June 22 as a result of cancer. Survived by Esther R. Horne of New York, their son Adam G. Horne, also of New York, and his sister Judyth H. Whitaker of Baton Rouge, Louisiana, and our extended families. Served aboard U.S.S. Murray in World War II. Bill touched the hearts of all who knew him. He was a gentle, loving soul who had multiple talents and interests. We mourn our loss but celebrate the life of this beautiful man. Memorial to be held Saturday, July 23 at Church of the Holy Apostles, 9th Ave and 28th St at 2PM.

title: Worst riots in a decade leave 16 dead in Yemen
Arts, Briefly; 'Dance' Stomps Brats
description: After a week on top, the whelps of ABC's "Brat Camp" are out. And dancers are back in, but this time they're on Fox. The network's two-hour series premiere of "So You Think You Can Dance," below, from the producers of "American Idol," was No. 1 from 8 to 10 p.m. on Wednesday night. According to Nielsen's estimates, the show grew in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49 with every half-hour, bringing in an average audience of 10 million. Fox won the night in all the important ratings measures. In total viewers, NBC took second place with a rerun of "The Most Outrageous Moments on Live TV" (8 million) and two repeats of the network's workhorse "Law & Order" (8.3 million, then 9 million). ABC was No. 2 for the night in the 18-to-49 demographic. Though it was down from its premiere last week, "Brat Camp" was ABC's highest-rated show, with 9.24 million viewers. KATE AURTHUR

title: A pimp falls for his own hustle
The Story of a Love Affair, in the Language of the Body
description: The notion that our sexual behavior is the purest expression of our deepest selves is delicately explored in "9 Songs," Michael Winterbottom's lyrical, graphically explicit chronicle of an ordinary love affair between two attractive people. The movie isn't the first art film to show real as opposed to simulated sex, but it's the first to scrutinize at length one couple's bedroom etiquette in a search for their identities. If anything, "9 Songs," conceived and directed by Mr. Winterbottom, the British filmmaker responsible for movies like "In This World" and "Welcome to Sarajevo," that boldly enter the topical fray, proves that showing what people do in bed may not reveal all that much. The truth lies hidden in their minds.

title: Vietnam economy grows 7.6% but misses target

description: JERUSALEM, July 22 -Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice made rapid visits of reassurance and support today to Israel and Lebanon during a difficult period for both countries.

title: Georgian Admits Tossing Grenade Near Bush, but Provides No Motive
description: MOSCOW, July 21 - The man arrested Wednesday night in Georgia after a shootout with the police admitted on Thursday to throwing a hand grenade near a stage where President Bush was addressing a huge public rally in May, two senior Georgian officials said.

title: Party Cove: Wild in the Ozarks
description: Osage Beach, Mo. - YOU won't find it on any of the regional maps the chambers of commerce around here pass out, but finding Party Cove is no problem. At about noon on any summer Saturday or Sunday, just nose your boat out onto the Lake of the Ozarks near the Grand Glaize Bridge -- that's where Route 54 passes over the water -- and follow the flotilla. This time of the week, everyone's headed, to paraphrase the colleagues of Nathan Detroit, for the oldest established permanent floating bacchanal in the country.

title: Shopping | Cold Treats
description: SAVORED slowly, ice cream becomes a languid celebration of summer. And cold drinks, splashed over ice, revive both body and mind. So, next time temperatures soar, serve up this season's frostiest pleasures. After all, nothing delivers a blast of cool like brightly colored ice pops. And the only thing better than an ice cream sandwich is knowing there are more in the freezer. BETHANY LYTTLE

title: Israel May Speed Gaza Pullout to Head Off More Protests
description: JERUSALEM, July 21 - Israel may advance its planned mid-August withdrawal of nearly 9,000 settlers from the Gaza Strip to avoid further mass protests and attempts to infiltrate Gaza by settler supporters, Vice Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said Thursday.

title: New Jersey Continues Steps to Diversify Pension Fund
description: WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 21 - New Jersey officials voted on Thursday to let two additional money management firms invest part of the state's $70 billion pension fund in areas other than the traditional mix of stocks and bonds, hoping that private-sector skills can bolster its public-sector portfolios.

title: German President Dissolves Parliament and Calls Early Elections
description: BERLIN, July 21 - President Horst Khler announced Thursday that he had dissolved the German Parliament and called for early national elections, moving the vote for chancellor up by a year.

title: Polanski Wins Vanity Fair Libel Suit
description: LONDON, July 22 - A jury declared today that Vanity Fair magazine libeled Roman Polanski, the film director, by describing an encounter it said he had at Elaine's restaurant in New York 36 years ago. Vanity Fair was ordered to pay almost $88,000 in damages and a substantial portion of Mr. Polanski's legal costs.

title: Formula One: Teams waiting for smoke to clear after tobacco ban
Fighting AIDS Behind Bars
description: The United States has done relatively little to curtail the AIDS epidemic that rages within the prison system, where the H.I.V. infection rates are many times as high as in the world outside. Strategies for fighting disease behind bars are better developed in Europe, where the World Health Organization is 10 years into a public discussion project aimed at slowing the spread of H.I.V. and other deadly infections in the prison population. The Europeans seem to have grasped the idea that infections contracted behind bars end up back in the broader society when infected inmates get out.

title: Art in Review; Lyonel Feininger (1871-1956)
description: A Small Retrospective of Works on Paper Achim Moeller Fine Art 167 East 73rd Street, Manhattan Through Sept. 16

title: In Washington, Taking the Express Lane to Diversity
description: LARGE law firms are generally not diverse places. Even though law schools for years have produced graduates of increasingly varied backgrounds, these young lawyers seem not to stay long enough to rise through the ranks of senior associates and eventually become partners.

title: As Leaders Hold Steady, a Rider Chases a Dream
description: MENDE, France, July 21 - He is one of the other American riders in the Tour de France, the ones not named Lance Armstrong. And for a few minutes on Thursday, after the first 10 riders had crossed the finish line in one of the final stages of this year's race, Levi Leipheimer seemed to have a shot at realizing his own, more modest, goal in the Tour de France.

title: The Listings: July 22 -- July 28; 'PHILOSOPHICAL TOYS'
description: This exceptionally interesting exhibition organized by Sina Najafi, the editor in chief of Cabinet magazine, introduces three ingenious people -- none of whom are nominally artists -- who share a belief that human beings learn best when the spirit of play is systematically engaged. In the 1830's, Friedrich Frbel devised his famous educational-system kindergarten, which had children play with objects of increasing geometrical complexity. The exhibition presents an array of building-block sets, puzzles and paper construction kits based on Frbel's system from the collection of Norman Brosterman, author of the book "Inventing Kindergarten." In the early 1950's, Shea Zellweger developed a system of logic based on geometrical relations among the letters of his own "logic alphabet," and, in the 70's, he created colorful, three-dimensional toylike objects that model those relations -- see "Logic Garnet," above. And in recent times, Jeannine Mosely, an electrical engineer who designs geometrical modeling software, has applied her mathematical interests to the construction of folded-paper objects. Here she presents a 26-letter "Minimalist Origami" alphabet in which each letter is produced by folding a single square sheet of paper, differently colored on either side, just four times. Also made from single sheets are her three-dimensional "Origami Buds," which look like eggs in individual protective holders. Contemplating the works of these singularly inventive people is oddly tantalizing: the pieces make you feel close to the creative, problem-solving center of the mind. (Apexart, 291 Church Street, TriBeCa, (212)431-5270, through July 30.) KEN JOHNSON

title: In His Opinions, Nominee Favors Judicial Caution
description: A look at the 49 published opinions of Judge John G. Roberts, President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court, reveals a distinct judicial philosophy, one that favors a strong executive, a cautious and self-effacing judiciary, limited federal power, and individual responsibility.

title: Google Profit Soars Again, Beyond High Expectations

Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Man Charged With Identity Thefts
description: Paul Bauers, 60, of Astoria, was charged yesterday with theft and fraud after prosecutors said he stole the identities of three doctors and used their personal information to apply for more than $220,000 in loans, said the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown. Mr. Bauers was charged with 51 counts of larceny, identity theft, fraud and other crimes and faces a possible 15 years in prison if convicted, prosecutors said. They said Mr. Bauers set up a phony company, Tech Medical Sales, and obtained the loans under the pretext of financing sales of medical equipment, including a Magnetic Resonance Imaging machine, to the doctors. The doctors called the police after they were contacted by finance companies seeking payments on the loans.

Harding, a son of one of New York's political power brokers, was sentenced yesterday to more than five years in prison for embezzling more than $400,000 as president of the New York City Housing Development Corporation, and for possessing child pornography. He was also ordered to repay much of the embezzled money.

title: Celebrating an Artist Who Was Also a Craftsman
description: New York women really love their jewelry. Last week, more than 200 of them turned up for the opening of "Georg Jensen Jewelry," the new exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center for Studies in the Decorative Arts, Design and Culture, at 18 West 86th Street in Manhattan. Proudly wearing their Jensen confections, the guests included two of Jensen's granddaughters and several collectors, among them Susan Weber Soros, the founder and director of the center and one of the authors of the 350-page catalog (Yale University Press).

title: North Korea Ties New Issue to 50's War
description: BEIJING, Friday, July 22 - North Korea said Friday that the crisis over its nuclear weapons program could be resolved if the United States was willing to normalize relations, including replacing the cease-fire that has existed since the end of the Korean War with a permanent peace agreement.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN LIEW, BARBARA FERRIS
description: VAN LIEW--Barbara Ferris. Noted architectural historian, preservationist and author, widow of General Harry R. Van Liew, U.S.M.C.R. and a United Airlines pilot passed away at her home in St. James, Long Island. She is survived by children Helen Louise Frohlich of Landrum, South Carolina, Alfred Buttler Van Liew of Middletown, Rhode Island and Jeffere Ferris Van Liew of St. James, New York, a sister, Mrs. Nils Anderson, Jr. of Southport, Connecticut and brother, Herbert Henry Ferris, Jr. of Alpine, California. A memorial service will be held at 11:00 AM at St. James Episcopal Church, North Country Road, St. James, Long Island, the 25th of July, 2005. In lieu of flowers, donations may bemade to the Smithtown Historical Society, Smithtown, Long Island, New York.

title: National Briefing | Science And Health: Mental Health Care Overhaul
description: The government will promote an overhaul of the nation's mental health care system, focusing on early diagnosis and treatment, coordinating state and community clinics, and helping people with mental illnesses find work and housing, the Department of Health and Human Services said. The plan is based on recommendations made in 2003 by a panel President Bush convened, and backed by six cabinet-level departments. The new agenda encourages the screening of minors for mental health problems, the most controversial of the recommendations, but only with parental permission. Benedict Carey (NYT)

He is survived by his wife, Kler Baruh and his four sons Isak & Semi of Switzerland, and Semih & Victor of New York. Funeral Services will be held on July 22 in Nice, France.

title: In legendary birthplace of coffee, an un-Starbucks
Sorrow in Harmony With the Sublime
description: At the end of Gus Van Sant's mesmerizing dream of a film, "Last Days," the director adds a cautionary note. Although "inspired" by the last days of Kurt Cobain, the film ends with a disclaimer stating that "it is a work of fiction and the characters and events portrayed in the film are also fictional." A similar disclaimer could have been fixed to Cobain himself. By the time he put a shotgun to his head in April 1994, it had become hard to tell which Cobain was real and which was fiction -- tortured genius, reluctant rocker, henpecked husband, depressive, addict or martyr -- a mystery that only deepened after he was nailed to the cross.

title: Quarterback Lifts Texas to National Title Expectations
description: HOUSTON, July 21 - It has been almost seven months since Vince Young hoisted the Rose Bowl's most valuable player trophy on New Year's Day, and Young, the quarterback of the Texas Longhorns, is still adjusting to his elevated celebrity status.

title: Echoes and Theories, but No Solid Links in London Bombings
description: LONDON, July 21 - The blueprint for Thursday's attempted terrorist strike seemed to resemble the deadly attacks of a fortnight ago: four small bombs, carried in backpacks, designed to kill and spread chaos as they exploded nearly simultaneously on three subway trains and a red double-decker bus.

Arts, Briefly; Moving to Warner Books
description: Jonathan Karp, below, who resigned suddenly last month as editor in chief of Random House Inc.'s flagship imprint, has been named publisher and editor in chief of a new imprint for Warner Books. The imprint, to be called Warner Twelve, will publish one book a month, far fewer than most major publishing divisions but in line with the output of some specialty publishers. Mr. Karp said that he would personally edit each book and that he would report to Jamie Raab, the publisher of Warner Books. "I want to be able to assure readers that each book matters," Mr. Karp said in a statement. "And by publishing no more than one book per month, I'll also be able to assure authors and literary agents that each of our books will have a clear shot at reaching its audience." EDWARD WYATT

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISS, FREDRIC H.
description: PREISS--Fredric H. Age 84. Died peacefully on Thursday July 21 after a long illness and valiant fight. He was a man of wide-ranging interests and talents--a musician, athlete, collector of art and an involved citizen of White Plains, NY. He was the deeply loved husband of Henriette, devoted father of Patricia Preiss-Harris (William), Richard (Cathy), David (Lori), fond stepfather of Henry (Ruth) Blinder, and Jon Blinder. His eight grandchildren adored Poppa Fred: Adam, Emily, Aaron, Abigail, Jordan and Joshua Preiss, Sarah Harris and Hanna Blinder. Funeral service Sunday July 24 at 10 AM, Congregation Emanu-El of Westchester, Rye, NY. 914-967-4382. PREISS--Fredric. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Fredric Preiss, and extend sincere condolences to his family. Charles J. Block, President

title: Giving the Hatemongers No Place to Hide
description: I wasn't surprised to read that British police officers in white protective suits and blue gloves were combing through the Iqra Learning Center bookstore in Leeds for clues to the 7/7 London bombings. Some of the 7/7 bombers hung out at the bookstore. And I won't be surprised if today's bombers also sampled the literature there.

World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Flights Grounded For Fuel
description: Air Zimbabwe, the state-run airline, has suspended flights to Victoria Falls, London and Johannesburg because it cannot afford fuel for its tiny fleet of jet and prop-jet passenger aircraft, the daily government-run newspaper, The Herald, reported. Zimbabwe suffers a chronic fuel shortage because it lacks enough foreign currency to buy imported gasoline and kerosene. The airline has endured international ridicule because of management and financial debacles. The Herald reported that a London-Harare flight was delayed for seven hours on Wednesday while airline officials scrounged for jet fuel. Airline officials said only that some flights had been suspended, but that "some are operational as usual." Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Looking Into the Divine Eyes of Spiritual Sculptures
description: The opening of the eyes is one of the very last steps in the making of a Hindu religious sculpture. A priest will ritually scrape the eye with a golden needle, or add an extra flick of paint, and a figure cast in bronze or carved in stone, a work of "fine art" in our dry vocabulary, becomes something else: a divinity who returns our gaze.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article on Wednesday about President Bush's nomination of John G. Roberts to the Supreme Court and its effect on Democratic opposition misstated the stance of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut. Senator Lieberman had been quoted last week by The Hartford Courant as saying Judge Roberts was "in the ballpark" as someone who could be considered without sparking an uproar in the Senate. He did not say that he was likely to support Judge Roberts if he were nominated.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Where Scoops Go to Die
description: In the Queens courthouse press room, there are two large metal file cabinets with three old typewriters on top, each supporting an old telephone. The tools of the trade are stacked like headstones, as if to memorialize a bygone era of newspapering.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RINGLER, ISIDORE
description: RINGLER--Isidore. The Jewish Center mourns the passing of the husband of our member, Miriam Ringler, father of Rachel Ringler and father-in-law of Yossi Siegel. May their entire family be comforted among all who mourn for Zion & Jerusalem. Ari Berman, Rabbi Joseph S. Kaplan, President Paulette Papilsky, Sisterhood RINGLER -- Isidore (Izzy). Born February 27, 1922. Adoring husband of Miriam, proud father of Cheryl (Steven), Louise (Mitchell) and Rachel (Yossi). Cherished grandfather of Adam (Melissa), Joshua (Penny) & Sara Schildkraut, Sarene, Ariel and Matthew Leeds, Alana, Sam and Talia Siegel, Howard (Jaime) and Paul Jeruchimowitz. Greatgrandfather of Madeline, Eli, Jonah, Caylie and Natalie. Survived by sisters Esther Preisler, Trude Vick & Goldie Bagatelle. Izzy served with pride and distinction with The Ozarks 102nd Infantry Division in WWII. Like his name, Yitzhak, he had an easy laugh. His wife, children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren were his whole world and his legacy. Funeral Friday 10 AM at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue and 91st Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHELLEY, RUTH
description: SHELLEY--Ruth. On July 21, 2005. Beloved mother of Paul Silagi. Beloved grandmother of Nicole and Todd. Great grandmother of Megan. She loved her family very much. Visiting hours 7-9PM Sunday, funeral service Monday, 1PM at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hostility persists on divided Cyprus
The Met, Putting Its Best Face Forward
description: AFTER 103 years, even the face of a goddess shows its age.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Acela Trains To Travel North Of New York
description: Amtrak plans to resume Acela Express service north of New York on Saturday, for the first time since the trains were halted on April 15 because of cracks in the brakes. The high-speed trains re-entered service between New York and Washington on July 11. Amtrak will run one Acela to Boston on Saturday and bring it back on Sunday. Beginning on Monday it will run one round-trip daily between Boston and Washington. The railroad expects to have all 20 repaired by fall. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Before Homer Simpson, There Was Commedia dell'Arte
description: Teenagers attending the Piccolo Teatro di Milano production of "Arlecchino, Servant of Two Masters" at the Lincoln Center Festival should be advised at the start that the fellow in the creepy black mask has not misplaced his chainsaw. He is, in fact, the hapless but resourceful title character, and despite his feistiness, he wouldn't hurt a fly. Instead of chasing nubile young women around with nasty intentions, he will be promoting a more benign form of mayhem, the theatrical delirium that was born a few centuries ago in Italy and called commedia dell'arte.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Scattered Electricity Failures
description: Power failures left about 33 households in Brooklyn and Queens without electricity last evening, some for a second day, a spokesman for Con Edison said. And in Far Rockaway, residents of the Ocean Village complex were without power for a fifth day. In Fort Greene, Brooklyn, some blocks were without electricity as Con Ed delivered reduced power to residents in a two-block area that lost power on Wednesday. Street lights were out on South Portland Avenue and South Elliott Place. At 9 p.m. at the Snip Snap Hair Salon at 66 Lafayette Avenue, Donette Senior, above, read a newspaper as her son, Marlon, 12, held a flashlight. A spokeswoman for the Long Island Power Authority, which provides power to Ocean Village in Far Rockaway, said that the building was receiving power from the utility but could not deliver it because of an equipment breakdown. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Spitzer Close to Settlement With Music Conglomerate
description: Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, is close to a settlement with one of the worldAs largest record companies to resolve accusations that it used improper tactics to influence radio programmers to play its songs, people involved in the discussions said last night.

title: Prosecutor in Essex Has the Job, Permanently
description: NEWARK, July 21 - It has been nearly six years since Essex County had a prosecutor who was not an "acting" prosecutor.

title: China No Longer to Peg Currency Only to Dollar
description: SHANGHAI, July 21 - After at least two years of resisting intense political and diplomatic pressure from its biggest trading partners, China said on Thursday that it would no longer peg its currency strictly to the dollar, a step that could allow it to rise gradually in value over time.

description: The Maytag board rebuffed the Whirlpool Corporation's $1.36 billion takeover bid late yesterday, telling investors that it continued to support its previous agreement to be sold for $1.13 billion to Ripplewood Holdings, a private equity firm.

title: Israel's war of the colors

description: Wearing a two-toned guayabera and a wide smile, Louis J. Eppolito, a retired city detective accused of being a paid Mafia killer, walked out of Brooklyn Federal Court after posting bail yesterday. He proclaimed his innocence and said he has long been plagued by his family ties to the mob.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 21 - With time running out in a Concacaf Gold Cup semifinal Thursday night, the United States was down a goal, a head coach and two starters.

title: China's Opaque Currency Policy
description: An old Chinese saying holds that the longest journey begins with the first step, but in the case of China's currency policy shift yesterday, the destination of the journey has been left completely unclear and the chosen route has many risks.

title: Four Arizona Students From Mexico Forestall Their Deportation
description: An immigration judge in Phoenix threw out a deportation case against four Arizona students on Thursday, ruling that they were illegally interrogated by immigration authorities during a high school trip they took to Niagara Falls three years ago.

description: WASHINGTON, July 22 - The Transportation Security Administration violated the federal Privacy Act by creating a database of aviation passenger records that merged airline records with commercial data in an improper way, government auditors said Friday.

title: Endangered Ferret Needs Its Prey, Furthering Ranchers' Woes
description: CANATA BASIN, S.D., July 20 - The beams of four spotlights swept the dust and rock and patches of grass growing like uneven stubble in the Badlands. It was a little past midnight, and the four spotters, biologists with the National Park Service, had fanned out in search of two little green eyes looking back at them.

title: 9 Campers Saw Staff Drinking, the Police Say
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 22 - The brochure promised a challenging week of competitive swimming under the guidance of Fairfield University's illustrious swim coach William Farley and supervised night activities centered on team-building. But as campers at a Nike swim camp told the police, their time away from home was challenging for all the wrong reasons, and hardly supervised.

title: Lock and Load
description: I have a name for it: 1775 disease. The United States of America wasn't born of the pretty words from Jefferson's pen in the declaration signed on July 4, 1776. It was born of anonymous gunfire at Lexington on April 19, 1775. And ever since, we have carried our violent nativity within us like a virus, a virus that lies dormant from time to time only to break out again and again.

title: John Herald, 65, Folk Singer and Guitarist, Dies
description: John Herald, a guitarist and singer whose group the Greenbriar Boys was among the first bluegrass bands in New York in the 1960's, died on Monday at his home in West Hurley, N.Y. He was 65.

title: As Armstrong Closes on Paris, Races Within the Race Continue
description: LE PUY-EN-VELAY, France, July 22 - Lance Armstrong smoothly moved a day closer to his coronation and retirement while spending a quiet Friday afternoon in the countryside as the Tour de France followed a script as inflexible as that of a Kabuki drama.

description: It was a week full of earnings reports -- some good, some bad -- more terrorism; testimony from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve; and the announcement that China was revaluing its currency.

description: Chicago - EVEN in calmer times, the words coming from the cockpit -- never mind the clipped tightness in the captain's voice -- would have caught the attention of the passengers. "We're going to be turning back to Chicago," the voice said, with not much more explanation than that.

description: DALY--Margaret A., "Peggy", (nee Hurley), of Edison, NJ on Thursday, July 21, 2005, age 66. Loving wife of Daniel F. Daly; devoted mother of Daniel J. Daly of Edison and Kathleen Kozak and her husband Bryan of San Antonio, TX; beloved sister of Jack Hurley of Long Island, NY and twin sister, Maureen Maroney of Jamesville, VA; cherished grandmother of two. Funeral services will be held on Monday, July 25, 2005 at 8:30 AM at the Gosselin Funeral Home, 660 New Dover Road, Edison NJ, followed by a 9:30 AM Mass at St. Helena's R.C. Church, Edison, NJ. Burial to follow in Holy Cross Cemetery, Brooklyn, NY. Visitation Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. Memorial gifts in honor of Peggy Daly may be made to: St. Jean Baptiste High School, 173 E. 75th St, NY, NY 10021 or NJ Coalition for Inclusive Education, 9 Auer Ct, Suite H., East Brunswick, N.J. 08816.

title: Is There Anyone Out There Who Can Read My Tag?
description: Over the last 20 years, tens of millions of dogs, cats and other pets have been implanted with tiny radio identification tags that are used to reunite tens of thousands of strays annually with their owners.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Nepal: Peacekeepers Sentenced To Prison
description: The Royal Nepal Army said a military court had sentenced six soldiers to three months in prison for sex abuses committed a few months ago while deployed as United Nations peacekeepers in Congo, the New China News Agency reported. Three of the soldiers were also demoted, said Brig. Gen. Deepak Gurung, an army spokesman.

title: Metro Briefing | Connecticut: Newtown: Woman Admits Being A Madam
description: A woman pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Bridgeport to money laundering and using health clubs in three Connecticut cities to promote prostitution, according to the United States attorney. The woman, Patricia Gougelmann, 66, of Newtown, owned Cleopatra's Spa in Waterbury, Genesis in Danbury, and Dolce Vita in Bridgeport. She admitted in court that the clubs were houses of prostitution that took in about $1.1 million between January 1998 and March 2004. Ms. Gougelmann is scheduled to be sentenced on Oct. 24. She faces a maximum prison term of 20 years and $500,000 in fines.

Loving mother of John Graubard. Dear grandmother of Naomi Kinderman and Michael Graubard. Services at Temple Beth El, 350 Roxbury Road, Stamford, CT, at 9:30 A.M. on Sunday, July 24. Donations to the Visiting Nurse Service of Greater New York in lieu of flowers.

description: In Britain, Polanski Wins Suit Against Vanity Fair A British jury declared that Vanity Fair magazine libeled the film director Roman Polanski, and the magazine was ordered to pay $87,700 in damages. The verdict essentially means that Vanity Fair was unable to prove that an encounter it said he had with a woman at a New York restaurant in 1969 had actually occurred. THE ARTS, PAGE B7

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend yesterday about podcasts referred incorrectly to Dan Klass, creator of "The Bitterest Pill." While he has indeed called himself an addict, he said that the description was intended as a humorous reference likening himself to fans of his podcast who call themselves addicts, and that he is not really an addict.

title: Giambi Focuses on Comeback, Not His Doubters
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 22 - Jason Giambi heard everything. He knows how many people thought he was finished as an elite hitter, how many people considered him a product of steroids and little else. He knows who buried him last winter and into this season.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Big Brother,' They're Watching You
description: There were no surprises in Nielsen's estimates for Thursday night. As usual on Thursdays, CBS won every hour. "Big Brother," on which an unpopular contestant, Michael Donnellan, below, was evicted from the house in a 9-1 vote, drew 8.02 million viewers. That led into repeats of "CSI," the most-watched show of the night with an audience of 14.19 million, and "Without a Trace" (12.69 million). CBS was also dominant among 18-to-49-year-olds, and was No. 1 among that audience in every half-hour slot. Over all, ABC and UPN tied for second among adults 18 to 49. UPN's lineup was made up solely of its steady performer "WWE Smackdown!" (4.74 million). On ABC, the dating documentary series "Hooking Up" turned in a weak performance in its second week, with 4.72 million total viewers. But a "Primetime Live," featuring the sister of Elizabeth Smart, the Utah girl who was kidnapped, brought in an audience of 6.7 million and bolstered the network's average.

title: Escaping From Liszt's Shadow
description: An attraction of the International Keyboard Institute and Festival at the Mannes College of Music is the diversity of its roster. Even as this year's festival seems, at times, to be a celebration of Liszt, several decidedly non-Lisztians have been given their share of the spotlight. Ursula Oppens, in her recital on Wednesday evening, spoke for those more interested in the musical world before and after Liszt -- although anyone looking for Liszt's shadow in her program might have found it in Frederic Rzewski's "Winnsboro Cotton Mill Blues" and in "La Valse," Ravel's swirling and sometimes muscular evocation of the ballroom.

title: Death Penalty to Be Sought in Killing of Two Police Detectives
description: Federal prosecutors in Brooklyn announced yesterday that they planned to seek the death penalty against a man accused of fatally shooting two police detectives in an undercover gun purchase on Staten Island two years ago.

title: Thorny Issues Remain on Draft of New Constitution for Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 22 - With only about three weeks left before the parliamentary deadline for the draft of a new constitution, a senior Western diplomat in Baghdad said Friday that some of the most contentious issues still remain to be resolved, including regional autonomy, women's rights, electoral law and the control of revenues from natural resources.

title: Lawyer Says He Leaked Memo to Writer in Corruption Case
description: A defense lawyer admitted at a hearing yesterday that he gave a court-sealed document to a reporter at The Plain Dealer regarding a federal investigation into suspected corruption by a former mayor of Cleveland.

title: In Violin Sections, Women Make Their Presence Heard
description: A male violinist's discrimination suit against the New York Philharmonic underscores a little-noted phenomenon: women have come to dominate the violin sections of some of the nation's leading orchestras, or at least hold their own. And their numbers among violin players have also helped raise their prominence as concertmasters, the most important orchestra jobs after the conductors.

The Fitzgerald Theater, which is serving as set piece, soundstage and framing device for the Robert Altman film about a dying radio show that bears striking similarities to "A Prairie Home Companion," is no different.

Deal Is Ratified, and N.H.L. Is Ready to Roll
description: With the National Hockey League shut down for the 2004-5 season because of a labor lockout, its dedicated followers pined for the game with the anguish of spurned lovers.

title: Making Our Subways Safer in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Handcuffs and Stethoscopes
description: The current zeal for sending doctors to jail for writing painkiller prescriptions may seem baffling, especially to the patients who relied on the doctors for pain relief. But if you consider it from the perspective of the agents raiding the doctors' offices, you can see a certain logic.

title: United States to Play Final of Gold Cup Minus Arena
description: BASKING RIDGE, N.J., July 22 - Bruce Arena, the manager of the United States men's soccer team, will not be on the sideline when his team takes on Panama in the finals of the Concacaf Gold Cup on Sunday. He must serve a one-game suspension after being ejected for arguing with game officials during a semifinal against Honduras on Thursday night.

title: On the Job, and Dissenting
description: Judge John G. Roberts may have his eyes on a new job on the United States Supreme Court, but he is not neglecting his current one on the federal appeals court in Washington. He issued a dissent yesterday, disagreeing with a decision by two of his more liberal colleagues to reverse a criminal conviction because of an illegal search.

title: Corrections
description: A Critic's Notebook article in Weekend yesterday about podcasts referred incorrectly to Dan Klass, creator of "The Bitterest Pill." While he has indeed called himself an addict, he said that the description was intended as a humorous reference likening himself to fans of his podcast who call themselves addicts, and that he is not really an addict. (Go to Article)

title: Briefly: Patients could set off airport radiation alarms
Large penalty in U.S. for Pinault firm
Toyota leads Asia drive in Europe
A Wider Inquiry on Fires in Ford Trucks
description: DETROIT, July 22 - As Ford Motor faces numerous lawsuits and tries to determine why hundreds of its trucks have burst into flames, federal authorities have widened their investigation into whether a faulty cruise control switch is causing the fires.

title: Tending the Memories of an Enduring Polish Family
description: KRAKOW, Poland - THE photograph is one of those sepia-toned images full of suggestions about the unrecoverable past: two women, one young, one older, seated on wicker chairs in a somewhat tangled garden, while lying at their feet is a young girl, maybe 9 or 10, her hand resting in what look like buttercups.

title: Corrections
description: A credit last Saturday for a front-page picture of rotting boxes of mortar rounds at a Ukraine arms depot misspelled the photographer's surname. He was Nikolai Khalip, not Khalap.

title: The Biology of No-Limit Hold'em
description: The winner of every World Series event this year was a man, as were all nine final tablists in the championship. So are the 69 highest-ranked tournament players. Jennifer Harman is No.70, Cyndy Violette No.72, Annie Duke No.374. Harman, Violette and Duke have all won bracelets, and Harman more than holds her own every night in the Bellagio's famous mixed game, which requires mastering a dizzying variety of poker forms and putting about $100,000 in action.

title: Making Our Subways Safer in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: One French icon goes to the Americans
Making Our Subways Safer in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: Market watch: Banks offering cheaper money are storing up trouble
Sizing Up Judge Roberts
description: THE timing of President Bush's announcement Tuesday night that he would nominate John G. Roberts, a federal appeals court judge with a conservative record, to the Supreme Court left the print media a bit hamstrung (by design, some say). Deadline-pressured newspaper editors scrambled to publish (mostly) serviceable articles the next day.

title: Off the Charts: Catching a falling knife
Cycling: A bucolic outing as the end nears
Police Make Second Arrest in London Bombings
description: LONDON, July 23 - The British police said today that they arrested a second suspect in the failed bombings two days ago, as the city sought to take stock of a bewildering three weeks that propelled its citizens from euphoria to gloom.

title: In Search of the Characters of New York
description: If you are not the sort of person who cares deeply about the Old World subtleties of Fournier, the retro-hipster swirl of Ministry Script or the plain-vanilla, rock-ribbed dependability of Helvetica -- nor the sort immediately able to identify the typeface you are reading right now as 8.7-point Imperial -- then you were probably not aware that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg declared this week Type Week in New York City.

title: Near No Man's Land, a Quest for Unity and Peace
description: HEYRI ART VALLEY, South Korea - The hill above Heyri Art Valley, an artists' village under construction about four miles south of the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea, is still marked by trenches from the 1950-53 Korean War. In one of these, the Korean artist Cho Duck Hyun has placed resin model heads that suggest the remains of South Korean soldiers excavated from the hillside. Nearby, a trail of Korean characters in rusted steel traces its way to the top of the hill, where steel panels with cut-out characters-- -- all part of a sculpture by Lim Ok Sang -- form a poem dedicated to a South Korean spy who was sent to the North in the 1970's and never returned. The themes of war and partition, here on the world's most fortified border, find further elaboration inside Heyri Art Valley's Jung Han Sook Memorial Hall, where two Swedish artists have installed the mock embassy of Elgaland-Vargaland. This is a mythical country made up of the frontiers of the world's divided territories. The flag is white with a red zigzag, and the artists offer passports and ministerial positions to anyone who applies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MILMAN, DONALD. PH.D.
description: MILMAN--Donald. Ph.D. At the age of 81, of Northport, Long Island and formerly of East Norwich, LI on July 21, 2005. Beloved husband of Ellen Milman. Devoted father of Douglas Milman and Lise McNamara. Fond father-inlaw of Stephen McNamara. Loving stepfather of Connie Dodds and Glenn Riggs. Proud grandfather of Matthew, Ryan and Kelsey. Cherished step grandfather of Alexandra, Emma, Taylor and Connor. Religious service at the Francis P. DeVine Funeral Home, Oyster Bay, Monday 10 AM. Interment to follow at Brookville Cemetery. Donations may be made to the Post Doctoral Program in Psychoanalysis and Psychotherapy, C/O Adelphi University, 1 South Street, Garden City, NY 11530.

title: Soon in Space: Repair Work, Some Walks and Music
description: Stephen K. Robinson is an astronaut who tries to combine his love of flying with the worlds of music and art.

title: London tourism outlookuncertain but worrisome
Polanski Wins Vanity Fair Libel Suit
description: LONDON, July 22 - A jury declared on Friday that Vanity Fair magazine libeled the film director Roman Polanski by describing an encounter it said he had at Elaine's restaurant in Manhattan 36 years ago. Vanity Fair was ordered to pay 50,000 ($87,700) in damages and a substantial portion of Mr. Polanski's legal costs.

title: Male stars find a home in design
Pricing Merck as Legal Storm Gathers
description: STOCKS can plunge if their quarterly earnings come in a penny below forecast, so how is anyone supposed to divine the right price for a stock like Merck's when the company is facing potential legal liability estimated as high as one-fourth of its entire value?

title: Eugene Record, 64, Singer and Writer for Chi-Lites, Dies
description: Eugene Record, the leader of the 1970's harmony group the Chi-Lites, which scored hits with mellifluous soul ballads like "Oh Girl" and "Have You Seen Her?," died yesterday. He was 64.

title: Carrying Duffels, and Bearing the Weight of Uncertainty
description: Grunting down the stairs to the A train, Kristin Kumpf, 20, hitches, heaves and then shifts her big duffel bag, its weight all but pitching her into Jennifer Kern, also 20, who lugs her own bag, crammed with what appears to be an entire dresser full of clothes, and maybe the dresser, too.

title: SUBWAY SUSPECT IS SHOT TO DEATH BY LONDON POLICE
description: LONDON, July 22 - Under a shoot-to-kill order after terrorist attacks that have traumatized Britain, plainclothes police officers on Friday fatally shot a suspect on a subway train as horrified passengers looked on.

title: A Showcase for Chivalry and Trouble
description: The Bolshoi Ballet's "Don Quixote" is full of the usual tomfoolery involving Kitri, the feisty daughter of an innkeeper, and Basil, a barber, as they valiantly forge a comic path to love and happiness. But for those accustomed to American Ballet Theater's streamlined version, Alexei Fadeechev's production, which continued at the Metropolitan Opera House on Tuesday and Wednesday, features several departures.

title: Ferrer Gets Endorsements From Harlem and Brooklyn Pastors
description: Fernando Ferrer, a Democratic candidate for mayor, received endorsements yesterday from two ministers of largely black congregations, a sign that his campaign was recovering from his controversial remarks that the police shooting of Amadou Diallo, an unarmed African immigrant, was not a crime.

title: Brown and Thomas: One Step at a Time
description: Larry Brown had his anticipated summit meeting with Isiah Thomas, and by all accounts it was pleasant and productive. But Brown's fate still rests on the wishes of his wife and children and on his own state of mind, and he said he would contemplate all of those matters this the weekend.

title: 2 Democrats Are Nominated to Fill Positions on S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 - President Bush on Friday nominated Roel C. Campos and Annette Nazareth to fill the two Democratic seats on the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Government Defies an Order to Release Iraq Abuse Photos
description: Correction Appended

title: Briefs:Windows version due in 2006
U.S. and Philippines Join Forces to Pursue Terrorist Leader
description: MANILA, July 22 - American and Philippine military forces have launched a joint operation to capture the leader of Abu Sayyaf, a small terrorist group that has kidnapped scores of people and beheaded several, including one American, United States and Philippine military officials said this week.

title: Drawing Center May Drop Plan to Move to Ground Zero
description: A year after being chosen as one of the cultural anchors on the World Trade Center site, but now embroiled in a controversy over what it might exhibit there, the Drawing Center may end up elsewhere in Lower Manhattan.

title: China's Shot Heard Around the World
description: RARELY has so little meant so much to so many. China's decision to give its currency a little more wiggle room overshadowed meaty news about some major American corporations struggling to right themselves after years at sea. This in addition to developments in another tussle involving China. It was nearly enough to make a Supreme Court nomination an afterthought.

title: A bad day for nonproliferation
EU halts imports of Chinese sweaters
Bush Urges Retirees to Get Behind His 'Senior Security Package'
description: ATLANTA, July 22 - With his Social Security legislation stymied in Congress and millions of eligible people apparently reluctant to sign up for the Medicare drug benefit that was the main domestic policy accomplishment of his first term, President Bush had a rally here on Friday to advance what he called his "senior security package."

title: Stem Cell Bill, Once Seen as a Sure Thing, Is Now Mired in Uncertainty
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 - A measure to expand federal financing for human embryonic stem cell research, passed by the House and once considered a shoo-in for adoption by the Senate, is tangled up in a procedural dispute that will probably delay a vote until fall -- and could wind up killing the bill, its chief Republican backer said.

title: Making Our Subways Safer in the Age of Terror (14 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 5 Shots in a Train Car Leave Londoners Shaken
description: LONDON, July 22 - It was around 10 a.m. on a sunny, summery Friday when London crossed a once-unthinkable line in its unfolding war on terror.

title: Currency rises in Malaysia
Some Disassembly Required
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 22 - Think of Hewlett-Packard as the technology world's version of the Hydra, the nine-headed, marsh-dwelling serpent of Greek mythology. The company sells a dizzying array of products, including printers and personal computers, of course, but also photocopiers, plasma televisions, digital projectors and a catalog of hardware and software products so thorough and arcane it would make the geeks running your average corporate computer center drool like Homer Simpson eyeing a doughnut.

title: S.U.V. Wreck at an Auction Injures 20
description: An elderly employee at a Long Island vehicle auction lost control of a sport utility vehicle yesterday and smashed into six other cars before hitting the concrete auction house, the Suffolk County police said. As many as 20 of the estimated 400 people at the auction were hurt, though none of the injuries were life-threatening, the police said.

title: Cheney Visits New Jersey to Raise Money for the Republican in the Governor's Race
description: PRINCETON, N.J., July 22 - In a major political event eagerly anticipated by Republicans and Democrats alike, Vice President Dick Cheney descended upon New Jersey on Friday night to help raise money for -- and elevate the profile of -- Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican running against Senator Jon S. Corzine for governor.

title: Making Our Subways Safer in the Age of Terror
description: To the Editor:

title: She's Not Just the Publisher, She's the Cover Model, Too
description: Judith Regan already has a healthy rsum: publisher, movie producer, television executive, talk-show host. To that list, add pinup girl.

title: Thank These Sweaty Men for Your Air-Conditioning
description: Before you complain about this week's heat and humidity, consider the Ravenswood power plant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: A Plea for Pro Athletes to Help Stop Sweatshops
description: A human rights advocate concerned with sweatshop labor says some athletic apparel is made under dismal working conditions, and he is calling on professional athletes to help stop the practice.

title: Across Asia, China's act wins praise
Sony BMG Called Close to Settlement With Spitzer
description: Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, is close to a settlement with one of the world's largest record companies to resolve accusations that it used improper tactics to influence radio programmers to play its songs, people involved in the discussions said last night.

title: The French Forgive a Former Rider's Tainted Past
description: LE PUY-EN-VELAY, France, July 22 - Despite the considerable pressure he faces each July during the Tour de France, Lance Armstrong usually manages to remain gracious. But last year, he momentarily buckled, taking a backhanded verbal swipe at one of his competitors.

title: Corrections
description: An art entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about a film at the New Museum of Contemporary Art in Chelsea misspelled the given name of the artist who made it. He is Aernout Mik, not Aernot.

title: New Incidents Heighten Tensions Among British Muslims
description: LEEDS, England, July 22 - A Muslim-owned store in a Leeds suburb was set ablaze Friday night in what witnesses called a racially motivated crime. The attack heightened tensions among Muslims already jittery about a fatal shooting by the London police that the force linked to its investigation of the subway bombing attempts the previous day.

title: Is This Game Coyness a Crime?
description: At the big annual video game convention in Los Angeles two months ago, Rockstar Games, creator of the now-infamous Grand Theft Auto series, demonstrated perfectly its special role in the game world.

title: A Return Engagement for a Ground Zero Oasis
description: It could never be just another park renovation.

title: Kimberly-Clark Announces Plans to Cut 6,000 Jobs and Close 20 Factories
description: DALLAS, July 22 - Kimberly-Clark said on Friday that it would cut 6,000 jobs and close or sell 20 manufacturing plants by the end of 2008 as part of a broad-based strategy to reduce costs.

title: No more tolerance?
London police kill a man in subway
World Briefing | Europe: Spain: No Smoking On Hikes
description: The government banned smoking in forests for the rest of the summer, saying the worst drought in at least 60 years had turned the country's woodlands into a tinderbox that could erupt in flames at any moment. The ban, one of several fire-prevention measures, came nearly a week after 11 firefighters died in a forest fire in the Guadalajara Province, east of Madrid. The blaze apparently started with a campfire. Renwick McLean (NYT)

title: It's How You Do the Math, Analysts Say of Bond Issue
description: ALBANY, July 22 - Behind the increasingly personal fight between Gov. George E. Pataki and State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi over a proposal to refinance $2.9 billion worth of transportation bonds is a question of math, although perhaps not a simple one.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-7

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Monday about a shootout outside a church in Queens in which two police officers and the man who fired on them were injured misstated the academic status of the suspect, Kevin Davy. He is not a student at the Art Institute of New York City in SoHo, according to the school. His relatives did not respond to attempts to find out which school, if any, he attends.

title: Scary Runways, Scary Skies
description: For those of us who travel, reports of near collisions on the runway send a jolt up the spine. Such incidents are admittedly rare. But there is no such thing as rare enough when you're strapped into your seat and waiting for takeoff.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Bulgaria: Minority Government To Form
description: The former ruling centrists refused to join a coalition government, a decision that will force the Bulgarian Socialist Party, which won the June 25 parliamentary elections, to form a minority government. For close to a month the Socialist leader, Sergei Stanishev, had been negotiating a possible alliance with the party of the departing prime minister, Simeon Saxe-Coburg, the onetime king. The Socialists already have the support of a party dominated by ethnic Turks, the Movement for Rights and Freedoms, but are five seats short of a majority in the 240-member Parliament. The failure to create a majority government comes as Bulgaria is under pressure to adopt essential reforms necessary for membership in the European Union. Nicholas Wood (NYT)

title: Briefly: New bride and mother among 12 killed in Iraq
What We Saw in London
description: Washington - THE British people suffered another attack this week, one that fortunately caused far less damage than the horrible events of July 7. But as they did earlier this month, the people of London responded bravely. Their courage over these harrowing few weeks reminds us that those who love freedom have prevailed against such evil before and can do so again.

title: For Thomas, Knicks' Job Is Debt Returned
description: FOR the past few weeks, the focus of the National Basketball Association has been on the bizarre turn of circumstances that led to Larry Brown's being ousted as head coach of the Detroit Pistons. A year after leading the Pistons to an N.B.A. championship and weeks after taking them back to the finals, Brown was effectively fired and then replaced. Now he's being pursued again.

Paid Notice: Deaths   ROACH, DAVID J. III.
description: ROACH--David J. III. 76 of Huntington. US Navy Veteran of WWII and the Korean conflict. Member of the US Naval Institute and National Maritime Historical Society. Loving husband of Betty. Beloved father of David IV (Valerie), Mary (Stephen) Wylong, Patrick (Nancy), Linda (Russell) Sodaro, and John (Maureen). Cherished grandfather of Katelyn, David V, Christine, Sean, Kyle, Juliane, Jane, John Patrick, and Liam. Dear brother of Justine Roach, Linda Fitzsimons, Erin Russell, James Roach and the late Jeffrey Roach. Visitation Sunday 2-5 and 7-9 PM at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Mass Monday 9:45 at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. In lieu of flowers please make donations to St. Patrick's Trocaire House, 630 New York Ave., Huntington, NY. 11743.

title: Blasts at Egyptian resort kill 88
Midsummer Mideast Madness
description: The second-to-last thing that Palestinians need is an internal civil war between members of President Mahmoud Abbas's Fatah party and militant extremists from Hamas and Islamic Jihad. It was heartening to see that after a week of the worst infighting in years, the two sides announced a cease-fire -- even if they did have a shootout four hours later.

title: Iraqis Simmer as Demand Outstrips Electricity Supply
description: ERBIL, Iraq - As the relentless summer heat in Iraq soars toward its August peak, electricity demand is roughly 25 percent higher than it was one year ago, while the supply to the nation's power grid is only slightly changed despite a $6 billion American program to rebuild the electrical infrastructure.

description: Correction Appended

title: For Ali G, More Fame But Fewer Dupes
description: Sacha Baron Cohen, the British comedian behind "Da Ali G Show" on HBO, is a master put-on artist. Playing one or another earnest yet ill-informed inquisitor, Mr. Baron Cohen seeks out the unsuspecting -- politicians preferred -- and tests their patience and good humor with inane, often offensive questions.

title: 'Feel-good' factor feeds a rush to risk
The Dancing Girls of Lahore: Selling Love and Saving Dreams in Pakistan's Ancient Pleasure District
Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, MARGARET ERSKINE
description: LEE -- Margaret Erskine. WWII Red Cross Nurse, died July 15, 2005 in Huntington, NY. She was 89. She was born in New York City, September 26, 1915 to Marion and James Erskine and grew up in Locust Valley, NY. She worked with the British Red Cross in the London Blitz, created the first USO in 1941, joined the 20th General in 1942 and served under General Stilwell on the Ledo-Burma Road. She married Burton J. Lee, Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor in 1946, was stepmother to four children, and had four of her own. She often said, "The Burma jungles were perfect training for the challenges of family life." Margaret is survived by sons, Jared and Timothy; daughters, Marion and Cecilia; stepchildren, Burton, Rosamond, Susannah and Mary Jo; brother, Drummond, and sister, Alison; 15 grandchildren and numerous great-grandchildren. Funeral service at 4 PM, Sunday, July 24, 2005, St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

title: Bridge; Honoring a Canadian Player Who Made His Doublers Sorry
description: One of the players being inducted into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame today is Percy Sheardown, known as Shorty, who won this year's von Zedtwitz award for players of the past. He owned and managed a bridge club in Toronto and became Canada's first life master in 1948. He was a brilliant card player, a great teacher and a mentor to rising Canadian experts. He died in 1993.

title: U.N. Condemns Zimbabwe for Bulldozing Urban Slums
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 22 - The United Nations on Friday condemned the mass destruction of urban slums and shantytowns in Zimbabwe by the government of President Robert G. Mugabe as a "disastrous venture," saying the policy had left 700,000 people homeless and created a "humanitarian crisis of immense proportions."

title: London police kill man in subway
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) SHAUN OF THE DEAD -- (2004). Simon Pegg (above right) plays Shaun, an appliance-store clerk, in this British horror comedy. When zombies take over London, he and a few friends band together to try to cross the city and make it to their favorite pub. Whenever they run into a band of wandering undead flesh-eaters, they just pretend to be part of the crowd.

title: Review: Printer that punches its weight
Other Views: Sydney Morning Herald, Globe and Mail, Asahi Shimbun
Cameras in Britain Record the Criminal and the Banal
description: The cameras of the London Underground never sleep.

title: Figuring Out What the Labor Deal Means
description: A free-agent free-for-all will likely precede the 2005-6 National Hockey League season, which will open Oct. 5 with all 30 teams in action. Some teams may not bear much resemblance to the teams that finished the 2003-4 season.

title: In New York, It's Open Bag or Find Exits
description: An anxious new era in the life of New York City's subways opened with the morning rush yesterday as the police began widespread searches of bags and packages in a highly visible attempt to protect the busiest transit system in the United States.

title: Army Replaces Commander in Charge of Training Iraqi Security Forces
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 - The Pentagon announced Friday that Lt. Gen. David H. Petraeus, who has been in charge of efforts to train Iraqi security forces, has completed his yearlong tour of duty and will become commander of the Army Combined Arms Center at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   BOSLER, CARL G.
description: BOSLER--Carl G. One year ago today we lost a very sweet and kind man, our father who will live in our hearts forever. "In loving memory." George and Lisa

title: Ferocious Heat Maintains Grip Across the West
description: PHOENIX, July 22 - A relentless and lethal blanket of heat has settled on much of the western United States, forcing the cancellation of dozens of airline flights, threatening the loss of electrical power, stoking wildfires and leaving 20 people dead in Phoenix alone in just the past week.

title: Getting Early Later
description: When it comes to daylight saving time, most of us are used to springing forward on the first Sunday in April and falling back on the last Sunday in October. It has been part of the pattern of our lives, a twice-a-year reminder that we agree upon keeping time by convention, and by law. Now an amendment has been added to the energy bill -- and approved by a joint Congressional committee -- that would extend daylight saving time by four weeks, so that it begins on the second Sunday of March and ends on the first Sunday of November. The amendment's sponsors claim the change would save 100,000 barrels of oil a day because Americans would use less electricity in the evenings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHELLEY, RUTH
description: SHELLEY--Ruth. On July 21, 2005. Beloved mother of Paul Silagi. Beloved grandmother of Nicole and Todd. Great grandmother of Megan. She loved her family very much. Visiting hours 7-9PM Sunday, funeral service Monday, 1PM at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bids by Banco Bilbao and ABN Amro For Two Italian Banks Fall Apart Bids for Italian banks from Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria of Spain and ABN Amro of the Netherlands fell apart yesterday after the offers failed to draw enough interest. Banco Bilbao withdrew its offer of 6.5 billion euros for Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which is based in Rome, hours before the deadline as it became clear that fewer than 1 percent of shares had been tendered. ABN Amro let its offer of 6.3 billion euros for Banca Antonveneta based in northeastern Italy, run its course, but received only about 2.2 percent of Antonveneta's shares, bringing its total stake to 27.2 percent. Rival Italian bidders had appeared for the two banks, and analysts said Antonio Fazio, above, the governor of the Bank of Italy, might have played a role. Eric Sylvers (IHT)

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Transit Union Criticizes M.T.A.
description: A union-organized panel of train operators and conductors who have been involved in evacuating passengers during emergencies said yesterday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had failed to prepare workers for the possibility of a terrorist attack. Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union has opposed the authority's recent moves to eliminate conductors on the L line and to reassign token booth clerks as roving customer service agents. In a statement, the authority's spokesman, Tom Kelly, said that all employees had been instructed on evacuating passengers and recognizing suspicious packages and customers, but added that "no amount of training or preparation is perfect or 100 percent effective."

title: A Glimpse Inside U.S. Tax Court and How It Made a Decision
description: The United States Tax Court is accustomed to operating without having to justify its actions. But this week, it did just that, explaining how it handled a long-running, contentious tax case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKEL, GLORIA
description: FRANKEL--Gloria. On July 21, 2005. She was 83. Gloria cofounded Trimtime Buttons and used both her fashion acumen and high quality standards to build a successful business. She helped others pursue their dreams. Beloved mother of Peter and Eric. Cherished grandmother of Elisabeth and Michael. Dear mother-in-law of Susan. She will be greatly missed by her family and friends. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to Memorial Hospital, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFFRON, JAMES W.
description: EFFRON--James W., 73, died peacefully after a brief illness on July 21 after a happy and well-lived life. He was the beloved husband of Dawn; adored father of Craig (Caryn), Blair (Cheryl), Drew (Sandra) and Brooke (Ross); and cherished grandfather of eight. He was born and lived proudly his entire life on the same street in Poughkeepsie, NY, and was a true and warm friend to all who knew him. After graduating from Princeton University in 1953, he served his country in the Army. He spent his career with Effron Oil Company, serving as its President for many years. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Vassar Temple, Poughkeepsie. Shiva at the Effron home in Poughkeepsie on Monday and Tuesday. Shiva in New York at 129 East 73rd Street on Wednesday from 6-9 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, to be credited to Dr. Stephen Nimer Leukemia Research. EFFRON--James. We will miss our skiing buddy! Our trips together and your unique "storytelling" will always be cherished. Our love to the entire Effron family. The Rosens: Debbie, Brett, Jamie, Rachel and Kyle

title: China Braces for Speculation in the Yuan
description: SHANGHAI, July 22 - A day after China moved to revalue its currency, the country is bracing to see whether the shift will set off a huge influx of speculative capital.
