QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "In wartime people used the tube as a shelter, a place to be protected. Now the war is in the tube"

title: Fear for the future
Paid Notice: Deaths   SEH, EDWARD
description: SEH--Edward. On July 20, at age 78. Beloved husband of Carmen Seh. Loving father of Jody Berman and Ellen Seh. Cherished grandfather of Jeb Berman. Dear brother of Rowie Samson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Saturday 7-9PM with service Sunday, 1:30 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Bethesda Memorial Hospital Fund of Boynton Beach, Florida.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Mine Adds Security After Gold Robbery
description: A gold mining company, Minera Aruntani, increased security after a group of heavily armed men stormed its mine in southern Peru, killed two guards and made off with nearly 300 pounds of gold. The robbery, which took place Thursday, stunned officials of the company, which is expected to produce 200,000 ounces of gold this year. Juan Forero (NYT)

title: House Panel Approves Bill To Upgrade Student Loans
description: Correction Appended

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Men Found Dead In Apartment
description: The decomposing bodies of two men were found in a Brooklyn apartment yesterday morning, the police said. The names of the men have not been released. The police were called to 175 Covert Street in Bushwick by neighbors who were concerned about a foul odor emanating from a third-floor apartment. When officers entered the apartment they found a white man, who appeared to be in his 30's, lying on the kitchen floor covered head to toe with a sheet. In the bedroom, they found another body, a black man in his 40's, face up in the bed and also covered with a sheet. The bodies were so badly decomposed that it was not immediately clear how the men had died, the police said. Neighbors said that the younger man had moved into the apartment about three months ago and that the older man had been a visitor for a few weeks. According to the police, neighbors had not seen the men since Wednesday. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Before disaster strikes (and it will)
Anti-Abortion Advocacy of Wife of Court Nominee Draws Interest
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 - Judge John G. Roberts has left little hard evidence of his views on abortion in recent years and is widely expected to try to avoid the issue in his coming confirmation hearings.

title: Whirlpool Raises Offer for Maytag, Hoping to Thwart Rival Bid by Ripplewood

title: Donaldson: The Exit Interview
description: I came with a mission," William H. Donaldson said the other day, reflecting on his tenure as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. In retrospect, that was the big surprise. Mr. Donaldson, who stepped down late last month after two and a half tumultuous years, was never supposed to be a man with a plan.

title: At Synagogues, Services Open Doors for the Deaf
description: Before she joined a synagogue for the deaf where services are conducted in sign language and two of the five choir members cannot hear, Roz Robinson found herself lost, unable to follow the cantor in her former synagogue as he chanted the prayers that had once been so familiar.

title: One Impediment After Another
description: People kept fumbling to free themselves from hindrances in Jaclyn Moynahan's "What's Holding You Up?," which JaxDance presented Thursday night at Studio 111 in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. One impediment led to another in this two-act production, danced to taped musical collages devised by Ann Donohue and the choreographer.

title: Times Names Editor for Digital Journalism
description: The New York Times has promoted Jonathan Landman, assistant managing editor, to the position of deputy managing editor in charge of digital journalism.

title: Stocks: Wall Street sags on Microsoft news
National Briefing | Washington: Farm Workers Join Dissident Unions
description: The United Farm Workers of America announced in Chicago that it was joining a coalition of unions that has criticized the A.F.L.-C.I.O. for not doing enough to reverse labor's decline. Arturo Rodriguez, president of the farm workers union, said he was joining the new group, the Change to Win Coalition, because it wanted more resources devoted toward unionization drives. Mr. Rodriguez said his goal was to help unionize far more immigrant workers and low- to moderate-wage Latino workers. The Change to Win coalition includes the Teamsters, the service employees, the laborers, the food and commercial workers and Unite Here. Unlike the leaders of some of those unions, Mr. Rodriguez said he was not considering quitting the A.F.L.-C.I.O. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: David Daiches, 92, Scholar of Literature and Whiskey, Dies
description: David Daiches, who was an authority on Scotch whiskey as well as Scottish and English literature, died on July 15 in Edinburgh. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DOYLE, ELLEN (NEE DENNEHY)
description: DOYLE--Ellen (nee Dennehy). Lady of the Holy Sepulchre. Beloved wife of the late Thomas M. Devoted mother of Mary Ellen, Noreen, Thomas, Patrick, Martin, Vincent, Brendan, Denis and the late Arthur. Proud grandmother. Graduate of the College of Mount Saint Vincent. Mass of Christian Burial, Immaculate Conception Church, 414 East 14 Street, Saturday, July 23, 10AM. Donations may be made to the College of Mount Saint Vincent, Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, N.Y. 10471.

description: BRODSKY--Arthur. July 21. Husband of the late Hilda. Loving father of Iris. Grandfather of Jeremy. Survived by devoted siblings, nieces & nephews. Graveside services at Riverside Cemetery, Lodi, N.J. Sunday, July 24, 11 AM.

title: Blasts in Egypt Kill at Least 59 at Sinai Resort
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, Saturday, July 23 - At least 59 people were killed in a series of powerful explosions early Saturday in the Egyptian Red Sea resort of Sharm el Sheik, Egypt's interior minister said.

title: A Big Change in Boot Camp
description: Years ago, drill sergeants accused of abusing recruits might have been only reprimanded or transferred. That is no longer true.

title: Not Your Parent's Lollapalooza
description: Billy Idol, Liz Phair and Perry Farrell were among the performers at the Lollapalooza Music Festival in Chicago.

title: Sharm el Sheik Attacks
description: A series of bombs exploded within minutes at a hotel and a coffeeshop packed with European and Egyptian tourists.

title: Baseball's Big Deals
description: Players traded in the equivalent week - between now and next Sunday - in the past decade.

title: A Hardening of Divisions
description: A look at attacks and retribution in Iraq since 2003.

title: One Capri for 'Only Visiting' and One for 'Don't Even Ask'
description: FEW specks of land yield as much romance as Capri, the fabled island that rises like a mirage from the Bay of Naples, just off the Sorrento peninsula of southern Italy. It is here that some say Odysseus resisted the seductive but deadly song of the Sirens, and the Roman emperor Tiberius caroused in orgiastic debauchery. The Russian novelist Gorki lived in exile on Capri, as did the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda, whose stay in the early 1950's inspired the film "Il Postino." Later, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis stopped by while on the yacht Christina, buying capri pants on her trips ashore.

title: Art Imitating Life, and Obsessively So
description: THE supposed super-sizing of the American documentary has reopened a greasy brown bag of ethical dilemmas. Among the contents: How close is too close? Is there a point where nonfiction filmmakers, like their cousin journalists, face what Janet Malcolm would call that eventual "moral impasse" of objectivity and exploitation?

title: In Biarritz, Catching a Wave With Aristocratic Flair
description: AT 10.30 a.m. on a sunny Wednesday in Biarritz, the promenade above the Grande Plage was still sleepy, cafe chairs piled up in leaning towers, umbrellas closed like seed pods. The long beach below was empty apart from an elderly couple taking an early constitutional and some sandpipers skittering along the water's edge.

title: Palma
description: WHY GO NOW There's no need to wait for 2007 when a Philippe Starck-designed hotel is scheduled to open in Palma's Old Town - the Spanish island of Majorca's charming but long-ignored capital is booming this summer. Not long ago Majorca's visitors would bypass Palma for the island's beach resorts. Now, thanks to the city's recent renaissance and affordable flights out of many European hubs, Palma has become one of Europe's most popular weekend destinations.

title: Yanks' Cano Playing as if He Belongs
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 23 - Robinson Cano is distracted. He is sitting at his locker earlier this week in Arlington, Tex., talking with a reporter while the Baltimore Orioles' Sammy Sosa is batting in a game on TV.

title: From Rowdy to Respectable
description: TODAY'S BMW 3 Series descends from a line of compact sedans that arrived in the United States nearly 40 years ago. Here are some significant changes over the years:

title: Rose's Credentials
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cigarettes, Taxes and Thin French Women
description: THE obesity epidemic isn't just a growing health risk; it's also a problem for the economy. The percentage of Americans over 20 who are regarded as obese has more than doubled, to about 30 percent, from about 14 percent in the early 1970's. And the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention says obesity was responsible for 112,000 premature deaths in 2002, and for $75 billion in medical costs in 2003.

title: In Nascar, Tires Don't Lose Races. Teams Do.
description: A Goodyear racing tire sells for $407, more than twice the price of a tire for a passenger car. It does not last much longer than 150 miles and is susceptible to springing a leak after running over even a tiny piece of sharp metal.

title: 'The Loss of Leon Meed'
Dentist Wins a Round On Mercury Warnings
description: A DENTIST from Orange who has fought against the use of mercury in tooth fillings can speak his mind without risking the loss of his dental license.

title: Would-Be Teacher Keeps Up the Fight
description: Would-Be Teacher Keeps Up the Fight

title: The Seat-Belt Solution
description: As pediatricians, scientists and leaders of the world's largest study on children in crashes, we think that overinterpretation of findings from a single source of data led Stephen J. Dubner and Steven D. Levitt (July 10) to claim that child safety seats are no more effective than seat belts for 2- to 6-year-olds. They examined children in fatal crashes (about 1,200 per year) while ignoring the equally informative data on those in nonfatal crashes (450,000 per year). Our research, which includes over 25,000 in-depth interviews and over 800 crash investigations, consistently shows that child safety seats and booster seats significantly lower the risk of serious injury compared to seat belts alone. Their conclusions stand in stark contrast to the existing body of scientific data that support current child restraint recommendations, and are, in our opinion, irresponsible and dangerous.

title: Fighting a Mall in Putnam County (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 'A Way From Home'
Underground Warfare
description: THE recent terrorist attacks on the London transit system are horrific, and a reminder of how vulnerable we all are. That's why starting today, Transport Workers Union Local 100 has arranged for security experts to provide drivers, conductors and other transit workers with terrorist-deterrence training.

title: The Lessons Popcorn Park Teaches
description: ABOUT two years ago, the people at the Popcorn Park Zoo in Forked River were still trying to wrap their heads around what had happened at their little oasis one night that May. Three teenagers had broken into the zoo, which takes in abused and unwanted animals, and wreaked the very kind of terror that the creatures had come there to escape. Eight birds, emus and rheas among them, were killed.

title: A Soldier's Pay, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridgeport Gets Look At Waterfront Project
description: The developer of the Steel Point project on Bridgeport's waterfront gave many city and state officials and business leaders their first formal look last Monday at its plans for the property.

title: Legal Issues Being Raised on Searches in Subways
description: Even more than security experts and intelligence analysts, one group of employees has become central to the new program of bag searches in the transit networks of the New York region: lawyers.

title: Before Scraping and Priming, Just Point and Click
description: DEVINE COLOR, a boutique paint maker, offers only 128 colors -- not the thousands offered by major paint companies. But Devine's selection was plenty for Nora Berwick, a marine biologist. Ms. Berwick recently had the white walls of her home in Hillsboro, Ore., repainted in Devine's Cayenne Red and Organza, a sand color, with some touches of Tempest, a gray-lavender.

title: An Architect Ready for His Close-Up
description: IT took a year to fuse David and Anita Mandl's two-bedroom apartment in a former bank building on Park Avenue South with the one-bedroom apartment they bought across the hall. It was, on the surface, a simple marriage of space, amplified further by absorbing into the renovation the common hall between the apartments.

title: A Gritty Midwest City Is Reinventing Itself As a Colony for Artists
description: IF Racine, Wis., is not yet the Hamptons of the Midwest, it's not for lack of effort.

title: Comings and Goings
description: An airport opened in MONTSERRAT this month, restoring air travel to the island for the first time since 1997, when volcanic eruptions destroyed its previous airport. The eruptions demolished much of Montserrat, a British colony, including its capital, Plymouth, and forced the evacuation of two-thirds of the island's inhabitants. Officials of Montserrat's tourist board hopes that the completion of the project will revitalize tourism. In mid-July, WINAIR was the only airline offering service to the island, with four daily flights. DISCOVERY WORLD CRUISES has managed to include the Galpagos Islands as a destination in 2006, making it one of the few larger lines permitted to sail there. The region is usually off limits to anything but small ships bearing the Ecuadorean flag. AMERICA WEST AIRLINES has announced nonstop flights to four Hawaiian islands from its hub in Phoenix and to Maui from Las Vegas, starting Dec. 16. AMERICAN AIRLINES will begin nonstop flights to India. Flights will leave from American's hub at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago once a day to make the 7,500-mile trip to New Delhi (American's longest nonstop route) beginning Nov. 15. AUSTIN CONSIDINE

title: Pace-Setting Horse Finds a New Pasture
description: KINGSTON - RITA DEE, a sculptor from Tivoli, is among 78 artists whose work is represented in the sixth Kingston Sculpture Biennial, which opened on July 16 and runs until Oct. 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GROTT, JOAN S.
description: GROTT--Joan S. 58, Director of the Mamaroneck Library, died July 18, 2005 of complications from breast cancer. She was Director of the Nyack Library (1981-88), President of the Ramapo Catskill Library System from 1984-1986. Director of the Mamaroneck Library since 1988, she helped form the Mamaroneck Library District. She helped create awareness for New York State legislation allowing library funding districts. She is lovingly remembered by husband Joel Azerrad; mother Audrey Grott; sister Judith Grott Lewis; brother-in-law Grant Lewis, Jr.; nephew Grant Lewis III; and niece Jill Lewis. Memorial service is Sunday, July 31, 2 PM, St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Mamaroneck, NY. Donations may be made to the American Cancer Society or the Mamaroneck Public Library.

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: In the final paragraph of "When an Explanation Doesn't Explain Enough" (July 17), you refer to "the mistaken perceptions of some readers." Were they really mistaken?

title: A Clam-Tasting Journey, Shack by Shack
description: SUMMER on the Connecticut shore means clam shacks -- informal joints specializing in seafood where you order at the counter and eat outside at picnic tables. They traditionally started out small. Some have stayed that way, but some have grown over the years, going upscale with indoor seating and a more varied menu. Many are open year round.

description: ON Friday nights, laughter and the rat-tat-tat of a cocktail shaker merge at the Blue Olive. This restaurant on the Tacoma waterfront is crowded with young people, many resting drinks on the strip of ice that runs along the U-shaped bar.

She will be deeply missed by her children, Cornelia S. Wallace, Campbell LLoydWallace, P. Woodbridge Wallace, sister Lady Campbell Adamson and grandchildren, family and friends.

title: Close Your Eyes and It's Almost Like Radio
description: IRA GLASS is having vision problems. This longtime public-radio producer, arguably the most visionary aural documentarian in the country, is not going blind; he is trying to bring "This American Life," his quirky and popular weekly radio hour, to the small screen. And he's worried that the bright lights of television might suck some of the power out of the show's intimate, confessional and often revelatory narratives.

Nenner, former Vice-President for Medical Affairs and member of the board. During his many years of dedicated service he greatly contributed to improving the health of New Yorkers. title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review of "The Letters of Robert Lowell" on June 26 misstated the date of the antiwar demonstration in Washington, attended by Lowell, that gave rise to Norman Mailer's "Armies of the Night." It was 1967, not 1969.

title: Elise Taft and Sam Morrissey
description: Elise Seymour Taft, the daughter of Cheryl and James P. Taft of Santa Ana, Calif., was married yesterday to Sam Gordon Morrissey, the son of Marcia L. Louis and the stepson of Charles A. Louis of Norwalk, Conn. David Seymour, a Universal Life minister and an uncle of the bride, officiated at the Bowers Museum of Cultural Art in Santa Ana.

title: Who's Watching Whom?
description: To the Editor: Regarding the showing of the BBC series "Footballers' Wives" in the United States, Anita Gates writes that "it seems fair to infer that somebody abroad has been watching 'Desperate Housewives"' [The Week Ahead, last Sunday]. Oh, really? The BBC show is in its fourth season, making its derivation from that American model quite a trick. As in the 1970's, when supposedly innovative shows like "All in the Family" were actually watered-down versions of British shows, many of today's hit shows ("American Idol," "Survivor" and so on) are just Americanized versions of overseas hits.

title: A Great Big Beautiful Pile of Junk
description: Tucker, Ga. - CHRIS JORDAN stood on a ladder, gazing down at 3,000 or so used cellphones in a pile on the warehouse floor. His 8 x 10 view camera was perched even higher, on a tripod 12 feet above them. He had spent the morning figuring out how to include every one of the phones in a single photograph, eventually sweeping them into a neat, trapezoidal-shaped mound, the shorter side closer to the camera, or what would be the bottom of the picture frame.

title: No Shakin' Goin' On
description: No Shakin' Goin' On

title: Fit to Print
description: I disagree with the Ethicist's advice (July 10) to a printer that she had no obligation to provide editorial assistance to a customer whose copy was near-illiterate (and whose message she disagreed with). I worked as a printer in my youth and was taught that "that's what the copy said" was never an excuse for letting errors go out the door. After all, we were proud of our traditions, skills and history.

title: 'The Secret Man'
description: In February 1992, as the 20th anniversary of the Watergate break-in approached, I went to the fortress-like J. Edgar Hoover FBI headquarters building on Pennsylvania Avenue in Washington. An imposing cement structure with large dark windows, the Hoover building sits appropriately about midway between the White House and the Capitol. It is as if Hoover, the founding director and the embodiment of the FBI from 1924 to 1972, is still present in Washington, D.C., playing off presidents against the Congress. I navigated the labyrinth of security and finally made my way to the documents room. I had come to examine some of the FBI's investigative Watergate files that had been opened to the public. Private cubicles are available in the classy, law-firm atmosphere, well lit, all done in high-quality wood paneling well above the standard government issue. The room is quiet. I was offered blue-lined paper to take notes.

title: In the Confirmation Dance, the Past but Rarely the Prologue
description: WASHINGTON - IT took only moments after President Bush's introduction of Judge John G. Roberts Tuesday night for the players in the Supreme Court confirmation game to train their microscopes on the nominee's views on the issues of the day: abortion, religion, Congressional authority to safeguard endangered species and enforce civil rights protections. Every brief he ever signed, the transcripts of every argument he ever made, were parsed for clues or smoking guns.

description: KILLING YOURSELF TO LIVE 85% of a True Story. By Chuck Klosterman. 245 pp. Scribner. $23.

title: A Fight Over Audubon Land Sale
description: THE Connecticut Audubon Society has become immersed in a dispute over its proposed sale of most of a parcel of land it owns in East Haddam.

title: Better Transit for All New Yorkers
description: Five years ago, state voters rejected a transportation bond issue mainly because upstate residents thought it was skewed to help New York City. State politicians now appear ready to do a better job of selling the needs of downstate transit by stressing the parallel needs of upstate transit. They will ask voters to approve a $2.9 billion bond package in November that would balance $1.45 billion for the New York City area with another $1.45 billion for the rest of the state.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 24-30; FILM
description: Living high on the hog may be the best revenge. But for everyone else, salivating over the lifestyles of the rich and supercilious, revenge is the pleasure of observing spoiled, glittering ninnies make fools of themselves. Few filmmakers have skewered their wretched excesses with the gleeful satirical eye of the director GREGORY LA CAVA (1892-1952), whose work is the focus of a 25-film MUSEUM OF MODERN ART retrospective. The series, which continues through Aug. 15, spans his career from the silent cartoons he made of popular comic strips to his early-1940's movies starring Irene Dunne. 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212)708-9400, www.moma.org.

title: Not Quite Petipa, and Not Quite Egyptian Either
description: WHEN the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow digs into history's shifting sands this week to present "The Pharaoh's Daughter," its dancers will relive roles initially created for Marius Petipa's 1862 Egyptological ballet. Last summer, Svetlana Zakharova, the stellar ballerina who will perform Aspicia, the ballet's feminine-flower title figure, told The Daily Telegraph of London that contemporary audiences "don't give a damn about what was going on in the 19th century"-- meaning, the reconstruction, originally staged in 2000 by Pierre Lacotte, couldn't reasonably stick to the letter of the original.

title: The Words a Musical Can't Do Without
description: "Grand Hotel: The Musical" in 1989 might have been first. But whichever show was Patient Zero, it's now a certified epidemic: hardly a new musical arrives without the suffix "the Musical," preceded by dash, colon or comma. Last season brought "Brooklyn, the Musical," "Dracula, the Musical" and "Little Women: The Musical." Likely to arrive in coming seasons are "Billy Elliot -- the Musical," "Legally Blonde -- the Musical" and "The First Wives Club -- the Musical."

title: Time Is Right for Searches, Police Official Tells New Yorkers
description: It took less than two hours after the bombing attempts in London's transit system on Thursday for the New York City police commissioner, Raymond W. Kelly, to decide to begin random checks of passengers' bags in the city's mass transit system. But he said Friday that his decision had been nearly a year and a half in the making.

title: Up Front
description: AS Southern cities go, Knoxville, Tenn., doesn't have the literary cachet of, say, Oxford, Miss., William Faulkner's hometown. But James Agee was born in Knoxville, and Cormac McCarthy grew up just outside the city and set his now-classic 1979 novel, "Suttree," there. McCarthy has a new novel out this month, "No Country for Old Men," and for this week's cover art we tapped yet another Knoxville institution -- the idiosyncratic design company known as Yee-Haw Industries. Owned and operated by Kevin Bradley and Julie Belcher, Yee-Haw has been making folk-art-like posters, album covers and other products for nearly 10 years, using antique equipment and operating out of a more-than-100-year-old building in downtown Knoxville. "Cormac McCarthy is revered in Knoxville, at least for the people who take reading seriously," Bradley said in a telephone interview. Belcher added: "We always tell people who move here to read his books, particularly 'Suttree.' A lot of things in that book take place near where we have our office." For Knoxville's literary crowd, Bradley and Belcher point out, one of the regular big events is the almost-annual "Suttree Stagger." Revelers visit sites mentioned in McCarthy's novel, and take part in readings, many of them in bars. As the Knoxville journalist Jack Neely put it recently, the "Suttree Stagger" isn't your typical and tame book-history stroll -- it's a "seven-hour literary pub crawl."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LONG, LOIS
description: LONG--Lois, 86, dear, delightful friend. Died Tuesday, July 19. Artist, illustrator, fabric designer, wit, world traveler. Collaborator with John Cage on Mushroom Book and Mud Book. Born 1918, Clarksdale, Mississippi. Survived by son Tucker, daughter Paula and three grandchildren.

title: 2 Men Found Dead Were Shot
description: Two Brooklyn men found dead in a Bushwick apartment under a blanket and a sheet on Friday were the victims of homicide, the medical examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Young Sailors, Making Their Way by Touch and Sound
description: The Pioneer, a two-masted schooner, pulled out of Pier 16 in Lower Manhattan last week, creating soft ripples as it glided into the Hudson River. The 18 students aboard took up positions on either side of the boat and prepared for action.

title: How a Trip to Film in Iraq Ended in a Military Jail Cell
description: LOS ANGELES, July 22 - After his first four days in solitary confinement at an American military prison in Iraq, Cyrus Kar was taken from his small cell and brought before two F.B.I. agents, who before questioning him gave him a sheet of paper listing his rights.

title: Joe Sent Me ...
description: SASHA PETRASKE, a traditionalist bar master, prides himself on the refuge his lounges offer from the glam and glitz of Manhattan's velvet-rope scene. First, he opened Milk and Honey, which made a name for itself by being slyly elitist: an unlisted number, no sign, rules that forbid men to approach women, and the refusal to serve common drinks like the cosmopolitan. But Mr. Petraske and his partners are taking a different approach with East Side Company Bar, which opened in late spring on Essex Street.

title: Margaret Segreti and Thomas Hohensee Jr.
description: Margaret Byrnes Segreti, the daughter of Judith Dillon Segreti and John L. Segreti of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Thomas Arthur Hohensee Jr., a son of Sharyan Hohensee and Mr. Hohensee Sr. of Aurora, Colo. The Rev. Lawrence M. Connaughton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Yorkville Church in Manhattan.

title: The Question of Rescue
description: In early May, when the government of Brazil rejected $40 million in American AIDS financing because of restrictions the United States would have imposed on groups that work with prostitutes, Rosanna Barbero gave a quiet cheer. She had been there before. Barbero is the head of Womyn's Agenda for Change, the leading advocacy organization for sex workers in Cambodia. WAC teaches the country's many prostitutes to organize and to improve their working conditions, and it has spun off a sex workers' union that now claims 5,000 members. Starting in 2001, the U.S. Agency for International Development supported Barbero, with about $73,000 over three years. Then in 2003 Congress mandated that any organization receiving U.S.A.I.D. assistance declare that it "does not promote, support or advocate the legalization or practice of prostitution." Technically, WAC doesn't do any of this, but in practice, it would have had to break with the sex workers' union. Barbero went to the union's elected leaders -- five women and two srey sros, or transvestite/transsexuals -- to ask what they thought she should do.

title: Reader, I Dated Him
description: Correction Appended

title: She Stoops to Conquer
description: Edward Klein's new book, "The Truth About Hillary," is not a biography, to be evaluated in terms of how well or poorly it relates to real events or a real person; it is something much more revealing -- a kind of cultural dreamwork, like that in 18th-century penny ballads that linked real political figures to folklore, giving them supernatural traits. In the stories that Klein tells, we can clearly see the collective unconscious of our culture at work, throwing up vivid, even lurid fantasies that emerge out of the shifting balance of power between women and men.

It happens four days a week in Mr. Katz's corner of Red Hook, Brooklyn -- twice on each side of Delavan Street -- and he has had just about enough.

Woman Stabbed at Bowery Subway Station
description: A 53-year-old woman was stabbed 13 times during a mugging yesterday afternoon in the Bowery subway station, the police said. She was taken to Beth Israel Medical Center, where she was in serious but stable condition, the police said.

title: Other People's Money
description: In his campaign for re-election, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has so far spent more than $23 million of his personal fortune. So it seemed like small change when Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, and one of four Democrats hoping to unseat Mr. Bloomberg, spent $1.6 million to mail fliers last month to millions of New Yorkers. The difference is, Mr. Miller's spree was paid for with taxpayer funds, in a way that reflects poorly on his judgment.

title: A Major-League Road Trip
description: AT 40, Kim Alberico of Cromwell has been a Red Sox fan "forever." But buying good, affordable tickets to Fenway Park, home of the 2004 World Series champion Sox, is nearly impossible, she said with a sigh.

title: For Bush, Effect of Investigation of C.I.A. Leak Case Is Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 - His former secretary of state, most of his closest aides and a parade of other senior officials have testified to a grand jury. His political strategist has emerged as a central figure in the case, as has his vice president's chief of staff. His spokesman has taken a pounding for making public statements about the matter that now appear not to be accurate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   O'BRIEN, MARTIN G.
description: O'BRIEN--Martin G. Of Roxbury, CT, died July 22, 2005. Born in Nyack, NY, March 30, 1957, Martin had a distinguished career as an international advisor to the hotel industry. He was President and CEO of The Page Group, a hotel management firm. His most recent projects included Brazilian Court, Palm Beach, FL, Traymore, Miami Beach, FL; and Georgian Terrace, Atlanta, GA. Martin is survived by his partner of 10 years G. Blane Withers, his mother Eunice Dube Yaffa of Palm Beach, FL, his brother and sister, Mitchell O'Brien of Nyack, NY, and Maris O'Brien Elder of Louisville, KY.

title: From Shoes to Aircraft to Investment, Zimbabwe Pursues a Made-in-China Future
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 23 - His new 25-bedroom palace is clad in midnight-blue Chinese roof tiles. His air force trains on Chinese jets. His subjects wear Chinese shoes, ride Chinese buses and, lately, zip around the country in Chinese propjets. He has even urged his countrymen to learn Mandarin and nurture a taste for Chinese cuisine.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about indispensable presidential aides misidentified the attorney general who was forced to resign because of the Watergate scandal. It was Richard Kleindienst, not John Mitchell.

title: INSIDE
description: Skepticism on Recruiting, and a Call for Sacrifice The top personnel officer for the Army said that it would probably miss its recruiting goal this year. Meanwhile, some in the military say they are frustrated that little wartime sacrifice is asked of the nation at large. PAGE 18

title: Snazzy Sentinels for an Unsafe World
description: IT is crowds. It is color. But most of all, Times Square is chaos, a user-friendly, Toys-"R"-Us kind of chaos that gives these clamorous street corners an excitement that is famous around the world.

title: Little Girls, Big Glasses
description: THE necklaces are candy, but the sunglasses are Chanel.

title: Super, Sure, but Not More Than Human
description: THE urban legends about Lance Armstrong have been circulating for years: He's superhuman, a genetic freak, the one person on the planet so perfectly made to ride the Tour de France that competitors don't have a chance. The mythmaking only increased last week as Mr. Armstrong headed toward Paris in pursuit of his seventh consecutive victory in the tour, a feat unmatched in the history of cycling.

title: Bad to Better in Yonkers
description: We awaited last week's release of a comprehensive state audit of Yonkers's finances the way you might brace for a new Ben Affleck movie: You know it's going to be bad, you just aren't sure how bad.

title: 'The Bradbury Chronicles': The Sci-Fi Writer Who Could Write
description: THE BRADBURY CHRONICLES The Life of Ray Bradbury. By Sam Weller. Illustrated. 384 pp. William Morrow. $26.95.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on July 3 about Alida Palma, who has worked to improve Montefiore Park in Upper Manhattan, misstated her view of her relationship with Parks Commissioner Adrian Benepe. She said it seemed to have deteriorated in the last few months -- not since he became commissioner three years ago -- with his office not returning her phone calls.

description: Correction Appended

title: 'The Bradbury Chronicles'
description: Ray Bradbury's most significant contribution to our culture is showing us that the imagination has no foreseeable boundaries. His skills as a storyteller have inspired and empowered generations to tell their stories no matter how bizarre or improbable. Today we need Ray Bradbury's gifts more than ever, and his stories have made him immortal. - Steven Spielberg, Academy Award-winning director

title: Long-Term-Care Insurance: How Much Is Too Much?
description: AFTER more than two decades on the market, long-term-care insurance remains a tough sell. Only 10 percent of people over 65 own policies, with many holdouts saying that they are intimidated by high costs and the bewildering array of benefit levels, deductible periods and other features.

title: India Without Tigers
description: BASED on an autobiographical novel by Rumer Godden, "The River" (1951), directed by Jean Renoir, is one of the most beautiful movies ever made. This is not so much a critical judgment as the recognition of a mathematical truth. Renoir, the son of the impressionist painter Pierre-Auguste Renoir and the director of such universally acknowledged classics as "The Rules of the Game" and "The Grand Illusion," was congenitally incapable of making anything ugly. Even his lesser efforts are distinguished by a precise and lively aesthetic sense -- an eye for fluid, pleasing compositions and an attentiveness to the audience's pleasure. Add to this the fact that in "The River" Renoir was deploying Technicolor (for the first time) and using its palette to capture the bright colors and lush greenery of India, and the rest of the equation falls into place. The artist, the medium and the location combine, as though effortlessly, to produce an experience of surpassing loveliness. Proof can be found starting Aug. 3 at Lincoln Center, which will be showing a restored print in connection with the Criterion Collection's release of a beautiful transfer of "The River" on DVD.

title: In Biarritz, Catching a Wave With Aristocratic Flair
description: AT 10.30 a.m. on a sunny Wednesday in Biarritz, the promenade above the Grande Plage was still sleepy, cafe chairs piled up in leaning towers, umbrellas closed like seed pods. The long beach below was empty apart from an elderly couple taking an early constitutional and some sandpipers skittering along the water's edge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEH, EDWARD
description: SEH--Edward. On July 20, at age 78. Beloved husband of Carmen Seh. Loving father of Jody Berman and Ellen Seh. Cherished grandfather of Jeb Berman. Dear brother of Rowie Samson. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 Street, Saturday 7-9PM with service Sunday, 1:30 PM. title: The Enigma Of Damascus
description: James Bennet's article on Bashar al-Assad (July 10) provided a much-needed insight into the workings of Syria and its president. I was struck by the account of Assad's night at the opera. There was no mention of a heavily armed escort or a selected and searched audience. And at the end of the performance, Assad and his wife mingled with the crowd before (and this was most amazing to me) driving off into the Damascus night traffic, the president at the wheel of an Audi.

title: Bollywood's Good Girls Learn to Be Bad
description: MUMBAI - HALFWAY through "Aitraaz" ("Objection"), a Bollywood take on Barry Levinson's "Disclosure," Sonia grabs hold of Raj. Once upon a time, they were lovers. But when Sonia, an ambitious model, opted for an abortion instead of child and marriage, Raj left her. Now she is his boss. Sonia starts to undress him, whispering, "Show me you are an animal." When he refuses and walks away, she screams: "I'm not asking you to leave your wife. I just want a physical relationship. If I don't have an objection, why should you?"

description: WHEN Mike Becker, a native of Oakdale, began shaping surfboards in 1993, he had no idea that within five years he would see his Nature's Shapes boards in an Old Navy advertisement and hear that his boards were skimming across waves as far away as Fiji.

The Rev. Dr. David D. Young, a minister of the United Church of Christ, officiated at the First Congregational Church of Greenwich. The Rev. Terence L. description: HOCKENHEIM, Germany, July 23 - In the next few races, Formula One's nearly 40-year nicotine habit will take its last gasps.

title: Don't Cha Blink
description: Before the rise of the singer-songwriter, songs were properties to be test-marketed in search of the ideal hit-making synergy. (See "I Heard It Through the Grapevine" by Gladys Knight and the Pips and "I Heard It Through the Grapevine" by Marvin Gaye.) The producers who dominate hip-hop and modern R&B have brought that model back, and the short history of "Don't Cha" -- first recorded by the Atlanta singer Tori Alamaze, now a hit for the Pussycat Dolls -- is a good case study. It also demonstrates how, in the Internet era, original versions that might have been forgotten can now leave ghostly echoes.

title: Photographs and Labels
description: The Times does not have to label its pictures better. The Times should print undoctored photos only. If the Times prints manipulated photos, are we then free to interpret the news stories to be manipulated also?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BULLEN, RICHARD H.
description: BULLEN--Richard H., on July 18, 2005, of congestive heart failure, having wondrously and with singular grace survived several years of failing health. Beloved and loving husband of Anne Marie; devoted father of Richard and Thomas; grandfather of Valerie, Georgia, Juliana and Richard. Born May 9, 1919, in Logan, Utah, son of Vivian and Asa Bullen. Dick Bullen graduated from Utah State University 1939, received an MBA from Harvard Business School, and served in the U.S. Army as a Lieutenant in the Quartermaster Corps in WWII. He enjoyed a long and successful career with IBM, joining the company as a salesman in 1945 and leaving 27 years later as Senior Vice President. He later served for many years on the boards of the Upjohn Company and Alaska Interstate and was a trustee of Lenox Hill Hospital. Dick Bullen was typical of men from an era often referred to as "The Greatest Generation" and exhibited their characteristic qualities of integrity, courage, optimism, and generosity. He was modest about his successes and never embittered by his setbacks. He will be profoundly missed by his many friends and loving family. A memorial service will be held on Monday August 22 1PM at Holy Trinity Church, 316 E. 88th St., (212) 289-4100. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Waterford School, 1480 East 9400 South, Sandy, UT. 84093.

title: To Fight Terror, New York Tries London's 'Ring of Steel'
description: FOR more than a century now, winged dragons flanking a shield have guarded each entrance to the City of London. In recent decades, this coat of arms has been reinforced with an elaborate anti-terrorism apparatus known as the "ring of steel," consisting of concrete barriers, checkpoints and thousands of video cameras. City planners call the system, set up to defend against bombings by the Irish Republican Army, "fortress urbanism."

title: Cinema Interruptus
description: To the Editor:

title: And the Bands Will Not Play On
description: Organizers of the Summer Music concert series, which has operated in the New London area for more than 20 years, have announced that the group is filing for bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STURGES, DRUSILLA GAYE
description: STURGES--Drusilla Gaye died at home in Chappaqua, New York, on July 9 with her family at her side. Born in Manchester, England, April 23, 1950, she came to the United States with The Royal Ballet in 1970. Her career spanned musical comedy, acting and teaching. She performed in Disney on Parade, the Bell Telephone Hour and the Voice of Firestone. Her Broadway credits included Pajama Game, My Fair Lady, Annie Get Your Gun, Evita, Onward Victoria, Fiddler on the Roof, Carousel and Oklahoma. She taught as a Dance Instructor at The International Dance School at Carnegie Hall in New York City, Adjunct Professor of Ballet at the State University of New York at New Paltz, Head of Dance Studies at The Masters School in Dobbs Ferry, Director and Choreographer at Mozartina Music Conservatory in Tarrytown, and Dance Instructor and Choreographer at both the Coupe Dance Studio in Nanuet and the Tappan Zee Dance Group in Tarrytown. She later had a successful real estate career with Julia B. Fee and Randolph Properties in Chappaqua. She was a longtime member of Actors' Equity and the Royal Academy of Dancing. She is survived by her husband, John Sturges; sons, Michael Ross, Charles and Max Sturges, and in England, her parents, Michael and Roona Seed of St. Mary's Platt, Kent, and her brother, Nigel Seed of Flansham, West Sussex. Family and friends will gather at Crabtree's Kittle House in Chappaqua on August 7th to honor her memory. The family requests that donations in her memory be directed to the Tappan Zee Dance Group, Carnegie Hall, Alvin Ailey Dance Foundation or the School of the American Ballet.

title: GOING OUT
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; by fax to (212) 556-7219, or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Editors' Choice
THE WEEK AHEAD: July 24-30; ART
description: Why work up a sweat doing sports yourself this summer when views of others performing can be enjoyed at galleries and outdoor sites around town? To really cool off, you can watch the former heavyweight boxing champion MUHAMMAD ALI work out under water in the 1960's (when he was still known as CASSIUS CLAY) in a series of photographs shot by FLIP SCHULKE for Life magazine. At the time, Clay, not averse to a bit of self-dramatization for publicity's sake, boasted that practicing his powerful hook and jab under water made him "the fastest heavyweight in the ring." The show, "FLOAT LIKE A BUTTERFLY," is on view at the KEITH DE LELLIS GALLERY, 47 East 68th Street, Manhattan, (212)327-1482, through Aug. 10.

title: Modern Dwelling
description: THE white clapboard 1855 Italianate house where Philip and Dorothy Silber live is in the Greens Farms section of Westport, surrounded by other similarly stately residences. There are few clues that it was once home to a little-known early champion of modern art, Hilla Rebay (1890-1967), who helped Solomon R. Guggenheim build his art collection and museum.

title: There's No Shortage of Intolerance in the Workplace
description: In the "good" old days, the American workplace was populated largely by white men who were either solidly heterosexual or pretended to be, and who retired gracefully before gray hair and wrinkles marred this monochromatic tableau.

title: From Rocket Science to Political Science to a Primary Victory
description: Correction Appended

title: Seeking a Safe Journey as Anxiety Rides the Rails
description: ONE rider always sits near the back of the train and stays close to the doors. Another takes note of all the exits when she sits down and tries to avoid walking through underground tunnels when she disembarks. Others watch closely for unattended packages, or passengers wearing bulky coats on hot days.

title: Reyes Helps Martnez and Mets to Victory
description: Early in the bottom of the first inning yesterday at Shea Stadium, the front of Jos Reyes's uniform was covered with dirt from an aggressive and varied trip around the bases. Dirty laundry is often a good sign for Reyes, and this game was no exception.

title: Putting for the Fences
description: On a damp Friday night in May, on a nearly empty miniature golf course beside Highway 17 in North Myrtle Beach, S.C., a 36-year-old professional putter named Mike Brown was having no fun at all. It was barely 12 hours before the first round of the 2005 U.S. Open of professional miniature golf, and Brown was still cramming, hard. But for the fact that they turn the lights -- and the volcano -- off at midnight, he might have stayed all night. His practice partner Fred Stewart had been there all week, studying the breaks and the grain, but Brown was trying to learn all three courses on which the tournament would be played in just one day.

title: Issue at I.R.S. Office Is an Audit, of Itself
description: IT may be in the business of auditing other people's finances, but the Internal Revenue Service office in Garden City is apparently not so eager to audit itself.

title: I'm Dick Cheney. I'm Here to Help.
description: It is hardly coincidental that the week -- a period in which New Jersey Democrats tried mightily to link Doug Forrester to the perceived sins of the Bush administration -- should end with a fund-raising visit from Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: One Capri for 'Only Visiting' and One for 'Don't Even Ask'
description: FEW specks of land yield as much romance as Capri, the fabled island that rises like a mirage from the Bay of Naples, just off the Sorrento peninsula of southern Italy. It is here that some say Odysseus resisted the seductive but deadly song of the Sirens, and the Roman emperor Tiberius caroused in orgiastic debauchery. The Russian novelist Gorki lived in exile on Capri, as did the Chilean poet Pablo Neruda, whose stay in the early 1950's inspired the film "Il Postino." Later, Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis stopped by while on the yacht Christina, buying capri pants on her trips ashore.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Golf Again Proves It Is a Sport of Honor

title: Journalist Jailed for a Year in Kabul Feels Abandoned by U.S. as He Seeks Ways to Survive
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, July 19 - On visitors day at Kabul's once-notorious Pul-i-Charkhi prison, there is one inmate who stands out from the Afghans, wearing blue shades and an American T-shirt. It is Edward Caraballo, 43, an independent filmmaker from the Bronx, who was one of the three Americans found guilty last year by a Kabul court of running a private jail and torturing hostages.

title: Alain Bombard, 80, Dies; Sailed the Atlantic Alone
description: Alain Bombard, who deliberately drifted across the Atlantic for 65 days in a lifeboat with no provisions -- subsisting on plankton, saltwater and raw fish -- to prove it was possible, died on July 19 at a hospital in Toulon, France. He was 80.

title: Lindsay Vasey and Patrick Barth
description: Lindsay Meredith Vasey, the daughter of Sandra and Roger M. Vasey of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Patrick Barth, a son of Dr. Elke Barth and Rdiger H. Barth of Bad Soden, Germany. The Rev. Paul D. Alcorn performed the ceremony at the Bedford Presbyterian Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Online, Eva Cassidy Trumps Elvis
description: When Amazon.com released its Musicians Hall of Fame this month, ranking the Top 25-selling CD's in the site's 10-year history, a few of the results might have been surprising -- Enya at No. 8? -- but all the names on the list were recognizable stars. Except one: No. 5, Eva Cassidy.

title: Armies Ready for Court Battle but Are Unable to Find a Fight
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 - Ed Gillespie, the White House commando in charge of the selling of Judge John G. Roberts for a seat on the highest court in the land, was settled into his temporary West Wing office on Friday with a ready army and almost no enemy to fight.

title: Giving Help to First-Time Buyers
description: PAMELA AND BARTHOLOMEW ISAACS were renting a two-bedroom apartment in North Amityville when they had their first child 14 years ago. A second child was born nine years later.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 24-30; DANCE
description: Except for one final performance of Shen Wei Dance Arts tonight at the New York State Theater, the Lincoln Center Festival's final week is dance free. Which leaves the Bolshoi Ballet, in its second and final week at the Metropolitan Opera House, as the terpsichorean big gorilla.

title: Planet of the Retired Apes
description: This past spring, in a secluded patch of forest in northwest Louisiana's Caddo Parish, a singularly bizarre bit of evolution unfolded. There, amid the sun-dappled pines and flitting birds, a pair of 40-something chimpanzees named Rita and Teresa -- lifetime research subjects who were originally taken from Africa for use in NASA's space program -- became American pioneers of a whole other sort: the first beneficiaries of an inspired piece of retirement legislation passed by the United States government. Under the watchful eyes of animal behaviorists, veterinarians, enrichment specialists and daily caretakers, Rita and Teresa checked in on the afternoon of April 4 at the recently opened Chimp Haven, the first federally financed, taxpayer-supported retirement home for chimpanzees.

title: Inside the List
description: ADVANCE WORK: Bob Woodward's slim new book, "The Secret Man," enters the hardcover nonfiction list this week at No. 4. Copies of "The Secret Man" -- reviewed in this issue by Christopher Hitchens -- hit bookstores barely a month after the surprise revelation of Deep Throat's identity, but Woodward's book is hardly a quickie; he had, with a kind of Zen journalistic wisdom, prepared his narrative years in advance. (Woodward is the kind of guy, his former partner Carl Bernstein sighs grouchily in an essay at the end of "The Secret Man," who "is prone to complete his homework before it is due or even assigned.") "The Secret Man" is Woodward's 13th consecutive book (three were written with co-authors) to make The Times's list in hardcover -- a run that is just about unparalleled on the nonfiction side of the list. "All the President's Men," written with Bernstein, was Woodward's first appearance on this page. Published in April 1974, in the middle of Richard Nixon's impeachment investigation, it stayed on the list in hardcover for more than eight months. His next two books -- "The Final Days," written with Bernstein, and "The Brethren," written with Scott Armstrong -- did just about as well. But the book that followed them, Woodward's "Wired: The Short Life and Fast Times of John Belushi" (1984), was a drop-off, making the hardcover list for half as long. These days, Woodward's books average three to five months on the list in hardcover. The worst performer of his career, at least in terms of this page, was "The Choice" (1996), about the Clinton-Dole presidential contest. It sat on the list for 11 weeks, and was gone.

title: See How the Money Flows. Then Go Upstream.
description: MOST investors try to steer clear of trash. Perhaps that's the wrong strategy.

title: A Shadowy Web of State Agencies and Developers
description: TRENTON - THROUGH a confusing maze of independent authorities and government commissions, the state offers millions of dollars each year to real estate developers in the form of low-interest loans, expedited permits and, most lucrative of all, choice sites and contracts -- amounts that make some government departments look like candy-store operations.

title: Poker Is a Sport
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Taking the Mango Paleta to Market
description: New Rochelle - BESIDES pineapple, mango and grape, Gerardo Rodriguez's ice pops come in flavors like rice pudding, pumpkin and cucumber flecked with red pepper. Sixty-seven varieties of pops -- called paletas, or paddles -- are listed on his shop's continuingly expanding menu. They are just like the ones his father and sister make in Mexico, except that here they are served on sticks rather than in small bags.

title: New to the Island? Reserve Your Judgment
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: You have proved beyond any doubt whatsoever that The Times's editorial process is in fact biased. If not, why would the editors even have proposed the textual changes that alluded to the surprise of Capt. Phillip Carter's call to active duty, when he clearly asserts that he was in "no way" surprised?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PREISS, FREDRIC H.
description: PREISS--Fredric H. Our beloved brother, brother-in-law and uncle passed away after a long illness, leaving a large void in our lives. Fred will truly be missed. Theo, Sy, Lois, Eli, Anna Portnoy and Dean Richards
