description: Anna Isabelle Kessler and Jason Michael Rulnick were married last evening at the Westin New York. Rabbi David Adelson officiated.

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: You do not cite the real problem: the system that encouraged the mistake to happen.

title: In the Words of the Welches
description: If you're a recent college graduate anxious about the future, John F. Welch Jr. wants to say just one word to you: biotech.

title: Cardboard for a Canvas, and the Sidewalk as a Gallery
description: ON most pleasant nights between 8 and 11, a wiry man stands on Bleecker Street near the Avenue of the Americas beside a neat array of images on cardboard propped on the sidewalk. Detailed, miniature illustrations of the buildings surrounding the spot make up a modest imaginary world rendered in Sharpie pen.

title: Hey, Eddie, They're Writing Our Song
description: GIVEN the current discord in the community of Springsteen worshipers -- sour reviews of his April release, "Devils & Dust," led to both fervent Boss-defending and disappointed speculation that "Bruuuuuuuce!" had entered permanent retirement -- the appearance of "Meeting Across the River" (Bloomsbury USA, $14.95) this month may be what is exactly needed to reconcile the faithful. At least in New Jersey.

title: 'A Way From Home': Starting Over
description: A WAY FROM HOME By Nancy Clark. 352 pp. Pantheon Books. $25.

title: 'The Interruption of Everything': You Go on a Diet, Girl!
description: THE INTERRUPTION OF EVERYTHING By Terry McMillan. 365 pp. Viking. $25.95.

title: An Angst-Impaled Actor Wanders a Familiar Setting
description: UNION - IT'S certainly an odd way to celebrate the arts.

title: Correction
description: Correction: The July 17 public editor column incorrectly reported where Phillip Carter lived and the location of the law firm where he worked before he was called to active Army duty. He lived in Santa Monica, Calif., and the law firm was in Los Angeles.

title: Eight Days in July
description: PRESIDENT BUSH'S new Supreme Court nominee was a historic first after all: the first to be announced on TV dead center in prime time, smack in the cross hairs of "I Want to Be a Hilton." It was also one of the hastiest court announcements in memory, abruptly sprung a week ahead of the White House's original timetable. The agenda of this rushed showmanship -- to change the subject in Washington -- could not have been more naked. But the president would have had to nominate Bill Clinton to change this subject.

title: A Journey Over the River for Dancers Hurt by Cost
description: There is something counterintuitive about the name of the Williamsburg Art Nexus these days: When dancers took the stage there last Sunday for the group's latest production, they were not in Williamsburg but on Rivington Street, on the Lower East Side.

title: A Court Ruling on Co-op Investors
description: A DECISION handed down last month by New York State's highest court could make it more difficult for co-ops to collect sublet fees and flip taxes from investors who own apartments but do not live in them, and to exercise control over subletting and sales by those investors, co-op lawyers say.

title: And Ice Cream for the Road
description: LESLIE FEIST, known professionally by her last name, sat on a stoop on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn a few weeks ago awaiting a takeout order from a Middle Eastern restaurant. With her Godard-heroine looks and a voice that has earned comparisons to Astrud Gilberto, Billie Holiday and Joni Mitchell, Ms. Feist has been much in the spotlight since the release of her sophomore album, "Let It Die," in late April. On an evening off from her rigorous touring schedule, her agenda was simple: to hang out. "I never get to do that," she said.

title: Everybody Calm? Let's Surf!
description: KATIE ANDERSON is not someone you'd call a yoga-head. A 34-year-old mother of two, she has taken classes off and on for years, most recently at her gym in Oxford, Miss. But she never considered going away to an ashram, which she thought of as "something for earthy types" who were willing to put up with bare-bones accommodations. Then Mrs. Anderson read about a yoga-and-chocolate retreat that was to take place at the Camino Real in Oaxaca, Mexico, and decided she had to go. "I love chocolate, and I wanted to practice my Spanish," said Mrs. Anderson, who went on the seven-day trip last October organized by Katrina Markoff, the Chicago chocolatier and founder of Vosges Haut-Chocolat, and David Romanelli, co-owner of a chain of Arizona yoga studios.

title: Corrections
description: A review of two books on public radio -- "Listener Supported," by Jack W. Mitchell, and "NPR," by Michael P. McCauley -- last Sunday referred incorrectly to Public Radio International. It is an independent producer and distributor of public radio programs; it is not part of American Public Media.

title: In Georgia, a Barrier to Voting (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Euthanasia For Babies?
description: The arguments raised in Holt's essay are heard daily in I.C.U.'s when we deal with massively brain-damaged adults. Once it is decided, either in advance by the patient or by the responsible family members, that not living is the better choice, then withholding treatment is what allows death; it does not cause death. Respirators, IV tubes, feeding tubes and operations are not found anywhere in nature, and it is in the use of these interventions that we play God, not in the withholding. It is the failure to understand this crucial distinction that leads to so much unnecessary anguish and pain in grieving relatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, GERALDINE
description: FITZGERALD--Geraldine, died July 17 at the age of 91. Geraldine fought a lengthy battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Her powerful constitution prevailed, but her beautiful mind was lost. Funeral service will be private and a memorial service will be held in the fall. Contributions may be made in her name to: Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th floor, NY, NY 10017, (212-983-0700).

title: Resurrecting Strains of the Past, Lovingly, Pipe by Pipe
description: The tools are ears, to listen for tone and volume. And hands, to coax each pipe to pronounce the perfect sound. The process is called organ voicing, an intensive fine-tuning in which one worker at the instrument's console pressed a note while another corrected the sound from high in the organ's chambers.

title: Unsafe at Any Speed Limit
description: HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON - EMPTY midsummer would seem a not-too-daring time for an experiment behind the wheel, so I decided to try spending an entire week on the roads of Westchester -- back-country to highway -- without going a single mile over the speed limit, no matter how slow that was.

title: An Art Scene That Truly Is a Meat Market
description: Correction Appended

title: Concessions
description: To the editor:

title: Egypt arrests 70 in hunt for attackers
South Beach Hotels Selling Out for Art Basel Auction
description: Though it doesn't get going until Dec. 1, Art Basel Miami Beach -- increasingly the party of the year for art collectors from around the world -- is once again proving a boon for South Beach hotels. The Raleigh Hotel, which last year was the site of the Richard Meier book party, one of the dozens of events scattered around town as part of the annual gathering, says it is already sold out for 2005 and that it is now just taking names for its waiting list. Also sold out, at least for the first two nights of the four-day event, are Loews Miami Beach and the National, while both the Setai and the Four Seasons say they are nearly fully booked.

title: Bringing the Hearings to Order
description: Washington - IT'S been 11 years since the Senate held confirmation hearings for a Supreme Court nominee. With the memory of the proceedings involving Robert H. Bork, Clarence Thomas and Anita Hill still fresh in their minds, the American people are eager for a sense of how the hearings for Judge John G. Roberts will play out. As chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, I will try to provide an answer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, RAY
description: GOLDMAN -- Ray. Beloved mother of Mimi and Judy. Beloved wife of the late Leon Goldman. Interment will take place at Beth David Cemetery, Hollywood, FL, 12 noon, Sunday.

title: Why Williamstown Needs to Watch Out
description: SHEFFIELD, Mass. - EVERY summer, a theater world routinely awakens, Brigadoon-like, in the Berkshires. But the past few summers have brought a genuine surprise: Julianne Boyd's nonprofit Barrington Stage Company, which has emerged as a serious challenge to the dominance of the region's most established venues.

title: A Soldier's Pay, Again
description: To the Editor:

title: For New York Visitors, Science Adventures and Hudson Cruises
description: My grandson, age 13, is interested in scientific/technological innovations and will be staying with me for a few days this summer. Any suggestions for visits in the tristate area? -- Florence Brodley, Somers, N.Y.

title: Erin Lewis and Ronald Posner
description: Erin Ilene Lewis, the daughter of Ellen S. Lewis and Russell T. Lewis of Armonk, N.Y., was married last evening to Ronald Bruce Posner, a son of the late Suzanne and Ira Posner. Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz officiated at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Keeping Eye on Yanks, Ledee a Happy Dodger
description: Ricky Ledee is still interested in what is going on with the Yankees, the team that signed him when he was 16 years old. Ledee is curious about what changes they may make, and he occasionally spoke as if he were Ricky from Ridgewood on Friday instead of an outfielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: A Vin Ros for Picnics on the Beach
description: THE pastel-colored scene on the label of Paumanok's Vin Ros evokes summer pleasures: tufts of beach grass, sand, blue water, hazy sky.

title: In Georgia, a Barrier to Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: The School That Skipped Ethics Class
description: THE Career Education Corporation, a for-profit provider of technical and business education, took a beating last week after a scathing report on one of the company's schools by a state oversight bureau. The report, by California's Bureau for Private Postsecondary and Vocational Education, concluded that the school, the Brooks Institute of Photography in Santa Barbara, had persuaded prospective students to enroll by "willfully misleading" them, "falsifying and omitting critical information."

title: No Change at the Top, but Crashes Affect Podium
description: ST.-TIENNE, France, July 23 - With a magnificent ride, Lance Armstrong capped his seventh consecutive victory in the Tour de France on Saturday by winning the final time trial of his 14-year career as a professional bicycle racer.

title: Armstrong Ends Career With Seventh Tour de France Win
description: PARIS, July 24 - Once more, and for the last time, Lance Armstrong swept into Paris today as the winner and undisputed champion of the Tour de France.

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: I agree that the editors' note on the Op-Ed page falls far short of being a full explanation. A bigger problem, however, is the question of what should be considered standard give-and-take. The changes made by the editor did not "clarify and improve" -- the standard set forth by David Shipley, the Op-Ed page editor. They completely changed the meaning as well as the focus of Capt. Phillip Carter's article.

title: Road Rules: Redefining Car Seizure
description: WHEN Suffolk County police officers arrested Salvatore M. Geha, 44, on July 6, a computer check on his driver's license found 204 suspensions since 1988 and $11,442 in unpaid fines on summonses for parking and moving violations, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DVORAK, PEGGY JOY (NEE DIAMOND)
description: DVORAK--Peggy Joy (nee Diamond). July 13. Wife of the late Sidney; survived by daughters Donna Dvorak, Judith Gray, Gina Krinsky, Barbara Kaufman, son Michael Dvorak, brother Ronald Diamond, 15 loving grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Contributions; Congregation BTBJ, 1001 Paper Mill Road, Erdenheim, PA. 19038.

title: Joanna Greenwald and Christopher Masters
description: AS nearly every grandmother will tell you, love is often easier to find when you are not looking. But Joanna Carrie Greenwald actually had her eyes closed when she met Christopher Allen Masters a little over a year ago -- in a car crash.

title: Bomber strikes Baghdad police station, killing at least 20
Knicks' Owner and Marbury Join Pursuit of Brown
description: Larry Brown got a gift basket from his potential future employer and an unexpected phone call from his prospective star player yesterday, and it may be just a matter of hours before he meets with his possible future boss.

title: Scenes From a Half-Century Show
description: IN November 1954, Joseph Papp founded the Shakespeare Workshop with the idea that anyone should be able to watch good, fresh Shakespeare -- free. That was more than 50 years ago. From that workshop sprang Shakespeare in the Park, the Public Theater, scores of directors, actors and playwrights, many lines around the block -- and, it turns out, photographs and souvenirs that make for a grand anniversary exhibition.

title: Kyra Danilchick and Frank van den Bosch
description: Kyra Petrovna Danilchick, a daughter of Tanya and Peter M. Danilchick of Oakton, Va., was married yesterday to Frank van den Bosch, the son of Louisa van den Bosch-Goyens and Dr. Jules van den Bosch of Zeist, the Netherlands. The Rev. Michael Plekon, a Russian Orthodox priest, performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Orthodox Cathedral in Washington.

title: Correction
description: The National Perspectives article last Sunday, about houses in Florida with boat slips, misidentified the county for Naples. It is Collier County, not Lee.

title: Healing Buildings and Healing Souls in the Catskills
description: Oak Hill, N.Y. - WITH a rushing stream in the foreground and the Catskill Mountains in the background, this hamlet two hours north of New York City looks like a postcard view of paradise. "I have to pinch myself that I get to live someplace this beautiful," said one resident, Joseph Reilly.

title: Once Again, Beltran Has Sense of Timing
description: As he stood on first base, still trying to catch his breath, Carlos Beltran let out a deep sigh and smiled. Finally, after a tough afternoon against the Dodgers made tougher by fans booing him, he heard cheers.

title: The Wonton That Ate My Plate
description: FUSION cuisine is usually considered the purview of upscale restaurants, where food lovers eat dainty, cross-cultural dishes like hamachi grapefruit salad or wasabi-marinated veal. It's certainly not a culinary style that one would expect to find at Ruby Tuesday, the restaurant chain known for its Hang Off the Plate Ribs.

title: Laugh Lines: July 17-23
description: The Supremes Well, I guess we're all excited that President Bush announced his nomination to the Supreme Court, John Roberts. That's right. Bush searched far and wide before he made the risky choice of a white guy in his 50's. David Letterman

title: A Farmers' Market, a Supermarket. Are Hordes From New York Next?
description: GREENWICH has long been winning civic beauty pageants for its quality of life, as have the quintessential New England landscapes of Guilford and New Milford. All three made Money magazine's annual list "Best Places to Live 2005." No surprise there.

title: Kerry Tatlock and David Vanole
description: Kerry Anne Tatlock, a daughter of Anne and William Tatlock of New York, was married in a nondenominational ceremony last evening to David Charles Vanole, a son of Merelyn and Raymond Vanole of Manhattan Beach, Calif. The Rev. Sharron Barnes, an Evangelical Christian minister, officiated at Gedney Farm in New Marlborough, Mass.

title: Behind-the-Scenes Battle on Tracking Data Mining
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 - Bush administration officials are opposing an effort in Congress under the antiterrorism law known as the USA Patriot Act to force the government to disclose its use of data-mining techniques in tracking suspects in terrorism cases.

title: The Story Behind a New York Billboard and the Interests It Serves
description: Ever since May, a small black-and-white billboard has looked south into Times Square from the top of a building on Broadway. It says simply: "PETA Kills Animals.com." You would think that the visual chaos of Times Square would hide a modest black-and-white sign. But if anything, the colliding planes of color in the foreground -- the pulsating staircase of signage -- make this reticent billboard all the more visible.

title: Methadone Lesson
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Opening Doors To the Lab
description: PURCHASE - TRACY STEVENS couldn't have been happier. Settled in a lab here on the Purchase College campus, she carefully studied the four glass columns in front of her on the laboratory table, assessing the chemical reaction taking place.

title: Armstrong's Legacy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Eleanor Rounds and Laura Stahl
description: Eleanor Irene Rounds and Laura Ann Stahl were married yesterday in Boston. Patricia A. Warren, a justice of the peace in Franklin, Mass., officiated at the couple's apartment.

title: Rebecca Haines and Patrick Kempton
description: Rebecca Catherine Haines, the daughter of Angela and William Haines of New York, was married yesterday to Patrick James Kempton, the son of Gail and Donald J. Kempton of Massapequa Park, N.Y. The Rev. Walter J. Smith, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. Patrick's Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: Sparklers
description: Full sparkle skirts, embroidered with sequins or chalk-white beads, are adding a festive glow to this summer's daytime look. The skirts, in many lengths, colors, patterns and varieties of spangles, catch the sunlight as the wearer moves.

title: Palestinian Gunmen Kill Israeli Couple
description: JERUSALEM, July 24 - Palestinian gunmen sprayed a civilian Israeli convoy with automatic fire early this morning, killing a husband and wife and wounding four other Israelis, three of them seriously. The attack took place on the main road connecting Israel's Gaza settlements with Israel.

title: A Landscape Altered by Crime
description: MSGR. WILLIS WEST and the priests at St. Joseph Church in Willimantic spent days tilling, composting, fertilizing and digging a new garden shrine to St. Joseph this spring. But an old saying, "When God blesses the harvest, there is enough for the thief as well as the gardener," became more than words when three of garden's prize hydrangeas were plant-napped the night of June 17.

title: Journeys of Recovery and Relaxation
description: FROM the ever-present airport bar to aprs-ski cocktails and tropical drinks at beachside bars, alcohol and traveling have always been closely linked. For recovering alcoholics, such temptations can be frightening. But as the stigma surrounding alcoholism has faded, a growing number of travel companies have found success combining the tenets of 12-step recovery with the relaxed atmosphere of a vacation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORUM, JOHN FRANKLIN (JACK)
description: BORUM -- John Franklin (Jack). Of Huntington, NY, died of a stroke June 27, 2005. Born and raised in California, he was a W.W. II veteran serving in Okinawa and the Philippines with the 86th and 96th Infantry Divisions. He was the loving husband of Joan Penrose-Borum for 50 years, and the loving father of twins, Trevan, an attorney, and Jenifer, a writer. He was a devoted educator and administrator, with the New York Institute of Technology for 27 years and the Oakland, California Public Schools for 18 years. Private family services were held. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor, August 25, 2005, at 11 AM. Donations to the American Stroke Association.

title: The Basics; Why (Not) Sell Nukes to India?
description: WASHINGTON - President Bush in effect legitimized India's nuclear arsenal last week, offering to sell it technology that has long been forbidden to anyone who played outside the world's nuclear rules. So what will senior officials say on Tuesday morning when North Korea opens its long-delayed negotiations with the West? "I can just see it now," said one of those officials, who spoke anonymously because of the sensitivity of the talks. "They come in, throw a newspaper from the other day on the table, and bellow: 'How can America demand that we give up all our nukes, while you just let the Indians keep all of theirs?"'

title: Jennifer Fal and Aftab Kherani
description: Jennifer Marie Fal, the daughter of Kathryn E. Fal of Commack, N.Y., and Andrew Fal of Hicksville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Aftab Razak Kherani, the son of Dr. Ismet R. Kherani and Dr. Razak U. Kherani of Grafton, Ohio. The Rev. Eddie Rodriguez, a nondenominational minister, officiated at the Breakers in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Oddities of the Subway, Frustrations of the Cabby
description: THE DISAPPOINTMENT ARTIST AND OTHER ESSAYS By Jonathan Lethem Doubleday ($22.95, hardcover)

title: A Stamp of Approval
description: THIS week, officials from Suffolk County's Board of Health are scheduled to meet for a second time to discuss the possibility of banning certain types of tattoos and body piercing. Depending on what they decide, the officials could call for the outright ban of nipple, genital, nose and tongue piercing, as well as permanent eye makeup, tongue splitting, branding, scarification and other procedures.

title: Photographs and Labels
description: I was surprised to read your comment on the difference between magazine and news photos: "The magazine, for instance, can reinforce the impact of a given article by deciding it wants a portrait that makes the subject look pious, or powerful, or gritty. Editors of the news columns, traditionally obligated to be impartial, aren't supposed to do that."

title: Write All About It (at Your Own Risk)
description: Q. You've embraced the daily catharsis of blogging, but given the recent spate of blog-sparked workplace controversies, you're worried that posts about work may jeopardize your job. How can you pontificate about your career in a manner that doesn't end with an unemployment check?

title: Not One Scene, but Many
description: IT'S 7 o'clock on a Saturday night at Daniele at 21 Water Street in Sag Harbor. The sunset happy hour with half-price drinks is beginning to wind down. Music is blaring, and gaggles of casually dressed young people, drinks in hand, are spilling onto the street.

title: 'No Country for Old Men': Texas Noir
description: NO COUNTRY FOR OLD MEN By Cormac McCarthy. 309 pp. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: Greetings From Camp Web Site
description: Irvington - THIS was supposed to be my summer. My oldest child, Sydney, who is 8 years old, decided to go to sleep-away camp. She left on the last day of school to spend seven weeks in Maine at Camp Vega. My youngest child, 4-year-old Benjamin, was finally old enough to get on the bus with his 6-year-old sister, Sarina, and drive over the Tappan Zee Bridge to attend Gate Hill Day Camp. Instead of spending my days as a chauffeur to three, I was supposed to spend these lazy summer days doing all the projects that I have been putting off. You know, things like cleaning out the closets and organizing our family photo albums, playing tennis and lunching with my girlfriends.

title: The Man Who Knew Too Much
description: IF a tourist visiting New York wants to get from Battery Park to Harlem, she checks her Rough Guide, then takes the No. 5 train. But what about the historical novelist, the wide-eyed tourist of the past? How can he escort his heroine across a single street of Manhattan on, say, a summer's day in 1820, without knowing what she might see, smell, or put her foot in, let alone what style of shoe might grace that foot? Where, in short, is the Rough Guide to Old New York?

title: Looks Like Barbie but Talks Like Ken
description: IN last week's episode of "Rescue Me," the firehouse drama on FX, the men of 62 Truck turn to their lone female crewmate, Laura, played by Diane Farr, with a query only she could answer. Laura had recently filed a grievance with her supervisors against one of the crew who, after a blunder at a fire scene, had dismissed her with a gender-specific epithet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MASUR, ALLAN
description: MASUR--Allan. Congregation B'nai Olam is forever grateful to its founder, its spirit and its Chairman. For over 40 years, Allan guided our Fire Island Pines community with his love and devotion, not only on the High Holidays, but throughout the year. His energy and his leadership will live on forever; he inspired all who shared his life. Congregation B'nai Olam Jon Wilner, President Laura Hartstein, V.P. Ward Auerbach, Barnett Brenin, Alan Brockman, Howard Goldfarb, Jack Lichtenstein, Edward Schwartz, Trustees

title: Real Estate Is on the Menu of More Workers' 401(k)'s
description: CORPORATE pension funds have plowed billions of dollars into commercial property over the years, buying everything from strip malls to landmark high-rises as they sought to diversify and build their portfolios.

title: Prostitution Puts U.S. and Brazil at Odds on AIDS Policy
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 23 - In their baseball caps and T-shirts adorned with a rose in the shape of a heart, they are a familiar and welcome presence in the red-light district on the outskirts of downtown here. For years now, they have been distributing condoms to the prostitutes who work the streets, part of the Brazilian government's larger effort to hold AIDS in check.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GRIST, KEITH PAUL
description: GRIST--Keith Paul July 24, 1967 - January 1, 1998 Dearest Keith, forever remembered. Always loved. Mom and George

title: Supreme Modesty
description: At the moment, liberals are afraid, very afraid. They fear that two Supreme Court appointments by President Bush could transform America for decades to come. And they fear that President Bush will accomplish this transformation by replacing Sandra Day O'Connor and, eventually, William Rehnquist with hard-core conservatives in the mode of Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas. A hypothetical worst case for liberals might be a multicultural twofer: the appointment of Judge Janice Rogers Brown, an African-American libertarian who makes Thomas look mild, and Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, who may well surprise his right-wing critics by becoming a reliable conservative on the bench.

title: Indonesia kills pigs to contain spread of bird flu
When the Arts Become a Rallying Point
description: BEFORE the performing arts center opened seven years ago in Westhampton Beach, the sun-splashed East End village seemed dreary. Its single-screen movie theater, long run-down, closed when its owner, United Artists, decided to build a multiplex in nearby Hampton Bays. Marakesh, a nightclub and bar in the center of town, shut down after a a racially motivated beating in its parking lot. Storefronts became vacant.

title: Make Your Hard Day's Night Healthier Than Ever
description: WATCHING a group of middle-age men take over a gym as he left basketball practice not long ago, Jason Haber, 12, observed: "That's the thing about Larchmont. A lot of older people play sports."

title: 'Under and Alone': Hairy Guys on Wheels
description: UNDER AND ALONE The True Story of the Undercover Agent Who Infiltrated America's Most Violent Outlaw Motorcycle Gang. By William Queen. Illustrated. 270 pp. Random House. $24.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MEAD, JAMES M., ESQ.
description: MEAD--James M., Esq. 76, of Washington, DC, Naples, FL, and Albuquerque, NM, died Thursday, July 21, 2005. He was born in Erie, PA. A graduate of Phillips Academy at Andover, Princeton University, University of Virginia, he also graduated from the George Mason University Law School. Mr. Mead was a Vice-President/Office Manager at Merrill Lynch for nearly 20 years. He then joined Kidder Peabody in Washington, DC, as Vice-President/ Manager. Services will be held in Erie, PA, Wednesday. For information, Burton Funeral Home, 602 West 10th Street, Erie, PA.

title: Will Environmental Fear Stick to DuPont's Teflon?
description: WHEN DuPont agreed to pay more than $100 million last fall to settle a lawsuit contending that its factory near Parkersburg, W.Va., had fouled local supplies of drinking water, some investors hoped to close the book on pollution caused by an important ingredient used in processing Teflon.

title: 'True to Life'
description: Ask someone what truth is and you are apt to be greeted by either puzzled silence or nervous laughter. Both reactions are understandable. Truth is one of those ideas-happiness is another-that we use all the time but are at a loss to define. This is why the question "What is truth?" is so often treated as rhetorical.

title: Why (Not) Sell Nukes to India?
description: WASHINGTON A President Bush in effect legitimized India's nuclear arsenal last week, offering to sell it technology that has long been forbidden to anyone who played outside the world's nuclear rules. So what will senior officials say on Tuesday morning when North Korea opens its long-delayed negotiations with the West? "I can just see it now," said one of those officials, who spoke anonymously because of the sensitivity of the talks. "They come in, throw a newspaper from the other day on the table, and bellow: 'How can America demand that we give up all our nukes, while you just let the Indians keep all of theirs?' "

title: While in Cold Spring, Do as the French Do
description: Cold Spring - PASCAL GRAFF, the owner and chef of Le Bouchon, has turned one of this village's lovely century-old homes into a cozy, casual French restaurant. The front porch, with its small tables, soft lighting and menu boards in classic Art Nouveau style, drew me right through the front door.

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: In the final paragraph of "When an Explanation Doesn't Explain Enough" (July 17), you refer to "the mistaken perceptions of some readers." Were they really mistaken?

description: Trio of Co-ops In the Hotel des Artistes $4,685,000

title: FOOTLIGHTS
description: Make Room for Two

title: Democrats Concerned by Prospects of a Labor Schism
description: With several of the nation's largest unions threatening to quit the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Democratic leaders say they fear that the possible schism might hurt their party's chances by making labor a less potent political force.

title: DataBank; Stocks Extend a Winning Streak to Four Weeks
description: The stock market continued its advance last week, with the three major market indexes rising despite the discovery of more explosives in the London subway system and the revaluation of China's currency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 3 about the history of National Lampoon Inc., which included comments from some early editors and writers for the National Lampoon magazine about disagreements with a company founder, Matty Simmons, and what they saw as a resulting decline in the magazine's quality, omitted an explanation of why three of the magazine's creators were not interviewed. Douglas Kenney died in 1980; Michael O'Donoghue died in 1994; and Henry Beard has not spoken publicly about the Lampoon since he left the magazine.

title: Wendy Woo and Brian Corbett
description: Correction Appended

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOODMAN, GUS
description: GOODMAN--Gus. 82, died suddenly and unexpectedly near his home in Long Island. He is survived by Harriet, his wife of 58 years, daughter Karen Stefano, sons David, Clifford and Mark, and four grandchildren.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Growing Up In the Bronx
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging, Pounding, Pulling, and the Real Work Lies Ahead
description: On Columbia Street near the Brooklyn waterfront, the sidewalk has been dug up so often by work crews in recent months that some residents have turned the inconvenience into a spectator sport.

title: A Softer Look for a Dark Campus
description: PURCHASE - TO soften the harshness of the school's modernistic architecture, officials at the SUNY College at Purchase have broken ground on a multicolored, U-shaped dormitory that will form a courtyard on campus and also have storefronts, to give it a small-town feeling.

title: 'Degrassi,' the N Iteration
description: Coming out, school shootings, self-mutilation: the Canadian series "Degrassi: The Next Generation" is known for aggressively taking on every teenage issue. In Canada it's shown in prime-time on CTV, a broadcast network aimed at audiences of all ages. But in the United States, "Degrassi" is on N, a cable channel that aims at teenage viewers. When N has deemed the show's content potentially problematic, it has edited an episode's content, rearranged the order of episodes or, in the case of a third-season show about abortion, not broadcast an episode at all.

title: The Seat-Belt Solution
description: Sure, there are occasions when adults ride in the rear seats. But most adult Americans ride in the front if they ride at all. Why not, then, make rear seat belts that fit children and adapt them to adults as needed, rather than the other way around?

title: The Truth Wars
description: TRUTH A Guide. By Simon Blackburn. 238 pp. Oxford University Press. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ALPERT, ELLEN

description: If you're a recent college graduate anxious about the future, John F. Welch Jr. wants to say just one word to you: biotech.

description: Megan Moynihan, a daughter of Patricia and James Moynihan of Worcester, Mass., was married yesterday to David Foley, a son of Nancy and Francis Foley of Medfield, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth R. Sicard, the executive vice president of Providence College, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Holy Redeemer Church in Chatham, Mass.

title: Pensions and Health Costs Threaten the Fiscal Future
description: A LAME DUCK may not be able to rule the roost, or wherever it is that ducks live. But they can still quack when danger looms, and Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey has been making plenty of noise lately about some of the problems that the next governor will face.

title: Homeless Man Charged in Stabbing
description: A homeless man was charged with second-degree murder in the death of a 75-year-old man in the Lower East Side, the police announced yesterday.

title: A World Grown Savage
description: In "River of Darkness" (1999), Rennie Airth memorably dramatized the dehumanizing nature of war in his grim account of a deranged World War I veteran who goes on a killing spree in the English countryside. In the unnerving sequel, THE BLOOD-DIMMED TIDE (Viking, $24.95), a serial killer who is ritualistically raping, disfiguring and killing young girls from rural farming districts becomes a powerful symbol of the moral chaos and breakdown of social restraints that is also a legacy of war.

title: Dolphins' New Coach Casts a Grimace in the Mold of Shula
description: DAVIE, Fla., July 22 - When Don Shula became their coach in 1970, the Miami Dolphins were struggling to achieve mediocrity, just as they are today. Before Shula could take his first glimpse of his players in training camp, the union declared a strike.

title: Going With Life's Curveball
description: ED ROWE had coached baseball 37 years at Fairfield Prep. Little that a player did on the field surprised him, until this spring.

title: Love the Job? What About Your Boss?
description: LOS ANGELES - THE pretty financial analyst just out of business school seems to catch the boss's eye. She is spending a lot of time in his office. Soon the speculation begins: Were they eating dinner together? Did he have his hand on her elbow? And suddenly the analyst is getting prize assignments and eventually a promotion.

title: Movies
description: NAPOLEON DYNAMITE (2004) Saturday at 10 p.m. and Sunday at 5:15 a.m. on Cinemax.

title: Anthony Brown and Gary Spino
description: Anthony Magruder Brown and Gary Louis Spino were married yesterday at the Mount Stephen Club in Montreal. The Rev. Darryl C. Macdonald, a minister of the United Church of Canada, officiated.

title: An Antidote to Summer
description: The great Spanish producer Miguel A. Torres must be a magician. He makes scintillating fruit flavors leap like genies out of his least and most expensive bottles. When deeply iced, his 2004 Via Esmeralda, a muscat-gewrztraminer blend that delivers a honeysuckle aroma and a citric taste, is a zippy antidote to summer. He recommends sipping this screw-capped Catalonian white with avocado, seafood, pts and melon with Serrano ham. McAdam Buy-Rite, 398 Third Avenue (28th Street), charges $14. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Makeovers at Marriott Take Extensive Work
description: Construction crews are facing extensive work as they strip out bathrooms in 15 of 17 handicapped-accessible rooms in the Marriott Hartford Downtown to bring them up to state code.

title: Killing Makes a City Re-examine Itself
description: WHITE PLAINS - JOSEPH M. DELFINO, the mayor of this rapidly growing city, has a joke he likes to tell about the transformation of its once moribund downtown.

title: Beverly Ang and Kyle Chorba
description: Beverly Janet Ang and Kyle Harrison Chorba, lawyers in Manhattan, were married yesterday in Brooklyn. The Rev. Thaddeus A. Grzelak performed the ceremony at St. Charles Borromeo Roman Catholic Church.

title: A Showdown on Taxes in Bronxville
description: BRONXVILLE - MARGARET MEAD once declared that a small group of committed citizens could change the world. Elisabeth S. Harding is showing that they may also be able to change the tax rolls.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFFRON, JAMES W.
description: EFFRON--James W., 73, died peacefully after a brief illness on July 21 after a happy and well-lived life. He was the beloved husband of Dawn; adored father of Craig (Caryn), Blair (Cheryl), Drew (Sandra) and Brooke (Ross); and cherished grandfather of eight. He was born and lived proudly his entire life on the same street in Poughkeepsie, NY, and was a true and warm friend to all who knew him. After graduating from Princeton University in 1953, he served his country in the Army. He spent his career with Effron Oil Company, serving as its President for many years. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Vassar Temple, Poughkeepsie. Shiva at the Effron home in Poughkeepsie on Monday and Tuesday. Shiva in New York at 129 East 73rd Street on Wednesday from 6-9 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, to be credited to Dr. Stephen Nimer Leukemia Research.

title: Sophisticated Baby
description: Fleurville Mothership Like many new entrepreneurs, Steve and Catherine Granville started out as dissatisfied consumers. The couple had a child, and they had a lot of things to buy, including a diaper bag. This, specifically, is where the dissatisfaction arose. Most of what they saw, Steve Granville maintains, was poor quality stuff, often tarted up with licensed images of cartoon characters and the like. It was as if the bags were meant to appeal to children. "But who," he asks, "is buying the product?" The answer isn't just parents, but parents his age; he is 37, and his wife is 36. "We're part of the generation that I would argue is the most sophisticated in terms of brand exposure and analysis," he says.

title: Haiti Eyes
description: I have been working in Haiti -- on and off -- for 22 years, and it seemed insane to me that, after all this time, I would die like this, in one of the country's violent moments. I somehow thought I was immune.

title: Armstrong Makes a Final Statement
description: St.-tienne, France - THE dude from Texas had something left. In a great burst of skill and pride, Lance Armstrong won the last competitive stage of his glorious career, mostly because he could not help himself.

title: In the Race for Mediocrity, the Mets Rule
description: In baseball's Hall of Fame of vapid clichs, "I just want to stay consistent" makes it on the first ballot. No one quite knows what it means, but the generally accepted translation is, "I just want this interview to end."

title: Tapp Francke and Lawrence Ingolia
description: Tapp FitzGerald Francke and Lawrence George Ingolia are to be married today on Block Island. John A.L. Sisto, a town warden of New Shoreham, R.I., is to officiate at the Spring House Hotel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CAMPAGNA, SUSAN W.
description: CAMPAGNA--Susan W. Of Boca Raton, FL., formerly of Quogue, N.Y. and Manhattan died July 12, 2005. Dearly loved wife of the late John J. Campagna and loving mother of John J. Campagna, Jr., David W. Campagna and Jeramy C. Dove. Loving grandmother of Stuart and Danielle Campagna, Gabriella and Giovanna Campagna, Kristen Wolf and Rudy Kammerer. Service private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Hospice and Home Care By the Sea, 1531 W. Palmetto Park Rd., Boca Raton, FL 33486.

title: 40 Years of Bolcom, With Primal Screams and Military Orgies
description: THE soprano Carole Farley bravely begins her new Naxos recording of songs by William Bolcom with a primal scream. That the scream is accompanied by peppery, skittish piano chords played by Mr. Bolcom does not lessen its impact. You know immediately that this is not going to be a typical song recital.

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: The Chamberlain in West Hollywood
description: THE BASICS -- Opened in May, the Chamberlain, a West Hollywood extension of the Kor Group line of modish boutique hotels, isn't a party destination like the Viceroy, or a watering hole like Maison 140. Instead, the Chamberlain's 112 rooms are set up as suites and studios and intended to attract more serious travelers (both pleasure and business). Located in an unattractive 70's-era former apartment building, the Chamberlain has a labyrinthine layout, which Kor Group's interior designers have worked hard to mask. Rather than having the theatrical designs of other Kor hotels, the Chamberlain has a palette of neutral grays, greens and blues. Considering the location -- in the largely gay city of West Hollywood -- it seems appropriate that the Chamberlain would be the Kor Group's most manly hotel.

title: A Star in Australia, Graham Is Seeking a Role With the Jets
description: The boat pulled away from Pier 83, and Ben Graham's face turned the colors of a Jets jersey.

title: Fighting Crime In Nassau County
description: To the Editor:

title: The Second Tsunami That Wasn't
description: In the days after the Christmas tsunami, public health experts worried about a second wave of deaths from waterborne diseases affecting huge, concentrated populations with no clean water or sanitation. Throughout the history of this sort of emergency, waterborne disease has been the major killer, more deadly than bullets are to civilians caught in armed conflicts. The vast majority of victims are children under 5. The World Health Organization warned that disease could kill more people than the tsunami itself.

title: Walk on Main Street: Pubs, Bargains, Lattes
description: PERHAPS appropriately for a street in an old Nordic working-class neighborhood, Thorvald Meyers Gate, a 15-minute walk from downtown Oslo, begins and ends with beer. Its northern end stands in the shadow of a former brewery with a tower that still sports the green Ringnes logo; the quaint old brick structure at the street's southern tip was once the Schous brewery and is now BI Oslo, a business college. In between runs a mile-long stretch of late 19th-century apartment houses that exude period atmosphere. On weekends during the warmer months, the street is a veritable smorgasbord of Oslo life, a place where students and pensioners, business people and laborers, young families and aging bohemians mingle to form a well-nigh Dickensian tableau.

title: Corrections
description: A theater report in The Week Ahead on Page 27 of Arts & Leisure today about the play "Dedication, or the Stuff of Dreams" misidentifies the theater where it begins previews on Tuesday in one reference. It is Primary Stages, not the Second Stage Theater.

title: Merchants Who Stayed After 9/11 Are Now Told to Go
description: Eight retail tenants in two buildings at Broadway and Dey Street have been notified by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority that they must leave to make way for the planned Fulton Street Transit Center, the agency said last week.

title: Choreographing a Toothlock on a Dancer's Tongue
description: ASK people to describe Aszure Barton's work, and the adjectives fly: dynamic, tribal, demanding, musical, authentic, risky. But ask them to place her in a tradition, and you're likely to get silence.

title: WHY WE TRAVEL: Galpagos Islands, Ecuador
description: OFF CHINESE HAT ISLAND, MAY 24, 2005 - Billy Blau of San Francisco, a former marketing manager for Oracle, jumping from the sun deck of Gabi I, a 16-passenger yacht: "I'm with my wife. We got married about one year ago and we were sort of deciding what to do with our lives. Was it buy a house and settle down and have kids or go do something like this first? So we just decided to do it. We put all our stuff in storage, quit our jobs, sold most of our furniture and left. While we were trying to figure out which boat to take we were warned, 'Just don't take the Gabi.' It happened to be the only available option so we made the best of it by jumping off the roof of the boat when the crew went on strike one day, or when the generator blew out another day. It was like going back to childhood a little bit -- jumping off repeatedly. Sort of pure, unadulterated fun." As told to Austin Considine

title: Art Imitating Life, and Obsessively So
description: THE supposed super-sizing of the American documentary has reopened a greasy brown bag of ethical dilemmas. Among the contents: How close is too close? Is there a point where nonfiction filmmakers, like their cousin journalists, face what Janet Malcolm would call that eventual "moral impasse" of objectivity and exploitation?

description: Jennifer Baldwin and Jeffrey Fremont Pryce are to be married today in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. George M. Caldwell is to perform the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIDDELL, JANE HAWLEY HAWKES
description: LIDDELL -- Jane Hawley Hawkes, age 97, died peacefully at home July 20, 2005 of complications of a stroke. She had remained passionate and involved with her family and her causes until last week. The widow of Donald M. Liddell, Jr., with whom she had celebrated 59 years of marriage, she is survived by her daughter, Jane Liddell Bass, and her son and daughter-in-law, D. Roger Brooke and Florence Liddell, of New York City, and four grandchildren, Steedman L. Bass of Cambridge, MA, Margot S. Bass of Takoma Park, MD, Alice Liddell Rooke of Bloomfield, CT and Torrey B. Liddell of New York City. She was predeceased by one granddaughter, Catherine H. Bass. Burial will be in Baltimore on July 25. A Memorial Service will be held September 16 at noon at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Liddell Memorial Garden at National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East 71 Street, NY, NY 10021.

Loving mother of Leslie and Dennis Appleton, John and Jenny (Santiago), and Steven and JoAnn. Cherished grandmother of Melissa, Danielle, Adam, Marc and Amy. Devoted sister of Walter L. Kraus and sister-in-law of Shirley M. Jason. Donations in memory of Arlyne may be made to National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Services Thursday, July 21 at 1:30PM at the "Boulevard-Riverside Chapels," 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, Long Island.

title: Better Transit for All New Yorkers
description: Five years ago, state voters rejected a transportation bond issue mainly because upstate residents thought it was skewed to help New York City. State politicians now appear ready to do a better job of selling the needs of downstate transit by stressing the parallel needs of upstate transit. They will ask voters to approve a $2.9 billion bond package in November that would balance $1.45 billion for the New York City area with another $1.45 billion for the rest of the state.

title: Defying U.S. Efforts, Guerrillas in Iraq Refocus and Strengthen
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 - They just keep getting stronger.

title: Euthanasia For Babies?
description: Jim Holt's essay (July 10) brought me back almost seven years ago to the waiting room of the intensive-care unit where we made the decision to let our 4-month-old daughter, Jenny, die. We did not view her death as passive euthanasia, although we did agree to withhold treatment that was deemed extraordinary. Nor did we view her death as a mercy killing, although she did receive a morphine drip that eliminated her pain while hastening her death. Removing Jenny from countless tubes, freeing her from painful dialysis machines and sparing her from surgery to amputate her leg so that she could die peacefully and painlessly in my arms days later were decisions that my husband and I, her doctors and a hospital ethics board found morally right.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOTTSEGEN, RITA (GILLETTE)
description: GOTTSEGEN--Rita (Gillette), died suddenly on July 16, 2005, her 78th birthday, in Rye, NY. Survived by her loving husband of 54 years, Dr. Robert Gottsegen. Cherished mother of Dr. David Gottsegen (Shelly), Daniel Gottsegen (Margaret Jackson) and Jonathan Gottsegen (Mindy). Devoted grandmother of Jessica, Liza, Samuel, Benjamin, Kate and Gardner. Dear sister of Dr. Burton Gillette (Marcia). A chemist who taught science at the Brearley School in Manhattan for 20 years. She will always be remembered for her great sensitivity, curiosity about the world and her passion for people. Memorial services were held at Zion Memorial Chapel in Mamaroneck, 914-381-1809. Donations in her memory may be sent to Southern Poverty Law Center, 400 Washington Avenue, Montgomery, AL 36104 or The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: Man Shot Ex-Girlfriend as Children Played Nearby, Police Say
description: A man abducted and shot his former girlfriend near her Brooklyn home yesterday, then was shot himself as he traded gunfire with police officers on a dead-end street where neighborhood children play, the police said.

title: The Green Machine That Could Be Detroit
description: IMAGINE that you are running a domestic automaker. Rising gasoline prices threaten your lucrative S.U.V. sales, a glut of car-making capacity promises ever more competition, and burdensome union contracts limit your ability to cut costs. Then there are the Chinese. They're beginning to put together the parts they've been making for years, and sooner rather than later, whole cars from China will arrive at scarily low prices.

The Yankees lost here for the third game in a row Saturday night, 8-6 to the Los Angeles Angels, on a night when their offense could not make up for Kevin Brown's dismal start.

title: Different Name, Same Architecture
description: AMID the retail jangle of Fulton Street in downtown Brooklyn, a community group is calling for landmark designation for the Macy's department store complex. Built over nearly 60 years on the block bounded by Fulton, Hoyt and Livingston Streets and Gallatin Place, it is better known under a previous name, Abraham & Straus. The complex has some of New York's most compelling retail architecture, but it is distinctive not so much for any single section as for the rich tapestry of its parts.

title: Euthanasia For Babies?
description: I was struck that Jim Holt's meditation on infant mercy killing appeared in the same issue as the article by Gretchen Reynolds, "Will Any Organ Do?" If amniocentesis and legal abortion had been available in Scotland in the 1940's, my life would have been discreetly terminated. Because I came into the world with minor congenital defects, my parents urged a physician to perform a mercy killing that effectively would have been a retroactive abortion. The doctor refused, pointing out that my malformities were not life-threatening. Rather than bear the social stigma of raising a malformed child, my parents eventually gave me to the British government as one of the "child migrants" who were expatriated from postwar Britain to rural Australia. My fraternal twin brother, who had no malformities, remained with my parents.

title: Photographs and Labels
description: Re "Pictures, Labels, Perception and Reality" (July 3):

title: A Woman Who Found a Way to Write
description: MY mom always wanted to be a writer. In 1926, when she was 18, she applied for a job at The Washington Post. An editor there told her that the characters she'd meet as a reporter were far too shady for a nice young lady.

title: Surfing for Dollars in a Blast From California's Golden Past
description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, Calif., July 22 - "Surfing's popularity," said Corky Carroll, a former five-time United States surfing champion, "seems to come in waves. There was a big wave in the 60's that dropped in the 70's. There was a big one in the 80's, and then that dropped off. But we've got another really big wave going now."

title: Fast and Furious
description: Denmark gave the world filmmaking by the rules: the mandatory handheld cameras, natural lighting and location shooting of Dogma 95 movies like "The Celebration" and "Mifune." Now comes the Japanese version, Cop Festival -- an ever-growing collection of films by a rotating cast of directors who, like the Dogmatists, want to get back to basics. Unlike the Dogmatists, though, they want to have fun in the process. The basic rules for a Cop Festival film: it must be about a cop, it must not exceed 10 minutes and it must have a gag every 60 seconds. "This is not low-budget film, but no-budget film," the director Makoto Shinozaki, who originated the project, said by e-mail from Tokyo. Two Cop Festival anthologies are to be shown this week in the New York Video Festival at Lincoln Center.

title: Can't Take the Heat? Plant a Tree
description: THE ancient Chinese proverb "No shade tree? Blame not the sun, but yourself," offers practical advice for improving our urban areas. As with many proverbs, the message is both profound and obvious.

title: A Studio, a Gallery and a Home, Too
description: AS artists, Alexandra and Michael Rivera were primarily concerned with studio space. She didn't need much -- as a jewelry maker, a workbench in a corner would suffice. But he did -- he creates steel sculptures, at heights up to 10 feet.

Claude Lenehan, also a Roman Catholic, assisted.

title: Who's Afraid of China Inc.?
description: WILLIAM A. REINSCH, an avowed free trader, welcomes China's rising stature in the international economy. After all, he is the president of the National Foreign Trade Council, an organization founded in 1914 to promote an "open world trading system." Indeed, when he was a senior trade official in the Clinton administration, Mr. Reinsch was chided by some security analysts who said he was being soft on China by placing matters of commerce ahead of national security.

title: R We D8ting?
description: THE orange message light on my cellphone started blinking as I was getting ready for bed. Barely an hour had passed since our quick kiss goodnight at the subway, and I was surprised to see the screen light up with the initials I'd just entered into my phone. It wasn't voice mail; it was a text message, and it made me smile.

title: Attacks Affect Travel and May Hurt Economy
description: LONDON, July 23 - Although a second round of bombs in London did not kill anyone, and a man shot Friday on the Underground was not carrying any explosives, the incidents are causing some travelers to change plans, and could damage Britain's already slowing economy, retailers and tourism specialists say.

Philip Zaeder, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the home of the bride's family in Peaks Island, Me.

title: Death Toll Rises to at Least 90 in Bombings at Egyptian Resort
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, July 23 - The death toll from three bombs at this Red Sea resort rose sharply on Saturday. The Egyptian authorities said at least 90 people had been killed in an attack strikingly similar to one that tore apart resorts farther up the coast of the Sinai Peninsula nine months ago.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: For the Record

title: A Landlord Who Asks a Tenant to Provide Him With Guest List
description: Q. Does the management of my rental building have the right to limit my holiday guests to only those whose names have been placed on a list and submitted to management before the holiday? ... Marye Elmlinger, Waterside Plaza, Manhattan.

title: In Georgia, a Barrier to Voting
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Interruption of Everything'
Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLOW, BELLA
description: KAPLOW--Bella. Died peacefully June 16. Publisher, labor educator and life-long fighter for social justice. Widow of George. Survived by Alicia, Judith, David, Joshua and Jessica. Donations to the Rosenberg Fund for Children.

title: Democratic Pedigree, Republican Employee
description: Few families have been more bound up in the state's Democratic politics in recent memory than the DeCotiis clan. Bob DeCotiis, for example, served as counsel to Gov. Jim Florio more than two decades ago, just as his son Michael served as counsel years later to Gov. Jim McGreevey.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 24-30; POP/JAZZ
description: Thirty-eight years ago last month, a scruffy and anarchic garage-rock band in Detroit called the MC5 opened a concert there by the free-jazz magus Sun Ra and his band, the Arkestra. Both bands were proudly raucous and uninhibited -- Sun Ra, who died in 1993, famously said he was from Saturn, and his music sometimes sounded as if he was -- but the young band learned much from Sun Ra's musical fearlessness. "There is no other band that has affected me to the degree Sun Ra and his Arkestra has," Wayne Kramer, one of the MC5's two guitarists, later said. "They opened the door to the New Music."

title: North, South Korea meet in Beijing before six-party talks
George Crews McGhee, 93, Oil Prospector and Diplomat, Dies
description: George Crews McGhee, a geophysicist who struck it rich in oil and became a top-ranking State Department troubleshooter and ambassador to West Germany in the cold war era, died on July 4 in Leesburg, Va. He was 93 and lived on his farm in Middleburg, Va.

title: Air Taxis in the Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Dealing With Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hopes for a Store Selling Used Books
description: PLOT: a used-book store's battle to stay afloat.

title: Kanye West's Argument With Himself
description: Correction Appended

title: Boogie On, Reggae Men
description: BELMAR - ALLISON MECKLEY and her cousin Sarah Wynn had just arrived at their summer house in Ocean Grove recently, and to celebrate they headed out for a drink at Bar Anticipation here. By chance, Bar Anticipation was playing host to its new summer-long series of original reggae played by local bands.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SACK, CLARA K.
description: SACK--Clara K. March 20, 2005. Wife of the late David Sack. Survived by brother Alton Kastner, sister Beatrice Olsen, sons Richard & Daniel, daughters Eleanor and Emily, grandchildren and great grandchildren.

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: You write: "Captain Carter's message led The Times that same afternoon to propose the textual changes that alluded to the surprise of his call to active duty, the officer said. 'Within 10 minutes' after receiving the changes, he recalled, 'I said, "No way." Those were not words I would have said. It left the impression that I was conscripted.' His call-up was 'not a surprise,' he told me, because he had actually 'volunteered' for mobilization."

title: A Clean Pool: Just Add Salt And Relax
description: THORNWOOD - IT was concern about his wife's hair that persuaded Joseph Jensen to choose a saltwater pool for his new house here.

title: Paperback Row
description: PORT MUNGO, by Patrick McGrath. (Vintage Contemporaries, $13.) McGrath's latest novel is a sinister web of family intrigue. His hero, a young painter named Jack Rathbone, is lured by a femme fatale, the volatile Vera Savage, to shed the comforts of London in search of inspiration. The pair arrive in Port Mungo, a seedy river town on the Gulf of Honduras, where Jack's art flourishes but his romance is torn apart by debauchery and death. "Port Mungo" is "immensely clever and tautly composed," Christopher Benfey wrote in the Book Review.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RINGLER, ISIDORE
description: RINGLER--Isidore. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Isidore Ringler, beloved father of Rachel Ringler and father-in-law of Seth M. (Yossi) Siegel, cherished leaders and friends. Rachel and Yossi's commitment to Jewish life and learning overflows with the spirit of klal Yisrael, profoundly impacting millions of lives around the globe. We extend our deepest sympathies to Isidore's beloved wife, Miriam; to Rachel and Yossi; and to the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

title: Evolving Through Sculpture, From Abstract to Garden Variety
description: MICHAEL STEINER, subject of a substantial exhibition at the Yellow Bird Gallery in Newburgh, N.Y., was once trumpeted by the art critic eminence Clement Greenberg as the everlasting hope of American abstract sculpture. These days, Mr. Steiner lives quietly in Bridgewater, turning out elegant if somewhat domesticated steel sculptures for house, lobby and garden, several dozen of which are inconspicuously parked at the gallery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 10 about family road trips referred incorrectly to the southern terminus of the Blue Ridge Parkway, in North Carolina, and to the age of an inn. The parkway ends near Cherokee, about 85 miles past Asheville. While the Biltmore Estate itself is more than a century old, the Inn on Biltmore Estate is four years old.

title: Is There a Role Today for a Women's College?
description: NEW BRUNSWICK - THERE was a time when Douglass College was considered a jewel in the crown of women's public education, when graduates like Janet Lippe Norwood went on to advise presidents, Janet Evanovich became a best-selling novelist, and Jaynee LaVecchia became a State Supreme Court justice. Parents of the privileged in New Jersey confidently sent their children to Douglass.

title: Having a Zen Hair Day
description: 'The shampoo sink is where you let go of your hatred and your pain," says Michael Koler, a salt-and-pepper braid trailing down the back of his Indian tunic. At Michael's Motorcycle, his sunny, cheerfully ramshackle salon in the ritzy Dallas neighborhood of Highland Park, we're about to walk over to that cathartic spot so that Koler and I can take the first step in my feng shui haircut.

title: A Dream Room May Depend on the Pillow
description: THE pillow talk begins almost the moment you check in to the Skylofts at the MGM Grand, a 51-room addition to the Las Vegas hotel that opened in January. A "dream butler" visits the guest to hand out a pillow menu explaining the fine points of the eight selections, from a memory foam pillow that molds to the shape of your head to an adjustable air pillow that comes with a pump. On the bed sit goose down pillows swathed in creamy Anachini pillowcases. The one in the middle is monogrammed with the guest's initials.

title: Palma
description: WHY GO NOW -- There's no need to wait for 2007 when a Philippe Starck-designed hotel is scheduled to open in Palma's Old Town -- the Spanish island of Majorca's charming but long-ignored capital is booming this summer. Not long ago Majorca's visitors would bypass Palma for the island's beach resorts. Now, thanks to the city's recent renaissance and affordable flights out of many European hubs, Palma has become one of Europe's most popular weekend destinations.

title: Many Bombs but Links Are Unclear
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 - First came Bali, then Riyadh, Casablanca and Istanbul, then Madrid, Taba, London, and now, Sharm el Sheik, all sites in the last three years of major terrorist attacks involving big bombs aimed at soft targets.

title: Follow the Bouncing Forecast
description: THE big economic report of the week comes on Friday, when the Commerce Department issues its first reading of economic growth in the second quarter.

title: Allison Jaffin and Seth Unger
description: Allison Jaffin, a daughter of Robin Jaffin and Dr. Robert Jaffin of Closter, N.J., is to be married today to Seth Unger, the son of Laine and Artie Unger of Miami Beach. Rabbi Allison Berlinger, a cousin of the bride, is to officiate at Club Getaway, a sports resort in Kent, Conn.

title: 'War Reporting for Cowards'
description: The day, like most of my days in Iraq, had got off to a bad start. I awoke that morning, as usual, shivering violently and aching from another night in the Humvee. Waking up, of course, shouldn't be a difficult or traumatic process. For the first twenty-seven years of my life, I had done it every day without even thinking. Open eyes. Yawn. Scratch balls. Look up at ceiling. Climb out of bed. Waking up in a Humvee, however, on the front lines of an invasion, is different. The first thing you notice is the contortion necessary to sleep inside the vehicle: the head dangles inches from the bare metal floor; the right leg is to be found somewhere behind the left ear. The spine feels as though it has been splintered like a cocktail stick. If the war doesn't kill you, sleeping in the Humvee might. Look what happened to David Bloom, the newsman from NBC: dead at thirty-nine from "deep vein thrombosis"-aka Economy Class Syndrome-after spending one too many nights folded inside his "Bloom-mobile."

title: Bad Times in Levytown
description: By the time you finish reading this, Steve Levy's approval rating as Suffolk County executive will probably be a few points higher, which is what happens whenever the news media criticize the way he treats Latino immigrants.

title: 74 Years Later, a Room With a View
description: New Yorkers are used to having their cherished light and views blotted out by the arrival of new high-rises. And so Shirley Kennedy, an Upper West Sider, was delighted this spring when her windows suddenly filled with brand-new light and she found herself looking out at a Manhattan vista that had never before existed.

title: Explosion hits train in Russia's Dagestan region
Sarah Schorr and Cameron Warner
description: Sarah Schorr, a photographer, and Cameron David Warner, a candidate for a doctorate in Tibetan and Himalayan studies, were married yesterday in a Tibetan Buddhist ceremony at the Moncrieff Cochran bird sanctuary on the campus of Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass. Lama Pema Wangdak received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: 'The Loss of Leon Meed': Immaterial Guy
description: THE LOSS OF LEON MEED By Josh Emmons. 338 pp. Scribner. $24.

title: Blueprint for Barbecue
description: THE gregarious architect of the striking and controversial glass-fronted apartment towers on the Greenwich Village riverfront, Richard Meier, has become as immovable a fixture in the fashionable landscape of New York City as the towers themselves. You might well then assume that he is above the common joys of suburbia. After all, the enormous high-tech United States District Courthouse he designed in Central Islip, N.Y. -- said to be the largest structure on all of Long Island -- presides over miles of suburban skyline with all the civil-sector serenity of a James Bond archvillain.

title: Correction
description: The Vows column last Sunday, about the wedding of Maria Ma and Benjamin Sand, misidentified the university from which Mr. Sand received a master's degree in journalism. It was the University of Southern California, not the University of California, Berkeley. The column also misspelled the surname of a sister-in-law. She is Anna Bondoc, not Boudoc.

title: Sophistication on Hudson's West Bank
description: EDGEWATER - "IT'S an amazing site jutting out into the Hudson River -- with amazing views of the most spectacular skyline in the world," said Bernardo Fort-Brescia, a founding principal of Arquitectonica, about a petite peninsula in Edgewater for which his firm has designed 29 very-high-end condominiums.

title: In Spanish Harlem, a Willow Undaunted
description: IT was my quest. My tree quest. To discover how a weeping willow easily five stories high, broad as a ship in full sail, her branches falling to the pavement like Rapunzel's hair, could have landed in the middle of Spanish Harlem.

title: Dross Into Gold
description: KEASBEY - IT has been a long time since this industrial town on the banks of the upper Raritan River has seen anything like it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ROSENTHAL, ARTHUR A.
description: ROSENTHAL--Arthur A. July 17, 2005, passed peacefully at age 90 in St. Thomas, VI, formerly of Larchmont, New York. Former president of Rochester Button Company, 50 years in the button industry. Loving husband of the late Edna, beloved father of Arthur Rosenthal, Jr. and Myrna Golden, father-in-law of Judith Rosenthal & Jacob Golden, grandfather of Peter & Jonathan Rosenthal and Michael Golden, great-grandfather of Jesse and Rachel Golden. A beacon for his family and friends. Donations may be made to the Humane Society of St. Thomas, St. Thomas, VI 00802.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 10 about truffle hunting in Italy misspelled a name and an Italian phrase, and misidentified the pasta that the author used in a dish tossed with truffles. The mayor of San Giovanni d'Asso is Michele Boscagli, not Boscaglia; the Italian phrase for "stop that" is "falla finita," not "fai la finita." The pasta was tagliolini (broad, flat noodles), not tagliatellini.

title: On Baseball; Deadline Deals Create Ripples
description: IF you have nothing better to do on a hot summer day, figure out the link among David Cone, David Wells, Randy Johnson, Curt Schilling, Jon Garland, Keith Foulke, Mark McGwire, Nomar Garciaparra, Scott Rolen, Jason Varitek, Aaron Boone, Dave Roberts and Jason Bay.

title: At European Championship, Players Came Out Swinging
description: Sometimes a tournament takes on a life of its own, a spirit of play that transcends the styles of the individual players to give an overall cast to the action. It's something magical or magnetic, but it does seem to be there. That's the way it looked at the Sixth European Individual Championship, held in Warsaw-Zegrze Poludniowe from June 17 to July 3. The games displayed a bent for open-field combat. No one crouched down behind his shield.

title: Elisa Hwu and Jay Park Jr.
description: Elisa B. Hwu, a daughter of Cindy Hwu and Dr. Charles Hwu of Roslyn, N.Y., was married last evening to Jay H. Park Jr., the son of Young Ae Park and Mr. Park Sr. of Jefferson Township, N.J. Cesar H. Quiones, a retired judge of the New York State Court of Claims, officiated at Tavern on the Green in Manhattan.

title: Amid Rolling Hills, a Push Against Whirling Turbines
description: Correction Appended

title: Clerics' Group Says It Won't Urge Sunnis to Boycott Votes
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 23 - A senior official representing a powerful group of Sunni Arab clerics said Saturday that the group would not discourage Sunnis from voting in the coming constitutional referendum and national elections, as it did in last January's elections.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-14

title: FAMILY MAN
description: When John C. Shaw Jr. resigned abruptly as president of the Jefferies Group last week, the company did not mention a concurrent federal investigation of Jefferies' gift to Thomas H. Bruderman, a Boston-based Fidelity fund manager with whom it did business.

title: For Two Scrappy Cousins, a Perennial Quest for Quiet
description: In their crusade against the noise that comes from the Ahava Food Corporation, a kosher dairy processing plant on Beard Street in Red Hook, two cousins, Emelia Kruger, 72, and Vivian Slaughter, 73, may be among the most committed protesters in the city.

title: 'Big Bosoms and Square Jaws'
description: Mother Meyer and the Poor Dear

title: A Bill Rewrite in Albany Upsets East Hampton
description: THE original bill, its proponents say, would have eliminated zoning regulations affecting 100 or more libraries across New York State. The bill as it was amended and sent to the governor's office this month for his signature, its critics say, would affect only one -- the East Hampton Library.

title: Tamara Frankfort and Ernest Odinec
description: Tamara Frankfort, a daughter of Bobbie and Lew Frankfort of Tenafly, N.J., was married last evening to Ernest D. Odinec, a son of Frances and Rajmiel Odinec of Potomac, Md. Rabbi Bruce S. Block officiated at the vacation home of the bride's parents in Sagaponack, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the opening of a 7-Eleven store on East 23rd Street referred incorrectly to its standing. It is the first 7-Eleven in Manhattan since the early 1990's, not the first ever.

title: The Newest Stars of Japanese Anime, Made in America
description: WHEN American anime fans caught up with the teenage martial arts series "Tenjho Tenge" on DVD last month, they saw an athletic black teenager break-dance across the titles. With every step, that figure kicked at a cultural barrier that is crumbling as the power of hip-hop converges with an equally powerful global force: Japanese animation.

title: The Way We Eat: Bleu-Plate Special
description: There is a culinary tussle under way in France. Old-guard chefs, whose restaurants were once seen as temples, are being challenged by new-guard diners, who would like to do away with Michelin stars, polished silver and the amuse-bouche. As you might expect in a country that debates everything from the meaning of work to the merits of a president who practically lives with his mistress, the standoff has become a popular topic.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: FREE GAS AT STOWE -- Guests who book the Free Ride Home package at one of more than a dozen participating Stowe, Vt., properties until Aug. 31 will receive a $50 Mobil gas card when they leave. The card must be used at Maplefields, a local store and gas station. A three-night minimum stay is required. For information, call (800) 247-8693 or see www.gostowe.com.

title: A Game Of Deception And Zingers
description: SAG HARBOR - WHEN Anthony Shaffer's "Sleuth" opened on Broadway in 1970, Clive Barnes, writing in The New York Times, called it "as clever as a wagonload of monkeys solving the crossword puzzle of The Times of London and as intricate as the Hampton Court Maze."

title: Other Voices: On Editing, Explanations and Perceptions
description: Despite your long and confusing explanation, it is clear that an Op-Ed editor's initial proposed insertion into Capt. Phillip Carter's article was made up out of whole cloth before later discussions with the writer. Even though the piece was to be revised based on editors' subsequent conversations with Captain Carter, the initial reaction by the editor who chose this language as the going-in position is indicative of both the inherent bias of this individual editor as well as (I fear) The Times's editorial staff.

title: A Deficit Disorder
description: With much ado, the White House recently announced that windfall tax revenues in the first half of 2005 would probably reduce this year's federal budget deficit to $333 billion, a $79 billion drop from last year.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   GILFORD, JACK
description: GILFORD--Jack. July 25, 1908--June 6, 1990. Sorely missed, loved forever. Madeline and all the Gilfords

title: Brooklyn Shootout Claims Life of a Pregnant Bystander
description: A pregnant bystander was killed early yesterday in a gunfight in front of her Brooklyn apartment house, but doctors were able to deliver her baby boy, the police said.

title: Rice says progress at hand on Gaza, but leaves without new promises
Paperback Row
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: A Disagreement Over Music Ends With Three Men Shot
description: An argument over music in a Chelsea bar spilled out onto West 23rd Street early yesterday and intensified, ending with the shooting of three men, law enforcement authorities said.

title: Sarah Johnson and Chris Dunagan
description: Sarah Susanna Johnson and John Christopher Dunagan were married last evening at Oak Knoll Ranch in Yountville, Calif. The Rev. V. Donald Emmel, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SIMON, MELINDA SUE MCVEY
description: SIMON--Melinda Sue McVey, 42, Plantation, FL, danced her way through life across the U.S. and internationally. Raised in New York City on Riverside Drive, she studied with the famous ballet master, George Chaffe, who helped her launch her career, which she continued until her marriage to Joshua Simon, Florida pastry entrepreneur. The cause of death was breast cancer, which she fought bravely for nearly five years. Melinda Sue died Tuesday, July 19, 2005. She is survived by husband Joshua, and their daughter Alexandra of Plantation, FL; in New York City by her parents Mr. and Mrs. William J. McVey, Jr., and her four brothers and sisters. A memorial service will be held NYC at later date.

title: The Saturday Ritual
description: STONE HARBOR - SUMMER after summer for the last 22 years, Ted Paladino has found himself at a real estate office here on Saturday asking for the keys that will unlock his sandy slice of heaven and begin his family's weeklong rented respite at the New Jersey Shore.

title: Upper East Side: After the Art-Gazing
description: The Matisse exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Otto Dix and Max Beckman's prints at the Neue Galerie a few blocks up Fifth Avenue may satisfy your cultural cravings. These restaurants in the neighborhood may appeal to other appetites.

title: Caroline O'Connor and Bradley Smith
description: Caroline Mary O'Connor, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. O'Connor Jr. of Manhasset, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bradley Richard Smith, a son of Sandra J. Smith of West Winfield, N.Y., and the late Peter H. Smith. The Rev. Nicholas Zientarski officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset.

title: Where the Right Is Right
description: Liberals took the lead in championing human rights abroad in the 1970's, while conservatives mocked the idea. But these days liberals should be embarrassed that it's the Christian Right that is taking the lead in spotlighting repression in North Korea.

title: Residential Sales Around the Region
description: In the following reports, the listed at price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.
