title: A Wallflower Among the Honky-Tonks
description: LEONARD STEEN, proprietor of Nagles Apothecary Cafe, a pharmacy-turned-restaurant on Main Avenue in Ocean Grove, N.J., takes new hires to the graves of the former owners of the building, which was built in the 1880's. "I show them that real people dedicated their lives to this place," he said. "You aren't working for a giant corporation that claims to be 'your neighborhood bar and grill."'

title: Honk if You Hate Me
description: IF traffic has been moving at a snail's pace on any of the New Jersey thoroughfares you have traveled in the past few months, the responsibility for the hold-up may lie with me. For more months than I care to admit I have been engaged in an informal, yet rigorously scientific, attempt to determine whether it is possible to stick to the speed limit while driving throughout the Garden State. The tortoise-like experiment has not been a pleasant one, not for me, not for anyone else on the highway during this rather long, dark, slow night of the Interstate soul.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 10 about truffle hunting in Italy misspelled a name and an Italian phrase, and misidentified the pasta that the author used in a dish tossed with truffles. The mayor of San Giovanni d'Asso is Michele Boscagli, not Boscaglia; the Italian phrase for "stop that" is "falla finita," not "fai la finita." The pasta was tagliolini (broad, flat noodles), not tagliatellini.

title: Once Derelict, Now Desirable
description: GRACE ADAMS and her family have seen the worst days of 870 Riverside Drive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOEHN, PROFESSOR MARGARET ''PEGGY,'' M.D.
description: HOEHN--Professor Margaret "Peggy," M.D., age 74, loving mother of Bob and Eve, died on July 16, 2005, at home in Denver, CO. Dr. Hoehn was internationally recognized for her work in Parkinson's disease. A pioneer in Parkinson's research, she developed the first Parkinson rating scale and created the Hoehn and Yahr Stages for Parkinson's. Used worldwide, this staging is used to follow the progression of that disorder. Born in San Francisco, Dr. Hoehn received her BA from the University Saskatoon and her MD from the University of British Columbia. She continued her Neurology training in Vancouver and in London at Queen's Square. Upon returning here, she was Chief Resident in Neurology at the Boston VAH before accepting an academic appointment at Columbia University where she became an Associate Professor of Neurology. She later moved to University of Colorado Medical School as Director of the Parkinson's Disase Program. Over her career Dr. Hoehn published over 193 scholarly articles while lecturing throughout the world. She continued to conduct numerous clinical trials testing various treatments for Parkinson's disease until her health prohibited her. She was beloved by her patients for her caring manner and her sincere, dedication to improving their condition. She will be sorely missed by the many whose lives she touched. Following a Memorial Service in Denver, burial will be at her famiy home in Regina, Saskatchewan. Her family invites everyone to sign the online guestbook at horanandmcconaty.com.

title: Yanks' Cano Playing as if He Belongs
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 23 - Robinson Cano is distracted. He is sitting at his locker earlier this week in Arlington, Tex., talking with a reporter while the Baltimore Orioles' Sammy Sosa is batting in a game on TV.

title: The Careful Construction of a Child Prodigy
description: SALZBURG, Austria - EVERY year, more than half a million people fight their way through small streets to visit Mozart's birthplace on the third floor of a medieval town house in the Getreidegasse. It is the place to go, even if you are really here only for the "Sound of Music" tour.

title: 'We're All in This Together': At the End of Wretch Lane
description: WE'RE ALL IN THIS TOGETHER A Novella and Stories. By Owen King. 223 pp. Bloomsbury. $23.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEVITT, MORTIMER
description: LEVITT -- Mortimer. New York City Opera mourns the loss of Mortimer Levitt, champion of the arts and dear friend. We will remember especially his candor and creativity, but most of all, his friendship. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Mimi, daughter Elizabeth, and son Peter. Susan L. Baker, Chairman Paul Kellogg, General and Artistic Director Jane M. Gullong, Executive Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBSON, ISHIER
description: JACOBSON--Ishier. Retired public utility executive, World War II veteran, and long-time resident of Stamford, CT., died July 20, 2005, at age 83. He was born in Worcester, MA. and raised in Waterbury, CT. He earned a B.A. from Clark University, M.S. in engineering from Harvard University, and law degree from Harvard Law School. He served as an officer in the U.S. Navy during World War II aboard a submarine in the Atlantic arena, and in many major engagements in the Pacific aboard the battleship U.S.S. Washington. He moved to Stamford in 1954 to work at Citizens Utilities Co. During his 36-year career there, he was named president in 1970 and CEO in 1981, a position he held until retirement in 1990. He gave much to the community, serving as chairman of Silver Hill Hospital, Connecticut Ballet, and the Harvard Graduate School Alumni Council, and playing key roles at the University of Connecticut's Stamford campus, Jewish Family Service, and Stamford Historical Society, among others. He was also an avid tennis player. He leaves his loving wife of 56 years, Maria (Bohm); his daughter Joanna of Stamford; his son Jonathan and his partner James McKibben of New York City; his daughter Paula and her husband Tom Grover of Danvers, MA; his four adored grandchildren, Alex, Jacob, and Rebecca Grover, and Brendan Jacobson O'Neil; his brother Alvin and his wife Karen; and his brother Larry. We will miss him dearly.

title: 'Dancing With Strangers': Spearing the Governor
description: DANCING WITH STRANGERS Europeans and Australians at First Contact. By Inga Clendinnen. Illustrated. 324 pp. Cambridge University Press. Cloth, $60. Paper, $21.99.

title: She Does the Math
description: EARLY in my career, when I was an analyst, there was one experience with a former male colleague that has stayed with me. Imagine working till 3 a.m. on a spreadsheet model to try to figure out the answer to a senior partner's question, going home to catch a couple of hours' sleep and a shower, back in at 9 a.m., only to find your colleague has taken the work and presented it that morning as if it were his own.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SULLIVAN, JANICE OLIVER
description: SULLIVAN--Janice Oliver. Of Delray Beach, FL, passed away on Sunday July 17, 2005, two months before her 99th birthday. A sculptor and translator of books into braille for the blind, she was formerly of Westport, CT. Her husbands, Lee Oliver and William Sullivan, prede ceased her as did her only son, John Lee Oliver. She is survived by grand daughter, Vicky Oliver, and her husband, Gordon Cohen, of NYC, as well as, daughter-in-law, Anne Oliver, of East Hampton, New York.

title: United Illuminating Asks for Rate Increase
description: United Illuminating, the state's second largest distributor of electricity, applied last Monday to the State Department of Public Utility Control for rate increases that would total almost 9 percent and produce an extra $60 million in revenue through 2009.

title: Line Up
description: I was at the counter of an Amtrak cafe car when a man entered, saw the very long line and announced that he would pay $5 to whoever would buy him two beers. A woman in line just behind me started to accept when I told this man he should wait like the rest of us. He turned and walked out, either to the back of the line or to parts unknown. Was I right, or was his offer legitimate? David Brenner, New York Yes, you were; no, it wasn't. The beer-seeker tried to violate the fundamental law of the line -- first come, first served -- by leaping to the front on the springboard of his wallet. And while his $5 might have compensated that one woman for being slightly inconvenienced, he offered nothing to those behind her who would have to wait just a bit longer. Thus she herself would have acted badly had she, in effect, sold her place at the front of the line without actually vacating it.

title: Barefoot (and More) in the Park
description: ON a glorious sunny day recently, four women in bathing suits -- three in their 20's and 30's in rainbow-colored bikinis and one who said she was 60 in a modest black tank -- lay sunbathing on a grassy hill in Central Park, near West 91st Street.

title: A 90-Year-Old Turns a Little White on Top
description: It was as if the Statue of Liberty had applied liberal dabs of white eyeliner while no one was looking. Or as if the top of the Sony Building, which many have likened to a giant piece of Chippendale furniture, had suddenly gone Danish Modern.

title: All Quiet on the Home Front, and Some Soldiers Are Asking Why
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 - The Bush administration's rallying call that America is a nation at war is increasingly ringing hollow to men and women in uniform, who argue in frustration that America is not a nation at war, but a nation with only its military at war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   STARKEY, AGNES
description: STARKEY--Agnes. 99. On July 21 of complications from a fall in her Amityville home. Widow of former State Supreme Court Justice John R. Starkey. Mother of John Richard of Manhattan, James G.-a Supreme Court Justice in Brooklyn like his father, and Mary Jane Canaan of Port Townsend, WA. She leaves seven grandchildren and 11 great-grandchildren. Viewing Sunday, 7:00-9:00 p.m. and Monday 2:00-4:30, 7:00-9:30 at D'Andrea Bros. Funeral Home, 99 Oak Street, Copiague. Funeral Mass will be 9:30 A.M. St. Martin of Tours Church, Amityville. Burial St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village.

title: 2006 BMW 3 Series: The Benchmark Settles Into Comfortable Middle Age
description: PITTSBURGH - CAR enthusiasts could bicker endlessly over which vehicle was the original sport utility -- the Land Rover? the Willys wagon? the military jeep? -- or raise their voices in the great debate over whether that pokey microbox from Volkswagen, which arrived long before Chrysler's Caravan and Voyager were gleams in their designer's eye, was actually the mother of all minivans.

title: 'South Park' Politics
description: To the Editor:

title: At Coney Island, Works of Art Are Built, Destroyed and Taken Home in Shoes
description: There were the usual temporary mermaids and here-till-high-tide fish at the 15th Annual Sand Sculpting Championships at Coney Island yesterday. There were lumpy sharks and disproportionate turtles.

title: Corrections
description: Entries in the Television section today for 13 cable channels at the bottom of each page of late-night program listings all this week are incorrect. The programs shown for the Oxygen Network (OXY) are actually those of Ovation (OVA); Ovation's symbol was omitted through a production error. Oxygen's symbol and those that follow should each move down one line, and WAM should be omitted, since it has no late-night listings. The last line, for WE, is correct. Listings for the daily newspaper have been corrected, and corrected versions of the pages from today's section are online at nytimes.com/television. The Times regrets the inconvenience to readers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   SAAD, SHAHNAZ (CHRIS)
description: SAAD--Shahnaz (Chris). It's been a long year without you but you still inspire us every day. Rest in peace knowing how many lives you touched. In your honor a memorial Mass will be held July 31 at 11 AM at Saint Paul The Apostle Church, 2534 Cedar Swamp Road, Glen Head, NY. 516-935-1880. We miss you. Dad, Mom, Andre & many, many friends & family.

title: Heir-Conditioning
description: Sweltering temperatures are bad enough when you're not pregnant. But when you're walking around with a well-upholstered, front-loaded baby-in-the-making, the heat becomes positively convection level. Luckily, this season maternity designers and maternity-friendly brands are offering rafts of chic, heat-beating essentials, like crisp white jeans with well-hidden elastic panels, featherweight tops, easy loungewear and dresses that embrace all the right curves. Toss them on, and soldiering through that second or third trimester might just get a little breezier.

title: Medical Records In the Computer Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Army Likely To Fall Short In Recruiting, General Says
description: WASHINGTON, July 23 - The Army's top personnel officer acknowledged this week that the service will probably miss its recruiting goal this year, the first public admission by a senior Army official and a stark reminder of the Iraq war's impact on enlistments.

title: Fresh Food Isn't Elitist
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain Says Man Killed by Police Had No Tie to Bombings
description: LONDON, July 23 - Scotland Yard admitted Saturday that a man police officers gunned down at point-blank range in front of horrified subway passengers on Friday had nothing to do with the investigation into the bombing attacks here.

title: Iran Warns Europeans to Respect Its Rights on Nuclear Program
description: TEHRAN, July 23 - Iran's Foreign Ministry spokesman said Saturday that Iran had delivered a message to Europe last week saying it would adopt a new nuclear policy if its basic rights were not observed in Europe's proposal expected to be announced in early August.

title: Organic Salmon March on Jersey City
description: In the New York City of recent vintage, there have been a number of leading indicators to mark a neighborhood's upward trend, but none so rabidly followed as the advent of the Web-based food delivery service known as FreshDirect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHLEIFER, SHIRLEY
description: SCHLEIFER--Shirley on July 21, 2005. Former Chief Law Stenographer, Supreme Court, Queens County. Mother of Iris Cleveland, Carol Fatoullah (Ronald) and the late Janice Fishman. Grandmother of five. We are deeply saddened by our loss. Services Sunday 12 noon at "Riverside-Nassau North Chapels", 55 North Station Plaza (opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY.

title: Scaring Us Senseless
description: Glasgow - I WAS visiting London last Thursday when a second wave of attacks hit the city, just two weeks after the traumatic events of July 7. It is hard to avoid feeling vulnerable to this invisible enemy who does not play by known or explicit rules. Of course, that is precisely the anxiety that terrorists seek to produce. But its opposite -- complacency -- is not an option.

title: Smoother Rides for All New Yorkers
description: Five years ago, state voters rejected a transportation bond issue mainly because upstate residents thought it was skewed to help New York City. State politicians now appear ready to do a better job of selling the needs of downstate transit by stressing the parallel needs of upstate transit. They will ask voters to approve a $2.9 billion bond package in November that would balance $1.45 billion for the New York City area with another $1.45 billion for the rest of the state.

title: 'Divided by God': One Nation, Under Whomever
description: DIVIDED BY GOD America's Church-State Problem -- and What We Should Do About It. By Noah Feldman. 306 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.

title: Mariana Upmeyer and Peter Du Brul
description: Mariana McMullen Upmeyer and R. Peter Du Brul were married on Monday in Mount Holly, N.J., at the office of Philip E. Haines, a Burlington County clerk, who officiated.

title: QUICK BITE: Cranford; Cranford Didn't Get the Olympics, Either
description: Cafe culture is Parisian culture. But it's awfully good, too, in Cranford if you're idling at Cafe Paris here, sipping a caf au lait and devouring a crpe  la framboise (fresh raspberries, orange sauce, homemade raspberry sauce and whipped cream, $7.95).

title: Cut Profit in Medicaid
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report and a picture caption in the Travel Advisory column last Sunday about making island resorts more accessible to the disabled misstated the name of one of the Virgin Islands. It is St. John, not St. John's.

title: Four Unions to Boycott A.F.L.-C.I.O. Convention
description: CHICAGO, July 24-Four major unions set off a major rift in organized labor today when they announced that they were boycotting the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s convention here, a move that is widely seen as a first step to their quitting the labor federation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ALDEA, ADRIAN ''ANDY.''
description: ALDEA--Adrian "Andy." Successful in Romania, Israel and the United States as a family leader, father, obstetrician-gynecologist and teacher, Dr. Aldea leaves a legacy of wisdom, erudition, courage, industry and love. Robert C. Wallach, M.D.

title: Those Freight Train Blues
description: IT'S time for New Jersey to face up to the rail freight challenge.

title: In a Shirt-Sleeve Neighborhood, It's a Wrap Party, With Spirit
description: It was not a wrap party you might find in TriBeCa. The red carpet, more of an off-red, actually, was set at an angle so as not to block the sidewalk. The entrance was covered in scaffolding. And the stars showing up at Viva Lounge in Washington Heights for the completion of the homegrown film "The Story of Juan Bago" were not exactly marquee names.

title: Romance: A Reader's Guide
description: IT was Friday night, just after 10.

title: Glory You-Know-What in Asbury Park
description: There is not a true, honest New Jerseyan who would not love to see the resuscitation of Asbury Park.

title: Coffee Growers Try to Revive a Toast of Cafe Society
description: ADJUNTAS, P.R. - Long before Starbucks and even Sanka, the coffee produced in this cool mountain region was internationally beloved -- so much that Puerto Rico, barely the size of Connecticut, was among the world's largest, proudest coffee exporters. The cafes of Vienna, Paris and Madrid served Puerto Rican coffee in the 19th century, as did European monarchs and even the Vatican.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 24-30; TELEVISION
description: Haters of light summer television, your antidote has arrived. FX begins broadcasting "OVER THERE" this week (Wednesday at 10 p.m.), a scripted grunt's-eye-view of the current Iraq war from the executive producers STEVEN BOCHCO and CHRIS GEROLMO. True to FX's emerging take on contemporary life -- as shaped by its other original shows like "The Shield," "Nip/Tuck" and "Rescue Me" -- the war scenes on "Over There" are bracing and harshly rendered.

title: A New Hotel, Near All Needs: L.I.E., Airport, Cemetery
description: The newest Comfort Inn and Suites hotel in New York, just opened for business, is a handsome four-story structure with tan brick, white-columned balconies and oversized semicircular windows. The hotel is covered in red, white and blue flags that declare its opening and point out toward the road with pride.

title: Scotland Yard Challenged by Missteps in Bombing Inquiry
description: LONDON, July 23 - Six hours after police officers chased a man down and shot him dead in the subway on Friday, Sir Ian Blair, the Metropolitan Police commissioner, assured the public that the slain man was "directly linked" to the investigation.

title: The Rap on Puffy's Empire
description: SEAN JOHN COMBS, the rap and clothing impresario still best known as Puff Daddy, a sobriquet he has now abandoned, stood before a conference table in his company's Midtown Manhattan headquarters recently, addressing his designers.

title: 'Star Dust': If You Love 'Howl' . . .
description: STAR DUST By Frank Bidart. 84 pp. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $20.

title: Oops
description: Word botches are music to my ears, and over the years I've arranged five anthologies of fluffs, flubs, goofs, gaffes, blunders, boners . . . well, you get the idea.

title: Ex-Diplomat's Surprise Volley on Iraq Drove White House Into Political Warfare Mode
description: WASHINGTON, July 22 - President Bush was celebrating his 57th birthday at the White House on July 6, 2003, a muggy midsummer Sunday. He had played golf with old friends at Andrews Air Force Base on Saturday, followed by an early birthday party arranged by his wife. The weekend marked a rare lull in the presidential schedule, a welcome break before a grueling trip to Africa that would start on Monday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GRANT, CHARLES J., JR.
description: GRANT--Charles J., Jr., 79, on June 28, 2005 in his sleep at St. Vincent's Hospital recovering from neck surgery. Preceded in death by his beloved companion of 23 years, Zan E. Van Antwerp. His wife, Joyce, died in 1973, and his stepdaughter, Joy, died in 1995. Survived by Zan's family, his wife's nieces in England, and a circle of close friends. Born and raised in Brooklyn, a graduate of NYU and a retired journalist, who for many years was the researcher and writer for Ripley's Believe It Or Not. Service at St. Luke in the Fields, Hudson Street at Grove Street, Tuesday, August 2 at 4PM. Reception to follow for family and friends. Inurnment at Fresh Pond Crematory.

title: Steinbeck's Hero, Here in Greenburgh
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: Air Taxis in the Neighborhood

title: There's a New China Syndrome on Wall Street
description: AMONG bankers on Wall Street the conversation invariably turns to one subject: China. They have just gotten back from a big trip to Beijing or are about to leave on one. Henry M. Paulson Jr., the chairman of Goldman Sachs, talks about the number of trips he has made to China each quarter as if it were a metric to be included when computing the firm's earnings. And, of course, the takeover bid for Unocal by Cnooc, one of China's top oil and natural gas companies, has made the country the subject du jour.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about gas usage by hybrid cars misstated the type of tax subsidy currently available to people who buy hybrids. It is a tax deduction, allowed under the Internal Revenue Service's "Clean Fuels" program, not a tax credit. (President Bush has proposed that hybrid buyers be given a tax credit of up to $4,000.)

title: Talkin' New York
description: To the Editor:

title: If It's Civil War, Do We Know It?
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - THE first signs that America's top officials in Iraq were revising their thinking about what they might accomplish in Iraq came a year ago. As Iraq resumed its sovereignty after the period of American occupation, the new American team that arrived then, headed by Ambassador John D. Negroponte, had a withering term for the optimistic approach of their predecessors, led by L. Paul Bremer III.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHARDSON, RALPH E.
description: RICHARDSON -- Ralph E. Died July 20, 2005 after a brief illness. Born November 1, 1927 Bristol, CT, son of the late Dr. Ralph and Estelle Richardson. Brother of Lynn and the late Martha Smith. U.S. Army Veteran Korea, graduate of Wesleyan University. Ralph worked at Wood Struthers before a long and distinguished career in publishing. Retail rep at Time, Inc., and later served as president of Mactier Publishing. Founder of Electronic Product News, Brussels and Managing Automation, Thomas Publishing, NY and member of the Council for Competitiveness, Washington, DC. His greatest pleasure came at his elevation to Commander of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin in Burgundy. Ralph is survived by his wife Collette Laffey Richardson, his four children, Martha, Sarah, Amy and Sam and two grandchildren. Memorial service Monday July 25 at 4PM, Frank E Campbell Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Av, NYC. Donations in his honor to Disabled American Veterans Mem'l Program, Box 14301, Cincinnati, OH 45250

title: BEST SELLERS: July 24, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Maccabiah Games Enter New Era but Cannot Erase Memory of '72
description: The Maccabiah Games are open to Jewish athletes from around the world. Yet the first Israeli to win a gold medal in this month's Maccabiah in Israel was an Arab girl from a Muslim town in the Galilee. Asala Halag, one of Israel's one million Arab citizens, wore the blue-and-white warm-up suit of the Israeli national team as she stood in the place of honor to collect her medal for 200-meter breaststroke on July 10.

title: South Beach Hotels Selling Out for Art Basel Auction
description: Though it doesn't get going until Dec. 1, Art Basel Miami Beach - increasingly the party of the year for art collectors from around the world - is once again proving a boon for South Beach hotels. The Raleigh Hotel, which last year was the site of the Richard Meier book party, one of the dozens of events scattered around town as part of the annual gathering, says it is already sold out for 2005 and that it is now just taking names for its waiting list. Also sold out, at least for the first two nights of the four-day event, are Loews Miami Beach and the National, while both the Setai and the Four Seasons say they are nearly fully booked.

title: Building Blind in Suffolk
description: AS a member of the community awareness committee of the Half Hollow Hills P.T.A., Deborah Harris keeps her ears cocked. But she never heard a word about the Wal-Mart, Home Depot and Kohl's stores that will be going in just down the road from her Dix Hills home.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEE, MARGARET ERSKINE
description: LEE -- Margaret Erskine. WWII Red Cross Nurse, died July 15, 2005 in Huntington, NY. She was 89. She was born in New York City, September 26, 1915 to Marion and James Erskine and grew up in Locust Valley, NY. She worked with the British Red Cross in the London Blitz, created the first USO in 1941, joined the 20th General in 1942 and served under General Stilwell on the Ledo-Burma Road. She married Burton J. Lee, Jr. of Cold Spring Harbor in 1946, was stepmother to four children, and had four of her own. She often said, "The Burma jungles were perfect training for the challenges of family life." Margaret is survived by sons, Jared and Timothy; daughters, Marion and Cecilia; stepchildren, Burton, Rosamond, Susannah and Mary Jo; brother, Drummond, and sister, Alison; 15 grandchildren and numerous great-grandchildren. Funeral service at 4 PM, Sunday, July 24, 2005, St. John's Church, Cold Spring Harbor, NY.

title: Air Taxis in the Neighborhood
description: To the Editor:

title: Walking for My Life
description: 'An' such a fine sight to see" is exactly how I imagine Steve Vaught (now about 350 pounds?) as he is walking through Winslow, Ariz., on his way across the country (Lives, July 10). Obesity and depression can throw hopes, goals and self-esteem into a black hole. To Steve I say: Walk on. Move on. Never forget, but forgive yourself.

title: Diedre Hollars and Justin Caldbeck
description: Diedre Janet Hollars, a daughter of Betty and Rod Hollars of Tracy, Calif., was married yesterday to Justin Hiley Caldbeck, a son of Diane and Gareth Caldbeck of Naples, Fla. The Rev. Michael P. Norkett, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Angela's Church in Pacific Grove, Calif.

title: Grace Kuo and T. C. Li
description: Dr. Grace Kuo, a daughter of Yuchih Kuo and Chung Kai Kuo of Livingston, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas C. Li, a son of Shue-Lee C. Li and Dr. Tien-Shun Li of Englewood Cliffs, N.J. Joseph Francione, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at St. Philomena Roman Catholic Church in Livingston.

title: History at Ground Zero
Floating Down the Highway
description: The International Amphicar Owners Club convention in Celina, Ohio, showcases the only amphibious vehicles ever mass produced for civilians.

title: On Vacation, With Resolve
description: Tourists at a resort along the Red Sea woke up determined, for the most part, to stick to the languid rhythms of a beach holiday.

title: Armstrong's Final Statement
description: Lance Armstrong closed out his amazing career with a seventh consecutive Tour de France victory on Sunday.

title: Putting for the Fences
description: On a damp Friday night in May, on a nearly empty miniature golf course beside Highway 17 in North Myrtle Beach, S.C., a 36-year-old professional putter named Mike Brown was having no fun at all. It was barely 12 hours before the first round of the 2005 U.S. Open of professional miniature golf, and Brown was still cramming, hard. But for the fact that they turn the lights -- and the volcano -- off at midnight, he might have stayed all night. His practice partner Fred Stewart had been there all week, studying the breaks and the grain, but Brown was trying to learn all three courses on which the tournament would be played in just one day.

title: Where Absinthe Makes the Kitchen Grow Hotter
description: "Maybe I shouldn't have drunk so much absinthe."

title: Heeeeere's Al, Thanks to Carson
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 - As vice president, Al Gore learned that the most disarming way to counter his wooden image was to tell better jokes about himself than the late-night comedians did. Mr. Gore now says he received occasional tutoring on those one-liners from the master of the television monologue, Johnny Carson.

title: Backstage Back-Stabbing as Reality Stars Make a Movie
description: The worst possible precedent, in the eyes of actors and writers in Hollywood, has happened: a scripted film is being made with only quasi celebrities who made their names (or disgraced their names) on reality shows. In one casting call, these novices, rescued from the garbage barge of fame, are given a chance that no so-called legitimate actor can get in a town that is overstocked with them. Most galling of all, the makers of this film, to be called "The Scorned" and shown on the E! channel this fall before being released on DVD, hail their own "all-star cast," a term once reserved for a cast of award nominees.

title: For Gore, a Reincarnation on the Other Side of the Camera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 - The day after President Bush announced his first Supreme Court nominee, his opponent in the hotly disputed 2000 election was a continent away from the White House, sitting in a darkened conference room in a converted coffee warehouse here.

title: Family of slain Brazilian say they may sue British police
In Most Cases, Israel Thwarts Suicide Attacks Without a Shot
description: JERUSALEM, July 24 - Very late on Friday night, Israeli military and counterintelligence forces intercepted a would-be suicide bomber on his way to Tel Aviv, wearing a suicide belt, and persuaded him to disrobe and surrender.

title: Stung by Last Season, NBC Sees More Tough Times Ahead
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24 - In an effort to lower expectations for the coming television season, Kevin Reilly, the president of entertainment for NBC, told reporters at a news conference here Sunday that the network might not achieve any ratings improvements soon, and said that NBC was altering the outlook for its financial prospects.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERMAN, ALBERT
description: BERMAN--Albert. On July 23, 2005. Beloved husband of Dorothy; married 60 years. Devoted father of Ellen Kramer, Nancy Berman Shapiro and Donald Berman. Cherished grandfather of Leigh, Adam, Jared and Jaimie. Former president of Harry Fox Agency. Past president of Music and Performing Arts Lodge of B'nai B'rith. Formerly of Yonkers, NY, recently resided in Pompano Beach, FL. Services were held Sunday, July 24, 2005, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FITZGERALD, GERALDINE
description: FITZGERALD--Geraldine, died July 17 at the age of 91. Geraldine fought a lengthy battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Her powerful constitution prevailed, but her beautiful mind was lost. Funeral service will be private and a memorial service will be held in the fall. Contributions may be made in her name to: Alzheimer's Association, 360 Lexington Avenue, 5th floor, NY, NY 10017, (212-983-0700).

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COLEMAN, CHESTER
description: COLEMAN--Chester. Age 95, on July 23, 2005. Beloved husband of Beatrice. Father of Martin and Enid, daughter-inlaw Gail, and grandchildren Alina and Vytas. His life was devoted to the students of the High School of Music and Art whose lives he touched in so many ways. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to Hospice Care of Southeast Florida, 309 SE 18th St, Fort Lauderdale, FL 33316.

title: Arts, Briefly; An Ending and a Beginning
description: "Border/Clash: A Litany of Desires," the autobiographical, one-woman play by Staceyann Chin, right, will close after its 4 p.m. performance on Aug. 7 at the Culture Project, 45 Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village. The Culture Project will also be the scene of "Women Center Stage 2005," July 29 through Aug. 31, a festival that explores women's choices and amplifies women's voices. Among its highlights are Lynn Redgrave in "Nightingale," a one-woman show inspired by memories of her maternal grandmother (Aug. 30), and Marisa Tomei in Carol Gilligan's fresh look at Hawthorne's "Scarlet Letter" (Aug. 7 and 8). LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: Shine a Light on Hate, Everywhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Yanks Save One in Anaheim to End Trip Right
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 24 - It was the menace in the middle of the Yankees' schedule, a three-city tour of the best lineups in the American League, in three time zones with no days off. It could have punctured their pennant hopes, but in the end it made them stronger.

title: A Perilous Journey to the End of the Performance
description: A piece of theater can be "like opening a chest in the attic and finding notes from someone's journey. There's a story but no literal plot so you have to keep picking out fragments. You know something important has happened that transformed them, but you're never told exactly what it is."

title: Swift Care for Slain Woman Helped Save Baby
description: The family of a 1-day-old boy delivered soon after his mother was fatally shot outside her Brooklyn apartment said last night that they wanted to name him for his mother.

title: When the Curtain Rises, I'll Still Be in Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a criminal investigation into the conduct of three law firms involved in asbestos litigation mischaracterized the allegations in civil court filings against two firms, Weitz & Luxenberg, and Ness, Motley, Loadholt, Richardson & Poole.

title: Measuring the Distance From Here to Eternity
description: Miss Leavitt's Stars The Untold Story of the Woman Who Discovered How to Measure the Universe By George Johnson 162 pages. Atlas Books/W.W. Norton & Company. $22.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDENBERG, MAY (NEE SHULMAN)
description: LINDENBERG -- May (nee Shulman). Loving wife of the late Michael. Adored mother of Karen Baye (Sumner). Sister Sylvia Levine (Harvey). Nephews Marty (dec.) Jamie (Angie), Matthew, grandnephew Cody. An incredible woman who made everyone feel special and unique. We shall never forget her. Graveside services Tuesday, July 26, 2 pm, at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Family at home after services and on Wednesday after 5.

title: An Art Class's Lesson in Politics
description: Correction Appended

title: Wireless: Single gadget weaves phone, Internet and media services
INSIDE
description: Congress Closes In On an Energy Bill With strong encouragement from the White House, top House and Senate negotiators said they were nearing final agreement on a broad energy bill that would drop a plan to protect producers of the gasoline additive MTBE from lawsuits over water pollution. But lawmakers must still agree on oil and gas drilling provisions, the amount of emphasis on renewable fuels, and the size of tax incentives. PAGE A15

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: WELCOME MAT -- For those with a stake in the housing market, and that includes just about everybody, figures for existing home sales and new home sales are being released this week. (Today and Wednesday.)

title: News analysis: Policing a changed landscape in London
Fears for the dollar persist
Film Channel Veers From Oldies and May Pay for It
description: The judge has ruled: "Look Who's Talking, Too," starring John Travolta and Kirstie Alley, just isn't a classic.

title: From Iron to Gold: A Stellar V-8
description: IF there were lifetime achievement awards for automotive engines, the Chevrolet small-block V-8 would be a sure winner.

title: Armstrong Wins Seventh Tour de France
description: PARIS, July 24 - Once more, and for the last time, Lance Armstrong swept into Paris on Sunday as the winner and undisputed champion of the Tour de France.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: U.S., North Korean envoys meet before nuclear talks
Katzenberg catches heat as studio stumbles
Arroyo Seeks to Shore Up Plunging Popularity
description: MANILA, July 25 - President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo sought to shore up her plunging popularity today by using the annual presidential speech to Congress to urge her audience, overwhelmingly party allies and supporters, to accelerate a shift to a parliamentary form of government.

title: A Page From the Playbook of Rock and the Machine
description: Now that the European tradition has painted itself into a corner, classical music -- for want of better of a better term -- looks for new connections. The atonal and antitonal people crowd themselves into a niche, there to be admired by their tiny fan clubs. Indeed Webern's Piano Variations or Schoenberg's String Trio are no more universally beloved now than they were half a century ago.

title: Once Again, Subway Changes Agencies
description: For the second time in 14 months, the Subway sandwich chain has parted ways with an agency handling its creative account.

title: Guardsman Pleads Guilty in Killing of Iraqi Officer
description: FORT KNOX, Ky., July 25 - A 22-year-old National Guard soldier pleaded guilty today to killing an Iraqi police officer while they were on patrol together, and then shooting himself to cover up the crime.

title: Shine a Light on Hate, Everywhere
description: To the Editor:

title: The Virus of Fear
description: They didn't kill anyone, but the four men who attempted to detonate four bombs in London 14 days after the bombings of July 7 left behind a clear message: The cycle of attacks is being ramped up, the attackers are flexible in their tactics, and citizens should never feel safe -- anywhere.

title: Franz Weissmann, Leading Brazilian Sculptor, Dies at 93
description: Franz Weissmann, one of Brazil's most prominent Modernist sculptors and the last surviving member of the Neo-Concrete movement of the early 1960's, died at his home in Rio de Janeiro on July 18. He was 93.

title: A Boasting Match Pits Television Advertising Against Radio
description: A recent study funded by major radio networks claims to show that radio advertising is a 49 percent better investment than television ads. So why is the television industry crowing?

title: Penn Station Evacuated After Bomb Threat
description: A man who falsely claimed to have a bomb in his bag prompted the authorities to evacuate Pennsylvania Station for more than an hour yesterday, causing delays for travelers across the Northeast and punctuating a tiresome week of increased security in New York City's subway stations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFFRON, JAMES W.
description: EFFRON--James W., 73, died peacefully after a brief illness on July 21 after a happy and well-lived life. He was the beloved husband of Dawn; adored father of Craig (Caryn), Blair (Cheryl), Drew (Sandra) and Brooke (Ross); and cherished grandfather of eight. He was born and lived proudly his entire life on the same street in Poughkeepsie, NY, and was a true and warm friend to all who knew him. After graduating from Princeton University in 1953, he served his country in the Army. He spent his career with Effron Oil Company, serving as its President for many years. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Vassar Temple, Poughkeepsie. Shiva at the Effron home in Poughkeepsie on Monday and Tuesday. Shiva in New York at 129 East 73rd Street on Wednesday from 6-9 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, to be credited to Dr. Stephen Nimer Leukemia Research.

title: Arts, Briefly; Strong Ratings on Cable
description: Last Monday Lifetime's movie "Murder in the Hamptons" provided a fictional rendering of the sensational murder of Ted Ammon (David Sutcliffe), a multimillionaire. According to Nielsen's estimates, the broadcast of this filmic equivalent of a beach-read drew 4.8 million viewers. In households, it got the highest ratings of a television film on advertiser-supported cable this year, tying with another Lifetime movie, "Odd Girl Out." For the week that ended July 10, the season premiere of USA Network's "Monk" brought in the four-season-long series' largest audience ever. The episode, in which Jason Alexander was a guest star as the grubby opposite of Monk, was also the most-watched cable show of the week in total viewers (6.38 million). USA had three other shows in the week's top 20: "The Dead Zone" (3.29 million), "The 4400" (3.22 million) and a repeat of "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" (3.1 million). But TNT, as usual, was the No. 1 cable channel in prime time. KATE AURTHUR

title: Palestinians Kill 2 Israeli Civilians on Road From Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, July 24 - Palestinian gunmen sprayed a civilian Israeli convoy with automatic gunfire early Sunday morning, killing a husband and wife and wounding four other Israelis, three of them seriously, the Israeli Army said. The attack took place on the main road connecting Israeli Gaza settlements with Israel.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Human Remains Found
description: The police arrested the roommate of a woman whose decomposing body was discovered in a bag in Brighton Beach in Brooklyn early Saturday, the police said. The police identified the roommate as Nikolay Baranov, 51, of 3022 Brighton 2nd Street, who they said had argued with the woman over money. They said a charge of murder was pending against him last night. The name of the woman was not released because her relatives had not yet been notified, the police said. In a separate discovery in Queens, the police said human remains were discovered yesterday morning in Little Bay under the Throgs Neck Bridge. A fisherman spotted the remains about 9:45 a.m. just east of the Utopia Parkway, the police said. The remains were taken to the city medical examiner's office.

title: Bomb kills at least 25 in Baghdad
The Tour de Lance
Dolan and Brown Get to Know Each Other
description: Larry Brown and James L. Dolan spent yesterday evening together in East Hampton, a highly anticipated rendezvous that could have a profound impact on the Knicks for years to come.

title: What Bush Doesn't Know
description: I remember the arrogance that accompanied the "shock and awe" bombing campaign that kicked off the war in Iraq more than two years ago. The war was supposed to be quick and easy, a cakewalk. The enemy, we were told, would fold like a dinner napkin. And then, in the neoconservative fantasies of some of the crazier folks in the Bush crowd, the military would gear up for an invasion of Iran.

title: Lance Armstrong: The Legend
description: George Vecsey of The Times discusses the legacy of Lance Armstrong, who won his seventh straight Tour de France. Launch Feature

title: A Radio Program Turns to a Blog to Cull Ideas
description: With its long reliance on talk formats and call-in programs, radio was arguably the first open-source media form. Now a new Public Radio International program, "Open Source from P.R.I.," will test whether the collective intelligence permeating the Web can make not just loud radio, but smart radio. Not only does the program pull from unfiltered voices and opinions found on blogs, Open Source uses its own blog (www.radioopensource.org) to cull ideas and sources from its listeners.

title: 4 Major Unions Plan to Boycott A.F.L.-C.I.O. Event
description: CHICAGO, July 24 - Leaders of four of the country's largest labor unions announced on Sunday that they would boycott this week's A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention, and officials from two of those unions, the service employees and the Teamsters, said the action was a prelude to their full withdrawal from the federation on Monday.

title: A New Worry for Investors: Retirees' Medical Benefits
description: As double-digit inflation in health care siphons more and more cash from old-line companies with generous benefits, big investors are growing wary.

title: Amid exodus, many tourists opt to stay in Egypt
Briefs: Malaysia will allow currency to find its level against dollar
Back-to-School Season Is Expanding, and So Are the Ambitions of Kmart
description: DECADES ago, back-to-school shoppers heard commercials featuring a choir warbling a jingle that began, "School bells ring and children sing, 'It's back to Robert Hall again."'

title: Guerrero makes hits count against Yankees
The Best Army We Can Buy
description: THE United States now has a mercenary army. To be sure, our soldiers are hired from within the citizenry, unlike the hated Hessians whom George III recruited to fight against the American Revolutionaries. But like those Hessians, today's volunteers sign up for some mighty dangerous work largely for wages and benefits -- a compensation package that may not always be commensurate with the dangers in store, as current recruiting problems testify.

title: Regrets, but No Apology, in London Subway Shooting
description: LONDON, July 24 - The British police on Sunday defended the killing of an innocent man on a subway train and a shoot-to-kill policy as Britain's political establishment rallied around the policies of Prime Minister Tony Blair in his antiterror campaign.

title: Klee-esque Spirit of Argentine Visionary Shines Anew
description: BUENOS AIRES - The Argentine writer Jorge Luis Borges, who was perhaps his closest friend, once described him as "our William Blake." Oscar Agustn Alejandro Schulz Solari, who called himself Xul Solar, was indeed a visionary, painter and poet, but only now, 40 years after his death, is the full scope of his imagination being fully appreciated.

title: Helping Inmates Start a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Indonesia destroys pigsin effort to halt bird flu
For Gore, a Reincarnation on the Other Side of the Camera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 - The day after President Bush announced his first Supreme Court nominee, his opponent in the hotly disputed 2000 election was a continent away from the White House, sitting in a darkened conference room in a converted coffee warehouse here.

title: Pressure is growingon Muslims in Italy
Heeeeere's Al, Thanks to Carson
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 23 - As vice president, Al Gore learned that the most disarming way to counter his wooden image was to tell better jokes about himself than the late-night comedians did. Mr. Gore now says he received occasional tutoring on those one-liners from the master of the television monologue, Johnny Carson.

title: From Burger King, Music to Eat Chicken By
description: Burger King and its creative agency, Crispin Porter & Bogusky in Miami, are hoping to score again with a campaign using entertainment to sell chicken menu items to fast-food consumers ages 18 to 34.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: American League

title: New York and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Shine a Light on Hate, Everywhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HILLS, MABEL ISABELLE
description: HILLS -- Mabel Isabelle. Passed away surrounded by her family on Friday, July 22, 2005, in Regina, Saskatchewan, Canada, at age 82. Beloved wife of Gordon R. Hills of Regina and mother of Eldon R. Hills of NYC. A funeral service in celebration of Mabel's life will be conducted on Wednesday, July 27, 2005, at 1:30 pm, in Speers Funeral Chapel Regina, Canada.

title: Mayor to Fight Ballot Petitions of G.O.P. Rival
description: The Bloomberg campaign plans today to try to prevent a Republican primary for mayor by challenging the nominating petitions of Thomas V. Ognibene, the former city councilman who is seeking to run on the Republican line.

title: Searching for Footprints:Bombings Link Doubted
description: LONDON, July 24 - As Britain and Egypt struggle to absorb the effects of terrorist attacks on their soil and determine who was responsible, both countries are asking the same two questions: Were the attacks linked, and was Al Qaeda involved?

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Vive le Tour. Forever."

title: Can an urban fortress keep city-dwellers safe?
New CD's
description: The annual Latin Alternative Music Conference returns to New York City on Aug. 3 through 6, gathering musicians and music-business figures who want the world to know about the sly, smart, joyfully polymorphous and culturally savvy rock and pop being made across the Americas. But there's no need to wait even that long. Albums being released tomorrow by Yerba Buena, from New York City, and Nortec Collective, from Tijuana, make the most of every border crossing.

title: Briefly: U.S. is testing system to find terrorist groups
Hijacking the Gaza pullout
Seoul's mayor shows his green streak
50 Candles for a Breakthrough Chevy
description: EVERYTHING in Detroit seemed to change for 1955, as if the entire auto industry awoke at once and shook off the last remaining traces of its cautious postwar mind-set.

title: Blacks Pin Hope on DNA to Fill Slavery's Gaps in Family Trees
description: All her life, Rachel Fair has been teased by other black Americans about her light skin. "High yellow," they call her, a needling reference to the legacy of a slave owner who, she says, "went down to that cabin and had what he wanted."

title: Scary runways, scary skies
Dialing Bloomberg? Check a Phone Book (and a Calendar)
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said recently that some residents had called him at his town house with concerns about city affairs, and noted that his phone number was still listed, some cynics thought it a ploy to make the billionaire mayor seem accessible.

title: Merck's Case Withstands First Week of Punches
description: Correction Appended

title: Rumsfeld Stop in Kyrgyzstan Aims to Keep Access to Base
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, July 25 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in this Central Asian nation today to shore up an unsettled military basing arrangement here that has been critical to operations in Afghanistan. The refueling and cargo mission operated by the American military from Manas Air Base, just outside the Kyrgyz capital, has been essential to ferry aid, troops and equipment to and from Afghanistan. About 1,000 American troops operate from the airfield, the base for a dozen KC-135 refueling jets and C-130 cargo planes.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The A-Team, a consulting company for marketers and agencies, has been opened in three cities by four longtime advertising and marketing executives. Peter Gerritsen will be based in the Boston office; he had previously been creative director at Allen & Gerritsen. The New York office of the A-Team will be staffed by Ann Billock, who has worked for consultants like Roth Associates, and Bill Nicholson, who had been executive vice president at the agency management division of the American Association of Advertising Agencies. And Jerry Gibbons will be based in the San Francisco office of the A-Team; he had been executive vice president at the agency association, overseeing the Western region as well as the agency relations and service division.

title: Helping Inmates Start a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Countdown Proceeding Normally, NASA Says
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 25 - The countdown was proceeding normally today for launching the space shuttle Discovery on Tuesday, but NASA officials said they would not know until fueling starts overnight if they have overcome a persistent fuel sensor problem.

title: A Web Site Helps Indie Artists Along a Hard Road
description: If there was a fast track, Jessica Hirst was on it. After graduating from Stanford University with a degree in environmental policy, she interned at the Clinton White House and landed a $35,000-a-year job in the Energy Department. "I'd been planning to be a policy wonk since I was a kid," Ms. Hirst, 34, said. But she wasn't happy, and she developed a painful repetitive-stress problem. So in 1996 she quit her job to devote herself to dance, because, she said, "it always made me happy when I was a kid, jumping around."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAPLAN, SIMON
description: KAPLAN--Simon. Died on Shabbat, peacefully, in his 90th year. Loving and beloved husband for almost 65 years of Gertrude, nee Gross; cherished father of Lawrence, Joseph and Sharon, and Rena and Bruce Spinowitz; adored grandfather of Zvi and Alisa, Yaffa and Ed, Pearl, Micole, Daniele, Gila and Israel, Moshe and Tovah, Raquel and Jason, Naomi, and Gabrielle; devoted brother and brother in law of Eli and Cherie, Sarah Katzman, and Lillian; doting great grandfather of seven; respected uncle, relative, community leader and friend. Shiva at 1144 Sage Street, Far Rockaway, through Friday.

title: When the Curtain Rises, I'll Still Be in Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Tackle Taboos With Girlish Glee
description: MANILA, July 22 - "I'm sorry, but I just can't control those girls." That is how one of this country's tycoons is said to deflect complaints about articles in Newsbreak, a magazine he founded.

title: Housing Market Revs Up Again, Setting Record in June
description: The nation's roaring housing market set its second record in three months as sales of existing homes climbed at an annual rate of 4.4 percent in June, to 7.33 million, according to a report released today.

title: Helping Inmates Start a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Nuclear talks must advance, North and South Korea agree
Backstage Back-Stabbing as Reality Stars Make a Movie
description: The worst possible precedent, in the eyes of actors and writers in Hollywood, has happened: a scripted film is being made with only quasi celebrities who made their names (or disgraced their names) on reality shows. In one casting call, these novices, rescued from the garbage barge of fame, are given a chance that no so-called legitimate actor can get in a town that is overstocked with them. Most galling of all, the makers of this film, to be called "The Scorned" and shown on the E! channel this fall before being released on DVD, hail their own "all-star cast," a term once reserved for a cast of award nominees.

title: A Soviet-Era Vision of a Rebellion by Roman Slaves
description: We had "Astarte"; they had "Spartacus." American grooviness, however crudely manipulated, versus Soviet triumphalism. The Soviet Union was riding high in 1968. There were those scary displays of bellicose hardware in Red Square, and the Soviets were still holding their own in the space race (Neil Armstrong hadn't yet stepped on the moon).

title: Upheaval Continues in San Diego as 11 Vie for Mayor
description: SAN DIEGO, July 21 - Discussing why he should be elected this city's next mayor, Jerry Sanders recalled how he commanded a SWAT team in 1984 that shot a man who had opened fire at a local McDonald's, killing 21 people.

title: Briefly: Iran acknowledges human rights violations
Arroyo urges shift to parliamentary government
WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (Travel) ANTHONY BOURDAIN: NO RESERVATIONS -- "Paris" (series premiere). Mr. Bourdain (above) is a chef, but this isn't a cooking show. He does eat, starting with caf crme and a croissant in the Seventh Arrondissement, but he also studies French (learning how to say: "I have a hangover. Please kill me.") and checks into the hotel room where Oscar Wilde died.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANKFORT, JAMES
description: FRANKFORT--James. Noted painter and cartoonist known as JAF, died July 22 of a heart attack in his home state, Oregon. He was a veteran of the Korean war. He is survived by his children Michele, Jacob, Reina, Madrone and Simon, two grandchildren, Simon and Ceder, and sister Terry and her husband Herbert Starr. He will be missed by all that knew him. Grief is the price we pay for love.

title: When the Curtain Rises, I'll Still Be in Line (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Too Soon to Assign Responsibility for Bombings, Authorities in Egypt Contend
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, July 24 - Egyptian authorities rounded up people for questioning on Sunday and tried to identify the mutilated bodies left by the bombings of the country's top resort. But they said it was too early to say who was responsible for the attack, one of the deadliest terrorist strikes in Egypt's modern history.

title: Congressional Negotiators Are Nearing Agreement on Broad Energy Measure
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 - With strong encouragement from the White House, top House and Senate negotiators said Sunday that they were nearing a final agreement on a broad energy bill that would drop a plan to protect producers of the gasoline additive MTBE from lawsuits over water pollution.

title: In Britain, police defend shooting
Pedagogy? No Problem. Fund-Raising? Tough Subject.
description: OXFORD, England - With the prospect of dwindling state funds, the leaders of Oxford and Cambridge face a question that many people living beneath this city's dreaming spires may consider beneath their dignity: How do you market an 800-year-old university?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALAGONIA, ELEANOR
description: PALAGONIA -- Eleanor. On July 22, 2005. Loving mother of Robert C. and Barbara Truesdale and five grandchildren. Family will receive friends at John J. Fox Funeral Home, Larchmont, on Monday, 7-9 PM, and Tuesday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Mass will be celebrated on Wednesday, Sts. John and Paul Church, 10 AM. Interment will be private.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: How Willkie Ran, Lost and Helped Win the War
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 - It is June 1940. France has just fallen to the Nazis. A conservative, isolationist Republican Party, incensed at the prospect of a third term for Franklin D. Roosevelt, nominates a liberal, interventionist political newcomer named Wendell Lewis Willkie. His moderate candidacy gives Roosevelt the cover he needs to pass a draft, swap American destroyers for bases from a beleaguered Britain and win re-election by five million votes.

title: Suicide Bombings Bring Urgency to Police in U.S.
description: SEATTLE, July 22 - Inside a former Starbucks warehouse, this city's bomb squad headquarters, the police chief and 15 captains and sergeants -- accompanied by a robot that can extract explosives from packages and pin down a suspect -- huddled the other day to tackle a topic suddenly urgent to the police across the nation: suicide bombers.

title: Opening New York to Internet Wine Sales
description: TWO months after the United States Supreme Court handed them a long-awaited victory, winemakers and drinkers in New York, California and many other states can finally celebrate.

title: Shine a Light on Hate, Everywhere (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LAUTENBACHER, EDWARD
description: LAUTENBACHER -- Edward. Born in Brooklyn on October 1, 1907, and long time resident of Franklin Square, passed away in Napa, CA, on July 20, 2005.

title: A Fleeing Man and a Burst of Gunfire: Britons Look Into Their Collective Conscience
description: LONDON, July 24 - With the emergence here of suicidal terrorism and what seems to be an enemy within, Britons are raising questions about their ability to sustain an image as tolerant, open and unwilling to sacrifice civil liberties for security.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice's visit to Israel and Lebanon referred incorrectly to the home of Hezbollah, which the United States considers a terrorist group. It is a Lebanese group, not Palestinian.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMIS, FREDERICK WOLFE
description: KAMIS--Frederick Wolfe. On July 23, at age 62, in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved son of Evelyn and Matthew Rosenfield of Delray Beach, FL, and the late Bernard Kamis; devoted brother of Richard, Aaron and the late Arthur Kamis; loving father of Daniella and Gordon Brown, Josh and Nikki Kamis, Shoshana and Kenny Dichter; proudest Pop-Pop to Ian, Alexandra, Elyssa, Jordyn, Chloe and Harley. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday July 26, at 11:30 AM, at East Brunswick Jewish Center and interment to follow at Beth Abraham Cemetery, East Brunswick, NJ.

title: Suicide attack in central Baghdad; at least 14 dead
Search for six Pakistanis in Sharm el-Sheik probe
Reports Sully Clean Image of a Mexican Candidate
description: MEXICO CITY, July 22 - Santiago Creel, Mexico's former interior minister, had that most rare of assets among Mexican politicians: a squeaky clean image. He seemed the clear front-runner to carry the banner for President Vicente Fox's conservative party in next year's presidential elections.

title: Arts, Briefly; Honors for the Honored
description: Elizabeth Taylor is to be honored by the Los Angeles branch of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts in Hollywood on Nov. 10, when she is to receive its Britannia award for excellence, Agence France-Presse reported. Tom Cruise is to receive a Britannia for film and Mike Newell one for directing. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

title: Look to Virginia, Not China
description: This week, the House of Representatives is expected to take up free trade. As is always the case with trade votes, the debate promises to be bloody, as President Bush and Congressional Republican leaders beg and bribe antitrade members of their party to make up for the legions of Democrats who are lining up in opposition.

title: Popular Demand
description: There are 119 syndicated series on television, from current-run talk shows to former network sitcoms. As summer reruns take hold, syndicated shows often pass their network cousins. According to the Syndicated Network Television Association, seven of the top 10 shows on four out of five weekday nights in June were syndicated.

title: On advertising: Dressing up commercials as short films
Battle for Amena heats up
John Baldry, 64, Singer Who Shaped British Rock, Dies
description: Long John Baldry, a British blues-rock singer who helped start the careers of the Rolling Stones, Rod Stewart, Elton John and other British stars, died on Thursday in Vancouver, British Columbia. He was 64 and had been a longtime resident of Vancouver.

title: Hoop Wizard Shows Off His 3-Point Skill
description: Jack Ryan, a 43-year-old from Brooklyn known as the Hoop Wizard, won the national amateur 3-point shooting contest yesterday at Seward Park in Chicago. He won $10,000.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Jan. 6, 1993, about William G. McLoughlin, an emeritus professor of history and religion at Brown University, misstated the date and cause of his death. Professor McLoughlin died on Dec. 28, 1992, not on Jan. 4, 1993; the cause was colon cancer, not liver cancer. The article also misstated the location of his World War II military service. It was at Fort Sill, Okla., not in Europe. TheTimes learned of the errors through a recent e-mail message from a family member.

title: Bid to Oust Arroyo Is Filed
description: MANILA, Monday, July 25 - An impeachment complaint was filed Monday against President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo, a few hours ahead of her scheduled annual address before a joint session of the Philippine Congress.

title: Out of the Office
description: Press secretaries can be surprisingly hard to get on the phone. But perhaps none have been harder to reach recently than David Chai, a member of the New York City Council's press office who handles reporters' inquiries about contracts and ethics, among other matters. On different days last week, we attempted to contact Mr. Chai at the press office, but no one seemed to know where he was or when he would be back, though a check with the Department of Citywide Administrative Services revealed that Mr. Chai remained an active employee of the Council.

title: 2 Israelis are killed and then 2 Palestinians
Paid Notice: Deaths   YOUNG, DR. KEVIN SCOTT
description: YOUNG--Dr. Kevin Scott. Died peacefully in his sleep on July 23 at his home in Easthampton, NY, surrounded by his family and friends: he was 43 years old. Dr. Young, a graduate of Colby College and NYU Medical School, practiced internal medicine in NYC for the last 15 years. He is survived by his loving partner George Laskaris, their dogs Bailey and Brady, parents Linda and Robert Young, brother and sister-inlaw Peter and Naomi, and their children Luci, Kofi and Emmett. Kevin was a passionate physician, gardener, chef, artist and friend. He will be dearly missed by his family, friends and patients. Private services will be held in Easthampton.

title: As NASA Prepares to Launch Shuttles Again, 70's-Era Technology Is Showing Its Age
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 24 - Like an increasingly creaky baby boomer who can still run a marathon, the space shuttle is a delicate organism that can do miraculous things. But as the Discovery prepares to lift off Tuesday morning on the first shuttle mission since the loss of the Columbia two and a half years ago, it is clearly feeling its age.

title: Japan's supercomputer
China Bird-Flu Scare Ends
description: BEIJING, Monday, July 25 - Chinese and international health officials said Monday that they believed that the mysterious deaths of at least 17 farmers in western China were caused by a bacterial infection in pigs and not, as initially feared, by a new outbreak of the deadly avian influenza.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WEISS, WILLIE
description: WEISS--Willie. On July 24, 2005. Dear mother of Victor (Nicole Anderson - Weiss), Amy (Peter Kadzik), and Betsy (Peter Tyras). Loving grandmother of Jack, Tobe, Julia Tyras, and Melissa, Alison, Mary-Pat, and P.J. Kadzik. Services will be held at "Wien & Wien," Hackensack, Monday, the 25th, at 10:30 am. For further information; 800322-0533.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,768 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American on Saturday:

title: Below Ground Zero, Stirrings of Past and Future
description: Having endured the construction and destruction of the World Trade Center above, the 96-year-old Hudson Terminal -- now a colossal underground ruin at ground zero -- will soon give way to a new transportation hub.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   AWAD, DEWEY JOHN
description: AWAD--Dewey John. July 3, 1899--July 25, 1979. Another year of missing you, loving you and respecting you. Jimmy

title: Nickell's Manners Honored, but He's a Scrapper
description: On Saturday night, along with the induction of four members into the American Contract Bridge League's Hall of Fame, Nick Nickell received the Sidney J. Lazard Jr. Sportsmanship Award in Atlanta.

title: Pressure is growingon Muslims in Italy
Corrections
description: An article on July 14 about a decision by the Episcopal bishop of Connecticut to remove a priest from his duties referred incorrectly at one point to the clergymen known as the Connecticut Six, who oppose the ordination of gay bishops. They are priests, not bishops.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Lawsuit Aims To Stop Park Renovation
description: A group opposed to a plan by the city's Parks Department to renovate Washington Square Park filed a lawsuit on Friday seeking to stop the work, members of the group said yesterday. The Parks Department plans to spend $16 million on renovations, including moving the park fountain and leveling variations in elevation. The lawsuit, filed in State Supreme Court, was first reported in The Villager. Luther Harris, a plaintiff and an author of a history of the park, said the renovation would change the park's historic role as a performance and gathering space. A Parks Department spokeswoman said that the department would not comment until it had a chance to review the lawsuit.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on July 8 about the children's theater company Theaterworks/USA misstated the connection of Jay Harnick, a founder of the company, to the musical "Young Abe Lincoln" when it opened in New York in 1961. He was the director, not the producer. (Arthur Shimkin was the producer.)

title: Once Again, Subway  Changes Agencies
description: For the second time in 14 months, the Subway sandwich chain has parted ways with an agency handling its creative account.

title: Arts, Briefly; New CD's This Week
description: After a few months when rock has dominated the Billboard album charts, hip-hop and R&B have returned recently with the release of several big sellers including R. Kelly and the Ying Yang Twins. This week another potential R&B hit will be released: "Grown & Sexy" (Arista), by Babyface. Other new CD's include the wide retail release of Alanis Morissette's "Jagged Little Pill Acoustic" (Maverick/Warner Brothers), which for the last six weeks has been sold exclusively at Starbucks stores; the pop singer Jason Mraz's "Mr. A-Z" (Atlantic); Brian Setzer and the Nash-Villains' "Rockabilly Riot Vol. 1: A Tribute to Sun Records" (Surfdog), which covers songs by Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Carl Perkins and Jerry Lee Lewis; and the gruff hip-hop crew Ruff Ryders' "Ryders or Die Vol. 4: The Redemption" (Ruff Ryders/Artemis), featuring N.O.R.E., DMX, Jadakiss , the Lox and others. BEN SISARIO

title: U.S. Holds Talks With North Korea
description: BEIJING, July 25 - Negotiators from the United States and North Korea held a rare private meeting today that underscored the heightened expectations and grave concerns attached to the six-nation disarmament talks opening Tuesday over the North Korean nuclear crisis.

title: To Reduce the Cost of Teenage Temptation, Why Not Just Raise the Price of Sin?
description: WHEN you look back on all the attempts to curb teenage drinking, smoking and drug use over the last couple of decades, you start to ask yourself a question that countless parents have asked: Does anybody really know how to change a teenager's behavior?

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Where Absinthe Makes the Kitchen Grow Hotter
description: "Maybe I shouldn't have drunk so much absinthe."

title: A Sport So Popular, They Added a Second Boom
description: CLEVELAND, July 20 - Twelve of the top action-sports athletes -- skateboarders and BMX stunt and freestyle motocross riders -- simultaneously started into a choreographed show at Gund Arena. On a sprawling ramps complex laid out like a Hot Wheels set, they twisted and flipped through the air, backed by a roaring soundtrack and cheers from the audience.

title: Helping Inmates Start a New Life (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary T. Washington, First Black Woman to Earn C.P.A. Credential, Is Dead at 99
description: Mary T. Washington, a bookkeeper who in the 1920's began methodically surmounting racial barriers in business to become the first African-American woman to be a certified public accountant and the head of one of the largest black-owned accounting firms in the nation, died on July 2 at a nursing home in Chicago. She was 99.

title: Johnson Bothered by Health Questions
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., July 24 - At one point during his rant against the news media on Sunday, Yankees starter Randy Johnson told reporters to talk to Kevin Brown. It was a good idea, but there was one problem: Brown had left the team to see a doctor in Colorado for his aching back.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a criminal investigation into the conduct of three law firms involved in asbestos litigation mischaracterized the allegations in civil court filings against two firms, Weitz & Luxenberg, and Ness, Motley, Loadholt, Richardson & Poole.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: 2 Charged In Shooting Outside Bar
description: Two men who work for The Source, a hip-hop magazine, were charged yesterday with attempted murder in connection with a shooting outside a Chelsea bar that injured three men, one critically, the police said. The two -- Alvin Childs, 35, a marketing director for the magazine, and Leroy Peeples, 32, the president of Source Entertainment, a related merchandising company -- were each charged with three counts of attempted murder. Their lawyer, Mel A. Sachs, said that both men pleaded not guilty at their arraignment and were expected to post bail, set at $25,000 cash or a $200,000 bond. The police said the shooting occurred after Mr. Childs and Mr. Peeples argued with two men about 2:15 a.m. Saturday at the Limerick House, a bar at 69 West 23rd Street. The police said the dispute spilled outside and Mr. Peeples and Mr. Childs shot the men, Orlando Orenga, 26, and Alex Colon, 30. A busboy, who was not identified, was hit by three bullets. Mr. Colon was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center. The two other men were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital Manhattan, where Mr. Orenga, who had been shot in the head, was in critical condition, the police said. The other men were in stable condition, the police said. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Sunnis to End Iraq Charter Boycott; Bomb Kills 25
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Monday, July 25 - With just three weeks to go before an important deadline for the new constitution, Sunni Arab leaders said Sunday that they were ready to end their boycott of the drafting process. The statements came as a suicide truck bomber rammed into barricades at a police station here in the middle of a raging sandstorm, killing at least 25 people and wounding at least 33 others, Iraqi officials said.

title: In rock, singing in German is cool again
DreamWorks Struggles as a Public Company
description: The noise from fans was deafening at the "Mr. & Mrs. Smith" premiere last month where, in the film, Brad Pitt takes a beating from his onscreen wife, played by Angelina Jolie. Inside the theater, Jeffrey Katzenberg, the chief executive of DreamWorks Animation, was more subdued, having taken something of a beating himself in recent days.

title: Ad in Public Advocate Race Is Critical of 9/11 Rescue Effort
description: Norman Siegel, the civil rights lawyer and candidate for the city's public advocate position, will present a campaign ad on television this evening featuring family members of victims of the World Trade Center attack, his campaign said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SMILES, BLANCHE
description: SMILES -- Blanche. Passed away July 23, 2005. Devoted wife of the late Albert, loving mother, sister, aunt and friend. Charming, funny, full of life, an inspiration to all. Loved by all who knew her. She will be profoundly missed. She is survived by her daughters Lynn and Joan Smiles, sisters Irene Travis, Marlene Semel, brother Nat Regenstreif, nieces and nephews.

title: The Gaza Gamble: A Way Out, or Another Dead End?
description: GAZA, July 19 - Despite the turmoil in Israeli society, there is little doubt that Prime Minister Ariel Sharon will pull the nearly 9,000 Israeli settlers out of Gaza, now a closed military zone.

title: Paul Steinberg, Longtime Dean and Rabbi, Is Dead at 79
description: Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg, a dean at Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York for 50 years, died on July 8 at a hospice in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 79.

title: Triumph and Resignation in Brahms's Autumnal Soul
description: LENOX, Mass., July 24 - Why all four Brahms symphonies in two sittings? Because they're there? Because they conveniently fill out two programs? Because they're crowd pleasers (for reasons never entirely clear to a listener who finds them harder and harder work as new depths loom beneath an already complex surface)?

title: Uniform Sacrifice
description: Mouans-Sartoux, France - IT was dawn, early December 1950: 40 below zero with gale-force snow-laced wind slicing down across the Yalu River from Manchuria while Chinese legions blasted away on their attack bugles just up ahead and probably with good reason believed they would annihilate every marine fighting his way through other equally determined Chinese trying to interdict the mountain road leading down to the waiting United Nations rescue flotilla -- and escape.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBSON, ISHIER
description: JACOBSON--Ishier. Retired public utility executive, World War II veteran, and long-time resident of Stamford, CT., died July 20, 2005, at age 83. He was born in Worcester, MA. and raised in Waterbury, CT. He earned a B.A. from Clark University, M.S. in engineering from Harvard University, and law degree from Harvard Law School. He served as an officer in the U.S. Navy during World War II aboard a submarine in the Atlantic arena, and in many major engagements in the Pacific aboard the battleship U.S.S. Washington. He moved to Stamford in 1954 to work at Citizens Utilities Co. During his 36-year career there, he was named president in 1970 and CEO in 1981, a position he held until retirement in 1990. He gave much to the community, serving as chairman of Silver Hill Hospital, Connecticut Ballet, and the Harvard Graduate School Alumni Council, and playing key roles at the University of Connecticut's Stamford campus, Jewish Family Service, and Stamford Historical Society, among others. He was also an avid tennis player. He leaves his loving wife of 56 years, Maria (Bohm); his daughter Joanna of Stamford; his son Jonathan and his partner James McKibben of New York City; his daughter Paula and her husband Tom Grover of Danvers, MA; his four adored grandchildren, Alex, Jacob, and Rebecca Grover, and Brendan Jacobson O'Neil; his brother Alvin and his wife Karen; and his brother Larry. We will miss him dearly.

title: Shine a Light on Hate, Everywhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Samsung and Sony, the Clashing Titans, Try Teamwork
description: TOKYO - They go head-to-head in Best Buy, Wal-Mart and CompUSA with their televisions, DVD recorders and camcorders: Sony, the world's best-known electronics maker, and Samsung Electronics, the hard-charging upstart.

title: Drug Maker May Buy Rival for $7.5 Billion
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. is near a deal to acquire the Ivax Corporation for about $7.5 billion in cash and stock, executives involved in the negotiations said late yesterday.

title: Sony BMG nears accord on radio play
Busch Leaves the Pack, and the Debris, in the Dust
description: LONG POND, Pa., July 24 - When Kurt Busch grabbed the lead from Jamie McMurray on the first lap Sunday, the race was pretty much over. Busch was the fastest driver by far, refusing to be unnerved by debris on the track or the numerous crashes that slowed the race.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Toddler Found Dead
