description: A 2-year-old girl was found dead in her bed Saturday evening in New Brighton, the police said yesterday. The cause of death was not known, and the police said they were awaiting the results of an autopsy. The girl, whose name was not released, was being watched by her mother's boyfriend at her home at 53 Brook Street while her mother was at work, the police said. The boyfriend, whose name was not released, found the girl about 6:30 p.m. Saturday, the police said. Michelle O'Donnell (NYT)

title: Daydreams From the Land of the Obscure
description: On Saturday night at the Lower East Side club Tonic, the room was full of young fans eager to see a not-so-young singer named Gary Higgins. The fans wanted to thank Mr. Higgins for the obscure album he released in 1973, full of mutant folk songs that sound both earthy and spaced-out. And they wanted to thank Mr. Higgins, too, for the lack of albums he has released since then.

title: Champagne on Champs-lyses Sends Armstrong Off to Act III
description: Paris - ONCE upon a time, another American had a magnificent Paris. They called him Lucky Lindy because, vox populi decided, anybody who could fly across the ocean all by himself was, by definition, lucky.

title: People
description: Cindy Gallop, United States chairwoman for Bartle Bogle Hegarty, London, and chief marketing officer for the agency, is resigning, effective in mid-August, after a 16-year career at Bartle Bogle. Ms. Gallop, who helped open the agency's offices in New York and Singapore, was president for the New York office from 1998 to 2004.

title: Watch the Fishes
description: There is a popular expression on Madison Avenue that the best way to sell clients' products is to "fish where the fish are." A hilarious new campaign is taking that advice to its illogical conclusion.

title: Israel is still blocking the road to peace
Mob sets fire to government buildings in Indonesia
Breaking News With a Familiar Ring
description: Last week, John Roberts, the chief White House correspondent for CBS News, had the task of announcing President Bush's nominee for the Supreme Court: John Roberts, the federal judge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PRESSMAN, SONIA
description: PRESSMAN--Sonia. Of Monsey, NY. Died July 23, 2005, of Alzheimer's and stomach cancer. She was the beloved wife of David, dearest mother to Olivia and Leonard, and dear grandmother to Anita, Jessica and Jay, great-grandmother to Devin. We will all miss you.

title: Sony Agrees to Halt Gifts for Airtime
description: Sony BMG Music Entertainment, one of the world's largest record companies, agreed today to stop providing lavish gifts, free trips and other giveaways in exchange for airtime for its artists on radio stations, under the terms of a settlement with the New York attorney general's office.

title: Family of slain man asks why it happened
Paid Notice: Deaths   EFFRON, JAMES WILBUR
description: EFFRON--James Wilbur. We are saddened by the death of our much loved classmate. Jim was our president, 1996-1998. We will remember his integrity, loyalty, generosity, kindness and great, good, robust humor. Our sympathies to Dawn and their four children. Class of 1953, Princeton

title: Relatives and Friends Remember a Busy, Hopeful Man, and Discover a New Fear
description: LONDON, July 24 - He was an electrician. He was 27 years old. He had lived in London for more than three years -- legally, a cousin said -- and was rattled enough by the first wave of bombs in London to consider forgoing the subway and buying a motorbike.

title: North Korea Nuclear Goals: Case of Mixed Signals
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 - Early this year, American spy satellites detected a spike in suspicious tunneling activity at a highly secretive military site in the mountains of North Korea.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: 'Charlie' And 'Wedding' Stay On Top

title: Nomination Reopens Debate on Disclosure
description: WASHINGTON, July 24 - For at least 34 years, Democrats and Republicans have staked out opposing positions on the question of whether a onetime Justice Department or White House lawyer, like John G. Roberts, should, when nominated to the Supreme Court, open up his government writings and recommendations to public scrutiny.

title: Cricket: Australia douses England's hopes
Paid Notice: Deaths   HARVEY, BRUCE
description: HARVEY -- Bruce. 96, of Greenwich, CT, died July 20, 2005. He was active in many organizations in NYC. Predeceased by his wife, Amy Aspegren Harvey, survived by three daughters, Lucille Taff, Marianne Olsen and Joan Wilson, five grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Burial is private. Memorial service July 30, at Christ Church, Greenwich, at 11 am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to St. George's Society of New York, 216 East 45 Street, Suite 901, New York, NY 10017; or to Friendly Connections, c/o Family Centers, 40 Arch Street, Greenwich, CT 06830.

title: Charles Colson and the Mission That Began With Watergate
description: Charles Colson, the quintessential Watergate-era hatchet man, once declared that he would "walk over my own grandmother" to get Richard Nixon re-elected. He may not have committed the worst dirty tricks attributed to him, like plotting to firebomb the Brookings Institution to destroy a secret report on the Vietnam War that was damaging to his boss. But before the Nixon White House scandals were over, he was sent away to federal prison for obstruction of justice.

title: Shine a Light on Hate, Everywhere
description: To the Editor:

title: Watch Me Do This and That Online
description: Can you vlog a dead horse? Only if you make a video of it and post it on the Web.

title: Down on the Collective Farm
description: Ah, well, the Bolshoi Ballet is in town and can't escape its past, so here's another Soviet ballet. But "The Bright Stream," which opened a three-performance run Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a very different work in nearly every respect from "Spartacus," which ended its run on Saturday.

title: When the Big Guys Fuss
description: New York's state officials have a terrible tendency to talk about a kind of ber-reality that sounds lofty and good but somehow also obscures what's really going on. Take the recent tit-for-tat between Gov. George Pataki, a Republican, and Comptroller Alan Hevesi, a Democrat. Listening to them last week, you'd think they were engaged in cosmic battles about pension security and fiscal soundness. Somehow, we doubt that's the whole story.

title: France Tlcom Is Expected to Win Bid for Amena
description: LONDON, July 24 - In a sign that the private equity firms that have dominated European deal making in recent years are beginning to be squeezed out, France Tlcom is expected to win a 10 billion-euro or $12 billion fight for the Spanish mobile company Amena.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Stamina for Demanding Works (and a Wild Ol)
description: Age is finally catching up with the American virtuoso pianist Earl Wild, who will turn 90 in November. But the aging process, it would seem, has largely affected his legs.

title: A Generous Armstrong Sees the Winner in Ullrich
description: PARIS, July 25 - Lance Armstrong fulfilled Jan Ullrich's wish for an invitation to the victory party, but whether the German rider was at the Hotel Ritz was impossible to tell. With 600 guests celebrating Armstrong's seventh consecutive Tour de France triumph, the buffet table was too crowded to notice everybody.

title: Corrections
description: Because of editing errors, articles on Thursday about John G. Roberts, the Supreme Court nominee, covering his life and his career as a lawyer in private practice, referred incompletely to his compensation as a law partner at Hogan & Hartson. Judge Roberts's financial disclosure reports show that he received $1,044,000 from the firm for the first five months of 2003, before he resigned to become a judge. That figure was the total of earnings plus a payout for his equity interest in the law firm, not earnings alone.

title: Egyptian Police Say Security May Have Disrupted Bombers' Plan
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, July 25 - Egyptian officials, giving their first detailed account of a deadly terror strike at this Red Sea resort, said today that all three bombs were suicide attacks, and suggested that they were intended to explode at two hotels and a busy nightlife strip packed with Western tourists.

title: Decision Time for Mets: Try for Playoffs or Punt
description: WITH the baseball nonwaiver trading deadline six days away, the Mets find themselves in a serious and -- for many fans -- unexpected predicament. They are in the thick of a playoff hunt.

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Day After Egypt Bombings, on Vacation, With Resolve
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, July 24 - A day after one of the worst terrorist attacks in Egyptian history, tourists at this sun-baked resort woke up Sunday determined, for the most part, to stick to the languid rhythms of a beach holiday.

title: Quietly, Ricky Williams Returns to the Dolphins
description: DAVIE, Fla., July 24 - The scene was festive across the street from the Miami Dolphins' training facility Sunday morning. People parked their cars along the side of the road, pulled beach chairs out of their trunks, passed around doughnuts, bagels and binoculars, and watched for the scheduled relaunching of an N.F.L. career that was scrubbed deep into the countdown for the 2004 season.

title: Was it real for you, too?
Miller Plays Up Poll Results
description: For some candidates, a 15 percent showing in a four-way race would be something to play down. But in a newsletter to supporters, the campaign for Council Speaker Gifford Miller, left, praised the performance, highlighting how it showed movement in the right direction for the Democratic mayoral candidate.

title: Senate Panel to Examine Use of Cover by U.S. Spies
description: The Senate Intelligence Committee will conduct hearings on American spy agencies' use of cover to protect the identities of intelligence officers, the committee chairman said on Sunday.

title: Some Industry Advice to German Musicians: Never Mind the English Lessons
description: LONDON, July 24 - German was the language of Wagner, Mozart, Bach and Beethoven. But since English rock 'n' roll arrived, German has not been a popular language for musicians, even native ones.

title: When the Curtain Rises, I'll Still Be in Line
description: To the Editor:

title: AOL Picks Agencies For Its Free Portal
description: America Online in Dulles, Va., part of Time Warner, has named three agencies to help introduce the AOL.com Web site as a free portal. America Online will spend an estimated $50 million to promote the portal in three advertising areas: search marketing, online and offline.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about an announcement by Turkey that it anticipates American help with capturing Kurdish rebel leaders hiding in northern Iraq omitted the byline. The article was written by Mark Landler.

title: Business Digest
description: DreamWorks Struggles as a Public Company For Jeffrey Katzenberg, who had top jobs at Paramount Pictures and the Walt Disney Company before co-founding DreamWorks SKG in 1994, it seemed natural that he would become the chief executive of his own company. But what has caught many by surprise is the number of blunders DreamWorks Animation has made since going public last October. [Page C1.]

title: White House Letter: The executive in chief likes to break the ice
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, EDWARD HARTLEY
description: BENENSON--Edward Hartley. Born March 27, 1914, in NYC. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Thomas, James and Deb, Amy and Clifford Aronson, Lisa and Joseph Quattrocchi, and Andrew Benenson and Ronnie and George Igel. Adored grandfather of 14 grandchildren and great grandfather of five great grandchildren. A great lover of food and wine, art and travel, the Yankees and the Civil War. Chairman of Benenson Funding Corporation. Edward H. Benenson graduated from Duke University in 1934 and has been involved with the University and Medical Center ever since. He was Trustee Emeritus and former Chairman of Friends of Duke University Museum of Art. He established the Edward H. Benenson Awards in the Arts at Duke and founded the Edward H. Benenson Merit Scholarship Fund for Duke University Medical Center (DUMC). He received the 2000 Honorary Medical Alumnus Award from DUMC and the 2002 Distinguished Alumnus Award from the University. He was co-founder and Honorary Trustee of the Culinary Institute of America where he was the generous donor of the Edward H. Benenson Scholarship Fund. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Grand Camerlingue Honoraire of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, Bailli Delegue Honoraire des Etats Unis of the Chine des Rotisseurs and member of the American Societies of the Italian Legions of Merit and of French Order of Merit. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Monday from 6-8. Funeral services on Tuesday at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Duke University Medical Center, c/o Ruth Irvin, DUMC, 512 South Mangum Street, Suite 400, Durham, NC 27701-3973. He had a heart of gold and will be greatly missed by all those whose lives he touched with his kindness, generosity and love.

title: Licking and Salting War's Open Wounds
description: LOS ANGELES, July 24 - This show doesn't have a lawyer plunging to her death down an elevator shaft. It doesn't have a foul-mouthed cop making broadcasting history by mooning more than 20 million viewers. What it does have -- and what makes it unmistakably a Steven Bochco production -- is plenty of button-pushing. It's called "Over There," and it's a television drama that takes direct aim at the single most polarizing subject in the United States right now: the war in Iraq.

title: Briefly: Music and drama festival opens for five-week run
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about second-quarter earnings for Dow Jones & Company and The New York Times Company misstated the profit results for About.com, a subsidiary of The Times Company. It had an operating profit of $2.5 million; it did not report a loss.

title: Iraq insurgents gathering strength
Sorry, Charlie, but Fog Lets Tuna Off the Hook
description: MONTAUK, N.Y. - If all the tuna in North America had applied for safe passage along the waters from Delaware to New Jersey, they could not have received better protection than the fog that blanketed the coast for much of early July. The tuna were there, no question about it, and they were taking flies. But first you had to find them.

title: Sale of a Chapel Pits Some Parishioners Against Pastor
description: OLD LYME, Conn., July 20 - The trouble began in October, after the summer worshipers left town. It was then that Msgr. Richard P. LaRocque announced that Our Lady of Good Counsel would be sold.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BARBERICH, ELSIE JAHN
description: BARBERICH--Elsie Jahn. On July 21, 2005 in her 97th year. Beloved wife of the late Norman. Dear sister of the late Johanna Kruger, Leah Bulfinch and Alfred Jahn. Loving aunt of Richard and Shirley Bulfinch of Oregon City, OR, Roger and Kathy Jahn of Monroe, CT, and Robert Jahn of Southington, CT. Also survived by many great nieces and nephews. Elsie worked well into her late eighties as a beautician at Georgoios in Flushing, NY. Also a 70 year resident of Queens, NY. Reposing Simonson Funeral Home, 119 - 04 Hillside Avenue, Richmond Hill, NY. Visiting hours Tuesday, 6-9 PM. Funeral Wednesday, 12 noon. Interment LI National Cemetery.

title: Myron Floren, 85, Welk's Accordion Player, Dies
description: Myron Floren, an accordion virtuoso whose televised solos with the Lawrence Welk band became a staple of the cheerful folksiness that was the Welk show's hallmark, died on Saturday at his home in Rolling Hills, Calif., said Margaret Heron, syndication manager for the show. He was 85.

title: Corrections
description: The Poker column on July 9, about presidents and generals who have played poker, misstated the position of Secretary of State James Byrnes on the use of the atomic bomb during World War II. He supported using the bomb against Japan; he did not oppose it.

title: With One Ace, Jann Wenner Doubles Down
description: JANN S. WENNER and Kent Brownridge, his wingman at Wenner Media, are the Thelma and Louise of publishing: every time they see a cliff, they gun the engine.

title: Egyptians seek clues to deadly bombings
Toyota, Moving Northward
description: Modern American politics is dominated by the doctrine that government is the problem, not the solution. In practice, this doctrine translates into policies that make low taxes on the rich the highest priority, even if lack of revenue undermines basic public services. You don't have to be a liberal to realize that this is wrong-headed. Corporate leaders understand quite well that good public services are also good for business. But the political environment is so polarized these days that top executives are often afraid to speak up against conservative dogma.

title: You're Hired! Job Interviews at the Top
description: WASHINGTON - People don't often think of the president of the United States as a boss, but in fact the chief executive spends a lot of time interviewing job applicants and worrying about personnel. That became clear last week when White House officials said that President Bush had conducted five interviews for one of the most rarified job openings in America and then decided, as everyone now knows, on Judge John G. Roberts as his Supreme Court nominee.

title: When the Curtain Rises, I'll Still Be in Line
description: To the Editor:

title: Elite U.K. universities are seekingtutorials on selling their brand
Even the City's Cultural Organizations Are Hiring Lobbyists Now
description: While reducing their hours or raising admission fees in recent years, the city's public libraries and cultural institutions have spent millions on lobbying, part of a growing trend in which nonprofit organizations hire professionals to pursue public subsidies.

title: Police release names of suspects in failed bombings
Third Gold Cup for the U.S. Leaves Legs Tired and Achy
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 24 - When midfielder Brad Davis's penalty kick hit the lower right corner of the net Sunday afternoon, his United States teammates rushed his way -- many of them limped, actually -- using what little energy they had to celebrate.

title: Off the Road to Burma
description: On her recent visit to Thailand, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said she was there to show that she cares about Southeast Asia. If so, skipping this week's meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations is a bad way to show it. No American secretary of state has missed the annual Asean meeting in more than two decades.

title: A Multilingual Ad Campaign
description: When Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg kicked off his high-flying campaign, some Democrats were agog that his campaign was so awash in cash it could simultaneously begin its first advertising push in Spanish and English.

title: British Police Name 2 Suspects and Detail Failed Attacks
description: LONDON, July 25 - The British police identified by name today two of four suspected assailants who tried and failed to set off bombs on the London transport network last week and said the bombers had used a Tupperware-like container to build the devices.

title: 4 Are Killed and 6 Hurt in 4 Gun Attacks
description: Four men were killed in four unrelated shootouts across the city during a violent six-hour period beginning late Saturday night and ending yesterday morning, the police said. Six men were injured in the shootings.

title: Mobile services on IHT.com
Paid Notice: Deaths   THOMAS, FRANCIS BRUCE
description: THOMAS--Francis Bruce. 67, of Brielle, NJ, died on Friday, July 22, 2005 in Neptune, NJ. Beloved son of the late Francis and Theresa Thomas. Dear brother of the late Pen Thomas and loving uncle to Kierin and Ryan MacEvoy and Clark Thomas. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated 9:30 AM on Tuesday, July 26, 2005 at St. Margaret's R.C. Church in Spring Lake, NJ. Interment will be private. For information, contact O'Brien Funeral Home in Wall, NJ.

title: Seeing Past the Hate: Kosovo's Factions Imagine a Future
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, July 22 - In the six years since NATO bombers forced Yugoslav troops out of this troubled province, progress toward resolving the entrenched enmity here between Serbs and ethnic Albanians has been slow. The United Nations, which has been administering Kosovo, now wants to broker a deal and step aside.

title: Piazza and the Mets Shed Their Cloak of Mediocrity
description: Before the Mets and Los Angeles played yesterday at Shea Stadium, there was a book on Mets Manager Willie Randolph's desk that had the words "Total Self-Confidence" in the title. After the game, catcher Mike Piazza wore a black T-shirt with the words "Beyond Fear" across the chest.

title: Other Views: The Scotsman, ChristianScience Monitor, South China Morning Post
Attacks worry U.K. tourism industry
Search Warranted?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Celebrating Brumidi
description: The frescoes of Constantino Brumidi, an Italian-born artist whose murals decorate much of the United States Capitol, are being restored for the 200th anniversary of his birth.

title: Indie Rock Embraced
In Search of the New Funny, but Using the Old Maps
description: Sitcoms may not be doomed, but they seem endangered: there are even fewer promising half-hour comedies this fall season than last.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CENSOR, JACQUES
description: CENSOR--Jacques. The Board of Trustees of Yeshiva University and Boards of Directors of its Stern College for Women and Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies mourn the passing of the beloved father of Dr. Monique C. (and Mordecai D.) Katz, vice chairman of the Stern College Board and University Benefactor with her husband (a YU trustee and chairman of the Revel Board), and Walter (and Linda) Censor, and adoring grandfather and great-grandfather. Our sincerest condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, Chancellor Morry J. Weiss, Chairman YU Board of Trustees Marjorie Diener Blenden Chairman, SCW Board of Directors Arthur Hyman, Dean BRGS

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RINGLER, ISIDORE
description: RINGLER--Isidore. The Heschel School community mourns the loss of Isidore "Izzy" Ringler, beloved husband of Miriam, adored father of Rachel Ringler and father-inlaw of Yossi Siegel. Esteemed grandfather of Alana '97, Sam '01 and Talia, a current student. Izzy was devoted to his family and left a legacy of love among the generations that were fortunate enough to share in his life. Rachel continues in her father's model by making her family the focus of her life. Rachel and Yossi are leaders in our school, giving so much of their talent, time and resources. May the entire Ringler-Siegel family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusaleum. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Roanna Shorofsky Head of School

title: 49ers Sign Smith, the No. 1 Pick, and Set the Market
description: Alex Smith, the No. 1 pick in this year's N.F.L. draft, has agreed to a six-year contract with the San Francisco 49ers. Smith will receive $24 million guaranteed and incentives that could make the base $49 million contract worth up to $57 million.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Ex-Premier Denounces 'Smear Campaign'
description: President Vladimir V. Putin's former prime minister, Mikhail M. Kasyanov, left, returned from a vacation in Europe and denounced a criminal investigation into accusations that he improperly acquired a government-owned summer cottage at a steep discount. The accusations, spurred by a member of Parliament from the pro-Putin majority party, surfaced shortly after Mr. Kasyanov began criticizing the Kremlin's policies and hinted at a possible presidential campaign in 2008, when Mr. Putin is required to step down after two terms. Mr. Kasyanov, in a statement, criticized what he called a "systematically launched smear campaign" and vowed to pursue politics. Steven Lee Myers (NYT

title: Where data thieves go shopping
Westmoreland's War
description: To the Editor:

title: Rumsfeld Stop in Kyrgyzstan Aims to Keep Access to Base
description: BISHKEK, Kyrgyzstan, July 25 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld arrived in this Central Asian nation on Monday to shore up an unsettled military basing arrangement that has been critical to operations in Afghanistan.

title: Courtship of Brown Is Complete; Negotiations Have Yet to Begin
description: After seven days of phone conversations and voice messages, living-room chats and dinner-time conclaves, the Knicks put away the expense account, the limousine and the Cablevision-owned helicopter and left the rest to Larry Brown.

title: Critics Call for Boycott of Memorial Fund-Raising
description: In the ever fiercer fight over a year-old plan to build a home for the Drawing Center and the International Freedom Center alongside the World Trade Center memorial, some relatives of 9/11 victims called yesterday for a fund-raising boycott.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SILVER, DR. IRVING
description: SILVER--Dr. Irving. 91, on July 22, 2005. Survived by wife Hilda, son David, brother Lee, and sister Mildred. Services 2Pm Tuesday, July 25, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel.

title: The Short View: What Do Stock Markets Know?
description: The US second quarter earnings season is about two-fifths complete, according to Ed Keon, chief investment strategist of Prudential Securities. So far, the news has been pretty positive, with only 8 per cent of companies reporting negative surprises, as against 40 per cent that beat expectations.

title: Development Rival Offers Compromise on Nets Arena
description: The real estate investment group battling with the developer Bruce Ratner for control of the Atlantic railyard near Downtown Brooklyn offered a compromise yesterday that it said would allow both parties to declare victory: The group would incorporate Mr. Ratner's plan to build a glass-walled basketball arena for the Nets into its project.

title: 'Are We There Yet?' (The Airplane Version)
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks: Mixed earnings push investors to sidelines
PepsiCo Says It Won't Try to Buy French Company
description: PARIS, July 25 - PepsiCo has indicated to French authorities that it is not preparing a bid for Groupe Danone, sending the French food company's shares tumbling and presumably ending a national furor over the possibility of an acquisition.

title: Nicholas D. Kristof and Charles Pritchard
description: Q. I am a veteran of the U.S. military intelligence who specialized for six years in North Korea. Hasn't it been the policy of the U.S. government for many, many years to engage North Korea only with the regional powers: Russia, China, Japan and most importantly South Korea? This isn't an invention of the current administration. The very sensible reason for this stance is that the North Koreans seek direct talks with the United States for only one reason: to enhance their prestige and power at the expense of Japan and South Korea. Opening direct talks would insult our allies and embolden the North Koreans. Do you not agree? A Adrian Stewart, New York

Metro Briefing | New York: Trade Center Campaign Ad Attacked
description: A candidate for public advocate, Andrew Rasiej, yesterday harshly criticized a rival's television ad featuring family members of victims of the World Trade Center attack. The ad, by the campaign of Norman Siegel, is being broadcast this week on NY1. It features relatives of two firefighters killed in the attack discussing their disenchantment with what they call a failure of communications during rescue efforts. In a statement, Mr. Rasiej said he shared many of Mr. Siegel's criticisms of the incumbent, Betsy Gotbaum, but that "it's a shame that Norm had to resort to running such a cheap, exploitative, Bush-league ad to make that point." Mr. Siegel responded by saying that it was both appropriate and necessary to help family members get out their message, which is "that we must learn from the mistakes of the past to ensure they don't happen again." Jonathan P. Hicks (NYT)

title: A deficit disorder

NEWS SUMMARY     U.S. Envoy Presses Iraqis To Finish a Constitution  The new American ambassador to Iraq waded into the debate over its constitution, signaling that the United States would work to guarantee the rights of Iraqi women and to blunt the desires of ethnic and religious factions pushing for broader autonomy in the new Iraqi state. A1    Evaluation of Palestinian Forces  The first independent survey of the Palestinian security environment since the death of Yasir Arafat found that the security forces of the Palestinian Authority were unfit, and said that more attention must be paid to building up institutions. A1    More Details on Egypt Attacks  Egyptian officials said that all three explosions were suicide bombings and suggested that police checkpoints may have forced two of the bombers to set off their explosives early, before reaching targets packed with Western tourists. A3    U.S. and North Korea Hold Talks  Negotiators from the United States and North Korea held a rare, private meeting, underscoring the heightened stakes and grave concerns surrounding the six-nation talks on the North Korean nuclear crisis scheduled to open Thursday. A3    2 Suspects Identified in Britain  The British police identified by name two of four men suspected of trying to set off bombs on the London transport network last week and said the bombers used a Tupperware-like container -- known as Delta 6250 -- to build the devices. A6    Two experienced militants, both veterans of the war in Afghanistan, told an independent Pakistani journalist that they had met one of the July 7 London bombing suspects, Shehzad Tanweer, on a trip to a known militant training camp north of the capital, Islamabad. A6    Arroyo Seeks Change in System  President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of the Philippines, facing demands for her resignation, called for the adoption of a parliamentary form of government to replace the current system. A9    Pope's Prayer Omits Israel  Israel and the Vatican traded sharp words over a Sunday sermon in which the new pope, Benedict XVI, prayed that God would stop the ''murderous hand'' of terrorists who had struck in ''Egypt, Turkey, Iraq, Great Britain.'' A9    ARTS E1-10    Floating Museum Reopens  The Waterfront Museum and Showboat Barge in Brooklyn, closed for the last two years for repairs to its hull, has reopened at a newly refurbished pier a few hundred feet from its longtime home. E1    Philharmonic Denies Bias  The New York Philharmonic angrily denied charges by a male violinist that a bias in favor of women caused his ouster from the orchestra. Unspecified behavior problems were the reason, a spokesman said. E3    NATIONAL A10-15    Administration to Release Some Nominee Records  The Bush administration plans to release documents from Judge John G. Roberts's tenure in the White House counsel's office and his earlier job working for the attorney general, but will not make public papers covering the four years he spent as principal deputy solicitor general. A1    Veto on Morning-After Pill  Confronting one of the most controversial issues to cross his desk, Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts vetoed a bill that would expand access to the morning-after pill, saying he believed it sometimes functioned as ''an abortion pill,'' not just a contraceptive pill. A10    U.S. Soldier Admits Guilt  A soldier accused of shooting an Iraqi police officer to death and then shooting himself to support a claim of self-defense pleaded guilty on the day his court-martial was to begin, and now faces a prison term. A10    Democrats Question Security  In the wake of terrorist attacks abroad, a procession of potential Democratic presidential candidates raised sharp questions about the Republican leadership's handling of national security. A11    Shuttle Liftoff Hangs on Sensor  Counting down to a planned liftoff, NASA officials said that two familiar obstacles remained in the way of the first space shuttle mission in two and a half years: a persistent fuel sensor problem and the fast-changing Florida weather. A14    NEW YORK/REGION B1-6         Bag Inspection Expanded For Suburban Commuters  Hundreds of suburban commuters, from central New Jersey to Rockland County, N.Y., were asked for the first time to submit their bags for inspection by the police, as two major transit carriers in the region joined New York City authorities trying to buffer their train, subway and bus systems against a terror attack. B1    A Close Call Recalled  The captain of a DC-8 cargo jet that nearly missed hitting a Boeing 767 that had blundered onto a runway at Kennedy Airport gave his first public account of the dramatic seconds when the two planes nearly collided. B1    Rich Democrats Back Mayor  Prominent Democratic donors are sending chills through local party leaders by publicly supporting the Republican mayor, Michael R. Bloomberg, this campaign year. A1    SCIENCE TIMES F1-8    Health & Fitness F5    SPORTSTUESDAY D1-8    OBITUARIES C16         Sir W. Richard S. Doll  A British epidemiologist whose pioneering studies linked smoking to lung cancer, he was 92. C16    BUSINESS DAY C1-15         Sony Settles Radio Case  Sony BMG agreed to a settlement with New York attorney general Eliot Spitzer in a case that accused the company of paying radio programmers and disc jockeys to play its music. The investigation is continuing at other record companies. A1    Executives Face Actions  RenaissanceRe Holdings Ltd., a reinsurer that recently restated three years of earnings, disclosed that its chief executive might face a civil complaint and enforcement proceedings have been recommended against a former vice president. C1    Business Digest C2    EDITORIAL A16-17    Editorials: Terrorism and the random search; truth telling on Zimbabwe; it depends on what ''member'' means; a few degrees.    Columns: John Tierney, Nicholas D. Kristof.    Crossword E6  TV Listings E9  Weather B7

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, EDWARD HARTLEY
description: BENENSON--Edward Hartley. Born March 27, 1914, in NYC. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Thomas, James and Deb, Amy and Clifford Aronson, Lisa and Joseph Quattrocchi, and Andrew Benenson and Ronnie and George Igel. Adored grandfather of 14 grandchildren and great grandfather of five great grandchildren. A great lover of food and wine, art and travel, the Yankees and the Civil War. Chairman of Benenson Funding Corporation. Edward H. Benenson graduated from Duke University in 1934 and has been involved with the University and Medical Center ever since. He was Trustee Emeritus and former Chairman of Friends of Duke University Museum of Art. He established the Edward H. Benenson Awards in the Arts at Duke and founded the Edward H. Benenson Merit Scholarship Fund for Duke University Medical Center (DUMC). He received the 2000 Honorary Medical Alumnus Award from DUMC and the 2002 Distinguished Alumnus Award from the University. He was co-founder and Honorary Trustee of the Culinary Institute of America where he was the generous donor of the Edward H. Benenson Scholarship Fund. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Grand Camerlingue Honoraire of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, Bailli Delegue Honoraire des Etats Unis of the Chine des Rotisseurs and member of the American Societies of the Italian Legions of Merit and of French Order of Merit. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Monday from 6-8. Funeral services on Tuesday at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Duke University Medical Center, c/o Ruth Irvin, DUMC, 512 South Mangum Street, Suite 400, Durham, NC 27701-3973. He had a heart of gold and will be greatly missed by all those whose lives he touched with his kindness, generosity and love.

title: Meanwhile: Confessions of a blooper snooper

INSIDE   Counting down to the liftoff of the space shuttle Discovery at 10:39 this morning, Bud Mann of Altoona, Fla., cooled off near Cape Canaveral. NASA says that risk of catastrophic failure is about 1 in 100, more than twice as great as an estimate issued before the loss of the Columbia in 2003. NASA put the chance of acceptable weather at 60 percent.   PAGE A14    2 Suspects Named in London  The British police have identified two of the four men suspected of trying to set off bombs last Thursday in London's transportation system. They also said the men used a type of plastic container for their devices that is sold in a number of stores in Britain.  PAGE A6    A Big Change in Boot Camp  Years ago, drill sergeants accused of abusing recruits might have been only reprimanded or transferred. That is no longer true. Just ask Staff Sgt. Michael G. Rhoades.  PAGE A12    Remaking a Face  After years of heated scientific debate over ethics and technical feasibility, the Cleveland Clinic has become the first medical institution to approve a face transplant. A team led by Dr. Maria Siemionow is seeking a patient to undergo the startling medical procedure.  SCIENCE TIMES, PAGE F1     Details on Bombings in Egypt  Egyptian officials, in the first detailed account of Saturday's terrorist attack at a resort on Egypt's Red Sea coast, said that the three explosions had been set off by suicide bombers and that police checkpoints might have forced two of the bombers to set off their explosives early, before reaching targets packed with Western tourists.  PAGE A3     Record Tower For Chicago  The Spanish architect Santiago Calatrava has designed what would be the country's tallest building, in Chicago. It would be 115 stories, topping out at 1,458 feet, with a spire that would reach about 2,000 feet. The developer, Christopher T. Carley, plans to announce the $500 million project today.  PAGE A13    Creating A Folk Hero  Millions of people have seen the frescoes of Constantino Brumidi, the Italian-born artist whose work decorates the United States Capitol. But most people don't know his name. It's one man's mission to restore luster and honors to Brumidi and, perhaps, make him an American folk hero.  PAGE E1

description: MARGOLIN--Joel A. On July 23 in New York at the age of 71. A respected psychoanalyst. He was loved by family and friends. Joel was a gifted man. One of his greatest gifts was his ability to understand you, those whom he helped to understand themselves, their feelings and the world around them. Through his music and the melodies he wrote, he made the words come alive. Through his poetry, Joel could make us think about who we are: In the hemorrhaged torn out night of a place in a place of light in the dreams of the hallways that cross our sleep is the hemorrhaged torn out night of a place in a place of light in that once complete place called mind by Joel Margolin-June 1972 Service Tuesday, 11:30AM, at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Staten Island: Ferry Service Expanded
description: The city's Department of Transportation said it would add trips to the weekday schedule of the Staten Island ferries, starting on Thursday. On the Staten Island side, a 5:30 a.m. departure from St. George Terminal will be added, and between 7 a.m. and 8 a.m. boats will leave every 15 minutes instead of every 20 minutes. From the Whitehall Terminal in Lower Manhattan, a 1 a.m. departure will be added, with subsequent departures every hour on the half hour from 1:30 a.m. until 5:30 a.m. In addition, the department said that by early 2007 half-hour departures will start at 6 a.m. on Saturdays and 9 a.m. on Sundays, instead of 11 a.m. on both days. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Russia Accused In Bombing
description: In a fresh sign of the strained relations between Georgia and the Kremlin, President Mikheil Saakashvili accused "Russian citizens" of organizing a bombing in Georgia in February. His statements came hours after the Georgian interior minister accused a Russian military intelligence officer of the same crime. Three Georgian policemen were killed in a bombing in Gori on Feb. 1. The Russian military strongly denied a role. Relations between the two nations have soured since the "Rose Revolution" in 2003, in which Mr. Saakashvili displaced President Eduard A. Shevardnadze in a bloodless coup and became an outspoken proponent of revolutions in former Soviet states. His administration has often accused Russia of supporting separatists in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, two breakaway regions. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEWIRTZ, STANLEY
description: GEWIRTZ--Stanley, 87, died on July 23, at his home in Manhattan following an amazingly brave struggle of many months. He is survived by his loving family, including his wife, Margie; daughters, Katherine Leiner and Marie Gewirtz; grandchildren, Dylan Leiner, Julien Gervreau and Makenna Goodman; and sister, Geraldine Friedman. His first wife, Jean, died in 1982. A tennis playing, cigar smoking voracious reader, theatre aficionado, lawyer and aviation executive, he lived for many years in Washington, DC, and Los Angeles, before returning to New York in 1967. At various times in his career, Stanley served as a consultant to the Secretary of Transportation, the FAA Administrator, the Administrator of NASA and as Special Consultant to the U.S. Senate Preparedness Subcommittee of the Armed Forces Committee. He also served as Vice Chairman of President Kennedy's Task Force on National Aviation Goals. He was a lecturer at the Harvard Business School, Northeastern University and the Law School of the University of Utah. In addition to being on the National Executive Board of the AJC and the Administrative Board of the Hebrew Union College, he served as a Director of the Interracial Council for Business Opportunity, a member of the Los Angeles Board of Education's Advisory Board Committee for Equal Education Opportunity and the Los Angeles Reiss-Davis Child Guidance Center. In 1965 President Johnson appointed him to the Board of the Virgin Island Corporation. A 1940 graduate of the Harvard Law School, Stanley served as an officer in the ATC of the Army Air Corps during World War II, and was awarded the Bronze Star. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, July 28, at 4:30PM, at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st and Madison. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to The Stanley Gewirtz Memorial Scholarship Fund at The Deer Hill Foundation, POB 180, Mancos, CO 81328.

title: New DVD's
description: Within a couple of years, the Oxford and Cambridge units would combine to produce "Monty Python's Flying Circus," and the rest of the story now belongs to history -- the history of television, movies and, most recently, Broadway. If the hit show "Monty Python's Spamalot" represents the end point in the evolution of Python comedy, with its most famous routines now frozen into canonical recitations, the two early television shows represent its infancy, the first fearless steps toward what was to become a genuine cultural phenomenon of the late 20th century.

description: People who do not exercise enough may have a new explanation in the weather. A new study finds that people in cool, dry climates spend more time exercising than those who live where it is hot and humid.

title: World Briefing: Africa: Malawi: Leader Bans Maize Exports To Avert Famine
description: Hoping to stave off mass hunger in a nation beset by poverty and drought, Malawi has banned all exports of maize and fertilizer and asked its citizens to give a tenth of their income to a fund to help feed the hungry. President Bingu wa Mutharika, left, took the action after discovering that speculators were buying fertilizer and the grain, southern Africa's staple crop, and reselling them at a profit in neighboring Zambia and Tanzania. "From today, our borders are sealed," he said. "We have to feed ourselves first." At 1.3 million metric tons, Malawi's recent maize harvest is about 900,000 short of the nation's minimum requirements. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: 'Are We There Yet?' (The Airplane Version)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bronx, a Fight for Health and Dignity
description: Gloria Altieri believes in the Bronx, especially in those neighborhoods that many of her contemporaries revisit only in memory, never in person. It is a mere detail that Ms. Altieri, born in Mott Haven 52 years ago and raised in Soundview, sleeps just over the border in Mount Vernon, since she has dedicated her most productive waking hours to the borough as an educator.

title: At Celebration for Armstrong, a Rival Is Included
description: PARIS, July 25 - After securing his seventh consecutive Tour de France victory on a rain-swept ride into Paris, followed by eight fast laps through the city's streets, Lance Armstrong and his team of Discovery Channel riders decided they no longer had to be first.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Man Charged In Shooting
description: Alfredo Perez, 22, of Adams Street in Parkchester, was arrested on Sunday and charged with attempted murder in the shooting of a 19-year-old man at 2700 Grand Concourse a little before 1 a.m. that day. The victim, who was not identified, was shot in the back of the head. He was in critical condition yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital.

title: S.E.C. Considers Civil Action Against Fidelity
description: Fidelity Investments, the giant mutual fund company, said yesterday that federal regulators were considering taking civil action against it as part of an inquiry over whether its employees improperly accepted gifts or entertainment from brokers.

title: Philippine lawmakers discuss Arroyo impeachment rules
Stricter Anti-Terror Laws Advance in Britain
description: LONDON, July 26 - Britain moved closer today to introducing stricter anti-terrorism laws when the three main political parties agreed in principle on new legislation for Parliament to consider in the fall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, CHARLES E.
description: MURPHY--Charles E. Artist, seventy-two, of New York City. Died July 23, 2005, of cancer at The Jacob Perlow Hopice, Beth Israel Hospital. Painted the decades-long series of oils-on-linen, "New York Impressions." His paintings reveal the changing cityscape through his palette of mood-setting color illuminated by crystalline light. His most recent solo exhibition was at The National Arts Club, January-February 2005. He was a graduate of The Yale School of Art and Architecture, and served in the U.S. Army. Beloved brother of Eileen M. Blessington, of Virginia Beach, VA, and Raphael R. Murphy, Jr., of Chappaqua, New York. Also survived by five nieces and nephews, twelve grand nieces and grand nephews, and business partner, and former wife, Jo Anne Murphy. Charles is the son of the late Raphael R. Murphy, a New York City Magistrate, and the late Madeline G. Murphy. Cremation will be followed by burial at Calverton National Cemetery, Riverhead, New York. A Memorial will be announced. Contributions may be made to The Jacob Perlow Hospice, 9 Nathan D. Perlman Place, New York, New York 10211-0122.

title: Checkpoints Are Thought to Have Hastened 2 Egypt Blasts
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, July 25 - Egyptian officials, giving their first detailed account of a deadly terrorist strike at this Red Sea resort, said Monday that all three explosions were suicide bombings and suggested that police checkpoints may have forced two of the bombers to set off their explosives early, before reaching targets packed with Western tourists.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.S.. Soldier Killed
description: An American soldier was killed and three others wounded in fighting with guerrillas in south central Oruzgan Province, the United States military said. An Afghan soldier and 11 militants also died. The insurgent attack, the latest ahead of elections in September, began when American-led forces came under fire from mortars, rocket-propelled grenades and small arms, the military statement said. The American was the second United States soldier to die in two days. The earlier casualty occurred in a clash in southern Helmand Province on Sunday, the military said. Somini Sengupta (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSKAY, JOSEPH A.
description: RUSKAY--Joseph A., on July 24, 2005 in his 95th year in NYC. Beloved husband of 57 years of Margot. Devoted father of David and Deborah. Loving grandfather of Morgan, Meagan & Benjamin. He was a highly successful attorney, specializing in anti-trust law, with a lifetime commitment to and passion for democratic and liberal political causes. He was also a member of the Board of Americans for Democratic Action. In his memory, donations may be made to: JCC, Manhattan, 336 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY 10023. Services will be private.

title: U.S. Officials Retool Slogan for Terror War
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 - The Bush administration is retooling its slogan for the fight against Al Qaeda and other terrorist groups, pushing the idea that the long-term struggle is as much an ideological battle as a military mission, senior administration and military officials said Monday.

title: Shuttle Launching Faces Two Familiar Obstacles
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 25 - Counting down to a liftoff planned for 10:39 on Tuesday morning, NASA officials said Monday that two familiar obstacles remained in the way of the first space shuttle mission in two and a half years: a persistent fuel sensor problem and the fast-changing Florida weather.

title: Are We There Yet?, the Airplane Version (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: When Treating Pain Became a Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: Beijing fears attack from hedge funds
Panel Completes Inquiry on Leader of U.N.'s Oil-for-Food Program
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 25 - The committee studying possible corruption in the Iraq oil-for-food program has completed its investigation into whether the United Nations official who headed the program profited from his position, the panel's spokesman said Monday.

title: New U.S. Envoy Will Press Iraqis on Their Charter
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 25 - The new American ambassador to Iraq waded into the debate over its constitution on Monday, signaling that the United States would work to guarantee the rights of Iraqi women and to blunt the desires of ethnic and religious factions pushing for broader autonomy in the new Iraqi state.

title: The Never-Ending Struggle of a Forgotten Bit of Africa
description: Ms. Wrong, an Africa correspondent and the author of "In the Footsteps of Mr. Kurtz: Living on the Brink of Disaster in Mobutu's Congo," does her utmost to put Eritrea back on the map. The task is daunting. A Pakistani businessman in the Cairo airport, asking her about her work, furrows his brow when he hears the subject. Did she mean Algeria? Nigeria? Or perhaps Al-Jazeera? Finally he throws up his hands. "I'm sorry," he says. "But I've simply never heard of the place."

title: Thrill Ride at Coney
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Face: A Bold Surgeon, an Untried Surgery
description: In an emergency room at a Finnish hospital, a man sprawled unconscious on an operating table as surgeons labored to reattach the hand he had lost hours earlier while chopping wood.

title: Six-party talks open in Beijing
Paid Notice: Deaths   EFFRON, JAMES W.
description: EFFRON--James W., 73, died peacefully after a brief illness on July 21 after a happy and well-lived life. He was the beloved husband of Dawn; adored father of Craig (Caryn), Blair (Cheryl), Drew (Sandra) and Brooke (Ross); and cherished grandfather of eight. He was born and lived proudly his entire life on the same street in Poughkeepsie, NY, and was a true and warm friend to all who knew him. After graduating from Princeton University in 1953, he served his country in the Army. He spent his career with Effron Oil Company, serving as its President for many years. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Vassar Temple, Poughkeepsie. Shiva at the Effron home in Poughkeepsie on Monday and Tuesday. Shiva in New York at 129 East 73rd Street on Wednesday from 6-9 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, to be credited to Dr. Stephen Nimer Leukemia Research.

title: Roundup: Sickly El Guerrouj cedes world title
Glynn Ross, Who Put Seattle on the Map for Opera Lovers, Dies at 90
description: Glynn Ross, the founding general director of Seattle Opera, who established the company's tradition of performing Wagner's "Ring" cycle, died on Thursday in Tucson. He was 90 and lived in Tucson and Seattle.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORGENSTEIN, SARAH SEGAL
description: MORGENSTEIN--Sarah Segal. On July 25, 2005. Loving mother of Paul Morgenstein, Myriam Sarachik, Henry Morgenstein. Devoted grandmother of Joy Lerner, Robin Fischer, Karen Sarachik, Benjamin and Ethan Morgenstein. Beloved great grandmother of Shiri, Ayelet, Lisa, Gabriel, Julia, and Clara. Services Tuesday 10 A.M. at "The Riverside", 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Bad Medicine; Worse TV
description: To the Editor:

title: Sir Richard Doll Dies at 92; Linked Smoking to Illnesses
description: Sir Richard Doll, a British epidemiologist whose pioneering studies lasting more than 50 years linked smoking to lung cancer, emphysema, heart attacks and many other ailments, died on Sunday in John Radcliffe Hospital in Oxford, England. He was 92.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NYE, JOAN HUNTER (MRS. RICHARD S.
description: NYE--Joan Hunter (Mrs. Richard S.) died peacefully at home in Greenwich, CT. July 23, 2005. Born in England March 6, 1914, she is survived by nieces Anne A. Hubbard (Mrs. Thomas J.) of Bronxville, NY and Cornwall, CT. and Gillian Attfield of NYC; nephews Ward Cheney of Lincoln, MA., and Hugh Cheney of Cornwall, CT; and step-children Richard Nye of Mount Holley, VT., Edith Jones of Orchard Park, N.Y. and Carolyn Hawe of Kill-Devil Hills, NC and their families. No service at her request.

title: Pope's Prayer Omits Israel, and Words Fly
description: ROME, July 25 - Israel and the Vatican traded sharp words on Monday over a Sunday sermon in which the new pope, Benedict XVI, prayed that God would stop the "murderous hand" of terrorists who had struck in "Egypt, Turkey, Iraq, Great Britain."

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article in Business Day yesterday about the trial against Merck over its painkiller Vioxx misstated the month in which Robert Ernst, whose family is suing the drug maker, died. It was May 2001, not June.

title: Coach Changes Panama for Better
description: When Jos Hernndez arrived from Colombia to coach Panama's national team, his players refused to practice in the rain. Not a good sign in a country with a tropical climate.

title: Salzburg builds on a shifting Mozart
Group Lynching Is Re-Created in a 'Call for Justice'
description: MONROE, Ga., July 25 - The gunshots were firecrackers. The stage blood came from a white plastic bucket of Open Pit barbecue sauce. The costumes did not evoke 1946.

title: The Philharmonic Denies Bias
description: The New York Philharmonic yesterday angrily denied charges by a male violinist that a bias in favor of women caused his ouster from the orchestra. Unspecified "behavior" problems were the reason, a spokesman said.

title: Disney Selects New Chief of Miramax
description: LOS ANGELES, July 25 - The Walt Disney Company on Monday chose Daniel Battsek, who has overseen the company's film distribution in Britain, to run Miramax Films after the departure of its co-chairmen, Harvey and Bob Weinstein.

title: World Business Briefing Americas: Mexico: Discount Airline on the Way
description: Carlos Slim Helu, Latin America's richest man, and Grupo Televisa, the Spanish-language media company, are investing in a low-cost airline -- named Vuela -- to begin next year, Televisa said. Mr. Slim, who has interests in a number of businesses, will participate through an investment fund run by a bank he controls, Banco Inbursa. Elisabeth Malkin (NYT)

title: 'Are We There Yet?' (The Airplane Version)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ambassador With Portfolio
description: Washington - LAST week's announcement that Prince Turki al-Faisal, former chief of Saudi intelligence and the current Saudi ambassador in London, will replace the long-serving Prince Bandar bin Sultan as ambassador in Washington provides the United States with an opening to restore its strategic partnership with Riyadh.

title: World Business Briefing Europe: Ireland: Eircom Buys Mobile Group
description: The Eircom Group, a fixed-line telecommunications company, completed its anticipated purchase of the cellphone group Meteor Communications for 420 million euros ($507 million), fully underwritten by a rights issue. Meteor, the third-largest mobile company in Ireland, is being sold by its United States parent, the Western Wireless Corporation. Analysts said the Meteor acquisition, though costly, removes concerns over additional sources of revenue and growth as Eircom faces competition in voice services. Revenue for quarter was virtually flat at 399 million euros ($481 million).

title: South Korea begins sending 500,000 tons of rice to North
Magic Pill for Dieting? Wait for It on the Treadmill
description: Summer has long been a time of renewed efforts to lose excess pounds that are hard to hide under skimpy hot-weather clothing. And to be sure, some people (rarely those significantly overweight) manage to shed 5 or even 10 pounds before the Fourth of July.

title: Vodafone reaffirms '05 forecast
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Fake Doctor Charged In Murder
description: A New Jersey man who posed as a doctor has been indicted for second-degree murder in the death of a woman who prosecutors say died after receiving treatment from him, the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. Dean Faiello, at left, was not licensed to practice medicine, but administered laser treatments to Maria Cruz, a bank employee, out of a West 16th Street apartment that belonged to a friend, prosecutors said. Mr. Faiello, 44, appeared in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday, holding a Harry Potter book in his handcuffed hands, while the prosecutor in charge of his case, Ann Prunty, filed notice with the court that a grand jury had indicted him. Investigators found Ms. Cruz's decomposed body buried in concrete in the floor of a house in Newark where Mr. Faiello was living at the time of her disappearance. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Bronx Lawyer Is a Power Behind Several Thrones
description: There he was, advising the Rev. Al Sharpton during last year's presidential primaries. This spring, he joined the legal team promoting the Jets' proposed West Side stadium. Now he is navigating government bureaucracy for the Yankees and also counseling Fernando Ferrer about mayoral campaign arcana.

title: Patient Keeps Doctors Guessing as He Treats Himself
description: The big man was slumped over his breakfast tray, face cradled in a bran muffin, silent and blue.

title: Some Documents of Supreme Court Choice Will Be Released
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 - The Bush administration plans to release documents from Judge John G. Roberts's tenure in the White House counsel's office in the mid-1980's and his earlier job working for the attorney general, but will not make public papers covering the four years he spent as principal deputy solicitor general starting in 1989, two senior administration officials said Monday.

title: Profit at Netflix Rises 97%
description: Netflix, the mail-order movie-rental service, said its second-quarter profit rose 97 percent, more than analysts expected, as it signed up new customers.

title: Richard Doll, 92; linked lung cancer with smoking
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Slashed On 42nd Street
description: A man was slashed repeatedly in the face, shoulder and abdomen with a box cutter on Sunday night in front of 324 West 42nd Street, the police said. The attack occurred about 10:30 p.m., and the man was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where he was listed in serious but stable condition. An investigation continued yesterday.

title: Main Street in the Cross Hairs
description: Along a crowded stretch of highway just south of Miami's downtown is a shopping area that might be called the data theft capital of the United States. In the wireless hacker equivalent of a drive-by shooting wave, criminals obtained the cardholder information of tens of thousands of customers at four major stores there, including a DSW Shoes retail outlet that appears to have been the initial source of a chainwide data breach.

title: I Can't Believe It's Not a TV Ad!
description: AN unconventional campaign for a nonbutter spread is unusual for the way the ads will be served up.

title: Questions of Planetary Design
description: To the Editor:

title: French Premier, in London as 'Friend,' Works on Sour Relationship
description: LONDON, July 25 - Ten years ago today, a terrorist bomb exploded in a crowded commuter train near Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris during the afternoon rush hour, killing eight people and wounding 200 others.

title: Massachusetts Veto Seeks to Curb Morning-After Pill
description: BOSTON, July 25 - Confronting one of the most controversial issues to cross his desk, Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts vetoed a bill on Monday that would expand access to the morning-after pill. The governor said he believed that the pill sometimes functioned as "an abortion pill," not just contraception.

title: The Mets Are Running Other Teams Ragged
description: DENVER, July 25 - When the Mets look at Manager Willie Randolph, as lean as many of the organization's top prospects at age 51, they sometimes wonder whether he could still steal a base or two.

title: Space shuttle Discovery passes first test
Corrections
description: A review on Wednesday about the Bolshoi Ballet's performance of "Don Quixote" at the Metropolitan Opera House misspelled the surname of a dancer, based on the cast listing in the program. She is Maria Allash, not Allah.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENLY, WILLIAM S. III.
description: KENLY--William S. III. Died suddenly on July 21. Former publicist and film historian with Paramount Pictures. Companion to Richard Buban for many years. He will be missed by many.

title: Dutch court sentences Van Gogh killer to life
Questions of Planetary Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FAYMAN, EDYTHE
description: FAYMAN--Edythe. Died peacefully, July 24, 2005. She was 87. Beloved wife of the late Leo, devoted mother of Stanley (Dianne), Elaine (Martin), cherished grandmother of Noah, Shayna (Brett). Past President of Sisterhood of Golden Lakes Temple and honored volunteer at the Jewish Community Center. Funeral service at 1:45 PM, Tuesday, July 26th, at Menorah Gardens, West Palm Beach, FL.

title: Soccer: Real Madrid is upset, 3-0, by Tokyo Verdy
Paid Notice: Deaths   DWORETZ, MILDRED
description: DWORETZ--Mildred, at home, on July 24, at 92 years of age. Profoundly loved wife of the late Philip L. Dworetz. Beloved mother of Susan and Peter Ralston, Linda and Dan Baron, and Steven Dworetz and Susan Taylor. She was the adored "Nanny" of her grandchildren, Bob and Merritt Rollins, Laura Marlin, Carrie Baron, Debra Baron, Charles Dworetz, and Rawley Dworetz, and of her greatgrandchildren, Alex and Lucy Rollins, Julia and Sarah Marlin, and Sierra Lieb. To our bereft family and to her many friends she was a constant source of love, encouragement, sympathy, and understanding. She was a woman of valor, intelligence, and wisdom, with a wideranging and lively interest in many subjects. Her generosity was boundless. We will remember her warmth and kindness forever. Funeral services 11:45 AM Tuesday, July 26, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, West 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: New disease is not SARS, China says
Metro Briefing | New York: Albany: Pataki Signs School Finance Bills
description: Two bills intended to increase financial accountability in school districts have been signed by Gov. George E. Pataki, his office announced yesterday. The first bill requires school board members to receive financial oversight training and school boards to create committees to work with financial auditors. The second requires each district in the state to be audited by the state comptroller at least once by 2010; the comptroller is to report the results to the governor and the Legislature.

title: Chinese checkers for Wall Street
For These Bonds, Security Requires Some Volatility
description: HOPE springs eternal for investors in convertible securities.

title: N. Korea and U.S. talk ahead of meeting
British police name2 bombing suspects
Police in Indian city crack down on 'Osama' video clips
The 411 on the 511 Navigation System
description: WHENEVER Robert Schaller wonders about traffic conditions ahead, he punches 511 on his cellphone. A free, voice-activated system answers, offering the latest information on "even the most obscure highway I plan to drive on," said Mr. Schaller, a program specialist for the Defensive Driving Program of the Arizona Supreme Court.

title: Home Sales Still Rising to Records
description: The nation's roaring housing market set its second record in three months as sales of existing homes climbed 2.7 percent in June, to 7.33 million, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COPPEDGE, HENRY A.
description: COPPEDGE--Henry A. on July 15, 2005. Survived by brother Arthur Coppedge (artist), sister Margot of Kentucky, nephew Daymond John founder of the F.U.B.U. Collection, and niece Courtney. He was a guidance counselor for the School of Global Studies and also John Jay High School. He was respected and admired by colleagues and students for his gracious, giving and professional manner. For information call the L.H. Woodward Funeral Home, 718-493-8120.

title: Rival views divide top leadership in Ukraine
Metro Briefing | New York: Hempstead: School Budget Approved
description: Under orders from the state to get its affairs in order, the board of the troubled Hempstead school district unanimously approved a $120 million contingency budget yesterday, board officials said. The amount was $8 million less than that twice rejected by voters. The district's superintendent, Nathaniel Clay, did not respond to messages seeking details of the impact on staffing, class size and programs. Critics have called for a state takeover of the district, which has test scores that are among Long Island's lowest, dropout rates that are among its highest, and board infighting that has turned the superintendent's office into a revolving door. The state's commissioner of education, Richard P. Mills, summoned the board to Albany this month and directed it to take several steps needed to start the new semester in September, including passing a district budget. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: All Ears for Tom Cruise, All Eyes on Brad Pitt
description: Some of us in the news media have been hounding President Bush for his shameful passivity in the face of genocide in Darfur.

title: De Beers sparkles on gem prices and demand
F.D.A. Hoping For Indictment Over Fake Pills
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | South Pacific: New Zealand: Elections Set
description: Prime Minister Helen Clark announced that parliamentary elections would be held on Sept. 17. Ms. Clark, leader of the Labor Party, will be seeking her third three-year term, with her strongest challenge expected to come from the conservative National Party, headed by Don Brash, a former banker. The country's relations with the United States, strained since New Zealand banned nuclear-powered ships from its ports in the 1980's, is expected to be an issue in the campaign. The ban is popular with most New Zealanders, but there is also a strong desire for a free trade agreement with the United States, which is unlikely as long as the ban remains. Mr. Brash has said he would review the ban, which Ms. Clark supports. Mr. Brash has also said that he would have been inclined to send troops to Iraq; Ms. Clark has denounced the war there. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: NASA Puts Shuttle Mission's Risk at 1 in 100
description: With a new realism born of disaster, NASA says that the risk of catastrophic failure during the space shuttle Discovery's mission is about 1 in 100, more than twice as great as an upbeat estimate issued before the loss of the Columbia in 2003.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Annan To Visit To Inspect Slum Campaign
description: Secretary General Kofi Annan said he had accepted an invitation from President Robert G. Mugabe to visit Zimbabwe, but had not set a date. Mr. Annan said he would first push for local and international help for the estimated 700,000 victims of the government's demolition of shantytowns that a United Nations report called a "disastrous venture" carried out "with indifference to human suffering." In a telephone conversation with Mr. Mugabe after the report was issued Friday, Mr. Annan said, "I stressed the need for action to be taken to help the people affected, to stop the clearances, and to ensure that those affected are not only looked after, but they are given adequate housing." Warren Hoge (NYT)

description: SHURMAN--Jack. On July 25, 2005. Beloved husband of the late Helen R. Shurman, loving father of Paul, his wife, Bari, Bill, his wife, Jenn, and the late Andy Shurman. Fond son-in-law of Ida Fishman, and brother of the late Lenore. Cherished grandfather of Jared, Jake, and Julia. Funeral service Wednesday 11:30 A.M. at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street.

Paid Notice: Deaths   KAMIS, FREDERICK WOLFE
description: KAMIS--Frederick Wolfe. On July 23, at age 62, in Boca Raton, FL. Beloved son of Evelyn and Matthew Rosenfield of Delray Beach, FL, and the late Bernard Kamis; devoted brother of Richard, Aaron and the late Arthur Kamis; loving father of Daniella and Gordon Brown, Josh and Nikki Kamis, Shoshana and Kenny Dichter; proudest Pop-Pop to Ian, Alexandra, Elyssa, Jordyn, Chloe and Harley. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Funeral services will be held Tuesday July 26, at 11:30 AM, at East Brunswick Jewish Center and interment to follow at Beth Abraham Cemetery, East Brunswick, NJ.

title: South Korea's ambassador to U.S. resigns
Truth Telling on Zimbabwe
description: Anna Tibaijuka, the highest-ranking African woman at the United Nations, is not one of the boys. Maybe that's why she did not mince her words about the horrors going on in Zimbabwe that Africa's male political establishment seems so afraid to talk about. Late last month, Secretary General Kofi Annan sent Mrs. Tibaijuka, a Tanzanian economist who is executive director of the U.N. agency that looks out for the interests of slum dwellers, to investigate the mass destruction of slums and shantytowns by Robert Mugabe's dictatorial regime.

title: Derrick Z. Jackson: What about Niger now?
Paid Notice: Deaths   HONACKI, RJ ''CANDY MAN''
description: HONACKI--RJ "Candy Man", 77, on July 23, 2005. Services July 27, 5-7PM, Forest Lawn in Davie, FL. 954-792-9360.

Blood Sugar Problems Found After Weight-Loss Operation
description: It seemed like a coincidence at first. The patient, suffering from mysterious attacks of low blood sugar so severe that she sometimes passed out, also happened to have had weight-loss surgery a few years before. But her doctors doubted that the surgery had anything to do with her blood sugar problem.

title: People: Roman Polanski, Bruce Lee, Huey Lewis
More Travelers Face Searches on Way to City
description: Hundreds of suburban commuters, from central New Jersey to Rockland County, N.Y., were asked for the first time yesterday to submit their bags for inspection by the police, as two major transit carriers in the region joined New York City authorities trying to buffer their train, subway and bus systems against a terror attack.

title: Stages in the Global Branding of the Tour de Lance Are About to Begin
description: Lance Armstrong is the ultimate athletic brand: an extraordinary winner, a cancer survivor who rebuilt his body into an endurance machine, an effective corporate spokesman and an outspoken advocate.

title: In Our Pages: 100, 75, & 50 years ago
World Briefing | South Pacific: Australia: Muslims Urged To Preach Against Terror
description: A national Islamic organization said it would ask Muslim clerics in Australia to preach moderation and speak out against terrorism and violence. "We are going to be asking community leaders and imams to address these issues in their sermons, to get the people to be united and to ensure there is no terrorism in Australia," said Amjad Mehboob, the leader of the group, the Australian Federal of Islamic Councils. Reports noted that the organization's announcement came against the backdrop of vitriolic attacks on Muslims on right-wing radio programs, with some callers demanding that mosques be closed and Muslims deported. Raymond Bonner (NYT)

title: White House Makes Deals for Support of Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 - With promises of more trade protection for textile companies, President Bush coaxed as many as six Republican lawmakers on Monday to vote for the Central American Free Trade Agreement.

title: G.O.P. Rival in Mayor's Race Says Petition Is in Jeopardy
description: Thomas V. Ognibene, the man seeking to compete against Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg in a Republican primary this summer, said that hundreds of his nominating petitions would be unlikely to survive the legal challenge the mayor's campaign filed last night.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about the resignation of John S. Carroll as editor of The Los Angeles Times incorrectly described the way the newspaper covered the opening of the Staples convention center in October 1999. The Staples center coverage (which helped cause a morale problem at the paper just before Mr. Carroll took over) was a special magazine section, not a single article.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the revaluation of China's currency and its effect on the country's trade surplus with the United States misstated the surname of an analyst at the consulting firm A.T. Kearney, who commented on the change. She is Sue Field, not Kearney.

title: A Workout for New Music by a Group With No Holds Barred
description: Alarm Will Sound has, in only a few years, become one of this country's liveliest new-music ensembles. One thing it has going for it is that its virtuosic players, most not long out of college, are both knowledgeable and fond of certain corners of pop music.
