New York and New Jersey
description: NEW YORK

title: Italian Muslims say new terror measures fall short
The Books of Summer
description: Wellfleet, Mass. - SUMMER is what we look forward to, it is the far away goalpost when we're slogging through winter, the antidote to ice and snow. It's the season of freedom, hydrangeas, drive-in movies, baseball. Just as there are songs that forever remind you of a certain summer in your life, there are books that claim a particular summer: the summer when everyone read "The Mists of Avalon"; the Harry Potter summers; the summer you tackled Dickens.

title: Man Who Killed Dutch Filmmaker Gets Life Sentence
description: AMSTERDAM, July 26 - A Dutch court ruled today that the cold-blooded slaying of a controversial filmmaker and critic of Islam was a terrorist attack designed to frighten politicians and the public, sentencing the Muslim man who carried it out to life in prison without any possibility of parole.

title: South Africa Puts the Unemployed to Work, Restoring Land and Water
description: CAPE TOWN - On a red-dirt road in the Baviaanskloof Nature Reserve in South Africa, Mike Powell suddenly hit the brakes and jabbed a finger in the direction of an innocuous-looking clump of pink flowers. "That is an alien," he said. "All these aliens are going ballistic."

title: Briefly: White House to guard documents on nominee
Commerzbank linked to Russia money-laundering inquiry
A Different Beat: Toyota Raises Prices While Detroit Cuts Deeply
description: Correction Appended

title: Rich Democrats AreLining Up With Mayor
description: Only a select few gave more money to the Democratic Party during the last presidential campaign than Patricia Duff, millionaire and generous donor -- nearly $100,000 all told, according to campaign finance records.

title: Looking Back on the Days of Daring Rock Rebellion
description: CHICAGO, July 25 - Lollapalooza is the trademark that refuses to retire. It made its latest comeback here in Grant Park on Saturday and Sunday: not a tour like previous Lollapaloozas, but a huge one-timeevent. The festival, which started in 1991, is no longer groundbreaking, and it has a lot of competitors for its old cachet. But with 20 hours of music from 50 bands over two days, there was plenty to hear: a few brilliantly idiosyncratic younger bands, a lot of retro rock, jam bands and some nostalgia for an era when alternative was alternative.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Takeover Of Housing Authority Urged
description: Douglas R. Forrester, the Republican candidate for governor, urged a federal takeover of the beleaguered Newark Housing Authority yesterday, saying the agency had spent millions of dollars on the Newark hockey arena while leaving public housing residents to live in substandard conditions. Last week, a report from the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development called the authority troubled and said it should return $6.4 million in what HUD claims are misspent funds. Some of that money was spent buying land near the arena site. John Holl (NYT)

title: A Few Degrees
description: By any measure, this has already been a summer of extremes. The brutality of the record-setting heat that lay over the desert Southwest for the past two weeks may have broken at last, but it has not really dissipated. It has merely slid further east and north, where it is torturing the country's midsection. Life is barely tolerable in Phoenix during an ordinary summer, when the monsoons arrive on schedule. But when the temperature passes 110 degrees day after day, as it did recently, with barely any respite at night, the city nears the very edge of human habitability. At 117 degrees, Las Vegas becomes a mirage, an implausible experiment in desert living. Now it is Chicago's turn to swelter.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about local opposition to proposals for dozens of wind farms in upstate New York referred incorrectly in some copies to the community where two such farms, with a total of 90 wind turbines, are planned. It is Prattsburgh, a town 60 miles south of Rochester, not Plattsburgh, the city 160 miles north of Albany.

title: 80 Years Ago, They Inherited the Wind
description: William Jennings Bryan died 80 years ago today as he napped in a Tennessee hotel room, just before he was finally to deliver his closing argument in the Scopes case. The trial had actually ended a few days before, after the judge abruptly cut short the testimony, but Bryan, after subjecting himself to a withering interrogation by Clarence Darrow, the nation's leading defense lawyer, was intent on getting the last word.

title: Chronicling the detritus of consumerism
No PepsiCo bid, regulator says
Paid Notice: Deaths   FINK, JEAN C.
description: FINK--Jean C. A longtime Scarsdale resident and tireless advocate for court reform and juvenile justice died on July 14, 2005 at age 88. Mrs. Fink was the daughter of Jacques Coe & Clara Bartels Coe. She was predeceased by her husband, attorney Marvin S. Fink and is survived by two daughters, Nancy Ceccorulli of Arnold, MD and Lisa Fink of Brunswick, ME and four grandchildren. A celebration of Jean Fink's life will be held on Sunday, July 31 at noon at the Center for Jewish Life at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale.

ESPN Signs Michaels for 'Monday Night Football'
description: ESPN has reached an eight-year agreement with Al Michaels to call "Monday Night Football" when the rights shift from ABC Sports after the coming season.

title: British managers' steady nerves
Terrorism and the Random Search
description: London's bombings continue to echo throughout the urban world. In New York City, commuters have been facing random searches of backpacks, duffel bags and briefcases by police officers who are trying to thwart a potential terrorist attack. The extra precautions, originally planned to continue for a few weeks, have already drawn complaints from some civil libertarians.

title: Egypt, London, Spain, New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's That Strange Monkey in the Mirror?
description: Humans, the great apes and, probably, dolphins share an intellectual skill unusual in the animal world: they recognize their own reflections in a mirror.

title: Braves and Nationals Find Their Own Levels
description: ATLANTA, July 25 - For seven weeks, the Nationals were the big night out in Washington because they were in first place in the National League East. A city that was without a baseball team for more than 30 years not only had a team, it also had a contender that had fans flocking to the ballpark.

title: The manga version of hip-hop
Kinsley Plans to Change Jobs at The Los Angeles Times
description: Michael Kinsley, the provocative editorial and opinion-page editor of The Los Angeles Times, said yesterday that he would be changing jobs in the next few months and most likely would no longer be running the department. He will not necessarily leave the editorial page, he said, but his new role is still being worked out.

title: A Dark Night and Then, 'Is That an Aircraft in Front of Us?'
description: WASHINGTON, July 25 - With his plane hurtling down a Kennedy International Airport runway at nearly 100 miles per hour, the first officer of a DC-8 cargo jet looked ahead through the darkness and driving rain and asked the captain sitting at his left, "Is that an aircraft in front of us?"

title: A Return to Its Maritime Roots
description: Usually, when a New York museum has to close for renovations, the doors never really close. The Museum of Modern Art bought a temporary home in Queens during its recent rebuilding. The New Museum of Contemporary Art, currently between locations, is bunking with another museum in Chelsea during the move.

title: Radio Payoffs Are Described as Sony Settles
description: Correction Appended

title: A Family Clothing Dynasty Will Go On Without the Family
description: When Robert Gray retired in 2002 from St. John Knits, the clothing company based in Irvine, Calif., that is the largest luxury supplier to Neiman Marcus, it was as if a single thread had been pulled from a family dynasty built over 40 years.

title: Key Rates
Ranger Fans Forgive, Forget and Rejoice
description: The Rangers began giving away 2,000 tickets at noon yesterday. Two hours later, the line ran out the door of the Madison Square Garden box office, trickled down the steps, took a hard left onto the sidewalk along Seventh Avenue and did not dry up until 33rd Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SEH, EDWARD
description: SEH--Edward. Central Synagogue records with profound sorrow the passing of its long time member Edward Seh. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Peter J. Rubinstein, Rabbi Alfred D. Youngwood, Pres

WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
Electrical Accident Kills 4 Boy Scout Leaders in Virginia
description: Four volunteer Boy Scout leaders from Alaska were accidentally electrocuted yesterday afternoon as they set up camp on the first day of the scouts' national jamboree at Fort A.P. Hill, Va., the organization said.

title: Death toll in China's mystery illness rises to 19
Paid Notice: Deaths   HERTZBERG, SIDNEY SONNY
description: HERTZBERG--Sidney Sonny. Beloved husband of Irene. Loving father of Lois & Bob and Howard & Leslie. Grandfather of Alyse & David, Lindsey & Jerry, Dana & Nikki. Former NY Knick and Boston Celtic. Services "BoulevardRiverside," 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, LI, 11:30 Tuesday.

title: What a Dancer Can Do With Four Elbows
description: BECKET, Mass., July 23 - The grandson of an evangelical pastor, Jaime Camarena prides himself on making irreligious dances of diverse origin. They are indeed irreligious and diverse, but not so very original.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. gains indefinite continued use of air base in Kyrgyzstan

World Briefing | Europe: Italy: 6 More With C.I.A. Sought In Kidnapping
description: An Italian appeals court ordered the arrest of 6 more officers and operatives for the Central Intelligence Agency, adding to the 13 wanted since June in Italy for the kidnapping of a radical Egyptian cleric from the northern city of Milan in 2003. Italian prosecutors had originally asked for the arrest of all 19, but a lower court ruled then that only those with a connection to the cleric's actual kidnapping could be arrested. The appeals court held that the other six -- suspected of reconnaissance work on the cleric and the city before the kidnapping -- could also face charges. The kidnapping has worsened already strained relations between the United States and Italy, where most people are opposed to the war in Iraq and the presence of Italian troops there. Court documents say the six, like the others, do not appear to be in Italy now. Ian Fisher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LA VINE, MIRIAM
description: La VINE--Miriam. Wife of the late Dr. William La Vine, mother of Susan (Joel) Brosse, Roni La Vine and Linda (Alan) Brown. Sister of Norma Tancer and Nana Rowe. Grandmother of Michael, Alisha, Alex and Sasha. Great grandmother of Zachary and Jacob. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM at "Gutterman-Musicant", 402 Park St., Hackensack, NJ.

title: Frequent Fliers' Favorites
description: FREQUENT FLIERS' FAVORITES Business travelers overwhelmingly prefer using the major legacy carriers, but Southwest Airlines, the low-cost carrier, nevertheless ranks No. 3 on the list of Top 5 airlines, after Delta and American but before United And Northwest. That's according to the 2005 National Business Travel Monitor by YPB&R/Yankelovitch Partners. Top criteria for ranking an airline: on-time departure record (cited by 92 percent), in-flight service (91 percent), legroom (88 percent) and frequency of upgrades (72 percent).

title: It Depends on What 'Member' Means
description: When news organizations reported last week that Judge John Roberts, the Supreme Court nominee, was a member of the Federalist Society, a conservative legal group, the White House forcefully denied it. But it now appears that if he was not a member, he had a status that looked very much like a member's. This apparent contradiction raises questions about how forthcoming Mr. Roberts and the White House have been. But it is also a reminder of a major concern about this nomination: a few Washington insiders seem to know a lot more about him than the Senate or the American people.

title: In Chicago, Plans for a High-Rise Raise Interest and Post-9/11 Security Concerns
description: CHICAGO, July 25 - In a city known for its skyscrapers, in an era when tall buildings have become targets, can the skyline handle one more that stretches the limit? In Chicago, it seems, the answer may be yes -- if the architect is a "starchitect" like Santiago Calatrava.

title: Nine Lives, but No Sweet Tooth
description: When Eros Got All Shook Up

title: After Love and Frivolity, a Penance of War Songs
description: HOLMDEL, N.J., July 24 - Lots of people know someone whose life has been transformed by the military: made bigger, stronger, more purposeful. Well, something similar happens at a concert by Toby Keith, the multimillion-selling country star.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Sometimes you have to get in their faces, but it's not about making them cry."

title: Lies Lose Value When Pride Goes Into Hock
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn. - If it's true that a pawnshop is a poor man's bank, then it is also an Everyman's confessional.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LINDENBERG, MAY (NEE SHULMAN)
description: LINDENBERG -- May (nee Shulman). Loving wife of the late Michael. Adored mother of Karen Baye (Sumner). Sister Sylvia Levine (Harvey). Nephews Marty (dec.) Jamie (Angie), Matthew, grandnephew Cody. An incredible woman who made everyone feel special and unique. We shall never forget her. Graveside services Tuesday, July 26, 2 pm, at the Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Family at home after services and on Wednesday after 5.

title: Blackstone takeover fund is the largest ever
Two Militants Place Suspect at a Camp in Pakistan
description: LAHORE, Pakistan, July 25 - Two experienced militants, both veterans of the war in Afghanistan, told an independent Pakistani journalist here last week that they had met one of the July 7 London bombing suspects, Shehzad Tanweer, on a trip to a known militant training camp north of the capital, Islamabad.

title: Egypt, London, Spain, New York ... (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For Yankees at Deadline, It's Shop Till You Drop
description: The Yankees flew home from Anaheim, Calif., on Sunday into an uncertain future. There was one week to go until the nonwaiver trading deadline, and the Yankees were not leading for a playoff spot.

title: Deadly Heat Wave Sends Temperatures Above 100
description: Clusters of states across the nation were enduring another stifling day in a deadly heat wave that broke record highs in some cities and had temperatures soaring above 100 degrees in others.

title: Raptors' Fidelity Is Proved Without Ruffling Any Feathers
description: These days, it seems, even the moral values of birds are subject to scrutiny.

title: A Lab Builds Better Barriers Against Invading Parasites
description: Dr. James H. McKerrow hails from a long line of activists. His father was a social worker and an advocate for abused children. His mother was a nurse. An ancestor was a prominent abolitionist who helped slaves make their way to freedom in Canada.

title: As Recruiting Suffers, Military Reins In Abuses at Boot Camp
description: FORT KNOX, Ky. - Staff Sgt. Michael G. Rhoades, until recently a driller of Army recruits at Fort Knox, says he was only doing his job, hammering civilians into soldiers who would not crack under the pressures of war.

title: Mets Stumble Over the League's Doormat
description: DENVER, July 25 - The Colorado Rockies have had 16 rookies this season, the most in the major leagues, and featured starters on Monday's lineup card such as Danny Ardoin, Garrett Atkins and Anderson Machado.

Japanese carmakers take high road to profit
Corrections
description: An article on July 12 about a lawsuit filed by Donald J. Trump against his Asian partners over the sale of property on the Upper West Side referred incorrectly to the clients of the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm that was one of the buyers. Although it buys property on behalf of Middle Eastern investors, it says none of them are members of the Saudi royal family.

title: Briefs: Truck orders slide at Volvo
7 World Trade Center Is Said to Be Close to Signing Its First Tenant
description: After trying for months to find its first tenant, the developer of the first new building at the World Trade Center site is expected to soon sign a lease with a unit of American Express that is to become an independent company, people briefed on the lease negotiations said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a federal judge's order regarding photographs and videotapes related to the Abu Ghraib prison scandal misstated a deadline and the response by Defense Department lawyers. The government was given until Friday to black out some identifying details in the material, not to release it. Defense Department lawyers met that deadline, but asked the court to block the public release of the materials. They did not refuse to cooperate with an order for the materials' release. (Go to Article)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERDACH, THEA
description: BERDACH--Thea, died Friday, July 22, 2005, at Mather Hospital, Port Jefferson, NY at the age of 86. Beloved wife of Fred Berdach. Loving mother of James & Howard Berdach. Devoted daughter of the late Sarah and Jacob Koppelmann. Dear sister of Litza and Sam Schlanger. Fond grandmother of Gabriel Franklin Berdach. Thea was an accomplished painter whose works were much admired. Her gentle smile and effervescent spirit will be sadly missed and fondly remembered by all who knew her. Funeral 12:30 PM, on Tuesday, July 26th, at Boulevard - Riverside Chapel, Hewlett, New York. Family requests that donations be made in her memory to the Simon Wiesenthal Center.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Limits On Video Game Sales
description: Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich signed legislation making Illinois the only state to ban the sale or rental of violent and sexually explicit video games to minors. The law, which goes into effect in January, requires retailers to label such video games. Retailers who violate the law could face fines of up to $1,000. Three trade groups in the computer and video game industry filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Chicago, arguing that the new law was unconstitutional. Federal courts have struck down similar bans in Washington State, Indianapolis and St. Louis. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: GMAC to Sell Billions in Auto Loans to Bank of America
description: GMAC, the finance arm of General Motors, announced a deal today to sell as much as $55 billion of its auto loans to Bank of America over the next five years, gaining a badly needed cash infusion for its parent company.

title: World Business Briefing Americas: Canada: Teleglobe Sold to VSNL
description: Teleglobe International Holdings, a telecommunications company that is based in Montreal, has agreed to be acquired by Videsh Sanchar Nigam, a telecommunication and Internet service company based in India. VSNL will pay $4.50 a share in cash, a 22 percent premium over Teleglobe's share price on Friday. Including assumption of debt, the deal is valued at about $239 million. Teleglobe's board has approved the Indian company's bid which still requires shareholder and regulatory approval. Ian Austen (NYT)

title: Q & A
description: Surviving Without Water

title: To Spell When a Family Is Flailing
description: Not many teenagers know the meaning of "pulchritudinous," including the star of South Pleasant Company's "To One I Saw Small." But she can spell it with her eyes closed. Literally.

title: Shuttle Roars Into Space in First Mission in More Than 2 Years
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 26 - With a stuttering roar that shook the air for miles around, the shuttle Discovery lifted off this morning.

title: In Search of the New Funny, but Using the Old Maps
description: Sitcoms may not be doomed, but they seem endangered: there are even fewer promising half-hour comedies this fall season than last.

title: Outcomes: In Gauging Twins' Health, Follow the Money
description: Female identical twins, even when raised together, differ significantly in health status depending on the economic class they attain as adults, according to research published yesterday in Public Library of Science Medicine.

title: Cardiologist Testifies Vioxx Contributed to Man's Death
description: ANGLETON, Tex., July 25 - The painkiller Vioxx probably led to the death of Robert Ernst, a cardiologist told jurors on Monday in the first Vioxx lawsuit to reach trial.

description: Minor league umpires travel nonstop during the season and are paid subsistence wages in their quest to make it to the major leagues.

title: Record rains kill at least 71 in India
World Briefing | United Nations: Security Council Votes To Monitor Child Soldiers
description: The Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution to monitor nations and rebel groups that abduct and abuse children or enlist them as soldiers and to consider sanctions against offenders, including travel restrictions, asset freezes and denial of amnesty provisions to military and political leaders. The United Nations said that in the last decade two million children were killed and six million disabled or injured in situations of armed conflict. Under the plan, task forces will track the conduct of 54 offending groups, among them the Tamil Tigers in Sri Lanka, the janjaweed militias in Sudan and government forces in Congo, Myanmar and Uganda. Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: Whose Bags Should Be Searched?      Re ''Terrorism and the Random Search'' (editorial, July 26):     You say the New York City Police Department should not simply pick people of South Asian or Middle Eastern descent for bag searches at subway entrances. But given the events of 9/11 and the recent attacks in London, aren't they the people most likely to commit a terrorist attack? I say this as someone of Indian descent.
description: Anyone is certainly capable of committing such an act, but a certain degree of profiling is necessary. Is it worse for the police to be skewed somewhat in that direction, or to be politically correct and do what they can to avoid hurting someone's feelings?

title: Metro Briefing | New York: White Plains: Victim's Kin Speak Out On Bill
description: State Senator Jeff Klein and the family of Concetta Russo-Carriero, the Westchester woman who was slain near a busy mall here last month, criticized Assembly Democrats yesterday, saying they had stalled a bill that would force violent sex offenders into psychiatric institutions after serving prison sentences. Their comments came at a hearing at Concordia College in Bronxville organized by Senator Klein to urge the Assembly, currently on a break, to vote on a civil confinement measure that received nearly unanimous approval in the State Senate in April and came to a standstill in the Assembly. The measure has been at the center of a debate since a convicted sex offender, Philip Grant, was arrested and charged with Ms. Russo-Carriero's murder. The Westchester County district attorney, Jeanine F. Pirro, said yesterday that since Mr. Grant told investigators he killed Ms. Russo-Carriero because she was white, he would be charged with murder as a hate crime, which carries a longer sentence than simple murder. Anahad O'Connor (NYT)

title: Justice Nominee Is Questioned On Department Torture Policy
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - President Bush's nominee for the second-ranking spot at the Justice Department shed new light Tuesday on the 2002 development of the administration's positions on the treatment of terrorism detainees, but characterized some of the legal conclusions as "sophomoric."

title: M.T.A. Projects Surplus of $833 Million
description: Buoyed by a surge in tax revenue, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced today that it would have an unexpected surplus of $833 million this year and that it would consider using the money to create a giant platform over its West Side railyard in Manhattan on which a developer could build offices and apartment towers.

title: 3 Main British Parties to Back Tougher Antiterrorism Laws
description: LONDON, July 26 - Prime Minister Tony Blair promised on Tuesday not to "give one inch" on British policies in the Middle East, and he said Britain's three main political parties were moving closer to introducing stricter antiterrorism laws for Parliament to consider in the fall.

title: Hello Justice, Hello Fairness: Teachers Discover Ethics Camp
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif. - WHAT do high school teachers do at science ethics camp?

She is survived by husband of 55 years, John C., son John S., two daughters Jane Willis Taylor and Anne Holliday Taylor and four grandchildren. Memorial service will be at a later date. Contributions: www.dever eux.org. For information Glackin/Saul Funeral Home, Hightstown, N.J.

title: Miller Seeks Referendum Limiting Size of Classes
description: City Council Speaker Gifford Miller yesterday proposed putting a referendum on the November ballot to limit class sizes in public schools, adding new momentum to an issue he hopes will be his ticket to the Democratic mayoral nomination.

title: In Surprise Visit to Baghdad, Rumsfeld Prods Iraqi Leaders
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 27 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld urged Iraqi political leaders today to settle their differences and agree on a new constitution quickly, and to exert more influence with Syria and Iran to force them to end support for the insurgency here.

title: School Councils in Turmoil Over Forms
description: Citing long-running frustration with the Department of Education, many of the most prominent members of the city's Community Education Councils, which were created last year to give parents a voice in running the schools, are refusing to file financial disclosure forms and say they expect to be forced out of their positions by Saturday.

title: Brown Is Set to Become Next Coach of Knicks
description: A Hall of Famer and a champion, a certified winner at every level, Larry Brown appears ready to add one more title to his considerable rsum: franchise savior.

title: Not So Bleak Houses
description: Advocates for the homeless and New York City officials have been battling in court for 25 years -- a figure that invariably calls up references to "Bleak House," the Charles Dickens novel about lives and hopes destroyed by an endless court fight. In the case of the city's shelter system, however, all that litigation has actually borne fruit. Although far from idyllic, things are much, much better than a quarter-century ago. Both the advocates and the Bloomberg administration deserve a great deal of credit.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SKLAR, EVA MOLINEUX
description: SKLAR--Eva Molineux. 81, of Los Angeles, Ca., on July 25, 2005. Cherished wife of Richard, beloved mother of Judith and of Katherine Sparling. Loving grandmother of Felix and Sophie. Caring nurse, a friend and helper to so many throughout the world.

title: Trenton Panel to Return to Court if Child Welfare Doesn't Improve
description: NEWARK, July 26 - Saying that New Jersey has been too slow to improve its system to protect abused or neglected children, the chairman of the state's Child Welfare Panel warned that child advocates would take the state back to court unless quick and significant progress was made.

title: Congress Calls for a Review of the Chinese Bid for Unocal
description: After more than a month of public wrangling and secret negotiations, Cnooc, the Chinese government-backed oil company, suffered a second blow in less than a week in its bid to acquire Unocal when the United States Congress called for a review that would delay such a takeover by many months.

title: Whose Bags Should Be Searched?      Because of my Indian origin, I frequently get pulled over when boarding planes, while several of my friends who travel more frequently than I do never get pulled over. This irked me in the beginning, but later I began to understand.
description: Since most of these terrorist attacks have been linked to people of Middle Eastern backgrounds, it is inevitable that people who appear to be of Middle Eastern background will be watched more closely and that there will be racial profiling to some extent in order to protect the security of the people.

title: Officer Wounded by Man Who Attacked Statue Is Released From Hospital
description: Nine days after he was shot in the head outside a Queens church, Officer Dominick Romano returned home yesterday after salutes and applause from his fellow officers outside the hospital where he had been recuperating.

title: In Clinton, Thai for All, Including the Trendy
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Judge Throws Out Genocide Charge
description: A judge has thrown out charges of genocide against former President Luis Echeverra and his interior minister, dealing a severe blow to the efforts of the administration of President Vicente Fox to hold high-ranking officials accountable for the killing of political dissidents in the late 1960's and early 1970's. The judge, Herlinda Valasco Villavicencio, did not make her opinion public. But the special prosecutor's office pursuing the charges said she had issued a ruling denying them arrest warrants for Mr. Echeverra and the former interior minister, Mario Moya Palencia. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; INXS Search's Ratings Lag
description: What does it mean for the future of INXS that the search for the band's new singer is lagging in the ratings? Though CBS won Monday night's Nielsen competition in both total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds, its 9:30 offering, "Rock Star: INXS," was No. 3 in its slot among all viewers (5.9 million) and tied for second in the 18-to-49 demographic. Besides that half-hour, CBS's lineup of repeats -- "King of Queens" (7.47 million), "Everybody Loves Raymond" (8.38 million), "Two and a Half Men" (9.6 million) and "CSI: Miami" (10.01 million) -- was No. 1 in households during all other prime-time periods. With an original episode of "Hell's Kitchen" bringing in 7.3 million viewers, Fox lost the battle for the 18-to-49 demographic by only a sliver. For the week that ended on July 24, however, Fox was first in that age group on the strength of "So You Think You Can Dance." As usual, CBS was No. 1 in total viewers for the week.

title: Square Feet; TRANSACTIONS
description: Recent Sale $84 million 3 Huntington Quadrangle Melville, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   EFFRON, JAMES W.
description: EFFRON--James W., 73, died peacefully after a brief illness on July 21 after a happy and well-lived life. He was the beloved husband of Dawn; adored father of Craig (Caryn), Blair (Cheryl), Drew (Sandra) and Brooke (Ross); and cherished grandfather of eight. He was born and lived proudly his entire life on the same street in Poughkeepsie, NY, and was a true and warm friend to all who knew him. After graduating from Princeton University in 1953, he served his country in the Army. He spent his career with Effron Oil Company, serving as its President for many years. Funeral services Monday, 11 AM, at Vassar Temple, Poughkeepsie. Shiva at the Effron home in Poughkeepsie on Monday and Tuesday. Shiva in New York at 129 East 73rd Street on Wednesday from 6-9 PM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, to be credited to Dr. Stephen Nimer Leukemia Research.

title: A Percussionist Puts Minimal Means to Eclectic Ends
description: When percussionists give recitals they usually pack the platform with instruments and objects to beat on. But Svet Stoyanov, a young percussionist from Bulgaria who won the Concert Artists Guild competition in 2003, used a surprisingly modest setup in his recital at the Michael Schimmel Center for the Arts at Pace University on Monday evening. Mostly, he played the marimba, and he did so with a winning combination of gentleness and fluidity. He also doubled on the vibraphone in one work, and offered short solos on a trap set and the tapan, a Bulgarian drum.

title: Is There an Extra Ingredient in Nonstick Pans?
description: THE question of whether Teflon cookware is safe has moved from Web site chatter to the courtroom. But more than nonstick frying pans are under scrutiny these days. Scientists are examining the chemical makeup of other products like food containers to gauge their potential hazards.

title: Techbrief: Microsoft blockade
German High Court Strikes Down Wiretapping Law
description: BERLIN, July 27 - Germany's highest court today struck down a state wiretapping law that the law's supporters said would have enabled the police to maintain closer surveillance of potential terrorists and other dangerous criminals.

title: 2 Central Asian States Reassure Rumsfeld on U.S. Use of Air Bases
description: DUSHANBE, Tajikistan, July 26 - The Pentagon received assurances from two Central Asian states on Tuesday that it could continue to use their air bases to support relief and counterterrorism operations in Afghanistan, easing concerns about the possible loss of access to a major air base in Uzbekistan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Geraldine Fitzgerald on July 19 misspelled the given name of the Macy's co-owner whose grandson she married. He was Isidor Straus, not Isador.

title: A Struggling TV Guide Will Get a New Look
description: TV Guide previewed a new design yesterday as the magazine looks to stem its declining advertising and circulation in recent years.

title: I.B.M.'s Latest Mainframe Adds Power and Encryption
description: I.B.M. introduced a new line of mainframe computer yesterday that is not only twice as powerful as its predecessor but also aims to make it easier for corporations to encrypt vast amounts of customer information and to bundle the workloads of many smaller computers onto an I.B.M. mainframe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENLY, WILLIAM S.
description: KENLY--William S. Willy K., we hardly knew you, but we loved you and will miss you. Ellen and Bill

title: In the Crowd, Emotions and Goosebumps
description: PORT ST. JOHN, Fla., July 26 - Alan Thomas left his home three counties away at 4 a.m., determined to claim a waterfront spot with a prime view of Launch Pad 39B. He set up his camera near a "Beware of Alligators" sign and waited as darkness gave way to a hot, bright morning and thrill-seekers from all corners of the nation asked to peer through his telephoto lens.

title: Stocks: Strong earnings fail to inspire investors

Minutemen At Our Borders      There is a serious difference between the Revolutionary militia of 1775 that fought the world's biggest empire at the time (Britain) and a bunch of national chauvinists who seek out vulnerable immigrants.
description: The actions of these vigilantes are not revolutionary but bigoted and reactionary. Anti-racists everywhere should confront them.

title: From Sex to Politics, All Captured on Video
description: The video revolution is here and has been for some time. George Lucas, among other once and future filmmakers, is rapidly changing our viewing habits, and along the way, making questions of format increasingly irrelevant. When one of the most successful movie directors in history hijacks a medium for world box office domination, as Mr. Lucas did by using high-definition digital video in his "Star Wars" franchise, it renders the old celluloid-versus-video debate moot. Arguably, it also renders events like the New York Video Festival, which has been renamed Scanners and opens today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, moot. Does it matter? Not really.

title: A Brooklyn Judge, Censured, Is Retiring
description: ALBANY, July 26 - A Brooklyn judge has been censured as part of an agreement that calls for him to retire by end of the year for failing disclose his close relationship to a politically connected lawyer who appeared before him, officials said Tuesday.

title: Artistic Odyssey: Film to Fiction to Film
description: DREUX, France, July 20 - Novels are routinely adapted for the screen. What is rare is for a best-selling writer to direct the movie version of his own book. Dai Sijie's experience, though, was still more unusual. He was a filmmaker who turned to fiction because his movie career was faltering. Now the worldwide success of his first novel, "Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress," has put his movie career back on track.

title: Report: North Korea demands U.S. remove nuclear threat
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, EDWARD HARTLEY
description: BENENSON--Edward Hartley. Born March 27, 1914, in NYC. Beloved husband of Gladys. Loving father of Thomas, James and Deb, Amy and Clifford Aronson, Lisa and Joseph Quattrocchi, and Andrew Benenson and Ronnie and George Igel. Adored grandfather of 14 grandchildren and great grandfather of five great grandchildren. A great lover of food and wine, art and travel, the Yankees and the Civil War. Chairman of Benenson Funding Corporation. Edward H. Benenson graduated from Duke University in 1934 and has been involved with the University and Medical Center ever since. He was Trustee Emeritus and former Chairman of Friends of Duke University Museum of Art. He established the Edward H. Benenson Awards in the Arts at Duke and founded the Edward H. Benenson Merit Scholarship Fund for Duke University Medical Center (DUMC). He received the 2000 Honorary Medical Alumnus Award from DUMC and the 2002 Distinguished Alumnus Award from the University. He was co-founder and Honorary Trustee of the Culinary Institute of America where he was the generous donor of the Edward H. Benenson Scholarship Fund. He was also a member of the Board of Overseers of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Grand Camerlingue Honoraire of the Confrerie des Chevaliers du Tastevin, Bailli Delegue Honoraire des Etats Unis of the Chine des Rotisseurs and member of the American Societies of the Italian Legions of Merit and of French Order of Merit. The family will receive friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street on Monday from 6-8. Funeral services on Tuesday at 11:30 AM, Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory may be made to Duke University Medical Center, c/o Ruth Irvin, DUMC, 512 South Mangum Street, Suite 400, Durham, NC 27701-3973. He had a heart of gold and will be greatly missed by all those whose lives he touched with his kindness, generosity and love.

title: French law would make firing easier
And now, command capitalism
Bravo's James Lipton to the Extreme, Dude
description: IF you heard that James Lipton, the intense, erudite host of "Inside the Actors Studio," was interviewing a blue-chip lineup of stars, you would normally not go wrong by expecting them to bear names like Cruise, Newman and Streisand. But a series of humorous television commercials that began running this week plays switcheroo with those expectations, incongruously pairing Mr. Lipton with stars named Dyrdek, Pastrana and Way.

title: Junior Welterweight Has Style and Substance
description: When Paul Malignaggi is preparing for a fight, he doesn't do his laundry, carry his car keys or cook. He has a friend do chores for him. Malignaggi, a junior welterweight from Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, handles the talking. And he handles it well.

title: In video blogging, mundane is in

Setting More Places at the Organic Feast      Greenmarket snobbery is a minor ill, but the scarcity of healthful eating options in poorer neighborhoods is a major one. When a cheeseburger costs 99 cents and the nearest Whole Foods store is several zip codes away, proper nutrition is unlikely.
description: Let us think what we can do to improve the odds, not out of any patronizing motive but out of a simple interest in the good health of others.

title: Clean Air Improvements      In ''The Clean-Air Wars'' (editorial, some editions, July 21), you rightly note the benefits of the administration's Non-Road Diesel Rule, which will result in significant health, environmental and economic benefits. But you do not mention the Clean Air Interstate Rule, which will cut power plant pollution in the eastern United States by almost 70 percent.
description: Each of these two landmark rules, issued under Jeffrey Holmstead's leadership, has greater public health benefits than any other rule initiated by the E.P.A. since the phase-out of lead in gasoline.

title: A. William Holmberg Jr., Former Newspaper Executive, Dies at 81
description: A. William Holmberg Jr., a newspaper executive and civic leader who was chief business officer of The Chattanooga Times from 1970 until the paper's sale in 1999, died yesterday at a hospital in Chattanooga, Tenn. He was 81.

title: New IBM mainframe enhances encryption
Questions Remain as Scouts Try to Deal With Four Deaths
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - It was early Monday afternoon in Anchorage when Ward Merkouris picked up the telephone and heard his son, Robert, so shaken he could barely talk, describe how electricity from a live power line coursed through a tall, tilting tent pole and electrocuted the leaders of his Boy Scout troop.

title: Easy Sailing for Nominee to the S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - Representative Christopher Cox, the president's choice to be the next leader of the Securities and Exchange Commission, pledged at his confirmation hearing on Tuesday that he would not undo regulations recently adopted by the agency but would, in his words, "build upon them."

title: Moving Into the Neighborhood
description: Correction Appended

title: 43 Years of Tips, Taken and Given
description: Long before the cheesecake was famous at Junior's, the Brooklyn restaurant, Mary Blevins was a popular item.

title: Rural Military Values      As ''The Rural War,'' by Robert Cushing and Bill Bishop (Op-Ed, July 20), illustrated so well, America's rural areas have indeed borne the casualty burden of the Iraq war to a greater degree than urban and suburban areas. But to state that this is primarily an ''economics story'' is to overlook the fact that citizens on farms and in smaller towns are often more conservative in nature regardless of party affiliation and more likely to have a positive view of military service.
description: I know this to be true from my own personal experience. I grew up in a rural area, enlisted in the Army and now live and work in the Chicago area.

title: Text: Pataki's Announcement
description: Following is a transcript of George E. Pataki's announcement that he will not seek a fourth term as governor of New York, as recorded by The New York Times.

Setting More Places at the Organic Feast      It is my hope that because I go out of my way to buy, and spend more for, organic foods now, I am hastening the day when they will be available and affordable to everyone.
description: Patricia Gordon Lamanna Poughkeepsie, N.Y., July 23, 2005

title: The Yanks Are Looking for a Few Good Pitchers
description: Correction Appended

title: Pataki Won't Run for a 4th Term, Confidants Say
description: ALBANY, July 26 - Gov. George E. Pataki told a group of supporters and aides on Tuesday night that he would not seek a fourth term as governor after abruptly summoning them to the governor's mansion, according to two people who attended the meeting.

title: Zimbabwe Police Resume Drive to Raze Slums
description: JOHANNESBURG, July 26 - The Zimbabwean police resumed a slum-demolition campaign on Tuesday, hours after the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, accepted a government invitation to view firsthand the impact of the widely condemned program.

title: France firm on decision to deport Algerian cleric
Shuttle starts journey after successful liftoff
People: Green Day, Cameron Diaz, Christo
Minor League Umpires Wait for the Big Call
description: CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex. - On a particularly stifling night in early July, when the air was as thick and grainy as oatmeal, the Hooks, the Houston Astros' farm club in the Class AA Texas League, had taken more than three hours to edge the visiting Midland RockHounds.

title: As August Recess Looms, Congress Finds High Gear
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - In a mad dash to rack up some accomplishments before Congress leaves town for its five-week August recess, the Senate on Tuesday temporarily abandoned work on a defense policy bill and took up a measure, likely to pass and laden with political implications for Democrats, that will shield gun manufacturers from lawsuits.

title: South Korea Proposes Aid to North as It Disarms
description: BEIJING, July 27 - North Korea criticized an American plan to defuse the nuclear crisis, saying today that the proposal demands too many steps toward dismantling the country's nuclear program before providing any corresponding aid or energy assistance, a senior United States official said.

title: Without Help, Northwest Says, Bankruptcy Looms
description: Turning up the pressure on its unions and Congress, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would have to seek bankruptcy protection without $1.1 billion in wage and benefit cuts and the passage of a pension reform bill.

title: Watching Over Poland's Ghosts, in a Spirit of Renewal
description: NOWA HUTA, Poland - You won't find two people more seemingly different than Bartosz Szydlowski and Leopold Kozlowski, separated by nearly two generations, living and working in Polish towns that represent contrasting pasts and contrasting presents.

title: Maine May Consider, for a Third Time, a Gay Bias Question
description: AUGUSTA, Me. - After saying no twice before, voters in Maine may be going to the polls again to decide whether to add sexual orientation to the state's human rights act, which prohibits discrimination based on age, sex, race, color, marital status, religion, ancestry or national origin.

title: Tribes of New York
description: At Yankee Stadium, 2 is far from the loneliest number. Yankees fans of all shapes and sizes profess their devotion to the captain, Derek Jeter. Their stories, as well as others featured in Tribes of New York, remain online at nytimes.com/tribes.

title: Minutemen At Our Borders      My understanding of the Minuteman Project is that its goal was not to capture or kill the illegal immigrants whom the volunteers discovered, but to alert federal border authorities to the illegal immigrants' presence so that they could apprehend and deport them.
description: I support such lawful efforts to interdict illegal immigrants at the border before they can disperse to other parts of our country.

title: Key figures sentenced in French sex case
Sun Earnings Beat Forecasts, but Sales Continue to Slip
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 - Sun Microsystems reported earnings on Tuesday that outpaced Wall Street expectations for the quarter. But the company's revenue continued to fall, indicating that the computer maker has yet to achieve a turnaround.

title: Letter from Europe: EU proves a tough sale: What is the message?
A Familiar Televised Ritual: Watching, Marveling and, Finally, Exhaling
description: We watch to make sure nothing bad happens. A space launching may be the only event that is watched for just one reason, and yesterday, as the networks hurriedly replaced "The Tony Danza Show" and "Guiding Light" with retired NASA engineers and blinking countdown clocks, a familiar television ritual took place.

title: Verdict expected Mont Blanc tunnel fire trial

description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NESTER, LORETTA M.
description: NESTER--Loretta M., of Point Lookout, LI on July 25, 2005. Beloved wife of Martin F. Nester. Loving mother of Dr. Jeanne N. Rolih (Peter A.), Suzanne M. Nester, M. Noel Nester (Glennis) and Dr. Matthew J. Nester (Dr. Elizabeth). Cherished grandmother of Nikolas, Savannah, Sofia, Olivia, Victoria and Loretta Lillian. Adored sister of Raymond McCue, Juel Carruthers and A. Harry McCue. Also survived by many nieces and nephews. Officer and member of the William Dawes Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution. Reposing after 7pm tonight Charles J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 603 Wantagh Ave. (Exit 28N SS Pkwy) Wantagh. Funeral Mass Friday 10:30am Our Lady of Miraculous Medal RC Church, Point Lookout, NY. Interment St. Patricks Cemetery, Huntington, NY. Family will recive friends Wednesday 7-10pm and Thursday 2-5 & 7-10pm.

title: Sichuan's Signature Is Now Legal Again
description: SOMETIMES the federal Department of Agriculture can be tough on connoisseurs. Its rules, set to protect the health of Americans and American crops, often mean that specialty foods cannot be sold unless strict conditions are met.

title: Memo From Weill to Employees
description: The following is text of a memo sent by Citigroup's chairman, Sanford I. Weill, to the company's employees.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposal by Representative Anthony D. Weiner, a Democratic candidate for New York mayor, to expand the city's business relationships with religious organizations referred incorrectly to legislation proposed in 2001 that would have increased the organizations' role in federal programs. Democrats including Mr. Weiner voted against the bill because it lacked a provision to bar the organizations from proselytizing or discriminating on the basis of religion or sexual orientation -- not because Republicans refused to remove such a provision.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Washington: F.A.A. To Review Near Collision
description: Federal Aviation Administration officials will meet with their Israeli counterparts this week to discuss enforcing penalties against the crew of an Israir plane that blundered onto a runway at Kennedy International Airport on July 6 as another plane was preparing to take off. A crash was narrowly averted when the pilot of the other plane, a DC-8 cargo jet, spotted the Israir Boeing 767 on the runway and climbed steeply to avoid it. An investigation into the incident is still in its early stages, but it seems that the Israeli crew, looking for the departure runway on a rainy night, missed a turn from one taxiway to another, and ended up on the runway instead. Matthew L. Wald (NYT)

title: Plan to Shift Army Units Is Complete, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - The Army has completed plans for bringing home 50,000 soldiers living overseas, mostly in Germany and South Korea, and settling them in bases across the United States where families will move less often and troops will be closer to training centers and ports, Pentagon officials said Tuesday.

title: IMF chief draws fire over style as leader
QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "Good luck, godspeed -- and have a little fun up there."

title: Watching Liftoff, With an Eye on the Future
description: The mission of the space shuttle Discovery is not yet a success -- far from it.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Republicans Demand Tape Release
description: New Jersey Republicans announced yesterday a radio campaign demanding the full release of secretly recorded conversations of George E. Norcross III, the Camden County Democratic leader. So far, Attorney General Peter C. Harvey has released only a fraction of the recordings, on which Mr. Norcross can be heard boasting of his ability to provide patronage jobs to allies. But Tom Wilson, the state's Republican chairman, criticized Mr. Harvey for acting too slowly, and urged state residents to sign a petition on the new Web sitereleasethetapes.com. Mr. Wilson said that the Web site was not tied directly to the campaign of the Republican candidate for governor, Douglas R. Forrester. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: New Home Sales and Orders for Durable Goods Rise Briskly
description: Sales of new homes and orders for durable goods rose faster than expected last month, the government reported today, providing more indications that the economy is expanding at a brisk pace.

title: British Police Arrest 4 Men in Connection With Failed Attacks
description: LONDON, July 27 - In what could a major breakthrough in the London bombing investigation, British police arrested four men in Birmingham early today, bringing one to London for questioning in connection with attempted bombings of subways and a bus here on July 21.

title: Labor Debates the Future of a Fractured Movement
description: CHICAGO, July 26 - The two giant unions that quit the A.F.L.-C.I.O. say their exodus will help revive the labor movement. But Greg Devereux, one of the 800 delegates at the union convention here, was not buying it.

title: Wasted Energy
description: Houston - LATELY there has been much grandstanding about the dangers of the bid by a government-backed Chinese oil company, Cnooc, for Unocal. But protectionists are focusing on the wrong target. It's true that China could be a threat to American energy security some day, but not because it wants to buy an American company already on the block.

title: Veteran of Iraq, Running in Ohio, Is Harsh on Bush
description: CINCINNATI, July 22 - In the Second Congressional District of Ohio, which Republicans have controlled for the last two decades, the quickest route to political oblivion could be the one chosen by Paul L. Hackett: calling President Bush a "chicken hawk" for not serving in Vietnam and harshly criticizing the decision to invade Iraq.

title: Film Studios Said to Agree on Digital Standards
description: LOS ANGELES, July 26 - Hollywood's major film studios are expected to announce on Wednesday that they have agreed to new technical standards that will make it easier for movie theaters to show digitally produced movies, according to two studio executives apprised of the announcement.

title: Beats the Heck Out of Ketchup
description: When the season demands the ripest tomatoes, like right now, it would be pointless to pick the fruit green. That can happen later, when tomatoes are abundant. In the meantime, an excellent substitute is a green tomato preserve imported from France by O & Co. Try it at breakfast or serve it with cheese, as a condiment for fried tomatoes, or as a topping for vanilla ice cream or lemon sorbet. Spread a thin glaze of it to seal a pastry shell before adding slices of red tomato for a tart.

description: CHICAGO, July 26 - At "Z" Frank Chevrolet, it takes a little more spice to sell a Chevy these days.

title: Long Night of Talk, Barbed and Bitter
description: Nothing is quite what it seems at first in "Brother," Lisa Ebersole's confrontational one-act play at Tom Noonan's Paradise Factory. The audience is uncomfortably close to the action in this theater-in-the-round production, which starts with an ambiguous tension that quickly escalates.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 P.M. (Sci Fi) GHOST HUNTERS -- Season premiere. Jason Hawes (near right) and Grant Wilson are plumbers by day (for Roto-Rooter) and investigators of the paranormal by night. Tonight they travel to Myrtles Plantation, an 18th-century house in St. Francisville, La., that is said to be haunted by numerous ghosts, including a slave named Chloe, who was hanged. They say the house was built on ancient American Indian burial grounds.

title: Rowland Set to Replace His Lawyer in State Case
description: With the possibility of criminal prosecution by the state he once ran still hanging over his head, former Connecticut Gov. John G. Rowland has indicated from prison that he wants a new lawyer to take over his defense on the state case.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the possibility of an indictment of H.D. Smith Wholesale Drug over the distribution of counterfeit Lipitor tablets misstated the number of investigations the Food and Drug Administration started in 2004 as a result of increased surveillance of the pharmaceutical supply chain. It was 58, not 8.

title: U.S. to give a 2nd look to Cnooc's bid
Damaged Cars Hinder New York's Order for New Subways
description: A $1.1 billion contract to build 660 subway cars for New York City has run into significant problems, including damage to two car shells during shipment from Brazil and a failure to order parts that must be installed before safety and mechanical tests can begin. The problems were made known this week in a report commissioned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Yes, the Kitchen's Open. Too Open.
description: THERE was a time when much of the point of fine dining was to be liberated from the frenetic, clangorous, sweaty making of a meal, to have it magically appear, an unlabored gift from unseen elves.

title: Slain Newark Officer Recalled as Being a Hero Even Before Fatal Shot
description: NEWARK, July 26 - The funeral procession for Officer Dwayne Reeves began Tuesday morning when nearly 1,000 police officers lined up, hip to hip.

description: GREENBERG -- Ralph. Our most sincere condolences to the Greenberg family. We are saddened about the passing of our dear devoted friend and most loyal employee of fifty years. Ralph will be greatly missed. He will be remembered always. The officers and employees Acker & Jablow Fabrics
