title: Slain Woman's Kin Push Civil Confinement Bill
description: BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 26 - A state senator and the family of a woman who was slain near a busy Westchester mall in June criticized Assembly Democrats on Tuesday, saying they had stalled a bill that would force violent sex offenders into psychiatric institutions after serving their sentences in prison.

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Reward For Corruption Tip
description: The Cook County Republican Party said it was offering a $10,000 reward to anyone who provided information leading to an indictment and conviction of Mayor Richard M. Daley of Chicago for political corruption. Mayor Daley's press secretary called the action ridiculous. Last week, federal prosecutors announced charges against two city officials accused of selecting city employees based on political connections. Mayor Daley has proposed an independent commission to be in charge of hiring and promoting most city employees. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Calling the 14th Floor
description: What is it about the 14th floor? In the Library Hotel, 299 Madison Avenue (41st Street), the new 14th-floor Rooftop Garden, above, has two terraces, a greenhouse and an indoor lounge for light food, inventive drinks and skyline views. Guy Heksch, who worked for Daniel Boulud, and Gil Rubenstein, who was director of food and beverages for the Essex House, are the owners: (212)983-4500.

title: Setting More Places at the Organic Feast (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A summer night
Casing John Roberts
description: San Francisco - IN its confirmation hearings, the Senate should ask Judge John G. Roberts to analyze specific cases that have come before the Supreme Court in the past. That is the only way to get a meaningful sense of where he may move the nation's jurisprudence.

title: British police arrest 4 as manhunt continues
Hugging the Ground, in the Style of a BMW
description: BMW of North America, which last year purchased office property in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., from the Ingersoll-Rand Company to expand its own headquarters there, will begin construction of an "environmentally sensitive" building on the property some time next year, according to the division's chief executive, Tom Purves.

title: Ex-WorldCom Executive Forfeits Florida Mansion
description: Scott D. Sullivan, the former chief financial officer of WorldCom, who faces 25 years in jail for his role in an accounting fraud that toppled the company, agreed yesterday to forfeit his lavish Florida estate and his retirement fund to settle a class-action lawsuit.

title: Corrections
description: A credit line yesterday for a report in the "Arts, Briefly" column about the Nielsen estimates of television viewers on Sunday night misspelled the writer's surname. She is Kate Aurthur, not Arthur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SAM, DR. DAVID
description: SAM--Dr. David. In the deepest and most loving memory of Dr. David Sam. He will always be loved, remembered and missed in the heart of his dearest beloved wife, Stephanie Cheung, parents, King and Meiling Sam, and siblings, Millie and Donnie Sam. The family will receive friends on Thursday, July 28, from 3 to 8 PM, Ng Fook Funeral Services, 36 Mulberry St., NY NY. Funeral at 12 noon, Friday, July 29. Interment service 1:30 PM in Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: Leahy Warns Against 'Activist' Role for High Court Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - The leading Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee says he is ready to vote against President Bush's Supreme Court nominee if he appears to be an "activist" ideologue. But a fellow committee Democrat says it appears the nominee may not deserve the "activist" label.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIVACK, EDITH I.
description: SPIVACK--Edith I. The NYC Law Department expresses its sympathy on the passing of Edith I. Spivack, former Executive Assistant Corporation Counsel. Edith served as a role model for all lawyers and public servants. She was one of NYC's first female attorneys, working in our office from 1934 to 2004. She served with distinction under 10 Mayors and 23 Corporation Counsels. Edith represented public service and professionalism at its finest. Our deepest condolences to her family. NYC Law Department & Michael A. Cardozo, Corporation Counsel

title: Myanmar to forgo leadership of Asean
French sex case verdict delayed

Whose Bags Should Be Searched?      While Israel has had more than its fair share of suicide bombings, the media do not often report the fact that Israel's security forces have thwarted a high percentage of potential attacks.
description: The reason: while most countries instruct their forces to search for potential bombs, Israelis are trained to pick out the potential bombers. New York City should follow this model.

title: CALENDAR
description: Gin Tasting in Brooklyn

title: U.S. to Join China and India In Climate Pact
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Wednesday, July 27 - The United States plans to join China and India in an Asian-Pacific climate agreement intended to replace the Kyoto pact as a method to control greenhouse emissions, an official attending the annual conference of Asian nations in Vientiane, Laos, said Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about a protest over plans to turn the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue into an arts center misidentified the man speaking through a bullhorn. He was Peter Scoville Wells, an officer of the veterans' group that held the protest, not David L. Dalva II.

title: Weill Says He'll Remain as Citigroup's Chairman
description: Sanford I. Weill, Citigroup's chairman, said today that he had abandoned plans to leave the financial services company early to start a private equity fund, ending a weeklong battle with board members about his employment contract.

title: Solidarity in Pieces
description: It's disturbing to hear the fracture of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. billed as the death of organized labor, particularly by those whose cheerful tone suggests that the sooner unions fade away, the better. Since we live in an era when the chasm between the lower and upper classes is growing, and the chances of moving out of poverty are getting slimmer, it's hard to imagine that working people have lost their need for a powerful advocate.

title: Exports lift confidence in Germany
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the Boldface column last Wednesday, about a party for Suzanne Somers, the star of a one-woman autobiographical show on Broadway, gave an outdated title for Alan Simpson, a guest. He is a former senator from Wyoming, not a current one.

title: BP profit surges 29% on rise of oil
New flaws discovered in software
Easing The Way To Dinner
description: LACKING the icy gloss of a dry martini or the urbanity of a perfect manhattan, aperitifs have always played the spinster aunt to the cocktail's gin-soaked good-time girl. And unlike a cocktail party, which looms large in our cultural consciousness, an aperitif party doesn't even register.

title: A Love Affair With Movies in Hong Kong
description: In this gently nostalgic valentine to Hong Kong cinema, Fa (Shawn Yu) and Ming (Wang You-nam) are two movie-mad teenagers who sell sugar-cane sticks from a stall outside a movie theater. Ten years before, Fan's father shot himself in a bathroom stall of the same theater while his young son sat watching a film. Growing up, Fan clings to the belief that his father was actually killed by a local gangster named Crazy (Anthony Wong), and takes up the study of kung fu in the hope of exacting his revenge. In a side plot, the two boys fall for the martial arts instructor's beautiful daughter, Nam (Charlene Choi), whom they nickname Heroine after a character in a classic kung fu film. Soon after, Fan also becomes fascinated with a mysterious girl known as Ghost (Gillian Chung), an orphan who lives in a remote nunnery.

title: Op-Art
Intense Hunt for Signs of Damage Could Raise Problems of Its Own
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 26 - Now that the Discovery is in orbit, the examination begins. Its 12 1/2-day mission will be the most photographed in the history of the shuttle program, with all eyes on the craft to see if it suffered the kind of damage from blastoff debris that brought down the Columbia in February 2003.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Praise And Doubts About Budget
description: State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that the city's economy was well on the mend but that he had concerns about debt facing the city in the future. Mr. Hevesi said the city's $3.5 billion surplus this fiscal year was a record, but was eclipsed by projected budget gaps of $4.5 billion in the 2007 and 2008 fiscal years. In a report released yesterday, his office said it had identified a potential $770 million surplus in the 2006 fiscal year budget that could help plug future gaps. Jim Rutenberg (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WRIGHT, ANN HALLOWELL
description: WRIGHT--Ann Hallowell, 85, wife of Judge Douglass B. Wright and widow of Howard (Algie) Ferguson died peacefully Saturday, July 23rd in Hartford, CT. She was a resident of Bloomfield, CT, and lived previously in Merion, PA, Greenwich, West Hartford, Avon, CT and Fishers Island, NY. She leaves her sister Patricia (Teedy) Stedman, her daughter Ann (Nancy) Lee Ferguson, her daughter Carroll Duchet of Brazil, her son Howard Ferguson Jr., of Arlington, MA, her grandsons Michael Hackett of Brazil, John Hackett of Texas and David Hackett of Brazil, her granddaughter Anna Hackett of Brazil and the University of Hartford, and her great-grandson Darren Hackett. She also leaves five stepchildren, eight step-grandchildren and three step-greatgrandchildren. A memorial service and reception will be held Saturday (July 30) at 10:30 A.M. at Duncaster Community, 40 Loeffler Road, Bloomfield, CT. In the afternoon the family will also gather at St. James Parish, 3 Mt. Rd., Farmington, Ct.

title: What Does 'Suspicious' Look Like?
description: POLICE officers stopped a sightseeing bus in Times Square on Sunday morning, and not because they suddenly desired to see the South Street Seaport. Urgent word had come to them of suspicious men on board, acting suspiciously in these suspicious times.

title: Terrorist Group Threatens to Kill Abducted Algerian Diplomats
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 26 - Twelve employees of a government-run ironworking company were gunned down Tuesday on their way home from work near the Abu Ghraib prison, an Interior Ministry official said. And a group led by the Jordanian terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarqawi released a video of two kidnapped Algerian diplomats and threatened to kill them.

title: Currencies: Dollar gains strength as traders await data
London bombers, Doling out EU funds
A Hectic Day for the G.O.P., Full of Hints and Speculation
description: The cellphones of several New York Republican leaders were ringing nearly nonstop by late yesterday afternoon as speculation built a powerful head of steam: Was Gov. George E. Pataki on the verge of announcing he would not run for a fourth term, instead preparing to consider a presidential bid?

title: Plastic Vessels May Link Two Sets of London Bombings
description: LONDON, July 26 - The police are investigating evidence that plastic containers may have been used to build bombs for the July 7 bombings as well as the failed attacks two weeks later. If confirmed, the evidence could help link the two attacks.

title: U.S. brings softer touch to new North Korea talks
Congress, After Years of Effort, Is Set to Pass Broad Energy Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - After coming up short for years, Congress is preparing to enact a broad energy plan that would provide generous federal subsidies to the oil and gas industries, encourage new nuclear power plant construction and try to whet the nation's appetite for renewable fuels like ethanol and wind power.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Depression Awareness Campaign
description: New Jersey opened an educational campaign yesterday to build awareness about postpartum depression. Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey called for the campaign, which features his wife, Mary Jo Codey, during his State of the State address in January. The campaign includes a Web site, njspeakup.gov, and a postpartum depression help line that offers information as well as emergency assistance. At a news conference yesterday, Health Commissioner Fred M. Jacobs estimated that 11,000 to 16,000 New Jersey women each year suffered from postpartum depression.

title: Talk aplenty, but WTO is mired
Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Newark: Five Egyptians Arrested
description: Five Egyptian men are in federal custody and facing deportation, accused of being in the country illegally, after an anonymous tip to the police, the F.B.I. said yesterday. No criminal charges were filed and federal investigators found no weapons or signs of terrorist activity, said Special Agent Steven Siegel. He said that the Newark police asked the F.B.I.'s help on Sunday after finding train schedules with circled stops and $8,000 in cash at the home on Ferry Street where the five men lived with a sixth Egyptian who was in the country legally. Investigators eventually found that one man had used the map to get to his restaurant job in New York. Damien Cave (NYT)

title: British Police Arrest 4 Men in Connection With Failed Attacks
description: LONDON, July 27 -British police today arrested a Somali man they suspect of being one of the bombers in the failed attacks on three subway trains and a bus last week, Scotland Yard announced this evening.

title: Airport Improvements to Cost Billions, Operators Predict
description: Capital development costs at the nation's airports will average $14.3 billion a year from 2005 through 2009 as air travel reaches record levels, according to a survey to be released today by an airport trade association.

title: EU money-transfer curb aims to disrupt terrorists
City Taxi Agency Approves Use of Six Hybrid Models
description: Correction Appended

title: Shuttle Roars Back to Space After 2-Year Absence
description: CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 26 - With a stuttering roar that shook the air for miles around, the shuttle Discovery lifted off on Tuesday morning, carrying seven astronauts on a 12 1/2-day mission to resupply the International Space Station and to try to demonstrate NASA's renewed commitment to safety.

title: Briefly: Single-sex transportation introduced in Nigeria
Paid Notice: Deaths   RUSKAY, JOSEPH A.
description: RUSKAY--Joseph A., on July 24, 2005 in his 95th year in NYC. Beloved husband of 57 years of Margot. Devoted father of David and Deborah. Loving grandfather of Morgan, Meagan & Benjamin. He was a highly successful attorney, specializing in anti-trust law, with a lifetime commitment to and passion for democratic and liberal political causes. He was also a member of the Board of Americans for Democratic Action. In his memory, donations may be made to: JCC, Manhattan, 336 Amsterdam Avenue, NY, NY 10023. Services will be private.

title: For 2 Asian firms, move to high end is central in drive for piece of Europe
Transit Aides Want Direction on Safety Help
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - The top transit security officials from New York, Los Angeles and Washington told a House panel on Tuesday that more federal money was not their only urgent need. They were desperate, they said, for advice on which of the dozens of antiterrorism devices that companies were trying to sell them actually worked.

title: Beauty and Terror Abide for People Caught in War
description: The acrid fog of war is palpable in Pirjo Honkasalo's magnificent documentary, "The 3 Rooms of Melancholia," one of the saddest films ever made. The movie, which opens today in New York, is evidence that when a director-cinematographer with a poet's vision photographs the material world, ordinary human faces and landscapes can leave impressions that transcend any words that might describe them.

title: Simon Property and Morgan to Develop Retail in China
description: SHANGHAI, July 26 - The Simon Property Group, one of the biggest real estate and shopping mall developers in the United States, said Tuesday that it had formed a partnership with Morgan Stanley and a state-owned Chinese company to develop about a dozen shopping centers in China.

title: Dutch bank's Italian bid may live
World Briefing: Europe; Middle East; Asia; The Americas; United Nations
description: EUROPE

title: General Motors to Sell Consumer Auto Loans to Bank of America
description: DETROIT, July 26 - General Motors said Tuesday that it would sell up to $55 billion worth of consumer car loans to Bank of America over the next five years.

title: Bloggers Register Cheers for Success
description: "Wow. God, please preserve these seven astronauts."

title: Michael Vatikiotis: Death in Jakarta
Agency Adopts Park Plan for Brooklyn Waterfront
description: State officials approved a draft plan yesterday for an 85-acre waterfront park near Downtown Brooklyn that would include playing fields, marinas, restaurants and offices, and 1,200 units of luxury housing.

title: Whose Bags Should Be Searched? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Knew a $10 Bill Had Such a Nice Bouquet?
description: DECADES ago, when people in wine-producing countries routinely drank a few glasses with every meal, vast amounts of wine were made quickly and cheaply. It was sold for pennies -- make that francs, lire and pesetas -- to be consumed right away. Most of it was utter swill: thin and sour, or thick, raisiny and volatile.

title: Peugeot's earnings veer off course
In a Stockpot, Home Brew Beats Store-Bought
description: ALL stocks are useful, and a good vegetable stock is a fine weapon to add to your culinary arsenal. I wouldn't argue that its flavor is better than that of meat stock, but it certainly is different -- cleaner, fresher and lighter -- which makes it especially good in summer dishes like vegetable risottos and cold soups.

title: Minutemen at Our Borders (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Timing of Hearings and Vote Stalls Confirmation Talks
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - Senator Arlen Specter, the Republican chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, said Tuesday that negotiations with Democrats had stalled over the timing of confirmation hearings and a final vote on nomination of Judge John G. Roberts to the Supreme Court.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BORUM, JOHN FRANKLIN (JACK)
description: BORUM -- John Franklin (Jack). Of Huntington, NY, died of a stroke June 27, 2005. Born and raised in California, he was a W.W. II veteran serving in Okinawa and the Philippines with the 86th and 96th Infantry Divisions. He was the loving husband of Joan Penrose-Borum for 50 years, and the loving father of twins, Trevan, an attorney, and Jenifer, a writer. He was a devoted educator and administrator, with the New York Institute of Technology for 27 years and the Oakland, California Public Schools for 18 years. Private family services were held. A memorial service will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church of Cold Spring Harbor, August 25, 2005, at 11 AM. Donations to the American Stroke Association.

title: Briefly: Plan seeks to protect children in war zones
In American orchestras, more women are taking the bow
McGraw-Hill Posts 18% Profit Increase
description: The McGraw-Hill Companies, owner of Standard & Poor's and BusinessWeek magazine, said yesterday that second-quarter profit rose 18 percent amid rising demand for schoolbooks and debt ratings.

title: China bars new movesfor yuan anytime soon
War Reporting for Cowards
In Greece, strikes over 'unjust' change
Mubarak expected to stand again as president
Learning From Lance
description: There is no doubt that Lance Armstrong's seventh straight victory in the Tour de France, which has prompted sportswriters to rename the whole race the Tour de Lance, makes him one of the greatest U.S. athletes of all time. What I find most impressive about Armstrong, besides his sheer willpower to triumph over cancer, is the strategic focus he brings to his work, from his prerace training regimen to the meticulous way he and his cycling team plot out every leg of the race. It is a sight to behold. I have been thinking about them lately because their abilities to meld strength and strategy -- to thoughtfully plan ahead and to sacrifice today for a big gain tomorrow -- seem to be such fading virtues in American life.

title: The Shuttle Returns to Duty
description: It was a relief to see the shuttle Discovery rise with a roar from its launching pad at Kennedy Space Center yesterday and glide smoothly into space, but disquieting to learn that a protective tile may have been damaged. There was no shaking the anxieties raised by the remembrance of past shuttle tragedies -- the breakup of the Challenger as it rose into the skies in 1986 and the disintegration of the Columbia as it re-entered the atmosphere in early 2003. Yesterday's ascent was only the first hurdle in a flight whose main goal is to get seven astronauts up into orbit and back again safely. Only then can this pivotal mission be deemed a success.

title: BMW to begin building American base in 2006
China Says It Does Not Plan More Revaluation
description: BEIJING, July 26 - Just days after China modestly revalued its currency and did away with its longstanding peg to the American dollar alone, the nation's central bank issued a statement Tuesday denying that there were any plans for further revaluation of the currency.

title: Inquiry opens into trading of Danone stock

Orderly on Broadway      As a native New Yorker and avid theatergoer, I've also noticed the phenomenon of long entrance lines for many theater performances (''Avenue Queue,'' by Richard Schickel, Op-Ed, July 20).
description: The usual process in the past was for the early arrivals to mill about under the theater marquee and then squeeze in en masse as the doors opened, at least 30 minutes before the printed curtain time.

title: An artist, a filmmaker and their creations
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: China Stresses That It Does Not Plan A Further Revalution of the Yuan Just days after China modestly revalued its currency and did away with its longstanding peg to the dollar, the nation's central bank stated that there were no plans for further revaluation of the currency. [Page C1.]

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MURPHY, CHARLES E.
description: MURPHY--Charles E. Artist, seventy-two, of New York City. Died July 23, 2005, of cancer at The Jacob Perlow Hopice, Beth Israel Hospital. Painted the decades-long series of oils-on-linen, "New York Impressions." His paintings reveal the changing cityscape through his palette of mood-setting color illuminated by crystalline light. His most recent solo exhibition was at The National Arts Club, January-February 2005. He was a graduate of The Yale School of Art and Architecture, and served in the U.S. Army. Beloved brother of Eileen M. Blessington, of Virginia Beach, VA, and Raphael R. Murphy, Jr., of Chappaqua, New York. Also survived by five nieces and nephews, twelve grand nieces and grand nephews, and business partner, and former wife, Jo Anne Murphy. Charles is the son of the late Raphael R. Murphy, a New York City Magistrate, and the late Madeline G. Murphy. Cremation will be followed by burial at Calverton National Cemetery, Riverhead, New York. A Memorial will be announced. Contributions may be made to The Jacob Perlow Hospice, 9 Nathan D. Perlman Place, New York, New York 10211-0122.

title: News Analysis:Arroyo plan seen as a diversion
Rivalry at the top stalls reform in Ukraine
World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Envoy To U.S. Steps Down In Scandal
description: South Korea's ambassador to the United States, Hong Seok Hyun, resigned following allegations that he was involved in channeling illegal campaign contributions in the country's election for president in 1997. Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

title: Minutemen At Our Borders      Re ''Lock and Load'' (column, July 23):     Sarah Vowell assumes that when people take on problems the government cannot solve, they must be childish. But those who illegally enter a country attack the very essence of a nation: its sovereignty.
description: These Minutemen citizens policing our borders are performing theater, to draw attention to a problem that is destroying the core of our culture. Or does Ms. Vowell imagine that more than 10 million illegal immigrants is a minor problem?

title: Correction
description: An article last Wednesday about wineries and restaurants in Walla Walla, Wash., misstated the name of a restaurant. It is the Creek Town Cafe, not the Town Creek Cafe. The article also misstated the surname of a local winemaker. He is Christophe Baron, not Byron.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TILLES, NORMAN
description: TILLES--Norman. The Officers, Board of Directors and staff of The American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of our esteemed, long-time Board member, Norman Tilles, whose steadfast support for JDC's efforts attests to his abiding concern for humanitarian needs and the welfare of Jewish communities around the globe. He served his home community of Providence as President of the Jewish Federation of Rhode Island, and he worked selflessly on behalf of those in need of refuge as Board President of HIAS (the Hebrew Immigrant Aide Society). We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Florence and to the entire Tilles family. May his memory be for a blessing. Judge Ellen M. Heller, President Eugene J. Ribakoff, Chairman of the Board Steven Schwager, Executive Vice President

title: Whose Bags Should Be Searched?      Your editorial says the bag searches should not end in a matter of weeks. I could not disagree more.     First, these searches will be totally ineffective in stopping a determined bomber.
description: Also, you talk about riders getting used to the searches, like the ones at airports. Let's be clear. What they would be getting used to is nothing less than the erosion of their civil liberties, their freedom of movement in the public space.

title: Files From 80's Lay Out Stances of Bush Nominee
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., July 26 - As a young lawyer in the Justice Department at the beginning of Ronald Reagan's presidency, John G. Roberts advocated judicial restraint on the issues of the day, many of which are still topical, documents released Tuesday by the National Archives show.

title: Explosives Detector at Newark Airport Is Expected to Reduce Pat-Down Searches
description: The federal Transportation Security Administration has installed an explosives-detection machine in Terminal A at Newark Liberty International Airport. It should eliminate the need for most pat-downs of passengers who are selected for more thorough searches.

title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Junta Gives Up Asean Chair
description: Under pressure from its neighbors and critics in the West, the military government in Myanmar, formerly called Burma, agreed with obvious reluctance to forgo its turn as chairman of the 10-member Association of Southeast Asian Nations in 2006. The United States and the European Union have said they will not attend meetings of the association if they are conducted under the auspices of a country they have condemned for repression and human rights violations. The chairmanship for 2006 will be taken by the Philippines. Seth Mydans (IHT)

title: Recipe: Prosciutto-Wrapped Peaches
description: Time: 10 minutes

title: Commerzbank linked to Russia money-laundering inquiry
Cheap Wines With a Difference Cozy Up to Tomatoes in Different Guises
description: INEXPENSIVE red or white wines will keep lunch or dinner within the budget, for sure. But if they are real finds, not cheap jug wines, they are the blessed answers when it comes time to set the bar for a summer cocktail party. Though wines like the sauvignon blancs or Ctes du Rhne we liked so well are not above being poured into plastic glasses, they really deserve better treatment. Use stemware, and your guests will think even better of them.

title: Minutemen At Our Borders      The real story of this nation is not that we are latently violent but that we as a people are slow to rise when challenged.
description: No, we don't automatically default to violence. Lest we forget, the deity did not confer freedom on Americans -- it was fought for and won dearly at the hands of farmer militiamen and regular soldiers.

title: Small Trade Pact Becomes a Big Political Deal
description: WASHINGTON, July 26 - It is a small trade agreement, affecting a volume of American exports about equal to those from New Jersey.

title: Great Start by Hernndez All for Naught for Nationals
description: ATLANTA, July 26 - If the Atlanta Braves cannot be unseated this season, then when?

title: In Poland, a culture revitalized
Examination Finds No Serious Concerns So Far on Discovery
description: HOUSTON, July 27 - NASA continued to examine the tiles and panels that protect the shuttle Discovery for launching damage on the crew's second full day on orbit, but while there is evidence of debris and some damage to a tile, nothing has yet emerged as a focus of serious concern, a mission manager said.

description: DENVER, July 26 - If the Mets needed one more reminder not to do anything rash at the trading deadline, not to be seduced by a veteran with questionable health in the throes of a potential pennant race, Victor Zambrano will take the mound here Wednesday night against Colorado.

title: Other Views: The Nation, Frankfurter Allgemeine, Times of India
Rise in Sales at Amazon Helps Shares
description: Amazon.com, the online retail giant, reported yesterday that its profit had declined 32 percent in the second quarter, mainly because of income tax expenses. Sales rose sharply, though, and its shares jumped in after-hours trading.

title: Heavy Jail Terms Handed Down in Vast French Pedophile Trial
description: PARIS, July 27 - Heavy jail sentences were handed down today in a pedophile case involving 65 adults accused of abusing 45 children in the central French city of Angers.

title: Trivial to Some and a Comedy to Others, a Ballet Revels in the Past
description: Ah, well, the Bolshoi Ballet is in town and can't escape its past so here's another Soviet ballet. But "The Bright Stream," which opened a three-performance run Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a very different work in nearly every respect from "Spartacus," which ended its run on Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Saturday about Michael Gibson, a trombonist and orchestrator of musicals, misidentified the version of "Grease" he orchestrated. It was the motion picture, not the Broadway production.

title: Playola
description: Perhaps the question is this: If you were a disc jockey or a radio station manager, would the chance to play blackjack with Celine Dion in Las Vegas induce you to put her single "I Drove All Night" on the air more often? Or would you find yourself wondering why a music giant like Sony BMG felt it needed to support a wealthy singer's new record with badly disguised bribes? The latter thought will occur to many who read the e-mail correspondence gathered by Eliot Spitzer, New York's attorney general, whose investigation of Sony BMG's payola practices ended this week with a $10 million payment.

title: Ex-Aide on Periphery of Leak Inquiry
description: POUND RIDGE, N.Y., July 25 - From the road, it is barely possible to see the home where Ari Fleischer lives. Tucked away behind a secured fence and a thicket of shrubbery, Mr. Fleischer, the former White House press secretary, is where he wants to be these days: nearly invisible.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILLIES, BREWSTER T. (BRUCE)
description: GILLIES -- Brewster T. (Bruce). Of Old Brookville, LI, suddenly on July 26, 2005. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of James T. (Wendy). Proud grandfather of Morgan Elizabeth (Meg). Dear son of the late John W. and Dorothy T. Loving cousin of Forrest (Kip) Towl. Charter member of the North Shore Rotary Club. Friends may visit at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, LI Friday, 3 to 5 and 7 to 9:30 PM. Service Saturday, 10:30 AM, St. Johns of Lattingtown. Interment private. In lieu of flowers a scholarship fund is being established for the benefit of Morgan Elizabeth Gillies.

title: U.S. firms join China mall surge
The Desire for Tallest Building Persists
description: Correction Appended

title: I.R.A. to Give Up Violence in Favor of Political Struggle
description: The Irish Republican Army has given up its armed struggle for a united Ireland, agreeing to turn solely to political methods, an American businessman said yesterday after being briefed on a statement expected from the guerrilla group later this week.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Saturday about Blue Barron, a band leader in the swing era, misidentified the university he attended. It was Ohio University in Athens, Ohio -- not Ohio State, in Columbus.

title: 16 killed in Baghdad bombing; Rumsfeld in surprise visit

Setting More Places at the Organic Feast      A tomato off the stalk tastes better than those set in plastic and mirrored by two others of the same shape and size. Does this have anything to do with wealth or ethics?
description: Going back in history, the poorest people, at least those outside cities, used locally grown produce. When I was small, my mother was assisted by W.I.C. -- which many greenmarket vendors accept -- and we ate well. As an autumn ritual, my father, my brother and I went into the woods and picked mushrooms for sauces and canning.

title: Right Now, Johnson Looks Like Himself
description: If Randy Johnson retired today, he would be elected to the Hall of Fame on the first ballot with plenty of room to spare. Johnson came to New York with a gaudy rsum, and the Yankees sometimes seem to be paying him for his past.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SOMMER, RUDOLPH
description: SOMMER--Rudolph. Loving husband of Evelyn, father of Peter, Cathy, and Timothy, grandfather, brother, and uncle, died peacefully on July 24, 2005 in Stamford, Connecticut. Born in Lemberg, Poland (now Lvov, Ukraine) in 1925, he was graduated from City College, CUNY; Brooklyn Law School; and the Palmer School of Library Science. A veteran of WWII, he practiced law for forty years, after which he became a dedicated teacher at the University of Bridgeport, where he was scheduled to teach in the fall. His worldly goods were his family, his books, and music. He was an enthusiastic, but noncompetitive tennis player, attentive sports fan, and lively actor in community theater. He was a uniquely selfless human being. For service details, call Leo P. Gallagher & Son Funeral Home at 203-327-1313.

title: U.S. Tries a New Approach In Talks With North Korea
description: BEIJING, July 26 - The Bush administration appeared to show signs of new flexibility in talks with North Korea on Tuesday, with American and North Korean diplomats meeting here at length to discuss the delicate question of how aid or energy assistance may be provided to the North as it begins the process of dismantling its nuclear weapons program.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CENSOR, JACQUES
description: CENSOR--Jacques. We extend heartfelt condolences to Dr. Monique Katz on the loss of her beloved father, a kind, sweet and modest family man. As an officer of the Mozes S. Schupf Foundation, together with her husband Mordecai, Dr. Katz carries on the lofty values of Jewish tradition and ethics that she learned from her father. We will always be grateful for the Foundation's exemplary support of our Dept. of Radiology and its sponsorship of the Well Baby Nursery. May Monique, her brother Walter Censor and the entire family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. American Committee for Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem Erica Jesselson, Chair Menno Ratzker, President Dr. Jonathan Halevy, Director General Lee Weinbach, President, National Women's Division

title: It's Hard to Watch as Mets Go Down Looking in Colorado
description: DENVER, July 26 - The Mets are that rare team to come to Coors Field and find a hitting slump.

title: As Did O.A.S., Bank Resists a Candidate Backed by U.S.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, July 26 - First the Organization of American States, now the Inter-American Development Bank? For the second time in three months, the Bush administration is meeting stiff resistance in Latin America to the candidate that the United States favors to head a regional organization.

title: Twins Have No Cure for What Ails Their Offense
description: Randy Johnson nicked Shannon Stewart's foot with his second pitch last night to give the Minnesota Twins an immediate base runner. Stewart jogged to first base to start the game against the Yankees innocently. He never budged. Hardly any of the other Twins made it those 90 feet.

title: Roundup: Powell may misschampionships
Paid Notice: Deaths   HERTZBERG, SIDNEY
description: HERTZBERG--Sidney. The Board of Governors and members of Inwood Country Club record with sorrow the passing of Sidney Hertzberg, beloved husband of Irene. We extend deepest sympathy to the family. Allan S. Sexter, President Peter Davidson, Secretary

title: An Iraqi-American Helps to Keep Soulful Music From Baghdad Alive
description: Correction Appended

title: Recipe: Marinated White Anchovies With Basil and Lemon Zest
description: Time: 5 minutes plus 10 minutes' resting

title: Ignoring U.S., Chalabi Pursues Attempt to Fire Hussein Judge
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 26 - Aides to Deputy Prime Minister Ahmad Chalabi said Tuesday that they planned to move forward with demands for the dismissal of the judge who has led the investigations of the mass killings committed under Saddam Hussein, ignoring American calls for restraint.

title: Wallace, Retiring After 25 Years, Was Nascar Before Nascar Was Cool
description: Stock-car drivers never seem to want to sit in one place for too long. Rusty Wallace will take a break this weekend from his last pursuit of a Nascar Nextel Cup series championship, but only because there is no race. He plans to drive fast, anyway.

title: World Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Van Gogh Killer Jailed For Life
description: A court concluded that the murder of the Dutch filmmaker Theo van Gogh last November was a "terrorist attack" intended to frighten politicians and the public and sentenced the man who carried it out to life in prison with no possibility of parole, the harshest penalty possible. The defendant, Muhammad Bouyeri, a 27-year-old Dutch citizen of Moroccan descent, admitted in court that he had killed Mr. van Gogh, a critic of radical Islam, on an Amsterdam street, and said he would do it again. Mr. van Gogh was shot at least six times and his throat was cut. A letter left on his body threatened a Somali-born member of Parliament, Ayaan Hirsi Ali. "Theo van Gogh was, in the eyes of the accused, a so-called enemy of Islam and had to die," the court said. The killing set off arson attacks against mosques and Muslim schools and strained relations with the country's immigrant Muslims. Gregory Crouch (NYT)

title: National Briefing | Education: New Head For Mellon Foundation
description: The Andrew W. Mellon Foundation named Don M. Randel, 64, the president of the University of Chicago since 2000, as its next president, effective July 1, 2006. He is to succeed William G. Bowen, 71, who has held the post since 1988. Mellon distributed $186 million in grants last year, with a primary focus on higher education and scholarship, arts and performing arts, libraries, and the environment. Karen W. Arenson (NYT)

title: U.S.-Afghan force kills up to 40 Taliban militants
Senate Panel Approves Bill to Fully Fund Pension Plans
description: The Senate Finance Committee approved legislation yesterday that would require companies to fully fund their traditional pension plans and give some airlines 14 years to pay off their obligations.

title: At Montreux, digging for pocket change
Figs by the Basket From a City Rooftop
description: For the past few summers, the fig trees on the roof of the Vinegar Factory, 431 East 91st Street, have provided their owner, Eli Zabar, with enough fruit for his personal use. But this year he has hit the jackpot with a crop of green and Mission figs large enough to sell in the store, $2.50 for a basket. Scott Bieber, his chef at Taste, the restaurant in Eli's Manhattan at 1411 Third Avenue (80th Street), is using the figs to make a rich confit served with artisanal cheeses ($11), a fig cake with a jam filling ($8) and a custardy trifle ($8).

title: Australia, U.S. plan alternative to Kyoto Protocol
Paid Notice: Deaths   SHATAN, NORMA ALTSTEDTER
description: SHATAN--Norma Altstedter. Died on July 26th, 2005 after a valiant four year battle with cancer. Born July 18th, 1932 in Flushing, NY, Norma was the beloved mother of Gregory Shatan, Gabrielle Shatan, Jessica Heslin and Jeremy Shatan, and mother-in-law of Deborah Elkind, Seymour Pardo, Terence Heslin and Karen Capucilli. Norma was also a loving grandmother to Nicholas, Maximilian, David, Sarah, Jacob (who predeceases her), Hannah and Noah. The widow of Chaim Shatan, MD, she is also survived by her sister, Joan Joseph of Los Angeles. A lifelong resident of NYC, Norma also kept a house near Stockbridge, MA. Norma's liveliness attracted many friends who knew her as an avid skier, tennis player and jazz fan. Her love of skiing took a professional turn some 15 years ago when she became an instructor at Butternut Basin in Great Barrington, MA. Norma was an accomplished artist, co-founding the Prince Street Gallery in 1970. Her 12th solo show was in October 2004. Norma studied art history at Goucher and received her MFA from Columbia University in 1983. Her cotranslation of Wolfflin's "The Sense of Form in Art" was her thesis. All who knew Norma will miss the warmth and brightness she brought to their lives and choose to remember her getting that last run in after the lifts had closed, experiencing the fullness of the life she enjoyed so much. Services Thursday at 11:45 at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

title: M.T.A. Is Expected to Postpone Vote on Railyard Bid
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to postpone a vote today to select a winning bid to develop the Atlantic railyard near Downtown Brooklyn, two people connected with the authority said yesterday.

description: NORTHWEST

description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,770 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

description: For Minor League Umpires, Long and Lonely Road The umpire Barry Larson preparing balls before a game between the Corpus Christi Hooks and the Midland RockHounds in Corpus Christi, Tex. Minor league umpires work long hours for subsistence wages, hoping for the chance to move up to the majors. SPORTSWEDNESDAY, PAGE D1

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, HAROLD
description: HOROWITZ--Harold. Beloved husband of Florence. Devoted father of Charlotte. Loving grandfather of Jacob and Amanda. Dear brother of Esther. Services were private.

title: How the Fear of Terror Itself Fueled a Tour Bus False Alarm
description: The concerns over a possible terror attack on a New York city tour bus emerged just before noon on Sunday, when a supervisor with Gray Line, the bus company, approached a police captain in Midtown Manhattan to tell him that five suspicious men had just boarded one of the company's famous red double-decker buses, No. 320.

title: Whose Bags Should Be Searched?      The best way to make random searches while preserving civil liberties seems obvious to me: dogs. Trained dogs are reportedly better than most machines at detecting explosives, and they are indifferent to ethnic background or any other grounds for discrimination.
description: I suspect that training dogs costs less than training, equipping and paying overtime for officers. If there aren't enough trained dogs, let's get started.

title: Suspect is identified in Egypt resort attacks
Police arrest London bomb suspect
Police Debate if London Plotters Were Suicide Bombers, or Dupes
description: LONDON, July 26 - Within hours of the July 7 attacks here, many British police and intelligence officials assumed that the four bombers had intended to die with their bombs.

title: Indictment Says East Side Priest Funneled $800,000 to Himself
description: A Roman Catholic priest was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $800,000 from his Upper East Side church, prosecutors said.

title: Outdoor Life Climbs Along With Armstrong
description: The final stage of the Tour de France on Sunday generated a 2.1 cable rating and attracted 1.7 million viewers, records for the Outdoor Life Network, which has carried the Tour since 2001. It was also the most-watched program in the network's history, thanks to Lance Armstrong's winning his seventh consecutive Tour.

title: Brazilians demand arrest of London officers
A Very Cool Podcast Service
description: OK, now this is totally and unbelievably cool.

title: An Analyst Receives a Time Out From Altera
description: For the 25 years that Tad LaFountain has been a technology stock analyst on Wall Street, he has often written negatively about the strategies or prospects of the companies he followed. Not once did a company retaliate, he said.

title: Setting More Places at the Organic Feast      Re ''Don't Get Fresh With Me!'' (Op-Ed, July 22):     Julie Powell seems to think that eating fresh, organic food is a luxury open only to the ''elite.'' If she spent more time at farmers' markets and Whole Foods stores, she would see that all the shoppers are not ''privileged.'' Surely the increase in the number of organic farms is not driven solely by a prosperous population.
description: And is it too elite of me to mention the harm that growing food that is sprayed and genetically altered causes to the environment and the workers? We should be grateful to the farmers who have taken risks by going organic and who spend long hours growing and marketing their wares.

title: Man in Millennium Bomb Plot Gets 22 Years
description: SEATTLE, July 27 - An Algerian man who planned to blow up Los Angeles International Airport on New Year's Eve in 1999 was sentenced to 22 years in prison today.

title: Nissan Sales Climb 12%, Pushed by Demand in U.S.
description: TOKYO, July 26 - Nissan Motor, the No.2 automaker in Japan, reported robust sales growth in its most recent quarter, helped by strong demand in the United States despite an aggressive sales campaign by General Motors.

title: A Bit Of Italy, To Go
description: Tempo Restaurant and Wine Bar, a sophisticated Mediterranean spot in Park Slope, Brooklyn, has added Tempo Presto, a bright little takeout shop, in the adjacent storefront at 254 Fifth Avenue (Garfield Place). The shop sells sandwiches of tuna nioise; Buffalo chicken and blue cheese; and porchetta (roast suckling pig) with hot peppers and greens. Desserts include brownies and lemon bars from the restaurant's kitchen and creamy Italian gelati in a dozen flavors: (718)636-8899. FOOD STUFF

title: Commercial Schools Lobby for Relaxation of Rules
description: WASHINGTON - For several years, the Career College Association has been doggedly trying to sway members of Congress about the intentions of its members -- private, postsecondary schools, institutes, colleges and universities that provide career-specific educational programs.

title: Krispy Kreme Loses in Fight Over Supplies for Franchisees
description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts, struggling to avoid a bankruptcy filing and come up with a plan to revive its business, is running into a new problem that threatens to drain more cash from the company.

title: Setting More Places at the Organic Feast      Farmers' markets and chefs who create seasonal menus based on local produce support the small farmer in America, who is predominantly a truck, or vegetable, farmer. Without these local markets, those small farmers would be largely extinct.
description: Participating in the local economies that keep these farms alive is a real virtue, not an imaginary one.

title: Mexican Judge Throws Out Genocide Charge
description: MEXICO CITY, July 26 - A judge has thrown out charges of genocide against former President Luis Echeverria and his interior minister, dealing a severe blow to the efforts of the administration of President Vicente Fox to hold high-ranking officials accountable for the killing of political dissidents in the late 1960's and early 1970's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DWORETZ, MILDRED
description: DWORETZ--Mildred, at home, on July 24, at 92 years of age. Profoundly loved wife of the late Philip L. Dworetz. Beloved mother of Susan and Peter Ralston, Linda and Dan Baron, and Steven Dworetz and Susan Taylor. She was the adored "Nanny" of her grandchildren, Bob and Merritt Rollins, Laura Marlin, Carrie Baron, Debra Baron, Charles Dworetz, and Rawley Dworetz, and of her greatgrandchildren, Alex and Lucy Rollins, Julia and Sarah Marlin, and Sierra Lieb. To our bereft family and to her many friends she was a constant source of love, encouragement, sympathy, and understanding. She was a woman of valor, intelligence, and wisdom, with a wideranging and lively interest in many subjects. Her generosity was boundless. We will remember her warmth and kindness forever.

title: In Reagan's White House, a Clever, Sometimes Cocky John Roberts
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif., July 26 - A sliver of John G. Roberts's voluminous files from his years as a junior White House lawyer reveals a young man with a facile mind and a sharp and sometimes smart-alecky tongue.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Summer School Tallies
description: A slightly smaller percentage of New York City third graders assigned to an intensive summer school program are attending this year, despite Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's threat that they would be held back if they failed to score high enough on citywide reading and math tests. An average of 79 percent of the 8,691 third graders enrolled in the program, called Summer Success Academy, have been attending on a daily basis, city education officials said yesterday. Last year, average attendance was 84 percent. Officials said yesterday that 79 percent of fifth graders -- also subject to the promotion rules -- have been attending summer school. Another 829 third graders and 467 fifth graders who were urged to attend summer school never enrolled. Students can retake the reading and math exams in August even if they did not attend classes. David M. Herszenhorn (NYT)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart on Sunday listing hate crime statistics for New York City referred incorrectly in some copies to the number of such crimes from 2000 through 2004 in which swastikas were reportedly present. It was 497, not 514. (Go to Article)

title: In Europe, abortion foes gain support, and funds
Profit surges 29% for BP as oil prices rise
U.N. Begins Relocating Uzbeks Displaced by Fighting
description: MOSCOW, July 27 - The United Nations today began relocating hundreds of Uzbek refugees who had sought sanctuary in Kyrgyzstan, moving them from a camp near the Uzbek border to the Kyrgyz capital, from where they were expected to airlifted from the country soon.

title: Growth in Wireless Unit Lifts Verizon's Profit
description: Verizon Communications, the country's largest phone carrier, said yesterday that its profits rose 18 percent in the second quarter, lifted by the sale of its operations in Hawaii and continued growth in the company's wireless group.

title: Where Japan Is a Point of Departure
description: THE new restaurant Taku recently served an interesting dessert, a chilled strawberry soup with savory challenges to its essential sweetness, like pinches of salt and pepper, a splash of white vinegar, a goat cheese panna cotta in the center and, around that silken island, a scattering of anise hyssop. The result was as engrossing and pleasurable as it was pretty.

title: Corrections
description: A picture on Sunday with the Focus chart on the Spotlight page, about baseball, carried an erroneous identification from Getty Images and was published in error. It showed Einar Diaz, the backup catcher for St. Louis -- not Yadier Molina of the Cardinals, who is the leading National League catcher in throwing out base stealers.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about the ballet dancer and director Adam Cooper referred incorrectly to Matthew Bourne's 1995 "Swan Lake," in which he appeared. While the ensemble of "swans" was comprised of only men, it was not an all-male production.

description: To the Editor:

title: Egypt Absolves 5 Pakistanis in Bombings
description: CAIRO, July 26 - Egyptian officials said Tuesday that five Pakistani citizens wanted for questioning in connection with the bombings of the resort at Sharm el Sheik had nothing to do with the attacks and that it appeared the deadliest terrorist strike in the country's modern history was carried out by its own citizens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDMAN, ADELE
description: GOLDMAN--Adele, of Hollywood, Fl., died July 25, 2005, sister of Ruth Popkin and Jeanette Plotsky, niece Louise Popkin, nephews Michael Popkin and David Plotsky. Private services.

World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Sharon's Son To Be Indicted On Corruption Charges
description: Attorney General Menachem Mazuz announced that he would indict Omri Sharon, a member of Parliament and the son of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, today on allegations of violating campaign finance laws, forging corporate documents, breaching trust and lying under oath, according to an online report by the newspaper Haaretz. The accusations relate to acts allegedly committed during Ariel Sharon's bid for chairmanship of the Likud Party, as well as during his term as prime minister. Omri Sharon has said he will give up parliamentary immunity and face the charges in court. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: Connecticut Casino Hopes to Save Online Game
description: HARTFORD, July 26 - The Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, which operates the Foxwoods Resort Casino on its reservation in eastern Connecticut, said Tuesday that it hoped soon to resume a new online game that the state has shut down out of concern that it is a form of Internet gambling.

title: Biztech: Some phones don't connect for Japanese, particularly foreign ones
Paid Notice: Deaths   HIRSCHHORN, JACK
description: HIRSCHHORN--Jack 84, on July 26, of Palm Beach, FL. He was the Executive Vice President of Alexander's Department Stores for over thirty years and a recipient of the Bronze Star from the U.S. Army during active service in World War II. Survived by his beloved wife of almost sixty years, Ruth, loving children Mark and (Lynne) and Peter and (Laurie), adored grandchildren Andrea, Eric, Samantha and Jeremy. Services are Thursday, 10:00 AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel W-150 Rt. 4 East, Paramus, NJ.

title: OFF THE MENU
description: With more than 200 seats, Nobu 57, 40 West 57th Street, will double your chances of scoring a table, compared to its older siblings in TriBeCa, Nobu and Nobu Next Door. There is a soaring ground-floor bar area for cocktails, sake and tidbits before or instead of dinner. At the new place, which is to open tomorrow, NOBU MATSUHISA, right, the chef and an owner, will serve his crowd-pleasers, including miso-glazed black cod, at tables on the upper level; in a few weeks he will open a 12-seat hibachi and shabu-shabu station. A sushi bar and a private dining room complete the picture: (212)757-3000.

title: Corrections
description: A highlights entry in the Television section on Sunday for "Hacker's Transformation," a four-part "Cyberchase" mini-series that began on Monday, misstated the daily broadcast time on Channel 13. It is 5 p.m., not 4:30.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIDDELL, JANE HAWLEY HAWKES
description: LIDDELL -- Jane Hawley Hawkes, age 97, died peacefully at home July 20, 2005 of complications of a stroke. She had remained passionate and involved with her family and her causes until last week. The widow of Donald M. Liddell, Jr., with whom she had celebrated 59 years of marriage, she is survived by her daughter, Jane Liddell Bass, and her son and daughter-in-law, D. Roger Brooke and Florence Liddell, of New York City, and four grandchildren, Steedman L. Bass of Cambridge, MA, Margot S. Bass of Takoma Park, MD, Alice Liddell Rooke of Bloomfield, CT and Torrey B. Liddell of New York City. She was predeceased by one granddaughter, Catherine H. Bass. Burial was in Baltimore on July 25. A Memorial Service will be held September 16 at noon at St. James' Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Liddell Memorial Garden at National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East 71 Street, NY, NY 10021.

title: Terrorist in '99 U.S. Case Is Sentenced to 22 Years
description: SEATTLE, July 27 - In a blow to the United States government, a federal judge here sentenced an Algerian man on Wednesday to 22 years in prison for plotting to bomb the Los Angeles International Airport during the 2000 millennium celebration. The term was 13 years short of what prosecutors had sought.

title: Music and Marshmallows, in Sync
description: Blue Man Group has been around so long and played so many cities that its easy to forget that its roots are in the New York performance art scene of the 1980s. Created by Matt Goldman, Phil Stanton and Chris Wink, the three earless mutes glistening with blue paint performed in tiny salons and downtown spaces like La MaMa E.T.C. and P.S. 122. One of the first public appearances was when the Blue Men held a funeral for the 80s in Central Park, which, of course, was a very 80s thing to do.

title: Heavy Prison Terms in France for 62 Pedophiles
description: PARIS, July 27 - Long sentences were handed down Wednesday in a pedophilia case involving 65 adults accused of abusing 45 children in Angers in central France.

title: A Keyboard That Eases Hand Strain (After You Hand Over $495)
description: Repetitive strain injury may be the scourge of the modern computerized workplace, but the engineers at Maltron Keyboards have been working on solving the problem since 1977. This British firm makes ergonomic keyboards to reduce strain on the hands of the tapping masses.

title: Metro Briefing | New Jersey: Trenton: Railroad Fined $2.5 Million
description: State environmental regulators have fined the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway Corporation $2.5 million for its violations involving the handling of solid waste at five transfer sites in North Bergen, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey said yesterday. A railroad spokesman, Tom O'Neil, said that the company has complied with all federal regulations that govern railroad operations and that the company planned to meet with state regulators to discuss the issue.

title: Back in the Spotlight on Judicial Nominee
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - The last time Senator Charles E. Schumer tried prying answers out of John G. Roberts about his legal views was in 2003, when the Judiciary Committee held hearings on Mr. Roberts's nomination to the federal appeals court.

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Local Police Return To Streets Of Violent Border City
description: A month after federal agents seized control of Nuevo Laredo, the city's police officers again began patrolling its violent streets in new uniforms and patrol cars. A third of the force has been fired for corruption and links to drug trafficking, but the drug-related shootings that have plagued the city for months have continued. At least 39 people have been killed since the federal takeover last month, which followed the new police chief's killing and the local police opening fire on a group of federal agents sent in to restore order. The violence has caused the United States to issue three warnings just this year to tourists thinking of traveling to border cities. James C. McKinley Jr. (NYT)

title: Efficient Medical Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Queens: Boy Killed In Crash
description: A 15-year-old boy was killed last evening when the S.U.V. in which he was riding slammed into a support piling and flipped onto its roof just off Northern Boulevard on 126th Street in Flushing. The driver, Edgar Romero, 28, of Jackson Heights, was charged with driving while intoxicated and taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, where he was listed in stable condition. The police said that beer was found in the car. Two other passengers, Leslie Pena, 30, and a 38-year-old whom the police did not identify, were also injured. They were taken to New York Hospital in Queens. Ms. Pena was charged with possession of controlled and dangerous substance, the police said. She told the authorities that she was from Florida, but is staying with friends in New York, and that she and the others in the car had just met in a karaoke bar. The dead boy's name was not released because his family had not been notified. Janon Fisher (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KENLY, WILLIAM S. III.
description: KENLY--William S. III. MoMA's Department of Film and Media remembers a generous friend, a wonderful film historian, and guest curator of several film exhibitions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIPKIND, LESTER
description: LIPKIND--Lester, 90, of Babylon, NY, on July 26, 2005. Cherished husband of Frieda; devoted father of Carol, Stuart (Ellen), Andrew (Amy), Alan (Liz); proud grandfather of Ruben, Hanna, Sara, Ethan, Eric, Jess, Talia; dear brother of Marvin, Vivian Sanders, the late Sylvia Hudes, and the late Jeanne Ostrow.

title: On The Street: Then
description: IN the summer of 1991 stretchy second-skin dressing, then a provocative, disco-inspired look built on leggings, cat suits and stirrup pants, migrated from below 14th Street to the rarefied precincts of Fifth and Park Avenues. Worn alone or as an underpinning to flyaway shirts and diaphanous dresses, body-huggers have re-emerged in recent seasons as a raffish element in the Hollywood-influenced ragpicker look. West Coast style setters like Kirsten Dunst and Mischa Barton have been sighted wearing contemporary variations under floor-sweeping gowns and miniskirts.

title: When the Profile Fits the Crime
description: IN response to the serial subway bombings in London, Mayor Michael Bloomberg prudently ordered the police to start searching the bags of New York's subway riders. But there will be absolutely no profiling, Mr. Bloomberg vowed: the police will select one out of every five passengers to search, and they will do so at random, without regard for race or religion.

Rendell," at the Grolier Club in Manhattan, referred incompletely to the founding of Boonesboro, in Kentucky. Daniel Boone led the expedition that established it; he was not the sole founder.

National Briefing | West: California: Energy Measure Ordered Back On Ballot
description: The State Supreme Court ruled that an initiative by consumer advocates to re-regulate the state's electricity market should appear on the November ballot, reversing an order last week by a state appeals court that found the measure "unquestionably invalid on its face." The Supreme Court said the validity of the measure, known as Proposition 80, "need not and should not be determined" before the election. If approved, the measure would give broader powers over utilities to the State Public Utilities Commission. Dean E. Murphy (NYT)

Danny Simon, Who Wrote Comedy for TV, Is Dead at 86
description: Danny Simon, a veteran television writer and teacher whose comedy writing partners over the years included Mel Brooks, Larry Gelbart, Woody Allen and his younger brother, the playwright Neil Simon, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Portland, Ore. He was 86.

title: Study Links Stem Cells in Marrow to Fertility
description: Women may possess a hidden cache of stem cells in the bone marrow that constantly replenish the ovaries with new eggs, a new study suggests.

description: COHEN--Rose. My beloved grandma, you are always in my heart. Freya

title: McDonald's Reaches Deal With Studio
description: McDonald's announced yesterday that it was joining with DreamWorks Animation SKG to create promotions based on the studio's film characters, including Shrek.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page news analysis article on Tuesday about a decision by the Teamsters and the Service Employees International Union to leave the A.F.L.-C.I.O. misstated the 10-year growth in the service union. Membership has risen to 1.8 million from 1.1 million -- not to 1.1 million from 900,000.

title: If East Weds West, Who Disciplines the Plants?
description: GLEN ECHO, Md. - HOLLY SHIMIZU, the executive director of the United States Botanic Garden in Washington, loves the six-foot bronze fennel that lounges like a shaggy dog against the white picket fence bordering her front yard here.

title: Trainers, Bettors, Horses and Officials on Edge at Saratoga
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 27 - Some things here remain timeless, like the robust opening day crowd that joined the track announcer Tom Durkin in the traditional first-race call of "and they're off at Saratoga," and the field of classy 2-year-olds that ran for a rich purse in the feature.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Lennon' Opening Delayed
description: "Lennon," the biographical musical about John Lennon, has delayed its Broadway opening at the Broadhurst Theater by 10 days to work out kinks in the show. The $7 million production, which was roughed up by critics in a recent tryout run in San Francisco, is now scheduled to open Aug. 14. Chris Boneau, a spokesman for the show, also said that the British director David Leveaux was working as a "friend of production," offering advice on the show's structure and characters. JESSE McKINLEY

title: Economic reform lags in Ukraine
In Vioxx Trial, Battle Nears Over Coroner's Testimony
description: ANGLETON, Tex., July 27 - A scientist for Merck acknowledged under pointed questioning on Wednesday that the company did not change its warning label on the painkiller Vioxx for two years after a study showed that it sharply increased the risk of heart attacks compared with an older drug.

title: More praise from doctors for green tea
Arts, Briefly; 'Rock Star' Gets a Boost
description: For the second night in a row, CBS won both in total viewers and among 18-to-49-year-olds in Nielsen's estimates. Its Tuesday night military crime show, "NCIS," continued to do well in summer repeats, drawing 8.73 million viewers. Following that, "Big Brother" brought in a slightly smaller audience (8.37 million), but scored higher than "NCIS" in the 18-to-49 demographic. Those strong numbers bolstered the languid "Rock Star: INXS" at 10 p.m. The episode of "Rock Star," in which the contestants performed, was No. 2 in its hour with 6.28 million viewers, but it took first place among adults 18 to 49. Its main competition was NBC's "Law & Order: Special Victims Unit" rerun (7.56 million), which lifted NBC into second place for the night in households. Also at 10 p.m., the ABC miniseries "Empire" came to a conclusion, but only 4.33 million viewers know what that conclusion was. KATE AURTHUR

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Man Pleads Guilty To Fraud
description: Mark Edwards, who was charged in December with forgery and fraud in connection with his offers of low-cost publicity for small businesses in Brooklyn, pleaded guilty yesterday to second-degree forgery, prosecutors with the Manhattan district attorney's office said. Mr. Edwards, who entered his plea just before his trial was to begin, faces a sentence of 2 1/2 to 5 years in state prison. He agreed to pay $17,000 in restitution. Prosecutors had charged that Mr. Edwards was paid to promote a series of small businesses, but did not deliver on his promises. His lawyer, Robert Fisher, had no comment yesterday. Michael Brick (NYT)

title: People: Mel Gibson, Jennifer Garner, Jodie Foster
Getting Dirty, Hoping for Rebirth
description: Soil. Israel. The mythical phoenix, rising from the ashes in rebirth. Combine these elements, and it is difficult to think of anything other than Israel's impending pullout from the Gaza Strip. As the five members ofthe Vertigo Dance Company of Israel assembled around a circular platform covered in dark, rich earth for the beginning of "Birth of the Phoenix," the metaphors were inescapable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NAVON, SHULAMITH EISNER
description: NAVON--Shulamith Eisner. Jewish Life Network/Steinhardt Foundation mourns the untimely passing of our dear colleague Shulamith Navon. We will miss the friendship, compassion and generosity of this extraordinary woman who served as Executive Director of the Steinhardt Family Foundation in Israel. May her family and multitude of friends be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Michael H. Steinhardt, Chairman Rabbi Yitz Greenberg, President Rabbi David Gedzelman, Executive Director
