title: A Black Hole, Represented as a Delicate Golden Veil
description: In this month's blazing heat, Maximilian's Schell, an installation at the gallery Materials & Applications, is casting the most buzzed-about bit of shade in Silver Lake. The airy vortex-shaped canopy was created by Benjamin Ball, far right, an architect and former production designer, and Gaston Nogues, near right, an architect and product designer at Frank Gehry Partners. They started developing the project over a year ago. They cut 504 pieces of amber Mylar with a computer-controlled machine, fitting them together to create a structure that shades and defines the gallery's outdoor space, which they lined with hay bales for seating. "We wanted to create an environment that would be used by the community," Mr. Gaston said. The hay, he said, "added to the casualness of the space." The project's name, Mr. Ball said, pays homage to the "obsessive, control-freak personality" of Dr. Hans Reinhardt, a character played by Maximilian Schell in the film "The Black Hole." "The sheer repetition of the project requires that sort of intensity and focus," he said.

title: National Briefing | Washington: Companies Approved For Airport Screening
description: The door opened a bit more for the return of private security screeners at airports, as the Transportation Security Administration announced that 34 companies had been designated qualified to provide passenger and baggage screening at airports nationwide, including government contractor giants Lockheed Martin and Northrop Grumman. To date, only five cities have private screening forces, under an agreement set up at the time of the federal takeover of security in the wake of the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001. Eric Lipton (NYT)

title: City Council's Meter Plan Restores Free Sunday Parking
description: Correction Appended

title: For banking vitality, Europe turns eastward
Heat, Good Cheer, Jagged Music and Even Some Melody
description: HOLMDEL, N.J., July 26 - This year's version of Ozzfest came to the arena and parking lot of the PNC Bank Arts Center on Tuesday for the first of two dates here. The traveling festival celebrates heavy metal music and culture, which is perhaps too grand a way of acknowledging the vendors who generously offer to sell you bumper stickers bearing discourtesies and panties emblazoned with pithy phrases touting their contents.

title: Some Say Macy's Tunnel Doesn't Go Far Enough
description: The idea of another train tunnel under the Hudson River came a step closer to reality yesterday, but not without impassioned arguments against its ending at a station below Macy's flagship store in Midtown.

title: Heat Wave? Who Cares? It's Fall Online
description: IT is nearly August, and the fall fashion season is fast approaching. What better time to add some fresh Web sites to your shopping repertory?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERG, DORIS
description: BERG--Doris. The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved member, Doris Berg. On behalf of all our members, we express our deepest sympathy to her husband, Jack, and their entire family. Earle Yaffa, President Dale Winston, Secretary

title: Police in Egypt expand hunt for bomb suspects
Locals With Hard Shells, Like the Oysters They Grow
description: "Oyster Farmer," the debut feature by the Australian writer-director Anna Reeves, soaks up the lush scenery and rich history of New South Wales's Hawkesbury River while recycling an all-too-familiar setup: urbanite struggles with a small-town existence but winds up falling for the lifestyle - and the local girl. But this darkly humorous, sometimes even raunchy film mostly eludes a typical cutesy, feel-good formula.

title: Currencies: Dollar's 3-day rise comes to abrupt end
A tale of 2 film festivals in Korea
Driftwood as Art, by an Unseen Hand
description: AMONG the many mysteries of the universe -- Stonehenge, black holes, alien corn mazes -- the driftwood sculptures along the Hudson River in Manhattan have to qualify among the most intriguing, at least to the many bikers, joggers, fishermen and picnickers who pass them every day.

title: I.R.A. Renounces Violence in Potentially Profound Shift
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 28 The Irish Republican Army declared an end on Thursday to a 36-year campaign of violence against Britain that was aimed at unifying Northern Ireland with the Irish Republic.

title: Corrections
description: The Short Cuts column in Business Day on Saturday, about recycling products that may be harmful to the environment, misstated the availability of a rebate program for Apple iPods. Only Apple Stores participate, not all stores that sell iPods.

title: British Police Round Up 9 More Suspects
description: LONDON, July 28 - Sir Ian Blair, London's chief police officer, warned today that terrorists who tried to set off bombs on July 21 could strike again, and the police arrested nine more men in early morning raids in south London.

title: INSIDE
description: Transportation Measure And Energy Bill Advance House and Senate negotiators cleared the way for major transportation legislation, and the finishing touches were put on an energy bill as Congress raced to wrap up for the summer. Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, said he would not try to force a vote in the next few days on a repeal of the estate tax. PAGE A22

title: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico and Brazil Cut Growth Forecasts
description: Mexico and Brazil, Latin America's two biggest economies, lowered their growth forecasts for this year as higher interest rates and a slowdown in United States manufacturing curb demand. Brazil's gross domestic product will expand 3.4 percent in 2005, less than previous forecasts of 4 percent and 4.32 percent, the Budget and Planning Ministry said on its Web site. Mexico's economy will grow as much as 3.75 percent in 2005, down from a previous forecast of growth of as much as 4 percent, the central bank said in its quarterly inflation report.

title: Terrorist in '99 U.S. Case Is Sentenced to 22 Years
description: SEATTLE, July 27 - In a blow to the United States government, a federal judge here sentenced an Algerian man on Wednesday to 22 years in prison for plotting to bomb the Los Angeles International Airport during the 2000 millennium celebration. The term was 13 years short of what prosecutors had sought.

title: Solving the Mystery of a Mac's Sounds
description: Solving the Mystery Of a Mac's Sounds

title: Amazon profit is hurt by tax expenses
Police in Britain Hold Somali Man in 2nd Bomb Plot
description: Correction Appended

title: With a Disturbing Vision of Utopia Lost, a Forgotten Modernist Is Remembered
description: SALZBURG, Austria, July 27 - The Austrian composer Franz Schreker was one of the great dreamers of early-20th-century music, a cartographer of distant sonic utopias and a prophet of their demise. His fame reached its height in German-speaking Europe around 1920, when his operas rivaled Strauss's in popularity, and he was hailed by some as the true heir to Wagner. But he was crushed by the double blow of shifting Weimar fashion and then the Third Reich.

title: Choosing Words Carefully
description: In todayAs column, I reviewed AppleAs iTunes 4.9 software. AIt manages the complete chain of podcasting commandAfinding podcasts, subscribing to them, and transferring them to your iPodAbeautifully and simply,A I wrote.

title: Hip and modern in West Hollywood
The Call Goes Against Replays at the U.S. Open
description: A chair umpire's flubbed call overshadowed all the well-executed shots in Serena Williams's three-set loss to Jennifer Capriati last year in the quarterfinals of the United States Open. At deuce in the first game of the decisive set, Williams stroked a backhand down the line that was ruled good by the linesman, only to have the call overruled by Mariana Alves, the chair umpire.

title: Arroyo accused, again, of foul play
Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on July 19 with an article about the new power brokers in China misidentified the law school from which Charles Li, chief executive of J.P. Morgan Chase China, graduated. It was Columbia, not Cornell.

title: 2 Panels Cite U.S. Problems in Stabilizing After Combat
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - Two new studies by independent panels are harshly critical of the way the United States government prepares for stabilization missions after major combat, such as in Iraq, and they place the blame on an interagency process that does little to harness the various departments and agencies for unified action.

title: A Couple of Englishmen in an Opium Dream: Voil! They're Ancient Egyptians
description: How much you enjoy "The Pharaoh's Daughter," the Bolshoi Ballet's grand 19th-century Orientalist fantasy that opened a four-performance run at the Metropolitan Opera House on Thursday night, depends on what expectations you bring to it.

title: Briefly: Deadly heat wave in U.S. to continue into 3rd day
Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on July 21 about entrepreneurs who have started fitness and health businesses misspelled the surname of the founder of Spa Chicks on the Go. She is Marie Scalogna, not Scalonga.

title: Text of Embargoed E.P.A. Report
North Korea Seeks U.S. Aid Before It Halts Its Nuclear Program
description: BEIJING, July 27 - North Korea on Wednesday criticized an American plan to defuse the nuclear crisis, saying the proposal demands too many steps toward dismantling the country's nuclear program before providing any corresponding aid or energy assistance, a senior United States official said in a background meeting with reporters.

title: Ballmer Tries to Restore Luster of Microsoft's Stock
description: REDMOND, Wash., July 28 - Microsoft's chief executive, Steven A. Ballmer, made a concerted effort today to persuade Wall Street analysts that the world's largest software publisher will again become a growth stock.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page news analysis article on Tuesday about a decision by the Teamsters and the Service Employees International Union to leave the A.F.L.-C.I.O. misstated the 10-year growth in the service union. Membership has risen to 1.8 million from 1.1 million - not to 1.1 million from 900,000. (Go to Article)

title: 13 guilty in tunnel fire that killed 39
Paid Notice: Deaths   APPLETON, SHELLEY
description: APPLETON--Shelley, humanitarian. Friend and husband of Jean Dubinsky Appleton, beloved father of Ryna and grandfather of Emma. Interment private. A memorial service will be arranged. He labored all his life for workers' rights and social welfare. His journey and selfless dedication involved him in many causes here and abroad. He was Secretary-Treasurer of the ILGWU, Chairman of the World ORT Union, President of The Tamiment Institute. He earned the Bronze Star for distinguished intelligence work in WWII. Always a loyal friend and true gentleman. Donations may be made to the World ORT Union, 126 Elbert St., London NW1 7NE England.

title: Let He Who Is Without a Reality Show Cast the First Sneer
description: David E. Kelley must be crying out for an intervention.

title: Asia's 'surprising resilience'
Yahoo Is Wooing I.B.M. Technical Talent
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif., July 27 - Yahoo plans to announce Thursday that it is recruiting scientists who pioneered an advanced search-engine technology at I.B.M.'s Silicon Valley research laboratory.

title: Yogurt and Champagne
What's Summer Without Good Books?
description: To the Editor:

title: Calendar
description: Garden Open House

title: Heard the One About Cameron? So Has He
description: DENVER, July 27 - For Mike Cameron, the countdown to the trading deadline started six months ago.

title: After Truly Scary Night, Relieved Clement Exhales
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., July 27 - Matt Clement said he had seen enough players injured to know that he should remain as motionless as possible after a line drive off the bat of the Tampa Bay Devil Rays' Carl Crawford clipped his right ear and crashed into his head.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   ROSE, HAZEL (SANDERS
description: ROSE--Hazel (Sandersamansky)/d, on July 27, 2005. Beloved wife of Bert. Cherished mother of Arthur Zamansky and Diane. Dear sister of Sam Sanders and the late Corrinne Levine. Much loved grandmother, aunt and friend.

title: Australia, U.S. and Asian nations offer Kyoto substitute
Energy Shortage
description: The energy bill that has been six years in the making and is nearing the president's desk is not the unrelieved disaster some environmentalists make it out to be. But to say, as President Bush undoubtedly will, that it will swiftly move this country to a cleaner, more secure energy future is nonsense. The bill, approved by a House-Senate conference early Tuesday morning, does not take the bold steps necessary to reduce the nation's dependence on foreign oil, and it also fails to address the looming problem of global warming.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CENSOR, JACQUES
description: CENSOR -- Jacques. The Board of Directors, members and staff of JOFA, the Jewish Orthodox Feminist Alliance, extend their heartfelt condolences to our valued Board members Dr. Monique Katz and Gail Katz upon the loss of their beloved father and grandfather, Jacques Censor. Nicky, a most devoted daughter, spent the last year traveling back and forth to Israel to be with her father. May her kibud av be an example to the entire Jewish community and may the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Carol Newman, President Robin Bodner, Executive Director

title: Pataki Says He Won't Seek a 4th Term
description: ALBANY, July 27 - Gov. George E. Pataki declared New York "a better state than it was 10 years ago" as he announced here on Wednesday that he would not seek a fourth term as governor in 2006 so he can "follow a new path, find new challenges."

title: The Mouse That Saved the Planet
description: IN Northern California where I live, a socially conscious life is encouraged. Park a Prius downtown, and you are likely to find upon return a note on the windshield that says, "Thank you for saving the planet." A sign at my local market informs me the strawberries were grown in the same county. And recently when I stuck my hand into the grab bag at a neighborhood party, I pulled out a bottle of certified organic, cruelty-free hand soap infused with grapefruit seed extract.

title: British Request Fails to Stop ABC Report on Bomb Investigation
description: The British police asked ABC News on Tuesday to withhold a report showing images of what were said to be unexploded bombs found in a car used by the July 7 bombers and of the inside of a subway train mangled in the attacks, a network official said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARTSHORNE, R. KIMBALL
description: HARTSHORNE--R. Kimball, of Pt. Pleasant, New Jersey, died on July 26. He was 85. A professional pianist, he was a successful entertainer as well as a composer and arranger. During World War II he served in the U.S. Army and was awarded a Bronze Star. After World War II he left the music world for the banking business. He retired as vice president of the Livingston National Bank in Livingston, New Jersey, in 1980. He is survived by his wife, Tina; a son, Christopher of Washington, NJ, and two grandchildren. His son, William, died in 1988. A memorial service will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church in Bay Head, NJ, on August 1st. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Monmouth Players C/O Duryea Navisink Library Association, PO Box 302 Atlantic Highlands, NJ 07716.

title: Amid inquiry, AMRO controls Italian bank
Iran's President Says Nuclear Work Will Resume
description: TEHRAN, July 27 - Iran's departing president said Wednesday that the country's senior officials had decided to resume activities at one nuclear site no matter what incentives were in a European proposal expected next week.

title: Santana May Be a Marked Man, but He Earns High Marks
description: For Johan Santana, the left-handed pitcher for the Minnesota Twins, last season's Cy Young award was followed by a huge new contract, honors from the president of his native Venezuela and lofty expectations from everyone.

title: Police Swoop Down on 2 Streets in Birmingham to Seize Suspects
description: BIRMINGHAM, England, July 27 - The police appeared at Heybarnes Road in this city at 4:30 a.m. on Wednesday. They evacuated the block and then arrested a man suspected of being one of the bombers in the failed bomb attacks in London on July 21. He was taken to London.

title: NASA SUSPENDING SHUTTLE FLIGHTS OVER FOAM DEBRIS
description: HOUSTON, July 27 - NASA suspended further flights of the space shuttle fleet on Wednesday after determining that a large piece of insulating foam had broken off the external fuel tank of the Discovery shortly after liftoff Tuesday morning, the same problem that doomed the Columbia and its seven astronauts in the last mission, two and a half years ago.

title: Weill, Chairman of Citigroup, TellsEmployees He Won't Leave Now
description: Sanford I. Weill told Citigroup employees yesterday that he now planned to stay on as chairman until his scheduled retirement next April, ending an internal debate that spilled outside the bank over his plans to leave and start a private equity fund.

title: On Melrose Avenue, Chic Has a Brazilian Accent
description: After three years of selling Brazilian furniture at his showroom, Espasso, in Long Island City, N.Y., Carlos Junqueira has opened a West Coast shop on a trendy block of Melrose Avenue, around the corner from the new Marc Jacobs store. Mr. Junqueira, seated below on a table made from a slice of peroba wood, represents several Brazilian designers, including Ricardo Fasanello, whose white leather Gaivota chair, to Mr. Junqueira's left, is $3,900. The small painted iron table, by the same designer, is $797. Espasso (8444 Melrose Ave., 323-653-0023; espasso.com) also sells midcentury pieces and accessories like wooden bowls and handmade ceramics, which start at $300. CURRENTS: FURNITURE

title: Critics wondering whether IMF chief is up to task
A haven rejected for 2 London suspects
Iraqi Boy, After Dream Trip to U.S., Hates to Go Home
description: After two fairy-tale weeks of pampering, shopping, top-notch medical care and limitless Pepsi, Ayad al-Sirowiy, the 13-year-old Iraqi boy who came to the United States to get the tattoo of war removed from his disfigured face, is going home.

title: Thais tap demand for outsourced medical care
Girls in Boots: Attitude on the Hoof
description: SAUNTERING down Lafayette Street in downtown Manhattan last week, Ayesha Habib was not about to rustle up anything more substantial than an iced mocha grande. But you would not have known that from her gear. On a day when the temperature rocketed to 98 degrees, Ms. Habib, a part-time fashion stylist, wore a T-shirt and rolled-cuff combat shorts -- and a pair of rusticated cowboy boots. Tropical heat be damned.

title: New York and Boston
description: Kleinfeld Bridal, for many years a vast Brooklyn emporium for brides-to-be, will open the doors of its new home in Chelsea tomorrow. The store, below, will continue to offer an array of designer wedding gowns, veils and other nuptial essentials. (Shopping is still by appointment only.) At 110 West 20th Street, (212)352-2180.

title: No Immunity for the Gun Industry
description: At a time when Congress is grappling with critical measures, including military and energy issues, the Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, has seen fit to catapult a special interest bill for the gun lobby to the head of the legislative queue. The bill would grant gun manufacturers, distributors and sellers an unreasonable degree of immunity from civil suits by families or communities harmed by gun violence. It would even require that lawsuits already filed be dismissed.

title: Futuro Flashback: The Prefab From Another Planet
description: RICHARD PISANI caught his first glimpse of a Futuro house beside a lake in Illinois in the early 1980's, outlined against the setting sun. "I was just out cruising and there it was in some subdivision," Mr. Pisani said, "like a prop from a sci-fi movie."

title: Public Relations' Purpose
description: To the Editor:

title: Wal-Mart Sues Ex-Executive, Saying He Stole $500,000
description: Wal-Mart Stores filed a suit yesterday against Thomas M. Coughlin, a former vice chairman, seeking to void his retirement package and to recover funds the company said he fraudulently siphoned from the company.

title: Hands-Free Walkie-Talkies for the Whole Family to Use
description: It's amusement park season, which poses the usual tough family logistics. The iZon walkie-talkies from Global American Technologies can help. These devices are truly hands-free: a small switch on one side allows you to transmit with a flick of the wrist. A central button on the face turns on talk mode.

title: On just another street, terror in Birmingham
How a Cultural Building Divides the Trade Center
description: TWO lines on a plan drawn two years ago may have settled the fate of a cultural building at the new World Trade Center.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   COOPER, DR. EUGENE
description: COOPER--Dr. Eugene. 66, distinquished North Shore physician, died on July 26, 2005. He is survived by his beloved wife Marcia, his loving children Stacy Cooper and Dr. Kimberly Cooper, his sons-inlaw Andrew Lottman and David Elbaum, and his adoring grandchildren Julia, Lily and Carly. Dr. Cooper dedicated his professional life to the care of his patients and devoted his private life to the love of his family and friends. Services will be held on Friday, July 29 at 11 A.M. at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, NY. In his memory donations can be made to the Melanoma Immunotherapy Fund, care of Dr. Jedd Wolchok, Memorial Sloan Kettering, 1275 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021. COOPER -- Dr. Eugene. Temple Sinai of Roslyn records with profound sorrow the death of our devoted member. We extend our condolences to his family. Rabbi Michael A. White Rabbi Norman Kahan, Emeritus Charles Berman, President

title: IRA says its 35-year 'armed campaign' is over
Net Profit Slips at Honda, but Global Sales Increase
description: TOKYO, July 27 - Profit at Honda Motor fell 3.1 percent in the latest quarter on derivatives losses, but sales rose in all its major markets and the company raised its profit outlook for the financial year.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Arts yesterday with an article about a musician who is trying to keep an ancient Iraqi musical tradition alive omitted part of the photographer's name. The photographer was Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times.

description: In percent

title: House Approves Free Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, July 28 - The House of Representatives narrowly approved the Central American Free Trade Agreement early Thursday, allowing President Bush to put his signature to the nation's biggest reduction of trade barriers in more than 10 years.

title: New York, New Jersey and Connecticut
description: NEW YORK

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIVACK, EDITH
description: SPIVACK--Edith. The partners, associates and staff of Marcus & Pollack LLP, express their sorrow on the passing of Edith I. Spivack. She was a great public servant to our city, and a friend and mentor to us and also for many others over her long and distinguished career. We extend our sincere condolences to her family and to the past and present members of the New York City Law Department who will miss her. Joel R. Marcus Robert M. Pollack Philip H. Azarian SPIVACK--Edith. Edith was an original. The best advocate New York City has ever had and the best it will ever have. She will be missed by all who knew her. Our sincere condolences to her family. Hubert J. Brandt Richard A. Steinberg Willa I. Lewis SPIVACK GOLDSTEIN--Edith I. Died peacefully on July 26, 2005, at age 95 after a brief illness. Barnard College Class of 1929, Columbia Law School Class of 1932. She devoted her career to the City of New York during more than 70 years as an attorney with the New York City Law Department, Office of the Corporation Counsel. Widow of Bernard H. Goldstein, Columbia Law School Class of 1930, mother of Rita Christopher Frank of Madison, CT, and Amy G. Bass of Port Washington, NY, mother-in-law of Dr. H. David Frank and Geoffrey A. Bass, grandmother of Alistair and Gordon Christopher, Jonathan and Susanna Bass, and grandmother-inlaw of Federica Roncini Christopher, Catherine Martin Christopher and Dr. Chloe A. Zera. At her request, funeral services will be private. There will be a memorial celebration of her life in September. Donations in Edith's memory may be made to the Edith I. Spivack Fund for Women in Law and Society at the New York County Lawyers' Association or to Columbia Law School.

title: EADS raises its profit forecast
Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, EDWARD H.
description: BENENSON--Edward H. Benenson Capital Partners mourns the loss of our distinguished cousin, partner and friend, Edward H. Benenson. We will miss his intelligence and sense of humor. We have over 60 years of business and friendship together to remember and cherish. We will always remember a man who was greatly dedicated to his family, business and philanthropy. Those of us who know how special he was share the sense of loss with his family, friends and associates. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Benenson family. Bill Benenson Fred Benenson Lawrence B. Benenson Richard A. Kessler James E. Stifel BENENSON--Edward H. The Noyac Golf Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Edward and extends sincere sympathy to his wife Gladys and other members of his family. Sincerely, Ted Ronick, President Richard Mathew, Secretary

Jeff Jacoby: The two-way street of intelligence failures
Paid Notice: Deaths   MCCOOL, GERALD ANTHONY, S.J.
description: McCOOL--Gerald Anthony, S.J. Survived by many loving cousins. Reposing at the Jesuit Community Chapel at Loyola Hall at Fordham University on Thursday from 3-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Loyola Hall, Friday at 11AM. For information contact Farenga Brothers, Inc, Directors 718-654-0500.

title: New Knicks Coach Promises Only to Do His Best
description: The New York Knicks introduced Larry Brown as their new head basketball coach today with the hope that Mr. Brown's history of turning mediocre teams into title contenders will work for a storied franchise that has struggled in recent years.

title: Funds in brief: Group seeks to block U.S. governance rule
Paid Notice: Deaths   GILLIES, BREWSTER T. (BRUCE)
description: GILLIES -- Brewster T. (Bruce). Of Old Brookville, LI, suddenly on July 26, 2005. Beloved husband of Lillian, devoted father of James T. (Wendy). Proud grandfather of Morgan Elizabeth (Meg). Dear son of the late John W. and Dorothy T. Loving cousin of Forrest (Kip) Towl. Charter member of the North Shore Rotary Club. Friends may visit at the Funeral Home of Dodge-Thomas, Glen Cove, LI Friday, 3 to 5 and 7 to 9:30 PM. Service Saturday, 10:30 AM, St. Johns of Lattingtown. Interment private. In lieu of flowers a scholarship fund is being established for the benefit of Morgan Elizabeth Gillies.

title: A Judge in Full: The Roberts Record
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHONFELD, HERB
description: SCHONFELD--Herb. Sue, Steven, Bobby, and Michael. Our heartfelt condolences to you. We feel your pain, and know that your love and fondest memories will help you through this time. We will all miss his sense of humor, and his love of cards. We love you all. Kathy, Chris, Oliver, and Quinn SCHONFELD -- Herbert. 75, died peacefully on July 26, 2005, after a life filled with joy and happiness. He was the beloved husband of Sue, and adored father to Steven, Robert, and Michael. As successful as he was in business (President of Generation Mills), so was he in life. He was a wonderful and loving husband (married for 49 years), and father. It was with the same qualities in business, and family life, as he was with his friends: honesty, integrity, witty, and generous. He will be greatly missed by many as he touched so many of us in his own special way. Funeral services will be held Thursday 1:45 P.M. at Gutterman's Chapel in Woodbury. SCHONFELD--Herbert. The Board of Governors and the members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of our esteemed member Herbert and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Sue and his family. Board of Governors Alan Goldberg, President SCHONFELD -- Herbert. Schonfeld Group Holdings, Executive, Traders, Employees and Associates, express our sincere sympathy to the entire Schonfeld family. We are saddened about the passing of Herb. He will be greatly missed and remembered always by all. SCHONFELD--Herb. To our dear friend Steven, his beautiful mom, Sue, and his brothers, Bobby and Michael. We mourn your loss. Treasure your memories. Brad, Maggie, Ryan, Sean, CJ

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 9 P.M. (4) THE LAW FIRM -- Series premiere. So this is what David E. Kelley -- prolific creator of "Ally McBeal," "The Practice," "Picket Fences" and "Chicago Hope" -- has been up to. It's a reality show in which 12 actual lawyers try cases in actual courts, and the lawyer who does the worst job each week (as judged by Roy Black, fifth from left) is eliminated. We're talking First Amendment cases, wrongfuldeath suits and neighborhood disputes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bloomberg Criticized For Skipping Debate
description: State Democrats attacked Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday for refusing to participate in one of the first televised debates of the mayor's race, set for tonight in Brooklyn. Organizers said that all of the other major candidates have agreed to attend, including Thomas V. Ognibene, whom Mr. Bloomberg's campaign has been working to prevent from getting on the Republican ballot. "New Yorkers deserve a mayor who will come out from behind his multimillion-dollar ad campaign and have a substantive discussion with his opponents," said Herman D. Farrell Jr., the state Democratic chairman. Bill Cunningham, a strategist for the mayor's campaign, dismissed the criticism as political posturing and said that Mr. Bloomberg had debated primary and general election opponents in 2001 and would do so again. Diane Cardwell (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A highlights entry in the Television section on Sunday for "Flip This House," a new A&E real estate series on Sundays at 6 p.m., misidentified the cable channel for "Flip That House," a similar series on Thursday nights at 9:30. It is the Discovery Home Channel, not TLC.

title: Meanwhile: Commemorating the Great Upheaval
Residential Sales
description: Brooklyn

title: The Rangers' New Goalie Hopes the Future Is Now
description: Al Montoya, the goaltender from Michigan who was the Rangers' first-round draft choice in 2004, signed a contract with the team yesterday, then said he was ready for whatever the success-starved franchise throws at him -- be it in New York or Hartford in the minors.

title: Pakistan Says It's Holding a Suspect in Pearl Killing
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 27 - A prime suspect in the kidnapping and killing of Daniel Pearl was arrested Wednesday by Pakistani intelligence agents, officials said.

title: Rumsfeld, in Baghdad, Presses the Iraqis On Insurgency and Writing Constitution
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 27 - Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld pressed Iraqi political leaders on Wednesday to settle their differences and agree on a new constitution quickly, and to exert more influence with Syria and Iran to force them to end support for the insurgency.

title: Music and Marshmallows, in Sync
description: Blue Man Group has been around so long and played so many cities that its easy to forget that its roots are in the New York performance art scene of the 1980s. Created by Matt Goldman, Phil Stanton and Chris Wink, the three earless mutes glistening with blue paint performed in tiny salons and downtown spaces like La MaMa E.T.C. and P.S. 122. One of the first public appearances was when the Blue Men held a funeral for the 80s in Central Park, which, of course, was a very 80s thing to do.

title: Free flow: Taking on a rail giant over logo
Watch Your Home TV. Even if You're Away From Home.
description: The VCR allowed you to watch your favorite television shows whenever you wanted, but you had to do it in front of the TV. Now comes the Slingbox personal broadcaster, which will let you watch live or recorded programs wherever you want -- on a computer.

title: Oil and Blood
description: It is now generally understood that the U.S.-led war in Iraq has become a debacle. Nevertheless, Iraqis are supposed to have their constitution ratified and a permanent government elected by the end of the year. It's a logical escape hatch for George W. Bush. He could declare victory, as a senator once suggested to Lyndon Johnson in the early years of Vietnam, and bring the troops home as quickly as possible.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Now' Series on Top Again
description: In a slow week for sales, the top spot on the Billboard album chart is the 19th and latest installment of the pop compilation series "Now That's What I Call Music!" The disc is the seventh in the series to make its debut at No. 1. Featuring songs by Gwen Stefani, Amerie, Anna Nalick, Coldplay, Keith Urban and 15 others, the album sold 436,000 copies, according to Nielsen SoundScan. That is nearly five times the sales of its nearest competitor, Mariah Carey's steady-selling "Emancipation of Mimi" (Island/Def Jam), which sold 90,000. Some familiar names round out the top of the chart: R. Kelly's "TP.3 Reloaded" (Jive), the top seller for the last two weeks, drops to No. 3, and Coldplay's "X&Y" (Capitol) holds at No. 4. But there are some unexpected debuts in the Top 10 this week. Carly Simon's latest, "Moonlight Serenade" (Columbia), sold 58,000 copies to reach No. 7 -- her highest chart ranking in 31 years, according to Billboard -- and Mary Mary, a hip-hop flavored gospel duo, is at No. 8 with a new self-titled album, on Columbia. BEN SISARIO

title: Beleaguered Former Miami Official Kills Himself
description: MIAMI, July 27 - A former city commissioner plagued by legal problems fatally shot himself in the lobby of The Miami Herald building on Wednesday, the same day that another local newspaper published lurid details of a state investigation of him.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Mets Avoid a Sweep, but Are Not Pleased
description: DENVER, July 27 - Just in case anybody thought the Mets were satisfied winning one game at Coors Field this season, first baseman Doug Mientkiewicz became the rare player to be ejected with an eight-run lead Wednesday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, CAROL RIEGELMAN
description: LUBIN -- Carol Riegelman, died on July 26 of heart failure at Lenox Hill Hospital after a very brief illnesss. She was born in 1909; graduated from Smith College in 1930; received an MA and a Ph.D from Columbia University; and was associated professionally with The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, The International Labor Organization, Rutgers University, The City of Reston, The New York Urban Coalition and The United Neighborhood Houses. She was the daughter of the late Charles A. Riegelman and the late Lilian E. Riegelman; the wife of the late Isador Lubin; and the sister of the late William I. Riegelman. She is survived by her daughter, Ann L. Buttenwieser; by her four grandchildren, William L. Buttenwieser, Carol B. Sharp, Jill B. Schloss and Peter L. Buttenwieser; by her 13 great-grandchildren; by her stepdaughter, Alice L. Everitt; by her sister-in-law, Rosalind W. Riegelman; by her two nieces, Mary A. Riegelman and Catherine R. Nathan; and by her two greatnieces. A memorial service for her will be held in the fall. LUBIN--Carol R. With deep sorrow, we bid farewell to our incredible neighbor. For the past 20 years, we were privileged to have her as a role model and inspiration. With her work at the UN and her many other interests she continued in her mid 90's to be a contributing member of society for the world at large. She will be greatly missed. We share her loss with her entire family. Gloria and Richard Kobrin

title: Alive and Thriving in the Midwest: Brawling in Cages
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 23 - When they rewind the video of the fight in the cage, all the blood will spray back into Gervis Fool Bull's nose, all the screams will be sucked into the collective chest of the sweating crowd, and the fist will snap back toward the big truck driver from Iowa who threw it, a man with a mohawk haircut who grew up fighting his twin brother in the neighborhood junkyard.

title: Laura Lippman: When Friendship Fails You
description: Baltimore - NANCY GOLDMAN rescued Laura Lippman on her first day of sleep-away camp by inviting Ms. Lippman, a newcomer, to share a bunk bed. She was 15, a scary age to join a cabin of girls who had summered together for half their young lives. But the bond was instant. From that day forward, Nancy and Laura would be best friends.

title: Culture clash, American influence
Approval Expected Today for Trade Center Rail Hub
description: In the name of security, Santiago Calatrava's bird has grown a beak. Its ribs have doubled in number and its wings have lost their interstices of glass.

title: U.S. Expresses Cautious Optimism in Tough Talks With North Korea
description: BEIJING, July 28 - The United States and North Korea met today for the third time this week in a tough session that lasted about three hours as negotiators focused on the specifics of their dispute over North Korea's nuclear program.

title: From Curbside to Canvas: The House as Muse
description: GRANT WOOD'S "American Gothic" is the most recognizable painting in the history of American art, which should make the modest Carpenter Gothic structure in the background the art world's most famous house.

title: Transit Surplus Announced, Along With Plan to Spend It
description: Buoyed by an unexpected surge in tax revenue, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it would have a surplus of $833 million this year and that it would consider using the money to create a giant platform over its West Side railyards, which it could then sell to developers for office and apartment towers.

title: A defector and a missionary, sharingtragedy
From Muslims in America, a New Fatwa on Terrorism
description: Muslim scholars in the United States and Canada plan to release a fatwa, or judicial ruling, in Washington today saying that Islam condemns terrorism, religious extremism and any violence against civilians, including suicide bombings.

title: WTO:Alarm bells ringing on trade talks
What, Her Worry?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HELD, AL
description: HELD--Al. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be mourned by the world of art.

title: Pataki Sparks G.O.P.Search for Successors
description: Gov. George E. Pataki's announcement yesterday that he would not seek a fourth term has set the stage for a realignment of political power and influence within the state Republican Party, with leaders scrambling for strategies to keep the Executive Mansion in the 2006 election and avoid being routed in other statewide races.

title: Seoul tries to break deadlock in talks
Britain arrests 4 as police explore East African link
Hip-Hop Conundrum: How Can a Pimp Be a Hero?
description: Hip-hop has managed to pull off a neat trick that has eluded most musical genres: it has grown both more mainstream and less respectable. The biggest hip-hop hits are usually filled with rhymes that have to be heavily redacted before they hit the radio stations, and rappers themselves are finding that all this radio activity scarcely makes them any less radioactive. 50 Cent sells more records in America than anyone else, yet he's so closely identified with violence and sex that no mainstream politician would go near him.

title: Business Digest
description: Chairman of Citigroup Tells Employees That He Will Stay Until Next April Sanford I. Weill told Citigroup employees that he now planned to stay on as chairman until his scheduled retirement next April, ending an internal debate that had spilled outside the bank over his plans to leave and to start a private equity fund. [Page C1.]

title: Publicis net jumps onnew clients
National Briefing | Washington: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Leaders Re-Elected
description: An unopposed John J. Sweeney was elected to a new four-year term as president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O, along with Richard Trumka as secretary-treasurer and Linda Chavez-Thompson as executive vice president. Mr. Sweeney, 71, has run the federation since 1995. Two of the largest unions, the service employees and the Teamsters, quit the federation at the convention in Chicago. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Creating Under-the-Sea Ambience
description: When the acclaimed chef Michael Cimarusti got ready to open the seafood restaurant du moment, Providence, he turned to Jennifer Prichard, a 36-year-old ceramic sculptor and installation artist, to help give the place the right visual cues.

title: An Online Artist Challenges Obscenity Law
description: In a landmark 1973 case, the United States Supreme Court defined obscenity in part as anything that "the average person, applying contemporary community standards" would find appealing only to prurient interests. But with the growth of the Internet, a difficult question has arisen: Which community's standards apply in cyberspace?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NESTER, LORETTA
description: NESTER--Loretta. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and employees of Long Beach Medical Center mourn the passing of Loretta Nester, wife of our former Chief Executive Officer, Martin F. Nester, Jr. We will remember Loretta for her efforts on behalf of the Medical Center, her support of Marty and her charming ways. We extend our deepest sympathies to Marty, sons Noel & Matthew, daughters Jeanne & Suzanne and grandchildren Nikolas, Savannah, Sophia, Olivia, Victoria and Loretta Lillian. Alfred I. Osterland, Chairman Board of Trustees Bernard Kennedy, President Board of Trustees Steven Harris, MD Chairman, Medical Staff Douglas L. Melzer Chief Executive Officer

title: Across Europe, a broad assault by abortion foes
Trance
Paid Notice: Deaths   MARCUS, VICTOR
description: MARCUS--Victor died peacefully at his home in Riverdale, New York, on July 27, 2005. He was 92 years old. A superb writer and editor, he was a retired editor for national news at the New York Times. Before that, he was an assistant national news editor at The New York Herald Tribune. A man of strong principles and beliefs, he held himself to exacting standards. He loved literature, art and music. He began writing poetry at the age of 82 and published four books of light verse. He taught himself to play the guitar and recorder and played duets with his late wife, Pearl, who accompanied him on the piano. An avid tennis player, he played three times a week until age 88. Born in Muscoda, Wisconsin, he graduated Phi Beta Kappa from the Experimental College at the University of Wisconsin with a Bachelor of Philosophy degree. Beloved husband of the late Pearl Maddow Marcus. Devoted brother of Herbert Marcus and sister-in-law Roberta Marcus. Loving father of Dr. Eric R. Marcus, Gerald and Steven Marcus and daughters-in-law Dr. Eslee Samberg, Frances Siegel and Tedda Fenichel. Cherished grandfather of Max and Pia Marcus, Jed Rosenzweig, and Sam and Adam Marcus. Services on Friday at 1PM, The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. The family will receive friends today, Thursday, from 7pm to 10pm and Friday from 3pm to 8pm at the home of Dr. Eric R. Marcus and Dr. Eslee Samberg, 37 Riverside Drive at 76th Street. His family will cherish his memory.

title: The healing power of prayer?
Nourishing the Palestinian Police
description: Anyone who has watched the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, struggle to assert control in the past few months should not claim to be surprised by a new report saying that the Palestinian Authority's security forces are divided, weak, overstaffed, badly motivated and underarmed. The survey, first reported by Steven Erlanger of The Times and the first of its kind since Yasir Arafat died, says there is no central command structure within the Palestinian security apparatus. Nor is there a formal structure to take account of, among other things, the powerful role rival clans play in various security forces, the chaotic behavior of many Palestinian fighters or the local powers in refugee camps.

title: Roundup: Real Madrid beats J-League's Jubilo
U.S. Suspects Bank Fraud by Greenwich Developer
description: GREENWICH, Conn., July 27 - A Greenwich real estate developer was arrested by the federal authorities on Tuesday on charges that he had engineered an elaborate fraud in which he had coaxed millions of dollars in new loans from banks by hiding old ones.

title: In One Stroke, Podcasting Hits Mainstream
description: EVER since Steven P. Jobs returned to Apple Computer in 1997 after a 12-year absence, his company has thrived by executing the same essential formula over and over: Find an exciting new technology whose complexity and cost keep it out of the average person's life. Streamline it, mainstream it, strip away the geeky options. Take the credit.

title: Jeans for No Body but Yours
description: IT would have been difficult for me to have had a happier childhood. Hugged, fed and educated, I suffered only one deprivation: stretch blue jeans. At age 12 this was cause for psychic lament, the absence piercing my adolescence with a longing so profound I never quite recovered. Charles Foster Kane pined for his Rosebud, Winston Churchill for his mother's love. For me it was Gloria Vanderbilt stretch jeans with the red piping down the leg.

title: Isn't It Romantic? Yes, and Edifying, Too
description: A little Liszt can go a long way, but if anyone can turn a full evening of Liszt's grandly Romantic piano music into an edifying experience, it is Leslie Howard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBLUM, MURRY
description: GOLDBLUM--Murry. We are shocked and terribly saddened by the sudden death of Murry. To his loving wife, Maxine, his 4 wonderful children, and their spouses, and his eight beloved beautiful grandchildren, we share your loss. Malka, Mannes and Ghita

title: U.S., North Korea meet one-on-one
A Constellation of Advisers and Others Starts Updating Rsums
description: ALBANY, July 27 - Gov. George E. Pataki's announcement on Wednesday that he would not seek a fourth term sent shudders through the influential circle of lobbyists, consultants and aides whose fortunes have been linked to his for more than a decade.

title: Prominent Cleric From Yemen Is Sentenced to 75 Years
description: A Yemeni cleric was sentenced in New York today to 75 years in federal prison for conspiracy to support Al Qaeda and Hamas and other charges. In a high, angry voice before Judge Sterling Johnson Jr. pronounced the sentence, the cleric, Mohammed Ali Hassan al-Moayad, protested his innocence, reciting a list of good deeds he had done in Yemen.

title: Panel Sends Judge 10-Page Questionnaire
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - The Senate Judiciary Committee sent a 10-page questionnaire to Judge John G. Roberts on Wednesday that could yield new details about his behind-the-scenes role in the Supreme Court case of Bush v. Gore, the Florida recount battle that decided the 2000 presidential election in favor of George W. Bush.

title: Text of IRA statement
Military's Opposition to Harsh Interrogation Is Outlined
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - Senior military lawyers lodged vigorous and detailed dissents in early 2003 as an administration legal task force concluded that President Bush had authority as commander in chief to order harsh interrogations of prisoners at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, newly disclosed documents show.

title: At Rocky Year 24, No Surprise That Mubarak Will Seek 6 More as Egypt's President
description: Correction Appended

title: Course of India-Pakistan Wooing Doesn't Run Smooth
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 27 - Back then, it was all peace, love and Meera.

title: Revolution on the Radio
description: Plug a set of headphones into a radio tuned to an FM jazz station. Hear the hiss at the bottom of the range and the fuzz at the top. Remember why you like compact discs.

title: ABC Defends 'Dancing' Show's Judging
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27 - After calling its "Dancing With the Stars" reality series the "phenomenon of the summer," ABC faced reporters' questions here on Tuesday about the judging process that resulted in a surprising victory for an ABC soap-opera actress, Kelly Monaco. The network acknowledged that the outcome had offended a sizable portion of the show's audience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GEWIRTZ, STANLEY
description: GEWIRTZ -- Stanley. Long time dedicated Board Member of Theatreworks/USA. The Board of Directors, Chair, Erica Gruen, and the entire staff, offer our condolences to the family. GEWIRTZ -- Stanley. Our pride in your accomplishments is surpassed only by our love. Gerry, Gene, John, Bob Friedman

title: Brown Is in Place, but Now Comes the Hard Part
description: Expectations were high and the results were dismal, so the Knicks decided to chase after the best available coach and gave him the richest contract in the league to transform an underachieving team into a winner.

title: Target Adjusts View for Runway Show
description: AS challenging as it may be to dress a bunch of models and ask them to walk in a straight line -- and it is more difficult than it looks -- the staging of fashion shows rarely calls for boastfulness. That is unless the models are expected to walk down the side of building in Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUR, PAULINE (NEE AMES)
description: SCHUR--Pauline (nee Ames). 93, died peacefully, July 25, in Philadelphia. She was the mother of Howard C. Katz and Vicki Gradess, grand mother of Betsey, Sara, Adam, Sam and Emily, greatgrandmother of Zachary, Nicholas and John Henry. She will be missed by her loving family and friends.

title: Sprint Says Its Profit More Than Doubled
description: Sprint, the telecommunications provider, said yesterday that its profits more than doubled in the second quarter, with growth being driven by adding and retaining more wireless customers.

title: Correcting an Error in Scoring Upsets a Tournament Outcome
description: In an ideal world, when winners are announced, that would be that. But at bridge tournaments scores can change for two reasons: an appeal of a director's ruling, if upheld, can alter the rankings or a scoring error may be found.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Reliance Industries Profit Surges
description: Reliance Industries, a leading oil refiner, reported a 61 percent rise in quarterly profit, helped by the lower cost of sour crude and higher fuel prices. Net profits rose to 23.1 billion rupees, or $533 million, while sales rose 23 percent, to 179.78 billion rupees, or $4.1 billion. Reliance Industries, part of the Reliance Group, is now run by Mukesh D. Ambani, who with his brother Anil recently split the group after an ownership feud. Reliance Industries runs the world's third-largest oil refinery and is based in Mumbai. Following the strong results, Reliance Industries stock rose 1 percent, to close at 698.40 rupees, and pushed the bellwether Mumbai Sensex index up to a record close of 7,605.03. Saritha Rai (NYT)

title: CONGRESSIONAL TRAVEL
description: With Representative Tom DeLay, the House majority leader, and other members of both parties facing questions about travel paid for by private groups, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert on Wednesday urged the ethics committee to develop a system to review and clear the trips of members before they embark.

title: Broadway's Havin' a Tropical Heat Wave
description: Maybe it's the air-conditioning or the advertising or even -- imagine this -- the entertainment, but Broadway is sizzling.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Polish-Belarussian Tensions Increase
description: Poland suggested it might withdraw its embassy from neighboring Belarus. The remark, made by the Polish Embassy's press attach to the Interfax news service, was a further deterioration in relations between the countries. In recent months they have expelled three of each others' diplomats, and Poland has complained about Belarus's treatment of its Polish minority. Belarus, a rigidly centralized post-Soviet state that has been sharply criticized by the West, has responded by accusing Western nations, including Poland, of plotting a revolution to overthrow President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. C.J. Chivers (NYT)

title: Bruce A. Bolt, 75, Scientist Who Improved Earthquake Safety, Dies
description: Bruce A. Bolt, a seismologist who made important observations about earthquakes in California and later helped translate the research into safer and more resilient bridges and buildings, died on July 21 in Oakland, Calif. He was 75.

title: Another Chinese Bank Has a Western Suitor
description: BEIJING, July 27 - The Royal Bank of Scotland, one of the world's biggest banks, is considering investing about $2.5 billion to acquire a stake in the Bank of China, according to a person briefed on the discussions.

title: As Maytag Chooses a Suitor, It's Not All About the Money
description: Maytag's board faces a conundrum.

title: Delta Says It Needs More Cuts; Shares Drop
description: Delta Air Lines shares plunged yesterday on a fresh warning by its chief executive that its reorganization plan was not shielding it from brutal competition, and that the airline would have to do more to avoid seeking bankruptcy protection.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FREEDBERG, IRWIN M.
description: FREEDBERG--Irwin M. The Department of Dermatology of Columbia University/New York Presbyterian Hospital mourns the death of Irwin M. Freedberg, the MacKee Professor and Chair of Dermatology at New York University. He was a charismatic and passionate physicianscientist who inspired generations of students, house officers, fellows and peers. He set very high standards for himself and those around him and his leadership of the department followed in the footsteps of his distinguished predecessors perpetuating the tradition that has made it an internationally recognized center of excellence in the field. We extend our deepest sympathy to his family. David R. Bickers, MD Carl Truman Nelson Professor/Chair, Dept of Dermatology, Columbia University

With Armstrong Out, N.H.L. May Be in at OLN
description: Correction Appended

title: Study Says Popular Herb Has No Effect on Colds
description: Echinacea, the herbal supplement made from purple coneflower and used by millions of Americans to prevent or treat colds, neither prevented colds nor eased cold symptoms in a large and rigorous study.

title: Easier Internet Calls, but Only With Vonage
description: Customers of phone services like Vonage, which convert voice signals into digital data and send them over the Internet, enjoy a number of advantages over people with traditional phone lines, like cheaper calls and fancy voice-mail and call-forwarding features. But getting started with what is known as VoIP, or voice over Internet protocol, is still a little daunting. The VTech IP-8100-2 broadband phone system can make things easier -- if your VoIP company is Vonage.

title: Baby Oil and Benzene Provide Look at Earth's Radioactivity
description: Using a telescope made of 1,000 tons of baby oil and benzene in a stainless steel tank, scientists have measured the total radioactivity of Earth for the first time, they are reporting today.

title: Trapped in the Bubble
description: IT may seem absurd that David and Christine Boals, a Manhattan couple with two young children, wound up in a $4,400-a-month rental in Chelsea.

title: In Web Posting, Terrorist Group Says Algerian Diplomats Were Slain
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 27 - Two Algerian diplomats who were kidnapped in broad daylight less than a week ago have been killed after receiving a death sentence from what was described as a religious court, a group led by the Jordanian terrorist Abu Musab al-Zarqawi said in an Internet posting on Wednesday.

title: How to Hire a Decorator
description: Q. How do I go about finding and hiring a decorator?

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption yesterday with an article about the Yankees' need for starting pitchers misstated the given name of a veteran pitcher who was released on Monday by Tampa Bay. He is Hideo Nomo, not Hideki.

title: France Tlcom wins
Edith I. Spivack, 95, Called 'Brains' of City's Law Office, Is Dead
description: Edith I. Spivack, a tireless lawyer who worked for the New York City Law Department from 1934, when few other women were government lawyers, until last year, when she reluctantly stopped showing up four days a week, died on Tuesday at St. Francis Hospital in Manhasset, N.Y. She was 95.

title: Many roles put heat on lawyer
For Spurrier, Happy Return Under SEC's Spotlight
description: HOOVER, Ala., July 27 - Urban Meyer was all business and cautious in talking about his new job as Florida's football coach. Phillip Fulmer had to explain his Tennessee players' bad behavior off the field. Ed Orgeron, the new coach at Mississippi, needed time to introduce his philosophies.

title: If You Think It, It Will Clear
description: STRESS may be inflaming your pimples. And hypnosis may help clear them up. Or deep breathing exercises. Or maybe imagining yourself lying on a beach in Aruba.

title: Congress Calls for Strict Rules on Pesticide Testing of Humans
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - Outrage over a planned program to use children from low-income Florida families for pesticide testing has led Congress to block all such tests until the Environmental Protection Agency sets strict guidelines for pesticide tests involving humans.

Survived by seven grandchildren and eight great - grandchildren. Gra duate of Hunter College, Class of 1928. Taught in NYC Schools for 35 years. Donations to Temple Judea, 2440 Esplanade, Bronx, NY 10469

title: M.T.A. to Deal Only With Ratner on Brooklyn Bid
description: Despite a higher cash offer from a rival bidder, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to enter into exclusive negotiations to sell the developer Bruce C. Ratner the rights to build an arena for the Nets and office and residential buildings over a railyard in Downtown Brooklyn.

title: In Britain, Migrants Took a New Path: To Terrorism
description: LONDON, July 27 - They came to Britain as children in the early 1990's, refugees from war and famine in East Africa looking for a haven in the West. But at some point, according to the authorities, something poisoned Muktar Said Ibrahim and Yasin Hassan Omar against the country that had taken them in.

title: E.P.A. Holds Back Report on Car Fuel Efficiency
description: DETROIT, July 27 - With Congress poised for a final vote on the energy bill, the Environmental Protection Agency made an 11th-hour decision Tuesday to delay the planned release of an annual report on fuel economy.

title: F.B.I.'s Translation Backlog Grows
description: WASHINGTON, July 27 - The Federal Bureau of Investigation's backlog of untranslated terrorism intelligence doubled last year, and the time it takes the bureau to hire translators has grown longer, officials said Wednesday.

title: Admiration abounds as Sharon and Chirac meet
Performers and Audience Get a Little Closer in Acoustical Experiment at Avery Fisher Hall
description: Performers, administrators and concertgoers who have long fretted over the acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall had a lot invested in the experiment that was tried out last night: the temporary reconfiguration of the stage. The occasion was the opening of the 39th season of the popular Mostly Mozart Festival, and the hall was packed. The dynamic French conductor Louis LangrAe directed the festival orchestra in an eclectic program featuring the starry soprano RenAe Fleming and the fine pianist Stephen Hough as soloists. With such musical news being made, PBS chose to broadcast the concert as part of its "Live From Lincoln Center" series.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brookhaven: Shipments To Resume
description: Shipments will resume today for about 65 railroad cars filled with earth contaminated with low-level radioactivity, Long Island Rail Road officials announced. The waste, excavated in the cleanup of an old graphite reactor site at Brookhaven National Laboratory, is being shipped for disposal in Utah. The project was halted last month when the Queens borough president, Helen Marshall, said that her office and various safety and health agencies had not been notified that hazardous material was moving through the community. After meetings with representatives from those agencies, the railroad said everyone agreed to resume the shipments. Bruce Lambert (NYT)

title: The rains have come and you're not married?
Pipe Down, Senators; Governor Is on the Line
description: ALBANY, July 27 - On Broadway, it might have been called Gov. George E. Pataki's conference call, a comedy in three acts.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Youth's Thumb Severed
description: Nine teenagers argued with a 17-year-old youth yesterday afternoon on Tinton Avenue in Morrisania, then chased him down and chopped off his left thumb with a machete, the police said. The victim, Robert Bill, of 2991 Eighth Avenue, was taken to Montefiore Medical Center, where doctors were determining whether they could reattach the thumb, which was recovered. The teenagers fled. Abeer Allam (NYT)

description: WEST

title: Liberty Loses Big Lead as Comets Win at 0.3
description: The Liberty returned to Madison Square Garden last night to face the Houston Comets having won three of its past four games on the road and showing few signs of fatigue from a six-day trip.

title: Yankees Sign Nomo and Keep Looking
description: The elevator stopped in the Yankee Stadium lobby yesterday, and a guard rushed over to Brian Cashman. There was a ticket problem, the man explained, and Cashman promised to solve it.

title: Insurance for Terrorism Gains Support
description: Republicans and Democrats in Congress expressed support yesterday for continuing a federal program that pays most of the insurance losses in a terrorist attack, but increasing the share covered by insurance companies.

title: After analysis, NASA calm over clipped tiles

description: TOKYO, July 28 - Sony posted a quarterly loss and slashed its annual earnings forecast today as lower global prices cut into its revenue from its core television business.

description: Filed at 9:07 a.m. ET

title: More Than 500 Reported Killed in Indian Floods
description: NEW DELHI, July 28 - More than 500 people have been killed as a result of the monsoon in western India, an Indian police official said today, and the death toll was expected to climb. Floods, landslides and building collapses were being caused by a rainfall that was the heaviest ever recorded in India in a 24-hour period.

title: Stocks: Investors cautious ahead of GDP data release
The Governor's Exit Strategy
description: Gov. George Pataki announced yesterday that he would not run in 2006 for a fourth term. This is a wise course. Not only have the governor's recent polls looked a little pallid, but Mr. Pataki also knows from firsthand experience that New York State's voters begin to tire of their leaders after a while. In 1994, that fed-up factor -- with Gov. Mario Cuomo -- helped Mr. Pataki get elected in the first place.

title: For Hard-Core Video Gamers, Big, Softly Padded Headphones
description: Communication is important in team sports -- and in all-night video games with friends around the world, when your platoon is pinned down on a ridge or aliens are trying to flank your squad. Poorly designed headsets can crackle and chafe when worn for long periods, but the PC 160 headphones from Sennheiser, which are specially designed for gaming, use extra-large padded ear caps that surround the ears instead of squashing them.

title: Success expected for China search firm's IPO
Trenton Agency Says It Has Only Enough Money for 59 of 400 School Building Projects
description: TRENTON, July 27 - Acknowledging flaws in its management and spending habits, the New Jersey Schools Construction Corporation announced on Wednesday that it had enough money left to complete only about an eighth of the projects proposed for the state's poorest districts.

title: Very Memorably Unruffled, Just Like a George Smiley
description: Alec Guinness The Authorized Biography By Piers Paul Read Illustrated. 632 pages. Simon & Schuster. $35.

title: Race for Mayor of San Diego Heads to November Runoff
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27 - A self-described surfer chick and the city's former police chief will face each other in a runoff election in November to determine the next mayor of San Diego.

Government Is Investigating 3rd Possible Case of Mad Cow
description: The Department of Agriculture is investigating another possible case of mad cow disease in a domestic cow, its chief veterinarian said yesterday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Furniture at a Discount, And You Can't Beat the Parking
description: A new open-air market called Peddler on the Roof has opened Saturdays, noon to 5 p.m., on a parking garage in Hollywood, attracting dozens of vendors of discounted home furnishings. Among them are Ziggy the Hipster, which recently displayed vintage furniture, painted yellow (above), and Libby's Vintage, which sells furniture and accessories from the 1930's to the 70's. Prices are up to 80 percent below store prices, according to Phillip Dane, who organized the market. About 40 to 70 vendors show up, a number that could swell to 300 within a year, he said. Admission is $3 but parking is free: the market sits above 1,100 spaces. Peddler on the Roof is at 1423 North Gordon Street near Sunset Boulevard; peddlerontheroof.com or (323)860-7109. CURRENTS: WHO KNEW?

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about price increases by Toyota misstated the period for figures showing manufacturers' average discount per vehicle and the percentage of the suggested retail prices represented by those discounts. The period was June 2005, not 2004.

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Divided Security Council Hears Slum Report
description: Anna Kajumulo Tibaijuka of Tanzania, the highest-ranking African woman at the United Nations and the envoy who produced a report deploring the destruction of shantytowns by the government of Robert G. Mugabe, briefed a closed meeting of the Security Council on her findings despite opposition to her appearance from African countries and China, which has close ties to Mr. Mugabe. China, along with Algeria, snubbed the meeting by sending low-ranking diplomats to occupy their ambassadors' seats. "It's the first time I've seen that," said Anne W. Patterson, the acting United States ambassador. "Since they all did the same thing, I can only draw the conclusion that it was some sort of political statement." Warren Hoge (NYT)

title: When a Simple 'Hello' Won't Suffice
description: It is a dedication to the craft of improvisation and a trenchant analysis of social mores, which is why ANDY DICK and AL GOLDSTEIN were there.

title: Before Bombings, Subway in London Had Troubles
description: LONDON, July 27 - Before the terrorist attacks earlier this month, the London subway system, the world's oldest, was already facing a creaky future.

title: Bills on Energy and Transportation Move Toward Passage
description: Correction Appended

title: Entrepreneurs Cater to Immigrants Financial Needs
description: Some weeks, Jos Edgardo Andrande makes less than $200. Other weeks, his pay tops $1,200. "But then it goes down to $500" the next week, said Mr. Andrande, 42, a job hopper from El Salvador who, for 24 years, has shuffled among delivery, electrician, restaurant and construction jobs in the United States.

title: Louvre Gets $20 Million for New Islamic Wing
description: PARIS, July 27 - In the largest gift ever to the world's largest museum, a Saudi prince agreed on Tuesday to donate $20 million to the construction of a wing for the Louvre's vast collection of Islamic art.

title: When You Have to Shoot First
description: Jerusalem - IN the summer of 1984, as we manned a hilltop observation post during my first stint of reserve duty in the Israel Defense Forces, I heard an awful story from a friend whom I'll call Eldad. Like the story of the police officer who killed an innocent man at the Stockwell subway station in London last week, this one had elements that got my liberal hackles up.

title: A Tribute to Her Mother
description: To the Editor:

title: Under Pressure, Chairman Plans to Step Down at DaimlerChrysler
description: FRANKFURT, July 28 - DaimlerChrysler said today that JA14rgen E. Schrempp, the embattled German auto titan who created a trans-Atlantic carmaker but spent years defending his trouble-prone empire, would step down as the company's chairman at the end of 2005, more than two years earlier than planned.

title: Leiter's Effort Not Enough for Yanks
description: The last time Al Leiter pitched for the Yankees at Yankee Stadium, he faced a reigning American League Cy Young award winner for the Minnesota Twins. Sixteen years ago, it was Frank Viola. Last night, it was Johan Santana.

title: FTC examines video scandal
World Business Briefing | Europe: Spain: France Tlcom Buys Amena
description: France Tlcom agreed to buy a controlling interest in Amena, Grupo Auna's Spanish mobile phone unit, for 6.4 billion euros ($7.7 billion) to become Europe's second-biggest provider of wireless services. France Tlcom, the former French phone monopoly, offered to pay cash for 80 percent of Amena, Didier Lombard, above, the chief executive of France Tlcom, said on a conference call. Including debt, the transaction values Amena at 10.6 billion euros. The takeover gives France Tlcom's Orange unit the fastest-growing wireless company in Spain and an additional 9.7 million customers, putting France Tlcom head-to-head with Telefnica Mviles and the Vodafone Group's local unit. France Tlcom also leapfrogs Deutsche Telekom's T-Mobile in the ranking of European mobile phone companies. "They were lucky this came up for sale," said Franck Hennin, a fund manager at Richelieu Finance, which oversees $2.2 billion in Paris. "It's an oligopoly situation. There's very little competition on price." France Tlcom is based in Paris, and Amena in Barcelona.

title: Many guilty of child rape after long French trial
Scientists Find Oldest Dinosaur Embryo Ever
description: For several years scientists have been finding fossilized embryos of dinosaurs from 80 million to 100 million years ago. They have now uncovered several 190-million-year-old dinosaur embryos, the oldest ever found.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column yesterday, about the Nassau County clerk's efforts to clear up a backlog of real estate documents, misspelled the writer's surname. He is Peter Applebome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   RICHTER, NATHANIEL
description: RICHTER--Nathaniel, of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of the Bronx. NYU graduate, owned Joseph Richter Inc., lighting fixture and interior design business. Survived by his loving family: wife, Anita; son, Michael, and his wife, Susan; son, Jason; daughter, Rosalyn, and her partner, Janet; and grandchildren, Leon, Sharon, David, Hannah. Private funeral arrangements. Donations may be made to Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

title: A Lawyer's Many Roles
description: When Morgan Stanley directors received a letter from a group of retired executives who argued for the ouster of Philip J. Purcell, their first call for help went to the superlawyer Martin Lipton.

title: World Briefing | Europe: France: 13 Convicted In 1999 Tunnel Fire
description: A court found 13 people and companies guilty of manslaughter in connection with a fire in the Mont Blanc auto tunnel in 1999 that killed 39 people. Two people were acquitted, and the court dropped charges against Volvo, which built the truck carrying margarine and flour that burst into flames, causing the fire. Its Belgian driver was given a four-month suspended sentence. The others convicted included the head of tunnel security, who received the most severe sentence, a six-month jail term plus two years suspended. The fire trapped cars, trucks and people and burned for more than two days. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: A Judge in Full: The Roberts Record
description: To the Editor:
