QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: "We decided it was safe to fly as is. Obviously, we were wrong."

title: German High Court Rules a State's Wiretap Law Is Unlawful
description: BERLIN, July 27 - Germany's highest court on Wednesday struck down a state law permitting wiretapping that supporters said would have let the police maintain closer surveillance of potential terrorists and other dangerous criminals.

title: For Sweet Size 16, Stylish Workout Wear
description: PLUS-SIZE women want their exercise apparel to provide coverage, comfort and a flattering cut. But they have limited choices. The average American woman wears size 16, according to a 2004 study conducted by TC2, a textile research and consulting firm, yet only a handful of companies have begun to make workout clothing that addresses the needs of larger women.

title: Iraqi President Says He Will Ensure Protection of Tribunal
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 28 - The president of Iraq said today that he would personally ensure the protection of the independent Iraqi tribunal preparing the trials of Saddam Hussein and his aides, which has been threatened with a purge of its judges, prosecutors and officials.

title: Man Dies After Being Shot With Taser in Holding Cell
description: A 35-year-old man who was shocked with a Taser stun gun while in a holding cell in a Queens police station early yesterday died a short time later, the police said.

title: Don't Tune Out the Darfur Tragedy (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Uzbek Refugees to Be Airlifted to New Havens
description: MOSCOW, July 27 - The United Nations on Wednesday began relocating hundreds of Uzbek refugees who had sought sanctuary in Kyrgyzstan, moving them from a camp near the Uzbek border to the Kyrgyz capital, from which they are expected to be airlifted out of the country soon.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Signs Of West Nile Found
description: City health officials said yesterday that mosquitoes collected in Eastchester, Woodlawn and Baychester had tested positive for the West Nile virus. The Health Department has increased surveillance and the application of larvicide in those areas, but no spraying of neighborhoods is currently planned. Officials also said that West Nile had been diagnosed in two Manhattan men who had recently traveled outside the city, and officials are trying to determine where they were infected. Neither were hospitalized and both are recovering, said the city's health commissioner, Thomas R. Frieden, above, who recommended that New Yorkers, particularly those over 50, reduce exposure to mosquitoes and use insect repellant.

title: A Good and a Bad Day for the Gotti Family
description: For the Gambino crime family, one of New York's oldest and largest, yesterday began with a surprising victory and ended, just before 6 p.m., with a demoralizing defeat.

title: 6 People From Dance Camp Are Killed in Crash in Catskills
description: A Dodge Neon ferrying a group of young people from a dance camp along a rural highway in the Catskills veered into oncoming traffic shortly before noon yesterday and slammed into a dump truck, killing all six of the car's occupants instantly, the authorities said. The driver of the dump truck was slightly injured.

title: Front to Back, TV's Get New Curves
description: Hannspree, a Taiwanese electronics company, opened its first American store this month in Beverly Hills. The 9,000-square-foot shop sells flat-screen LCD televisions designed on a "360 degree" principle, according to which the back of a product should look as good as the front. There are three lines available: Sports, which includes Yankees- and Lakers-theme televisions; Fantasy, with many child-friendly models, including a fire truck and a monkey; and Style, which includes the black walnut veneer HANNSvaas, right, a 15-inch TV inspired by the shape of a cello ($850 ). Prices range from $500 to $1,400 . A second American store is scheduled to open in San Francisco in September. Hannspree is at 420 North Beverly Drive (Brighton Way), Beverly Hills, Calif., (877) 665-9477 or www.hannspree.com. CURRENTS: ELECTRONICS

title: Still Mostly Mozart, but Now Up Close
description: Like a blood-colored island, the new stage emerges from a three-sided basin of black seats. Metal truss work suspended from the ceiling forms a canopy studded with white fiberglass discs, resembling an insect's magnified eye.

title: A Magazine to Help You Do-It-Yourself
description: A sample issue of a new magazine landed in my mailbox the other day. It's not quite like any other magazine I've seen, and it reflects the activities of a growing contingent of tech-heads. It's called Make, and it's all about do-it-yourself technology projects and hardware hacking, from "modding" (modifying and hot-rodding) your PC to cobbling together your own TiVo.

title: Personal Shopper; For the Wall: Lace, Pearls and Interactive Paper
description: MODERNISTS like me have always found wallpaper too traditional. But with designers using texture and bold patterns, and with one even offering wallpaper that is "interactive," I'm beginning to be won over. Too much wallpaper can be like too much candy. But used sparingly, itcan be an effective accent in an otherwise white box.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCQUILLER, CHARLES
description: McQUILLER--Charles. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Charles McQuiller, associated with The Times from June 1959, until retiring in January 1991.

title: At the Colts' Camp, a Familiar Center of Distraction
description: TERRE HAUTE, Ind., July 27 - The Indianapolis Colts could have entered training camp with nothing to worry about beyond preparing for their early start to the preseason and finally making a run past the New England Patriots to the Super Bowl.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Design Candidates Chosen
description: Seven teams of architectural firms have been asked to prepare a proposal for the $1.4 billion expansion of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the Empire State Development Corporation said yesterday. The expansion, north to 40th Street and south to 33rd Street, will add exhibition space, a hotel and a ballroom. The Tishman Construction Corporation of New York will oversee the project. The teams, whose proposals are due by Aug. 17, are Foster & Partners with Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum; Grimshaw; Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates; Morphosis, with Gruzen Samton; Richard Rogers Partnership, with Fox & Fowle; Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; and Rafael Violy Architects. Absent were the center's original architects, Pei Cobb Freed & Partners. David W. Dunlap (NYT)

title: Briefly: Governor rules out a run at fourth term
National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Ex-Officers Sue Over Firings
description: Seven Boston police officers who were fired after failing a drug test have sued the police department, saying the test was unreliable and racially biased. The seven officers, along with one job applicant, all submitted hair samples to the department for mandatory annual testing. All of their samples tested positive for traces of cocaine. The lawsuit said the hair test had been shown to produce false positive results in African-Americans, whose hair collects and retains more airborne particles than does lighter-colored hair. The former officers' lawyer said the officers had passed independent tests. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian In West Bank Raid
description: The Israeli army fought a gunbattle in the West Bank city of Jenin as troops arrested a wanted member of Islamic Jihad. In the gunfire, the army killed an unarmed 17-year-old Palestinian who was throwing stones. The army, which entered the town with tanks and bulldozers and surrounded a house where the youth was present, said it fired when its troops were attacked with gunfire. Two soldiers were lightly injured. Steven Erlanger (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Americas: U.S.-Backed Candidate To Lead Development Bank
description: Luis Alberto Moreno, Colombia's ambassador to the United States, was elected president of the Inter-American Development Bank, decisively defeating Joo Sayad, a Brazilian economist. Mr. Moreno, whom the Bush administration favored to replace Enrique V. Iglesias of Uruguay at the helm of an institution that disburses more than $5 billion a year in loans, triumphed in the first round, winning the support of 20 of the 28 countries eligible to vote, plus 56 percent of the bank's voting shares. Mr. Moreno will take office in October for a five-year term. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: Would-be airport bomber gets 22-year prison term
NBC Universal Said to Be in Talks for DreamWorks Unit
description: LOS ANGELES, July 27 - DreamWorks SKG, the live-action entertainment company co-founded by the director Steven Spielberg, is in talks to be acquired by its longtime partner, NBC Universal, according to two people with knowledge of the negotiations.

title: Several Indicators Point to Brisk Economic Growth
description: Sales of new homes and orders for durable goods rose faster than expected last month, the government reported yesterday, providing more indications that the economy is expanding at a brisk pace.

title: Traveling to Exotic Places and Blowing Things to Bits
description: The sight of Jessica Biel wiggling her shapely rear through the North Korean backcountry in the action flick "Stealth" isn't the most ludicrous image of our current movie season, but it comes close. As it happens, the most preposterous moment in this preposterous crypto-video game occurs after Ms. Biel's character, a United States naval pilot, parachutes from her stealth aircraft through a hailstorm of fiery debris, races across North Korea while chased by thugs with guns, and rushes into the arms of the man who risks worldwide nuclear holocaust to rescue her. Thanks, dude!

title: Is Mozart Thinking of Chairman Mao?
description: The Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, which convulsed China in the late 1960's and early 70's, has earned a special place in the annals of monstrous modern ideological experiments, not only for its cruelty but also for its absurdity.

title: Deutsch Resigns LensCrafters Account
description: Deutsch in New York has resigned the creative account of a longtime client, the LensCrafters chain of optical stores, by declining to take part in a review for the assignment. LensCrafters spends about $50 million to $60 million a year on advertising.

title: Sony Reports a Loss and a Bleaker Profit Outlook
description: TOKYO, July 28 - Sony, the struggling electronics giant, reported a second straight quarterly loss as sales of its television sets plunged, and slashed its profit outlook 88 percent for the financial year in a sign of its deepening troubles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BENENSON, EDWARD H.
description: BENENSON--Edward H. Benenson Capital Partners mourns the loss of our distinguished cousin, partner and friend, Edward H. Benenson. We will miss his intelligence and sense of humor. We have over 60 years of business and friendship together to remember and cherish. We will always remember a man who was greatly dedicated to his family, business and philanthropy. Those of us who know how special he was share the sense of loss with his family, friends and associates. Our deepest sympathy to the entire Benenson family. Bill Benenson Fred Benenson Lawrence B. Benenson Richard A. Kessler James E. Stifel

title: National Briefing | Midwest: Illinois: Chicago To Expand O'Hare Airport
description: The Federal Aviation Administration approved plans for a $15 billion expansion of O'Hare International Airport in Chicago to increase capacity and reduce congestion and delays at the airport, the world's second busiest. The agency said that it chose the city's plan, which involves building runways and taxiways and modifying others, over about 20 other proposals. The final environmental impact statement outlines plans for the city to soundproof homes and schools that would be exposed to high noise levels, put in place emission reduction initiatives and pay for the relocation of graves from one cemetery. Construction could begin immediately after a final decision, which is expected in September, and is scheduled to be completed in 2013. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Multiparty Referendum Ignored
description: Voters went to the polls in low numbers to decide whether to allow multiparty politics after nearly 20 years. Opposition leaders had declared the referendum a waste of time, and many Ugandans regarded the change preordained since President Yoweri Museveni had endorsed it. His party has governed since seizing power in 1986, and Parliament recently altered the Constitution to allow him to run for a third term. Marc Lacey (NYT)

title: Floyd vs. Oswalt Becomes the New Mets-Astros Feud
description: HOUSTON, July 28 - Mike Piazza and Roger Clemens will not be able to continue their rivalry this week at Minute Maid Park, but the Mets and the Astros have found capable replacements.

title: Desperately Painting the Plague
description: WORCESTER, Mass. - SOME of us thought the end of a world had come when AIDS started picking off friends and lovers in the 1980's, and in a sense it had. A certain world really did end. Yet even that experience left us unequipped to imagine the kind of despair today blanketing parts of Africa, where the disease has spread monstrously, reducing whole communities to less than a memory, to nothing.

title: Corrections 1/3
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on July 21 about the elimination of northbound tolls at the Essex plaza on the Garden State Parkway in New Jersey misstated the number of plazas that no longer have them. It is two, including Raritan, not four. The Union and Asbury Park plazas have eliminated southbound tolls. 1/3 1/3

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, SHEILA
description: BLOCK--Sheila. Died at home on July 27, 2005 after fighting a valiant battle against leukemia. Survived by cherished daughter Ellen (Frommer), loving son - in - law Steve, adored grandchildren Matt and Jenni, life partner Chuck Stroh, mother Fay Kravitz and many valued friends. Sheila spent her entire career in the fashion industry, most recently as the President of the Accessories Council. She had remarkable passion and energy in both her career and personal life. She was one-ofa-kind, had an incredible will, amazing style and a wonderful love for life. A Memorial Service will be held Monday, August 1, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Donations can be made to the Sheila Block Fund for Leukemia Research, C/O Accessories Council, 390 5th Avenue, New York, New York 10018.

title: Fields Sees a Need to Increase Police Antiterror Force
description: In the first televised debate of the city mayoral race, candidates sharply criticized the random police searches of bags taken into the subways, safety and dropout problems in public schools, and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, portraying him as an out-of-touch billionaire.

title: The Listings: July 29 -- Aug. 4; RUFUS WAINWRIGHT, BEN FOLDS
description: You have to imagine that the pop musician Rufus Wainwright would at this point enjoy being free from constant comparison to his folky parents, Loudon Wainwright III and Kate McGarrigle. Since his debut in 1998, the young Mr. Wainwright, above, has offered piano-driven torch songs that have grappled with his musical legacy as much as they've chronicled the love and heartbreak that attend being young, gifted and gay among the millennial jet set. If his 2000 album, "Poses" (DreamWorks), was Mr. Wainwright's rumination on cosmopolitan decadence, his latest duo, "Want One" (DreamWorks), and the more operatic "Want Two" (Geffen) seemed like attempts at a kind of healing. Granted, this can be a scalding process, as when Mr. Wainwright applies his potent nasal baritone to songs like "Dinner at 8," which details his father's departure from the family on a snowy night. But he can be funny as well. In "Gay Messiah," he rejects that mantle, preferring instead to play a cheeky John the Baptist. The woozy, escapist "Peach Trees" is an urban pastoral that mixes the wistfulness of Nick Drake and the cheesy grooves of Martin Denny. There's also evidence here of this songwriter's desire to move beyond self-study, as in the beautiful piano lament "Memphis Skyline," which bemoans the death of the late-1990's crooner Jeff Buckley, who drowned in the Mississippi on the verge of a glorious career. Songs like this transcend narcissism and open up a world of options. Mr. Wainwright plays the Celebrate Brooklyn Festival with Ben Folds, who has become more sincere since his melodic, snarky piano pop made his Ben Folds Five an alt-rock favorite in the mid-90's. (Thursday at 7 p.m., Celebrate Brooklyn, Prospect Park Bandshell, Prospect Park West and Ninth Street, Park Slope, $35; $40 at the door.) LAURA SINAGRA

title: Despite Problems, Bush Continues to Make Advances on His Agenda
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 - His problems remain many, and include the relentless violence in Iraq, the leak investigation that has ensnared some of his top aides and poll numbers that suggest substantial dissatisfaction with both his foreign and domestic policies. But President Bush has still had a pretty good July, showing how his own doggedness and a Republican majority in Congress have consistently allowed him to push his agenda forward even when the political winds are in his face.

title: AstraZeneca Chooses an Insider as Its Chief
description: LONDON, July 28 - AstraZeneca, the European drug maker, announced on Thursday that David R. Brennan, head of its North American operations, would become chief executive in January, ending questions about succession.

title: Time for Wind Energy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Listings: July 29 -- Aug. 4; SAVION GLOVER
description: Savion Glover has been saddled with the unfortunate "hip-hop tap dancer" label for years now, done in by his own success with Broadway's "Bring In 'da Noise, Bring In 'da Funk." After his wildly popular "Classical Savion" show at the Joyce Theater this winter, maybe "orchestral hoofer" will make it into the mix. But try calling him either to audiences at the B.B. King Blues Club & Grill, where Mr. Glover and his jazz quartet, the Otherz, have wowed sellout crowds with standards and improvisations, including "The Stars & Stripes Forever (for Now)," his tribute to John Coltrane's "My Favorite Things." Mr. Glover, above, and his band return there tonight; he promises new material, but expect it to be delivered with his usual go-for-broke virtuosity. He was drumming before he started tapping, and percussive, polyrhythmic ferocity remains one of his hallmarks: toe-heel combinations punctuated by flat-footed stamps and long slides across his microphone-enhanced platform stage. Tap continues to make inroads in proscenium theaters like the Joyce, but there's nothing like a club for up-close scrutiny of Mr. Glover's rapid-fire delivery -- if your eyes can keep up with his feet. With any luck, the evening will feature guest appearances by noteworthy young hoofers like Marshall Davis Jr. Get there early for a good seat, and be prepared for you and your dinner or drinks to be sprayed if you're sitting at one of the tables adjoining the stage: Mr. Glover sweats as hard as he works. (Tonight at 8 and 10:30, B.B. King Blues Club & Grill, 237 West 42nd Street, Manhattan, (212)997-4144.) CLAUDIA LAROCCO

title: Luxury, au naturel, in Cape Town

As an editorial at daringfireball.net astutely observed, Apple is flipping the traditional business plan on its head. It's giving away the razor blades, but selling a staggering number of razors."

description: WASHINGTON, July 28 - It was just before midnight on Wednesday when Representative Robin Hayes capitulated.

description: A byline was omitted yesterday from a front-page article in Thursday Styles about adult children who take objects from their parents' homes. The writer was Stephanie Rosenbloom.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 8 TO 10 P.M. (5) ARRESTED DEVELOPMENT -- A four-episode block of Fox's best-reviewed, yet barely surviving comedy begins with "The One Where Michael Leaves," first shown in November, in which Michael (Jason Bateman), the normal character surrounded by crazy people, learns that his family can get along without him very well. In the last episode, at 9:30, "Good Grief!," Michael's mother (Jessica Walter) hires a bounty hunter to find her husband (played by Jeffrey Tambor, above, with Mr. Bateman). As the title suggests, there will be references to Charlie Brown and other "Peanuts" characters.

title: A Team and a Company Are Banking on a Coach
description: When he was asked yesterday if the signing of Larry Brown to coach the Knicks, the end of the National Hockey League lockout and the disappearance of the West Side stadium fight offered evidence of brighter times at Madison Square Garden, James L. Dolan offered a one-word response: "Yes." He uttered it with a self-satisfied smile but with none of the zip of Marv Albert, his least favorite former Knicks announcer.

Paid Notice: Deaths   DISTASIO, JOHN
description: DiSTASIO--John. Age 55. Died on July 27, 2005 after a long illness. Cherished husband of Elizabeth, devoted father of Anthony, Johnny, Priscilla and Jeanine. He was a retired New York Times employee and member of Paperhandlers Local 1. He will be greatly missed by his loving family and friends and will always be remembered for his sense of humor. DiSTASIO--John C. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of John C. DiStasio, associated with The Times from August 1987, until retiring in June 2001.

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Questions for Central Bank
description: The Italian stock market regulator Consob suspended Banca Popolare Italiana's two takeover bids for Banca Antonveneta, challenging the earlier approval of those bids by the governor of the Bank of Italy, Antonio Fazio, left. The suspension, which may give ABN Amro Holding another chance to win Antonveneta, came amid an inquiry into the Bank of Italy and Popolare Italiana by Italian prosecutors, and calls for Mr. Fazio's resignation. The regulator froze Popolare Italiana's cash offer and stock-and-cash bid because of a "lack of information" from the bank and concern about how the offers would be financed, according to its Web site. Prosecutors are investigating whether the central bank acted properly in authorizing those bids. Phone calls between Mr. Fazio and the chief executive of Popolare Italiana, Gianpiero Fiorani, were tapped as part of the inquiry.

title: Mubarak adds Western touch to election bid
At hackers conference, orderly mayhem rules
Aides Find No Evidence Linking Iranian to Embassy Seizure
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 - A month after some former American hostages in the United States Embassy in Tehran asserted that the president-elect of Iran was among their captors in 1979, government officials say they have turned up no evidence to support that claim.

title: The Listings: July 29 -- Aug. 4; 'SCRATCH'
description: The Studio Museum in Harlem's artists-in-residence program has regularly given contemporary American art a salutary push in a productive direction. It does so this year in "Scratch," an intricate, multilayered show of work by the three 2004-5 residents, organized by the museum's associate curator, Christine Y. Kim. William Cordova, born in Peru in 1971, raised in Florida, educated at Yale, weaves strands of this history together without tying them into easy knots. His basic visual material is a street language of rap lyrics, graffiti tags and images of boomboxes, seen in drawings as exquisite as illuminated gospel pages, and in an assemblage of personal items that looks random but is as purposefully arranged as an altar. Michael Queenland makes reference to religion too, but, as is the case with Mr. Cordova, his is an altogether cooler take on spirituality than what we were seeing in art a decade or two ago. Many of his sculptures and collages are based on plain-style, proto-modernist 19th-century Shaker designs, which he remakes on a larger scale, forging links with Minimalist artists like Donald Judd. The real subject of the work is American utopianism, a double-edged phenomenon that in Mr. Queenland's light-touch, idea-rich art retains its prickly complexity. Utopianism of a specific kind, namely the Black Power movement of the 1960's, is the focus of Marc Andr Robinson's new work. And he has added striking sculpture and film to the memorable figurative painting he was producing before his Studio Museum residency. The video "Wish You Were Here" is a loving tribute, delivered by residents of Harlem, to Malcolm X. The sculpture "Throne for the Greatest Rapper of All Time," above, is a double homage: to the religious artist James Hampton, creator of the monumental "Throne of the Third Heaven of the Nations Millennial Assembly" (1950-64), and to Huey Newton, who, in a famous photograph, sat in a fan-shaped wicker chair holding a spear and a gun. Mr. Robinson's fantastic throne, like much else in this fine show, is as stirring as it is indeterminate in meaning: made from floating scraps of used furniture, it could be coming together or blowing apart. (Studio Museum in Harlem, 144 West 125th Street, (212)864-4500, through Oct. 23.) HOLLAND COTTER

title: Europa: Odd-fellow coalition roils German politics
All Fall Down
description: In visiting Gaza and Israel a few weeks ago, I realized how much the huge drama in Iraq has obscured some of the slower, deeper but equally significant changes happening around the Middle East. To put it bluntly, the political parties in the Arab world and Israel that have shaped the politics of this region since 1967 have all either crumbled or been gutted of any of their original meaning. The only major parties with any internal energy and coherence left today are Hamas, Hezbollah and the Muslim Brotherhood, and they are scared out of their minds -- scared that if all the secular parties collapse, they may have to rule, and they don't have the answers for jobs, sewers and electricity.

title: Campers, Your Parents Are Storming the Gates
description: MOUNTAIN CITY, Ga. - AT a little before 7:30 on a recent Saturday night, the street outside the main gate of Camp Blue Ridge began to resemble a livestock holding pen. A herd of parents, a strange breed dressed in polo shirts, sandals and khaki shorts, waited for the gates to open. A lone father considered how to break the news that his son's grandfather had passed away. A mother from Florida wiped away tears as she waited to see her daughter for the first time in four weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRIEDMAN, PEPI
description: FRIEDMAN--Pepi. On July 27, 2005. Widow of Mark H. Friedman. Mother of Ruth Simring and Jeremiah Friedman. Grandmother of Mia and Noah Simring, and Rose, Sophie and Nina Friedman. Loving mother-in-law of Carolyn Fine Friedman and James J. Simring. Retired teacher at BOCES, active community member, volunteered at her local food pantry, docent at The MET, lover of Yiddish, strong Zionist pioneer, founding member of kibbutz Gesher Haziv. Services July 29th, 11AM at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91st St corner of Amsterdam Ave. Also survived by Rabbi Zigfried Wahrman and his wife Roberta, and Rabbi Solomon Wahrman and his wife Sara. Sister-in-law of Betty Friedan and Carl Friedan. Donations can be made to "Education and Training in Medicine" Fund, c/o Dr. Franco Muggia, 462 First Ave., VCD Room 556, NY, NY 10016.

title: National Briefing | New England: Maine: Referendum On Antidiscrimination Addition
description: A conservative group has gathered enough valid signatures to place a referendum on the November ballot asking voters if they want to add sexual orientation to the state's antidiscrimination law, the third time in eight years residents will vote on the issue. Gov. John Baldacci submitted legislation this year that added sexual orientation to the Maine Human Rights Act; he signed it into law in March. The Grassroots Coalition, a conservative group based in Lewiston, mounted a statewide drive soon after in an effort to repeal the law. The group submitted 56,560 votes to the secretary of state's office, about 6,100 more than needed. Katie Zezima (NYT)

title: To Curb Injuries, Giants Change Training Times
description: ALBANY, July 28 - Tom Coughlin prepared to kick off his second training camp as Giants coach on Thursday armed with a new practice schedule aimed at reducing injuries, a roster bolstered by free-agent signings and a somewhat sunnier-than-usual disposition. That may have been inspired by the hope that his second season may help people forget that the first was a 6-10 calamity that included an eight-game losing streak.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FINK, JEAN C.
description: FINK--Jean C. A longtime Scarsdale resident and tireless advocate for court reform and juvenile justice died on July 14, 2005 at age 88. Mrs. Fink was the daughter of Jacques Coe & Clara Bartels Coe. She was predeceased by her husband, attorney Marvin S. Fink and is survived by two daughters, Nancy Ceccorulli of Arnold, MD and Lisa Fink of Brunswick, ME and four grandchildren. A celebration of Jean Fink's life will be held on Sunday, July 31 at noon at the Center for Jewish Life at the Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale.

title: Perry St.
description: For a while there, the gimmickry seemed to be trumping the talent, the hip or cheeky themes getting as much consideration as the food. Jean-Georges Vongerichten was playing games, putting foie gras in dim sum at the sleek and sexy 66, giving Thai and Vietnamese street food a sybaritic spin at Spice Market and seasoning rib-eyes with irony at V Steakhouse.

title: Corrections 1/3
description: An article yesterday about a New York City Council vote to abolish metered parking on Sundays citywide referred imprecisely to the status of the city's meters in 2003, before free Sunday parking was curtailed. At the time, 6,400 of New York's 73,200 metered spaces required payment seven days a week; the city's action increased that number to 32,100, where it remains today. 1/3 1/3

title: Guessing game starts in Italy over banker
Shuttle Docks; Shield Damage Is Called Minor
description: HOUSTON, July 28 - The Discovery astronauts worked through their second full day in orbit on Thursday, executing an elegant orbital back flip and docking with the International Space Station. Back on Earth, hundreds of engineers scrutinized startlingly clear pictures of the shuttle's delicate protective tiles to see whether they had sustained the kind of liftoff damage that would make it unsafe to come home.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Bronx: Subway Station To Close For 4 Months
description: The 241st Street-Wakefield subway station, the northern end of the No. 2 line, in the northern Bronx, will be closed from 12:01 a.m. tomorrow through Dec. 11 as part of a $167 million project to rehabilitate the 10 stations on White Plains Road. The Bx41 bus, which operates along White Plains Road, will provide free trips to the 241st station from the Nereid Avenue station, the next station to the south. Extra bus trips will be added on weekdays from 6:30 to 9:30 a.m. and 3:30 to 7:30 p.m. In addition, a free shuttle bus will run every 10 minutes, from 11:30 p.m. to 6:30 a.m., every day between the two stations. The work to be done includes demolition and reconstruction of the station mezzanine's floors and walls and installation of new staircases. Sewell Chan (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRUMBEIN, AARON
description: KRUMBEIN -- Aaron. Born April 13, 1921, of Aventura, Florida, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, died July 27, 2005. Dear husband of Leona (nee Summerfield). Loving father of Hannah Miriam (the late Richard) Miller. Loving son of the late Abraham & Sarah (nee Milberg) of Boro Park and NYC. Caring brother of Eliezer (Elaine) of Highland Park, IL, the late Judith (the late Cantor Robert H.) Segal of New York City and Jerusalem. Graduate of Boro Park Yeshivas Etz Chaim, New Utrecht High School, B.A. NYU, M.A. Columbia. Formerly Principal, Peerless/ Taube Travel, and Service for Palestine and Israel; associated with Consolidated Tours, New York City. Passionate Zionist, student of American history, raconteur, lover of music and arts; founder, Queens, NY. Solomon Schecter Day School and Yeshivah University Albert Einstein Medical School. Longtime member Forest Hills N.Y. Jewish Center, Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center, FL. Also mourned by cousins, nieces and nephews, dear friends, former business associates and admirers of his travel articles for travel professionals. Interned with his loving family, Mt. Judah Cemetery, 81-14 Cypress Avenue, Ridgewood, Queens, NY, on Friday, July 29, 1 P.M.

title: Finally ready to play ball
Emergency decreestill worrying Thais
Farmhouse goes on the market
36 Hours in Kennebunkport, Me.
description: THERE'S more to Kennebunkport than pricey shops and hordes of George and Barbara Bush watchers gawking through binoculars at their Walker's Point compound. Exploring by foot, bike and boat reveals this old coastal town's enduring charms. It has been a seasonal destination since the end of the last Ice Age, when Indians fished there and hunted on coastal plains. Europeans later fished the region's rich waters, and the area was incorporated by Massachusetts as Cape Porpus in 1653. In the early 1800's, shipbuilding boomed on the Kennebunk River, and by the late 1800's, well-heeled summer people were building grand cottages along Ocean Avenue. Their descendants tend to keep to themselves, but you can occasionally glimpse them as they dismount large S.U.V.'s for an early morning tennis match or a round of golf. KIMBERLY RIDLEY

title: Spitzer Hones Campaign Themes as G.O.P. Seeks Candidate for Governor
description: ALBANY, July 28 - As he prepares for a post-Pataki era in state government, Attorney General Eliot Spitzer portrayed himself on Thursday as the candidate who can put New York's fiscal house in order.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAVRUSKA, CHARLES
description: VAVRUSKA--Charles. Passed away peacefully on July 28, 2005 in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was a lifelong resident of Queens. He served in the Navy as a navigator on the aircraft carrier Bennington during the Korean War. He was very active in cooperative and community affairs. He received his Bachelor's degree and his Master's degree from the NYU School of Engineering Evening Program. He retired from AT&T long lines after 27 years of service as a transmission engineer. He was president of the family-owned business TCE Systems which he started in 1984. He leaves behind his loving wife Mary, his son Charles, daughter-in-law Susan and his granddaughter Mary. Also survived by his brothers Joseph and his wife Marion, Ronald and his wife Jeanne and his sister-in-law Gloria and her husband Arthur. Visiting at the Conway Funeral Home, 82-19 Northern Blvd, Jackson Heights (at 83rd Street) Friday 2 to 5 and 7 to 9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Blessed Sacrament RC Church, Saturday 9:45AM. Interment Flushing Cemetery. Contributions may be madeto NYU School of Medicine.

title: Goodenow Resigns as Leader of N.H.L. Players' Association
description: TORONTO, July 28 - Bob Goodenow, who guided the N.H.L. Players' Association through more than a decade of prosperity, resigned as its executive director Thursday, six days after the official end of the lockout that canceled the 2004-5 season.

description: A New York State judge said yesterday that John A. Thain, the chief executive of the New York Stock Exchange, may have had a conflict of interest when negotiating the Big Board's takeover of Archipelago Holdings earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PALOZZOLO, EDNA
description: PALOZZOLO -- Edna. The Board of Trustees, medical staff, and administration of Maimonides Medical Center mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague and friend, Edna Palozzolo. We gratefully recognize her 39 years of devoted service to the hospital, culminating in her role as President of the Maimonides Research and Development Foundation. In this role, Mrs. Palozzolo was a tireless advocate for the research activities of the Foundation. The entire Maimonides family wants also to extend our deepest sympathy to her loving husband Jack and the Palozzolo family. Martin D. Payson, Chairman Board of Trustees Pamela S. Brier, Pres. & CEO Maimonides Medical Center Marvin Eisenstadt, Chairman Maimonides Research and Development Foundation

title: Nurturing Modernism With Spades, Water and Black Flowers
description: Postmodernist pests have invaded the formal garden! Or so an alarmist might react to "Down the Garden Path: The Artist's Garden After Modernism." This big, messy, uneven, but -- for patient and interested viewers -- intellectually stimulating show at the Queens Museum of Art is about how contemporary artists have cultivated gardens in fantasy and reality.

title: Chinese Teacher Sentenced to Death for Raping 23 Schoolgirls
description: BEIJING, July 29 - A teacher who raped 23 fourth- and fifth-grade girls after summoning them to his office was sentenced to death in western China, according to an account this week in a Chinese newspaper.

title: A Date That Lives in Oratory
description: IT did not take George E. Pataki long -- he managed to get out all of four words -- before he invoked Sept. 11 in announcing that he would not run again for governor. The terrorist attacks of 2001 weren't even the subject. He was talking about the inspiration that he drew from his father.

title: Up Next: Finding a Game Worthy of the Coaching Hunt
description: WHAT possibly was the most public recruitment of a coach in the history of professional sports reached an anticlimactic conclusion yesterday when Isiah Thomas thanked Larry Brown for teaching him how to dress a quarter-century ago, then introduced him as the man best suited to re-tailor the tattered Knicks.

description: NOBLE--Rose. Of Pompano Beach, FL died peacefully in NYC on July 27. She was active until the very end. Loving wife of the late Harry Noble, devoted mother to her two sons, Kenneth and Bruce, adoring grandmother to Danielle and Joshua. Her grace and charm will be missed by all the lives she touched.

title: Poland recalls envoy to protest Belarus raid
Metro Briefing | New York: Federal Transit Funds Increased
description: A highway and mass transportation bill set to be approved by Congress contains $16.5 billion for New York over the next five years, according to Senators Charles E. Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton. The bill provides $3 billion, or 22 percent, more money for New York than was provided under a previous six-year transportation spending bill. The legislation provides tens of millions of dollars for projects across New York City, including: $7 million for the Harlem River bridges; $7 million to improve walkways on West 65th Street around Lincoln Center; $5 million for transportation improvements around the Children's Museum in Brooklyn; $4 million each for improvements to the Staten Island and Governors Island ferries; $15 million for transforming the James A. Farley Post Office Building into a rail station; and even $3 million to restore the facade of the New York Public Library on 42nd Street. Raymond Hernandez (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Demolitions Halt Announced
description: Vice President Joyce Mujuru declared an end to the government's two-month campaign to demolish urban shantytowns and called on international donors to give money to a "noble effort" to house those evicted in the operation. Zimbabwe has declared the demolitions over before, and there was no way to know whether this proclamation was accurate. The government has proposed a $300 million effort to house the 700,000 people said to have been displaced, but few expect the bankrupt treasury to produce the money. Opposition politicians said donors should not give Zimbabwe money without guarantees that it would reach those in need. Michael Wines (NYT)

title: Manager at Merrill Branch Pleads Guilty to Tampering
description: A former Merrill Lynch compliance officer pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of conspiring to tamper with a witness in an industrywide investigation into how information on Wall Street trading desks is shared.

title: A Little Summer Night's Music
description: ON a Saturday this month in Sherman, Conn., cars began converging just before 8 p.m. on a spot overlooking the placid, tree-lined waters of Lake Mauweehoo. As the tiny parking lot filled, some found spaces next to canoes and dinghies laid out alongside the lakefront. The passengers who emerged were dressed as if for a cookout or garden party, but they had come for another kind of summer entertainment: chamber music.

title: Man Charged With Raping 5-Year-Old Daughter
description: A Manhattan man raped his 5-year-old daughter and then offered her to another man he had met on a telephone chat line, who then joined him in sexually abusing the girl this month, the police said yesterday.

title: An Island Unto Itself, Loved for What It Lacks
description: PELEE ISLAND, Ontario - PEOPLE come to this unassuming outpost in Lake Erie's western basin as much for what it lacks as for what it has.

title: Broken Record
description: Chicago - "THIS is not a pretty picture," declared Eliot Spitzer, the New York attorney general, at a press conference on Monday to trumpet his office's yearlong investigation into corrupt dealings between big music companies and broadcasters. "What we see is that payola is pervasive. It is omnipresent. It is driving the industry and it is wrong." But the picture might look a little different to Mr. Spitzer were he to pick up a few history books.

title: A Sense of Proportion at Ground Zero
description: Somewhere in the ill-conceived campaign to "take back the memorial" at ground zero, false impressions have managed to triumph over facts. This week, Debra Burlingame, a board member of the World Trade Center Memorial Foundation, and others called for a boycott of fund-raising for the memorial until the International Freedom Center and the Drawing Center have been banished from ground zero. She argues that money for the memorial will be intermingled with funds for the cultural building that is supposed to house the Freedom Center and the Drawing Center. This is both misleading and harmful to the memorial itself. The World Trade Center Memorial Foundation has pledged that its first priority is to build the memorial and create an endowment for it. Private donors are free to specify how they choose to have their money spent.

title: U.S. jails Yemeni cleric for financing terrorists
French Family Values
description: Americans tend to believe that we do everything better than anyone else. That belief makes it hard for us to learn from others. For example, I've found that many people refuse to believe that Europe has anything to teach us about health care policy. After all, they say, how can Europeans be good at health care when their economies are such failures?

title: Briefly: Airport in South Dakota to use private screeners
A Playwright Parts With His Portraits
description: A Playwright Parts With His Portraits

title: Scientists Warn Fewer Kinds of Fish Are Swimming the Oceans
description: Researchers who studied decades of catch records from Japanese fishing fleets say fishing has greatly reduced the diversity of fish in the world's open oceans, leaving ocean ecosystems less resilient against environmental changes like global warming.

title: Japan plans to retaliate for U.S. tariffs on steel
Politically Popular Shuttle Program May Be Hard to Kill
description: Is this the crisis that ends the shuttle and throws the nation's space effort onto a new path?

title: Appeal Restores Libel Case Against Times
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that a libel suit filed against The New York Times Company by a former Army bioterrorism expert could proceed, reversing a Federal District Court decision last November that dismissed the case.

title: U.S. Economy Grew at a Strong Rate Last Quarter
description: Businesses and households went on a spring shopping spree this year, causing warehouse stockpiles to shrink and likely setting the stage for faster economic growth during the rest of the year.

title: Army Mechanic Is Acquitted on Desertion Charge
description: An Army mechanic who did not return to Iraq with his unit, saying he was opposed to war after seeing it firsthand, was acquitted yesterday of desertion, but convicted of a lesser charge of purposely missing his unit's deployment.

title: Corrections 1/3
description: A front-page article on July 15 about financial details of a contract between Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California and a group of fitness magazines referred incompletely to the news reports that brought the terms to light. Before their publication in California newspapers, they were disclosed by the Reuters news agency. 1/3 1/3

title: Police Chiefs Moving to Share Terror Data
description: LOS ANGELES, July 28 - Frustrated by what they say is the slow and sometimes grudging way that federal officials share information about terrorist incidents, police chiefs from around the country are creating an informal network of more rapid communication.

title: Lance Armstrong And America
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plan to Cut Conductor Jobs
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority intends to eliminate the positions of 313 train conductors on four subway lines, starting in 2007, in a significant expansion of a program that has drawn criticism from union leaders and some advocates for transit riders.

title: Redux of Hazzard: The General Lee Flies Again
description: EVERY Friday night from 1979 to 1985, millions of television viewers tuned in to watch an orange superhero fly. The star of the TV show "Dukes of Hazzard" was a 1969 Dodge Charger named General Lee, as in Robert E. The car was Nascar-ready, with welded-shut doors, "01" in big, black numerals stamped on the sides, a horn that tooted the first 12 notes of "Dixie" and the Confederate battle flag painted on the roof. The General could jump ravines, chase down bandits and outrun corrupt lawmen, occasionally on two wheels. Despite its apparent immortality, more than 300 Generals were wrecked during the show's run.

Paid Notice: Deaths   SPIVACK, EDITH
description: SPIVACK--Edith. We mourn the passing of the widow of the late Bernard H. Goldstein, senior partner of Tenzer Greenblatt, Blank Rome's New York predecessor. Spiv, as she was affectionately known to us, was an extraordinary woman. Her remarkable 70 year career will forever be an inspiration to female attorneys and indeed all attorneys. Our heartfelt condolences to Edith's family. Blank Rome LLP

title: Cops and Their Quarry
description: Gary Cole, right, stars as Lt. Conrad Rose in the police drama "Wanted," which begins Sunday on TNT. Rose leads an elite squad of specialists in Los Angeles whose dangerous mission is to arrest the 100 worst criminals in the city. The series, created by Jorge Zamacona, also stars Ryan Hurst, Rashida Jones, Benjamin Benitez and Josey Scott.

title: Fiat Banks on New Model to Assist in Its Recovery
description: MILAN, July 28 - Fiat, Italy's beleaguered carmaker, showed glints of recovery in its latest results on Thursday, and also offered a look at its newest car, one analysts say will be crucial to Fiat's survival.

title: Beltran and Mets Feel Unwelcome in Houston
description: HOUSTON, July 28 - The Astros drew 43,552 spectators to Minute Maid Park on Thursday night, and they came not so much to watch the home team as to glare at one unwelcome visitor.

title: Archaeology Jamboree
description: WHEN archaeologists of the American Southwest gather for their annual meeting, there are no stuffy hotel meeting rooms or bland college auditoriums. The events are all under a great big tent at a different, often spectacularly scenic locale; this year's Pecos Conference, as it's known, is in the high desert country of pinyon and juniper trees near Bandelier National Monument in north-central New Mexico. And unlike, say, the Congress of the International Union of Physiological Sciences, this conference welcomes -- even encourages -- amateurs to attend.

title: Yemeni Cleric Is Sentenced to 75 Years in Terrorism Case
description: A federal judge in Brooklyn sentenced a Yemeni cleric yesterday to 75 years in prison for supporting terrorism, the maximum penalty in a case that had appeared uncertain after the government's chief witness set himself on fire outside the White House last November.

title: Needing to Make Noise, Knicks Had One Option
description: A COUPLE of weeks ago, I championed Herb Williams for the Knicks' coaching job. At the time, the Knicks were trying to figure out whether the Pistons really intended to pull the plug on Larry Brown, the coach who had led Detroit to the N.B.A. title last year and the finals this year.

title: Bill to Curb Mortgage Giants Gains in Senate
description: The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill yesterday that would tighten oversight of the mortgage finance companies Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and shrink their assets.

Not So Loudly, Governor Gets Point Across
description: Gov. George E. Pataki is no longer in a New York state of mind.

title: Profit rises for Europe's phone companies
Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Guilty Plea In Threat
description: A candy store manager pleaded guilty yesterday to making a threatening telephone call to The New York Post over pictures of Saddam Hussein in his underwear, published in May. According to prosecutors, Nagi Nashal, 53, told a newspaper employee that he was "very upset" with the photographs. "How dare you disgrace my people," he was quoted by prosecutors as having said in the call. "I will come down there and blow up the building." The police traced Mr. Nashal to his store on First Avenue between 74th and 75th Streets. He is expected to be sentenced to six months in jail. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: The Shadow of His Predecessor Dominates the Pataki Legacy
description: ALBANY, July 28 - When Gov. George E. Pataki announced this week that he would not seek a fourth term as governor, quite a few news accounts began by identifying him the same way they did more than a decade ago: as the man who beat Mario M. Cuomo.

title: We are all threatened by this plague
World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Bank Profit Rises
description: Deutsche Bank, Germany's biggest bank by assets, said profit increased 44 percent as it earned more from trading than any of its Wall Street competitors. Net income in the second quarter climbed to 947 million euros ($1.14 billion), or 1.90 euros a share, the bank said in a statement. The company plans "a substantial increase" in its 2005 dividend after paying investors 1.70 euros a share last year. Its chief executive, Josef Ackermann, has relied on income from trading, the bank's biggest source of revenue, to improve profitability. Deutsche Bank's earnings exceeded analysts' estimates for a fourth consecutive quarter, helped by a 9 percent increase in revenue to 5.9 billion euros. Deutsche Bank is based in Frankfurt.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. Leader Says Split Hurts Labor
description: CHICAGO, July 28 - John J. Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has long been known as a steady-as-you-go consensus builder, but this week, when two giant unions bolted the labor federation, he got his Irish up.

title: DaimlerChrysler chief to leave
Accounts
description: L'Oral, Paris, consolidated the media planning and buying duties for its namesake cosmetics brands in 26 European countries, effective Oct. 1, and awarded the assignment to offices of the ZenithOptimedia Group, part of the Publicis Groupe. The offices had shared the media duties with offices of Universal McCann, part of the McCann Worldgroup division of the Interpublic Group of Companies. L'Oral spends an estimated $300 million to $400 million a year on campaigns that run in Europe.

title: He's an Isolated Fellow; She's Addicted to Shopping
description: A delicate wisp of a film with a surprisingly sharp sting, "Tony Takitani" tells the story of a lonely man who at age 37 awakens to life for the first time during a brief idyll. The film was directed by Jun Ichikawa, who has adapted this Haruki Murakami short story of the same title with grace and fidelity. Short on incident and narrated in the third person with serene detachment, the original story was published in The New Yorker three years ago and, at least on first reading, would seem impossible to transpose to the screen.

description: MAJOR LEAGUE BASEBALL

title: Mitsubishi Sues Seven Former Executives
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation, the Japanese automaker, said on Friday that it had filed a 1.15 billion yen lawsuit ($10.2 million) against seven former executives for covering up one of the country's worst vehicle recalls.

title: U.S. Offers North Korea Evidence That Nuclear Secrets Came From Pakistani's Network
description: WASHINGTON, July 28 - In negotiations with North Korea this week, the Bush administration has for the first time presented the country with specific evidence behind American allegations that North Korea secretly obtained uranium enrichment technology from a founder of Pakistan's nuclear program, two senior administration officials said.

title: Fiat pins hopes on a new Punto
INSIDE
description: Sole Black Trustee Quits Over Harvard's President The only black member of the Harvard University's seven-member governing board, Conrad K. Harper, said he was resigning over disagreements with Harvard's president, Lawrence H. Summers. Mr. Summers has had several public disputes with prominent black faculty members and angered many on campus by suggesting that "intrinsic aptitude" might be a factor in the low number of women in science and engineering. PAGE A17

title: The Dinosaur That Walked on Two Legs May Have Started Life on Four
description: For several years scientists have been finding fossilized embryos of dinosaurs from 80 million to 100 million years ago. They have now uncovered several 190-million-year-old dinosaur embryos, the oldest ever found. The discovery is being reported today in the journal Science by a team of paleontologists headed by Robert Reisz of the University of Toronto.

title: When Guests Go Bad
description: IN retrospect, Kusum Gaind, 52, a jewelry designer and retired banking executive, can see the comedy in the scene that greeted her in the kitchen of her country house in Austerlitz, N.Y., one morning several summers ago. But at the time, she wasn't laughing.

title: Obituary: A.William Holmberg Jr., 81, news executive
As American As Copland, Who Forged Our New Sound
description: A THOROUGH exploration of Aaron Copland's music, with a comprehensive look at the 20th-century American culture that shaped him and that he shaped, seems a natural idea and a likely audience draw. So the most astonishing thing about the festival "Copland and His World" at Bard College is that it was so long in coming.

title: In Records, a Privately Blunt Roberts Showed Public Tact

Roberts clearly had a knack for the telling and occasionally biting comment, but a closer review of documents he wrote while in the Justice Department also reveals an early glimpse of the thoughtful reserve he cultivated as a lawyer and a judge.

title: The Boys [Sic] Return, Pledging Undying Love
description: When Backstreet Boys performed on Wednesday night at Radio City Music Hall, the screams weren't as loud this time around, and many of the fans were out of their teens. That's what happens when the defining boy band of the 1990's takes a five-year break between albums, while pop changes and some fans outgrow their teeny-bopper crushes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LIEBERMAN, SANDRA
description: LIEBERMAN -- Sandra. On July 27, 2005. Beloved wife of the late Morris. Devoted mother of Valrie Woltz, Kimberly Vlastaras and Leslie and mother-in-law of Alan Woltz, Steve Vlastaras and Barbara. Cherished grandmother of Jason, Peter and Lauren. Services on Friday 11:45 AM at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY.

title: The Listings: July 29 -- Aug. 4; 'LE DERNIER CARAVANSRAIL'
description: Just because it's six hours long doesn't mean that you can arrive late to "Le Dernier Caravansrail," the eye-popping two-part epic about the plight of refugees that runs through Sunday at the Lincoln Center Festival. While most of the 62 scenes take place on small rolling platforms, the opening (above) is a huge portrait of physical and emotional endurance, an audacious spectacle that pushes the limits of theatrical stagecraft. It takes less than a minute for the director, Ariane Mnouchkine, to transform the empty stage into a vast, roiling river that threatens to capsize a wicker basket full of refugees being smuggled to Kyrgyzstan. The screams of the flailing passengers are lost in the cacophony of the crashing waves and thundering storm. One man falls overboard and is consumed by the water. Another is shot because he did not pay. Even though this image is accomplished with simple materials like a vast gray silk sheet and a pulley system, it is an action scene worthy of Steven Spielberg. In a show that constantly calls attention to its own artifice -- the dressing rooms are exposed, the set changes are lighted -- this violent, grueling and suspenseful exodus is far too involving to allow for any intellectual distance. A terrible, unforgettable disaster has occurred right in front of your eyes, one that you will not forget soon. (Part 2, tonight, tomorrow night and Sunday night at 7:30; Part 1, tomorrow and Sunday at 3 p.m. Damrosch Park, Lincoln Center, (212)721-6500.) JASON ZINOMAN

title: With Apology to an Analyst, Altera Seeks to Repair a Rift
description: The Altera Corporation, acknowledging that it was wrong to cut off a securities analyst who had published negative comments about it, apologized to the analyst yesterday and promised to provide him and all Wall Street analysts covering the company with access to management.

title: A Microsoft 'charade'

Arts, Briefly; Brats Cast Their Spell
description: Fox and NBC divided Wednesday night's Nielsen spoils. Fox was No. 1 in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49, while NBC won in households. The second week of Fox's "So You Think You Can Dance" drew 7.9 million viewers, 2 million fewer than its debut last week; the dance competition is no "American Idol." On NBC a Wednesday installment of "Average Joe" (4.39 million) hurt the network's average. Its victory in households was thanks to two "Law & Order" repeats (7.55 million, then 8.36 million). Though ABC finished third among viewers and second among 18-to-49-year-olds, its "Brat Camp," during which both the pot-smoking Lauren and the dyslexic Nick experienced emotional breakthroughs, was the night's most-watched program (8.65 million). Also on Wednesday, UPN's "R U the Girl" made its debut. While a mere 2.65 million viewers watched TLC begin its search for a new bandmate, the show was No.2 in the hour among women 18 to 34. KATE AURTHU

title: Taking a Long, Winding and Bumpy Road to the Magical Intersection of Mr. and Ms. Right
description: Watching "Must Love Dogs," an Internet dating comedy so weightless that it makes a trifle like "You've Got Mail" look like Chekhov, you have to wonder how actors of the caliber of Diane Lane, John Cusack, Christopher Plummer and Stockard Channing were bamboozled into lending their talents to the project.

He makes $20 million a year -- that's the No. 20 with six zeroes attached -- for playing baseball in Boston, and he's tired and uncomfortable.

title: Applauding the Cafta 15
description: In the wee hours yesterday, the House of Representatives passed the Central American Free Trade Agreement by a sliver of two votes. Fifteen Democrats joined 202 Republicans in voting to open up trade between the United States and El Salvador, Costa Rica, Nicaragua, Honduras, Guatemala and the Dominican Republic. Anyone who believes, as this page does, that the benefits of free trade outweigh those of protectionism should give a pat on the back to the Democrats who chose principle over politics and defied their party's leaders to vote for the trade pact.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FRANCISCUS, SR. MARY, RSM
description: FRANCISCUS--Sr. Mary, RSM Came to the fullness of her life July 27, 2005. As educator and administrator within the Brooklyn Diocese Schools, Sr. Mary helped students attain the highest level of achievement. In 1983 Sr. Mary founded Opportunities for a Better Tomorrow to assist economically disadvantaged youth. Sr. Mary transformed lives of hopelessness to those of hope and success. Sr. Mary was a true-blue ardent Yankee fan. She was a devoted sister to Howard, Margaret and the late John. She is also survived by her sister-in-law Marion, three nieces, two nephews and their families. Mass of Resurrection at St. Rocco's in Brooklyn, 10AM Saturday July 30. Wake at Aievoli Funeral Home, 13th Avenue at 65th Street, Brooklyn, Thursday July 28, 7-9pm and Friday July 29, 2-4:30pm and 7-9pm. FRANCISCUS--Sr. Mary. The Robin Hood Foundation mourns the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Sister Mary Franciscus. Sister Mary helped lift thousands of people out of poverty. With foresight and tenacity she founded one of New York's best job training programs. Sister Mary left an indelible mark on our city and everyone who had the privilege to know her. Our condolences to her family, friends and everyone at Opportunities for a Better Tommorow.

Bolton, President Bush's nominee to be ambassador to the United Nations, failed to tell the Senate during his confirmation hearings that he had been interviewed by the State Department's inspector general looking into how American intelligence agencies came to rely on fabricated reports that Iraq had tried to buy uranium from Africa, the State Department said Thursday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AUER, LOUIS V.
description: AUER--Louis V., of Westhampton Beach, New York, and La Quinta, CA, passed away at his home in California on July 26, 2005. He was 78. He graduated Yale University in 1947. He worked on Wall Street for 30 years. He was predeceased by his wife of 50 years, Jean Patchett, and his son, Bart. He is survived by his daughter, Amy, of Westhampton Beach, his sister-in-law, Lee Auer, and his nephew, Louis Auer VI, of California. Arrangements for a memorial service are still pending. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Arthritis Foundation, 1330 W. Peachtree St. NW, Suite 100, Atlanta, GA 30309, or charity of choice would be appreciated by his family.

A Six-Stringed Storm of Runs and Rhythms
description: During his lifetime, Django Reinhardt was the guardian of a jazz guitar style so distinct as to seem inimitable. But the half-century since his death has seen a parade of imitators, great and small. At Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the third annual "Spirit of Django Reinhardt" concert brought a few of them together, in a brotherhood of blistering fretboard runs and brightly swaggering rhythms.

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel Plans 3 Fences On Gaza Border
description: Israel is building two additional fences along the perimeter of the Gaza Strip that will run parallel to the existing barrier built a decade ago, the military said. Israel's barrier has been largely successful in keeping out armed Palestinians, but the military is looking to create more protection as Israel prepares to withdraw from Gaza next month. Both new fences will be on the Israeli side of the border. One will consist mostly of razor wire, while the other will have electronic sensors and surveillance cameras. Greg Myre (NYT)

National Briefing | Washington: New Director For National Zoo
description: The Smithsonian Institution named a new director for its National Zoological Park, which has been dogged in recent years by criticism of animal deaths and accusations of mismanagement. John Berry, the executive director of the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation, was named director of the National Zoo. He succeeds Dr. Lucy H. Spelman, a veterinarian who resigned in December after a study ordered by Congress found shortcomings in the zoo's record keeping and overall maintenance. Mr. Berry, 46, has held other posts at the Smithsonian. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Bad News From Connecticut
description: The No Child Left Behind Act has been a burden for the school districts struggling with yearly tests that often show unpleasant results. But it's been working on the most critical level, improving students' performance and closing the gap between minority and white students. So Gov. Jodi Rell of Connecticut took the wrong road this week when she signed a bill that endorses a plan by the state attorney general to sue the federal government over some of the act's provisions.

title: Deft Portrayals in a Polemics-Free Zone

Back in 1935, dour dancegoers pronounced the original version of this ballet about a collective farm much too trivial. But the bright new choreographic version by Alexei Ratmansky, which the Bolshoi Ballet presented through Wednesday at the Metropolitan Opera House, is a delightful comedy about lovers' mix-ups and disguises.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Reputed Mob Family Boss Indicted
description: A legendary 85-year-old reputed gangland figure who was at Umberto's restaurant in Little Italy when Joey Gallo was killed there in 1972 in one of organized crime's most storied killings was indicted yesterday on federal racketeering charges. Matthew Ianniello, who is known as Matty the Horse and was identified by federal prosecutors as the acting boss of the Genovese crime family, was charged along with 19 other reputed mob figures. He was arrested at 6 a.m. yesterday at his Long Island home, where agents and police detectives found him sitting in an easy chair, the credits of the film "The Godfather III" rolling across his TV screen, a law enforcement official said. "Don't let age his fool you, he's still an influential player in the Genovese family," said Matt Heron, a senior official in the New York office of the F.B.I. William K. Rashbaum (NYT)

title: Arts, Briefly; August Benefits at CBGB
description: CBGB, the famously grungy 32-year-old rock club on the Bowery that faces possible eviction when its lease expires at the end of August, is having a monthlong series of benefit concerts and an auction on eBay of rock memorabilia to support its campaign to remain in place. The shows, to begin on Tuesday, include a battery of veteran punk and rock bands: the Misfits (Aug. 12), the Dead Boys (Aug. 26 and 27), the Bush Tetras (Aug. 5), Sham 69 (Aug. 28 and 29), Chevelle (Aug. 4), the Gorilla Biscuits (Aug. 14) and the Vandals (Aug. 20). Sting, Motorhead, Elvis Costello and Norah Jones have donated materials for the auction. The club said that the money raised would support its Save CBGB legal defense fund, and if an agreement is reached with its landlord, the nonprofit Bowery Residents' Committee, then the money would be donated to that group. BEN SISARIO

title: Suicide Blast in North Iraq Kills at Least 20
description: A suicide bomber detonated an explosive belt at an Iraqi Army recruiting station in northern Iraq today, killing at least 20 people and wounding at least 25 others, as Iraqi leaders continued to work at drafting a constitution.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Nightline' Producer Named
description: James Goldston, a veteran producer of news programs on British television who joined ABC News last year, has been named executive producer of "Nightline," the network announced yesterday. Mr. Goldston will assume his duties in late fall, when the host of "Nightline," Ted Koppel, and the program's current executive producer, Tom Bettag, leave the network when their contracts expire. Both had announced their departures in the spring. Mr. Goldston is being asked to undertake one of the toughest assignments in television news: to widen the appeal of "Nightline" at a time when Americans have never had more choices for how to get the news. Although Mr. Goldston has produced news programs and documentaries on the war in Iraq, among other subjects, he is perhaps best known in the United States for "Tonight With Trevor McDonald" the program on ITV1, which broadcast the documentary "Living With Michael Jackson." Parts of that film helped lead to Mr. Jackson's indictment on child-molestation charges. JACQUES STEINBERG

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Charges In Raid Of Chechen Village
description: A Russian military prosecutor told Russian news agencies that a commander serving in a federal battalion in Chechnya faced charges stemming from a June raid on the village of Borozdinovskaya, in which at least 2 people died and 11 others disappeared. If so, it would be a rare instance of Russia prosecuting federal soldiers or officers for crimes committed in Chechnya. The raid caused hundreds of residents to flee to neighboring Dagestan. The prosecutor, Col. Maxim L. Toporikov, acknowledged the presence of federal forces in the village, but provided few details and did not answer the question of what happened to the 11 missing men. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: World Briefing | Middle East: Vatican Denounces Israeli Reprisals
description: Escalating a public war of words, the Vatican accused Israel of retaliating against Palestinian attacks at times in ways "not always compatible with the rules of international law." The unusually strong Vatican statement followed a formal Israeli complaint this week that Pope Benedict XVI had "deliberately" left out of a sermon against terrorism on Sunday any mention of a suicide attack in Israel this month while citing recent strikes in Britain, Egypt, Iraq and Turkey. In its statement yesterday, the Vatican said it could not protest every Palestinian attack if Israel did not follow international law in its response. It also scolded Israel for questioning the pope. "The Holy See cannot take lessons or instructions from any other authority on the tone and content of its own statements," the Vatican said. Ian Fisher (NYT)

description: ROSSBACH -- Eleanor, for merly of Riverdale, NY, passed away on July 26. Born in 1916 in Savannah, graduated from Smith College. Wife of the late J. Howard Rossbach. A community activist with interests in art, politics and gerontology, she served on Planning Board 8, Municipal Arts Council, Riverdale Mental Health Assn, Riverdale Neighborhood House, The Jewish Home and Hospital, Visiting Nurse Association, Riverdale Yacht Club, Cosmopolitan Club. Ellie also was a longtime volunteer to brother - in - law Jonathan Bingham's congressional campaign. Her children, Anne (Ernie) Munch, Sarah (Douglas) Fleming, and Howard (Katie) Rossbach and six grandchildren will miss her and remember her love, generosity and intelligence. Private service. Contributions may be made in her memory to Wave Hill, 675 West 252 Street, Bronx, NY 10471.

title: In Houston, the Euphoria Vanishes
description: HOUSTON, July 28 - Clara Olvera has worked in the cafeteria at the Johnson Space Center here for only a year, but on Thursday afternoon she could detect a shift in the mood of the engineers, astronauts and administrators who come in for lunch each day. The grounding of shuttle flights because of another pesky foam problem, she said, was clearly weighing on spirits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CONNEALY, MARY JO
description: CONNEALY--Mary Jo. Vice President and Artist Manager at Columbia Artists, passed away Tuesday morning July 26, 2005 at her home in Manhattan after a long illness. She is survived by her beloved son Sean, a specialist in Information Technology at Columbia Artists, and by her brothers and sisters-in-law Larry and Judy Maupin of Grand Island, NE and Kenneth and Anne-Marie Maupin of Spokane, WA. A native of Lincoln, NE she comes from a musical family and graduated in music from the University of Nebraska. Her professional career began with creating special projects for the National Endowment for the Arts, bringing the performing arts to the heartland of America and singing in the Robert Shaw Chorale. Ms. Connealy was employed by Columbia Artists for 26 years, and was one of its most respected and loved artist managers. Her artists included Rudolf Buchbinder, Renaud and Gautier Capucon, Sir Peter Maxwell Davies, The Empire Brass, Claude Frank, the late Lillian Kallir, Katia and Marielle Labeque, Ute Lemper, Cecile Licad, Valentina Lisitsa and Alexei Kuznetsoff, Vadim Repin, Vladimir Spivakov, Alexander Toradze and Christian Zacharias. She worked closely with R. Douglas Sheldon, Senior Vice President of CAMI, in representing Anne-Sophie Mutter, Leonard Slatkin, Nigel Kennedy and Marilyn Horne as well as touring the New York Philharmonic with Kurt Masur, the Orchestre National de France with Lorin Maazel, and the Los Angeles Philharmonic with Carlo Maria Giulini. Ms. Connealy's long-term collaboration with Sir Peter Maxwell Davies resulted in no less than six North American and three World Premieres of his works. She produced more than 500 performances by international opera companies coast to coast in the United States for Helikon Opera, Stanislavsky Opera and the London City Opera. Ms. Connealy was proud to be associated with such award winning talents as the Eroica Trio (Grammy Award winners), Nikolaj Znaider (Queen Elizabeth Competition winner), Renaud & Gautier Capucon (named "Talents of the Year" by Victoire de la Musique), and Arabella Steinbacher. Information regarding a Memorial Event will be available at a later date. Donations may be made in her name to: The Ovarian Cancer Research Fund 14 Pennsylvania Plaza, Suite 1400 New York, NY 10122 (800) 873-9569 Friends and Colleagues Columbia Artists Management, Inc

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, CAROL RIEGELMAN
description: LUBIN -- Carol Riegelman, died on July 26 of heart failure at Lenox Hill Hospital after a very brief illnesss. She was born in 1909; graduated from Smith College in 1930; received an MA and a Ph.D from Columbia University; and was associated professionally with The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, The International Labor Organization, Rutgers University, The City of Reston, The New York Urban Coalition and The United Neighborhood Houses. She was the daughter of the late Charles A. Riegelman and the late Lilian E. Riegelman; the wife of the late Isador Lubin; and the sister of the late William I. Riegelman. She is survived by her daughter, Ann L. Buttenwieser; by her son-inlaw, Lawrence B. Buttenwieser; by her four grandchildren, William L. Buttenwieser, Carol B. Sharp, Jill B. Schloss and Peter L. Buttenwieser; by her 13 great-grandchildren; by her stepdaughter, Alice L. Everitt; by her sister-in-law, Rosalind W. Riegelman; by her two nieces, Mary A. Riegelman and Catherine R. Nathan; and by her two great-nieces. A memorial service for her will be held in the fall. LUBIN--Carol. We mourn the loss of Carol Lubin, whose remarkable life honored the values of Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt. She was an inspiration to our work and a cherished friend for all of us. William J. vanden Heuvel Anna Eleanor Roosevelt, Co-Chairs, Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute Christopher N. Breiseth, President and CEO The Directors and Governors of the Franklin and Eleanor Roosevelt Institute

title: The Safest Shuttle Tank Ever
description: When a piece of insulating foam more than half the weight of the one that doomed the Columbia broke off from the shuttle Discovery's external fuel tank during ascent this week, it not only raised questions about the safety of future shuttle flights, but also called into question the competence and engineering judgment of NASA, its contractors and its oversight boards. This was the very problem that NASA had spent two years and hundreds of millions of dollars trying to correct.

title: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Poland Recalls Ambassador
description: Poland withdrew its ambassador from Belarus, adding to a diplomatic feud over the erosion of democracy and human rights under Belarus's authoritarian president, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko. The withdrawal followed weeks of tit-for-tat expulsions of diplomats from each country involving accusations of harassment of ethnic Poles in Belarus. On Wednesday, the Belarussian police stormed the office of an ethic Polish organization in Grodno, detaining several members of the group and journalists, before releasing them early yesterday, according to news reports. Poland's foreign minister, Adam Daniel Rotfeld, said his country's ambassador would not return "until the situation changes and repressions stops," The Associated Press reported from Warsaw. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: NASA Engineers Didn'tSee Foam Ramp as Danger
description: NASA's engineers knew that the foam insulation around the space shuttle's giant external fuel tank was a problem. They were particularly worried about any hand-sprayed sections, like the foam that broke off and fatally damaged the Columbia in 2003.

description: WASHINGTON, July 28 - The number of businesses owned by minorities and women grew in recent years at rates that were two or more times the national average, according to the United States Census Bureau, which released the statistics on Thursday.

title: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Retail Sales Increase Again
description: Japan's retail sales rose in June for a fourth month as consumers increased spending on clothing and automobiles, supporting a recovery from recession in the economy, the world's second-largest. Sales rose 3.1 percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry said in Tokyo, accelerating from a 2.9 percent gain in May. From the previous month, sales increased 0.1 percent in June, seasonally adjusted. Rising wages and improving job prospects are spurring spending at retailers. The increase suggests that consumer demand, which accounts for more than half of the economy, will help Japan overcome a slowdown in exports and extend a recovery from the fourth recession since 1991. "Consumer sentiment is stable and at a high level and the household income situation has been improving," said Naoki Iizuka, chief economist at Dai-Ichi Life Research Institute. "Private consumption will have to support the economy."

Devoted father of Gwendolyn Parks, Ann Napp, John Parks, Grace Mitchell, James Parks, Mark Parks, Mary Heersink, Paul Parks, Philip Parks, Joan Whitlow and the late Peter Parks.
