title: Arts, Briefly; Fox Pursues Abdul Inquiry
description: Peter Liguori, the Fox Broadcasting president for entertainment, said yesterday that the network had asked an "independent counsel" to investigate claims by a former contestant on "American Idol" that he had a sexual relationship with Paula Abdul, right, one of the judges on the show. Asked at a news conference in Los Angeles if Ms. Abdul was in jeopardy of being fired, Mr. Liguori would not say. But he said that a critical line of inquiry was to determine if Ms. Abdul had compromised the fairness of the competition. "The credibility of that competition is Job1," Mr. Liguori said. And yet, in what could be a lifeline for Ms. Abdul, Mr. Liguori reminded reporters that "Idol" was "a piece of entertainment," and that while she expresses her opinions on camera, it is the viewers, not the judges, who vote. Since the fourth season of "Idol" ended in May, Fox has given Ms. Abdul additional responsibilities as an on-camera instructor on the summer reality series "So You Think You Can Dance." In a series of interviews last spring, the first broadcast on ABC, Corey Clark, a contestant on the show in 2003, said he had had a romantic relationship with Ms. Abdul during the competition and that she had tried to help him by buying him clothes. Mr. Clark's run on "Idol" ended in April 2003, when the producers disqualified him, saying he had failed to disclose that he had once been arrested and accused of assault. He later pleaded no contest to a lesser charge. In a statement in May, Ms. Abdul said that she would not respond to Mr. Clark's assertions. Mr. Liguori said yesterday that Ms. Abdul and Mr. Clark had been interviewed as part of the inquiry. He declined to identify the company conducting the investigation. JACQUES STEINBERG

title: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Unemployment Rate Falls
description: German unemployment fell for a fourth consecutive month in July, adding to signs that the economy, Europe's largest, is improving as the euro's decline helps exports and raises business confidence. The number of unemployed, adjusted for seasonal swings, fell by 42,000 to 4.81 million, the Federal Labor Agency in Nuremberg said. The adjusted jobless rate declined to 11.6 percent, from 11.7 percent. The euro's 11 percent fall against the dollar this year took optimism among German executives to a five-month high, the Ifo economic institute said earlier this week. "Unemployment will continue to fall in the coming months, and indeed fall more strongly," the economy and labor minister, Wolfgang Clement, told a news conference in Berlin. While unemployment has fallen from a post-World War II record in March, the jobless figures are still damaging Chancellor Gerhard Schrder's chances of winning an early election in September.

description: APPLETON--Shelley, humanitarian. Friend and husband of Jean Dubinsky Appleton, beloved father of Ryna and grandfather of Emma. Interment private. A memorial service will be arranged. He labored all his life for workers' rights and social welfare. His journey and selfless dedication involved him in many causes here and abroad. He was Secretary-Treasurer of the ILGWU, Chairman of the World ORT Union, President of The Tamiment Institute. He earned the Bronze Star for distinguished intelligence work in WWII. Always a loyal friend and true gentleman. Donations may be made to the World ORT Union, 126 Elbert St., London NW1 7NE England. APPLETON--Shelley. The officers of the former ILGWU mourn the death of ILGWU's secretary-treasurer and manager of Local 23-25. Shelley was an inspiration to working people as he fought for the rights of garment workers and immigrants. Shelley dedicated his life to improving working conditions for NYC garment workers. Edgar Romney, Chair ILGWU APPLETON--Shelley. We mourn the loss of a friend and colleague. He served the ILGWU for more than 40 years. He was a champion of labor and civil rights. He shall be missed. Jay and Connie Mazur

title: Once a Frightened Newcomer, Argentine Consul Now Seeks to Guide Immigrants
description: Twenty-six years ago, as a young political refugee from Argentina, Hector Timerman was afraid to ask police officers for directions. When the landlord of his Greenwich Village apartment failed to provide heat, he just moved. And when he faced a judge in small-claims court, he trembled, remembering judges in Argentina under the military dictatorship that had imprisoned and tortured his father.

title: Traveling to Exotic Places and Blowing Things to Bits
description: The sight of Jessica Biel wiggling her shapely rear through the North Korean backcountry in the action flick "Stealth" isn't the most ludicrous image of our current movie season, but it comes close. As it happens, the most preposterous moment in this preposterous crypto-video game occurs after Ms. Biel's character, a United States naval pilot, parachutes from her stealth aircraft through a hailstorm of fiery debris, races across North Korea while chased by thugs with guns, and rushes into the arms of the man who risks worldwide nuclear holocaust to rescue her. Thanks, dude!

description: CAIRO, July 28 - President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt may be moving slowly in his embrace of Western-style democracy, but Mr. Mubarak, the man who has been called a modern-day pharaoh because of his unrivaled power over 24 years in office, opened his re-election campaign on Thursday with many of the hallmarks of Western-style politics.

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Power Failures Hit Suburbs
description: Thousands of residents in the northern suburbs remained without power yesterday, after severe thunderstorms on Wednesday evening. The New York State Electric and Gas Corporation reported that 2,000 customers in Westchester, Putnam and Dutchess Counties had no electricity as of early evening, but by 11:30 p.m., that number was down to 344. About 8,600 Orange and Rockland Utilities customers were also without power in those counties and in parts of northern New Jersey, and company officials said some repairs might not be finished until tomorrow morning. Knocked-down power lines also cut electricity for 1,600 Con Edison customers in Westchester, as well as 29,000 Public Service Electric and Gas customers in New Jersey, but power was restored in nearly all of those homes, company officials said. Jennifer Medina (NYT)

title: A Medium in the Making: Slicing Familiar Films Into Something New
description: MILWAUKEE - Movie-loving artists divide roughly into two groups, fans and users. The fans flock to films, or the nearest video rental store, for both respite and inspiration; they discuss and sometimes write about what they see with distinctive intelligence. Their numbers are legion; their apotheosis is probably Manny Farber, the artist who had a distinguished career as a film critic before turning to painting full time.

description: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts has won a court ruling against a franchisee that blamed its financial woes on the federal investigation of the larger company.

title: A real-time war drama
Exploring borders in open air
The Fort That Let Outsiders In
description: The government has been keeping tabs on immigrants since 1820, and Castle Garden at the Battery, originally built to defend New York from foreigners, was the city's first official debarkation point. It was the gateway for immigrants until 1890, when federal officials took over responsibility for the newcomers, who were processed first at the nearby Barge Office and, starting in 1892, on Ellis Island.

Negroponte, the new director of national intelligence, has imposed strict safeguards intended to ensure that the government's National Intelligence Estimates are based on credible information instead of the kinds of unsubstantiated claims that were the basis for prewar intelligence on Iraq, his top deputy said Thursday.

title: From Veteran of Another War on Terror, a Crash Course
description: A COMMON housefly has sneaked into a formal conference room at John Jay College of Criminal Justice and, imitating a dive bomber, is making persistent passes at Rafi Ron, an Israeli antiterrorism expert hired by New York City's transit union to instruct its workers in the cutting edge skill of terrorism detection in a series of weekend seminars. Mr. Ron, a mature 58, and already a grandfather of three, seems more amused than annoyed by the insect; although he acknowledges taking deadly aim against human targets during his military career, he doesn't swat to kill.

title: Airborne Sex and Wicked Wallpaper: Sensual Samplings
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn. - The Romans did it. Rembrandt did it. Japanese masters did it. Picasso, especially in his dotage, did it. They all made erotic imagery, the kind that has been chiseled, carved, painted and drawn the world over since even before picture-making segued into art.

description: Lal Krishna Advani, the president of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party and the opposition leader in Parliament, appeared in a court in Uttar Pradesh on charges of inciting a Hindu mob to demolish a 16th-century mosque in Ayodhya in 1992. The demolition set off nationwide riots between Hindus and Muslims in which thousands died. The same charge against Mr. Advani, 75, was dismissed in 2003, when he was deputy prime minister, but a High Court overturned that ruling this month. Hari Kumar (NYT)

A longtime educator who had been an associate professor, superintendent and social studies teacher, Mr. Librera, 59, was named commissioner by former Gov. James E. McGreevey. David W. Chen (NYT)

title: Cool Deals: Resorts Fight the Heat
description: LAST week, after temperatures climbed as high as 120 degrees in Palm Springs, Calif., the Viceroy resort came up with a novel way to cool things down: it dumped 10-pound blocks of ice into its swimming pools. Now, on Saturdays -- the most popular pool day -- the resort plans to use 250 pounds of ice, bringing the temperature down 5 degrees to about 87. Diving is not advised until the pieces fully dissolve.

title: Being Picked Last in Gym, Even if You're a Superhero
description: For anyone who hasn't grasped the connection between the ruthless pecking order of the suburban American high school and the popularity of movies and games in which geeky adolescents dream themselves into becoming superheroes, "Sky High" should help explain the world, or at least the world of entertainment.

title: Police in London and Rome Arrest 4 Suspects in Attack
description: LONDON, July 29 - The police in London and Rome swooped down on four suspected terrorists today in an attempt to round up attackers who tried and failed to bomb subway trains and a bus in London on July 21.

description: Ayad al-Sirowiy, a 13-year-old Iraqi boy, came to the United States to get the tattoo of war removed from his disfigured face.

description: A violent, self-imploding poetry is captured in two searing short dramas by Yukio Mishima.

description: Susan Dodge, the young artistic director of the Dodge Dance Company, knows her dance history. She wears her influences plainly, especially the felicitous ones of Paul Taylor, for whom she danced.

title: Corrections 1/3
description: An obituary on July 20 about Gen. William C. Westmoreland, who commanded United States forces in Vietnam from 1964 to 1968, misidentified a World War II position held by Maxwell D. Taylor, a senior officer who eventually helped advance Westmoreland's career. When the two first met, in 1943, Taylor, a future chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was division artillery commander of the 82nd Airborne, not division commander. 1/3 1/3

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DUBROW, FAY
description: DUBROW--Fay of Brooklyn on July 27. Loving aunt of Stan Pressment and the late Bea Weile. Graveside service will be held on Sunday 10:30AM at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: WHAT'S ON TONIGHT
description: 10 P.M. (HBO) BILL MAHER: I'M SWISS -- Mr. Maher (right), whose series "Politically Incorrect" bit the dust after he described the Sept. 11 terrorists as not cowardly, returns in this performance special, filmed in Portland, Ore. His topics include the presidential election, marijuana, homeland security and gay marriage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, CAROL RIEGELMAN
description: LUBIN -- Carol Riegelman, died on July 26 of heart failure at Lenox Hill Hospital after a very brief illnesss. She was born in 1909; graduated from Smith College in 1930; received an MA and a Ph.D from Columbia University; and was associated professionally with The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, The International Labor Organization, Rutgers University, The City of Reston, The New York Urban Coalition and The United Neighborhood Houses. She was the daughter of the late Charles A. Riegelman and the late Lilian E. Riegelman; the wife of the late Isador Lubin; and the sister of the late William I. Riegelman. She is survived by her daughter, Ann L. Buttenwieser; by her son-inlaw, Lawrence B. Buttenwieser; by her four grandchildren, William L. Buttenwieser, Carol B. Sharp, Jill B. Schloss and Peter L. Buttenwieser; by her 13 great-grandchildren; by her stepdaughter, Alice L. Everitt; by her sister-in-law, Rosalind W. Riegelman; by her two nieces, Mary A. Riegelman and Catherine R. Nathan; and by her two great-nieces. A memorial service for her will be held in the fall.

title: Slain Brazilian is buried amid quiet anger
Taiwan signals easing of travel ban
World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: Mayor Resigns To Seek Presidency
description: Mayor Andrs Manuel Lpez Obrador of Mexico City, the leader of the leftist Democratic Revolutionary Party, stepped down to begin his campaign for president in next year's election. Polls continue to show him to be the most popular politician in the country. Ginger Thompson (NYT)

title: INSIDE
description: Majority Leader as Odd Man Out In challenging President Bush's stem cell policy, Senator Bill Frist, the majority leader, angered conservatives. Mr. Frist, center rear, watched yesterday as Mr. Bush signed a bill that seeks to reduce medical errors. PAGE A11

title: Porsche and unions reach deal
Hewlett-Packard Quietly Ends Deal With Apple to Sell the IPod
description: SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 - It was with great fanfare that Hewlett-Packard announced in January 2004 that it would begin selling Apple's digital music player, the iPod, in a deal that was cast as a major step forward for both companies.

title: Other Legal Matters Hold Up Release of Palladium Convict
description: Correction Appended

title: World Briefing | Americas: Mexico: U.S. Shuts Consulate In Lawless City
description: A day after rival drug gangs clashed on a residential street in Nuevo Laredo with automatic weapons, grenades and bazookas, the American ambassador to Mexico, Tony Garza, said he was ordering the United States Consulate there closed for a week and would open it again only if the security situation improved. No deaths were reported in the latest gun battle in the city, across the Rio Grande from Laredo, Tex., but it came just days after the State Department issued its third travel warning in less than a year over drug-related violence along Mexico's northern border, with Mr. Garza saying that there had been more than 100 violent deaths there since just last month. Antonio Betancourt (NYT)

title: Corrections 1/3
description: A theater review in Weekend yesterday about "Stomp," at the Orpheum in Manhattan, misidentified who plays the leading man. He is Carlos Thomas; Raymond Poitier is another cast member. 1/3 1/3

title: Trade officials warn of collapse in talks
Arts, Briefly; Writers Celebrate the Book
description: The Library of Congress has announced that the novelists John Irving, below, Tom Wolfe and Jonathan Safran Foer are among about 80 writers who have agreed to participate in the fifth annual National Book Festival on Sept. 24. The all-day event will have as it host Laura Bush, who organized a similar event in Texas when President Bush was governor of that state. Authors will read and discuss their works at seven themed pavilions: Fiction and Fantasy, Mysteries and Thrillers, History and Biography, Children, Teens and Children, Poetry, and Home and Family. Among the writers scheduled to give readings and sign books are the astronaut Buzz Aldrin, the presidential biographer David McCullough, E.L. Doctorow, Tom Clancy and Sandra Brown. R.W. Apple Jr., Thomas L. Friedman and David Brooks of The New York Times will also appear. Discussions and readings from the History and Biography pavilion will be broadcast live from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. on C-SPAN2, the library said. (The program will be shown again at 8 p.m.) JOHN FILES

title: Talk Is Cheap, but Not That Cheap
description: REMEMBER when the phone bill was just one bill? Last month, I realized that my husband and I were paying for six different phone/cable/D.S.L./local/long-distance/cellular services. Not only is it a pain to keep track of all these charges, our monthly telecom costs are infuriatingly high: $350 or more.

title: Man Confesses to 3 Killings in Bronx in 1988 and 1990
description: A 37-year-old man has confessed to killing three young girls, ages 13 to 17, in the Bronx more than 15 years ago, the police said yesterday.

title: The Playground M.B.A.
description: FORGET about obtaining a master's degree in business administration, reading scholarly management tomes and putting in long days at the office.

title: Corrections 1/3
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about ever taller buildings misidentified the developer for the 2,300-foot Burj tower in Dubai, which is expected to be the world's tallest building. It is Emaar Properties. (Balfour Beatty is the contractor for a vast shopping mall that is also part of the Burj Dubai development project.) 1/3 1/3

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Flamenco Star Sentenced

title: In Home Games, It's Just Harry, Johnny or Mel
description: Home poker games are played in every American hamlet and metropolis, and in more than a few other hemispheres. With over 250 online sites offering a chance to contest pots with strangers from Rio to Seoul any time of the day or night, the tradition of sitting down in person with friends also continues to flourish.

title: In Spingold Knockout Teams, Defenders Are Knocked Out
description: The premier event of the Summer North American Bridge Championships taking place in Atlanta is the Spingold Master Knockout Teams. On Monday the 76th edition began with a field of 74 teams. After play on Thursday eight teams remained, but not the Nickell team, the defending champion.

title: Arthur Zankel, Concert-Hall Benefactor, Dies at 73
description: Arthur Zankel, a financier who oversaw the Carnegie Hall endowment fund and made a $10 million donation that led to the construction of a new concert space there named for him, died in a fall from his Upper East Side apartment building on Thursday. He was 73.

title: The Roots of Prisoner Abuse
description: This week, the White House blocked a Senate vote on a measure sponsored by a half-dozen Republicans, including Senator John McCain, that would prohibit cruel, degrading or inhumane treatment of prisoners. Besides being outrageous on its face, that action served as a reminder of how the Bush administration ducks for cover behind the men and women in uniform when challenged on military policy, but ignores their advice when it seems inconvenient.

title: To Some in Ulster, Celebration of I.R.A. Pledge Is Early
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 29 - If Northern Ireland woke up on Friday morning to a new era in the province's troubled history, few people here were in a mood to celebrate.

title: Pakistan Investigates Contacts Made in London Bombers' Visit
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, July 29 - President Pervez Musharraf said Friday that Pakistan's investigators were still trying to determine where two of the July 7 London bombers traveled here last year, as well as whom they met.

title: Woods Is So in Control He Was Out of Control
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 29 - As Tiger Woods watched his golf ball disappear into the cup time and again Friday, he peeked beneath his cap at the thousands of spectators who followed him on his four-mile walk.

title: A Long Fight With Giggling, Exploding Monsters
description: Capcom's action adventure game Killer7 deserves a warning label on the front of the box that says "Caution: may cause head to explode." With its off-kilter camera angles, convoluted story, odd premise and surreal imagery, this game is sometimes an overwhelming sensory experience.

title: Roberts Nomination Raises the Issue of the Role of Religious Faith in Public Life
description: Scarcely had Judge John G. Roberts been chosen for the Supreme Court than religion reared its lovely head. And just as swiftly, opponents and supporters of the selection traded accusations over who was responsible.

title: Highway Bill Imposes Strict Car Safety Rules
description: DETROIT, July 29 - Sweeping auto safety initiatives make a transportation bill passed by Congress on Friday the most comprehensive legislation of its kind in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRECKIR, DOROTHY K.
description: BRECKIR--Dorothy K. Died July 29, 2005 in New York City at the age of 97. Her last few years were a struggle between her body and her mind for autonomy. She is finally at rest after a long, productive life. Beside a host of loving and caring friends, wonderfully supportive healthcare givers, she is survived by her daughter Patricia Breckir Miller and husband Irwin, her son Joseph Breckir, grandchildren Jane Miller Henderson and Bart, James Miller and Dale, Luke Miller, Ellen Lear and Peter Ruig, Kate Lear and Jonathan LaPook, Maggie Lear and Daniel Katz and her great-granchildren Olivia, Lily, Owen, Clementine, Daniel, Noah, Griffen, Zoe and Zaneta. She will be missed by all. A celebration of her life will be held at a future date. Contributions may be made in her memory to People for the American Way.

title: Developer's Former Neighbors Criticize Delay in Co-op Case
description: Some 18 months before Andrew M. Kissel's arrest this week by federal authorities on charges that he defrauded banks and investors from Seattle to Stratton, Vt., the Manhattan district attorney's office received complaints that Mr. Kissel had looted more than $3 million from his neighbors on the Upper East Side.

title: Rangers Part Ways With Holik
description: The Rangers, no strangers to outspending their rivals but who now have to grapple with the constraints of a salary cap, bought out the contract of center Bobby Holik, who was scheduled to make an estimated $16 million over the next two seasons.

title: Gentle Desert Breeze for Troubled Fisherman
description: SANTA FE, N.M., July 29 - Suspension of disbelief becomes particularly hard when the cold, cruel world of "Peter Grimes" finds itself framed in a New Mexico sunset. Operagoers everywhere are hardened to improbability, but one wondered how patrons at the Santa Fe Opera on Thursday night were taking in Benjamin Britten's unforgiving world of precipitous tides, punishing winds and reeking fish as soft breezes off the desert blew across their faces.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: New Jersey Judge Rules That Health Plans Can Sue as a Class Over Vioxx Spending In the latest blow to Merck & Company, a New Jersey judge has ruled that health plans that paid for members' Vioxx prescriptions can sue as a class to recover billions of dollars they spent on the recalled painkiller. Superior Court Judge Carol E. Higbee in Atlantic City yesterday granted a motion filed by a labor union health plan to allow a nationwide class-action lawsuit to proceed under the New Jersey Consumer Fraud Act. The International Union of Operating Engineers Local 68 Welfare Fund had sued Merck in early 2003, arguing that its health plan would not have covered Vioxx prescriptions but for Merck's deception about the risks of the drug, which cost several times as much as older, traditional anti-inflammatory medicines. Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., said in a statement that the judge's decision was "not a ruling on the merits" and that the company believes the plaintiffs' claims are unfounded. (AP)

title: Corrections 1/3
description: An article in Business Day on July 20 about a court ruling in a closely watched case about the use of a family limited partnership to reduce inheritance taxes referred incorrectly to a statement by the chief counsel for the Internal Revenue Service, Donald L. Korb. He indeed addressed the case specifically, praising the ruling, which upheld the position of the I.R.S. that the partnership was improper; he did not decline to comment. The article also paraphrased his remarks imprecisely. He said that family partnerships were often abused to avoid taxes -- not that they were used in general for that purpose. 1/3 1/3

title: A Rising Star's Startling Flameout
description: The story of the rapid rise and tragic descent of Frances Farmer, the 1930's Hollywood actress, has been told before -- most memorably in the 1982 film "Frances," starring Jessica Lange. It would be hard for any actress to compete with Ms. Lange's heartbreaking performance, but Sarah Ireland, in the title role of Sally Clark's "Saint Frances of Hollywood," isn't even on the same planet.

title: Death for Rapist Teacher in China
description: BEIJING, July 29 - A teacher in western China who raped 23 fourth- and fifth-grade girls in his office has been sentenced to death, according to an account this week in a Chinese newspaper.

title: Senate Approves Bill Protecting Gun Businesses
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 - The Senate agreed to shield gun manufacturers and dealers from liability lawsuits on Friday, as Congress broke for a monthlong recess after sending President Bush energy and transportation bills that had been years in the making.

title: Saluting Father of Spaghetti Westerns
description: LOS ANGELES, July 29 - On Tuesday, in a museum tucked into a corner of Los Angeles's sprawling Griffith Park, three men re-enacted the climactic shootout from the 1966 western "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly."

title: The World According to Kunstler
description: JAMES HOWARD KUNSTLER, author of the visionary urban-planning jeremiad "The Geography of Nowhere" and the even better "Home From Nowhere," has taken to the Web in a big way.

title: Belichick's Mission: Prove Attrition Is Not Erosion
description: FOXBORO, Mass., July 29 - Who could blame New England Patriots Coach Bill Belichick if he were suffering from an acute case of empty-nest syndrome? He began training camp Friday without many of the cogs that helped him win two consecutive Super Bowls and three in the past four seasons.

title: I.R.A. Pledge Seen as Potential Model for Other Conflicts
description: At a celebratory lunch yesterday in New York, one eminent speaker after another, from an archbishop to a former secretary of state, rose to rejoice in the news that the Irish Republican Army had abandoned violence and suggest that Northern Ireland could prove an example to the world.

title: Returning to Familiar Spot, Mets Look for Way Out
description: Correction Appended

title: From silver screen to smaller screens
Personal Business; More American Retirees Seek Havens Abroad
description: These days, some Americans heading for retirement are as concerned with pesos as pensions, and foreign language classes as Medicare. They are part of an emerging population expecting to spend their retirement abroad.

title: On the Road to an Irish Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: NASA Administrator Says Debris Problems Will Be Quickly Fixed
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 - The NASA administrator, Michael D. Griffin, said Friday that problems with falling debris from the space shuttle's fuel tank would be quickly solved. "I think we are going to fix it," he said of the tank, "fix it in short order and get back to flying."

title: Corrections 1/3
description: An article on Thursday about the part played by Walter Pincus, a reporter for The Washington Post involved in the C.I.A. leak case, misstated his view about the reason an administration official might have volunteered information to him about the role reportedly played by the wife of the diplomat Joseph C. Wilson in arranging her husband's trip to Niger. Mr. Pincus wrote in the current issue of Nieman Reports that he believed the official was "practicing damage control by trying to get me to stop writing about Wilson" -- not by trying to get him to write about Mr. Wilson. 1/3 The article also misstated the month in 2003 that the special prosecutor in the case said that another reporter, Judith Miller of The New York Times, talked to a specified government official. It was July, not June. 1/3 The article also carried an erroneous dateline. It was written in Washington on July 27, not 26. 1/3 1/3

title: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Fury At ABC Interview With Warlord
description: Russia reacted with fury to ABC's broadcast of a rare interview with Shamil Basayev, the Chechen rebel who has claimed responsibility for the country's deadliest terrorist attacks, including the siege of a school in Beslan that ended with the deaths of more than 300 hostages last September. The Foreign Ministry took the rare step of summoning the top American diplomat now in Moscow, Daniel Russell, the deputy chief of mission, while officials and lawmakers sharply criticized the interview as evidence of anti-Russian hostility and a double-standard in attitudes toward terrorism. In rambling, at time muddled remarks, broadcast Thursday on "Nightline," Mr. Basayev remained defiant and vowed new attacks. "We're always looking for new ways," he said. Steven Lee Myers (NYT)

title: After Dispute, Judge's Confirmation Hearings Set to Start Sept. 6
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 - Senate leaders agreed Friday to begin hearings on the nomination of Judge John G. Roberts to the Supreme Court on Sept. 6, but the scheduling plan was nearly derailed by a dispute among the Democrats over how hard to push back against the nomination.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGER, MARK H.
description: BERGER--Mark H. 77, of New York, N.Y., suddenly on July 27, 2005. Loving husband of 51 years of Margaret, beloved father of Joshua (Leeza) and David (Tracey), and wonderful grandfather of Tashi and Noah. He was an alumnus of Polytechnic University (1947) and of Harvard Law School (1950). Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, July 31, 11:30am. Donations in lieu of flowers to East 55 St. Conservative Synagogue, 308 E. 55 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10022.

title: Bringing Us Nearer, Mozart, to Thee
description: Performers, administrators and concertgoers who have long fretted over the acoustics of Avery Fisher Hall had a lot invested in the experiment tried on Thursday night: the temporary reconfiguration of the stage. The occasion was the opening of the 39th season of the popular Mostly Mozart Festival, and the hall was packed. The dynamic French conductor Louis Langre directed the festival orchestra in an eclectic program featuring the starry soprano Rene Fleming and the fine pianist Stephen Hough as soloists. With such musical news being made, PBS chose to broadcast the concert as part of its "Live From Lincoln Center" series.

title: Arts, Briefly; 'Law Firm' Spills a Secret
description: CBS's Thursday supremacy continued unabated this week. According to Nielsen's estimates, the network had nearly twice as large an audience as its closest competition, both in total viewers and among adults 18 to 49. CBS led off with "Big Brother," in which the bossy Boston firefighter, Eric Littman, was ousted from the house in a close vote. The episode drew 7.5 million viewers, and its ratings were slightly lower than on previous Thursdays, but it won the hour in all key demographics. Repeats of "CSI" (13.14 million) and "Without a Trace" (11.34 million) were also No. 1 in their time slots. Facing "CSI," the most-watched show of the night, was the debut of NBC's "Law Firm," a reality show in which good-looking young lawyers try real cases for a $250,000 prize. It caused barely a ripple, bringing in 5.09 million viewers and placing third among 18-to-49-year-olds. Making matters worse, before the first two contestants were eliminated, scenes from next week's show were broadcast during a commercial break, revealing who the axed lawyers were. A statement from NBC confirmed the mistake, and said it happened in the East and Central time zones only. KATE AURTHUR

description: Lottery Numbers

title: After Role Is Cut, State Dept. Official Quits
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 - Roger F. Noriega, an outspoken critic of Cuba and Venezuela who has been assistant secretary of state for Latin American affairs for the past two years, announced his resignation on Friday, saying he had served in government long enough.

title: A Briton's Vision Takes Hold in the Heartland
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa - For three decades, the moribund downtown of this historic Mississippi River city, where barges heaped with coal ply the water and freight trains rumble day and night, has waited for its future. That future, many here say, has finally materialized in the form of a new museum: a spare box under glass designed by a British architect who in recent years has landed some of Europe's most prestigious commissions.

title: Congress Caps Credits for Hybrid Cars
description: DETROIT, July 29 - Tucked away on page 1,391 of the 1,724-page energy bill approved by Congress this week is a new tax credit intended to make fuel-efficient vehicles like hybrids more appealing to consumers. But as is often the case with tax credits, the devil is in the details.

title: Mayor Backs M.T.A.'s Railyard Plan
description: After the failure of his effort to build a stadium for the Jets on a giant platform on the site of the West Side railyards, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that he supported a plan by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which owns the site, to use surplus funds to build a platform anyway and sell development rights for office and residential towers.

title: Jets Fan Learns to Be Careful What to Ask For
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 29 - Ray Hoffman, a Jets fan from Staten Island, would have been hard to miss at the team's first practice of training camp yesterday even if he had not been screaming. He stood out in his green cape, tights and white winged hard hat.

title: Waiting for Another L. B. J.
description: IN March 1964, President Lyndon B. Johnson eyed one of the toughest unfinished tasks he had inherited from John F. Kennedy: creation of a national health care program for the elderly. With typical ambition and determination, he told his aide on health care, Wilbur Cohen, "We're going to spend the rest of our lives if necessary passing medical care."

title: Gadgets of the week: Typing comfort isn't cheap
Sinai Bombings Renew Old Tensions Between Bedouins and Egyptian Authorities
description: SHARM EL SHEIK, Egypt, July 29 - Sitting in a makeshift hut of wood scraps and thistle, the Jabal el-Thabt mountain looming above him, Eid Hussein grew agitated recounting the insults he had faced at the hands of the authorities recently.

Foreign banks under fire inParmalat case
Dump Truck Plows Through Intersection, Causing 20-Vehicle Accident and Killing 4
description: HARTFORD, July 29 - Laden with dirt as it descended a mountain into a prosperous suburb, a dump truck with a history of brake violations barreled into traffic at a busy intersection in Avon, Conn., on Friday morning, crushing cars and setting off a chain of fiery collisions that killed four people and injured 14.

title: Talk Is Cheap, but Acquiring a Slugger Isn't
description: HOUSTON, July 29 - While many major league teams are trying to acquire a middle reliever or move a fringe prospect before the nonwaiver trading deadline Sunday, the Mets are pursuing one All-Star slugger after another.

title: Senate Leader Criticized and Praised for Stem Cell Shift
description: Correction Appended

title: A Cycle of Destruction, From Love to Despair
description: Flowers do not fall softly in the elegant, angry theater of Yukio Mishima. In the first of the two searing short dramas by Mishima performed by the Ninagawa Company under the title "Modern Noh Plays," as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, red camellias drop from unseen heights onto the stage of the Rose Theater in a succession of hollow, wooden plops.

title: Storage companies grab the spotlight
Suggestions of Strength in Economy
description: Businesses and households went on a shopping spree this spring, causing warehouse stockpiles to shrink and setting the stage for faster economic growth during the rest of the year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINTO, NICK
description: PINTO--Nick. Unexpectedly we lost Nick Pinto July 2, 2005. Friend, Colleague, Bon Vivant Raconteur. Man about Greenwich Village, a good man lost in a medical maelstrom. Memorial gala to be held 3-6pm Kettle of Fish, Sunday July 31, 2005. Ruth Rogin

title: Interest Is Now Turning Toward Younger Murdoch
description: LONDON, July 29 - Now that Lachlan K. Murdoch has stepped down from the News Corporation, the spotlight is turning toward his younger brother James, chief executive of the pay-television company, British Sky Broadcasting.

title: A Windfall for the M.T.A.
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, long strapped for cash, has suddenly found itself with an $833 million surplus. Election-bound politicians have quickly demanded that the money be used to stave off planned fare increases. Transit officials, meanwhile, have floated the idea of using most of the money to build a platform over the West Side railyards to make the site more valuable for future real estate development.

title: I'm Here to See a Man About a Suit
description: I WENT looking for a custom suit like some wiseacre detective named Jake in a film noir, only to wind up in Chinatown on the hottest day of the summer so far. The sidewalks were packed tighter than subway cars at rush hour; the air smelled like pork fried rust. Vendors were hawking $5 soap bubble guns, and the red and gold Chinese characters plastered on the banks, the Buddhist temple, the fish market and the retail stores looked like they were about to melt into candle wax.

title: 4 London suspects all in police hands
For the Beginners, Some Balanchine and Ray Charles
description: Even though the Nilas Martins Dance Company's performance at Central Park SummerStage on Thursday night was not a New York City Ballet event, it was like a casual, charming to-go version. Mr. Martins's program was impressively designed to introduce neophytes to the ballet without cheapening the experience for Lincoln Center groupies.

title: In Ulster, skepticism on the IRA runs deep
Citing DNA, Court Annuls Murder Conviction From 1989
description: MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., July 29 - The rape and murder conviction of a New Jersey man imprisoned for 18 years was overturned by a Superior Court judge on Friday after DNA testing invalidated all the physical evidence tying him to the crime.

title: Lawmakers' Pet Projects (and Not Just for Roads) Find Home in Transportation Bill
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 - Representative Don Young, Alaska's lone congressman, flew home happy on Friday for the August recess.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, JOHN IGNATIUS
description: DAVIS--John Ignatius, of Englewood Cliffs, NJ suddenly July 29, 2005. Born August 9, 1919, much loved husband for 55 years of Mariam Prisament Davis. Cherished father of Ted and Susan, Judy and Jeff Fagan, Gerry and Debbie. Loving grandfather of James and Alison Fagan, Brandon, Jessica, Elizabeth and Benjamin Davis. Dear brother of Lucille Winters and brother-in-law of Gloria Prisament and the late Norman. Friend of many. Mason, past District Deputy F&M, First Manhattan District of NY. Avid fisherman, golfer, world traveler, always ready for an adventure. He will be missed. Services Sunday, 11:30AM Gutterman - Musi cant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey. DAVIS--John. Temple Sinai of Bergen County deeply mourns the passing of our longtime member, John Davis, husband of Mariam Davis. Condolences are extended to the entire family. Dr. Bruce S. Block, Rabbi George Bean and Janene Edlin, Presidents DAVIS--John. description: Gary Skoien, the chairman of the Cook County Republican Party, was fired from his job as chief operating officer at a real estate development company after offering a $10,000 reward for information leading to an indictment and conviction of Mayor Richard M. Daley earlier this week. Michael Reschke, chief executive officer of Prime Group Inc., called Mr. Skoien's action intemperate, unfair and crass. Mr. Skoien, above, said his firing was a sad commentary about fear and intimidation in the city. "In America you can stand up and say a political thought and go on with life, but in Chicago you might lose your job," Mr. Skoien said. Mayor Daley said in a statement that it was unfortunate that any of the events had happened. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Debunking the Concept of 'Race'
description: Black Americans who explore their family histories typically hit a dead end in the early 19th century, when black Americans who were slaves were not listed in the census by name. Now some black Americans are trying to fill in the gap with genetic screening tests that purport to tell descendants exactly where in Africa their ancestors came from. But, like most people, those who think of themselves as African-American will need to search well beyond Africa to find all of their origins.

The recurring drought in the Sahel, that parched strip across Africa that separates the Sahara from the rain forests, dried up Niger's harvest, and the crops that survived drought were hit by locusts. The result is sadly familiar: dead or dying children by the thousands, as Niger's most vulnerable succumb first to these forces of nature.

description: A St. Helena Boy Scout troop leader was killed and a teenage scout was brain-dead after lightning struck a makeshift shelter they had erected in Sequoia National Park during a hailstorm, the authorities said. Steve McCullagh, 29, an assistant scoutmaster, was killed, and Ryan Collins, 13, was on life support. Mr. McCullagh, four other adults and five teenage scouts had taken cover under a tarp that was hit by a lightning bolt. The incident comes just days after four men were electrocuted while putting up a tent at the National Scout Jamboree in Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARBER, LEONARD L.
description: FARBER--Leonard L. On July 28, 2005, Leonard died peacefully in his home in Fort Lauderdale, FL. He was 89 years old and for years fought Parkinson's Disease with great courage and success. Beloved and adoring husband of Antje, his wife of 30 years. Loving and supportive father of Lindy Linder, Peggy Farber, Felicia Farber Gervais and the late Robert Farber. Grandfather of Liza and Luke Linder, Ben and Sam Jacoff. Loving and supportive father - in - law to Charles S. Gervais, uncle to Eric W. Deckinger and so many more. Born in New York, Leonard skipped college as his father, Morris, died when Leonard was 17 years old and he had to work to support mother Clara and sister Norma. A non-commissioned officer in the U.S. Army, he received the Purple Heart and two Bronze Stars for his bravery and heroism during his duty in Europe during WWII. Leonard was Chairman of Leonard L. Farber Company, a shopping center development firm that had its first seeds of formation in the early 1950's when Leonard and a small group of visionaries began building suburban shopping centers. Leonard was a pioneer in this new industry and was the founding President of the International Council of Shopping Centers, which he helped found in 1957. By this year the organization, now known as the "ICSC", has 45,000 members worldwide, up from the approximate seven original members so many years ago. Over the course of his career, Leonard developed 45 shopping centers from California to Puerto Rico. Leonard received the Horatio Alger Award in 1985 and his Honorary Degree from Brandeis University in 1989. He also served as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Brandeis in the mid 1980's where he built the Leonard L. Farber Library and the Robert D. Farber University Archives. President Jimmy Carter appointed Leonard in 1979, to serve on the board of the National Endowment for the Arts. Leonard also was an active community leader, philanthropist and friend. He served over the years on many boards as well as being a donor to many organizations and causes, most notably, The Broward Center for the Performance Arts, The Ft. Lauderdale Symphony Orchestra, The Museum of Arts, The Boys and Girls Club of Ft. Lauderdale, Nova University, Brandeis University, and the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Leonard loved most to cruise on his boat Stoneface, with wife and "1st mate", Antje. He especially enjoyed their summers cruising up the Eastern seaboard to their home away from home, Nantucket Harbor. He was always happiest aboard Stoneface and hosting family and friends in ports in the Caribbean to Bar Harbor to Capri - and all points in between. Leonard's love of life, sensitivity to others, leadership position in so many roles, and determination served as a beacon and role model to all those lucky enough to know him. A Funeral will be held at 2:00p.m. on Sunday, July 31st, at Temple Kol Ami Emanu-El at 8200 Peters Road Plantation, Fla. In Lieu of flowers the family requests memorial gifts be made in Leonard?s honor to The National Parkinson's Foundation or the Massachusetts General Hospital Institute for Neurodegenerative Disease.

title: With Interest: 'China model' is tough to copy
Paid Notice: Deaths   ZANKEL, ARTHUR
description: ZANKEL--Arthur on July 28, 2005 at age 73. Founding partner of High Rise Capital Management, former director of Citigroup, former comanaging partner of First Manhattan Company, ViceChairman of Carnegie Hall and Trustee of Teachers College. Beloved husband of Judy. Loving father of Kenneth, Thomas, Mark and James. Cherished grandfather of Maura and Andrew. Devoted brother of Martin and Jeffrey. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 11:30AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall at Carnegie Hall 881 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10019. ZANKEL--Arthur. The Board and staff of Carnegie Hall mourn the loss of beloved friend and dedicated Trustee Arthur Zankel, who died on July 28, 2005, at the age of 73. Arthur joined the Board of Carnegie Hall in 1992, and for more than a decade provided this institution with expert leadership and sound financial advice, overseeing, in particular, the steady growth of the Hall's endowment fund. Arthur's unbounded generosity to Carnegie Hall and his unstinting conviction that all lovers of great music should find a home here led to the opening of Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall in September 2003, a watershed event that has created the opportunity for Carnegie Hall to welcome truly diverse great music from around the globe, and provided a technological platform for outreach to new audiences worldwide. Arthur will be remembered fondly for his genuine warmth, his extraordinary humor, and his uncanny ability to make you feel that you were the most important person in the world. In Judy, he found an equally caring and gracious partner, who shared his deep love of music and his great passion for life. All of us at Carnegie Hall feel personally bereft by this sudden and unexpected loss. We express our heartfelt condolences to Judy, and to James, Kenneth, Mark, Thomas, and the extended family. Funeral services will be held at Frank E. Campbell-The Funeral Chapel at 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Sanford I. Weill Chairman of the Board ZANKEL--Arthur, financier and philanthropist. Mr. Zankel was a longtime trusted advisor who joined Citigroup's Board of Directors at its inception in 1986. His experience and judgment helped the company grow from Commercial Credit into Citigroup -- a journey of remarkable accomplishment. Mr. Zankel served Citigroup for more than a decade as chairman of the personnel and compensation committee. As a member of the succession subcommittee, he helped to assure the extraordinarily smooth transition to Citigroup's new CEO and COO structure in 2003. When Mr. Zankel retired from the Board in 2004, Citigroup Chairman Sanford I. Weill said, "It's not an exaggeration to say that no company approaching our size and scale and depth of management talent has ever had such a successful, virtually seamless transition. Arthur deserves much of the credit." Citigroup appreciates his years of dedicated service and extends its condolences to his wife Judy, and sons, James, Mark, Thomas, and Kenneth. A memorial service will be held Sunday, July 31, 2005, at 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, New York, New York 10028; 212288-3500. ZANKEL--Arthur. Teachers College is deeply saddened at the passing of Arthur Zankel, Vice Chairman of our Board of Trustees. Arthur was a highly intelligent and caring man who never forgot his roots. He had a wonderful sense of humor and was a wise counselor who knew what he believed and never took himself too seriously. He was a good and caring friend. He was deeply in love with his wife, Judy, and his children. He was passionate about the need to improve the lives of the children who have the least. He gave generously of his time and resources to accomplish this. Our world is a better place and our lives have been enriched because Arthur Zankel walked among us. There can be no higher measure of success in life. His passing is a profound loss to all who were touched by his enthusiasm and generosity. Our thoughts are with his wife, Judy, and his four children. Arthur Levine, President John C. Hyland William D. Rueckert Co-Chairs Board of Trustees Teachers College Columbia University ZANKEL--Arthur. Our hearts are broken over the tragic loss of our dearest friend Arthur. With his wisdom, his warmth and compassion, his sensible advice and his outrageous sense of humor he was such an important part of our lives and our decisions. He was always there for us, ready to take "a walk in the woods" or "a swim in the pool". Our New Year's weekends will never be the same, but we are so lucky to have those treasured memories of our time together. Our hearts go out to his beloved wife Judy who made him so very happy in the eight years of their marriage. He also felt such pride and love for his boys Kenny, Tommy, Mark and Jimmy, their spouses and his grandchildren. Arthur, we already miss you, and we will never forget all you have been to us. May you rest in peace, dear friend. With all our love. Joan and Sandy Weill ZANKEL--Arthur. The Alan Greene family deeply mourns the loss of a great friend and confidant, Arthur Zankel. We send our heartfelt condolences to Judy, Kenneth, Tommy, Mark and James. We will miss him greatly. Helen, Alan, Jimmy and Michael ZANKEL--Arthur. The Board of the New York Foundation mourns the passing of our former trustee, Arthur Zankel. He was a dedicated trustee and a longtime supporter of the work of the New York Foundation. ZANKEL--Arthur. Our world will never be the same. Our love to Judy and the boys. Kathy & Freddy

description: About two weeks before a college student with a flawed heart device died in March, another heart patient implanted with the same model that also failed almost died, according to a government filing by the device's maker, the Guidant Corporation.

title: U.N. Aides Freed in Gaza
description: JERUSALEM, July 29 - A Palestinian family in Gaza sought to win the release of a kidnapped relative on Friday by briefly seizing two United Nations workers, the family said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GANG, FAY
description: GANG--Fay, 83, on July 28. Wife of Dr. Kenneth Gang. Mother of Kenneth Hirsch. Grandmother of Benjamin Hirsch. She devoted her life to young children and their education.

title: Serving an Industry That Saved Him
description: THE former congressman, W.J. "Billy" Tauzin of Louisiana, left Capitol Hill last year and, in January, became chief executive of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, the trade association known as PhRMA.

title: Bolton Not Truthful, 36 Senators Charge in Opposing Appointment
description: WASHINGTON, July 29 - Charging that John R. Bolton was "not truthful" in answering questions about his record, 36 senators urged President Bush on Friday not to make a recess appointment of Mr. Bolton as United Nations ambassador after the Senate's failure to confirm him for that job.

title: A Week of Random Backpack Searches Yields Little Drama
description: In the past eight days, the New York Police Department has randomly searched through the bags of several thousand commuters in more than 400 subway stations. About 20,000 other travelers have submitted to inspections of their belongings in bus terminals and commuter train stations in and around the city.

title: Eagles' McDougle Is Shot During Robbery the Night Before Camp Opens
description: PHILADELPHIA, July 29 - An anxious off-season for the Philadelphia Eagles grew more unsettled on the eve of training camp, when defensive end Jerome McDougle was shot in the abdomen while being robbed Thursday night in suburban Miami, the police said.

title: Seeking Edge, Ferrer Readies Ad Blitz
description: Fernando Ferrer is set to start advertising as soon as Tuesday, his campaign manager said yesterday, an attempt to expand his lead over his Democratic rivals and one that signals a new phase in the race for mayor.

title: Briefly: U.S. military identifies German bases to close
Senator Frist's Stem Cell Shift
description: The Senate majority leader, Bill Frist, deserves credit for moving gingerly toward a more expansive policy on stem cell research. Mr. Frist -- the transplant-surgeon-turned-lawmaker who was last seen catering to religious conservatives by questioning whether Terri Schiavo was really in a persistent vegetative state -- showed courage and common sense yesterday by endorsing a bill to expand federal financing for embryonic stem cell research. Such research has the potential to provide cures for a range of diseases someday, but it is anathema to the religious right because the stem cells are extracted from microscopic embryos that are destroyed in the process.

title: Young Quarterbacks, Future Pitchmen
description: ALISO VIEJO, Calif., July 27 - Cody Hawkins arrived from Boise, Idaho, wearing Converse sneakers and a rainbow-colored polo shirt he bought for $3 at Goodwill. As soon as he set foot on campus here Monday, Hawkins, along with 11 other top high school quarterbacks, was handed new gear. In an oversized black Nike duffel bag, he found pairs of Nike Shox running shoes and cleats, and a Nike football, the only brand he would be allowed to use for the next four days.

title: U.N. Charges Sudan Ignores Rapes in Darfur by Military and Police
description: UNITED NATIONS, July 29 - Sexual attacks by soldiers, militia members and the police are widespread throughout Sudan's Darfur region, and the authorities often end up accusing the victims rather than investigating the crimes, the United Nations said Friday.

title: Making babies for France
Raw Emotions on the Tip of the Tongue
description: BECKET, Mass., July 29 - Although dancers may accidentally bite their tongues while rehearsing or performing, choreography does not ordinarily involve tongue biting. But Aszure Barton made a duet with four minutes of it biting the climax of "Lascilo Perdere," which she presented on Thursday night at Jacob's Pillow here.

title: Yankees Will Receive Help by Fits and Starts
description: Shawn Chacon rolled into Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon, put on a new pinstriped uniform and prepared to meander through what has been a revolving door at the back of the rotation. Chacon is scheduled to start today against the Los Angeles Angels. After that, who knows?

title: POLICE IN LONDON AND ROME ARREST 4 BOMB SUSPECTS
description: LONDON, July 29 - The police in London and Rome, acting several hours apart on Friday, arrested the remaining bombing suspects in the July 21 failed attacks in London, according to a Scotland Yard official, placing the four main suspects in police custody.

title: Corrections 1/3
description: A report in the "Arts, Briefly" column on Tuesday about the cast of "A Mother, a Daughter and a Gun," which is to open in the fall at Dodger Stages, misidentified the show for which Veanne Cox was nominated for a Tony. It was the revival of "Company," not "Caroline, or Change." 1/3 1/3

title: Investing: Yuan shifts. Now what?
World Briefing | Asia: India: Kashmir Violence Escalates
description: A spate of recent violence in Indian-held Kashmir continued as the police and militants engaged in a gun battle in the heart of the summer capital, Srinagar, in broad daylight, and suspected militants carried out a vicious sectarian slaying. The Srinagar battle left 15 injured, the police said. In a hilly, violence-prone border area called Rajouri, the police said suspected militants entered a village, separated its Hindu and Muslim residents and killed five Hindu men by slitting their throats. In a nearby village, the body of a Muslim woman was found with her throat slit. The authorities said they were investigating whether the separate killings were linked. Hari Kumar (NYT)

title: Corrections 1/3
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on July 20 about Paul Duke, longtime moderator of the public television program "Washington Week in Review," misstated its broadcast history. By the time Mr. Duke joined the program, in 1974, it was seen nationally. (It began as a local program in 1967.) 1/3 1/3

title: Arts Guide
Meanwhile: The Dear Leader provides good drinking water
National Briefing | Plains: Kansas: Killer Forgoes Lawyers In Civil Suits
description: Dennis Rader, the convicted serial killer who called himself B.T.K., for bind, torture, kill, plans to represent himself in seven civil wrongful-death lawsuits by relatives of his victims. Mark Hutton, a lawyer for two relatives of a victim, Kathryn Bright, said he was not surprised by the move, suggesting that it would have been difficult for Mr. Rader, who pleaded guilty last month to killing 10 people in the Wichita area from 1974 to 1991, to find a lawyer. His sentencing is scheduled for Aug. 17. Gretchen Ruethling (NYT)

title: Ordeal in Niger
description: Images of victims of a food crisis in the vast, landlocked West African nation of Niger look like something the world has seen before - the famine in Ethiopia in the 1980's.

title: The Adderall Advantage
description: IT was finals week at Columbia University and Angela needed a miracle. Like many of her classmates, Angela, a bleary-eyed junior, had already pulled a pair of all-nighters to get through a paper on "Finnegans Wake," a French test and an exam for her music humanities class. All that remained was a Latin American literature final, but as midnight approached, her stamina was beginning to fade. "This week is killing me," she said, taking a cigarette break in front of the school library. "At this point, I could use a little help."

title: Making a Less Fusty Frick (and Hoping Nobody Notices)
description: WITH its selection of revered old master paintings and imposing Gilded Age dcor, the Frick Collection is set in its ways. And visitors apparently like it that way. People were so startled by improved lighting in the galleries a few years ago that they worried that all the paintings had been cleaned. One woman recently wrote to complain after she discovered that her Bronzino had been moved. When a never-before-displayed portrait bust quietly took up residence next to Jacques-Louis David's well-known oil portrait of the Comtesse Daru last fall, it was a potential earthquake in the making.

title: Switched Off in Basra
description: Basra, Iraq

title: Bologna
description: WHY GO NOW With its millennium-old university, chiming bicycle traffic and devotion to perfect pasta, Bologna, Italy's quintessential college town, enjoys a summer break from its roughly 100,000 students and puts its dusky red medieval architecture on center stage.

title: What We Talk About When We Talk About Editing
description: IN February 2004, I published an essay in this space describing life at the Op-Ed page. While the article touched on the main facets of our operation high up in the Times building, it focused largely on the submission and selection process.

description: Analysts figured that Loral Space and Communications would be dismembered after it entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings two years ago, a development that probably would have ended the long and sometimes unconventional career of its chairman and chief executive, Bernard L. Schwartz, then 77.

title: Margaret Williams, Geoffrey Zakarian
description: Margaret Anne Williams, a marketing executive, and Geoffrey Harry Zakarian, the chef, were married yesterday at Our Lady of Lebanon Roman Catholic Church in Niagara Falls, N.Y. The Rev. John F. Lauri, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

description: THE hostess was standing inside a taco stand covered in cheap wood paneling when two guys approached. Had she heard of a new restaurant, hidden somewhere below the triangular crossroads of SoHo, NoLIta and Chinatown?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   APPLETON, SHELLEY
description: APPLETON--Shelley. We admire our friend's tireless efforts on behalf of workers. He fought the good fight. He finished the race. He kept the faith. Marvin and Evelyn Jones Rich

title: The Framing Wars
description: Bai's otherwise excellent dissertation pays scant attention to the vital element of timing. In the 2004 campaign, Bush, using a strategy uncharacteristic for a sitting president, set out to frame John Kerry even before Kerry could frame himself. The frame of the story is important, of course, but being first is paramount.

title: Bohemian Rhapsody
description: NEW YORKERS already know that their city is a global center for everything from finance and business to arts and culture. But even the most self-assured resident would likely be astounded by the extraordinary magnitude of the greater New York regional economy.

description: IT was, in the words of one reporter, "a precious commodity," and to the great consternation of the city's masses, its price was once again on the rise.

title: Fall '05 Trend Report
description: 90's (That's the 1890's) 1893: The World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago introduces the Beaux-Arts style to America, setting the stage for the Gilded Age and its fitted jackets and balloonish sleeves. 1896: Sigmund Freud uses the term "psychoanalysis." 1897: Queen Victoria celebrates the 60th anniversary of her ascension. 1898: H.G. Wells publishes "The War of the Worlds."

title: Two Faces of Terrorism: Is One More Evil Than the Other?
description: LONDON - THERE was a moment of cruel poignancy last week when Britain bid a long hoped-for farewell to I.R.A. terrorism only to acknowledge that it may now face a still more determined enemy in suicidal Islamic terrorism. Both the hopeful note and the warning involved men named Blair.

description: ADORED By Tilly Bagshawe. 548 pp. Warner Books. $23.95.

title: Independent Bookstore To Close in Greenwich
description: The owners of Just Books, an independent bookstore in Greenwich long known as a host for book signings with famous authors, have announced that the store would close Aug. 14 after more than a half-century on East Putnam Avenue. They will continue to operate a second store, Just Books, Too in Old Greenwich.

title: Earned Run Average Is Not the Best Performance Review
description: In most lines of work, failing to do what your boss asks will not help your performance review. Relief pitching, however, is a strange profession.

description: THE whistle-stop town of Emporia, Kan. (population 27,000), has two claims to fame: William Allen White, the Pulitzer Prize-winning newspaper editor and confidant of Theodore Roosevelt, and turning out teachers.

title: You'll Never Do Research in This Town Again
description: WALL STREET analysts have taken a lot of heat in recent years from regulators and this columnist for being incessantly, unjustifiably upbeat about the companies they follow. Cheerleading from the sidelines was, of course, a proven way to generate investment banking revenue for analysts' firms. Incompetence also played a role in many reports, where a corporate outlook was always rosy.

title: Dancing as Fast, and as Tightly, as She Can
description: Montclair, N.J. - SUSAN MARSHALL is putting the finishing touches on her new work, five brief dances sheltering under the umbrella title "Cloudless," to have its premiere this week at Jacob's Pillow. At least the rehearsal schedule called for finishing touches. It sometimes looks as if she is reinventing the dances from scratch, like a God with second thoughts.

title: Ramirez Well Worth Keeping or Getting
description: IN the event the Red Sox masterminds Larry Lucchino and Theo Epstein failed to notice, their baseball team awoke today as the defending World Series champion, in first place in the American League East and, as presently constituted, with Manny Ramirez, at worst a pick 'em choice between them and the pitching-starved Yankees this season to make the playoffs.

title: Glynis Gotwald, Adam Ford
description: Glynis Anne Gotwald, a public affairs specialist, and Adam Caleb Ford, a lawyer, were married yesterday in Syracuse. The Rev. Frederick R. Mannara performed the ceremony at the Most Holy Rosary Roman Catholic Church.

title: Fraud in the Schools
description: The New York State Regents examinations are for the most part well-administered and, in general, immune from wholesale fraud. But a blatant case of test tampering at a Brooklyn high school that took years to uncover suggests that state and city officials can still do more to protect the integrity of the testing process. New procedures that shield teachers who report irregularities, and make it easier for them to report fraud , would be a good place to start.

description: THOMAS PAINE AND THE PROMISE OF AMERICA By Harvey J. Kaye. 326 pp. Hill & Wang. $25.

title: Pollution in a Box
description: SINCE entering the New York market in 2003, the online grocer Fresh Direct has grown quickly. Sales have doubled, to more than $100 million a year. It is beloved by those who hate supermarkets, by families with two parents working outside the home and by residents of neighborhoods that lack fresh fava beans and Stilton.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about Jun Choi, who unexpectedly won Edison's Democratic primary for mayor last month, misstated the given name of a Republican opponent and referred incorrectly to the status of his campaign. He is Carl Perlin, not George, and he is no longer a candidate, having withdrawn on June 20.

title: DINING IN BOSTON
description: To the Editor: Regarding "A New SoHo 200 Miles Northeast" (July 10): You have to be kidding me. I thought New Yorkers were walkers. Though delighted to see the new SoWa arts area in Boston's South End featured, I was horrified at your last stumble, "There aren't a lot of eating and drinking options."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MARBER, PATRICIA
description: MARBER--Patricia, recently of Boca Raton, Florida, died on Thursday, July 28 in Norwalk, Connecticut. Retired Investment Manager and Life Master Bridge Player, she was a tenacious competitor in all aspects of her life. She is survived by her brother William Burke, her three children, Cynthia Nikbin, Philip Marber, Michele Montano and six beautiful grandchildren. Services were held on Friday, July 29 in Redding, Connecticut. Donations in Pat's memory can be made to the Whittingham Cancer Center at Norwalk Hospital Cancer Research Program, 24 Stevens St, Norwalk, Ct. 06851.

title: Inside the List
description: OLD SCHOOL: John Irving's 11th novel, "Until I Find You," enters the hardcover fiction list this week at No. 3. The book's reviews have been, for the most part, fairly brutal. (Writing in The Washington Post Book World, Marianne Wiggins complained that Irving's sex-driven novel "goes for over 800 pages and leaves one with an even greater appreciation for the Viagra label's warning of penile erectile states that might last up to four or five hours. Make it stop!") Irving's brand of leisurely, old-school storytelling has legions of admirers, however, and sales of his new book have been given a push by profiles of the author in People and Entertainment Weekly that underscored this novel's autobiographical aspects. (Like his book's hero, Irving had a father who went missing early in his life and, like his book's hero, he was molested by a much older woman before he was in his teens.) Irving's first three novels -- "Setting Free the Bears," "The Water-Method Man" and "The 158-Pound Marriage" -- did not make the Times list. His fourth, "The World According to Garp," was his shot heard round the world; it spent almost six months on the hardcover fiction list in 1978-79. Since then, all of his books have had substantial runs on this page, with the exception of "Trying to Save Piggy Sneed" (1996), a collection of assorted prose, and his memoir, "My Movie Business" (1999), both of which failed to climb into the hardcover Top 15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   OSTROW, LOUISETTE MELLEN
description: OSTROW--Louisette Mellen (1921-2005) has passed on with grace, surrounded by love--she will be sorely missed. Louisette (Lou) will always be in our hearts; her love and caring touched many lives. Lou was predeceased by her first husband, Werner Mellen, her daughter Diana Louise Mellen, and her second husband Philip Ostrow. She is survived by children Richard and Suzanne, stepson Jon Ostrow, and five grandchildren. Lou was a dedicated elementary school teacher starting in Harlem during the 1940's, ending her career with the Roslyn Public School System (Highlands, Heights and East Hills schools) in 1983. Lou was a dedicated public servant, working on many volunteer and extra curricular programs for the betterment of mankind. She was instrumental in establishing the Martin Luther King scholarship awarded each year to a Roslyn High School student. Please contact Suzanne Mellen at srmellen@comcast.net or (415) 268-0351

title: Katharine Stein, Michael Fahey
description: Katharine Ellen Stein, the daughter of Ellen C. Stein and David F. Stein of New York, was married on Martha's Vineyard yesterday to Dr. Michael Christian Fahey, a son of Helen D. Fahey and Peter M. Fahey of Sands Point, N.Y. The Rev. Vincent DeCola, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the home of the bride's parents in Edgartown, Mass.

description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 30 - Two British security contractors working for the British consulate in the southern city of Basra were killed Saturday by a roadside bomb while driving in a convoy of vehicles on the outskirts of the city, police and consular officials reported.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SPRUNG, RUTH
description: SPRUNG--Ruth. Died peacefully on July 28 at home with her devoted daughter Trudy at her side. Ruth was a loving and caring mother, grandmother, great-grandmother, and wife of 41 years to her late husband Sol. She was a respected NYC public school teacher. She loved all things New York. She is survived by her daughter Trudy Duschaneck of White Plains and her grandchildren Samantha and Amy. She is also survived by a son James (Lynne), grandchildren Arlene (Gregg) Lechner and Eric (Aimee), and great-grandchildren Jared and Jacob Lechner. All children brought her joy. For information: 914646-3484. In lieu of flowers please make contributions to Williams Syndrome Assn., P.O. Box 297 Clawson, Mi. 48017.

title: DETECTION DEVICE AT NEWARK AIRPORT
description: The federal Transportation Security Administration has installed an explosives-detection machine in Terminal A at Newark Liberty International Airport. It should eliminate the need for most pat-downs of passengers selected for more-thorough searches. The machine, which blows a series of puffs of air at each person who steps inside it, is the first the security administration has delivered since it completed a test of the machines last spring at 14 airports. It may help to allay some of the concerns raised by recent blunders at the airport, including a traveler's discovery in February that she had cleared security with a five-inch butcher knife in her handbag. In December, screeners lost track of a fake bomb being used in a training exercise, and it wound up on a plane to Amsterdam. But the new machine will not significantly reduce the need for a vigilant staff of screeners. It will simply add another, more sensitive layer of defense against terrorist threats, said Anthony R. Coscia, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which operates the airport. Patrick McGeehan

After being elected president of the Confederate government, Jefferson Davis arrived in Montgomery, Ala., in February 1861, not 1860. Lee surrendered to Grant on April 9, 1865, not April 1.

Three years ago, the Marreros bought a one-bedroom co-op in a prewar Art Deco building on Cabrini Boulevard for $165,000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GILL, THE REV. DR. THEODORE ALEXANDER
description: GILL--The Rev. Dr. Theodore Alexander. 85, a former provost of John Jay College of Criminal Justice in the City University of New York (CUNY), and formerly president of San Francisco Theological Seminary, died Friday, June 10, 2005, in Princeton, NJ following a lengthy illness. Born in Eveleth, MN on January 7, 1920, Ted Gill was educated at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, Princeton Theological Seminary, Union Seminary in New York City, and the University of Zurich. After serving Presbyterian parishes in New Rochelle, NY and West End Presbyterian Church in New York City, he became professor of religion at Lindenwood College in St. Charles, MO, and subsequently managing editor of The Christian Century magazine in Chicago. He was president of San Francisco Theological Seminary from 1958 to 1966, leaving that position to occupy the higher education desk of the World Council of Churches in Geneva, Switzerland. He joined the faculty of John Jay College of Criminal Justice in midtown Manhattan where he remained from 1971 through 1989. In retirement, he served as theologian in residence at Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, NJ. At the time of his death, he was a member of the Presbytery of New York City in the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.). Due to blockage of his carotid artery in May 1994, he lost the capacity for speech and began a gradual decline in health. His wife of 57 years, Katherine Yonker Gill, died in July 2002. He is survived by a daughter, Laurie Melissa Keeran of Brewster, MA and her husband Donald Keeran; a son, the Rev. Theodore A. Gill, Jr. of Geneva, Switzerland and his wife Ruth Ann Shriver Gill; a granddaughter, Elizabeth Katherine Gill of Durham, NC and her husband Jacob Burt; and longtime caregiver Ben Mensah of New York City. A memorial service was held at Nassau Presbyterian Church in Princeton, NJ on June 20.

description: SPIVACK--Edith. The partners, associates and staff of Marcus & Pollack LLP, express their sorrow on the passing of Edith I. Spivack. title: Corrections
Don't Worry About China. Learn From It.
description: ONE disadvantage of being 60 is that you have to get up in the middle of the night, often more than once. But a big advantage of advancing age is that you get to recognize news media silliness when it happens.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE AMERICANIZATION OF BENJAMIN FRANKLIN, by Gordon S. Wood. (Penguin, $16.) A rich blend of history and biography, this reappraisal closes the gap between the Franklin of popular imagination -- the plain-spoken, entrepreneurial patriot -- and the real Franklin, a flirtatious rogue and the most cosmopolitan of the founders. Wood, a Pulitzer Prize-winning historian, builds his narrative around various turning points in Franklin's life, and suggests that "no person in American history has taken on such emblematic and imaginative significance for Americans as has Franklin."

title: The Cinema of Latter-Day Saints
description: Near the top of Variety's list of the 250 top-grossing films for 2004, at No. 3, sits "The Passion of the Christ." Near the bottom, at No. 245, resides another independent film made for and by believers. It's called "The Best Two Years," and it tells the story of four young Mormons performing their church-mandated stints as missionaries. The film was released by a company based in Orem, Utah, called HaleStorm Entertainment.

title: The Framing Wars
description: Matt Bai faults Democrats for their first show of moxie in years. He complains that framing is not a suitable substitute for fresh ideas, while he frames the framing pioneer, George Lakoff, as an opportunistic publicity hound. Republicans have so entrenched their words into the collective American mind that Democrats have no choice but to fight fire with fire. It's about time.

title: Two Koreas agree to open connecting railways, roads in October
New Iran Leader to Address U.N.
description: TEHRAN, July 30 - Iran's incoming conservative president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is planning to address the United Nations General Assembly in September on his first official trip abroad despite investigations by the United States about whether he took part in the siege at the American Embassy in Tehran in 1979.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HOROWITZ, RUTH
description: HOROWITZ--Ruth. On July 23, 2005, age 94. The NYU Steinhardt School of Education mourns the loss of our dear friend and benefactor, Ruth Horowitz. Author, teacher, lecturer, teaching supervisor, and Steinhardt alumna, Ruth mentored hundreds of students and influenced generations of teachers and teacher educators. Ruth's legacy and vision will always be a part of us through the Ruth Horowitz Center for Teacher Development, which she endowed, and the scholarship fund she so generously established for teachers in elementary education. Ruth was a great lady; a devoted and passionate teacher and friend. We will miss her. Our deepest condolences to her sister, Rosslyn.

description: HARRY POTTER AND THE HALF-BLOOD PRINCE By J. K. Rowling. Illustrated by Mary GrandPr. 652 pp. Arthur A. Levine Books/Scholastic. $29.99.

title: Admissions: Director's Cut
description: IN ABC's summer reality show "The Scholar," three genuine college admissions officers offer color commentary as telegenic college-bound students compete for scholarship money.

title: The Basics; Least Likely Ladder To the Presidency
description: Correction Appended

title: An End to a Dolphin Program
description: Radisson Seven Seas Cruises recently announced that it has discontinued its onshore "dolphin encounters" programs, which allowed guests to interact with dolphins in water parks and holding facilities on its Caribbean cruises. According to the International Council of Cruise Lines, Radisson is the first line to discontinue such a program.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
