description: "I am scared about Iraq, but I am going to have to give something in return for those benefits I want."

title: A Number That's Meant to Be Second-Guessed
description: IT'S an axiom of business that first impressions count. Opinions formed in the initial moments of a new encounter are notoriously hard to shake. But first impressions are often wrong. After all, can anyone really size up complex issues in just a glance?

title: Robert Maguire, 75, Expert on Soviet Literature, Dies
description: Robert Alan Maguire, an authority on early Soviet literature and the writings of Nikolai Gogol, died on July 8 at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 75 and lived in Morningside Heights in Manhattan.

title: Hundreds of protesters take to the streets in northern Sinai
Don't Insult Fulton Street
description: To the Editor:

title: For Moms-to-Be, A Prenatal Marvel: The Midwife Is a Man
description: WHEN Ruth Lawyer, a doula, heard that a friend was considering having her baby at Bellevue Hospital Center, she felt a need to offer a sheepish warning: "You know," she said with a chuckle, "They have a male midwife there."

title: A Fishing Village After All
description: Seated in a director's chair in the Place des Lices, cooled by an overhead wind machine, a 50-something man in white pants, a white shirt and a white sweater around his neck is giving orders. In front of him is a group of old Frenchmen who are playing the traditional game of pAtanque. The thud of steel balls landing in dusty earth mixes with the wind rustling the leaves of the tree-shaded park.

title: Hotel Amenities Goal: Deliver More
description: The hotel upgrade race continues. Hilton recently announced that it was adding new amenities. As of July 15, 250,000 rooms in Hilton properties in the United States had new, easy-to-set alarm clocks (left), with large screens and cables for connecting to iPods or computers. All but a few hotels offer high-speed Internet access, either wired or wireless.

title: Cellphone Casualty
description: DASHING across campus, late for class, today's students check the time not on their wrists but on their cellphones. "Watches are kind of pointless if they aren't used for fashion," says Cyndi Loza, a junior at the University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. "Since every portable electronic - i.e., iPods - comes with a watch, they are obsolete." The trend has also been noted at Portland State University in Oregon and Clark University in Worcester, Mass.

title: What Does a Terrorist Look Like?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WIENER, RONALD CHARLES
description: WIENER--Ronald Charles. Died July 29, 2005 of natural causes. Adored husband of Heather. Loving father to Kaitlin, Nicholas and MacGregor. Caring uncle to Elizabeth, Oliver, Annabel, Jackson, Kennedy, Hudson, Lucy, Ross and Brody. Beloved brother-in-law to Victoria, Cammie, Kimberly, Blake, Brooks and Hillary. His humor and strength will be missed by all those whose lives he touched. Funeral services will be held at 11:30 AM Monday, August 1st, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street.

title: A Heart of Water
description: New Jersey is not quite an island, but it is certainly intimate with water; you could almost call it the Amniotic State.

title: That Thing? It's Famous?
description: Haddon Heights - AN unexpected (and largely forgotten) treasure sits off the White Horse Pike here, in the Haddon Heights post office: a bas-relief by Isamu Noguchi, one of the most significant American sculptors of the 20th century.

title: Autism as Metaphor
description: Correction Appended

title: Why Bill Gates Wants 3,000 New Patents
description: "EXCITING," "uninteresting" and "not exciting" don't seem like technical terms. But they show up a lot in United States patent application No.20,050,160,457, titled "Annotating Programs for Automatic Summary Generation." It seems to be about baseball. The inventors have apparently come up with software that can detect the portions of a baseball broadcast that contain what they call "excited speech," as well as hits (what I call "excited ball") and automatically compile those portions into a highlights reel.

title: From Uptown (Bodegas) to Downtown (Galleries)
description: She didn't have time to get attached to, let alone miss, the neighborhood it once was before it became Nueva York. A neighborhood filled with fruit markets, a corner bookstore, the small photo shop that stank of unwashed scalp and damp wool, the five-and-dime that didn't sell anything for less than a quarter, or the bakery display cases of rugelach and babka.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Yanks' Pitchers Need Old School

title: A New Hope for Dreams Suspended by Segregation
description: Correction Appended

title: When Your Mileage Doesn't Match the Window Sticker
description: FOR decades, Americans have paid little attention to the fuel economy numbers on cars' window stickers -- or to whether their vehicles actually attained those mileage figures. But for hybrid car owners, impressive city and highway mileage numbers are often the primary selling point. When a hybrid's mileage falls short, the owner logically asks why the real-world figures don't match the ones listed by the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: On the Trail Of Trash
description: To the Editor:

title: Where the Human Footprint Is Lightest
description: PRISTINE lands, by the strictest definition, no longer exist. Atmospheric pollution has settled on every earthly surface; human-induced climate change is affecting ecosystems across the planet, scientists say.

title: Getting in the Swim With Pop-Up Pools
description: ONE of the hottest products used for cooling off this summer is a new type of above-ground pool known as a pop-up. The item, which sells for a fraction of the cost of conventional above-ground pools, can usually be installed in a couple of hours on just about any sufficiently sized patch of level ground.

title: Power Breakfasts, Quirks on the Side
description: With no relief from two dormant ceiling fans or the air-conditioning breathing wearily from vents in the peach-pink walls, the early morning air in Teresa's Restaurant is already thick with humidity. The regulars have returned from the July Fourth weekend in full force, and by 8 a.m., this unassuming place is off to business as usual, with the Who's Who of Brooklyn drowning out the soft rock mix on Lite FM (106.7) and the buzz of the ice machine.

title: Movies
description: THE GOLDEN BOWL (2001) Wednesday at 11:45 a.m. and 6:45 p.m. on IFC. In Henry James novels, Americans living or traveling abroad are often innocents in a strange land. But in this James work, turned into a lavish if aloof Merchant Ivory film, the Americans are the corrupters. The chief offender is Adam Verver (Nick Nolte, who had played a Merchant Ivory Thomas Jefferson in 1995), a coal-mining robber baron who is in Europe to buy up great art and possibly to win the heart and soul of Charlotte Stant (Uma Thurman, above, with Mr. Nolte), a penniless socialite. But Charlotte's heart already belongs to the royal but not rich Prince Amerigo (Jeremy Northam), who has married Adam's daughter (Kate Beckinsale) for her money.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: The MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL is in full swing, with attractive prime-time events tomorrow through Saturday. But not to be overlooked are the delectably intimate late-night concerts of a type introduced last summer, in a passable imitation of a nightclub. The pianists EMANUEL AX (Tuesday and Wednesday) and JEAN-YVES THIBAUDET (Friday) moonlight after their concerto performances in Avery Fisher Hall, and EMMA BELL, a soprano, joins Mr. Ax on Tuesday. Early-music fanciers will be particularly interested in the appearance of the harpsichordist EMMANUELLE HAM and members of her ensemble, LE CONCERT D'ASTRE, on Saturday, the night before their larger-scale appearance at Alice Tully Hall. Ms. Ham and company gained wide attention last year with superb recordings of Monteverdi's "Orfeo" and Purcell's "Dido and Aeneas." Here they play works of Jean-Marie Leclair and Bach. 10:30 p.m., Kaplan Penthouse, Lincoln Center (212)721-6500.

title: An Oasis of Green, Reclaimed by City and Community
description: IN the 1960's and 70's, Morningside Park, the effective boundary between Morningside Heights and Harlem, had a dangerous reputation, compounded by years of neglect. But these days, a walk through its craggy slopes, which have gradually been reclaimed by the Parks Department and a community group, can be comfortable and refreshing, with an alpine quality.

title: A Chef Expands His Empire
description: ROCKFISH is the quintessential summer restaurant with its enclosed garden and light seasonal seafood. Tom Schaudel, the talented restless-for-a-new-venture chef, has added Rockfish to his lineup of successful restaurants (Coolfish, Angelfish and Thom Thom), taking over the kitchen at Finley's, a popular Huntington watering hole, and turning it into Rockfish at Finley's, a dining destination.

title: Medical Center Cited In Death of Boy, 12
description: THE Westchester Medical Center contributed to the death of a 12-year-old boy who was treated with morphine and several other powerful painkillers and then left with his vital signs and oxygen level unmonitored overnight, according to a report issued by the State Department of Health in June and first reported in The Journal News. The hospital was cited for eight violations of state health regulations and ordered to come up with a plan to remediate its "deficiencies of care."

title: Up Front
description: How does Richard A. Posner do it? A federal appeals court judge, a senior lecturer at the University of Chicago Law School, an editor of The American Law and Economics Review and a blogger, he is the author of 38 books, more than 300 articles and book reviews (including one, in these pages last year, of the 9/11 Commission Report), and almost 2,200 published judicial opinions. One reaches for science fiction explanations: Posner has cloned himself; he has found a way to slow down time. Surely it's the case that he never sleeps.

title: Pushing and Pulling Stamford's Orchestra In New Directions
description: WHEN Eckart Preu was a student at the Hartt School of Music in Hartford in the mid-90's, he lived in Manhattan and commuted to Connecticut, where he took conducting lessons and was music director of the Norwalk Youth Symphony. For him, Stamford was just another stop on the Metro-North Railroad.

title: Philanthropy Outside the Box
description: At 92, Sir John Marks Templeton may seem an unlikely dispenser of the maxim that life is short.

title: Not Quite Off The Rack
description: MONTCLAIR - NOBODY knows where it came from, who made it or how it reached New Jersey. All the puzzled curators at the Montclair Art Museum are sure about is that it was discovered by accident about 20 years ago during a major inventory of the collection. It was found inside an unmarked box in a storeroom that holds other items from the museum's costume collection.

title: Foundering?
description: When a constitution succeeds, its framers come to be regarded as visionaries. They are seen in retrospect to have predicted future difficulties and dealt with them ingeniously, by building a machine that would run of itself. From the inside, though, constitution drafting is not so philosophical and frictionless; it does not take place under the aspect of the eternal. The immediate politics of the moment dominate, along with the lurking fear that if the constitution is not ratified, national collapse may follow.

title: Any Human to Another
description: Any Human To Another

title: Cicely Saunders Dies at 87; Reshaped End-of-Life Care
description: Dame Cicely Saunders, a founder of the modern hospice movement, died July 14 in the prototype she had built in Britain 38 years ago, St. Christopher's in Sydenham, south London. She was 87.

title: Fortunoff Family Sells Controlling Interest
description: The Fortunoff family, founder of the chain of home furnishing and jewelry stores that bear the Fortunoff name, has sold a controlling interest in the chain to two private equity firms in Manhattan, Trimaran Capital Partners and the Kier Group.

title: Agnieshka Kostro, Jared Burke
description: Agnieshka Kostro and Jared Burke were married yesterday at Our Lady of Ostrabrama Roman Catholic Church in Cutchogue, N.Y. The Rev. Walter Rudnicki performed the ceremony.

title: Jana Packman, Mark Greenblatt
description: Jana Ruth Packman, a daughter of Nina J. Packman and Rabbi A. David Packman of Oklahoma City, was married last evening to Mark Lee Greenblatt, a son of Marshal Greenblatt of Potomac, Md., and the late Marian Greenblatt. The bride's father officiated at the Willard InterContinental in Washington.

title: And a Lawyer Makes Three
description: MAUREEN MURPHY, a genial lawyer from Middletown, was speaking before a crowd of about 100 people in the basement of the East Norwalk Library on Monday when she grabbed a stack of papers nearly a foot high and dropped them onto her lectern with a dramatic thump.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JULIG, ANTON F.
description: JULIG--Anton F., 72, on July 22. Father of Lisa (Alexander), Louis, Suzanne (John) and Linda. Grandfather of Alexandra, Ricky and Olivia. A leading fragrance industry sales executive, his wit, love of nature and music, and beautiful voice will be missed.

title: Matsui Lets the Yankees Walk Away With a Victory
description: More than anything, Francisco Rodriguez needed a strike. He had thrown eight balls in a row, and his fourth walk of the ninth inning had forced in a run. The Yankees now trailed the Los Angeles Angels by only a run with one out, and Hideki Matsui came to the plate.

title: Cluttering Up the City Charter
description: It is very difficult to get a referendum on the ballot in New York City. This year a coalition of groups is circulating petitions that would amend the city charter to require more spending for smaller class sizes in public schools. Although the groups have collected more than 70,000 signatures, the odds are still against them.

title: House Party
description: ONE weekend last semester, a blinking, three-story colonial house in Ann Arbor, Mich., spoke up and warned passersby about the perils of drinking. Christopher Bradley, who created "Homie" as a senior in the University of Michigan's School of Art and Design, played the voice of the house (his former residence), sharing experiences like: "I went to a party, drank too much and I don't remember what happened. How do you guys handle your partying?" Students responded through a microphone on the lawn. By asking others for their thoughts, Homie will "hopefully get them to think about their own drinking," says Mr. Bradley, who says he has occasionally downed one shot too many. He will recreate Homie in October and is planning other campus stops. ABBY ELLIN

title: Margaret Gould, Adam Korn
description: Margaret Suzanne Gould, the daughter of Nancy Walters Gould and M. Anthony Gould of Oxford, Md., was married yesterday to Adam Michael Korn, a son of Susan and David Korn of Manhattan. George R. Villegas, an acting justice of State Supreme Court in the Bronx, officiated at the Inn at Irving Place in Manhattan.

title: Margaret Finn, Andrew King
description: Margaret Ellen Finn, the daughter of Thomas P. Finn of Sleepy Hollow, N.Y., and the late Margaret Quinn Finn, was married yesterday to Andrew Michael King, a son of Denise W. King and Jack King, both of Chatham, N.Y. The Rev. John P. Donovan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Labor Must Explain Benefits of a Split
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TURNER, JOY STARRY
description: TURNER--Joy Starry, an internationally recognized Montessori educator and leader, and a colleague and beloved friend of the American Montessori Society, died July 11, 2005. A memorial service will take place August 13, 3 PM, at Montessori Greenhouse School in Garden Grove, CA.

title: A Law Firm's Ideal Home: Substantial but Not Lavish
description: IT would be understandable if visitors to the new headquarters of the law firm of Kramer Levin Naftalis & Frankel had an overwhelming desire for a martini. Dim the lights and the firm's classically modern space on the 29th floor of a Midtown Manhattan building could double as the lobby of a boutique hotel.

title: Yanks' Pitchers Need Old School
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Numbers Are Cast in Bronze, but Are Not Set in Stone
description: At the National Baseball Hall of Fame gallery in Cooperstown, N.Y., 258 bronze plaques hang on the walls, each casting for eternity a player's name, visage and career accomplishments. The statistics on them -- the hits, the victories, the stolen bases -- are baseball's lingua franca, digits considered as inviolable as they are sacrosanct.

title: How High, Mr. Bloomberg?
description: IF New Jersey commuters needed a reminder that they move to a tune that is conducted from Manhattan, they received one when transit police started prying open their briefcases, purses and backpacks.

title: Quick, What Do You Do for A Heart Attack?
description: JUST about everyone in medicine agrees that a patient who shows up in the emergency room with a heart attack should be given aspirin. That simple treatment has been proven to cut death rates by nearly a quarter.

title: Massage In a Sandal
description: If sneakers that simulate the rolling gait of barefoot Kenyan tribes seem just a bit too cloddish, Jimmy Choo has come out with a slight thong that dresses feet in the bare minimum. The company's new Waikiki thong sandal ties around the ankles, espadrille-style, with metallic-threaded cotton straps and has a flat jelly sole with a pebbled foot bed that gives tired toes a nubby massage with every step. With a waiting list in tow, a second delivery of the sandals is now hitting stores (in purple or brown, $230 at Jimmy Choo stores, 866-524-6687).

title: Color-Coding
description: Correction Appended

title: The Affluent Meet the Effluent
description: LAND values along the still-fetid Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn have shot up because of plans for high-end housing on its banks, and now something similar seems to be happening at Newtown Creek, an oil-slicked industrial waterway that forms part of the border between Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Life Imitating Art Imitating Life
description: CALL it reality recruiting. Two heartland universities have turned to reality-show concepts to drum up interest. The University of Nebraska, Lincoln, agreed to let the Motley CrA14e drummer Tommy Lee take three courses - chemistry, American literature, horticulture - with cameras in tow. "Tommy Lee Goes to College" begins Aug. 16 on NBC. Not everyone was thrilled with the idea. (Mr. Lee was convicted in 1998 of spousal abuse and never completed high school.) But Chancellor Harvey Perlman, in an e-mail message to faculty and staff, cited "the potential for our recruiting efforts," noting that "education is one of the ways a person can redeem himself." And afterward? "I suspect Tommy learned something."

title: Driving Slowly In the Passing Lane
description: To the Editor:

title: Fear of Committing?
description: ON the diving board of dashed hopes and denial paces an unhappy figure: the would-be buyer who shops for years but resists taking the plunge.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MORAN, RUTH M.
description: MORAN--Ruth M. Of Huddleston, VA and formerly of White Plains and Suffern, died July 28, 2005. She was preceded in death by her husband, Brian T. Moran, Jr. She was the daughter of Lina and Gotthilf Merkle and the surviving sister of six siblings. She is survived by two sons and two grandchildren.

title: Taking Care of Small People Is Becoming a Big Business
description: THE expression "child care industry" still sounds like an oxymoron to many parents, who retain the homespun image of a local mother who has turned minding the neighbors' kids into a small business.

title: A Gas Station Seeks Growth, the Neighbors See Trouble
description: The crowd gathered a little before 7 p.m., on a street corner across Fort Hamilton Parkway from Moshe Sarfati's Exxon Mobil gas station. When the light changed, the 60 or 70 protesters marched across the street and took their positions, signs in the air.

title: The Framing Wars
description: I don't care how many creative-writing courses the Democratic leadership takes; it won't win elections until it wins the centrist vote. Harry Truman gave the party the template in the 1948 election. Keep the F.D.R. coalition of ethnic voters, Catholics, labor unions, Southern Democrats and Jews, and you can't lose. Over the past 35 years, Democrats have jettisoned the Southern Democrats and made little attempt to include ethnic voters and Catholics in the political process. In the 2004 election, there were defections among Jewish voters. If this continues, there will be no one left to vote for Democratic candidates.

title: Chelsea, Then and Now      My childhood years in Chelsea during the late 1920s and early 30's were probably the happiest of my life even though times were tough. After reading ''Cheek by Jowl'' (July 10), I felt an overwhelming sense of loss for the Chelsea I grew up in. The new one seems to have traded its character and sense of community for the color of money.
description: The solution to some of Chelsea's problems may lie with the affluent newcomers who have upended the lives of the Fulton Houses residents. If they care enough they can give back something.

title: The Fountains of Wayne Will Always Have New Jersey
description: FOUNTAINS of Wayne have been called the pop poet laureates of the New Jersey suburbs, and some brave -- if not misguided -- souls have even compared the band's New Jersey to Faulkner's Mississippi.

title: A Puppet Master, Still Standing
description: Broadway marathons aren't what they used to be. What with actors moving between stage, film and TV, and corporate musicals that can support a stream of interchangeable faces, the days when a Marian Seldes would play 1,793 performances of "Deathtrap" without missing a curtain are long gone. But that doesn't mean stars with staying power are extinct. Stephanie D'Abruzzo, who plays the puppet protagonist Kate Monster (as well as her rival, Lucy T. Slut) in the two-year-old-plus "Avenue Q," recently woke up to find she was the only 2004 Tony Award acting nominee (out of 40) who was still working the job for which she was nominated. Ms. D'Abruzzo, who was beaten out for best actress in a musical by that relative short-timer Idina Menzel of "Wicked," spoke with Robert Simonson about keeping it fresh after more than 800 shows.

title: SKAGEN, DENMARK
description: To the Editor: My friends and I were delighted to see "On Water's Edge, a Land Where Art Flowered" (July 17), the article about Skagen and the northern part of Denmark. Four of us spent a wonderful week in what the Danes call "Toppen af Danmark" two summers ago.

title: Chelsea, Set to Face Milan, Is New Boss
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., July 30 - A group of professional athletes playing in the New York area Sunday is making a combined salary of more than $200 million.

title: The Framing Wars
description: In Bill Clinton's presidential races, he distilled his message and kept pounding away at it, and he won. He was insightful, intuitive and charismatic. Bush (with Karl Rove at the helm) simply repeated the same formula. It doesn't take a gaggle of geeks and academics to figure out this simple formula. George Lakoff should hold onto his day job, as his 15 minutes may be coming to an end.

title: For Native Sons, Less Favor at Home
description: When Gov. George E. Pataki disclosed on Wednesday that he would not seek a fourth term in 2006, about the only person who cared enough to have a party was Mr. Pataki. As likable as he might be, his poll numbers suggest that voters are more than ready for him to move on to retirement.

title: Under the Covers
description: THERE is a new novel for teenagers called "Rainbow Party," and it has been causing a stir. A rainbow party is apparently a gathering at which each girl wears a different color of lipstick and performs oral sex on each of the boys. The rainbow, I gather, is what the boys end up with. I'm not sure what the girls end up with. There is some debate about whether these parties exist anywhere apart from this book.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   HERMAN, MINDY J.
description: HERMAN--Mindy J. You will always be remembered with love. Gloria, Bernie, Steven Donna, Philip, Ross and Grandma Elsie

title: Giuliani and The Crime Rate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Concierge Doctor Is Available (at a Price)
description: Correction Appended

title: Survey Finds Support For Train Shuttle
description: A new survey says that East End residents would strongly support and make use of a revamped and localized public transportation system that would include local trains running every half-hour and linked to bus service.

title: By the Script
description: In many New York City public schools, children sit cross-legged on rugs. Desks must be arranged into clusters of students with varying abilities, not in rows. A "word wall" serves as a vocabulary reference. Lessons last five minutes.

title: Suspect Held in Italy Said to Admit Carrying Bomb in Train
description: The suspect arrested in Rome, identified as both Osman Hussain and Hussain Osman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DAVIS, JOHN IGNATIUS
description: DAVIS--John Ignatius, of Englewood Cliffs, NJ suddenly July 29, 2005. Born August 9, 1919, much loved husband for 55 years of Mariam Prisament Davis. Cherished father of Ted and Susan, Judy and Jeff Fagan, Gerry and Debbie. Loving grandfather of James and Alison Fagan, Brandon, Jessica, Elizabeth and Benjamin Davis. Dear brother of Lucille Winters and brother-in-law of Gloria Prisament and the late Norman. Friend of many. Mason, past District Deputy F&M, First Manhattan District of NY. Avid fisherman, golfer, world traveler, always ready for an adventure. He will be missed. Services Sunday, 11:30AM Gutterman - Musi cant, 402 Park Street, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Uzbeks Order U.S. From Base in Refugee Rift
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 - Uzbekistan formally ordered the United States to leave an air base that has been a hub for operations in Afghanistan in protest over a predawn United Nations operation on Friday to spirit out refugees who had fled an uprising in Uzbekistan in May, senior State Department officials said Saturday.

title: Bad News
description: THE conventional news media are embattled. Attacked by both left and right in book after book, rocked by scandals, challenged by upstart bloggers, they have become a focus of controversy and concern. Their audience is in decline, their credibility with the public in shreds. In a recent poll conducted by the Annenberg Public Policy Center, 65 percent of the respondents thought that most news organizations, if they discover they've made a mistake, try to ignore it or cover it up, and 79 percent opined that a media company would hesitate to carry negative stories about a corporation from which it received substantial advertising revenues.

title: Life Imitating Art Imitating Life
description: CALL it reality recruiting. Two heartland universities have turned to reality-show concepts to drum up interest. The University of Nebraska, Lincoln, agreed to let the Motley Cre drummer Tommy Lee take three courses -- chemistry, American literature, horticulture -- with cameras in tow. "Tommy Lee Goes to College" begins Aug. 16 on NBC. Not everyone was thrilled with the idea. (Mr. Lee was convicted in 1998 of spousal abuse and never completed high school.) But Chancellor Harvey Perlman, in an e-mail message to faculty and staff, cited "the potential for our recruiting efforts," noting that "education is one of the ways a person can redeem himself." And afterward? "I suspect Tommy learned something."

title: If Interest Rates Turn Upside Down, Look Out
description: ALAN GREENSPAN, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, is upbeat -- but still worried. Inflation, energy prices and stubbornly low longer-term interest rates top his list of "significant uncertainties" about the economic outlook.

title: Iraq Dances With Iran, While America Seethes
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq - DONALD H. RUMSFELD, the defense secretary, delivered a blunt message to Iraqi leaders during a visit here last week: the Iraqis would have to be more aggressive in opposing the "harmful" meddling of Iran in this country's affairs before the Americans could consider regional stability assured and the way clear for the United States forces to go home.

title: What Does a Terrorist Look Like?
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Vermazen, James Anderson
description: Susan Vermazen and James Everett Anderson were married yesterday in Connelly House at Boston College. John McDargh, an associate professor of theology there, received permission from Massachusetts to officiate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   ZANKEL, ARTHUR
description: ZANKEL--Arthur on July 28, 2005 at age 73. Founding partner of High Rise Capital Management, former director of Citigroup, former comanaging partner of First Manhattan Company, ViceChairman of Carnegie Hall and Trustee of Teachers College. Beloved husband of Judy. Loving father of Kenneth, Thomas, Mark and James. Cherished grandfather of Maura and Andrew. Devoted brother of Martin and Jeffrey. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday 11:30AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall at Carnegie Hall 881 Seventh Avenue, NY, NY 10019.

title: Flower Alley Wins Duo a 3rd Straight Jim Dandy
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 - It was no accident that Todd Pletcher and John Velazquez won their third straight Jim Dandy Stakes on Saturday. It was their colt Flower Alley, after all, who did the running in the Grade II, $500,000 Jim Dandy for 3-year-olds.

title: Fiction Chronicle
description: THE HUNGRY TIDE. By Amitav Ghosh. (Houghton Mifflin, $25.) From the Calcutta byways of "The Shadow Lines" to the royal Burmese backrooms of "The Glass Palace," Ghosh has imbued his novels with rich social, historical, even anthropological detail. His latest is set in the Sundarbans, a magical, mythlike archipelago -- "the trailing threads of India's fabric, the ragged fringe of her sari" -- that's also a fragile ecosystem under siege. A young marine biologist, born in India but raised in Seattle, is investigating the few remaining freshwater dolphins in this alluring landscape, a vast string of islands and mangrove forests in the Bay of Bengal. She is accompanied by a local fisherman, stubbornly devoted to the old ways of life, who acts as her guide, and by a Delhi-based translator revisiting the region to help an aunt sort through some long-lost family papers. To each, the Sundarbans represent something different, but for all they become "a proliferation of small worlds . . . a meeting not just of many rivers, but a roundabout people can use to pass in many directions -- from country to country and even between faiths."

title: The Ethicist
description: I am not at all certain that the Ethicist's response to the Jewish woman married to a non-Jewish man was representative or right (July 17). If the couple in question fessed up to their rabbi about their lack of real commitment to create a Jewish home, the foundation for that "Jewish wedding" going forward might well have been lost.

title: Some Ask if the Disney Magic Is Slipping
description: MAYBE it was the rollaway bed that didn't materialize because it was suddenly deemed a fire hazard.

title: They Didn't Forget the Camera
description: THE introductory wall panel for "Picture Perfect: Masterworks of Photography" at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich describes the exhibition as drawn from one of the world's finest collections of vintage photography in private hands. The museum is not gilding the lily here, for the Hochberg-Mattis Collection, from which these wonderful photographs are drawn, is probably the most comprehensive and important private collection of vintage photography in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   NOBLE, ROSE
description: NOBLE--Rose. Of Pompano Beach, FL died peacefully in NYC on July 27. She was active until the very end. Loving wife of the late Harry Noble, devoted mother to her two sons, Kenneth and Bruce, adoring grandmother to Danielle and Joshua. Her grace and charm will be missed by all the lives she touched.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BRECKIR, DOROTHY K.
description: BRECKIR--Dorothy K. Died July 29, 2005 in New York City at the age of 97. Her last few years were a struggle between her body and her mind for autonomy. She is finally at rest after a long, productive life. Beside a host of loving and caring friends, wonderfully supportive healthcare givers, she is survived by her daughter Patricia Breckir Miller and husband Irwin, her son Joseph Breckir, grandchildren Jane Miller Henderson and Bart, James Miller and Dale, Luke Miller, Ellen Lear and Peter Ruig, Kate Lear and Jonathan LaPook, Maggie Lear and Daniel Katz and her great-granchildren Olivia, Lily, Owen, Clementine, Daniel, Noah, Griffen, Zoe and Zaneta. She will be missed by all. A celebration of her life will be held at a future date. Contributions may be made in her memory to People for the American Way.

title: Christina Juliano, Daniel Zibel
description: Christina Noel Juliano, the daughter of Caroline Juliano of Amityville, N.Y., and James Juliano of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married last evening to Daniel Aaron Zibel, a son of Diane Kolb of Cambridge, Mass., and the late Michael Zibel of Wellesley, Mass. Rabbi Lewis D. Solomon officiated at Celebrations at the Bay, an event space in Pasadena, Md.

title: A Week to Test Momentum
description: DOES good economic news breed good economic news? That is this week's question, as investors await a host of important data, concluding with the July employment report on Friday.

title: Oh, Holly
description: Tourists have found a delightful street scene as a backdrop for their summer Fifth Avenue photos. A whimsical fashion mural by Ruben Toledo suggests Truman Capote's Holly Golightly, as Audrey Hepburn played her in "Breakfast at Tiffany's," prancing across the scaffolding on Tiffany's facade, where the entrance is under construction.

title: Keeping Things Live in the Studio
description: Mark Batson is a busy man. A long-established jazz and R&B keyboardist, Mr. Batson has become ubiquitous as a producer. Since producing, performing on and co-writing songs for the R&B singer India.Arie's debut album, "Acoustic Soul," in 2001, he has had a hand -- more often two -- in creating music by a variety of artists, including Seal, Gwen Stefani, 50 Cent and the Game. Most recently he collaborated with the Dave Matthews Band on the album "Stand Up" (RCA). Mr. Batson spoke with Joel Topcik last week between studio sessions with the hip-hop producer Dr. Dre:

title: Security Rises, But So Does Anxiety
description: WHITE PLAINS - IT'S likely that the "If you see something, say something" posters along the subways and trains are far more ubiquitous than the police officers who may respond to such a report.

title: Htel Ste.-Anne in Quebec City
description: THE BASICS -- Created from two adjoining 17th-century stone buildings in Vieux Qubec, Htel Ste.-Anne is the third in a small, locally owned group of properties. It opened in June 2004 in the shadow of the celebrated Chteau Frontenac. While the Ste.-Anne's exterior radiates Old World charm, its interior is sleek and modern. The Ste.-Anne, which has 28 rooms, fronts on a cobblestoned, pedestrian-only street and in nice weather patrons of its restaurant, Le Grill, can dine outside.

title: On the Trail of Art
description: Like to travel? Love art? Both www.SculptureandNature.org and a glossy new brochure, "Hudson Valley Art Trail," offer self-guided art tours of the Hudson Valley and beyond.

title: Disabilities and Social Deficits
description: It's So Much Work To Be Your Friend By Richard Lavoie Touchstone Books, hardcover

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HARDING, HELEN
description: HARDING--Helen. A Holocaust survivor, born in Yugoslavia, passed away at the age of 100. She and her late partner in life Mane, and their son Ray, found a new and happy life in America, the land of opportunity. She is survived by her loving family, Ray and Liz, Russell, Bob and Fran, Rachael and Madeline. Service Monday, 11:30 AM, at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hildegarde, Influential Cabaret Headliner, Is Dead at 99
description: Hildegarde, whose career as an international cabaret chanteuse spanned almost seven decades and who was credited with starting the single-name vogue among entertainers, died on Friday at NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell hospital. She was 99.

title: The Stylist Did It
description: WHY do revenge fantasies thrive at the point where fashion and publishing meet, with a fever rarely glimpsed since the days of Louis XIV? Is it because the higher-ups are so hilariously awful, indulging in petty abuses of power that are far more entertaining than boring old Washington corruption and white-collar crime? Or is it because the oh-so-worthy lower-downs are so unwilling to do the mind-numbing and demeaning tasks it takes to clamber up in that world?

title: Jason Kibbey and Elizabeth Baker
description: HIS first letter began: "Dear Liz, You probably don't remember on the bus when our conversation turned to stationery and I said I would write you a letter. "

title: For NASA, Misjudgments Led to Latest Shuttle Woes
description: "We are ready to fly."

title: BEST SELLERS: July 31, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BELDEN, WILLIAM A
description: BELDEN--William A, 80, of Medfield, MA, formerly of Southport, CT and Bedford Hills, NY, July 26, 2005, husband of the late Mary M. (Cluett) Belden. Father of Catherine Cluett Belden and her husband James Nail of Medfield, MA. Also survived by a foster daughter Pinar Oya Yilmaz of Houston, TX and one cousin Diana Toner Keenan of McLean, VA. Memorial Service Saturday, August 6 at 2 PM at St. Dunstan's Church, 18 Springdale Ave, Dover, MA. If desired, memorial contributions may be made to Atlantic Salmon Federation, PO Box 807, Calais, ME 04619 or S.P.C.A. of Westchester, 590 N. State Rd, Briarcliff Manor, NY 10510. The obituary, guest book and additional information may be found at www.robertsmitchell.com.

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS
description: On view through next Sunday is an exhibition called "Colors of Harvey Dunn." "We rotate his work out quite regularly," said the curator of exhibitions, John Rychtarik. But when a show doesn't include "The Prairie Is My Garden," Dunn's most famous image, Mr. Rychtarik said, "People have a tendency for complaining." Information: www3.sdstate.edu/Administration/SouthDakotaArtMuseum.

title: A Little Candy Behind the Ear?
description: The quick pickup pocketbook accessories of the summer are sweet treats by Bond No. 9 New York that look like bonbons but are, in fact, free sample bottles of fragrance. Vials of the company's new perfume collection are swathed like candies in bright, shiny wrappers and come in 23 scents for men and women: scent names include Chelsea Flowers, Nuits de NoHo, Hamptons, Riverside Drive and New Haarlem. Of course the fragrances come in larger portions ($40 to $198, depending on bottle size), but customers have been raiding Bond No. 9 stores in New York (877-273-3369 for locations) for the witty giveaways, all of which are both calorie and cost free.

title: Cultural History Found in a Cabinet
description: THE furniture designs of Eliphalet Chapin have long been known and admired by experts in 18th-century cabinetmaking. Now others can appreciate his work -- and that of his contemporaries -- in a show at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hartford.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; DANCE
description: It's wonderful when ballet companies can present spectacular works in big theaters. The ROYAL SWEDISH BALLET is blessed: its home theater is the handsome Stockholm Opera. But ballet companies don't always long to think big. Sometimes, they want to stage sleek, offbeat creations on an intimate scale. That's one reason for STOCKHOLM/59degrees NORTH, the group of principals and soloists from the Royal Swedish Ballet that performs this week in the Ted Shawn Theater at JACOB'S PILLOW in the Berkshires. Founded by Madeleine Onne in 1997 and directed by JOHANNES OHMAN since 2002, this ensemble emphasizes new works, especially by Scandinavian choreographers, and takes its name in part from Stockholm's latitude.

title: Loving Armstrong
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: History Comes Home to Roost
description: DAVID COWELL is eager to catch his first glimpse of a newly discovered map of New York Harbor, drawn in 1683. The map is part of a collection of documents from Colonial-era New Jersey that the Codey administration bought recently for more than $600,000 at an auction in Manhattan.

title: Labor Must Explain Benefits of a Split
description: To the Editor:

title: Museum Shows Children the Faith of Their Neighbors
description: The Red Robins and the Bluebirds took a trip the other day. They took the subway to the new Jewish Children's Museum in Brooklyn.

title: Jessica Ritz, Henry Myers
description: Jessica Nemeroff Ritz and Henry Alonso Myers were married yesterday at Traxx Restaurant in Los Angeles. Jesse Hendrich, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Boomwhackers: Instruments of Democracy
description: NEVER underestimate the power of a basic concept. In 1994, Craig Ramsell, a guitar player with a master's in management from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, invented Boomwhackers, brightly colored plastic tubes that make musical notes when whacked against arms, legs or inanimate objects.

title: North Korea And U.S. Meet In Atomic Talks
description: BEIJING, July 30 - The United States and North Korea held another private session to try to narrow their differences, while all six of the nations meeting here for the North Korean nuclear talks spent Saturday considering a draft joint statement circulated by China.

title: Cloth Protrusions on Discovery May Constitute a Threat
description: HOUSTON, July 31 - NASA may conduct a spacewalk to correct a problem on the underside of the space shuttle Discovery that provoked "strong disagreement" among NASA analysts about whether or not it poses a safety hazard to the spaceship and its crew, the lead flight director for the mission said today.

title: In the Trenches, the Giants Are in Dire Need of Some Common Ground
description: ALBANY - TOM COUGHLIN presided over the Giants' traditional opening-of-training-camp picnic Thursday; Michael Strahan reported to camp Friday afternoon.

title: Introduction
description: Will "framing," as reported by Matt Bai, help Democrats get their message out? Is it the key to victory at the polls? The reader response was heavy and heated. Some said it sounded a lot like spin; others compared the Democrats' "Six Core Values" with the Republicans' "Contract With America."

title: Correction
description: The L.I. @ Work column last Sunday about independent hardware stores and drugstores misstated the address of the Middle Neck Pharmacy in Great Neck. It is at 531 Middle Neck Road, not Great Neck Road.

title: The Framing Wars
description: Character, inspiration and the ability to lead is what's needed, along with a real desire to put the nation's best interests above ideology. These are things that seem a bit thin these days. Let's leave framing to picture hangers and move on to substance.

title: President Is Given Regular Checkup at Naval Hospital
description: President Bush has purposely lost eight pounds since his last medical checkup, in December, and his doctors said after his annual physical examination yesterday that he was in "excellent health."

title: Millionaire or Not, You Can Find a Financial Planner
description: NORMAN IANNARELLI sought the services of a financial adviser after he inherited a family home and other modest assets last year. Before that, the thought of hiring a financial planner had never occurred to him.

title: Tessa Warren, David Offner
description: Tessa Cartwright Warren, an assistant professor, and David Ellis Offner, a graduate student, were married yesterday in Northampton, Mass. Duane G. Watson, a friend of the couple who received permission from Massachusetts to perform the ceremony, officiated at the Unitarian Society of Northampton and Florence.

title: 'Five Days in Philadelphia': The Plot Against Germany
description: FIVE DAYS IN PHILADELPHIA The Amazing "We Want Willkie" Convention of 1940 and How It Freed FDR to Save the Western World. By Charles Peters. Illustrated. 274 pp. PublicAffairs. $26.

title: Life Imitating Art Imitating Life
description: CALL it reality recruiting. Two heartland universities have turned to reality-show concepts to drum up interest. The University of Nebraska, Lincoln, agreed to let the Motley Cre drummer Tommy Lee take three courses -- chemistry, American literature, horticulture -- with cameras in tow. "Tommy Lee Goes to College" begins Aug. 16 on NBC. Not everyone was thrilled with the idea. (Mr. Lee was convicted in 1998 of spousal abuse and never completed high school.) But Chancellor Harvey Perlman, in an e-mail message to faculty and staff, cited "the potential for our recruiting efforts," noting that "education is one of the ways a person can redeem himself." And afterward? "I suspect Tommy learned something."

title: Take the Four-Cylinder Instead
description: If you want a hybrid car to save energy, you may be disappointed in the Highlander Hybrid. On a recent 900-plus-mile Los Angeles-Phoenix round trip, my all-wheel-drive test car averaged just 21.6 m.p.g. -- on pricey premium fuel. What's more, my average for one 400-mile leg was just 16 m.p.g.

title: Amid Jeers, Seeking Pride in a Day's Work
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y. - "ALL right, girls. Feet together. We have a huge smile on our face. Here we go!"

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 24 about living through an Antarctic winter gave an incorrect Web address in some copies for a discussion forum moderated by "King Penguin." Its address is IceBoard.org.

title: Body of Woman Discovered in a Dumpster in Harlem
description: Correction Appended

title: This Season, Catching Waves and Trying to Catch a Rival
description: Halfway through the 12-event 2005 world tour of the Association of Surfing Professionals, Andy Irons, 27, the three-time defending world champion, has found himself running second behind the resurgent Kelly Slater, 33, who won six world titles from 1992 to 1998. After flying from the last World Contest Tour event in Jeffreys Bay, South Africa, where he lost to Slater, Irons, a native of Hanalei, Hawaii, arrived at the United States Open of Surfing in Huntington Beach, Calif. He was interviewed Thursday.

title: The Framing Wars
description: Although I am a constant newspaper reader, I am unaware of the "victory" claimed by Democrats in the fight over retaining the filibuster.

title: Bird Lives! The Birth of Bebop, Captured on Disc
description: IT'S an unlikely story, but the most stunning jazz discovery in a decade -- the Rosetta Stone of bebop -- was unearthed at an Elks Lodge in Chelmsford, Mass. The trove consisted of seven 12-inch acetate discs, on which was recorded a 40-minute concert by Dizzy Gillespie and Charlie Parker at Town Hall in New York on June 22, 1945.

title: Great Ruppert's Ghost
description: Assemblyman Joseph R. Lentol, a Brooklyn Democrat who, by the way, doesn't drink, sponsored the bill, which is designed to help increase tourism by publicizing the more than 60 breweries in the state. It passed both houses in June and awaits action by the governor.

title: Jets' Rookie Pouha Knows How to Take the Heat
description: HEMPSTEAD, N.Y., July 29 - His new teammates need not worry about Sione Pouha, the Jets' rookie nose tackle. He will not come unglued under extreme heat. He will not buckle under pressure.

title: Something for the Ducklings (and the Swans)
description: If Copenhagen is not the most family-friendly city in Europe, it has to be among the front-runners. With its storybook streets and canals, and a people so welcoming that even their fiendish smoking and drinking is somehow charming, Copenhagen is a gentle way to sample a European capital.

title: The Governor Goes to Iowa
description: George E. Pataki, who announced this week that he was not running for a fourth term as governor of New York, has been very tentatively -- but very publicly -- testing the presidential waters. His trip to the National Governor's Association meeting in Iowa earlier this month was a sure giveaway. (There was, it seems, no thought whatsoever of Mr. Pataki going to the association's gathering simply to meet with his fellow governors.)

title: What Seeps Beneath
description: Correction Appended

title: The Framing Wars
description: As Matt Bai reminds us, framing is nothing new in politics. What Democrats need to remember is that neither good advertising nor a play on words can sell a bad product or public policy. The challenge for Democrats is to show (not tell) Americans that they have a coherent and cohesive set of substantive ideas (policies).

title: Diane-Marie Johnston, Stephen Spruiell
description: Diane-Marie Johnston, a daughter of Diane and Richard Johnston Jr. of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Stephen Hill Spruiell, a son of Suzanne and David Spruiell of Arlington, Tex. The Rev. Dennis Kleinmann, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Mary Catholic Church in Alexandria.

title: Audubon Society Lists 25 Areas Vital to Birds
description: YOU may not be allowed to barbecue the piping plovers, as Jerry Della Femina famously suggested recently, but now birders will have some help finding them. A new book published by Audubon New York has identified 25 locations on Long Island that are vital to the endangered plovers and a host of other birds that breed or winter on the Island or pass through it on their migrations.

title: Home, Interrupted
description: FOR five years, my husband, David, and I lived in the top two floors of an uncomely three-story brick co-op at 239 East Seventh Street, between Avenues C and D. We faced south, the tulip-ringed playgrounds of Tompkins Square Park at our right hand, the East River at our left.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   YELLEN, DWIGHT
description: YELLEN--Dwight. Oct. 12, 1917-Aug. 1, 2004. Beloved father, grandfather and avid golfer, we salute you! Whitney, Dwight, Fran, Jamie and Sara

title: The Cover Video: Not Note for Note, But Nearly Shot for Shot
description: For the first video from his band's debut album, Brady Seals of Hot Apple Pie wanted to make a splash in the sometimes hidebound world of country music. "We're big fans of hip-hop," he said, "and what we do as a band is very progressive. So we thought, why don't we make hip-hop-style videos in the country world?" Then they took the idea one step further: the video for "Hillbillies," the first single from the group's self-titled album, is almost a shot-for-shot cover of the clip for Snoop Dogg's "Drop It Like It's Hot," which was released last fall.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; ART
description: Midsummer travelers to Boston and environs will find three enticingly small but substantial exhibitions. The seriously beautiful "DEGAS AT HARVARD" (Monday through Nov. 27), at the ARTHUR M. SACKLER MUSEUM in Cambridge, is worth a trip in itself. In 1911 Harvard organized the first Degas museum show anywhere and the only one mounted during the artist's lifetime. The present show surveys the "study collection" of some 60 pieces the university has assembled since, which includes paintings, drawings, prints, sculptures and photographs. The resulting display is as stimulating in impact as it is untaxing in scale. 485 Broadway, (617)495-9400.

title: Jessica Angell, Sean Moore
description: Jessica Notman Angell, a daughter of Lea and I. Jackson Angell of Mendham Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Sean Doyle Moore, a son of Joanne and Gene Moore of Attleboro, Mass. The Rev. J. Gregory Prior, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Andrew's by-the-Sea in Little Compton, R.I.

title: Boys of Summer
description: SARASOTA, Fla. - Every few weeks a newspaper or magazine will do an article on the professionalization of youth sports. It will be about these insane parents who spend their weekends driving or flying around the country for tournaments; who spend $60 an hour so their little ones can get tutoring from former minor leaguers; who can be seen screaming on the sidelines as their children compete.

title: The Politics of Driving The Speed Limit      Joe Queenan may have found his exercise in literal law-abiding to be pure hell, but some of us who plod along at the legal limit actually enjoy a feeling of self-righteousness as the Type A's whiz by.
description: My Prius dashboard display positively reinforces my driving restraint by showing miles per gallon in the 50's.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a picture caption last Sunday about a graffiti event at Vista Food Exchange in the Hunts Point Cooperative Market in the Bronx misstated the surname of a participant. He is Chris Ellis, not Elliott.

title: In a New Series, the Suburbs Light Up
description: IT doesn't take long for "Weeds," a gleefully transgressive new Showtime series, to light a fire underneath the exhausted form of the half-hour television comedy. In the opening scene of the pilot episode, we are introduced to Nancy Botwin, a recently widowed soccer mom played by Mary-Louise Parker, at a P.T.A. meeting. While she is arguing to have soda machines banned from her children's school, her peer group of despairing homemakers is quietly gossiping about the authenticity of her new designer handbag and wondering how the suddenly single mother of two has been able to maintain her standard of living.

title: The China Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Decommissioned US-built Australian Navy ship scuttled
Bohemian Rhapsody
description: NEW YORKERS already know that their city is a global center for everything from finance and business to arts and culture. But even the most self-assured resident would likely be astounded by the extraordinary magnitude of the greater New York regional economy.

title: On Baseball; For Some Players, No-Trade Provision Is an Escape Clause
description: MIKE STANTON is pitching in Washington, not Florida. Larry Walker plays for St. Louis, not Florida or Texas or Arizona. Juan Gonzalez never played for the Yankees or Barry Larkin for the Mets. Mike Mussina has not pitched for the Chicago White Sox. John Olerud didn't play for San Francisco or Jeromy Burnitz for San Diego. Phil Nevin didn't play for Cincinnati and he's not playing for Baltimore either.

title: British Inquiry Shifts Away From Foreign Aid for Plots
description: LONDON, July 30 - As police officers investigating the two London bombing attacks questioned suspects rounded up in London and Rome, they have begun to explore the possibility that both were largely homegrown efforts with minimal outside support, senior British investigators said Saturday.

title: The Arsenal: Gele
description: The hallmarks of French food -- the silkiness of a foie gras terrine, the crunch of duck skin, the weightless deceit of a good souffl -- are often about texture. On a recent trip to Paris, I noticed that the texture that seemed to be on every chef's mind was the soft, wobbly chill of geles -- which are essentially Jell-O made with real flavors. Chefs blend fruit and vegetable juices, and even broths, with plain gelatin, then use bits of the chilled geles as a flavoring component -- lemon verbena gele in a lobster salad, say, or squares of plum gele surrounding an almond cake. One chef dotted a salad of asparagus and beets with a version made from chicken stock and dressed the vegetables with a spicy paprika vinaigrette. Geles can be loose or firm. (One packet of powdered gelatin mixed with two cups of liquid will yield a firm gele.) They are an especially handy touch in summer, when a cool and sparkling spoonful can intensify a dish's flavor at the same time it refreshes. At L'Entredgeu, a bistro, strawberries were tucked beneath clear pink beads of Cerdon gele (Cerdon is a sweet, lightly fizzy ros) and topped with a fromage blanc sorbet. Here, I've used raspberries in place of strawberries and layered the gele, fromage blanc and fruit in glasses, like a parfait.

title: Iran to Resume Nuclear Activity, Spokesman Says
description: TEHRAN, July 31 - Iran's foreign ministry spokesman said today that Iran had decided to resume nuclear activities at one of its nuclear sites but that it would keep its freeze over uranium enrichment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   DEHN, VIRGINIA ENGLEMAN
description: DEHN--Virginia Engleman. Age 82, died suddenly at her home in Santa Fe, NM on July 28, 2005. Born in Nevada, MO on October 26, 1922, Virginia moved to Connecticut as a child and grew up in Hamden, CT. Virginia graduated from Stephens College and studied at the Art Students League in New York City. While working at the Art Students League she met and later married noted artist Adolf Dehn. They were wonderful partners in art until his death in 1968. She moved from New York City to Santa Fe in 1985. Her work was exhibited in shows and galleries throughout the country and paintings of hers are part of many public collections. In her dedication to art, her creativity, independence and generosity, Virginia inspired and will continue to inspire many people. Her husband Adolf Dehn and her sister Nancy Engleman Lowe predeceased Virginia Dehn. She is survived by her niece Virginia Connors and husband Martin of Connecticut, and her nephews Frederick Lowe III and his wife Barbara of Massachusetts and Andrew Lowe and his wife Andrea of Connecticut. Virginia's remains will be cremated. No funeral or calling hours are planned.

title: Want to See the City After Dark? Grab a Paddle and Try to Keep Up
description: The water was black and flat, and the guide's voice echoed across the eerie quiet.

title: Earthly Delights
description: CHERRY HILL - MARRIED with children has many blessings but, between finding and paying a sitter and reluctance to spend time away from the little rascals, we, like many of our friends, rarely go out. And I can't remember the last time we went dancing.

title: Day Labor Gets Organized
description: Not far from the Long Island Rail Road tracks in Huntington Station, N.Y., a neighborhood of old frame houses and industrial yards, there is a field bordered at one end by woods. It's less a forest than a tangle of towering weeds and brambles that blot out the sun but cannot mask the startling blare and rumble of the Port Jefferson train.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LITVACK, JULIUS (JULIE)
description: LITVACK--Julius (Julie). We are saddened by the sudden passing of our dear friend Julie. To his beloved wife Elaine, his children and grandchildren, we send our heartfelt condolences. Enid and Mel Zuckerman & the Canyon Ranch Family

title: Massive weapons cache seized in central Afghanistan
Queuing Up For the Croc
description: Denim has been taking itself rather seriously the past few years with designers of super-dyed ultra-ripped jeans attaching astronomic price tags to the once-humble dungaree. Now a new addition to the Lacoste label -- skirts and jeans that have clean cuts and an easy whimsy -- puts the nonchalance back into the true-blue denim category. The skirts and jeans ($125 each, at Lacoste stores, 800-452-2678) possess a minimum of posturing and distress, a hint of stretch and clever pocket detailing: a stitched outline of the company's iconic crocodile, head at one end, tail at the other. The denim pieces arrived in stores this month and sold out in weeks; customers (including the cast of "The OC") are queuing up on waiting lists for a second shipment, which is to arrive in stores on Aug. 15.

title: The $8.78 Million Maneuver
description: Pop quiz: What do the water bills at Stanford have in common with library expenditures at the University of Illinois?

title: Those Who Can, and Can't
description: IN the last five years, 500,000 new teachers have taken jobs in the nation's elementary and secondary school classrooms. In the next five, a half million more will be needed as the student population swells and aging boomers accelerate their march to retirement. In some ways -- by gender, race, idealism -- today's new teachers resemble their graying counterparts. In others, they are quite different.

title: Willem F. Duisenberg, Former European Central Bank President, Dies at 70
description: BERLIN, July 31 - Willem F. Duisenberg, the blunt-spoken Dutch central banker who oversaw the introduction of the euro as the first president of the European Central Bank, was found dead today in a swimming pool at his villa in the south of France, the French government said. He was 70.

title: Down, Perhaps, But Not Yet Out
description: Analysts figured that Loral Space and Communications would be dismembered after it entered Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings two years ago, a development that probably would have ended the long and sometimes unconventional career of its chairman and chief executive, Bernard L. Schwartz, then 77.

title: Will a Rooftop Sunroom Spoil a Scenic View?
description: If one piece of Park Avenue most deserves to be known for its scenic view, Lo van der Valk thinks it must be the elevated area around 91st Street. There, pristine sunlight washes the elegant historic buildings in the early morning and late afternoon, and the Brick Presbyterian Church stands at handsome attention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   KRIVELOFF, JOSEPH
description: KRIVELOFF -- Joseph. Of NYC, died peacefully on July 29, 2005, at the age of 84. Devoted husband of Natalie for 56 years; loving father of Adam, Susan and the late Martha; affectionate fatherin-law of Andrew and Estrellita; and adoring "Poppy" of Allison, Robert and Emily; dear brother of Sam and the late Jack, Rae and Rose. He established PIE Facilities, Inc, an insurance brokerage firm. His zest for living, sense of humor, and compassion will be missed by his family and friends. Services will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave, NYC, on Monday, August 1, at 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers the family requests memorial gifts be made in Joseph's honor to the National Parkinson's Foundation or the charity of your choice.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HERSH, BENJAMIN B.
description: HERSH--Benjamin B. On July 23rd 2005, at age 91 Ben Hersh passed away. He was a well-respected resident and attorney of Peekskill, New York. He graduated New York University Law School in 1928 and began practicing law. He started his law career at Pines and Sterling, a leading firm in Peekskill, where his starting salary was $5 per week. He practiced until 1970 when he formed a partnership, Hersh and Hersh P.C., with his sons, which is still carried on by his son, Robert, at the old County Trust Bank Building located on Central Avenue in Peekskill. Never afraid of hard work, Ben was at the office every day well past his 90th birthday. An accomplished attorney, Ben was at times, Counsel to Peekskill Hospital, Counsel to the Mohegan Fire District, and Counsel to Caring for the Homeless of Peekskill. He served as Special Counsel to the Town of Cortlandt and was a Trustee of The Security Title Company. He served a term as director of the YWCA, although, as he put it, he was neither young, nor a woman, nor Christian. In the sixties, he served as closing attorney for Chase Manhattan Bank. During the term of Peekskill mayor Michael J. Dibart, Ben served as Prosecutor for the City of Peekskill. He was also elected to the Board of Directors for the Westchester County National Bank. While still a student at Columbia Law School, Governor George Pataki clerked for Ben Hersh and got his first experience in the practice of law. Ben was a longtime friend of the Pataki family, and represented the Governor's father, and grandfather. Two of his siblings followed Ben into the practice of law; Jerome and Frederick. So did his two sons, Robert and Philip as well as three of his nephews, Eric, John, and Scot. All continue to practice on the same street in Peekskill, except for Eric who is deceased. The legacy of attorneys seems to be continuing as Ben's granddaughter, Sarah, graduated Denver Law School in May 2005. An active member of the First Hebrew Congregation, Ben Hersh served three terms as president. As Chairman of the Building Committee, he was instrumental in the property acquisition and construction of the First Hebrew's Rt. 6 Building in Peekskill. He was the beloved husband of Anita Joseph for 58 years. Devoted father to Philip and Robert and cherished grandfather of Jenn, Sarah, Vicki, Jeff, Zack and Becky. He was the devoted father-in-law to Patrice; brother to Esther, Fredrick and Jerome, uncle to Scot, John, Richard, Anne, Todd, Baron, Miriam, and Nicole. A service was held at the First Hebrew Congregation on Monday morning. 350 people attended. In lieu of flowers, the family has suggested donations to the First Hebrew Congregation of Peekskill.

title: Desecration
description: The House of Representatives, by more than the required two-thirds majority, recently approved a proposed amendment to the Constitution that reads, "The Congress shall have the power to prohibit the physical desecration of the flag of the United States."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   VAN AMBURG, DR. JAMES E.
description: Van AMBURG--Dr. James E. A leading educator in independent schools died on Tuesday, July 26, 2005. He was 59 years old. The cause of death was a cerebral hemorrhage, his wife, Penelope Van Amburg, said. Dr. Van Amburg was the Head of Windward School in White Plains, New York since 1999. Windward is a school for students with language-based learning disabilities. As one of the seminal figures in independent school education, Dr. Van Amburg was educated at Dartmouth College where he received a Bachelor of Arts degree in English with honors and was a Choate Scholar. He attended Columbia University earning a Master of Arts degree in Comparative Literature and was recognized as a University Fellow. His Doctorate in Education was received from Stanford University in Palo Alto, California. "Dr. VA" as he was widely known, touched the lives of countless children in hiscareer. From 1984 to 1998, Dr. Van Amburg was the Head of Dwight Englewood School in Englewood, New Jersey. Prior to that he was Director of the University of Chicago Laboratory Schools in Chicago, Illinois, and Superintendent of Schools for The Carlisle School District in Massachusetts. He served as President of the Concord Massachusetts Special Education Collaborative. This position ignited an undying dedication to serve children with special needs. Dr. Van Amburg was committed to making independent education accessible to children who could not otherwise afford it. As a founding trustee of New Jersey S.E.E.D.S., (Scholars Educators Excellence Dedication Success), he was instrumental in identifying and placing economically disadvantaged students throughout the state in independent schools. He also served as Director of Project Broad Jump, an enrichment program for gifted students from East Harlem and the South Bronx. He served on the National Association of Independent Schools School Heads Advisory Committee helping shape policies and procedures for over 1,200 independent schools across the United States, Europe and Asia. Dr. Van Amburg was a member of the Education Advisory Council of the New York University Child Study Center. Due to Dr. Van Amburg's wide ranging expertise he was sought after as a board member for independent schools, serving at Kent Place School in Summit, New Jersey, Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Connecticut, and Creative Montessori Learning Center in East Palo Alto, California. As a cutting edge researcher and powerful speaker, Dr. Van Amburg served as a lecturer in the University of Chicago's Department of Education and as an instructor at Teachers College Columbia University. Jim Van Amburg was a man of unsurpassed integrity with a vibrant personality filled with life and love for his family, friends and colleagues. His devotion for his dear wife Penelope, his son Noah, daughter-in-law Kim, and his son Nicholas and fiance Cornelia Henning, knew no bounds. He was a loving husband, father, son, and brother. He is remembered and cherished by his immediate family--his mother, Mary Catherine Hosack, his sisters, Kate Van Amburg and Christine Juskewycz and her husband Stephen, and his brother David Van Amburg-and his many friends, colleagues, as well as current and former students. The family has requested that memorial contributions be made to Windward School, 5 Windward Avenue, White Plains, New York 10605 (914-949-6968 x 2281) or to the Human Rights Campaign, 1640 Rhode Island Avenue, NW, Washington, DC 20036 (202-628-4160). A memorial service will be held at Windward School, 40 West Red Oak Lane, White Plains, NY 10604 on Sunday, September 11, 2005 at 12:00 p.m.

title: Finding Shoes for Hard-to-Fit Feet (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHUR, PAULINE (NEE AMES)
description: SCHUR--Pauline (nee Ames). 93, died peacefully, July 25, in Philadelphia. She was the mother of Howard C. Katz and Vicki Gradess, grand mother of Betsey, Sara, Adam, Sam and Emily, greatgrandmother of Zachary, Nicholas and John Henry. She will be missed by her loving family and friends.

title: RAIL LINE FINED OVER WASTE
description: State environmental regulators have fined the New York, Susquehanna & Western Railway Corporation $2.5 million for its violations involving the handling of solid waste at five transfer sites in North Bergen, Acting Gov. Richard J. Codey said Wednesday. A railroad spokesman, Tom O'Neil, said that the company has complied with all federal regulations on railroad operations and that the company planned to meet with state regulators to discuss the issue. Mr. Codey said last week that he intends to crack down on waste sites along the state's freight lines.

title: The Sniffer vs. the Cybercrooks
description: THE investment bank, despite billions in annual revenue and the small squadron of former police, military and security officers on its payroll, was no match for Mark Seiden.

title: The Scent of Quarters Clattering on the Floor
description: The smell of a casino, for many, usually conjures the reek of stale cigarettes, sweaty desperation and that special scent of a man who has spent 14 hours at blackjack.

title: Why Can't Hempstead Fix Its Schools?
description: HEMPSTEAD - HERE is how Tim Butler, recently appointed to the Hempstead school board, got a feel for his new post.

title: Prince Turki's Rsum
description: It would be hard to find a more telling symbol of the contradictory nature of Saudi-American relations than Prince Turki al-Faisal, the Saudis' new ambassador to the United States. As head of Saudi intelligence from 1977 until Aug. 31, 2001, he personally managed Riyadh's relations with Osama bin Laden and Mullah Muhammad Omar of the Taliban. Anyone else who had dealings with even a small fraction of the notorious characters the prince has worked with over the years would never make it past the immigration counter at Dulles Airport, let alone to the most exclusive offices in Washington.

title: New Sparkle From Spain
description: Many wines from the Codorni Group, long beset by a lackluster image, have been reborn. Codorni's nonvintage Reserva Ravents is a smart alternative for hosts on tight budgets who cannot afford brut Champagnes. This delicate cava (Spanish sparkling wine) is suitable for Park Avenue. Champagne aficionados will detect chardonnay and be tantalized by the unfamiliar flavors of macabeo and xarel-lo grape. Heights Chateau, 123 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street), Brooklyn, charges $10 and delivers to Manhattan. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: Comings and Goings
description: The newest member of HOLLAND AMERICA's fleet will set sail on its first voyage, from New York on Feb. 22. The 1,848-passenger Noordam will offer 10- and 11-day cruises to the southern and eastern Caribbean through April and then from October through December. (It will spend the summer months in Europe.) Prices start at $1,199 a person, double occupancy. Reservations: (877) 724-5425 or visit www.hollandamerica.com. A new Web site for Americans was recently introduced by the SLOVAK TOURIST BOARD. The site, www.cometoslovakia.com, provides practical advice, lists of places to see and five detailed, self-guided driving itineraries. SPIRIT AIRLINES will introduce daily nonstop service from La Guardia Airport in New York and Orlando, Fla., to Nassau, the Bahamas, on Nov. 10. Information and reservations: (800) 772-7117 or www.spiritair.com. A new boutique-style hotel opened on St. Lucia this month. Amenities at the 83-room COCO PALM, in Rodney Bay Village, include free high-speed wireless Internet access and DVD players. The restaurant features Caribbean and creole cuisine and has live entertainment each night. Rates start at $125 a night and include continental breakfast. Reservations: (758) 456-2800; www.coco-resorts.com.

title: Fair Affair?
description: I've been happily married for 21 years. Ten years ago, my husband suffered a debilitating disease that keeps us from making love. Four years ago, I bumped into an ex-lover, himself married, and began a sexual relationship, reawakening my sexual feelings. Neither of us would ever divorce. I'm sure I can keep this relationship secret, so my husband will not get hurt. My devout Catholicism forbids such an affair, but does secular ethics? Anonymous Secular ethics notwithstanding, this secular ethicist is surprised that, in the decade since your husband became ill, you two have not discussed the demise of your sex life. You might also have talked about the many ways people make love, some of which might still be possible for him. Professional advice could be helpful here.

title: The Framing Wars
description: George Lakoff maintains that as a linguist he is able to recognize Republican code words, and yet he puts out a DVD called "How Democrats and Progressives Can Win." The increasingly common use of "progressive" as a euphemism for "liberal" only validates right-wing insinuations that liberalism is somehow shameful. Are we to believe that fundamentalists and N.R.A. members will vote for liberal candidates as long as they think they are voting for progressives? Please.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; THEATER
description: Can August be here already? Sure enough, everywhere you look things theatrical seem to be winding down. Off Broadway is no exception, where two notable productions will play their final performances this week, giving audiences one last chance to see them before the dog days set in. "THE PARIS LETTER," a drama about two former lovers on opposite life tracks, has perhaps the higher profile, with an author (JON ROBIN BAITZ), a star (RON RIFKIN) and a director (DOUG HUGHES) who are all bona fide members of the theatrical world's "in" crowd. Considering their pedigrees, its not surprising that the play was considered a possibility for Broadway. That was before it received less than across-the-board raves. Still, much good work was praised; see what it was, and what it might have been, until Aug. 7. The Laura Pels Theater, Harold and Miriam Steinberg Center for Theater, 111 West 46th Street. (212)719-1300.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; TELEVISION
description: July 5, 1954, was SAM PHILLIPS's lucky day. A 19-year-old named ELVIS PRESLEY walked into his Memphis storefront, Sun Records. On Wednesday (8 p.m.), the PBS documentary "GOOD ROCKIN' TONIGHT: THE LEGACY OF SUN RECORDS" takes a look at Phillips (1923-2003) and his ego and offers up some unbeatable musical performances, including PAUL McCARTNEY doing "That's All Right" with Elvis's old musicians, and RUFUS THOMAS singing "Bearcat."

title: First-Year Help: For Parents Only
description: OH, bittersweet, the excitement and aggravation of helping children get ready for college. To sustain parents through that first year of college, many colleges create briefing materials on how best to empathize and communicate.

title: Ah, Wilderness!
description: Gale A. Norton, the secretary of the interior, gave a curious analysis of the decline in national-parks attendance (Deborah Solomon, July 17). It brings to mind a classic Yogi Berra-ism: Nobody goes there anymore; it's too crowded.

title: The Basics; About That Unquivering Flesh
description: Londoners have largely refused to be cowed by terrorists. Our phlegmatic cousins across the pond, admirers say, are "keeping a stiff upper lip." The expression is synonymous with resolution in the face of adversity. But where did it come from?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GOLDBERG, CHARLES
description: GOLDBERG--Charles. 88, of Tamarac, Florida, formerly of New York, passed away July 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Susan Lindenbaum and Joan. Cherished grandfather of Brett, the late Marni, and Jayme. Adored great-grandfather of Melanie, Avery, and Dylan. Will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. Services entrusted to Star of David Funeral Home, North Lauderdale, FL.

title: New SAT, New Score, New Confusion
description: COLLEGE-BOUND seniors have reason to be even more confused by the admissions process this school year. In addition to the usual uncertainties, they will be the first to submit scores from the new SAT.

title: 'Augustine'
description: Augustine's Hippo Regius was the center of the universe for some who lived there and the back of beyond for many who visited. A port city on the Mediterranean coast of Africa, where the river Seybouse came down from the mountains to the sea, it stood a distant second to Carthage in commerce and prestige. Augustine hadn't lived there all his life.

title: Sibernie Dalloo and Micah Morrison
description: Sibernie Dalloo is to be married today to Joseph Micah Morrison. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel is to officiate at the Mark hotel in Manhattan, with the bride's father, the Rev. Frank A. Dalloo, a minister of the Nazarene Church, participating in the ceremony.

title: 'Dark Genius of Wall Street'
description: Outside the townhouse at the northeast corner of Forty-seventh Street and Fifth Avenue a stray adventurer did a good business selling freshly printed calling cards with the chiseled name of one of the sons: Edwin Gould. "This will get you in, dead certain," he assured those who forked over their two-dollar notes. Then he vanished with his profits just as his first customers were brusquely shown the door and the balance refused admittance. Old Jay Gould-who lay stiff and cold in the living room of 579 Fifth Avenue-would have applauded both the huckster's boldness and his wile.
