Jay had always believed that shrewd aptitude should be rewarded and its absence punished. He despised fools.

title: Switched Off in Basra
description: BASRA, Iraq - THE British call it being "switched on" -- a state of high morale and readiness, similar to what Americans think of as "gung ho" attitude. During the 10 days I recently spent embedded with the British-led multinational force in this southern Iraqi city, I met many switched-on soldiers involved in what the British call "security sector reform." An effort to maintain peace while training Iraqis to handle their own policing and security, security sector reform is fundamental to the British-American exit strategy. As one British officer put it, "The sooner the locals assume their own security, the sooner we go home."

title: Heavy rains hamper relief work in India, death toll will reach 1,000
Chinese Government Warns Citizens About Threats to Social Stability
description: BEIJING, July 31 - In a sign that top leaders are growing increasingly worried about unrest in the countryside, the Chinese government has warned citizens that they must obey the law and that any threats to social stability will not be tolerated.

title: Boston to Oregon to Bronx, Embree Has New Uniform
description: When Shawn Chacon took the mound yesterday, the Yankees set a club record for pitchers used in one season, with 25. Later in the game, Alan Embree brought the number to 26. If the Yankees get their wish before today's 4 p.m. nonwaiver trading deadline, the total will climb even higher.

title: Restrictions on Sales in a Condo
description: Q. A recent column in the Real Estate section referred to a New York State court ruling that appeared to give condominium boards greater flexibility in adopting restrictions on sales of units that go beyond the simple right of first refusal ("Your Home," June 19, "Court Backs Condos on Sale Restrictions"). Our board is concerned that low interest rates and aggressive lenders are making apartments affordable to buyers who may have trouble down the road if interest rates increase. Does this recent case suggest that a bylaw change limiting the extent of financing may now be allowed? ... Stewart Halpern, Manhattan.

title: The Governor Goes to Iowa
description: George E. Pataki, who announced this week that he was not running for a fourth term as governor of New York, has been very tentatively -- but very publicly -- testing the presidential waters. His trip to the National Governor's Association meeting in Iowa earlier this month was a sure giveaway. (There was, it seems, no thought whatsoever of Mr. Pataki going to the association's gathering simply to meet with his fellow governors.)

title: In SoHo, No Trees Allowed      ''Can't Take the Heat? Plant a Tree,'' by Mike Dombeck (Op-Ed, July 24), illustrates the multifaceted benefits of street trees for the city: shade, cooling, reduction of energy consumption and pollutants, fresher air and enhancement of the streetscape. Who would not want trees?
description: The Landmarks Preservation Commission, that is who.

title: On the Beach, Courtesy of New Jersey
description: As the 4 p.m. sun ducked behind an accommodating cloud last weekend, two shirtless men of considerable girth discovered they were neighbors. Sipping frothy beverages with their feet tucked into the sand, the neighbors, from Woodside, Queens, reflected on their good fortune.

title: Small Museums, Good Deeds
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FARBER, LEONARD L.
description: FARBER--Leonard L. On July 28, 2005, Leonard died peacefully in his home in Fort Lauderdale, FL. He was 89 years old and for years fought Parkinson's Disease with great courage and success. Beloved and adoring husband of Antje, his wife of 30 years. Loving and supportive father of Lindy Linder, Peggy Farber, Felicia Farber Gervais and the late Robert Farber. Grandfather of Liza and Luke Linder, Ben and Sam Jacoff. Loving and supportive father - in - law to Charles S. Gervais, uncle to Eric W. Deckinger and so many more. Born in New York, Leonard skipped college as his father, Morris, died when Leonard was 17 years old and he had to work to support mother Clara and sister Norma. A non-commissioned officer in the U.S. Army, he received the Purple Heart and two Bronze Stars for his bravery and heroism during his duty in Europe during WWII. Leonard was Chairman of Leonard L. Farber Company, a shopping center development firm that had its first seeds of formation in the early 1950's when Leonard and a small group of visionaries began building suburban shopping centers. Leonard was a pioneer in this new industry and was the founding President of the International Council of Shopping Centers, which he helped found in 1957. By this year the organization, now known as the "ICSC", has 45,000 members worldwide, up from the approximate seven original members so many years ago. Over the course of his career, Leonard developed 45 shopping centers from California to Puerto Rico. Leonard received the Horatio Alger Award in 1985 and his Honorary Degree from Brandeis University in 1989. He also served as the Chairman of the Board of Trustees at Brandeis in the mid 1980's where he built the Leonard L. Farber Library and the Robert D. Farber University Archives. President Jimmy Carter appointed Leonard in 1979, to serve on the board of the National Endowment for the Arts. Leonard also was an active community leader, philanthropist and friend. He served over the years on many boards as well as being a donor to many organizations and causes, most notably, The Broward Center for the Performance Arts, The Ft. Lauderdale Symphony Orchestra, The Museum of Arts, The Boys and Girls Club of Ft. Lauderdale, Nova University, Brandeis University, and the National Conference of Christians and Jews. Leonard loved most to cruise on his boat Stoneface, with wife and "1st mate", Antje. He especially enjoyed their summers cruising up the Eastern seaboard to their home away from home, Nantucket Harbor. He was always happiest aboard Stoneface and hosting family and friends in ports in the Caribbean to Bar Harbor to Capri - and all points in between. Leonard's love of life, sensitivity to others, leadership position in so many roles, and determination served as a beacon and role model to all those lucky enough to know him. A Funeral will be held at 2:00p.m. on Sunday, July 31st, at Temple Kol Ami Emanu-El at 8200 Peters Road Plantation, Fla. In Lieu of flowers the family requests memorial gifts be made in Leonard?s honor to The National Parkinson's Foundation or the Massachusetts General Hospital Institute for Neurodegenerative Disease.

title: 'The Method Actors': The Truth Is Over There
description: THE METHOD ACTORS By Carl Shuker. 492 pp. Shoemaker & Hoard. Paper, $16.

title: Internment Camp; Skagen, Denmark
description: INTERNMENT CAMP

title: Letters
description: Will ''framing,'' as reported by Matt Bai, help Democrats get their message out? Is it the key to victory at the polls? The reader response was heavy and heated. Some said it sounded a lot like spin; others compared the Democrats' ''Six Core Values'' with the Republicans' ''Contract With America.''

title: They Didn't Forget the Camera
description: THE introductory wall panel for "Picture Perfect: Masterworks of Photography" at the Bruce Museum of Arts and Science in Greenwich describes the exhibition as drawn from one of the world's finest collections of vintage photography in private hands. The museum is not gilding the lily here, for the Hochberg-Mattis Collection, from which these wonderful photographs are drawn, is probably the most comprehensive and important private collection of vintage photography in the United States.

title: What Does a Terrorist Look Like?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: A New Face of Hunger, Without the Old Excuses
description: THE pictures are wrenching. A nomad holds an infant aloft, its gaunt head lolling dangerously, its matchstick limbs akimbo. A father asks God to forgive him for weeping publicly; he has just buried his son. A child in an emergency clinic awakens from a hunger-induced stupor only to moan and weep from the pain of his starvation-induced skin sores.

title: More Thirsty Than You'd Think
description: THE all-wheel-drive version of the Toyota Highlander Hybrid uses a powertrain almost identical to the one in the Lexus RX400h, and both vehicles carry fuel economy ratings of 31 miles per gallon in town and 27 on the highway. But try as I might, and I did try hard, I could not budge the Highlander Hybrid above 25 m.p.g. on a recent road test in eastern Connecticut.

title: Seeking Summer All Year
description: SUMMER is ripe in the modest seaside cottages here in Old Lyme: Soul-deep heat. Lazy lopes back to the house after a day in the sun. Porches cluttered with inflatable beach toys. Cheap charcoal grills in the grass. Italian ice. Carousel rides. A couple of rowdy bars but mostly just a gentle family tempo. And the evening light is perfect.

title: Mission Impossible? Living the High Life in Newport While Keeping Costs Low
description: FOR a beachy vacation spot, Newport has an unusual theme: anxiety. In Edith Wharton's day, one worried about impressing the social set. For one longtime resident, Doris Duke, shyness mutated into Paxil-worthy pathology. In "Reversal of Fortune," the Hollywood adaptation of the Claus von Blow trial, the objects of anxiety are dire: murder, justice, truth. Even those old Newport cigarette ads straddle the line between pleasure and terror, as the media critic Mark Crispin Miller once pointed out: Are those tan, rich folk laughing or screaming?

title: HIGHFLIER
description: The shareholders of Computer Associates should not look to Lewis S. Ranieri, a director and the chairman of its compensation committee, to limit executive use of the corporate jet.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 31, 2005
description: Weeks

title: Greetings From Rumson, N.J.
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Letters Of Robert Lowell'
description: To the Editor:

title: What's a Tech Company?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WATERS, STUART
description: WATERS--Stuart. As "Reader's Digest" used to chronicle, "the most unforgettable person we ever met." The friends and family of Stu Waters mourn his sudden passing from complications of leukemia on July 29, at the age of 67. Born in Brooklyn, a graduate of Lafayette High School and Florida State, Stu lived life to the fullest. He loved the ponies, football, tennis and a beverage or two. But most of all he loved his wife or 37 years, Karmen, and his friends. He enjoyed his work--for almost 50 years managing hotels and eventually to GM of the Philmont Country Club in Huntingdon Valley, PA. Wherever he went you could be sure Stu was having a good time and all those around him were too. There will be a memorial service in the near future.

title: Corrections
description: A roundup on July 10 about road trips in the United States referred incorrectly to Boothbay Harbor, Me., a stop on an itinerary from Portland to Bar Harbor, Me. While the amount of fishing has decreased, Boothbay Harbor remains a fishing port and is not a former one.

title: Learning the Ins and Outs of Pampering
description: I WAS never a froufrou kind of person," said Joyce Brown, her hair worn in a slight pouf and pulled back from her face, her white lab coat, embroidered with the word "student," open over a black and white shell and skirt. "I was basic. I was soap and water. I don't even wear makeup."

title: Building the Bisbol Brand
description: On the June morning that I visited the Mets' Dominican Academia de Bisbol, a pair of perfect diamonds surrounded by stucco walls topped with barbed wire in the tiny town of Boca de Nigua, the Dominican Summer League had just begun. The Mets' prospects were playing the Detroit Tigers' prospects. One of the Mets' most promising young players on the island, a 17-year-old shortstop named Samuel Jiuz, was making his first start. As he took infield and batting practice, it was easy to see why the Mets are so high on Jiuz. He possesses what scouts call "plus tools" -- a strong arm, soft hands, speed and power -- as well as a "good body." Lean and muscular, he appears in no danger of growing fat. Right now, he's listed at 6-foot-3 and 176 pounds, but with better nutrition and weight training, the Mets' senior scout for the Dominican Republic, Eddy Toledo, expects him to put on 25 pounds of muscle over the next few years. Scouts like to match a prospect with the major leaguer whom he most closely resembles; Toledo compares Jiuz to the former All-Star shortstop Tony Fernandez.

title: Goodbye Gritty, Hello Trendy
description: WHEN it comes to trendy neighborhoods, Toronto's east end has traditionally lagged behind more westerly hot spots such as Queen Street West or College Street's Little Italy. Now, however, Queen Street East is the new Queen Street West, with the formerly industrial stretch known as Leslieville emerging as Toronto's hippest place to dine, drink, shop and live.

title: The Best of All Possible Towns
description: Larchmont - I WOKE up in my bed in Larchmont, the 11th-best place to live in the United States, according to the latest issue of Money magazine. I brushed my teeth with the 11th-best toothbrush, shaved with the 11th-best razor and then took a quick 11th-best shower before pulling on the 11th-best polo shirt in the entire United States.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advisory column on July 10 referred incompletely to statistics for two home exchange programs. Homeexchange.com has 7,500 listings, as the report said, and 20,000 members. Digsville.com has 10,000 members, as the report said, and 1,600 listings.

title: Gentrifying Without Evicting the Artists
description: HOBOKEN - IT is a truism of urban redevelopment: whatever shabby spot artists choose to populate, that place will be gentrified next. A related truth goes like this: as the neighborhood turns upscale, the artists are forced out to find new and funkier circumstances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BOOK, SHIRLEY
description: BOOK--Shirley. For 84 years she lived life by her own rules. Survived by daughter Pamela Marcus, grandson Robert, sister Harriet, nieces Diane and Dede, nephew Paul. We will miss her humor.

title: GOING TO SEATTLE (OR NOT)
description: To the Editor: "Going to Seattle" (July 17) includes some tips my wife and I will probably use in our visit there next month. Unfortunately, in celebrating all the reasons to go there this summer, the essay fails to mention the one that will take us there, as well as many others. That is to attend the Seattle Opera's greatly acclaimed production of the "Ring" cycle, a musical event of national significance.

title: Emily Rand, Allen Popowitz
description: Emily Rand, the daughter of Madelon and Lawrence Rand of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married at her parents' house yesterday morning to Allen Jeffrey Popowitz, a son of the late Harriet Popowitz and the late Dr. Martin Popowitz. The bride's father, who is the mayor of Rye Brook, officiated. Last evening, Rabbi Andre Ungar officiated at a religious service at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   PARNES, SIDMORE
description: PARNES--Sidmore. Dearest friend. Love never forgotten. David

title: Between Home and Work, an Abyss
description: BALANCING life and work is like riding a teeter-totter. Sometimes it's life that is heavier. Sometimes it's work that pulls you down. Once in awhile, for a fleeting moment, everything aligns, parallel and in sync.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 3 about the Ukrainian Village area of Chicago misstated its relationship to a neighborhood known as West Town. West Town includes Ukrainian Village; it is not another name for the area.

title: Far From the Flash of Chelsea, a Gay Pub with a Local Feel
description: ALL men are islands. Perhaps especially gay men, so many of them wary of homophobia. But, as Manhattan itself proves, islands need not feel isolated.

title: Sometimes the Sizzle Can Drown Out the Pitch
description: AFTER spending huge amounts on advertising and marketing in the late 1990's, companies are taking new approaches to building brands, says Kenneth J. Roberts, chief executive of Lippincott Mercer, a brand consulting firm. Following are excerpts from a conversation:

title: Unmet Expectations
description: Advertisements trumpet the RX400h as a hybrid with Lexus luxury and V-8 performance, and indeed the wagon accelerates briskly. But the conventional RX330 is no slouch either, and it costs thousands less.

title: The Politics of Driving The Speed Limit      Joe Queenan's ''Honk if You Hate Me'' (July 24) vis--vis his quest to drive the speed limit was a fine article. It was literary, amusing and to the point. However, my question: Why does your paper have to have such a liberal bias in everything . even in something as mundane as an article about how fast we drive?
description: There was nothing political in the fact that New Jerseyans (and the rest of the country) drive faster than the speed limit. Why question Bill O'Reilly's fairness at the end? Why was it necessary to take a cheap shot at someone?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GUSBERG, SAUL B., M.D.
description: GUSBERG--Saul B., M.D. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society record with profound regret the recent death of their Life Fellow, Saul B. Gusberg, M.D.

title: Lautenberg's Head Is Still Very Much in the Game
description: ASK many New Jersey Democrats, and they'll say that Senator Frank Lautenberg's role as chairman of Jon Corzine's gubernatorial campaign is as much a ceremonial one as it is practical.

title: Newark's Problems? Where to Begin?
description: Ask Newark residents what needs fixing in their neighborhoods, and a litany of issues will likely arise, from crime to noise. But which problems should be tackled first?

title: A Very Long Orientation Pays Off
description: NEWARK - PAULA T. DOW waited patiently for nearly two years. And when she was finally sworn in to a five-year term as the Essex County prosecutor on July 21, after spending 21 months as the acting prosecutor, she couldn't help but smile, a lot.

title: 'The Truth About Hillary': Many a Dubious Revelation
description: THE TRUTH ABOUT HILLARY What She Knew, When She Knew It, and How Far She'll Go to Become President. By Edward Klein. Illustrated. 305 pp. Sentinel. $24.95.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; POP/JAZZ
description: Among those who might find it amusing to torture LIZ PHAIR's serious, somewhat needy-seeming fans, count Ms. Phair herself. In 2003, the singer-songwriter enraged many fans by shedding the trappings of indie-rock: she collaborated with the very mainstream songwriting and production team the Matrix (the team had recently helped make AVRIL LAVIGNE a star); she also posed for a series of unusually flirty promotional photographs.

title: Randall Flinn, Michael Stiglitz
description: Randall Elizabeth Flinn, the daughter of Elizabeth F. Tracey of Brookline, Mass., and Michael deVlaming Flinn of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday on Nantucket to Michael Edwin Stiglitz, the son of Charlotte V. Kuh of Washington and Joseph E. Stiglitz of New York. The Rev. Edward B. Anderson, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Siasconset Union Chapel in Siasconset, Mass.

title: THE WEEK AHEAD: July 31-Aug. 6; FILM
description: It is certainly possible to regard "THE CONFORMIST," Bernardo Bertolucci's 1970 adaptation of Alberto Moravia's novel, as a case study in the psychology of fascism. The antihero, Marcello Clerici (JEAN-LOUIS TRINTIGNANT), is a bureaucratic cold fish deformed by a dysfunctional haute-bourgeois family and a childhood sexual trauma. In 1938, betrothed to a giggly middle-class woman (STEFANIA SANDRELLI), he accepts an assignment from Mussolini's secret police that involves the assassination of his former mentor, a philosopher living in exile in Paris. In Mr. Trintignant's characterization, you can see the lineaments of Moravia's portrait of a man willing to sacrifice his own decency -- his own soul -- in the interests of building "a normal life."

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   EMDEN, HARRY D.
description: EMDEN--Harry D. In cherished memory of a beloved father and grandfather. Passed away July 31, 1971. Forever in our hearts. Howard, Jeffrey, James and Robert

title: What Do Peacocks Say? ACK
description: YOU might think it would be enough for someone who vacations in one of the elite communities of the Northeast to slip away quietly on weekends, to recuperate and laze in peace without heckling the less fortunate.

title: A Cinema So Indie It's 5,000 Miles Away
description: LOS ANGELES - IF the actor Rob Schneider ever shows up in the jungles of Taveuni, Fiji, he will undoubtedly be hailed as a Polynesian god. "Our audience went absolutely nuts for 'The Hot Chick,"' said John Pierson, a major player in the American independent film scene who spent a year showing harebrained comedies and other escapist fare free at a ramshackle island theater roughly 5,000 miles from Hollywood.

title: Uruguay Tackles Old Rights Cases, Charging Ex-President
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay - Juan Mara Bordaberry's years as president here in the mid-1970's are remembered as perhaps the bleakest in the history of this small country, marked by a wave of disappearances, torture and killings aimed at wiping out the remnants of the leftist Tupamaro guerrilla movement.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2006 Lexus RX400h; The Hybrid Emperor's New Clothes
description: CHICAGO - ONE question lingers after driving the 2006 Lexus RX400h: How did it come to this, that Toyota is now selling a hybrid gas-electric vehicle with no tangible fuel economy benefits?

title: The Cows Are Thriving. Now How About Their Doctors?
description: LOWVILLE, N.Y. - On a recent Friday afternoon, in a county where cows outnumber people by more than two to one, Dr. Mark J. Thomas picked up three liters of intravenous fluid from his roving office: the back of a 2002 Ford pickup truck. His patient at the Hilltop Farm was a sick 12-year-old cow, one of more than 60,000 dairy cattle that he and the five other veterinarians at the Countryside Veterinary Clinic provide care for in this rural upstate area.

title: The Industry: Fiber Optic
description: The interior of the Manhattan restaurant Craft is composed of meticulously sourced materials designed to make diners take notice. Panels of hand-stitched leather undulating across one wall are made from bookbinders' calfskin. The floors are of imbuia, a hard Brazilian walnut, while the tables have been carved from Vermont cherry, a wood the architects selected because it would darken to a handsome red over time.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FEDER, DR. STUART
description: FEDER--Dr. Stuart. 75, of Manhattan, died July 29, 2005. Predeceased by his beloved and cherished wife Carol. Dear and devoted father to Susanna, Adam, and Aaron. Caring father-in-law to Colleen. Loving grandfather to Katlyn and Allison. Devoted friend to his companion Charlotte. Dr. Feder was a deeply creative man, infusing himself into all that he did. Dr. Feder will be remembered as a gifted psychoanalyst, psychiatrist, and outstanding teacher. He authored several important biographical works on Charles Ives and Gustav Mahler exploring the connection between psychoanalysis and music. Dr. Feder grew up in Brooklyn, attended Erasmus Hall High School, received his BA from Johns Hopkins University, and obtained a Masters Degree in music from Harvard University. He earned his medical degree from Albert Einstein College of Medicine and completed a residency in Psychiatry at Mt. Sinai Medical Center. He is a graduate of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute where he became a member of the faculty. Until his death Dr. Feder was Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Attending Psychiatrist at Beth Israel Medical Center where he was honored by his students as "Teacher of the Year" for 2005. In addition to being a scholar and physician, he was a chef for all occasions, a passionate gardener, and a Yankee fan. He was dearly and deeply loved by his family and close circle of friends and will be profoundly missed and lovingly remembered. Services will be held on Monday, August 1, at 11:45 AM at "The Riverside," 76th and Amsterdam.

title: The Last of the Indies
description: Although he bristles at the title -- his expression hardens, and his face starts to resemble a cloudy day with thunder threatening -- Jim Jarmusch is the last major truly independent film director in America. This is not a statement about his sensibility, although it is true that his minimalist cinematic style and his ability to deftly cross-pollinate pop culture, Eastern philosophy and classic movie genres have made him a unique presence in film for the past 20 years. While other directors may be hailed for their originality and independent point of view, Jarmusch, unlike Quentin Tarantino or pretty much any other auteur, has never made a film under a studio's watch. Ever since his debut feature, "Stranger Than Paradise," in 1984, which cost $150,000, grossed $2.5 million in North America, won the Camera d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival and permanently upended the idea of independent film as an intrinsically inaccessible avant-garde form, he has owned and controlled all of his movies.

title: What Does a Terrorist Look Like?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JACOBSON, ISHIER
description: JACOBSON--Ishier. The staff and directors of Silver Hill Hospital mourn the passing of Ishier Jacobson, a Director since 1988 and Chairman of the Board of Directors from 1990 to 2002. Ishier guided the hospital with unfailing wisdom, clarity and devotion. His commitment to the mission of the hospital and his concern for the well being of its staff were an inspiration. While we will miss his active leadership, his imprint on our hospital will endure.

title: Augustine for the New Age
description: AUGUSTINE A New Biography. By James J. O'Donnell. 396 pp. Ecco/ HarperCollins Publishers. $26.95.

title: Archaeologists Trace Mystery Wall Not to War, but to Beer
description: Not enough to have fired a shot, but quite enough to have fired a few imaginations, a fortresslike 19th-century wall came to light briefly in recent weeks under a construction site at West End Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Karen Wiessen, Christopher Anrig
description: Karen Leslie Wiessen and Christopher Michael Anrig were married last night at the Angel Orensanz Foundation in New York. Rabbi Marcia Rappaport officiated.

title: DATEBOOK
description: EDINBURGH

title: Finding Shoes For Hard-to-Fit Feet      I totally relate to Pari Chang's lament regarding her search for size 5 shoes (''Small Feet, Big Dreams,'' July 17). I am her male counterpart who has searched Manhattan and beyond for a men's size 5 1/2.
description: I, too, have experienced the frustrating experience of trying to find stylish shoes. The best I can do is find a pair of boy's shoes. No trouble finding a pair of sneakers, but they don't go with a business suit. I have ventured into Stride Rite stores to find Buster Browns inside. I do have my limits! Once in a while I locate a pair of Rockports, or else I buy a unisex-style Birkenstock.

title: Sarah Gall, Richard Pelliccio
description: Dr. Sarah Gall and Richard J. Pelliccio were married yesterday by the Rev. Paul D. Alcorn at Bedford Presbyterian Church in Bedford, N.Y.

title: I Screen, You Screen: The New Age of the Music Video
description: IT'S hard to remember now, but there was a time when MTV was new -- an upstart with barely enough clips to fill its airtime, using "I Want My MTV!" commercials to urge local providers to take notice. The viewing experience was unlike any before it: almost exclusively music videos, a strange new medium of three-minute units and an uncharted arena of artistic and commercial opportunities.

title: A BRIDGE TOO HIGH
description: To the Editor: Regarding "A Soaring Bridge Puts an Ancient Town Back on the Map" (July 17): I have been reading articles for some time now about the Viaduct of Millau and I was wondering if there are others out there, like me, who would not drive over a bridge that high for all the tea in China.

title: The Old Harvard Try
description: How They Got Into Harvard By the Harvard Crimson staff St. Martin's Press, paperback

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GARNETT, BLYNN
description: GARNETT -- Blynn. Born NYC. Circulation Director of New York Review of Books. Died West Newbury, VT.

title: Making a Less Fusty Frick (and Hoping Nobody Notices)
description: WITH its selection of revered old master paintings and imposing Gilded Age dcor, the Frick Collection is set in its ways. And visitors apparently like it that way. People were so startled by improved lighting in the galleries a few years ago that they worried that all the paintings had been cleaned. One woman recently wrote to complain after she discovered that her Bronzino had been moved. When a never-before-displayed portrait bust quietly took up residence next to Jacques-Louis David's well-known oil portrait of the Comtesse Daru last fall, it was a potential earthquake in the making.

title: Nonfiction Chronicle
description: IN THE SHADOWS OF HISTORY: Fifty Years Behind the Scenes of Cold War Diplomacy. By Chester L. Cooper. (Prometheus, $28.) The unmasking of W. Mark Felt as Deep Throat is a reminder of the power of a No. 2: he wasn't the boss, but he was twice as dangerous. Cooper's political memoir opens with the claim that in his long career as a senior officer in the C.I.A. and various other federal agencies -- "as deputy or special assistant to, of or for somebody or something" -- he has had a wisdom far beyond that of his high-powered but short-term bosses. A promising hypothesis, but what Cooper's experience shows -- from minor O.S.S. operations in China during World War II through Korea, the Cuban missile crisis, Vietnam and other conflicts -- is that bureaucratic work, even all the way (or almost all the way) to the top, is always dull and usually inconsequential. During the Suez crisis of 1956, as the British-French-Israeli plan to recover the canal from Egypt builds to a dangerous standoff, our hero wrings his hands for a while and then plays Monopoly with his family; in 1966 he rubber-stamps an empty promise from President Lyndon Johnson to withdraw troops from Vietnam within six months. Cooper describes every diplomatic tea party and handshake in fetishistic detail, but his role is never clear, nor are any of those vital lessons from history. Sometimes a fly on the wall is just a fly.

title: QUICK BITE: Lodi; Warehouse Spices
description: Many immigrants from all over the Indian subcontinent have been settling in Bergen County. With them they have brought the exotic flavors of their homeland, available in local grocery stores specializing in Indian and Pakistani spices and produce. Unfortunately, if you are looking for authentic regional Indian cuisine, you may be disappointed and faced with the same old and tired menu offered in most Indian restaurants, as the best Indian food is served in private homes.

title: 'Dark Genius of Wall Street': Jay Millionaire
description: DARK GENIUS OF WALL STREET The Misunderstood Life of Jay Gould, King of the Robber Barons. By Edward J. Renehan Jr. Illustrated. 352 pp. Basic Books. $30.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   COOPER, ADELE ESTHER AND JOSEPH ABRAHAM
description: COOPER--Adele Esther and Joseph Abraham. Devoted Parents and Grandparents Lovingly Remembered.

title: Trying to Keep les Bons Temps From Rolling Over Them
description: New Orleans - On a Friday morning in 1995, a group of French Quarter residents swarmed a tour bus full of female barbershop singing contestants and held it motionless for nearly an hour.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   GIAMELLI, JOSEPH
description: GIAMELLI -- Joseph. New York Medical College is stunned and grieved by the sudden loss of our Board of Trustee member Joseph Giamelli who died from injuries sustained in a car accident on July 28, 2005. Mr. Giamelli resided in Irvington, NY. Mr. Giamelli is survived by his loving wife of 34 years, Joann, his daughter, Christina and sons Richard, and Joseph Giamelli, Jr., M.D. Mr. Giamelli's career spanned many achievements as a shrewd executive for Citibank, Toys R Us and Barnes and Nobles. Mr. Giamelli was elected to the Board of Trustees of the College in 1996. During his tenure as trustee, he served on numerous Committees of the Board including the Development Committee, Academic Affairs and the Executive Committees. His involvement with the College began with his support of the pediatric hematology and oncology division and has grown through the years. Until his untimely death, he continued to be involved in the College's annual Founder's Dinner, the President's Circle, the Children's Cancer Fund and various College building and scholarship projects. We will miss his steadfast support and unselfish dedication. We extend heartfelt condolences to his loved ones. Visitors may call on Sunday, Monday and Tuesday, 2-4 p.m. and 7-9 p.m. at Dwyer Funeral Home, 90 N. Broadway, Tarrytown. A Mass of the Resurrection will be celebrated Wednesday at 10 a.m. at Church of the Immaculate Conception, 16 N. Broadway, Irvington. Ronald F. Poe, Chairman Board of Trustees Rev. Msgr. Harry C. Barrett President and CEO Ralph A. O'Connell, M.D. Provost and Dean School of Medicine

title: EGYPTIANS FACING DEPORTATION
description: Five Egyptian men are in federal custody and facing deportation, accused of being in the country illegally, after an anonymous tip to the police, the F.B.I. said Tuesday. No criminal charges were filed and federal investigators found no weapons or signs of terrorist activity, said Special Agent Steven Siegel. He said that the Newark police asked for the F.B.I.'s help after finding train schedules with circled stops and $8,000 in cash at the home on Ferry Street where the five men lived with a sixth Egyptian who was in the country legally. Investigators eventually found that one man had used the map to go to his restaurant job in New York. Damien Cave

title: It's a Bird! It's a Plane! It's Architecture!
description: FOR some comic book fans, the fictional cities of Metropolis and Gotham, home to Superman and Batman, feel as real as New York, the inspiration for both towns. Now there is another city to add to their dreamscape: the Cinderella City, the setting for the comic book series Manhattan Guardian, the latest issue of which arrives on Sept. 7. As the title of the series indicates, Cinderella City is unmistakably New York, but it is a New York that is at once more true to life and more fantastical than that of any other comic book tribute.

title: Seething Unease Shaped British Bombers' Newfound Zeal
description: LEEDS, England, July 30 - Mohammad Sidique Khan was never on the corner, a detail friends offer as a compliment. In a neighborhood where many young South Asian men had lost their way, or foundered into drug dealing, Mr. Khan's peers admired his focus on family, work, working out, and Islam.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   FIX, HOWARD D.
description: FIX--Howard D. Devoted father of Audrey (Steven) Schaeffer and Steven (Terri) Fix. Adored grandfather of Rebecca and Joey Schaeffer and Rachel and Jessica Fix. Beloved brother of Emily (Larry) Aibel, Florence (Irwin) Zahn, Marjorie (Robert) Davis. A gentle man who loved and was loved by his family and friends. He will forever remain in our memories.

title: Lofty Goals: The MetroStars Are Ready to Excel
description: EAST RUTHERFORD - THE voice of the MetroStars' new general manager, Alexi Lalas, bounced around the empty stands of Giants Stadium as he talked about the ghosts of New York soccer past.

title: The Framing Wars
description: As a Democrat, I shook my head. The title of the new pamphlet "The House Democrats' New Partnership for America's Future: Six Core Values for a Strong and Secure Middle Class" offers 18 abstract and windy words compared with the Republicans' succinct "Contract With America." Writers, not focus groups, are what we need.

title: Laurel Friedmann and Marc Friedman
description: Laurel Hope Friedmann and Marc Stuart Friedman were married yesterday evening at Bouley, the New York restaurant. Rabbi Nathan Benjamin officiated.

title: The Costco Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEEK: Faces of Protest | July 24-30
description: They Object -- The reach, overreach and potential reach of government was the subject of protests around the globe last week. A sampling, clockwise from top left:

title: Off the Waterfront
description: ALTHOUGH many of the old piers that line the Hudson River have been made over in recent years, outfitted in brick-lined dog runs and sporting fields topped with "turf grass," Pier 25 in TriBeCa is still scruffy and untouched, and defiantly so.

title: The Ghosts of Emmett Till
description: We've known his story forever, it seems. Maybe that's because it's a tale so stark and powerful that it has assumed an air of timelessness, something almost mythical: Emmett Till, a 14-year-old black kid born and raised in Chicago, went down in August 1955 to visit some relatives in the hamlet of Money, Miss. One day, he walked into a country store there, Bryant's Grocery and Meat Market, and, on a dare, said something fresh to the white woman behind the counter -- 21-year-old Carolyn Bryant, the owner's wife -- or asked her for a date, or maybe wolf-whistled at her. A few nights later, her husband, Roy Bryant, and his half brother, J.W. Milam, yanked young Till out of bed and off into the dark Delta, where they beat, tortured and, ultimately, shot him in the head and pushed him into the Tallahatchie River. His body, though tied to a heavy cotton-gin fan with barbed wire, surfaced a few days later, whereupon Bryant and Milam were arrested and charged with murder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BERGER, MARK H.
description: BERGER--Mark H. 77, of New York, N.Y., suddenly on July 27, 2005. Loving husband of 51 years of Margaret, beloved father of Joshua (Leeza) and David (Tracey), and wonderful grandfather of Tashi and Noah. He was an alumnus of Polytechnic University (1947) and of Harvard Law School (1950). Services at Riverside Chapel, 76th St and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, July 31, 11:30am. Donations in lieu of flowers to East 55 St. Conservative Synagogue, 308 E. 55 St., N.Y., N.Y. 10022.

title: U.S. Study Pinpoints Near-Misses by Allies in Fathoming the Unfolding Holocaust
description: Who in Allied governments, the Vatican and the press knew what about the Holocaust and when? What could and should have been done to save Europe's Jews? Ever since World War II, those questions have been fiercely debated.

title: Will Fame and Fortune Change Utility Stocks?
description: IF technology stocks are the market's equivalent of Ferraris in the fast lane, then utilities are Volvos driven down Main Street at two miles an hour below the speed limit. They are bought for safety and stability, not high performance.

title: All Worked Up and Wondering Why
description: THE squabble that dominated last week's union convention in Chicago might have seemed like a quaint reminder of a time when big labor really mattered. As union leaders traded insults about who had workers' interests at heart, three of the nation's biggest unions split from the A.F.L.-C.I.O., claiming that they had fresher ideas for halting organized labor's long decline.

title: Surprise, Straight Up
description: WHY are there no new classic cocktails? I mean, the martini was a long time ago. With all this invention, why am I still drinking gimlets?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PINTO, NICK
description: PINTO--Nick. Unexpectedly we lost Nick Pinto July 2, 2005. Friend, Colleague, Bon Vivant Raconteur. Man about Greenwich Village, a good man lost in a medical maelstrom. Memorial gala to be held 3-6pm Kettle of Fish, Sunday July 31, 2005. Ruth Rogin

title: Longing for a Cuss-Free Zone
description: Correction Appended

title: The Quarterless Phone (but Read the Ads)
description: Four pay phones sit on the corner of West 34th Street and 10th Avenue, two on the southeast corner and two on the northwest, and on a sultry afternoon last week a steady stream of callers fed them a steady stream of quarters.

title: Chelsea Handler: The Jokes Are on Her
description: LOS ANGELES - ONE July evening at the NBC studios where "The Tonight Show" is taped, Chelsea Handler, who stars in "Girls Behaving Badly" on the Oxygen network, was holding court in her dressing room. She entertained her audience with anecdotes from a book tour of the Netherlands and Belgium.

title: An Employee, Hired as a Man, Becomes a Woman. Now What?
description: On a recent Wednesday, Kim Dower, a Denver pharmacist, arrived at her job of 10 years wearing a cream chiffon blouse, long crepe skirt and black flats.

title: Where the Entertainment Vies With the Food
description: Correction Appended

title: Homes Taken, Lives Rebuilt
description: PORT CHESTER - IN 1996, when Gregg Wasser, a developer from Long Island, first scouted the blighted waterfront along the Byram River here, the scene consisted of shabby wood frame homes, run-down commercial buildings and alleyways littered with crack vials. In his imagination, though, Mr. Wasser saw a bustling retail complex drawing throngs of shoppers from throughout Westchester County and southern Connecticut.

title: Age-Limit Reason
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Anti-Mubarak Protesters Clash With Police in Cairo
description: CAIRO, July 30 - Wielding bamboo batons and small leaded clubs, Egyptian security agents attacked and beat protesters on Saturday as they tried to rally in the central Tahrir Square here, chanting slogans calling for the end of Hosni Mubarak's 24-year-reign as president.

title: Lois Najarian, Christopher O'Neill
description: Lois Marie Najarian and Christopher James O'Neill were married yesterday at the bride's weekend house in White Sulphur Springs, N.Y. The Rev. Kim Kirkley, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

title: The Many Faces of John Lennon: Black, White, Male, Female
description: FOR Don Scardino, the idea of writing and directing a musical about John Lennon was impossible to resist, even though the pitfalls of undertaking the project could not have been clearer. A Beatles fan since the group's earliest hits -- now 57, he said he hightailed it to Kennedy Airport to see the group's arrival here on its first visit in 1964 -- he caught both Beatles concerts at Shea Stadium, in 1965 and 1966, and still quotes lines from "A Hard Day's Night" and "Help!" from memory. So he knew enough about the world of obsessive fandom to understand that however he presented Lennon, there would be choruses of objection.

title: Katharine O'Connor, Felix Lopez
description: Katharine Maura O'Connor, a daughter of Andrew S. O'Connor and a stepdaughter of Kelly C. O'Connor of Larchmont, N.Y., was married yesterday to Felix James Lopez, the son of Magdalene and Felix E. Lopez of Port Washington, N.Y. Msgr. Walter F. Kenny performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont.

title: The Lady Was a Muse
description: 'My Lady Rich'

title: Heather Schoenfeld and Harvey Young Jr.
description: Heather Alma Schoenfeld, a daughter of Ellen Schoenfeld-Beeks and David Schoenfeld of Sharon, Mass., was married yesterday to Harvey Young Jr., the son of Regina Young and Mr. Young of Amherst, N.Y. The Rev. Cheryl Cavalconte and the Rev. Charles C. Cavalconte, both Apostolic Catholic priests who are married to one another, officiated at the Linden Place Museum in Bristol, R.I.

title: When the Backyard Views Are of Wells and Drilling Rigs
description: WHEN Peggy and Bob Utesch bought a house five years ago on four acres in a town called Silt in rural Garfield County, Colo., they envisioned a quiet, pastoral life. What they got instead was the constant noise and exhaust of heavy trucks and natural gas drilling equipment, not to mention rig workers urinating on their lawn.

title: Riding Out the Storms While on Vacation
description: IF last summer's tempests weren't a powerful enough reminder of the risks of traveling during hurricane season, this year's early string of violent storms should do the job. Between Dennis and Emily, and the National Weather Service's grim prediction of seven to nine hurricanes this season, the odds of a tropical getaway turning into a brush with disaster seem stacked against the traveler.

title: Letters
description: The Costco Strategy

title: Bridgit Dengel, Ray Gaspard
description: Bridgit Dengel and Ray Gaspard were married yesterday at the couple's home in Brooklyn. Justice Gustin L. Reichbach of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: LONDON AFTER THE BOMBINGS
description: To the Editor: Regarding "London After the Bombings: Life Goes On" by Stuart Emmrich (July 17): I too arrived in London from New York just after the bombings, for a whirlwind weekend visit. I had received an invitation from the prime minister and the government of Britain to attend an event on July 10, in the presence of the queen, as part of the weekend celebration to honor British veterans of World War II.

title: Talks for Ramirez Break Down Over Prospects
description: HOUSTON, July 30 - Not since the 1986 World Series have the Mets and the Boston Red Sox engaged in such a dramatic confrontation.

title: No Cash for Nobu? Try All-You-Can-Eat Sushi
description: Andrew Block, a preppy 25-year-old, had just paid $160 for himself and five friends to feast on all-you-can-eat sushi and half-priced drinks. Actually, one friend had only chicken teriyaki and drinks, but the meal was still one weird dining moment.

title: Carroll Ballard's Second Chance
description: Carroll Ballard's elegant and engaging films have consistently enchanted critics while baffling their distributors. "The Black Stallion," his debut, gained a general release from United Artists in 1979 only through the intervention of his film-school friend, the director Francis Ford Coppola, and he has had just four features released since. Now his latest film, "Duma," the story of a boy and a cheetah, has Warner Brothers wondering what to do.

title: About That Unquivering Flesh
description: Correction Appended

title: A Foundation's Missions
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A classical music report on the Week Ahead page last Sunday about the Mostly Mozart Festival at Lincoln Center referred incorrectly to the New York Philharmonic's adoption of the thrust-stage configuration being used by the festival orchestra. The Philharmonic's board has approved a redesign plan featuring such a stage, but not for next season; no date has been set.

title: Leslie Duhaylongsod, Eric Beerbohm
description: Leslie Joan Duhaylongsod, the daughter of Lourdes and Douglas M. Duhaylongsod of Isleton, Calif., was married yesterday to Eric Anthony Beerbohm, the son of Kathleen and Kenneth R. Beerbohm of Belmont, Calif. The Rev. Patrick L. LaBelle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Stanford Memorial Church in Stanford, Calif.

title: The Bolshoi Ballet Returns to New York and Finds Moscow
description: Almost 15 years ago, my daughter and I sat in very high seats at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow for a "limited view" of "Swan Lake." Mostly, the view was limited to the tops of the dancers' heads, but it was still the Bolshoi Ballet and as foreigners we knew we were among the favored. Outside, Russians were begging for tickets, even our tickets.

title: An Unwanted Mall In Our Backyard
description: To the Editor:

title: There's Always Teaching
description: With jobs aplenty and an increasing number of adults joining the profession, schools for aspiring teachers seemed destined to go online. This year, with new programs from Kaplan Inc. and other commercial ventures, the concept appears to have reached critical mass. Online students still do fieldwork in real classrooms, but they take courses in theory and methodology on their own time, with the help of e-mail, bulletin boards, digital libraries, video streaming and teleconferencing.

title: On Board at Bendheim...
description: For several years the Bendheim Performing Arts Center of the J.C.C. of Mid-Westchester in Scarsdale had been managing without an artistic director, but no longer. When the right person became available at the right time, said Stephen E. Young, the group's executive director, he seized the opportunity to hire Brad Garfield, an arts-oriented Emmy-winning television director.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   LIEBERMAN, WILLIAM S.
description: LIEBERMAN--William S. The Metropolitan Museum of Art will hold a memorial service for William S. Lieberman on Monday, September 12, at 5:30PM. He was the Museum's Jacques and Natasha Gelman Special Consultant for Modern Art at the time of his death on June 1, and for the previous 24 years served as chairman of the department of modern art at the Metropolitan. Inquiries may be addressed to the Development Office, The Metropolitan Museum of Art, 1000 Fifth Ave., NY, NY 10028.

title: Spreading as Quietly as a Clam
description: LONG ISLANDERS have been harvesting shellfish for 4,000 years, and dining on fried clams is a tradition. But if you're eating clams this summer, consider yourself lucky. Red tide -- the enemy of clam lovers everywhere -- came farther south this summer than it has in decades. And now the deadly blight may be poised to colonize Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   JEZER, MARTY
description: JEZER--Marty. Marty Jezer, 64, activist and author, died June 11, 2005 at home in Brattleboro, VT. Born and raised in the Bronx, he influenced four decades of progressive politics. He considered his greatest accomplishment his co-founding of the Working Group on Electoral Democracy and co-authoring of ground-breaking model legislation for publicly financed election campaigns. He wrote a widely distributed column for the Brattleboro Reformer and authored highly praised biographies of Rachel Carson and Abbie Hoffman, a postwar history of the U.S. (1945-1960), and a personal memoir about his life as a stutterer. Marty is survived by his loving partner of the past twelve years, Arlene Distler, his daughter Kathryn Ruth Jezer-Morton, her husband Gray Miles, Kathryn's mother Mimi Morton, and step-children Josh, Aaron, Rachel, and Ezra Distler.

title: Nepal soldiers hunt for kidnapped government officials
For Pataki, a Rare Path Toward the National Stage
description: George E. Pataki's decision not to run for a fourth term puts him in an exclusive club: only two New York governors in modern times transformed themselves overnight into lame ducks by announcing that they would not seek re-election.

title: DEALS & DISCOUNTS
description: THEME PARK PENNSYLVANIA -- For a late summer visit to Dorney Park and Wild Water Kingdom in the Lehigh Valley of Pennsylvania, there are 30 hotels in the area that offer Dorney Deals through Sept. 6. Most packages combine accommodations, discounted park tickets and breakfast; taxes of 9.5 percent are extra. A few properties include free all-day tickets as part of the package. For more information, call the Lehigh Valley Convention and Visitors Bureau at (800)747-0561 or see www.lehighvalleypa.org.

title: 'The Lady and the Panda'
description: It was a bitter winter night, February 19, 1936, and on the outskirts of Shanghai, far from the neon and the wailing jazz, thirty-four-year-old William Harvest Harkness, Jr., lay in a private hospital, blood-stiffened silk sutures tracking across his pale abdomen. He was dying, and alone in his agony. His original expedition mates, four adventurous men with dreams of capturing the giant panda, had all deserted him long before. Though he knew people in the city from previous trips and more recent escapades in notorious nightclubs and bars, in the end he had stayed true to some deeper nature, pushing them all away and stealing off in secret. His family, including his young wife back in Manhattan, had no idea he was even sick. With what little strength he could summon, he had been writing sunny notes home that masked his horrible condition. Perhaps he really believed his own words, for just weeks earlier he had been pressuring the doctor to release him so he could get back to his campaign. But, finally, on this frigid night, scarred by other attempts to scalpel tumors from his neck and torso and wretched from his latest incision, he found himself unable to eat or drink, then even to breathe. The sportsman who lived to rough it in the wild died under starched white sheets, in a ward reeking of antiseptic. His young life had ended in the pursuit of the most mysterious animal of his time, yet he had never managed to set a laced boot in the great snow-covered mountains that separated China and Tibet.

title: The Framing Wars
description: George Orwell would have enjoyed Matt Bai's entertaining article (July 17). It has already made me more conscious of the words politicians use.

title: Read the Book, Then See Where the Story Took Place
description: While "The Da Vinci Code" has spawned its own tourist phenomenon with $3,000 trans-Atlantic tours and $400 all-day walks in Paris along the da Vinci trail, a number of niche tour operators are offering customized literary tours that cater to the interests of a wide variety of book lovers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   BUXTON, SUSAN
description: BUXTON--Susan. Born May 14, 1933 in Milwaukee, WI. Daughter of Ruth and Ralph Abrams, died July 26, 2005 in NYC. Wife of the late Edward F. Buxton. Step-mother to Gail Buxton and Leslie Buxton Moreno. Cousin of James and Thomas Krauskopf. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MACCRACKEN, ELEANOR D.
description: MacCRACKEN--Eleanor D., 86, died on July 29, 2005, at her home in New York City. The daughter of Eleanor G. and Charles A. Dickson, of Pittsburgh, she attended the Ellis School in that city and was a graduate of Miss Hall's School and Vassar College (Class of 1940). From 1949 to 1974 she lived in New Canaan, CT, and from 1956 to 2001, spent summers in Amagansett, NY. She is survived by her son and daughter-in-law, Thomas G. and Alexandra J. MacCracken, of Oakton, VA; her daughter, Linda P. MacCracken, of Newcastle, WA; and her granddaughter, Paige F. Ioppolo, also of Newcastle. Funeral services and interment will be in her native Pittsburgh. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Cancer Research Institute, 681 5th Avenue, NYC 10022; or the Natural Resources Defense Council, 40 West 20th St, NYC 10011.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   WINSTON, JEROME (JERRY)
description: WINSTON--Jerome (Jerry). Of Greensboro, NC and NYC, died on July 28, 2005. Beloved husband of Sylvia. Father and father-in-law of Gail Winston, Gary Donaldson, Silver Spring, MD; Patricia and Glenn Werner, Roslyn, NY; Charles Winston, Tampa, FL. Grandfather of Bradley and Andrew Werner; Alexandra, Brett, and Jason Winston. He is survived by siblings Carol Herman Janis (David), Richard Winston (Susan). Many cousins, nieces and nephews, all equally loved. During WWII, Jerry fought in the Battle of the Bulge, receiving a Bronze Star and Purple Heart. He was a graduate of Cornell U ('47). As a teenager, Jerry worked summers for his uncle (the late Harry Winston) where he developed a passion for the diamond and jewelry industry. He felt fortunate to have spent his life doing what he loved. His other great love was golf. Donations may be sent to Beacon Pl, 2502 Summit Ave, Greensboro, NC 27405, or any hospice.

title: Zoning Fight Is Over, but Argument Isn't
description: Zoning Fight Is Over, But Argument Isn't

title: Blockbusted
description: The recent laments over Hollywood's steadily declining box office figures sometimes neglect to point out that movies are spreading themselves across more and more screens while earning those disappointing results. Of the 11 widest openings in Hollywood history -- from "Robots" in 3,776 theaters up to "Shrek 2" in 4,223 -- five have appeared already this year, and another five were in 2004. (The lone exception: "Spider-Man" on 3,876 screens in 2002.)

title: ...And at the Neuberger
description: Thom Collins has been appointed director of the Neuberger Museum of Art, Westchester's largest art museum. Mr. Collins, a native of Philadelphia, joins the Neuberger from the Contemporary Museum of Baltimore, where for two years he has been executive director. He also served as senior curator of the Contemporary Arts Center in Cincinnati.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Stephanie Klein, who writes a blog about her dating life, referred imprecisely to sororities that did not invite her to join when she was at Barnard College. The sororities are recognized by its affiliated university, Columbia; Barnard does not have sororities.

title: For Security, Follow the House
description: After the London bombings, it is more obvious than ever that next year's Homeland Security budget should direct as much money as possible to the places most at risk of attack. But that may not happen. The Senate, disgracefully, voted this month to take money from states like New York, California and Texas, which are at greatest risk, and give it to states like Wyoming. But the House of Representatives has now done the right thing, and voted to hand out more of the money based on risk. When the final formula is settled on, it is important that the House version prevail.

title: With Mets Getting Itchy, Boston Star Is Scratched
description: BOSTON, July 30 - There were 6 Boston Red Sox in and around the batting cage, 2 others fielding grounders, 10 more shagging fly balls and one talking to fans. There was also one prominent player missing from this pregame picture at Fenway Park. Where was Manny Ramirez?

title: Looking Back on Days of Indulgence, and Forward
description: SEE if this sounds familiar: "Striving so passionately to be Good Parents -- the ultimate accolade in these child-minded times -- many mothers and fathers have turned parenthood into a painfully competitive sport. In an era when traditional status symbols can turn obsolescent overnight, they have discovered that social stature may still be gained by raising the best-dressed, -fed, -educated, -mannered, -medicated, -cultured, and -adjusted child on the block."

title: Paperback Row
description: FICTION | NONFICTION

title: Two Parents Are Charged in Deaths of Two Toddlers
description: The father of one of two boys who died in a Yonkers apartment on Friday had turned on scalding hot bathtub water and locked them in the bathroom, Westchester County and Yonkers police officials said yesterday. He then fell asleep with their intoxicated mother while the tub overflowed, the officials said.

title: On the Cover
description: IN the overstuffed genre of television police dramas, TNT's "Wanted," which arrives this week, may have the distinction of having the baddest bad guys on the air. The series follows an elite squad in Los Angeles whose assignment is to bring in the 100 worst criminals out there, and the miscreants make crystal clear why they are on the list, by assaulting and killing with vicious abandon before the good guys catch up with them.

title: Prep's Cool
description: PRIVATE-SCHOOL enrollment is up nearly 20 percent over 10 years. Factor in fashion's current crush on stripes, polka dots and polo shirts -- not to mention Curtis Sittenfeld's boarding-school best-seller "Prep" -- and the result is clear: preppies are back in a big way. Think Holden Caulfield, Jenna and Barbara Bush (Hockaday School alumnae), and anyone who uses "summer" as a verb. While sporting the look no longer takes a trust fund, it does call for a combination of rumpled clothes and subtle status symbols, like a simple strand of pearls. Here, students from three top boarding schools show how it's done.

title: Finding Shoes For Hard-to-Fit Feet      I commiserate with Pari Chang's problem about finding shoes. Like Ms. Chang, I'm short (4-foot-10 in my stocking feet) and I have searched for 6W's. She is correct: it is almost impossible to find good-looking shoes if you don't wear at least a size 7.
description: But hey, Ms. Chang, I'll let you in on a secret: the two Upper West Side stores that advertise nearly daily in The Times are fabulous for hard-to-find shoe sizes. Catalogues and online services offer more options. And the best-kept secret for hard-to-fit feet are the ubiquitous Payless stores. They carry terrific knock-offs of top-of-the-line shoes, and best of all, the shoes are so inexpensive, you can buy a year's worth of shoes for half the price of a pair of Manolos!

description: A Medically Dubious Ailment

title: An Art-Architecture Tour of Berlin; Child Care in Rome
description: Correction Appended

title: Suspect Held in Italy Said to Admit Carrying Bomb in Train
description: ROME, July 30 - A suspect in the failed July 21 bombings arrested in Rome on Friday confessed to investigators to carrying a bomb through London's subway, but claimed it was meant as a "demonstration" rather than as a means of killing, a person with firsthand knowledge of the interrogation said on Saturday.

title: In Race to Stem Cell Center, New Jersey's Efforts Stall
description: In New Jersey, which bills itself as the medicine cabinet of the nation, the potentially lucrative stem cell research race has gone off with both a bang and a whimper.

title: Speaking Dance in 3 Weeks
description: Alice Teirstein's mission: to turn 16 or so teenagers into a dance company in three weeks (and to teach all of them to choreograph while she's at it). Each year Ms. Teirstein, the founder of Young Dancemakers, gives a group of students from New York high schools the opportunity to learn choreography by creating their own works; the results of this year's program are currently being performed around the city, including at a gala on Thursday at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. Here is Ms. Teirstein's almost foolproof plan, which, she said, has worked effectively for 10 seasons now.

title: Utterly Confused In the Maze of Love
description: MORRIS TOWNSHIP - "WHAT is so rare as a day in June?"

title: Blond and Blonder: It's Not Easy Playing Dumb
description: THE incandescent Diane Lane and the appealing John Cusack are the stars, playing mopey singles stepping warily back into circulation after painful divorces. The supporting cast, an ensemble of scene stealers, includes Christopher Plummer and Stockard Channing. And as the title, "Must Love Dogs," suggests, several adorable pooches figure in as well.

title: Hey, Jon, Pass Me a Wrench
description: Doug Forrester last week was right where Jon Corzine wants him: on his knees.

description: Amy Marie Ludwig and Jonathan Jeffrey Blyth are to be married today at Christ Episcopal Church in Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Shirley Smith Graham is to perform the ceremony.

description: It was supposed to be a Day-Glo kind of summer for downtown Stone Harbor, but now the tony Cape May County beach town will just have to get by on blue skies and smiles.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LADENSON, IRENE AKHIMOFF
description: LADENSON--Irene Akhimoff. Died this past winter, on January 15, 2005, in New York City. Born in the Bronx on January 22, 1931, she attended the University of Pennsylvania and the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts. She worked as a restorer of paintings and photographs, and was a longtime volunteer at the Riverside Branch of the New York Public Library. Her husband, Sam, died in 2004. She is survived by her daughter, Elisabeth.

title: Iraqi Official Says Panel Will Try to Meet Constitution Deadline
description: Iraq's national security adviser said today that a committee set up to write the country's constitution would try to meet a deadline to complete the draft, sticking to a United States-backed timetable that he described as essential to the credibility of the new government.

title: Astronauts Test Repair Methods on Heat Tiles
description: WASHINGTON, July 30 - Two astronauts from the space shuttle Discovery ventured outside the craft on Saturday for the first of three scheduled spacewalks. The pair tested prototype methods for repairing a shuttle's heat-resistant tiles and completed several tasks for upgrading the International Space Station.

title: Hepsibah Hats in London
description: There's a fifth season to the British year, starting about the time the buds break on the trees and the country's residents once again hit the garden party circuit.

title: Holding Their Breath, Spear Gun in Hand
description: Montauk - STRAPPING a belt holding 30 pounds of lead plates to his wet suit, Chris Miller adjusted his snorkel mask and grabbed a yellow spear gun. Looking at the gray fog that engulfed his boat, he asked, "Why'd they have to do this to me?"

title: New Degree Will Focus On Homeland Security
description: Long Island University will begin the second of the nation's graduate programs in homeland security management this fall when it offers a 15-credit curriculum leading to a certificate.

title: Deciding When It's Time To Say Yes
description: Not every reluctant buyer needs to clean mental house first. There are plenty of sane reasons -- mostly bearing the likenesses of presidents -- to avoid putting pen to contract. Here, four buyers tell their stories. TERI KARUSH ROGERS

title: Mad Hot Classrooms Are Abundant This Summer
description: TARRYTOWN - ALEX BASESCU has seen his favorite movie, "Mad Hot Ballroom," twice. He used the word thrilling to describe the film about a ballroom dancing competition among children in New York City.

description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: An L.I. School of Poetry: Does Such a Thing Exist?
description: Starting from the fish-shaped Paumanok where I was born, Well-begotten, and rais'd by a perfect mother, After roaming many lands, lover of populous pavements. -- Walt Whitman, "Leaves of Grass"

title: Formula One Seeks Riches in Russia
description: BUDAPEST, July 30 - Two decades after Formula One's first race in Hungary, the country has embraced a market economy, but Formula One is still chasing the riches of expansion into the former Soviet Union.

title: SKHIRAT, APRIL 2005
description: Neall Epstein, 27, a biochemist and snowboard guide from Vancouver, British Columbia. "I was at a surf camp in Taghazout, but the waves were very small, and Grilo, the guy sitting behind me on the camel, said 'I know this really cool area. We'll have to take camels, and not everyone's allowed to go there because it's where the king's summer palace is. Don't worry though, because I know the head security guard.' These guys we met loaded up their camels. For some reason ours was the only one that didn't want surfboards. At the beach, two guards came out with guns and started asking questions. Grilo said, 'I know your boss and I've spoken with him many times before. You can either go find him, waste his time and he'll tell us its o.k., or you can go and have lunch.' They went and had lunch. It was one of the best days of surfing we had." WHY WE TRAVEL: MORROCCO

title: A Welcoming Place to Raise a Family
description: EACH weekday evening, as Madeline Urena, a detective with the New York City Police Department, drives north to her home in New City, N.Y., she unwinds from the day's pressures by watching the cityscapes of Manhattan yield to the lush landscapes along the Palisades Interstate Parkway. It is a commute that functions like a decompression chamber, she said.

title: Growing Up With a Dose of Magic
description: FRANKLIN LAKE, N.J. - I WISH I could say I started reading Harry Potter before the mania hit, but the first time I ever heard about the books was months after the release of "Sorcerer's Stone," when I ran across a small display table at the local Barnes & Noble. I read the jacket flap, decided not to buy a copy, and forgot all about Harry Potter.

title: Police Seek Boy Lost At Stadium
description: The police were searching yesterday for a 13-year-old Connecticut boy who disappeared at Yankee Stadium during a game on Friday night.

title: An Auspicious Beginning for a North Fork Vineyard
description: MAKING a debut with a $40 cabernet sauvignon and a $38 merlot takes chutzpah. Few single-grape or blended Long Island reds cost that much. But Richard Pisacano's prices are based on 28 years as a man of the soil.

title: Small Outlets Find Local News Irresistible
description: STARTING last year, the Gannett Company began suspending publication of the first of four of its six local news weekly supplements to The Journal News; the last one was finished off in the spring.

title: Rhyme and Reasoning
description: "Poetry is the universal language which the heart holds with nature and itself," the critic William Hazlitt wrote. Do you speak the tongue? On the left, a poem from the General Educational Development exam, or G.E.D., created by the American Council on Education; on the right, one from the SAT subject test in literature, from the College Board.

title: No Surprise at the Top: Penguins Get Crosby
description: Sidney Crosby, a hockey prodigy whose skills have been compared to Wayne Gretzky's and who is being marketed as the player who will help rekindle interest in a beleaguered sport, was selected by the Pittsburgh Penguins with the first pick in the N.H.L. draft yesterday.

title: Chasing the Mood and Then the Train
description: EACH weekday around 4 p.m., a great rush of commuters floods through the big wooden doors of Grand Central Terminal, pouring onto the marble floor and fanning out to the trains waiting to shuttle them back to Darien, Dobbs Ferry and Chappaqua.

title: Little Sympathy For the Devils
description: NEWARK - THE National Hockey League is back, and so is State Assemblyman Craig A. Stanley (no relation to Lord Stanley or his gloried cup), who wants the New Jersey Devils to change their satanic team name before it ruins the minds of too many more youngsters.

title: How Wall Street Wrecked United's Pension
description: HAD anyone listened to Doug Wilsman, tens of thousands of United Airlines employees would not be facing big cuts in their pensions. And the federal agency that guarantees pensions might not be struggling with its biggest losses ever.

title: FRIEND OF GEORGE
description: Brushing aside concerns about his lack of diplomatic experience and language skills, the Senate moved ahead on the nomination of William R. Timken Jr., the Ohio industrialist, as the next American ambassador to Germany.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 3 about the Ukrainian Village area of Chicago misstated its relationship to a neighborhood known as West Town. West Town includes Ukrainian Village; it is not another name for the area.

description: A CENTRAL downtown Stamford site that has been the subject of significant proposals but that has nonetheless lain dormant for almost a decade is again the focus of development plans.

title: Iraqi constitution chairman wants a 30-day extension
Another Face of Terror
description: Pakistan's president, Pervez Musharraf, is supposed to be our valued ally in the war on terrorism. But terror takes many forms, not all of them hijacked airplanes or bombed subways.

title: From Start, Singh Had It and Woods Did Not
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 30 - It was quiet along the knolls and knobs of Warwick Hills Golf & Country Club, a quiet broken at times by the golf shoes of Tiger Woods crunching through pine cones in the rough.

title: At Practice, a Scare for the Giants' $25 Million Man
description: ALBANY, July 30 - For all of Giants Coach Tom Coughlin's injury-prevention plans, his team did not make it through the first practice of training camp Saturday morning before doctors were scurrying onto the field to look after the star wide receiver Plaxico Burress, who hyperextended his right knee while landing awkwardly after leaping to make a catch.

title: Singh Believes in His Swing; He's Agnostic on Putting
description: GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 30 - Vijay Singh said he wouldn't dare change the golf swing that has given him 12 victories since January 2004. But sometimes he switches putters.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   KAHN, MAX
description: KAHN--Max. October 21, 1927 to July 30, 2004. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. Greatly missed by all. Beatrice, Melissa, Judith, Liana and Emma

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LUBIN, CAROL
description: LUBIN--Carol. The officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Carol Lubin, beloved mother of Ann L. Buttenwiesser and mother-in-law of Lawrence Buttenwiesser, treasured leaders and friends. The Buttenwiesser family's historic commitment to the Jewish community, including Lawrence's dedicated service as our former president, is marked by a boundless generosity & devotion that has been invaluable in strengthening our network of agencies and impacting lives throughout New York. We extend our deepest sympathies to Ann & Lawrence, to their children, & the entire family. Morris W. Offit, President Susan K. Stern, Chair of the Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. V.P. & C.E.O.

description: Correction Appended
