description: 'The Life of a Giant'

title: The Lady Was a Muse
description: 'My Lady Rich' Emily Van Evera, soprano; Christopher Morrongiello, lutenist; others. Avie AV 0045; CD.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   TALBERT, ALFRED A.
description: TALBERT--Alfred A. 85, died on July 20. He resided in Lenox, MA., and Highland Beach, FL. The Talberts lived in Rockville Centre, NY for 50 years. He earned his BS in engineering and his MBA at NYU. A Sergeant in the US Air Force he served during WWII. He was Vice-President of the former Collins Tuttle & Co., Inc. Real Estate in NYC, he managed and developed properties in Manhattan, throughout the country; and Paris, France. He retired in 1999. He was on the Board of the Real Estate Board of New York and the 92nd St. Y of NYC. He and his wife, the former Edith Jackson would have celebrated their 54th wedding anniversary on September 23. They were married in Harrison, NY. Beside his wife he is survived by his son Richard Harrison Talbert of NYC, his daughter Hope Candace Talbert of Lenox, MA., and his brother Leon Abramson of Great Neck, NY and one granddaughter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   HUMES, WILLIAM
description: HUMES--William. Died July 5, 2005 in Tigard, OR. Born March 15, 1918 in Altoona, PA to the late Anna and Frank Humes. Graduated Harvard University in 1940. Worked for over 20 years for Union Carbide Corporation, becoming group vice president for consumer products. Assumed position of vice president at Bell & Howell in 1967. Ended career in early 1970s as an independent management consultant. Predeceased by his wife, the former Geraldine Hart, in 1966. Survived by daughter Kathryn and her husband Duane Schulz, of Portland, OR; their children Stacy and Lisa; and son Steven and his partner Mark Waters, of Durham, NC. Memorials to Woodland Heights Assisted Living Center, 9355 SW McDonald St., Tigard, OR 97224.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on July 17 about a poll examining the environmental views of people in the Hudson River region referred imprecisely to the organizations that conducted it. It was conducted by the Pace Poll of Pace University in cooperation with the Pace Academy for the Environment.

title: Making a Case for More Rental Units
description: THE idea that moving to Long Island means residing in a house on a plot of land with a backyard, a garage and a mailbox at the end of the driveway may have already become a nostalgic notion.

title: Rudeness, Interrupted
description: The party was crowded, but without many familiar faces. So when a young woman walked up and interrupted a conversation I was having with one of the few people there that I knew, it made me feel particularly excluded. Not only did she not excuse herself, she didn't even make eye contact with me. I was mortified and disgusted.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   MCINTYRE, ''HARRY'' (HENRY PIERRE)
description: McINTYRE--"Harry" (Henry Pierre). Passed away July 12, 2005 in Reston, VA at the age of 81. Harry was born in Boston, MA on January 18, 1924, the son of Alfred R. and Helen H. McIntyre, and older brother to Ann. He attended Milton Academy and Harvard Univerity before graduating from Columbia University. He served in Italy during WWII as a P-51-D pilot, and received the Distinguished Flying Cross. He was married to Carmen Diaz, and later, to Rita Hayman. He was an avid tenants' rights advocate, swimmer, jazz enthusiast, and piano player. He retired to Easthampton, NY after living and working in New York City. He is survived by his children, Deborah, Michael, and William; nephews Will, Rob, and David; their families, and a multitude of friends. A memorial celebration will be held on Sunday, August 14, 2005 from 12:303:30pm at the Maidstone Arms, Easthampton, NY.

title: Passport Not Required
description: IN a way, Catie Powell has come full circle to a place she never fully knew.

title: A Hidden Camp, an Open Shame
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, N.Y. - Not far from the Long Island Rail Road tracks in this mixed-up neighborhood of old frame houses and industrial yards, there is an open field bordered on one end by woods. It's less a forest than a dense tangle of towering weeds, with brambles and branches that close overhead to blot out the sun. The underbrush is alive with the rustling of rabbits and birds, which can startle a visitor almost as much as the blare of the Port Jefferson train.

title: Kari Leveton, Elias Lehrer
description: Kari Lois Leveton, a daughter of Marcia and David Leveton of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn, is to be married today to Elias Abraham Lehrer, the son of Sheribel F. Rothenberg and Robert E. Lehrer of Chicago. Rabbi Reeve Robert Brenner will officiate at the 2941 Restaurant in Falls Church, Va.

title: Leela de Souza, Peter Bransten
description: Leela Ann de Souza and Peter Manfred Bransten are to be married today by Rabbi Helen Cohn at Temple Emanu-El in San Francisco.

title: Staten Island: Taking the Ferry to Lunch
description: A $124 million overhaul of St. George terminal and the home games for the Staten Island Yankees in the stadium next door offer are two new reasons to visit the North Shore of Staten Island. Once you've arrived at the ferry terminal, these restaurants nestled along the North Shore, are just a short walk or bus ride away.

title: A Spate of Thefts Stirs Unease Amid the Manicured Lawns
description: In Fieldston, a sedate private community of gracious homes and landscaped grounds, residents typically feel so safe that many think nothing of leaving their cars or garages unlocked.

title: The Costco Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: The World's Oldest Snack Food
description: THIRTY years ago, Roger Bennatti, a science teacher at George Stevens Academy in Blue Hill, Me., decided to test the myth that a Twinkie lasts forever. So he bought a two-pack, ate one and placed the other, still in its wrapper, on top of the intercom box. There it sat until he retired last year.

title: Porter Harris, Peter May
description: Porter Anne Harris, the daughter of Rania and Stephen Harris of Pittsburgh, was married yesterday to Peter Goldsborough May, the son of Joan and Henry May IV of Essex, Conn. The Rev. Sarantos Serviou performed the ceremony at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Pittsburgh.

title: 'The Letters Of Robert Lowell'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   FRANKEL, BERTHA
description: FRANKEL--Bertha. Dearest Mom, 13 years have gone by. Miss you and think of you always. Your loving daughter.

title: Hip-Hop, Fresh Squeezed
description: White guys and live instruments may be minorities in hip-hop, but they are not so rare. Julian Hintz, who performs as Julz A, below, still manages to be a hip-hop anomaly, however: he rhymes while playing the accordion. The instrument is less apt to roll with the posse than roll out the barrel, but onstage Mr. Hintz, 27, is polka's antithesis. Fingers fanned out at chest level, terry-cloth band on his wrist, leaning back slightly, he strikes a classic rapper's pose despite playing an instrument that has been relegated to Dorkville at least since the Beatles. Mr. Hintz has long aimed to sex up the squeezebox: after he picked up the accordion at 16, the first song he learned to play was "Purple Haze." Today he uses a wah-wah pedal and distortion on tracks like "Julz-A.com" ("What's that new sound/ accordion lowdown" and "the accordion man/ with the rockin' hand") from his first solo EP, "Squeeze Rock," to be released at a Knitting Factory show on Aug. 30. Mr. Hintz discussed a few other modern appearances of the accordion with Andrew Adam Newman.

title: The Race to Put Daniel Pearl on Screen
description: OF the many stories born of our encounters with terror in the last four years, few have had the obvious narrative power of Daniel Pearl's. Accompanied by a young wife, the 38-year-old Wall Street Journal reporter -- relentlessly inquisitive, a bit poetic and, not incidentally, a Jew -- landed in Pakistan in the heady months following the Afghan invasion by the United States, determined to find and report on some of the religious extremists in the region. In January of 2002, he disappeared, leaving his pregnant spouse to mount a search that spiraled toward a hideous endpoint: the videotape of his throat being slit by Islamic militants.

title: Out of the Loop
description: In the latest round of transportation precautions taken against terrorism, New Jersey often found itself dancing to a tune called by New York City.

title: Editors' Choice
Astronauts exchange trash for supplies
Paid Notice: Deaths   BLOCK, SHEILA
description: BLOCK--Sheila. Died at home on July 27, 2005 after fighting a valiant battle against leukemia. Survived by cherished daughter Ellen (Frommer), loving son - in - law Steve, adored grandchildren Matt and Jenni, life partner Chuck Stroh, mother Fay Kravitz and many valued friends. Sheila spent her entire career in the fashion industry, most recently as the President of the Accessories Council. She had remarkable passion and energy in both her career and personal life. She was one-ofa-kind, had an incredible will, amazing style and a wonderful love for life. A Memorial Service will be held Monday, August 1, 3:30PM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. Donations can be made to the Sheila Block Fund for Leukemia Research, C/O Accessories Council, 390 5th Avenue, New York, New York 10018.

title: As Clerk for Rehnquist, Nominee Stood Out for Conservative Rigor
description: They are not exactly father and son, but they share a singular bond in an elite business: 25 years ago this summer, almost exactly half his lifetime ago, John G. Roberts went to work for William H. Rehnquist, and now he stands poised to become the first Supreme Court clerk in American history to sit on the bench alongside the justice he served.

title: Michelle Ferrari and Richard Wallach
description: Michelle Dana Ferrari, the daughter of Francine and Charles Ferrari of Livingston, N.J., is to be married this evening to Richard Samuel Wallach, a son of Susan and Robert Wallach of Manhattan. Rabbi Seth Limmer is to officiate at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: SKAGEN, DENMARK
description: To the Editor: How could you run a story on Skagen in Denmark as a place where art flowered without a single illustration of this art? Instead we get dull photos of a beach and some seafood.

title: Patient's-Eye View
description: Over a long career, Art Shay, 83, has taken thousands of photographs for Life, Time and other magazines, including this one -- covering news stories like the 1968 Democratic National Convention and photographing the likes of Cassius Clay (pre-Ali), Simone de Beauvoir (in the nude) and Nikita Khrushchev (in Iowa). In 1987, Shay shot the events surrounding his own cardiac surgery, in which doctors successfully replaced his failing aortic valve with that of a pig. Last year, just months after winning a doubles racquetball tournament, Shay began feeling weak and listless. Tests showed his porcine valve had worn out. (They generally last 10 to 15 years; Shay's lasted 17.) So he went in to have a new one installed at Evanston Hospital in Evanston, Ill., near his home. Needless to say, he brought his camera.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   LEWIS, JEANNE (BONDURANT)
description: LEWIS--Jeanne (BonDurant). On July 4, 2005 after a short illness. Memorial services will be held at 11AM Saturday, August 13 at Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 W. 73rd St, New York, N.Y.

title: DataBank: JULY 25-29; Two Stock Gauges Defy Talk of Higher Rates
description: Two of the three major market indexes managed to continue their upward climb, despite concerns that the Federal Reserve might need to raise interest rates further than had been expected.

title: The Tour and TV
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: The Finnish-American Record Keepers
description: BURTON JERNSTROM'S family moved from New York City to a small farm in the Central Village section of Plainfield in 1943. Shortly after, the Jernstroms' barn was struck by lightning and burned down.

title: On Farthest U.S. Shores, Iraq Is a Way to a Dream
description: SAIPAN, Northern Mariana Islands - By jogging at sunset on the white sands of a palm-fringed beach here, 17-year-old Audrey O. Bricia is doing more than toning up for her next try in this island's Miss Philippines contest. She is getting in shape for United States Army boot camp.

title: 'The Lady and the Panda': Bear Market
description: THE LADY AND THE PANDA The True Adventures of the First American Explorer to Bring Back China's Most Exotic Animal. By Vicki Constantine Croke. Illustrated. 372 pp. Random House. $25.95.

title: A Year Under His Belt, Manning Is Ready to Add Some Notches
description: ALBANY, July 30 - Standing under a tree outside his dorm room after reporting to training camp, Eli Manning wore no visible scars from a jarring first season as a Giants quarterback.

title: The Color of Honey: No More Bickering
description: THE honey sold in those squeezable, bear-shaped bottles is always the same golden-brown color. But the raw honey gathered by beekeepers can be as white as snow or as dark as a Budweiser bottle, and it must be blended in order to produce the consistent versions familiar to shoppers. Bees, it seems, don't concern themselves too much with the aesthetic preferences of human consumers.

title: Going West, Young M.B.A.? Well, Maybe Not
description: Why do students study business in college? They may love financial minutiae, or perhaps they see it as the fastest route to cruising in their very own BMW. Some surely have the idea tucked in a corner of their minds that it would be awfully nice to run a company one day.

title: The Mallozzi Code
description: THE Radio Shack mystery has finally been solved, but now I have a real investigation on my hands.

title: Guardian Angels Get Greenport's Blessing
description: Greenport - CAUGHT somewhere between gentrification, illegal immigration and its own wide-open Wild East past, the Village of Greenport is calling in Curtis Sliwa and the Guardian Angels to help restore order to its streets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SCHNEIDER, JEFF STEWART
description: SCHNEIDER--Jeff Stewart, 51, on July 23 in Boca Raton, FL. Cherished son of Phyllis, and of Jack who predeceased him. Loving brother of sister Ann, brother Bill and sister-inlaw Dr. Catherine Irwin. Loving stepfather of Cherie Hourigan and of his special companion, the chihahua mix he rescued, Sadie Mae. Jeff will always be remembered for his humanity, his gentleness and loyalty to all who crossed his short life's path.

title: Robins Seen as Links In West Nile Virus
description: A scientist at the Connecticut Agricultural Experiment Station in New Haven has said that the state bird, the robin, has played an important role in transmitting the West Nile virus.

title: The Gallery Director
description: The paintings, drawings, photographs and collages in "Girls on Film," the current show at the Zwirner & Wirth gallery on East 69th Street, have one thing in common: They riff on the female form as depicted in popular culture. Kristine Bell, the gallery director and partner, organized works by artists like John Currin, Richard Prince and Cindy Sherman into three categories -- starlet, pinup and fashion model -- for the show. Her objective, she said, was to expose society's obsession with images of women.

title: How to ... Identify a Gifted Child
description: DISCERNING gifted children, long an imperfect science, is even tougher in today's label-prone culture. James T. Webb, a clinical psychologist and author of "Misdiagnosis and Dual Diagnosis of Gifted Children and Adults," explains what can go wrong.

title: Rebecca Haverstick, Adam Schwartz
description: Rebecca Jean Haverstick, a daughter of Brenda Haverstick and Dr. Park Haverstick of Lebanon, Pa., was married yesterday evening to Adam Joshua Schwartz, a son of Madeline and Edward Schwartz of Weston, Fla. Cantor Ellie Shaffer officiated at the Millstream Farm Inn in Lebanon.

title: The Adderall Advantage
description: IT was finals week at Columbia University and Angela needed a miracle. Like many of her classmates, Angela, a bleary-eyed junior, had already pulled a pair of all-nighters to get through a paper on "Finnegans Wake," a French test and an exam for her music humanities class. All that remained was a Latin American literature final, but as midnight approached, her stamina was beginning to fade. "This week is killing me," she said, taking a cigarette break in front of the school library. "At this point, I could use a little help."

title: A Medically Dubious Ailment
description: To the Editor:

title: Out From Under the Influence
description: MY first date with Julie did not begin well and ended even worse. For starters, I didn't show. It was Saturday evening of Presidents' Day weekend, and I was drinking gin and tonics and watching hoops in the Telephone Bar on Second Avenue, whiling away the time before I was supposed to meet her at John's Pizzeria just down the block. The next thing I knew it was hours later, and the phone was waking me from my slumber in my apartment on East 12th Street.

title: All This (and More) for $11.59
description: ALTHOUGH 59 Bank in Ridgefield is new, it is the sibling of another restaurant of the same name in New Milford, which I have not visited. In New Milford, the name is the same as the street number, and at both restaurants, all prices end in 59 cents, as in $5.59. As a gimmick this does not make much sense in Ridgefield, where the street number is 37.

title: How Payola Went Corporate
description: IN the fall of 2002, Celine Dion fans who listened to radio stations owned by Infinity Broadcasting, the country's second largest chain, were offered a chance to meet the object of their adoration.

title: Kate Bostock, Jesse Shefferman
description: Kate Bostock, the daughter of Merilee and Roy Bostock of Rye, N.Y., was married last evening at her parents' vacation home in Aspen, Colo., to Jesse Michael Shefferman, a son of Marcy Bergeron of Salem, Mass., and Laurence Shefferman of Patchogue, N.Y. The Rev. Donald Poole, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: The Shinnecocks and Their Allies (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Framing Wars
description: So Republicans have successfully framed their agenda in the words: lower taxes, less government, strong defense and family values. Democrats meet with experts to rework their message. But isn't their agenda really higher taxes, more government, weaker defense and individual values? If so, then Lakoff's talk about frames and the "rationalist-materialist paradigm" is not science but just so much political voodoo.

title: DEMAND FOR NORCROSS TAPES
description: New Jersey Republicans have started a radio campaign demanding the full release of secretly recorded conversations of George E. Norcross III, the Camden County Democratic leader. So far, Attorney General Peter C. Harvey has released only a fraction of the recordings, on which Mr. Norcross can be heard boasting of his ability to provide patronage jobs to allies. But Tom Wilson, the state's Republican chairman, criticized Mr. Harvey for acting too slowly, and urged state residents to sign a petition on the new Web site releasethetapes.com. Mr. Wilson said that the Web site was not tied directly to the campaign of the Republican candidate for governor, Doug Forrester. David W. Chen

title: Kirsten Davis, Kevin Smyth Jr.
description: Kirsten Root Davis, the daughter of Eunice Davis of Westbury, N.Y., and Russell Davis of Elmira, N.Y., is to be married today to Kevin Patrick Smyth Jr., a son of Elaine Smyth and Mr. Smyth Sr. of Manasquan, N.J. The ceremony, at the Grand View House, a private residence in North Hero, Vt., will be led by Jason Shea, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister.

title: A Leap of Faith Produces a Do-It-Yourself First Album
description: I DID everything I could to not do this," Adam Mugavero said of his career as a singer and songwriter. Mr. Mugavero, a Long Island native, went to the University of Buffalo to study communications and public relations, then returned to study musicology with thoughts of teaching.

title: INTERNMENT CAMP
description: To the Editor: I read with interest the mention of Manzanar, the Japanese-American internment camp, in "Places That Tell America's Diverse Story" (July 10).

title: Some Colorful Tiebreak Play at World Open in Philadelphia
description: The Polish grandmaster Kamil Miton and the international master Magesh Chandran Panchanathan of India shared first place in the 33rd World Open Tournament held in Philadelphia over the Independence Day weekend. They each scored 7 1/2-1 1/2 in the nine-round Swiss System competition. Miton was named World Open champion after he won the blitz tiebreak.

title: Elaine Buckberg, Timothy Helwick
description: Dr. Elaine Karen Buckberg and Timothy John Helwick were married last evening at the Harold Pratt House in Manhattan. Justice Joseph Kevin McKay of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn officiated.

title: A School With 60's Roots Seeks to Mold Young Lives
description: MOUNT VERNON - A WALL at Pelham Memorial High School bears a plaque honoring Michael Schwerner, a 1957 graduate who became a civil rights worker and was killed, along with two others, by Mississippi Klansmen in 1964.

title: Honor Thy Father
description: DURING the 1969-70 season, I was the last man on the bench for the Carleton College freshman basketball team, perhaps the worst squad in N.C.A.A. history: we didn't win any games, and lost most by large margins. My only stat came in the final five minutes of the last game, against our crosstown rival St. Olaf. My left-handed, behind-the-back, at-the-buzzer assist allowed us not to be doubled -- we lost 105-53 -- and earned me the sardonic nickname God. When I ran for student senate the next year, my teammates put up what they thought were funny signs: A Vote for Strauss Is a Vote for God. The student newspaper editorialized against that, and when my father saw the editorial, he immediately wrote me a letter about how disappointed he was in my lack of religious respect.

title: Be Very Quiet, Montclair Is Sleeping      Re: ''Those Freight Train Blues,'' July 24:
description: This article talks about public opposition to expanded freight train service despite the advantages of efficiency and environmental improvement. What about passenger trains and the same problem?

title: Quiz Answers
description: The G.E.D. exams, which lead to a high-school equivalency diploma, measure knowledge in social studies, science, mathematics, writing and reading. In addition to a poem like "Any Human to Another," the reading test asks students to interpret a piece of drama. Up to half of the SAT subject test in literature, from which "Permanently" is taken, is devoted to the dissection of poetry. Many colleges use the subject test results for admissions decisions.

title: As I.R.A. Backs Off, Loyalist Gangs Battle One Another
description: Correction Appended

title: Megan von Reinhart, Charles Forelle
description: Megan Rose Lozier von Reinhart, a daughter of Jodi Lozier von Reinhart and Walter von Reinhart of Providence, R.I., was married last evening to Charles Forelle, a son of Patricia and John Forelle of New York. The Rev. Charles F. Flagg, a Unitarian Universalist minister, performed the ceremony at the First Unitarian Church of Providence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   PEKELNER, JOSEPH E.
description: PEKELNER--Joseph E. Died July 28, 2005 at 102. Beloved husband of the late Beatrice. Devoted father of Alan and Alice. Shiva at the family residence through noon Thursday, August 4.

title: St.-Tropez  Go-Go
description: JUNE had barely begun, but the legendary French Riviera celebrity bastion of St.-Tropez already had its first scandale of the summer. All across the seaside village, fresh piles of the June 10 issue of La Tribune de St.-Tropez declared the breaking news. From socialites shopping in the Rodeo Drive-like stores along Rue FranAois Sibilli to the jet-setting playboys and billionaires trawling the coconut-oil-scented fleshpots along Mediterranean beaches, the summer crowd that arrives early suddenly found a disturbing front-page discovery that would once have been unthinkable.

title: Labor Must Explain Benefits of a Split (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Geeks, Get Out Your Light Sabers! Impostor Alert
description: "MY Yoda sucks, absolutely sucks," said Charles Ross while sitting in the front row of the Lamb's Theater, where his solo show "One Man Star Wars Trilogy" will have its New York debut on Tuesday. "But, you know something? I don't care. If I'm going to sit there and mull over the fact that I can't do a certain voice, then what's the point of even trying?"

title: Bologna
description: WHY GO NOW -- With its millennium-old university, chiming bicycle traffic and devotion to perfect pasta, Bologna, Italy's quintessential college town, enjoys a summer break from its roughly 100,000 students and puts its dusky red medieval architecture on center stage.

title: ON THE MARKET
description: Central Park West Co-op $899,000

title: Where, Again, the Sweet Birds Sing
description: LYNDHURST - WHY am I, on a Monday on which the fog is as thick as soup, and the humidity makes the 89 degrees outdoors feel as if it were 100, driving to a park that attracts fewer people in a year than the Ron Jon Surf Shop on Long Beach Island draws in a single morning?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   CRAIG, AMBROSE LEO
description: CRAIG--Ambrose Leo. Died July 30, 2005, at age 73. Son of John and Mary Craig. Predeceased by his brother John and sister Mary. Survived by sisters Catherine Germaine Dodd (Frank) and Patricia Ann Ruas (Albert), seven nieces and nephews, and eight grandnieces and nephews. Wake at Ruggiero Funeral Home, 732 Yonkers Ave, Yonkers, NY, Sunday, 24 and 7-9 PM, Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass St. Joseph's Church, Kraft Ave, Bronxville, NY, 11 AM, Tuesday.

title: The Governor Goes to Iowa
description: George E. Pataki, who announced this week that he was not running for a fourth term as governor of New York, has been very tentatively -- but very publicly -- testing the presidential waters. His trip to the National Governor's Association meeting in Iowa earlier this month was a sure giveaway. (There was, it seems, no thought whatsoever of Mr. Pataki going to the association's gathering simply to meet with his fellow governors.)

title: The Steadfast Ones
description: "ARE the two of you originals?" the chatty woman asked me and my wife at our building's annual rooftop barbecue.

title: Armstrong Doubts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   SHIFREEN, SEYMOUR S.
description: SHIFREEN--Seymour S. of West Hartford, CT, formerly of New London, CT and NYC, died July 24, 2005. Survived by loving wife Rhoda, two sons, a daughter, sister, and four grandchildren. Funeral services and burial were held in Hartford, CT.

title: A Pass on Privacy?
description: Christopher Caldwell's essay (July 17) reminded me of the trade-off between convenience and security. To wit, if you had a VeriChip implanted in, say, your arm, what's to keep a desperate and violent criminal from hacking off your arm and taking it to the nearest A.T.M. to make a withdrawal?

title: GOING TO SEATTLE (OR NOT)
description: To the Editor: Once again a glowing article was written about Seattle, and once again Seattle has proven itself unwilling or unable to live up to the promise. It is raining as I write, and it is forecast to rain all weekend.

title: Manon Wagner, Alexander DeFelice
description: Manon Maria Wagner, the daughter of Denisa D. Wagner and Sheldon H. Wagner of Dover, Mass., was married there yesterday to Alexander Hogan DeFelice, a son of Louise DeFelice and Leslie P. DeFelice of Wheeling, W.Va. The Rev. John A. Nelson, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony at the Dover Church.

title: A Dream Awakens in Africa
description: IN 1978, I went into the hotel and restaurant business with my wife, Nicky. We've been together since we were teenagers. In Cape Town, we built a business, which consisted of three hotels and four restaurants. It was going quite well until I had a massive heart attack just short of my 40th birthday, in 1994. I decided to do something less stressful.

title: Time for Vacation: Who Will Watch the Dog?
description: BEFORE leaving for California this summer, Karen Young of Darien hired a pet sitter for her two dogs, a local woman willing to come into her home to prepare the high-carb meals the older dog needed.

title: In Ljubljana, the Old Europe and the New Are Still in Balance
description: FROM the 16th-century fortress walls atop Castle Hill, the view of Ljubljana is exquisite: waves of red-tiled roofs, turquoise domes, spires and, here and there, lacy bridges spanning the green Ljubljanica River, stitching the two sides of Slovenia's capital city together. The overall effect is that of a snow-globe town in the foothills of the Alps.

title: In Green Bay, Title Town Has Given Way to Team Turmoil
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 29 - A city of a little more than 100,000 people, Green Bay has a love affair with the Packers that no other N.F.L. city knows. But this season, the beloved home team is in turmoil.

title: Elizabeth Cohen, Christopher Kojima
description: Elizabeth Rachel Cohen, a daughter of Charlene Cohen and Dr. Gary Cohen of Baltimore, was married in New York yesterday evening to Jay Christopher Akira Kojima, a son of Amy Kojima and Henry Kojima, both of Winnipeg, Manitoba. The Rev. David Rothblat, an interfaith minister, officiated at the Harvard Club. Cantor Judith Steel, who is married to Mr. Rothblat, participated.

description: To the Editor:

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally last week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: What Does a Terrorist Look Like?
description: To the Editor:

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the listed at price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to sales agreement.

title: The Ultimate F.O.C. (Friend of Craig)
description: JAMES KWUN, a 35-year-old Californian with wispy black hair and slightly graying sideburns, is the definition of the Craigslist-made man. In just a few months, he has used the Craigslist Web site to unload all his possessions, move across the country to New York, find a job, secure a loft apartment above a fish market, meet friends and maybe find love.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths   AARONI, ABRAHAM
description: AARONI--Abraham. 98, beloved husband of Celia (Siegel) who predeceased him two weeks ago, dear brother of Yetta, Minnie, Ida, Sam, Tillie and Paul, adored by his many nieces, nephews, great and grand nieces and nephews. Cherished by generations of devoted students and loyal friends. Most of all, he was the consummate teacher, a mentor respected by all he touched with his charm, search for perfection, love of language and lifelong dedication to knowledge, history and culture. He practiced teaching as an art, his life was a masterpiece. Graveside service at Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, NJ, August 1, 10 AM.

title: Faces of Protest
description:
The reach, overreach and potential
reach of government was the subject of protests
around the globe last week.

title: Student Style
description: Preppies are back in a big way. Here, students from three top boarding schools show how it's done.
